tuv.seg: Nu Kae Nye "Ŋkeke Mamlɛawo " Alo "Nuwuɣi " La Ƒe Dzesi?
What Is the Sign of "the Last Days, " or "End Times "?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia gblɔ nudzɔdzɔ kple nɔnɔme siwo ade dzesi "nuɖoanyi [sia] ƒe nuwuɣi " alo ɣeyiɣi siwo ado ŋgɔ na "xexea me ƒe nuwuwu " la ɖi.
The Bible describes events and conditions that would mark "the conclusion of the [current] system of things, " or "the end of the world. "

(Mateo 24:3; Eʋegbe Biblia) Biblia yɔ ɣeyiɣi sia be "ŋkeke mamlɛawo, " "nuwuwu ƒe ɣeyiɣi, " alo "nuwuɣi " la. (2 Timoteo 3:1; Daniel 8:​19; Eʋegbe Biblia) Nyagblɔɖi siwo le eme vam ku ɖe ŋkeke mamlɛawo, alo nuwuɣia, ŋu dometɔ vevi aɖewoe nye esi:

(Matthew 24:3; King James Version) The Bible calls this time period "the last days " and the "time of the end, " or "end times. " (2 Timothy 3:1; Daniel 8:​19; Easy-to-Read Version) The following are some outstanding features of last-days, or end-times, prophecies:
Aʋawɔwɔ dziŋɔwo.​ Mateo 24:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 6:4.
War on a large scale.​ Matthew 24:7; Revelation 6:4.
Dɔwuame.​ Mateo 24:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 6:​5, 6.
Famine.​ Matthew 24:7; Revelation 6:​5, 6.
Anyigbaʋuʋu gãwo.​ Luka 21:11.
Great earthquakes.​ Luke 21:11.
Dɔvɔ̃wo.​ Luka 21:11.
Pestilences, or epidemics of "terrible diseases. "​ Luke 21:11, Contemporary English Version.
Nu vlo wɔwɔ ƒe dzidziɖedzi.​ Mateo 24:12.
Increase of crime.​ Matthew 24:12.
Amegbetɔwo le anyigba la gblẽm.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 11:18.
Ruining of the earth by mankind.​ Revelation 11:18.

Amewo ƒe nɔnɔme le gbegblẽm ɖe edzi, elabena ame geɖewo nye "ame madakpewo, ame mawɔnuteƒewo, . . . ame siwo melɔ̃na ɖe ɖoɖo aɖeke dzi o, ameŋugblẽlawo, ame siwo meɖua wo ɖokuiwo dzi o, ame wɔadãwo, ame siwo melɔ̃a nu nyui o, yomemɔfialawo, totrilawo, ame siwo doa wo ɖokuiwo ɖe dzi glodzoo. "​ 2 Timoteo 3:1-4.

Deterioration of people’s attitudes, as shown by many who are "unthankful, disloyal, . . . not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride. "​ 2 Timothy 3:​1-4.
Ƒomewo le gbagbãm, elabena ƒometɔ aɖewo ‘megalɔ̃a ame ƒe nya o,’ eye ɖevi geɖe ‘megaɖoa to wo dzilawo o.’​ 2 Timoteo 3:2, 3.
Breakdown of the family, with people who have "no natural affection " and children who are "disobedient to parents. "​ 2 Timothy 3:​2, 3.
Ame akpa gãtɔ ƒe lɔlɔ̃ na Mawu yi to.​ Mateo 24:12.
Love of God growing cold in most people.​ Matthew 24:12.
Subɔsubɔhawo ƒe alakpanuwɔwɔwo le dzedzem gaglãa.​ Mateo 24:12.
Noteworthy displays of religious hypocrisy.​ 2 Timothy 3:5.
Biblia me nyagblɔɖiwo gɔmesese ɖe edzi, esiwo ku ɖe ŋkeke mamlɛawo ŋu hã le eme.​ Daniel 12:4.
Increased understanding of Bible prophecies, including those related to the last days.​ Daniel 12:4.
Gbeƒãɖeɖe Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyuia le xexea me godoo.​ Mateo 24:14.
Global preaching of the good news of the Kingdom.​ Matthew 24:14.
Ame akpa gãtɔ metsɔ ɖeke le kpeɖodzi siwo ɖee fia be nuwuwua gogo me o, eye eɖia kokoe na wo gɔ̃ hã.​ Mateo 24:37-​39; 2 Petro 3:​3, 4.
Widespread apathy and even ridicule toward the evidence of the approaching end.​ Matthew 24:37-​39; 2 Peter 3:​3, 4.
Nyagblɔɖi siawo katã le eme vam le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me, ke menye wo dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo alo wo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ ko o.​ Mateo 24:33.
The simultaneous fulfillment of all these prophecies, not just a few or even most of them.​ Matthew 24:33.
"Ŋkeke mamlɛawo " mee míele vavã?
Are we living in "the last days "?
Yes.
Nu siwo le dzɔdzɔm le xexea me kple Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubuwo ɖee fia be ŋkeke mamlɛawo dze egɔme tso ƒe 1914 me.
World conditions as well as Bible chronology indicate that the last days began in 1914.
Ɣemaɣi la, Mawu Fiaɖuƒea dze dziɖuɖu gɔme le dziƒo, eye tɔtrɔ siwo wòhe vɛ dometɔ ɖekae nye be wonya Satana Abosam kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo le dziƒo ɖo ɖe anyigba dzi.
At that time, God’s Kingdom began ruling in heaven, and one of its first actions was to expel Satan the Devil and the demons from heaven and restrict their activity to the earth.

(Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7-12) Ale si Satana le ŋusẽ kpɔm ɖe amegbetɔwo dzi egbea la dzena le woƒe nuwɔna kple nɔnɔme gbegblẽwo me, si wɔe be ŋkeke mamlɛawo nye ‘ɣeyiɣi sesẽ siwo me nɔnɔ sesẽ’ vavã.​ 2 Timoteo 3:1.
(Revelation 12:​7-​12) Satan’s influence on mankind can be seen in many of the bad attitudes and actions that make the last days "critical times hard to deal with. "​ 2 Timothy 3:1.
Susuŋutinunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Brain Pathologist Explains His Faith
NUFIALAGÃ Rajesh Kalaria, si le Newcastle Yunivɛsiti le England la le nu srɔ̃m tso amegbetɔwo ƒe susu ŋu wu ƒe 40.
PROFESSOR Rajesh Kalaria, of Newcastle University, England, has studied the human brain for more than 40 years.
Tsãa, exɔe se be ɖe nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si.
He used to believe in evolution.
Gake eva trɔ susu emegbe.
But later, he changed his views.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe xɔse kpakple eƒe dɔa ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his work and faith.
Míeɖe kuku subɔsubɔha ka mee nènɔ tsã?
Please tell us about your religious background.
Wodzi tɔnye le India, eye togbɔ be Indiatɔe danye nye hã Uganda ye wodzii le.
My father was born in India, and my mother, although of Indian origin, was born in Uganda.
Hindutɔwo ƒe dzixɔsewo koŋue kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe wo dzi.
Their lives were largely governed by Hindu customs.
Mí ame etɔ̃e wodzi eye nyee nye evelia.
I am the second of three children.
Míenɔ Nairobi, le Kenya.
We lived in Nairobi, Kenya.
Hindutɔ geɖewo hã nɔ afi ma.
Many other Hindu people lived nearby.
Nu kae na dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya va dzɔ dzi na wò?
What stimulated your interest in science?
Lãwo ƒe nu dzɔa dzi nam eye zi geɖe la, nye kple xɔ̃nyewo míezɔa mɔ legbeewo ɖatsia avewo me be míakpɔ lãwo.
I was always interested in animals, and I often went hiking and camping with my friends to see the spectacular wildlife.
Dɔ si koŋ medi be mawɔe nye be manye lãwo ƒe ɖɔkta.
My initial goal was to be a veterinary surgeon.
Gake esi medo le asinudɔsrɔ̃suku aɖe le Nairobi la, meyi London Yunivɛsiti le England, va srɔ̃ nu tso ale si dɔlékuiwo wɔna tsina ŋu.
But after graduating from a technical college in Nairobi, I went to England to study pathology at the University of London.
Emegbe meva srɔ̃ nu tso amegbetɔwo ƒe ahɔhɔ̃ koŋ ŋu.
Later, I specialized in research into the human brain.
Ðe wò sukunusɔsrɔ̃wo kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe wò dzixɔsewo dzia?
Did your studies affect your religious beliefs?
Yes.
Esi menɔ nu geɖe srɔ̃m tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu la, eva sesẽ nam be mayi edzi axɔ Hindutɔwo ƒe nyakpakpawo kple kɔnuwo dzi ase. Esia ƒe ɖewoe nye lãwo kple legbawo subɔsubɔ.
The more I studied science, the harder I found it to believe in Hindu mythology and traditions, such as the worship of animals and images.
Nu ka tae nèxɔ nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia dzi se?
Why did you accept the teaching of evolution?
Esi menye ɖevi la, ame siwo dome menɔ la xɔe se be Afrika ye nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dze egɔme tsoe, eye wofiaa nu siawo mí le suku enuenu.
In my younger years, many people around me held the view that human evolution began in Africa, and we often discussed this idea at school.
Azɔ hã, nufialawo kple yunivɛsiti nufialagãwo na mí sukuviawo míexɔe se be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala gãwo katã ka ɖe edzi be ɖe nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si.
Also, the teachers and university professors gave us students the impression that all respected scientists believe in evolution.
Esi ɣeyiɣiawo va nɔ yiyim la, wò susu va trɔ le afi si agbe dzɔ tso ŋu.
In time you reconsidered the question of the origin of life.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Menɔ nu srɔ̃m tso nu gbagbewo kple woƒe wɔwɔme ŋu ƒe aɖewo va se ɖe esime sukuhati aɖe va gblɔ nu siwo srɔ̃m wònɔ le Biblia me tso Yehowa Ðasefowo gbɔ la nam.
I had been studying biology and anatomy for some years when a fellow student told me what he was learning about the Bible from Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Medi be manya nu geɖe.
I became curious.
Eya ta esi Ðasefoawo va wɔ takpekpe aɖe le míaƒe sukua ƒe takpexɔ me le Nairobi la, nye hã mede.
So when the Witnesses held an assembly at our college hall in Nairobi, I attended.
Emegbe Ðasefo eve siwo nye dutanyanyuigblɔlawo va ɖe Biblia me nufiafia aɖewo me nam.
Later, two Witness missionaries explained some Bible teachings to me.
Esi mekpɔe be woxɔ Wɔla Gã aɖe dzi se eye be egbɔe míakpɔ agbemebiabia vevitɔwo ƒe ŋuɖoɖowo le la, nyemebui kura be nyakpakpa aɖee o.
Their belief in a Grand Designer who has the answers to life’s big questions did not sound like mythology.
Enya se nam eye susu le eme hã.
It appealed to me as being reasonable.
Ðe nu siwo nèsrɔ̃ tso ahɔhɔ̃a ŋu na wòsesẽ na wò be nàxɔe ase be ɖe wowɔ nuwoa?
Did your medical knowledge hinder your belief in creation?
Kura o!
On the contrary!
Esi menɔ nu srɔ̃m tso nuwo ƒe wɔwɔme ŋu la, meva kpɔe be wowɔ nu gbagbewo le mɔ wɔnuku aɖe ŋutɔ nu.
As I studied anatomy, I saw how well-designed and complex living things are.
Be míagblɔ be naneke mefiaa mɔ nuwɔwɔ wɔnuku siawo o la nye nu si me susu megava nɔ nam o.
To attribute such a high level of sophistication to an unguided process no longer made sense to me.
Àte ŋu agblɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖe na mía?
Can you give us an example?
Medze nusɔsrɔ̃ tso amegbetɔ ƒe ahɔhɔ̃ ŋu tso ƒe 1970-awo me, eye ahɔhɔ̃a ƒe dɔwɔwɔ gawɔa nuku nam kokoko.
I have studied the human brain since the early 1970’s, and this remarkable organ never ceases to amaze me.
Ahɔhɔ̃a koŋ ye nana míebua tame, ɖoa ŋku nu dzi eye wònana míaƒe ŋutinu vovovoawo katã wɔa dɔ.
It is the seat of thought and memory and the control center for many bodily functions.
Eya kee nana lãmesidzenu vovovoawo wɔa dɔ eye wòwɔa nyatakaka siwo tso ametia me kple esiwo tso ametia godo siaa ŋu dɔ.
The brain is also the hub of our many senses, interpreting information that comes from both inside and outside the body.
Susu si ta míaƒe ahɔhɔ̃a wɔa dɔ nyuie nye be eme tsiwo kple ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbeviwo wɔa dɔ aduadu le mɔ wɔnuku aɖe nu.
Our brain functions the way it does largely because of its complex chemistry and intricate networks of neurons, the primary brain cells.
Ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbevi biliɔn gbogbo aɖewoe le amegbetɔ ƒe ahɔhɔ̃ me, eye wowɔa dɔ aduadu kple wo nɔewo to lãmeka falɛfalɛ legbee siwo woyɔna le Eŋlisigbe me be axons dzi.
The human brain has many billions of neurons, which communicate with one another through long fibers called axons.
Ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbevi siawo dometɔ ɖeka ate ŋu awɔ dɔ aduadu kple ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbevi bubuwo to lãmeka falɛfalɛ (dendrites) siwo dzea alɔ la dzi.
From these, a single neuron may make many thousands of connections with other neurons by way of branching fibers called dendrites.
Esia wɔe be xexlẽme mele ale si ahɔhɔ̃mekawo de nu wo nɔewo me ŋu o!
As a result, the total number of connections in the brain is astronomical!
Azɔ hã ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbevi akpeakpe siawo kple lãmeka falɛfalɛ siawo wɔa dɔ ɖe ɖoɖo nyui nu eye wometɔtɔna o.
What is more, this dense forest of neurons and dendrites is, not chaotic, but precise.
Ale si "wolɔ̃ " ɖe wo nɔewo me la wɔ nuku ŋutɔ.
It is an amazing feat of "wiring. "
Míeɖe kuku ɖe eme.
Please explain.
Ahɔhɔ̃mekawo dzea dɔwɔwɔ ɖe ɖoɖo nu gɔme ne vidzĩwo le dɔ me kple ne wodzi wo vɔ megbe.
The wiring progresses in a most orderly way during a baby’s development in the womb as well as postnatally.
Ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbeviwo ɖoa lãmeka falɛfalɛwo ɖa be woavae tsiã kple ahɔhɔ̃menugbagbevi bubu siwo dome didi tso wo gbɔ sentimeta ʋɛ aɖewo gake dometsotsoa adidi ŋutɔ ne lãmenugbagbeviwo gbɔe woɖo wo ɖo.
Neurons send out fibers to target neurons that may be a few centimeters away​ a vast distance on the cellular level.
Gake menye lãmenugbagbevi aɖe koŋ koe lãmeka falɛfalɛa yina ɖatsiãna kple o ke eƒe akpa aɖe koŋ ye.
The target of a fiber, by the way, may be not just a specific cell but a specific part of that cell.
Ne lãmeka falɛfalɛ yeye aɖe dze tso ahɔhɔ̃meka aɖe me la, lãmetsiwo fiaa mɔe eye wogblɔna nɛ be "tɔ, " "dzo " alo "trɔ " va se ɖe esime wòaɖo afi si yim wòle.
As a new fiber branches out from a neuron, it is guided by chemical signposts that say such things as "stop, " "go, " or "turn " until the fiber reaches its target.
Ne womefia mɔ lãmeka falɛfalɛ siawo nyuie o la, woabu.
Without clear instructions, growing fibers would soon get lost.
Ale si nu siawo katã wɔa dɔ nukutɔe la nɔ te ɖe mɔfiame siwo woŋlɔ ɖe domenyiŋusẽfianua (DNA, ADN) me la dzi.
The whole process is brilliantly orchestrated, starting with the instructions written in our DNA.
Togbɔ be míenya nu siawo hã la, nu gbogbo aɖewo gali siwo mímenya tso ale si ahɔhɔ̃a wɔa dɔe, ale si wòwɔna ɖoa ŋku nu dzi, ɖea seselelãmewo fiana kple ale si wòbua nuwo ŋu la nyuie o.
That said, we are far from understanding fully how the brain develops and functions, including how it forms memories, emotions, and thoughts.
Le gonyeme la, ale si ahɔhɔ̃a wɔa dɔe ɖeɖe dzaa fiam be ame aɖe si ƒe susu de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu mía tɔ la li, eye mehiã be maƒo nu tso ale si ahɔhɔ̃a wɔa dɔe tsitotsito gɔ̃ hã ŋu o.
For me, just the fact that the brain works​ not to mention how well it works and how beautifully it develops ​points to a mind far superior to our own.
Nu kae na nèva zu Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Ðasefoawo na mekpɔ kpeɖodziwo be Biblia nye Mawu ƒe Nya.
The Witnesses showed me evidence that the Bible is God’s Word.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽe Biblia nye o, gake ne ele nu ƒom tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu la edena pɛpɛpɛ.
For example, the Bible is not a science book, but when it touches on scientific matters, it is consistently correct.
Nyagblɔɖi siwo de pɛpɛpɛ hã le eme.
It also contains accurate prophecies.
Eye ame siwo wɔna ɖe emenyawo dzi la nɔa agbe nyui.
And it improves the lives of those who apply its teachings.
Ale si mele agbe nɔm fifia la hã nye kpeɖodzi ɖeka.
My own life is evidence of that.
Tso esime meva zu Yehowa Ðasefo le ƒe 1973 me la, Bibliae nye agbalẽ vevitɔ si fiaa mɔm.
Since I became one of Jehovah’s Witnesses in 1973, the Bible has been my guidebook.
Esia wɔe be nye dzi dze eme eye taɖodzinu va le nye agbe ŋu.
As a result, my life has become truly satisfying and purposeful.
Fugboeŋutinunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
An Embryologist Explains His Faith
NUFIALAGÃ Yan-Der Hsuuw nye fugboewo ŋuti nusrɔ̃ƒe dzi kpɔla le Taiwantɔwo ƒe yunivɛsiti aɖe me.
PROFESSOR Yan-Der Hsuuw is the director of embryo research at Taiwan’s National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.
Tsã la, exɔ amedzɔtsolãme ƒe nufiafiaa dzi se, gake esi wòva zu dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala si wɔa numekuku la, etrɔ susu.
He once believed in evolution, but after becoming a research scientist, he changed his mind.
Egblɔ nu si tae la na Nyɔ! talawo.
He explained his reasons to Awake!
Míeɖe kuku ƒo nu tso ɖokuiwò ŋu na mí vie.
Please tell us a little about your background.
Yan-Der Hsuuw
Yan-Der Hsuuw
Wodzim le ƒe 1966 me eye menɔ Taiwan tsi.
I was born in 1966 and grew up in Taiwan.
Tao subɔsubɔha kple Buddha subɔsubɔha mee dzinyelawo nɔ.
My parents’ religion was based on both Taoism and Buddhism.
Togbɔ be míedea ta agu na tɔgbui kukuwo hedoa gbe ɖa na nɔnɔmewɔwɔwo hã la, míeka ɖe edzi be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo o.
Although we worshipped our ancestors and prayed to images, we never entertained the concept of a personal Creator.
Nu ka tae nèsrɔ̃ nu tso nu gbagbewo ŋu?
Why did you study biology?
Esi menɔ ɖevime la, meléa be na aƒemelãwo, eye medina be masrɔ̃ ale si mawɔ akpe ɖe lãwo kple amegbetɔ siwo le fu kpem la ŋu.
As a child, I liked caring for pets, and I wanted to learn how to relieve animals and people of suffering.
Eya ta mesrɔ̃ nu tso ale si mawɔ atike na lãwo woanɔ lãmesẽ me ŋu vie, eye emegbe meva srɔ̃ nu tso fugboewo hã ŋu be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye mase ale si agbe wɔ dze egɔme la gɔme.
For a time, I studied veterinary medicine, and later I studied embryology a field that I hoped would also shed light on the origin of life.
Ɣemaɣi la, èxɔ amedzɔtsolãme dzi se.
You believed in evolution at the time.
Àte ŋu agblɔ nu si tae?
Can you tell us why?
Yunivɛsiti nufialagãwo fia nu be amegbetɔ dzɔ tso lã me, eye wogblɔ be kpeɖodzi le eŋu.
The university professors taught evolution, claiming that evidence supports it.
Mexɔ woƒe nya sia dzi se.
I believed them.
Nu kae na nèva dze Biblia xexlẽ gɔme?
Why did you start reading the Bible?
Taɖodzinu eve ye nɔ asinye.
My motive was twofold.
Gbã la, mesusuna be le mawu gbogbo siwo amewo subɔna dome la, ɖeka aɖe anɔ anyi si kpɔ ŋusẽ wu bubuawo katã.
First, I reasoned that of the many gods that people worship, one must be greater than the others.
Gake wo dometɔ kae?
But which one?
Evelia, menya be Biblia nye agbalẽ si ŋu ame geɖe dea asixɔxɔe.
Second, I knew that the Bible is a highly respected book.
Eya ta medze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ ƒe kpekpewo dede gɔme.
So I joined Bible study classes.
Esime menɔ nu srɔ̃m le Katolikotɔwo ƒe yunivɛsiti aɖe me le Leuven, Belgium le ƒe 1992 me la, meyi Katolikotɔwo ƒe sɔlemeha aɖe me ɖabia woƒe nunɔla be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye mase Biblia gɔme, gake egbe.
When I started studying at Belgium’s Catholic University of Leuven in 1992, I visited a Catholic church and asked the priest to help me understand the Bible, but he declined my request.
Ke aleke nèwɔ kpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na wò Biblia me biabiawo?
So how was your spiritual hunger satisfied?
Le ƒe eve megbe, esime mekpɔtɔ nɔ Belgium nɔ nu srɔ̃m la, medo go Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Ruth tso Poland.
Two years later, while I was still in Belgium doing scientific research, I met a Polish lady named Ruth, who was one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Esrɔ̃ Chinagbe be wòate ŋu akpe ɖe yunivɛsitivi siwo di be yewoasrɔ̃ nu tso Mawu ŋu la ŋu.
She had learned Chinese in order to help university students who wanted to learn about God.
Medo gbe ɖa be makpɔ ame aɖe wòakpe ɖe ŋunye nenema, eya ta dzi dzɔm esi medo goe.
I had prayed for such help, so I was delighted to meet her.
Ruth fiam be togbɔ be Biblia menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽ o hã, emenyawo wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya.
Ruth showed me that the Bible, while not a science book, is in harmony with science.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia ŋlɔla David gblɔ na Mawu le gbedodoɖa me be: "Wò ŋkuwo kpɔm esime menye ʋukɔe; eye woŋlɔ eŋu nuwo katã ɖe wò agbalẽ me, le ŋkeke siwo me wowɔ wo, esime wo dometɔ aɖeke medo haɖe o. "

For example, the Bible writer David said in prayer to God: "Your eyes even saw me as an embryo; all its parts were written in your book regarding the days when they were formed, before any of them existed. "
(Psalmo 139:16) Togbɔ be hakpanya mee David gblɔ nya sia le hã la, ne míagblɔe la, nyateƒee wòto!
(Psalm 139:16) Although David was using poetic language, in principle, he was right!
Hafi míaƒe ŋutinuwo nado la, mɔfiame siwo dzi woazɔ ɖo la li xoxo.
Even before body parts form, the instructions for their development are all there.
Ale si Biblia me nyawo de pɛpɛpɛ la na meka ɖe edzi be Mawu ƒe Nyae wònye.
The accuracy of the Bible helped convince me that it is God’s Word.
Meva se egɔme hã be Mawu vavã ɖeka, si nye Yehowa koe li.
I also began to appreciate that there is only one true God, Jehovah.
Nu kae na nèva ka ɖe edzi be Mawu gbɔe agbe dzɔ tso?
What convinced you that God created life?
Taɖodzinu si le numekuku si dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo wɔna ŋue nye be woake ɖe nyateƒea ŋu, ke menye be woada asi ɖe susu siwo le amewo si dzi o.
A goal of scientific research is to find the truth, not to support preconceived ideas.
Esi meva nɔ nu srɔ̃m tso ale si fugboe wɔna tsina ŋu la, metrɔ susu, eye meƒo nya ta be Wɔla lae wɔ nuwo.
My study of embryo development led me to change my view that is, I concluded that life was created.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo le mɔ̃ aɖe wɔm la, wokpɔa egbɔ be wode eƒe akpa ɖe sia ɖe teƒe si wòle be wòanɔ la pɛpɛpɛ.
To illustrate, engineers design assembly lines so that the right parts are fitted together in the right order and in the right way.
Nenemae fugboe hã le, gake ale si fugboe ya wɔna tsina gɔme sese sesẽ ale gbegbe.
Embryo development is somewhat similar but vastly more complex.
Nu bliboa dzea egɔme ne ŋutsu ƒe tsi kple nyɔnu ƒe azi do go, alo menye nenemae oa?
The process all starts with a single fertilized cell, doesn’t it?
Yes.
Lãmenugbagbevi sue ma si ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o la mana, eye wòyia edzi nɔa mamam.
That microscopic cell then divides, starting the process of cell division.
Lãmenugbagbeviawo ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ dzina ɖe edzi teƒe eve tso gaƒoƒo 12 va se ɖe 24 hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
For a time, the number of cells doubles every 12 to 24 hours.
Le ɣeyiɣi sia me la, lãmenugbagbevi aɖe dona.
Early in this process, cells called stem cells form.
Eyae wɔna lãmenugbagbevi vovovo siwo ade 200 alo esi wu ema, abe lãmenugbagbevi siwo wɔa ʋu, ƒuwo, lãmekawo kple bubuawo ene, esiawo katãe ƒoa ƒu wɔa vidzĩ le dɔ me.
Stem cells can produce almost any of the 200 or so different cell types needed for a fully formed baby, such as blood cells, bone cells, nerve cells, and so on.
Esi meva nɔ nu srɔ̃m tso ale si fugboe wɔna tsina ŋu la, meƒo nya ta be Wɔla lae wɔ nuwo
My study of embryo development led me to conclude that life was created
Ele be lãmenugbagbevi si tɔgbi tututu hiã la nado le teƒe si tututu wòhiã le.
The right cells must be produced in the right order and at the right places.
Gbã la, wonyea ʋukɔe siwo me lãmenuwo kple ŋutinuwo va dona tso.
First they assemble into tissues that will in turn assemble themselves into organs and limbs.
Mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla kae aku drɔ̃e be yeate ŋu aŋlɔ mɔfiame siwo dzi fugboe ato atsi la ɖi?
What engineer even dreams of writing instructions for such a process?
Ke hã, woŋlɔ mɔfiame si dzi fugboe ato atsi la ɖe eƒe DNA me nukutɔe.
Yet, the instructions for embryo development are superbly written in DNA.
Ne mede ŋugble tso ale si gbegbe esia wɔ nukui ŋu la, enana mekana ɖe edzi be Mawue wɔ nuwo.
When I consider the beauty of it all, I’m convinced that life was designed by God.
Nu ka tae nèva zu Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Kpuie ko la, lɔlɔ̃ si le wo dome ye.
In a word, love.
Yesu Kristo gblɔ be: "Esia me amewo katã anyae le be nye nusrɔ̃lawo mienye, ne lɔlɔ̃ le mia dome. "
Jesus Christ said: "By this all will know that you are my disciples if you have love among yourselves. "
(Yohanes 13:35) Ameŋkumemakpɔmakpɔ aɖeke mele lɔlɔ̃ sia me o.
(John 13:35) That love is impartial.
Teƒe si ame aɖe tso, dekɔnu alo ŋutigbalẽ ƒe amadede mekpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe lɔlɔ̃ sia ɖeɖe fia dzi o.
It is not influenced by a person’s nationality, culture, or skin color.
Esi medze hadede kple Ðasefowo la mekpɔ lɔlɔ̃ sia le wo dome eye woɖe lɔlɔ̃ sia fiam.
I both observed and experienced that kind of love when I began to associate with the Witnesses.
Ayikudɔdala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Kidney Specialist Explains Her Faith
Ðɔkta Céline Granolleras, si tso France, nye atikeŋutinunyala si bi ɖe ayikudɔdada me.
Dr. Céline Granolleras is a medical doctor in France who specializes in kidney disease.
Esi wòzu ɖɔkta ƒe 20 kple edzivɔwo megbe la, eva ƒo nya ta be Wɔla aɖe li si tsɔa ɖe le eme na mí.
More than 20 years after becoming a doctor, she came to the conclusion that there is a Creator who cares for us.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe xɔse kpakple eƒe dɔa ŋu.
Awake! asked her about her work and her faith.
Ƒo nu tso wò ɖevimenɔɣi ŋu na mí.
Tell us about your childhood.
Esi mexɔ ƒe asieke la, míaƒe ƒomea ʋu tso Spain va tsi France.
My family moved to France from Spain when I was nine.
Dzinyelawo nye Katolikotɔwo, gake esi mexɔ ƒe 16 la, nyemegava xɔ Mawu dzi se o.
My parents were Catholic, but I stopped believing in God when I was 16.
Le nye susu nu la, viɖe aɖeke mele mawusubɔsubɔ me o.
For me, religion had no bearing on reality.
Ne ame aɖe biam be, ne Mawu meli o la, ke aleke agbe wɔ dze egɔme mahã la, meɖoa eŋu nɛ be: "Fifia dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo mete ŋu ɖe eme haɖe o, gake gbe ɖeka woava kpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nya ma. "
If anyone asked me how life began if there is no God, I replied, "For now, scientists cannot explain it, but one day they will. "
Nu ka tae nèsrɔ̃ nu tso ayikudɔ ŋu?
What made you study kidney disease?
Mesrɔ̃ nu le ɖɔktasuku le Montpellier si le France.
I studied at a medical school in Montpellier, France.
Nufialagã aɖe si le sukua me la ɖo aɖaŋu nam be masrɔ̃ nu tso ayikudɔ ŋu.
A professor there spoke to me about working in nephrology, a branch of medicine involving the kidneys.
Dɔ sia bia numekuku kple dɔnɔwo gbɔ kpɔkpɔ le ɣeyiɣi ma ke me.
The work combined research with the care of patients.
Dɔ sia tututu dim mele be mawɔ.
That was just what I wanted.
Le ƒe 1990 me la, meva nɔ nu srɔ̃m tso lãmetsi si dzia ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwo ɖe edzi le ame ƒe ƒu me la ŋu.
In 1990, I began taking part in research on the clinical use of recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) to control the production of red blood cells in our bones.
Ɣemaɣi la, wobunɛ be enye numekuku yeye.
At that time, it was considered a relatively new field of research.
Nu kae na nèva di be yeanya ne Mawu li?
What made you start thinking about God?
Tso keke ƒe 1979 me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo va nɔ Biblia srɔ̃m kple srɔ̃nye Floréal.
Back in 1979, my husband, Floréal, started studying the Bible with Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Gake nyemetsɔ ɖeke le eme o.
But I was not interested.
Esi menɔ ɖevime la, mawusubɔsubɔ ti kɔ nam.
As a child, I had had enough of religion.
Ke hã srɔ̃nye kple mía viwo va zu Yehowa Ðasefowo, eye medidi o mía xɔlɔ̃wo katã kloe zu Yehowa Ðasefowo.
Nevertheless, my husband and children became Witnesses, and soon nearly all our friends were Witnesses.
Mía xɔlɔ̃awo dometɔ ɖeka si ŋkɔe nye Patricia ɖo aɖaŋu nam be manɔ gbe dom ɖa.
One of them, Patricia, suggested that I try praying.
Egblɔ nam be: "Ne ame aɖeke mele dziƒo se wò gbedodoɖa o hã la, magblẽ naneke le ŋuwò o.
"If there is nobody in heaven, you don’t risk anything, " she said.
Gake ne ame aɖe li la, wò ŋutɔ àkpɔ nu si adzɔ. "
"But if there is, you will see what happens. "
Le ƒe aɖewo megbe la, meva di be manya tameɖoɖo si le agbea ŋu, eye meɖo ŋku Patricia ƒe nyawo dzi.
Years later, I started to wonder about the meaning of life, and I remembered Patricia’s words.
Ale wɔ meva nɔ gbe dom ɖa be mate ŋu ase nuwo gɔme.
I began to pray for understanding.
Nu ka tae nèva di be yeanya tameɖoɖo si le agbea ŋu?
What made you wonder about the meaning of life?
Esi ŋɔdzinuwɔlawo dze Xexeame Katã ƒe Asitsaƒegã si le New York dzi la, mebia ɖokuinye be nu ka tae nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ xɔ aƒe ɖe amegbetɔwo dome mahã.
The terrorist attack on the World Trade Center in New York made me wonder why there is so much evil in society.
Megblɔ na ɖokuinye be: ‘Mawusubɔla zazɛ̃nyahelawo le afɔku gã aɖe he ge ava mía dzi.
I thought: ‘Religious extremism endangers our future.
Ke hã nye ame nyanyɛ gbogbo aɖewo nye Yehowa Ðasefo ŋutifafamewo.
Yet here I am surrounded by Jehovah’s Witnesses who are peaceful.
Woawo ya to vovo sãsãsã na zazɛ̃nyahelawo.
They are not extremists.
Wowɔna ɖe Biblia me nyawo dzi.
They follow the Bible.
Ðewohĩ ahiã be nye hã madzro Biblia me kpɔ.’
Perhaps I should look into what it says.’
Ale wɔ mede asi Biblia xexlẽ me.
So I began reading the Bible for myself.
Ðe wòsesẽ na wò be nàxɔe ase be Wɔla aɖe li le esi nènye ɖɔkta ta?
As a doctor, did you find it difficult to believe in a Creator?
Ao.
No.
Mekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe ale si míaƒe ametia ƒe wɔwɔme wɔ nukue la ŋu ŋutɔ.
I had a deep respect for our body’s sophisticated design.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ale si míaƒe ayiku nana be ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwo ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ dana sɔna le míaƒe ʋu me la wɔ nuku nam ŋutɔ.
For example, the way our kidneys control the amount of red cells in our blood is awe-inspiring.
Nu kae na nègblɔ nenema?
Why do you say that?
Meva nyɔ le ɖokuinye me be Mawu koe ate ŋu awɔ nu wɔnuku mawo gbegbe
It struck me that only God could design such an elegant system
Ðewohĩ ènyae be ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwoe tsɔa ya ƒomevi si woyɔna be ɔksidzin la yia ŋutilã ƒe akpa vovovowo.
As you may know, red blood cells transport oxygen.
Ne ʋu sɔgbɔ do le ŋuwò alo nèle teƒe kɔkɔ aɖe la, ɔksidzin masɔ gbɔ le lã me na wò o.
If you lose a lot of blood or if you go to a high altitude, your body will lack oxygen.
Míaƒe ayikuwo dea dzesi ɔksidzin ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ si le lã me na mí.
Our kidneys have oxygen sensors.
Ne wode dzesii be ɔksidzin mesɔ gbɔ le lã me na mí kura o la, wonana be lãmetsi si nana be ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwo dzina ɖe edzi la sɔna gbɔ ɖe edzi abe teƒe akpe ɖeka ene.
When they detect an oxygen shortage in the blood, they activate the production of EPO, and the level of EPO in the blood may rise as much as a thousandfold.
Lãmetsi sia nana be ƒutomemiwo wɔa ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩ yeyewo, eye ʋumenugbagbevi siawo tsɔa ɔksidzin gbogbo aɖewo yia ŋutilã ƒe akpa vovovowo.
The EPO stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red cells, which in turn transport more oxygen.
Ewɔ nuku loo!
It’s wonderful!
Togbɔ be mesrɔ̃ nu siawo hã la, ƒe ewo megbe hafi meva nyɔ le ɖokuinye me be Mawu koe ate ŋu awɔ nu wɔnuku mawo gbegbe.
Strangely, I studied this process for ten years before it struck me that only God could design such an elegant system.
Aleke nèbua Bibliae?
What was your impression of the Bible?
Mexlẽ ŋutinyagbalẽ kple modzakaɖegbalẽ xɔŋkɔ geɖewo, gake esi mexlẽ Biblia la, mekpɔe dze sii enumake be eto vovo.
I had read lots of history books and famous novels, but I immediately recognized that the Bible was different.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo le eme ɖea vi na ame ale gbegbe be mekpɔe be ele be wòatso ame aɖe si kɔ boo wu amegbetɔwo gbɔ.
Its advice is so practical that it must come from a source higher than man.
Yesu ƒe nuwɔnawo wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
Jesus’ character fascinated me.
Mekpɔe be ame ŋutɔŋutɔe wònye.
I saw that he was a real person.
Seselelãmewo le esi eye xɔlɔ̃wo hã nɔ esi.
He had feelings, and he had friends.
Esi wònye be nyemedi be maxlẽ Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe agbalẽwo o ta la, mekua nu me le numekugbalẽwo kple agbalẽ bubuwo me ne medi be makpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nyabiase aɖewo.
Since I didn’t want to use the publications of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I did research in encyclopedias and other reference works when questions arose.
Nu kawo ŋue nèkua nu me le?
What did you research?
Meku nu me le ŋutinyagbalẽwo me . . .
I researched history books . . .
Mlɔeba meƒo nya ta be Biblia ƒe nyagblɔɖi sia va eme ɖe ɣeyiɣi dzi pɛpɛpɛ
Finally, I concluded that this Bible prophecy had come true on time
Nu siwo wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye la dometɔ ɖekae nye ale si Biblia gblɔ ƒe si me woanyrɔ Yesu ɖe tsi me la ɖi.
Among other things, I was intrigued by the way the Bible foretold the year of Jesus’ baptism.
Egblɔ ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ siwo ava yi tso Persia-dziɖula Artaxsasta ƒe dziɖuɖu ƒe ƒe 20 lia me dzi va se ɖe ƒe si me Yesu ado abe Mesia ene.
It shows exactly how much time would elapse between the 20th year of the reign of the Persian ruler Artaxerxes and the year Jesus would present himself as the Messiah.
Numekuku mam elabe nye dɔa ƒe akpa ɖee wònye.
I am accustomed to doing research it is part of my job.
Eya ta meku nu me le ŋutinyagbalẽwo me be makpɔ kpeɖodzi na ƒe siwo me Artaxsasta ɖu dzi kple ƒe siwo me Yesu wɔ eƒe subɔsubɔdɔa.
So I researched history books to confirm the dates of Artaxerxes’ rule and the dates of Jesus’ ministry.
Mlɔeba meƒo nya ta be Biblia me nyagblɔɖi sia va eme ɖe ɣeyiɣi dzi pɛpɛpɛ, eye meƒo nya ta be Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔe kokokoe anya ʋã ame siwo ŋlɔe.
Finally, I concluded that this Bible prophecy had come true on time and that it must have been inspired by God.
Kɔmpiutadziɖoɖoŋlɔla Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Software Designer Explains His Faith
AGBALẼNYALAGÃ Fan Yu dze eƒe dɔwɔɖui si nye akɔntabubu ŋuti numekuku gɔme le Chinatɔwo ƒe Atɔmikŋusẽ Suku si gogo Beijing.
DR. FAN YU began his career as a research mathematician at the China Institute of Atomic Energy, near Beijing.
Ɣemaɣi la, enye mawudzimaxɔsela, eye wòxɔ nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia dzi se.
At that time he was an atheist and believed in the theory of evolution.
Gake fifia, exɔe se be Mawue wɔ nuwo.
But now Dr. Yu believes that life was designed and created by God.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe xɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his faith.
Míeɖe kuku ƒo nu tso ɖokuiwò ŋu na mí.
Please tell us about your background.
Wodzim le ƒe 1959 me le Fuzhou City, le Jiangxi Nutoa me, le China.
I was born in 1959 in Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province, China.
Kaka maxɔ ƒe enyi la, dukɔa nɔ Hadomegbenɔnɔ ƒe Tɔtrɔwo wɔm.
By the time I was eight years old, the country was experiencing the effects of what is now called the Cultural Revolution.
Woɖe gbe na fofonye si nye mɔdodoɖaŋunyala be wòado ketekemɔ ato gbedada aɖe ƒo.
My father, a civil engineer, was ordered to build a railway in a distant wilderness area.
Zi ɖeka ko wòtea ŋu va srãa mí kpɔna ƒe sia ƒe hena ƒe geɖe.
For years he could visit us only once a year.
Ɣemaɣi la, danye si fiaa nu le gɔmedzesuku gbɔe menɔ.
During that time I lived with my mother, who was a teacher in an elementary school.
Suku si me wòfiaa nu le la kee míenɔ.
We actually lived in the very school where she taught.
Le ƒe 1970 me la, eva hiã be míaʋu ayi Liufang, ɣemaɣi la enye kɔƒedu si me ahedada le le Linchuan Nutoa me eye nuɖuɖu hã vena le afi ma.
In 1970, we had to move to Liufang, at the time a poor rural village in the Linchuan District, where food was scarce.
Nu ka dzie miaƒe ƒomea xɔ se?
What did your family believe?
Fofonye metsɔ ɖeke le mawusubɔsubɔ loo alo dunyahehe me o.
My father was not interested in religion or politics.
Buddhatɔe danye nye.
My mother was a Buddhist.
Wofiam le suku be ɖe agbea dzɔ le eɖokui si, eye mexɔ nu si nye nufialawo gblɔ la dzi se.
At school, I was taught that life evolved by natural processes, and I believed what my teachers said.
Nu ka tae nèva tsɔ ɖe le akɔntabubu me?
Why did you become interested in mathematics?
Akɔntabubu va dzɔa dzi nam elabena ele be nàtsɔ nanewo asɔ kple nanewo be nànya nane ƒe nyateƒenyenye.
I was attracted to mathematics because it involves seeking truth through logical reasoning.
Esi hadomegbenɔnɔ ƒe tɔtrɔwɔlawo ƒe ŋgɔnɔla Mao Tse-tung ku le ƒe 1976 megbe ye meyi yunivɛsiti.
I went to university shortly after the leader of the revolution, Mao Tse-tung, died in 1976.
Akɔntabubu koŋ ye mesrɔ̃.
I chose mathematics as my main subject.
Esi mexɔ Yunivɛsiti ɖaseɖigbalẽ vɔ la, dɔ gbãtɔ si mewɔ lae nye be maku nu me tso ale si woawɔ nukliaŋusẽ ƒe mɔ̃wo la ŋu.
After I obtained a master’s degree, my first job involved mathematical research for the design of nuclear reactors.
Tsãa, aleke nèbua Bibliae?
What was your first impression of the Bible?
Le ƒe 1987 me la, meyi Amerika be mayi nye yunivɛsiti nusɔsrɔ̃ dzi le Texas A&M Yunivɛsiti, axɔ ɖaseɖigbalẽ si de ŋgɔ wu.
In 1987, I came to the United States to pursue doctorate studies at Texas A&M University.
Menya be Amerikatɔ geɖe xɔ Mawu dzi se eye woxlẽa Biblia.
I was aware that in America, many people believe in God and read the Bible.
Mese hã be Biblia me nyawo ɖea vi ŋutɔ, eya ta mekpɔe be ele be maxlẽe.
Also, I had heard that the Bible contains a lot of practical wisdom, so I thought I should read it.
Mekpɔe be susu le Biblia me nyawo me.
The teachings of the Bible sounded practical.
Gake eƒe akpa aɖewo gɔmesese sesẽ nam eya ta medzudzɔ exexlẽ.
But I found some parts hard to understand and soon stopped reading it.
Nu kae na nègava tsɔ ɖe le Biblia me nyawo me?
How was your interest in the Bible renewed?
Nusɔsrɔ̃ tso Wɔla aɖe ŋu la nye nu yeye nam, ta meɖoe be nye ŋutɔ maku nu me tso nyaa ŋu
The idea of a Creator was new to me, so I decided to do my own research on the subject
Le ƒe 1990 me la, Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe va gbɔnye le aƒe me, eye wòtsɔ nu si Biblia gblɔ tso etsɔme nyui si le amegbetɔwo si la fiam.
In 1990, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses called at my house and showed me what the Bible says about a better future for mankind.
Ewɔ ɖoɖo be atsu kple asi aɖe nava kpe ɖe ŋunye mase Biblia me nyawo gɔme.
She arranged for a married couple to come and help me understand the Bible.
Emegbe, srɔ̃nye Liping, si mexɔ Mawu dzi se o, si fiaa dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununya le China la, hã dze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ gɔme.
Later, my wife, Liping, who had taught high school physics in China and who was also an atheist, began studying the Bible as well.
Míesrɔ̃ nu si Biblia gblɔ tso afi si agbe dzɔ tso la ŋu.
We learned what the Bible says about the origin of life.
Nusɔsrɔ̃ tso Wɔla aɖe ŋu la nye nu yeye nam, ta meɖoe be nye ŋutɔ maku nu me tso nyaa ŋu.
The idea of a Creator was new to me, so I decided to do my own research on the subject.
Aleke nèwɔe?
How did you go about that?
Esi menye akɔntanyala ta la, ele bɔbɔe be mabu akɔnta anya ale si wòdzɔe be nuwo le ale si wole.
As a mathematician, I was trained to calculate the probabilities of events.
Mesrɔ̃e hã be hafi agbe nate ŋu adzɔ le vome la, ele be amenyinu (protein) vovovowo nanɔ anyi xoxo.
I had also learned that for life to occur spontaneously, proteins would already have to exist.
Eya ta medze agbagba be makpɔe ɖa be anya wɔ be amenyinu sia nadzɔ le eɖokui si hã.
So I tried to calculate the probability of a protein originating by an unguided process.
Amenyinu siawo le lãmenugbagbevi suetɔ siwo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ gɔmesese sesẽ la dome, eye amenyinu sia ƒomevi vovovo akpe geɖe ye le lãmenugbagbeviwo me eye wowɔa dɔ le ɖoɖo nu pɛpɛpɛ.
Proteins are among the most complex molecules known, and living cells can have thousands of different types of proteins interacting in very precise ways.
Abe ame bubuwo ke ene la, meva de dzesii be manya wɔ be amenyinu sia nadzɔ le eɖokui si kura o!
I realized, as others have, that the spontaneous formation of a protein is so improbable that it is essentially impossible!

Nyemexlẽ naneke le nɔnɔmetɔtrɔnufiafiagbalẽ aɖeke me kpɔ si ɖe eme be lãmenugbagbevi suetɔ siwo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ gɔmesese sesẽ la ate ŋu adzɔ le wo ɖokui si, kaka woahayi nugbagbevi si me wowɔa dɔ le la ƒe akpa aɖe nye ge o.

I have not read anything in evolution theory that explains to my satisfaction how these highly complex molecules could, in effect, create themselves let alone the living systems of which they form an integral part.
Le gonyemea, kpeɖodziawo fia be Wɔla aɖe li.
To me, the facts pointed to a Creator.
Nu kae na nèka ɖe edzi be Mawu gbɔe Biblia tso?
What convinced you that the Bible comes from God?
Esi Yehowa Ðasefowo yi nua sɔsrɔ̃ dzi kplim la, mesrɔ̃ nu tso Biblia me nyagblɔɖi gbogbo aɖewo siwo va eme la ŋu.
As I continued studying with the help of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I learned that the Bible contains many detailed prophecies that have been fulfilled.
Esi meva nɔ wɔwɔm ɖe Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi la, eɖe vi nam.
I also began experiencing the benefits of applying Bible principles.
Mebiaa ɖokuinye be, ‘Aleke wòanya wɔ be Biblia ŋlɔla siwo nɔ anyi ƒe akpe geɖe do ŋgɔ la naŋlɔ nu siwo gale vi ɖem na mí egbea?’
I wondered, ‘How could Bible writers living thousands of years ago write words of wisdom that remain so practical today?’
Vivivi la, meva kpɔe be Mawu ƒe Nyae Biblia nye vavã.
Progressively, I realized that the Bible is God’s Word.
Nu kae na nègava ka ɖe edzi geɖe wu be Wɔla aɖe li?
What continues to convince you that there is a Creator?
Ne mede ŋugble le xexea me nuwo ŋu la, naneke meli mawɔ tsɔ wu be maxɔ Wɔlaa dzi ase o.
When I give thought to the many elements in nature, I cannot help but believe in a Creator.
Fifia meŋlɔa kɔmpiutadziɖoɖowo eye zi geɖe la, ewɔa nuku nam be míaƒe susu wɔa dɔ sãsãsã wu kɔmpiutadziɖoɖowo.
Currently I design software for computers, and I often feel amazed at how our brain outperforms computer programs.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ŋutete si le míaƒe susua ŋu be wòade dzesi gbeɖiɖi vovovowo la wɔ nuku ŋutɔ.
For example, our brain’s ability to recognize speech is mind-boggling.
Mía dometɔ geɖe tea ŋu sea gbeɖiɖiwo gɔme, ne womegblɔ nya aɖe wu enu o gɔ̃ hã, ne ame aɖe ko nu, kpe kpe, ku kɔ, do gbe bubu, do ɣli, ne hoowɔwɔ le edzi yim, alo ne telefon me mekɔ o.
Most of us can easily understand speech, even if it includes incomplete sentences, laughter, coughs, stutters, accents, echoes, background noise, or telephone distortion.
Ðewohĩ àbui be esia nye nu tsɛ aɖe ko.
You might think this unremarkable.
Ke hã, kɔmpiutadziɖoɖoŋlɔlawo bunɛ be ele etɔxɛ.
But software designers know otherwise.
Amegbetɔ ƒe susu de ŋgɔ wu kɔmpiutadziɖoɖo nyuitɔ si tea ŋu dea dzesi gbeɖiɖiwo sãsãsã.
Even the best speech-recognition software is a far cry from the human brain.
To vovo na kɔmpiuta deŋgɔwo la, míaƒe susu ya tea ŋu dea dzesi seselẽlamewo, gbegbɔgblɔ vovovowo kple ame vovovowo ƒe nuƒowo.
Unlike the most complex computers, our brain can discern emotions, recognize accents, and identify speakers by their voice characteristics.
Kɔmpiutadziɖoɖoŋlɔlawo le nu me kum tso ale si woate ŋu ana kɔmpiuta nawɔ dɔ abe amegbetɔ ƒe susu ene ŋu eye wòade dzesi gbeɖiɖi vovovowo.
Software designers are researching how computers could mimic the human brain’s ability to recognize speech.
Meka ɖe edzi be esia wɔwɔ fia be wole nu srɔ̃m tso nu siwo Mawu wɔ la ŋu.
I am convinced that in doing so they are actually studying the handiwork of God.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
An Experimental Physicist Explains His Faith
WENLONG HE srɔ̃ nu tso dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽ ŋu zi gbãtɔ le Suzhou si le Jiangsu Nuto me le China.
WENLONG HE first studied physics in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, China.
Ekpɔ gome le dukɔwo dome magazine si ku ɖe mɔ̃ɖaŋununya ŋu ŋɔŋlɔ me eye eya ŋutɔ ŋlɔ agbalẽ geɖe ku ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu.
He helps edit an international journal of technology and has had dozens of papers published in scientific literature.
Fifia, Wenlong He le dɔ wɔm le Strathclyde Yunivɛsiti si le Scotland.
At present, Wenlong He works for Scotland’s University of Strathclyde.
Le eƒe sɔhɛme la, exɔe se be ɖeko nu gbagbewo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si, gake emegbe eva ƒo nya ta be ɖe wowɔ wo.
As a youth, he believed in evolution, but later he concluded that life was created.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe xɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his faith.
Ƒo nu tso ɖokuiwò ŋu na mí.
Tell us about your background.
Wenlong He
Wenlong He
Wodzim le ƒe 1963 me eye metsi le China ƒe kɔƒe aɖe si le Yangtze Tɔsisia ƒe anyiehe le Jiangsu Nutoa me.
I was born in 1963 and grew up in China, in a village south of the Yangtze River in Jiangsu Province.
Enye nuto si me yame xɔa dzo le eye tsi hã dzana nyuie. Wolɔ̃a nuto ma yɔyɔ be mɔlu kple tɔmelã ƒe anyigba elabe nuɖuɖu bɔ ɖe afi ma ale gbegbe.
It is a subtropical area famous for its food production, so it is often called the land of rice and fish.
Esi menye ɖevi la, mebiaa ɖokuinye be: ‘Nu ka tae nuɖuɖu viviwo bɔ ɖe xexea me alea?
As a child, I used to wonder: ‘Why does nature provide so many tasty foods?
Ðe wodzɔ le wo ɖokui sia?
Did they come about by chance?
Wo dometɔ kae dzɔ gbã, koklovi alo koklozi?’
Which came first the chicken or the egg?’
Mawudzimaxɔselawo bɔ ɖe China, eya ta wofiam le suku be ɖeko nu gbagbewo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si.
Atheism is predominant in China, so at school I was taught about evolution.
Ƒo nu tso wò ƒometɔwo hã ŋu na mí.
What about your family?
Dzinyelawo mexɔ Mawu dzi se o.
My parents were atheists.
Danye nye agbledela. Fofonye nye xɔtuɖaŋunyala eye wòɖo xɔtudɔwɔƒe aɖe.
My mother did farmwork, while my father worked as an architect and established a construction company.
Nyee nye woƒe ŋutsuvi atɔ̃awo ƒe tsitsitɔ.
I’m the eldest of their five sons.
Nublanuitɔe la, nɔvinye ŋutsu eve ku le woƒe ɖevime.
Sadly, two of my brothers died young.
Esia na mexaa nu vevie eye mebia ɖokuinye be: ‘Nu ka tae ame kuna?
That caused me much grief, and I wondered: ‘Why do people die?
Ðe magakpɔ nɔvinyeawo gbe ɖeka?’
Will I ever see my brothers again?’
Nu ka tae nèsrɔ̃ dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya?
Why did you study science?
Nu si tae nye be mebua tame vevie tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu eye mesusui be nusɔsrɔ̃ ƒomevi sia akpe ɖe ŋunye makpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nyabiase siwo ɖea fu nam tso ɖevime ke.
I wanted to study physics because I was intrigued by the natural world and I thought physics might answer the questions that had intrigued me since childhood.
Nu kawo ŋue nèkua nu me le?
What is your field of research?
Mesrɔ̃ nu tso ale si mana atɔm-menuwo ƒe dusisi nadzi ɖe edzi agogo kekeli ƒe dusisi.
I explore ways of accelerating charged particles to speeds close to the speed of light.
Esia wɔe be mesrɔ̃ nu tso atɔm ƒe wɔwɔme ŋu.
I do this to study the structure of atoms.
Meku nu me hã tso ale si woatrɔ asi le keklẽŋusẽ ƒe sesẽme ŋu wòato keklẽŋusẽ siwo woyɔna be microwave (micro-onde) ƒe sesẽme ŋu evɔ made keklẽŋusẽ si woyɔna be infrared (infrarouge) ƒe sesẽme nu o.
I also investigate how to generate high-power radiation with a frequency between that of microwave and infrared radiation.
Togbɔ be ga tae mewɔa esia ɖo hã la, nu bubu si hã tae mewɔnɛ ɖoe nye be manya nu tso ale si xexea wɔ va dzɔ ŋu.
Although my research has commercial value, it is also linked to efforts to understand how the universe began.
Aleke wòdzɔe be nèva tsɔ ɖe le Biblia me?
How did you become interested in the Bible?
Le ƒe 1998 me la, Yehowa Ðasefo eve va gbɔnye le aƒe me.
In 1998, two of Jehovah’s Witnesses visited my home.
Wogblɔ be yewoakpe ɖe ŋunye makpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nye nyabiaseawo le Biblia me.
They offered to show me the Bible’s answers to my questions.
Srɔ̃nye Huabi, si hã nye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala va wɔ ɖeka kpli mí le numedzodzroa me.
My wife, Huabi, who is also a research scientist, joined us.
Togbɔ be zi gbãtɔe nye ema míekpɔ Biblia hã la, aɖaŋuɖoɖo nyui siwo le eme la wɔ dɔ ɖe mía dzi ŋutɔ.
We had never seen a Bible before, but we were impressed by its practical advice.
Míekpɔ ale si Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo dzi wɔwɔ ɖe vi na atsu kple asi siwo va dzroa nuwo me kpli mí.
We noticed how the Witness couple who visited us benefited by applying Bible principles.
Dzi dzɔa wo eye wometsɔ nu geɖe do agba na wo ɖokui le agbe me o.
They were happy and enjoyed an uncomplicated way of life.
Gake nu si Biblia gblɔ tso Mawu ŋu la na nye susu va nɔ wɔwɔm eveve be ɖe woanya wɔ xexea mahã.
But what the Bible says about God set me to wondering again whether the universe could have been created.
Abe dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununyala ene la, nye dɔe nye be mase dzɔdzɔmenuwo gɔme.
As a physicist, my job is to understand nature.
Eya ta medi be magaku nuwo me tsitotsito.
So I decided to give the facts some careful thought.
Abe dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununyala ene la, nye dɔe nye be mase dzɔdzɔmenuwo gɔme.
As a physicist, my job is to understand nature.
Eya ta medi be magaku nuwo me tsitotsito
So I decided to give the facts some careful thought
Ke nu kawo ŋue nèva ke ɖo?
What facts did you consider?
Gbã la, menya be nu vovovo siwo le ƒuƒoƒo me mate ŋu anɔ ɖoɖo nu o negbe ɖe nu bubu aɖe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe wo dzi.
First, I knew that a closed system cannot become more organized or remain organized unless acted upon by an external agent.
Emae woyɔna be dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽ ƒe se evelia.
That is the second law of thermodynamics.
Esi wònye be ɖe xexe gbahooa kple nu gbagbewo le ɖoɖo manyagblɔ aɖe nu ta la, meƒo nya ta be ame aɖee wɔ wo, eyae anye Wɔla la.
Since the universe and life on earth are highly ordered, I concluded that they must be products of an external agent, a Creator.
Eveliae nye be edze abe ɖe wowɔ xexe gbahoo sia kple anyigba ale be agbe nanya nɔ le edzi ene.
The second fact was that the universe and the earth seem to be specifically designed to support life.
Nu kae ɖo kpe edzi na wo be ɖe wowɔ nu gbagbewo?
What evidence of design did you see?
Le nyateƒe me la, nu gbagbe siwo katã le anyigba dzi la hiã ɣe ƒe ŋusẽ hafi woate ŋu anɔ agbe.
Practically all life on earth depends on energy from the sun.
Ne ŋusẽ sia tso ɣea gbɔ gbɔna anyigba la ezua keklẽŋusẽ le yame.
This energy travels through space as radiation.
Keklẽŋusẽ sia va ɖoa anyigba hezua keklẽŋusẽ ƒomevi vovovowo.
It comes to earth in a vast spectrum of wavelengths.
Woyɔa keklẽŋusẽ si ƒua du wu la be gamma ray (rayon gamma) si gblẽa ŋu.
The shortest are the lethal gamma rays.
Esiwo kplɔe ɖoe nye X-ray (rayon X), ultraviolet ray, kekeli, infrared, microwave kple esi meɖoa anyigba kaba o, si nye radio ƒe gbeɖiɖixɔŋusẽwo.
Then come X-rays, ultraviolet rays, visible light, infrared, microwaves, and the longest of all, radio waves.
Eɖe dzesi ŋutɔ be wowɔ ya si ƒo xlã míaƒe anyigba be wòaxe mɔ na keklẽŋusẽ siwo gblẽa nu evɔ wòaɖe mɔ na keklẽŋusẽ siwo ɖea vi na mí ya be woaɖo anyigba dzi.
Remarkably, our atmosphere blocks much harmful radiation while allowing other needed radiation to reach the earth’s surface.
Nu ka tae nu ma wɔ dɔ ɖe dziwò nenema gbegbe?
Why did that fact impress you?
Nya siwo wogblɔ ku ɖe nuwɔwɔwo ŋu le Biblia ƒe gɔmedzedze tso kekeli ŋu la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
I was intrigued by the introduction to the Bible’s creation account and its reference to light.
Afi ma gblɔ be: "Mawu gblɔ be: Kekeli nedo!
It states: "God said: ‘Let there be light.’
Eye kekeli do. "
Then there was light. "
Ɣe ƒe keklẽ si le xexe gbahooa me ƒe akpa sue aɖe koe amegbetɔwo tea ŋu kpɔna, ke hã kekeli hiã hafi nu gbagbewo nate ŋu anɔ nyigba dzi.
Only a very narrow band of the vast spectrum of solar radiation is visible light, but light is vital for life.
Atiwo hiã na kekeli be woatsɔ awɔ woƒe nuɖuɖuwo, eye mí amegbetɔwo hã míehiã nɛ be míate ŋu akpɔ nu.
Plants need it to produce food, and we need light to see.
Ale si kekeli wɔna tea ŋu va ɖoa anyigba dzi la mate ŋu anye nudogoɖenunu o.
The atmosphere’s special transparency to light cannot be a coincidence.
Esi gawɔ nuku wue nye ale si ya si ƒo xlã anyigba ɖea mɔ ultraviolet-keklẽŋusẽ ʋɛ aɖe ko va ɖoa anyigba dzi.
Even more remarkable is the tiny amount of ultraviolet light that reaches the earth’s surface. Why is that significant?
Nu kae ɖe dzesi le keklẽŋusẽ sia ŋu?
Some ultraviolet radiation is critical.
Míehiã ultraviolet-keklẽŋusẽ ʋɛ aɖe be wòana nunyiame si woyɔna be vitamin D la míaƒe ŋutigbalẽ, enaa ŋusẽ nɔa míaƒe ƒuwo ŋu eye wòkpɔa mía ta tso kansa kple dɔléle bubuwo si me.
We need a small amount of it on our skin to produce vitamin D, which is vital for bone health and evidently for protection from cancer and other diseases.
Gake ne keklẽŋusẽ sia sɔ gbɔ akpa la, enaa ŋutigbalẽmekansa kple ŋkudɔ mí.
However, too much of this particular radiation causes skin cancer and eye cataracts.
Ne ya si ƒo xlã anyigba ɖe mɔ ɖe keklẽ sia ƒe sue aɖe si sɔ ŋu wòva ɖo anyigba dzi la, esɔna na mí ŋutɔ.
In its natural state, the atmosphere allows only a tiny amount of this ultraviolet radiation to reach the earth’s surface and it is just the right amount.
Le nye ya gonyeme la, esia ɖo kpe edzi be ame aɖee wɔ anyigba kple nu gbagbewo.
For me, that is evidence that someone designed the earth to sustain life.
Ʋɛʋɛʋɛ la, nye kple srɔ̃nye Huabi míeva ka ɖe edzi be Wɔla aɖe li eye be eyae na woŋlɔ Biblia.
Gradually Huabi and I became convinced that there is a Creator and that he inspired the Bible.
Le ƒe 2005 me la, míezu Yehowa Ðasefowo eye míekpɔa gome le Biblia me gbedeasia fiafia amewo me.
In 2005, we became Jehovah’s Witnesses, and now we share in teaching the Bible to others.
Atikeŋutinumekula Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
I Am Convinced That There Is a Creator "
Frédéric Dumoulin
Frédéric Dumoulin
Frédéric Dumoulin ku nu me tso atikewɔwɔ ŋu le Ghent Yunivɛsiti si le Belgium ƒe ewo kple edzivɔ.
For more than a decade, Frédéric Dumoulin has worked in the field of pharmaceutical research at Ghent University in Belgium.
Ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, mexɔe se be Mawu li o.
At one time he was an atheist.
Gake emegbe Frédéric va xɔe se be Mawue wɔ nu gbagbewo.
But later Frédéric became convinced that God created life.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbe Frédéric si nye Yehowa Ðasefo fifia tso eƒe xɔse kpakple eƒe dɔa ŋu.
Awake! asked Frédéric who is now one of Jehovah’s Witnesses about his work and his faith.
Ðe wonyi wò le mawusubɔsubɔha aɖe mea?
Did religion have any role in your childhood?
Yes.
Katolikotɔe danye nye.
My mother was Roman Catholic.
Gake esi mexlẽ nu tso Atitsogaʋa kple Ŋutasẽʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ ŋu la, mawusubɔsubɔ to le mo nam keŋkeŋ.
But when I read about the Crusades and the Inquisition, I felt disgusted with religion and wanted nothing more to do with it.
Mexlẽ nu tso subɔsubɔha siwo mexɔ Kristo dzi se o hã ŋu, gake mekpɔe be tɔgã-tɔɖiviwo koe wo katã wonye.
I also read about non-Christian religions and saw that they were no better.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 14 la, mese le ɖokuinye me be nu fitifiti wɔwɔ si bɔ ɖe subɔsubɔhawo me ɖo kpe edzi be Mawu meli o.
When I was 14, I reasoned that the prevalence of corruption in religion proves that God doesn’t exist.
Eya ta esi wofia num tso nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ŋu le suku la, melɔ̃ ɖe edzi be nu siwo me agbe me le o woe trɔ ʋuu va zu nu gbagbewo.
So when I was taught the evolution theory at school, I concluded that life originated by natural processes.
Nu kae na nèva tsɔ ɖe le dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya me?
How were you attracted to science?
Esi mexɔ ƒe adre la, wona nusuekpɔmɔ̃m eye wòva zu nye fefenu vevitɔ.
When I was seven, I was given a microscope and it became my favorite toy.
Metsɔnɛ léa ŋku ɖe nudzodzoevi lédzinamewo abe kpakpaluʋui ene ŋu.
Among other things, I used it to examine fascinating insects, such as butterflies.
Aleke wòdzɔe be nèva tsɔ ɖe le ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ me?
How did you become interested in the origin of life?
Esi mexɔ ƒe 22 la, medo go Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe si nye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala.
When I was 22, I met a scientist who was one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Exɔe se be Mawue wɔ nu gbagbewo.
She believed that God created life.
Esia wɔ moya nam ŋutɔ.
That seemed really strange to me.
Mesusui be mate ŋu ana wòakpɔe be bometsitsie eƒe dzixɔse ma nye.
I thought I could easily prove her faith to be ridiculous.
Gake nukutɔe la, eɖo nye nyabiasewo ŋu nam wòde edeƒe.
But to my surprise, she had sensible answers to my questions.
Meva nɔ ŋugble dem tso ame siwo xɔ Mawu dzi se la ƒe nuwɔnawo ŋu.
I became curious about people who believe in God.
Le ɣleti ʋɛ aɖewo megbe la, megado go Ðasefo bubu si hã nya nu tso atikewɔnyawo ŋu.
A few months later, I met another Witness who was quite knowledgeable about medical matters.
Esi wòbe yeaƒo nu tso yeƒe dzixɔsewo ŋu nam la, melɔ̃ elabena medi be manya nu si tae amewo xɔ Mawu dzi se.
When he offered to explain what he believed, I accepted his offer because I wanted to know why people believe in God.
Medi be maɖe fuflugba si wòdo na eɖokui la ɖa le ta nɛ.
I wanted to save him from his delusion.
Ðe nète ŋu na wòkpɔe be ɖe woflu yea?
Did you convince him that he was mistaken?
Ao.
No, I didn’t.
Eya ta meva te nusɔsrɔ̃ tso nufiafia siwo ƒo nu tso ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ la ŋu.
I began researching theories on the origin of life.
Nukutɔe la, meva kpɔe be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala xɔŋkɔ aɖewo gblɔ be lãmenugbagbevi suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã ƒe wɔwɔme de ŋgɔ ale gbegbe be mate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si le anyigba sia dzi o.
To my surprise, I found that some eminent scientists say that even the simplest living cell is so complex that it couldn’t have originated on earth.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo xɔe se be yamenutowo mee lãmenugbagbevi mawo dzɔ tso.
Some of them think such cells came from outer space.
Woƒe nu mesɔ kura le ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ ŋu o.
There is a lot of disagreement about how life began.
Ekema ɖe woƒe nu sɔ le nane ya mea?
Is there a point of agreement?
Ewɔ moya be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala geɖe da asi ɖe edzi be le mɔ aɖe nu la, dzɔdzɔmenu siwo me agbe mele o lae trɔ ʋuu va zu nu gbagbewo.
Strangely, many scientists agree that somehow natural processes caused life to spring from nonliving matter.
Meva nɔ ɖokuinye biam be: ‘Ne wobe ɖeko agbe dzɔ le eɖokui si evɔ womenya ale si wòdzɔe o la, ke nu kae na woka ɖe edzi alea gbegbe be nenema wòdzɔe?’
I began to wonder, ‘If they don’t know how life could come about without a Creator, how can they be so sure that it happened that way?’
Meva nɔ nu si Biblia gblɔ tso ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ la ŋu bum vevie.
I began to look into what the Bible says about the origin of life.
Aleke nèkpɔ Biblia ƒe nyawoe?
What conclusions did you draw about the Bible?
Zi ale si meva le nu srɔ̃m tso Biblia ŋui la, zi nenemae mekana ɖe edzi be emenyawo nye nyateƒe.
The more I learned from the Bible, the more I became convinced that it’s true.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nyitsɔ laa hafi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va kpɔe dze sii be gɔmedzedze li na xexe gbahoo sia.
For example, only recently have scientists found evidence that the universe had a beginning.
Gake Biblia ƒe kpukpui gbãtɔ si woŋlɔ ƒe 3,500 aɖewoe nye esia gblɔ be: "Le gɔmedzedzea me Mawu wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba. "
But the opening verse of the Bible, written some 3,500 years ago, says: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. "
Meva kpɔe be ne Biblia gblɔ nya aɖe tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu la, nenema tututu wònɔna.
And I found that whenever the Bible comments on scientific matters, it is accurate.
Meva kpɔe be ne Biblia gblɔ nya aɖe tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu la, nenema tututu wònɔna
I found that whenever the Bible comments on scientific matters, it is accurate
Ðe wòsesẽna na wò be nàxɔ Mawu dzi ase le esi nènye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala ta?
Did your knowledge of science make believing in God difficult?
Kpao!
No.
Ɣeyiɣi si me meva xɔ Mawu dzi se la, menɔ nu srɔ̃m tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu anɔ abe ƒe etɔ̃e nye ema ene.
When I first came to believe in God, I had been studying science at a university for three years.
Va se ɖe fifia la, zi ale si mele nu srɔ̃m tso nu gbagbewo ƒe wɔwɔme ŋu la, zi nenemae mexɔnɛ sena be Wɔla aɖe li.
To this day, the more I study the design of living things, the more I am convinced that there is a Creator.
Àte ŋu ana eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖe mía?
Can you give us an example?
Yes.
Mesrɔ̃ nu tso ŋusẽ si atikewo kple aɖinuwo kpɔna ɖe nu gbagbewo dzi la ŋu.
I’ve studied the effects of medications and toxins on living creatures.
Nu si wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye wue nye ale si aɖinuwo kple nugbagbevi gblẽnuwo metea ŋu gena ɖe míaƒe ahɔhɔ̃ me o.
A design that impresses me is how our brain is protected from dangerous substances and from bacteria.
Nane li si tso míaƒe ʋu kple lãmenugbagbevi siwo le ahɔhɔ̃a me la dome.
There is a barrier that keeps our blood separate from our brain cells.
Nu kae wɔ nuku le nu ma ŋu?
What is remarkable about that?
Anɔ abe ƒe alafa ɖeka kple edzivɔ aɖewoe nye esia la, numekulawo de dzesii be nu siwo gena ɖe míaƒe ʋu me la yina ɖe ŋutilã ƒe akpa sia akpa negbe ahɔhɔ̃ kple dzimeƒuka koe do le eme.
Over a hundred years ago, researchers noticed that substances introduced into the bloodstream enter every area of the body except the brain and spinal cord.
Nu ma wɔ nuku nam ŋutɔ elabe ʋuka wuwlui gbogbo aɖewoe tsɔa ʋu yina na lãmenugbagbevi ɖe sia ɖe si le ahɔhɔ̃a me.
That fact is astonishing to me, because an immense network of tiny capillary vessels takes blood to every cell in the brain.
Ʋua klɔa lãmenugbagbevi siwo katã le ahɔhɔ̃a me la, eye ʋua kee naa nuɖuɖu kple ɔksidzin wo.
All brain cells are cleaned, fed, and oxygenated by blood.
Ke aleke wòdzɔe be ʋua megena ɖe lãmenugbagbevi siwo le ahɔhɔ̃a me la me o?
So, how can our blood be kept separate from our brain cells?
Ƒe geɖewoe nye esia womenya ale si tututu esia dzɔnae o.
For many years it was a mystery. How does the barrier work?
Nu kae xea mɔ na ʋua be megena ɖe lãmenugbagbevi siwo le ahɔhɔ̃a me la me o? Ʋuka wuwlui siwo le ahɔhɔ̃a me mele abe aŋenuwo ene o.
Microscopic blood vessels are not like plastic tubes that keep what’s inside separate from what’s outside.
Lãmenugbagbeviwo le ʋuka mawo ŋuti.
The walls of blood vessels are made of cells.
Lãmenugbagbevi mawo ɖea mɔ nu ƒomevi aɖewo kple nugbagbevi nyaŋuinyaŋuiwo gena ɖe wo me alo zɔna le wo dome.
These cells allow substances and microbes to pass through them and between them.
Ke hã, lãmenugbagbevi siwo le míaƒe ahɔhɔ̃ ƒe ʋukawo ŋu ya to vovovo kura.
However, the cells making up the blood vessels in our brain are different.
Wotigi ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu.
They’re tightly connected to each other.
Lãmenugbagbevi siawo kple woƒe kpeƒewo wɔ nuku.
These cells and the tight junctions between them are amazing.
Nu siawo tea ŋu ɖea mɔ nanewo abe ɔksidzin, karbɔn-ya kple ʋumesukli toa ʋukawo me gena ɖe wo me le ɖoɖo nu.
A vast array of complex mechanisms ensure that some things such as oxygen, carbon dioxide, and glucose pass between the bloodstream and the brain in a regulated way.
Gake meɖea mɔ nu bubuwo abe protein kple lãmenugbagbevi bubuwo gena ɖe eme o.
But other compounds, proteins, and cells are kept out.
Eya ta nu si xea mɔ na ʋua be megena ɖe ahɔhɔ̃a me o la nyea molecule si xea mɔ na lãmenu vovovowo.
So the blood-brain barrier operates at a molecular level to produce physical, chemical, and electrical barriers.
Nye ya mekpɔe be nu ma mate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si o.
For me, such design simply could not have evolved.
Nu Gbagbewo Ŋuti Nunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Biotechnologist Explains His Faith
Ðɔkta Hans Kristian Kotlar
Dr. Hans Kristian Kotlar

Le ƒe 1978 me la, Ðɔkta Hans Kristian Kotlar dze eƒe agbemedɔ gbãtɔ abe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala ene gɔme le Norwegian Radium Hospital. Ekua nu me tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu. Eku nu me tso kansadɔ kple amegbetɔ ƒe ŋutilã ƒe dɔlélenutsiŋutete hã ŋu.
In 1978, Dr. Hans Kristian Kotlar’s first job in scientific research was at the Norwegian Radium Hospital, where he studied cancer and the human immune system.
Ɣemaɣi la, eva di vevie be yeanya ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ.
At that time, he also became interested in the origin of life.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe numekukuwo kple eƒe mawudzixɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his research and his religious faith.
Nu kae na nètsɔ ɖe le ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ kple nu si tae míele agbe ɖo la me?
What stirred your interest in the origin and meaning of life?
Tɔ́nye nye Katolikotɔ eye Nɔnye nye Protestanttɔ.
My father was Catholic and my mother was Protestant.
Gake wometsɔa mawusubɔsubɔ nu vevie o.
That said, they did not view religion as important.
Esime menye ŋutsuvi dzaa la, medea ŋugble tso nu si tae míele agbe ɖo la ŋu, eye mexlẽ agbalẽwo tso Buddha Subɔsubɔha, Hindu Subɔsubɔha kple Islam Subɔsubɔha ŋu.
As for me, during my teens, I wondered about the meaning of life, and I read books about Buddhism, Hinduism, and Islam.
Mebia Mawu gɔ̃ hã kpɔ be wòana manya nyateƒe la.
I even asked God to reveal the truth to me.
Le ƒe 1970 ƒe ƒeawo me la, wova wɔ ŋgɔyiyi ɖedzesi geɖewo le lãmenugbagbeviwo ŋuti nunya me, eye mesusui be esia ate ŋu ana woava nya ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ.
By the 1970’s, the field of molecular biology had made some amazing advances, and I wondered if it might reveal how life began.
Nu gbagbewo ƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo ƒe wɔwɔme wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ, eya ta metiae be masrɔ̃ nu tso nu gbagbewo ŋu.
The mechanisms within living cells intrigued me, so I chose to study biotechnology.
Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, nufialawo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ gblɔna be ɖe nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si, eye mexɔ woƒe nyawo dzi se.
I might add that most of my professors said that life evolved by natural processes, and I believed them.
Nu ka tae nètsɔ ɖe le Biblia me?
Why did you take an interest in the Bible?
Yehowa Ðasefo eve va míaƒe aƒe me gbe ɖeka.
Two of Jehovah’s Witnesses visited our home.
Togbɔ be wodo vivi ɖe ŋunye hã la, meblu ɖe wo ta, eye megblɔ be nyemedi be mase woƒe nyawo o.
Although they were pleasant, I reacted rudely and told them I was not interested. My wife overheard me.
Srɔ̃nye se mía ŋkɔ, eye wògblɔ nam be: "Srɔ̃nye Hans Kristian, mèwɔe nyuie o.
"That was not kind, Hans Kristian, " she said.
Menye wòe dina be yeanya nu si ta míele agbe ɖo oa? "
"You have always been interested in the meaning of life. "
Mekpɔe be eƒe nya le eme; ŋu kpem.
She was right, and I felt ashamed.
Ale wɔ mesi du dze Ðasefoawo yome.
So I ran after the Witnesses.
Esi míenɔ dze ɖom la, megblɔ na wo be medi be manya nenye be Biblia wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya.
During our conversation, I told them that I wanted to know if the Bible is in harmony with science.
Aleke wowɔ nui?
How did they respond to that?
Woxlẽ nya si Biblia gblɔ tso afi si dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽ si le xexea me la dzɔ tso la ŋu nam.
They showed me what the Bible says about the Source of the energy manifest in the universe.
Mawunyakpukpui si woxlẽ nam la gblɔ be: "Mifɔ mo dzi, ne miakpɔ nu!
The scripture they read states: "Lift up your eyes to heaven and see.
Ame ka wɔ nu siawo? . . .
Who has created these things? . . .
Wo dometɔ aɖeke mesusɔna o le eƒe ŋusẽ geɖe kple alɔkame sesẽ la nu. "
Because of his vast dynamic energy and his awe-inspiring power, not one of them is missing. "
Nya sia wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
This statement intrigued me.
Eye susu le eme hã be míaxɔe ase be Nunyala aɖe kokoko gbɔe dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽ si na nuwo le ɖoɖo nu le xexea me la tso.
It also seemed reasonable that only an intelligent Source of energy could account for the order in the universe.
Ðe susu si le asiwò tsã be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si la trɔa?
Did your view of evolution change?
Vivivi la, meva nɔ dzesi demee be kpeɖodzi boo aɖeke mele ame siwo fiaa nu be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si ƒe nufiafia vovovoawo ŋu o.
I gradually realized that the various theories of evolution lacked rigorous scientific proof.
Le nyateƒe me la, wonye nya siwo wokpa be woatsɔ aɖee afia be ɖe nu gbagbewo ƒe lãmenu siwo ƒe wɔwɔme wɔ nuku, abe woƒe dɔlélenutsiŋutete ene la, dzɔ le vo me.
In fact, they are basically stories invented to explain how the remarkable designs found within living things, such as the immune system, could originate in a mindless manner.
Zi ale si meyi edzi le nu srɔ̃m tso dɔlélenutsiŋutete ŋu la, zi nenemae mekpɔnɛ be eƒe wɔwɔme de ŋgɔ eye wòwɔa dɔ nyuie ŋutɔ.
The more I studied the immune system, the more I realized just how complex and effective it is.
Eya ta nye numekukuwo na meƒo nya ta be Wɔla nyanu aɖee wɔ nu gbagbewo.
Thus, my research led me to conclude that life is a product of an intelligent Creator.
Nye numekukuwo na meƒo nya ta be Wɔla nyanu aɖee wɔ nu gbagbewo
My research led me to conclude that life is a product of an intelligent Creator
Àte ŋu agblɔ nu siwo ɖo kpe edzi be ɖe wowɔ nu gbagbewo la dometɔ aɖewo na mía?
Can you give us some evidence of design?
Dɔlélenutsiŋutete ƒe wɔwɔme kple eƒe dɔwɔwɔ keke ta eye wowɔ wo wonye ŋutilãtakpɔnuwo koŋ tso dɔlékui vovovowo si me.
The immune system is actually an astonishing array of structures and mechanisms designed to defend us from a wide variety of agents, including bacteria and viruses.
Ŋutilãtakpɔnu siawo le hatsotso eve me eye wowɔa dɔ aduadu.
The mechanisms, in turn, can be grouped into two complementary systems.
Hatsotso gbãtɔ hona ɖe dɔlékui siwo ge ɖe ŋutilã me ŋu le gaƒoƒo ʋɛ aɖewo me.
The first mobilizes an attack on invading microbes within hours.

Gake exɔa ŋkeke geɖe hafi hatsotso evelia hona ɖe dɔlékuiawo ŋu eye wòdzidzea dɔlékuiawo pɛpɛpɛ hedzea wo dzi abe ale si wodzidzea aŋutrɔ hedanɛ ene. Ŋutilãtakpɔnu ƒe hatsotso evelia sia me tɔwo ɖoa ŋku nu dzi ŋutɔ.
The second takes several days to respond but targets the invaders like a well-aimed arrow.
Eya ta ne dɔlékui mawo ke gage ɖe ŋutilã me le ƒe aɖewo megbe gɔ̃ hã la, wodea dzesi wo hehoa aʋa ɖe wo ŋu enumake.
This second system also has a good memory, so that if a specific invader returns years later, this enemy will be met with a rapid response.
Dɔlélenutsiŋutetea wɔa dɔ nyuie ale gbegbe be míenyana kura be dɔlékuiwo ge ɖe míaƒe ŋutilã me eye takpɔnuwo wɔ avu kpli wo o.
The whole system works so well that often you do not even realize that you have been infected and effectively defended.
Eye nu si gawɔ nukue nye ale si dɔlélenutsiŋutetea tea ŋu dea vovototo nu siwo tso gota ge ɖe lã me kple lãmenugbagbevi alafa geɖe siwo le míaƒe lã me la dome.
Also amazing is the way the immune system distinguishes between foreign substances and the hundreds of cell types that make up our body.
Gblɔe na mí, nu kae dzɔna ne dɔlékui aɖe ge ɖe ŋutilã me?
Tell us, what happens when a microbe enters our body?
Dɔlékuiwo toa míaƒe dzitodzito, nuɖuɖu, aɖiɖɔtoe kple ŋutigbalẽ me gena ɖe míaƒe lã me.
Microbes sneak in through our breath, our food, our urogenital tract, or breaks in our skin.
Ne míaƒe dɔlélenutsiŋutetea de dzesii be dɔlékuiwo ge ɖe míaƒe lã me la, enana be ŋutilãtakpɔnu geɖewo hoa aʋa ɖe dɔlékuiawo ŋu ɖe wo nɔewo yome.
When the immune system detects intruders, it sets in motion a cascade of reactions involving dozens of precisely designed proteins.
Ŋutilãtakpɔnu ɖe sia ɖe ƒe hoho nana be bubu si sẽ wui hona ɖe eyome hewɔa avu kple dɔlékuiawo vevie.
Each component in this cascade activates the next to amplify the counterattack.
Ale si nu sia yia edzii la gɔme sese mele bɔbɔe o!
The process is mind-boggling!
Ke ɖe míate ŋu agblɔ be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya na nègaxɔ Mawu dzi se wua?
Could we say, then, that your knowledge of science has strengthened your faith in God?
Nenema tututue!
Absolutely!
Ale si míaƒe dɔlélenutsiŋutete sẽ ŋu kple ale si eƒe dɔwɔwɔ de ŋgɔe la ɖo kpe edzi be Wɔla nyanu lɔ̃ame aɖee wɔ nuwo.
The power and sophistication of our immune system points to a wise and loving Creator.
Magblɔ kpee be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya na hã be megaxɔ Biblia dzi se wu.
I might add that science has also strengthened my faith in the Bible.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Lododowo 17:22 gblɔ na mí be "dzi kpɔdzidzɔ nana lãme hayana. "
For example, Proverbs 17:22 tells us that "a joyful heart is good medicine. "
Numekulawo va de dzesii be míaƒe seselelãmewo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe míaƒe dɔlélenutsiŋutete ƒe dɔwɔwɔ nyuie dzi.
Researchers have discovered that our state of mind can influence our immune system.
Nuxaxa ate ŋu ana be míaƒe ŋutilãtakpɔnuwo nagbɔdzɔ.
Stress, for instance, can weaken our immune response.
Mia tɔ dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala geɖe mexɔ Mawu dzi se o, nu ka gbɔe wòtso?
Many of your peers don’t believe in God. Why is that?
Susu vovovowo tae.
The reasons vary.
Abe ale si wònɔ le gonyeme ene la, ɖeko wo dometɔ aɖewo xɔa nu siwo wofiaa wo le suku dzi sena.
Some, as was true of me, simply accept what they were taught.
Ðewohĩ wosusuna be kpeɖodzi sẽŋuwo le nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la ŋu.
Perhaps they assume that evolution is backed up by good science.
Wo dometɔ geɖe hã mebua tame boo tso ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ la ŋu o.
Others give little thought to how life began.
Eɖe fu ŋutɔ!
That’s a pity.
Ðe wòle be woabia nya geɖe tso nufiafia sia ŋu hafi.
I think they should ask more questions.
Nu ka tae nèva zu Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe amedzrowɔwɔ kple ale si woxɔ ŋugbe si Wɔlaa do ku ɖe etsɔme nyui aɖe ŋu dzi se la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
I was attracted by their hospitality and their faith in the Creator’s promise of a better future.
Ðe wokua nyawo me tsitotsito hekpɔa kpeɖodzi na wo hafi xɔa wo dzi sena, ke menye nyakpakpa alo nususugblɔwo dzie woxɔna sena o.
And that faith rests on research and sound reasoning, not myths or speculation.
Nugbagbesueŋutinunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Microbiologist Explains Her Faith
Ðɔkta Feng-Ling Yang
Dr. Feng-Ling Yang
Feng-Ling Yang nye numekulagã ƒe kpeɖeŋutɔ le Taipei ƒe numekuƒe gã si le Taiwan.
Feng-Ling Yang is a senior research assistant at the central research academy in Taipei, Taiwan.
Wota nu siwo ŋu wòke ɖo la ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ƒe agbalẽwo me.
Her work has been published in scientific journals.
Tsã la, exɔ nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si la dzi se.
She used to believe in the theory of evolution.
Gake eva trɔ susu emegbe.
But then she changed her mind.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya kple eƒe xɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked her about her science and her faith.
Ƒo nu tso wò ƒometɔwo kple hehe si nèxɔ ŋu na mí.
Tell us about your background.
Dzinyelawo da ahe kolikoli eye nɔnye meɖo afɔ suku xɔ me kpɔ o.
My parents were very poor, and my mother never learned to read.
Míenyia ha eye míedea amagbewo ƒe agble hã le teƒe aɖe si tsi ɖɔna ɖo edziedzi si te ɖe Taipei-dua ŋu.
We raised pigs and grew vegetables in a flood-prone area near the city of Taipei.
Dzinyelawo fia nu si tae wòle vevie be manye dɔ sesẽ wɔla lam eye wofiam hã be makpe ɖe amewo ŋu.
My parents taught me the value of hard work, and they also taught me to help other people.
Mawusubɔlawoe dziwòlawo nyea?
Was your family religious?
Dzinyelawo nye Tao-subɔsubɔha me tɔwo.
My family practiced Taoism.
Míesaa vɔ na "Dziƒo Mawu " la, gake míenya naneke tso eŋu o.
We made sacrifices to the "Heaven God, " but we didn’t know anything about him.
Mebiaa ɖokuinye be: ‘Nu ka tae amewo ɖua aya?
I used to wonder: ‘Why do people suffer?
Nu ka tae amewo dia wo ɖokuiwo tɔ?’
Why are people selfish?’
Mexlẽ agbalẽ geɖe tso Tao-subɔsubɔha, Buddha-subɔsubɔha kpakple Europatɔwo kple Amerikatɔwo ƒe ŋutinyawo ŋu.
I read books about Taoism and Buddhism and about Eastern and Western history.
Mede sɔleme geɖewo gɔ̃ hã.
I even went to a couple of churches.
Gake nyemete ŋu kpɔ nye nyabiaseawo ƒe ŋuɖoɖowo o.
But I couldn’t find answers to my questions.
Nu ka tae nèsrɔ̃ dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya?
Why did you study science?
Melɔ̃ akɔntabubu, eye se siwo fiaa mɔ ɖoɖo si nu dzɔdzɔmenuwo nɔna la wɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
I liked mathematics and was fascinated by the way physical and chemical laws govern the structure of things.
Se aɖewoe fiaa mɔ ɖoɖo si nu nuwɔwɔ ɖe sia ɖe wɔa dɔ le, tso xexeme gbahoo sia dzi va se ɖe nugbagbevi suetɔ kekeake dzi.
Everything, from the immense universe to tiny microbes, has a structure that is controlled by rules.
Medi vevie be mase ale si se siawo wɔa dɔe la gɔme.
And I wanted to understand those rules.
Nu ka tae nèxɔ nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la dzi se tsã?
Why did you believe the theory of evolution to be a fact?
Nyemesrɔ̃ naneke si tsi tre ɖe nufiafia sia ŋu kpɔ o.
I was taught nothing to the contrary.
Le nye sekɛndrisukudeɣi kple yunivɛsitideɣi sia la, wofiaa mí be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si.
From junior high school through university, evolution was the only explanation I heard.
Eye esi wònye mekua nu me tso nu gbagbewo ŋu ta la, ele nam be maxɔ nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la dzi se.
And then because of being a researcher in a life science, I was expected to accept evolution.
Esi wònye mekua nu me tso nu gbagbewo ŋu ta la, ele nam be maxɔ nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la dzi se
Because I was a researcher in a life science, I was expected to accept evolution
Nu kae na nèva dze Biblia xexlẽ gɔme?
What made you start reading the Bible?
Meʋu yi ɖatsi Germany le ƒe 1996 me be masrɔ̃ nu ayi ŋgɔe le nye yunivɛsitiɖaseɖigbalẽ gbãtɔ xɔxɔ megbe.
I went to live in Germany in 1996 to start my postgraduate studies.
Le ƒe si kplɔe ɖo me la, medo go aƒenɔ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Simone.
The following year I met a lady named Simone.
Yehowa Ðasefoe wònye, eye egblɔ be yeakpe ɖe ŋunye makpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nye nyabiasewo le Biblia me.
She was one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, and she offered to show me the Bible’s answers to my questions.
Esi wògblɔ nam be Biblia gblɔ nu si ta míele agbe ɖo la, ewɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ale gbegbe.
When she told me that the Bible explains the purpose of life, I was intrigued.
Esia ta mefɔna fɔŋli ga ene kple afã gbe sia gbe xlẽa Biblia gaƒoƒo ɖeka sɔŋ.
I began getting up at half past four each morning to read the Bible for an hour.
Eyome menɔa zɔzɔm le nutoa me henɔa ŋugble dem le nu siwo mexlẽ ŋu.
Then I would go for a walk to meditate.
Le ƒe si kplɔe me la, mexlẽ Biblia katã vɔ.
During the next year, I read the whole Bible.
Ale si Biblia me nyagblɔɖiwo va eme pɛpɛpɛ la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
I was impressed by the accuracy of its prophecies.
Vivivi la, meva ka ɖe edzi bliboe be Mawu gbɔe Biblia la tso.
Gradually, I became convinced that the Bible is from God.
Afi kae nèsusuna tsã be nu gbagbewo dzɔ tso?
What were your thoughts about the origin of life?

Esi menɔ afi si nu gbagbewo dzɔ tso ŋu bum vevie le ƒe 1990 ƒe nuwuwu la, molecule ŋuti nunyalawo va te dzesidedee be ɖoɖo si nu nu gbagbewo ƒe lãmenuwo le kple woƒe dɔwɔwɔ de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu ale si wobui tsã.
Well, when I began giving this serious thought in the late 1990’s, molecular biologists were beginning to realize that the chemistry of life is much more elaborate than anyone had previously thought.
Enye nyateƒe be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo nyae tso gbe aɖe gbe ke be nunyiame siwo le nu gbagbewo ƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo me la ƒe wɔwɔme kple dɔwɔwɔ gɔme sese sesẽ wu molecule ɖe sia ɖe si li la tɔ.
Of course, scientists had long known that the proteins in living cells are the most chemically sophisticated molecules in existence.
Gake fifia la, wova nya nu tso ale si protein gbogbo aɖewo ƒua ƒu wɔa mɔ̃ siwo ƒe akpa aɖewo zɔna la ŋu.
But now, they were discovering how whole assemblies of proteins are organized to form elegant machines with moving parts.
Protein 50 kple edzivɔwo ƒoa ƒu wɔa molecule-mɔ̃ ɖeka.
A molecular machine might be composed of over 50 proteins.

Eye lãmenugbagbevi suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã hiã mɔ̃ siawo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo vovovowo be wòawɔ dɔ vovovowo. Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ehiã mɔ̃ sia be wòatsɔ awɔ ŋusẽ, agbugbɔ nyatakakawo aŋlɔ alo be wòadzɔ mɔnu vovovo siwo le lãmenugbagbevia ŋuti la nu.
And even the simplest cell needs a collection of different machines for example, to generate power, to duplicate information, and to control access across membranes.
Aleke esia na nèƒo nya tae?
What did you conclude?
Mebia ɖokuinye be, ‘Aleke wòdzɔe be protein-mɔ̃ mawo de ŋgɔ nenema gbegbe?’
Well, I asked myself, ‘How did those protein machines become so well engineered?’
Ɣemaɣi la, ale si gbegbe lãmenugbagbeviwo ƒe wɔwɔme de ŋgɔ eye wo gɔme sese sesẽe la na be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala geɖewo hã bia nya sia ke.
At the time, the unexpected complexity of cell chemistry made a number of scientists ask the same question.
Lãmetsiŋutinunyalagã aɖe si le United States ta agbalẽ aɖe si ɖe nu me be molecule-mɔ̃ siwo le lãmenugbagbeviwo me de ŋgɔ ale gbegbe be womate ŋu adzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si o.
A professor of biochemistry in the United States published a book arguing that the molecular machines in living cells are so complex that they could not have originated randomly.
Melɔ̃ ɖe eƒe nyaa dzi.
I agreed.
Mekpɔe be ame aɖe kokokoe wɔ nu gbagbewo.
I felt that life must have been created.
Mebia ɖokuinye be, ‘Aleke wòdzɔe be protein-mɔ̃ mawo de ŋgɔ nenema gbegbe?’
I asked myself, ‘How did those protein machines become so well engineered?’
Nu kae na nèva zu Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Ale si Simone mele lãmesẽ me tututu o gake wòzɔa mɔ kilometa 56 kwasiɖa sia kwasiɖa va fiaa Bibliam la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ale gbegbe.
I was impressed that although Simone had health problems, she traveled some 35 miles (56 km) each week to teach me the Bible.
Mese be esime Nazitɔwo ɖu Germany dzi la, wode Yehowa Ðasefo aɖewo fuwɔamegaxɔwo me le esi wogbe be yemade nu dunyahehe me o ta.
I learned that during Germany’s Nazi era, some Witnesses were imprisoned in concentration camps for their political neutrality.
Eye ale si dzi nɔ wo ƒoe hã wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
Their courage deeply impressed me.
Nenema kee ale si gbegbe Ðasefoawo lɔ̃ Mawui na meɖoe be manɔ abe woawo ke ene.
The Witnesses’ love for God made me want to be like them.
Esi nèxɔ Mawu dzi se la, vi kae wòɖe na wò?
Has believing in God benefited you?
Nye dɔwɔhatiwo gblɔ be fifia ya mele dzidzɔ kpɔm ŋutɔ.
My colleagues say that I’m happier now.
Tsã la, mebua ɖokuinye be nyemele ɖeke me o, eye wòkpea ŋu nam be maƒo nu tso nye ƒometɔwo ŋu le esi wonye ame dahewo ta, eye nyemenana wonyaa du si me tɔ menye o.
I used to feel inferior because of my poor background, so I never told anyone where I grew up and never mentioned my parents.
Meva srɔ̃e le Biblia me be ɖoƒe si ame le le agbe me menɔa vevie na Mawu o.
But I’ve learned from the Bible that God is not interested in social status.
Le nyateƒe me la, anɔ eme be ƒome si me wonyi Yesu le la da ahe abe míaƒe ƒomea ene.
In fact, Jesus was raised in a family that was probably as poor as mine.
Fifia metsɔa ɖe le eme na dzinyelawo eye meɖea wo fiaa xɔ̃nyewo.
Now I care for my parents and enjoy introducing them to my friends.
Lãmetsiŋutinunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Biochemist Explains Her Faith
Ðɔkta Paola Chiozzi nye lãmenu suesuewo ŋuti nunyala si le dɔ wɔm le Ferrara Yunivɛsiti le Italy ƒe 20 kple edzivɔe nye esia.
For more than 20 years, Dr. Paola Chiozzi has worked as a molecular biologist at the University of Ferrara in Italy.
Nyɔ! ƒe magazinea talawo bia gbee tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si wòsrɔ̃ kple nu si dzi wòxɔ se la ŋu.
Awake! asked her about her science and her faith.
Ƒo nu tso ɖokuiwò ŋu na mí vie.
Tell us about your background.
Fofonye nye afɔkpawɔla, eye danye nye agbledela.
My father was a cobbler, and my mother was a farmworker.
