Gake nye ya medi be mava nye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala.
But I wanted to be a scientist.
Seƒoƒowo, xeviwo, kple nudzodzoe vovovo siwo ƒo xlã míaƒe aƒea doa dzidzɔ nam ale gbegbe.
The beautiful flowers, birds, and insects around my home fascinated me.
Mesusunɛ be ame aɖe si si nunya le wu amegbetɔwoe anya wɔ nu siawo.
I felt that they were products of superhuman wisdom.
Esia fia be èxɔe se be Wɔla aɖe li tso ɖevime kea?
So you always believed in a Creator?
Kura o.
No.
Mekea ɖi tso nye ɖevime ke nenye be Mawu aɖe li.
In fact, my doubts about God began when I was a child.
Dzidɔ wu fofonye kpata, eye mebia ɖokuinye be, ‘Nu ka tae Wɔla aɖe si wɔ nu nyui siawo aɖe mɔ ɖe fukpekpe kple ku ŋu?’
My father suddenly died of a heart attack, and I wondered, ‘Why would the Creator of so much beauty allow suffering and death?’
Ke ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si nèsrɔ̃ kpe ɖe ŋuwò nèkpɔ ŋuɖoɖoa?
Did your study of science help you to find an answer?
Nyemekpɔ ŋuɖoɖoa enumake o.
Not at first.
Mesrɔ̃ nu tso lãmenugbagbeviwo ƒe kuku ŋu tso esiwo le dɔ dzi le míaƒe lãme la ƒe kuku kple wo ɖokui ɖɔliɖɔli ŋu.
When I became a molecular biologist, I began to study death the normal, programmed death of the cells that make up our body.
Esia to vovo na esiwo kuna le esi womekpɔ nunyiame nyuitɔ o, si wɔnɛ be míedzea dɔ ɣeaɖewoɣi la.
This is very different from the uncontrolled cell death that causes inflammation and gangrene.
Ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo metsɔa ɖeke le nu sia si dzɔna la me boo o, togbɔ be ele vevie na míaƒe lãmesẽ hã.
Until a few years ago, scientists paid little attention to this process, even though it is vital to our health.
Mɔ ka nue lãmenugbagbevi siwo le dɔ dzi le míaƒe lãme ƒe kuku ɖea vi le?
In what way is programmed cell death vital?
Lãmenugbagbevi suesue siwo ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o miliɔn teƒe miliɔn geɖe ye le míaƒe lãme.
Well, our body is made up of trillions of microscopic cells.
Le ɖoɖoa nu la, ele be esiawo katã naku eye bubuwo naxɔ ɖe wo teƒe.
Practically all of them must die and be replaced.
Lãmenugbagbevi siawo ƒe agbenɔƒewo le vovovo; ɖewo ɖɔlina le kwasiɖa ʋɛ aɖewo megbe eye bubuwo nɔa anyi ƒe ʋɛ aɖewo hafi kuna.
Each type of cell has a different life span; some are replaced every few weeks, and others every few years.
Woƒe kuku kple wo ɖokui ɖɔliɖɔli zɔna ɖe ɖoɖo nyui aɖe ŋutɔ nu ale be wòagagblẽ naneke le mía ŋu o.
Our body’s system of programmed cell death has to be highly controlled to maintain the delicate balance between cell death and cell formation.
Ke nu kae ate ŋu agblẽ nu le mía ŋu?
What can go wrong?
Numekuku aɖewo ɖee fia be, ne ele be lãmenugbagbevi aɖe naku gake meku o la, ate ŋu ahe ƒunukpeƒetetedɔ kple kansa avɛ.
Some studies indicate that when cells fail to die as they should, rheumatoid arthritis or cancer may result.
Azɔ hã, ne lãmenugbagbevi aɖe ku do ŋgɔ la, ate ŋu ahe lãmetutudɔ kple tsitsimedɔléle si gblẽa nu le ame ƒe susu ŋu avɛ.
On the other hand, when cells die before they should, it could cause Parkinson’s disease or Alzheimer’s disease.
Nye numekukua ƒe akpa aɖee nye be madi ale si woada dɔ siawoe.
My research is linked to finding ways to treat these diseases.
Vi kae nusɔsrɔ̃ tso ale si lãmenugbagbeviwo kuna ŋu ɖe na wò?
How did your study of cell death affect you?
Le nyateƒe me la, ewɔ nuku nam.
Frankly, it puzzled me.
Mekpɔe be ame aɖe si di be míanɔ lãmesẽ me kokokoe anya wɔ ɖoɖo nyui sia.
This marvelous process was clearly designed by someone who wants us to be healthy.
Eya ta megabiaa ɖokuinye kokoko be, Nu ka tae amegbetɔwo kpea fu hekuna?
So I was still left with the question, Why do people suffer and die?
Nyemekpɔ ŋuɖoɖoa o.
I couldn’t find an answer.
Gake èva ka ɖe edzi be ame aɖee wɔ ɖoɖo be lãmenugbagbeviwo nanɔ wo nɔewo ɖɔlim ya.
But you were convinced that the system of programmed cell death was designed.
Yes.
Ðoɖo bliboa gɔmesese mele bɔbɔe kura o, gake ale si lãmenu siawo wɔa dɔ le ɖoɖo nyui nu la ɖe nunya gã aɖe fia.
The complexity of the whole process is mind-boggling, yet its elegance displays exceptional wisdom.
Meka ɖe edzi be Mawu ƒe nunyae.
I believe it’s the wisdom of God.
Mezã nusuekpɔmɔ̃ be matsɔ ase ɖoɖo vovovo siwo nana lãmenugbagbevi siawo nɔa dɔ dzi la gɔme.
I use powerful microscopes to study the many complex mechanisms that regulate the process.
Ðoɖo siawo dometɔ aɖewo tea ŋu ɖɔa nu ɖo le aɖabaƒoƒo ʋɛ aɖewo ko me ne ehiã.
Some mechanisms can trigger the destruction process within seconds if need be.
Lãmenugbagbevi siawo ŋutɔe ɖea esiwo gblẽ la ɖa.
The cells participate in their own self-destruction.
Wowɔ ɖoɖoa wòde ŋgɔ ale gbegbe be nu bliboa wɔ nuku ŋutɔ.
The process is so well-designed that it’s absolutely awe-inspiring.
Esi míaƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo katã ɖɔa li wo nɔewo ɖe ɖoɖo nyui aɖe nu ta la, anya wɔ be míanɔ agbe tegbee
Since nearly all our cells are regularly replaced, living forever is certainly feasible
Nyabiase aɖewo nɔ asiwò ku ɖe nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ ɖe fukpekpe ŋu.
You had questions about God and suffering.
Aleke nèwɔ kpɔ ŋuɖoɖoawo?
How did you find answers?
Le ƒe 1991 me la, atsu kple asi aɖe siwo nye Yehowa Ðasefowo va nye aƒe me, eye mebia be woaɖe nu si tae míekuna me nam.
A couple of Jehovah’s Witnesses called at my home in 1991, and I asked them why we die.
Wotsɔ ale si Biblia ɖo nya sia ŋui la fiam: "To ame ɖeka dzi nu vɔ̃ ge ɖe xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va. "
They showed me the Bible’s answer: "Through one man sin entered into the world and death through sin. "
(Romatɔwo 5:12) Ne ɖe ame gbãtɔ ɖo to Mawu la, anye ne anɔ agbe tegbee.
(Romans 5:12) If the first man had not disobeyed God, he would have lived forever.
Enumake mede dzesii be esia wɔ ɖeka kple nu siwo ŋu meke ɖo le nye numekukuwo me.
I immediately realized that this harmonized with what I had learned from my research.
Eme va kɔ nam azɔ be Mawu mewɔ mí be míaku hafi o.
In fact, it’s clear to me that God didn’t intend for people to die.
Esi míaƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo katã ɖɔa li wo nɔewo ɖe ɖoɖo nyui aɖe nu ta la, anya wɔ be míanɔ agbe tegbee.
Since nearly all our cells are regularly replaced, living forever is certainly feasible.
Nu kae na nèva ka ɖe edzi be Mawu ƒe Nyae Biblia la nye?
What convinced you that the Bible is God’s Word?
Meva srɔ̃ nu si Biblia gblɔ tso Mawu ŋu le Psalmo 139:16: ‘Esi menye ʋukɔe la, wò ŋkuwo kpɔm, eye woŋlɔ wo ɖe wò agbalẽ me.’
I learned what the Bible says about God at Psalm 139:16: "Your eyes saw even the embryo of me, and in your book all its parts were down in writing. "
Esi menye lãmetsiŋutinunyala ta la, mesrɔ̃a nu tso ale si míaƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo wɔa dɔe ŋu.
As a biochemist, I study the genetic information that is written in our cells.
Aleke ame si ŋlɔ Psalmowo wɔ nya esia?
How did the psalmist know about such writing?
Zi ale si meyi Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ dzi la, zi nenemae meva ka ɖe edzi be Mawue na woŋlɔ Biblia.
The more I learned from the Bible, the more I was convinced that it is inspired of God.
Aleke wokpe ɖe ŋuwò nèva se Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo gɔmee?
How were you helped to understand what the Bible teaches?
Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe srɔ̃ Biblia kplim.
One of Jehovah’s Witnesses offered to study the Bible with me.
Meva se nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ amegbetɔwo kpea fu ɖo la gɔme.
Finally, I learned why God has allowed suffering.
Meva srɔ̃e, abe ale si Biblia ŋutɔ gblɔe ene, be Mawu do ŋugbe be ‘yeami ku saɖagatsi tegbee.’
I also learned that, as the Bible states, God purposes to "swallow up death forever. "
(Yesaya 25:8) Ele bɔbɔe na mía Wɔla la be wòatrɔ asi le míaƒe ameti wɔnukua ŋu be wòayi edzi anɔ dɔ wɔm le ɖoɖo deblibo nu ale be míase vivi na agbe si nuwuwu manɔe na o.
(Isaiah 25:8) It will be easy for our Creator to make the marvelous systems of our body operate perfectly so that we can enjoy life without end.
Aleke nèzã Biblia me nunya si su asiwò la tsɔ kpe ɖe amewo ŋui?
How have you used your knowledge of the Bible to help others?
Meva zu Yehowa Ðasefo le ƒe 1995 me, eye tso ɣemaɣi la, meƒoa nu tso nu siwo mesrɔ̃ le Biblia me ŋu na amewo.
Well, I became one of Jehovah’s Witnesses in 1995, and since then I have freely shared with others the things I’ve learned from the Bible.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nye dɔwɔhati aɖe ƒe dzi gbã vevie esime nɔviaŋutsu wu eɖokui.
For example, a colleague of mine was devastated when her brother committed suicide.
Sɔleme si wòdena fiaa nu be Mawu matsɔ ame siwo wu wo ɖokui la ƒe nu vɔ̃ ake wo gbeɖe o.
Her church teaches that God never forgives suicide.
Gake metsɔ ale si Biblia ƒo nu tso tsitretsitsi mɔkpɔkpɔa ŋu la fiae.
But I showed her how the Bible gives a hope of a resurrection.
(Yohanes 5:28, 29) Eƒe dzi dze eme ŋutɔ esi wòva kpɔe be Wɔla la tsɔa ɖe le eme na mí.
(John 5:28, 29) She was deeply comforted to learn that the Creator cares for us.
Le nɔnɔme siawo tɔgbi me la, mekpɔnɛ be Biblia me nyawo gbɔgblɔ na amewo nana mekpɔa dzidzɔ wu nu si dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si menya ate ŋu awɔ nam!
At such moments, I feel that sharing Bible truths with others brings me more satisfaction than science itself!
Lãmetsiŋutinunyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Biochemist Explains His Faith
Ðɔkta Davey Loos nye lãmetsiŋutinunyala le Belgium.
Dr. Davey Loos is a biochemist in Belgium.
Ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, mexɔe se be Wɔla aɖe li o, ke boŋ exɔe se be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si.
At one time, he doubted the existence of a Creator, believing instead in evolution.
Gake eva trɔ susu emegbe.
Later, he changed his mind.
Nu kae na ɖɔkta sia gbugbɔ ŋku lé ɖe eƒe dzixɔse ku ɖe ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ la ŋu?
What caused a researcher to reconsider his beliefs about the origin of life?
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso eƒe xɔse kpakple eƒe dɔa ŋu.
Awake! asked Dr. Loos about his science and his faith.
Aleke nèwɔ va zu dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala?
How did you become involved in scientific research?
Esi menɔ yunivɛsiti la, mesrɔ̃ lãmetsiŋutinunya.
When I attended university, I chose to study chemistry.
Nu siwo wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye vevie nye protein kple nucleic acid siwo de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu molecule ɖe sia ɖe le anyigba dzi.
I was particularly fascinated by proteins and nucleic acids, which are by far the most complex molecules on our planet.
Gake ale si molecule aɖewo wɔa nui ne ɣe klẽ ɖe wo dzi la wɔa nuku nam ŋutɔ.
In time, I became intrigued by the way certain molecules respond to sunlight.
Ðe nèxɔ Mawu dzi se tsãa?
Did you believe in God?
Mexɔ Mawu dzi se esime menɔ ɖevime.
I did when I was a little boy.
Gake esi meva nɔ suku dem le Catholic University le Leuven la, wofiam be dzɔdzɔmenuwoe nɔ tɔtrɔm vivivi va zu nu gbagbewo.
But later, while I was studying at the Catholic University of Leuven, I was taught that living things owe their designs to natural processes.
Ale si nufialagã siawo ɖea dzɔdzɔmenuwo ƒe tɔtrɔ siawo dometɔ aɖewo gɔme la wɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
The professors made some of these processes sound quite complicated.
Esi wònye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala kpɔnuteƒewoe wonye ta la, mexɔ woƒe nyawo dzi se.
They were experienced scientists, so I believed what they said.
Mlɔeba la, eva sesẽ nam be maxɔe ase be Mawu li.
Eventually, I found it difficult to accept the existence of God.
Nu kae na nègbugbɔ ŋku lé ɖe nu gbagbewo ƒe dzɔtsoƒe ŋu?
What made you reconsider the origin of life?
Le ƒe 1999 me la, medo go xɔ̃nye aɖe si nye kplii míede suku si va zu Yehowa Ðasefo, eye mede woƒe kpekpeawo dometɔ ɖeka.
In 1999, I met a friend from my school days who had become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, and I attended one of their meetings.
Ɣemaɣi la, Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe va mía ƒe me eye wòna agbalẽ si nye Is There a Creator Who Cares About You? (Y a-t-il un Créateur qui se soucie de vous?) ɖekam.
Also about that time, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses visited our house and left a copy of the book Is There a Creator Who Cares About You?
Nu kae nèsusu tso agbalẽa ŋu?
What did you think about the book?
Ale si woku nu me memie hafi tae la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye.
I was impressed by the quality of the research that it presented.
Esia na meva nɔ eŋu bum nenye be nu siwo le xexea me la woate ŋu adzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si vavã.
I began to wonder if evolution really did explain the designs seen in nature.
Nuwɔwɔ siwo le xexea me la dometɔ kae wɔ nuku na wò wu?
What designs in nature impressed you?

Esi menye lãmetsiŋutinunyala ta la, mesrɔ̃ nu tso molecule siwo le cyanobacteria siwo le atsiaƒu me la ŋu, siwo nye nugbagbevi suesuesue siwo wɔa woawo ŋutɔwo ƒe nuɖuɖuwo eye womekpɔa woƒe nuɖuɖu tso nu gbagbe bubu aɖeke gbɔ o.
My work as a biochemist involved studying the design of certain molecules found in ocean-dwelling cyanobacteria, which are microorganisms that don’t depend on other living things for food.
Numekula aɖewo susui be nugbagbevi suesuesue siawoe nye nu gbagbe gbãtɔ siwo nɔ anyigba dzi.
Some researchers think that these organisms were the first living things on our planet.
Wowɔa ŋusẽ si tso ɣe ƒe dzoxɔxɔ gbɔ ŋu dɔ tsɔ trɔa tsi kple ya si woyɔna be carbon dioxide wozua nuɖuɖu na wo, eye ale si wowɔa nu siae la gɔme sese sesẽ ŋutɔ.
Using energy from sunlight, the microbes use an extremely complex chemical process, which is still not fully understood, to convert water and carbon dioxide into food.
Ale si cyanobacteria tea ŋu wɔna kpɔa ɣe ƒe keklẽ si dena nɛ la hã wɔa nuku nam ŋutɔ.
I was also amazed at how cyanobacteria can harvest light with incredible efficiency.
Aŋgbawo hã trɔa ɣe ƒe kekeli wòzua nuɖuɖu na wo.
Leaves also use sunlight to make food.
Eya ta mɔ ka nue nugbagbevi sia tɔ ɖe dzesi le?
So, what is remarkable about those bacteria?
Ɣe ƒe keklẽ vi aɖe koe tea ŋu ɖoa atsiaƒu gɔme.
The deeper you go in the sea, the less light you find.
Eya ta ele na nugbagbevi si nye cyanobacteria, si nɔa atsiaƒu gɔme la be wòalé ɣe ƒe keklẽ sue ɖe sia ɖe si wòkpɔ la ɖi eye wòzãa ŋusẽxɔti deŋgɔ aɖe tsɔ wɔa esia.
So the cyanobacteria that live there must capture every scrap of light energy that comes their way, and they do this by means of highly sophisticated antennae.
Etrɔa ŋusẽ si wòlé ɖi la katã kloe wòzua nuɖuɖu.
The collected energy is transmitted to food-producing centers with nearly 100 percent efficiency.
Ale si nugbagbevi sia tea ŋu léa ɣe ƒe keklẽ ɖi la wɔa nuku na ame siwo wɔa elektrik-namɔ̃ siwo zãa ɣe ƒe keklẽ ale gbegbe be wova tsɔ ɖe le eme vevie.
The design of this light-harvesting machinery has even attracted the interest of solar-panel manufacturers.
Ke hã, ale si nugbagbevi sia wɔna léa ɣe ƒe keklẽ ɖi la de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu elektrik-namɔ̃ siwo zãa ɣe ƒe keklẽ.
Of course, manufactured solar cells are nowhere near as efficient as the systems found in bacteria.
Nya ta kae esia na nèƒo?
What did that cause you to conclude?
Mede ŋugble tso mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla siwo dze agbagba srɔ̃ nu wɔnuku siwo yia edzi le nu gbagbewo me la ŋu eye meƒo nya ta be Mawu kokokoe wɔ nu gbagbewo
I thought about engineers trying to imitate the marvelous mechanisms found in living things, and I came to the conclusion that life must have been designed by God
Mede ŋugble tso mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla siwo dze agbagba srɔ̃ nu wɔnuku siwo yia edzi le nu gbagbewo me la ŋu eye meƒo nya ta be Mawu kokokoe wɔ nu gbagbewo.
I thought about engineers trying to imitate the marvelous mechanisms found in living things, and I came to the conclusion that life must have been designed by God.
Gake menye nu siwo mesrɔ̃ le dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya me koe na meva xɔe se be Mawu li o.
But my faith was not based solely on what I studied in science.
Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ veviedodotɔe hã kpe ɖe ŋunye.
It was also based on a careful study of the Bible.
Nu kae na nèka ɖe edzi be Mawu gbɔe Biblia tso?
What convinced you that the Bible is from God?
Nu siwo na meka ɖe edzi la dometɔ ɖekae nye ale si Biblia me nyagblɔɖiwo vaa eme pɛpɛpɛ.
One of the many things that convinced me was the detailed fulfillment of Bible prophecies.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesaya gblɔ Yesu ƒe ku kple eɖiɖi ŋu nya ɖi tsitotsito ƒe alafa geɖe do ŋgɔ.
For example, centuries in advance Isaiah described in abundant detail the death and burial of Jesus.
Míenya be woŋlɔ nyagblɔɖi sia ɖi hafi wova dzi Yesu, elabena wogbugbɔ ŋlɔ Yesaya ƒe Agbalẽ xatsaxatsa si wofɔ le Qumran la anɔ abe ƒe alafa ɖeka ene do ŋgɔ na Yesu dzidzi.
We know this prophecy was written before Jesus’ death because the Isaiah Scroll, found at Qumran, was copied about a hundred years before Jesus was born.
Nyagblɔɖi ma gblɔ be: "Woɖe yɔdo nɛ ɖe ame vɔ̃ɖiwo dome eye le eƒe ku me wòmlɔ kesinɔtɔwo dome. "
That prophecy says: "He will make his burial place even with the wicked ones, and with the rich class in his death. "
(Yesaya 53:9, 12, Agbenya La) Nukutɔe la, wowu Yesu abe ame vɔ̃ɖi ene, gake woɖii ɖe kesinɔtɔwo ƒe ƒome aɖe ƒe yɔdo me.
(Isaiah 53:9, 12) Remarkably, Jesus was executed with criminals but was buried in the tomb of a wealthy family.
Esia nye nyagblɔɖi gbogbo siwo va eme, siwo na meka ɖe edzi be Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔe ʋã amewo woŋlɔ Biblia la dometɔ ɖeka ko.
This is just one example of the many fulfilled prophecies that convinced me that the Bible is inspired of God.
(2 Timoteo 3:16) Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, meva zu Yehowa Ðasefo.
(2 Timothy 3:16) In time, I became one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Nu ka tae wònye dzidzɔ na wò be yenye Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why do you enjoy being one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Xɔse si le mía si menye esi ŋea aɖaba ƒua nu siwo dzi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ɖo kpee la dzi o
Our faith is not blind faith that ignores the facts of science
Xɔse si le mía si menye esi ŋea aɖaba ƒua nu siwo dzi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ɖo kpee la dzi o.
Our faith is not blind faith that ignores the facts of science.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo ko dzie míezɔna ɖo.
Also, the principles that guide us are firmly based on the Bible.
Esi menye Yehowa Ðasefo ta la, edzɔa dzi nam be magblɔ Biblia me gbedeasi fakɔnamewo na amewo ahakpe ɖe wo ŋu woakpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na woƒe nyabiasewo.
As one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I enjoy sharing the Bible’s comforting message with others and helping them to find answers to their questions.
Akɔntanyala Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Mathematician Explains His Faith
Wodzi nufialagã Gene Hwang le ƒe 1950 me le Tainan, Taiwan, eye wònye nufialagã si fia akɔnta le yunivɛsiti aɖe le Taiwan kpɔ.
Dr. Gene Hwang, born in 1950 in Tainan, Taiwan, is a retired professor of mathematics at the National Chung Cheng University in Taiwan.
Efia akɔnta kple ale si woawɔ numekuku tso nuwo ŋu le Amerika yunivɛsiti aɖe hã kpɔ.
He is also professor emeritus at Cornell University, U.S.A., where he taught and did research in statistics and probability.
Hena ƒe geɖe la, eƒe agbalẽ siwo wòŋlɔ tso akɔntabubuwo ŋu la le esiwo amewo zãna wu la dome, eye egakpɔtɔ le akɔnta fiam.
For years he was one of the most published authorities on statistics, a field in which he is still involved.
Esi wònye sɔhɛ la, exɔe se be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie agbe to va dzɔ.
As a young man, he believed that life began by evolutionary processes.
Gake eva trɔ susu emegbe.
But he later changed his view.
Nyɔ! talawo bia gbee tso eƒe dɔwo kple dzixɔsewo ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his work and religious beliefs.
Nu kawoe wofia wò le ɖevime?
What teachings were you exposed to as a youth?
Wofiaa nu le suku si mede la be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie agbe to va dzɔ, gake ame aɖeke mete ŋu ɖe ale si agbea wɔ hafi dze egɔme me o.
My school taught the theory of evolution, but no one explained how life itself began.
Esi dzinyelawo va zu Tao subɔsubɔha me tɔwo la, meva nɔ to ɖom woƒe subɔsubɔhakplɔlawo ƒe nufiafiawo eye mebiaa nya geɖe wo.
When my parents became Taoists, I used to listen to their religious instructors and ask them a lot of questions.
Gake nye biabia ʋɛ aɖewo ŋu koe wote ŋu ɖo nam nyuie.
But I received few answers that satisfied me.
Aleke wòdzɔe be nèva zu akɔntanyala?
Why did you become a mathematician?
Esime menɔ gɔmedzesuku la, akɔntasɔsrɔ̃ doa dzidzɔ nam.
When I was in elementary school, I became fascinated with mathematics.
Esi meyi yunivɛsiti la, meyi akɔntasɔsrɔ̃ kple ale si woawɔ numekuku tso nuwo ŋu si doa dzidzɔ nam la dzi.
This fascination continued when I went to university, where I especially enjoyed courses in mathematics and probability.
Le gonyeme la, akɔnta si wobu wòkpɔ kuxi aɖe gbɔ la doa dzidzɔ nam.
To me, a concise mathematical proof can be both beautiful and elegant.
Aleke wòdzɔe be nèva tsɔ ɖe le Biblia me nyawo me?
How did you become interested in the Bible?
Le ƒe 1978 me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo va te Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ kple srɔ̃nye Jinghuei, eye ɣeaɖewoɣi la mekpɔa gome le nusɔsrɔ̃a me.
In 1978 my wife, Jinghuei, began studying the Bible with Jehovah’s Witnesses, and occasionally I shared in the discussions.
Míenɔ Amerika ɣemaɣi.
By then, we were living in the United States.
Srɔ̃nye Jinghuei wu yunivɛsiti nu eye wòzu dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽwo ŋuti nunyalagã eye nye hã menɔ akɔntabubu srɔ̃m le yunivɛsiti aɖe le Indiana, Amerika.
Jinghuei had just received her doctorate in physics, and I was studying statistics at Purdue University in Indiana.
Aleke nèbua Bibliae?
What did you think of the Bible?
Nya si Biblia gblɔ tso ale si wotrɔ asi le anyigbaa ŋu be agbe nanya nɔ le edzi la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye.
I was impressed by its account of how the earth was prepared for human life.
Togbɔ be ŋkeke ade siwo Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ gblɔ be wotsɔ wɔ nuwoe dze nu bɔbɔe hã la, susu le eme eye mele abe ale si blemaxotutuwo gblɔe ene o.
The six creative periods described in Genesis, albeit in simple language, seemed to fit the facts​ unlike ancient mythologies.
Togbɔ be ele alea hã la, hena ƒe geɖe la, nyemexɔe se be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo o.
Still, for many years I did not commit to belief in a Creator.
Nu ka tae wòsesẽ be nàxɔe ase be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo?
Why was that an issue for you?
Ne mexɔe se be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo katã la, efia be megbe nu le nu si wofiam tso ɖevime gbɔ
Believing in a Creator meant rejecting my childhood religion
Ema bia be mawɔ nyametsotso sesẽ aɖe.
My feelings were involved.
Ne mexɔe se be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo katã la, efia be megbe nu le nu si wofiam tso ɖevime gbɔ, elabena Tao subɔsubɔha si me menɔ fiaa nu be Mawu ɖeka si nye Wɔla si wɔ nuwo katã aɖeke meli o.
Believing in a Creator meant rejecting my childhood religion, because traditional Taoism does not teach that there is a personal God, or Creator.
Gake èva trɔ susu emegbe.
Later, though, your viewpoint changed.
Nu kae gbɔe wòtso?
Why was that?
Zi ale si meyi edzi le ŋugble dem tso ale si agbe dze egɔmee ŋu la, zi nenemae meva ka ɖe edzi be nu gbagbe gbãtɔ anya wɔ nuku ŋutɔ.
The more I thought about the origin of life, the more I became convinced that the first living thing must have been very complex.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, enye nu sesẽ be nu gbagbe nadzi etɔgbi, eye hafi esia nadzɔ la ele be wòanɔ te ɖe nyatakaka siwo le eme siwo ŋu dɔ wòawɔ la dzi, eye ele be ɖoɖo aɖe hã nanɔ anyi si dzi wòazɔ ɖo adzi etɔgbia pɛpɛpɛ.
For example, it had to be able to reproduce, which requires genetic information and a mechanism for accurately replicating that information.
Azɔ hã, nu gbagbevi suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã hiã nu siwo awɔ dɔ le eme abe mɔ̃ ene hafi wòate ŋu awɔ lãmenugbagbevi yeye ƒe akpa vovovoawo, eye ele be ŋutete nanɔ eŋu be wòate ŋu afia mɔ dɔ siwo wòawɔ.
Also, even the simplest living cell needs molecular machines for building all the parts of a new cell, as well as the means to harness and direct energy.
Aleke lãmenugbagbevi ƒe dɔwɔwɔ si wɔ nuku alea la awɔ adzɔ le eɖokui si ne menye ame aɖekee wɔe o?
How could such complex mechanisms assemble randomly from nonliving matter?
Abe akɔntanyala ene la, mekpɔe be Wɔla aɖee wɔ nuwo.
As a mathematician, I could not accept that assumption.
Elabena nu wɔnuku sia ƒe dɔwɔwɔ mate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si o.
It asks far too much of random processes.
Nu kae ʋã wò be nèva dzro Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nufiafiawo me nyuie?
What was it that moved you to examine more closely the teachings of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Ɣeaɖewoɣi mesrɔ̃a nu kple Yehowa Ðasefoawo gadzudzɔna.
I had studied with the Witnesses on and off.
Ke le ƒe 1995 me la, mezɔ mɔ yi Taiwan, eye le afi ma la, medze dɔ vevie.
Then, in 1995, while visiting Taiwan, I fell sick and needed help.
Srɔ̃nye si le Amerika la ƒo ka na Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le Taiwan be woakpe ɖe ŋunye.
From the United States, my wife contacted Jehovah’s Witnesses in Taiwan.
Hafi woava ke ɖe ŋunye la menɔ kɔ aɖe dzi gake esi dɔnɔwo yɔ abatiawo katã dzi ta la, womekpɔ teƒe nam o; nu te ŋunye ŋutɔ.
They found me exhausted outside a hospital where there were no available beds.
Ðasefoawo dometɔ ɖeka kplɔm yi amedzrodzeƒe be maɖi ɖe eme.
One of the Witnesses took me to a hotel to rest.
Sẽ kple sẽ ko eva kpɔm ɖa, emegbe ekplɔm yi kɔ bubu aɖe dzi be woakpɔ gbɔnye.
He kept checking on me and then took me to a clinic for treatment.
Ale si wokpe ɖe ŋunye lɔlɔ̃tɔe la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ, esia na mede ŋugble tso ale si Yehowa Ðasefowo nyo dɔme na nye ƒomea zi geɖe le mɔ vovovowo nu va yi la ŋu.
That genuine concern deeply touched me, and I reflected on how often Jehovah’s Witnesses had shown kindness to my family on other occasions.
Ðasefoawo ƒe xɔse na woto vovo.
The Witnesses’ faith made them different.
Eya ta mena wogadze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ gɔme kplim.
So I resumed my study of the Bible with them.
Le ƒe si kplɔe ɖo me la, wonyrɔm ɖe tsi me.
The following year I was baptized.
Ðe nu siwo ŋu nèkena ɖo le sukunusɔsrɔ̃a me la tsi tsitre ɖe wò xɔse yeyea ŋua?
Does your faith conflict with your secular studies?
Kura o!
Not at all!
Le ƒe ʋɛ siwo va yi me la, mewɔ akɔntabubu aɖewo tsɔ kpe ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala siwo srɔ̃a nu tso ale si DNA wɔa dɔe ŋu la ŋu.
In recent years I have provided mathematical support for scientists who study gene function.
Ale si DNA wɔa nyatakaka siwo le eme la ŋu dɔe kpe ɖe mía ŋu míegava se nu geɖe gɔme tso agbe ŋu gɔmesese sia na Wɔlaa ƒe nunya wɔa nuku nam.
The study of genetics provides insight into the mechanisms of life​ an insight that fills me with awe for the Creator’s wisdom.
Àte ŋu aƒo nu tso nunya ma ƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖe ŋu na mía?
Give an example of that wisdom.
Na míade ŋugble tso ale si nu gbagbewo dzinae ŋu kpɔ.
Consider reproduction.
Menye atsu kple nɔ ƒe gododo dzie nugbagbevi aɖewo abe amoeba ene tona hafi dzina o.
Some organisms, such as amoebas, don’t have male and female counterparts.
Ne nugbagbevi sia di be yeadzi bubu la, ɖeko wòmana, eye wòwɔa nyatakaka siwo le eƒe DNA me la ƒe kɔpi ɖe esi dzim wòle la me.
These single-cell microbes simply make a copy of their genetic information and divide​ a process called asexual reproduction.
Gake le lãwo kple ati geɖe gome la, atsu kple nɔ ye doa go hafi wodzia bubu, eye esia wɔnɛ be nu si wodzina la nyia nɔnɔme aɖewo dome tsoa edzila eveawo gbɔ.
Most animals and plants, however, reproduce sexually, combining genetic information from male and female parents.
Nu ka tae nu gbagbe siwo nye atsu kple nɔ ƒe gododo hafi adzi la wɔ nuku?
Why is sexual reproduction remarkable?

Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzixɔselawo fiaa nu be nu gbagbe ƒe mama dzie nugbagbeviwo tona dzina hena ƒe gbogbo aɖe si ame aɖeke menya o, emegbe nu gbagbe siwo nye atsu kple nɔ ƒe gododo adzi bubu va dzɔ tso esia me, ɖe susu le numeɖeɖe sia mea?
Why would a system of reproduction in which one organism simply divides into two​ and has done this very well for who knows how long ​develop into a system in which two things combine to form one?

Elabena le atsu kple nɔ ƒe gododo hafi adzi ya gome la, ebia be atsu kple nɔ siwo le go dom la naɖo nyatakaka siwo le woƒe DNA me la ɖa sɔsɔe woava do go wo nɔewo azu nu ɖeka, eye ale si esia dzɔnae me ɖeɖe zua taɖui na dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala siwo xɔ nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzi se.
The mechanisms required to take half the genetic information from the male and half from the female and combine them are immensely complex, presenting a huge problem to evolutionary biologists.
Le nye susu nu la, ɖikeke aɖeke mele eme o be ale si nu gbagbe siwo nye atsu kple nɔ doa go hafi dzina la nye Mawu ƒe nunya si wɔ nuku.
In my view, gender-based reproduction points unequivocally to the mind of God.
Saŋkuƒola Aɖe Ƒe Xɔse
A Classical Pianist Explains His Faith
Eldar Nebolsin si tso Uzbekistan nye saŋkuƒola si ƒe ŋkɔ de du ŋutɔ.
Eldar Nebolsin of Uzbekistan is an internationally acclaimed pianist.
Eƒo saŋku le London, Moscow, St. Petersburg, New York, Paris, Rome, Sydney, Tokyo kple Vienna, eye eya ɖeka ƒoa saŋku le haƒohawo ŋgɔ.
He has played as a soloist with orchestras in London, Moscow, St. Petersburg, New York, Paris, Rome, Sydney, Tokyo, and Vienna.
Soviet Union ye Eldar tsi le eye wònye mawudzimaxɔsela.
Eldar grew up in the Soviet Union as an atheist.
Gake eva ƒo nya ta emegbe be Wɔla lɔ̃ame aɖee wɔ amegbetɔwo.
But later he concluded that humans are the work of a loving Creator.
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso haƒoƒo kple eƒe xɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his music and his faith.
Aleke nèwɔ va zu haƒola?
How did you become a musician?
Dzinyelawo nye saŋkuƒolawo.
My parents are both pianists.
Wote saŋkuƒoƒo fiafiam esime mexɔ ƒe atɔ̃ ko.
They began teaching me when I was five years old.
Emegbe mede hasrɔ̃suku deŋgɔ si le Tashkent.
Later, I studied at the advanced school of music in Tashkent.
Ƒo nu tso kuxi siwo nèdoa goe ne èle saŋku ƒom kple haƒoha ŋu na mí.
Tell us about the challenges of playing with an orchestra.
Haƒoha aɖeke mesɔ kple bubu o.
No two orchestras are alike.
Haƒoha ɖe sia ɖe le ko abe haƒonu gã si "ƒom " haƒoha ƒe ŋgɔnɔla le ene.
They are like giant musical instruments that are "played " by their conductors.
Ðewohĩ nu si koŋ sesẽna na saŋkuƒola ɖekɛ wue nye ale si wòaƒo saŋkua wòawɔ ɖeka kple haƒoha ƒe ŋgɔnɔla ƒe atidada.
Perhaps the main challenge for the soloist is to achieve balanced interaction with the conductor.
Abe ale si xɔlɔ̃wo ɖoa dze ene la, ele be saŋkuƒola kple haƒoha ƒe ŋgɔnɔla nawɔ nu aduadu.
It’s like a conversation between friends rather than one always taking the lead, each should yield to the other.
Zi geɖe la, numetoto ɖeka alo eve koe míetea ŋu wɔna tsɔ srɔ̃na ale si míawɔ nu woasɔ ɖe mía nɔewo tɔ dzi.
Usually, you have only one or two rehearsals in which to develop this rapport.
Ɣeyiɣi didi kae nètsɔ toa saŋkuƒoƒoa me?
How much time do you spend practicing?
Mezãa gaƒoƒo etɔ̃ ya teti, eye menye haa ƒe akpa siwo sesẽ la me koe mezãa ɣeyiɣi sia tsɔ tonae o.
At least three hours a day and that isn’t just to practice difficult passages.
Mesrɔ̃a ɖoɖo si nu woɖo haa ɖo hã evɔ nyemeƒoa haa ŋutɔ le ɣeyiɣi sia me o.
I also study the structure of the piece I’m preparing but without actually playing it.
Nu bubu siwo mewɔna ye nye be meɖoa to hakpala ma ƒe ha bubuwo eye esia wɔnɛ be mesea ha si srɔ̃m mele la gɔme ɖe edzi wu.
Another thing I do is listen to the composer’s other works, which gives me more insight into the present piece.
Nu kae ɖea dzesi le saŋkuƒola bibi ŋu?
What would you say distinguishes a fine pianist?
Eyae nye ale si wòtea ŋu nana saŋku "dzia ha. "
His ability to make a piano "sing. "
Maɖe eme miase.
Let me explain.
Saŋku nye haƒonu si wotsɔa asi ƒona.
The piano is a kind of percussion instrument.
Ne wote asi ɖe saŋku ƒe kpevi dzi la, ɖeko eƒe ɖiɖi yia to; mele abe haƒonu siwo me woɖoa ƒuƒu ɖo alo amegbetɔ ƒe gbe si tea ŋu yia dzi alo nɔa ɖeka ene o.
After a note is struck, the sound can only decrease in volume unlike that of wind instruments or the human voice, which can hold a note or even increase its volume.
Kuxi si dzi wòhiãna be saŋkuƒola naɖue nye ale si wòakpɔ egbɔ be haa ƒe ɖiɖi aɖe nagayi to o.
The challenge for pianists is to overcome the tendency of a note to fade.

Ewɔa esia to eƒe asibidewo kple alɔtsinuwo ʋaʋã to saŋkukpeviwo dzi aɖaŋutɔe me tsɔ kpe ɖe afɔɖoɖo gbeɖiɖitrɔnu ɖusimetɔ dzi le ɣeyiɣi si sɔ me eye esia wɔnɛ be wòléa gbea ƒe ɖiɖi ɖe te eteƒe didina, eye wòtea ŋu trɔa gbeɖiɖi vovovowo.
They do this by subtle movement of their fingers and wrists, along with the complex interaction of the right pedal, which extends the duration of a note and varies its timbre.
Ne saŋkuƒola te ŋu ɖu tu na aɖaŋu siawo siwo sɔsrɔ̃ mele bɔbɔe o nyuie vɔ la, ate ŋu aƒo saŋku wòaɖi abe dze, kpẽ alo haƒoha tɔ ene.
When pianists master these difficult techniques, they can make the piano sound like a flute, a horn, or even an orchestra.
Ate ŋu ana hã be saŋku naɖi abe amegbetɔ ƒe gbe, si nye gbeɖiɖi nyuitɔ kekeake ene.
They can also make it resemble the finest musical instrument of all the human voice.
Edze kɔtɛe be èlɔ̃a haƒoƒo ŋutɔ.
It’s obvious that you have a deep love for music.
Le gonyeme la, mebunɛ be haƒoƒo nye gbegbɔgblɔ si tea ŋu ɖea seselelãme siwo mele bɔbɔe be woagblɔ kple nu o la gblɔna tẽe wu.
For me, music is the language that most directly expresses and evokes feelings that are difficult, if not impossible, to communicate in words.
Nu kae na nèva tsɔ ɖe le mawusubɔsubɔ me?
What aroused your interest in spiritual matters?
Míaƒe aƒe me yɔ fũu kple agbalẽ siwo fofonye tsɔ tso Moscow gbɔe.
Our house was always full of books, which my father brought from Moscow.
Agbalẽ si do dzidzɔ nam wue nye esi me Biblia me ŋutinya siwo ku ɖe amegbetɔ ƒe ŋutinya ƒe gɔmedzedze kple Israel-viwo ƒe ŋutinya ŋu la le.
A book that especially interested me contained Bible stories about the dawn of history and the experiences of the Israelites.
Agbalẽ si hã ŋu meke ɖoe nye Ate Ŋu Anɔ Agbe Tegbee le Paradiso me le Anyigba Dzi, si Yehowa Ðasefowo ta.
Another book I came across was You Can Live Forever in Paradise on Earth, published by Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Ale si woɖe Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo me wo me kɔ nyuie le eme la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
Its clear presentation of Bible teachings fascinated me.
Esi meʋu yi Spain le ƒe 1991 me be maɖasrɔ̃ haƒoƒo la, metsɔ agbalẽ sia ɖe asi eye mexlẽe zi geɖe.
When I moved to Spain in 1991 to study music, I took that book with me and read it several times.
Meva de dzesii be xɔse si ŋu agbalẽ sia ƒo nu tsoe la nye esi ŋu kpeɖodzi le si nɔ te ɖe nuŋububu nyui dzi, ke menye seselelãme dzro aɖe ko o.
I discovered a faith based not merely on emotion but also on sound reasoning and convincing evidence.
Nufiafia si wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye wue nye ŋugbe si Biblia do be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu anɔ agbe tegbee le anyigba dzi.
A teaching that really intrigued me was the Bible’s promise that humans can live forever on earth.
Susu le nya sia me ŋutɔ!
That made so much sense!
Gake va se ɖe ɣemaɣi la, nyemekpɔ do go Yehowa Ðasefo aɖeke o.
I might add that I still had not met Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Ke hã metso nya me be ne medo go wo dometɔ aɖe la, mabia tso esi be wòasrɔ̃ Biblia kplim.
But I resolved that when I did meet them, I would ask for Bible lessons.
Aleke nèwɔ va ke ɖe Ðasefowo ŋu?
How did you meet the Witnesses?
Kwasiɖa ʋɛ aɖewo le nye nyametsotso ma megbe la, medo go ɖetugbui eve aɖewo siwo lé Biblia ɖe asi.
A few days after I made that mental resolution, I saw two ladies, each with a Bible in hand.
Megblɔ le susu me be: ‘Ame siawo ɖi ame siwo ŋu mexlẽ nu tsoe le nye agbalẽa me.
‘They look like the people I’ve read about in my book,’ I thought.
Wonɔ gbeƒã ɖem abe ale si ko Kristotɔ siwo nɔ anyi le Biblia-ŋlɔɣiwo la wɔe ene.’
‘They are preaching just as Christians did in Bible times.’
Eteƒe medidi o, Ðasefo aɖe te Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ kplim.
Soon, I was studying the Bible with a Witness.
Egbea la, nu si doa dzidzɔ nam wue nye be makpe ɖe amewo ŋu woasrɔ̃ ŋu tso mía Wɔla la ŋu.
Today, my greatest joy is helping others to learn about our Creator.
Nu kae na nèva xɔe se be Wɔla aɖe li, evɔ mawudzimaxɔselae nenye tsã?
What convinced you, a former atheist, to believe in a Creator?
Haƒoƒo hã kpe ɖe ŋunye.
Music itself did.
Amegbetɔwo katã kloe kpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe haƒoƒo ŋu, si nye nu si lãwo ya mate ŋu awɔ o.
Almost everybody appreciates music, and in a way that no animal can.
Wotea ŋu ɖea dzidzɔ, kakaɖedzi, tufafa kple seselelãme ƒomevi ɖe sia ɖe kloe fiana le haƒoƒo me.
Music can express joy, confidence, tenderness, and almost every other emotion.
Le dzɔdzɔme nu la, míeʋãna ɖe haƒoƒo ƒe ɖiɖi dzi.
We naturally move to the rhythms in music.
Gake ɖe haƒoƒo hiã kokoko hafi míate ŋu anɔ agbea?
But is music necessary for our survival?
Ðe haƒoƒo wɔa akpa aɖe le nufiafia si nye be "ŋusẽtɔ lae tsia agbe " abe ale si ame siwo fia nu be ɖe nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si la fianɛ ene la mea?
Does it play a role in the "survival of the fittest, " as evolutionists teach?
Gbeɖe!
I think not.
Le nye susu nu la, nunya mele eme be míaƒo nya ta be amegbetɔ ƒe ahɔhɔ̃, si ŋu ŋutete le be wòate ŋu akpa ha alo ase vivi na haƒoƒowo abe Mozart kple Beethoven ƒe haƒoƒo ene la, dzɔ le eɖokui si o.
In my view, it’s unreasonable to conclude that the human brain, with its ability to create and appreciate music like that of Mozart and Beethoven, is the product of evolution.
Numeɖeɖe si me susu le wue nye be Wɔla nyanu lɔ̃ame aɖee wɔ míaƒe ahɔhɔ̃ la.

A far more reasonable explanation is that our brain is the product of a wise and loving Creator. The Bible is like a symphony with an elegant structure, a masterful arrangement, and a moving message for all mankind
Nu kae na nèva xɔe se be Biblia tso Mawu gbɔ?
What led you to believe that the Bible is from God?
Agbalẽ suesuesue 66 ye le Biblia me eye ame 40 ye ŋlɔe eye eŋɔŋlɔ xɔ ƒe 1,600 kple edzivɔwo.
The Bible is a collection of 66 smaller books written over some 1,600 years by about 40 men.
Mebia ɖokuinye be: ‘Ame kae ate ŋu ana woaŋlɔ agbalẽ deŋgɔ sia si me nyawo wɔ ɖeka alea?’
I asked myself, ‘Who could have orchestrated the writing of this unified masterpiece?’
Ŋuɖoɖo si me susu le koe nye be Mawue na woŋlɔe.
The only reasonable answer is God.
Le nye susu nu la, Biblia le ko abe hadzidzi si me nyawo le ɖoɖo nyui aɖe si de ŋgɔ ŋutɔ nu ene, eye gbedeasi siwo le eme la wɔa dɔ ɖe ameƒomevi ɖe sia ɖe dzi.
In my mind, the Bible is like a symphony with an elegant structure, a masterful arrangement, and a moving message for all mankind.
"Mexɔe Se Be Mawue Wɔ Nu Gbagbewo "
"I Am Convinced That Life Was Designed by God "
Brett Schenck nye nutomeŋutinunyala si xɔ dzudzɔ le United States.
Brett Schenck is a retired environmental consultant in the United States.
Esrɔ̃ nu tso ale si atiwo, lãwo kple nutoa me hiãa wo nɔewoe la ŋu.
He studied the interdependency of plants, animals, and the environment.
Nu ka tae wòxɔe se be Wɔla aɖe li?
Why does he believe in a Creator?
Nyɔ! magazinea talawo bia gbee tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya kple eƒe dzixɔse ŋu.
Awake! asked him about his science and his faith.
Ƒo nu tso ɖokuiwò ŋu na mí.
What is your background?
Fofonye nye mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla.
My father was a mechanical engineer.
Eɖoa dze nam tso akɔntabubu kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu vividoɖenuŋutɔe.
He often talked enthusiastically to me about math and science.

Esi menɔ ɖevime la, mekpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe nu miemiewo, lãwo, tɔsisiwo kple ta siwo le míaƒe nutoa me le New Paris, Ohio, le United States la ŋu. Eya ta esi meyi Purdue Yunivɛsiti la, metiae be masrɔ̃ nu tso kadodo si nɔa nu gbagbewo kple nutoa me dome la ŋu.
As a boy, I was fascinated by the plants and animals in the creeks and pools near my home in New Paris, Ohio, U.S.A. So when I went to Purdue University, I chose to study ecology.
Ðe nèlɔ̃a mawusubɔsubɔa?
Did religion interest you?
Yes, it did.
Papa dea dzi ƒo nam be masrɔ̃ nu tso míaƒe Luther subɔsubɔha ŋu.
Dad encouraged me to study our Lutheran religion.
Mesrɔ̃ Koine (Helagbe si wodona wu), si nye gbegbɔgblɔ siwo me woɖe Biblia gɔme ɖo zi gbãtɔ la dometɔ ɖeka.
I studied Koine (common) Greek, one of the languages in which the Bible was first written.
Esia wɔe be meva dea asixɔxɔ gã aɖe Biblia ŋu.
I developed deep respect for the Bible.
Aleke nèbua nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si lae?
How did you view the theory of evolution?
Míaƒe sɔlemeha la da asi ɖe edzi.
My church accepted it.
Nye dɔwɔhatiwo hã xɔe se.
My colleagues believed it.
Eya ta nyemeke ɖii kpɔ o.
So I never questioned it.
Gake megaxɔ Mawu hã dzi se.
But I also believed in God.
Ewɔna nam be dzixɔse eve siawo wɔ ɖeka.
I had a foggy notion that the two beliefs were compatible.
Togbɔ be medea asixɔxɔ Biblia ŋu hã la, nyemebunɛ be Mawu gbɔe wòtso o.
Although I respected the Bible, I didn’t think it came from God.
Nu kae na ale si nèbua Bibliae la va trɔ?
What made you change your view of the Bible?
Yehowa Ðasefo eve siwo ŋkɔwoe nye Steve kple Sandy va srã nye kple srɔ̃nye Debbie kpɔ.
Two of Jehovah’s Witnesses, Steve and Sandy, visited my wife, Debbie, and me.
Wona míede dzesii be togbɔ be Biblia menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽ o hã la, emenyawo wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya.
They showed us that the Bible, though not a science textbook, is scientifically accurate.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, egblɔ le Mawu ŋu be: "Eya, ame si le xexea me godoo tame. "
For example, it says of God: "There is One who is dwelling above the circle of the earth. "
(Yesaya 40:22) Egblɔ hã be: "Meku anyigba ɖe naneke ŋu o. "
(Isaiah 40:22) It also says: "He is . . . hanging the earth upon nothing. "
(Hiob 26:7) Ɣemaɣi la, mezãa foto siwo wotsɔ yamenutomeɖemɔ̃ ɖe tsɔ srɔ̃a nu tso kadodo si nɔa nu gbagbewo kple nutoa me dome ŋu, eya ta mawunyakpukpui siawo wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
(Job 26:7) At that time, I was using satellite photographs to study ecology, so these scriptures impressed me.
Woŋlɔ nya siawo ɖi gbe aɖe gbe ʋĩ ke hafi amewo va ɖe fotowo hekpɔe be anyigba la le nogoo eye womekui ɖe naneke ŋu o.
They were written long before anyone photographed the circle of the earth hanging on nothing.
Esi Steve kple Sandy nɔ Biblia srɔ̃m kpli mí la, míesrɔ̃ nu tso Biblia me nyagblɔɖi siwo va eme kple Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo ɖea vi ŋu, eye woƒe numeɖeɖewo me kɔ nam.
As my wife and I studied the Bible with Steve and Sandy, I learned of prophecies that had come true, advice that works, and explanations that satisfied me.
Vivivi la, meva ka ɖe edzi be Mawu ƒe Nyae Biblia la nye.
Gradually, I became convinced that the Bible is the Word of God.
Ɣekaɣie nèva trɔ susu ku ɖe ale si agbe wɔ va dzɔ ŋu?
When did you change your mind about the origin of life?
Mlɔeba la, Steve tsɔ nya si Biblia gblɔ eme kɔ ƒãa la fiam, si nye be: "Yehowa Mawu tsɔ anyi mè ame. " (1 Mose 2:7) Woŋlɔ ale si ame gbãtɔ wɔ va dzɔ la ŋu nyawo ɖi.
Eventually, Steve showed me the Bible’s clear statement: "Jehovah God proceeded to form the man out of dust from the ground. " (Genesis 2:7) The first man has a documented life history.
Esia fɔ nyabiase sia ɖe te be: Ðe Biblia wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya?
This raised the question: Is the Bible in harmony with scientific facts?
Steve de dzi ƒo nam be maku nya ma me, eye mewɔe nenema hã.
Steve encouraged me to research the matter, so I did.
Nu kae nèsrɔ̃ tso nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si la ŋu?
What did you learn about evolution?
Mesrɔ̃ nu geɖe.
Many things.
Wo dometɔ ɖekae nye ale si nu sia fialawo dzea agbagba be yewoaɖe ale si nu gbagbewo wɔ va dzɔ la me.
To mention just one, the evolution theory attempts to explain the origin of species.
Ŋutinu siwo wɔa dɔ nyuie hele ɖoɖo nu, abe dzi, dzitodzito kple ŋku ene, le nu gbagbewo si.
Living things are made up of efficient organs, such as the heart, lungs, and eyes.
Eye ne wotsɔ mɔ̃ kpɔ nu gbagbewo ƒe lãmenugbagbeviwo me la, àkpɔ ‘mɔ̃’ wɔnukuwo le wo me.
Also, at the microscopic level, we see marvelously designed ‘machines’ within cells.
Aleke wòdzɔe be mɔ̃ mawo le lãmenugbagbeviwo me?
Where do the designs for those come from?
Ame siwo fiaa nu be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si gblɔ be ɖeko mɔ̃ mawo ŋutɔwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si, elabena nu gbagbe siwo me wole lae tsia agbe.
Evolutionists claim that the best mechanisms are automatically selected because the living things that have them survive better.
Gake numeɖeɖe ma meɖo nyabiase si nye, Aleke wòdzɔe be mɔ̃ siawo le lãmenugbagbeviwo me? la ŋu o.
But that idea does not answer the question: Where do the mechanisms come from?
Meva nya be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala geɖe mexɔe se be woate ŋu anɔ te ɖe nufiafia sia dzi aɖo nya ma ŋu o.
I learned that many scientists do not believe that the evolution theory answers that question.
Lãwo ŋuti nunyala aɖe ʋu eme nam be yemexɔ nufiafia si nye be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la dzi se o.
A professor of zoology confided to me that he did not believe any of the theories of evolution.
Ke hã esi wònɔ vɔvɔ̃m be dɔ ava gblẽ na ye ta la, mekɔ nu le edzi o.
However, he did not air his views for fear of losing his job.
Ðe nusɔsrɔ̃ tso nu gbagbewo kple nutoa me ŋu do ŋusẽ wò xɔsea?
Does your knowledge of ecology strengthen your faith?
Yes, it does.
Mesrɔ̃a nu tso ale si nu gbagbewo hiãa wo nɔewo hafi woate ŋu anɔ agbe la ŋu.
My work involved studying how living things depend on each other.
Nu gbagbe siwo katã le anyigba dzi hiãa wo nɔewo hafi woate ŋu anɔ agbe.
On earth, all living things depend on something else.
Bu seƒoƒowo kple anyiwo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider flowers and bees, for example.
Wowɔ seƒoƒowo ale be woƒe amadedewo, woƒe ʋeʋẽ lililiwo, wo me tsiwo kple woƒe wɔwɔme tea ŋu hea anyiwo, eye anyiwo kpɔa seƒoƒoŋuwɔ gbogbo aɖewo le wo dzi.
The color, fragrance, nectar, and structure of flowers are designed to attract bees and to sprinkle them with pollen.
Wowɔ anyiwo be woano seƒoƒometsiwo, eye woalɔ seƒoƒoŋuwɔwo le seƒoƒo aɖe dzi ayi na ati bubu ale be wòate ŋu aƒo se.
Bees are designed to extract nectar and to take one flower’s pollen to another plant for fertilization.
Edze kɔtɛe be ɖe wowɔ seƒoƒowo kple anyiwo be woakpɔ wo nɔewo ƒe nuhiahiãwo gbɔ.
Clearly, the flowers and bees are designed to supply what the other needs.
‘Ale si nu gbagbewo kple afi si wole ɖɔa wo ɖokuiwo ɖo la na mexɔe se be Mawue wɔ nu gbagbewo’
‘The resilience of the entire system of life on earth convinces me that life was designed by God’
Le nutoa me la, míekpɔe be nu gbagbewo hiãa wo nɔewo le mɔ geɖewo nu.
In an ecosystem, we see interdependence on a vast scale.
Nuto si míewɔnɛ la fia nu gbagbe akpe geɖewo, abe lãwo, nu miemiewo kple hlo ƒomeviwo ene, kple afi si wole.
An ecosystem is an environment with a community of perhaps thousands of types of animals, plants, bacteria, and fungi.
Lãwo katã hiãa gbe kple ya si woyɔna be ɔksidzin hafi woate ŋu anɔ agbe, eye nenema ke ati siwo ƒoa se la dometɔ akpa gãtɔ hiã lãwo hafi woate ŋu anɔ agbe.
All animals depend on plants for food and oxygen, and most flowering plants depend on animals.
Togbɔ be ale si lãwo kple nu miemiewo hiã wo nɔewo gɔme sese sesẽ ŋutɔ, eye edze abe wo dome ate ŋu agblẽ bɔbɔe ene hã la, woayi edzi anɔ anyi ƒe akpe.
Although ecosystems are exceedingly complex and the organisms in them are fragile, they may continue surviving for millennia.
Ne edzɔ be ɖiƒoƒo gblẽ nu le nuto aɖe ŋu gɔ̃ hã la, nu gbagbe gbogbo aɖewo agate ŋu adzi ɖe nuto ma me ne ɖiƒoƒoa nu yi.
Even after damage by pollution, once the source of pollution is gone, a complex ecosystem soon develops again.
Ne mebu ale si nu gbagbewo kple afi si wole tea ŋu ɖɔa wo ɖokuiwo ɖoe ŋu la, mexɔe se be Mawue wɔ nu gbagbewo.
When I think about the resilience of the entire system of life on earth, I am convinced that life was designed by God.
Nu ka tae nèzu Yehowa Ðasefo?
Why did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Metsi dzi vevie ɖe ale si ameƒomea le anyigbadzinuwo dome gblẽmee la ŋu.
I was deeply concerned about the way human society is ruining the environment.
Menyae be togbɔ be nu gbagbewo kple nuto siwo me wole ate ŋu aɖɔ wo ɖokuiwo ɖo hã la, mefia be wo dome mate ŋu agblẽ ɖikaa o.
I knew that although ecosystems are resilient, they are not indestructible.
Yehowa Ðasefowo fiam le Ŋɔŋlɔawo me be Mawu ahe "gbegblẽ ava ame siwo le anyigba la gblẽm la dzi. "
I learned from Jehovah’s Witnesses that, according to the Scriptures, God will "bring to ruin those ruining the earth. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 11:18) Nya mawo nɔ vevie nam ŋutɔ.
(Revelation 11:18) Those words were important to me.
Esi meyi Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ dzi la, meva de dzesii be mɔkpɔkpɔ si ŋu nya Biblia gblɔ nye nu ŋutɔŋutɔ.
As I continued studying the Bible, I gradually realized that the hope that the Bible presents is sure.
Nuƒoƒo na amewo tso nye dzixɔsewo ŋu dzɔa dzi nam, eye mesrɔ̃ Biblia kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala aɖewo.
I enjoy sharing my beliefs with others, and I have studied the Bible with some scientists.

Esi mexɔ ƒe 55 la, mexɔ dzudzɔ le dɔ me togbɔ be nye dzudzɔxɔɣi meɖo o hã, ale be mate ŋu azã ɣeyiɣi geɖe atsɔ akpe ɖe amewo ŋu woase Ame si wɔ nu gbagbewo kple eƒe tameɖoɖo ku ɖe anyigba dzeani sia ŋu la gɔme.
At age 55, I took early retirement to spend more time helping people to understand the Creator of life and his purpose for our magnificent earth.
Ŋutete Si Le Amegbetɔ Ƒe Ŋutilãa Ŋu Be Wòawu Abi
The Human Body’s Ability to Repair Wounds
Abiteƒe si wotsɔ plasta tre
A bandage on a hand
NU VOVOVO siwo wɔe be amegbetɔ nɔa agbe la dometɔ ɖekae nye ŋutete si le ŋutilãa ŋu be wòawu abi, eye wòana lãmenu siwo gblẽ le teƒe si wɔ abi la nagaɖɔ ɖo.
AMONG the numerous mechanisms that make human life possible is the body’s ability to heal wounds and regenerate damaged tissue.
Ne ŋutilãa ƒe akpa aɖe nya xɔ abi ko la, nu siwo ana abia naku la dzea dɔ gɔme enumake.
The process begins as soon as an injury occurs.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Lãmenugbagbevi gbogbo aɖewo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ wɔnuku aɖe dzie abi ƒe kuku dzea egɔme tsona abe esiwo gbɔna ene:
Consider: The healing process is made possible by a cascade of complex cellular functions:
Ʋumenu gbabɛwo va nɔa abia me, eye wonaa ʋua blana hetrea ʋuka siwo le ʋu ɖuɖum la nu.
Platelets adhere to tissues around a wound, forming a blood clot and sealing damaged blood vessels.
Abia ƒe tete vie kpɔa eta tsoa dɔlékuiwo si me eye wòɖea "ɖiwo " ɖa le eme.
Inflammation protects against infection and removes any "debris " caused by the injury.
Le ŋkeke ʋɛ aɖewo megbe la, ŋutilã la dzea lãmenu siwo gblẽ le abiteƒea ɖɔliɖɔli gɔme, enana abia miana eye wòɖɔa ʋuka siwo gblẽ la ɖo.
Within days, the body begins to replace injured tissue, make the wound contract, and repair damaged blood vessels.
Mlɔeba la, lãmenu siwo gblẽ la ɖɔna ɖo hezua abikukuteƒe eye ŋusẽ ɖoa teƒea ŋu.
Finally, scar tissue remodels and strengthens the damaged area.
Numekulawo kpɔe be yewoate ŋu anɔ te ɖe ale si ʋu blanae dzi awɔ aŋenu siwo ne wogbã la woate ŋu aɖɔ ɖo le wo ɖokui si.
Inspired by blood clotting, researchers are developing plastics that can "heal " damage to themselves.
Le aŋenu sia si woawɔ me la, pɔmpi suesuesue aɖewo anɔ eme siwo me atike ƒomevi eve aɖewo anɔ siwo ado ne aŋenua ƒe akpa aɖe gbã.
Such regenerating materials are equipped with tiny parallel tubes containing two chemicals that "bleed " when any damage occurs.
Ne aŋenua ƒe akpa aɖe gbã la, atike eveawo ado ava bla ɖe teƒea eye wòaɖɔ gbagbãƒea ɖo.
As the two chemicals mix, they form a gel that spreads across the damaged areas, closing cracks and holes.
Ne atike eve siwo tsaka le teƒea le ƒuƒum la, alia eye wòana teƒea naɖɔ ɖo abe ale si wònɔ tsã ene.
As the gel solidifies, it forms a tough substance that restores the material’s original strength.
Numekula aɖe gblɔ be, "Míekpɔ ale si nu gbagbe aɖewo wɔna ɖɔa woƒe ŋutilã ɖo ne woxɔ abi dzi be míawɔ aŋenu siwo me agbe mele o be woawo hã nate ŋu aɖɔ wo ɖokuiwo ɖo ne wogbã. "
One researcher admits that this synthetic healing process currently under development is "reminiscent " of what already exists in nature.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ŋutete si le amegbetɔ ƒe ŋutilãa ŋu be wòawu abi la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the body’s ability to repair wounds come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Nyatakaka Si Gbegbe Nɔa Domenyiŋusẽfianu Me
The Storage Capacity of DNA
KƆMPIUTAZÃLAWO trɔa asi le nyatakaka gbogbo aɖewo ŋu, eye wòhiãna be woadzra wo ɖo ale be woate ŋu ava wɔ wo ŋu dɔ emegbe ne ehiã.
COMPUTER users generate enormous amounts of digital data that has to be stored for access as needed.

Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le mɔ kpɔm be yewoahe tɔtrɔ gã aɖe ava nyatakakadzadzraɖo ƒe mɔnuwo me. Woƒe susue nye be yewoanɔ te ɖe dzɔdzɔme nyatakakadzraɖonu si de ŋgɔ sãsãsã la ƒe ŋutete dzi awɔ yewo tɔa. Dzɔdzɔmenu mae nye domenyiŋusẽfianu (DNA alo ADN).
Scientists are hoping to revolutionize current methods for digital storage by imitating a far superior data-storage system found in nature DNA.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Nyatakaka miliɔn akpe geɖewoe nɔa nu gbagbewo ƒe domenyiŋusẽfianuwo me.
Consider: DNA, found in living cells, holds billions of pieces of biological information.

Aƒetɔ Nick Goldman si wɔa dɔ le Europatɔwo ƒe dɔwɔƒe aɖe (European Bioinformatics Institute) gblɔ be: "Míate ŋu aɖe wo tso atiglinyi ƒomevi aɖewo siwo nɔ anyi le blema ƒe ƒuwo me . . . ahase nyatakaka siwo le wo me la gɔme. Wole nyaŋui ŋutɔ, gake nyatakaka gbogbo aɖewoe le wo me, eye mehiã be woazã elɛktrik-ŋusẽ aɖeke hafi ate ŋu adzra nyatakaka mawo ɖo o, ale wɔ wo tsɔtsɔ kple wo dzadzra ɖo ɖi le bɔbɔe. "

"We can extract it from bones of woolly mammoths . . . and make sense of it, " says Nick Goldman of the European Bioinformatics Institute. "It’s also incredibly small, dense and does not need any power for storage, so shipping and keeping it is easy. "
Ðe woate ŋu adzra nyatakaka siwo ŋu amegbetɔwo trɔ asi le la ɖo ɖe domenyiŋusẽfianuwo dzia?
Could DNA store man-made data?
Numekulawo ɖo eŋu be ɛ̃, woate ŋui.
Researchers say yes.

Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo te ŋu wɔ domenyiŋusẽfianuwo hedzra nuŋɔŋlɔwo, fotowo kple nu léɖemɔ̃dziwo ɖo ɖe wo dzi abe ale si ko wodzraa nyatakakawo ɖe elɛktronik-nuwo dzi ene. Numekulawo te ŋu trɔ nyatakaka siwo wodzra ɖo ɖe domenyiŋusẽfianu wɔwɔeawo dzi hegbugbɔ wo va ale si wonɔ tsã, eye wode pɛpɛpɛ.

Scientists have synthesized DNA with encoded text, images, and audio files, much as digital media stores data. The researchers were later able to decode the stored information with 100 percent accuracy.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo xɔe se be gbe ɖeka yewoate ŋu ato mɔnu sia dzi adzra nyatakaka siwo anɔ CD 3,000,000 dzi la ɖe domenyiŋusẽfianu wɔwɔe gram 1 dzi.

Scientists believe that in time, using this method, 0.04 ounce (1 g) of artificial DNA could store the data of some 3,000,000 CDs and that all this information could be preserved for hundreds if not thousands of years.
Wosusui be woate ŋu azã mɔnu sia atsɔ adzra nyatakaka siwo le xexea me ƒe elɛktronik-nyatakakawo dzraɖoƒewo katã dzi ɖo.
Potentially, this system could store the whole world’s digital archive.
Ale wɔ wona ŋkɔ domenyiŋusẽfianu be "nyatakakadzraɖonu gãtɔ. "
DNA has thus been dubbed "the ultimate hard drive. "
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si domenyiŋusẽfianu tea ŋu xɔa nyatakaka gbogbowo la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Could the storage capacity of DNA have come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Tɔmesisiblisi Ƒomevi Aɖe Ƒe Fu
The Sea Otter’s Fur
AMI titri aɖe le tɔmelã siwo dzia vi siwo nɔa tsi fafɛwo me la dometɔ geɖe ƒe ŋutigbalẽ te si kpena ɖe wo ŋu be vuvɔ mewɔa wo o.
MANY aquatic mammals that live in cold waters have a thick layer of blubber under the skin to help them stay warm.
Nu bubu aɖe si gakpena ɖe tɔmesisiblisi ƒomevi sia ya ŋue nye fu titri si le eŋu.
The sea otter relies on another insulation method a thick fur coat.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Fu si le ƒumelã sia ŋu mimi ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu wu lã bubuwo tɔ.
Consider: The fur of the sea otter is denser than that of any other mammal, with some one million hairs per square inch (155,000 per sq cm).
Ne wodzidze eƒe ŋutigbalẽ sentimeta ɖeka ɖe dzogoe ene me la, fu siwo ade 155,000 ye le eme.
When the otter swims, its coat traps a layer of air close to its body.
Ne ƒumelã sia le tsi ƒum la, ya aɖe gena ɖe eƒe fuawo te si wɔnɛ be tsi fafɛa mekaa eƒe ŋutilã ŋu be vuvɔ nawɔe o.
That air acts as an insulator, preventing the cold water from coming into direct contact with the animal’s skin and sapping its body heat.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kpɔe be míate ŋu asrɔ̃ nane tso fu si le ƒumelã sia ŋu la ŋuti.
Scientists believe that there is a lesson to be learned from the sea otter’s fur.
Wotee kpɔ wɔ fuwu siwo ƒe fuwo ƒe didime le vovovo eye mɔ si le fuawo domee hã le vovovo.
They have experimented with a number of artificial fur coats, varying such factors as hair length and hair spacing.
Numekulaawo kpɔe be "ne fuawo sɔ gbɔ eye wodidi la, womeɖoa tsi o. "
The researchers have concluded that "the denser and the longer the hairs are, the dryer or the more water-repellent the hairy surface is. "
Ne míagblɔe bubui la, ƒumelã siawo ate ŋu aƒo adegbe be yewo sie vuvɔmewu titri adodoea le.
Put another way, sea otters can boast a truly efficient fur coat.
Numekulawo le mɔ kpɔm be ale si wole ŋgɔ yim le mɔ̃ɖaŋununya me la awɔe be yewoawɔ avɔ ƒomevi aɖe si mate ŋu aɖo tsi o.
Researchers hope that their studies will lead to technological advances in the design and production of novel water-repellent textiles.
Esia ate ŋu ana amewo naƒo nya ta be fuwu titri si sɔ kple ƒumelã sia ƒe fuwo la ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo doa ɖi yia tɔ gɔme la ŋu ŋutɔ!
This may lead some to wonder whether people who have to dive in cold waters may not be better off wearing a hairy wet suit one similar to that of the sea otter!
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ƒumelã sia ƒe fu siwo nana vuvɔ mewɔnɛ o la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the heat-insulating fur of the sea otter evolve?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Dɔ Si Dadi Ƒe Nufuwo Wɔna
The Function of Cat Whiskers
ZÃ ME koŋ aƒemedadiwo dona.
DOMESTIC cats are mostly nocturnal.
Anɔ eme be woƒe nufuwo (fu lɔbɔlɔbɔ siwo nɔa nugbɔ na wo) kpena ɖe wo ŋu wokpɔa nu siwo tsɔ ɖe wo gbɔ kple nu si wodi be yewoalé la dzea sii, vevietɔ le anyinufaɣiwo.
Whiskers apparently help them to identify nearby objects and catch prey, particularly after dusk.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Lãmeka geɖewo le lãkusi siwo me dadi ƒe nufuwo mie tso la me.
Consider: Cats’ whiskers are attached to tissues that have multiple nerve endings.
Ne ya vi aɖe teti gɔ̃ hã ƒo la, lãmekaawo nana dadia senɛ le eɖokui me.
These nerves are sensitive to even the slightest movement of air.
Esia wɔe be etea ŋu dea dzesi nu siwo tsɔ ɖe egbɔ ne mekpɔ wo o hã eye ɖikekemanɔmee la, esia kpena ɖe eŋu le zã me.
As a result, cats can detect nearby objects without seeing them obviously an advantage in the dark.

Esi wònye be ne ya vi aɖe teti ƒo lɔ dadi ƒe nufuwo la, dadia tea ŋu senɛ le eɖokui me ta la, ezãa eƒe nufuwo tsɔ dea dzesi afi si nu si wòdi be yealé la le kple eƒe zɔɖeɖe kpakple afi si nu bubuwo hã le.
Since whiskers are sensitive to pressure, cats use them to determine the position and movement of an object or of prey.
Nufuwo hã kpena ɖe dadi ŋu wònyaa nuwo ƒe nugbɔ ƒe lolome hafi nyana ne ate ŋu atoe alo mate ŋu atoe o.
Whiskers also help cats to measure the width of an opening before they attempt to go through it.
Numekugbalẽ aɖe (Encyclopædia Britannica) gblɔ be "nu ʋɛ aɖe ko wonya tso dɔ si nufuwo wɔna la ŋu, ke hã wode dzesii be ne wotso dadi aɖe ƒe nufuwo la, exɔa ŋusẽ le dadia si hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe. "

The Encyclopædia Britannica acknowledges that "the functions of the whiskers (vibrissae) are only partially understood; however, it is known that, if they are cut off, the cat is temporarily incapacitated. "
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le robot aɖewo wɔm siwo ŋu wodea nu siwo wɔa dɔ abe dadi ƒe nufuwo ene la le ale be wòakpe ɖe wo ŋu woaƒo asa na mɔxenuwo.
Scientists are designing robots equipped with sensors that mimic cat whiskers to help the robots navigate around obstacles.

Aƒetɔ Ali Javey si nye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyafiala le California Yunivɛsiti si le Berkeley gblɔ be woate ŋu azã nufu siwo tɔgbi wowɔ la na "robot deŋgɔwo, mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ƒe dɔ bubuwo. "

These sensors, called e-whiskers, "should have a wide range of applications for advanced robotics, human-machine user interfaces, and biological applications, " says Ali Javey, a faculty scientist at the University of California, Berkeley.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si dadi ƒe nufuwo wɔa dɔe la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the function of cat whiskers come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Avu Ƒe Nuʋeʋẽse
The Dog’s Sense of Smell
Numekulawo gblɔ be avu tea ŋu wɔa ŋutete si le esi be wòase nu ƒe ʋeʋẽ ŋu dɔ nyana ne avu bubu aɖe nye atsu alo nɔe, ƒe si wòxɔ kple eƒe seselelãme.
Researchers say that dogs can use their sense of smell to detect the age, gender, and mood of other dogs.
Amewo tea ŋu naa hehe avuwo be woade dzesi bɔmbwo kple atike vɔ̃ɖiwo gɔ̃ hã.
Dogs can even be trained to detect explosives and illegal drugs.
Ŋku koŋue amegbetɔwo zãna tsɔ dea dzesi nu siwo ƒo xlã wo, gake avuwo ya zãa woƒe ŋɔti.
While humans mainly use sight to investigate their surroundings, dogs use their sense of smell.
Woƒe ŋɔtie wotsɔ dea dzesi nui.
They "read " with their nose.
Bu nya sia ŋu kpɔ: Ale si avu ƒe ŋɔti tea ŋu ʋẽa nu sena la de ŋgɔ wu amegbetɔwo tɔ zi gbɔ zi akpe geɖe.
Consider: A dog’s sense of smell is thousands of times more refined than ours.
Le numekuhabɔbɔ aɖe ƒe nya nu la, "ne woate ŋu ama nane ƒe ʋeʋẽ ɖe akpa miliɔn teƒe miliɔn me la, avu ate ŋu ase ʋeʋẽa ƒe akpa suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã.
According to the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology, a dog "can detect certain compounds at parts per trillion.

Ðeko wòle abe woama sukli gativi ɖeka ɖe akpa ene me ahakɔ akpa ɖeka ɖe ta gã si ƒe lolome sɔ kple esi me Olimpik hoʋlilawo ƒua tsi le me eye ame naɖɔ tsia kpɔ ase suklia ŋkɔ ene. " U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology.
This feat is the equivalent of tasting about a quarter teaspoon of sugar dissolved in an Olympic-sized swimming pool. "
Nu ka gbɔe wòtso be avu ƒe nuʋeʋẽse de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu amegbetɔwo tɔ?
What accounts for the dog’s superior sense of smell?
Avu ƒe ŋɔti nu fa, eya ta enɔa bɔbɔe be wòase nuwo ƒe ʋeʋẽ.
A dog’s nose is wet and is therefore better able to capture scent particles.
Yatoƒe eve ye le avu ƒe ŋɔti me egbɔa ya toa ɖeka me, eye wòzãa evelia tsɔ sea nuwo ƒe ʋeʋẽ.
A dog’s nose has two airways​ one for breathing, another for smelling.
Ne avu ʋẽ nu se la, ya gena ɖe eƒe ŋɔtia ƒe akpa si nana wòsea nuwo ƒe ʋeʋẽ la me.
When a dog sniffs, air is directed to the part of the nasal cavity that contains scent receptors.
Avu ƒe ŋɔti ƒe akpa si nana wòsea nu ƒe ʋeʋẽ la ƒe lolome tea ŋu nyea sentimeta 130 le dzogoe ene me, gake amegbetɔwo tɔ ya nye sentimeta 5 pɛ ko le dzogoe ene me.
A dog’s olfactory region can measure 130 square centimeters (20 sq in.) or more, whereas a human’s measures only 5 square centimeters (0.8 sq in.).
Lãmenugbagbevi siwo nana avuwo sea nu ƒe ʋeʋẽ la sɔ gbɔ wu esiwo nana amegbetɔwo sea nu ƒe ʋeʋẽ la zi gbɔ zi 50.
A dog can have up to 50 times as many scent receptor cells as we do.
Esiawo katã wɔnɛ be avu tea ŋu sea nu vovovo siwo le nane me la ƒe ʋeʋẽ.
All of this enables a dog to differentiate between the components of a complex scent.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le numekula aɖewo ƒe nya nu la, amegbetɔwo ate ŋu ase detsi ƒe ʋeʋẽ, gake avu ya ate ŋu ase nu vovovo siwo wozã tsɔ ƒo detsia la ƒe ʋeʋẽ.
For example, we can smell soup, but a dog can detect every ingredient in the recipe, according to some experts.
Wota agba si me detsi le ɖe amegbetɔ ƒe ta ŋuti, gake wota nu vovovo siwo wotsɔ ƒo detsia la ɖe avu ƒe ta ŋuti
A bowl of soup is superimposed on a man’s head, but every ingredient in the recipe is superimposed on a dog’s head

Numekula siwo le habɔbɔ aɖe (Pine Street Foundation) si kua nu me tso kansa ŋu me la gblɔ be, ale si avu ƒe ahɔhɔ̃ kple eƒe ŋɔti wɔa dɔ aduadu la wɔe be wònye "ŋudɔwɔnu deŋgɔ siwo dea dzesi nu ƒe ʋeʋẽ wu ɖe sia ɖe le anyigba dzi la dometɔ ɖeka. "
Researchers at the Pine Street Foundation, a cancer research institute, say that the dog’s brain and nose work together to be "one of the most sophisticated odor detection devices on the planet. "
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le agbagba dzem be yewoawɔ elektrɔnikmɔ̃ siwo awɔ dɔ abe avu ƒe ŋɔti ene siwo ade dzesi bɔmbwo, dɔlélewo abe kansa ene, kple nu siwo amewo tsɔ gbãa de.
Scientists are developing electronic "noses " to detect explosives, contraband, and disease, including cancer.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe avu ƒe nuʋeʋẽse la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the dog’s sense of smell evolve?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Sɔfɔti
The Horse’s Leg
SƆWO tea ŋu sia du kilometa 50 le gaƒoƒo ɖeka me.
A HORSE (Equus caballus) can gallop at a speed of up to 30 miles per hour (50 km/h).
Togbɔ be esia lɔ ŋutinu geɖewo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ ɖe eme hã la, ŋusẽ ʋɛ aɖe ko wozãna.
Although this involves considerable mechanical work, relatively little energy is spent.
Nu ka gbɔe esia tsona?
How is this possible?
Etsoa sɔfɔtiawo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ gbɔ.
The secret is in the horse’s legs.
Bu nu si dzɔna ne sɔ le du dzi ŋu kpɔ.
Consider what occurs when a horse gallops.
Ŋusẽ ɖoa lãkusi kple kpeƒetsiaka ƒomevi aɖe siwo me hena siwo wɔa dɔ aduadu la me ne sɔa tu afɔ anyi eye ne woɖe asi le ŋusẽa ŋu la, etutua sɔa dona ɖe ŋgɔ.
Elastic muscle-tendon units absorb energy when the leg steps onto the ground, and much like a spring, they return it, propelling the horse forward.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, ne sɔa le du sim la, eƒe afɔtiwo nɔa ƒoƒom sesĩe, si ate ŋu agblẽ nu le eƒe kpeƒetsiakawo ŋu hafi.
Furthermore, at a gallop the horse’s legs vibrate at high frequencies that could injure its tendons.
Gake lãkusiawo xɔna na kpeƒetsiakawo ale be nu megblẽna le wo ŋu o.
However, the muscles in the legs act as dampers.
Numekulawo gblɔ le ŋutinu siawo ƒe wɔwɔme ŋu be enye "lãkusi kple kpeƒetsiakawo ƒe wɔwɔme si de ŋgɔ ŋutɔ. "
Researchers call this structure a "highly specialized muscle-tendon design " that provides both agility and strength.
Numekulawo le agbagba dzem be yewoakpɔ sɔfɔti ƒe wɔwɔme dzi awɔ robot siwo si afɔ ene anɔ.
Engineers are trying to imitate the design of the horse’s legs for use in four-legged robots.

Ke hã Massachusetts Ƒe Mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔƒea ƒe dɔwɔƒe si nye Dzɔdzɔmenuwo Dzi Kpɔkpɔ Awɔ Robot Ƒe Numekuƒe gblɔ be ale si gbegbe sɔfɔti ƒe wɔwɔme de ŋgɔe la wɔe be yewomate ŋu awɔ esia bɔbɔe kple dɔwɔnu kpakple mɔ̃ɖaŋununya si su yewo si egbea o.

However, according to the Biomimetic Robotics Laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the complexity of this design cannot be easily duplicated with current materials and engineering knowledge.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe sɔfɔti ƒe wɔwɔme sia dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the structure of the horse’s legs come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ale Si Adzawo Wɔna Trea Wo Ðokui Ðe Nu Ŋu
The Glue of the Barnacle
Ɣeyiɣi didi aɖee nye esia lãwo ŋuti nunyalawo de dzesii be adzawo tea ŋu léna ɖe agakpewo, tɔdzisasrãwo kple meliwo ŋu goŋgoŋ.
Zoologists have long noted the ability of barnacles to cling tenaciously to rocks, piers, and the hulls of ships.
Nutrenu si adzawo wɔna la de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu nutrenu ƒomevi ɖe sia ɖe si amegbetɔwo wɔ kpɔ.
The glue of the barnacle is said to be far superior to synthetic products.
Nyitsɔ laa koe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va nya ale si adzawo wɔna trea wo ɖokui ɖe nu siwo le tsi me ŋu.
Just how barnacles adhere to wet surfaces remained a mystery until recently.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Numekukuwo ɖee fia be adzawo ƒe vi siwo do le woƒe aziwo me, siwo ate ŋu aƒu tsi la, léa ŋku ɖe nu siwo ŋu woalé ɖo la ŋu nyuie hafi léa wo ɖokui ɖe wo ŋu.
Consider: Studies have revealed that a free-swimming barnacle larva examines various surfaces before choosing a suitable anchoring spot.
Eye ne wokpɔ afi si woalé ɖo ko la, woɖea lãmetsi ƒomevi eve aɖewo ɖe teƒea.
Once it has found that spot, the larva apparently secretes two substances.
Lãmetsi gbãtɔa, si le abe ami ene la, tea ŋu ɖea tsinu ɖa le teƒe si adzaa di be yealé ye ɖokui ɖo.
The first is an oily lipid primer that displaces water from the chosen surface.
Eye lãmetsi ma wɔnɛ be teƒea sɔna nyuie be lãmetsi evelia, si nye protein ƒomevi aɖe la, hã nate ŋu alé ɖe teƒea.
The primer also creates an environment suitable for the application of the second substance, which is made up of proteins called phosphoproteins.
Lãmetsi eve siawo ƒoa ƒu zua nutrenu aɖe si nu sẽ ale gbegbe be nugbagbevi suesuesue siwo gblẽa nu dome gɔ̃ hã mate ŋu agblẽe o.
Together, the two substances form a strong adhesive plaque that even resists degradation by bacteria.
Ele vevie ŋutɔ be ŋusẽ nanɔ nutrenua ŋu alea, elabe afi mae adzaa anɔ le eƒe agbenɔɣi katã.
This enduring strength is important because the barnacle will spend the rest of its life anchored to that spot.
Adzawo, kpakple ale si woƒe nutrenua le ŋuti foto
Barnacles, with inset showing threads of barnacle glue
Adzawo, kpakple ale si woƒe nutrenua le ŋuti foto
Barnacles, with inset showing threads of barnacle glue
Ale si adzawo wɔa woƒe nutrenuae la de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu ale si dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo susui gbã.
The barnacle’s glue-making process is far more complex than previously thought.

Numekula siwo va srɔ̃ nu tso ale si adzawo tea ŋu wɔa woƒe nutrenuae ŋu la dometɔ ɖeka gblɔ be: "Ale si adzawo wɔna trea wo ɖokui ɖe nu siwo le tsi me ŋu le dzɔdzɔme nu la ɖe nunya deŋgɔ aɖe ŋutɔ fia. "
A member of the team that discovered the process said: "It’s an incredibly clever natural solution to this problem of how to deal with a water barrier on a surface. "
Nu siwo ŋu numekulawo ke ɖo la ate ŋu akpe ɖe wo ŋu be woawɔ nutrenu siwo woate ŋu azã le tsi gɔme, kpakple nutrenu ƒomevi bubu siwo ŋu dɔ woate ŋu awɔ le elektrɔnik mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo kple atikewɔnyawo me.
The findings may help researchers develop glues that can be used under water, as well as synthetic bioadhesives for use in electronics and medical implants.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si adzawo tea ŋu trea wo ɖokui ɖe nu ŋu la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Is the glue of the barnacle the product of evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ale Si Wowɔ Ƒumelã Aɖewo Ƒe Gowo
The Shape of Seashells
ƑUMEBƆBƆWO ƒe gowo kple adzawo ƒe gowo (alo gatsuƒliwo) ye kpena ɖe wo ŋu wonɔa agbe le nɔnɔme sesẽwo me, eye wonɔa te ɖe ale si atsiaƒua nɔa wo nyamam la nu.
SEASHELLS enable mollusks to live in harsh conditions, resisting tremendous pressures on the seabed.

Ale si woƒe goawo kpɔa wo ta nyuie la ʋã mɔ̃ɖaŋununyalawo wole nu me kum tso woƒe dzedzeme vovovoawo kple ale si goawo le ŋu kple susu be yewoata ʋu siwo woawɔ kple xɔ siwo woatu be woate ŋu akpɔ amewo ta.
This ability to provide optimum protection inspired engineers to study the shape and structure of seashells with a view to designing vehicles and buildings that will protect their occupants.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Mɔ̃ɖaŋununyalawo lé ŋku ɖe goawo dometɔ eve siwo nye gbadzɛtɔ kple lɔbɔetɔ ƒe dzedzemewo ŋu.
Consider: Engineers analyzed two seashell forms​ bivalve (clamshell-style) and spiral (screw-shaped).
Le gbadzɛtɔ gome la, wode dzesii be ale si fliwo tso eƒe nugbɔ va wu enu ɖe kpeƒea ye wɔe be ŋusẽ va le kpeƒea ŋu wu.
In the case of the bivalve, it was found that the ribbing on the exterior of a shell directed stresses toward its hinge and outer edges.
Gake le lɔbɔetɔ gome la, ale si fliawo gɔdɔ̃ to eŋu wɔe be ŋusẽ va le eƒe nugbɔ si keke wu la ŋu.
In contrast, the curving exterior of a spiral shell directed pressure toward its core and wide top.
Le gbadzɛtɔ kple lɔbɔetɔ siaa gome la, zi geɖea ne nane lɔ goa la, sesẽƒea kpɔa eta si wɔnɛ be nu vevi mewɔa lã si le goa me la o.
In both cases, the seashells’ shapes channeled pressure to their strongest areas, meaning that in the event of damage, harm to the mollusk would be less likely.
Numekulawo hã do ƒumelã siawo ƒe go kple esiwo ɖi esiawo siwo wowɔ le kɔmpiuta dzi la kpɔ.
Researchers also ran comparative stress tests on real shells and on simple hemispheres and cones (produced on a 3-D printer) that mimicked shells’ shapes and composition.
Nu si wova de dzesii ye nye be, ale si wowɔ ƒumelã siawo ƒe gowo nukutɔe la na wosesẽ wu esiwo wowɔ le kɔmpiuta dzi la zi gbɔ zi eve.
The results showed that natural seashells’ complex surfaces nearly doubled their ability to withstand pressure when compared to the simple shapes.

Esi agbalẽ aɖe (Scientific American) nɔ nu ƒom tso nu siwo ŋu woke ɖo le numekukua me ŋu la, egblɔ be: "Ne èva le ʋu siwo wowɔ ɖe ƒumelã siawo ƒe go ƒe nɔnɔme nu ƒe ɖe kum gbe ɖeka la, anya kpɔ ŋutɔ eye àkpɔe be ɖe wowɔe be wòakpɔ emenɔlawo ta. " Nu kae nèsusu?
Commenting on the applications of this research, Scientific American says: "If you wind up driving a shell-shaped car someday, it’ll be both stylish and designed to protect the soft bodies inside. "
Ðe ƒumelã siawo ƒe goawo dzɔ le wo ɖokui sia?
What do you think: Did the shape of seashells evolve?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ƒumefɔlĩ Ƒe Ade Si Wòtsɔ Wɔa Ðɔ
The Byssus of the Marine Mussel
ABE adzawo ene la, ƒumefɔlĩwo hã léna ɖe agakpewo, atiwo alo tɔdziʋuwo ŋu.
LIKE barnacles, marine mussels attach themselves to rocks, wood, or ship hulls.
Gake fɔlĩwo meléna ɖe nuwo ŋu kpaɖii abe ale si adzawo wɔnɛ ene o, ɖe woawo ya wokuna ɖe nuwo ŋu segee to ɖɔ aɖe si woƒe ade si wotuna wɔ la dzi.
However, unlike barnacles, which fasten themselves tightly to a surface, marine mussels dangle by a network of thin filaments called byssus threads.

Togbɔ be fɔlĩwo ƒe nuwɔwɔ alea wɔnɛ be wònɔa bɔbɔe na wo be woaɖu nu ahaku ɖe tɔdziʋuwo ŋu woatsɔ wo ayi teƒe bubuwo hã la, edze abe ŋusẽ mele woƒe ɖɔa ŋu be woanɔ te ɖe atsiaƒu ƒe ƒutsotsoewo nu o ene.
While this method increases the mussel’s flexibility for feeding and migration, the threads seem too flimsy to withstand the impact of ocean waves.
Ke aleke woƒe ɖɔa nana wokuna ɖe tɔdziʋuwo ŋu be womegena ɖe atsiaƒua me o?
How does the byssus allow the mussel to hang on and not be swept out to sea?
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Fɔlĩ ƒe ɖɔa liana goŋgoŋ le akpa ɖeka gake bɔbɔ hedena le akpa kemɛa.
Consider: Byssus threads are stiff on one end, yet soft and stretchy on the other.
Numekulawo va de dzesii be esi ɖɔa ƒe akpa 80 le alafa me liana goŋgoŋ eye akpa 20 mamlɛa le alafa me bɔbɔna tae wòtea ŋu wɔa dɔ nyuie nenema.
Researchers have found that the precise ratio used by the mussel 80 percent stiff material to 20 percent soft is critical for providing the strongest attachment.
Esia tae fɔlĩ tea ŋu nɔa te ɖe ƒutsotsoe siwo nɔa ehem ganɔa etutum la nu le tɔdziʋuwo ŋu.
Hence, the byssus can handle the force of dramatic pulling and pushing by marine waters.

Nufialagã Guy Genin yɔ nu si ŋu woke ɖo le numekuku sia me la be "nukunu " hegblɔ kpee be: "Fɔlĩ ƒe ɖɔ si adea wɔna ƒe akpa bɔbɔea kple akpa si liana goŋgoŋ ƒe dɔwɔwɔ aduadu la gbɔe wòtso be fɔlĩ wɔa nukunu sia. "
Professor Guy Genin calls the results of this research "stunning, " adding: "The magic of this organism lies in the structurally clever integration of this compliant region with the stiff region. "

Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo susu be woate ŋu azã fɔlĩ ƒe ɖɔa le mɔ vovovowo nu; woate ŋu azãe atsɔ aku nuwo ɖe xɔwo ŋu, aku nuwo ɖe tɔdziʋuwo ŋu le tsi me, woate ŋu azãe atsɔ alé lãkusi ɖe ƒuwo ŋu eye amekolawo ate ŋu atsɔe axe abidowo nu ne wole ame kom.

Scientists believe that the design of the byssus threads could have uses as diverse as attaching equipment to buildings and underwater vessels, connecting tendons to bones, and sealing surgical incisions.
Nufialagã J. Herbert Waite si le California Yunivɛsiti le Santa Barbara, Amerika la gblɔ be: "Nu wɔnuku gbogbo aɖewo siwo mele xexlẽme o la li míasrɔ̃ tso nuwɔwɔwo ŋu ku ɖe nulénuwo ŋu. "
"Nature is a bottomless treasure trove, as far as adhesion strategies go, " says J. Herbert Waite, a professor at the University of California in Santa Barbara, U.S.A.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ƒumefɔlĩ ƒe ade si wòtsɔ wɔa ɖɔ la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the byssus of the marine mussel come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ŋutete Si Le Abosra Si Be Wòatrɔ Eƒe Amadede
The Color-Changing Ability of the Cuttlefish
ABOSRA tea ŋu trɔa eƒe amadede si wɔnɛ be menɔa bɔbɔe be woakpɔe o.
CUTTLEFISH can change their color and camouflage themselves, becoming almost invisible to the human eye.
Nyatakaka aɖe si ku ɖe abosra ŋu la gblɔ be, "ŋutilã ƒe amadede vovovowoe le esi eye wòtea ŋu trɔa eƒe amadede le sekɛnd ɖeka ko me. "
According to one report, cuttlefish "are known to have a diverse range of body patterns and they can switch between them almost instantaneously. "
Aleke wòtea ŋu wɔa esiae?
How do cuttlefish do it?
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Lãmenugbagbevi tɔxɛ aɖe si le abosra la ƒe lãme ye kpena ɖe eŋu wòtea ŋu trɔa eƒe amadede.
Consider: The cuttlefish changes color by using the chromatophore, a special kind of cell found under its skin.
Amadedeawo le kotoku suesuesue ƒomevi aɖewo me fũu le lãmenugbagbevia me, eye lãkusiwo ƒo xlã wo keŋ.
Chromatophores contain sacs that are full of colored pigment and that are surrounded by tiny muscles.
Ne abosra la di be yeatrɔ yeƒe amadede ne woagakpɔ ye o la eƒe ahɔhɔ̃ ɖoa nyatakakawo ɖe lãkusi siwo ƒo xlã kotoku suesuesueawo, eye esia nana womiana.
When the cuttlefish needs to camouflage itself, its brain sends a signal to contract the muscles around the sacs.
Emegbe kotoku suesuesue siwo me amadedeawo le la vuna si nana abosra la trɔa eƒe amadede kple nɔnɔme enumake.
Then the sacs and the pigment within them expand, and the cuttlefish quickly changes its color and pattern.
Menye ɖeko abosra tea ŋu zãa ŋutete sia be woagakpɔ ye ko o, ke ezãnɛ hã be yeatsɔ awɔ nu si adze yeƒe kpeɖeŋutɔ ŋu alo aɖo dze.
The cuttlefish may use this skill not only for camouflage but also to impress potential mates and perhaps communicate.
Mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla siwo le yunivɛsiti aɖe si le Bristol, England la wɔ abosra sia ƒe ŋutilã ƒomevi aɖe.
Engineers at the University of Bristol, England, built an artificial cuttlefish skin.
Wode aŋe yibɔ gbagbɛgbagbɛ aɖewo abosraa ƒe ŋutilã ƒomevi si wowɔ la ƒe akpa aɖewo me be wòawɔ dɔ abe abosra ƒe lãkusi ene.
They sandwiched disks of black rubber between small devices that function like cuttlefish muscles.
Esi wode elektrikŋusẽ abosra ƒe ŋutilã ƒomevi si wowɔ me la, ewɔ gbagbɛ hena aŋe gbagbɛ yibɔawo vu eye wòna abosra ƒe ŋutilã ƒomevi si wowɔ la ƒe amadede nɔ tɔtrɔm.
When the researchers applied electricity to the skin, the devices flattened and expanded the black disks, darkening and changing the color of the artificial skin.

Jonathan Rossiter si nye mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔ- wɔla gblɔ tso numekuku si wowɔ tso abosra ƒe lãkusi ŋu be, "ale si tɔmelã sia tea ŋu trɔa eƒe amadede bɔbɔe la " ate ŋu ana be woawɔ nudodo siwo anɔ amadede trɔm le sekɛnd ɖeka ko me.
Research on cuttlefish muscles "the soft structures that nature is so good at making, " according to engineer Jonathan Rossiter could lead to clothing that changes color in a fraction of a second.
Aƒetɔ Rossiter yi edzi be amewo ate ŋu ado awu si woawɔ la be amewo nagakpɔ wo adze sii o loo alo be wòanye awudodo ƒe atsyã ko.
Rossiter says that people might wear cuttlefish-inspired clothes for camouflage or simply for fashion.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ŋutete si le abosra si be wòatrɔ eƒe amadede la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the ability of cuttlefish to change color come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Hawaiitɔwo Ƒe Totsitotsi Ƒe Dzosinu
The Light Organ of the Hawaiian Bobtail Squid

HAWAIITƆWO ƒe totsitotsi alo akladzĩ daa ade le zã me, eye eya ŋutɔ sia akaɖi aɖe si sɔna kple ɣleti kple ɣletiviwo ƒe keklẽ. Le esi akaɖi sia nana lã bubuwo nakpɔe teƒe la, ɖe wònana boŋ be wometea ŋu kpɔnɛ o.
A NOCTURNAL hunter, the Hawaiian bobtail squid creates its own light not to be seen, but to be unseen to blend in with the ambient moonlight and starlight.
Nu si kpena ɖe ƒumelã sia ŋu wòtea ŋu wɔa nu siae nye nugbagbevi suesue aɖewo siwo le eƒe dzosinu me siwo klẽna.
The animal’s secret is its partnership with light-emitting bacteria.
Lã sia kple nugbagbevi suesue siawo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ aduadu alea ate ŋu aɖe vi na mí le go aɖe me.
That partnership may also hold secrets that could benefit us, but in a seemingly unrelated way.
Ate ŋu ade míaƒe lãmesẽ dzi.
It may benefit our health.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Hawaiitɔwo ƒe totsitotsi nɔa Hawaii Ƒukpoa ƒe ƒu siwo me kɔ la me.
Consider: The Hawaiian bobtail squid lives in the clear coastal waters of the Hawaiian Islands.
Ðe wòle be ɣleti kple ɣletiviwo ƒe keklẽ nana ƒumelã lénu siwo to totsitotsia gɔme va yina la nakpɔ eƒe vɔvɔli hafi.
Light from the moon and the stars would normally make the silhouette of the creature stand out to predators below.
Gake dzo aɖe sina le totsitotsia ƒe ƒodo dzi si sɔna kple ɣleti ƒe keklẽ pɛpɛpɛ.
The bobtail squid, however, emits a glow from its underside that mimics ambient night light in both intensity and wavelength.
Esia wɔnɛ be lã sia ƒe vɔvɔli medzena o.
The result is stealth no silhouette, no shadow.
