Nu si nana be lã sia tea ŋu wɔa "aɖaŋu deŋgɔ " siae nye nugbagbevi suesue aɖewo siwo le eƒe dzosinu la me. Nugbagbevi siawo sia dzo. Nugbagbevi suesue siawo ƒe dzoa ƒe keklẽ sɔna kple ɣleti ƒe keklẽ pɛpɛpɛ, si nana be ƒumelã lénuwo metea ŋu kpɔa totsitotsi la o.
The squid’s "high-tech " apparatus is its light organ, which houses bioluminescent bacteria that produce just the right glow to camouflage their host.
Ðewohĩ nugbagbevi suesue siawo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe totsitotsia ƒe alɔ̃dɔdɔ kple eƒe nyɔnyɔ dzi.
The bacteria may also help to regulate the squid’s sleep-wake pattern.
Numekulawo tsɔ ɖe le esia me vevie, elabe wosusui be ɖewohĩ nugbagbevi suesue siwo le nu gbagbe bubuwo hã me la kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe ɖoɖo si nu woƒe ŋutilã wɔa dɔ ɖo gbe sia gbe la dzi.
This interests researchers because the bobtail squid may not be the only creature where there is a link between bacteria and circadian cycles, or daily rhythms in activity.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le lã siwo naa no vi gome la, nugbagbevi siwo nana be nuɖuɖu wɔa dɔ le lãme hã anya kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe ɖoɖo si nu woƒe ŋutilã wɔa dɔ ɖo gbe sia gbe la dzi.
In mammals, for example, bacteria that play a role in digestion may also be associated with circadian rhythms.
Wogblɔ be ne nane tɔtɔ ɖoɖo si nu míaƒe ŋutilã wɔa dɔ ɖo gbe sia gbe la, etea ŋu hea blanuiléledɔ, suklidɔ, lolo fũu akpa kple alɔ̃dɔkuxiwo vɛ.
Disturbances of these rhythms have been linked to depression, diabetes, obesity, and sleep disorders.
Eya ta nusɔsrɔ̃ tso totsitotsi kple nugbagbevi siwo le eƒe dzosinua me ŋu ate ŋu ana woaganya nu geɖe tso amegbetɔwo ƒe lãmesẽ ŋu.
Hence, the study of the squid’s bacteria-host system may furnish insights into human health.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe totsitotsi ƒe dzosinu la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the light organ of the Hawaiian bobtail squid come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Bosrã Ƒe Alɔ Wɔnukuawo
The Amazing Arm of the Octopus
Robɔt-wɔlawo le dɔwɔnuwo tom vɛ siwo akpe ɖe ɖɔktawo ŋu be woawɔ dɔ le teƒe siwo xaxa le ametia me eye woazã amekomɔnu siwo me womade abi ame ŋu fũu le o.
Robotics engineers are developing equipment to help doctors operate in tight spaces in the body using minimally invasive surgical techniques.
Nu siwo wosrɔ̃ tso bosrã ƒe alɔ siwo bɔbɔ hetea ŋu xatsana bɔbɔe ŋu la le kpekpem ɖe wo ŋu be woato nu yeyewo vɛ le amekomɔnu sia ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ me.
One innovation in this field is inspired by the highly flexible arm, or tentacle, of the octopus.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Bosrã tea ŋu zãa eƒe alɔ enyi siwo bɔbɔ siwo me wòtea ŋu hena bɔbɔe la tsɔ hea nu, léa nu alo mianɛ, le teƒe siwo xaxa gɔ̃ hã.
Consider: The octopus can grab, hold, and squeeze objects with its eight extendable and flexible arms, even in tiny spaces.
Menye ɖeko wòtea ŋu xatsana eƒe alɔwo yia go sia go me ko o, ke etea ŋu nana eƒe alɔwo ƒe akpa vovovowo liana hã ne ehiã be wòawɔe nenema.
Not only can the octopus bend its tentacles in any direction but it can also stiffen different sections of its arms as needed.
Numekulawo xɔe se be robɔt ƒe alɔ siwo bɔbɔ hexana bɔbɔe abe bosrã tɔ ene la aɖe vi ŋutɔ le amekomɔnu siwo me womedea abi ame ŋu le fũu o la ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ me.
Researchers believe that a similarly soft and flexible robotic arm would be invaluable in performing minimally invasive surgery.
Dɔwɔnu sia ƒomevi ate ŋu awɔe be woako dɔnɔwo evɔ womazã amekomɔnu siwo ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ sesẽ akpa o.
This kind of equipment could make it possible to operate on patients who otherwise would have to undergo more complex procedures.
Kpɔ ale si bosrã ƒe alɔ siwo tea ŋu xana bɔbɔe la le ɖa
See the flexible tentacles of the octopus in action
Wowɔ robɔt ƒe alɔ sia tɔgbi xoxo eye wole edom kpɔ hafi ava zãe le amewo koko me.
Such a robotic arm has already been developed and is being used in simulated operations.

Robɔt la ƒe alɔ ƒe akpa ɖeka si ƒe didime le milimeta 135 la tea ŋu léa dɔmenu siwo bɔbɔ eye wòkɔa wo yia dzi vie evɔ megblẽa nu le wo ŋu o, eye alɔa ƒe akpa bubu wɔa dɔ le dɔmenu si ŋu wòhiã be woawɔ dɔ le la ŋu.
One part of the 135-millimeter (5 in.) arm can manipulate soft internal organs by lifting and holding them without causing any damage to them, while another part performs the actual operation.
Agbalẽnyalagã Tommaso Ranzani, si nye ame siwo to dɔwɔnua vɛ dometɔ ɖeka, gblɔ be, "míexɔe se be dɔwɔnu sia aʋu mɔ na dɔwɔnu yeye siwo de ŋgɔ wu la wɔwɔ. "
According to Dr. Tommaso Ranzani, a member of the team that developed the equipment, "we believe this system will be the start for new and improved versions with more advanced features. "
Bosrã kpakple robɔt ƒe alɔ
An octopus and a robotic arm
Robɔt ƒe alɔ si bɔbɔ hexana bɔbɔe la aɖe vi ŋutɔ le amekoko me
A soft and flexible robotic arm would be invaluable in surgery

Boso Kpoɖoɖoe Ƒe Tsiƒunuwo
The Flipper of the Humpback Whale
BOSO sia si míayɔ be boso kpoɖoɖoe la ƒe tsitsitɔ lolo hekpe wu bɔs legbetɔ.
THE adult humpback whale is bigger and heavier than a city bus.
Ke hã, ale si ƒumelã gã sia tea ŋu ɖea zɔ kabakaba ne ele ɖi dom hele eɖokui trɔm la ɖe dzesi ŋutɔ.
Still, this colossal mammal is remarkably agile when diving and turning.
Aleke wòdzɔe be ŋutete sia le boso ƒomevi sia si?
How can the humpback whale be so nimble?
Nu si gbɔ wòtso ƒe ɖee nye nu glidzaglidza siwo le eƒe tsiƒunuwo ƒe to.
Part of the secret lies in the bumps on its flippers.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Boso kple ƒumelã gã geɖewo ƒe tsiƒunuwo ƒe to zrɔ̃na.
Consider: Most whales and other cetaceans have flippers with smooth leading edges.
Gake boso sia ya tɔ mele nenema o.
However, the humpback whale is different.
Eƒe tsiƒunuwo ƒe to le glidzaglidza.
It has uniquely large bumps (called tubercles) on the leading edge of its flippers.
Ne boso sia le tsi ƒum la, tsi va lɔa nu glidzaglidza siwo le tsiƒunuawo ƒe to hegbagbana.
As the humpback swims, water flows over the bumps and breaks up into a multitude of vortices.
Ne "tsia gbagba alea la " ekɔa bosoa yia dzi, eye esia wɔnɛ be wòtea ŋu kekea tsiƒunuawo ɖe dzogoe si keke nyuie me si wɔnɛ be metɔna hafi kekea tsiƒunuawo me o.
The bumps channel the water flow and create turbulence. This "tubercle effect " provides the whale with more lift, allowing it to tilt its flippers at a high angle without stalling.

Ale si wòtea ŋu kekea tsiƒunuawo ɖe dzogoe si keke nyuie me la wɔnɛ be tsia ƒuƒu nɔa bɔbɔe nɛ wu ale si eƒe tsiƒunuawo didii lae nye nu vevi si gbɔ wòtso be wòtea ŋu wɔa esia. Ne woma boso sia ƒe didime ɖe akpa etɔ̃ la, tsiƒunuawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe didime axɔ akpa ɖeka.
At high angles these bumps also reduce drag an important benefit for the humpback’s long flippers, each being about one third of the whale’s body length.
Numekulawo le ŋutete sia si le boso sia si la ŋu dɔ wɔm be yewoatsɔ awɔ tɔdziʋu ƒe kuɖɔɖoti, tsiŋusẽnamɔ̃, yaŋusẽnamɔ̃ kple helikɔpta ƒe yaƒonu siwo de ŋgɔ wu.
Researchers are applying this concept to make more-efficient boat rudders, water turbines, windmills, and helicopter rotor blades.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe boso kpoɖoɖoe ƒe tsiƒunua dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the flipper of the humpback whale come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Boso Ƒe Ŋutigbalẽ Si Klɔa Ði Le Eɖokui Ŋu
The Pilot Whale’s Self-Cleaning Skin
Adzawo kple nugbagbevi bubuwo abe adru ene siwo léna ɖe meliwo ŋu hetsina ɖe wo ŋu la nye kuxi gã aɖe na meliwo ŋu dɔwɔlawo.
Barnacles and other marine organisms that grow on the hulls of ships present a big problem to vessel operators.

Nu mawo siwo léna ɖe meliwo ŋu la wɔnɛ be meliwo meɖea zɔ kabakaba o, ewɔnɛ be wonoa ami geɖe wu, eye wòwɔnɛ hã be ƒe ʋɛ aɖewo ko megbe la, ele be woaɖe meliwo ayi go dzi be woaklɔ ɖinu mawo le wo ŋu.
Such biofouling, as it is called, slows ships down, causes them to burn more fuel, and requires that they be taken out of service every couple of years to be cleaned.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le tɔtrɔm ɖe dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu be yewoakpɔ ta na kuxi sia.
Scientists are turning to nature for solutions.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Numekukuwo ɖee fia be ŋutete le boso ƒomevi aɖe (Globicephala melas) si be wòaɖe ɖinuwo ɖa le eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu.
Consider: Studies have revealed that the skin of the long-finned pilot whale (Globicephala melas) has self-cleaning abilities.
Do suesuesue aɖewo le eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu le fli me siwo le sue ale gbegbe be adzawo ƒe aziwo mate ŋu age ɖe wo me ahalé ɖe wo me o.
It is covered with tiny ridges, called nanoridges, which are too small to allow barnacle larvae to get a good grip.
Ami aɖe si le abe nugbagbeviwutike ene si ɖea adru kple dɔlékuiwo ɖa la le dometsotso siwo le fliawo dome la me.
The spaces between these ridges are filled with a gel that attacks algae and bacteria.
Ne bosoa ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ɖe tsro la, ami bubu gadona.
The whale secretes fresh gel as it sheds its skin.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ɖoe be yewoawɔ ŋutete si le boso si be wòaɖe ɖi le eɖokui ŋu la ŋu dɔ na meliwo.
Scientists plan to adapt the whale’s self-cleaning system for the hulls of ships.
Tsã la, wosia aŋɔ tɔxɛ aɖewo ɖe meliwo ŋu be ɖinu mawo nagalé ɖe wo ŋu o.
In the past, antifouling paints were applied.
Gake nyitsɔ laa la, woɖo asi aŋɔ si wozãna wu na dɔ sia wɔwɔ la dzi, elabena aɖi si le eme la gblẽa nu le ƒumelãwo ŋu.
Yet, the most commonly used of such paints have recently been banned because they are toxic to marine life.
Nu si numekulawo ɖo be yewoawɔ atsɔ akpɔ kuxia gbɔe nye be yewoaɖe do vivivi siwo me atike si megblẽa nu le ƒumelãwo ŋu o dona tso la ɖe meliwo kɔgo keŋ eye woafa gaɖɔ ɖe eŋu.
The researchers’ solution is to cover ships’ hulls with a metal mesh over an array of holes that exude a biosafe chemical.
Ne atsiaƒutsia ka atikea ŋu ko la, atikea blana ɖe edzi helilina ɖe melia kɔgo godoo va kpe.
The chemical thickens into a viscous gel on contact with seawater, forming a skin that coats the entire hull.
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, atike si lili ɖe melia ŋu la klona ɖa eye nugbagbevi siwo lé ɖe eŋu la hã ɖena ɖa kpena ɖe eŋu.
In time, this skin, about 0.7 millimeters [0.03 in.] thick, wears away, taking with it any organisms that may have been hitching a ride.
Eyome atikea gadona tso do suesuesueawo me xɔna ɖe esi klo ɖa la teƒe.
The system then secretes a fresh coating of gel to cover the hull.
Adzawo lé ɖe meli aɖe kɔgo
Barnacles on the hull of a ship
Adzawo wɔnɛ be meliwo meɖea zɔ kabakaba o, eye wo ɖeɖe sesẽna ŋutɔ
Barnacles slow ships down and are difficult to remove
Dodokpɔ siwo numekulawo wɔ la ɖee fia be mɔnu sia ate ŋu ana be ɖinu siwo léna ɖe meliwo ŋu la dzi naɖe akpɔtɔ teƒe alafa ɖeka.
Laboratory tests have shown that this system could reduce biofouling of ships 100-fold.
Eye esia aɖe vi na melidɔwɔƒewo ale gbegbe, elabena wogblẽa ga geɖe ŋutɔ ne woɖe meliwo va go dzi be woaɖe ɖinuwo ɖa le wo ŋu.
And that would be a huge advantage for shipping companies, because bringing a vessel into dry dock for cleaning costs a great deal of money.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe boso sia ƒe ŋutigbalẽ si klɔa ɖi le eɖokui ŋu la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the pilot whale’s self-cleaning skin evolve?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ƒumeha Ƒe Dzesidede Nu Ƒe Ŋutete La
The Dolphin’s Sonar
Ƒumehawo xlɔ̃na helia aku le mɔ vovovowo nu. Ƒumehaa ƒe xɔxlɔ̃a ƒe ɖiɖi trɔna ne gbeɖiɖia lɔ nu siwo ƒo xlãe. Ƒumehaa sea esia eye wòkpena ɖe eŋu wònyana nu siwo ƒo xlãe kple afi si wòato.
Dolphins produce a variety of clicks and whistles and then listen for echoes in order to navigate and explore their environment.

Nu siwo dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo srɔ̃ tso ƒumeha sia tɔgbi (Tursiops truncatus) ƒe dzesidede nu ƒe ŋutete ŋu la le kpekpem ɖe wo ŋu be woawɔ ƒugɔmemɔ̃ siwo akpe ɖe wo ŋu woakpɔ kuxi siwo sesẽ akpa be woazã egbegbe mɔ̃ɖaŋununya atsɔ akpɔ wo gbɔe la gbɔ.

Inspired by the natural sonar of the bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops truncatus), scientists are developing underwater acoustic systems to solve problems that lie beyond the capabilities of existing technology.
Bu esia ŋu kpɔ: Ƒumeha ƒe dzesidede nu ƒe ŋutetea wɔnɛ be etea ŋu kena ɖe ƒumelã sue siwo ɣla wo ɖokuiwo ɖe ke me le ƒua gɔme la ŋu, eye wòtea ŋu dea vovototo ƒumelãwo kple kpewo dome.
Consider: The dolphin’s sonar allows it to find fish hiding in sand on the seabed and to distinguish between a fish and a rock.

Aƒetɔ Keith Brown, si nye nufialagãtenɔla le Heriot-Watt University, le Edinburgh, le Scotland, gblɔ be ƒumeha tea ŋu "dea dzesi vovototo si le nugo siwo me tsi nyui, dzetsi, suklitsi kple tomemi le dome ne ele adzɔge tso wo gbɔ meta ewo gɔ̃ hã. "

According to Keith Brown, an associate professor at Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, Scotland, the dolphin can also "tell the difference between containers that hold fresh water, salt water, syrup, and oil from [a distance of] ten meters [32.8 ft]. "
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo di be yewoawɔ mɔ̃ siwo hã ate ŋu ade dzesi nu alea.
Scientists would like to develop devices having some of the same abilities.
Ƒumeha aɖe wɔ eƒe dzesidede nu ƒe ŋutetea ŋu dɔ tsɔ nya nu si le nugo aɖe me
A dolphin uses its sonar to detect the contents of a container
Ƒumeha tea ŋu nɔa te ɖe nu si le nugo vovovowo me dzi dea vovototo nugoawo dome ne ele adzɔge meta ewo gɔ̃ hã
From a distance of ten meters, dolphins can tell containers apart by their contents
Numekulawo ku nu me tso ƒumehawo ƒe xɔxlɔ̃ kple nusese ŋu eye wodze agbagba be yewoawɔ mɔ̃ siwo hã wɔa nu nenema ke.
Researchers analyzed the dolphins’ vocalizations and hearing and attempted to replicate them.
Nu si do tso emee nye be wowɔ mɔ̃ aɖe si me elektrɔnik mɔ̃ɖaŋunu deŋgɔwo le hetsɔe de nugo aɖe si ƒe didime mede meta ɖeka o la me.
The result was a sonar device packed with sophisticated electronics and fitted into a cylinder less than one meter (3.3 ft) long.

Wotsi mɔ̃ sia ɖe ƒugɔmeʋu aɖe si ɖi ƒugɔmeʋutsrɔ̃mɔ̃ la ŋu, eye wotrɔ asi le eŋu be wòate ŋu ade dzesi nɔnɔme si me nu siwo woɖi ɖe ƒu gɔme ʋĩi ke, abe elektrik-kawo kple amipɔmpigakpowo ene, la le evɔ mɔ̃a ŋutɔ maka wo ŋu o.

The device, which is attached to an underwater robotic vehicle that resembles a torpedo, was designed to inspect the seabed, find buried items such as cables or pipelines, and analyze them without making direct contact.
Ame siwo to mɔ̃ sia vɛ la kpɔe be aɖe vi geɖe na adzɔha siwo kua tomemi.
Its developers foresee applications in the oil and gas industry.

Mɔ̃ siwo wonɔ te ɖe ƒumeha ƒe dzesidede nu ƒe ŋutete dzi wɔ la ate ŋu ana ƒugɔmemɔ̃wo ƒe dɔwɔnawo nagade ŋgɔ ɖe edzi wu, si awɔe be mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo nada ƒugɔmedɔwɔnuwo ɖe teƒe nyuitɔ kekeake, ade dzesi nu siwo gblẽ le wo ŋu kple teƒe siwo nuwo xaxa ɖo le amipɔmpigakpowo me gɔ̃ hã. Eye ne tomemikuƒe siwo wotu ɖe atsiaƒu me ƒe sɔtiwo ƒe akpa aɖe fe vie gɔ̃ hã la, ade dzesii.

The dolphin-inspired sonar should enhance the range of data that can be collected by current sonar devices, helping technicians to place underwater equipment in the best location, detect any damage to it​ such as hairline cracks in oil-rig support legs​ and even find blockages in pipelines.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ƒumeha ƒe dzesidede nu ƒe ŋutetea dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the bottlenose dolphin’s sonar come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ɣletivi Ƒe Ŋuti Katã Nye "Ŋku "
The "Seeing " Skeleton of the Brittle Star
NU ÐEDZESI aɖe le ɣletivi sia si nɔa adzakpowo me le atsiaƒu me la ƒe ŋuti katã.
THE reef-dwelling brittle star has an amazing form of armor on its upper surface.
Gadaglamakui siwo womate ŋu akpɔ kple ŋku ƒuƒlu o la le ɣletivi sia ƒe ŋuti katã, eye esia wɔe be eŋuti katã zu ŋku ƒokpli ɖeka.
This part of its skeleton is studded with microscopic lenses that turn the animal’s armor into a compound eye.
Nu lɛlɛlɛ siwo me dza siwo le ɣletivi ƒe ŋuti la nye gadaglamakui suesuesue siwo de ŋgɔ sãsãsã
Crystalline bumps on the skeleton serve as high-quality microlenses

Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Esi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo lé ŋku ɖe ɣletivi sia ŋu la, wokpɔe be "nu lɛlɛlɛ gbogbo aɖewo siwo me dza, eye woƒe titrime mede amegbetɔ ƒe taɖa nu o la le eŋuti katã le ɖoɖo tɔxɛ aɖe nu. "

Consider: When scientists examined the skeletal plates of the brittle star, they saw "an unusual pattern of densely packed, crystal-clear bumps, each thinner than a human hair, " says the magazine Natural History.
(Natural History) Nu suesuesue (calcium carbonate) siawo siwo me dza la nye gadaglamakui siwo de ŋgɔ sãsãsã, eye woklẽna ɖe lãmeka siwo xɔa kekeli siwo le ɣletivia ƒe ayi te tututu la dzi.
These crystalline bumps, made of calcium carbonate (calcite), proved to be high-quality microlenses that focus light onto what seem to be photosensitive nerves just below the plates.
Gawu la, gadaglamakuiawo le nɔnɔme si sɔ me si wɔe be lãvi sia tea ŋu kpɔa nuwo nyuie.
Moreover, the lenses have the exact shape needed to produce the desired image.

Atikedokpɔla Joanna Aizenberg gblɔ be ale si tsro si le ɣletivi ƒomevi sia ŋuti tea ŋu wɔa dɔ ƒomevi eve la "ɖo kpe gɔmeɖose vevi sia dzi be, le nu gbagbe ŋutinunya me zi geɖe la, ele be woatrɔ asi le nuwo ŋu hafi wòate ŋu awɔ dɔ vovovowo. "
According to chemist Joanna Aizenberg, the brittle star’s dual-purpose shell "demonstrates an important principle: in biology, materials are often optimized for multiple functions. "
Nu siwo numekulawo srɔ̃ tso ɣletivi ƒomevi sia ŋu la na wote ŋu to mɔnu bɔbɔe si melɔ ga geɖe zazã ɖe eme o la dzi zã calcium carbonate tsɔ wɔ gadaglamakui suesuesue vovovowo.
Taking a lesson from the biology of the brittle star, researchers have devised a simple, low-cost method of producing arrays of microlenses made of calcium carbonate.
Mɔ vovovo siwo nu wozãa ɣletivi ƒomevi sia ƒe ŋutete sia le dometɔ ɖekae nye nyatakakaxɔmɔnu, si me wozã elektrikka si me keklẽ tona bɔbɔe le.
The many applications of these arrays include telecommunications, where they are used to conduct light signals through optical fibers.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si ɣletivi ƒomevi sia ƒe ŋuti katã nye "ŋku " la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the "seeing " skeleton of the brittle star come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ƒumenugbagbevi Siwo Ðea Mɔ̃memi Ða Le Tsi Me
Microorganisms That Break Down Oil
LE ƑE 2010 me la, mɔ̃memikuƒe aɖe si wotu ɖe atsiaƒu me le Mexico la wó, eye mɔ̃memi lita 476,961,885 kple edzivɔwo ɖuɖu ɖe atsiaƒu me.
IN 2010, almost five million barrels (800 million L) of crude oil leaked into the Gulf of Mexico after a drilling rig exploded and sank.
Gake le dzinu ʋɛ aɖewo megbe la, mɔ̃memi ƒe ɖiƒoƒo aɖeke meganɔ tsia me o.
Yet, within months much of the contamination had disappeared.
Aleke wòdzɔe?
How was that possible?
Ƒumenugbagbevi siwo ɖea mɔ̃memi ɖa le tsi me
Microbes that break down oil
Bu esia ŋu kpɔ: Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ku nu me kpɔe be ƒumenugbagbevi suesue aɖewo tea ŋu ɖea nu si woyɔna be karbɔn si nɔa mɔ̃memi me la ɖa.
Consider: Scientific research has shown that an array of marine bacteria can break down the long-chain carbon molecules present in oil.
Nufialagã Terry Hazen, si nye nugbagbevi suewo ŋuti nunyala gblɔ le nugbagbevi suesue siawo ŋu be wonye "aʋawɔnu siwo wɔa avu kple mɔ̃memi. "
Professor Terry Hazen, an environmental microbiologist, described these organisms as "oil-seeking missiles. "
Nugbagbevi siawo hã wɔ akpa aɖe hafi atsiaƒua me gakɔ le Mexico.
Such organisms were partly responsible for what took place in the Gulf of Mexico, as described at the outset.
Esi nyatakakadɔwɔƒe si nye BBC nɔ nya ta kam tso ale si wòdzɔe ŋu la, egblɔ be: "Le mɔ aɖe nu la, mewɔ nuku be nugbagbevi siwo tea ŋu ɖea mɔ̃memi ɖa la le atsiaƒu me o. "
"In a sense, it is no surprise that the seas should host oil-hungry microbes, " says a BBC report on the topic.
Egblɔ yi edzi be ƒe akpe geɖewoe nye esia "ami sina tsoa atsiaƒu gɔme gena ɖe tsiawo me. "
After all, "natural seeps from the ocean floor have been releasing oil into the world’s waters " for aeons.
Ele eme be amegbetɔwo hã tea ŋu wɔa wo tɔ sinua ɖea ami siwo ɖuɖuna ɖe tsiwo me ya.
Granted, human efforts in cleaning oil spills are productive.
Gake nu siwo amegbetɔwo ƒe agbagbadzedze siawo gblẽna la sɔa gbɔ wu nu nyui siwo doa go tsoa eme.
Yet, man’s best efforts to clean up oil spills may do more harm than good.
Atike siwo amegbetɔwo zãna wɔnɛ be dzɔdzɔmenu siwo ɖea amiwo ɖa le tsi me la megatea ŋu wɔa woƒe dɔwo nyuie o.
Chemical dispersants interfere with natural processes that break down oil.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, atike mawo siwo nye aɖi la gblẽa nu le nutoa me ŋu eteƒe didina.
Added to that, such chemicals are toxic and have lasting ill effects on the environment.

Gake dzɔdzɔmenu siwo ɖea amiwo ɖa le atsiaƒu me siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ƒumenugbagbevi siawo ya kpena ɖe atsiaƒua ŋu wòɖea ɖinuwo ɖa le eɖokui si evɔ megblẽa naneke le nutoa me ŋu abe ale si wònɔna le atike siwo amegbetɔwo zãna ya gome ene o.
But nature’s oil-decomposing capacity, including oil-hungry microbes, enables the sea to activate a self-cleansing process without the negative side effects of artificial methods.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si ƒumenugbagbevi mawo tea ŋu ɖea mɔ̃memi ɖa le atsiaƒu me la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the oil-devouring property of marine microorganisms come about by chance?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Xeviwo Ƒe Aʋala Nugbɔ
The Upturned Wing Tip of Soaring Birds
YAMEƲU si le yame la ƒe aʋala nugbɔ nana ya trona abe yali ene.
A JET plane in flight creates rapidly spiraling swirls of air at the tips of its wings.
Ne ya le totrom alea la, edoa kplamatsɛ yameʋua ƒe duƒuƒu si wɔnɛ be wònoa ami geɖe.
These vortices cause drag, increasing fuel consumption.
Eye ne yameʋu bubu aɖe kplɔ yameʋu si le ŋgɔa ɖo tututu la, ya si le totrom le gbãtɔa megbe la doa kplamatsɛ eya hã vevie.
They also buffet planes that may be following closely.
Eya ta ne ehiã be yameʋu eve nato yameʋudzeƒea ƒe mɔ gbadza ɖeka dzi aho eye gbãtɔ ho la, woɖea mɔ ɣeyiɣi aɖe va yina ale be ya si le totrom le gbãtɔa megbe la nu natsi hafi evelia naho.
Thus, flights departing from the same runway must be sufficiently spaced to allow time for the vortices to dissipate.
Yameʋuwɔlawo va ke ɖe nu si woawɔ atsɔ aɖe kuxiawo dzi akpɔtɔ la ŋu.
Airplane engineers have discovered a way to reduce these problems.
Nu ka nue woke ɖo?
Their solution?
Wosrɔ̃ esia tso ale si fu siwo le xeviwo, abe hɔ̃ kple damixe ene, ƒe aʋalawo ƒe nugbɔ fɔna ɖe dzi la me.
Winglets, inspired by the upturned wing-tip feathers of soaring birds, such as buzzards, eagles, and storks.
Yameʋu ƒe aʋala ƒe nugbɔ
An airplane winglet
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Ne xevi gã siawo le agba sam le yame la, fu siwo le woƒe aʋalawo nugbɔ nɔa fɔfɔm ɖe dzi kaka va dzɔna kã.
Consider: During flight, the feathers on the wing tips of those large birds bend upward until they are almost vertical.
Esia wɔnɛ be xevi siawo tea ŋu yia yame nyuie togbɔ be woƒe aʋalawo medidi o hã.
This configuration balances maximum lift with minimum wing length.
Enana hã be wodzona nyuie.
It also improves performance.
Yameʋuwɔlawo wɔ yameʋu siwo ƒe aʋalawo nugbɔ dzɔ kã abe xevi siawo tɔ tea ŋu dzɔna ene.
Engineers have designed airplane wings with a similar shape.

Esi woku nu me tso ŋusẽ si ya kpɔna ɖe yameʋu dzi le yame ŋu la, wokpɔe be ne wotrɔ asi le yameʋu ƒe aʋala nugbɔwo ŋu hebi wo ɖe dzidze aɖe koŋ nu eye wosɔ ɖe ale si ya le ƒoƒom nu la, ana yameʋuawo nadzo nyuie wu. Eye egbea la, asitɔtrɔ sia na be ale si yameʋuwo dzona la ganyo ɖe edzi teƒe 10 le alafa me alo wu nenema gɔ̃ hã.

Using innovative wind-tunnel testing, they found that if the modified wings were precisely curved at the tip and properly aligned with the airflow, they improved aircraft performance nowadays by up to 10 percent or more.
Nu ka tae?
The reason?
Aʋalawo ƒe nugbɔwo ɖea ale si ya doa kplamatsɛ yameʋuwo ƒe duƒuƒu la dzi kpɔtɔna.
Winglets minimize drag by reducing the size of the vortices.
Gawu la, wonana be ŋutete tɔxɛ aɖe ɖoa yameʋuwo ŋu "wotsɔ nɔa te ɖe ya ƒe kplamatsɛdonu bubuwo hã nu. " Encyclopedia of Flight.
Moreover, winglets also create a form of thrust that "counteracts some of the normal drag of the airplane, " says the Encyclopedia of Flight.

Yameʋu ƒe aʋala nugbɔ siwo dzɔ kã nana be yameʋuwo tea ŋu dzona yia didiƒe, wotsɔa agba geɖe wu tsã, woƒe aʋalawo va le kpuie wu, esia nana be wotea ŋu kpɔa dzeƒe na yameʋu geɖe le yameʋudzeƒea, eye womegazãa ami geɖe hã o.
Winglets thus enable airplanes to fly farther, carry a greater load, have shorter wings which also facilitates parking and save fuel.
NASA dɔwɔƒea ka nya ta be le ƒe 2010 me la, ami siwo yameʋuwo zã la "dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ lita miliɔn 7,600 sɔŋ " eye esia na hã be ya ƒoɖi siwo yameʋuwo tuna ɖe yame la dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ ale gbegbe.
In 2010, for example, airlines "saved 2 billion gallons [7,600 million L] of jet fuel worldwide " and contributed to large reductions in aircraft emissions, says a NASA news release.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si xevi ƒe aʋala nugbɔ tea ŋu dzɔna kã la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the upturned wing tip of soaring birds come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ƒumexegã Ƒe Fuwo
The Emperor Penguin’s Feather Coat
XE SIA ƒua tsi sesĩe nukutɔe hetia kpo va dzea keke sno babla dzi ke.
THE emperor penguin can jet through the water and leap onto an ice shelf at an amazing speed. How?
Aleke wòtea ŋu dzɔnɛ?
Emperor penguin feather
Ƒumexegã ƒe fu Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Ƒumexegã (emperor penguin alo manchot empereur) sia lɔa ya ɖe eƒe fuwo me.
Consider: The emperor penguin traps air in its feathers.
Ya sia wɔnɛ be fafa melénɛ o, eye wòkpena ɖe eŋu hã be wòtea ŋu ƒua tsi zi gbɔ zi eve alo etɔ̃ wu ale si wòaƒui yaa manɔmee. Aleke wòtea ŋu wɔnɛ?
Not only does this insulate the bird against extreme cold but it also enables it to move two or three times faster than it otherwise could.
Ƒumexewo ŋuti nunyala aɖe gblɔ be anɔ eme be ewɔa esia to asiɖeɖe le ya siwo wòlɔ la ŋu vivivi to eƒe fuwo me.
How? Marine biologists have suggested that it does so by releasing tiny air bubbles from between its feathers.
Ya siawo ƒe dodo nana be nu siwo awɔe be eƒe fuwo mate ŋu ato tsia me bɔbɔe o la dzi ɖena kpɔtɔna si wɔnɛ be wòtea ŋu ƒua tsia kabakaba.
As these bubbles are released, they reduce friction on the surface of the penguin’s plumage, enabling the bird to accelerate.
Dzidzɔtɔe la, mɔɖaŋununyalawo le nu srɔ̃m tso mɔnu aɖe si dzi woato awɔ do suesuesue siwo me ya anɔ totom anɔ dodom la ɖe meli ŋu si ana wòate ŋu aƒu du sesĩe kplamatsɛdonu aɖeke manɔmee.
Interestingly, engineers have been studying ways to make ships go faster by using bubbles to reduce friction against their hulls.
Ke hã numekulawo lɔ ɖe edzi be yewomete ŋu le kekem ɖe mɔnu sia ŋu o, elabena "asesẽ be amegbetɔwo nawɔ nane si me do suesuesuewo anɔ abe ƒumexegã ƒe fuwo tɔ ene. "
However, researchers acknowledge that further investigation is challenging because "the complexity of penguin plumage would be difficult to replicate in a man-made porous membrane or mesh. "
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ƒumexegã ƒe fuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui sia?
Did the emperor penguin’s feather coat come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Ale Si Ƒudzixe Albatross Saa Agba Ŋusẽ Boo Mazamazãe
The Energy-Efficient Flight of the Wandering Albatross
XEVI aɖewo tea ŋu saa agba le yame ŋusẽ boo mazamazãe.
BIRDS that soar can stay airborne with minimum effort.
Ƒudzixe si woyɔna be albatross nye esia ƒe kpɔɖeŋu ɖedzesi.
The wandering albatross is an outstanding example.
Xevi sia ƒe kpekpeme ade kilogram 8.5 eye ƒe aʋala ƒe kekeme nye meta 3.4. Etea ŋu dzona kilometa akpe geɖe ŋusẽ boo mazamazãe!
With a wingspan of 11 feet (3.4 m) and weighing nearly 20 pounds (8.5 kg), this bird can fly thousands of miles using very little energy!
Eƒe wɔwɔme kple ŋutete si wòzãna ne ele dzodzom la gbɔe wòtsona be wòtea ŋu saa agba bɔbɔe nenema.
Its secret lies in both its anatomy and its soaring technique.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Ne albatross le dzodzom eye wòkeke aʋala me keŋkeŋ la, eƒe kpeƒetsiaka tɔxɛ aɖe va glãa eƒe aʋalawo eye womegaƒona o, si wɔnɛ be eƒe lãkusiwo ɖina ɖe eme.
Consider: During flight, an albatross engages special tendons that lock its wings in place when fully extended, thus allowing the muscles to rest.
Nu evelia si kpena ɖe ƒudzixe sia ŋu wòtea ŋu saa agba le atsiaƒu dzi gaƒoƒo geɖe lae nye ale si wòtea ŋu nyaa afi si ƒudziyawo ɖo tae.
The bird’s other secret how it soars hour after hour involves its mastery of oceanic winds.
Ne albatross le agba sam le ƒua dzi la, eyia yame ʋĩ, trɔna heɖiɖina vaa anyime, enɔa esia wɔm enuenu, eye nu sia wɔwɔ nana wògakpɔa ŋusẽ si wòzã esime wòdzo kpe ƒudziya la.
At sea, albatrosses climb, turn, and descend in continually repeated arcs a maneuver that gives the birds enough momentum to compensate for that lost through drag.
Nyitsɔ laa ko hafi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va ke ɖe nu si kpena ɖe ƒudzixe sia ŋu wòtea ŋu wɔa nu sia la ŋu.
Only recently did scientists figure out how the birds are able to do this.
Wozã mɔ̃ deŋgɔwo kple kɔmpiutaɖoɖo tɔxɛwo tsɔ kpɔe be ne albatross dzo yi yame hetrɔ be yeaɖiɖi lae wòkpɔa ŋusẽ si wòhiã.

Using high-resolution tracking devices and special computer software, they found that albatrosses gain the needed energy when they wheel from windward (into the wind) to leeward in the upper part of the flight curve.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔ be ƒudzixe sia "nɔa ŋusẽ si wòtsɔ saa agbae la kpɔm blewu eye wòyia edzi ɖaa. "
"The extraction of energy " is "smooth and continuous, " state the scientists.
Nu kae dona tso eme?
The result?
Xe sia tea ŋu dzona gaƒoƒo geɖe aʋalamaƒomaƒoe!
The bird can soar for hours on end without a single flap of its wings!
Nu sia nyanya tso xevi sia ŋu ate ŋu akpe ɖe mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo ŋu be woawɔ yameʋu siwo mazã ami boo o, ɖewohĩ yameʋu siwo mahiã be woazã mɔ̃ hafi aku wo o.
These insights may help engineers design aerial vehicles that are more fuel efficient, perhaps even using engineless propulsion.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si albatross saa agba le atsiaƒu dzi ŋusẽ boo mazamazãe kple eƒe wɔwɔme tɔxɛ la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the energy-efficient flight of the albatross, as well as its specialized anatomy, come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Bar-Tailed Godwit Xe Dzodzoea Ƒe Ŋutete Tɔxɛ La
The Bar-Tailed Godwit’s Navigational System
DZODZO ƒe ŋutete tɔxɛ si le bar-tailed godwit si la wɔa nuku na ame geɖe ŋutɔ.
THE bar-tailed godwit makes one of the most amazing migrations known to man.
Elabena xevi sia tea ŋu dzona kilometa 11,000 sɔŋ, si xɔa ŋkeke enyi kple edzivɔ.
The bird’s 7,000-mile (11,000 km) journey can take more than eight days.
De Ŋugble Tso Eŋu: Numekulawo gblɔ be anyigba ƒe nuheŋusẽe kpena ɖe xevi aɖewo ŋu wote ŋu dzona le mɔ tɔxɛ siawo nu. Wowɔa nu abe ɖe wowɔ taɖoƒefianu de woƒe ahɔhɔ̃ me ene.
Consider: Researchers speculate that some types of birds use the earth’s magnetic field for navigation, as if they had a compass built into their brain.
Anɔ eme hã be godwit xevia zãna ɣe ƒe keklẽ le ŋkeke me, kple ɣletiviwo ƒe keklẽ le zã me tsɔ fiaa mɔ eɖokui.
It is possible that the godwit additionally navigates by means of the sun by day and the stars by night.
Ewɔ abe xevi sia nyana ne ya sesẽ aɖe ƒo gbɔna ene, eye wònana yaƒoƒoa kpena ɖe eŋu wòdzona yia afi si yim wòle.
It seems that the godwit can also sense upcoming storm systems that could allow it to benefit from tailwinds.
Dzodzo ƒe ŋutete tɔxɛ si le xevi siawo si la kpɔtɔ wɔa nuku na xe dzodzoe ŋuti ŋunyalawo kokoko.
Still, the details of just how these birds make their incredible journey baffle experts.
Nugbagbeŋutinunyala Bob Gill gblɔ be: "Ƒe 20 enye esia si mele nu srɔ̃m tso xevi siawo ŋu gake woƒe nuwɔna kpɔtɔ wɔa nuku nam kokoko. "
"I’ve been studying them 20 years, " says biologist Bob Gill, "and it’s still jaw-dropping to me. "
Nu Kae Nèsusu?
What Do You Think?
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie dzodzo ƒe ŋutete tɔxɛ si le xevi sia si la to va dzɔa?
Did the navigational system of the bar-tailed godwit come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Adoglo Si Ŋuti Ŋùwo Le Si Hea Tsi Toa Eƒe Ŋutigbalẽ Ŋu
The Thorny Devil Lizard’s Moisture-Extracting Skin
AUSTRALIATƆWO ƒe adoglo aɖe si ŋuti ŋùwo le la hea tsi tsoa afu, yame ƒe fafa kple ke si me tsi le la me.
THE Australian thorny devil lizard (Moloch horridus) extracts moisture from fog, humidity, and wet sand.
Emegbe enana tsia tsana toa eŋuti yia eƒe nu me wònona.
Then it channels the water to its mouth for drinking.
Aleke wòwɔa esiae?
How?
Anye be ale si eƒe ŋutigbalẽ wɔa dɔ nukutɔe la gbɔe wòtso.
The answer may lie in the lizard’s amazing skin.
Nutata si ɖe ale si ʋeawo le le adogloa ŋuti keŋ fia
Sketches that show grooves on the surface of the thorny devil lizard’s skin
Ʋe siwo le eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋu la de nu wo nɔewo me va do ɖe pɔmpi aɖewo ƒomevi me le ʋeawo te ale be tsi toa pɔmpiawo me le eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋu va gena ɖe eƒe nu me
Grooves on the surface of the skin are connected to a network of channels below the skin so that water is directed to the sides of the thorny devil’s mouth
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Tsro ƒlatsawo le adoglo sia ŋu keŋ.
Consider: The thorny devil’s skin is overlaid with scales.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala aɖewo susui be ne tsi alo ahũ ge ɖe eƒe tsroa dzi la, etsana yia eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu eye wògena ɖe ʋe aɖewo siwo le tsroawo dome la me.

Some scientists think that moisture or dew collected on the scales runs down to the rough surface of the skin and enters the skin’s network of half-open channels, or grooves, located between the scales.
Ʋe siawo siwo le eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu la de nu wo nɔewo me vae do ɖe eƒe nu me.
These channels are interconnected and lead to the sides of the thorny devil’s mouth.
Gake aleke wòdzɔnae be adoglo sia hea tsi yia dzi toa eƒe atawo kple ŋutigbalẽa ŋu yia eƒe nu me, evɔ tsia mekɔna ɖe anyi o?
But how does this lizard draw up water up its legs, across its body, and into its mouth defying gravity in the process?
Aleke wòdzɔnae be adoglo sia tea ŋu hea tsi tsoa ke siwo me tsi le la me ne etiti eƒe ƒodo ɖe kea me ko?
And how does the thorny devil extract moisture from wet surfaces by rubbing its belly against them?
Numekulawo ke ɖe nu siwo nana wòtea ŋu wɔnɛ alea la ŋu.
Researchers have apparently unveiled the thorny devil’s secret.
Wode dzesii be pɔmpi tɔgbi aɖewo ƒomevi le ʋeawo te le eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋu.
The channels on the surface of the skin are connected by way of ducts to another network of channels below, that is, within the lizard’s skin.
Pɔmpi siawo mee tsiawo tona le eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋu yia eƒe nu me abe ale si ko tsi toa pɔmpi siwo amegbetɔwo wɔ me yia dzi bɔbɔe ene.
The structure of these channels enables capillary action a phenomenon in which water is drawn into narrow spaces even against the force of gravity.
Eya ta adoglo sia ƒe ŋutigbalẽ le abe papahũ si noa tsi ene.
The lizard’s skin thus acts as a sponge.

Aƒenɔ Janine Benyus, ame si nye dɔwɔƒe si kpɔa dzɔdzɔmenuwo dzi hewɔa wo tɔgbi la ƒe tatɔ gblɔ be mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo ate ŋu akpɔ ale si adoglo sia hea tsi toa eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu dzi awɔ mɔ̃ aɖe si aɖe dzoxɔxɔ ɖa le yame ale be xɔwo me nate ŋu afa, eye woakpɔ tsinono hã tso esia me.

Janine Benyus, president of the Biomimicry Institute, says that mimicking moisture-extracting technologies may help engineers design a system to remove humidity from air in order to cool buildings more efficiently and also to obtain drinking water.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si adoglo sia ƒe ŋutigbalẽ tea ŋu hea tsi la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the moisture-extracting skin of the thorny devil come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Adoglo Ƒe Asike
The Tail of the Agama Lizard
ADOGLO tea ŋu tia kpo tso teƒe gbadza ɖakuna ɖe gli ŋu bɔbɔe.
THE agama jumps from a horizontal surface onto a vertical wall with ease.
Gake ne teƒea zrɔ̃ la, adogloa ƒe afɔwo ɖiɖina, ke hã etea ŋu tia kpo kuna ɖe glia ŋu dzidzedzetɔe.
But if that surface is slippery, the lizard loses its footing, yet it still makes a successful landing on the wall.
Aleke wòwɔnɛ?
How?
Eƒe asikea ye wòzãna.
The secret is in the lizard’s tail.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Ne teƒe si adogloa ti kpo tso la le glidzaglidza la, eƒe afɔwo lia anyi nyuie, eya ta ɖeko wòdzɔa eɖokui heɖiɖia eƒe asike vaa anyi me hetia kpo.
Consider: When agamas jump from a coarse surface which provides grip they first stabilize their body and keep their tail downward.
Esia wɔnɛ be wòtea ŋu trɔna nyuie le ya me.
This helps them to jump at the correct angle.
Gake ne afi si wòti kpo tso la zrɔ̃ la, eƒe afɔwo ɖiɖina, si wɔnɛ be metea ŋu trɔna nyuie le ya me o.
When on a slippery surface, though, the lizards tend to stumble and jump at the wrong angle.
Gake ne ele ya me la, ekɔa eƒe asike yia dzi, si wɔnɛ be wòdzɔna nyuie.
However, in midair, they correct the angle of their body by flicking their tail upward.
Ale si nɔnɔmea le la nue wòtrɔa asikea ɖo.
The process is intricate.
Le California Yunivɛsiti si le Berkeley ƒe nyatakaka nu la, "adogloa mate ŋu adzɔ eɖokui le ya me o, negbe ɖeko wòle eƒe asikea trɔm nyuie ale si dze. "
"Lizards must actively adjust the angle of their tails just right to remain upright, " says a report released by the University of California, Berkeley.
Ale si gbegbe wòdoa eƒe asikea ɖe dzii la nɔa te ɖe teƒea ƒe zɔzrɔ̃ dzi. Aleae wòwɔna be wòtea ŋu dzea glia ŋu dedie.
The more slippery the platform, the more the lizard must raise its tail to ensure a safe landing.
Nusɔsrɔ̃ tso adoglo ƒe asike ŋu ate ŋu akpe ɖe mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo ŋu woawɔ robot siwo mamu adze anyi bɔbɔe o, siwo woate ŋu atsɔ adi agbetsilawo le anyigbaʋuʋu alo afɔku bubu aɖe dzɔdzɔ vɔ megbe.
The agama’s tail may help engineers design more-agile robotic vehicles that can be used to search for survivors in the aftermath of an earthquake or other catastrophe.
Numekula Thomas Libby gblɔ be: "Le kelili gome la, lãwo de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu robotwo, eya ta nu sia nu si ate ŋu ana robotwo nali ke wu la nye ŋgɔyiyi. "
"Robots are not nearly as agile as animals, " says researcher Thomas Libby, "so anything that can make a robot more stable is an advancement. "
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe adoglo ƒe asike la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the agama’s tail come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Lo Ƒe Glã
The Crocodile’s Jaw
LO ƑE glã sesẽ wu lã siwo katã li tɔ.
THE crocodile has the most powerful bite ever measured for animals that are now living.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, tɔmelo si le Australia lɔƒo tea ŋu ɖua nu siwo sesẽ zigbɔzi etɔ̃ wu esiwo dzatawo alo kpɔ̃wo tea ŋu ɖuna.
For example, the saltwater crocodile, found near Australia, can bite nearly three times as hard as a lion or a tiger.
Gake nukutɔe, ne lo ɖo aɖu nuwo dzi la, etea ŋu dea vovototo wo me, eye eƒe ŋutete sia wu ale si amegbetɔwo ƒe asibidɛnu tea ŋu nana wonyaa nu siwo ŋu woka asii la gɔ̃ hã.
Yet, the crocodile’s jaw is also incredibly sensitive to touch even more sensitive than the human fingertip.
Aleke wòwɔa esiae esi eƒe ŋuti le ƒlatsaa nenema gbegbe?
How can that be, considering the crocodile’s armored skin?
Lãmenusenu akpe geɖewo le lo ƒe glã ŋu.
The crocodile’s jaw is covered with thousands of sense organs.
Esi numekula Duncan Leitch ku nu me tso lo ƒe glã ŋu megbe la, egblɔ be: "Lãmeka wluiwluiwluiwo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe nugbɔ le do aɖe si le eƒe tago me la me. "
After studying them, researcher Duncan Leitch noted: "Each of the nerve endings comes out of a hole in the skull. "
Esia kpɔa lãmeka siwo le eƒe glã ŋu la ta eye wònana hã be eƒe aɖu dea vovototo nuwo me. Ale si wòtea ŋu dea vovototo nuwo me nu sẽ le eƒe teƒe aɖewo ale gbegbe be womate ŋu atsɔ mɔ̃ adzidzee o.
This arrangement protects the nerve fibers in the jaw while providing sensitivity that in some spots is greater than instruments could measure.
Esia wɔe be ne nane le nu me na lo la, etea ŋu nyana nenye nuɖuɖue loo alo nu bubu aɖee.
As a result, the crocodile can distinguish between food and debris in its mouth.
Esia ke tae ne lonɔ kɔ via ɖe nu me la, etea ŋu nyana be ye vie eye meɖunɛ o.
That is also how a mother crocodile can carry her hatchlings in her mouth without accidentally crushing them.
Ŋusẽ le lo ƒe glã kple eƒe aɖuwo ŋu, gake etea ŋu dea vovototo nuwo me hã.
The crocodile’s jaw is a surprising combination of power and sensitivity.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe lo ƒe glã la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the crocodile’s jaw come about by evolution?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Akpɔkplɔ Ƒomevi Aɖe Ƒe Viƒoƒo
The Gastric Brooding Frog’s Reproductive System
AUSTRALIATƆWO ƒe akpɔkplɔ ƒomevi aɖe si wosusu be enu yi keŋkeŋ le keke ƒe 2002 me ke la, ƒe viƒoƒo wɔ moya ŋutɔ.
THE Australian gastric brooding frog, thought to be extinct since 2002, had a bizarre means of reproduction.
Akpɔkplɔnɔa mia azi siwo wòɖa la eye wonɔa eƒe dɔ me abe kwasiɖa ade ene.
The female swallowed her fertilized eggs and incubated her young in her stomach for about six weeks.
Aziawo ƒona le dɔa me hezua akpɔkplɔ keŋ hafi doa go tso eƒe nu me.
Her babies later emerged from her mouth as fully developed frogs.
Be akpɔkplɔnɔ sia ƒe dɔgbo magatu aziawo o la, edzudzɔa nuɖuɖu eye veve megadzana ɖe eƒe dɔgbo me hã o.
To keep from digesting her eggs, it was necessary that the mother frog not only stop eating but also stop producing stomach acid.
Eme kɔ ƒãa be aziawo kple akpɔkplɔviawo ƒe lãmetsi aɖewoe xea mɔ na vevea be magadza o.
Evidently, chemicals released by the eggs and hatchlings inhibited the production of acid.
Akpɔkplɔnɔa mia azi siwo ade 24.
The mother would brood about two dozen eggs.
Kaka eƒe vidziɣi naɖo la, akpɔkplɔvi siwo katã le eƒe dɔ me la ƒe kpekpeme dea akpɔkplɔnɔa ƒe kpekpeme ƒe afã kloe.
By the time she gave birth, her young could make up almost 40 percent of her total body weight.
Esia le ko abe nyɔnu aɖe si ƒe kpekpeme nye kilogram 68 do ŋgɔ na eƒe fufɔfɔ. Esi wòfɔ fu la, vi 24 ye le dɔ me nɛ eye ɖe sia ɖe ƒe kpekpeme nye kilogram 1.8!
This would be like a woman who weighed 150 pounds (68 kg) before she became pregnant carrying 24 babies weighing four pounds (1.8 kg) each!
Ale si akpɔkplɔviawo sɔ gbɔ le wo dada ƒe dɔ me la nana eƒe ƒodo vuna gblotoo ale gbegbe be eƒe dzitodzito miana henana gbɔgbɔ zua dɔ nɛ eye esia wɔnɛ be wògbɔna to eƒe ŋutigbalẽ me.
The young frogs stretched the mother’s stomach to the point that it completely compressed her lungs, forcing her to breathe through her skin.
Zi geɖe la, akpɔkplɔviawo dona le eƒe nu me ne wotsi le ŋkeke aɖewo megbe.
The baby frogs would normally emerge over a period of days as they became ready.
Ke ne wo dada kpɔ be afɔku aɖe gbɔna la, etua wo to eƒe nu me.
If the mother sensed danger, though, she would give birth by vomiting them out.
Gbe ɖeka la, numekulawo ke ɖe akpɔkplɔnɔ aɖe ŋu wòtu akpɔkplɔvi ade zi ɖeka eye woyi yame abe meta ɖeka ene.
Researchers once observed a female expel six young frogs together, shooting them about 40 inches (1 m) in the air.
Ke hã, ame aɖewo gblɔna be ɖe akpɔkplɔ ƒomevi sia ƒe viƒoƒo alo vidzidzi mɔnu sia dzɔ le eɖokui si. Ne ele nenema la, ke ele be tɔtrɔ ɖedzesiwo nava le eƒe agbenɔnɔ kple eƒe wɔwɔme ŋu zi ɖeka kpata.
If, as some claim, its reproductive system evolved, the gastric brooding frog would have had to make vast changes to both its physical makeup and its behavior all at once.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala kple nɔnɔmetɔtrɔfiala Michael J. Tyler gblɔ be: "Mate ŋu adzɔ be akpɔkplɔ sia ƒe viƒoƒo alo vidzidzi mɔnu nanɔ tɔtrɔm vivivi kaka ava zu abe ale si míenyae egbea ene o.
"It is inconceivable to contemplate a slow and progressive change in its reproductive biology, " wrote scientist and evolutionist Michael J. Tyler.
Ele be eƒe viƒomɔnu sia nadzɔ kple akpɔkplɔa tso gɔmedzedzea ne menye nenem o la, ke manya wɔ kura o. "
"The habit is totally effective or it fails completely. "
Aƒetɔ Tyler yi edzi be numeɖeɖe ɖeka si me susu lee nye be viƒoƒomɔnu sia le akpɔkplɔa ŋu ‘tso eƒe dzɔdzɔme ke.’
The only plausible explanation, Tyler says, is "a single, huge, quantum step. "
Esia tae ame aɖewo ƒoa nya ta be ɖe wowɔe.
Some would say that such a quantum step is called creation.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si akpɔkplɔ sia ƒoa vi la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the reproductive system of the gastric brooding frog come about by evolution?

Or was it designed?
Da Ƒe Ŋutigbalẽ
Snake Skin
ESI wònye be ƒodo dzi ko da zɔna ɖo ta la, ele be eƒe ŋutigbalẽ nasesẽ ale be wòate ŋu ato afi sia afi dedie.
BECAUSE they move without limbs, snakes need robust skin that can withstand constant friction.
Da ƒomevi aɖewo lia ati siwo ŋuti le glidzaglidza, eye bubuwo hã ɖia wo ɖokuiwo ɖe ke me.
Some species climb up rough tree trunks, while others burrow into abrasive sand.
Nu kae na da ƒe ŋutigbalẽ sesẽna nenema gbegbe?
What makes the skin of a snake so durable?
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Dawo ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ƒe titrime kple wɔwɔme tea ŋu toa vovo na wo nɔewo tɔ.
Consider: The skin of snakes can differ in thickness and structure from one species to another.
Gake dawo katã ƒe ŋutigbalẽ sɔ le nu ɖeka ya gome: Eyae nye be woƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋuti sesẽna, gake etume nɔa bɔbɔm vivivi yina ɖe ememe.
However, the skin of all snakes has one thing in common: It is firm on the outside and becomes progressively softer toward the inside.
Vi kae esia ɖena?
Why is this advantageous?
Numekula Marie-Christin Klein gblɔ be: "Le nu siwo ƒe ŋuti sesẽ evɔ woƒe tume ya bɔbɔ gome la, ne nane ka wo ŋu alo va lɔ wo la, wotea ŋu maa vevesesea ɖe ŋutilã ƒe akpa geɖe sɔsɔe. "
"Material that has a transition from a stiff outside to a flexible inside can distribute an impacting force over a larger area, " says researcher Marie-Christin Klein.

Ale si da ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ƒe wɔwɔme le etɔxɛe la wɔe be etea ŋu lina ɖe anyigba nyuie eye wòtea ŋu zɔna bɔbɔe. Eye ne eto kpe glidzaglidza siwo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu dzi la, ŋutilã ƒe akpa si to edzi la maa vevesesea ɖe ŋutilã ƒe akpa bubuwo sɔsɔe, eye esia wɔnɛ be megblẽa nu le eƒe ŋutilã ŋu boo o.

The unique structure of snake skin allows sufficient traction between body and ground for the snake to be able to move, and at the same time, it evenly distributes pressure from sharp-edged stones so that there is less damage to the skin.
Esi wònye be exɔa ɣleti eve alo etɔ̃ hafi da ɖea tsro ta la, ehiã vevie be eƒe ŋutigbalẽ nasesẽ.
Durability is vital, since snakes usually shed their skin only every two to three months.
Nu siwo ƒe wɔwɔme le abe da ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ene ate ŋu aɖe vi ŋutɔ le atikewɔwɔ me.
Materials with the properties of snake skin may be useful in the field of medicine for example, in manufacturing slip-resistant and extra-durable artificial implants.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, woate ŋu azã aɖaŋu ma atsɔ awɔ amegbetɔ ƒe ŋutinu siwo asesẽ eye womate ŋu aɖe bɔbɔe o.
Also, drive and conveyor machinery that mimics the construction of snake skin may require fewer pollutive lubricants.
Woate ŋu azã da ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ƒe wɔwɔme hã ƒe aɖaŋu atsɔ awɔ akpa siwo troa mɔ̃wo abe gatekpa ene, si awɔe be mɔ̃memi, siwo ƒoa ɖi yame la, ƒe vi aɖe ko wòahiã be woazã.
What do you think?
Nu kae nèsusu?
Did snake skin come about by evolution?
Ðe da ƒe ŋutigbalẽ dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Or was it designed?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
The Landing Strategy of the Honeybee
Ale Si Anyi Wɔna Dzena Ðe Nu Dzi
HONEYBEES can safely land at virtually any angle without problems.
ANYI tea ŋu dzena ɖe teƒe ɖe sia ɖe dedie.
How do they do it?
Aleke wòwɔnɛ?
Consider: A safe landing requires that the honeybee reduce its approach speed to nearly zero before contact.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Be anyi nate ŋu adze ɖe nane dzi dedie la, ele be wòaɖiɖi du si wòtsɔ le dzodzom yina nua gbɔ la dzi akpɔtɔ keŋkeŋ.
One logical way to do this would be to measure two factors flight speed and the distance to the target and then reduce speed accordingly.

Be wòate ŋu awɔ esia la, ele be wòabu nu eve siawo ŋu gbãa, ele be wòabu ale si wòle dua ƒumee kple dometsotso si le eya kple nu si gbɔ yim wòle dome la ŋu eye wòaɖiɖi eƒe duƒuƒua wòasɔ ɖe dometsotsoa nu.
However, that method would be difficult for most insects because they have close-set, fixed-focus eyes that cannot directly measure distance.
Gake mɔnu sia asesẽ na nudzodzoe geɖe elabena woƒe ŋku metea ŋu dzidzia dometsotso si le woawo kple nu si dzi wodi be yewoadze ɖo la dome o.
The vision of honeybees is very different from that of humans who use binocular vision.
Ale si anyi kpɔa nui la to vovo na amegbetɔwo elabena amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋku evea siaae kpɔa nu.
Honeybees seem to use the simple fact that an object appears to get bigger as they approach it.
Edze abe ne anyi ya le tetem ɖe nane ŋu la nua nɔa lolom ɖe edzi ene.
The closer they get to an object, the faster it seems to increase in size.
Zi ale si wòle tetem ɖe nua ŋu la zi nenemae nua lolonae.
Experiments conducted at the Australian National University indicate that the honeybee decreases its flight speed so that the rate of apparent enlargement of an object remains constant.
Numekuku si wowɔ le Australia Dukɔa Ƒe Yunivɛsiti ɖee fia be anyi ɖiɖia du si wòtsɔ le dzodzom yina nane gbɔ kura be wòakpɔ nua ƒe lolome nyuie adze ɖe edzi.
By the time the honeybee reaches its target, its speed has decreased to almost zero, allowing it to land safely.

Kaka anyi naɖo nu si gbɔ yim wòle gbɔ la, eɖiɖia du si wòtsɔ le dzodzom la keŋkeŋ ale be wòate ŋu adze ɖe nua dzi dedie. Agbalẽ aɖe (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences) gblɔ be: "Ŋkuléle ɖe mɔnu si dzi anyi tona dzena ɖe nu dzi ŋu . . . [wɔe] be wowɔ nane de robɔtwo me be wòafia mɔ wo woate ŋu adzo nyuie. "

The journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences reports: "The simplicity and generality of this landing strategy . . . [make] it ideal for implementation in the guidance systems of flying robots. "
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe ale si anyi wɔna dzena ɖe nu dzi la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the honeybee’s landing strategy evolve?
Alo Wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?
Anyixe
The Honeycomb
ANYIWO zãa anyiŋe alo anyiŋɔ si dona ɖe woƒe ƒodo ŋu tsɔ wɔa anyixe alo anyigbà.
HONEYBEES (Apis mellifera) construct their honeycombs with wax secreted from glands found on the underside of their abdomen.
Wobua anyixea be enye aɖaŋunu wɔnuku aɖe ŋutɔ.
The honeycomb is regarded as an engineering marvel.
Nu ka tae?
Why?

Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ: Ƒe geɖewoe nye esia la, akɔntaŋutinunyalawo susunɛ be nu alo xɔ siwo ƒe nɔnɔme le dzogoe ade me nyo wu esiwo ƒe nɔnɔme le dzogoe etɔ̃, ene alo bubu ɖe sia ɖe me, elabena woate ŋu atu alo awɔ nu gbogbo aɖewo ɖe nɔnɔme sia me ɖe teƒe sue aɖe eye dɔwɔnu siwo woazã hã anɔ ʋɛe wu.

Consider: For centuries, mathematicians suspected that partitions in the shape of hexagons were better than equilateral triangles or squares​ or any other shape ​for maximizing space with the least amount of building material.
Ke hã, womete ŋu ɖe nu si tututu ta wogblɔ nenema ɖo la me o.
But they could not fully explain why.

Gake mlɔeba le ƒe 1999 me la, nufialagã Thomas C. Hales gblɔ kpeɖodzi siwo ŋu woke ɖo le akɔntaŋutinunya me si ɖe ale si nu siwo ƒe nɔnɔme le dzogoe ade me ɖea vi wu la fia hena ŋkɔe be "anyixe ƒe kpeɖodziwo. "
In 1999, Professor Thomas C. Hales provided mathematical proof for the advantage of what he termed "honeycomb conjecture. "
Eɖee fia be xɔwo kple nu bubuwo tutu woanɔ dzogoe ade me nye mɔ nyuitɔ si nu woama teƒewo ɖo pɛpɛpɛ evɔ womazã nu boo atsɔ alé wo ɖe te o.
He demonstrated that regular hexagons are the best way to divide a space into equal parts with minimal structural support.

Esi wònye be anyiwo wɔa woƒe anyixewo wonɔa dzogoe ade me ta la, wozãa teƒe siwo katã le wo si la nyuie, woƒe anyixea mekpena o evɔ wòhesẽna nyuie, womezãa anyiŋɔ fũu o, eye wotea ŋu ɖaa anyitsi gbogbo aɖe ɖe teƒe sue aɖe.

By using hexagonal cells, bees can make the best use of all the space available to them, produce a light but sturdy honeycomb with a minimum amount of wax, and store the maximum amount of honey in a given space.
Mewɔ nuku o be woyɔ anyixe be "aɖaŋunu deŋgɔ. "
Not surprisingly, the honeycomb has been described as "an architectural masterpiece. "
Egbea la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kpɔa anyixe ƒe wɔwɔme dzi tsɔ wɔa nu siwo sesẽ evɔ womexɔa teƒe fũu o.
Today, scientists mimic the bees’ honeycomb to create structures that are both resilient and space efficient.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, yameʋuwɔlawo wɔ yameʋu siwo ƒe nɔnɔme le dzogoe ade me abe anyixe ene. Yameʋuawo sesẽ eye womekpe hã o, eye esia wɔe be womenoa ami sɔgbɔ o.
Aircraft engineers, for example, use panels patterned after the honeycomb to build planes that are stronger and lighter and thus use less fuel.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe anyixe ƒe wɔwɔme deŋgɔ la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the superior structure of the honeycomb come about by evolution?

Anyidi Ƒe Kɔ
The Ant’s Neck
Anyidɔ tsɔ gbe ɖe nu
An ant carries foliage in its mouth
ALE SI anyidi tea ŋu kɔa nu siwo kpena wu eya ŋutɔ zi geɖe la wɔa nuku na mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔlawo ŋutɔ.
MECHANICAL ENGINEERS marvel at the ability of a common ant to lift weights many times heavier than its own body.
Be woate ŋu ase anyidi ƒe ŋutete sia gɔme la, mɔ̃ɖaŋudɔwɔla siwo le Amerika le Ohio Nutoa ƒe yunivɛsiti tsɔ kɔmpiuta wɔ nane si ɖi anyidi be wòawɔ nu pɛpɛpɛ abe anyidi ene.
To understand this ability, engineers at Ohio State University, U.S.A., reverse engineered some of the ant’s anatomy, physical properties, and mechanical functions by means of computer models.
X-ray fotoɖemɔ̃woe wozã tsɔ wɔ anyidi sia be woatsɔ akpɔ ŋusẽ si gbegbe anyidi zãna hafi tea ŋu kɔa agba kpekpewo.
The models were created using X-ray cross-sectional images (micro CT scans) and simulations of the forces an ant generates when carrying loads.
Anyidi ƒe kɔe nye eƒe ametia ƒe akpa vevi si kpena ɖe eŋu wòtea ŋu kɔa agba kpekpe ɖe nu.
A critical part of the ant’s anatomy is its neck, which has to bear the full weight of loads grasped in its mouth.
Lã falɛfalɛ siwo le anyidi ƒe kɔ ŋu la miãna ɖe eƒe ametia ƒe sesẽƒe kple eƒe ta ŋu wònɔna abe ale si wodea asi asitɛ me ene.
Soft tissues within the ant’s neck bind with the stiff exoskeleton of its thorax (body) and head in a manner that mimics the interlocking of fingers in folded hands.
Numekulawo dometɔ ɖeka gblɔ be: "Ale si kɔa va miãna ɖe taa kple eƒe ametia ƒe sesẽƒea ŋu hiã vevie ŋutɔ be kɔa nate ŋu awɔ eƒe dɔ.
"The design and structure of this interface is critical for the performance of the neck joint, " says one of the researchers.
Ðewohĩ ale si eƒe ametia ƒe akpa si bɔbɔ va miãna ɖe sesẽƒea ŋu lae nana be ŋusẽ nɔna eŋu be wòtsɔa agba siwo lolo wu eya ŋutɔ. "
"The unique interface between hard and soft materials likely strengthens the adhesion and may be a key structural design feature that enables the large load capacity of the neck joint. "
Numekulawo le mɔ kpɔm be ne yewova se ale si anyidi ƒe kɔ wɔa dɔe gɔme nyuie la, akpe ɖe yewo ŋu be yewoawɔ robɔt siwo gade ŋgɔ wu.
Researchers hope that a clear grasp of how the ant’s neck functions will contribute to advancements in the design of man-made robotic mechanisms.
Nu kae nèsusu?
What do you think?
Ðe anyidi ƒe kɔ wɔnuku la kple ale si wòwɔa dɔe la dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Did the ant’s neck with its complex and highly integrated mechanical systems evolve?
Alo wɔla lae wɔea?
Or was it designed?

Togbɔ be ame aɖewo bua tɔtrɔ siwo ate ŋu ava nuwɔwɔwo me ne wole tɔtrɔm ɖe nutoa me ƒe nɔnɔmewo ŋu be enye nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ hã la, menye nyateƒe o, elabe wometrɔna zua nu gbagbe yeye bubu sã o.
While some view such adaptations as a form of evolution, no new kind of life is produced.
Numekuku siwo wowɔ le míaƒe ŋkekea me la ɖo kpe edzi be atiwo kple lãwo metrɔ boo tso ale si wonɔ le blema gbɔ o.
Modern research supports the idea that the basic categories of plants and animals have changed little over vast periods of time.
ALEKE NYA SIA KA WÒ?
WHY IT MATTERS
Ale si Biblia ƒo nu tso nu gbagbe "hamehame " siwo wowɔ ŋu wòde pɛpɛpɛ la nana be míegakana ɖe edzi le go bubuwo me. Go siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ŋutinyawo kple nyagblɔɖi siwo le eme.
The Bible’s scientific accuracy in describing basic "kinds " of life strengthens its credibility in other areas, including history and prophecy.
Afi kae nu si wotsɔ wɔ xexeme gbahoo la tso?
Where did the raw material of the universe come from?
"Nye asie he dziƒo me. "
"I stretched out the heavens with my own hands. "
Yesaya 45:12.
Isaiah 45:12.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Mawue nye ŋusẽ si seɖoƒe meli na o la tsoƒe.
God is the Source of infinite power, or energy.
(Hiob 37:23) Esia ɖe dzesi ŋutɔ elabe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔ be wotea ŋu trɔa ŋusẽ wòzua nu sesẽwo.
(Job 37:23) This is significant, because scientists have learned that energy can be converted into matter.
Biblia gblɔ be Mawu ŋutɔe nye "ŋusẽ " si wotsɔ wɔ xexeme gbahoo sia la Tsoƒe.
The Bible says that God himself is the Source of the "vast dynamic energy " that produced the universe.
(Yesaya 40:26) Mawu do ŋugbe be yeazã yeƒe ŋusẽa atsɔ alé yeƒe nuwɔwɔ blibo la ɖe te, elabena Biblia gblɔ tso ɣe, ɣleti kple ɣletiviwo ŋu be: "[Mawu tsɔ] wo ɖo anyi ɖaa tegbee. "
(Isaiah 40:26) God promises to use his power to sustain his creation, for the Bible says regarding the sun, moon, and stars: "[God] keeps them established forever and ever. "
Psalmo 148:3-6.
ALEKE NYA SIA KA WÒ?
WHY IT MATTERS
Ɣletiviŋununyala Allan Sandage gblɔ kpɔ be: "Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo mate ŋu aɖo nyabiase goglowo ŋu o.
The astronomer Allan Sandage once said: "Science cannot answer the deepest questions.
Ne ènya bia wo be aleke wòdzɔe be nane va li ne menye nane gbɔe wòtso o mahã la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo megatea ŋu kpɔa nya aɖeke gblɔna o. "
As soon as you ask why is there something instead of nothing, you have gone beyond science. "
Gake nu si gayi ŋgɔ wu emae nye be Biblia ɖoa nyabiase aɖewo ŋu, siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo mate ŋu aɖo o. Nyabiase mawo dometɔ ɖekae nye, Tame kae Mawu ɖo ɖe anyigba la kple amegbetɔwo ŋu?
Not only does the Bible explain creation in a way that harmonizes with science but it also answers questions that science cannot such as, What is God’s purpose for the earth and for mankind?
Karbɔn Nye Nu Wɔnuku Aɖe
The Wonder Element
Karbɔn ƒe atɔmwo
Carbon atoms
Agbalẽ aɖe (Nature’s Building Blocks) gblɔ be: "Nu siwo nana míenɔa agbe la dometɔ aɖeke mele vevie de karbɔn nu o. "
"No element is more essential to life than carbon, " says the book Nature’s Building Blocks.

Nɔnɔme tɔxɛ aɖewo le karbɔn si si na eƒe atɔmwo tea ŋu léna ɖe wo nɔewo kple dzɔdzɔmenu bubu geɖewo hã ŋu. Esia wɔnɛ be wòtea ŋu tsakana kple nu bubuwo zua nu yeye miliɔn geɖe. Wole kekem ɖe nu yeye siawo ŋu gbe sia gbe hele nu siwo de sɔsɔ ge kpli wo hã tom vɛ.
The unique characteristics of carbon enable it to bond with itself and many other chemical elements, thus forming millions of compounds, more of which are constantly being discovered or synthesized.
Abe ale si kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna ɖee fiae ene la, karbɔn ƒe atɔmwo ate ŋu aƒo ƒu awɔ nu siwo ƒe nɔnɔme le abe kɔsɔkɔsɔwo, piramidwo, nu kotoewo, nu gbadzɛwo kple nu lɔbɔe siwo me to le.
As the examples here show, carbon atoms can also combine to form various shapes, including chains, pyramids, rings, sheets, and tubes.
Karbɔn nye nu wɔnuku aɖe vavã!
Carbon truly is a wonder element!
LOTAMEKPE
DIAMOND
Lotamekpe
A diamond
Karbɔn ƒe atɔmwo ƒoa ƒu kple wo nɔewo le piramid ƒe nɔnɔme me eye woyɔnɛ le Eŋlisigbe me be tetrahedron. Nɔnɔme sia nana wòliana ale gbegbe si wɔnɛ be lotamekpe sesẽna wu kpe ɖe sia ɖe si wonya.
Carbon atoms form pyramids, called tetrahedrons, making the structure extremely rigid and making diamond the hardest naturally occurring substance known.
Lotamekpe adodoea nye karbɔn ƒe atɔmwo ɖeɖe dzaa ƒe ƒuƒoƒo kple wo nɔewo.
A perfect diamond is essentially a single molecule of carbon atoms.
GRAFAIT
GRAPHITE
Pensil
A lead pencil
Karbɔn ƒe atɔm siwo lé ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu kpaɖii la tea ŋu ɖena ɖa le wo nɔewo ŋu abe ale si ko agbalẽ ɖeɖi siwo le wo nɔewo dzi la tea ŋu ɖena ɖa ene.
Tightly bonded carbon atoms are set out in loosely bonded layers that can slide away from one another like sheets of paper on a stack.
Nɔnɔme tɔxɛ siawo wɔnɛ be grafait nye nu si bɔbɔa nu eye wòwɔa akpa vevi aɖe le nuŋlɔti si nye pensil (crayon) me.
Because of these characteristics, graphite is both a fine lubricant and a key compound in lead pencils.
GRAFEN
GRAPHENE
Pensil si wote ɖe agbalẽ dzi
A pencil trace
Esia nye karbɔn ƒe atɔm siwo tsyã ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu le dzogoe ade me abe ɖɔ ene.
This refers to a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal mesh, or lattice.
Grafen sesẽ wu gayibɔ bobobo.
Graphene has a tensile strength many times that of steel.
Ne woŋlɔ nu kple pensil la, grafen suesue siwo le wo nɔewo dzi ƒe ɖeka alo esi wu ema nɔa eme.
A pencil trace may have small amounts of graphene in single or multiple layers.
FULEREN
FULLERENES
Fuleren
Fullerenes
Wonye karbɔn me nu suesuesue siwo me do le, eye wole nɔnɔme vovovowo abe bɔl kple nu lɔbɔe siwo me to le ene la me. Woyɔa wo le eŋlisigbe me be nanotubes, eye ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ wo o.
These hollow molecules of carbon come in shapes that include microscopic balls and tubes called nanotubes.
Ne wobe woadzidzee la, anye meta ɖeka si woma ɖe biliɔn ɖeka me ƒe ɖeka.
They are measured in nanometers, or billionths of a meter.
NUGBAGBEVIWO
LIVING ORGANISMS
Nugbagbevi siwo me karbɔn le
Living cells that contain carbon
Lãmenugbagbevi siwo le nu miemiewo, lãwo kple amegbetɔwo me la nɔ te ɖe karbɔn ƒe dɔwɔwɔ dzi, eye karbɔn le nuɖuɖu siwo me goma, aminu kple amino acid le la me.
The many cells that make up plants, animals, and humans are built on a framework of carbon​ an element found in carbohydrates, fats, and amino acids.
"[Mawu ƒe] nɔnɔme makpɔmakpɔawo dzena gaglãa wokpɔna . . . le nu siwo wòwɔ la me. " Romatɔwo 1:20.
"[God’s] invisible qualities . . . are perceived by the things made. "​ Romans 1:20.
Ɣletivi
A star
Karbɔn Nu Si Nana Ɣletiviwo Klẽna Nyuie
Carbon​ A Product of Ultrafine Tuning in the Stars
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo xɔe se be nu siwo le ya ƒomevi etɔ̃ aɖewo tome lae ƒoa ƒu wɔa karbɔn, eye atɔmwo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo kple wo nɔewo alea yia edzi le ɣletivi siwo woyɔna be red giants la me.
Carbon is formed by the fusion of three helium nuclei, which scientists believe occurs inside stars called red giants.
Gake be ya etɔ̃ siawo nado go la, ele be nanewo nayi edzi pɛpɛpɛ ɖe eƒe ɖoɖo si nu wòle la nu.
For the helium to combine, however, certain conditions must be exactly right.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununyala Paul Davies gblɔ be: "Ne tɔtrɔ vi sue aɖe teti va dzɔdzɔmesewo ŋu la, xexea, agbe alo amegbetɔ aɖeke manɔ anyi o. "
"Change just a few of the settings [of physical laws] even an infinitesimal amount, " wrote physicist Paul Davies, and "we’d have no universe, no life and certainly no humans. "
Aleke karbɔn si nana ɣletiviwo klẽna nyuie la wɔ va dzɔ?
How can we account for such ultrafine tuning?
Ame aɖewo gblɔna be ɖeko wòdzɔ le eɖokui si.
Some say it just happened.
Ame bubuwo hã ka ɖe edzi be Wɔla nyanu aɖee wɔe.
Others see it as evidence of a wise Creator.
Esiawo dometɔ ka dzie nèda asi ɖo?
Which view do you consider more reasonable?
Nyatakakadzraɖoƒe Aɖe Si Le Wò Lãmenugbagbeviwo Me!
Your Cells Living Libraries!

LE ƑE 1953 me la, nugbagbeŋutinunyala, James Watson kple Francis Crick ta numekuku aɖe si ŋu woke ɖo ku ɖe nu gbagbewo ŋu la ɖe agbalẽ me si dzi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo nɔ te ɖo va se nu geɖe gɔme tso agbe ŋu.
IN 1953, molecular biologists James Watson and Francis Crick published a discovery that was critical to our scientific understanding of life.
Woke ɖe nu gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ aɖe si le abe aŋutsrɔe ene, si nye DNA alo ADN (domenyiŋusẽfianu) ŋu.
They had discovered the double-helical structure of DNA.
Nu gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ sia le lãmenugbagbeviwo to me ɖaa, eye afi mae nyatakakawo le, alo "woŋlɔ " wo ɖo, esiae nye nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si le lãmenugbagbeviwo me.
This threadlike substance mostly found in the nucleus of cells contains encoded, or "written, " information, making cells living libraries, as it were.
Nu wɔnuku sia si ŋu woke ɖo la gade dzo yeye nusɔsrɔ̃ tso nu gbagbewo ŋu me!
This amazing discovery opened up a new era in biology!
Gake nu ka tae wòhiã be nyatakakadzraɖoƒe nanɔ lãmenugbagbeviwo me?
But what purpose is served by the "writing " in cells?
Eye aleke wòdzɔe be wova le afi ma?
More intriguing, how did it get there?
NU KA TAE LÃMENUGBAGBEVIWO HIÃ NYATAKAKAWO?
WHY CELLS NEED INFORMATION
Ðe nèbia ɖokuiwò kpɔ be nu kae nana nuku wɔna va zua ati, alo aleke ŋutsu ƒe tsi kple nyɔnu ƒe azi wɔna va zua amegbetɔ?
Have you ever wondered how a seed becomes a tree or how a fertilized egg becomes a human?
Ðe nèbia kpɔ be, aleke wòdzɔe be míenyia nɔnɔme aɖewo dome tso mía dzilawo gbɔ?
Have you ever wondered how you inherited your traits?
Nya ma ƒe ŋuɖoɖo nɔ te ɖe nyatakaka siwo le DNA me la dzi.
The answers involve the information found in DNA.
DNA le abe aŋutsrɔe didi gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ ene
DNA molecule, resembling long twisted ladder with rungs
DNA si le abe aŋutsrɔe didi gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ ene la le lãmenugbagbevi ɖe sia ɖe kloe me.
Nearly all cells have DNA, complex molecules that resemble long twisted ladders.
Le DNA si le abe aŋutsrɔe si le amegbetɔwo me la, dometsotsowo le eme keŋ, eye esiawo ƒe xexlẽme ade biliɔn etɔ̃ kloe.
In the human genome, or our complete set of DNA, the ladders have approximately three billion chemical "rungs. "
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔ be dometsotso siawo zɔna eveve elabena lãmetsi ƒomevi eve aɖewoe ƒoa ƒu wɔa wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe si wɔe be dometsotsoawo va nɔa ene.
Scientists call these rungs base pairs because each rung is made up of two chemical substances, of which there are four altogether.
Wozãa Eŋlisigbe me ŋɔŋlɔdzesi ene siwo nye A, C, G kple T wònɔa tsitre ɖi na woƒe yɔyɔ kpuie.
Using the first letter of each, these substances are abbreviated A, C, G, and T a simple, four-letter alphabet, as it were.
Aƒetɔ Crick do susu ɖa le ƒe 1957 me be dometsotso siawo siwo nye lãmetsi mee nyatakakawo nɔna.
In 1957, Crick proposed that it is the linear sequence of the chemical rungs that forms coded instructions.
Nu geɖe me va kɔ tso esia ŋu le ƒe 1960-awo me.
In the 1960’s, that code began to be understood.
Mɔ vovovowo li si dzi wotona dzraa nyatakakawo abe fotowo, gbeɖiɖiwo, alo nuŋɔŋlɔwo ene ɖo hena zazã emegbe.
Information, whether in the form of pictures, sounds, or words, can be stored and processed in many ways.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, kɔmpiuta dzraa nyatakakawo ɖo wonɔa xexlẽdzesi ƒe nɔnɔme me hafi zãna.
Computers, for example, do this all digitally.
Lãmenugbagbeviwo hã dzraa nyatakakawo ɖo wonɔa tsi ƒe nɔnɔme me hafi wozãna, eye DNA la me koŋue esiawo yia edzi le.
Living cells store and process information chemically, DNA being the key compound.
Ne lãmenugbagbeviwo le mamam hele ŋutinuwo zum la, DNA si le eme la ɖoa nyatakaka siwo hiã ɖa. Esia wɔnɛ be nu gbagbeviwo tsɔa ame alo nu si me wodo tso ƒe dzedzeme kple nɔnɔme.
DNA is passed on when cells divide and organisms reproduce abilities that are considered defining characteristics of life.
Aleke lãmenugbagbeviwo zãa nyatakakawo tsɔ wɔa dɔe?
How do cells use information?
Mina míatsɔ DNA la abe mɔfiame aɖe si woŋlɔ eme kɔ nyuie si dzi woazɔ ɖo amè abolo ene.
Think of DNA as a collection of recipes, each one involving step-by-step processes, with each step carefully scripted in precise terms.
Ne wozɔ ɖe mɔfiamea dzi la, nu si ado tso emee nye abolo, le DNA ya gome la, le nyatakaka si tɔgbi ŋu dɔ wɔm wòle nu la, nu si ado go tso eme ate ŋu anye nane abe fetri alo nyi ene.
But instead of the end result being a cake or a cookie, it might be a cabbage or a cow.
Gake le lãmenugbagbeviwo ya gome la, woawo ŋutɔwoe wɔa dɔ le wo ɖokui si, si wɔe be wonye nu wɔnuku si gɔme sese goglo.
In living cells, of course, the processes are fully automated, adding yet another layer of complexity and sophistication.
Nyatakaka si le nugbagbevi sue (bacterial) me la ate ŋu axɔ agbalẽ si ƒe axawo ade 1,000
The information in a bacterial cell would fill a 1,000-page book
Nyatakakawo nɔa nyatakakadzraɖoƒea va se ɖe esime wohiã wo, ɖewohĩ ne woaɖɔli lãmenugbagbevi siwo gblẽ kple yeyewo alo be nu gbagbe siwo woadzi la nanyi nɔnɔme aɖe dome tso wo dzilawo gbɔ ko hafi.
Genetic information is stored until it is needed, perhaps to replace worn out or diseased cells with healthy new ones or to pass on traits to offspring.
Nyatakaka agbɔsɔsɔ ka gbegbee le DNA la me?
How much information does DNA hold?
Na míade ŋugble tso nugbagbevi suetɔ kekeakewo dometɔ ɖeka si nye bacteria (bactérie) ŋu kpɔ.
Consider one of the smallest organisms, bacteria.

Germanytɔ Bernd-Olaf Küppers si nye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala gblɔ be: "Be míate ŋu ase egɔme bɔbɔe la, nyatakaka agbɔsɔsɔ si le nu gbagbevi sue ma ƒe lãmenugbagbevi me la ate ŋu axɔ agbalẽ si ƒe axawo ade akpe ɖeka. "

German scientist Bernd-Olaf Küppers stated: "Carried over to the realm of human language, the molecular text describing the construction of a bacterial cell would be about the size of a thousand-page book. "
Nufialagã David Deamer gblɔ be: "Nu gbagbevi suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã ƒe wɔwɔme wɔ nuku ale gbegbe. "
For good reason, chemistry professor David Deamer wrote: "One is struck by the complexity of even the simplest form of life. "
Ke nyatakaka agbɔsɔsɔ ka gbegbee le amegbetɔ ƒe DNA me?
How does the genome of a human compare?
Aƒetɔ Küppers yi edzi be: "Anye agbalẽ akpe geɖe siwo ayɔ agbalẽdzraɖoƒe gã aɖe. "
"[It] would fill a library of several thousand volumes, " says Küppers.
DNA Ƒe Ŋutinya
DNA Key Dates
Ƒe 1869 Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala Friedrich Miescher ke ɖe nu si woyɔna egbea be DNA (ADN) la ŋu.
1869 Chemist Friedrich Miescher identified what we now call deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA.
Ƒe 1900 ƒe gɔmedzedze Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala Phoebus Levene ke ɖe ɖoɖo aɖe si nu DNA la me tsiwo wɔa dɔ le kple ale si esia ƒoa ƒu va nyea DNA gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ la ŋu.
Early 1900’s Biochemist Phoebus Levene discovered the order of certain chemical components of DNA and how these combine to form a chainlike molecule.
Ƒe 1950 Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala Erwin Chargaff ku nu me va kpɔe be ale si DNA la le le nu gbagbe vovovowo me la to vovo.
1950 Biochemist Erwin Chargaff discovered that the composition of DNA varies among species.
Ƒe 1953 Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala James Watson kple Francis Crick ɖɔ ale si tututu DNA la le, wogblɔ be ele abe aŋutsrɔe si le gɔdɔ̃gɔdɔ̃ ene.
1953 Scientists James Watson and Francis Crick described the double-helical structure of DNA.
"WOŊLƆ WO WOLE BƆBƆE BE MÍATE ŊU ASE WO GƆME "
"WRITTEN IN A WAY THAT WE CAN UNDERSTAND "
Aƒetɔ Küppers gblɔ be menye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔe nuŋlɔɖi siwo wogblɔ be wole DNA me la nye o.
To describe the writing in DNA as "molecular-genetic language " is more than "mere metaphor, " says Küppers.
Egblɔ kpee be, "nuŋlɔɖiawo le abe gbegbɔgblɔ siwo amewo dona ene. "
"Like human language, " he points out, "the molecular-genetic language also possesses a syntactic dimension. "
Ne míagblɔe kpuie la, "gbeŋutisewo " alo sewo le DNA hã si si dzi wòzɔna ɖo si nana wòtea ŋu nyana nu si tututu mɔfiamewo fia hafi wòzɔna ɖe wo dzi.
Put simply, DNA has a "grammar, " or set of rules, that strictly regulates how its instructions are composed and carried out.
Nuŋlɔɖi siwo le DNA la me lae nye se siwo fiaa mɔ lãmenugbagbeviawo le ŋutinu vovovo siwo va ƒoa ƒu wɔa ameti blibo la wɔwɔ me.

The "words " and "sentences " in DNA make up the various "recipes " that direct the production of proteins and other substances that form the building blocks of the various cells that make up the body.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nuŋlɔɖia tea ŋu fiaa ale si woawɔ lãmenugbagbevi siwo awɔ ƒuwo, lãmekawo, ahɔhɔ̃mekawo kple ŋutigbalẽa.
For example, the "recipe " might guide the production of bone cells, muscle cells, nerve cells, or skin cells.
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔŋutinunyala Matt Ridley gblɔ be: "Nyatakaka siwo le DNA la me la sɔ kple eƒe ŋɔŋlɔdzesi.
"The filament of DNA is information, a message written in a code of chemicals, one chemical for each letter, " wrote evolutionist Matt Ridley.
Ewɔ nuku ŋutɔ be mɔfiame kple sewo le DNA la si si dzi wòzɔna ɖo alea, gake woŋlɔ wo wole bɔbɔe be míate ŋu ase wo gɔme. "
"It is almost too good to be true, but the code turns out to be written in a way that we can understand. "
Biblia ŋlɔla David gblɔ le gbedodoɖa me na Mawu be: "Wò ŋkuwo kpɔm esime menye ʋukɔe; eye woŋlɔ eŋu nuwo katã ɖe wò agbalẽ me. "
The Bible writer David said in prayer to God: "Your eyes even saw me as an embryo; all its parts were written in your book. "
(Psalmo 139:16) Ɛ̃, David ƒe nya siawo nye hakpanyawo.
(Psalm 139:16) Of course, David was using poetic language.
Ke hã, nyateƒe tututu wòto abe ale si wòle le Biblia ŋlɔla bubuwo hã gome ene.
Nevertheless, in principle, he was right on the mark, which is typical of the Bible writers.
Xotutu siwo nɔ anyi ɣemaɣi kple blematɔ bubuwo ƒe gliwo mekpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe Biblia ŋlɔlawo dzi le mɔ suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã nu o.
None were even slightly influenced by the fanciful folklore or mythology of other ancient peoples.
2 Samuel 23:1, 2; 2 Timoteo 3:16.
2 Samuel 23:1, 2; 2 Timothy 3:16.
Dzilawo kple wo vi nyɔnuvi sue aɖe
Parents with their little girl
Aleke wòdzɔna be ɖeviwo nyia nɔnɔme aɖewo dome tso wo dzilawo gbɔ?
How does a child inherit traits from its parents?
ALEKE WÒDZƆE BE NUŊLƆÐI MAWO VA LE DNA ME?
HOW DID THE WRITING GET THERE?
Abe ale si wònɔna zi geɖe ene la, ne dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo wɔ numekuku se nane gɔme la, wonɔa te ɖe edzi wɔa numekuku bubuwo ganyaa nu geɖe.
As is often the case, when scientists explain one mystery, they open a door to another.
Alea tututue wòdzɔe hafi wova nya nu geɖe tso DNA la ŋu.
That was true regarding the discovery of DNA.
Esi wova nya be nyatakakawo le DNA me la, ame siwo bua nu ŋu nyuie biana be: ‘Aleke wòdzɔe be nuŋlɔɖi mawo va le afi ma?’
When it was understood that DNA contains coded information, thoughtful people asked, ‘How did the information get there?’
Nyateƒeae nye be ame aɖeke menɔ eteƒe esi wowɔ DNA gbãtɔ o.
Of course, no human observed the formation of the first DNA molecule.
Eya ta mía ŋutɔwoe aƒo nya ta ne ɖe wòdzɔ le eɖokui si loo alo ame aɖee wɔe.
So we have to draw our own conclusions.
Ke hã ele be kpeɖodzi sẽŋu nanɔ míaƒe nyataƒoƒowo ŋu.
Even so, these conclusions need not be speculative.
Na míakpɔ esia ŋuti kpɔɖeŋu aɖewo ɖa.
Consider the following comparisons.
Le ƒe 1999 me la, woke ɖe blemaze kakɛ aɖewo siwo dzi nuŋɔŋlɔ kple dzesi aɖewo siwo mebɔ o le la ŋu le Pakistan.
In 1999, fragments of very ancient pottery with unusual markings, or symbols, were found in Pakistan.
Va se ɖe egbea la, womenya nu si dzesi mawo fia o.
The marks still remain undeciphered.
Gake wonya kokoko be amegbetɔ aɖee ŋlɔe.
Nevertheless, they are considered man-made.

Esi Watson kple Crick ke ɖe ale si tututu DNA la le ŋu le ƒe ʋɛ aɖewo megbe la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala eve aɖewo do susua ɖa be yewoaku nu me kpɔ be yewoate ŋu ake ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu le yamenutowo me ahado ka kpli wo hã.
A few years after Watson and Crick discovered the structure of DNA, two physicists proposed searching for coded radio signals from space.
Aleae wòdzɔe be wodze numekuku tso ɣemaɣi be woake ɖe amewo ŋu le ɣletinyigba bubuwo dzi gɔme.
Thus began the modern-day search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Nu kae esia fia?
The point?
Ne amewo ke ɖe nyatakakawo eɖanye dzesi siwo le anyinuwo ŋu, alo nyatakaka siwo tso yamenutowo me o ŋu la, wonyana be ame aɖee wɔe alo ame aɖe gbɔe wòtso.
People attribute information to intelligence, whether that information is in the form of symbols on clay or signals from space.
Mehiã be woakpɔ esia teƒe hafi alɔ ɖe edzi o.
They do not need to see the information being created to draw that conclusion.
Gake esi wova ke ɖe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe wɔnuku si le DNA me ŋu la, ame geɖe gblɔna be menye ame aɖekee wɔe o.
Yet, when the most sophisticated code known to man the chemical code of life was discovered, many shoved that logic aside, attributing DNA to mindless processes.
Ðe susu le nya ma mea?
Is that reasonable?
Ðe amewo katã da asi ɖe edzia?
Is it consistent?
Ðe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ate ŋu aɖo kpe edzia?
Is it scientific?
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala xɔŋkɔ gbogbo aɖewo melɔ̃ ɖe edzi o.
A number of respected scientists say no.
Ame siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye Ðɔkta Gene Hwang kple Nufialagã Yan-Der Hsuuw.
These include Dr. Gene Hwang and Professor Yan-Der Hsuuw.
Na míade ŋugble tso nya si wogblɔ ŋu kpɔ.
Consider what they say.
Ðɔkta Gene Hwang nye ame si srɔ̃a nu tso DNA ŋu.
Dr. Gene Hwang studies the mathematical basis of genetics.
Tsã la, exɔ amedzɔtsolãme nufiafia dzi se, gake nu siwo ŋu wòva ke ɖo le eƒe numekukuwo me na wòtrɔ susu.
At one time he believed in evolution, but his research changed his view.
Egblɔ na Nyɔ! talawo be, "Nusɔsrɔ̃ tso nyatakaka siwo le DNA me ŋu na meva se agbe gɔme ɖe edzi, si wɔe be nunya si gbegbe le Wɔlaa si la wɔa nuku nam. "
"The study of genetics, " he told Awake! "provides insight into the mechanisms of life an insight that fills me with awe for the Creator’s wisdom. "
Nufialagã Yan-Der Hsuuw nye ame si kpɔa numekuku si wowɔna tso fugboewo ŋu dzi le Taiwantɔwo ƒe yunivɛsiti aɖe me.
Professor Yan-Der Hsuuw is the director of embryo research at Taiwan’s National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.
Tsã la, eya hã xɔ amedzɔtsolãme nufiafia dzi se. Gake nu siwo ŋu wòva ke ɖo le eƒe nusɔsrɔ̃wo me na wòtrɔ susu.
He too once believed in evolution until his research led him to conclude otherwise.
Egblɔ tso lãmenugbagbeviwo ƒe mama kple dɔ vovovo siwo wowɔna ŋu be: "Ele be woanye lãmenugbagbevi siwo tututu hiã, woanɔ ɖoɖo nu eye woayi aɖawɔ nu si tututu wòle be woawɔ.
Regarding cell division and specialization, he said: "The right cells must be produced in the right order and at the right places.
Gbã la, wozua ʋukɔe, emegbe ŋutinu vovovoawo dona.
First they assemble into tissues that will in turn assemble themselves into organs and limbs.
Ðe aɖaŋudɔwɔla aɖe ate ŋu aku drɔ̃e be yeaŋlɔ mɔfiame siwo dzi nu siawo azɔ ɖo alea ɖia?
What engineer can even dream of writing instructions for such a process?
Ke hã woŋlɔ ale si fugboe wɔna tsina la ɖe DNA la me pɛpɛpɛ.
Yet the instructions for embryo development are superbly written in DNA.
Ne mede ŋugble tso ale si nu siawo wɔa dɔ nukutɔe ŋu la, ena meva ka ɖe edzi be Mawu gbɔe agbe dzɔ tso. "
When I consider the beauty of it all, I’m convinced that life was designed by God. "
Ðɔkta Gene Hwang; 2.
Dr. Gene Hwang; 2.
Nufialagã Yan-Der Hsuuw
Professor Yan-Der Hsuuw
