ÐE WÒHIÃ BE WOAGBLƆ BE MAWUE WƆEA?
DOES IT MATTER?
Ɛ̃, ehiã!
Justice says yes!
Elabena ne Mawue wɔ agbe la, ke eyae dze na eŋuti kafukafua, menye nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ o.
If God created life, then God deserves the credit, not evolution.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Azɔ hã ne Wɔla nyanu aɖee wɔ mí la, ekema susu aɖe tae wòwɔ mí ɖo.
(Revelation 4:11) Also, if we are the work of an all-wise Creator, then we are here for a reason.
Ne ɖe agbe dzɔ le eɖokui si la, anye tameɖoɖo aɖeke manɔ agbe ŋu o.
That would not be so if life were a result of undirected processes.
Ame siwo bua nuwo ŋu nyuie la dia ŋuɖoɖo na nyabiase siawo.
Indeed, thinking people long for satisfying answers.
Aƒetɔ Viktor Frankl si fia nu tso ahɔhɔ̃ ŋu kpɔ va yi gblɔ be, "Tameɖoɖo si le agbe ŋu lae nye nu vevitɔ si ŋu amegbetɔwo tsia dzi ɖo. "
"Man’s search for meaning is the primary motivation in his life, " said Viktor Frankl, who was a professor of neurology and psychiatry.
Ne míagblɔe bubui la, amegbetɔwo dina be yewoadze si ame si tututu Mawu nye, eye esia sɔ nenema ne míexɔe se be eyae wɔ mí.
To put it another way, we have a spiritual hunger that we yearn to satisfy a hunger that makes sense only in the light of special creation.
Gake ne Mawue wɔ mí nyateƒe la, ɖe wòna nu si akpe ɖe mía ŋu míadze sii la mía?
But if we are the handiwork of God, did he give us the means to satisfy our spiritual need?
Yesu Kristo ɖo nya sia ŋu. Egblɔ be: "Menye abolo ɖeɖe ko nu amegbetɔ anɔ agbe ɖo o, ke boŋ ɖe nya sia nya si dona tso Yehowa [alo Mawu] ƒe nu me la hã nu. "
Jesus Christ answered that question, saying: "Man must live, not on bread alone, but on every word that comes from Jehovah’s [or, God’s] mouth. "
(Mateo 4:4) Yehowa ƒe nya si woŋlɔ ɖe Biblia me la kpe ɖe ame miliɔn geɖewo ŋu wova kpɔ tameɖoɖo si le woƒe agbe ŋu, si na etsɔmemɔkpɔkpɔ nyui aɖe va su wo si.
(Matthew 4:4) Jehovah’s words, which are recorded in the Bible, have satisfied the spiritual hunger of millions, giving meaning to their lives and providing them with a hope for the future.
(1 Tesalonikatɔwo 2:13) Neva eme be Biblia nakpe ɖe wò hã ŋuwò nenema ke.
(1 Thessalonians 2:13) May the Bible do the same for you.
Asɔ be nàdi ɣeyiɣi adzro agbalẽ tɔxɛ sia me.
At the very least, this unique book merits your consideration.
Ðe Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya Ðo Kpe Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ Nufiafia Dzia?
Is Evolution a Scientific Theory?
Nu kawo dzie dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya tea ŋu ɖoa kpee be wonye nyateƒe?
What qualifies a theory as a scientific theory?

Agbalẽ si nye Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ƒe sewo kple gɔmeɖosewo kpakple nusɔsrɔ̃wo (si le Eŋlisigbe me) gblɔ be, hafi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya nate ŋu aɖo kpe nane abe nu si Albert Einstein fia tso nuheŋusẽ ene dzi be enye nyateƒe la, ele be
According to the Encyclopedia of Scientific Principles, Laws, and Theories, a scientific theory, such as Albert Einstein’s theory of gravity, must
Wòanye nu si woate ŋu akpɔ kple ŋku
Be observable
Woate ŋu awɔ nu ma ke ƒe kpɔɖeŋu sue aɖe le nusɔsrɔ̃ me
Be reproducible by controlled experiments
Woate ŋu agblɔ emetsonu ɖi wòava eme pɛpɛpɛ
Make accurate predictions
Ðe wote ŋu wɔ esiawo hã le nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ nufiafiaa gomea?
In that light, where does evolution stand?
Womekpɔ ale si wòdzɔnae kple ŋku kpɔ o.
Its operation cannot be observed.
Womate ŋu awɔ esia ƒe kpɔɖeŋu le nusɔsrɔ̃ me o.
It cannot be reproduced.
Eye womate ŋu agblɔ emetsonu ɖi wòava eme o.
And it cannot make accurate predictions.
Ðe woate ŋu abu nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ nufiafia be enye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si dzi woava ɖo kpee le etsɔmea?
Can evolution even be considered a scientific hypothesis?

Numekugbalẽ ma ke gblɔ tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si dzi woava ɖo kpee le etsɔme ŋu be "enyea nu si woate ŋu akpɔ kple ŋku fifia [menye agbalẽ me nusɔsrɔ̃ dzro ko o] si ŋu kakaɖedzi le, eye woate ŋu awɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu le nusɔsrɔ̃ me gɔ̃ hã. "
The same encyclopedia defines a hypothesis as "a more tentative observation of facts [than a theory], " yet lends itself "to deductions that can be experimentally tested. "
Ðe Xexea Dzɔ Le Eɖokui Sia?​ Akpa 1: Nu Ka Tae Wòle Be Nàxɔ Mawu Dzi Ase?
Creation or Evolution?​—Part 1: Why Believe in God?
Ðe wowɔ xexea alo eya ŋutɔ koe dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Creation or evolution?
Nu ka tae mexɔ Mawu dzi se?
Why do I believe in God?
Ale si maɖe nye dzixɔsea me
Explaining my belief
Ðe wowɔ xexea alo eya ŋutɔ koe dzɔ le eɖokui sia?
Creation or evolution?
Èxɔe se be Mawue wɔ nuwo katã?
Do you believe that God created all things?
Ne èxɔe se la, ke menye wò ɖeka koe o, sɔhɛ (kple ame tsitsi) gbogbo aɖewo hã xɔe se nenema.
If so, you’re not alone; many young people (and adults) share your view.
Gake ame bubuwo ya be ɖeko nu gbagbewo kple xexea dzɔ le wo ɖokui si, menye "Ŋusẽkatãtɔ " aɖekee na wodzɔ o.
But others say that life and the universe evolved​—without the help of a “Supreme Being.”
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Ame siwo xɔe se be ɖe wowɔ nuwo kple ame siwo gblɔna be ɖe nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si la siaa tea tɔ ɖe woƒe susuwo dzi evɔ wometea ŋu ɖoa kpe woƒe nyawo dzi o.
People on both sides of the debate are often quick to state what they believe without really knowing why they believe it.
Ame aɖewo xɔe se be ɖe wowɔ xexea kple emenuwo, elabe nenemae wofia wo le tsɔtsi.
Some people believe in creation simply because that’s what they’ve been taught at church.
Ame geɖewo hã xɔe se be ɖeko xexea kple emenuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si elabe nenemae wofia wo le suku.
Many people believe in evolution simply because that’s what they’ve been taught at school.
Nyati vovovo siawo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàgaxɔe se geɖe wu be Mawue wɔ xexea kple nu gbagbewo eye àsu te nyuie aɖe wò dzixɔsea me na amewo.
This series of articles will help you to reinforce and explain your belief in creation.
Gake gbã la, ehiã be nàbia nya bɔbɔe sia ɖokuiwò:
First, though, you need to ask yourself an even more basic question:
Nu ka tae mexɔ Mawu dzi se?
Why do I believe in God?
Nu ka tae biabia sia le vevie?
Why is that question important?
Elabe Biblia de dzi ƒo na wò be nàzã wò "tamebubuŋutete. "
Because the Bible encourages you to use your mind, “your power of reason.”
(Romatɔwo 12:1) Esia fia be wò mawudzixɔse manɔ te ɖe
(Romans 12:1) That means your belief in God should not be based merely on
seselelãme dzro ko dzi o (Efia be menye esi nèse le ɖokuiwò me be ele be ŋusẽtɔ aɖe nanɔ anyi ta koe nèxɔ Mawu dzi se ɖo o)
emotion (I just feel that there must be a higher power)
ame bubuwo ƒe susu dzi o (Menye esi nutoa me tɔwo nye mawusubɔlawo tae wò hã nàgblɔ be yexɔ Mawu dzi se o)
the influence of others (I live in a religious community)
ŋusẽkpɔɖeamedzi dzi o (Efia be menye esi dziwòlawo fia wò be ele be nàxɔ Mawu dzi se alo susu mawo tɔgbi aɖe ko tae o)
pressure (My parents raised me to believe in God​—or else)
Ke boŋ ele be wò ŋutɔ nàka ɖe edzi be Mawu li eye ele be nu siwo tae nèxɔe se nenema ƒe kpeɖodziwo nanɔ asiwò.
Instead, you should be personally convinced that God exists and should have sound reasons for your belief.
Ke nu kae na nèka ɖe edzi be Mawu li?
So, what convinces you that God exists?
Dɔwɔgbalẽvi si nye "Nu Ka Tae Mexɔ Mawu Dzi Se? " akpe ɖe ŋuwò kakaɖedzi ma nasu asiwò.
The worksheet “Why Do I Believe in God?” will build your conviction.
Anyo hã be nàkpɔ ale si sɔhɛ bubuwo ɖo nyabiase sia ŋui.
You might also find it helpful to consider how other young people have answered that question.
"Ne mele sukuxɔ me le to ɖom nufiala wòle ale si míaƒe ametia wɔa dɔe me ɖem la, ɖeko megakana ɖe edzi bliboe be Mawu li.
“When I’m in class listening to the teacher explain how our bodies function, there’s no doubt in my mind that God exists.
Míaƒe ŋutinu ɖe sia ɖe, nyaŋuitɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã, wɔa dɔ aɖe. Zi geɖe la, míenyana gɔ̃ hã be wole dɔ wɔm o.
Each part of the body has its own function, down to the smallest detail, and these functions are often carried out without our awareness.
Nyateƒee, míaƒe ametia gɔme sese ɖu ta! "​ Teresa.
The human body truly is mind-boggling!”​—Teresa.
"Ne mekpɔ xɔ kɔkɔ, meli alo ʋu aɖe la, mebiaa ɖokuinye be, ‘Ame kae wɔe?’
“When I see a skyscraper, a cruise ship, or a car, I ask myself, ‘Who built this?’
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ehiã be aɖaŋu nanɔ tagbɔ na ame hafi wòate ŋu awɔ ʋu, elabe ele be ʋuŋutinu suesue geɖeawo nawɔ dɔ pɛpɛpɛ hafi ʋu blibo la nawɔ dɔ nyuie.
It takes intelligent people to build a car, for example, because so many small components have to work just right for the whole thing to function.
Nenye be ʋu mate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si o ele be ame aɖe kokoko nawɔe la, ke ele be ame aɖe nawɔ mí amegbetɔwo hã. "​ Richard.
And if cars have to be designed by someone, then so do we humans.”​—Richard.

"Ne ède dzesii be ehiãna be amegbetɔ tagbɔɖaɖɛtɔwo kekeake gɔ̃ hã nasrɔ̃ nu tso xexemenuwo ŋu ƒe agbogbo aɖewo hafi wotea ŋu esea eƒe akpa suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã gɔme la, ke susu aɖeke manɔ eme be woagblɔ be menye nunyala aɖekee wɔ xexe sia o! "​ Karen.

“When you realize that it’s taken the most intelligent human minds hundreds of years to understand even the smallest fraction of the universe, then thinking that it took no intelligence to bring that universe into existence seems completely unreasonable!”​—Karen.
"Zi ale si meyi edzi le dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya srɔ̃m la, zi nenemae mekpɔnɛ be kpeɖodzi aɖeke mele nufiafia si nye be ɖeko xexea kple emenuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si la ŋu o.
“The more I studied science, the less credible evolution seemed.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, mede ŋugble tso ale si xexemenuwo le ɖoɖo nu pɛpɛpɛ, ale si amegbetɔwo le etɔxɛe, ale si mí amegbetɔwo míedina be míanya afi si míetso kple afi si míeɖo tae la ŋu.
For example, I thought about the mathematical precision in nature and the uniqueness of humans, including our need to know who we are, where we came from, and where we are going.
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔfialawo dzea agbagba be yewoazã nu siwo do ƒome kple lãwo atsɔ aɖe nya siawo mee, gake wometea ŋu ɖea nu si tae amegbetɔwo ya le etɔxɛe la me o.
Evolution aims to explain all these things in terms associated with animals, but it has never been able to explain why humans are unique.
Le gonyeme la, ebia be xɔse ŋkuagbã geɖe nanɔ ame si hafi wòaxɔe se be nuwo ŋutɔ koe dzɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si, wu be ame naxɔe se be Wɔla aɖe li. "​ Anthony.
To me, it takes more ‘faith’ to believe in evolution than to believe in a Creator.”​—Anthony.
Ale si maɖe nye dzixɔsea me
Explaining my belief
Ke ne wò sukuxɔmeviwo koa wò be èxɔ nane si mekpɔna o dzi se ya ɖe?
What if classmates ridicule you for believing in something you can’t see?
Alo be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo "ɖo kpe " edzi be ɖeko nuwo dzɔ le wo ɖokui si ya ɖe?
What if they say that science has “proved” evolution?
Gbã la, ka ɖe nu si dzi nèxɔ se la dzi.
First, be confident in what you believe.
Vɔvɔ̃ megaɖo wò o eye ŋu hã megakpe wò o.
Do not be intimidated or ashamed.
(Romatɔwo 1:16) Ðo ŋku edzi be:
(Romans 1:​16) After all, remember:
Menye wò ɖeka koe xɔ Mawu dzi se o; ame geɖewo xɔ edzi se.
You are not alone; many people still believe in God.
Ame siawo dometɔ aɖewo gɔ̃ hã nye nunyala gãwo.
That includes highly intelligent, professional people.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala aɖewo gɔ̃ hã xɔe se be Mawu li.
For example, there are scientists who believe there is a God.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, ne amewo gblɔ be yewomexɔ Mawu dzi se o la, nu si wowɔnae nye be yewomesea Mawu ƒe nuwɔnawo gɔme o.
When people say that they don’t believe in God, sometimes what they really mean is that they don’t understand God.
Le esi woaɖo kpe woƒe nyawo dzi teƒe la, nyawo ko wonɔa biabiam. Wotea ŋu biana be, "Ne Mawu li ŋutɔŋutɔ la, ke nu ka tae wòɖe mɔ fukpekpe li? "
Rather than offer evidence to support their view, they raise questions such as, “If God exists, why does he allow suffering?”
Le nyateƒe me la, wotrɔ nya aɖe si hiã tamebubu wɔ seselelãmenyae.
In effect, they turn an intellectual issue into an emotional one.
"Gbɔgbɔmenuwo hiã " amegbetɔwo.
Humans have a “spiritual need.”
(Mateo 5:3) Esia lɔ Mawu dzi xɔxɔ se ɖe eme.
(Matthew 5:3) This includes a need to believe in God.
Eya ta ne ame aɖe gblɔ be Mawu meli o la, eya dzie agba le be wòaɖe nu si tae wòƒo nya ta nenema ɖo la me, ke menye wò agbae o.​ Romatɔwo 1:18-20.
So if someone says there is no God, that person​—not you​—has the responsibility to explain how he or she could reach such a conclusion.​—Romans 1:​18-​20.
Esɔ le goawo katã me be míaxɔ Mawu dzi se.
Belief in God is entirely reasonable.
Esia wɔ ɖeka kple nyateƒenya aɖe si dzi woɖo kpee, si nye be nu gbagbe mate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si o.
It conforms to the proven fact that life cannot come into existence by itself.
Kpeɖodzi aɖeke meli be nu gbagbe ate ŋu adzɔ le eɖokui si tso nu si me agbe mele o me o.
No evidence exists to support the idea that life could spontaneously come from nonliving matter.
Ekema nya kae nàte ŋu agblɔ ne ame aɖe tsɔ nya ɖe ŋuwò be mesɔ be nàxɔ Mawu dzi ase o?
What, then, could you say if someone questions your belief in God?
Kpɔ nu siwo nàte ŋu awɔ dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo ɖa.
Consider a few possibilities.
Ne ame aɖe gblɔ be: "Ame manyagbalẽwo koe xɔa Mawu dzi se. "
If someone says: “Only uneducated people believe in God.”
Àte ŋu aɖo eŋu nɛ be: "Èda asi ɖe susu totro ma dzi ŋutɔŋutɔa?
You could respond: “Do you really accept that stereotype?
Nye ya nyemeda asi ɖe edzi o.
I don’t.

Some people say that life evolved.

Others contend that God merely started creation off and then let the process of evolution take over.
Nu kae Biblia ya gblɔ?
What does the Bible say?
Ðe nya si Biblia gblɔ tso nuwɔwɔ ƒe gɔmedzedze ŋu fia be nuwɔwɔwo medze egɔme zi ɖeka kpoyi oa?
Does the Bible’s creation account rule out the possibility that the universe began with the big bang?
Biblia gblɔ kpuie ko be: "Le gɔmedzedzea me Mawu wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba. " (1 Mose 1:1) Biblia megblɔ ale si tututu Mawu wɔ nu sia nui o.
The Bible simply says: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. " (Genesis 1:1) It does not comment on exactly how God created everything.
Eya ta ne nane ƒe wowó kpoyie na xexea va dzɔ hã la, ema matsi tre ɖe nu si Biblia gblɔ la ŋu o.
So even if a cosmic explosion produced our universe, that would not contradict what is stated in the Bible.
Ke boŋ nu si wogblɔ le 1 Mose 1:1 aɖo nyabiase si nye, Ame kae na be nua wó kpoyi? la ŋu.
Rather, Genesis 1:1 would answer the question, Who caused the big bang?
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala geɖewo xɔe se be ame aɖeke mefia mɔ nua ƒe wowó kpoyi, si wɔe be esi ɣeyiɣiawo va nɔ yiyim la, ɣletiviwo, ɣletinyigbawo kple nu bubu siwo le ɖoɖo nu la va dzɔ o.
Of course, many scientists believe that the big bang was a spontaneous, undirected event that led to the self-arranging of particles of matter into stars and planets over a period of time.
Biblia meda asi ɖe susu ma dzi o, ke boŋ egblɔ be Mawue wɔ xexea, anye be to nuwo ƒe wowó dzi loo alo to mɔnu bubu aɖe dzi.
The Bible does not support that view but states that the formation of the universe was a direct act of God, whether he employed some sort of cosmic explosion or some other method of creation.
"Le gɔmedzedzea me Mawu wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba. " 1 Mose 1:1.
"In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. " Genesis 1:1.
Ðe Biblia gblɔ be nu gbagbewo tea ŋu trɔna ne ɣeyiɣiwo va le yiyima?
Does the Bible’s account allow for living things to change over time?
Yes.
Biblia gblɔ be Mawu wɔ nu gbagbewo "le wo ƒomeviwo nu. " (1 Mose 1:11, 12, 21, 24, 25) Ðe vovototo ate ŋu anɔ nu gbagbe siwo tso ƒome ɖeka me la mea?
The Bible says that God created living things "according to their kinds. " (Genesis 1:11, 12, 21, 24, 25) Can variation occur within a kind?
Yes.
Gake ɖe vovototo si dzena le nu gbagbe siwo tso ƒome ɖeka me fia be nu yeye aɖe kura ate ŋu adzɔ tso emea?
However, does observed adaptation within a kind prove that eventually new kinds can evolve?
Ao.
No.

An ape’s head superimposed on a man’s head
Bu eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖe ŋu kpɔ: Le ƒe 1970-awo me la, numekulawo srɔ̃ nu tso aloe siwo le Galápagos Ƒukpoa dzi la ŋu.
Consider an example: In the 1970’s, researchers studied finches on the Galápagos Islands.
Wode dzesii be enɔa bɔbɔe na aloe siwo ƒe dɔ lolo vie la be woatsi agbe.
They noted that climate changes caused finches with slightly larger beaks to survive more readily.
Esia na ame aɖewo ƒo nya ta be kpeɖodzi le nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ŋu.
This, some concluded, provided evidence of evolution.
Gake ɖe esia ɖo kpe nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzi loo alo tɔtrɔ ɖe nɔnɔme yeye ŋu koe wònye?
But was it evidence of evolution, or was it simply adaptation?
Ƒe geɖe megbe la, aloe siwo ƒe dɔ le sue la, gava sɔ gbɔ wu.
Years later, the finches with smaller beaks once again dominated the population.

Numekuku sia na nufialagã Jeffrey H. Schwartz si srɔ̃ nu tso amegbetɔwo kple woƒe nuwɔnawo ŋu la ƒo nya ta be togbɔ be tɔtrɔ ɖe nɔnɔme yeyewo ŋu ate ŋu akpe ɖe nu gbagbewo ŋu woatsi agbe hã la, "wometrɔna zua nu bubu aɖeke o. "
This experiment led Jeffrey H. Schwartz, a professor of anthropology, to conclude that while adaptation may help a species survive under changing circumstances, "it is not creating anything new. "
Ðe Biblia ƒe nufiafia kple nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ nufiafia wɔ ɖeka?

Ðe Biblia Me Nyawo Wɔ Ðeka Kple Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya?
Does Science Agree With the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, togbɔ be Biblia menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinyagbalẽ o hã, emenyawo de pɛpɛpɛ nenye be eƒo nu tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu.
Yes, for although the Bible is not a science textbook, it is accurate when it mentions matters of science.

Bu kpɔɖeŋu siwo ɖee fia be Biblia me nyawo wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya, eye be nyateƒenya siwo ku ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu le Biblia me, siwo to vovo kura na dzixɔse siwo nɔ ame siwo nɔ anyi le Bibliaŋlɔɣi la si ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some examples showing that science and the Bible agree and that the Bible contains scientific facts that differed greatly from the beliefs of many people living at the time it was written.
Gɔmedzedze li na xexea.
The universe had a beginning.
(1 Mose 1:1) Gake blema nyakpakpa geɖewo gblɔ be menye ɖe wowɔ xexea o, ke boŋ edzɔ tso zitɔtɔ manɔɖoɖonu aɖe me.
(Genesis 1:1) In contrast, many ancient myths describe the universe, not as being created, but as being organized from existing chaos.
Babilontɔwo xɔe se be mawu siwo na xexea dzɔ la tso atsiaƒu gbahoo eve me.
The Babylonians believed that the gods that gave birth to the universe came from two oceans.
Blemaxotutu aɖewo hã gblɔ be azi gã aɖe mee xexea dzɔ tso.
Other legends say that the universe came from a giant egg.
Dzɔdzɔmesewo dzie xexea zɔna ɖo gbe sia gbe, ke menye mawu aɖewo siwo wɔa nu eŋumabumabui woe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe xexe gbahoo la dzi o.
The universe is governed day-to-day by rational natural laws, not by the whims of deities.

(Hiob 38:33; Yeremiya 33:25) Nyakpakpawo le xexea ƒe akpa vovovowo, siwo fiana be wɔna aɖeke mele amegbetɔwo ŋu le mawu siwo dzi womate ŋu aka ɖo o eye nublanuikpɔkpɔ hã mele woƒe nuwɔnawo me o, la si me o.
(Job 38:33; Jeremiah 33:25) Myths from around the world teach that humans are helpless before the unpredictable and sometimes merciless acts of the gods.
Womeku anyigba ɖe naneke ŋu o.
The earth is suspended in empty space.
(Hiob 26:7) Ame geɖe siwo nɔ anyi le blema xɔe se be anyigba la le gbadzaa eye ame dzɔtsu alo lã gã aɖe, abe to alo klo ene, dzie wònɔ.
(Job 26:7) Many ancient peoples believed that the world was a flat disk supported by a giant or an animal, such as a buffalo or a turtle.
Ɣea hea tsi tsoa atsiaƒu kple tsi bubuwo me yia yame eye wòtrɔna zua tsi, sno alo kpetsi dzana ɖe anyigba dzi eye wogasina yia tɔsisiwo kple tsidzɔƒewo me.
Rivers and springs are fed by water that has evaporated from the oceans and other sources and then has fallen back to earth as rain, snow, or hail.
(Hiob 36:27, 28; Nyagblɔla 1:7; Yesaya 55:10; Amos 9:6) Gake blema Helatɔwo susui be tsi siwo le anyigbaa gɔmee ŋɔna yia tɔsisiwo me, susu sia nɔ amewo si kaka va ɖo ƒe alafa 18-awo me.
(Job 36:27, 28; Ecclesiastes 1:7; Isaiah 55:10; Amos 9:6) The ancient Greeks thought that rivers were fed by underground ocean water, and this idea persisted into the 18th century.
Towo hona ɖe dzi eye wogabuna, eye to siwo li egbea nɔ atsiaƒu gɔme kpɔ.
The mountains rise and fall, and today’s mountains were once under the ocean.
(Psalmo 104:6, 8) Gake nyakpakpa geɖewo gblɔna be mawuawoe wɔ to siwo li egbea.
(Psalm 104:​6, 8) In contrast, several myths say that the mountains were created in their current form by the gods.
Dzadzɛnyenye kpɔa ame ƒe lãmesẽ ta.
Sanitary practices protect health.

Ðoɖo aɖewo nɔ Se si wotsɔ na Israel-dukɔa me, siwo bia tso wosi be woaklɔ wo ɖokuiwo ŋu nenye be woka asi nukuku alo amekuku aɖe ŋu, woaɖe ame siwo ŋu dɔxɔleameŋu le la ɖe aga, eye woaɖi woƒe nugodowo ɖe do me.
The Law given to the nation of Israel included regulations for washing after touching a dead body, quarantining those with infectious disease, and disposing of human waste safely.
(3 Mose 11:25-28; 13:1-5; 5 Mose 23:13) To vovo na ema la, esime wona se sia Israel-dukɔa, Egiptetɔwo wɔa atike aɖe si me amegbetɔwo ƒe nugodo le tsɔ ɖoa abi.

(Leviticus 11:28; 13:​1-5; Deuteronomy 23:13) By contrast, one of the Egyptian remedies in use when these commands were given called for applying to an open wound a mixture that included human excrement.
Ðe vodadawo le nya siwo Biblia gblɔ tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋua?
Are there scientific errors in the Bible?
Biblia me dzodzro yi ŋgɔe ɖee fia kɔtɛe be vodadawo mele eme o.
A reasonable examination of the Bible shows the answer to be no.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe ale si Biblia me nyawo wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya la ƒe ɖewoe nye esiawo:
Here are some common misconceptions about the scientific accuracy of the Bible:
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be ŋkeke ade siwo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nye gaƒoƒo 24 ye wotsɔ wɔ xexea katã.
Myth: The Bible says that the universe was created in six 24-hour days.
Nyateƒea: Biblia megblɔ ɣeyiɣi tututu si me Mawu wɔ xexea o.
Fact: According to the Bible, God created the universe in the indefinite past.
(1 Mose 1:1) Azɔ hã, nuwo wɔwɔ ƒe ŋkeke si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ la nye ɣeyiɣi agbɔsɔsɔ me si womeyɔ o.
(Genesis 1:1) Also, the days of creation described in chapter 1 of Genesis were epochs whose length is not specified.
Le nyateƒe me la, woyɔ ɣeyiɣi si wotsɔ wɔ anyigba kple dziƒo la katã hã be "ŋkeke " ɖeka.​ 1 Mose 2:4.
In fact, the entire period during which earth and heaven were made is also called a "day. "​ Genesis 2:4.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be wowɔ numiemiewo hafi va wɔ ɣea, ale be numiemiewo nazã ɣea ƒe ŋusẽ atsɔ awɔ woƒe nuɖuɖu.​ 1 Mose 1:11, 16.
Myth: The Bible says that vegetation was created before the sun existed to support photosynthesis.​ Genesis 1:​11, 16.
Nyateƒea: Biblia ɖee fia be wowɔ ɣea, si nye ɣletivi siwo le "dziƒo " la dometɔ ɖeka hafi va wɔ numiemiewo.
Fact: The Bible shows that the sun, one of the stars that make up "the heavens, " was created before vegetation.
(1 Mose 1:1) Kekeli si tso ɣea gbɔ la ɖo anyigba dzi flukpee le nuwɔwɔ ƒe "ŋkeke " gbãtɔ dzi.
(Genesis 1:1) Diffused light from the sun reached the earth’s surface during the first "day, " or epoch, of creation.
Esi yame nɔ kɔkɔm va ɖo nuwɔwɔ ƒe "ŋkeke " etɔ̃lia dzi la, ɣea ƒe keklẽ nu sẽ va ɖo afi si numiemiewo te ŋu zãe tsɔ wɔ woƒe nuɖuɖu.
As the atmosphere cleared, by the third "day " of creation, the light was strong enough to support photosynthesis.
(1 Mose 1:3-5, 12, 13) Ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe ko hafi ɣea va te dzedze nyuie.​ 1 Mose 1:16.
(Genesis 1:​3-5, 12, 13) Only later did the sun become distinctly visible from the surface of the earth.​ Genesis 1:​16.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be ɣea ƒoa ɣla anyigba la.
Myth: The Bible says that the sun revolves around the earth.
Nyateƒea: Nyagblɔla 1:5 gblɔ be: "Ɣe dzena, eye wòɖoa to, eye wòɖea abla gatrɔna yia afi si wòdzena tso. "
Fact: Ecclesiastes 1:5 says: "The sun rises, and the sun sets; then it hurries back to the place where it rises again. "
Ke hã, ɖeko nya sia le ale si amegbetɔwo kpɔa ɣea wòtsona ɣedzeƒe va yina ɣetoɖoƒe la ɖɔm.
However, this statement merely describes the apparent motion of the sun as viewed from the earth.
Egbea gɔ̃ hã, amegbetɔwo tea zãa nya siwo nye "ɣe dze " kple "ɣe ɖo to, " evɔ wonyae be anyigbae ƒoa xla ɣea.
Even today, a person can use the words "sunrise " and "sunset, " yet he knows that the earth revolves around the sun.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be anyigba la le gbadzaa.
Myth: The Bible says that the earth is flat.
Nyateƒea: Biblia zã nyagbe si nye "anyigba ƒe seƒe ke, " gake mefia be anyigba la le gbadzaa alo seƒe le eŋu o.
Fact: The Bible uses the phrase "the ends of the earth " to mean "the most distant part of the earth "; this does not imply that the earth is flat or that it has an edge.

(Dɔwɔwɔwo 1:8) Nenema kee nyagbe si nye "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " nye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ si fia anyigba dzi godoo; eye ame aɖe ate ŋu azã taɖoƒefianu (compass alo la boussole) ƒe dzesi eneawo wòafia kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ ma ke.​ Yesaya 11:12; Luka 13:29.

(Acts 1:8; footnote) Likewise, the expression "the four corners of the earth " is a figure of speech referring to the entire surface of the earth; today a person might use the four points of the compass as a similar metaphor.​ Isaiah 11:12; Luke 13:29.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be togodo ƒe ɣlaƒoƒo ɖeka ƒe dzidze nye fli si tso eƒe toga ɖeka yi kemea ƒe teƒe etɔ̃ pɛpɛpɛ, gake togodo ƒe ɣlaƒoƒo ƒe dzidze ŋutɔŋutɔ anɔ abe 3.1416 si nye (pi alo π).
Myth: The Bible says that the circumference of a circle is exactly three times its diameter, but the correct value is pi (π), or about 3.1416.
Nyateƒea: "Gazɔ gã la " si ƒe nya wogblɔ le 1 Fiawo 7:23 kple 2 Kronika 4:2 ɖee fia be eƒe didime tso to ɖeka yi kemea nye abɔklugui ewo eye "ka didime abɔklugui blaetɔ̃e " hiã hafi "akpee ɖo. "

Fact: The measurements of "the Sea of cast metal " given at 1 Kings 7:​23 and 2 Chronicles 4:2 indicate that it had a diameter of 10 cubits and that "it took a measuring line 30 cubits long to encircle it. "
Ate ŋu anɔ eme be woatsɔ nu sue aɖe kpe xexlẽme siawo alo aɖee le eme hafi woade pɛpɛpɛ.
These dimensions might have been merely the nearest round numbers.
Anɔ eme hã be gazɔa ƒe togodo kple eƒe didime tso eƒe toga ɖeka yi kemea tsi tsitre ɖi na gazɔa me kple egodo ƒe dzidze.
It is also possible that the circumference and diameter represented inner and outer measurements of the basin respectively.
Ðe Biblia Me Nyawo Do Xoxo Alo Wodo Ŋgɔ Na Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyaa?
Outdated or Ahead of Its Time?
DZƆDZƆMEŊUTINUNYA
SCIENCE
MENYE DZƆDZƆMEŊUTINUNYA GBALẼE BIBLIA NYE O, KE HÃ NU SIWO WÒGBLƆ KU ÐE DZƆDZƆMEŊUTINUNYA ŊU DO ŊGƆ SÃSÃSÃ NA NU SIWO WONYA ƔEMAƔI.
THE BIBLE IS NOT A SCIENCE TEXTBOOK, YET IT CONTAINS STATEMENTS THAT WERE WAY AHEAD OF THEIR TIME.
NA MÍADE ŊUGBLE LE KPƆÐEŊU ƲƐ AÐEWO ŊU KPƆ.
CONSIDER A FEW EXAMPLES.
Ðe gɔmedzedze li na xexea?
Did the physical universe have a beginning?
Tsã la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala bibiwo bui be nya ma ƒe ŋuɖoɖoe nye ao.
Leading scientists once felt strongly that the answer was no.
Fifia wova lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be gɔmedzedze li na xexea.
Now they generally accept that there was a beginning to the universe.
Biblia ya gblɔ nya ma xoxoxo eme kɔ. 1 Mose 1:1.
The Bible said that clearly all along.​ Genesis 1:1.
Aleke anyigba ƒe nɔnɔme le?
What is the shape of the earth?
Tsã la, ame geɖe susu be anyigbaa le gbadzaa.
In ancient times, many people thought that the earth was flat.
Le ƒe alafa atɔ̃lia Do Ŋgɔ Na Yesu (D.Y.) me la, Helatɔwo ƒe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔ be anyigba le godoo.
In the fifth century B.C.E., Greek scientists suggested that it was a sphere.
Gake do ŋgɔ kura na ema, le ƒe alafa enyilia D.Y. me la, Biblia ŋlɔla Yesaya gblɔ be ‘anyigba le nogoo’ eye esia ate ŋu afia "godoo. " Yesaya 40:22.
But long before that​ in the eighth century B.C.E.​ the Bible writer Isaiah referred to "the circle of the earth, " using a word that may also be rendered "sphere. "​ Isaiah 40:22; footnote.
Ðe dziƒowo ŋutɔŋutɔ dome ate ŋu agblẽa?
Are the physical heavens subject to decay?
Helatɔwo ƒe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala Aristotle, si nɔ anyi le ƒe alafa enelia D.Y. me la, bu be anyigba koe ate ŋu agblẽ, gake dziƒo si ɣletiviwo le ya matrɔ alo agblẽ o.
Greek scientist Aristotle, of the fourth century B.C.E., taught that decay happens only on the earth, while the starry heavens could never change or decay.
Eƒe susua nɔ amewo si ƒe alafa geɖe.
That view prevailed for many centuries.
Gake le ƒe alafa 19 lia me la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va nɔ gbɔgblɔm be nuwo ate ŋu atɔtɔ.
But in the 19th century, scientists formulated the concept of entropy.
Wogblɔ be nu siwo le dziƒo kple anyigba dzi la ate ŋu agblẽ.
It suggests that all matter, whether heavenly or earthly, tends to decay.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalaawo dometɔ ɖeka si do susu sia ɖe ŋgɔ si nye Lord Kelvin, va de dzesi nya si Biblia gblɔ tso dziƒo kple anyigba ŋu be: "Wo katã woanyunyɔ abe avɔ ene. "
One of the scientists who helped to advance this concept, Lord Kelvin, noted that the Bible says about heaven and earth: "Just like a garment they will all wear out. "
(Psalmo 102:25, 26) Abe ale si Biblia gblɔe ene la, Kelvin xɔe se be Mawu ate ŋu atiae be yeaxe mɔ be yeƒe nuwɔwɔwo dome nagagblẽ o. Nyagblɔla 1:4.
(Psalm 102:25, 26) Kelvin believed, as the Bible teaches, that God could choose to prevent such decay from destroying His creations.​ Ecclesiastes 1:4.
Nu kae lé ɣletinyigbawo abe míaƒe anyigba ene ɖe yame?
What holds up planets such as our earth?
Aristotle fia nu be dziƒonuwo le wo nɔewo me nogonogo, woate ŋu akpɔ nu to wo me, eye anyigba le woƒe titina.
Aristotle taught that all the heavenly bodies were encased in crystalline spheres, each one nested tightly within the next, with the earth innermost.
Kaka ƒe alafa 18 lia Kristotɔwo Ŋɔli (K.Ŋ.) naɖo la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va nɔ lɔlɔ̃m ɖe susu si nye be womeku ɣletiviwo kple ɣletinyigbawo ɖe naneke ŋu o la dzi.
By the 18th century C.E., scientists were accepting the idea that stars and planets might hang in a void.
Gake Hiob ƒe agbalẽ si woŋlɔ le ƒe alafa 15 lia D.Y. me gblɔ be Wɔla la "meku anyigba la ɖe naneke ŋu o. "
But in the book of Job, of the 15th century B.C.E., we read that the Creator is "suspending the earth upon nothing. "​ Job 26:7.
Hiob 26:7.
MEDICINE
ATIKEWƆNYAWO TOGBƆ BE MENYE ATIKEŊUTINUNYA GBALẼE BIBLIA NYE O HÃ, EƑO NUTSO MƆFIAME SIWO KU ÐE LÃMESẼNYAWO ŊU LA ŊU XOXOXO.
THE BIBLE, THOUGH NOT A MEDICAL TEXTBOOK, CONTAINS SOME PRINCIPLES THAT REFLECT ADVANCED KNOWLEDGE OF HEALTH.
Dɔnɔwo ɖeɖe ɖe aga.
Isolating sick people.
Mose ƒe Sea gblɔ be woaɖe ame siwo ŋu kpodɔ le la ɖe aga.
The Mosaic Law prescribed keeping people with leprosy separate from others.
Tso esime dɔvɔ̃wo do le ƒe alafa 5 lia K.Ŋ., va ɖo ƒe alafa 15 lia ƒe nuwuwu lɔƒo hafi ɖɔktawo va kpɔe be ele be woanɔ dɔnɔwo ɖem ɖe aga, eye wole ewɔm va se ɖe egbea. 3 Mose ta 13 kple 14.
Not until the plagues of the Middle Ages did medical doctors learn to apply this principle, which is still deemed effective.​ Leviticus, chapters 13 and 14.
Ele be woaklɔ asi ne woka asi ame kuku ŋu.
Washing after touching a dead body.
Do ŋgɔ na ƒe alafa 19 lia la, zi geɖea, ne ɖɔktawo ka asi ame kukuwo ŋu la, womeklɔa asi hafi kpɔa dɔnɔwo gbɔ o.
Until late in the 19th century, physicians often worked on corpses and then on living patients​ without washing their hands in between.
Esia na ame geɖe ku.
That practice caused many deaths.
Ke hã, Mose ƒe Sea gblɔ be ame sia ame si ka asi ame kuku ŋu la ŋu mekɔ o.
Yet, the Mosaic Law stated that anyone who touched a dead body was ceremonially unclean.
Sea gblɔ gɔ̃ hã be, ele be woazã tsi atsɔ akɔ amea ŋu.
It even directed that water be used for ceremonial cleansing in such cases.
Subɔsubɔnuwɔna mawo de wo dzi le lãmesẽnyawo gɔ̃ hã me.
Those religious practices surely had health benefits as well.​ Numbers 19:11, 19.
Waste disposal.
Afɔdzi ɖiɖi ɖe to me. Afɔdzi siwo womeɖi o nana mĩtsinyenyedɔ wua ɖevi gbogbo aɖewo ƒe sia ƒe.
Each year, over half a million children die of diarrhea, largely because of exposure to human waste that is not disposed of properly.
Mose ƒe Sea gblɔ be ele be woaɖi afɔdzi ɖe to me le afi si mete ɖe aƒewo ŋu o. 5 Mose 23:13.
The Mosaic Law said that human waste should be buried, disposed of away from human habitation.​ Deuteronomy 23:13.
Ɣeyiɣi si woatso aʋa.
Timing of circumcision.
Mawu ƒe Sea gblɔ be ne wodzi ŋutsuvi la, woatso aʋa nɛ le ŋkeke enyiagbe.
God’s Law stipulated that a male child should be circumcised on the eighth day of life.
(3 Mose 12:3) Ne wodzi vi la, axɔ abe kwasiɖa ɖeka ene hafi eƒe ʋua nate ŋu abla.
(Leviticus 12:3) In newborn babies, the blood’s ability to clot is understood to reach normal levels after the first week.
Le Biblia ŋlɔɣi, hafi atikewɔnyawo va de ŋgɔ la, ale si wolalana kwasiɖa ɖeka megbe hafi tsoa aʋa na ɖeviwo la, kpɔ wo ta.
In Bible times, before advanced medical treatments were available, waiting for over a week before circumcision was a wise protection.
Ale si nɔnɔme nyuiwo dea lãmesẽ dzi.
The link between emotional health and physical health.
Dɔdada ŋuti numekulawo kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔ be nɔnɔme nyuiwo abe dzidzɔ, mɔkpɔkpɔ, akpedada kple didi be woatsɔ ake dea ame ƒe lãmesẽ dzi.
Medical researchers and scientists say that positive emotions such as joy, hope, gratitude, and a willingness to forgive have some beneficial effects on health.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dzi kpɔdzidzɔ nye atike nyui, ke gbɔgbɔ si dzi nu te ɖo vevie la nana ŋusẽ vɔna le ame ŋu. " Lododowo 17:22.
The Bible says: "A joyful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit saps one’s strength. "​ Proverbs 17:22.
Ale Si Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya Ðea Vi Na Wòe
How Science Affects Your Life

Nyagɔmeɖegbalẽ aɖe ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya gɔme be, enye "nusɔsrɔ̃ tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ƒe nɔnɔme kple ɣletinyigba siwo le yamenutowo me ƒe zɔɖeɖe ŋu tsitotsito to wo dodo kpɔ, ŋkuléle ɖe wo ŋu kple wo ŋuti kɔntabubuwo me. "
Science, according to one dictionary, is "the systematic study of the nature and behaviour of the material and physical universe, based on observation, experiment, and measurement. "
Ebia kutrikuku geɖe hafi woawɔ esia, eye zi geɖe la, dɔa tea ɖeɖi ame ŋu.
To do all of that is hard, often frustrating, work.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kua kutri doa nuwo kpɔ heléa ŋku ɖe wo ŋu hena kwasiɖawo, ɣletiwo, alo ƒe geɖee gɔ̃ hã.
Scientists struggle with experiments and observations for weeks, months, or even years.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, woƒe agbagbadzedzewo meɖea vi aɖeke o, ke hã woƒe dɔawo ɖe vi na ameƒomea le go geɖe me.
Sometimes their labors lead to dead ends, but in many cases they deliver benefits to mankind.
Bu eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖewo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider a few examples.
Asitsaha aɖe si le Europa la tsɔ aŋe sesẽwo kple sranui deŋgɔwo tsɔ wɔ tsitsyɔnu aɖe si tsyɔa tsi ƒoɖi wòzua tsi nyui, be amewo nagano tsi ƒoɖi o, ale be woaƒo asa na dɔlélewo.
A European company has combined strong plastic and advanced filters to produce a device that has made it possible for a person to avoid illness from drinking contaminated water.
Wozãa tsitsyɔnu siawo ƒomevi ne dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le teƒe aɖewo, abe anyigbaʋuʋu si dzɔ le Haiti le ƒe 2010 me ene.
Devices like that one have been put to use during natural disasters, such as the 2010 earthquake in Haiti.
Woda mɔ̃ siwo woyɔna be satelait la ɖe yame ʋĩi woƒoa xlã anyigbaa hedoa ka kple wo nɔewo eye wozu mɔfianu si wona ŋkɔe be GPS.
High above the earth, networks of satellites make up what is called the Global Positioning System (GPS).
Togbɔ be le gɔmedzedzea me la, asrafowo koŋue wowɔ mɔfianu sia na hã, ekpena ɖe ʋukulawo, yameʋukulawo, melikulawo, adelawo kple mɔzɔla tsaɖilawo ŋu be woagabu o.
Originally designed for military applications, the GPS helps motorists, airplane pilots, ship navigators, and even hunters and hikers to find their way.
Ame siwo to GPS-mɔfianua vɛ la na wòle bɔbɔe fifia be mɔzɔla naɖo afi si yim wòle dedie.
Thanks to the scientists who invented it, the GPS makes it easier to get to where you want to go.
Ðe nèwɔa asitelefon, kɔmpiuta, alo Internet ŋu dɔa?
Do you use a cell phone, a computer, or the Internet?
Ðe nèkpɔe be wò dɔléle ka ɖe eme na ye alo yele lãmesẽ nyui me fifia le atike deŋgɔ si wowɔ na wò ta?
Have you seen that your health has improved or has been restored because of advanced medicine?
Ðe nèɖoa yameʋua?
Do you travel by airplane?
Ne èɖo eŋu be ɛ̃ la, ekema wò hã èle gome kpɔm le viɖe gbogbo siwo dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya he vɛ na ameƒomea la me.
If so, you are benefiting from some of the ways in which science has been a boon to humanity.
Ena agbea ka ɖe eme na wò le go geɖe me.
Science has affected your life in many positive ways.
DZƆDZƆMEŊUTINUNYA ƑE SEÐOƑE
THE REACH OF MODERN SCIENCE
Esi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le agbagba dzem be yewoadzi yewoƒe nunya ɖe edzi ta la, woyi edzi le numekuku wɔm le dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu le xexea me godoo egbea.
In an effort to expand their horizon, modern scientists are searching deep into the natural world.

Nukliaŋutinunyalawo léa ŋku ɖe ale si atɔm wɔa dɔe le etome ŋu, eye ɣletiviŋutinunyalawo hã srɔ̃a nu tso ale si ɣletiviwo nɔ le ƒe biliɔn geɖe siwo va yi me ŋu ale be yewoanya ale si xexe bliboa wɔ va dzɔ.
Nuclear physicists peer into the inner workings of the atom, while astrophysicists trace back billions of years, in an attempt to understand the origin of the universe.

Esi wole yamenutoa me tsam yi didiƒe ʋĩi hele nu siwo ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o kple nu siwo asi mate ŋu alé o dim ta la, wo dometɔ aɖewo xɔe se be, ne Mawu si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe la li la, ke ele be yewoake ɖe eŋu.
As they probe deep and far, even into realms that are invisible and untouchable, some scientists feel that if the God of the Bible exists, they should be able to find him.
Menye nu ma koe ame mawo kple xexemenunyala xɔŋkɔwo susu o.
Some prominent scientists and philosophers go further.
Ke wolé nu si dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala agbalẽŋlɔla Amir D. Aczel yɔ be, "dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ƒe kpeɖodzi siwo ɖee fia be Mawu meli o " hã me ɖe asi.
They carry on what science author Amir D. Aczel called "a scientific argument against the existence of God. "

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, wo dometɔ aɖe si wonya nyuie le xexea me godoo la gblɔ be, "esi womeke ɖe kpeɖodzi aɖeke ŋu be Mawu aɖe li si wɔ akpa vevi aɖe le xexe bliboa wɔwɔ me o ta la, esia ɖee fia ɖikekemanɔmee be mawu ma meli o. "
For example, a world-famous physicist claimed that "the absence of evidence for any God who plays an important role in the universe proves beyond a reasonable doubt that such a god does not exist. "
Eye wo dometɔ aɖewo hã gblɔna be "akunyawɔwɔ " kple "amefuflu manyatalenu " ye Mawu si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe la ƒe dɔwɔwɔwo nye.
Others allude to the activity of the God of the Bible as "magic " and "supernatural shenanigans. "
Gake biabia lae nye be: Ðe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo srɔ̃ nu tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu ale si dze be woaƒo nya keŋkeŋ azɔa?
However, the question must be asked: Has science learned enough about the natural world to be able to draw definitive conclusions?
Ŋuɖoɖoae nye ao.
The simple answer is no.
Togbɔ be wowɔ ŋgɔyiyi geɖe hã la, wo dometɔ geɖe lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be nu gbogbo aɖewo gali siwo yewomenya haɖe o, siwo ɖewohĩ yewomate ŋu anya gbeɖe o.
Science has made tremendous progress, but many scientists recognize that there are still many unknowns and perhaps unknowables.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala xɔŋkɔ, Steven Weinberg, si xɔ Nobel nunana le dzɔdzɔmenuwo gɔmesese ŋu la gblɔ be: "Míate ŋu anya nu tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu keŋkeŋ gbeɖe o. "
"We will never get to the bottom of things, " said physicist and Nobel laureate Steven Weinberg on understanding nature.
Nufialagã, Martin Rees, si nye Britain Fiaƒometɔ Ɣletiviŋutinunyala la, ŋlɔ bena: "Nanewo li siwo gɔme amegbetɔwo mate ŋu ase gbeɖe o. "
Professor Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal of Great Britain, wrote: "There may be things that humans will never understand. "
Nyateƒea ye nye be dzɔdzɔmenu geɖewo gakpɔtɔ li siwo gɔme dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala siwo li egbea mekpɔ se o tso lãmenugbagbevi suetɔ kekeake dzi yi ɖe nu siwo le xexe gbahooa me dzi.
The truth is that much of nature, from the tiny cell to the vast universe, still remains beyond the grasp of modern science.
Kpɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu siawo ɖa:
Note the following examples:
Domenyiŋusẽfianu Nugbagbeŋutinunyalawo mekpɔ se lãmenugbagbeviwo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ gɔme bliboe o.
DNA Biologists do not fully understand the processes that take place in living cells.
Eye nu siwo gɔme womekpɔ se o ye nye ale si lãmenugbagbeviwo nyia wo ɖokuiwoe, ale si wowɔa nunyiame siwo nye protein-wo kple ale si wowɔna dzina ɖe edzii.
How cells consume energy, how they produce proteins, and how they divide are questions science has not yet completely answered.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe ɖe asi le bɔl ŋu wòle kpo tim
A boy dropping a ball
Nuheŋusẽ kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe mía dzi gbe sia gbe le aɖabaƒoƒo ɖe sia ɖe me.
Gravity affects us every second of every day.
Ke hã, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo metea ŋu sea egɔme o.
Yet it is something of a mystery to physicists.
Womenya ale si tututu nuheŋusẽ hea wò ɖe anyi ne èti kpo alo ale si wòwɔna be ɣletia ƒoa xlã anyigbaa pɛpɛpɛ evɔ metena ɖa le eƒe mɔ dzi gbeɖe o.
They do not know fully how gravity pulls you down to the ground when you jump or how it keeps the moon in orbit around the earth.
Xexe gbahoo la
The universe
Yamenutomeŋutinunyalawo bu akɔnta be nu siwo wotsɔ wɔ xexe gbahooa la ƒe akpa si ade 95 le alafa me la nye nu makpɔmakpɔwo kple nu siwo woƒe mɔ̃wo mate ŋu ade dzesii o.
Cosmologists estimate that about 95 percent of what makes up the universe is invisible and undetectable by scientific instruments.
Woma nu wɔnuku sia ɖe akpa eve me heyɔ wo be nu makpɔmakpɔ kple ŋusẽ makpɔmakpɔ.
They divide this strange entity into two categories, dark matter and dark energy.
Womenya ale si tututu nu siawo ƒe nɔnɔme le va de asi na egbea o.
The nature of these remains unknown.
Nu bubu aɖewo hã li siwo dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo menya o, siwo nana wotɔtɔna.
There are other unknowns that confound scientists.
Nu ka tae nya sia le vevie ɖo?
Why is this important?
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala agbalẽŋlɔla xɔŋkɔ aɖe ŋlɔ bena: "Nu siwo míenya o la sɔ gbɔ sãsãsã wu nu siwo míenya.
A popular science writer notes: "Our knowledge is vastly outstripped by our ignorance.
Nye ya mekpɔe be ele be nu siwo nàsrɔ̃ le dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya me la nàwɔ nuku na wò eye wòaʋã wò be nàgasrɔ̃ nu geɖee tsɔ wu be nàde ga wò susu. "
For me, a life in science prompts awe and exploration over dogmatism. "

Ne ewɔ na wò be esusɔ vie dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya nava xɔ ɖe Biblia teƒe ahaɖe Mawu dzi xɔse ɖa kura la, ke bu nya sia ŋu kpɔ: Ne dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala bibiwo wɔ woƒe dɔwɔnu sesẽwo ŋu dɔ le numekukuwɔwɔ me evɔ nu sue aɖe koe wote ŋu nya le dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu la, ɖe wòasɔ be woaŋe aɖaba aƒu nu siwo womenya haɖe o la dzia?

So if you wonder whether science is about to replace the Bible and dispense with belief in God, consider this point: If brilliant scientists with their powerful instruments have been able to gain only limited understanding of the natural world, would it be logical to dismiss out of hand the matters that lie beyond the reaches of science to investigate?

Numekugbalẽ deŋgɔ aɖe yi nyaa gbɔ tẽe le nyati legbee aɖe si woŋlɔ ku ɖe ɣletiviŋutinunya ƒe ŋutinya kple eƒe ŋgɔyiyi ŋu la me esi wòƒo nya ta be: "Esi amegbetɔwo srɔ̃ nu tso ɣletiviwo ŋu ƒe 4,000 sɔŋ vɔ la, edze abe womenya nu boo aɖeke le xexe gbahoo sia ŋu o abe ale si ko wòanya nɔ le blema Babilontɔwo gome ene. " Encyclopedia Britannica.

Quite to the point, at the end of a lengthy article on the history and development of astronomy, Encyclopedia Britannica concludes: "After almost 4,000 years of astronomy, the universe is no less strange than it must have seemed to the Babylonians. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo dea bubu gome si le ame ɖe sia ɖe si be wòatso nya me le nya sia ŋu la ŋu.
Jehovah’s Witnesses respect each person’s right to make a decision on this matter.
Míedzea agbagba be míazɔ ɖe Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖo si nye, "Amewo katã nanyae be nugɔmeselawo mienye " la dzi.
We endeavor to follow the Biblical guideline: "Let your reasonableness become known to all. "
(Filipitɔwo 4:5) Esi nya sia le susu me na mí la, míele dzi dem ƒo na wò be nàxlẽ nu tso ale si Biblia kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya wɔ ɖeka hede nu wo nɔewo me la ŋu.
(Philippians 4:5) It is with that spirit that we invite you to examine how science and the Bible harmonize and complement each other.
Biblia La Kple Nyateƒenya Siwo Dzi Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya Ðo Kpee
The Bible and Proven Scientific Facts
Menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽ ye Biblia nye o.
The Bible does not claim to be a textbook of scientific knowledge.
Ke hã ame siwo ŋlɔe la gblɔ nyateƒenya siwo ado dzidzɔ na dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo egbea.
Its writers, however, did make accurate comments on matters that should interest scientists today.
Eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖewoe nye esiawo.
Here are some examples.
Xexe gbahoo la
The universe
Anyigbaa kple xexe bliboa ƒe ƒexɔxɔ
Age of the earth and the universe
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo bu akɔnta be ƒe biliɔn 4 ye nye esia tso esime wowɔ míaƒe anyigba la, eye anɔ abe ƒe biliɔn 13 va ɖo 14 ye nye esia wowɔ xexe bliboa.
Scientists estimate that the earth is about 4 billion years old and that the universe was born some 13 to 14 billion years ago.
Biblia megblɔ ƒe si me wowɔ xexe bliboa o.
The Bible sets no date for the creation of the universe.
Eye megblɔ le afi aɖeke be ƒe akpe ʋɛ aɖewo koe nye esia wowɔ anyigbaa o.
In no place does it affirm that the earth is only a few thousand years old.

Biblia ƒe mawunyakpukpui gbãtɔ gblɔ be: "Le gɔmedzedzea me Mawu wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba. " (1 Mose 1:1) Nyaa gbɔgblɔ gbadza alea ʋu mɔnukpɔkpɔ ɖi na dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo be woato woƒe aɖaŋu deŋgɔwo dzi anya ƒe si xexea xɔ.

The very first verse in the Bible reads: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. " (Genesis 1:1) That general statement allows scientists to determine the age of the physical world according to sound scientific principles.
Towo, gbe damawo, kple tsi
Mountains, vegetation, and water
Anyigba la dzadzraɖo be amegbetɔwo nanɔ edzi
Preparation of the earth for human habitation
Wozã nyagbe "ŋkeke " le 1 Mose ta 1 esi wole nu ƒom tso ɣeyiɣi siwo me wodzra anyigbaa dzi ɖo be nu gbagbe ƒomeviwo katã nanɔ edzi la ŋu.
Genesis chapter 1 uses the term "day " to set out the stages in the preparation of the earth for life in all its diverse forms.
Nu mamlɛtɔ si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le nuwɔwɔwo ƒe ŋutinya kpui sia mee nye amegbetɔwɔwɔ.
The culminating event in this simple description was the appearance of humans.
Biblia meyɔ nuwɔwɔ ƒe "ŋkeke " adeawo ƒe didime o.
The Bible fixes no duration for the six creative "days. "
Ke boŋ egblẽ nyatakaka ma ɖi be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala siwo li egbea nato woƒe numekukuwo dzi anya ɣeyiɣi ƒe didime si tututu wotsɔ wɔ xexeae.
Instead, it opens the door for modern scientists to study them and assign accurate time spans to them.
Míenyae be nuwɔwɔ ƒe ‘ŋkekeawo’ didi sãsãsã wu ŋkeke siwo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nye gaƒoƒo 24.
We know that the creative "days " were much longer than 24-hour days.
Anyigba la
The earth
Ale si wòdzɔe be anyigba la li ke le yame
How the earth is suspended
Biblia gblɔ be womeku anyigba la ɖe "naneke ŋu " o.
The Bible describes the earth as suspended "upon nothing. "
(Hiob 26:7) Womegblɔ be míaƒe anyigba la le ame dzɔtsu aɖe ƒe abɔta alo atiglinyi siwo le tsitre ɖe klo aɖe dzi la ƒe dzime abe ale si blema xotutu nyanyɛ aɖewo gblɔe ene o.
(Job 26:7) There is no mention of our planet resting on the shoulders of a giant or on the backs of elephants that stand on a turtle, as some popular myths of ancient times had it.
Ke boŋ nya si Biblia gblɔ la ʋu mɔ ɖi na dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo wova ke ɖe nyateƒea ŋu.
Rather, the Bible leaves the door open to scientific discovery.
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Nicolaus Copernicus kple Johannes Kepler woɖe ale si ŋusẽ makpɔmakpɔ aɖe na ɣletinyigbawo ƒoa xlã ɣe lae la me.
In time, Nicolaus Copernicus and Johannes Kepler described how the planets move around the sun driven by an invisible force.
Esia megbe la, Isaac Newton va ɖe ale si ɣletinyigba siwo katã le xexe gbahooa me la zɔna ɖe xlãƒoƒo ƒe sea nu la me.
Isaac Newton later showed how gravitation governs the movement of all objects in space.
Dɔlékuiwo
Rod-shaped bacteria
Mɔfiamewo le dzadzɛnyenye kple asaƒoƒo na dɔlélewo ŋu
Instructions on disease control and hygiene
Wona mɔfiamewo Israel-viwo le Mose ƒe Agbalẽ Etɔ̃lia me ku ɖe ale si woawɔ be dɔxɔleameŋuwo nagakaka ɖe dukɔa me o ŋu; se si ku ɖe ameɖeɖe ɖe aga ŋu hã le eme.
The book of Leviticus contains the instructions given to the Israelites on how they were to avoid outbreaks of contagious diseases, including the practice of quarantine.
Eye wode se na Israel-viwo ku ɖe dzadzɛnyenye ŋu le 5 Mose 23:12, 13 be woade afɔdzi le asaɖa la godo.
And regarding sanitation, the law recorded at Deuteronomy 23:12, 13 ordered the Israelites to care for their waste in a private place outside their encampments.
Ele be woade afɔdzi ɖe do me ‘ahaxe ke ɖe edzi.’
They had to ‘cover their excrement’ in the ground.
Gake ƒe 200 aɖewo koe nye esia dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kple ɖɔktawo kpɔe be ehiã be amewo nawɔ ɖe mɔfiame sia dzi.
It is only in the last 200 years that scientists and doctors have seen the need to set such standards.
Ƒe alafa geɖewoe nye esia tso esime woŋlɔ Biblia ƒe mɔfiame siwo nèxlẽ fifia la ɖi.
The Bible information that you just read was written down many centuries ago.
Aleke Biblia-ŋlɔlawo wɔ nya nyateƒenya mawo esime ame siwo nye nunyala gãwo ɣemaɣi la menya naneke tso mɔfiame mawo ŋu o?
How did those writers come up with such accurate information when even the most learned people of their time were ignorant of such things?
Ame si na woŋlɔ Biblia la ɖo eŋu be: "Ale si dziƒowo kɔ boo wu anyigbae la, nenemae nye mɔwo kɔ wu miaƒe mɔwo, eye nye susuwo kɔ wu miaƒe susuwoe. "
The Bible’s Author answers: "As the heavens are higher than the earth, so my ways are higher than your ways and my thoughts than your thoughts. "
Yesaya 55:9.
Isaiah 55:9.
Ðe Biblia Fia Nu Be Anyigba La Le Gbadzaa?
Does the Bible Teach That the Earth Is Flat?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, Biblia mefia nu be anyigba la le gbadzaa o.
No, the Bible does not teach that the earth is flat.
Menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽe Biblia nye o.
The Bible is not a science textbook.
Ke hã, Biblia me nya aɖeke metsi tre ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si ŋu kakaɖedzi le ŋu o.
At the same time, nothing in the Bible contradicts proved science.
Míate ŋu "aɖo ŋu ɖe " nya siwo Biblia gblɔ la "ŋu ɖaa tegbee. " Psalmo 111:8.
What the Bible says is "always reliable, now and forever. "​ Psalm 111:8.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ be "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " gɔme ɖe?
What does the Bible mean by "the four corners of the earth "?
Ke tetekpɔ si Abosam he va Yesu dzi ya ɖe?
What about the Devil’s temptation of Jesus?
Nya si Biblia gblɔ be "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " gɔme ɖe?
What does the Bible mean by "the four corners of the earth "?
Mele be míase nyagbɔgblɔ "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " kple "anyigba ƒe mlɔenuwo " si Biblia zã la gɔme ɖe nyagbeawo ŋutɔŋutɔ nu abe ɖe dzogoe ene le anyigba si alo abe ɖe seƒe le anyigba si ene o.
The expressions "the four corners of the earth " and "the ends of the earth " used in the Bible are not to be taken literally, as if the earth were square or had ends.
(Yesaya 11:12; Hiob 37:3) Ke boŋ, edze ƒãa be wonye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ siwo fia anyigba bliboa katã dzi.
(Isaiah 11:12; Job 37:3) Instead, these evidently are figures of speech referring to the entire surface of the earth.
Gɔmesese ma ke nue Biblia zãa nyagbɔgblɔ si nye "ɣedzeƒe, ɣetoɖoƒe, dziehe kple anyiehe " le.
The Bible uses the four points of the compass in a similar way.​ Luke 13:29.
Luka 13:29. Anɔ eme be Hebrigbe me nya si gɔme woɖe be ‘dzogoe’ alo ‘mlɔenu’ la nye adagana si wotu ɖe nya si wozãna na "aʋala " la dzi.
The Hebrew term translated "corners " or "ends " seems to be an idiom based on the word for "wings. "
Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be, "esi xewo tsɔa woƒe aʋala tsyɔa wo viwo dzi ta la, [Hebrigbe me nya sia] fia nu sia nu si me wohe la ƒe mlɔenuwo. "

According to The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia, "because the wing of a bird is used as a covering for its young, [this Hebrew term] acquires the meaning of the extremity of anything stretched out. "
Agbalẽ sia ke gagblɔ be nya siwo wozã le Hiob 37:3 kple Yesaya 11:12 la fia "anyigba ƒe liƒowo, mlɔenuwo, alo eƒe yɔyrɔenuwo. "
The same reference work adds that at Job 37:3 and Isaiah 11:12, "the term means the coasts, boundaries, or extremities of the land surface of the earth. "
Ke tetekpɔ si Abosam he va Yesu dzi ya ɖe?
What about the Devil’s temptation of Jesus?
Esi Abosam be yeate Yesu kpɔ la, ekplɔe "yi to aɖe si kɔkɔ ŋutɔ la dzi, eye wòɖe xexemefiaɖuƒewo katã kple woƒe ŋutikɔkɔe fiae. "
To tempt Jesus, "the Devil took him along to an unusually high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. "
(Mateo 4:8) Ame aɖewo gblɔna be Biblia me ŋutinya sia ɖee fia be ame ate ŋu akpɔ xexe bliboa ne etɔ ɖe teƒe ɖeka le anyigba la si le gbadzaa dzi.
(Matthew 4:8) Some claim that this Bible account teaches that the entire world is visible from a single spot on a flat earth.
Ke hã, edze abe "to aɖe si kɔkɔ ŋutɔ " si dze le nuŋlɔɖi sia me la nye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ ene, ke menye teƒe ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
However, the "unusually high mountain " in this account seems to be a metaphor and not a physical location.
Kpɔ nu si tae susu le nyataƒoƒo sia me la ɖa.
Consider why this conclusion is reasonable.
To aɖeke mele anyigba dzi si dzi woatsi tsitre ɖo akpɔ xexemefiaɖuƒewo katã o.
There is no literal mountain on earth from which all the kingdoms of the world are visible.
Menye fiaɖuƒewo katã koe Abosam ɖe fia Yesu o, ke woƒe "ŋutikɔkɔe " hã.
The Devil showed Jesus not only all the kingdoms but also "their glory. "
Ame mate ŋu anɔ teƒe didi aɖe akpɔ nu mawo gbegbe o, eya ta edze abe Abosam ɖe nu mawo fia Yesu to ŋutega ƒomevi aɖe dzi ene.
Such details could not be seen from a great distance, so it seems that the Devil used some sort of vision to show these to Jesus.
Míate ŋu atsɔ esia asɔ kple ale si woɖea xexea ƒe akpa bubuwo fiana le filmwo me egbea.
This could be similar to the way a person uses a projector and a screen to show someone pictures of various places on earth.
Nudzɔdzɔ sia ke ŋuti nuŋlɔɖi si dze le Luka 4:5 gblɔ be Abosam ɖe "anyigbadzifiaɖuƒewo katã [fia Yesu] le ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe ko me, " evɔ manya wɔ be ame natsɔ ŋku dzro ko awɔ esia o.
The parallel account at Luke 4:5 says that the Devil showed Jesus "all the kingdoms of the inhabited earth in an instant of time, " which would not be possible through normal human vision.
Esia fia be Abosam to mɔ aɖe dzi ɖe nu mawo fia Yesu tsɔ tee kpɔ, ke menye be ena wòkpɔ wo kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
This implies that the Devil presented this temptation to Jesus through some means other than literal human sight.
ŊKUÐOÐO BLEMATƆ AÐEWO DZI
PORTRAITS FROM THE PAST
Ignaz Semmelweis
Ignaz Semmelweis
Ignaz Semmelweis
Ignaz Semmelweis
AƑETƆ Ignaz Semmelweis nye ame si ame geɖe menya o, ke hã eƒe dɔ ɖea vi na ƒome geɖe egbea.
IGNAZ SEMMELWEIS may not be a household name, yet his work has benefited most modern families.
Wodzii le dugã si nye Buda (si woyɔna fifia be Budapest) le Hungary, eye wòxɔ yunivɛsiti ɖaseɖigbalẽ le atikewɔnyawo me le dugã si nye Vienna ƒe yunivɛsiti le ƒe 1844 me.
Born in Buda (now Budapest), Hungary, he received his medical degree at the University of Vienna in 1844.
Esi wòva zu nufialagã aɖe ƒe kpeɖeŋutɔ le kɔdzi si wodzia vi le le Vienna le ƒe 1846 me la, ede dzesi kuxi gã aɖe si nye asrã ƒomevi aɖe si wua funɔ siwo va dzi vi ƒe 13 le alafa me.

On taking up his post as assistant to a professor at the First Maternity Clinic of Vienna’s General Hospital in 1846, Semmelweis faced an appalling reality​ more than 13 percent of the women giving birth there died from a disease called childbed fever.
Ame geɖe do susu vovovo siwo gbɔ dɔlélea anya tso la ɖa, ke hã, wo dometɔ aɖeke mete ŋu kpɔ ta nɛ o.
Various theories as to the cause of this disease had been proposed, yet no one had solved the mystery.
Agbagba siwo katã wodze be woaɖe funɔwo ƒe kuku dzi akpɔtɔ la medze edzi o.
All attempts to reduce the mortality rate proved futile.
Esi aƒetɔ Semmelweis yi edzi nɔ tame bum tso ale si vidadawo sea veve hekunae ŋu la, eɖoe kplikpaa be yeadi nu si gbɔ dɔlélea tso ahaxe mɔ nɛ.
Troubled by the spectacle of numerous mothers suffering a slow, agonizing death, Semmelweis determined to find the cause of the disease and prevent it.
Vidzidzidɔwɔƒe evee le kɔdzi si aƒetɔ Semmelweis wɔa dɔ le, eye edze gaglã be funɔ siwo kuna le vidziƒe gbãtɔ sɔa gbɔ wu funɔ siwo kuna le vidziƒe evelia.
The hospital in which Semmelweis worked had two separate maternity clinics, and curiously, the maternal death rate was much higher in the first clinic than it was in the second.
Vovototo si le vidziƒe eve siawo domee nye be wofia nu sukuvi siwo ava nye ɖɔktawo le vidzidzidɔwɔƒe gbãtɔ eye wofiaa vixexe le evelia me.
The only difference between the two clinics was that medical students were taught in the first and midwives in the second.
Ke nu ka gbɔe wòtso be amewo kuna le vidzidzidɔwɔƒe gbãtɔ wu evelia?
Why, then, such a difference in death rates?
Aƒetɔ Semmelweis ku nu geɖe me tso nu vovovo siwo gbɔ dɔlélea anya tso ŋu gake gbeɖegbeɖea koe.
Probing that question, Semmelweis systematically eliminated possible causes of the disease, but the culprit remained elusive.
Le ƒe 1847 me la, aƒetɔ Semmelweis kpɔ nane si ate ŋu akpe ɖe eŋu wòakpɔ ta na kuxia.
In early 1847, Semmelweis was presented with a crucial clue.
Eƒe dɔwɔhati si ganye exɔlɔ̃ si ŋkɔe nye Jakob Kolletschka xɔ abi esime wònɔ ame kuku aɖe dom kpɔ si wɔe be dɔlékuiwo to abia me ge ɖe lãme nɛ si na wòku.
His colleague and friend Jakob Kolletschka had died from blood poisoning after sustaining a wound while performing a postmortem examination.
Esi aƒetɔ Semmelweis nɔ dodokpɔ si wowɔ tso nu si wu exɔlɔ̃a xlẽm la, ekpɔe be le mɔ aɖe nu la, dɔléle si wui la sɔ kple dɔléle si nɔa funɔawo wum.
As he read the report of the autopsy performed on Kolletschka, Semmelweis realized that in some aspects, the findings were identical to those of the victims of childbed fever.
Eya ta aƒetɔ Semmelweis ƒo nya ta be ɖewohĩ "aɖi " aɖe si le ame kukuwo ŋue nɔa funɔawo wum.
Hence, Semmelweis thought that perhaps what he termed "poisons " from cadavers were infecting pregnant patients, thus causing childbed fever.
Ekpɔe be ɖɔkta kple sukuvi siwo doa ame kukuwo kpɔna edziedzi hafi yia vixeƒea la tsɔa dɔlékuiawo tsoa ame kukuawo ŋu eye funɔwo xɔa dɔa tso wo gbɔ le manyamanya me ne wole wo dom kpɔ!

Doctors and medical students, who frequently did autopsies before going to the maternity ward, had unwittingly been transmitting the disease to expectant mothers during obstetric examinations or childbirth!
Funɔ siwo vana vidzidzidɔwɔƒe evelia mekuna dea gbãtɔ nu o elabena vixela siwo wɔa dɔ le vidzidzidɔwɔƒe evelia ya mewɔa dɔ le ame kukuwo ŋu o.
Mortality in the second ward was lower because students of midwifery did not perform autopsies.
Aƒetɔ Semmelweis de se enumake be ele vevie be woanɔ asi klɔm, eye woazã atike siwo wua nugbagbevi suesuesuewo hã atsɔ anɔ asi klɔm hafi ado funɔwo kpɔ.
Semmelweis immediately introduced a strict policy of handwashing, which included sterilizing the hands in a solution of chlorinated lime before initiating examinations of pregnant women.
Nu siwo do tso eme la wɔ nuku ŋutɔ: ale si funɔwo kunae dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ kura tso 18.27 le alafa me le April me va ɖo 0.19 le alafa me le ƒea ƒe nuwuwu.
The results were dramatic: mortality rates plummeted from 18.27 percent in April to 0.19 percent by the end of the year.
"Taɖodzinu si le nu si mefiana ŋue nye be wòakpe ɖe vidzidzidɔwɔƒewo ŋu be woakpɔ nyɔnuwo ta na wo srɔ̃wo kple vidadawo ta na wo viwo. " Ignaz Semmelweis
"My doctrines exist to rid maternity hospitals of their horror, to preserve the wife for her husband and the mother for her child. "​ Ignaz Semmelweis
Menye ame sia amee da asi ɖe nu si ŋu aƒetɔ Semmelweis ke ɖo la dzi o.
Not all welcomed Semmelweis’ success.
Nu si ŋu wòke ɖo tso nu si gbɔ funɔwo ƒe ku tsona la tsi tre ɖe eƒe tatɔ ƒe nufiafia si ku ɖe nu si le kua hem vɛ la ŋu, Semmelweis ƒe tɔtete ɖe nu siwo ŋu wòke ɖo dzi ku dzi na eƒe tatɔa.
The results he obtained challenged the theories concerning childbed fever held by his superior, who also found Semmelweis’ insistent manner irritating.
Ema wɔe be mlɔeba la, dɔ va ge le aƒetɔ Semmelweis si le Vienna kɔa dzi si na wòtrɔ yi Hungary.
Semmelweis eventually lost his post in Vienna and returned to Hungary.
Le afi sia la, eva nye dɔdzikpɔla le funɔwo dzi kpɔƒe le St. Rochus Kɔdzi, le dugã si nye Pest me eye esi wònaa ɖɔktawo klɔa asi hafi kpɔa funɔwo gbɔ ta la, funɔwo ƒe kuku dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ kura.
There he took charge of the obstetrics department at the St. Rochus Hospital in Pest, where his methods brought down the mortality rate for childbed fever to under 1 percent.
Le ƒe 1861 me la, eŋlɔ nu tso eƒe dɔa ŋu ɖe agbalẽ si nye Nu Si Gbɔ Funɔwo Ƒe Ku Tsona Kple Ale Si Woalé Enu (ele Eŋlisigbe me).
In 1861, Semmelweis published his life’s work, The Cause, Concept, and Prophylaxis of Childbed Fever.
Nublanuitɔe la, amewo mekpɔ vevienyenye si le nu si ŋu wòke ɖo la ŋu o hena ƒe geɖe.
Unfortunately, the importance of his findings was not recognized until some years later.
Ema wɔe be ame gbogbo aɖewo siwo woate ŋu axɔ ɖe agbe hafi la ku nublanuitɔe.
In the meantime, countless lives that could have been saved were tragically lost.
Ðɔktawo le asi klɔm
Doctors wash their hands
Aƒetɔ Semmelweis kpɔ egbɔ be kɔdzidɔwɔlawo klɔa asi le kɔdzi si nɔ eƒe dzikpɔkpɔ te. Robert Thom ye ta nu sia
Semmelweis enforced hygienic measures at medical facilities under his supervision.​ Painting by Robert Thom
Wova kpɔe emegbe be aƒetɔ Semmelweis hã le ame siwo gbɔ wòtso be wova wɔ atike siwo wua nugbagbevi suesuesue siwo dea dɔ lãme na ame la dome.
Semmelweis was eventually recognized as one of the fathers of the modern antiseptic technique.
Nu siwo ŋu wòke ɖo na wova kpɔe be nugbagbevi suesuesue siwo ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o gɔ̃ hã ate ŋu ade dɔ lãme na ame.
His work helped to establish that microscopic matter can cause disease.
Eya hã wɔ akpa aɖe hafi wova nyae be nugbagbevi suesuesuewo tea ŋu dea dɔ lãme na ame eye enye nu "ɖedzesi aɖe le atikewɔnyawo me. "
He is part of the history of the germ theory of disease, which has been called "the single most important contribution to medical science and practice. "
Ewɔ nuku be ƒe 3,000 do ŋgɔ la, Mose ƒe Sea, si va nye Biblia ƒe akpa aɖe na mɔfiame ku ɖe nu si ame awɔ ne eka asi ame kuku ŋu la ŋu.
Interestingly, over 3,000 years earlier, the Mosaic Law, which was later included in the Bible, had already provided sound guidance on the proper handling of corpses.
EŊUTINYA VEVI AÐEWO
QUICK FACTS
Le ƒe alafa 19 lia me la, asrã ƒomevi aɖe wu funɔ 30 le alafa me le Europa.
In 19th-century Europe, many women died of childbed fever, a scourge with mortality rates of up to 30 percent.
Wotsɔa nusuekpɔmɔ̃ kpɔa nugbagbevi suesuesuewo tso keke ƒe 1674 me ke, gake womenya afɔku si gbegbe le nugbagbevi suesuesuewo ŋu o.
Microbes had been observed under a microscope as early as 1674, but their dangers had not been fully understood.
Ebɔ ɣemaɣi be ɖɔktawo nado ame kuku kpɔ evɔ womaklɔ asi hafi axe vi na funɔwo o.
It was common practice for doctors to deliver babies right after performing autopsies, without first sterilizing their hands.
Aƒetɔ Semmelweis gbɔe wòtso be ɖɔktawo klɔa asi ne wole dɔ dam na dɔnɔwo, si wɔe be wokpɔa ame geɖewo ƒe agbe ta.
Semmelweis introduced handwashing into medical practice, thus saving countless lives.
Nya Si Biblia Gblɔ
What the Bible Said
Le Se si Mawu na Israel-viwo to Mose dzi le ƒe alafa 16 lia D.Y. me la, ame si ka asi ame kuku ŋu la ŋu mekɔ o hena ŋkeke adre eye ele be wòakɔ eɖokui ŋu to tsilele kple eƒe nuwo nyanya dzi.

According to the Mosaic Law, which dates to the 16th century B.C.E., anyone touching a corpse became unclean for seven days and had to undergo a cleansing procedure that included bathing and washing his garments.
Le ɣeyiɣi sia me la, mele be wòaka asi amewo ŋu o. 4 Mose 19:11-22.
During this time, the person was to avoid physical contact with others.​ Numbers 19:11-22.
ŊKUÐOÐO BLEMATƆ AÐEWO DZI
PORTRAITS FROM THE PAST
Galileo
Galileo
Le ƒe alafa wuienelia kple wuiadelia me la, Europatɔwo ƒe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kple xexemenunyalawo va te xexe gbahoo sia gɔme sese le mɔ si to vovo na Katolikoha ƒe nufiafiawo nu.
Between the 14th and 16th centuries, European scientists and philosophers began to understand the universe in a way that conflicted with the teachings of the Catholic Church.
Ame siawo dometɔ ɖeka si gbugbɔ ŋku lé ɖe yamenuto me ŋue nye Galileo Galilei.
One man who took a fresh look at the heavens was Galileo Galilei.
DO ŊGƆ na Galileo ŋɔli la, ame geɖewo xɔe se be ɖe ɣe, ɣletinyigba kple ɣletiwo nɔa xlã ƒom míaƒe anyigba la.
BEFORE Galileo’s time, many people believed that the sun, the planets, and the stars all revolved around the earth.
Dzixɔse mae nye Katolikohaa ƒe nufiafia.
That belief was part of the official dogma of the Catholic Church.
Gake esi Galileo zã eƒe didiƒekpɔmɔ̃ tsɔ kpɔ yamenutowo me la, ekpɔ kpeɖodzi siwo ɖee fia be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ƒe nufiafia si dzi ame geɖewo da asi ɖo la mele eteƒe o.
With his telescope, however, Galileo saw evidence that contradicted widely accepted scientific teachings.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi wòkpɔ nu yibɔyibɔ siwo dzena le ɣea ŋu abe ɖe wole zɔzɔm ene la, ekpɔe dze sii be ɖe ɣea nɔ totrom le eɖokui si.
For example, as he watched sunspots appear to shift across the surface of the sun, he discerned that the sun rotates on an axis.
Nu siawo tɔgbi nyanya na be amegbetɔwo gava nya nu geɖe tso xexe gbahoo sia ŋu. Ke hã, esia he masɔmasɔ de Galileo kple Katolikohaa dome.
Observations like this greatly increased man’s knowledge of the universe, yet they would also result in Galileo’s coming into direct conflict with the Catholic Church.
DZƆDZƆMEŊUTINUNYA KPLE MAWUSUBƆSUBƆ
SCIENCE AND RELIGION
Galileo ɖe nu siwo ŋu wòke ɖo la ɖe go
Galileo publicizing his discoveries
Ƒe geɖe do ŋgɔ la, Polandtɔwo ƒe ɣletiviŋununyala Nicolaus Copernicus fia nu be anyigba la ƒoa xlã ɣea.
Decades earlier, the Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus developed a theory that the earth moves around the sun.
Galileo srɔ̃ nu tso Copernicus ƒe nufiafia ku ɖe ɣe kple ɣletinyigbawo ƒe zɔɖeɖe ŋu eye wòƒo kpeɖodzi siwo le nufiafia sia ŋu la nu ƒu.
Galileo studied Copernicus’ work on the movements of celestial bodies and collected evidence in harmony with the theory.
Le gɔmedzedzea la, Galileo medi be yeaɖe nu siwo ŋu yeke ɖo la ɖe go o, elabena enɔ vɔvɔ̃m be amewo ava ɖu fewu le ye ŋu.
Initially, Galileo hesitated to publicize some of his observations, fearing that they would be met with ridicule and scorn.
Gake mete ŋu ɣla dzi si gbegbe nɔ edzɔm ɖe nu siwo wòkpɔ le didiƒekpɔmɔ̃a me ta la o, eya ta mlɔeba la eɖe nu siwo ŋu wòke ɖo la ɖe go.
Unable to restrain his enthusiasm for what he saw through his telescope, he eventually went public with his discoveries.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala aɖewo bu eƒe nyawo be wonye vlodoamenyawo, eye eteƒe medidi hafi subɔsubɔhaŋgɔnɔlawo va nɔ vlo dom Galileo le woƒe mawunyagbɔgblɔwo me o.
Some scientists found his arguments to be provocative, and soon clergymen were discrediting Galileo from their pulpits.
Le ƒe 1616 me la, Papatenɔla Bellarmine, "ame si nye mawunyaŋununyala xɔŋkɔ ɣemaɣi " la gblɔ na Galileo be Katolikohaa ɖe se yeye aɖe ɖe go si tsi tre ɖe Copernicus ƒe nufiafia ŋu.
In 1616, Cardinal Bellarmine, "a leading theologian of the period, " informed Galileo of a newly issued Catholic decree against Copernicus’ ideas.
Eƒoe ɖe Galileo nu vevie be wòawɔ ɖe sedede ma dzi, ale wɔ Galileo megagblɔ le dutoƒo kpɔ be anyigbaa ƒoa xlã ɣe la o hena ƒe geɖe.
He strongly urged Galileo to comply with that decree, and for years thereafter Galileo did not argue publicly that the earth moves around the sun.
Le ƒe 1623 me la, Papa Urban VIII, ame si nye Galileo xɔlɔ̃ dze dziɖuɖu gɔme.
In 1623, Pope Urban VIII, Galileo’s friend, began to reign.
Eya ta le ƒe 1624 me la, Galileo bia tso esi be wòate fli ɖe ƒe 1616 ƒe sededea me.
So in 1624, Galileo asked the pope to revoke the 1616 decree.
Gake ɖeko Papa Urban bia tso Galileo si be wòaɖe Copernicus kple Aristotle ƒe nufiafia siwo tsi tsitre ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu la gɔme le mɔ aɖe nu be wòagade wo dometɔ aɖeke dzi o.
Instead, Urban urged Galileo to explain the conflicting theories of Copernicus and Aristotle in a way that favored neither.
Galileo ŋlɔ agbalẽ si ŋkɔe nye Xexemenuɖoanyi Gãtɔwo Me Dzodzro (ele yevugbe me).
Galileo then wrote a book entitled Dialogue on the Great World Systems.
Togbɔ be papa la xlɔ̃ nu Galileo be eƒe numeɖeɖea megade ame aɖeke dzi o hã la, eƒe agbalẽa va de Copernicus ƒe nufiafia boŋ dzi.
Although the pope had ordered Galileo to be neutral, the book came across as favoring Copernicus’ conclusions.
Eteƒe medidi o Galileo ƒe futɔwo va nɔ gbɔgblɔm be eƒe agbalẽa me nyawo klo bubu le papa ŋu.
Soon Galileo’s enemies were claiming that his book ridiculed the pope.
Esi wobu fɔ Galileo be edze aglã ɖe sɔlemehaa ŋu eye wodo vɔvɔ̃ nɛ be yewoawɔ funyafunyae ta la, egbe nu le Copernicus ƒe nufiafiawo gbɔ.
Accused of heresy and threatened with torture, Galileo was forced to deny the teachings of Copernicus.
Le ƒe 1633 me la, Romatɔwo Ƒe Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea bu fɔe hesikae ɖe aƒe me eye wòde se ɖe eƒe agbalẽwo xexlẽ nu na amewo.
In 1633, the Roman Inquisition sentenced him to perpetual house arrest and banned his writings.
Galileo ku le aƒe me le January 8, 1642 le Arcetri si te ɖe Florence ŋu.
Galileo died at home in Arcetri, near Florence, on January 8, 1642.
Papa John Paul II (Jean-Paul II) lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Katolikohaa bu fɔ Galileo madzemadzee
Pope John Paul II acknowledged that the Catholic Church had wrongly condemned Galileo
Wobu Galileo ƒe agbalẽwo dometɔ aɖewo de agbalẽ siwo nu Katolikohaa de se ɖo be womegaxlẽ o la dome ƒe alafa geɖe.
For hundreds of years, some of Galileo’s works remained on the index of books that Catholics were not permitted to read.
Gake le ƒe 1979 me la, sɔlemehaa gbugbɔ ŋku lé ɖe ale si Romatɔwo Ƒe Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea kpɔ nyaa gbɔ ƒe 300 aɖewoe nye ema va yi la ŋu.
But in 1979, the church reconsidered the action taken by the Roman Inquisition 300 years earlier.
Mlɔeba le ƒe 1992 me la, Papa John Paul II (Jean-Paul II) lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Katolikohaa bu fɔ Galileo madzemadzee.
Finally, in 1992, Pope John Paul II acknowledged that the Catholic Church had wrongly condemned Galileo.
EŊUTINYA VEVI AÐEWO
QUICK FACTS
Wodzi Galileo Galilei le ƒe 1564 me le Pisa si le Italy. Wonya Pisa-du sia ɖe eƒe xɔ kɔkɔ si bi ɖe akpa ɖeka ta.
Galileo Galilei was born in 1564 in Pisa, Italy, the city famous for its leaning tower.
Efia nu le Padua Yunivɛsiti eye emegbe wòva nɔ Florence hewɔ dɔ le afi ma.
He taught at the University of Padua and later lived and worked in Florence.
Togbɔ be menye Galileo ye to didiƒekpɔmɔ̃ vɛ o hã la, etrɔ asi le eŋu ale be wòkpɔa nu nyuie wu si wɔe be wova kpɔ ale si woagazãe wòaɖe vi wu.
Although Galileo did not invent the telescope, he greatly improved its magnification and thus its usefulness.

Esi wònye be Galileo ƒe susu le xexe gbahooa ŋu to vovo na ame bubuwo tɔ ta la, wosamae ɖe Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe zi eve. Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe nye Katolikohaa ƒe ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe si hea to na ame siwo trɔ ɖa le sɔlemehaa ƒe dzixɔsewo yome.
Because of his views on the universe, Galileo was twice called before the Inquisition the Catholic tribunal responsible for the punishment of those who deviated from church doctrine.
Ðe Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea Wɔ Funyafunya Galileo Ŋutɔŋutɔa?
Did the Inquisition Torture Galileo?
Blemaŋutinyaŋlɔla aɖewo gblɔ be Romatɔwo Ƒe Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea wɔ funyafunya Galileo ŋutɔŋutɔ.
Some historians have suggested that the Roman Inquisition may have physically tortured Galileo.
Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea gblɔ be ehiã be "woabia gbe [Galileo] ŋkubiãtɔe " ale be woanya eƒe tamesusuwo ŋutɔŋutɔ.
The sentence issued against him states that in order to establish Galileo’s real intentions, it was necessary to proceed against him by "rigorous examination. "
Zi geɖe ne wozã nya sia le Ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea la, efiaa "funyafunyawɔwɔ " ame, si ate ŋu anye "ŋɔdzidonamenyawo gbɔgblɔ na ame atsɔ awɔ fui. "
In inquisitorial jargon this phrase often meant "torture, " possibly meaning at least "the verbal threat of physical torture. "
Ame siwo nya nu tso ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe sia ŋu gblɔ be funyafunyawɔwɔ ame ƒe mɔnu vovovowo kple woƒe sesẽmee li.
Specialists point out that there were stages and degrees of torture.
Etea ŋu nyea funyafunyawɔnuwo tsɔtsɔ fia amea, amaɖeɖe amea, ebabla alo funyafunyawɔwɔe ŋutɔŋutɔ gɔ̃ hã.
It could include anything from merely showing the victim the instruments of torment to stripping or binding him or even inflicting physical pain with increasing severity.
Ale si tututu ‘wobia gbe’ Galileo "ŋkubiãtɔe " la kpɔtɔ le ɣaɣla.
The nature of Galileo’s "rigorous examination " remains a mystery.
Aristotle
Aristotle
Aristotle
Aristotle
ƑE 2,300 kple edzivɔe nye esia la, Aristotle do dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya kple xexemenunya ɖe ŋgɔ le mɔ geɖe nu.
OVER 2,300 years ago, Aristotle made major contributions to science and philosophy.
Aristotle ƒe dɔwo do dzidzɔ na amewo, eye woɖe wo gɔme hesrɔ̃ wo hena ƒe geɖe.
His works have commanded sustained interest and have been widely translated and studied.
Blemaŋutinyawo ƒe nufialagã James MacLachlan ŋlɔ bena, "Ale si Aristotle bua dzɔdzɔmenuwoe la kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe Europatɔwo dzi ƒe 2,000 kloe. "
History Professor James MacLachlan wrote that "Aristotle’s views of nature dominated European thought for almost 2,000 years. "
Aristotle ƒe susu le nanewo ŋu kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe Katolikotɔwo, Protestantɔwo kple Moslemtɔwo gɔ̃ hã ƒe nufiafiawo dzi.
Some of Aristotle’s views even influenced Catholic and Protestant teachings, as well as Islam.
Nu Siwo Ŋu Wòŋlɔ Nu Tsoe Keke Ta
His Range of Interests Was Vast

Aristotle ŋlɔ nu tso aɖaŋunuwo, ɣletiviŋutinunya, nugbagbeŋutinunya, agbenɔnɔŋutisewo, gbegbɔgblɔ, senyawo, nuwo ŋu bubu nyuie, galékpeŋusẽ, dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋutinunya, nuwo ƒe zɔɖeɖe, dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ, hakpanyawo, dunyahehe, susuŋutinunya, nuƒoƒo ƒe ŋutete kpakple luʋɔ si wòsusu be ekuna la ŋu.

Aristotle wrote about art, astronomy, biology, ethics, language, law, logic, magnetism, metaphysics, motion, pleasure, poetry, politics, psychology, and rhetoric, as well as the soul, which he viewed as mortal.
Ke hã, nu siwo wòŋlɔ tso nugbagbeŋutinunya kple nuwo ŋu bubu nyuie ŋu ye na eƒe ŋkɔ de du.
His fame, however, rests foremost on his work in biology and logic.
Blema Hela-gbalẽnyalawo nɔ te ɖe woƒe ŋkuléle ɖe nu ŋu, nu siwo dzi woka ɖo be wonye nyateƒe kple nuwo ŋu bubu nyuie ƒe ŋutete dzi tsɔ ɖea ale si nuwo le le xexea me la me.
Ancient Greek scholars relied on their powers of observation, deduction, and logic to explain the natural world.
Woxɔe se be ne yewonɔ te ɖe nu siwo yewo susu be wonye nyateƒe dzi hebu wo ŋu nyuie la, yewoate ŋu aƒo nya ta nyuiwo.
Starting with what they considered to be obvious truths, they believed that if they reasoned carefully on such truths, they would be able to come to correct conclusions.
Nunya ma kpe ɖe wo ŋu woƒo nya ta nyuiwo le nanewo ŋu, wo dometɔ ɖekae nye be wokpɔe be sewo dzie xexea zɔna ɖo.
Guided by that philosophy, they did draw a number of sound conclusions​ one being that there was an underlying order in the universe.
Ke hã, kuxiae nye be esi wònye nu siwo wokpɔna dzi koe wonɔ te ɖo tso nya me ta la, wo dometɔ aɖewo siwo nye nunyala gãwo, siwo dome Aristotle le da ƒu le nanewo me.
A major problem, however, was that their powers of observation were limited to their unaided senses​ a limitation that led many brilliant men, including Aristotle, astray.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, woxɔe se be ɣletinyigbawo kple ɣletiviwo ƒoa xlã anyigba la.
For instance, they believed that the planets and stars moved around the earth.
Ɣemaɣi la, ame geɖe da asi ɖe susu ma dzi.
At that time, this was considered to be a self-evident truth.
Agbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be, "Nuŋububu kple nu siwo teƒe amewo kpɔ ɖo kpe Helatɔwo ƒe susu si nye be anyigbaa le xexea titina la dzi. " The Closing of the Western Mind.
"Both reason and experience seemed to confirm the Greek view of an earth-centred universe, " states the book The Closing of the Western Mind.
Ne dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo dome koe nuŋububu totro sia tsi la, ne enyo.
That mistaken view would have been of little consequence had it remained purely in the realm of science.
Gake medzɔ alea o.
But it did not.
Katolikoha La Lɔ̃ Ðe Aristotle Ƒe Nufiafiawo Dzi
Catholicism Embraces Aristotle
Wolɔ̃ ɖe Aristotle ƒe nufiafia aɖewo dzi be wonye nyateƒe le Titinaɣeyiɣiwo me le Europa "Kristotɔwo " dome.
In medieval "Christian " Europe, some of Aristotle’s teachings attained the status of received truth​ that is, they were generally accepted as being correct.
Roma Katolikotɔwo ƒe mawunyaŋutinunyalawo, siwo dometɔ ɖekae nye Thomas Aquinas (ƒe 1224-1274 lɔƒo) zã nu siwo ŋu Aristotle ŋlɔ nu tsoe le eƒe nufiafiawo me.
Roman Catholic theologians​ most notably Thomas Aquinas (c. 1224-1274)​ incorporated Aristotle’s writings into their theology.
Aleae wòdzɔe be Aristotle ƒe nuŋububu si nye be anyigbaa le xexea titina la va zu Katolikoha la ƒe nufiafia.
Thus, Aristotle’s notion that a stationary earth lies at the center of the universe became Catholic dogma.
Protestantɔwo ƒe ŋgɔnɔlawo abe Calvin kple Luther hã lɔ ɖe nufiafia ma dzi eye wogblɔ be Biblia mee wòtso. Kpɔ aɖaka si nye " Wose Biblia Me Nya Aɖewo Gɔme Bubui. "
The teaching was also adopted by Protestant leaders, such as Calvin and Luther, who said it was Biblical.​ See the box " They Read Too Much Into the Bible. "
Wolɔ̃ ɖe Aristotle ƒe nufiafia aɖewo dzi be wonye nyateƒe
Some of Aristotle’s teachings attained the status of received truth
Agbalẽŋlɔla si ŋkɔe nye Charles Freeman gblɔ be: "Eva sesẽ be woade vovototo [Aristotle ƒe nufiafiawo] kple Katolikotɔwo ƒe dzixɔsewo dome le nanewo me. "
"In some areas of thought [Aristotle’s teachings] and Catholicism became virtually indistinguishable, " said writer Charles Freeman.
Eya ta wogblɔna be Aquinas "nyrɔ " Aristotle wòzu Katolikotɔ.
Thus, it has been said that Aquinas "baptized " Aristotle into the Catholic faith.
Gake le nyateƒe me la, Freeman ŋlɔ bena, "Aquinas boŋue va zu Aristotle yomedzela. "
In reality, however, "Aquinas was converted to Aristotelianism, " wrote Freeman.
Eye míate ŋu agblɔ kpee be le mɔ aɖe nu la, sɔlemeha la hã dze eyome.
And to some extent, we might add, so was the church.

Esia wɔe be, esi Italytɔ ɣletiviŋununyala kple akɔntanyala Galileo te kpɔ be yeagblɔ be nu si yede dzesie nye be anyigba la ƒoa xlã ɣea la, wobia tso esi be woado ɖe ŋutasẽʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea ŋkume eye wozi edzi be wòagblɔ be aʋatsoe yeka.

As a result, Italian astronomer and mathematician Galileo, who dared to present observational proof that the earth orbited the sun, was required to appear before the Inquisition and was forced to recant.
Ke hã woate ŋu agblɔ be esia na Aristotle kpɔe be nu geɖe li woagasrɔ̃ tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu.
Ironically, Aristotle recognized that scientific knowledge is progressive, subject to revision.
Ne ɖe sɔlemehawo hã kpɔe nenema la anye ne enyo hafi!
If only churches had adopted the same view!
EŊUTINYA VEVI AÐEWO
QUICK FACTS
Aristotle di vevie be yeanya nu geɖe eye "wòde bubu kple asixɔxɔ gã xexe si ƒo xlãe la ŋu. " Aristotle A Very Short Introduction.
Aristotle had a passion for knowledge and "a deep reverence for the value and excellence of the universe about him. "​ Aristotle ​A Very Short Introduction.
Exɔe se be ŋusẽ aɖe si li tegbee ye lé dzɔdzɔmenuwo ɖe te eye wònana woʋãna.
Nature, he believed, has an eternal "Prime Mover " that causes eternal movement and that is good and exists outside the universe.
Wotsɔa nugbagbeŋutinunya kple nuwo ŋu bubu nyuie toto vɛ ŋuti kafukafua naa Aristotle.
Aristotle is credited with founding two sciences​ biology and logic.
Aristotle ye fia nu Makedonia ɖekakpui Aleksanda Gãtɔ si va zu fiagã emegbe.
Aristotle tutored a Macedonian boy who later became the empire builder Alexander the Great.
Wose Biblia Me Nya Aɖewo Gɔme Bubui
A drawing of an earth-centered universe
Anyigba si le xexea titina ƒe tata
