Many ancients believed in an earth-centered universe
Blematɔ geɖe xɔe se be anyigbaa le xexea titina
They Read Too Much Into the Bible
Mawunyaŋununyala aɖewo siwo nɔ anyi ɣemaɣi lé Aristotle ƒe nufiafia be anyigbaa le xexea titina me ɖe asi kpaɖii, elabena wose Biblia me nya aɖewo abe Psalmo 104:5 gɔme bubui.
Some early theologians clung to Aristotle’s geocentric view of the universe because they read too much into certain Bible passages, such as Psalm 104:5.
Kpukpui ma gblɔ be: "[Mawu ɖo] anyigba gɔme anyi ɖe eƒe anyinɔwo dzi; maʋã akpɔ o tso mavɔ me yi mavɔ me. "
It states: "[God] established the earth on its foundations; it will not be moved from its place forever. "
Menye teƒe si anyigbaa le le xexea me ƒe nya gblɔmee Biblia ŋlɔla sia le o.
The Bible writer was not describing earth’s place in the cosmos.
Ke boŋ ezã hakpanya tsɔ ƒo nu tso ale si Mawu ɖo tame be anyigbaa nanɔ anyi tegbee la ŋu. Nyagblɔla 1:4.
Rather, using poetic language, he was pointing to the planet’s permanence according to God’s purpose. ​ Ecclesiastes 1:4.
Eya ta ne Biblia le nu ƒom tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu la, eƒe nyawo dena pɛpɛpɛ.
That said, when the Bible touches on scientific matters, its statements are accurate.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Hiob 26:7 si woŋlɔ anɔ ƒe 3,500 ye nye esia gblɔ be, Mawu "meku anyigba la ɖe naneke ŋu o. "
For example, Job 26:7, recorded about 3,500 years ago, says that God "[suspended] the earth upon nothing. "
Eye Hiob 38:33 gblɔ be sewoe kplɔa dziƒonuwo.
Job 38:33 states that celestial bodies are governed by physical laws.
Se Siwo Mawu De Le Blema Ku Ðe Dzadzɛnyenye Ŋu La De Ŋgɔ Sãsãsã Wu Nu Siwo Wonya Ɣemaɣi
God’s Laws on Hygiene Were Ahead of Their Time
Anɔ abe ƒe 3,500 aɖewoe nye esi va yi esi wòsusɔ vie Israel-viwo nage ɖe Ŋugbedodonyigbaa dzi la, Mawu gblɔ be yeakpɔ wo ta tso "dɔléle vɔ̃ɖi " siwo wonya le Egipte la si me.
Shortly before the nation of Israel entered the Promised Land some 35 centuries ago, God said that he would protect them against "the terrible diseases " that they had known in Egypt.
(5 Mose 7:15) Mɔ ɖeka aɖe si dzi wòto wɔ esia ye nye be ena mɔfiamewo woamawo tsitotsito ku ɖe dzadzɛnyenye kple ale si woawɔ atsi dɔlélewo nu ale be woagakaka o ŋu.
(Deuteronomy 7:15) One way he did this was by giving them detailed instructions on disease control and hygiene.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me:
For example:
Tsilele kple nudodowo nyanya nɔ nu siwo wobia tso Israel-viwo si le Mawu ƒe sea me dome.
The nation’s code of laws required bathing and clothes washing.
Leviticus 15:4-27.
Ku ɖe nugododede ŋu la, Mawu gblɔ be: "Afɔdzideƒe nanɔ asiwò le asaɖa la godo, eye afi ma nàdo go ayi.
Regarding human waste, God stated: "A private place should be designated for use outside the camp, and there is where you should go.
Eye ati gbabɛ nanɔ asiwò le wò dɔwɔnuwo dome.
A peg should be part of your equipment.
Ne èbe yeabɔbɔ le asaɖa la godo ade afɔdzi la, ekema nàtsɔe aɖe doe, eye emegbe nàxe ke ɖe wò afɔdzi la dzi. " 5 Mose 23:12, 13.
When you squat outside, you should dig a hole with it and then cover your excrement. " Deuteronomy 23:12, 13.
Woɖea ame siwo wokpɔ be wole dɔxɔleameŋu aɖe lém la ɖe aga hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
People who were thought to have a communicable disease were quarantined kept away from others for a time.
Hafi dɔnɔ siwo haya la natrɔ ava ame dome la, ele be woanya woƒe awuwo ahale tsi; ema ko hafi woate ŋu abu wo be wo ŋu ‘kɔ.’ 3 Mose 14:8, 9.
Before returning, those who recovered from sickness had to wash their garments and bathe in water if they were to be considered "clean. "
Woɖea ame sia ame si ka asi ame kuku alo lã kuku aɖe ŋu la ɖe aga.
Leviticus 14:8, 9. Anyone who touched a dead body was quarantined.
Leviticus 5:2, 3; Numbers 19:16.
Se siwo nɔ Israel-viwo si ku ɖe lãmesẽnyawo kple dzadzɛnyenye ŋu la de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu wo ŋɔlimetɔwo tɔ.
Israel’s laws reflected medical concepts and views on sanitation that were far ahead of their time.
Dukɔ bubu me tɔwo menya nu boo aɖeke ku ɖe dzadzɛnyenye ŋu o.
Elsewhere, primitive standards of hygiene were prevalent.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me:
For example:
Wokɔa gbeɖuɖɔ ɖe mɔwo dzi.
Waste was deposited in streets.
Eye tsi ƒoɖiwo, nuɖuɖu gbegblẽwo kple ɖinu bubuwo nana woƒe nutowo me ƒoa ɖi, eye esia wɔnɛ be ame geɖe dzea dɔ eye vidzĩ gbogbowo kuna.
Polluted water, contaminated food, and other kinds of refuse created unsanitary conditions that contributed to a high rate of disease and infant mortality.
Atikewɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema la menya naneke tso dɔlékuiwo ŋu o.
Ancient medical doctors had little or no knowledge of germs and pathogens.
Nu siwo Egiptetɔwo zãna be yewotsɔ le dɔ dam ƒe ɖewoe nye adoglo ƒe ʋu, aluge ƒe mĩ, afi kuku, aɖuɖɔ kple yevubolo dzefufu.
Egyptians used such "remedies " as lizard blood, pelican dung, dead mice, urine, and moldy bread.
Wozãa amegbetɔwo kple lãwo hã ƒe mĩ zi geɖe le woƒe atikewɔnyawo me.
Human as well as animal excrement was also commonly used in their medical procedures.
Ðinu siwo ge ɖe Nil-tɔsisia kple tɔʋu siwo woɖe tsɔ dea tsi agblewo me la nana dɔlékui vovovowo nɔa tsiawo me si wɔnɛ be Egiptetɔwo dzea dɔ.
The ancient Egyptians picked up a variety of parasites from the contaminated waters of the Nile River and its irrigation canals.
Nenema kee ɖinu siwo ge ɖe nuɖuɖuwo me la wɔnɛ be ɖevi geɖe siwo nɔ Egipte la kuna le mĩtsinyenyedɔ kple emawo tɔgbi ta.
Likewise, many infants in Egypt died of diarrhea and similar disorders caused by contaminated food.
Gake lãmesẽnyawo de Israel-viwo ya dzi wu dukɔ bubu me tɔwo le esi wowɔ ɖe mɔfiame siwo le Mawu ƒe Sea me dzi ta.
The Israelites, on the other hand, benefited and remained comparatively healthy by following the standards set out in God’s Law.
Fukpekpe
Suffering
Ame aɖewo susunɛ be Mawu gbɔe amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpewo tso alo be ne menye eya gbɔe wotso o hã la, metsɔa ɖeke le amewo ƒe fukpekpewo me o.
Some people feel that God causes human suffering or that, at the very least, he is indifferent to it.
Gake nu siae Biblia fia?
But is that what the Bible teaches?
Ŋuɖoɖoa awɔ nuku na wò.
You might be surprised at the answer.
Mawue nana míekpea fua?
Does God cause us to suffer?
"Nyateƒee, Mawu mewɔa nu vɔ̃ɖi o. "​ Hiob 34:12.
"For a certainty, God does not act wickedly. "​ Job 34:12.
NYA SIWO AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Ame aɖewo gblɔna be nu sia nu si dzɔna la nye Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu.
Some say that everything that happens is God’s will.
Woxɔe se ko be Mawue nana míekpea fu.
Thus, they believe that God causes us to suffer.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo dzɔ la, wosusunɛ be Mawue le nu siawo zãm be yeatsɔ ahe to na nu vɔ̃ wɔlawo.
When natural disasters strike, for instance, they think that these events are God’s way of punishing those who have sinned.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Biblia fia nu eme kɔ be menye Mawue nana míekpea fu o.
The Bible clearly teaches that God does not cause us to suffer.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔ be ne ame aɖe le tetekpɔ me tom la, anye vodada be wòagblɔ be, ‘Mawue le ye tem kpɔ.’
For example, the Bible says that when we go through trials, it would be a mistake to say: "I am being tried by God. "
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabena "womate ŋu atsɔ nu vɔ̃ɖiwo ate Mawu kpɔ o, eye eya ŋutɔ hã metea ame aɖeke kpɔ o. "
Because "with evil things God cannot be tried, nor does he himself try anyone. "
(Yakobo 1:13) Ne míagblɔe bubui la, menye Mawu gbɔe tetekpɔwo alo míaƒe fukpekpewo tsona kura o.
(James 1:13) In other words, God never causes the trials we face or the suffering that follows.
Ne eya gbɔe wòtsona la, ke evɔ̃ɖi ŋutɔ, gake "Mawu mewɔa nu vɔ̃ɖi o. "​ Hiob 34:12.
To do so would be wicked, but "God does not act wickedly. "​ Job 34:12.
Ne menye Mawu gbɔe míaƒe fukpekpewo tsona o ɖe, ke afi kae wotsona?
If God does not cause us to suffer, then who or what does?
Nublanuitɔe la, amegbetɔ nu vɔ̃ mewoe nana wo haviwo kpea fu.
Sadly, humans are often victimized by other imperfect humans.
(Nyagblɔla 8:9) Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, "nuɖiɖeame " ate ŋu ana vɔ̃ nadzɔ ɖe ame dzi le vo me.
(Ecclesiastes 8:9) Additionally, we may face calamities because of "unexpected events "​ that is, because of simply being in the wrong place at the wrong time.
(Nyagblɔla 9:11) Biblia fiaa nu be Satana Abosam, si nye "xexe sia dzi ɖula " koŋ gbɔe míaƒe fukpekpewo tsona elabena "xexe blibo la katã le vɔ̃ɖitɔ la ƒe ŋusẽ te. "
(Ecclesiastes 9:11) The Bible teaches that ultimately "the ruler of this world, " Satan the Devil, is responsible for human suffering, for "the whole world is lying in the power of the wicked one. "
(Yohanes 12:31; 1 Yohanes 5:19) Satanae nana míekpea fu ke menye Mawu o.
(John 12:31; 1 John 5:19) It is Satan​ not God ​who causes people to suffer.
Ðe Mawu tsɔa ɖe le míaƒe fukpekpewo mea?
Does God care about our suffering?
"Ekpe fu kpli wo le woƒe fukpekpewo me. "​ Yesaya 63:9, Eʋegbe Biblia, ƒe 2010 tɔ.
"During all their distress it was distressing to him. "​ Isaiah 63:9.
NYA SIWO AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Ame aɖewo susui be Mawu metsɔ ɖeke le míaƒe fukpekpewo me o.
Some think that God is indifferent to our trials.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, agbalẽŋlɔla aɖe ƒo nu tso nu si eya ŋutɔ yɔ be Mawu ƒe "amenumavemave kple nublanuimakpɔmakpɔ le míaƒe fukpekpewo me " ŋu.
For example, one writer cites what he calls God’s "apparent lack of mercy or pity in reaction to our suffering. "
Agbalẽŋlɔla sia gblɔ be ne Mawu li nyateƒe la, ke "mekpɔa nublanui alo tsɔa ɖeke le eme " na amegbetɔwo o.
This writer argues that if God exists, he must view humans with "pitiless indifference. "
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Biblia megblɔ kura be Mawu nye nublanuimakpɔla kple ame si metsɔa ɖeke le eme na mí o, ke boŋ efia nu be etena ɖe edzi vevie ne míele fu kpem eye be ava ɖe fukpekpewo katã ɖa kpuie.
Far from depicting God as pitiless or indifferent, the Bible teaches that God is deeply moved by our suffering​ and that he will soon bring an end to it.
Bu nyateƒenya fakɔname etɔ̃ siwo le Biblia me la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider three comforting truths found in the Bible.
Mawu nya fu siwo kpem míele.
God is aware of our suffering.
Tso amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpewo ƒe gɔmedzedze ke la, Yehowa, ame si ƒe "aɖabawo " kpɔa nu sia nu la ƒe ŋku le aɖatsiwo katã ŋu.
From the very start of human suffering, not a single teardrop has gone unnoticed by Jehovah, whose "watchful eyes " see everything.
(Psalmo 11:4; 56:9) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi wonɔ Mawu subɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema tem ɖe anyi la, egblɔ be: "Mekpɔ ale si wole nye dukɔ tem ɖe anyi. "
(Psalm 11:4; 56:8) For example, when his worshippers in ancient times were being oppressed, God said: "I have certainly seen the affliction of my people. "
Gake ɖeko wònɔ woƒe teteɖeanyiwo teƒe kpɔm dzro koa?
But was he only vaguely aware of their pain?

Kpao, elabena egblɔ be: "Menya woƒe fukpekpewo. " (2 Mose 3:7) Enyanya be Mawu nya míaƒe fukpekpewo katã kple tetekpɔ siwo me tom míele siwo ŋu ame aɖeke menya nu tsoe o la ɖeɖe dzaa faa akɔ na ame geɖewo.​ Psalmo 31:8; Lododowo 14:10.

No, for he added: "I well know the pains they suffer. " (Exodus 3:7) Many people have found comfort in that truth alone​ the thought that God is aware of everything we suffer, even the trials that others may not be aware of or fully understand.​ Psalm 31:7; Proverbs 14:10.
Etena ɖe Mawu dzi ne míele fu kpem.
God feels for us when we suffer.
Menye ɖeko Mawu nya amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpewo o, ke etena ɖe edzi vevie hã.
Jehovah God is not only aware of human suffering but also deeply moved by it.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ete ɖe Mawu dzi vevie esime esubɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema la nɔ fu kpem.
For example, God was sincerely troubled when his ancient worshippers faced trials.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ekpe fu kpli wo le woƒe fukpekpewo me. "
"During all their distress it was distressing to him, " says the Bible.
(Yesaya 63:9, Eʋegbe Biblia, ƒe 2010 tɔ) Togbɔ be Mawu kɔ boo wu amegbetɔwo hã la, esea veve ɖe ame siwo le fu kpem la nu abe ɖe woƒe vevesesewo le dzi dzi nɛ ene.
(Isaiah 63:9) Although God is vastly superior to humans, he feels empathy for those who suffer​ as if their pain were in his heart!
Le nyateƒe me la, "Yehowa ƒe dɔmetɔtrɔ sɔ gbɔ ŋutɔ, eye wòkpɔa nublanui na ame. "
Indeed, "Jehovah is very compassionate and merciful. "
(Yakobo 5:11) Gawu la, Yehowa kpena ɖe mía ŋu míenɔa te ɖe míaƒe fukpekpewo nu.​ Filipitɔwo 4:12, 13.
(James 5:11; footnote) Additionally, Jehovah helps us to bear our suffering.​ Philippians 4:12, 13.
Mawu aɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpewo katã ɖa.
God will end all human suffering.
Biblia gblɔ be Mawu aɖe fu si kpem ame sia ame le la ɖa le anyigba dzi.
According to the Bible, God will bring an end to the suffering of every human on the planet.
Yehowa ato eƒe Dziƒofiaɖuƒea dzi atrɔ nɔnɔme siwo me tom amegbetɔwo le la wòanyo wu sãsãsã.
By means of his heavenly Kingdom, Jehovah will drastically change the human condition​ for the better.
Biblia gblɔ tso ɣeyiɣi ma ŋu be Mawu "atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi o, eye konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o.
Regarding that time, the Bible promises that God "will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore.
Nu siwo nɔ anyi tsã la nu va yi. "
The former things have passed away. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4) Ke ame siwo ku xoxo ya ɖe?
(Revelation 21:4) What about those who have already died?
Mawu afɔ wo ɖe tsitre woava nɔ anyigba si dzi fukpekpe maganɔ o la dzi.
God will bring them back to life here on earth so that they too can enjoy life free from suffering.
(Yohanes 5:28, 29) Ðe fu siwo kpem míele egbea agava susu me na mía?
(John 5:28, 29) Will anyone be plagued by painful memories of past suffering?
Ao, elabena Yehowa do ŋugbe be: "Womagaɖo ŋku tsãtɔwo dzi, alo woava ame ƒe ta me o. "​ Yesaya 65:17.
No, for Jehovah promises: "The former things will not be called to mind, nor will they come up into the heart. "​ Isaiah 65:17.
Fukpekpe Tohehee Wònye Tso Mawu Gbɔa?
Suffering​ Is It Punishment From God?
LUZIA TƆNA ÐE EƑE MIAFƆ DZI.
LUZIA LIMPS ON HER LEFT LEG.
Esi wònye ɖevi la, elé ɖeviwo ƒe tutudɔ, si nye dɔxɔleameŋu vɔ̃ɖi aɖe si gblẽa nu le ame ƒe lãmekawo ŋu.
As a small child, she contracted poliomyelitis, a highly contagious disease that attacks the body’s nervous system.
Esi Luzia xɔ ƒe 16 la, nyɔnu aɖe si wòwɔa dɔ na la gblɔ nɛ be, "Mawue tsɔ tutudɔ sia le to hem na wò elabe èdze aglã ɖe nɔwò ŋu eye mèɖoa toe o. "
When she was 16, a lady whom Luzia worked for told her, "God punished you with paralysis because you were disobedient and nasty to your mother. "
Ƒe gbogbo aɖewo va yi gake Luzia gaɖoa ŋku ale si wòse le eɖokui me la dzi kokoko.
Years later, Luzia still remembers how devastated she felt.
ESI DAMARIS VA NYA BE AHƆHƆ̃MEKANSA LE YE ŊU LA, tɔa biae be: "Agɔ kae nèdze si na be nu sia dzɔ ɖe dziwò?
WHEN DAMARIS LEARNED THAT SHE HAD BRAIN CANCER, her father asked her: "What have you done for this to happen to you?
Ànya wɔ nu gbegblẽ aɖe.
You must have done something very bad.
Eya tae Mawu le to hem na wò. "
That is why God is punishing you. "
Tɔa ƒe nya mawo te ɖe Damaris dzi vevie.
Damaris’ spirit was crushed by his comment.
Amewo xɔe se tso blema ke be Mawu tsɔa dɔlélewo hea to na amewo.
The thought that sickness is punishment from God has a long history.
Agbalẽ aɖe (Manners and Customs of Bible Lands) gblɔ be ame geɖe siwo nɔ anyi le Kristo ŋɔli xɔe se be "ɖewohĩ nu vɔ̃ aɖe si ame alo eƒe ƒometɔ aɖe wɔ gbɔe eƒe dɔléle tso eye wònye tohehe. "

The book Manners and Customs of Bible Lands says that many in Christ’s time believed that "sickness was caused by either the sin of the sick person, or of his relations, and that it was sent as punishment for that sin. "

Ƒe alafa gbogbo aɖewo le Kristo ƒe dzodzo le anyigba dzi megbe la, Agbalẽ aɖe (Medieval Medicine and the Plague) gblɔ be: "Ame aɖewo bui be Mawu tsɔ dɔlélewo nɔ to hem na yewo ɖe yewoƒe nu vɔ̃wo ta. "
Medieval Medicine and the Plague says that in the Middle Ages "some people believed that God brought plagues to punish them for their sins. "
Eya ta esi dɔvɔ̃ aɖe na ame gbogbo aɖewo ku le ƒe alafa 14 lia me le Europa la, ɖe míagblɔ be Mawue nɔ ʋɔnu drɔ̃m ame vɔ̃ɖiwoa?
So when millions throughout Europe died from the plague in the 14th century, was God executing judgment on wicked people?
Alo ɖe wòanye be dɔlékuiwo gbɔe wòtso abe ale si ɖɔktawo ƒe numekukuwo ɖee fia enea?
Or was the plague simply caused by a bacterial infection, as medical researchers have since determined?
Ame aɖewo abia be, ɖe Mawu toa dɔlélewo dzi nana amewo kpea fu ɖe woƒe nu vɔ̃wo ta?
Some may wonder, does God really use sickness to make people suffer for their sins?
BU NYA SIAWO ŊU KPƆ: Ne Mawue tsɔ dɔléle kple fukpekpe le to hem na amewo la, ke nu ka tae Yesu da dɔ na ame siwo nɔ dɔ lém?
CONSIDER: Why would Jesus heal people who were sick if sickness and suffering were deserved punishments from God?
Ðe ema mafia be mebu Mawu ƒe ʋɔnu dzɔdzɔe dɔdrɔ̃ kple eƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye ɖe ɖeke me oa?
Would that not amount to undermining God’s justice and righteousness?
(Mateo 4:23, 24) Yesu mawɔ nu atsi tsitre ɖe Mawu ŋu gbeɖe o.
(Matthew 4:23, 24) Jesus would never counteract God’s actions.
Egblɔ be: "Mewɔa nu siwo dzea eŋu ɣesiaɣi " eye "mele nu si tututu Fofo la de se nam be mawɔ la wɔm. "
He said: "I always do the things pleasing to him " and, "I am doing just as the Father has commanded me to do. "​ John 8:29; 14:31.
The Bible is clear.

Biblia gblɔe eme kɔ be: Yehowa Mawu "mewɔa nu madzɔmadzɔ gbeɖe o. " (5 Mose 32:4) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, menye Mawue nana yameʋuwo dzea afɔku si nana ame alafa gbogbo siwo medze agɔ aɖeke o la kuna le esi wòdi be yeahe to na ame aɖe si le yameʋua me la ta o!
Jehovah God "is never unjust. " (Deuteronomy 32:4) For example, God would never cause an airplane disaster, killing hundreds of innocent people, because he wanted to punish someone on board!
Abraham si nye mawusubɔla wɔnuteƒe gblɔ ku ɖe Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye ŋu be: Mawu ‘matsrɔ̃ ame dzɔdzɔewo kpe ɖe ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ŋu o.’
In harmony with God’s righteousness, Abraham, a faithful servant of God, said that God would never "sweep away the righteous with the wicked. "
Egblɔ be ‘mawɔ nu ma’ o.
That would be "unthinkable, " he said.
(1 Mose 18:23, 25) Biblia gblɔ hã be "Mawu mewɔa nu vɔ̃ɖi o; " mewɔa "nu gbegblẽ gbeɖe o! " Hiob 34:10-12.
(Genesis 18:23, 25) The Bible also says that "God does not act wickedly "; he does not "do wrong. "​ Job 34:10-12.
NU SI BIBLIA FIA MÍ TSO FUKPEKPE ŊU
WHAT THE BIBLE TEACHES US ABOUT SUFFERING
Ne míele fu kpem la, mefia be Mawue le to hem na mí ɖe nu vɔ̃ aɖe ta o.
The suffering we encounter is not divine punishment for a specific sin.
Yesu ŋutɔ na nya sia me kɔ esi eya kple eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo kpɔ ŋutsu aɖe si wodzi ŋkuagbãtɔ.
Jesus himself was very clear on this matter when he and his disciples saw a man who had been blind from birth.
"Eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo biae be: ‘Rabi, ame kae wɔ nu vɔ̃ be wodzi ame sia ŋkuagbãtɔe, eya ŋutɔe loo alo edzilawo yea?’
"His disciples asked him: ‘Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, so that he was born blind?’
Yesu ɖo eŋu be: ‘Menye ame sia alo edzilawoe wɔ nu vɔ̃ o, ke boŋ be woaɖe Mawu ƒe dɔwɔwɔwo afia to edzi tae.’ " Yohanes 9:1-3.
Jesus answered: ‘Neither this man sinned nor his parents, but it was so that the works of God might be made manifest in his case.’ "​ John 9:1-3.
Esi susu totro sia bɔ ɣemaɣi ta la, ewɔ nuku na Yesu ƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be wògblɔ be menye ŋutsua alo edzilawoe wɔ nu vɔ̃ si he nɔnɔme wɔnublanui ma va edzi o.
In view of prevailing misconceptions, Jesus’ disciples must have been surprised when he told them that neither the man nor his parents had sinned in a way that brought on misfortune.
Menye ɖeko Yesu da dɔ na ŋkuagbãtɔa o, ke eto esia dzi ɖee fia be menye Mawue tsɔa nɔnɔme mawo hea to na amewo ɖe woƒe nu vɔ̃wo ta o.
Not only did Jesus cure the man’s blindness but by so doing he overturned the erroneous belief that suffering is punishment from God.
(Yohanes 9:6, 7) Egbea ne ame siwo dze dɔ vevie va nya be menye Mawue na yewole fu kpem o la, esia ana woƒe dzi nadze eme.
(John 9:6, 7) Those who suffer from serious health problems today can find comfort in knowing that God is not the cause of their affliction.
Ne Mawue tsɔ dɔléle le to hem na amewo ɖe woƒe nu vɔ̃wo taa, ke nu ka tae Yesu da dɔ na wo?
Why would Jesus heal sick people if God was punishing them for wrongdoing?
Biblia ka ɖe edzi na mí be
The Scriptures assure us
"Womate ŋu atsɔ nu vɔ̃ɖiwo ate Mawu akpɔ o, eye eya ŋutɔ hã metea ame aɖeke kpɔna o. "
"With evil things God cannot be tried, nor does he himself try anyone. "
(YAKOBO 1:13) Nyateƒee, ‘nu vɔ̃ɖi’ siwo nye dɔléle, vevesese kple ku, siwo ɖe kpe na amegbetɔwo ƒe alafa gbogbowo la, nu ava yi.
(JAMES 1:13) Indeed, the "evil things " that have plagued mankind for centuries, including sickness, pain, and death, will soon be eliminated.
Yesu Kristo ‘da gbe le ame siwo katã ƒe lãme gblẽ la ŋu.’
Jesus Christ "cured all who were suffering. "
(MATEO 8:16) Esi Mawu ƒe Vi la da dɔ na ame siwo katã va egbɔ la, eɖe nu si Mawu Fiaɖuƒea awɔ le xexea me katã la fia.
(MATTHEW 8:16) In healing all who came to him, God’s Son demonstrated what God’s Kingdom will accomplish on a worldwide scale.
"[Mawu] atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o.
"He [God] will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore.
Nu siwo nɔ anyi tsã la nu va yi. " NYAÐEÐEFIA 21:3-5.
The former things have passed away. "​ REVELATION 21:3-5.
KE AME KAE NANA MÍEKPEA FU?
WHO IS TO BLAME?
Nu ka tae amegbetɔwo sea veve helĩhelĩ eye wokpea fu?
Why, then, does mankind experience so much pain and suffering?
Amewo biaa nya sia tso gbe aɖe gbe ke.
Mankind has been pondering that question for centuries.
Ne menye Mawue nana míekpea fu o la, ke ame ka gbɔe wòtso?
If God is not to blame, who is responsible?
Woaɖo biabia siawo ŋu le nyati si kplɔ esia ɖo me.
The answers to those questions will be discussed in the next article.
Aleke Mawɔ Anɔ Te Ðe Nya Vɔ̃wo Nu?
How Can I Deal With Tragedy?
Nya vɔ̃wo dzɔna ɖe ame sia ame dzi.
Tragedy can affect anyone.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dziɖuɖu le duɖimekeke me mele afɔ ɖeablɛ me ɣesiaɣi o, . . . elabena azãgbe kple nuɖiɖeame li na wo katã. "
"The swift do not always win the race, nor do the mighty win the battle, " the Bible says. "Unexpected events overtake them all. "
(Nyagblɔla 9:11) Esia nye nyateƒe le sɔhɛ aɖewo siwo dzi nya vɔ̃wo dzɔ ɖo hã gome.
(Ecclesiastes 9:11) That includes some young people who have faced tragedy.
Aleke wowɔ te ŋu nɔ te ɖe nya vɔ̃wo nu?
How have they dealt with it?
Se wo dometɔ eve aɖewo ƒe ŋutinyawo ɖa.
Consider two examples.
REBEKAH
REBEKAH
CORDELL
CORDELL
REBEKAH
REBEKAH
Rebekah
Rebekah
Dzinyelawo gbe wo nɔewo esime mexɔ ƒe 14.
My parents divorced when I was 14.
Nyemexɔe se be dzinyelawo le wo nɔewo gbem ŋutɔŋutɔ o, ewɔ nam abe ɖeko tɔnye di be yeaɖe ye ɖokui ɖe aga vie ene.
I told myself that my parents’ divorce wasn’t happening, that my dad just needed time to himself for a while.
Elɔ̃ nɔnye ŋutɔ, ke nu ka tae wòdzo le egbɔ ɖo?
He loved my mom​ why would he leave her?
Nu ka tae wòadzo le gbɔnye ɖo?
Why would he leave me?
Esesẽna nam be maɖo dze tso nu si nɔ dzɔdzɔm la ŋu na ame aɖe.
It was difficult for me to talk to anyone about what was happening.
Medi be maɖe nya mawo katã ɖa le susu me.
I wanted to block it out.
Dzi kuam vevie, gake nye ŋutɔ nyemenyana ɣeaɖewoɣi hã o.
I was angry, although at the time I didn’t realize it.
Metsia dzimaɖi vevie, eye alɔ̃ menya dɔna nam o.
I began having problems with anxiety, and I had trouble sleeping.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 19 la, kansa wu nɔnye.
When I was 19, I lost my mother to cancer.
Tsi metoa nye kplii dome o.
She was my best friend.
Enye nyateƒe be ete ɖe dzinye vevie esi dzinyelawo gbe wo nɔewo, gake nɔnye ƒe ku ya gbã dzi nam ale gbegbe.
If my parents’ divorce was shocking, my mom’s death was utterly devastating.
Mekpɔ fa nam o.
I’m still not over it.
Alɔ̃ meganya dɔna nam kura o, eye megatsia dzimaɖi kokoko.
Sleep has gotten even more elusive for me, and I still have anxiety.
Gake mekpɔe be nu geɖewo li mate ŋu awɔ tso nɔnɔmea ŋu.
At the same time, I have found several things to be helpful.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Lododowo 18:1 xlɔ̃ nu mí tso ame ɖokui ɖeɖe ɖe aga ŋu, eye mewɔ ɖe aɖaŋuɖoɖo ma dzi.
For example, Proverbs 18:1 warns us against isolating ourselves, so I try to follow that advice.
Eye esi wònye Yehowa Ðasefoe menye ta la, medzea agbagba xlẽa míaƒe Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ dedziƒonameawo.
Also, as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I try to read our encouraging Bible-based publications.
Agbalẽ siawo dometɔ aɖe si kpe ɖe ŋunye esime dzinyelawo nɔ wo nɔewo gbem lae nye Nya Siwo Sɔhɛwo Biana Ƒe Ŋuɖoɖo Vavãwo, ele yevugbe me.
One that helped me during the time of my parents’ divorce was Questions Young People Ask​ Answers That Work.
Meɖo ŋku edzi be mexlẽ Babla 2 lia ƒe nyati si nye: "Ðe Mate Ŋu Akpɔ Dzidzɔ Le Dzila Ðeka Ƒe Dzikpɔkpɔ Tea? "
In particular, I remember reading the chapter in Volume 2 entitled "Can I Be Happy in a Single-Parent Family? "
Biblia me nya vevi siwo kpena ɖe ŋunye menɔa te ɖe nye dzimaɖitsitsia nu la dometɔ ɖekae nye esi dze le Mateo 6:​25-34.
One of my favorite scriptures for dealing with my anxiety is found at Matthew 6:​25-34.
Le kpukpui 27 lia me la, Yesu bia be: "Mia dometɔ kae li, si ne ele dzimaɖi tsim la, wòate ŋu atsɔ abɔklugui ɖeka akpe ɖe eƒe agbenɔƒe ŋu? "
In verse 27, Jesus asked: "Who of you by being anxious can add one cubit to his life span? "
Nya vɔ̃wo dzɔna ɖe mí katã dzi, gake mesrɔ̃e le nɔnye ƒe kpɔɖeŋua me be ale si míenɔa te ɖe wo nui la le vevie.
Bad things will happen to all of us, but I learned from my mom’s example that the way we deal with those trials is important.
Eto nu geɖe me. Atsuƒe gblẽ nɛ, eye wòdze dɔ aɖe si womate ŋu ada o. Gake le wo katã me la, dzi meɖe le eƒo o, eye xɔse sẽŋu gakpɔtɔ nɔ esi va se ɖe eƒe kugbe.
She went through a lot​ a divorce and then a terminal illness​ but through it all she kept a positive attitude, and her faith in God remained strong right to the end.
Nyemaŋlɔ nu siwo wòfiam tso Yehowa ŋu la be gbeɖe o.
I’ll never forget the things she taught me about Jehovah.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke Biblia kple Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽwo xexlẽ ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe nya vɔ̃wo nu?​ ⁠Psalmo 94:19.
To think about: How can reading the Bible and Bible-based publications help you deal with tragedy?​ Psalm 94:19.
CORDELL
CORDELL
Cordell
Cordell
Esi mexɔ ƒe 17 la, mekpɔ tɔnye ƒe ku teƒe.
When I was 17, I saw my father take his last breath.
Tɔnye ƒe kue nye nya vɔ̃ gãtɔ kekeake si dzɔ ɖe dzinye kpɔ.
Losing him was the worst thing that ever happened in my life.
Nye dzi gbã gudugudu.
I was devastated.
Ewɔna nam be meku ŋutɔŋutɔ o, menye tɔnyee nye ema wotsyɔ avɔa na o.
I felt that he wasn’t really dead, that it wasn’t really my dad under the sheets when they covered the body.
Megblɔna na ɖokuinye be, ‘Ele fɔfɔ ge etsɔ.’
I told myself, ‘He will wake up tomorrow.’
Gbɔgblɔ bu ɖem.
I felt empty and lost.
Yehowa Ðasefowoe nye kple dzinyelawo míenye, eye míaƒe hametɔwo kpe ɖe mía ŋu ale gbegbe esi tɔnye ku.
My family and I are Jehovah’s Witnesses, and our congregation was a tremendous support when my father died.
Wona nuɖuɖu mí, wova nɔa mía gbɔ, eye womegblẽa mí ɖi o, eye wowɔ esia ɣeyiɣi didi aɖe.
They fed us, offered to stay with us, and stuck close to us​ not just for a little while but for the long term.
Woƒe kpekpeɖeŋu siawo katã gaɖo kpe edzi nam be Kristotɔ vavãwoe Yehowa Ðasefowo nye.​ ⁠Yohanes 13:35.
To me, their support was proof that Jehovah’s Witnesses are genuine Christians.​ John 13:35.
Mawunyakpukpui aɖe si de dzi ƒo nam ŋutɔ lae nye 2 Korintotɔwo 4:17, 18.
A scripture that has really encouraged me is 2 Corinthians 4:​17, 18.

Egblɔ be: "Togbɔ be ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe ƒe xaxa si nu mesẽ o koe wònye hã la, ehea ŋutikɔkɔe gã mavɔ si ƒoa nu sia nu ta sãsãsã la vanɛ na mí; esi míenana míaƒe ŋkuwo nɔa nu siwo wokpɔna la ŋu o, ke boŋ nu siwo womekpɔna o la ŋu.

It says: "Though the tribulation is momentary and light, it works out for us a glory that is of more and more surpassing greatness and is everlasting; while we keep our eyes, not on the things seen, but on the things unseen.
Elabena nu siwo wokpɔna la nɔa anyi ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe ko, ke nu siwo womekpɔna o ya nɔa anyi tegbee. "
For the things seen are temporary, but the things unseen are everlasting. "
Mawunyakpukpuia ƒe akpa mamlɛtɔa wɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
That last verse was powerful to me.
Ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe ƒe nu koe tɔnye ƒe fukpekpea nye, gake nu siwo ƒe ŋugbe Mawu do be yeawɔ na mí le etsɔme ya anɔ anyi tegbee.
My father’s suffering was temporary, but what God promises for the future is everlasting.
Tɔnye ƒe kua na megbugbɔ ŋku lé ɖe nye agbenɔnɔ ŋu hetrɔ asi le nye agbemetaɖodzinuwo hã ŋu.
My dad’s death gave me the opportunity to reflect on how I was using my life and to adjust my goals.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke nya vɔ̃ dzɔɖeamedzi ate ŋu ana be ame nagbugbɔ ŋku alé ɖe eƒe agbemetaɖodzinuwo ŋu?​ ⁠1 Yohanes 2:17.
To think about: How can a personal tragedy help you to reassess your goals in life?​ 1 John 2:17.
Ðe Mawu Tsɔ Ðe Le Míaƒe Fukpekpewo Mea?
Does God Care About Our Suffering?
Na míakpɔ ale si Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖoa dze kple amewoe la ƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖe ɖa.
The following is a typical conversation that one of Jehovah’s Witnesses might have with a neighbor.
Tsɔe be Ðasefo si ŋkɔe nye Fafa va nyɔnu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Dzigbɔɖi gbɔ le eƒe me.
Let us imagine that a Witness named Michelle has come to the home of a woman named Sophia.
NU KA TAE MAWU ÐE MƆ NU SIA DZƆ?
HOW COULD HE LET THIS HAPPEN?
Fafa: Mele trakt sia mam na ame sia ame le nutoa me.
Michelle: Today I’m sharing this tract with everyone in the area.
Eƒe tanyae nye Àdi Be Yeanya Nyateƒe Laa?
It’s entitled Would You Like to Know the Truth?
Tɔwòe nye esi.
Here’s your copy.
Dzigbɔɖi: Mawunyagbalẽ yea?
Sophia: Is this about religion?
Fafa: Ɛ̃.
Michelle: Yes.
Kpɔ nyabiase ade siwo woŋlɔ ɖe edzi ɖa.
Notice the six questions listed on the cover.
Nyabiase siawo dometɔ kae nàdi be
Which of these questions
Dzigbɔɖi: Wò ya tɔ, ema nyo.
Sophia: Let me stop you there.
Wò ɣeyiɣi ko nàgblẽ dzodzro.
You would be wasting your time talking with me.
Fafa: Meɖe kuku, nu ka tae nègblɔ nenema?
Michelle: Why do you say that?
Dzigbɔɖi: Nyaa koe nye be, nyemeka ɖe edzi be Mawu li o.
Sophia: The truth is, I’m not sure that I even believe in God.
Fafa: Edzɔ dzi nam be ègblɔ wò dzimenya siawo nam.
Michelle: Well, I appreciate your being honest with me.
Meɖe kuku mabia lo, tso ɖevime kee mexɔ Mawu dzi se oa?
May I ask, Have you always felt that way?
Dzigbɔɖi: Ao, menɔ sɔleme dem tso ɖevime.
Sophia: No, I grew up attending church.
Gake ɣeyiɣi didi aɖee nye esia nyemegadena o.
But I stopped going a long time ago.

Nu Ka Tae Mawu Ðe Mɔ Vɔ̃ɖinyenye Kple Fukpekpe Li Ðo?
Why Does God Allow Evil and Suffering?
Aleke vɔ̃ɖinyenye dze egɔmee?
How did evil begin?
Adam le ati si ŋuti wode se ɖo la kpɔm; 2.
Adam looking at the forbidden fruit; 2.
Amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖula vovovowo; 3.
Various human rulers; 3.
Aʋawɔwɔ
Scenes of war
Ɣeyiɣi didi si Mawu ɖe mɔ na amegbetɔwo woɖu dzi la na wòdze ƒãa be womate ŋu akpɔ ameƒomea ƒe kuxiwo gbɔ o
God has allowed men to rule for long enough to demonstrate that they cannot resolve mankind’s problems
Esime Satana da alakpa gbãtɔe vɔ̃ɖinyenye dze egɔme le anyigba dzi.
Evil began on earth when Satan told the first lie.
Mawudɔla debliboe Satana nye le gɔmedzedzea me, gake "meli ke ɖe nyateƒe la me o. "
Satan was originally a perfect angel, but "he did not stand fast in the truth. "
(Yohanes 8:44) Edi be woatsɔ tadedeagu si Mawu ɖeɖe ko dze na la na ye.
(John 8:44) He developed a desire for worship that rightly belongs only to God.
Satana ble nyɔnu gbãtɔ Xawa nu wòɖo toe le esi teƒe be wòaɖo to Mawu.
Satan lied to the first woman, Eve, and persuaded her to obey him instead of God.
Adam wɔ ɖeka kple Xawa wogbe toɖoɖo Mawu.
Adam joined Eve in disobeying God.
Adam ƒe nuwɔna sia he fukpekpe kple ku vae.​ Xlẽ 1 Mose 3:1-6, 19.
Adam’s decision led to suffering and death.​ Read Genesis 3:1-6, 19.
Esi Satana doe ɖe Xawa gbɔ be wòagbe toɖoɖo Mawu la, tsitretsitsi ɖe Mawu ƒe dziɖulanyenye alo eƒe ɖoƒe abe Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la ene ŋu gɔmee ma wòdze.
When Satan suggested that Eve disobey God, he was starting a rebellion against God’s sovereignty, or position as Most High.
Ameƒomea me tɔ akpa gãtɔ wɔ ɖeka kple Satana, eye wogbe be Mawu naganye yewoƒe Dziɖula o.
The majority of mankind have joined Satan in rejecting God as their Ruler.
Ale wɔ Satana va zu "xexea dzi ɖula. "​ Xlẽ Yohanes 14:30; 1 Yohanes 5:19.
Thus, Satan has become "the ruler of the world. "​ Read John 14:30; 1 John 5:19.
Ðe kpɔtsɔtsɔ nɔ Mawu ƒe nuwɔwɔwo ŋua?
Was God’s creation defective?
Nu siwo katã Mawu wɔ la de blibo.
All of God’s works are perfect.
Ŋutete nɔ amegbetɔ kple mawudɔla siwo Mawu wɔ la ŋu be woawɔ eƒe nudidiwo dzi bliboe.
The humans and angels whom God created were capable of obeying God perfectly.
(5 Mose 32:4, 5) Mawu na ablɔɖe mí be míatiae nenye be míawɔ nyui alo vɔ̃.
(Deuteronomy 32:4, 5) God created us with the freedom to choose between doing good and doing evil.
Ablɔɖe sia naa mɔnukpɔkpɔ mí be míaɖee afia be míelɔ̃ Mawu.​ Xlẽ Yakobo 1:13-15; 1 Yohanes 5:3.
That freedom gives us a way to express love for God.​ Read James 1:13-15; 1 John 5:3.
Nu ka tae Mawu ɖe mɔ fukpekpe li va se ɖe fifia?
Why has God allowed suffering until now?
Yehowa ɖe mɔ ɖe aglãdzedze ɖe eƒe dziɖulanyenye ŋu hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
For a limited time, Jehovah has allowed rebellion against his sovereignty.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Be wòaɖee afia be dziɖuɖu si me Mawu ƒe asi mele o la maɖe vi na amewo o.
To show that no effort to rule without him benefits people.
(Nyagblɔla 7:29; 8:9) Nu siwo dzɔ le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya me ƒe 6,000 aɖewoe nye esi la ɖo kpe nya sia ƒe nyateƒenyenye dzi.
(Ecclesiastes 7:29; 8:9) After 6,000 years of human history, the evidence is clear.
Amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo mete ŋu ɖe aʋawɔwɔ, nu vlo wɔwɔ, nu madzɔmadzɔ wɔwɔ, kple dɔléle ɖa o.​ Xlẽ Yeremiya 10:23; Romatɔwo 9:17.
Human rulers have failed to eliminate war, crime, injustice, or disease.​ Read Jeremiah 10:23; Romans 9:17.
Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu hea viɖe geɖe vanae na ame siwo le eƒe akpa dzi, ke mele nenema le amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo ya gome o.
In contrast to human rulership, God’s rule benefits those who accept it.
(Yesaya 48:17, 18) Eteƒe madidi o, Yehowa aɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo katã ɖa.
(Isaiah 48:17, 18) Soon, Jehovah will bring all human government to an end.
Ame siwo abɔbɔ wo ɖokui ɖe Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu te la koe anɔ anyigba dzi. Yesaya 11:9.​ Xlẽ Daniel 2:44.
Only people who choose to be ruled by God will inhabit the earth.​ Isaiah 11:9; Read Daniel 2:44.

Nu Ka Tae Mawu Ðe Mɔ Nazitɔwo Tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo?
Why Did the Holocaust Happen?
Ame geɖe siwo biaa nya sia la ŋutɔ kpe fu dziŋɔwo alo woƒe ame veviwo kpe fu le tsɔtsrɔ̃ dziŋɔ sia me eye menye biabia sia ƒe ŋuɖoɖo ko dim wole o, ke boŋ akɔfafa dimee wole.
Why Didn’t God Stop It? Many who ask these questions have suffered extreme personal loss and seek not just answers but solace.
Ame aɖewo bua ale si Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo be enye amegbetɔwo ƒe nuwɔna dziŋɔtɔ kekeake eye esia na wòsesẽna na wo be woaxɔ Mawu dzi ase.
Others see the Holocaust as the height of human evil, and they struggle to believe in God.
Susu totro siwo nɔa amewo si ɖe Mawu Kple Yudatɔwo ƒe tsɔtsrɔ̃ sia ŋu
Common misconceptions about God and the Holocaust
Alakpanya: Mesɔ be ame nadi be yeanya nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo o.
Myth: It’s wrong to ask why God allowed the Holocaust.
Nyateƒenya: Ame siwo si xɔse sẽŋu le bia nya Mawu ku ɖe nu si tae wòɖe mɔ ɖe nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ ŋu la ŋuti.
Fact: People of great faith have questioned why God allows evil.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nyagblɔɖila Xabakuk bia Mawu be: "Nu ka ŋuti nèna mele nu vlo wɔwɔ teƒe kpɔm, eye nèle hiãkame kpɔm kple ŋku, gbegblẽ kple ŋutasesẽ le ŋkunye me, avuwɔwɔ li, eye dzre dzɔ? "
For instance, the prophet Habakkuk asked God: "Why do you allow violence, lawlessness, crime, and cruelty to spread everywhere? "
(Xabakuk 1:3) Mawu meka mo na Xabakuk o, ɖe wòna wòŋlɔ eƒe nyabiase ma ɖe Biblia me boŋ be mí katã míava xlẽ.
(Habakkuk 1:3, Contemporary English Version) Rather than rebuke Habakkuk, God had the questions he asked recorded in the Bible for all to read.
Alakpanya: Mawu metsɔa ɖeke le amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpewo me o.
Myth: God doesn’t care about human suffering.
Nyateƒenya: Mawu lé fu ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔwo kple fukpekpe siwo esiawo hena vaa amewo dzi la siaa.
Fact: God hates wickedness and the suffering it causes.
(Lododowo 6:16-19) Le Noa ƒe ŋkekeawo me le blema la, ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ siwo xɔ aƒe ɖe anyigba bliboa dzi la ‘ɖu dzi’ na Mawu.
(Proverbs 6:16-19) Back in the days of Noah, God "felt hurt at his heart " because of the violence spreading in the earth.
(1 Mose 6:5, 6) Ðikeke mele eme o be ale si Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo la hã ɖu dzi nɛ ŋutɔ.
(Genesis 6:5, 6) No doubt, God also felt tremendous pain over the Holocaust.
Maleaxi 3:6.
Malachi 3:6.
Alakpanya: Mawue na Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo be yeatsɔ ahe to na wo.
Myth: The Holocaust was God’s punishment of the Jews.
Nyateƒenya: Enye nyateƒe be Mawu ɖe mɔ Romatɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yerusalem le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me ya.
Fact: God did allow Jerusalem to be destroyed by the Romans in the first century.
(Mateo 23:37–24:2) Gake tso ɣemaɣi la, Mawu megatia gbegbɔgblɔ aɖe koŋ dolawo be woawoe nye ye tɔ hewɔa nu ɖe wo ŋu etɔxɛe alo hea to na wo o.
(Matthew 23:37–24:2) Since then, however, God does not single out any ethnic group for special favor or for punishment.
Le Mawu gbɔ la, "vovototo aɖeke mele Yudatɔ kple Helatɔ dome o. "
In God’s view, "there is no difference between Jews and Gentiles. "
Romatɔwo 10:12.
Romans 10:12, Good News Translation.
Alakpanya: Ne ɖe Mawu lɔ̃ame ŋusẽkatãtɔ aɖe li la, anye ne meɖe mɔ Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo o.
Myth: If a loving and all-powerful God existed, he would have prevented the Holocaust.
Nyateƒenya: Togbɔ be Mawu mehea fukpekpe vaa amewo dzi gbeɖe o hã, ɣeaɖewoɣi la, eɖea mɔ ɖe eŋu ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe.
Fact: Although God never causes suffering, he sometimes allows it temporarily.
Nu ka tae Mawu ɖe mɔ Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo o?
Why did God allow the Holocaust?
Susu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ amegbetɔwo katã le fu kpem ɖo la ke tae wòɖe mɔ Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo ɖo: be woakpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na nyui kple vɔ̃ ƒe nya si fɔ ɖe te gbe aɖe gbe ʋĩ ke la.
God allowed the Holocaust for the same reason that he has permitted all human suffering: to settle moral issues that were raised long ago.
Biblia ɖee fia kɔtɛe be Abosam ye le xexea dzi ɖum egbea, menye Mawu ye o.
The Bible clearly indicates that at present the Devil, not God, rules the world.

(Luka 4:1, 2, 6; Yohanes 12:31) Togbɔ be nyati si ƒe kadodo nàkpɔ le tanya sia te ɖe nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ ɖe fukpekpe ŋu me tsitotsito hã la, nyateƒenya eve aɖewo dze le Biblia me siwo akpe ɖe mía ŋu míase nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo ɖo la gɔme.
(Luke 4:1, 2, 6; John 12:31) Two basic facts from the Bible can help explain why God allowed the Holocaust.
Ame ka gbɔe wòtso be Nazitɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yudatɔwo?
God created humans with free will.
Mawu gblɔ nu si wòdi tso amegbetɔ gbãtɔ siwo nye Adam kple Xawa si la na wo, gake mezii ɖe wo dzi o.
God told the first humans, Adam and Eve, what he expected of them, but he did not force them to obey.

Wotiae be yewo ŋutɔwo yewoaɖo nu si nye nyui kple nu si nye vɔ̃ na yewo ɖokuiwo, eye nenema ko amegbetɔ bubuawo hã le ewɔm le ƒe gbogbo siwo kplɔe ɖo me. Woƒe nyametsotso gbegblẽ ma he nɔnɔme dziŋɔwo va ameƒomea katã dzi.
They chose to decide for themselves what was good and bad, and their bad choice and similar choices by people throughout history has brought horrible consequences to mankind.
(1 Mose 2:17; 3:6; Romatɔwo 5:12) Ðeko wòle abe ale si agbalẽ aɖe gblɔe ene be: "Fukpekpe siwo le xexea me ƒe akpa gãtɔ tso ale si mímewɔa tiatiawɔblɔɖe si wona mí la ŋu dɔ nyuie o gbɔ. "

(Genesis 2:17; 3:6; Romans 5:12) It is as the book Statement of Principles of Conservative Judaism says: "Much of the world’s suffering directly results from our misuse of the free will granted to us. "
(Statement of Principles of Conservative Judaism) Mawu mexɔ tiatiawɔblɔɖe le mía si o, ke boŋ ɖe wòna ɣeyiɣi amegbetɔwo be woawo ŋutɔwo woakpɔ woƒe nyawo gbɔ le wo ɖokuiwo si ye Mawu manɔmee.
Rather than revoke our free will, God has given humans time to try to manage their affairs independent of him.
Mawu ate ŋu aɖɔ nu siwo Nazitɔwo gblẽ le Yudatɔwo ŋu la ɖo eye awɔe hã.
God can and will undo all the damage of the Holocaust.
Mawu do ŋugbe be yeafɔ ame miliɔn geɖe siwo ku la ɖe tsitre eye Yudatɔ siwo Nazitɔwo wu hã anɔ eme.
God promises to bring back to life millions who have died, including Holocaust victims.
Aɖe veve si ame siwo tsi agbe le Nazitɔwo ƒe ametsɔtsrɔ̃ ma me sena ne woɖo ŋku nu dziŋɔ siwo me woto dzi la hã ɖa.
He will also eliminate the pain that Holocaust survivors feel because of horrific memories.
(Yesaya 65:17; Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15) Lɔlɔ̃ si le Mawu si na amegbetɔƒomea nye kpeɖodzi be awɔ ɖe eƒe ŋugbedodo siawo dzi.
(Isaiah 65:17; Acts 24:15) God’s love for mankind guarantees that he will fulfill these promises.
Yohanes 3:16.
John 3:16.

Ame siwo tsi agbe le Nazitɔwo ƒe ametsɔtsrɔ̃ ma me la dometɔ geɖe te ŋu va xɔ Mawu dzi se eye woƒe dzi dze eme le agbe me esi wova se nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ vɔ̃ɖinyenye kpɔtɔ li kple tame si wòɖo be yeaɖɔ nu siwo vɔ̃ɖinyenye gblẽ le amewo ŋu la katã ɖo la gɔme.
Many Holocaust victims and survivors were able to maintain their faith and find meaning in life by understanding why God has allowed evil and how he purposes to undo its effects.
Fukpekpe Nu Ayi Kpuie!
The End of Suffering Is at Hand!
Tsɔe be èle xexe si me nu siwo nana míekpea fu, abe nu vlo wɔwɔ, aʋawɔwɔ, dɔléle kple dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo ene mele o la me.
Imagine living in a world free of suffering a world without crime, warfare, sickness, and natural disasters.
Kpɔe ɖa le susu me be ne èfɔ ŋdi sia ŋdi la, mètsia dzimaɖi le vovototodedeameme, ameteteɖeanyi nuwɔna, alo ganyawo ƒe kemalimali ta o.
Imagine waking up every morning without having to worry about discrimination, oppression, or economic uncertainty.
Ðe wòwɔ na wò be drɔ̃e gbɔlo koe nya siawo nyea?
Does all of this sound too good to be true?
Enye nyateƒe be amegbetɔ alo amegbetɔwo ƒe habɔbɔ aɖeke mate ŋu ahe tɔtrɔ mawo ava xexea me o.
Granted, no human or man-made organization can bring about such conditions.
Gake Mawu do ŋugbe be yeaɖe nu siwo katã nana amegbetɔwo kpea fu la ɖa; esiwo me míedzro le nyati si do ŋgɔ me la hã le eme.
But God has promised to do away with all causes of human suffering, including those discussed in the preceding article.
De ŋugble le Mawu ƒe ŋugbedodo siawo siwo dze le eƒe Nya, Biblia, me la ŋu kpɔ:
Note the following promises from God’s Word, the Bible:
DZIÐUÐU NYUI AVA
THE RULE OF GOOD GOVERNMENT
"Dziƒo ƒe Mawu la aɖo fiaɖuƒe aɖe anyi, si matsrɔ̃ gbeɖegbeɖe o, eye eƒe fiaɖuƒe mayi ɖe dukɔ bubu aɖeke si me o; agbã fiaɖuƒe mawo katã, eye wòagblẽ wo, ke eya ŋutɔ anɔ anyi tegbee. "

"The God of heaven will set up a kingdom that will never be brought to ruin. And the kingdom itself will not be passed on to any other people. It will crush and put an end to all these kingdoms, and it itself will stand to times indefinite. "
Daniel 2:44.
Daniel 2:44.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nye dziɖuɖu si woɖo anyi le dziƒo.
The Kingdom of God is a heavenly government.
Yesu Kristo, si nye Dziɖula si Mawu tia la axɔ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo teƒe eye wòakpɔ egbɔ be wole Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu wɔm le dziƒo kple anyigba dzi afi sia hã.
Its chosen Ruler, Jesus Christ, will take the place of all human rulership and will ensure that God’s will is done not only in heaven but also here on earth.
(Mateo 6:9, 10) Amegbetɔ ƒe dziɖuɖu aɖeke mava xɔ ɖe dziɖuɖu sia teƒe o, elabena "mía Aƒetɔ kple Ðela Yesu Kristo ƒe fiaɖuƒe mavɔ " ye wònye.
(Matthew 6:9, 10) This government will not be replaced by any human government because it is "the everlasting kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. "
Ŋutifafa axɔ aƒe ɖi tegbee le dziɖuɖu ma te.
Lasting peace will be assured.
2 Petro 1:11.
2 Peter 1:11.
ALAKPASUBƆSUBƆ MAGANƆ ANYI O
NO MORE FALSE RELIGION
"Satana ŋutɔ yia edzi trɔa eɖokui wɔa kekeli ƒe dɔla.
"Satan himself keeps transforming himself into an angel of light.
Eya ta menye nu gã aɖekee wònye, ne eƒe subɔlawo hã yia edzi trɔa wo ɖokuiwo dzɔdzɔenyenye ƒe subɔlawo o.
It is therefore nothing great if his ministers also keep transforming themselves into ministers of righteousness.
Gake woƒe nuwuwu anɔ ɖe woƒe dɔwɔwɔwo nu. " 2 Korintotɔwo 11:14, 15.
But their end shall be according to their works. " 2 Corinthians 11:14, 15.
Woaklo nu le alakpasubɔsubɔ dzi wòadze gaglãa be Abosam ƒe dɔwɔwɔe wònye, eye woaɖee ɖa keŋkeŋ le anyigba dzi.
False religion will be exposed as the work of the Devil and will be eliminated from the earth.
Fuléle si subɔsubɔhawo dona ɖe ŋgɔ kple woƒe ʋukɔkɔɖi nu ayi.
Gone will be all religious bigotry and bloodshed.
Esia ana mɔnukpɔkpɔ ame siwo katã lɔ̃ "Mawu gbagbe vavã " la be woasubɔe le "xɔse ɖeka " me, le "gbɔgbɔ kple nyateƒe " me.
This will allow all lovers of the "living and true God " to worship him in "one faith " and "with spirit and truth. "
Ŋutifafa kple ɖekawɔwɔ ka gbegbee nye esi wòanye! 1 Tesalonikatɔwo 1:9; Efesotɔwo 4:5; Yohanes 4:23.
What peace and unity! 1 Thessalonians 1:9; Ephesians 4:5; John 4:23.
AMEGBETƆWO ƑE BLIBOMADEMADE NU AYI
HUMAN IMPERFECTION WILL BE NO MORE
"Mawu ŋutɔ anɔ anyi kpli wo.
"God himself will be with them.
Eye wòatutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi o, eye konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o.
And he will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore.
Nu siwo nɔ anyi tsã la nu va yi. "
The former things have passed away. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.
Revelation 21:3, 4.
Yehowa Mawu ana esia nava eme to Via, Yesu, ame si tsɔ eƒe agbe sa vɔe ɖe ameƒomea ta la dzi.
Jehovah God makes this possible by means of his Son, Jesus, who gave his life for the world of mankind.
(Yohanes 3:16) Le Yesu ƒe mɔfiafia te la, woana amegbetɔwo nagava zu ame deblibowo ake, abe ale si wònɔ le gɔmedzedzea me ene.
(John 3:16) Under Jesus’ direction, humankind will be brought to perfection.
Fukpekpe aɖeke maganɔ anyi o, elabena "Mawu ŋutɔ anɔ anyi kpli wo " eye atutu "aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume. "
There will no longer be any suffering because "God himself will be with them " and will erase "every tear from their eyes. "
Eteƒe madidi o, amegbetɔ ƒe blibomademade kple fukpekpe azu gbe aɖe gbe nya; "ame dzɔdzɔewo anyi anyigba la dome, eye woanɔ edzi tegbee. "
Human imperfection and suffering will soon be a thing of the past; "the righteous themselves will possess the earth, and they will reside forever upon it. "
Psalmo 37:29.
Psalm 37:29.
GBƆGBƆ VƆ̃WO MAGANƆ ANYI O
WICKED SPIRITS WILL BE GONE
"[Yesu Kristo] lé ʋɔ driba, si nye da xoxo la, si nye Abosam kple Satana, eye wòblae hena ƒe akpe ɖeka.
"He [Jesus Christ] seized the dragon, the original serpent, who is the Devil and Satan, and bound him for a thousand years.
Eye wòtsɔe ƒu gbe ɖe aʋli la me, eye wòtu nu ɖe enu, eye wòtre enu, bene wòagakplɔ dukɔwo atrae azɔ o. "
And he hurled him into the abyss and shut it and sealed it over him, that he might not mislead the nations anymore. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 20:2, 3.
Revelation 20:2, 3.
Ne wolé Satana kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo de "aʋli la " si nye dɔmawɔmawɔ ƒe nɔnɔme me me vɔ la, womagakpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi azɔ o.
All satanic influence will be gone when Satan and the demons are bound and hurled into "the abyss, " a state of total inactivity.
Ɣemaɣi la, gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo magakpɔ ŋusẽ gbegblẽ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe ɖoɖowo dzi le mɔ aɖeke nu o.
They will no longer exercise their evil control over human affairs.
Gbɔdzɔe ka gbegbee nye esi wòanye be míanɔ agbe le xexe si me Satana kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ƒe fuɖename maganɔ o la me!
What a relief it will be to live in a world free from the influence of Satan and the wicked spirits!
"ŊKEKE MAMLƐAWO " AWU ENU
"THE LAST DAYS " WILL BE OVER
"Ŋkeke mamlɛawo " awu enu ne "xaxa gã " si ŋu Yesu ƒo nu tsoe la va.
"The last days " will end with what Jesus called the "great tribulation. "
Egblɔ be: "Ɣemaɣi la, xaxa gã ava, si tɔgbi meva kpɔ o, ao, meva kpɔ tso xexea ƒe gɔmedzedze va se ɖe fifia o, eye magava ake o. "
He said: "Then there will be great tribulation such as has not occurred since the world’s beginning until now, no, nor will occur again. "
Mateo 24:21.
Matthew 24:21.
Anye xaxa gã le gɔmesesea nu be nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo tɔgbi meva kpɔ o lae ava.
The tribulation will be great in the sense that unprecedented calamities will occur.
Awu enu kple "Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la ƒe ŋkeke gã la ƒe aʋawɔwɔ, " si woyɔna be "Harmagedon. "
These will climax at "the war of the great day of God the Almighty, " better known as "Armageddon. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14, 16.
Revelation 16:14, 16, footnote.
Le xexea me godoo la, ame siwo lɔ̃ nu nyui wɔwɔ la le mɔ kpɔm na nuɖoanyi vɔ̃ɖi sia ƒe nuwuwu vevie.
People everywhere who love what is right look forward to the end of this wicked system of things.
Bu yayra siwo le wo lalam le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe dziɖuɖu te la dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo ko ŋu kpɔ.
Consider just a few of the blessings that await them under God’s Kingdom.
YAYRA BUBUWO AGATSO MAWU GBƆ!
GOD WILL DO EVEN MORE!

Woakpɔ "ameha gã aɖe " ta woage ɖe ŋutifafa ƒe xexe yeye me: Mawu ƒe Nya la gblɔ be "ameha gã " aɖe si womenya xexlẽme na o la "[ado] go tso xaxa gã la me " eye woakpɔ wo ta woage ɖe xexe yeye si me dzɔdzɔenyenye anɔ la me.

"A great crowd " will be preserved into a peaceful new world: God’s Word says that an unnumbered "great crowd " of people will "come out of the great tribulation " and be preserved alive into a righteous new world.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 7:9, 10, 14; 2 Petro 3:13) Woalɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Yesu Kristo, "Mawu ƒe Alẽvi si le xexea ƒe nu vɔ̃ ɖem ɖa " la dzie woto ɖe yewo.
(Revelation 7:9, 10, 14; 2 Peter 3:13) They will attribute their salvation to Jesus Christ, "the Lamb of God that takes away the sin of the world. "
Yohanes 1:29.
John 1:29.
Nufiame si tso Mawu gbɔ aɖe vi geɖe: Le xexe yeyea me la, ‘sidzedze Yehowa axɔ anyigba la dzi.’
Great benefits will come from divine education: In the new world, "the earth will certainly be filled with the knowledge of Jehovah. "
(Yesaya 11:9) Ale si amewo anɔ anyi kple wo nɔewo le ŋutifafa me ahalé be na anyigba la hã le nufiame si atso Mawu gbɔ la me.
(Isaiah 11:9) This divine education will include instruction on how to live in peace with all people and in harmony with the environment.
Mawu do ŋugbe be: "Nye Yehowa, wò Mawu, enye ame si fia nu si nyo na wò la wò, nyee akplɔ wò to mɔ, si dzi nàto la. "
God promises: "I, Jehovah, am your God, the One teaching you to benefit yourself, the One causing you to tread in the way in which you should walk. "
Yesaya 48:17.
Isaiah 48:17.
Woafɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre: Esime Yesu nɔ anyigba dzi la, efɔ exɔlɔ̃ Lazaro si ku la ɖe tsitre.
Dead loved ones will be raised from the grave: While on earth, Jesus raised his friend Lazarus from the dead.
(Yohanes 11:1, 5, 38-44) Eto esia dzi ɖe nu si wòato Mawu Fiaɖuƒea dzi awɔ le xexea me godoo la fia.
(John 11:1, 5, 38-44) Thus he demonstrated what he will do on a much larger scale under God’s Kingdom arrangement.
Yohanes 5:28, 29.
Ŋutifafa kple dzɔdzɔenyenye anɔ anyi tegbee: Le Kristo ƒe dziɖuɖu te la, sedzimawɔmawɔ azu gbe aɖe gbe nya.
Peace and righteousness will prevail forever: Under Christ’s rulership, lawlessness will be a thing of the past.
Aleke míewɔ nya?
How do we know that?
Elabena ŋutete le Yesu si be wòanya nu si le ame ƒe dzi me, eye awɔ ŋutete ma ŋu dɔ atsɔ adrɔ̃ ʋɔnu ame dzɔdzɔewo kple ame vɔ̃ɖiwo.
Because Jesus is able to read hearts, and he will use that ability to judge between the righteous and the wicked.
Womaɖe mɔ na ame siwo gbe be yewomatrɔ le yewoƒe mɔ vɔ̃wo dzi o la be woayi edzi anɔ agbe le Mawu ƒe xexe yeyea me o.
Those who refuse to change their wicked ways will not be allowed to live in God’s new world.
Psalmo 37:9, 10; Yesaya 11:3, 4; 65:20; Mateo 9:4.
Psalm 37:9, 10; Isaiah 11:3, 4; 65:20; Matthew 9:4.
Nu siwo me míedzro la nye Biblia me nyagblɔɖi siwo ƒo nu tso ɣeyiɣi nyui si le ŋgɔ gbɔna ŋu la dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo ko.
We have considered just a few of the many Bible prophecies that point to the wonderful time to come.
Ne Mawu Fiaɖuƒea le anyigba dzi ɖum la, "ŋutifafa gbogbo " axɔ aƒe ɖi tegbee.
When God’s Kingdom exercises rulership over the earth, an "abundance of peace " will prevail forever.
(Psalmo 37:11, 29) Woaɖe nu siwo hea vevesese kple fukpekpe siwo me tom amegbetɔwo le vɛ la katã ɖa.
(Psalm 37:11, 29) All the causes of pain and suffering that have plagued mankind will be undone.
Mawu ŋutɔe do ŋugbe esi wògblɔ be: "Kpɔ ɖa!
We have God’s own word on it: "Look!
Mele nuwo katã wɔm yeyee. . . .
I am making all things new. . . .
Nya siawo nye nyateƒenyawo kple nya vavãwo. "
These words are faithful and true. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:5.
Revelation 21:5.
Ne Wò Ame Vevi Aɖe Ku
When a Loved One Dies
"Bebe, Mawu nya nu si nyo na mí. . . .
"God knows best, baby. . . .
Èseea? . . . Mègafa avi o. "
Don’t . . . you . . . cry. "
Nya mawoe ame aɖe gblɔ ɖe to me na nyɔnu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Bebe, si fofo ku le ʋufɔku aɖe me la, le kua teƒe.
Those words were whispered into the ear of a woman named Bebe. She was at the funeral of her father, who had died in a car accident.
Tsi metoa Bebe kple fofoa dome o.
Bebe had been very close to her father.
Wo xɔlɔ̃ aɖe si nya ƒomea nyuie lae gblɔ nya mawo be yeatsɔ afa akɔ nɛ, gake nya mawo mefa akɔ na Bebe o, ke boŋ ɖeko wogado nuxaxa nɛ.
The remark came from a well-meaning family friend, but Bebe found it more cutting than comforting.
Bebe nɔ egbɔgblɔ dzi be, "Eƒe kua menye nu si nyo nam o. "
"His death wasn’t for the best, " she kept repeating to herself.
Nu si Bebe ŋlɔ ɖe agbalẽ aɖe me tso nudzɔdzɔa ŋu le ƒe aɖewo megbe la ɖee fia kɔtɛ be egakpɔtɔ nɔ fofoa ƒe ku fam kokoko.
It was clear that when Bebe recounted the incident in a book years later, she was still grieving.
Abe ale si Bebe kpɔe dze sii ene la, etea ŋu xɔa ƒe geɖe hafi ame si dzi ku dzɔ ɖo la dzudzɔa nuxaxa, vevietɔ ne woa kple ame si ku la dome nɔ kplikplikpli.
As Bebe came to see, it can take a long time for someone to overcome grief, especially when the bereaved person was very close to the deceased.
Esɔ nyuie be woyɔ ku le Biblia me be "futɔ mamlɛtɔ. " (1 Korintotɔwo 15:26) Ðeko wòva dzea mí kpoyi le vo me, míetea ŋu wɔa naneke le eŋu o, eye wòkplɔa míaƒe ame veviwo dzonɛ.

In the Bible, death is aptly described as "the last enemy. " (1 Corinthians 15:26) It breaks into our lives with irresistible force, often when we are completely unprepared, and it robs us of those we hold dear.
Mía dometɔ aɖeke mate ŋu asi le nu si ku gblẽna le ame ŋu la nu o.
None of us are immune to its ravages.
Eya ta mewɔ nuku o be ne ku dzɔ ɖe mía dzi la, míetɔtɔna, eye míegaxaa nu kokoko ne ɣeyiɣiawo va le yiyim gɔ̃ hã.
So it is not surprising if we feel at a loss when it comes to coping with death and its aftermath.
Ðewohĩ àbia be: ‘Ne ku dzɔ ɖe ame dzi la, ɣeyiɣi didi kae wòxɔna hafi wodzudzɔa nuxaxa?
Perhaps you have wondered: ‘How long does it take to get over grief?
Aleke ame awɔ ado dzi ne ku dzɔ ɖe edzi?
How can a person cope with grief?

Ne Wò Ame Vevi Aɖe Ku
Loss of a Loved One
Ronaldo si le Brazil kple eƒe ƒometɔ atɔ̃ bubu aɖewo dze ʋufɔku, ame atɔ̃awo ku, tɔa kple nɔa hã le wo me.
Ronaldo, in Brazil, was in a car accident that took the lives of five family members, including his mother and father.
Egblɔ be: "Menɔ kɔdzi ɣleti eve hafi wova gblɔ nam be wotsi ʋufɔkua me.
"I was in the hospital for two months before I was told that they had died in the crash, " he says.
Ronaldo
Ronaldo
"Le gɔmedzedzea la, esesẽ nam be maxɔe se be woku.
"At first, I could not believe that they were gone.
Aleke wo katã woate ŋu aku nenema ko?
How could they all be dead?
Esi meva de dzesii kɔtɛe be woku vavã la, dzidzi ƒom.
Once I realized that it was true, I was shocked.
Nyemese veve nenema gbegbe kpɔ o.
I had never felt such pain.
Le ŋkeke siwo kplɔe ɖo me la, ewɔ nam be nye hã maku kpe ɖe wo ŋuti boŋ.
In the days that followed, I felt that life was not worth living without them.
Mefaa avi gbe sia gbe hena ɣleti geɖewo!
I cried every day for months!
Mebua fɔ ɖokuinye be nye ŋutɔ nyemeku ʋua gbe ma gbe o.
I blamed myself for letting someone else drive the car.
Megblɔna na ɖokuinye be, ne nyee ku ʋua la, anye ne womeku o.
If only I had been driving, they might still be alive.
"Ƒe wuiade sɔŋue nye esi va yi, eye mete ŋu dze agbagba ɖɔ nuwo ɖo le nye agbe me ya.
"Sixteen years have passed, and I have been able to get back to my routine of life.
Ke hã woƒe ku kpata ma na be mesena le ɖokuinye me be nu vevi aɖe bu nam le agbe me si dzi nye asi mekpɔ su haɖe o. "
However, their tragic death has left a void in my heart that has yet to be filled. "
TENƆNƆ ÐE AFƆKUA NU
COPING WITH TRAGEDY
Fa wò ame vevi si ku la.
Grieve over your loss.
Biblia gblɔ be "avifaɣi li. "
The Bible says that there is "a time to weep. "
(Nyagblɔla 3:1, 4) Ronaldo gblɔ be: "Ɣesiaɣi si avifafa tsɔm la, mefaa avi.
(Ecclesiastes 3:1, 4) Ronaldo says: "Every time I felt like crying, I allowed myself to do so.
Avitete ame ɖokui meɖea vi o, eye nye dzi dzea eme ŋutɔ ne mefa avi. "
Fighting back tears was futile anyway, and I felt relief afterward. "
Enye nyateƒe be amewo ƒe nuxaxa le vovovo.
Of course, not everyone grieves in the same way.
Eya ta ne mèfa avi alo xa nu wokpɔ le gota o hã la, ema mefia be èle nuxaxa tem ɖokuiwò o eye mègase le ɖokuiwò me hã be ele be yeafa avi godoo o.
So if you do not outwardly display sorrow, this does not mean that you are suppressing your emotions or that you should force tears.
Mègaɖe ɖokuiwò ɖe aga o.
Avoid isolating yourself.
(Lododowo 18:1) Ronaldo gblɔ be: "Medzea agbagba be nyemaɖe ɖokuinye ɖe aga o.
(Proverbs 18:1) "I tried not to give in to the urge to remain socially isolated, " says Ronaldo.
Amewo va srãam kpɔ eye mexɔa wo.
"People visited me, and I welcomed them.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, megblɔa nye seselelãmewo na srɔ̃nye kple xɔ̃nye veviwo. "
I also poured out my feelings to my wife and close friends. "
Lé ɖokuiwò kpoo ne amewo gblɔ nya gbãdzinamewo na wò.
Remain calm if someone says painful words.
Nya siawo dometɔ aɖewo ate ŋu anye, "Susu nyui aɖe tae. "
These might include expressions such as "It was for the best. "
Ronaldo gblɔ be: "Nya siwo amewo gblɔ be yewoatsɔ afa akɔ nam dometɔ aɖewo gbã dzi nam boŋ. "
Ronaldo recalls, "Some comments that were meant to comfort me had the opposite effect. "
Esi nànɔ nya gbãdzinamewo ŋu bum teƒe la, wɔ ɖe Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖo sia dzi boŋ, egblɔ be: "Mègalé to hã ɖe amewo ƒe nu siwo katã woƒona la ŋu o. "
Rather than dwelling on sayings that hurt, follow the Bible’s wise advice: "Do not take to heart every word that people say. "
Nyagblɔla 7:21.
Ecclesiastes 7:21.
Srɔ̃ nu tso nɔnɔme si me kukuawo le ŋu.
Learn the truth about the condition of the dead.
Ronaldo gblɔ be: "Nyagblɔla 9:5 na míenya be kukuawo mekpea fu o, eye esia nyanya na nye susu me dze akɔ anyi.
Ronaldo says: "At Ecclesiastes 9:5, the Bible shows that the dead are not suffering, and that fact gives me an inner peace.
Biblia gblɔ hã be tsitretsitsi li eye woafɔ ame siwo ku la ɖe tsitre.
The Bible also teaches that there is going to be a resurrection and that those who are dead will be brought back to life.
Eya ta mebua nye ame vevi siwo ku la abe ɖeko wozɔ mɔ ene. "
So I think of the loved ones I have lost in death as if they were away on a trip. "
Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15.
Acts 24:15.
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Biblia do ŋugbe be ɣeyiɣi aɖe gbɔna eye Mawu "ami ku saɖagatsi tegbee. "
The Bible promises a time when God "will swallow up death forever. "
Yesaya 25:8.
Isaiah 25:8.
Nyati siawo ƒo nu tso ale si nàwɔ anɔ te ɖe nya vɔ̃wo nu la ŋu.
This series of articles discusses how you can cope with tragedy.
