Ale Si Nàwɔ Anɔ Te Ðe Nuxaxa Nu Nu Si Nàte Ŋu Awɔ Egbea
Coping With Grief​ What You Can Do Today
Ne èdi aɖaŋuɖoɖo tso ale si nàwɔ anɔ te ɖe nuxaxa nu ŋu la, ɖewohĩ àke ɖe gbogbo aɖewo ŋu, eye ɖewo aɖe vi wu bubuwo.
If you look for advice on dealing with grief, you will likely find a myriad of ideas​ some more helpful than others.
Ðewohĩ susu si tae nye be, abe ale si míegblɔe va yi ene la, amewo xaa nu le mɔ vovovowo nu.
Perhaps that is because, as mentioned earlier, everyone grieves differently.
Mɔnu aɖe si wɔ dɔ na ame aɖea, mawɔ dɔ na ame bubu o.
What works for one person may not work for someone else.
Togbɔ be ele alea hãa, aɖaŋuɖoɖo mawo ƒe ɖewo ɖe vi na ame geɖe.
Even so, there are some basic guidelines that have proved practical for many.
Zi geɖea wonye esiwo ame siwo ɖoa aɖaŋu tso nuxaxa ŋu la ɖona, eye wowɔ ɖeka kple mɔfiame si dze le blemagbalẽ aɖe si nye Biblia, si me nyawo gaɖea vi la me.
They are frequently cited by grief counselors, and they echo timeless principles found in an ancient book of wisdom, the Bible.
1: NA WÒ ƑOMETƆWO KPLE XƆLƆ̃WO NAKPE ÐE ŊUWÒ
1: ACCEPT SUPPORT FROM FAMILY AND FRIENDS
Ame aɖewo le fefem le ƒuta eye wole foto ɖem
People at the seashore fly a kite and take pictures
Aɖaŋuɖola bibi aɖewo bui be esia nye mɔ vevi siwo dzi woato anɔ te ɖe nuxaxa nu la dometɔ ɖeka.
Some experts consider this to be the most important factor in getting through grief.
Ke hã ɣeaɖewoɣia màdi be ame aɖeke nanɔ ye ŋu o.
Yet, at times, you may want to be alone.
Àte ŋu ado dziku ɖe ame siwo le agbagba dzem be yewoakpe ɖe ŋuwò la ŋu gɔ̃ hã.
You may even feel irritated at those who are trying to help you.
Naneke megblẽ le eŋu o.
This is normal.
Mègasusu be ele be amewo nanɔ ye ŋu ɣesiaɣi o, gake mèganya wo ɖa keŋkeŋ le ɖokuiwò ŋu hã o.
Do not feel that you must always be around others, but do not completely push them away either.
Àva hiã woƒe kpekpeɖeŋu emegbe.
After all, you may need their support in the future.
Gblɔ nu si nèdi be woawɔ na ye kple nu si mèdi o la na wo.
Kindly let others know what you need at the moment and what you do not.
Togbɔ be àdi be amewo nawɔ nanewo na ye alo woagawɔ nanewo na ye o hã, ele be nàda asɔ be nàte ŋu akpɔ ɣeyiɣi na amewo hã.
According to your needs, find a balance between time with other people and time alone.
MƆFIAME: "Ne ame le eve la, enyo wu ame ɖeka, . . .
PRINCIPLE: "Two are better than one . . .
Elabena ne wo dometɔ ɖeka dze anyi la, evelia afɔe ɖe tsitre. " Nyagblɔla 4:9, 10.
For if one of them falls, the other can help his partner up. "​ Ecclesiastes 4:9, 10.
2: LÉ ŊKU ÐE WÒ NUÐUÐU ŊU, EYE NÀDI ƔEYIƔI ADE KAME
2: WATCH YOUR DIET, AND MAKE TIME FOR EXERCISE
Ne èɖua nu nyuie la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàte ŋu anɔ te ɖe nuxaxa nu.
A balanced diet will help with the stress that comes from dealing with grief.
Dze agbagba be yeanɔ atikutsetsewo, amagbewo kple nuɖuɖu siwo me protein le la ɖum.
Try to eat a variety of fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins.
No tsi sɔgbɔ eye nàno nunono bubu siwo dea lãmesẽ dzi hã.
Drink plenty of water and other healthful liquids.
Ne nu menya le ɖuɖum na wò o la, ekema ɖui vivivi edziedzi.
If your appetite is low, eat small portions more frequently.
Azɔ hã, àte ŋu agblɔ na wò ɖɔkta be wòana nunyiametikewo wò.
You may also ask your doctor about nutrition supplements.
Azɔlizɔzɔ atsɔ ade kame kple kamedede bubuwo ate ŋu ana ame matsi dzi fũu o.
Brisk walks and other forms of exercise can lessen negative emotions.
Kamedede ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàde ŋugble le ale si nuwo trɔ na wò fifia la ŋu alo ana nàɖe susu ɖa le nu si dzɔa dzi vie.
Exercise can provide time to reflect on your loss or to take a break from thinking about it.
MƆFIAME: "Ame aɖeke melé fu eya ŋutɔ ƒe ŋutilã kpɔ o, ke boŋ enyinɛ, eye wòléa be nɛ nyuie. " Efesotɔwo 5:29.
PRINCIPLE: "No one has ever hated his own body but he feeds it and takes care of it. "​ Ephesians 5:29, NET Bible.
3: DƆ ALƆ̃ NÀÐI ÐE EME NYUIE
3: GET PLENTY OF SLEEP
A bati
A bed
Alɔ̃dɔdɔ le vevie, gake egale vevie na ame siwo le nu xam ya wu elabena nuxaxa naa nu tia kɔ na ame.
Sleep is always important, but this is especially so for those who are grieving, as grief can bring extra fatigue.
Mègano nu siwo me caffeine le fũu o eye mèganɔ aha hã nom fũu o elabe woate ŋu agblẽ alɔ̃ me na wò.
Be careful with the amount of caffeine and alcohol you consume, as both can interfere with your sleep.
MƆFIAME: "Gbɔɖeme asiʋlo ɖeka nyo wu dɔ sesẽ wɔwɔ kple dagbadagba ɖe yame asiʋlo eve. " Nyagblɔla 4:6.
PRINCIPLE: "Better is a handful of rest than two handfuls of hard work and chasing after the wind. "​ Ecclesiastes 4:6.
4: DA SƆ
4: BE FLEXIBLE
Nyɔnu aɖe si le nu xam la le nu ƒom tso eƒe kuxia ŋu na exɔlɔ̃
A grieving woman expresses herself to a friend
Nenɔ susu me na wò be ame sia ame kple ale si wòxaa nui.
Recognize that everyone grieves differently.
Ele be nàte ŋu anya esi ade dziwò wu.
Ultimately, you will need to determine the strategy that works best for you.
Ame geɖe kpɔe be ne yewoƒo nu tso yewoƒe nuxaxa ŋu na ame bubuwo la, ekpena ɖe yewo ŋu yewonɔa te ɖe enu, gake ame bubuwo ya medina be yewoaƒo nu tso eŋu o.
Many find that expressing their grief to others helps them deal with it, while others prefer not to express their grief.
Eŋuti aɖaŋuɖolawo ƒe susu mesɔ le nya sia ŋu o.
Experts have various opinions as to whether expressing one’s feelings is vital to success in coping with grief.
Ne èdi be yegblɔ yeƒe dzimenya na ame aɖe gake wòle sesẽm na wò la, ɖewohĩ anɔ bɔbɔe na wò wu be nàgblɔ ale si nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me ƒe sue aɖe na xɔ̃wò vevi aɖe.
If you need to confide in someone but are hesitant to do so, you might find it easier to start small by expressing some of your feelings to a close friend.
Le ame aɖewo gome la, wokpɔe be ne yewofa avi la, ekpena ɖe yewo ŋu yewonɔa te ɖe nuxaxa nu, gake ame bubuwo ya tea ŋu nɔa te ɖe enu ne womefa avi boo o hã.
Some people find that crying helps them deal with their grief, while others seem to cope even though they cry less.
MƆFIAME: "Ame ƒe dzi nya eya ŋutɔ ƒe vevesese. " Lododowo 14:10.
PRINCIPLE: "Each heart knows its own bitterness. "​ Proverbs 14:10, New International Version.
5: TSRI NU SIWO AGBLẼ NU LE ŊUWÒ LA WƆWƆ
5: AVOID SELF-DESTRUCTIVE HABITS
Ŋutsu aɖe le ahasesẽ nom
A man drinks alcohol
Ame aɖewo siwo ame ku na nɔa aha mum eye wonɔa atike vɔ̃ɖiwo zãm be yewoatsɔ atsi yewoƒe vevesesea nu.
Some bereaved ones try to ease their emotional pain through the misuse of alcohol or drugs.
Nuwɔna sia gblẽa nu le ame ŋu.
Such "escape " is self-destructive.
Ðeko aha kple atike vɔ̃wo nana ame kpɔa gbɔdzɔe hena ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe ko, gake emegbe emetsonuawo gblẽa nu vevie.
Any relief a person may feel is short-lived, only to be followed by major negative consequences.
Di mɔ siwo dzi nàto anɔ te ɖe nuxaxa nu evɔ magblẽ nu le ŋuwò o.
Try harmless ways to calm your anxieties.
MƆFIAME: "Mina míakɔ mía ɖokui ŋu tso . . . ɖiƒoƒo sia ɖiƒoƒo me. " 2 Korintotɔwo 7:1.
PRINCIPLE: "Let us cleanse ourselves of every defilement. "​ 2 Corinthians 7:1.
6: ZÃ WÒ ƔEYIƔIWO NYUIE
6: BALANCE YOUR TIME
Ame geɖe kpɔe be eɖea vi ne yewowɔ nanewo be yewoaɖe susu ɖa le nuxaxaa ŋu ahawɔ nu siwo ana yewoƒe susu nadze akɔ anyi ale be wòaɖe yewoƒe vevesesea dzi akpɔtɔ vie.
Many find it helpful to alternate periods of grieving (experiencing and dealing with their emotions) with temporary breaks (activities that temporarily distance them from their pain).
Wò dzi adze eme vie ne èdze xɔlɔ̃ nyuiwo, srɔ̃ asinudɔ yeye aɖe alo ɖe modzaka.
You may find temporary relief by forming or strengthening friendships, learning new skills, or engaging in recreation.
Ne ɣeyiɣiawo va le yiyim la, àva trɔ ɖe nɔnɔmea ŋu.
As time passes, the balance will likely change.
Àva kpɔe be wò nuxaxaa maganɔ abe tsã ene o, edzi anɔ ɖeɖem kpɔtɔ eye esia akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe kuxia nu.
You may notice that your breaks from grieving become longer and more frequent​ a natural part of the healing process.
MƆFIAME: "Ɣeyiɣi li na nu sia nu, . . . avifaɣi li, eye nukoɣi li; konyifaɣi li, eye ɣeɖuɣi li. " Nyagblɔla 3:1, 4.
PRINCIPLE: "There is an appointed time for everything, . . . a time to weep and a time to laugh; a time to wail and a time to dance. "​ Ecclesiastes 3:1, 4.
7: YI NU SIWO NÈWƆNA DZI
7: KEEP A ROUTINE
Nyɔnu aɖe le ɖoɖo wɔm ɖe nu siwo wòawɔ ŋu
A woman uses a calendar to plan her routine
Ne anya wɔa, yi nu siwo nèwɔna dzi.
As soon as possible, resume a normal routine.
Ne èmlɔa anyi ɖe game dzi, wɔa dɔ, eye nèwɔa nu bubuwo la, nuwo ava nɔ na wò abe tsã ene.
When you hold to a routine for sleep, work, and other activities, you will likely regain a sense of normalcy.
Ne ètrɔ ɖe dɔ bubuwo ŋu la, ana nàɖe veve si kua do na wò la dzi akpɔtɔ.
Keeping yourself occupied with positive activities can help to mitigate painful emotions.
MƆFIAME: "Ƒãa hafi wògabua eƒe agbemeŋkekewo ƒe yiyi ŋu, le esi Mawu vavã la na eƒe susu katã le eƒe dzi ƒe dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ ŋu ta. " Nyagblɔla 5:20.
PRINCIPLE: "He will hardly notice the passing days of his life, because the true God keeps him preoccupied with the rejoicing of his heart. "​ Ecclesiastes 5:20.
8: MÈGATSƆ DZITSITSI WƆ NYAMETSOTSOWO O
8: AVOID MAKING BIG DECISIONS TOO SOON
Ame siwo tsɔ dzitsitsi wɔ nyametsotsowo le woƒe ame vevi aɖe ƒe ku megbe kpuie la va kpɔnɛ be yewowɔ vodada.
Many who make big decisions soon after losing a loved one later regret those decisions.
Ne anya wɔ la, lala ɣeyiɣi aɖe hafi aʋu, adi dɔ yeye alo atsɔ wò ame vevi si ku la ƒe nanewo aƒu gbe.
If possible, wait for a reasonable length of time before moving, changing jobs, or discarding your loved one’s belongings.
MƆFIAME: "Veviedola ƒe ɖoɖowo hea dzidzedzekpɔkpɔ vanɛ, ke ame sia ame si tsia klokloklo la, hiã atui. " Lododowo 21:5.
PRINCIPLE: "The plans of the diligent surely lead to success, but all who are hasty surely head for poverty. "​ Proverbs 21:5.
9: MÈGAŊLƆ WÒ AME VEVI SI KU LA BE O
9: REMEMBER YOUR LOVED ONE
Ŋutsu aɖe tsɔ srɔ̃a si ku la ƒe fotowo le amewo fiam
A man shows friends pictures of his deceased wife
Ame geɖe siwo ame ku na kpɔe be eɖea vi ne yewowɔa nu siwo akpe ɖe yewo ŋu be yewoaɖo ŋku yewoƒe ame si ku la dzi.
Many bereaved ones feel it is beneficial to do things that help keep alive their memory of the person who has died.
Àkpɔe be wò dzi adze eme ne èdzra foto alo ŋkuɖodzinu aɖewo ɖo loo alo ŋlɔ nudzɔdzɔ vevi aɖewo siwo màdi be yeaŋlɔ be o la ɖi.
You might find it therapeutic to collect pictures or mementos or to create a journal of events and stories you wish to recall.
Dzra nu siwo ana nàɖo ŋku nuwo dzi kple dzidzɔ la ɖo, eye ne dzi ɖe le ƒowò la, tsɔ wo eye nàlé ŋku ɖe wo ŋu.
Store items that trigger pleasant memories and look through them later, when you feel ready.
MƆFIAME: "Ðo ŋku tsãŋkekewo dzi. " 5 Mose 32:7.
PRINCIPLE: "Remember the days of old. "​ Deuteronomy 32:7.
10: YI MƆKEKE
10: GET AWAY
Àte ŋu atiae be yeayi mɔkeke.
You might consider taking a vacation.
Ne manya wɔ be nàyi mɔkeke didi oa, ɖewohĩ àte ŋu awɔ nane si doa dzidzɔ na wò la ŋkeke ɖeka alo eve, abe azɔ zɔli legbe aɖi tsa, ayi blemanudzraɖoƒe alo aku ʋu ado vie.
If a lengthy vacation is not practical, perhaps you can do something enjoyable for just a day or two, such as hiking, visiting a museum, or taking a drive.
Ne èwɔ nane si to vovo na nu si nèwɔna gbe sia gbe vie gɔ̃ hã la, ana nànɔ te ɖe nuxaxa nu.
Even a brief change of pace can help you cope with your grief.
MƆFIAME: "Miva, ne míawo ɖeɖe míayi teƒe aɖe si ame aɖeke mele o, ne míaɖi ɖe eme vie. " Marko 6:31.
PRINCIPLE: "Come, you yourselves, privately into an isolated place and rest up a little. "​ Mark 6:31.
11: KPE ÐE AMEWO ŊU
11: HELP OTHERS
Ðetugbi aɖe le kpekpem ɖe nyɔnu tsitsi aɖe ŋu be wòaɖi asi
A young woman helps an older woman with her grocery shopping
De dzesii be ɣesiaɣi si nèkpe ɖe ame aɖe ŋu la, akpe ɖe wò ŋutɔ hã ŋu be nàŋlɔ wò nuxaxaa be vie.
Remember that any time you can spend being of help to others can help you feel better.
Ðewohĩ àte ŋu adze egɔme tso ame siwo hã dzi wò ame vevia ƒe kua le tetem ɖo la dzi, abe xɔlɔ̃wo alo ƒometɔ siwo hã le nu xam, elabe wonya be èse nu siwo me tom yewole la gɔme.
You might start by helping others who have been affected by the loss of your loved one, such as friends or relatives who may need a grieving companion.
Ne èkpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu hefa akɔ na wo la, ana dzi nagadzɔ wò eye agbe yeye aɖo mewò.
Supporting and comforting others can give you renewed joy and a sense of purpose that may seem to be lacking.
MƆFIAME: "Dzidzɔ geɖe le nunana me wu nuxɔxɔ. " Dɔwɔwɔwo 20:35.
PRINCIPLE: "There is more happiness in giving than there is in receiving. "​ Acts 20:35.
12: GBUGBƆ ŊKU LÉ ÐE NU SIWO LE VEVIE NA WÒ LA ŊU
12: REEVALUATE YOUR PRIORITIES
Nuxaxa ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàva de dzesi nu siwo tututu le vevie.
Grief can provide new insights into what truly matters.
Wɔ mɔnukpɔkpɔa ŋu dɔ nàtsɔ alé ŋku ɖe ale si nèle agbea nɔmee ŋu.
Take advantage of the opportunity to evaluate how you are using your life.
Ne ehiãa, trɔ asi le nu siwo nèbuna nu vevii la ŋu.
As needed, make adjustments in your priorities.
MƆFIAME: "Kuƒemeyiyi nyo wu aglotuƒeyiyi, elabena afi kemɛa nye amegbetɔwo katã ƒe nuwuƒe, eye ele be wòade dzi gbɔ na agbagbeawo. " Nyagblɔla 7:2.
PRINCIPLE: "Better to go to the house of mourning than to the house of feasting, for that is the end of every man, and the living should take it to heart. "​ Ecclesiastes 7:2.
ALE SI NÀWƆ ANƆ TE ÐE NUXAXA NU | TOTOÐEME
COPING WITH GRIEF | SUMMARY
1: NA WÒ ƑOMETƆWO KPLE XƆLƆ̃WO NAKPE ÐE ŊUWÒ
1: ACCEPT SUPPORT FROM FAMILY AND FRIENDS
Togbɔ be àdi be amewo nawɔ nanewo na ye alo woagawɔ nanewo na ye o hã, ele be nàda asɔ be nàte ŋu akpɔ ɣeyiɣi na amewo hã.
According to your needs, balance time spent with others and time spent alone.
2: LÉ ŊKU ÐE WÒ NUÐUÐU ŊU, EYE NÀDI ƔEYIƔI ADE KAME
2: WATCH YOUR DIET, AND MAKE TIME FOR EXERCISE
Ðu nuɖuɖu siwo me nunyiame le, no tsi sɔgbɔ eye nade kame ale si sɔ.
Eat healthful food, drink plenty of water, and exercise moderately.
3: DƆ ALƆ̃ NÀÐI ÐE EME NYUIE
3: GET PLENTY OF SLEEP
Nyae be alɔ̃dɔdɔ akpe ɖe ŋuwò be naɖe nuteameŋu kple nuxaxa dzi akpɔtɔ.
Recognize that sleep is essential to dealing with the fatigue of grieving.
4: DA SƆ
4: BE FLEXIBLE
Nenɔ susu me na wò be ame sia ame kple ale si wòxaa nui, di mɔnu si ade dziwò wu.
Since everyone grieves differently, find what works for you.
5: TSRI NU SIWO AGBLẼ NU LE ŊUWÒ LA WƆWƆ
5: AVOID SELF-DESTRUCTIVE HABITS
Tsri ahamumu kple atike vɔ̃ɖiwo zazã elabe kuxiwo boŋue woahe vɛ na wò.
Avoid the misuse of alcohol or drugs​ which creates more problems than it solves.
6: ZÃ WÒ ƔEYIƔIWO NYUIE
6: BALANCE YOUR TIME
Wɔ nu siwo ana nàɖe susu ɖa le nuxaxaa ŋu, abe xɔlɔ̃ nyuiwo dzedze kple modzakaɖeɖe ene.
Alternate periods of grieving with time for socializing and recreation.
7: YI NU SIWO NÈWƆNA DZI
7: KEEP A ROUTINE
Ne èyi nu siwo nèwɔna dzi la, nuwo agava nɔ na wò abe tsã ene.
Regain a sense of normalcy by keeping yourself occupied with a good routine.
8: MÈGATSƆ DZITSITSI WƆ NYAMETSOTSOWO O
8: AVOID MAKING BIG DECISIONS TOO SOON
Ne anya wɔ la, lala ƒe ɖeka alo esi wu ema hafi atso nya me le nu vevi aɖewo siwo ava ve wò emegbe la ŋu.
If possible, wait a year or more before making big decisions you may later regret.
9: MÈGAŊLƆ WÒ AME VEVI SI KU LA BE O
9: REMEMBER YOUR LOVED ONE
Dzra foto kple ŋkuɖodzinu aɖewo ɖo alo ŋlɔ nudzɔdzɔ vevi aɖewo siwo màdi be yeaŋlɔ be o la ɖi atsɔ anɔ ŋku ɖom ame si ku la dzi.
Collect pictures and mementos or write in a journal to keep alive your memory of the person who has died.
10: YI MƆKEKE
10: GET AWAY
Di ɣeyiɣi nàwɔ nane si to vovo na nu si nèwɔna gbe sia gbe, àte ŋu awɔe ŋkeke ɖeka alo le ŋkekea ƒe akpa aɖe ko.
Make time for a change of pace​ even if for just a day or part of a day.
11: KPE ÐE AMEWO ŊU
11: HELP OTHERS
Kpe ɖe amewo ŋu nàtsɔ ado ŋusẽ ɖokuiwò; amewo abe ame siwo hã dzi wò ame vevia ƒe kua le tetem ɖo la ene.
Renew your sense of purpose by doing things for those who need help, including others affected by the loss of your loved one.
12: GBUGBƆ ŊKU LÉ ÐE NU SIWO LE VEVIE NA WÒ LA ŊU
12: REEVALUATE YOUR PRIORITIES
Wɔ mɔnukpɔkpɔa ŋu dɔ nàtsɔ alé ŋku ɖe nu siwo tututu le vevie la ŋu, eye ne ehiã la, trɔ asi le nu siwo nèbuna nu vevii la ŋu.
Use this opportunity to gain new insights into what truly matters and, as needed, make adjustments to your priorities.
Le nyateƒe mea, naneke mate ŋu atsi wò vevesesea nu keŋkeŋ o.
Realistically, nothing will completely erase the pain you feel.
Ke hã ame geɖe siwo ƒe ame vevi aɖe ku la alɔ̃ ɖe edzi be esi yewowɔ ɖe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe le nyati sia me dzi la, ekpe ɖe yewo ŋu yewoƒe akɔ fa.
However, many who have lost a loved one can attest that taking positive steps, such as those listed in this article, helped them to find comfort.
Ke hã, menye nu siwo katã akpe ɖe ame ŋu wòaɖe nuxaxa dzi akpɔtɔ ŋue míeƒo nu tsoe o.
Of course, this is not a comprehensive list of every possible way to alleviate grief.
Gake ne ète mɔnu siawo dometɔ aɖewo kpɔ la, àkpɔe be woakpe ɖe ye ŋu yeƒe vevesesea nu naɖiɖi vie.
But if you try some of these suggestions, you may find that they will bring you a welcome measure of relief.
Ne Wò Ame Vevi Aɖe Ku
When a Loved One Dies
"Wɔna vɔ le ŋunye esi fonye tsitsia ku kpata.
"I felt helpless when my older brother died unexpectedly.
Ɣleti geɖe megbe la, meɖoa ŋku fonyea dzi le vome, eye mesea veve abe ɖe woƒo hɛ̃ ɖe nye dzi me ene.
Months later I would suddenly remember him and feel sick, as if a knife were stabbing me deep inside.
Dzi kuam ɣeaɖewoɣi mebiana be nu ka tae nɔvinyea ku?
At times, I was also angry.
Eye mebu fɔ ɖokuinye be ɖe wòle be nye kplii míawɔ nu ɖekae geɖe wu hafi. "
Why did my brother have to die?
Vanessa, Australia.
And I felt guilty for not having spent more time with him. "​ Vanessa, Australia.
NE AME vevi aɖe ku na wò kpɔ la, wò hã àse seselelãme vovovowo le ɖokuiwò me, àfa konyi, àtsi akogo, eye wɔna avɔ le ŋuwò.
IF YOU have lost someone you love in death, you too may have felt a wide range of emotions, from sorrow to loneliness and helplessness.
Ðewohĩ àdo dziku, anɔ fɔ bum ɖokuiwò, eye vɔvɔ̃ aɖo wò.
Perhaps you have also felt anger, guilt, and fear.
Ànɔ ɖokuiwò biam gɔ̃ hã be ɖe agbea aganya nɔ na yea?
You may have even wondered whether life is still worth living.
Megblẽ be ame naxa nu o.
Be assured that grief is not a sign of weakness.
Ke boŋ efia ale si gbegbe ame si ku la le vevie na wò.
It indicates how much your loved one meant to you.
Ke hã ɖe wòanya wɔ be nàkpɔ akɔfafa aɖe si nu ne èle nu xam veviea?
However, is it possible to find a measure of relief from your painful grief?
ALE SI AME AÐEWO WƆ NƆ TE ÐE ENU
HOW SOME HAVE COPED
Togbɔ be adze abe wò nuxaxa nu gbe tsotso hã la, nya siwo gbɔna ate ŋu afa akɔ na wò:
While your pain can seem unending, you may find the following suggestions consoling:
MÈGAZI WÒ NUXAXA DZI O
ALLOW YOURSELF TIME TO GRIEVE
Menye amewo katãe xaa nu le mɔ ɖeka aɖe nu alo hena ɣeyiɣi ƒe didime ɖeka o.
Not everyone grieves in the same way or for the same amount of time.
Ke hã avifafa ate ŋu ana vevesesea dzi naɖe vie.
Still, crying can provide an outlet for fragile emotions.
Vanessa, si ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi gblɔ be: "Avi koe metsɔnɛ na; ɖeko medi be maɖe vevesesea dzi vie. "
Vanessa, quoted earlier, says: "I would just cry; I needed to release the pain. "
Sofía, si nɔvinyɔnu ku kpata gblɔ be: "Ne meɖo ŋku nu si dzɔ kple ale si mese le ɖokuinye me dzi la, ɖeko wòle abe abi si dze adru si klɔm wole ene.
Sofía, whose sister died suddenly, says: "Confronting my thoughts and feelings is very painful, like opening and cleaning an infected wound.
Vevesesea wua tsɔtsɔ na ame, gake ekpena ɖe abia ŋu wòkuna. "
The pain is almost unbearable, but it allows the wound to heal. "
ƑO NU TSO ALE SI NÈLE SESEM LE ÐOKUIWÒ ME ŊU
TALK ABOUT YOUR THOUGHTS AND FEELINGS
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, àdi be yeaɖe ye ɖokui ɖe aga, eye megblẽ o.
Understandably, at times you may wish to be alone.
Gake nuxaxa nye agba kpekpe aɖe si wò ɖeka màte ŋu atsɔ o.
But grief is a heavy burden to carry by yourself.
Jared, si xɔ ƒe 17 si fofo ku ɖo ŋku edzi be: "Megblɔa nye seselelãmewo na amewo.
Seventeen-year-old Jared, who lost his father, recalls: "I talked about my emotions with others.
Nyemenya ne susu nɔa nya siwo megblɔna me ya o, gake edzɔ dzi nam be meƒo nu tso wo ŋu. "
I doubt I made much sense, but it was good just to be able to express myself. "
Janice, si ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe le nyati gbãtɔ me gblɔ viɖe bubu si le ewɔwɔ nenema ŋu be: "Ne èƒo nu tso eŋu na amewo la, ana wò dzi nafa.
Janice, quoted in the opening article, adds another benefit: "Talking with others was tremendously comforting.
Mesena le ɖokuinye me be wose nu gɔme nam, eye nyemegatsia akogo o. "
I felt understood, and I didn’t feel so alone. "
LƆ̃ WOAKPE ÐE ŊUWÒ
ACCEPT HELP
Ðɔkta aɖe gblɔ be: "Ame siwo dzi ku dzɔ ɖo kpata siwo lɔ̃na be xɔlɔ̃wo kple ƒometɔwo nakpe ɖe yewo ŋu la, tea ŋu nɔa te ɖe nuxaxa si vana le mɔ vovovowo nu la nu wu. "
One doctor says: "The bereaved who allow friends and relatives to help them through [the] initial period [of shock] tend to continue to move with some ease through the different phases of grief. "
Na xɔ̃wòwo nanya kpekpeɖeŋu si nèhiã; woadi be yewoakpe ɖe ŋuwò gake womanya ale si tututu woakpe ɖe ŋuwòe o.
Let your friends know what they can do to help; they likely want to but might not know how.​ Proverbs 17:17.
Lododowo 17:17.
DRAW CLOSER TO GOD
TE ÐE MAWU ŊU Tina gblɔ be: "Esi kansa wu srɔ̃nye kpata la, nyemagate ŋu agblɔ nye dzimenyawo nɛ o, eya ta megblɔa nya sia nya na Mawu!
Tina says: "When I suddenly lost my husband to cancer, I could no longer confide in him, so I would tell God everything!
Ŋdi sia ŋdi la, mebiana Mawu be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye le ŋkekea me.
I started each day asking him to help me get through the day.
Eye ekpe ɖe ŋunye le mɔ geɖe nu wu gbɔgblɔ. "
God helped me in more ways than I can mention. "
Tarsha si xɔ ƒe 22 esime dadaa ku la gblɔ be: "Biblia xexlẽ gbe sia gbee nye nu si fa akɔ nam.
Tarsha, who was 22 years old when her mother died, says: "Bible reading was my daily source of comfort.
Enana mekpɔa dzideƒonamenya siwo ŋu made ŋugble le. "
It gave me something encouraging to think about. "
NƆ TSITRETSITSIA KPƆM LE SUSU ME
VISUALIZE THE RESURRECTION
Tina yi edzi gblɔ be: "Gbãa, tsitretsitsi ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔa mefa akɔ nam o, elabe mehiã srɔ̃nyea eye ɖeviawo hã hiã wo fofo ɣemaɣi.
Tina continues: "Initially, the resurrection hope didn’t comfort me because I needed my husband​ and my boys needed their father ​right then.
Gake fifia le ƒe ene megbe la, melé mɔkpɔkpɔ sia me ɖe asi goŋgoŋ.
However, now, four years later, I cling to this hope.
Enye mɔkpɔkpɔ si lé nye agbe ɖe te.
It’s a lifeline for me.
Mekpɔnɛ le susu me be magava kpɔ srɔ̃nyea, eye esia nana mekpɔa ŋutifafa kple dzidzɔ! "
I imagine seeing him again, and it brings me such peace and joy! "
Esia mefia be àdzudzɔ nuxaxa enumake o.
You are not likely to experience instant relief from your grief.
Ke hã, nu si me Vanessa to ate ŋu ade dzi ƒo na wò.
Nevertheless, Vanessa’s experience can be reassuring.
Egblɔ be: "Àsusu be mafa na ye gbeɖe o, gake ʋɛʋɛʋɛ la, nuxaxaa dzi aɖe akpɔtɔ. "
She says, "You think you’ll never get through it, but you will see brighter days. "
Ðo ŋku edzi be togbɔ be nuxaxa le dzi me na wò hã la, susu nyuiwo li siwo ta wòle be nàyi edzi anɔ agbe.
Remember, while the void you feel in your heart may not disappear, life is still worth living.
Le Mawu ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu me la, xɔ̃wòwo ate ŋu ana susu nyui naganɔ asiwò ɖe agbea ŋu.
With God’s tender help, you can still enjoy warm friendships and a purposeful life.
Eye eteƒe madidi o Mawu afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre.
And soon God will resurrect the dead.
Edi be nàgava wɔ atuu na wò ame vevia ake.
He wants you to be able to embrace your loved one again.
Ɣemaɣi la, vevesese si le wò dzi me la nu ayi keŋkeŋ!
Then that pain in your heart will be healed forever!
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò
Bible Verses That Can Help
Mawu le wò nuxaxa kple wò aɖatsiwo kpɔm.
God cares about your grief and tears.
Biblia ŋlɔla aɖe gblɔ na Mawu be: "Kɔ nye aɖatsiwo ɖe wò lãgbalẽgolo me.
One Bible writer said to God: "Do collect my tears in your skin bottle.
Ðe mèŋlɔ wo ɖe wò agbalẽ me oa? " Psalmo 56:8.
Are they not recorded in your book? "​ Psalm 56:8.
Àte ŋu agblɔ wò dzimenyawo na Mawu.
You can pour out your heart to God.
"Meƒo nu le nye xaxawo ŋu le [Mawu ŋkume], . . .
"Before [God] I tell about my distress . . .
Oo Yehowa, wò yɔm mele be nàxɔ nam. " Psalmo 142:2, 5.
I call to you, O Jehovah, for help. "​ Psalm 142:2, 5.
"Tsitretsitsi li. "
You can have hope.
Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15.
"There is going to be a resurrection. "​ Acts 24:15.
Mawu do ŋugbe be yeava fɔ ame gbogbo siwo ku la ɖe tsitre, eye edi vevie be yeafɔ wo hã. Hiob 14:14, 15, etenuŋɔŋlɔ.
God promises to bring back to life countless people who have died, and he yearns to do so. ​ Job 14:14, 15, footnote.
Ne Dziwòla Aɖe Ku
When a Parent Dies
KUXIA
THE CHALLENGE
Esi Dami xɔ ƒe ade la, ʋukametetedɔ wu fofoa.
Dami was six years old when an aneurysm claimed the life of her dad.
Derrick xɔ ƒe asieke esi dzidɔ wu fofoa.
Derrick was nine when his father died of heart disease.
Esi azigolomekansa ɖe fu na Jeannie dada wu ƒe ɖeka la, eku esi Jeannie xɔ ƒe adre pɛ ko.
Jeannie was seven when her mom passed away after a year-long battle with ovarian cancer.
Ðevi etɔ̃ siawo metsi hafi ame vevi aɖe ku na wo o.
All too soon, these three young people were confronted with the death of a loved one.
Ðe nu sia tɔgbi dzɔ ɖe dziwò kpɔa?
Have you had a similar experience?
Ne nenemae la, ke nyati sia ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe wò ame vevia ƒe ku nu.
If so, this article can help you come to terms with your loss.
Gbã la, na míade ŋugble le nu siwo wòle be míanya tso nuxaxa ŋu la ŋu.
First, though, consider a few facts about grieving.
NU SI WÒLE BE NÀNYA
WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW
Ale si amewo xaa nui la le vovovo.
There are many ways to grieve.
Esia fia be ame sia ame kple ale si wòxaa nui ne ku dzɔ ɖe edzi.
This means that the way you express your sorrow might differ from the way others do so.
Agbalẽ aɖe (Helping Teens Cope With Death) gblɔ be: "Mɔ ɖeka aɖe koŋ meli si dzi míetona nɔa te ɖe míaƒe ame aɖe ƒe ku nu o. "
"Coping with a death does not follow a simple pattern or set of rules, " says the book Helping Teens Cope With Death.
Nu vevitɔ si nàwɔ koe nye be mègatsi wò nuxaxa nu madzemadzee o.
The important thing is that you do not unduly suppress your grief.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabena . . .
Because . . .
Ame ɖokui dzi zizi be woagaxa nu o ate ŋu agblẽ nu.
Suppressing grief can be harmful.
Jeannie si ŋu nya míegblɔ le gɔmedzedzea me gblɔ be: "Mesusu be ele be manɔ te sesĩe le nɔvinyenyɔnuvia ta, eya ta mezi nye nuxaxawo dzi.
Jeannie, mentioned at the outset, says: "I thought I had to be strong for my little sister, so I buried my emotions.
Va se ɖe fifia gɔ̃ hã, megazia nye vevesesewo dzi kokoko, gake esia menyo o. "
Even today, I tend to suppress painful feelings, and that’s not healthy. "
Eŋunyalawo da asi ɖe eƒe nyaa dzi.
Experts would agree.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Grieving Teen) gblɔ be: "Ne ame gbe nuƒoƒo tso nu si le fu ɖem nɛ ŋu la mefia be maƒo nu tso eŋu gbeɖe o.
"Feelings denied or bottled up won’t stay bottled up forever, " says the book The Grieving Teen.
[Seselelãme] mawo atrɔ ava le ɣeyiɣi si me mèle mɔ kpɔm nɛ o eye ana nàva nɔ dziku dom kabakaba alo anɔ dɔ lém. "
"They will return when you least expect [them to] in the form of emotional flare-ups or physical ailments. "
Nuxaxa dzi zizi ate ŋu ana ame nava nɔ aha geɖe nom alo anɔ atike muamewo zãm atsɔ anɔ vevesesea nu tsim.
Suppressed grief can also lead to the abuse of alcohol or drugs, all done in an effort to numb the pain.
Nuxaxa ate ŋu ana ame natɔtɔ.
Grieving may be accompanied by confusing emotions.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, amewo doa dziku ɖe ame si ku la ŋu be "egblẽ " yewo ɖi.
For example, some people feel anger at the person who died, feeling that the person "abandoned " them.
Ame bubuwo hã bua fɔ Mawu be ɖe wòle be wòaxe mɔ be amea nagaku o hafi.
Others blame God, thinking that he should have prevented the death.
Ame geɖe siwo xaa nu la bua fɔ wo ɖokuiwo le nu si wowɔ ɖe ame si kua ŋu alo nya si wogblɔ ɖe eŋu le esi fifia womagate ŋu awɔ naneke le eŋu o ta.
Many who grieve feel guilt for things they did or said to the person, since there is now no way to make amends.
Edze ƒãa be ate ŋu asesẽ be míase nuxaxa gɔme.
Clearly, grieving can be a complex process.
Aleke nàwɔ akpɔ gbɔdzɔe ahayi agbea dzi?
How can you get relief and be helped to move forward?
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ
WHAT YOU CAN DO
Ƒo nu tso eŋu na ame aɖe.
Talk to someone.
Ðewohĩ awɔ na wò be yeaɖe ye ɖokui ɖe aga le ɣeyiɣi sesẽ siawo me.
You might be inclined to isolate yourself during this difficult time.
Gake ne ègblɔ wò dzimenyawo na wò ƒometɔ alo xɔ̃wò aɖe la, ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe wò nuxaxawo nu be woagawu tsɔtsɔ na wò o.
But pouring out your feelings to a family member or a friend will help you deal with your emotions and keep this tragedy from overwhelming you.
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Lododowo 18:24.
Bible principle: Proverbs 18:24.
Ŋlɔ wo ɖi.
Keep a journal.
Ŋlɔ nu tso dziwòla si ku la ŋu.
Write about the parent you lost.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nu kawoe dzɔa dzi na wò tso eŋu si dzi nèɖoa ŋkui?
For example, what is your most cherished memory of that person?
Ŋlɔ nu nyui mawo ɖi.
Write about his or her commendable qualities.
Eƒe nɔnɔme nyui mawo dometɔ kae nàdi be yeasrɔ̃ le wò agbe me?
Which ones would you like to imitate in your life?
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne susu manyomanyowo le fu ɖem na wò, abe nya manyomanyo aɖe si nègblɔ ɖe dziwòlaa ŋu hafi wòku ene la, ŋlɔ wò seselelãmewo ɖi eye nàŋlɔ nu si ta nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me nenema hã ɖi.
If you are plagued with negative thoughts for example, if you cannot stop thinking about something harsh you said to your parent before he or she passed away write down what you feel and why.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, àte ŋu aŋlɔ be "etena ɖe dzinye be le ŋkeke si do ŋgɔ na fofonye ƒe ku la, meʋli nya kplii. "
For example, "I feel guilty because I had an argument with my dad the day before he died. "
Azɔ kpɔe ɖa be asɔ be nànɔ fɔ bum ɖokuiwò hã?
Next, challenge the reasonableness of your guilt.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Grieving Teen) gblɔ be: "Màte ŋu abu fɔ ɖokuiwò be madzɔ gbeɖe be yeawɔ nane si tae yeaɖe kuku ɖo o.
"You cannot blame yourself for not knowing that there would never be an opportunity to apologize, " says The Grieving Teen.
Masɔ be woasusu gbeɖe be mele be ame nagblɔ nya aɖe alo awɔ nane si ta wòava ɖe kuku ɖo o. "
"To suggest that one must never say or do anything that might call for a future apology is simply not realistic. "
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Hiob 10:1.
Bible principle: Job 10:1.
Lé be na ɖokuiwò.
Take care of yourself.
Dɔ alɔ̃ nyuie, de kame edziedzi, ɖu nu si me amenyinu le.
Get adequate rest, sufficient exercise, and proper nutrition.
Ne medzro wò be yeaɖu nu o la, ke ɖu numeɖenu siwo me amenyinu le le ŋkeke bliboa me tsɔ wu be nàɖu nu kpekpe, wɔ esia va se ɖe esime wòadzro wò be yeaɖu nu.
If you do not feel like eating, have a number of healthful snacks throughout the day instead of full meals at least until your appetite returns to normal.
Mègatsi wò nuxaxa nu kple nuɖuɖu siwo me amenyinu mele o alo anɔ aha muame nom o, ɖeko wòagblẽ nyaa ɖe edzi.
Do not soothe your grief with junk food or alcohol; they will only make things worse.
Do gbe ɖa na Mawu.
Talk to God in prayer.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dro wò agba ɖe Yehowa dzi, ekema alé wò ɖe te. "
The Bible says: "Throw your burden on Jehovah, and he will sustain you. "
(Psalmo 55:22) Menye ɖeko gbedodoɖa nana ame ƒe susu dzea akɔ anyi ko o.
(Psalm 55:22) Prayer is not merely an emotional crutch.
Enye nuƒoƒo kple Mawu, "ame si faa akɔ na mí le míaƒe tetekpɔwo katã me. " 2 Korintotɔwo 1:3, 4.
It is real communication with the God who "comforts us in all our trials. " 2 Corinthians 1:3, 4.
Mɔ aɖe si dzi Mawu tona faa akɔ na ame siwo le nu xam lae nye to eƒe Nya, Biblia la dzi.
One way that God comforts those who mourn is through his Word, the Bible.
Ðe manyo be nàdzro nu si Biblia fia tso nɔnɔme si me ame kukuwo le kple tsitretsitsimɔkpɔkpɔa ŋu me oa ?
Why not examine what it teaches about the true condition of those who have died and the hope of a resurrection?
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Psalmo 94:19.
Bible principle: Psalm 94:19.
MAWUNYAKPUKPUI VEVI AÐEWO
KEY SCRIPTURES
"Xɔlɔ̃ aɖewo kuna ɖe ame ŋu wu ame nɔvi gɔ̃ hã. "
"There is a friend who sticks closer than a brother. "
Lododowo 18:24.
Proverbs 18:24.
"Maƒo nu le nye vevesese helĩhelĩ la ta! "
"I will speak out in my bitter distress! "
Hiob 10:1.
"Ne metsi dzodzodzoe akpa la, [Mawu faa] akɔ nam henana mekpɔa gbɔdzɔe. "
"When anxieties overwhelmed me, you [God] comforted and soothed me. "
Psalmo 94:19.
Psalm 94:19.
ÀTE ŊU AKPE ÐE AME BUBUWO ŊU
YOU CAN HELP OTHERS
"Yehowa Ðasefowoe nye kple nye ƒomea míenye, eye ƒe ʋɛ aɖewoe nye esi va yi la, kansa wu ɖevi eve aɖewo siwo míenya la dada.
"My family and I are Jehovah’s Witnesses. A few years ago, two children we know lost their mother to cancer.
Ðeka xɔ ƒe ade eye evelia xɔ ƒe etɔ̃, ƒe siawoe nye kple nɔvinyenyɔnu míexɔ esi mía fofo ku anɔ ƒe 17 enye esia.
They were 6 and 3 years old virtually the same ages my sister and I were when our dad died nearly 17 years earlier.
"Nye kple nɔnye, nɔvinyenyɔnuvi kpakple nɔvinyeŋutsu míeɖoe be míakpe ɖe ƒome sia ŋu.
"My mom, my younger sister, my brother, and I decided to make ourselves available to this family.
Míekpea wo vaa míaƒe aƒe me.
We would invite them over.
Míeɖea mɔ na wo be woagblɔ nya sia nya si le wo si.
We would let them talk when they needed to.
Míenɔa wo gbɔ wɔa nu sia nu si wodi be míawɔ na yewo la na wo, ne ahiã be míafe kpli wo, aɖo to wo alo axlɔ̃ nu wo gɔ̃ hã.
We would spend time with them and be whatever they needed us to be at the moment, whether it was someone to play with them or listen to them or give them advice.
"Ame dzila ƒe ku vena ale gbegbe be womate ŋu aŋlɔe be gbeɖe o.
"Losing a parent is devastating, and you never get over it.
Anɔ eme be wò vevesesewo aɖiɖi ya, gake màte ŋu aŋlɔe be o.
It gets easier, but you are constantly reminded of your loss.
Menya nuxaxa si gbegbe me tom ƒome ma le, eye esia tae wòdzɔ dzi nam be míaƒe ƒomea te ŋu kpe ɖe wo ŋu.
I knew what this grieving family was going through, and that’s one reason why I’m glad our family reached out to them.
Esia kpe ɖe mía ŋu be míete ŋu te ɖe ƒome ma ŋu eye míawo ŋutɔwo hã míeva nɔ kplikplikpli wu. "
It helped us to draw closer to them and to each other as well. "
Dami.
Dami.
Ne Ðeviwo Le Nu Xam Le Wo Dzila Ƒe Ku Ta
When Children Grieve
Ðe nèle nu xam le wò ƒometɔ aɖe ƒe ku ta?
Are you grieving over the death of a family member?
Ne nenemae la, nu kae akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe enu?
If so, how can you cope with your loss?
De ŋugble tso ale si Biblia kpe ɖe sɔhɛ etɔ̃ aɖewo ŋu wote ŋu nɔ te ɖe kuxi ma nu la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider how the Bible helped three young people deal with this very challenge.
NU SI ME DAMI TO
DAMI’S STORY
Dami lé fofoa ƒe foto ɖe asi
Dami holds a picture of her father
Dami
Dami
Gbã la, ɖeko wòwɔ abe ta koe nɔ papa ɖum ene.
At first, it seemed to be a simple headache.
Gake esi papa ƒe vevesesea dzi ɖe edzi la, nɔnye yɔ dɔnɔkɔʋu.
But when my dad’s pain got worse, my mom called an ambulance.
Megaɖoa ŋku ale si dɔnɔgbɔkpɔlawo kɔe dzoe la dzi kokoko.
I still remember the paramedics taking him away.
Nyemenya be emae anye zi mamlɛtɔ si makpɔe o.
Little did I know that it was the last time I would see him alive.
Le ŋkeke etɔ̃ megbe la, ʋukametetedɔ wu papa.
Three days later, my dad died as a result of an aneurysm.
Ƒe ade koe mexɔ ɣemaɣi.
I was just six years old.
Megabua fɔ ɖokuinye le papa ƒe ku ta.
For years, I blamed myself for my dad’s death.
Megaɖoa ŋku ale si dɔnɔgbɔkpɔlawo kɔe dzoe la dzi eye mebiaa ɖokuinye be: ‘Nu ka tae metɔ ɖi ko nɔ wo kpɔm?
In my mind I would replay that scene of the paramedics taking him away, and I would ask myself: ‘Why did I just stand there?
Nu ka tae nyemewɔ naneke tso eŋu o?’
Why didn’t I do something?’
Ne mekpɔ ame tsitsi siwo nye dɔnɔwo la, mesusuna be, ‘Nu ka tae woawo le agbe eye papa ya ku?’
I would look at older ones with health problems and wonder, ‘Why are they alive and my dad isn’t?’
Esi ɣeyiɣiawo va nɔ yiyim la, nɔnye kpe ɖe ŋunye mete ŋu ƒo nu tso nye seselelãmewo ŋu.
In time, my mom helped me to talk about my emotions.
Esi míenye Yehowa Ðasefowo taa, míaƒe hamea me tɔwo na kpekpeɖeŋu geɖe mí.
And as Jehovah’s Witnesses, we had wonderful support from the congregation.
Ame aɖewo susuna be ne afɔku aɖe dzɔ la, woate ŋu axa nu sẽe ko wòafa na ame, gake menɔ alea le gonyeme o.
Some people think that you can grieve right after a tragedy and then be over it, but that wasn’t the case with me.
Nyemexa nu boo o va se ɖe nye ƒewuiwo me hafi.
I didn’t really grieve until I was in my early teens.
Aɖaŋu si maɖo na sɔhɛ siwo dzila aɖe ku na ye nye be, "Gblɔ nu si me tom nèle la na ame aɖe.
My advice to young people who have lost a parent in death is, "Talk to someone about what you’re going through.
Ne ègblɔ nu siwo me tom nèle na ame aɖe kaba la, ate ŋu aɖe vi na wò. "
It may be that the sooner you let your emotions out, the healthier it will be for you. "
Nyateƒee, esesẽ nam be fofonye mele agbe hafi meɖo ɣeyiɣi vevi siawo me le nye agbe me o.
Yes, it’s hard to go through milestones in my life and know that my dad isn’t here with me.

Gake ŋugbe si Biblia do le Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4 si gblɔ be eteƒe madidi o Mawu "atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le [míaƒe] ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o " la faa akɔ nam.

But I find comfort in the Bible’s promise at Revelation 21:4, which says that soon God "will wipe out every tear from [our] eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore. "
NU SI ME DERRICK TO
DERRICK’S STORY
Derrick lé fofoa ƒe foto ɖe asi
Derrick holds a picture of his father
Derrick
Derrick
Nu vevi aɖewo siwo dzi meɖoa ŋkui le fofonye ŋue nye ale si nye kplii míedea tɔƒo kple ale si míeva tsia towo dzi dɔna.
Some of the best memories I have are of fishing with my dad and camping with him in the mountains.
Toawo dzi nɔnɔ doa dzidzɔ nɛ.
He loved the mountains.
Dzidɔ nɔ fu ɖem na fofonye; meɖo ŋku edzi be meva srãe kpɔ le kɔdzi zi ɖeka eve aɖewo le nye ɖevime.
My dad had heart problems for some time; I remember visiting him in the hospital once or twice in my early childhood.
Gake nyemenya be eƒe dɔa sesẽ nenema gbegbe o.
But I didn’t understand the severity of his illness.
Dzidɔa wu fofonye esi mexɔ ƒe asieke.
My dad died of heart disease when I was nine years old.
Esi wòku la, avifafa dzi koe menɔ.
After he died, I cried and cried.
Ðeko helehele tsi akɔ nam eye nyemedi be maƒo nu na ame aɖeke o.
I felt as if I were suffocating, and I didn’t want to talk to anyone.
Nyemese le ɖokuinye me alea kpɔ o eye naneke wɔwɔ megadzroam o.
I hadn’t felt this bad in my whole life, and I didn’t feel like doing anything anymore.
Sɔhɛwo ƒe habɔbɔ si me menɔ le sɔleme la me tɔwo fa akɔ nam le gɔmedzedzea me gake wova dzudzɔ.
The church youth group I was part of showed interest in me initially, but it quickly faded.
Nya siwo wogblɔna ƒe ɖewoe nye, "Fofowò ƒe ɣeyiɣie de " alo "Mawue yɔe " alo "Fifia ele dziƒo. "
People there would say things like this, "It was your father’s time " or "God called him " or "He’s in heaven now. "
Nya mawo mena nye dzi dze eme o, gake nyemenya naneke tso nu si Biblia fia tso nya mawo ŋu o.
Those answers never really satisfied me, but I had no knowledge of what the Bible really teaches about those things.
Emegbe Yehowa Ðasefowo va nɔ Biblia srɔ̃m kple nɔnye eye nye kple fonye hã míeva te nua sɔsrɔ̃.
Then my mom started studying the Bible with Jehovah’s Witnesses, and later my brother and I joined her.
Míesrɔ̃ nu tso nɔnɔme si me ame kukuwo le kple tsitretsitsi ƒe ŋugbe si Mawu do si faa akɔ na ame la ŋu.
We learned about the condition of the dead as well as God’s comforting promise of a resurrection.
(Yohanes 5:28, 29) Gake mawunyakpukpui si kpe ɖe ŋunye wue nye Yesaya 41:10, afi si Mawu gblɔ le be: "Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò.
(John 5:28, 29) But the scripture that helped me the most was Isaiah 41:10, where God says: "Do not be afraid, for I am with you.
Mègatsi dzi o, elabena nyee nye wò Mawu.
Do not be anxious, for I am your God.
Mado ŋusẽ wò; makpe ɖe ŋuwò. "
I will fortify you, yes, I will help you. "
Enyanya be Yehowa li kplim la fa akɔ nam ŋutɔ ɣemaɣi eye egafaa akɔ nam fifia.
Knowing that Jehovah was with me was a tremendous comfort during my grieving, and it still is.
NU SI ME JEANNIE TO
JEANNIE’S STORY
Jeannie lé nɔa ƒe foto ɖe asi
Jeannie holds a picture of her mother
Jeannie
Jeannie
Kansa wu nɔnye esi mexɔ ƒe adre.
When I was seven years old, my mom died of cancer.
Ðeko wònɔ abe drɔ̃e kum menɔ gbe ma gbe ene.
That whole day seemed surreal.
Meɖo ŋku edzi be eku le aƒe me eye tɔgbuinye kple mamanye nɔ anyi hafi wòku.
I recall that she died at home and that my grandparents were there.
Eye ame sia ame nɔ anyi kpoo.
I remember that everyone was calm.
Meɖo ŋku edzi hã be koklozi tɔtɔe míeɖu fiẽ ma.
I remember that we had scrambled eggs for dinner.
Mese le ɖokuinye me be evɔ nam.
I felt as if my whole life were turning upside down in slow motion.
Mesusui ɣemaɣi kple ƒe aɖewo megbe be, ele be manɔ te sesĩe le nɔvinyenyɔnuvia ta.
At the time and for years after that I thought I had to be strong for my little sister, so I buried my emotions.
Eya ta nyemekɔa nu le nye seselelãmewo dzi o.
Even today, I tend to suppress painful feelings, and that’s not healthy.
Meɖo ŋku ale si Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hame si le míaƒe nutoa me ɖee fia be yewolɔ̃ mí eye wokpe ɖe mía ŋu la dzi.
I remember the love and support we had from the local congregation of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Togbɔ be míedze kpekpeawo dede le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me medidi o hã, mía nɔvi siwo le hamea me kpe ɖe mía ŋu abe ɖe wodze si mí ƒe gbogbowo ene.
Even though we had just started attending meetings at the Kingdom Hall, fellow believers rallied around us as if we had been family for years.
Papa meɖa fiẽnu o hena ƒe ɖeka sɔŋ elabena ame aɖe tsɔa nuɖuɖu vanɛ na mí fiẽ sia fiẽ.
I don’t think my dad had to cook dinner for an entire year because it was always waiting by the front door.
Mawunyakpukpui aɖe si dzi meɖoa ŋkui ye nye Psalmo 25:16, 17.
One scripture that stands out to me is Psalm 25:16, 17.
Hakpalaa ƒo koko na Mawu le afi ma be: "Trɔ ɖe ŋunye, ne nàve nunye, elabena metsi akogo, eye metsi asi.
There the psalmist implored God: "Turn your face to me and show me favor, for I am alone and helpless.
Nye dzimexaxawo dzi ɖe edzi; ɖem tso nye xaxawo me. "
The distresses of my heart have multiplied; free me from my anguish. "
Efaa akɔ nam be manyae be ne èlé blanui la, ame aɖe li akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
It is comforting for me to know that you are never really alone when you are sad.
Mawu akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
God is there for you.
Biblia ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu wɔe be nyemena ta o eye mena nye susu le nu nyuiwo abe tsitretsitsi mɔkpɔkpɔ si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe si faa akɔ na ame ene la ŋu.
With help from the Bible, I have been able to move forward with my life and focus on positive things, such as the Bible’s comforting promise of a resurrection.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ le asinye be magakpɔ nɔnye ake eye mava nya nu geɖe tso nɔnye si le lãmesẽ blibo me la ŋu le paradiso me le anyigba dzi.
I have hope of seeing my mother again and getting to know her in perfect health on a paradise earth.
2 Petro 3:13.
2 Peter 3:13.

Ne Viwò Bia Nya Wò Tso Ku Ŋu
When Your Child Asks About Death
KUXIA
THE CHALLENGE
Viwò si xɔ ƒe ade bia wò be: "Ta, wò hã ègbɔna kuku gea? "
Your six-year-old asks, "Are you going to die someday? "
Nyabiasea wɔ nuku na wò eye nèbia ɖokuiwò be: ‘Ðe vinyea tsi ase nya sia gɔmea?
Startled by his question, you wonder: ‘Is my child old enough to understand the answer?
Aleke maɖe nu me nɛ tso ku ŋu?’
How can I talk to him about death?’
NU SI WÒLE BE NÀNYA
WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW
Ðeviwo bua tame tso ku ŋu.
Children do think about death.
Ne wole fefem la, wo dometɔ aɖewo wɔa aye be yewoku gɔ̃ hã.
Some even play games in which someone pretends to die.
Eya ta mele be nàƒo asa na nuƒoƒo tso ku ŋu na viwòa o, eye ne ebia nya aɖe wò tso ku ŋu la, lɔ̃ faa nàɖe eme nɛ.
Therefore, death should not be considered a taboo subject, and you should welcome any questions your child may have about it.
Ne èƒoa nu tso ku ŋu na viwòa ɣeaɖewoɣi la, awɔe be mavɔ̃ agbɔ eme ne miaƒe ame vevi aɖe ku o.
By occasionally talking openly about death, you help your child learn how to cope with the loss of a loved one.
Nuƒoƒo tso ku ŋu mana viwò navɔ̃ agbɔ eme o.
Talking about death will not cause your child to have morbid thoughts.
Ke boŋ aɖe eƒe vɔvɔ̃a dzi akpɔtɔ.
Rather, it will help him alleviate fears.
Ke hã ehiã be nàɖɔ eƒe susu ɖo le nanewo gome.
However, you may need to correct some misunderstandings.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, numekula aɖewo gblɔna be ɖevi siwo mekpɔ xɔ ƒe ade haɖe o la dometɔ geɖe bunɛ be ame ate ŋu aku agafɔ enumake.
For example, some experts say that many children under the age of six do not view death as final.
Ne ɖeviwo le fefem la, wo dometɔ aɖewo kua ayeku, eye kaka nàkpɔ la, woawoe nye ema gafɔ.
In their games, a child will be "dead " one moment and "alive " the next.
Gake ne ɖeviawo va tsi vie wu la, wova nɔa tame bum tso ku ŋu vevie, esiae wɔnɛ be wonɔa nya geɖewo biam, wotsia dzi eye wovɔ̃na gɔ̃ hã, vevietɔ ne woƒe ame vevi aɖe ku.
When they get a little older, however, children begin to grasp the seriousness of death a fact that may cause them to have questions, concerns, or even fears, especially if a loved one has died.
Eya ta ele vevie be miadzro nu me tso ku ŋu kpli wo.
Therefore, it is vital that you discuss the subject.
Susuŋutinunyala Marion Haza gblɔ be: "Ne viwòa se le eɖokui me be mèlɔ̃na ɖoa dze tso ku ŋu na ye o la, atsi dzi vevie ne ele tame bum tso ku ŋu. "
Mental-health expert Marion Haza points out: "A child will develop anxieties related to death if he feels that he is not allowed to talk about this subject at home. "
Mehiã be nàtsi dzi fũu ɖe nya si nàgblɔ nɛ ŋuti o.
You need not worry excessively about what to say.
Le numekuku aɖe nu la, nu si ko ɖeviwo "dinae nye be woagblɔ nyateƒea na yewo tufafatɔe. "
According to one study, children just want to "hear the truth expressed in kind words. "
Nyae be ɖeviwo mebiaa nya ne womesu te na ŋuɖoɖoa sese o.
Be assured that a child will usually not ask a question unless he is ready to hear the answer.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ
WHAT YOU CAN DO
Wɔ mɔnukpɔkpɔ siwo aʋu ɖi ŋu dɔ nàƒo nu tso ku ŋu nɛ.
Take advantage of opportunities to talk about death.
Ne viwòa kpɔ xevi kuku aɖe le mɔ to alo miaƒe aƒemelã aɖe ku la, àte ŋu abia nya bɔbɔe aɖewoe siwo ana wòagblɔ eƒe susu.
If your child sees a dead bird on the side of the road or if a beloved pet dies, use simple questions to encourage him to talk.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, àte ŋu abiae be: "Ðe lã kukua le fu kpema?
For example, you could ask: "Does a dead animal suffer?
Ðe vuvɔ le ewɔma?
Is it cold or hungry?
Ðe dɔ le ewuma? Aleke nàwɔ anya be ame alo lã aɖe ku? "
How do you know that an animal or a person is dead? "
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Nyagblɔla 3:1, 7.
Bible principle: Ecclesiastes 3:1, 7.
Mègaɣla nyateƒea ɖee o.
Do not hide the truth.
Ne miaƒe ame nyanyɛ alo ƒometɔ aɖe ku la, mègade ba mo na nyaa agblɔ be, "Eyi nugbe " o.
When an acquaintance or a relative has died, avoid using confusing euphemisms such as "He has gone away. "
Viwòa asusui vodadatɔe be ame si ku la agatrɔ agbɔ kpuie.
Your child might wrongly conclude that the deceased will soon return home.
Ke boŋ zã nya siwo gɔme sese le bɔbɔe nàtsɔ aɖe nu me nɛ.
Instead, use simple and direct words.
Àte ŋu agblɔ nɛ be: "Esi mama kua, eƒe ŋutilã megale dɔ wɔm o.
For example, you might say: "When Grandma died, her body stopped working.
Mímagate ŋu aɖo dze kplii o, gake míate ŋu anɔ ŋku ɖom edzi. "
We can’t talk to her, but we will never forget her. "
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Efesotɔwo 4:25.
Bible principle: Ephesians 4:25.
Esi ɖeviwo susunɛ be ne wole nu ƒom tso ku ŋu la ɖe wokuna ta la, ka ɖe edzi nɛ be naneke mele ewɔ ge o
Since a young child might think that death is contagious, assure him that he is safe
Ka ɖe edzi nɛ be menye eƒe vodadae o.
Reassure your child.
Ate ŋu asusui be yee wɔ nane alo yee susu nane tae amea ku.
He might think that his actions or thoughts caused someone’s death.
Esi nàgblɔ ko be menye egbɔ wòtso be amea ku o teƒe la, àte ŋu abiae be: "Nu kae na nèsusui be wò vodadae? "
Instead of just saying that he is not responsible for what happened, you could ask, "What makes you think that it is your fault? "
Ðo to nyuie nàse eƒe nyawo, eye mègada eƒe nyawo ɖe anyi o.
Listen carefully, without belittling his feelings.
Esi ɖeviwo susunɛ be ne wole nu ƒom tso ku ŋu la ɖe wokuna ta la, ka ɖe edzi nɛ be naneke mele ewɔ ge o.
Also, since a young child might think that death is contagious, assure him that he is safe.
Na viwòa nagblɔ eƒe susu.
Draw out your child.
Miɖo dze tso miaƒe ame vevi siwo ku, siwo dometɔ aɖewo nye miaƒe ƒometɔ siwo viwòa mekpɔ kpɔ o, la ŋu.
Talk freely about loved ones who have died, including relatives whom your child has never met.
Àte ŋu agblɔ nu nyui siwo mia tasi, nyrui, mama alo tɔgbui aɖe wɔ kpɔ la nɛ, eye miagblɔ nu ɖikokoe aɖe si amea wɔ kpɔ hã nɛ.
You might evoke fond memories of an aunt, an uncle, or a grandparent and relate amusing anecdotes.
Ne mieƒoa nu tso ame siawo tɔgbi ŋu la, akpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòakpɔe be mele be yeaƒo asa na wo ŋu bubu alo nuƒoƒo tso wo ŋu o.
When you openly discuss such people, you help your child understand that he need not avoid talking or thinking about them.
Gake mègazi viwòa dzi be wòaƒo nu kokoko o.
At the same time, do not force your child to talk.
Àte ŋu ado nyaa ɖa ɣebubuɣi si nèkpɔ be asɔ wu.
You can always broach the subject later, when you feel the time is right.
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Lododowo 20:5.
Bible principle: Proverbs 20:5.
Agbalẽ si nye Srɔ̃ Nu tso Nufiala Gã la Gbɔ ƒe ta 34 kple 35 ate ŋu akpe ɖe viwòwo ŋu woasrɔ̃ nu tso nya si Biblia gblɔ tso ku ŋu la ŋu.
Chapters 34 and 35 of the book Learn From the Great Teacher can help your children learn what the Bible teaches about death.

MAWUNYAKPUKPUI VEVI AÐEWO
KEY SCRIPTURES
"Ðoɖoeziɣi li, eye nuƒoɣi li. "
"There is . . . a time to be silent and a time to speak. "
Nyagblɔla 3:1, 7.
Ecclesiastes 3:1, 7.
"Ame sia ame neto nyateƒe. "
"Each one of you speak truth. "
Efesotɔwo 4:25.
Ephesians 4:25.
"Ŋutsu ƒe tameɖoɖo ɖe dzi me le abe tɔ goglo ene, ke nugɔmesela dunɛ. "
"The thoughts of a man’s heart are like deep waters, but the discerning man draws them out. "
Lododowo 20:5.
Proverbs 20:5.
NYA VEVI SIWO NÀTE ŊU AGBLƆ NƐ
IMPORTANT POINTS TO CONVEY
Ne miaƒe ame vevi aɖe ku la, àte ŋu akpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòase nya siwo gbɔna la gɔme nyuie ale be vɔvɔ̃ nagaɖoe agbɔ eme o:
If a loved one has died, you can help your child overcome inordinate fears about death by making sure he understands the following:
Ka ɖe edzi nɛ be eya hã maku o.
He is not going to die.
Gblɔ nɛ be ne nane dzɔ ɖe ye dzi la, matsi asi o, yeƒe ƒometɔwo li akpe ɖe eŋu.
If something happens to you, he will not be abandoned; relatives will look after him.
Ne ame ku la, megale fu kpem o.
Once dead, a person is no longer suffering.
Gblɔ nɛ be yewoanɔ ŋku ɖom ame si ku la dzi.
The deceased person will not be forgotten.
Àte ŋu agblɔ be: "Mímagate ŋu akpɔ mama o, gake àte ŋu anɔ ŋku ɖom edzi. "
You might say, "You cannot see Grandma anymore, but you can keep memories of her in your heart. "
Mègasusu be ne meɖe nya sia me na viwòa o lae ana wòaɖe dzi ɖi o.
Remember, saying nothing to your child will not reduce his anxiety.
Ðe wòana wòava nɔ nu tramatramawo susum boŋ.
On the contrary, it may only serve to give his imagination free rein.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ Si Li Na Kukuawo Aleke Nàwɔ Aka Ðe Edzi?
Hope for the Dead​ How Can You Be Sure?
Ame siwo mele ɖeke me nyam o lae xɔnɛ sena be ame kukuwo agava nɔ agbe akea?
Is it naive to think that the dead will live again?
Apostolo Paulo mesusui nenema o.
The apostle Paul did not think so.
Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ ʋãe wòŋlɔ bena: "Ne agbe sia ɖeɖe ko mee míekpɔ mɔ na Kristo le la, ekema míaƒe nue wɔ nublanui wu.
He wrote under inspiration: "If in this life only we have hoped in Christ, we are to be pitied more than anyone.
Gake azɔ wofɔ Kristo ɖe tsitre tso ame kukuwo dome, eye wònye ame siwo dɔ alɔ̃ le ku me la ƒe kutsetse gbãtɔ. " (1 Korintotɔwo 15:19, 20) Paulo ka ɖe tsitretsitsia dzi bliboe.
But now Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep in death. " (1 Corinthians 15:19, 20) Paul saw the resurrection as a certainty.
Woɖo kpe tsitretsitsia ƒe nyateƒenyenye dzi esi wofɔ Yesu ŋutɔ ɖe tsitre.
It was, in effect, guaranteed by the resurrection of Jesus himself.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:31) Ema tae Paulo yɔ Yesu be, "kutsetse gbãtɔ " ɖo, elabena eyae nye ame gbãtɔ si wofɔ ɖe tsitre hena agbe tegbee nɔnɔ.
(Acts 17:31) That is why Paul called Jesus "the firstfruits "​ he was the first one raised to eternal life.
Ne Yesue nye ame gbãtɔ si wofɔ alea la, ke efia be woafɔ ame bubuwo hã nenema ke.
If Jesus was first, then logically there would be others.
Nyɔnu aɖe ʋu Biblia ɖe asi hele etsɔme kpɔm ɖaa kakaɖedzitɔe
A woman holds her Bible open and confidently gazes ahead
Hiob gblɔ na Mawu be: ‘Wò asinudɔwɔwɔ ƒe nu adzro wò vevie.’ Hiob 14:14, 15
Job said to God: "You will long for the work of your hands. "​ Job 14:14, 15
Susu bubu si tae nàte ŋu aka ɖe tsitretsitsimɔkpɔkpɔa dzie nye esi: Yehowa nye nyateƒe Mawu.
Here is another reason you can be sure of the resurrection hope. Jehovah is the God of truth.
"Mawu . . . mate ŋu aka aʋatso o. "
"God . . . cannot lie. "
(Tito 1:2) Yehowa meka aʋatso kpɔ o, eye maka aʋatso gbeɖe o.
(Titus 1:2) Jehovah has never lied, and he never will.
Ðe wòado ŋugbe be yeafɔ ame siwo ku la ɖe tsitre, eye kura gɔ̃ hã wòaɖee afia be yeate ŋu afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre, evɔ mawɔ eƒe ŋugbedodoa dzi oa?
Would he hold out the resurrection hope, even demonstrating that he can fulfill it, and then turn his promises into lies?
Yehowa mate ŋu awɔ nu nenema gbeɖe o!
The very notion is absurd!
Nu ka tae Yehowa ɖoe be yeafɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre le etsɔme?
Why has Jehovah arranged for the future resurrection?
Eƒe lɔlɔ̃ tae.
Because of his love.
Hiob bia be: "Ne ame ku la, ɖe wòagagbɔ agbea? "
"If a man dies, can he live again? " asked Job.
Eya ŋutɔ ɖo eŋu be: ‘Àyɔm, eye matɔ na wò.
"You will call, and I will answer you.
Wò asinudɔwɔwɔ ƒe nu adzro wò vevie.’
You will long for the work of your hands. "
(Hiob 14:14, 15) Hiob ka ɖe edzi be ye Fofo lɔ̃ame si le dziƒo la adi vevie be yeafɔ ye ɖe tsitre.
(Job 14:14, 15) Job was convinced that his loving heavenly Father would yearn to resurrect him.
Ðe Mawu trɔa?
Has God changed?
Mawu ŋutɔ gblɔ be: "Nyee nye Yehowa; nyemetrɔna o. "
"I am Jehovah; I do not change. "
(Malaki 3:6) Egakpɔtɔ le Mawu dzrom vevie be yeana ame siwo ku la nagbɔ agbe eye woanɔ lãmesẽ kple dzidzɔ me.
(Malachi 3:6) God still longs to see the dead brought back to life healthy and happy.
Ðeko wòle abe ale si dzila lɔ̃ame ɖe sia ɖe si vi ku na la dina vevie be yeagakpɔ ye via ake la ene.
This is just as any loving parent would wish after losing a child in death.
Gake nu si to vovoe nye be, ŋusẽ le Mawu ya si be wòawɔ nu sia nu si wòdi. Psalmo 135:6.
The difference, of course, is that God has the power to do as he wishes.​ Psalm 135:6.
Ku nye kuxi sesẽ aɖe, gake egbɔkpɔnu si de blibo le Mawu si
Death is a terrible problem, but God has the perfect solution
Yehowa ana ŋusẽ Via be wòafɔ ame siwo ku la ɖe tsitre be wòahe dzidzɔ manyagblɔ vɛ na ƒometɔ siwo le woƒe ame veviwo ƒe ku fam.
Jehovah will empower his Son to bring unbounded joy to those who have mourned the loss of loved ones.
Gake aleke Yesu sena le eɖokui me le tsitretsitsia ŋu?
And how does Jesus feel about the resurrection?
Hafi Yesu nafɔ Lazaro ɖe tsitre la, ekpɔ veve si gbegbe sem Lazaro nɔvinyɔnuawo kple wo xɔlɔ̃wo le, eye eya ŋutɔ hã "fa avi. "
Before raising Lazarus to life, Jesus observed the anguish of Lazarus’ sisters and friends, and he "gave way to tears " himself.
(Yohanes 11:35) Ɣebubuɣi la, Yesu do go ahosi si tso Nain, si ƒe viŋutsu ɖekɛa ku.
(John 11:35) On another occasion, Jesus encountered the widow of Nain, who had lost her only son in death.
Esi Yesu kpɔ ahosia la, "eƒe nu wɔ nublanui nɛ, eye wògblɔ nɛ be: ‘Dzudzɔ avifafa.’
Jesus "was moved with pity for her, and he said to her: ‘Stop weeping.’
" Eye wòfɔ via ɖe tsitre enumake.
" Immediately he raised her son.
(Luka 7:13) Esia fia be amewo ƒe ku kple nuxaxa tena ɖe Yesu dzi vevie.
(Luke 7:13) So Jesus feels deeply about grief and death.
Eya ta dzidzɔ ka gbegbee nye esi wòanye na Yesu be yeana ame siwo le nu xam le xexea me godoo la ƒe nuxaxa nu nayi eye dzidzɔ nayɔ woƒe dziwo me!
How delighted he will be when he will turn sorrow into elation all over the world!
Ŋutsu aɖe wɔ atuu na vianyɔnuvi sue
A man embraces his little girl
Ðe ku do nuxaxa na wò kpɔa?
Have you been touched by grief?
Ðewohĩ awɔ na wò be ku nye kuxi si ŋu womate ŋu awɔ naneke le o.
You might feel that death is a problem that has no solution.
Gake egbɔkpɔnu li. Eyae nye be Mawu ato Via dzi agbɔ agbe ame siwo ku.
But there is a solution​ namely, the resurrection that God will carry out by means of his Son.
Ðo ŋku edzi be Mawu di be wò ŋutɔ nàkpɔ eteƒe.
Remember that God wants you to see that solution.
Edi be nànɔ afi ma awɔ atuu na wò ame veviwo.
He wants you to be there to embrace your loved ones again.
Kpɔe ɖa ko be wò kpli wo miewɔ ɖeka hele ɖoɖo wɔm ɖe etsɔme mavɔ ŋu, esime ame aɖeke magaku agblẽ nɔvia ɖi gbeɖe o!
Imagine planning together for an everlasting future, never again to say good-bye!
Lionel, si ŋu nya míegblɔ va yi la, gblɔ be: "Meva srɔ̃ nu tso tsitretsitsia ŋu mlɔeba.
Lionel, quoted earlier, reflects: "Eventually, I learned about the resurrection.
Le gɔmedzedzea me la, esesẽ nam be maka ɖe edzi, eye nyemexɔ ame si ƒo nu tso eŋu nam la dzi se o.
At first, it was hard to believe, and I did not trust the person who told me about it.
Gake nye ŋutɔ medii le Biblia me eye mekpɔe be nyateƒee!
But I checked it out in the Bible and found it was true!
Eya ta mele tsɔtsɔm nam o, medi be magakpɔ tɔgbuinye ake. "
I can hardly wait to see my grandfather again. "
Àdi be yeagasrɔ̃ nu geɖe tso nya sia ŋua?
Would you like to know more?
Adzɔ dzi na Yehowa Ðasefowo be yewoakpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔ nu si tae yewoka ɖe tsitretsitsia dzi nenema gbegbe ɖo la le wò ŋutɔ wò Biblia me.
Jehovah’s Witnesses would be delighted to show you in your own Bible why they are convinced of the future resurrection.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ Kae Li Na Kukuawo?
What Hope Is There for the Dead?
Nya nyui kae li ku ɖe ame kukuwo ŋu?
What is the good news about the dead?
Lazaro si wofɔ ɖe tsitre la nɔvinyɔnu Marta kple Maria xɔe atuu
The resurrected Lazarus is welcomed back by his sisters Martha and Mary
Esi Yesu va ɖo Betania, afi si te ɖe Yerusalem ŋu la, exɔlɔ̃ Lazaro ku xoxo ŋkeke enee nye ema.
When Jesus arrived at Bethany near Jerusalem, his friend Lazarus had been dead for four days.
Yesu kplɔ Marta kple Maria, siwo nye ame si ku la nɔvinyɔnuwo, ɖo yi afi si woɖi Lazaro ɖo.
Jesus went to the burial place with Martha and Mary, sisters of the deceased man.
Eteƒe medidi o, amewo va ƒo zi ɖe teƒea.
Soon, a crowd gathered.
Àte ŋu akpɔ ale si gbegbe dzi dzɔ Marta kple Maria esi Yesu fɔ Lazaro ɖe tsitre la le susu mea?​ Xlẽ Yohanes 11:21-24, 38-44.
Can you imagine the joy of Martha and Mary when Jesus raised Lazarus back to life?​ Read John 11:21-24, 38-44.
Marta nya nu tso nya nyui si ku ɖe kukuawo ŋu la ŋuti xoxo.
Martha was already aware of the good news about the dead.
Enyae be Yehowa afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre woagava nɔ agbe le anyigba dzi.​ Xlẽ Hiob 14:14, 15.
She knew that Jehovah will resurrect the dead to live on earth again.​ Read Job 14:14, 15.
Nɔnɔme ka mee ame kukuwo le?
What is the condition of the dead?
Adam wɔwɔ, kple eƒe ku emegbe
Adam’s creation, and later his death
Mawu gblɔ na Adam be: "Anyi nènye, eye anyi ke nàgatrɔ azu! " 1 MOSE 3:19.
God told Adam: "Dust you are and to dust you will return. "​ GENESIS 3:19.
Anyie wotsɔ mè amegbetɔwo.
Humans are made from dust.
(1 Mose 2:7; 3:19) Menye gbɔgbɔ siwo do ŋutilã woe míenye o.
(Genesis 2:7; 3:19) We are not spirits living in a body of flesh.
Anyigbadzinuwɔwɔwoe míenye, eya ta míaƒe akpa aɖeke meyia edzi nɔa agbe le míaƒe ku megbe o.
We are physical creatures, so no part of us survives death.
Ne míeku la, míaƒe susu dzudzɔa dɔwɔwɔ, eye míaƒe tamesusuwo nu yina.
When we die, our brain dies too, and our thoughts perish.
Eya ta esi wofɔ Lazaro ɖe tsitre la, megblɔ nya aɖeke si fia be ekpɔ nane teƒe le ku me o, elabena kukuawo meganyaa naneke o.​ Xlẽ Psalmo 146:4; Nyagblɔla 9:5, 6, 10.
Thus, Lazarus said nothing about his experience of death because the dead are unconscious.​ Read Psalm 146:4; Ecclesiastes 9:5, 6, 10.
Ðe Mawu wɔa funyafunya ame kukuwo le dzo mea?
Does God torment people with fire after death?
Esi Biblia gblɔ be kukuawo menya naneke o ta la, edze ƒãa be funyafunyawɔwɔ amewo le dzo mavɔ me nye alakpanufiafia si doa vlo Mawu.
Since the Bible shows that the dead are unconscious, hellfire is clearly a false teaching that slanders God.
Fuwɔwɔ amewo le dzo me nye ŋunyɔ nɛ.​ Xlẽ Yeremiya 7:31.
The very idea of tormenting people with fire disgusts him.​ Read Jeremiah 7:31.
Kpɔ video si nye Nɔnɔme Ka Mee Ame Kukuwo Le?
Watch the video What Is the Condition of the Dead?
Ðe kukuawo ate ŋu aƒo nu na mía?
Can the dead speak to us?
Ame kukuwo mate ŋu aƒo nu alo ase nu o.
The dead can neither speak nor hear.
(Psalmo 115:17) Gake mawudɔla vɔ̃ɖiwo li, eye woate ŋu aƒo nu na amewo ameflutɔe abe ame siwo ku lae le nu ƒom ene.
(Psalm 115:17) But some angels are wicked, and they may speak to people and pretend to be dead humans.
(2 Petro 2:4) Yehowa medina kura be míate kpɔ be míaƒo nu kple ame kukuwo o.​ Xlẽ 5 Mose 18:10, 11.
(2 Peter 2:4) Jehovah forbids trying to inquire of the dead.​ Read Deuteronomy 18:10, 11.
Ame kawoe woafɔ ɖe tsitre?
Who will return to life?
Ŋutsu aɖe si wofɔ ɖe tsitre le Paradisoa me le nu srɔ̃m tso Mawu ŋu.
A man who was resurrected back to life in Paradise learns about God.
Eye ŋutsua hã va le nu fiam ame bubu siwo wofɔ ɖe tsitre.
Then the man helps teach others who are resurrected.
Woafɔ ame kuku miliɔn geɖe siwo le yɔdowo me la ɖe tsitre woava nɔ agbe le anyigba dzi.
Many millions of people who are dead in the grave will return to life on earth.
Woafɔ ame siwo menya Mawu o eye wowɔ nu vlowo la dometɔ aɖewo gɔ̃ hã ɖe tsitre.​ Xlẽ Luka 23:43; Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15.
Even some who did not know God and who practiced bad things will be resurrected.​ Read Luke 23:43; Acts 24:15.
Mɔnukpɔkpɔ asu ame siwo woafɔ ɖe tsitre la si be woasrɔ̃ nu tso Mawu ŋuti nyateƒea ŋu ahaɖee afia be yewoxɔ Yesu dzi se to toɖoɖoe me.
Resurrected ones will be able to learn the truth about God and to exercise faith in Jesus by obeying him.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:11-13) Ame siwo woafɔ ɖe tsitre la dometɔ siwo awɔ nu nyui la anɔ agbe tegbee le anyigba dzi.​ Xlẽ Yohanes 5:28, 29.
(Revelation 20:11-13) Those who return to life and do good things will be able to enjoy life forever on earth.​ Read John 5:28, 29.
Nu kae tsitretsitsia fia mí tso Yehowa ŋu?
What does the resurrection tell us about Jehovah?
Ale si Mawu dɔ Via ɖa wòva tsɔ eƒe agbe na ɖe mía ta lae wɔe be woate ŋu afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre.
God made hope for the dead possible by sending his Son to die for us.
Eya ta tsitretsitsia nye Yehowa ƒe lɔlɔ̃ kple amenuveve ɖeɖe fia mí.
So the resurrection tells us about Jehovah’s love and undeserved kindness.
Ne wofɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre la, wo dometɔ kae nàdi vevie be yeakpɔ?​ Xlẽ Yohanes 3:16; Romatɔwo 6:23.
When the dead return to life, whom do you especially want to see?​ Read John 3:16; Romans 6:23.
NU SI AKPE ÐE AME SIWO LE NU XAM LA ŊU
The Best Help for Those Who Grieve
VEVE SI AME SENA NE EƑE AME VEVI AÐE KU LA NYE NU SI ŊU NUMEKULAWO LE NU ME KUM TSOE VEVIE LE ŊKEKE SIAWO ME.
THE PAIN OF LOSING A LOVED ONE IN DEATH HAS BEEN THE SUBJECT OF MUCH RESEARCH IN RECENT TIMES.
Ke hã, abe ale si míegblɔe va yi ene la, zi geɖe la, aɖaŋuɖola nyuitɔ ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo wɔa ɖeka kple esi dze le blemagbalẽ aɖe si nye Biblia, si ƒe nyawo gaɖea vi la me.
Yet, as demonstrated previously, the best expert advice often harmonizes with the ancient wisdom found in the Bible.
Esia gate gbe ɖe ale si Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo nu meyi na gbeɖe o la dzi.
This speaks well of the timelessness of the Bible’s guidance.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo gbogbo aɖewo siwo dzi míate ŋu aka ɖo la le Biblia me.
The Bible, however, contains more than dependable advice.
Aɖaŋu siwo wòɖo la, megale teƒe bubu aɖeke o eye woate ŋu afa akɔ na ame siwo le nu xam.
It provides information found nowhere else, which can bring immeasurable comfort to those who grieve.
Eka ɖe edzi na mí be míaƒe ame vevi siwo ku la, mele fu kpem o
Assurance that our dead loved ones are not suffering
Biblia gblɔ le Nyagblɔla 9:5 be: "Kukuawo meganya naneke kura o. "
"The dead know nothing, " says the Bible at Ecclesiastes 9:5.
Woƒe "tamesusuwo katã nu yina. "
Their "thoughts perish. "
(Psalmo 146:4) Esia sɔ kple nya si Biblia gblɔ be ku sɔ kple alɔ̃dɔdɔ la. Yohanes 11:11.
(Psalm 146:4) Consistent with this, the Bible likens death to peaceful sleep.​ John 11:11.
Mawu si lɔ̃a ame la dzixɔse si me sẽ nana ame kpɔa akɔfafa
A strong belief in a loving God brings comfort
Biblia gblɔ le Psalmo 34:15 be: "Yehowa ƒe ŋkuwo le ame dzɔdzɔewo ŋu, eye eƒe towo le woƒe ɣlidodowo ŋu. "
The Bible says at Psalm 34:15: "The eyes of Jehovah are on the righteous, and his ears listen to their cry for help. "
Gbedodoɖa mele abe ale si míagblɔ míaƒe dzimenya na ame aɖe be míaƒe dzi nadze eme alo aɖɔ míaƒe susu ɖo ko o.
Expressing our feelings in prayer to God is more than good therapy or a means of organizing our thoughts.
Ekpena ɖe mía ŋu be mí kple mía Wɔla, ame si ate ŋu azã eƒe ŋusẽ atsɔ afa akɔ na mí la, dome nɔna nyuie.
It actually helps us to establish a personal relationship with our Creator, who can use his power to comfort us.
Míele mɔ kpɔm na etsɔme nyui aɖe
A better future to look forward to
Bu ɣeyiɣi aɖe si ava le etsɔme esime woafɔ ame siwo le yɔdowo me la ɖe tsitre woagava nɔ agbe le anyigba dzi la ŋu kpɔ!
Imagine a time in the future when those in the grave will be brought back to life here on earth!
Biblia ƒo nu tso nya sia ŋu zi geɖe.
The Bible repeatedly speaks of such a time.

Biblia ɖɔ ale si nɔnɔmea anɔ le anyigba dzi ɣemaɣi be Mawu "atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le [míaƒe] ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o. " Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.

Describing what conditions on earth will then be like, the Bible states that God "will wipe out every tear from [our] eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore. "​ Revelation 21:3, 4.
Ame geɖe siwo xɔ Yehowa, Mawu si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe dzi se la va srɔ̃ ale si woanɔ te ɖe woƒe nuxaxa nu esi wova nya nu tso ale si woafɔ woƒe ame vevi siwo ku la ɖe tsitre ŋu eye wole mɔ kpɔm nɛ.
Many who believe in Jehovah, the God of the Bible, are significantly empowered to cope with grief by embracing the hope of seeing their dead loved ones again.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Ann si srɔ̃ xɔ ƒe 65 eye wòku la gblɔ be: "Biblia ka ɖe edzi nam be míaƒe ame vevi siwo ku la mele fu kpem o eye Mawu afɔ ame siwo katã le eƒe susu me la ɖe tsitre.
For example, Ann, who lost her husband of 65 years, says: "The Bible assures me that our dead loved ones are not suffering and that God will resurrect all who are in his memory.
Nu siawo vaa susu me nam ne mebu ame si ku nam la ŋu, eye esia wɔnɛ be metea ŋu nɔa te ɖe nu si dzɔ ɖe dzinye va yi la nu! "
These thoughts come to the surface whenever I think of my loss, and as a result, I am actually able to cope with the worst thing that has ever happened to me! "
Tiina si ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe le nyati siawo me gblɔ be: "Tso esime Timo kua, mekpɔe be Mawu lém ɖe te.
Tiina, mentioned earlier in this series of articles, says: "Since the day Timo died, I have felt God’s support.
Meka ɖe edzi bliboe be Yehowa kpe ɖe ŋunye le nɔnɔ sesẽ ma me.
I have strongly felt Jehovah’s helping hand in my time of distress.
Eye ŋugbe si Biblia do tso tsitretsitsia ŋu la nye nu ŋutɔŋutɔ nam.
And the Bible’s promise of a resurrection is very real to me.
Edoa ŋusẽm be manɔ mɔ kpɔm na gbe si gbe magakpɔ Timo ake. "
It strengthens me to keep going until the day when I will see Timo again. "
Eƒe nya siawo wɔ ɖeka kple ame miliɔn geɖe siwo ka ɖe Biblia dzi la tɔ.
These sentiments echo those of millions of people who are convinced of the Bible’s reliability.
Ne èsusu be nya siwo Biblia gblɔ menye nyateƒe o alo be wonye drɔ̃eƒenyawo la, ke ele be wò ŋutɔ nàku nu me akpɔe ɖa be ɖe aɖaŋu kple ŋugbe siwo wòdo la le eme hã.
Even if you feel that the Bible’s claims are unreal or just a dream, you owe it to yourself to investigate the evidence that its counsel and promises are sound.
Àva kpɔe be Bibliae nye agbalẽ nyuitɔ si akpe ɖe ame siwo le nu xam la ŋu.
You just might find the Bible to be the best help for those who grieve.

Ne Afɔku Aɖe Dzɔ Nu Siwo Míawɔ Be Míatsi Agbe
When Disaster Strikes​ Steps That Can Save Lives
"Ya sesẽ si do tso nane si wó sesĩe me la tutum xlã ɖi kloe.
"A deafening explosion nearly threw me to the floor.
Dzudzɔ to yatoƒe siwo le míaƒe ɔfis, si le dziƒoxɔ kɔkɔ aɖe dzi la me ge ɖe ɔfis la me eye wòlé dzo vlavlavla. "
Smoke came from the air vents, and our high-rise office erupted in flames. "​ Joshua.
Joshua. Anyigbaʋuʋu . . . ahom sesẽ ƒe tutu . . . ŋɔdzidonamelawo ƒe amedzidzedze . . . kple tudada amewo le sukukpodzi nye nudzɔdzɔ siwo ŋu nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽwo ƒoa nu tsoe zi geɖe.
Earthquake . . . hurricane . . . terrorist attack . . . school shooting. Those terms appear in the headlines too often.
Le nyateƒe me la, nuxexlẽ tso afɔkuwo ŋu to vovo sãa na afɔku me toto ŋutɔŋutɔ.
Of course, it is one thing to read about a disaster; it is another to live through one.
Nu kae wòle be nàwɔ hafi afɔku aɖe nadzɔ, le afɔkua dzɔɣi kple ne wòdzɔ vɔ megbe si awɔe be nàtsi agbe?
What can you do before, during, and after a disaster to improve the likelihood of your survival?
DZRA ÐO​ HAFI AFƆKU AÐE NADZƆ!
BEFORE​ PREPARE!
AFƆKU ate ŋu adzɔ ɖe ame sia ame dzi.
NO ONE is immune to disaster.
Eya ta dzadzraɖo do ŋgɔ le vevie be nàte ŋu atsi agbe.
Preparation is your most important key to survival.
Ke aleke nàdzra ɖoe?
But what does preparation involve?
Dzra ɖo le susu me.
Prepare mentally.
Lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be afɔkuwo dzɔna eye be afɔku ate ŋu adzɔ ɖe wò kple wò ame veviwo dzi.
Acknowledge the fact that disasters happen and that you and your loved ones are potentially at risk.
Ne afɔku aɖe dzɔ vɔ hafi nèbe yeadzra ɖo la, ke etsi megbe akpa.
It is too late to prepare after disaster strikes.
Ku nu me tso afɔku siwo ate ŋu adzɔ le mia gbɔ la ŋu.
Learn about disasters that can happen in your area.
Nya teƒe siwo amewo asi ayi ne afɔku dzɔ.
Know where shelters are.
Lé ŋku ɖe wò aƒea kple teƒe si wòle ŋu be wotui nyuie, eye wòate ŋu anɔ te ɖe afɔkua nu hã.
Consider whether the construction of your home and its location are as safe as possible.
Ðe nu siwo ate ŋu ana dzo nadze aƒe la ɖa.
Remove fire hazards.
De mɔ̃ siwo ana nànya be dzo dze aƒe la wò aƒea ŋu eye nànɔ kpe siwo le wo me la ɖɔlim edziedzi alo zi ɖeka ya teti ƒe sia ƒe.
Install smoke detectors, and change their batteries at least once a year, if not more often.
Dzra nuhiahiã veviwo ɖo.
Prepare emergency supplies.
Ate ŋu adzɔ be akaɖi, tsi kple ʋuwo manɔ anyi ne afɔku dzɔ o eye fonwo hã mawɔ dɔ o.
Power, water, phone, and transportation services can fail.
Ne ʋu le asiwò la, dze agbagba nàna ami nanɔ eme wòaɖo afã ya teti, eye nàna nuɖuɖu, tsi kple akplo si me nuhiahiã veviwo le nanɔ mia si le aƒea me ɣesiaɣi.
If you own a car, try to keep the fuel tank at least half full, and always have food, water, and an emergency kit in your home.​ See the box " Do You Have What You Need? "
Ƒome aɖe le nuhiahiã veviwo dzram ɖo
A family prepares emergency supplies
Dzadzraɖo do ŋgɔ le vevie be nàte ŋu atsi agbe
Preparation is your most important key to survival
Kaƒodzesiwo. Na xɔ̃wò siwo le kpuiƒe kple didiƒe siaa ƒe kaƒodzesiwo nanɔ asiwò.
Have access to the phone numbers of friends, both near and far.
Wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe ale si miasii ŋu eye minɔ eme dzrom.
Make and rehearse an escape plan.
Teƒe si tsɔ kpuie wu si miasi ato le miaƒe aƒea me nenɔ nyanya na mi, eye nàfia viwòwo nu si woawɔ ne afɔku aɖe dzɔ le woƒe suku.
Know the nearest exits in your building, as well as the emergency plan of your children’s school.
Afi si ƒomea akpe ta le ne afɔku dzɔ nenɔ nyanya na mi katã; ɖeka nate ɖe mia ŋu eye ɖeka nanɔ adzɔge, ate ŋu anye sukukpo aɖe dzi loo alo gbadzaƒe aɖe.
Set up family meeting places​ such as a school or a library ​one nearby and another outside your neighborhood.
Afɔkuŋutinunyalawo ɖo aɖaŋu be wò kple wò ƒomea minɔ zɔzɔm yi teƒe siawo edziedzi.
Authorities recommend that you practice walking with your family to those meeting points.
Ðoe be yeakpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu, ame siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ame tsitsiwo kple dɔnɔwo.
Plan to help others, including the elderly and the infirm.
WƆ NU KPATA​ LE AFƆKUA DZƆƔI
DURING​ ACT QUICKLY
Joshua si ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi gblɔ be: "Esi míaƒe ɔfis lé dzo la, vɔvɔ̃ meɖo ame akpa gãtɔ o, womewɔ nu kpata o.
"When fire broke out, most people didn’t panic​ they delayed, " relates Joshua, quoted at the outset.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo tsi woƒe kɔmpiutawo alo nɔ tsi kum ɖe woƒe tsigowo me.
"Some turned off a computer or filled a water bottle.
Ŋutsu aɖe ya gblɔ be: ‘Ðewohĩ ele be míalala.’
One man said, ‘Maybe we should just wait.’
" Togbɔ be amewo metsi dzi o hãa, Joshua ya do ɣli be: "Ele be míadzo fifi laa! "
" Despite the hesitancy of others, Joshua shouted: "We need to get out of here now! "
Enumake eƒe dɔwɔhatiwo do kplɔe ɖo ɖi to atrakpuiawo dzi ɖo ta anyigba.
At that, his coworkers snapped out of denial and followed him down the stairs.
"Joshua yi ɣlia dodo dzi be: "Ne ame aɖe dze anyi la milée wòafɔ, mí katã míaɖi dedie! "
"If anyone falls, pick him up and keep moving, " Joshua kept calling out. "We’re all going to make it! "
Ne dzo dze aƒe.
In a fire.
Bɔbɔ eye nàwɔ kaba ato mɔ si te ɖe ŋuwò ado go.
Stay close to the floor, and move quickly to the nearest exit.
Esesẽ be woakpɔ nu to dzudzɔ me, eye dzudzɔ si amewo gbɔnae nana wokuna.
Smoke makes it hard to see, and most fire deaths are caused by smoke inhalation.
Gblẽ nunɔamesiwo ɖi nàdzo.
Leave behind personal items.
Ne èdzo le teƒea kaba la, ana nàtsi agbe.
Seconds can make the difference between life and death.
Ne anyigba le ʋuʋum.
In an earthquake.
Bè ɖe kplɔ̃ aɖe te alo ɖe gli aɖe xa.
Get under sturdy furniture or next to an inside wall.
Nya be anyigbaʋuʋu suesuesuewo ate ŋu adzɔ akplɔe ɖo, eya ta do yi xexe enumake ne anya wɔ.
Expect aftershocks, and get outside and away from buildings as soon as you can.
Ate ŋu adzɔ be kpekpeɖeŋunadɔwɔlawo mava ɖo kaba o, eya ta ne àte ŋui la, dze agbagba nàkpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu.
Trained rescuers may not arrive for hours, so try to rescue others if you can.
Ne anyigba le ʋuʋum le atsiaƒu me.
In a tsunami.
Ne atsiaƒutsia trɔ dzo enumake la, wɔ kaba nàyi teƒe kɔkɔ si tsia maɖo o.
If the water suddenly rushes away from the shore, move quickly to higher ground.
Nya be tsi gbogbo aɖe kple ƒutsotsoe gãwo atrɔ ava.
Expect more and larger waves.
Ne ahom sesẽ aɖe le tutum.
In a tornado or a hurricane.
Yi teƒe si woɖo ɖi be amewo nanɔ ne ahom tu la enumake.
Go to a storm shelter without delay.
Ne tsi ɖɔ.
In a flood.
Mèganɔ xɔ siwo me tsi ɖɔ ɖo la me o.
Stay out of flooded buildings.
Ƒo asa na tsimezɔzɔ alo ʋukuku to tsi me.
Avoid wading in or driving through water.
Afɔku si manya kpɔ bɔbɔe o ate ŋu anɔ tsi si le sisim me, esia ƒe ɖewoe nye nu gbagbã siwo tsia lɔ ɖe enu, do globowo kple do siwo me elektrik-kawo to le tome.
Floodwater can contain sewage and conceal dangers, including debris, open manholes, and downed power lines.
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Tsi si le sisim si ƒe goglome mede meta ɖeka o (0.6) la ate ŋu akɔ ʋu adzoe.
Two feet [0.6 m] of moving water can carry a car away.
Ame siwo kuna le tsiɖɔɖɔ me la dometɔ geɖe nyea ame siwo dzea agbagba be yewoaku ʋu to tsi siwo le sisim me.
Most deaths in a flood result when people try to drive through moving water.
Ne dumegãwo gblɔ be misi la, dzo enumake!
If the authorities order evacuation, leave immediately!
Na xɔ̃wòwo nanya afi si nèle, ne menye nenema o la, woava de woƒe agbe afɔku me anɔ diwòm.
Let friends know where you are, or they may risk their lives looking for you.
Ƒome aɖe le to ɖom radio
A family listens to a radio
Ne dumegãwo gblɔ be misi la, dzo enumake!
If authorities order evacuation, leave immediately!
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Le afɔkudzɔɣiwo la, nyatakakawo ɖoɖo ɖa to text message dzi ate ŋu anyo wu kaƒoƒo.
Text messaging may be more reliable than telephone voice service.
Ne dumegãwo de se be ame sia ame nenɔ eƒe me loo alo afi si wòle la, nɔ xɔ me.
If the authorities direct residents to remain at home or shelter in place, stay inside.
Ne edzɔ be aɖi xɔ yame le miaƒe nutoa me loo, nuklia-mɔ̃ aɖe wó loo alo ame aɖe wu aɖi ɖe yame tsɔ dze miaƒe nutoa dzi la, nɔ xɔ me, tu yatoƒewo, eye nàxe yatoƒe ɖe sia ɖe le ʋɔtruwo kple fesrewo ŋu.

In case of an outdoor chemical, biological, or nuclear accident or attack, stay indoors, turn off ventilation, and seal all doors and windows. In a nuclear event, go to the lowest internal part of your building to reduce exposure to radiation.
Se mia gbɔ nyadzɔdzɔwo le television alo radio dzi.
Listen to local TV or radio news.
Nɔ xɔ me va se ɖe esime dumegãwo gblɔ be afɔkua nu yi hafi nàdo go.
Stay indoors until authorities announce that the threat has passed.
WƆ NU SIWO ANA NÀNƆ DEDIE​ NE WÒDZƆ VƆ MEGBE!
AFTER​ STAY SAFE!
Be nàƒo asa na dɔlélewo kple afɔku bubuwo la, bu aɖaŋuɖoɖo siawo ŋu kpɔ:
To avoid disease and danger, consider the following recommendations:
Nɔ xɔ̃wòwo gbɔ ne anya wɔ, tsɔ wu be nànɔ afi si wosika ame gbogbowo ɖo.
Stay with friends, if possible, rather than in a camp.
Na afi si nèle la nanɔ dzadzɛ.
Keep your living space sanitary.
Zã ametakpɔnuwo ne èle gbeɖuɖɔwo lɔm.
Use personal protective equipment when cleaning up debris.
Ne anya wɔ la, do aŋesiwuiwo kple afɔkpa titri, ɖɔ xɔtulawo ƒe kuku eye nàtsɔ nu abla ŋɔti.
If possible, wear gloves, sturdy shoes, a hard hat, and a dust mask.
Nɔ ŋudzɔ ɖe elektrik-kawo kple dzo siwo ate ŋu anɔ nu siwo fiã la me ŋu.
Beware of electrical wires and hidden embers.
Yi dɔ siwo nèwɔna gbe sia gbe dzi abe ale si nèwɔnɛ ene, ne anya wɔ.
Keep your daily routine as normal as possible.
Ele be viwòwo nakpɔe be wò susu dze akɔ anyi eye mɔkpɔkpɔ mebu ɖe wò o.
Your children need to see that you are calm and hopeful.
Kpe ɖe viwòwo ŋu woawɔ woƒe sukudɔdeasiwo, fe kpli wo eye miaxlẽ Biblia, ado gbe ɖa ɖekae.
Do school lessons, play, and worship as a family.
Mègana nyadzɔdzɔ siwo woanɔ gbɔgblɔm tso afɔkua ŋu naxɔ susu me na wò o, eye mèganɔ dziku ɖem ɖe ƒomea me tɔwo ŋu o.
Do not dwell on news coverage of the tragedy, and do not take out your anxiety or frustration on family members.
Lɔ̃ woakpe ɖe ŋuwò eye nàkpe ɖe amewo ŋu.
Accept help, and help others.
Ƒome aɖe le dɔ siwo wowɔna gbe sia gbe la wɔm le afɔku aɖe megbe
A family sticks to their routine after a disaster
Le afɔkua megbe la, yi dɔ siwo nèwɔna gbe sia gbe la dzi ne anya wɔ
After the disaster, keep your routine as normal as possible
Nenɔ susu me na wò be afɔkuwo gblẽa nu.
Acknowledge that disasters cause loss.
Dziɖuɖua kple kpekpeɖeŋunahabɔbɔwo ƒe taɖodzinue nye be woakpe ɖe amewo ŋu woatsi agbe menye be woaɖo woƒe nu siwo katã gblẽ la teƒe na wo o.
Government and other relief efforts focus on helping people to survive, not on replacing everything that was lost.
Nu siwo ko míehiã be míanɔ agbee nye tsi nyui, nuɖuɖu, nudodowo kple mlɔƒe. 1 Timoteo 6:7, 8.
To survive, we need clean water, food, clothing, and shelter from the weather.​ 1 Timothy 6:7, 8.
