Nyae be nu ate ɖe dziwò eye lɔ̃ woakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Recognize and address emotional injury.
Zi geɖe la, esia dzɔna ne afɔkua nu yi vɔ.
This often surfaces after the initial shock has passed.
Dzesia ƒe ɖewoe nye dzodzodzoetsitsi, blanuiléle kple seselelãme ƒe tɔtrɔ kpata kpakple ale si wòsesẽna be woabu tame, awɔ dɔ alo adɔ alɔ̃.
Symptoms include anxiety, depression, and mood swings, as well as difficulty thinking, working, and sleeping.
Ðo dze tso eŋu na xɔ̃wò siwo tsɔa ɖe le eme na wò.
Talk to caring friends.
Togbɔ be Joshua tsi agbe esi dzo dze afi si wòwɔa dɔ le hã, eƒe ame nyanyɛ geɖe ku.
Although Joshua survived the fire in his workplace, many of his acquaintances did not.
Kristotɔ hamemetsitsiwo kple tagbɔdɔdalawo kpe ɖe eŋu.
He received assistance from Christian elders and mental-health professionals.
Joshua gblɔ be: "Woka ɖe edzi nam be nye nuxaxaa ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋunye be mahaya eye be enu ava yi.
"They assured me that my grief was part of a natural healing process and that it would pass, " Joshua says.
Le ɣleti ade megbe la, drɔ̃e baɖabaɖa siwo mekuna la dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ.
"After six months, the nightmares lessened.
Dzesia ƒe ɖewo ya nɔ anyi didi. "
Other symptoms have lasted longer. "
Ne afɔku dzɔ la, enana mímebua nuwo ŋu nyuie o.
Disasters assault our very sense of justice.
Esia nana ame aɖewo bua fɔ Mawu.
In response, some people mistakenly blame God.
Abe Joshua enea, "ame geɖe sea veve ɖe ame siwo tsi afɔku aɖe me la ta. "
Many, like Joshua, experience "survivor’s guilt. "
Egblɔ be "Egawɔna nam kokoko be ɖe wòle be maxɔ ame geɖe ɖe agbe hafi.
"I still wonder if I could have saved more people, " he says.
Nu si dzi mexɔ see nye be madidi o Mawu aɖɔ nu madzɔmadzɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖo le anyigba dzi, eye esia faa akɔ nam.
"I am comforted by my belief that God will soon bring complete justice to the earth and will right all wrongs.
Gake fifia, medea asixɔxɔ agbe ŋu eye mewɔa nu sia nu si mate ŋui be makpɔ eta. " Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4, 5.
In the meantime, I cherish each day of life and do what I reasonably can to preserve it. "​ Revelation 21:4, 5.
Ðe Nu Siwo Nèhiã La Le Asiwòa?
DO YOU HAVE WHAT YOU NEED?
Nuhiahiã veviwo
Emergency supplies
Habɔbɔ siwo kpɔa nuwo gbɔ ne afɔku dzɔ ɖo aɖaŋu na ƒomewo be, woadzra nuhiahiã veviwo ɖo eye woanɔ esiwo hiã be woaɖɔli la ɖɔlim ƒe sia ƒe.
Disaster management organizations urge families to store and annually update emergency supplies.
Afi si nèle kple nɔnɔme si me nèle ye abia nu si nàtsɔ ɖe asi, eya ta bia nya kpatawo gbɔ kpɔdɔwɔƒe si le mia gbɔ be woaɖo aɖaŋu na wò.
Of course, needs will vary according to your location and circumstances, so check with local emergency management services for recommendations that could be applied in your area.
Anyo be ame sia ame nàdzra tsi galɔn etɔ̃ (Lita 11) ya teti kple nuɖuɖu si magblẽ o, si mehiã be woaɖa hafi aɖu o la ɖo.
In general it is recommended that you keep at least three gallons (11 L) of water per person and three days of nonperishable, ready-to-eat foods.
Azɔ hã, ƒome aɖewo dzra "akplo si me nuhiahiãwo le si woate ŋu atsɔ ɖe asi bɔbɔe " la ɖo, eye nu siwo nɔa eme ƒe ɖewoe nye esiawo:
Also, some families have prepared "go bags " with such items as the following:
Kuntruwo, vuvɔmewuwo kple afɔkpa titriwo
Blankets, complete change of warm clothes, and sturdy shoes
Tɔtsi, radio (kpe alo nu si wotsɔ tsadzi na kpea) kple kpe bubuwo
Flashlight, radio (battery or windup), and spare batteries
Nugo si me atike veviwo le kple kpẽ si woaku abia kpekpeɖeŋu
First-aid kit and a whistle to signal for help
Nuɖugbawo, ganugoeʋunu, dɔwɔnuwo abe sakisi, hɛ̃ vi kple esiawo tɔgbi kple matsesi si mate ŋu aɖo tsi o
Eating utensils, can opener, pocket tool set, and waterproof matches
Ŋɔtiblanu kple aŋe gbadzaa si woate ŋu atsɔ awɔ agbadɔ
Dust masks, waterproof tape, and plastic sheeting for shelter
Numeklɔbrɔs, adzalẽ, tsiletse kple afɔdzidepepa
Toothbrushes, soap, towels, and toilet paper
Nu siwo woatsɔ akpɔ ɖeviwo kple ame tsitsi alo dɔnɔ si ŋu hiahiã tɔxɛwo le la gbɔ
Child-care supplies and special-needs items for seniors or the disabled
Nugo si me tsi mate ŋu age ɖo o, si me atike veviwo kple atike siwo ɖɔktawo ŋlɔ kpakple agbalẽ vevi bubuwo le
A waterproof container with needed medication, copies of prescriptions, and other important documents
Kaƒodzesiwo kple teƒe siwo woate ŋu aƒo ƒu ɖo kple anyigbatatagbalẽ
List of emergency contacts and meeting places and a local map
Ga kple gaxɔgbalẽvi
Credit cards and cash
Aƒe alo ʋu ƒe safui bubu siwo li
Extra set of house keys and car keys
Pepa, nuŋlɔti, agbalẽ kple ɖeviwo ƒe fefenuwo
Paper, pencils, books, and games for children
Biblia
Bible
Ne Afɔku Aɖe Dzɔ
When Disaster Strikes
"Gbã la, mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖe mí.
"Our first feeling was total despair.
Ba kple tsiɖɔɖɔ gblẽ nu siwo katã nɔ mía si la dome. " Andrew, Sierra Leone.
Everything we owned had been destroyed by a mudslide and flooding. "​ Andrew, Sierra Leone.
"Le ahom sesẽa megbe la, míetrɔ va míaƒe aƒea me.
"After the hurricane, we returned to our home.
Naneke mesusɔ o.
Nothing was left.
Míaƒe nu ku.
We were speechless.
Ðeko vinyenyɔnua tu klo anyi eye wòwó avi doo. " David, Virgin Islands.
My daughter dropped to her knees and wept. "​ David, Virgin Islands.

NE AFƆKU dzɔ ɖe dziwò kpɔ eye nètsi agbe la, àse ale si ame siwo hã tsi agbe le afɔku aɖe me la sena le wo ɖokuiwo me la gɔme: ana wò mo nada tu, màxɔe ase o, àtɔtɔ, àtsi dzi eye àku drɔ̃e baɖabaɖawo.
IF YOU have ever survived a disaster, you may understand what other survivors have experienced: shock, denial, confusion, anxiety, and nightmares.
Agbetsila siwo ƒo dzi ɖe le eye nu te wo ŋu la megadina be yewoanɔ agbe o.
Many disheartened and fatigued survivors have little motivation to move on in life.
Ne afɔku aɖe gblẽ nu le ŋuwò kpɔ la, ke wò hã àse le ɖokuiwò me be ewu tsɔtsɔ na ye.
If your life has been devastated by a disaster, you too may feel that you are near the breaking point.
Àte ŋu ase le ɖokuiwò me be ne yeku la enyo wu.
You may even begin to feel that your life is not worth living.
Ke hã, Biblia na eme kɔ be susu nyuiwo li siwo ta wòle be nàyi edzi anɔ agbe eye nànɔ mɔ kpɔm na etsɔme nyui aɖe.
However, the Bible explains that your life is worth living and that you can have a firm basis for hope in a better future.
NE ÈNYA BIBLIA ME NYATEƑEA LA ANA MƆKPƆKPƆ WÒ
KNOWING BIBLE TRUTH MAKES LIFE WORTH LIVING
Nyagblɔla 7:8 gblɔ be: "Nu ƒe nuwuwu nyo wu eƒe gɔmedzedze. "
Ecclesiastes 7:8 says: "Better is the end of a matter than its beginning. "
Mɔkpɔkpɔ buna ɖe ame ne afɔku dzɔ ɖe ame dzi teti eye wòle agbagba dzem be yeaŋlɔe be.
When you are just beginning to recover from a disaster, life may seem hopeless.
Gake ne ègbɔ dzi ɖi be nuwo naɖɔ ɖo vivivi la, nɔnɔmea ava ka ɖe eme.
But as you patiently work at rebuilding your life, things can get better.
Biblia gblɔe ɖi be, ɣeyiɣi aɖe ava si me "womagase avifafa alo konyifafa . . . azɔ o. "
The Bible foretells a time when "no more will there be heard . . . the sound of weeping or a cry of distress. "
(Yesaya 65:19) Esia ava eme ne Mawu Fiaɖuƒea va trɔ anyigbaa wòzu paradiso.
(Isaiah 65:19) This will be true when the earth is transformed into a paradise under God’s Kingdom.
(Psalmo 37:11, 29) Afɔkuwo magadzɔ azɔ o.
(Psalm 37:11, 29) Disasters will be a thing of the past.
Vevesese kple dzodzodzoetsitsiwo katã nu ayi tegbee elabe Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la do ŋugbe be: "Tsãnuwo magava susu me na ame, alo ava ame ƒe dzi me o. " Yesaya 65:17.

Any painful memories and lingering trauma will be wiped out forever, because Almighty God promises: "The former things will not be called to mind, nor will they come up into the heart. "​ Isaiah 65:17.
Bu eŋu kpɔ ko: Wɔlaa wɔ ɖoɖo be ‘yeana mɔkpɔkpɔ wò eye etsɔme nanyo na wò’ si fia be ànɔ agbe le tomefafa me le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea me.
Just think: The Creator has arranged "to give you a future and a hope "​ a peaceful life under God’s perfect rulership.
(Yeremiya 29:11) Ðe nyateƒenya sia nyanya na nèdi be yeayi edzi anɔ agbea?
(Jeremiah 29:11) Can having knowledge of this truth help make your life worth living?
Sally si ƒe nya míegblɔ le nyati gbãtɔ me gblɔ be: "Ne èɖoa ŋku nu nyui siwo katã Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ava wɔ na mí le etsɔme dzi na ɖokuiwò la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàŋlɔ nu siwo dzɔ va yi la be eye nàkpɔ ŋgɔ. "

Sally, quoted in the opening article, states, "Reminding yourself of all the wonderful things that God’s Kingdom is going to do for us in the future can help you let go of the past and get through the present. "
Ðe manyo be nàsrɔ̃ nu geɖe tso nu si Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ava wɔ na amegbetɔwo kpuie la ŋu oa?
Why not learn more about what God’s Kingdom will soon do for mankind?
Ne èwɔe alea la, ana nàka ɖe edzi be togbɔ be afɔku dzɔ ɖe ye dzi hã la, susu nyuiwo li siwo ta wòle be yeayi edzi anɔ agbe fifia eye yeanɔ mɔ kpɔm na ɣeyiɣi si afɔku aɖeke magadzɔ o.
Doing so can assure you that despite the disaster you have suffered, your life is worth living now as you eagerly await a disaster-free future.
Hafi ɣeyiɣi ma naɖo gɔ̃ hã la, Biblia ɖo aɖaŋu nyui siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàdo dzi le afɔku si dzɔ ɖe dziwò la me.
In the meantime, the Bible provides practical guidance that can help you to cope with the aftermath of a disaster.
Kpɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu ʋɛ aɖewo ɖa.
Consider a few examples.
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò
Bible Verses That Can Help
Ði ɖe eme nyuie.
Get needed rest.
"Gbɔɖeme asiʋlo ɖeka nyo wu dɔ sesẽ wɔwɔ kple dagbadagba ɖe yame asiʋlo eve. " Nyagblɔla 4:6.
"Better is a handful of rest than two handfuls of hard work and chasing after the wind. "​ Ecclesiastes 4:6.
Numekulawo gblɔ be ne afɔku aɖe dzɔ ɖe ame dzi, eye emegbe "amea meɖi ɖe eme nyuie o la, dzikatsoƒonamenuawo anyra ɖe edzi, eye wòana amea natɔtɔ ɖe edzi. "
Researchers report that after a traumatic experience, "a lack of quality sleep . . . can exacerbate your trauma symptoms and make it harder to maintain your emotional balance. "
Eya ta anyo be ame nadɔ alɔ aɖi ɖe eme nyuie.
Therefore, it is wise to get sufficient rest.
Ðo dze tso eŋu na ame aɖe.
Discuss your feelings.
"Nuxaxa le dzi me ɖe wòtea ame ƒe dzi ɖe anyi [alo, "ɖe wònana ame léa blanui, " etenuŋɔŋlɔ], ke nya nyui nana dzi kpɔa dzidzɔ. " Lododowo 12:25.
"Anxiety in a man’s heart weighs it down [or, "depresses him, " footnote], but a good word cheers it up. "​ Proverbs 12:25.
Gblɔ wò dzimenyawo na wò ƒometɔ alo xɔlɔ̃ si dzi nèka ɖo.
Confide in a family member or trusted friend.
Menye ɖeko ƒometɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃ kplikplikpliwo aɖo to wò ko o, ke boŋ woate ŋu ade dzi ƒo na wò eye woakpe ɖe ŋuwò hã.
In addition to providing a listening ear, family members or close friends can provide words of encouragement and give practical help.
Wò susu nenɔ ɣeyiɣi si me nuwo aɖɔ ɖo ŋu.
Look ahead to better times.
"Míele dziƒo yeye kple anyigba yeye, siwo me dzɔdzɔenyenye anɔ la, lalam le [Mawu ƒe] ŋugbedodo la nu. " 2 Petro 3:13.
"There are new heavens and a new earth that we are awaiting according to [God’s] promise, and in these righteousness is to dwell. "​ 2 Peter 3:13.
Nya Kae Biblia Gblɔ Tso Dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo Ŋu?
What Does the Bible Say About Natural Disasters?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Menye Mawu gbɔe dzɔdzɔmefɔku siwo dzɔna egbea la tso o, gake etsɔa ɖe le eme na ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le.
God does not cause the natural disasters occurring today, but he is concerned about people who are affected by them.
Gake fifia gɔ̃ hã la, Mawu faa akɔ na ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le.
Natural disasters are one of the causes of suffering that God’s Kingdom will eliminate.
2 Korintotɔwo 1:3. Nu ka tae míate ŋu aka ɖe edzi be dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo menye tohehe tso Mawu gbɔ o?
In the meantime, God provides comfort for those who are affected by natural disasters.​ 2 Corinthians 1:3.
Ðe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo nye dzesi be míele ŋkeke mamlɛawo mea?
Why can we be sure that natural disasters are not punishment from God?
Aleke Mawu kpena ɖe ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le la ŋu?
Are natural disasters a sign of the times?
Ðe Biblia ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu be míadzra ɖo ɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo ŋua?
How does God help victims of natural disasters?
Nu ka tae míate ŋu aka ɖe edzi be dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo menye tohehe tso Mawu gbɔ o?
Can the Bible help with natural-disaster preparedness?
Mawu zã dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽwo tsɔ he to na amewo le blema.
Bible verses to comfort victims of natural disasters
Gake ne Mawu zã dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽwo tsɔ he to na amewo la, ekpɔa egbɔ be ame vɔ̃ɖiwo koe tsrɔ̃na.
Why can we be sure that natural disasters are not punishment from God?
(1 Mose 19:29, 30) Mawu kpɔ du mawo me tɔwo ƒe dziwo me, eye wòtsrɔ̃ ame siwo wòkpɔ be wovɔ̃ɖi la ɖeɖe ko.
Natural disasters differ from God’s use of natural forces, as recorded in the Bible.
Zi geɖe la, dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo dzɔna le vo me.
Natural disasters kill and maim indiscriminately.
Gake hafi Mawu nazã dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽwo atsɔ ahe to na ame vɔ̃ɖiwo la, exlɔ̃a nu wo do ŋgɔ.
In contrast, God’s acts of judgment recorded in the Bible were selective.
Eya ta mɔnukpɔkpɔ sua ame siwo ɖo to nuxlɔ̃amea la si be woasi le afɔkua nu.
For example, when God destroyed the ancient cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, he spared the good man Lot and his two daughters.
(Genesis 19:29, 30) God read the hearts of the individuals of that time and destroyed only those he deemed wicked.​ Genesis 18:23-​32; 1 Samuel 16:7.
Amegbetɔwo ƒe nuwɔnawo hã le eme tae dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo dzɔna alo gblẽa nu le amewo ŋu.
On the other hand, God gave warnings to the wicked before using natural forces against them.
Le mɔ ka nu?
How?
Wogblẽa dzɔdzɔmenuwo dome eye wotua xɔ ɖe teƒe siwo anyigbaʋuʋu, tsiɖɔɖɔ kple ya sesẽwo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le bɔbɔe.
By damaging the natural environment and by building in areas prone to earthquakes, floods, and extreme weather.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 11:18) Mele be míabu fɔ Mawu ɖe tiatia mawo siwo amewo wɔna la ta o. Lododowo 19:3.
(Revelation 11:18) God is not to blame for such human choices.​ Proverbs 19:3.
Ðe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo nye dzesi be míele ŋkeke mamlɛawo mea?
Are natural disasters a sign of the times?
Ɛ̃, Biblia gblɔe ɖi be afɔkuwo adzɔ le "nuɖoanyia ƒe nuwuɣi, " alo "ŋkeke mamlɛawo me. "
Yes, Bible prophecies suggest that there would be disasters during "the conclusion of the system of things, " or "the last days. "
(Mateo 24:3; 2 Timoteo 3:1) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesu gblɔ tso míaƒe ŋkekea ŋu be: "Nuɖuɖu ave le teƒeteƒewo, eye anyigba aʋuʋu le teƒeteƒewo. "
(Matthew 24:3; 2 Timothy 3:1) For example, concerning our time, Jesus said: "There will be food shortages and earthquakes in one place after another. "
(Mateo 24:7) Eteƒe madidi o, Mawu aɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo kple nu siwo katã nana míesea veve eye míekpea fu la ɖa le anyigba dzi. Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.
(Matthew 24:7) Soon, God will rid the earth of all causes of pain and suffering, including natural disasters.​ Revelation 21:​3, 4.
Aleke Mawu kpena ɖe ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le la ŋu?
How does God help victims of natural disasters?
Mawu toa eƒe Nya, Biblia, dzi faa akɔ na ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le.
God comforts victims with his Word, the Bible.
Biblia ka ɖe edzi na mí be Mawu tsɔ ɖe le eme na mí eye wòsea veve ɖe mía nu ne míele fu kpem.
The Bible assures us that God cares for us and that he feels for us when we suffer.

(Yesaya 63:9; 1 Petro 5:6, 7) Biblia na míekpɔe hã be Mawu do ŋugbe be ɣeyiɣi aɖe ava si me dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo magadzɔ azɔ o. Kpɔ aɖaka si nye " Mawunyakpukpui siwo ate ŋu afa akɔ na ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le. "
(Isaiah 63:9; 1 Peter 5:​6, 7) It also reveals his promise of a time when natural disasters will not happen anymore.​ See " Bible verses to comfort victims of natural disasters. "
Mawu toa esubɔlawo dzi kpena ɖe ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
God helps victims by means of his worshippers.
Mawu ʋãa esubɔla siwo le anyigba dzi be woasrɔ̃ kpɔɖeŋu si Yesu ɖo.
God uses his worshippers on earth to imitate the example set by Jesus.
Biblia gblɔe ɖi be Yesu afa akɔ na "ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã " kple "konyifalawo katã. "
It was prophesied that Jesus would comfort "the brokenhearted " and "all who mourn. "
(Yesaya 61:1, 2) Mawu subɔlawo hã dzea agbagba be yewoawɔ nenema ke. Yohanes 13:15.
(Isaiah 61:​1, 2) Worshippers of God strive to do the same.​ John 13:15.
Mawu gatoa esubɔlawo dzi naa kpekpeɖeŋu siwo hiã la ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le. Dɔwɔwɔwo 11:28-30; Galatiatɔwo 6:10.
God also uses his worshippers to provide practical relief to victims of natural disasters.​ Acts 11:28-30; Galatians 6:​10.
Yehowa Ðasefowo le aƒe aɖe dzram ɖo le Puerto Rico
Jehovah’s Witnesses repair a home in Puerto Rico
Yehowa Ðasefowo le kpekpeɖeŋu nam ame siwo ŋu ahom sesẽ aɖe gblẽ nu le le Puerto Rico
Jehovah’s Witnesses providing practical relief to hurricane victims in Puerto Rico
Ðe Biblia ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu be míadzra ɖo ɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo ŋua?
Can the Bible help with natural-disaster preparedness?
Yes.
Togbɔ be menye dzadzraɖo ɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo ŋu tae woŋlɔ Biblia ɖo o hã la, mɔfiamewo le eme siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu.
Although the Bible is not a manual for disaster preparedness, it contains principles that can help.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye esiawo:
For example:
Nɔ dzadzraɖoɖi ɖe afɔkuwo ŋu.
Plan ahead for potential disasters.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Aɖaŋudzela kpɔa afɔku gbɔna eye wòɣlaa eɖokui. "
"The shrewd one sees the danger and conceals himself, " says the Bible.
(Lododowo 22:3) Nunya le eme be míadzra ɖo ɖe afɔkuwo ŋu do ŋgɔ.
(Proverbs 22:3) We are wise to prepare an emergency plan in advance.

Dzadzraɖo do ŋgɔ abia be nàƒo nu vevi siwo nàhiã ne afɔku dzɔ kpata la nu ƒu ɖe akplo me ahana wòanɔ asitsɔƒe na wò, eye wò kple wò ƒomea miadzro nu me ahalɔ̃ ɖe afi si miava do go le ne afɔku dzɔ la dzi.
Such planning may include assembling an emergency kit that is ready to go in case of an emergency and rehearsing with one’s family where to meet if a disaster occurs.
Agbea nenɔ vevie na wò wu kesinɔnuwo.
Value life over possessions.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Míetsɔ naneke va xexea me o, eye míate ŋu atsɔ naneke adzoe hã o. " (1 Timoteo 6:7, 8) Ele be míanɔ klalo be míagblẽ míaƒe aƒe kple kesinɔnuwo ɖi ale be míasi le afɔku nu.

The Bible acknowledges: "We have brought nothing into the world, and neither can we carry anything out. " (1 Timothy 6:​7, 8) We need to be willing to leave our home and possessions in order to escape disaster.
Ehiã be míaɖo ŋku edzi be míaƒe agbe le vevie wu nunɔamesi ɖe sia ɖe. Mateo 6:25.
We do well to remember that our life is more important than any material things.​ Matthew 6:​25.
Mawunyakpukpui siwo ate ŋu afa akɔ na ame siwo ŋu dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo gblẽ nu le
Bible verses to comfort victims of natural disasters
1 Mose 18:25: ‘Meka ɖe edzi be Mawu mawɔ nu ma, awu ame dzɔdzɔe kple ame vɔ̃ɖi siaa gbeɖe o.
Genesis 18:25: "It is unthinkable that [God] would act in this manner by putting the righteous man to death with the wicked one . . .
Ðe anyigba blibo la ƒe Ʋɔnudrɔ̃la la mawɔ nu dzɔdzɔe oa?’
Will the Judge of all the earth not do what is right? "
Nu si wòfia: Mawu wɔa nu si le eteƒe ɣesiaɣi; mele be míabu fɔe ne ame nyuiwo ku le dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo me o.
Meaning: God always does what is right; he is not to blame when good people die because of natural disasters.
Psalmo 46:1, 2: "Mawu nye míaƒe sitsoƒe kple míaƒe ŋusẽ, eyae nye xɔnametɔ si li ɖaa le xaxaɣiwo.
Psalm 46:​1, 2: "God is our refuge and strength, a help that is readily found in times of distress.
Esia tae míavɔ̃ o, togbɔ be anyigba la ƒe nɔnɔme le tɔtrɔm hã. "
That is why we will not fear, though the earth undergoes change. "
Nu si wòfia: Nu ka kee ɖadzɔ le afi si míele o, míate ŋu aɖo ŋu ɖe Mawu ŋu be wòakpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ te sesĩe.
Meaning: No matter what may happen around us, God is a reliable Source of strength.
Yesaya 63:9: "Le woƒe vevesesewo katã me la, eya hã se veve. "
Isaiah 63:9: "During all their distress it was distressing to him. "
Nu si wòfia: Mawu sea veve ɖe mía nu ne míele fu kpem.
Meaning: God has empathy​ he feels for us when we suffer.
Yohanes 5:28, 29: "Gaƒoƒo la gbɔna, esime ame siwo katã le ŋkuɖodziyɔdowo me la ase [Yesu ƒe] gbe, eye woado go. "
John 5:​28, 29: "The hour is coming in which all those in the memorial tombs will hear [Jesus’] voice and come out. "
Nu si wòfia: Míele mɔ kpɔm be míava kpɔ míaƒe ame vevi siwo ku la ake, elabena Mawu ana ŋusẽ Yesu be wòafɔ wo ɖe tsitre.
Meaning: We can have the hope of seeing our dead loved ones again because God will empower Jesus to bring them back to life.
1 Petro 5:6, 7: "Eya ta mibɔbɔ mia ɖokui ɖe Mawu ƒe asi sesẽ la te . . . esime miedro miaƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo katã ɖe edzi, elabena eléa be na mi. "
1 Peter 5:​6, 7: "Humble yourselves, therefore, under the mighty hand of God . . . while you throw all your anxiety on him, because he cares for you. "
Nu si wòfia: Mawu tsɔ ɖe le eme na mí vevie eye wòdi be míado gbe ɖa na ye tso míaƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo ŋu.
Meaning: God has deep concern for us and wants us to pray to him about our anxieties.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4: "[Mawu] atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o.
Revelation 21:4: "[God] will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore.
Nu siwo nɔ anyi tsã la nu va yi. "
The former things have passed away. "
Nu si wòfia: Mawu aɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo kple nu siwo katã nana míekpea fu la ɖa.
Meaning: God will eliminate all causes of suffering, including natural disasters.
Lãmesẽ
Health
Ðe Mawu tsɔ ɖe le míaƒe lãmesẽnyawo mea?
Does God care about how we treat our bodies?
"Meganɔ wain tsu nolawo kple lã tsu ɖulawo dome o. "
"Do not come to be among heavy drinkers of wine, among those who are gluttonous eaters of flesh. "
Lododowo 23:20.
Proverbs 23:20.
NU KA TAE WÒLE VEVIE?
WHY DOES IT MATTER?
Biblia menye atikewɔgbalẽ o; eye mede se ku ɖe amegbetɔ ƒe agbemenuwɔna ɖe sia ɖe hã ŋu o.
The Bible is not a medical textbook; nor does it regulate every aspect of human behavior.
Ke hã ale si Mawu bua lãmesẽnyawoe xexlẽ le Biblia me aɖe vi na wò.
Still, you can benefit from understanding God’s view of health as expressed in the Bible.
NU SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Mawunyakpukpui geɖe ƒo nu tso ale si Mawu bua ale si míewɔa nu ɖe míaƒe ŋutilã ŋu la ŋu.
Numerous Bible passages shed light on how God feels about the way we treat our bodies.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia ƒo nu tsi tre ɖe nu siwo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le míaƒe ŋutilã ŋu, abe ahamumu kple nu tsu ɖuɖu ene ŋu.
For instance, the Bible condemns harmful excesses, including drunkenness and gluttony.
(Lododowo 23:20) Se si Mawu de na blema Israel dukɔa dometɔ aɖewo ku ɖe nu siwo woawɔ atsɔ alé dɔlélewo nu alo axe mɔ ɖe wo nu kura la ŋu.
(Proverbs 23:20) God’s Law code given to ancient Israel included measures that would control and in some cases even prevent diseases.
Dedienɔnɔ ŋuti mɔfiame aɖewo koŋ le Sea me siwo akpe ɖe ame ŋu wòaƒo asa na afɔkuwo.
The Law also incorporated specific safety regulations for the prevention of injuries.
(5 Mose 22:8) Edze kɔtɛe be Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be míalé be na mía ɖokuiwo eye míaɖe afɔ siwo sɔ atsɔ akpɔ míaƒe lãmesẽ ta.
(Deuteronomy 22:8) Clearly, the Bible encourages us to take care of our bodies and take reasonable measures to protect our health.
Le Biblia ƒe nya nu la, nu ka gbɔe wòtso be míedzea dɔ?
According to the Bible, why do we get sick?
"To ame ɖeka dzi nu vɔ̃ ge ɖe xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va. "
"Through one man sin entered into the world and death through sin. "
Romatɔwo 5:12.
Romans 5:12.
NYA SI AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Ame geɖe xɔe se be dɔléle nye nane si dzɔ le eɖokui si esime amegbetɔwo nɔ tɔtrɔm.
Many believe that sickness is simply a quirk of human evolution.
Ame bubuwo susui be vivimeŋusẽwo, abe gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ene, gbɔe míaƒe lãmesẽkuxiwo tsona.
Others think that mysterious forces, such as evil spirits, are the cause of our health problems.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Le Biblia ƒe nya nu la, esi amegbetɔ gbãtɔwo dze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu tae míedzea dɔ ɖo.
According to the Bible, we get sick as a result of the first human rebellion against God.
(Romatɔwo 5:12) Mía dzila gbãtɔ Adam kple Xawa nɔ lãmesẽ blibo me hafi wova dze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu.
(Romans 5:12) Before their rebellion, our first parents, Adam and Eve, enjoyed perfect health.
Wonyae be ne yewogbe Mawu ƒe beléname si me lɔlɔ̃ le la, yewoaku.
They knew that they would die if they withdrew from God’s loving care.
(1 Mose 2:16, 17) Ke hã woɖoe koŋ tso xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔ si nɔ wo kple Mawu dome la me, ale wobu woƒe blibodedea.
(Genesis 2:16, 17) Still, they willfully severed their friendship with God and lost their perfection.
Míenyi blibomademade ƒe dome tso mía dzila gbãtɔ siwo dze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu la gbɔ.
The flawed nature of our rebellious first human parents has been passed on to us.
Eya ta togbɔ be ameƒomea le agbagba dzem kpem be yeaɖe dɔléle ɖa hã la, gbeɖegbeɖea koe.
Hence, despite all efforts to eliminate human maladies, we still get sick.
NU KAE NÀWƆ?
WHAT CAN YOU DO?
Biblia fia nu be ne èwɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe mɔfiame siwo me nunya le dzi tsɔ dzra wò kplii dome ɖo la, àva nɔ agbe le paradiso me le anyigba dzi le lãmesẽ blibo me.
The Bible teaches that if you become reconciled to God by obeying his wise principles, you will eventually enjoy perfect health in an earthly paradise.
(Yesaya 33:24) Mawu do ŋugbe be yeaɖe vevesese, dɔléle kple ku ɖa.
(Isaiah 33:24) God promises to eliminate pain, sickness, and death.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.
Revelation 21:3, 4.
Ðe Biblia xe mɔ ɖe atikewɔwɔ nua?
Does the Bible discourage medical treatment?
"Ame siwo le lãmesẽ me la mehiã atikewɔla o, gake ame siwo le dɔ lém la hiãe. "
"Persons in health do not need a physician, but the ailing do. "
Mateo 9:12.
Matthew 9:12.
NYA SI AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Ame aɖewo gblɔna be gbɔgbɔmegbedada (si wogayɔna be xɔsegbedada) la nyo wu atikewɔwɔ.
Some promote spiritual healing (also known as faith healing) over medical treatment.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Mawu ɖe mɔ atikewɔlawo nɔ eƒe ame siwo nɔ anyi le Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣiwo me la dome.
God allowed health-care practitioners to operate among his people in Bible times.
(1 Mose 38:28; Kolosetɔwo 4:14) Naneke mele Biblia me si ɖee fia be Mawu mekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe atikewɔla mawo ƒe gbewo, dɔmiwo kple nuɖuɖu aɖewo koŋ tsitsri kple dɔdamɔnu bubuwo zazã ŋu o.

(Genesis 38:28; Colossians 4:14) There is nothing in the Bible that would indicate that God was displeased with their use of medicinal plants, ointments, prescribed diets, and other health treatments.
Le nyateƒe me la, Yesu gblɔ be "ame siwo le lãmesẽ me la mehiã atikewɔla o, gake ame siwo le dɔ lém la hiãe. "
In fact, Jesus acknowledged that "persons in health do not need a physician, but the ailing do. "
Mateo 9:12.
Matthew 9:12.
Ke hã Biblia meda asi ɖe dɔdamɔnu ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi dzi o.
Yet, the Bible does not endorse the pursuit of health at all costs.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia meda asi ɖe xɔsegbedada siwo li egbea la dzi o.
For instance, the Bible does not endorse the modern-day practice of faith healing.
Eye Mawu meda asi ɖe dɔdamɔnu siwo lɔ gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ ɖe eme hã dzi o.
And cures that involve spiritistic practices are not approved by God.
(Galatiatɔwo 5:19-21) To vovo na dɔdamɔnu siwo Biblia tsri la, nu nyuitɔ si wòle be míawɔ ne míedze dɔe nye be míadi dɔdamɔnu si sɔ kaba ne ɖe li.
(Galatians 5:19-21) Aside from practices that the Bible condemns, the sensible thing to do when faced with infirmities would be to seek appropriate health care promptly, if it is available.
Nu Siwo Nàwɔ Be Nànɔ Lãmesẽ Me Wu
Ways to Improve Your Health
AME kae dina be yealé dɔ?
WHO wants to be sick?
Dɔléle doa nuxaxa na ame eye wògblẽa ga na ame hã.
At the very least, an illness is an inconvenience and an expense.
Ana be dzi madzɔ wò o, eye màte ŋu ayi suku alo awɔ dɔ akpɔ ga o, eye màte ŋu akpɔ wò ƒomea dzi hã o.
You not only feel bad, but when you are sick, you may not be able to go to work or school, earn any money, or look after your family.
Ahiã gɔ̃ hã be ame aɖe nakpɔ dziwò eye nàzã ga gbogbo aɖe ɖe atikewo kple dɔdada ŋu.
You may even need someone to look after you, and you may have to pay for expensive medicines and treatment.
Màte ŋu aƒo asa na dɔléle aɖewo ya o.
Well has it been said that "Prevention is better than cure. "
Gake nu geɖewo li nàte ŋu awɔ be dɔlélewo makpɔ ŋusẽ boo ɖe dziwò o alo aƒo asa na wo keŋkeŋ.
Some illnesses cannot be avoided.
Elabena dzeaʋaɖia, aʋa mesinɛ o.
Still, there is much you can do to slow down or even prevent the onset of illness.
Kpɔ nu atɔ̃ siwo nàte ŋu awɔ tso egbea dzi be nànɔ lãmesẽ me la ɖa.
Consider five things that you can do today to get on the road to better health.
1 WƆ NU SI ANA NÀNƆ DZADZƐE
1 PRACTICE GOOD HYGIENE
Nu siwo wozãna tsɔ kpɔa ŋutilãmedzadzɛnyenye gbɔ
Items used for good physical and dental hygiene
Kɔdzi si woyɔna be Mayo gblɔ be, "mɔ nyuitɔ siwo dzi ame ato aƒo asa na dɔlélewo kple dɔlékuiwo kaka la dometɔ ɖekae " nye asikɔklɔ.
According to the Mayo Clinic, "one of the best ways to avoid getting sick and spreading illness " is to wash your hands.
Mɔ siwo dzi ame tona xɔa kpeƒoame alo dzamezã ƒe dɔlékuiwo bɔbɔe ye nye be wòatsɔ asi si ŋu dɔlékuiwo le anɔ ŋɔtinu alo ŋku lilim.
One of the easiest ways to catch a cold or influenza is to rub your nose or your eyes when your hands have been contaminated by germs.
Mɔ nyuitɔ si dzi nàto aƒo asa na esia ye nye be nànɔ asi klɔm edziedzi.
Your best defense against such contamination is to wash your hands regularly.

Beléle na ame ɖokui ahanɔ dzadzɛe ate ŋu axe mɔ ɖe dɔ vɔ̃ɖi aɖewo kaka nu, wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye axamedɔ kple mitsinyenyedɔwo, dɔ siawo wua ɖevi siwo mekpɔ xɔ ƒe atɔ̃ haɖe o la dometɔ miliɔn eve aɖewo ƒe sia ƒe.
Good hygiene can also prevent the spread of more serious conditions, such as pneumonia and diarrheal diseases, which every year cause the death of over two million children under the age of five.
Asikɔklɔ ate ŋu aɖe dɔ vɔ̃ɖi si ŋkɔe nye Ebola gɔ̃ hã ƒe kaka dzi akpɔtɔ.
Even the spread of deadly Ebola can be minimized by the simple habit of washing hands.
Asikɔklɔ le vevie le ɣeyiɣi aɖewo koŋ me be míakpɔ míawo ŋutɔwo kple ame bubuwo ƒe lãmesẽ ta.
There are certain times when hand washing is particularly important to protect your own health and that of others.
Ele be nàklɔ asi:
You should wash your hands:
Ne ède afɔdzi.
After using the toilet.
Ne èɖɔli godui na viwò alo ne ede afɔdzi nèkpɔ egbɔ.
After changing diapers or helping a child to use the toilet.
Hafi nàkpɔ abi gbɔ, eye ne èkpɔ abia gbɔ vɔ hã.
Before and after treating a wound or a cut.
Hafi nàyi dɔnɔ aɖe gbɔ, eye ne èdzo le egbɔ hã.
Before and after being with someone who is sick.
Hafi nàɖa nu, nàtsɔ nuɖuɖu aɖo kplɔ̃e alo aɖu nu.
Before preparing, serving, or eating food.
Ne ènyè, èkpe kpe alo fi mitsi.
After sneezing, coughing, or blowing your nose.
Ne èka asi lã aɖe ŋu alo lãmi aɖe ŋu.
After touching an animal or animal waste.
Ne èbla gbeɖuɖɔ alo tsɔe ƒu gbe.
After handling garbage.
Mele be nàklɔ asi ɖewoɖewoe o.
And do not take it for granted that you are cleaning your hands properly.
Numekukuwo ɖee fia be ame siwo yia dugazewo la dometɔ akpa gãtɔ meklɔa asi nyuie ne wode afɔdzi o eye ame aɖewo meklɔnɛ gɔ̃ hã o.
Studies have shown that a large percentage of those who use public toilets do not wash their hands afterward or do not wash them correctly.
Aleke wòle be nàklɔ asie?
How should you wash your hands?
Kɔ tsi dzadzɛ ɖe asi dzi eye nàwɔ adzalẽ ɖe asi me.
Wet your hands in clean running water and apply soap.
Nɔ asiawo klɔm, ɖo ŋku edzi nàɖe fetuwo kple degblefetsuwo me nyuie, klɔ wò asimegbewo kple asitomewo.
Rub your hands together to make a lather, not forgetting to clean your nails, your thumbs, the backs of your hands, and between your fingers.
Wɔe sekɛnd 20 ya teti.
Keep rubbing for at least 20 seconds.
Azɔ kɔ tsi ɖe asi dzi nàkpalae.
Rinse in clean running water.
Tsɔ asitutunu kɔkɔe alo pepatakuvi tutu asi.
Dry with a clean cloth or a paper towel.
Mɔnu siawo le bɔbɔe gake woate ŋu akpɔ tawò tso dɔléle si me eye wòakpɔ wò agbe ta.
Such measures are simple but can avert illness and save lives.
2 ZÃ TSI SI LE DZADZƐE
2 USE A SAFE WATER SUPPLY
Kɔpo si me tsi dzadzɛ le kple dɔŋuti tsotsoe
A glass of clean water and pieces of lemon
Le dukɔ aɖewo me la, avu kple kɔe wònyena na ƒome aɖewo be woakpɔ tsi nyui azã.
Obtaining sufficient clean water for one’s family is a regular chore in some countries.
Ke hã, tsi nyui kpɔkpɔ ate ŋu azu kuxi le xexemedukɔ ɖe sia ɖe me, elabena tɔɖɔɖɔ, ahom, pɔmpiwo ƒe gbagbã kple nu bubuwo ate ŋu ana tsi nyui siwo amewo nona la me naƒo ɖi.

Yet, access to clean water can become a concern in any part of the world when a main supply that is usually good to drink becomes contaminated as a result of a flood, a storm, a pipe break, or some other issue.
Ne afi si wokpɔa tsiawo tso alo nu siwo me wokɔa wo ɖo me mele dzadzɛe o la, ate ŋu ana amewo nalé dɔ siwo nye koléra, mitsinyenyedɔ siwo tea ŋu wua ame, asrã sesẽ, aklãdɔ kple dɔléle bubuwo.
If water does not come from a safe source or is not stored correctly, it can cause parasite infestation, as well as cholera, life-threatening diarrhea, typhoid, hepatitis, and other infections.
Wobu akɔnta be tsi nyui ƒe anyimanɔmanɔ nana ame miliɔn 1,700 xɔa mitsinyenyedɔwo ƒe sia ƒe.
Unsafe drinking water is one of the causes of an estimated 1.7 billion cases of diarrheal disease every year.
Nu geɖewo li nàte ŋu awɔ be dɔlélewo makpɔ ŋusẽ boo ɖe dziwò o alo nàƒo asa na wo keŋkeŋ
There is much you can do to slow down or prevent the onset of illness
Zi geɖe la, amewo xɔa koléra nenye be wono tsi siwo me ame siwo ŋuti dɔ sia le la de afɔdzi ɖo alo ɖu nu siwo tsi siawo ƒomevi ƒo ɖii.
Cholera is most often contracted when a person drinks water or eats food that is contaminated with fecal matter from infected people.
Nu kawoe nàte ŋu awɔ atsɔ akpɔ ɖokuiwò ta tso dɔ sia kple bubuwo si me nenye be dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo dzɔ teti gɔ̃ hã?
What steps can you take to protect yourself, even in the immediate aftermath of a disaster, from this and other types of water contamination?

Kpɔ egbɔ be tsi siwo nèzãna na numekɔklɔ, nuɖuɖuwo kple agbawo kɔklɔ, nuɖaɖa alo tsikpewɔwɔ la le dzadzɛe, ate ŋu anye pɔmpitsi si woléa be na nyuie alo aŋetukpametsi siwo adzɔha siwo ŋu kakaɖedzi le la wɔ.

Ensure that all your drinking water including the water used for brushing teeth, making ice, washing food and dishes, or cooking comes from a safe source, such as an adequately treated public supply or sealed bottles from a reputable firm.
Ne ewɔ na wò be yewoƒe pɔmpitsia mele dzadzɛe o la, ke ɖa tsia alo de atike siwo wua dɔlékui le tsi me la tsia me hafi nàzãe.
If there is any possibility that your piped supply has been contaminated, boil your water before use or treat it with an appropriate chemical product.
Ne èbe yeazã atike siwo wotsɔ dzaa tsi me abe klorine kple esia tɔgbi ene la, wɔ ɖe atikeawo wɔlawo ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi pɛpɛpɛ.
When using chemicals, such as chlorine or water-purifying tablets, follow the maker’s directions carefully.
Zã tsitsyɔnu adodoewo ne ɖe li alo ne womexɔ asi fũu akpa o.
Use quality water filters, if available and affordable.
Ne nu siwo wotsɔ dzaa tsi me meli o la, ke de ɖiɖetike (bleach alo l’eau de Javel) gege toŋtoŋ eve ɖe tsi lita ɖeka me, blu tsia me nyuie, eye nàda tsia ɖi miniti 30 hafi nàzãe.
If no water-treatment products are available, add household bleach, eight drops per gallon of water (two drops per liter), mix well, and then let the water stand for 30 minutes before using it.
Kɔ tsi nyuiwo alo tsi siwo nèɖa la ɖe nu siwo me kɔ me eye nàtu nu wo nu nyuie ale be dɔlékui aɖeke nagage ɖe wo me o.
Always store treated water in clean, covered containers to protect it from possible recontamination.
Kpɔ egbɔ be nu sia nu si nàtsɔ aku tsi le tsigoa me la le dzadzɛe.
Ensure that any vessel used to take water from your stored supply, such as a ladle, is clean.
Asiwò nekɔ hafi nàlé nu siwo me tsi dzadzɛwo le eye mègade asi tsi nono me o.
Handle water containers with clean hands, and do not dip your hands or fingers into water used for drinking.
3 LÉ ŊKU ÐE WÒ NUÐUÐUWO ŊU
3 WATCH WHAT YOU EAT
Agblemenuku nyui vovovowo
A variety of wholesome foods from different food groups
Mímate ŋu anɔ lãmesẽ me ne mímeɖua nu nyuie o, eye nuɖuɖu nyuie bia be míaɖu nu siwo me nunyiame vovovowo le.
Good health is impossible without good nutrition, and for good nutrition you need a healthy, balanced diet.
Ele be nàlé ŋku ɖe dze, ami, sukli kple nuɖuɖu agbɔsɔsɔme si nèɖuna ŋu.
You may need to consider your intake of salt, fats, and sugar, and you should watch your portion sizes.
Nɔ atikutsetsewo kple amagbewo ɖum, eye nɔ nu vovovowo ɖum.
Include fruits and vegetables in your diet, and vary what you eat.
Ne èxlẽa nu siwo woŋlɔ ɖe nuɖuɖuwo abe yevubolo, nukuwo, makaroni alo mɔlu ene dzi hafi ƒlea wo la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàtia nuɖuɖu siwo wowɔ kple nuku blibowo.
Reading the packaging will help you to select whole-grain foods when buying bread, cereals, pasta, or rice.
Nunyiame kple ŋutilãtuɖonu geɖe nɔa nuɖuɖu siwo wotsɔ nuku blibowo wɔ la me wu nuɖuɖu siwo wotsɔ nuku siwo ŋu wotrɔ asi le la wɔ.
These are richer in nutrients and fiber than the alternatives made from refined grain.
Ðu ʋulã alo koklolã ƒe akpa siwo ami menɔna o la ƒe sue aɖe eye nàdze agbagba aɖu tɔmelã zi eve le kwasiɖaa me ne anya wɔ.
As for proteins, eat small and lean portions of meat and poultry and try to eat fish a couple of times a week, if possible.
Le dukɔ aɖewo me la, woate ŋu akpɔ nunyiame siwo nɔa lãwo me le amagbewo hã me.
In some lands it is also possible to find protein-rich foods from vegetable sources.
Ne èɖua suklinu alo aminu akpa la, ate ŋu ana nàlolo.
If you eat too many sugars and solid fats, you risk becoming overweight.
Eya ta no tsi ɖe aha viviwo teƒe.
To minimize this risk, drink water instead of sweet beverages.
Ðu atikutsetse geɖe wu numeɖenu viviwo.
Eat more fruit instead of sugary desserts.
Ðe sausage (saucisse), ʋulã, nyinotsi babla kple akpɔnɔviviwo ɖuɖu dzi kpɔtɔ ale be ami magasɔ gbɔ ɖe lãme na wò o.
Limit your intake of solid fats from such items as sausages, meat, butter, cakes, cheese, and cookies.
Le esi nàzã ami kpekewo atsɔ aɖa nu teƒe la, zã ami siwo dea lãmesẽ dzi boŋ.
And instead of using solid fats for cooking, you may want to use healthier oils.
Dzeɖuɖu fũu ate ŋu ana nàxɔ ʋusɔgbɔdɔ.
Too much salt, or sodium, in the diet can raise your blood pressure to an unhealthy level.
Eya ta ne èɖua dze fũu la, ke xlẽ nu si woŋlɔ ɖe nuɖuɖuawo ƒe akpa dzi ne nàkpɔ dze agbɔsɔsɔ si wode wo me ale be dze nagasɔ gbɔ fũu ɖe lãme na wò o.
If this is your problem, use the information on food packaging to keep your sodium intake low.
Eya ta zã amagbewo kple nu ʋeʋĩwo ɖe dze teƒe.
Instead of salt, use herbs and spices to flavor your meals.
Nu agbɔsɔsɔ si nèɖuna hã le vevie ko abe nu siwo nèɖuna ke ene.
How much you eat can be as important as what you eat.
Eya ta ne nuɖuɖua le nuwò vivim hã la, mègayi eɖuɖu dzi ne èɖi ƒo o.
So, while enjoying your food, do not keep eating after you are no longer hungry.
Nu bubu si ŋu wòle be nàlé ŋku ɖo le wò nuɖunyawo gome hãe nye nuɖuɖu siwo me dɔlékuiwo le.
An issue tied to nutrition is the risk of food poisoning.
Ne womeɖa nuwo nyuie alo lé be na wo nyuie o la, dɔlékuiwo ate ŋu anɔ wo me agblẽ nu le ŋuwò.
Any food can poison you if it is not prepared and stored properly.
Ƒe sia ƒe la, Amerikatɔ 1 le 6 me xɔa dɔlékuiwo le nu siwo woɖuna me.
Every year, 1 out of every 6 Americans falls sick from food poisoning.
Wo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ hayana ya, gake wo dometɔ aɖewo hã kuna.
Most recover without lasting ill effects, but some die from it.
Nu kae nàte ŋu awɔ atsɔ aɖe afɔku sia dzi akpɔtɔ?
What can you do to minimize the risk?
Wotea ŋu tsɔa lãmiwo nyroa anyigba hafi doa amagbewo ɖe wo dzi, eya ta hafi nàɖu amagbewo la, klɔ wo nyuie.
Vegetables grow in soil that may have been treated with manure, so wash these items carefully before preparing them.
Tsɔ tsi dzodzoe kple adzalẽ klɔ asi, nuɖanuwo kple agbawo nyuie eye nàklɔ kplɔ̃wo kple nu siwo dzi nètso nuɖuɖu aɖe le la dzi nyuie hafi nàgazãe na nu bubu le nua ɖaɣi.
Wash your hands, cutting board, utensils, dishes, and countertops with hot, soapy water before preparing each item.
Be nàƒo asa na dɔlékuiwo kaka la, mègada nuɖuɖu ɖe nu si dzi nèda nuɖuɖu siwo womeɖa o abe koklozi mumu, koklolã, ʋulã kple tɔmelãwo ene la dzi ne mèklɔ edzi o.
To avoid cross-contamination, never put food on a surface or plate that was previously in contact with raw eggs, poultry, meat, or fish, without first washing that surface.
Ða nuwo woabi nyuie, eye nàde nuɖuɖu siwo gblẽna kaba siwo màɖu enumake o la nufamɔ̃ me.
Cook until the food reaches the right temperature, and promptly refrigerate any perishable items that are not going to be eaten immediately.

Tsɔ nuɖuɖu siwo gblẽna kaba dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe si wogblẽ ɖe nuvo wòwu gaƒoƒo eve la ƒu gbe, eye ne wogblẽ nuɖuɖu aɖe ɖe nuvo ɖe afi si yame ƒe dzoxɔxɔ sɔ gbɔ wu Celsius 32 wòde gaƒoƒo ɖeka la, tsɔe ƒu gbe.
Discard perishable items left at room temperature for more than two hours or one hour if air temperature exceeds 90 degrees Fahrenheit (32°C).
4 NƆ KAME DEM
4 STAY PHYSICALLY ACTIVE
Bɔl kple bɔlƒofɔkpa eve
A soccer ball and a pair of soccer shoes
Ƒe ka kee nèɖaxɔ o, ehiã be nànɔ kame dem be nànɔ lãmesẽ me.
Regardless of your age, you need regular physical activity to stay in good shape.
Egbea la, ame geɖewo medea kame fũu o.
Many people today do not exercise enough.
Nu ka tae kamedede le vevie?
Why is exercise important?
Kamedede ate ŋu:
Staying physically active can help you to:
Ana nàdɔ alɔ̃ nyuie.
Sleep well.
Ana agbe nanɔ mewò.
Stay mobile.
Ana be ŋusẽ nanɔ wò ƒuwo kple lãkusiwo ŋu.
Maintain strong bones and muscles.
Ana be mànɔ lolom ɖe edzi o.
Maintain or achieve a healthy weight.
Aɖe blanuiléle dzi akpɔtɔ.
Lower your risk of suffering from depression.
Aɖe kukpokuku dzi akpɔtɔ.
Lower your risk of premature death.
Ne mèdea kame o la, ate ŋu:
If you do not stay physically active, you are more likely to:
Ana be nàxɔ dzidɔ.
Suffer from heart disease.
Ana nàxɔ suklidɔ alo aɖuɖɔvividɔ.
Suffer from type 2 diabetes.
Ana nàxɔ ʋusɔgbɔdɔ.
Develop high blood pressure.
Ana be ami nasɔ gbɔ ɖe lãme na wò.
Develop high cholesterol.
Ana nàxɔ gbagbadɔ.
Suffer a stroke.
Kamedefefe si asɔ na wò la anɔ te ɖe ƒe si nèxɔ kple wò lãmesẽ dzi. Eya ta anyo be nàdzro eme kple wò ɖɔkta hafi nàte kamedefefe yeyewo kpɔ.
The kind of physical activity that is right for you depends on your age and your health, so it would be wise to consult your doctor before beginning any new exercise program.
Atikeŋutinunyala geɖewo ɖo aɖaŋu be ele be ɖeviwo kple sɔhɛwo nakpɔ gome le kamedefefe bɔbɔewo kple sesẽwo siaa me miniti 60 ya teti gbe sia gbe.
According to various recommendations, children and adolescents should get at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous activity every day.
Eye ame tsitsiwo ya nakpɔ gome le kamedefefe bɔbɔewo me miniti 150 alo kamedefefe sesẽwo me miniti 75 kwasiɖa sia kwasiɖa.
Adults should get 150 minutes of moderate activity or 75 minutes of vigorous activity every week.
Tia kamedefefe si doa dzidzɔ na wò.
Choose an activity that is fun.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye baskɛtbɔlƒoƒo, tenis-ƒoƒo, afɔbɔlƒoƒo, azɔlizɔzɔ sesĩe, gasɔdodo, abɔdɔwɔwɔ, nakedzedze, tsiƒuƒu, tɔdziʋukuku, duƒuƒu kple bubuwo.
You might consider basketball, tennis, soccer, brisk walking, cycling, gardening, chopping wood, swimming, canoeing, jogging, or other aerobic exercise.
Aleke nàwɔ ade vovototo kamedefefe bɔbɔewo kple kamedefefe sesẽwo dome?
How can you tell whether an activity is moderate or vigorous?
Kamedefefe bɔbɔewo nana ame tea fifia, gake ne wole gome kpɔm le kamedefefe sesẽwo ya me la, dzeɖoɖo sesẽna.
A general guide would be that moderate activity makes you sweat, but more vigorous exercise makes it hard for you to hold a conversation while doing it.
5 DƆ ALƆ̃ NYUIE
5 GET ENOUGH SLEEP
Xɔ dɔme si naa ame ƒe susu me dzea akɔ anyi
A quiet and relaxing bedroom
AME sia ame kple alɔ̃ agbɔsɔsɔme si wòhiã.
The amount of sleep needed varies from person to person.
Gbe sia gbe la, vidzĩ akpa gãtɔ dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 16 va se ɖe 18, ɖevi dzeazɔliwo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 14, ɖevi siwo mekpɔ dze suku gɔme o dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 11 alo 12.
Most newborns sleep for 16 to 18 hours a day, toddlers about 14 hours, and preschoolers about 11 or 12.
Zi geɖe la, ɖevi siwo dze suku gɔme la dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 10, sɔhɛwo tea ŋu dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 9 alo 10, eye ame tsitsiwo dɔa alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo 7 va se ɖe 8.
School-age children generally need at least 10 hours of sleep, adolescents perhaps 9 or 10, and adults from 7 to 8.
Alɔ̃ agbɔsɔsɔ si hiã dɔdɔ le vevie.
Getting the right amount of rest should not be considered optional.
Numekulawo gblɔ be alɔ̃ agbɔsɔsɔme si hiã dɔdɔ le vevie hena:
According to experts, sufficient sleep is important for:
Ðeviwo kple sɔhɛwo ƒe tsitsi nyuie.
Growth and development in children and teenagers.
Nusɔsrɔ̃ kple nyatakaka yeyewo léle ɖe susu me.
Learning and retention of new information.
Lãmetsi siwo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe nuɖuɖu ƒe dɔwɔwɔ nyuie kple míaƒe kpekpeme dzi la ƒe dɔwɔwɔ ɖe ɖoɖo nu.
Maintaining the right balance of hormones that impact metabolism and weight.
Dzi ƒe dɔwɔwɔ nyuie.
Cardiovascular health.
Mɔxexe ɖe dɔlélewo nu.
Disease prevention.
Wogblɔna be alɔ̃madɔmadɔ nyuie tea ŋu hea lolo fũu akpa, blanuiléledɔ, dzidɔ, suklidɔ kple afɔku dziŋɔwo vɛ.
Insufficient sleep has been linked to obesity, depression, heart disease, diabetes, and tragic accidents.
Esiawo katã na míekpɔe be ele vevie be míadɔ alɔ̃ wòasu mí.
Surely these give us good reason to want to get enough rest.
Eya ta nu kae nàte ŋu awɔ ne èkpɔe be yemetea ŋu dɔa alɔ̃ nyuie o?
So, what can you do if you realize that you have a problem getting enough sleep?
Dze agbagba nànɔ anyi mlɔm ɖe game ɖeka aɖe koŋ dzi ahanɔ fɔfɔm ɖe game ɖeka aɖe koŋ dzi gbe sia gbe.
Try to go to bed and get up at the same time every day.
Mègana toɣliɖeɖe aɖeke nanɔ wò xɔ me o, tsi akaɖiwo, xɔa me nanɔ ɖoɖo nu, eye eme megafa akpa alo axɔ dzo akpa o.
Make your bedroom quiet, dark, relaxing, and neither too warm nor too cold.
Mèganɔ aba dzi le anyimlɔɣi hafi anɔ television kpɔm alo elektrɔnik-nuwo zãm o.
Do not watch TV or use gadgets while in bed.
Na wò aba nanye esi dzi nàmlɔ aɖe dzi ɖi.
Make your bed as comfortable as possible.
Mègaɖu nu kpekpe alo ano aha sesẽ alo nu siwo me kafein le le anyimlɔɣi o.
Avoid heavy meals, caffeine, and alcohol before bedtime.

Ne èzɔ ɖe mɔfiame siawo katã dzi tso gake mègate ŋu le alɔ̃ dɔm nyuie o alo alɔ̃dɔkuxiwo, abe alɔ̃tsɔame vevie le ŋkeke me alo gbɔgbɔmasuame le alɔ̃ me ene gakpɔtɔ le fu ɖem na wò la, anyo be nàkpɔ atikewɔla bibi aɖe.

If after applying these suggestions you still suffer from insomnia or other sleep disorders such as excessive daytime sleepiness or gasping for breath while sleeping you may want to consult a qualified health-care professional.
KPƆ WÒ LÃMESẼ TA!
SAFEGUARD YOUR HEALTH!
Nɔnɔme siwo ŋu màte ŋu awɔ naneke le o la woe kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe wò lãmesẽ dzi. Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ganyawo, nuhiahiãwo ƒe anyimanɔmanɔ kple bubuawo.
Your health is affected by realities over which you have no control such as economic conditions, the availability of resources, and so on.
Gake eɖanye aleke kee nɔnɔmeawo le o, anɔ eme godoo be àte ŋu awɔ ɖe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo me míedzro le nyati sia me la dometɔ aɖewo dzi.
In all likelihood, however, it should be within your means to adopt at least some of the suggestions given in the foregoing article.
Nunyala aɖe si nɔ anyi le blema la gblɔ be, "aɖaŋudzela kpɔa afɔku gbɔna eye wòɣlaa eɖokui. "
As a wise man of ancient times put it, "the shrewd one sees the danger and conceals himself. "
Lododowo 22:3.
Proverbs 22:3.

Ŋugbedodo si ŋu kakaɖedzi le si nye be "dua me tɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, ‘Mele dɔ lém’ o " la faa akɔ na ame siwo xlẽa Biblia. (Yesaya 33:24) Gake fifia ya la, wɔ wò ŋutete katã be nàkpɔ wò kple wò ame veviwo ƒe lãmesẽ ta.

Readers of the Holy Scriptures are comforted by the trustworthy promise that one day soon, "no resident will say: ‘I am sick.’ " (Isaiah 33:24) In the meantime, do all you can to safeguard your health and that of your loved ones.
Dɔlélewo Ale Si Míaɖe Wo Dzi Akpɔtɔ
Disease How to Reduce the Risk
Míaƒe ametia wɔa avu kple futɔ aɖewo siwo ate ŋu awu mí evɔ míekpɔa wo alo sea wo ŋkɔ o la gbe sia gbe.
Every day your body wages war against enemies that are silent and unseen but potentially deadly.
Dɔlékui vovovowo gena ɖe lãme na mí siwo gblẽa nu le míaƒe lãmesẽ ŋu.
Foreign invaders, such as bacteria, viruses, and parasites, threaten your health.
Míate ŋu anya ale si tututu ŋutilãa wɔa avu kple dɔlékui siawo o, elabena míaƒe ametia tsia dɔlékuiawo nu alo wua wo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ hafi woayi nu gblẽ ge le mía ŋu.
You are not likely to be aware of those battles because your immune system repels or destroys most of the invaders before the onset of symptoms.
Gake ɣeaɖewoɣi la, dɔlékui vɔ̃ɖi aɖewo ɖua dzi.
Sometimes, however, the harmful germs gain the upper hand.
Ne edzɔ alea la, ahiã be nàno atike alo azã dɔdamɔnu aɖewo be woado ŋusẽ wò ametia.
If so, you may need to bolster your defenses with medicine and other treatments.
Nu vovovo siwo ate ŋu ana míadze dɔ dometɔ aɖewoe nye, mɔzɔzɔ, nugbagbevi suesuesue siwo ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o, ahedada kple nuɖuɖu siwo womelé be na nyuie o
Various causes of disease, including travel, microscopic organisms, poverty, and improperly prepared food
Ƒe akpe geɖewo va yi la, amewo menya nu boo aɖeke tso ale si dɔlékui siwo ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o la gblẽa nu le ame ŋu la ŋu o.
For thousands of years, people knew virtually nothing about the dangers of microscopic or other small harmful organisms.
Emegbe le ƒe alafa 19 lia me la, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo va ɖo kpe ale si dɔlékuiwo nana míedzea dɔ la dzi eye esia na míeva kpɔ ale si wòhiã be míakpɔ mía ɖokuiwo ta la dze sii.
However, when 19th-century scientists confirmed the link between germs and disease, we became better equipped to defend ourselves.
Tso ɣemaɣi la, dɔdada ŋuti numekulawo dze agbagba be yewoaɖe dɔxɔleameŋu aɖewo abe sakpate kple ɖevimetutudɔ dzi akpɔtɔ alo aɖe wo ɖa kura.
Medical researchers have since eliminated or greatly reduced the threat of some infectious diseases, including smallpox and polio.
Ke hã, nyitsɔ laa la, dɔlélewo abe ŋudza ƒomevi aɖe kple ƒunukpeƒeŋudza gatrɔ gbɔ.
Recently, however, others, such as yellow fever and dengue, have made a comeback.
Nu ka gbɔe wòtso?
Why?
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider these factors:
Ƒe sia ƒe la ame akpe geɖe zɔa mɔ yia teƒeteƒewo le xexea me godoo, eye zi geɖe la, dɔlékuiwo nɔa wo ŋu wotsɔ nɔa yiyim.
Every year, millions of people travel around the globe, often transporting disease-causing agents.

Nyati aɖe si wota ɖe magazine aɖe (Clinical Infectious Diseases) me gblɔ be: "Esi yameʋuwo tsoa dukɔ ɖeka me yia bubu me le ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe me ta la, amewo kakaa dɔléle vɔ̃ɖiwo kabakaba le manyamanya me. "
According to an article in the journal Clinical Infectious Diseases, "virtually all of the contagious virulent infections " can be spread by international travelers.
Dɔlékui aɖewo megasea atike o.
Some bacteria have developed resistance to antibiotics.
Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔ ka nya ta be: "Xexea ɖo ta teƒe aɖe si dɔlélewo magase atike o si awɔe be dɔléle siwo wokpɔ atike na tsã la nagate amewuwu. "
"The world is heading towards a post-antibiotic era, in which common infections . . . can once again kill, " states the World Health Organization.
Dukɔwo me zitɔtɔ kple ahedada na wòle sesẽm na dziɖuɖuwo be woatsi ale si dɔlélewo le kakam la nu.
Civil unrest and poverty often hinder government efforts to control the spread of disease.
Ame geɖewo menya nu siwo tututu woawɔ be woatsi dɔlélewo nu o.
Many people lack practical knowledge of how to prevent disease.
Togbɔ be nɔnɔme siawo katã li hã la, àte ŋu awɔ wò akpa dzi be nàkpɔ ɖokuiwò kple wò ƒomea ta.
Despite these disturbing trends, there is much you can do to protect yourself and your family.
Nyati si kplɔe ɖo la afia mí be le dukɔ madeŋgɔwo gɔ̃ hã me la, míate ŋu azã mɔnu bɔbɔe siwo wɔa dɔ atsɔ atsi dɔlélewo nu.
The following will show that, even if you live in a developing land, simple and effective strategies may be within your reach.
Nɔnɔme Si Le Asiwò Ye Ana Nàkpɔ Dzidzɔ!
Attitude Makes a Difference!
Nu etɔ̃ siawo dometɔ kae ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ?
Which of the following do you think has the biggest effect on your happiness?
Nɔnɔme si me nèle
your circumstances
Ame si ƒomevi nènye
your genes
Nɔnɔme si anɔ asiwò
your attitude
AME aɖewo atia, "nɔnɔme si me nèle, " ɖewohĩ woagblɔ be, "makpɔ dzidzɔ geɖe . . . "
SOME would choose "circumstances, " perhaps saying, "I would be happy . . .
"Ne ga geɖe le asinye "
"if only I had more money "
"Ne mekpɔ srɔ̃ nyui aɖe ɖe "
"if only I had a great marriage "
"Ne mele lãmesẽ me "
"if only I had better health "
Le nyateƒe me la, nɔnɔme si anɔ asiwò ye ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ ke menye nɔnɔme si me nèle alo ame si ƒomevi nènye o.
In reality, though, attitude often trumps circumstances and genes when it comes to happiness.
Eye esia nye dzidzɔnya.
And that is good news.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
To vovo na nɔnɔme si me nèle kple ame si ƒomevi nènye siwo ŋu màte ŋu awɔ naneke le o la, àte ŋu awɔ nane tso nɔnɔme si le asiwò ya ŋu.
Because unlike your circumstances or your genes over which you have little or no control you can control your attitude.
"ATIKE NYUI "
"GOOD MEDICINE "
Biblia me lododo aɖe gblɔ be: "Dzi kpɔdzi- dzɔ nye atike nyui, ke gbɔgbɔ si dzi nu te ɖo vevie la nana ŋusẽ vɔna le ame ŋu. "
A Bible proverb states: "A joyful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit saps one’s strength. "
(Lododowo 17:22) Ne míagblɔe bubui la, nɔnɔme si anɔ asiwò ye ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ loo alo makpɔ dzidzɔ o!
(Proverbs 17:22) In other words, your attitude makes a difference!
Ate ŋu ana nàɖo wò taɖodzinu aɖe gbɔ loo alo màɖo egbɔ o; alo ate ŋu ana be nànɔ te ɖe nɔnɔmewo nu ne nya vɔ̃ aɖe dzɔ ɖe dziwò loo alo be dzi naɖe le ƒowò.
It can affect whether you attain a goal or give up or whether a tragic event brings out the best in you or the worst.
Asesẽ na ame aɖewo be woaxɔe ase be nɔnɔme si anɔ ame si ye ana wòakpɔ dzidzɔ loo alo makpɔe o.
Some people might be skeptical of that idea.
Woagblɔ be:
They might reason:
‘Nu ka tae manɔ fu kpem evɔ ahanɔ mɔ kpɔm be nuwo ava nyo?’
‘Why hide my hardships behind a mask of optimism?’
‘Ne mele mɔ kpɔm be nuwo ava nyo nam hã la, mɔkpɔkpɔ dzodzro koe wònye.’
‘No amount of positive thinking will change my situation.’
‘Ele be mawɔ nu ɖe ale si tututu nɔnɔmea le nu tsɔ wu be manɔ drɔ̃e kum be nuwo ava nyo.’
‘I would rather be a realist than a dreamer.’
Adze abe susu le nya siawo me ene.
Those thoughts might seem valid.
Ke hã, eɖea vi ne míekpɔa mɔ be nuwo ava nyo.
Still, there are benefits to adopting a positive outlook.
Na míade ŋugble le kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna ŋu kpɔ.
To illustrate, consider the following scenarios.
Alex kple Brian wɔa dɔ le dɔwɔƒe ɖeka, gake wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kple dɔ si wòwɔna.
At their place of employment, Alex and Brian each work hard on separate projects.
Esi woƒe dɔdzikpɔlaa va lé ŋku ɖe woƒe dɔwo ŋu la, ehe woƒe susu yi vodada aɖewo siwo le woƒe dɔwo ŋu la dzi.
After analyzing their work, the supervisor points out key errors in each project.
Alex
Alex
Alex: "Mewɔ nye ŋutetewo katã hezã ɣeyiɣi geɖe ɖe dɔ sia ŋu, gake wogakpɔ vodada le eŋu kokoko!
Alex: "I put so much time and effort into this project, and I still didn’t get it right!
Nyemate ŋu awɔ dɔ sia nyuie gbeɖe o.
I’ll never succeed at this job.
Ne meku kutri le eŋu hã la, gbeɖegbeɖea koe.
No matter how hard I work, it’s never good enough.
Nu ka tae wòle be magayi ewɔwɔ dzi? "
Why do I even try? "
Brian
Brian
Brian: "Nye dɔtɔ ƒo nu tso nye dɔa ƒe akpa si mewɔ nyuie la ŋu, ke hã mewɔ vodada ɖeka eve aɖewo.
Brian: "My boss highlighted aspects of my work that he liked, but I made a few fundamental mistakes.
Mesrɔ̃ nu vevi aɖewo le aɖaŋu si wòɖo nam la me si akpe ɖe ŋunye mawɔ dɔa nyuie ɣebubuɣi. "
I’ve learned some valuable lessons that will help me do better next time. "
NU KAE NÈSUSU?
WHAT DO YOU THINK?
Ame eve siawo dometɔ kae akpɔ dzidzedze le eƒe dɔa me le ɣleti ade megbe, Alex loo alo Brian?
Six months from now, which one will be a more capable employee Alex or Brian?
Ne ènye dɔtɔ ɖe, ame eve siawo dometɔ kae nàdi be yeaxɔ ɖe dɔ me alo ne èva hiã be nàtso dɔwɔlawo dzi la, eka ŋue nàɖe asi le?
If you were an employer, which of those two men would you be more likely to hire or keep on your payroll?
Ne nuwo meyi nyuie abe ale si nèkpɔ mɔe ene o la, ame eve siawo dometɔ kae wò nuwɔnawo ɖina?
When you face disappointment, which of those two men do you react like?
Blanuilédɔ dzea Andrea kple Brittney dzi ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Andrea and Brittney suffer from bouts of loneliness.
Wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kple ale si wònɔa te ɖe enui.
Each of them has a different way of coping with the situation.
Andrea
Andrea
Andrea ƒe susu katã nɔa eɖokui ŋu.
Andrea focuses most of her attention on herself.
Melɔ̃na be yeawɔ naneke na ame aɖeke o negbe ɖe ame aɖe wɔ nane nɛ ko hafi.
She refuses to do things for others unless they do things for her first.
Esusuna be, ‘nu ka tae wòle be magblẽ ɣeyiɣi ɖe ame siwo mawɔ naneke wòaɖe vi nam o la ŋu?’
She reasons, ‘Why should I waste my time on people who give me nothing in return?’
Brittney
Brittney
Brittney ya dzea agbagba vevie be yeanyo dɔme na amewo ahawɔ nu siwo aɖe vi na wo, ne wokpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe eŋu alo womekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe eŋu o hã.
Brittney makes a concerted effort to be kind to people and to do things for others, whether they seem appreciative or not.
Enɔa agbe ɖe Sikasededea nu si nye be ewɔa nu ɖe amewo ŋu abe ale si wòadi be woawɔ nu ɖe ye ŋu ene.
She lives by the Golden Rule to treat others as she would like to be treated.
(Luka 6:31) Le Brittney gome la, nu nyui geɖe doa go tsoa nyuiwɔwɔ na amewo me.
(Luke 6:31) For Brittney, doing good is its own reward.
NU KAE NÈSUSU?
WHAT DO YOU THINK?
Nyɔnu eve siawo dometɔ kae nàdi be wòanye xɔ̃wò?
Which of these two women would you rather have as a friend?
Wo dometɔ kae anɔ ƒomedodo nyui me kple amewo?
Which one is more likely to feel satisfied with her relationships?
Ne èlea blanui ɣeaɖewoɣi la, ɖe nèwɔa nu abe Andrea ene loo alo abe Brittney enea?
If you suffer from bouts of loneliness, is your approach more like Andrea’s or more like Brittney’s?
Ðewohĩ ànya ame aɖewo siwo wɔa nu abe Brian kple Brittney ene.
You probably know people who fit the profile of Brian and Brittney.
Ðewohĩ àse le ɖokuiwò me be yewɔa nu abe woawo ene.
You might even feel that you are like them.
Ne ele nenema la, àkpɔe be nɔnɔme si anɔ asiwò ye ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ le agbe me loo alo makpɔe o.
If so, undoubtedly you can see that your attitude can make a difference in your life.
Ke ne èwɔa nu abe Alex alo Andrea ene ɖe?
On the other hand, what if you are more like Alex or Andrea?
Na míade ŋugble tso mɔ etɔ̃ siwo nu Biblia ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe agbemekuxiwo nu nyuie wu la ŋu.
Consider three ways the Bible can help you to adopt a more positive view of life’s struggles.
1 MÈGANƆ MƆ KPƆM BE NUWO MANYO O
1 AVOID PESSIMISM
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Ne dzi ɖe le ƒowò le xaxagbe la, ekema wò ŋusẽ dzi aɖe kpɔtɔ. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "If you become discouraged in the day of distress, your strength will be meager. "
Lododowo 24:10.
Proverbs 24:10.
NU SI WÒFIA: Dziɖeleameƒo mana nàkpɔ ŋusẽ atsɔ aɖe afɔ siwo hiã aɖɔ nɔnɔmea ɖo loo alo akpɔ kpekpeɖeŋu atsɔ anɔ te ɖe nɔnɔmea nu o.
WHAT IT MEANS: Pessimism will sap you of the strength you need to improve your situation or to help you deal with it.
Juliza
Juliza
KPƆÐEŊU: Juliza mekpɔ dzidzɔ aɖeke tso eƒe ɖevime o.
EXAMPLE: Juliza’s childhood was anything but happy.
Fofoa nye ahanoxe, eye eƒe ƒomea da ahe.
Her father was an alcoholic, and her family was poor.
Woʋuna tsoa teƒe yia teƒe.
They moved from place to place.
Gbã la, Juliza mekpɔa mɔ be nuwo ava nyo o.
At first, Juliza was pessimistic about her lot in life.
Gake etrɔ eƒe susu.
But that changed.
Nu kae kpe ɖe eŋu?
What helped?
Juliza gblɔ be, "Hafi dzinyelawo nawɔ asitɔtrɔ le woƒe agbenɔnɔ ŋu wòanyo la, Biblia kpe ɖe ŋunye mɔkpɔkpɔ su asinye le agbe me.
"Even before my parents overcame their difficulties, " Juliza says, "the Bible helped me to improve my outlook.
Va se ɖe egbea la, Biblia me nyawo kpena ɖe ŋunye be nyemebua dziɖeleameƒonuwo ŋu o.
And to this day, thoughts from the Bible keep my thinking from spiraling downward.
Fifia ne amewo ɖe nɔnɔme manyomanyo aɖe fia la, medzea agbagba be mase nu si ta wowɔ nu nenema ɖo la gɔme. "
Now, when people display traits I don’t like, I try to understand why they behave the way they do. "
Abe ale si Juliza va srɔ̃e ene la, mɔfiame nyui geɖewo le Biblia me.
As Juliza learned, the Bible is a book of sound principles.
Eƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe nɔnɔme madeamedziwo nu.
Its advice can help you to cope with negative circumstances.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔ le Efesotɔwo 4:23 be: "Minɔ miaƒe tamesusu ƒe nɔnɔme si kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe mia dzi wɔm yeyee. "
For example, Ephesians 4:23 says: "Continue to be made new in your dominant mental attitude. "
Abe ale si mawunyakpukpui sia gblɔe ene la, àte ŋu awɔ nane le wò nɔnɔmewo ŋu.
As that verse implies, your outlook is not set in stone.
Àte ŋu anɔ nɔnɔme si kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe dziwò la "wɔm yeyee. "
You can "be made new " in your thinking.
Eya ta tɔtrɔwo wɔwɔ nye nu si wòle be nànɔ wɔwɔm ɖaa.
However, making such a change is an ongoing process.
Esia tae mawunyakpukpuia gblɔ be míayi edzi anɔ míaƒe ‘tamesusu ƒe nɔnɔme si kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe mía dzi wɔm yeyee.’
That is why the verse says that we should "continue to be made new. "
2 WÒ SUSU NÈNƆ NU NYUIWO ŊU
2 FOCUS ON THE POSITIVE
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Ame si le fu kpem la ƒe ŋkekewo katã nye vɔ̃, ke ame si ƒe dzi le dzidzɔ kpɔm la tua aglo ɣesiaɣi. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "All the days of the afflicted one are bad, but the one with a cheerful heart has a continual feast. "
Lododowo 15:15.
Proverbs 15:15.
NU SI WÒFIA: Ne èbua nɔnɔme ɖe sia ɖe be made ame dzi o la, ekema "nuxaxa " axɔ aƒe ɖe mewò eye ŋkeke sia ŋkeke anye "vɔ̃ " na wò.
WHAT IT MEANS: If you see everything negatively, you will feel "afflicted " and every day will appear "bad, " or gloomy.
Gake ne wò susu le nu nyuiwo ŋu la, wò ‘dzi akpɔ dzidzɔ’ eye àtso aseye gɔ̃ hã.
But if you focus on positive things, you will have "a cheerful heart " and even feel joyful.
Wò ŋutɔe awɔ tiatiaa.
The choice is yours.
Yanko
Yanko
KPƆÐEŊU: Wowɔ dɔ heɖe nutete le ahɔhɔ̃ me na Yanko zi geɖe. Eye esia gblẽ nu le eƒe lãmesẽ kple nuƒoƒo ŋu.
EXAMPLE: After several surgeries to remove a brain tumor, Yanko had physical limitations that affected his movement and speech.
Esi Yanko kpɔe be esia awɔe be yemaɖo yeƒe taɖodzinuwo gbɔ o la, dzi ɖe le eƒo hena ƒe geɖe.
Feeling that these would stop him from reaching his goals, Yanko was deeply discouraged for years.
Emegbe etrɔ susu.
Then he changed.
Aleke wòtrɔe?
How?
Egblɔ be, "Le esi teƒe be mana nye susu nanɔ nɔnɔme madeamedziwo ŋu la, mesrɔ̃ ale si manɔ nu siwo ade dzi ƒo nam la ŋu bum boŋ. "
"Instead of focusing on my limitations, " he says, "I learned to occupy my mind with encouraging subjects. "
Mɔ ɖeka aɖe si dzi wòwɔna esia toe nye ale si wòxlẽa Biblia me nyawo.
One way Yanko does this is by reading passages from the Bible.
Egblɔ be: "Esia naa nye susu nɔa nu nyuiwo ŋu.
"This keeps my thoughts positive, " he says.
Nyemeŋlɔ taɖodzinu siwo gbɔ medi be maɖo le etsɔme la be o, gake nye susu le esiwo gbɔ mate ŋu aɖo fifia la ŋu.
"I haven’t totally put aside my long-term goals, but I’m focusing on the smaller goals that I can reach now.
Ne dziɖeleameƒonuwo va susu me nam la, medea ŋugble tsoa susu geɖe siwo ta wòle be makpɔ dzidzɔ ɖo la ŋu. "
When discouraging thoughts creep into my mind, I reflect on the many reasons I have to be happy. "
Abe ale si Yanko wɔe ene la, àte ŋu adzudzɔ dziɖeleameƒonuwo ŋu bubu ahanɔ nu siwo ade dzi ƒo na wò la ŋu bum.
Like Yanko, you can confront your pessimistic thoughts and replace them with something positive.
Ne èle akɔ kpem kple nɔnɔme sesẽwo ɖewohĩ lãmesẽkuxiwo abe Yanko ene la, bia ɖokuiwò be: ‘Ðe nɔnɔmea nye esi ŋu nyemate ŋu awɔ naneke le kura oa?
If you are dealing with negative circumstances perhaps a health problem, as was the case with Yanko ask yourself: ‘Is the situation really hopeless?
Ðe wòvɔ nama, alo mɔxenu aɖe koe wònyea?’
Have I reached a dead end, or is this merely a roadblock?’
Srɔ̃ ale si nàdzudzɔ dziɖeleameƒonuwo ŋu bubu ahanɔ nu siwo atu wò ɖo boŋ la ŋu bum.
Learn to keep negative thoughts out by concentrating on something constructive.
3 WƆ NU SI AÐE VI NA AMEWO
3 DO THINGS FOR OTHERS
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Dzidzɔ geɖe le nunana me wu nuxɔxɔ. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "There is more happiness in giving than there is in receiving. "
Dɔwɔwɔwo 20:35.
Acts 20:35.
NU SI WÒFIA: Nunana amewo tso dzi me faa naa ame kpɔa dzidzɔ.
WHAT IT MEANS: Unselfish giving brings deep satisfaction to the giver.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabena wowɔ mí be míawɔ nu wòaɖe vi na amewo wu be míaƒe susu nanɔ míawo ŋutɔwo ƒe nuhiahiãwo ko ŋu.
Because we were created to do more than simply look after our own needs.
(Filipitɔwo 2:3, 4; 1 Yohanes 4:11) Dzidzɔ si míakpɔ tso nunana amewo me ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ te ɖe nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo míado goe le agbe me la nu.
(Philippians 2:3, 4; 1 John 4:11) Experiencing the joy of giving can do much to help us cope with negative circumstances in life.
Josué
Josué
KPƆÐEŊU: Dzimeƒudɔ sesẽ aɖe ɖe fu na Josué.
EXAMPLE: Josué suffers from spina bifida, a severe defect in his spinal column.
Esia na wòsea veve ale gbegbe.
He is often racked with pain.
Gake Josué wɔa nu si ɖea vi na amewo si naa wòkpɔa dzidzɔ.
But Josué enjoys a productive life helping others.
Josué gblɔ be, "le esi magblɔ be, ‘nyemate ŋu awɔ esi kple ekemɛ o’ teƒe la, mebua mɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ siwo dzi mato akpe ɖe amewo ŋu gbe sia gbe la ŋu.
"Rather than say, ‘I can’t do that,’ " says Josué, "I enjoy thinking of practical ways to help people with their daily needs.
Media mɔ siwo dzi mato awɔ nu siwo aɖe vi na amewo, eye esia naa mekpɔa dzidzɔ. "
I find ways to do things for others, and this fills my life with happiness. "
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ
WHAT YOU CAN DO
Josué le dzidzɔ kpɔm kple ƒome aɖe esime wòle agba klɔm
Josué washes dishes while he enjoys the company of a young family
Di mɔ siwo dzi nàto akpe ɖe amewo ŋu.
Look for opportunities to be self-sacrificing.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ɖe nàte ŋu aɖa nu na aƒelika aɖe si dze dɔa?
For example, can you prepare a meal for a sick neighbor?
Ðe nàte ŋu akpe ɖe ame tsitsi aɖe si hiã kpekpeɖeŋu be wòadzra eƒe aƒe me ɖo la ŋua?
Do you know elderly ones who need help with tasks around the home?
Trɔ asi le wò nɔnɔme ŋu wòanyo ɖe edzi abe ale si nànɔ be lém na abɔ ene.
Care for your attitude in the same way you would cultivate a garden.
Ho aɖigbe siwo nye dziɖeleameƒonuwo ɖa le susu me.
Root out the poisonous weeds of pessimism and negativity.
Eye nàƒã nu nyui siwo anɔ wò tum ɖo si ana nɔnɔme nyui nanɔ asiwò.
Sow seeds of realistic optimism, and fertilize your life with actions that produce positive emotions.
Ne èwɔe alea la, àŋe nu siwo awɔe be nàkpɔ dzidzɔ le agbe me.
You will reap an emotional crop that will make your life much more rewarding.
Eye esia aɖo kpe edzi be nɔnɔme si anɔ asiwò ye ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ.
And it will confirm the fact that attitude makes a difference!
Ame aɖewo dzudzɔ nanewo ɖuɖu le woƒe lãmesẽ ta, nenema ke wò hã àte ŋu aɖe asi le nɔnɔme manyomanyowo ŋu
For the sake of their health, some people learn to say no to certain foods; you can do the same with negative attitudes
Míaƒe Seselelãmewo
Emotional Health
Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí tso seselelãme siwo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le mía ŋu la ŋu, eye wòde dzi ƒo na mí be míatu esiwo aɖe vi na mí la ɖo.
The Bible warns against emotions that are harmful and encourages us to cultivate those that are beneficial.
DZIKU
ANGER
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ame si gbɔa dzi ɖi blewu la nyo wu kalẽtɔ. " Lododowo 16:32.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "The one slow to anger is better than a mighty man. "​ Proverbs 16:32.
NU SI WÒFIA: Ne míetea ŋu ɖua míaƒe seselelãmewo dzi la, eɖea vi na mí.
WHAT IT MEANS: We benefit when we develop the strength to control our emotions.
Togbɔ be asɔ ɣeaɖewoɣi be míado dziku hã la, ne míeɖua míaƒe dziku dzi o la, egblẽa nu.
Although some anger may be justified at times, uncontrolled anger is destructive.
Numekuku siwo wowɔ nyitsɔ laa ɖo kpe edzi be ne ame aɖe do dziku la, zi geɖe la, egblɔa nya alo wɔa nu siwo va venɛ emegbe.
Modern researchers point out that in the heat of the moment, angry people often say or do things that they will later regret.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Srɔ̃ ale si nàɖu wò dziku dzi hafi wòana nàwɔ nu gbegblẽ.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Learn to control your anger before it controls you.
Togbɔ be ame geɖe bua dzikudodo be ènye kalẽwɔwɔ hã, míawo ya míenyae be gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔ ƒe dzesi boŋue wònye.
While some people think that uncontrolled anger is a sign of strength, we are wise to recognize that it is really a sign of weakness.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ame si meɖua eƒe dziku dzi o la le abe du si ŋu wogbã gli le wòtsi nuvo ene. "
"As a city broken through, without a wall, is the man who cannot control his temper, " says the Bible.
(Lododowo 25:28) Mɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ aɖe si dzi nàto aɖu wò dziku dzie nye be nànya nyateƒe bliboa hafi aɖe afɔ.
(Proverbs 25:28) A practical way to control your anger is to get the facts before reacting.
"Ame si sea nu gɔme nyuie la, medoa dziku kabakaba o. "
"The insight of a man certainly slows down his anger. "
(Lododowo 19:11) Anyo be míanya nyaa ƒe akpa sia akpa, esia ana míase nuwo gɔme nyuie eye wòana míalé mía ɖokui.
(Proverbs 19:11) We do well to listen carefully to both sides of a matter, which may provide insight that can steady our emotions.
NYE AKPEDALA
GRATITUDE
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Minye akpedalawo. " Kolosetɔwo 3:15.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Show yourselves thankful. "​ Colossians 3:15.
NU SI WÒFIA: Wogblɔna zi geɖe be ame siwo nye akpedalawo la kpɔa dzidzɔ.
WHAT IT MEANS: It has been said that only a grateful person can be happy.
Ame siwo to nɔnɔme sesẽ aɖewo me kpɔ gɔ̃ hã lɔ̃ ɖe nya sia dzi.
Even those who have gone through tremendous loss can attest to this.
Wogblɔ be nu si koŋ kpe ɖe yewo ŋu yewote ŋu nɔ te ɖe nɔnɔmea nue nye be menye nu siwo bu na yewo ŋue yewotsɔ susu ɖo o, ke ɖe nu siwo ta yewoate ŋu ada akpe ɖo boŋ ŋue.
They point out that the key to their emotional survival has been to focus on​ not what they lost ​but what they have to be grateful for.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Gbe sia gbe la, ŋlɔ nu siwo ta nàda akpe ɖo la ɖi.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Each day, make a list of the things that you are grateful for.
Mele be nu siawo nanye nu gãwo kokoko o.
These do not have to be major things.
De ŋugble le nu suesuesuewo abe agu ƒe dzedze, dze nyui si wò kple ame vevi aɖe mieɖo, alo esi agbeŋu bubu gake ɖe wò ene ta.
Reflect on even the small things, such as a beautiful sunrise, a pleasant conversation with a loved one, or simply having another day of life.
Ne èdea dzesi nu siawo eye nèbua wo ŋu hedaa akpe ɖe wo ta la, ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ.
These positive things can do much to boost your emotional health​ if you take the time to notice and appreciate them.
Aɖe vi geɖe ŋutɔ na wò ne èbu susu siwo tae nàda akpe ɖe wò ƒomea kple xɔ̃wòwo ta la ŋu.
It can be especially beneficial to think about why you are grateful for your family and friends.
Ne ède dzesi nu si dzɔa dzi na wò tso amewo ŋu la, na woanya to egbɔgblɔ na amea ŋutɔ tẽe, to lɛta, e-mail alo to text message dzi.
When you have identified what you appreciate about other people, tell them about it, either in person or in a letter, an e-mail, or a text message.
Esia ana wò kple amea ƒe ƒomedodo me nasẽ ɖe edzi, eye àkpɔ dzidzɔ si dona tsoa nunana me. Dɔwɔwɔwo 20:35.
This will likely strengthen your relationships and enable you to experience the happiness that comes from giving.​ Acts 20:35.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME BUBUWO
OTHER BIBLE PRINCIPLES
Vidada aɖe le to ɖom Biblia si woxlẽ lé ɖe mɔ̃ dzi la esi wòle via ƒe awuwo ŋem
A mother listens to an audio recording of the Bible while she folds her little girl’s clothes
Àte ŋu awɔ Biblia si woxlẽ lé ɖe mɔ̃ dzi la ƒe kɔpi.
You can download audio recordings of the Bible.
Ele gbegbɔgblɔ 40 me le jw.org
They are available in some 40 languages on jw.org
DZO LE TEƑEA HAFI WÒAVA ZU DZRE.
WALK AWAY FROM ARGUMENTS.
"Dzregɔmetoto le abe ale si woŋɔa tɔʋui ene; eya ta dzudzɔ hafi wòava zu dzre. " LODODOWO 17:14.
"Beginning a fight is like opening a floodgate; before the quarrel breaks out, take your leave. "​ PROVERBS 17:14.
MÈGATSI DZIMAÐI ÐE ETSƆME ŊU O.
AVOID UNNECESSARY WORRY ABOUT THE FUTURE.
"[Mègatsi] dzimaɖi gbeɖe le etsɔ si gbɔna ŋu o, elabena etsɔ si gbɔna la kple eya ŋutɔ ƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwoe.
"Never be anxious about the next day, for the next day will have its own anxieties.
Ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe ƒe kuxiwo sɔ gbɔ nɛ. " MATEO 6:34.
Each day has enough of its own troubles. "​ MATTHEW 6:34.
BU NUWO ŊU NYUIE EYE MÈGANƆ TE ÐE WÒ SESELELÃME DZAA KO DZI AÐE AFƆ O.
THINK THINGS THROUGH INSTEAD OF REACTING MERELY ON THE BASIS OF EMOTION.
"Tamebubuŋutete adzɔ ŋuwò, eye nugɔmesese akpɔ tawò. "
"Thinking ability will keep watch over you, and discernment will safeguard you. "​ PROVERBS 2:11.
LODODOWO 2:11.
Physical Health and Resilience
Lãmesẽmenɔnɔ Kple Tenɔnɔ Ðe Nu Nu
CHRONIC ILL HEALTH OR DISABILITY CAN HAVE A MAJOR IMPACT ON A PERSON’S LIFE.
NE AME AÐE LE DƆ LÉM ATRAÐII ALO ZU NUWƆAMETƆ LA ATE ŊU ANA AMEA MAKPƆ DZIDZƆ O. Esi ŋutsu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Ulf, si nɔ lãmesẽ me tsã va tsi teƒe ɖeka la, egblɔ be: "Nu te ɖe dzinye vevie.
After becoming physically paralyzed, a once active and healthy man named Ulf said: "I became deeply depressed.
Ŋusẽ vɔ le ŋunye, dzi ɖe le ƒonye eye . . . mese le ɖokuinye me be ‘evɔ nam.’ "
My strength, courage, and power drained away . . . I felt ‘destroyed.’ "
Nu si dzɔ ɖe Ulf dzi na míekpɔe be mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ate ŋu adze dɔ.
Ulf’s experience reminds us that none of us have complete control over our health.
Ke hã míate ŋu awɔ nu vevi aɖewo atsɔ akpɔ mía ɖokuiwo ta.
Still, we can take reasonable measures to reduce the risk of ill health.
Gake ne edzɔ be míaƒe lãme le gbegblẽm ɖe edzi ɖe?
But what if our health deteriorates?
Ðe ema ana míado kpo dzidzɔkpɔkpɔa?
Does that doom us to unhappiness?
Abe ale si míava kpɔe ene la, mele be wòayi alea o.
Not at all, as we shall see.
Gbã la, na míade ŋugble tso mɔfiame aɖewo siwo akpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ lãmesẽ me la ŋu.
First, though, let us consider some principles that promote good health.
‘DA SƆ LE NUWƆNA ME.’ (1 Timoteo 3:2, 11) Nu tsu ɖuɖu alo aha tsu nono agblẽ nu le míaƒe lãmesẽ ŋu eye egblẽa ga dome na ame hã.
BE "MODERATE IN HABITS. " (1 Timothy 3:2, 11) Habitually eating or drinking to excess is obviously bad for our health​ not to mention our finances!
"Mèganɔ aha tsu nolawo kple lã tsu ɖulawo dome o, elabena ahamula kple nu tsu ɖula la, ada ahe. " Lododowo 23:20, 21.
"Do not be among those who drink too much wine, among those who gorge themselves on meat, for a drunkard and a glutton will come to poverty. "​ Proverbs 23:20, 21.
MÈGAƑO ÐI WÒ ŊUTILÃ O.
DO NOT POLLUTE YOUR BODY.
"Mina míakɔ mía ɖokui ŋu tso ŋutilã kple gbɔgbɔ ƒe ɖiƒoƒo sia ɖiƒoƒo me. " (2 Korintotɔwo 7:1) Ame siwo ɖua atama alo yɔnɛ alo mua aha alo zãa atike vɔ̃ɖiwo la le ɖi ƒom woƒe ŋutilãwo.
"Let us cleanse ourselves of every defilement of flesh and spirit. " (2 Corinthians 7:1) People defile their bodies when they chew or smoke tobacco or abuse alcohol or drugs.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Dɔléle Nutsitsi Kple Mɔxexe Ðe Enu Dɔwɔƒe si le Amerika gblɔ be, atamanono "nana woléa dɔ vovovowo eye ame zua nuwɔametɔ eye wògblẽa nu le dzitodzito, aklã kple lãmenu vevi bubuwo katã kloe ŋu. "
Smoking, for example, "leads to disease and disability and harms nearly every organ of the body, " says the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
BU WÒ ŊUTILÃ KPLE WÒ AGBE BE WONYE NUNANA XƆASIWO.
VIEW YOUR BODY AND YOUR LIFE AS PRECIOUS GIFTS.
"[Mawue] na míele agbe, eye míeʋãna, eye míeli. "
"By [God] we have life and move and exist. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:28) Ne míelɔ̃ ɖe nya ma dzi la, aʋã mí be míade míaƒe agbe afɔku me le dɔ me, ne míele ʋu kum alo le modzaka si míaɖe tiam o.
(Acts 17:28) Appreciating that fact moves us to avoid taking needless risks, whether we are at work, driving, or choosing our recreation.
Viɖe kae wòanye ne ame aɖe di be yease vivi ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe ko gake wòazu nuwɔametɔ emegbe?
A momentary thrill is not worth a life of disability!
MÈGANƆ DZIKU DOM KABAKABA O. Kadodo kplikplikpli le wò susu kple ametia dome.
CONTROL NEGATIVE EMOTIONS. Your mind and body are closely linked.
Eya ta dze agbagba nàɖu dzimaɖitsitsi, dziku, ŋuʋaʋã kple seselelãme gbegblẽ bubuwo dzi.
So try to avoid undue anxiety, unbridled anger, envy, and other harmful emotions.
Psalmo 37:8 gblɔ be: "Wò dɔmedzoe nu nefa, eye nàdzudzɔ dzikudodo. "
"Let go of anger and abandon rage, " says Psalm 37:8.
Ŋɔŋlɔ bubu gblɔ be: "Migatsi dzimaɖi gbeɖe le etsɔ si gbɔna ŋu o, elabena etsɔ si gbɔna la kple eya ŋutɔ ƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwoe. " Mateo 6:34.
We also read: "Never be anxious about the next day, for the next day will have its own anxieties. "​ Matthew 6:34.
NA WÒ SUSU NANƆ NU NYUIWO ŊU.
TRY TO FOCUS ON POSITIVE THOUGHTS.
Lododowo 14:30 gblɔ be: "Dzi fatu naa agbe ametia. "
"A calm heart gives life to the body, " says Proverbs 14:30.
Biblia gagblɔ be: "Dzi kpɔdzidzɔ nye atike nyui. "
The Bible also states: "A joyful heart is good medicine. "
(Lododowo 17:22) Nya ma wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ƒe nyawo.
(Proverbs 17:22) That is a scientifically sound statement.
Ðɔkta aɖe si le Scotland gblɔ be, "ne dzi dzɔa wò la, ekema anɔ eme be le etsɔme la, mava nɔ dɔ lém abe ame siwo mekpɔa dzidzɔ o la ene o. "
"If you are happy, " said a doctor in Scotland, "you are likely in the future to have less in the way of physical illness than those who are unhappy. "
SRƆ̃ ALE SI NÀNƆ TE ÐE NU NU.
BUILD RESILIENCE.
Abe Ulf, si ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi ene la, ɖewohĩ naneke meli si míawɔ tso míaƒe kuxi aɖe ŋu wu be míado dzi anɔ te ɖe enu o.
Like Ulf, mentioned earlier, we may have no choice but to endure a persistent trial.
Ke hã, míate ŋu adi mɔ siwo dzi míato ado dzi.
Still, we can choose how we endure.
Dzi ɖena le ame aɖewo ƒo vevie, si gblẽa nyaa ɖe edzi.
Some become overwhelmed with discouragement, which may only make matters worse.
Lododowo 24:10 gblɔ be: "Ne dzi ɖe le ƒowò le xaxagbe la, ekema wò ŋusẽ dzi aɖe kpɔtɔ. "
"If you become discouraged in the day of distress, your strength will be meager, " says Proverbs 24:10.
Gake ɖewohĩ le ame aɖewo gome la, dzi ɖena le wo ƒo vie gake emegbe ŋusẽ gaɖoa wo ŋu.
Others, perhaps after initial feelings of despair, bounce back.
Wotrɔna ɖe nɔnɔmea ŋu.
They adapt.
Wodia mɔ siwo dzi woato ado dzi.
They find ways to cope.
Aleae wònɔ le Ulf gome.
That was the case with Ulf.
Egblɔ be esi yedo gbe ɖa zi geɖe eye yede ŋugble le Biblia me nyawo ŋu la, "yeƒe susu va nɔ nu siwo yeate ŋu awɔ ŋu tsɔ wu kuxiawo. "
He said that after much prayer and meditation on the Bible’s positive message, he "started to see opportunities instead of obstacles. "
Azɔ hã, abe ale si wòle le ame siwo to kuxi sesẽwo me gome ene la, esrɔ̃ nublanuikpɔkpɔ kple veveseɖeamenu eye esia ʋãe wògblɔ akɔfanamenya siwo le Biblia me la na amewo.
Moreover, like many who undergo major trials, he learned valuable lessons in compassion and empathy, which moved him to share the Bible’s comforting message with others.
Ame bubu aɖe hã si to kuxi sesẽwo mee nye Steve.
Another person who suffered greatly was a man named Steve.
Esi wòxɔ ƒe 15 la, edze afɔku si na wòtu tso eƒe kɔ gbɔ va ɖo afɔgɔme.
At age 15, he had an accident that paralyzed him from the neck down.
Esi wòxɔ ƒe 18 la, ŋusẽ va ɖo eƒe abɔwo ŋu.
By the time he was 18, he had regained the use of his arms.
Eyi yunivɛsiti eye le afi maa ezã atike vɔ̃ɖiwo, enoa aha eye wòƒo eɖokui ɖe gbɔdɔdɔ manɔsenu me.
He then went to a university, where his life spiraled into drugs, alcohol, and sexual immorality.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖee, gake esi wòva dze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ la, eƒe agbenɔnɔ va trɔ eye esia na wòdzudzɔ agbe vlo nɔnɔ.
