He had no hope​ until he began to study the Bible, which gave him a new outlook on life and helped him to conquer his bad habits.
Egblɔ be "Nye agbe megale abe tsã ene o, taɖodzinu va le eŋu.
"The emptiness that I had felt for so long was no longer there, " he said.
Fifia mele ŋutifafa me, mele dzidzɔ kpɔm eye nye dzi dze eme. "
"My life is now filled with peace, happiness, and contentment. "
Steve kple Ulf ƒe nyawo na míeɖo ŋku Psalmo 19:7, 8 me nyawo dzi. Afi ma gblɔ be: "Yehowa ƒe se de blibo, enana ŋusẽ gaɖoa ame ŋu. . . .
Steve and Ulf’s comments call to mind the words at Psalm 19:7, 8: "The law of Jehovah is perfect, restoring strength. . . .
Yehowa ƒe ɖoɖowo dzɔ, wodoa dzidzɔ na dzi; Yehowa ƒe sedede dza, enana ŋku dzi kɔna. "
The orders from Jehovah are righteous, causing the heart to rejoice; the commandment of Jehovah is clean, making the eyes shine. "
NYA VEVIAWO
KEY POINTS
Ne míewɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe se kple mɔfiamewo dzi la, enana ‘ŋusẽ gaɖoa ame ŋu, wodoa dzidzɔ na dzi eye wonana ŋku dzi kɔna.’​ Psalmo 19:7, 8.
When applied, God’s laws and principles ‘restore strength, cause the heart to rejoice, and make the eyes shine.’​ Psalm 19:7, 8.
Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be . . .
The Bible encourages us to . . .
Míada asɔ le nuwɔna me
Be moderate in habits
Míalé be na míaƒe ametia

View life as sacred

Control negative emotions
Míana míaƒe susu nanɔ nu nyuiwo ŋu

Míasrɔ̃ ale si míanɔ te ɖe nu nu
Build resilience
Lãmesẽmenɔnɔ
Physical Health
Menye atikeŋutinunyagbalẽe Biblia nye o.
The Bible is not a medical textbook.
Ke hã aɖaŋu siwo wòɖo la akpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ lãmesẽ me.
Yet, it promotes a healthful course of life.
Bu Biblia ƒe mɔfiame aɖewo siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nànɔ lãmesẽ me la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some Bible principles that can improve your life physically.
LÉ BE NA WÒ AMETIA
TAKE CARE OF YOUR BODY
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ame aɖeke melé fu eya ŋutɔ ƒe ŋutilã kpɔ o, ke boŋ enyinɛ, eye wòléa be nɛ nyuie. " Efesotɔwo 5:29.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "No man ever hated his own body, but he feeds and cherishes it. "​ Ephesians 5:29.
NU SI WÒFIA: Biblia ƒe mɔfiame sia de dzi ƒo na mí be míawɔ mía tɔ sinua alé be na mía ɖokui.
WHAT IT MEANS: This Bible principle encourages us to do what we can to care for our physical health.
Numekuku aɖe ɖee fia be ale si ame akpa gãtɔ nɔa gbee gbɔe lãmesẽkuxi geɖewo tsona.
One study shows that many health problems are related to personal lifestyle choices.
Eya ta ale si nènɔa agbee la ate ŋu ana nànɔ lãmesẽ nyuie me.
Hence, making the right personal choices can lead to better health.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ:
WHAT YOU CAN DO:
Ðu Nu Si Me Nunyiame Le.
Nutrition.
Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le eye nànɔ tsi nom sɔ gbɔ.
Take charge of your nutrition by eating healthful foods and drinking enough water.
Nɔ Kame Dem.
Stay Active.
Ƒe ka kee nèɖaxɔ o, èɖanye nuwɔametɔ alo dɔléle sesẽ aɖe le ŋuwò o, kamedede ana nànɔ lãmesẽ me.
Physical activity can improve your health regardless of your age, even if you are disabled or limited by chronic illness.
Togbɔ be ame siwo lɔ̃ wò kple ɖɔktawo aɖo aɖaŋu nyuiwo na wò hã la, wò ŋutɔe awɔ edzi be wòaɖe vi na wò!
While loved ones and health practitioners can assist you with your exercise program, only you can make it work!
Dɔ Alɔ̃ Wòasu Wò.
Get Enough Sleep.
Ne mèdɔa alɔ̃ wòsua wò o la, ate ŋu ana nàva dze dɔ vevie emegbe.
Prolonged sleep deprivation is associated with risks for serious illnesses.
Ame aɖewo tsɔa nu geɖe doa agba na wo ɖokuiwo le alɔ̃dɔɣiwo.
As a result of the choices they make, many people do not get enough sleep.
Ke hã ne ètiae be yeadɔ alɔ̃ wòasu ye nyuie la, ànɔ lãmesẽ me.
Yet, by choosing to sleep enough, you choose to live better.
TSRI NUMAME GBEGBLẼWO
AVOID HARMFUL HABITS
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Mina míakɔ mía ɖokui ŋu tso ŋutilã kple gbɔgbɔ ƒe ɖiƒoƒo sia ɖiƒoƒo me. " 2 Korintotɔwo 7:1.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Let us cleanse ourselves of every defilement of flesh and spirit. "​ 2 Corinthians 7:1.
NU SI WÒFIA: Eɖea vi na mí ŋutɔ ne míetsri nu siwo gblẽa nu le mía ŋu abe atama kple nu bubu siwo nye nu siwo koŋ gblẽa nu le míaƒe lãmesẽ ŋu eye wohea ku vɛ.
WHAT IT MEANS: We benefit from not polluting our bodies with harmful substances such as tobacco products, which are known to be a major cause of disease and death.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Ðo ɣeyiɣi si nàdzudzɔ keŋkeŋ eye nàde dzesii ɖi.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Set a date to quit, and mark it on your calendar.
Hafi ŋkeke ma naɖo la, tsɔ sigaretwo, dzowɔgbawo, dzosinuwo kple nu bubu siwo do ƒome kplii la ƒu gbe.
Just before that day, dispose of cigarettes, ashtrays, lighters, and other paraphernalia associated with this harmful habit.
Mèganɔ teƒe siwo amewo aƒoe ɖe nuwò be nàƒo ɖokuiwò ɖe nuwɔna siawo me yim o.
Avoid places where others engage in habits like this.
Gblɔ ale si nètso nya mee na xɔlɔ̃ siwo di be nàtrɔ ne woakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Tell supporting friends about your decision.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME BUBUWO
OTHER BIBLE PRINCIPLES
Ŋutsu aɖe le Biblia xlẽm
A man reads the Bible
Bia Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le miaƒe nutoa me dometɔ aɖe ne wòana Biblia ɖeka wò
You may obtain a printed copy of the Bible by contacting one of Jehovah’s Witnesses in your community
WƆ NU SIWO ANA NÀNƆ DEDIE.
BE SAFETY CONSCIOUS.
"Ne ètso aƒe yeye la, tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔa tame, bena ame aɖeke magage le edzi, eye nàna wò aƒe naɖi ʋufɔ o. " 5 MOSE 22:8.
"If you build a new house, you must also make a parapet for your roof, so that you may not bring bloodguilt on your house because of someone falling from it. "​ DEUTERONOMY 22:8.
ÐU WÒ DZIKU DZI.
CONTROL YOUR ANGER.
"Ame si medoa dziku kabakaba o la, nugɔmesese bɔ ɖe esi, ke ame si megbɔa dzi ɖi o la ɖea eƒe bometsitsi fiana. "
"The one who is slow to anger has great discernment, but the impatient one displays his foolishness. "​ PROVERBS 14:29.
LODODOWO 14:29.
AVOID OVEREATING.
TSRI NU TSU ÐUÐU. ‘Mèganɔ nu tsu ɖulawo dome o.’
"Do not be . . . among those who gorge themselves. "​ PROVERBS 23:20.
LODODOWO 23:20.
How to Age Gracefully
Ale Si Nàtsi Le Atsyɔ̃ɖoɖo Me Ahase Vivi Nɛ
HOW do you feel when the thought of aging comes up?
ALEKE nèsena le ɖokuiwò me ne èbu tsitsi ŋu?
It fills many with concern, anxiety, and even dread.
Enana ame geɖe tsia dzimaɖi, wotsia dzodzodzoe, eye edzia ŋɔ na wo gɔ̃ hã. Nu si tae nye be amewo bua tsitsi zi geɖe be kuxi sɔŋ koe wòhena vanɛ.
This is because aging is usually associated with negatives, such as diminished looks, a frail body, memory loss, and chronic diseases.
Ke hã nyateƒeae nye be, ame sia ame ƒe tsitsi metoa mɔ ɖeka o.
However, the fact is that people differ greatly in the way they age.
Ame aɖewo nɔa lãmesẽ me ne wole tsitsim; ŋusẽ nɔa wo ŋu eye woƒe susu hã nɔa nu ŋu.
Some enjoy relatively good health, physically and mentally, in their later years.
Ŋgɔyiyi le atikewɔnyawo me wɔe be ame aɖewo te ŋu da dɔléle si le fu ɖem na wo alo wote ŋu lé dɔmavɔleameŋuwo nu vie.
Advances in medicine have enabled others to treat or control chronic illnesses.
Esia wɔe be le dukɔ aɖewo me la, ame geɖe nɔa agbe didi eye wonɔa lãmesẽ me.
As a result, in some lands more and more people are living longer and healthier lives.
Ke hã tsitsimekuxiwo va alo womeɖa va o, ame geɖe dina be yewoatsi le atsyɔ̃ɖoɖo me ahase vivi nɛ.
Nevertheless, whether confronted with age-related problems or not, most people wish to be able to age gracefully.
Aleke esia anya wɔe?
How can this be done?
Eƒe akpa aɖe atso ale si míebua tsitsii, míaƒe ŋutete kple lɔlɔ̃ faa be míatrɔ ɖe míaƒe nɔnɔme yeyea ŋu la gbɔ.
In part, doing so depends on our attitude and our willingness and ability to adapt to this new phase in life.
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame bɔbɔe siwo dzi wɔwɔ ɖea vi la li akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàwɔ esia.
To help in these areas, let us consider some simple and practical Bible principles.
NYA WÒ ŊUTETE: "Ame siwo nyaa afi si woƒe ŋutete se ɖo la si mee nunya le. "
BE MODEST: "Wisdom is with the modest ones. "

(Lododowo 11:2) Le nya si me dzrom míele nu la, ‘ame siwo nya woƒe ŋutete’ ate ŋu afia ame tsitsi siwo de dzesi afi si woƒe ŋutete se ɖo helɔ̃ ɖe edzi eye womedzea agbagba be yewoaŋe aɖaba aƒu edzi o.
(Proverbs 11:2) In this context, "the modest ones " can refer to elderly ones who recognize and come to terms with the limitations of their age, not trying to deny or ignore them.
Charles, si xɔ ƒe 93, si le Brazil la gblɔe wòsɔ nyuie be: "Ne èle agbe didi la, àtsi godoo.
Charles, 93, in Brazil, is realistic when he says: "If you live long, you will have to age.
Màte ŋu awɔ naneke le eŋu o. "
There is no way to turn back the clock. "
Ke hã be nànya afi si wò ŋutete se ɖo mefia be nàbui be wɔna vɔ le ye ŋu ahanɔ susum be, "Fifia metsi, eye naneke megali mate ŋu awɔ o. "
Being modest, however, in no way means adopting the defeatist attitude "I am old, and there is nothing more for me. "
Nuŋububu alea ate ŋu awɔe be mànɔ dzidzɔ kpɔm o.
Such an attitude can sap one of enthusiasm.
Lododowo 24:10 gblɔ be: "Ne dzi ɖe le ƒowò le xaxagbe la, ekema wò ŋusẽ dzi aɖe kpɔtɔ. "
"If you become discouraged in the day of distress, your strength will be meager, " says Proverbs 24:10.
Le esia teƒe la, ame si nya afi si eƒe ŋutete se ɖo la wɔa nu sia nu si wòate ŋui be nɔnɔme si me wòle nàɖe vi nɛ.
Instead, a modest person shows wisdom, making the best of a situation.
Corrado, si xɔ ƒe 77, si le Italy la gblɔe nyuie be: "Ne èle tsitsim la, ehiã be nàɖe nu siwo nèwɔna tsã la dzi kpɔtɔ. "
Corrado, 77, in Italy, wisely says: "When you drive uphill, you just change gears and avoid stalling the engine. "
Ɛ̃, ne ame le tsitsim la, ehiã be wòawɔ tɔtrɔ siwo hiã.
Yes, adjustments need to be made when someone grows older.
Corrado kple srɔ̃a wofɔ aye na aƒemedɔwo wɔwɔ ale gbegbe be womenana ɖoɖo si dzi wozɔna ɖo la tea ɖeɖi wo ŋu fũu akpa o, ale be ŋusẽ nagavɔ le wo ŋu hafi zã nado o.
Corrado and his wife have developed a balanced approach to domestic chores, following a moderately relaxed schedule to avoid feeling completely drained of energy at the end of the day.
Marian, si xɔ ƒe 81, si le Brazil hã ɖe eƒe dɔwɔnawo dzi kpɔtɔ esi wòle tsitsim.
Marian, 81, in Brazil, also has a down-to-earth approach to aging.
Egblɔ be: "Meva nya dɔ agbɔsɔsɔme si mate ŋu awɔ.
"I have learned to pace myself, " she says.
Ne ɖeɖi te ŋunye la, meɖina ɖe eme vie.
"I take short breaks between tasks when necessary.
Menɔa anyi alo mlɔa anyi be maxlẽ nu alo ase haƒoƒo.
I sit down or lie down to read or listen to music.
Meva lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be nyemagate ŋu awɔ nu siwo mewɔna tsã o. "
I have learned to recognize and respect my limits. "
Ŋutsu tsitsi aɖe le kɔla blam
An older man putting on a tie
Da sɔ
Be balanced
DA SƆ: ‘Nyɔnuwo nado awu ɖe nɔnɔme nyui me, le ŋukpekpe kple ŋuɖɔɖo me.’ (1 Timoteo 2:9) Nyagbɔgblɔ si nye "nado awu ɖe nɔnɔme nyui me " fia dadasɔ kple dzadzraɖo nyuie.
BE BALANCED: "Women should adorn themselves in appropriate dress, with modesty and soundness of mind. " (1 Timothy 2:9) The expression "appropriate dress " denotes balance and good taste.
Barbara, si xɔ ƒe 74, si le Canada la, gblɔ be: "Medzea agbagba be mado awu nyuie ahanɔ dzadzɛ.
Barbara, 74, in Canada, says: "I try to look neat and clean.
Nyemedi be mado awu ɖewoɖewoe ahanɔ abe ame siwo gblɔna be, ‘Metsi; eya ta mehiã be magatsi dzi ɖe dzadzraɖo ŋu o’ la ene o. "
I don’t want to look dowdy with that ‘I’m old; I don’t care what I look like’ attitude. "
Fern, si xɔ ƒe 91, si le Brazil la gblɔ be: "Meƒlea awu ʋɛ aɖewo ɣeaɖewoɣi tsɔ doa dzidzɔ na ɖokuinye. "
Fern, 91, in Brazil, says: "I buy some new clothes once in a while to boost my spirits. "
Ke ŋutsu tsitsiwo ya ɖe?
And what can be said about older men?
Antônio, si xɔ ƒe 73, si le Brazil la gblɔ be: "Medzea agbagba be nye dzedzeme nanya kpɔ ɣesiaɣi, eya ta medoa awu siwo kɔ hele dzadzɛ. "
"I try my best to look smart, wearing clean and fresh clothes, " says Antônio, 73, in Brazil.
Le beléle na ameɖokui gome la, egblɔ be: "Melea tsi helũa ge gbe sia gbe. "
Regarding personal hygiene, he adds: "I shower and shave daily. "
Gake mehiã be nàtsi dzi ɖe wò dzedzeme ŋu ale gbegbe be nàdo kpo nuwɔwɔ ‘le ŋuɖɔɖo me’ o.
On the other hand, it is important to avoid becoming concerned about your personal appearance to the point of failing to exercise "soundness of mind. "
Bok-im, si xɔ ƒe 69, si le South Korea la da sɔ le awudodo me.
Bok-im, 69, in South Korea, has a balanced view about clothes.
Egblɔ be: "Menyae nyuie be masɔ kura be mado awu siwo medona tsã esime menye ɖetugbui o. "
She says: "I am quite aware that it is not appropriate for me to wear some of the clothes that I wore when I was young. "
Ŋutsu tsitsi aɖe le dzidzɔ kpɔm esi wòle saŋku ƒom na srɔ̃a
An older man enjoys playing the piano for his wife
Nye dzidzɔme
Be positive
NYE DZIDZƆME: "Ame si le fu kpem la ƒe ŋkekewo katã nye vɔ̃, ke ame si ƒe dzi le dzidzɔ kpɔm la tua aglo ɣesiaɣi. "
BE POSITIVE: "All the days of the afflicted one are bad, but the one with a cheerful heart has a continual feast. "
(Lododowo 15:15) Esi nèle tsitsim la, ne èɖo ŋku ɣeyiɣi siwo me nènye ɖetugbui alo ɖekakpui, esime ŋusẽ nɔ ŋuwò eye nètea ŋu wɔa nu geɖe dzi la, ate ŋu ate ɖe dziwò.
(Proverbs 15:15) As you age, you may experience negative feelings when you remember your youthful vigor and the many things you were once able to do.
Gɔmesese le esia ŋu.
This is understandable.
Ke hã dze agbagba be seselelãme mawo nagaɖu dziwò o.
However, make an effort not to be overcome by those negative feelings.
Tsã ŋkekewo ŋu bubu ate ŋu awɔe be mànɔ dzidzɔ kpɔm o, eye dzi aɖe le ƒowò ale gbegbe be màte ŋu awɔ nu siwo wòle be nàwɔ o.
Dwelling on the past can make your days gloomy and discourage you from doing what you are still able to do.
Joseph, si xɔ ƒe 79, si le Canada, la gblɔe nyuie be: "Medzea agbagba sea vivi na nu siwo mate ŋu awɔ eye nyemexaa nu le nu siwo mewɔna tsã, siwo nyemate ŋu awɔ fifia o, la ta o. "
Joseph, 79, in Canada, thinks positively: "I try to enjoy doing the things I can do and not cry over the things that I used to do but can’t do now. "
Nuxexlẽ kple nusɔsrɔ̃ ate ŋu ana wò susu nanɔ nu nyuiwo kple nu yeyewo ŋu.
Reading and learning can also make you feel more positive, broadening your horizons.
Eya ta ne anya wɔ la, wɔ nuxexlẽ kple nusɔsrɔ̃ ƒe mɔnukpɔkpɔ siwo le ʋuʋu ɖi la ŋu dɔ be nàsrɔ̃ nu yeyewo.
Thus, to the extent possible, be alert for opportunities to read and learn new things.
Ernesto, si xɔ ƒe 74, si le Philippines la yia agbalẽdzraɖoƒe ɖadia agbalẽ nyui siwo wòate ŋu axlẽ.
Ernesto, 74, in the Philippines, goes to the library and checks out interesting books to read.
Egblɔ be: "Edzɔa dzi nam be mate nu yeyewo kpɔ, eye metoa nuxexlẽ dzi nyaa nu tso teƒe siwo nyemate ŋu azɔ mɔ ayi o la ŋu. "
He says, "I still enjoy the thrill of adventure, the joy of traveling beyond the confines of home through the written word. "
Lennart, si xɔ ƒe 75, si le Sweden la dze dɔ aɖe, si mele bɔbɔe o, si nye gbe bubu sɔsrɔ̃, gɔ̃ hã gɔme.
Lennart, 75, in Sweden, even took on the daunting task of learning a new language.
Nyɔnu tsitsi aɖe le nu nam srɔ̃a
An older woman giving a gift to a friend
Nyo dɔme
Be generous
NYO DƆME: "Minɔ nu nam amewo, eye amewo ana nu mi. "
BE GENEROUS: "Practice giving, and people will give to you. "
(Luka 6:38) Zã wò nunɔamesiwo kple wò ɣeyiɣi wòaɖe vi na amewo; na esia nazu numame na wò.
(Luke 6:38) Make it a practice to share some of your time and resources with others.
Esia ana nàkpɔe be yewɔ nu nyui aɖe, eye ana dzi nadzɔ wò.
This will give you a feeling of accomplishment and happiness.
Hosa, si xɔ ƒe 85, si le Brazil la ɖoe be yeana kpekpeɖeŋu amewo togbɔ be lãmesẽ mede edzi o hã.
Hosa, 85, in Brazil, makes it a point to help others despite her physical limitations.
Egblɔ be: "Meƒoa ka na xɔ̃nye siwo dze dɔ alo esiwo ƒo dzi ɖe le, eye meŋlɔa lɛta ɖo ɖe wo.
She says: "I call friends who are sick or discouraged and write letters to them.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, meɖoa nunana suewo ɖe wo.
Sometimes I send them little gifts.
Edzɔa dzi nam hã be maɖa nu alo awɔ numeɖenu aɖe na ame siwo dze dɔ. "
I also like to cook a meal or make a dessert for sick ones. "
Ne míenyo dɔme na amewo la, eʋãa wo be woawo hã nanyo dɔme na ame.
Generosity begets generosity.
Jan, si xɔ ƒe 66, si le Sweden la gblɔ be: "Ne èwɔ nu ɖe amewo ŋu lɔlɔ̃tɔe la, aʋã wo woawɔ nu ɖe ŋuwò lɔlɔ̃tɔe, eye woatsɔ ɖe le eme na wò. "
"When you show love to others, they respond by giving you their love and affection, " says Jan, 66, in Sweden.
Ɛ̃, dɔmenyola nana ame siwo dome wòle la kpɔa dzidzɔ.
Yes, a generous person creates an atmosphere of warmth and appreciation that others find enjoyable.
WƆ XƆLƆ̃: "Ame sia ame si ɖea eɖokui ɖe aga la le eya ŋutɔ ƒe nudzodzrowo yome tim; etsia tre ɖe nunyawo katã ŋu. "
BE FRIENDLY: "Whoever isolates himself pursues his own selfish desires; he rejects all practical wisdom. "
(Lododowo 18:1) Togbɔ be àdi be ye ɖeɖe yeanɔ anyi ɣeaɖewoɣi hã la, ƒo asa na ɖokuiɖeɖe ɖe aga.
(Proverbs 18:1) While there are times when you may want to be alone, avoid becoming isolated and withdrawn.
Innocent, si xɔ ƒe 72, si le Nigeria la lɔ̃a xɔlɔ̃wo dome nɔnɔ.
Innocent, 72, in Nigeria, enjoys the company of friends.
Egblɔ be: "Melɔ̃ hadede kple ɖeviwo kple tsitsiawo siaa. "
"I joyfully associate with people of all ages. "
Börje, si xɔ ƒe 85, si le Sweden la gblɔ be: "Medzea agbagba be manɔ sɔhɛwo dome.
Börje, 85, in Sweden, says: "I strive to be around young people.
Dzo si le wo me nana dzo gaɖoa menye le ememe, abe sɔhɛ ene. "
Their vitality makes me feel young again at least on the inside. "
Tso le ɖokuiwò si nàwɔ ɖoɖo anɔ xɔlɔ̃wo kpem ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Take the initiative to invite friends over occasionally.
Han-sik, si xɔ ƒe 72, si le South Korea la gblɔ be: "Edzɔa dzi na nye kple srɔ̃nye be míakpe mía xɔlɔ̃wo, ɖeviwo kple tsitsiawo siaa, be míaɖu nu ɖekae. "
Han-sik, 72, in South Korea, says: "My wife and I like to invite friends of all ages elderly ones and teenagers for a get-together or dinner. "
Ðeviwo kple tsitsiawo siaa le dzidzɔ kpɔm ɖekae
People of various ages enjoying refreshments and association
Wɔ xɔlɔ̃
Be friendly
Ame siwo ɖoa dze nyuie lae wɔa xɔlɔ̃ nyuie.
Friendly people are communicative.
Gake esi wònye be ame evee ɖoa dze ta la, ɖewohĩ ahiã be nàdze agbagba anye ame si gbɔ nɔnɔ doa dzidzɔ na ame.
But since communication is a two-way street, you need to make it a point to be good company.
Eya ta tsɔ ɖe le eme na amewo.
Show personal interest in others.
Helena, si xɔ ƒe 71, si le Mozambique la gblɔ be: "Melɔ̃a amewo eye medea bubu wo ŋu.
Helena, 71, in Mozambique, says: "I am friendly and treat others with dignity.
Meɖoa to sea nya si gblɔm wole ale be manya ale si wobua nu ŋui kple nu si wolɔ̃na. "
I listen to what they have to say in order to find out what they think and what they like. "

José, si xɔ ƒe 73, si le Brazil la gblɔ be: "Amewo lɔ̃a ame siwo ɖoa to nyuie, ame siwo sea veve ɖe ame nu, ame siwo tsɔa ɖe le eme na ame, siwo kafua ame ne esɔ nenema hedoa nukokoe na ame la gbɔ nɔnɔ. "
José, 73, in Brazil, says: "People enjoy being around good listeners those who show empathy and interest in others, who give a word of commendation at the right time, and who have a sense of humor. "
Ne èle wò susuwo gblɔm la, dze agbagba be ‘dze nanɔ nya si gblɔm nèle la me.’
When expressing your thoughts, take care to ‘season your words with salt.’
(Kolosetɔwo 4:6) Bu ameawo ƒe nɔnɔmewo ŋu nyuie eye wò nya nade dzi ƒo na wo.
(Colossians 4:6) Be thoughtful and encouraging.
NYE AKPEDALA: "Minye akpedalawo. "
BE THANKFUL: "Show yourselves thankful. "
(Kolosetɔwo 3:15) Ne ame aɖe na kpekpeɖeŋu wò la, da akpe ɖe eƒe ɖetsɔlemea ta.
(Colossians 3:15) When receiving help, show appreciation for the attention.
Akpedada nana amewo dome vivina.
Expressions of thankfulness help to cultivate good relationships.
Marie-Paule, si xɔ ƒe 74, si le Canada la gblɔ be: "Nyitsɔ laa la, nye kple srɔ̃nye míeʋu yi aƒe bubu me.
"My husband and I recently moved from a house to an apartment.
Mía xɔlɔ̃ gbogbo aɖewo kpe asi ɖe mía ŋu.
We had dozens of friends helping us.
Míate ŋu ada akpe na wo wòade edeƒe o.
We could not thank them enough.
Míeɖo akpedagbalẽvi tɔxɛ ɖe wo, eye tso ɣemaɣi la, míekpe wo dometɔ aɖewo wova ɖu nu kpli mí. "
We sent personalized thank-you cards and have had some of them over for a meal since then, " says Marie-Paule, 74, in Canada.
Edoa dzidzɔ na Jae-won, si xɔ ƒe 76, si le South Korea la be exɔlɔ̃wo kɔnɛ ɖe ʋu me yia Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me.
Jae-won, 76, in South Korea, appreciates the rides she gets to the Kingdom Hall.
Egblɔ be: "Kpekpeɖeŋu si xɔ̃nyewo nanam la doa dzidzɔ nam ale gbegbe be meɖoe be manɔ gakpekpeɖeŋu aɖe nam be woatsɔ anɔ ami dzem ɖe ʋua me.
She says: "I am so grateful for all this help that I make a point of offering some money for the gas.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, menaa nunana sue aɖe wo heŋlɔa akpedanya aɖe kpena ɖe eŋu. "
I sometimes prepare small gifts with thank-you notes. "
Ƒo wo katã ta la, da akpe ɖe agbe si nèle ta.
Above all, be thankful for life itself.
Nunyala Fia Salomo ɖo ŋku edzi na mí be: "Avu gbagbe nyo wu dzata kuku. "
"A live dog is better off than a dead lion, " wise King Solomon reminded us.
(Nyagblɔla 9:4) Ɛ̃, ne susu nyui le asiwò ɖe tsitsi ŋu eye nèlɔ̃na faa wɔa tɔtrɔ siwo hiã la, anya wɔ be nàtsi le atsyɔ̃ɖoɖo me ahase vivi nɛ.
(Ecclesiastes 9:4) Yes, with the right attitude coupled with willingness to adapt, it is possible to age gracefully.
Nyɔnu tsitsi aɖe le agbalẽ ŋlɔm
An older woman writing a letter
Nye akpedala
Be thankful
Ðe Ya Kple Ɣe Ƒe Keklẽ Wua Dɔlékuiwoa?
Fresh Air and Sunshine Natural "Antibiotics "?
ESI dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ke ɖe dɔlékuiwutike ŋu le ƒe 1900-awo ƒe domedome la, ɖɔktawo kpɔ mɔ be atike yeye siawo akpe ɖe yewo ŋu yewoaɖe dɔléle aɖewo ɖa.
WHEN scientists first discovered chemical antibiotics in the mid-20th century, doctors hoped that these new medications would eliminate certain diseases.
Le gɔmedzedzea me la, atikeawo wɔ dɔ eteƒe mekɔ o.
At first, the new medicines seemed to live up to their promise.
Gake ale si ame geɖewo va le atikeawo zãm wògbɔ eme la wɔe be womegate ŋu va le dɔlékuiwo wum o.
Yet, their widespread use since then has resulted in the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
Esi dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo le ŋugble dem tso ale si woawɔ awu dɔlékuiwo ŋu la, wogava le tɔtrɔm ɖe mɔnu siwo wozãna tsɔ wua dɔlékuiwo le blema la ŋu.
To find new weapons against infection, some scientists are taking a second look at disease-control methods of the past.
Esiawo dometɔ ɖekae nye ale si ya kple ɣe ƒe keklẽ wua dɔlékuiwoe.
One of these involves harnessing the health benefits of sunshine and fresh air.
Nu Si Míesrɔ̃ Tso Blematɔwo Gbɔ
A Lesson From the Past
Eŋlisiawo dometɔ geɖe ƒo nu tso ale si ɣe ƒe keklẽ kple ya si ƒona le gota tea ŋu wua dɔlékuiwo la ŋu.
England had several early advocates of the curative value of sun and fresh air.
Atikewɔla John Lettsom (ƒe 1744-1815) gblɔ be ɖevi siwo ŋu yɔmekpe le la nagbɔ ya si ƒona le ƒuta eye woanɔ ɣe ƒe keklẽ nu ale be woahaya.
Physician John Lettsom (1744-1815) prescribed sea air and sunshine for children who were suffering from tuberculosis (TB).

Le ƒe 1840 me la, amekola George Bodington de dzesii be ame siwo wɔa dɔ le gota abe agbledelawo kple alẽkplɔlawo ene mexɔa yɔmekpe o, gake dɔwɔla siwo zãa woƒe ɣeyiɣi akpa gãtɔ le xɔ me la tea ŋu xɔa yɔmekpe bɔbɔe.

In 1840, surgeon George Bodington noted that those who worked in the open air farmers, plowmen, shepherds were generally free of TB, while those who spent much of their time indoors seemed more susceptible to it.
Aƒenɔ Florence Nightingale (ƒe 1820-1910) va xɔ ŋkɔ ŋutɔ le nu siwo wòto vɛ esime wònɔ Britain-ʋawɔla siwo xɔ abi le Crimea-ʋaa me gbɔ kpɔm la ta.
Florence Nightingale (1820-1910) became famous for her innovations in nursing while caring for British soldiers injured during the Crimean War.
Ebia be: "Ðe mège ɖe ame aɖe ƒe xɔ dɔme me le zã me alo ŋdi kanya esime womekpɔ ʋu fesre o eye nèkpɔ be ya si le xɔa me la bla hele ʋeʋẽm ɖe ƒomevie kpɔ oa? "
She asked: "Do you ever go into the bed-rooms of any persons . . . at night, or before the windows are opened in the morning, and ever find the air anything but unwholesomely close and foul? "
Egblɔ be ele be woana ya si le dɔnɔ ƒe xɔ me la nasɔ kple esi le gota, evɔ womana vuvɔ nawɔ dɔnɔa atso eme o.
She recommended that the air in a patient’s room be kept as fresh as the outside air, but without chilling the patient.
Egblɔ kpee be: "Nu siwo katã teƒe mekpɔ la ɖo kpe edzi be nu eve ye dɔnɔ hiã vevie, woawoe nye gotaya kple keklẽ . . .
She added: "It is the unqualified result of all my experience with the sick, that second only to their need of fresh air is their need of light . . .
Gake menye keklẽ ɖe sia ɖe ko o, ke boŋ ɣe ƒe keklẽ. "
And that it is not only light but direct sun-light they want. "
Ɣemaɣi la, ame geɖewo xɔe se be ne wosia abadzivɔwo kple awuwo ɖe ŋdɔgbe la, edea lãmesẽ dzi.
Many at that time also believed that exposing bed linens and clothing to the sun promoted health.
Togbɔ be amegbetɔwo yi ŋgɔ le dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya me tso ƒe 1800-awo me hã la, egbegbe nusɔsrɔ̃wo hã ɖo kpe edzi nenema.
Science has progressed since the 1800’s, yet modern studies have reached similar conclusions.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, numekuku aɖe si Chinatɔwo wɔ le ƒe 2011 me ɖee fia be sukuvi siwo sɔ gbɔ ɖe xɔ dɔmewo me wu ale si dze, evɔ ya megena ɖe xɔ siawo me tututu o la "xɔa akɔtadɔ. "
For instance, a 2011 study in China found that crowded college dormitories with a low rate of ventilation are "associated with more respiratory infections. "
Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔ gblɔ be ele vevie be woana gotaya nage ɖe xɔwo me ale be wòate ŋu awɔ avu kple dɔlékuiwo.
The World Health Organization (WHO) recognizes that natural ventilation, which includes outside air flowing through a building, is important for infection control.
Nyateƒee, habɔbɔ sia gblɔ le mɔfiamegbalẽ aɖe si wòɖe ɖe go le ƒe 2009 me la me be woaɖe mɔ ya siawo nage ɖe kɔdzixɔwo me ale be woaɖe dɔlékuiwo dzi akpɔtɔ le afi mawo.
Indeed, WHO guidelines published in 2009 encourage use of such natural ventilation as an effective measure in reducing the risk of infection at health-care facilities.
Ðewohĩ àgblɔ be, ‘Nya siawo nya se loo.
‘That is all very good,’ you might say.
Gake kpeɖodzi kae le wo ŋu?
‘But what is the science behind this?
Aleke ya kple ɣe ƒe keklẽ ate ŋu awu dɔlékuiwo?’
How do sunshine and air prevent infection?’
Dzɔdzɔmenu Siwo Wua Dɔlékuiwo
Nature’s Disinfectants
United Kingdom (Royaume-Uni) ƒe dɔwɔƒe si kpɔa lãmesẽnyawo gbɔ ƒe numekuku aɖe ɖo nyabiase siawo ŋu.
Studies conducted at a United Kingdom Ministry of Defence site provide some answers.
Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala siwo le dukɔ sia me la di be yewoanya ɣeyiɣi didi si wòaxɔ hafi dɔlékuiwo navɔ le ya me ne woda dɔlékuiʋawɔnuwo ɖe London dua me.
Scientists there were trying to establish how long the air would remain dangerous if a biological weapon armed with harmful bacteria were exploded over London.
Esi numekulawo di be yewoanya ɣeyiɣi didi si dɔlékuiawo ate ŋu anɔ agbe le ya me la, wotsɔ dɔlékui si woyɔna be E. coli de yiyiɖɔ ŋu tsɔ da ɖe ya nu le gota.
To determine the viability of airborne pathogens, the researchers anchored E. coli microorganisms to threads of spider silk and exposed them to the open air.
Wowɔ nu sia le zã me, elabe wonya be ɣe ƒe keklẽ wua dɔlékuiwo.
The experiment was performed at night, since it was known that sunlight kills these bacteria.
Nu kawoe do tso eme?
What were the results?
Le gaƒoƒo eve megbe la, dɔlékuiawo ƒe akpa gãtɔ ku.
Some two hours later, nearly all the bacteria were dead.

Gake esi wowɔ dodokpɔ ma ke eye wotsɔ dɔlékuiawo de aɖaka me hetu nu ɖe enu eye wotsɔ aɖakaa da ɖe teƒe si tututu woda yiyiɖɔa ɖo va yi eye yame ƒe dzoxɔxɔ sɔ kple gbãtɔ nu la, dɔlékui akpa gãtɔ gakpɔtɔ le agbe le gaƒoƒo eve si woɖo la megbe.
Yet, when the bacteria were kept in a closed box in the same location and at the same temperature and humidity, most of them were still alive past the two-hour mark.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Edze ƒãa be nane le ya me si wua dɔlékuiwo.
Evidently, something about being in the open air kills germs.
Gake womekpɔ nya nu si tututu wònye o.
This so-called open-air factor has not been clearly identified.
Ke hã, numekulawo gblɔ be nu vovovo aɖewo anya nɔ "ya me siwo wua dɔlékuiwo. "
However, researchers point to a compound that occurs naturally in open air and that "acts as a natural disinfectant against pathogens or germs that lurk in the atmosphere. "
Ɣe ƒe keklẽ hã wua dɔlékuiwo.
Sunlight also has natural disinfecting properties.
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ aɖe (Journal of Hospital Infection) gblɔ be: "Dɔlékui geɖe siwo nɔa ya me la metea ŋu nɔa te ɖe ɣe ƒe keklẽ nu o. "
The Journal of Hospital Infection explains that "the majority of microbes that cause airborne infections cannot tolerate sunlight. "
Nu kae nàwɔ be wòaɖe vi na wò?
How can you take advantage of this?
Ðewohĩ àdi be yeanɔ ŋdɔ nu vie ale be yeaxɔ ya nyui ma.
You might want to go outdoors, where you can spend a moderate amount of time in the sunshine and breathe some fresh air.
Ate ŋu ade wò lãmesẽ dzi.
It will likely do you good.
Tenɔnɔ Ðe Dɔ Mavɔleameŋu Nu Ðe Biblia Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Mía Ŋua?
Living With Chronic Illness Can the Bible Help?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Mawu tsɔ ɖe le eme na esubɔla siwo le dɔ lém la.
God cares about his servants who are sick.
Biblia gblɔ le mawusubɔla wɔnuteƒe aɖe ŋu be: "Yehowa akpe ɖe eŋu le dɔba dzi. "
Regarding a faithful servant, the Bible says: "Jehovah himself will sustain him upon a divan of illness. "
(Psalmo 41:4) Ne èle dɔ mavɔleameŋu aɖe lém la, afɔɖeɖe etɔ̃ siwo gbɔna la akpe ɖe ŋuwò:
(Psalm 41:3) If you are living with chronic illness, the following three steps can help you to cope:
Do gbe ɖa be Mawu nàdo ŋusẽ wò nànɔ te ɖe enu.
Pray for strength to endure.
Àkpɔ "Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒoa susu ɖe sia ɖe ta " eye wòaɖe wò dzimaɖitsitsiwo dzi akpɔtɔ ahalé wò ɖe te.
You can receive "the peace of God that excels all thought, " which can reduce your anxiety and sustain you.​ Philippians 4:6, 7.
Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7.
Be positive.
Na dzi nanɔ dzɔwòm.
The Bible says: "Being cheerful keeps you healthy.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dzi kpɔdzidzɔ nana lãme hayana, ke gbɔgbɔ xanu nana ƒuwo ƒuna kplakplakpla. "
It is slow death to be gloomy all the time. "
(Lododowo 17:22) Megatsɔ nya sia nya nya vevii akpa o, elabena esia ana dzi nadzɔ wò le ɣeyiɣi sesẽwo me, eye akpɔ ŋusẽ nyui ɖe wò lãmesẽ hã dzi.
(Proverbs 17:22, Good News Translation) Cultivate your sense of humor, since this not only can lighten dark times but also can benefit your health.
Kpɔ mɔ na nu siwo le etsɔme.
Build your hope in the future.
Ne mɔkpɔkpɔ nyuiwo le asiwò la, ana dzi nadzɔ wò togbɔ be dɔ mavɔleameŋuwo anɔ fu ɖem na wò hã.
A sound hope can help you have joy despite chronic ailments.
(Romatɔwo 12:12) Biblia gblɔ ɖi be le etsɔme la, "duametɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, yele dɔ lém o. " (Yesaya 33:24) Ɣemaɣi la, Mawu ada dɔ mavɔleameŋu siwo ɖɔktawo mete ŋu le ta kpɔm na egbea o la.
(Romans 12:12) The Bible foretells a time when "no resident will say: ‘I am sick.’ " (Isaiah 33:24) God will then cure chronic illnesses that are beyond the power of modern science to solve.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia ƒo nu tso ale si ame tsitsiwo agbugbɔ aɖo woƒe sɔhɛmenɔɣiwo me la ŋu ale: "Ekema dzo aɖo eƒe lãme abe ɖekakpui ene, eye wòagaɖo eƒe ɖekakpuiŋkekewo me. " Hiob 33:25.
For example, the Bible describes the reversal of the aging process this way: "Let his flesh become fresher than in youth; let him return to the days of his youthful vigor. "​ Job 33:25.
De dzesii: Togbɔ be Yehowa Ðasefowo lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Mawu kpena ɖe yewo ŋu hã la, wonaa ɖɔktawo wɔa atike na wo ne wole dɔ mavɔleameŋu lém.
Note: While acknowledging the help that God provides, Jehovah’s Witnesses also seek medical treatment for chronic illness.
(Marko 2:17) Ke hã, míekafua dɔdamɔnu aɖe koŋ be eyae nyo wu o; míesusu be ekpo ɖe ame sia ame ŋutɔ gbɔ be wòatso nya me le dɔdamɔnu si woazã nɛ la ŋu.
(Mark 2:17) We do not, however, endorse any specific medical approach; we feel that each person should make his own health decisions.
Ne Dɔléle Sesẽ Aɖe Dze Dziwò
When You Have a Serious Illness
"Esi mese be wokpɔ kansa le nye dzitodzito kple dɔgbo me la, mebu be wòtso kufia nam.
"When I learned that I had cancer in my lung and colon, I thought that I had just received a death sentence.
Gake esi megbɔ tso kɔadzi la, megblɔ na ɖokuinye be, ‘Enyo, menye nu mae menɔ mɔ kpɔm na o, gake ele be mato mɔ aɖe dzi anɔ te ɖe enu.’ " Linda, si xɔ ƒe 71.
But after I got home from the doctor, I thought, ‘OK, it’s not what I expected, but I have to find a way to deal with this.’ "​ Linda, aged 71.
"Dɔléle sesẽ aɖe na mesea veve le nye mo ƒe miakpa dzi eye gbegblẽm ɖe edzi koe wòle.
"I suffer from a debilitating nerve syndrome on the left side of my face.
Zi geɖe la, metsia akogo eye medina be mawu ɖokuinye gɔ̃ hã. "
On occasion, the severe pain has caused me to fall into depression.
Elise, si xɔ ƒe 49.
Many times, I felt alone and even contemplated suicide. "​ Elise, aged 49.
Dɔnɔ aɖe si le bunɔkeke me la ƒe ame vevi siwo lɔ̃e la le eŋu
A sick man in a wheelchair is surrounded by loved ones
NE WOKPƆ dɔléle si ate ŋu awu ame le wò ŋutɔ alo wò ame vevi aɖe ŋu kpɔ la, ke ànya ale si wògbãa dzi na amee.
IF YOU or a loved one has been diagnosed with a potentially life-threatening illness, you know how distressing it can be.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe dɔlélea ŋutɔ ŋu la, ele be nànɔ te ɖe wò ŋutɔ loo alo dɔnɔa ƒe nuwɔnawo hã nu.
In addition to the disease itself, you have to deal with fragile emotions.
Ne mɔ si dzi woto le dɔa dam na wò nana nèsea veve, mèkpɔ ga aƒle atikeawo o, alo ale si atikeawo ava ɖe fu na wò emegbe, ate ŋu ana vɔvɔ̃ naɖo wò eye nàtsi dzi.
Fear and anxiety can be intensified by nerve-racking medical appointments, difficulty obtaining or paying for treatment, or the unpleasant side effects of medications.
Ne ame aɖe ƒe lãme gblẽ vevie la, ale si wònana ame tsia dzii la gagblẽa nyaa ɖe edzi.
The mental anguish associated with serious illness can be overwhelming.
Afi kae míakpɔ kpekpeɖeŋu le?
Where can we turn for assistance?
Ame geɖe kpɔe be ne yewoziɔ ɖe Mawu ŋu do gbe ɖa nɛ, eye yewoxlẽ akɔfanamenyawo le Biblia me la, enana yewokpɔa gbɔdzɔe ŋutɔ.
Many have found that their greatest comfort comes from leaning on God in prayer and reading comforting passages found in the Bible.
Lɔlɔ̃ si ƒometɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃wo ɖena fiana kple woƒe kpekpeɖeŋu hã kpena ɖe ame ŋu.
Another help may come through the love and support that family and friends can provide.
NU SI AME AÐEWO WƆ TE ŊU NƆ TE ÐE ENU
HOW SOME HAVE COPED
Robert si xɔ ƒe 58 ɖo aɖaŋu be: "Na ale si nèxɔ Mawu dzi se nakpe ɖe ŋuwò nàdo dzi.
"Face illness with your faith in God, " advised 58-year-old Robert, "and he will carry you through.
Do gbe ɖa na Yehowa.
Go to Jehovah in prayer.
Gblɔ ale si nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me nɛ.
Let him know how you feel.
Bia eƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea.
Ask him for holy spirit.
Biae be wòado ŋusẽ wò nànɔ te sesĩe eye nàde dzi ƒo na wò ƒomea eye nàɖe dzi ɖi esime nèle dzi dom.
Ask him for strength to be strong for the family and to allow you to go through your illness with dignity.
"Eɖea vi ŋutɔ ne wò ƒomea sea veve ɖe nuwò, eye woli na wò.
"It means so much when your family supports you emotionally, when they are there for you.
Gbe sia gbe la, wo dometɔ ɖeka alo eve ƒoa ka nam biana be, ‘Èfɔ nyuiea?’
I get phone calls every day from one or two who ask, ‘How are you doing?’
Xɔ̃nye siwo le teƒe vovovowo hã dea dzi ƒo nam.
I get encouragement from friends all over.
Esia kpena ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ be magana ta o. "
They definitely give me a boost, and that helps me to keep going. "

Ne èyi xɔ̃wò aɖe si dze dɔ srã ge kpɔ la, na Linda ƒe nya sia nanɔ susu me na wò. Egblɔ be: "Dɔnɔa adi be yeaɖe susu ɖa le dɔlélea ŋu ne yeƒe susu nanɔ nu bubuwo ŋu, si ta madi be yeanɔ nu ƒom tso eŋu ɣesiaɣi o.
If you are a friend visiting a sick person, note what Linda points out: "The patient no doubt wants to lead as normal a life as possible and may not always want to talk about the sickness.
Eya ta miɖo dze tso nu bubu siwo ŋu mieɖoa dze tsonae ne miedo go. "
So talk about the things you usually talk about. "

Le Mawu ƒe ŋusẽdoame kple akɔfanya siwo le Biblia me kple kpekpeɖeŋu si ƒometɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃wo nana mí ta la, míate ŋu aka ɖe edzi be susu nyuiwo li siwo tae wòle be míayi edzi anɔ agbe, ne míele dɔ lém vevie gɔ̃ hã.

With strength from God and comfort from the Scriptures, as well as the support of loving family and friends, we can maintain our assurance that life is worth living, even when we are enduring a serious illness.
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò
Bible Verses That Can Help
Ðo ŋu ɖe Mawu ŋu.
Lean on God.
Eɖem tso nu siwo katã vɔ̃m mele la me.
"I inquired of Jehovah, and he answered me.
Esi hiãtɔ sia yɔe la, Yehowa see. "
He rescued me from all my fears.
Psalmo 34:4, 6.
This lowly one called, and Jehovah heard. "​ Psalm 34:4, 6.
Linda, si ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe va yi gblɔ be: "Nyemedoa gbe ɖa be ‘Na mahaya o.’
Linda, quoted earlier, says: "I never pray, ‘Make me better.’
Ke boŋ medoa gbe ɖa ɣesiaɣi be: ‘Kpe ɖe ŋunye ŋusẽ nanɔ ŋunye manɔ te ɖe nye dɔlélea nu.’ "
I always pray, ‘Help me be strong, and help me to endure my illness.’ "
Xlẽ Mawu ƒe Nyaa be wòado ŋusẽ wò.
Draw strength from God’s Word.
"Dua me tɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, ‘Mele dɔ lém’ o. " Yesaya 33:24.
"No resident will say: ‘I am sick.’ "​ Isaiah 33:24.
Nɔ ŋugble dem le ŋugbe siwo Mawu do ku ɖe etsɔme ŋu la ŋu, esia ana mɔkpɔkpɔ si ado ŋusẽ wò be nàdo dzi la wò.
Tap into the sustaining power of hope by meditating on God’s promises for the future.
Na wò ƒometɔwo kple xɔ̃wòwo nakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Seek support from family and friends.
"Xɔlɔ̃ vavã lɔ̃a ame ɣeawokatãɣi eye ame nɔvi wònye wodzi ɖe xaxagbe ŋu. " Lododowo 17:17.
"A true friend shows love at all times and is a brother who is born for times of distress. "​ Proverbs 17:17.
Elise, si ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe va yi gblɔ be: "Mèganɔ ɖokuiwò ɖem ɖe aga o.
"Do not isolate yourself, " advises Elise, quoted earlier.
Na xɔ̃wòwo nakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
"Allow your friends to help you.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi àse le ɖokuiwò me be yetsi akogo eye wòawɔ na wò be Mawu gɔ̃ hã meɖoa to ye o, gake mègaɖe ɖokuiwò ɖe aga o. "
There might be times when you feel alone and you don’t even think that God is listening, but do not isolate yourself. "
Alekee Mawɔ Akpe Akɔ Kple Dɔmavɔleameŋu?
How Can I Cope if I’m Not Well? Play
Sɔhɛwo Biana Be
Current time 0:00
Alekee Mawɔ Akpe Akɔ Kple Dɔmavɔleameŋu?
Duration 0:00 Mute
LODODOWO 20:29 gblɔ be: "Ðekakpuiwo ƒe atsyɔ̃ enye woƒe ŋusẽ. "
"THE glory of the young is their strength, " says Proverbs 20:29.
Ne dɔmavɔleameŋu le ŋuwò, alo nènye nuwɔametɔ la, àse le ɖokuiwò me be mawunyakpukpui sia me nyawo menye nyateƒe le ye gome o.
(The Jerusalem Bible) If you’re sick or disabled, you might feel as if that scripture could never apply to you.
Gake menye nenemae kura o!
But it can!
Elabena sɔhɛ geɖe siwo dɔmavɔleameŋu le fu ɖem na kple esiwo nye nuwɔametɔwo la te ŋu ɖu kuxi sesẽtɔwo kekeake gɔ̃ hã dzi.
The fact is, many youths with disabilities and chronic illnesses have overcome the most daunting of obstacles.
Nyɔ! talawo bia gbe sɔhɛ siawo dometɔ ene.
Awake! interviewed four such youths.
Hiroki, si le Japan, lé ahɔhɔ̃medɔ si naa wozua nuwɔametɔ la tso edziɣi ke.
Hiroki, in Japan, has suffered with cerebral palsy from birth.
Egblɔ be: "Lãmeka siwo le nye kɔ me mete ŋu léa nye ta ɖe te o, eye ne medi be matsɔ nye asiwo awɔ nane la, nu bubu koe asiawo wɔna.
"My neck muscles aren’t able to hold my head up straight, and my hands do just the opposite of what I want them to, " he says.
Ame bubuwo koe wɔa nu sia nu nam. "
"I’m completely dependent on others for help. "
Natalie kple nɔvia ŋutsu James le South Africa, eye ƒumedɔléle aɖe si naa ame kua te, si tɔgbi mebɔ o, la nɔ wo ŋu tso wo dziɣi ke.
Natalie and her brother, James, in South Africa, were born with a rare form of dwarfism.
Dzimeƒugɔglɔ̃dɔ hã le Natalie ŋu.
Natalie also has scoliosis, a deformity of the spine.
Egblɔ be: "Wowɔ dɔ nam zi ene sɔŋ, eye ale si nye dzimeƒua glɔ̃e la wɔe be ŋusẽ mele nye dzitodzitowo ŋu tututu o. "
"I have undergone four spinal surgeries, " she says, "and because of the curvature of my spine, I have weak lungs. "
Timothy le Britain, esime wòxɔ ƒe 17 la, wokpɔ ɖeɖiteameŋu atraɖii ƒe dɔléle le eŋu.
Timothy, in Britain, was diagnosed at the age of 17 with chronic fatigue syndrome.
Egblɔ be: "Mede ɣleti eve hafi nye ame si nɔ lãmesẽ me eye ŋusẽ nɔ ŋunye nyuie la meva gbɔdzɔ belibeli, eye nyemegate ŋu va nɔ tɔtɔm ɖe nye afɔwo dzi o. "
"In less than two months, " he says, "I went from being healthy and active to being so weak that my legs would not support me. "
Danielle le Australia, wokpɔ suklidɔ le eŋu esime wòxɔ ƒe 19.
Danielle, in Australia, was diagnosed with diabetes at 19 years of age.
Egblɔ be: "Esi wònye be suklidɔ medzena le ame ŋu wokpɔna kple ŋku o ta la, amewo menya ale si gbegbe wòvɔ̃ɖii o.
"Since diabetes isn’t visible, " she says, "some people don’t realize how serious it is.
Nyateƒeae nye be dɔ sia ate ŋu awum. "
The fact is, diabetes could kill me. "
Ne dɔmavɔleameŋu aɖe le fu ɖem na wò, alo ènye nuwɔametɔ la, Hiroki, Natalie, Timothy, kple Danielle ƒe nya siwo gbɔna ade dzi ƒo na wò godoo.
If you suffer from some form of illness or disability, no doubt you’ll find the comments of Hiroki, Natalie, Timothy, and Danielle to be encouraging.
Ne èle lãmesẽ nyui me gɔ̃ hã la, ɖewohĩ woƒe nyawo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàse ame siwo dɔmavɔleameŋu kple nuwɔametɔnyenye le fu ɖem na la ƒe nɔnɔmewo gɔme nyuie wu.
If you enjoy good health, their comments may help you to be more understanding of those who struggle with disability or illness.
Nyɔ! talawo: Nu kae nye kuxi sesẽtɔ kekeake le wò nɔnɔmea ŋu?
Awake!: What is most challenging about your condition? Natalie, 20 South Africa
Natalie: Le gonye me la, ale si amewo wɔa nu ne wokpɔm lae ɖea fu nam wu.
Natalie: For me, it’s dealing with how people react when they see me.
Nyemete ŋu ɖea dzi ɖi gbeɖe o.
I never feel at ease.
Mesena le ɖokuinye me be amewo fɔa ŋku ɖe dzinye dzoɣlii ɣesiaɣi.
I feel as if I’m constantly being looked at.
Danielle: Le nye suklidɔlélea gome la, kuxia koŋue nye nu si ƒomevi maɖu, nu agbɔsɔsɔme si maɖu, kple nuɖuɖu siwo wòle be matsri la nyanya.
Danielle: With diabetes, the main challenge is knowing what to eat, how much to eat, and which foods I need to limit.
Ne nyemeɖɔ ŋu ɖo le nu siwo maɖu me o la, sukli agbɔsɔsɔme si hiã la mava nɔ nye ʋu me o, si ate ŋu awɔe be mayi ɖi me.
An imbalance in my diet could lead to hypoglycemia, which could put me in a coma.
Hiroki: Wowɔ bunɔkeke tɔxɛ aɖe si sɔ ɖe nye nɔnɔmea nu la nam, eye menɔa nɔnɔme ɖeka aɖe me hena gaƒoƒo 15 sɔŋ le ŋkekea me.
Hiroki: I have a special wheelchair that’s adapted to my physique, and I spend about 15 hours a day in one position.
Nyemete ŋu dɔa alɔ̃ hã nyuie o.
Also, I don’t sleep well.
Kaka nane naɖi kikli ko la, menyɔna.
The slightest noise wakes me up.
Timothy: Gbã la, nu si ɖe fu nam wue nye lɔlɔ̃ ɖe edzi be mezu dɔnɔ.
Timothy: At first, my biggest challenge was just accepting the fact that I was sick.
Nɔnɔme si me meva le la tena ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
I was embarrassed by my condition.
Nyɔ! talawo: Kuxi bubu kawoe ɖea fu na wò?
Awake!: What other difficulties do you face?
Danielle: Suklidɔlélea nana ɖeɖi tea ŋunye ale gbegbe.
Danielle, 24 Australia Danielle: Diabetes causes me to be very tired.
Ehiã be madɔ alɔ̃ gaƒoƒo geɖe wu hanyetiwo.
I need more sleep than others my age do.
Azɔ hã, suklidɔ nye dɔ aɖe si womete ŋu dana o.
Also, diabetes is a chronic illness for which there is no cure.
Natalie: Ale si gbegbe mele kpuie la wɔe be nyemete ŋu wɔa nanewo o.
Natalie: Obviously, the height issue comes into play for me.
Nu suesuesue aɖewo, abe asidodo ɖa atsɔ nane si woɖo ɖe ati si kɔ vie dzi le fiase me ene, gɔ̃ hã menya wɔna nam o.
Doing ordinary things​ like reaching for items on the shelf at a store ​is a challenge.
Mekpea fu ŋutɔ ne nye ɖeka meyi nane ƒle ge le fiase me.
When I shop alone, it takes a lot of effort.
Timothy: Hekpe ɖe ale si mesea lãmeve atraɖii ŋu la, blanuiléle hã ɖea fu nam enuenu.
Timothy: I’ve had to cope with continuous pain, along with bouts of depression.
Hafi mava zu dɔnɔ la, mete ŋu wɔa nu sia nu nyuie.
Before I got sick, I was very active.
Dɔwɔɖui nɔ asinye, eye mekua ʋu hã.
I had a job and a driver’s license.
Mewɔa kamedefefewo, abe afɔbɔlƒoƒo ene.
I’d play sports, such as football and squash.
Fifia, nyee nye esia va tsi bunɔkeke me.
Now I’m confined to a wheelchair.
Hiroki: Nyemete ŋu ƒoa nu nyuie o.
Hiroki: I have a speech disability.
Esia ɖea dzi le ƒonye, eye wòna nyemete ŋu doa dzeɖoɖo ɖe amewo gbɔ o.
This discourages me and holds me back from starting conversations.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nye asi ʋãna le eɖokui si ɖaƒoa ame aɖe le vo me.
Sometimes, involuntary hand movements cause me to hit someone accidentally.
Ne edzɔ nenema la, le nye nuƒoƒo ƒe kuxia ta la, nyemete ŋu gblɔna be, "Meɖe kuku, " gɔ̃ hã o.
When this happens, I can’t even say "I’m sorry, " on account of my speech problem.
Nyɔ! talawo: Nu kae kpe ɖe ŋuwò nète ŋu nɔ te ɖe kuxiawo nu?
Awake!: What has helped you to cope with your situation?
Danielle: Medzea agbagba tsɔa nye susu ɖoa nu nyui siwo ade dzi ƒo nam la ŋu.
Danielle: I try to focus on the good things in my life.
Ƒome nyui aɖe mee mele, xɔlɔ̃ lɔ̃amewo le asinye le hamea me, eye ƒo wo katã ta la, Yehowa Mawu nye nye kpeɖeŋutɔ gãtɔ.
I have a wonderful family, I have loving friends in the congregation and, most of all, I have Jehovah God as my support.
Medzea agbagba hã nyaa nyatakaka yeye ɖe sia ɖe si ku ɖe ale si suklidɔlélawo awɔ anɔ te ɖe woƒe kuxiwo nui ŋu.
I also try to keep up-to-date with information on diabetes management.
Menya be nye ŋutɔe anɔ ŋudzɔ be nye dɔa naganyra ɖe edzi o, eya ta medzea agbagba vevie léa be na ɖokuinye.
I take responsibility for my health and do my best to look after myself.
Natalie: Gbedodoɖa doa ŋusẽm geɖe ŋutɔ.
Natalie: Prayer is a source of strength.
Medzea agbagba kpɔa nye kuxiwo gbɔ ɖekaɖeka.
I try to deal with my problems one at a time.
Medzea agbagba be manɔ nu ɖɔʋu aɖe wɔm ɣesiaɣi, si wɔnɛ be nyemebua nu siwo ana dzi naɖe le ƒonye la ŋu o.
Keeping busy helps me not to dwell on negative thoughts.
Dzila nyui eve hã le asinye, siwo mete ŋu gblɔa nye dzimenyawo na faa.
And I have two wonderful parents in whom I can confide. Timothy, 20 Britain
Timothy: Mewɔa nane si do ƒome kple nye mawusubɔsubɔ gbe sia gbe, ne eɖanye hena ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe gɔ̃ hã.
Timothy: I do something spiritual each day, even if it’s just for a short time.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, medzea ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe gɔme kple Ŋɔŋlɔawo me dzodzro.
For example, I start each day with a consideration of the daily text.
Nyemelɔ̃a nu le ɖokuisi Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ kple gbedodoɖa gbɔ o, vevietɔ le ɣeyiɣi siwo me nu te ɖe dzinye vevie.
Personal Bible study and prayer are very important to me, especially when I’m at an emotional low.
Hiroki: Medzea agbagba be magatsi dzi fũu akpa ɖe nu siwo ŋu nyemate ŋu awɔ naneke le o ŋu o.
Hiroki: I try not to worry about things that I can’t do anything about.
Esia anye fuɖeɖe na ɖokuinye yakatsyɔ.
That’s a waste of time.
Gake mewɔa nu sia nu si mate ŋui bene mía kple Mawu dome ƒomedodoa me nasẽ ɖe edzi, eye nyemetsɔa nɔnɔme si me mele doa taflatse le Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ gome o.
On the other hand, I do all I can to build myself up spiritually, and I don’t use my condition as an excuse not to study the Bible.
Ne medo kpo alɔ̃dɔdɔ le zã me la, mewɔa mɔnukpɔkpɔa ŋu dɔ tsɔ doa gbe ɖa.
When I can’t sleep, I view it as an opportunity to pray.​ See Romans 12:12.
Xlẽ Romatɔwo 12:12.
Awake!: How have others encouraged you?
Nyɔ! talawo: Aleke ame bubuwo de dzi ƒo na wòe?
Hiroki, 23 Japan
Hiroki: Hamemetsitsiwo kafuam ɣesiaɣi ɖe agbagba sue si mete ŋu dzena la ta.
Hiroki: The elders always commend me for the little that I can do.
Nɔviŋutsu kple nɔvinyɔnu siwo le hamea me hã naa mekplɔa wo ɖo mieɖasrãa ame siwo tsɔ ɖe le nya nyuia me la kpɔ hesrɔ̃a Biblia kple ame bubuwo hã. Xlẽ Romatɔwo 12:10.
The brothers and sisters in the congregation also take me with them on their return visits and Bible studies.​ See Romans 12:10.
Danielle: Magblɔ be, nu si wɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye koŋue nye ne nɔviŋutsu kple nɔvinyɔnu siwo le hamea me kafum tso dzi blibo me.
Danielle: Probably the thing that touches me most is when the brothers and sisters in the congregation sincerely commend me.
Esia nana mekpɔnɛ dzea sii be wolɔ̃m vevie, eye wòdea dzi ƒo nam be mawɔ geɖe wu.
That makes me feel appreciated, and it encourages me to continue.
Timothy: Nɔvinyɔnu tsitsi aɖe dzea agbagba etɔxɛe ɖoa dze kplim ɣesiaɣi si míeyi kpekpewo.
Timothy: There’s an elderly sister who always makes a special effort to talk to me at the meetings.
Hamemetsitsiwo kple wo srɔ̃wo hã dea dzi ƒo nam heɖoa aɖaŋu nyuiwo nam.
Elders and their wives have also given me encouragement and practical advice.
Hamemetsitsi aɖe si xɔ ƒe 84 la kpe ɖe ŋunye meɖo taɖodzinu siwo gbɔ mate ŋu aɖo la na ɖokuinye.
One elder, who is 84 years old, has helped me to set reachable goals.
Subɔsubɔdɔwɔla aɖe si le míaƒe hamea me la kpem be makpɔ gome le gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me kpli ye, eye ena míeɖawɔ dɔ le nuto siwo me nye bunɔkekea ate ŋu azɔ le bɔbɔe la me. Xlẽ Psalmo 55:23.
A ministerial servant invited me to work with him in the ministry, and he arranged for us to work in an area that was flat and therefore accessible to my wheelchair.​ See Psalm 55:22.
Natalie: Ne menya ge ɖe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me ko la, hamea me nɔviŋutsu kple nɔvinyɔnuwo doa gbe nam vividoɖeameŋutɔe.
Natalie: As soon as I walk into the Kingdom Hall, my spiritual brothers and sisters greet me with warm smiles.
Ame tsitsiwo gblɔa dzideƒonamenyawo nam ɣesiaɣi, togbɔ be kuxiwo ɖea fu na woawo ŋutɔwo hã gɔ̃ hã. Xlẽ 2 Korintotɔwo 4:16, 17.
The older ones always have an encouraging thought to share, despite their own hardships.​ See 2 Corinthians 4:16, 17.
Nyɔ! talawo: Nu kawoe kpe ɖe ŋuwò nègakpɔtɔ kpɔa dzidzɔ?
Awake!: What helps you to keep a positive attitude?
Hiroki: Abe Yehowa Ðasefo ene la, menyae be habɔbɔ si me tɔwo si mɔkpɔkpɔ wɔnuku aɖe le la me tɔe menye.
Hiroki: As one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I associate with an organization of people who have a bright hope.
Nyanya be habɔbɔ sia mee mele nana mekpɔa dzidzɔ. Xlẽ 2 Kronika 15:7.
Realizing what I’m part of helps me to be positive.​ See 2 Chronicles 15:7.
Danielle: Medea ŋugble tso mɔnukpɔkpɔ si su asinye be mese Mawu ƒe tameɖoɖowo gɔme la ŋu.
Danielle: I think about the privilege I have of understanding God’s purpose.
Ame aɖewo li siwo le lãmesẽ nyui me, gake womekpɔa dzidzɔ le agbe me abe ale si mele dzidzɔ kpɔm ene o. Xlẽ Lododowo 15:15.
There are people who are in good health, yet they aren’t as satisfied with their life as I am with mine.​ See Proverbs 15:15.
Natalie: Medina vevie be manɔ ame siwo kpɔa dzidzɔ la dome ɣesiaɣi.
Natalie: I find it important to surround myself with people who are positive.
Ame siwo kua kutri le Yehowa subɔsubɔ me togbɔ be wotoa nɔnɔme sesẽwo me la ƒe agbemeŋutinyawo xexlẽ hã dea dzi ƒo nam ŋutɔ.
It’s also encouraging to read experiences of others who are serving Jehovah despite trials.
Eye ɣesiaɣi si meyi Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me la, menyae be maxɔ ŋusẽdodo kple ŋkuɖodzinya geɖe ku ɖe mɔnukpɔkpɔ gã si wònye be ame nanye Yehowa Ðasefowo dometɔ ɖeka la ŋu. Xlẽ Hebritɔwo 10:24, 25.
And when I go to the Kingdom Hall, I always know I’ll be strengthened and reminded of what a privilege it is to be one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.​ See Hebrews 10:24, 25.
Timothy: Le 1 Korintotɔwo 10:13 ƒe nya nu la, Yehowa meɖea mɔ be nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo me míate ŋu ato o la nava mía dzi o.
Timothy: According to 1 Corinthians 10:13, Jehovah won’t let us go through more than we can bear.
Megblɔna na ɖokuinye be ne Wɔnyela la ka ɖe edzi be mate ŋu ato nɔnɔme sesẽ sia me la, ame kae menye be mato nyatoƒoe le eŋu? g08 02-E.
I reason that if my Creator is confident that I can cope with this trial, who am I to argue?
BU NYA SIAWO ŊU
TO THINK ABOUT
▪ Hiroki kple Timothy siaa tsi bunɔkeke me.
Hiroki and Timothy are both confined to wheelchairs.
Ne nɔnɔme ma tɔgbi mee nèle la, alekee nya siwo wogblɔ ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔtɔ anye dzidzɔme?
If you are in a similar situation, how can their comments help you to maintain a positive attitude?
▪ Danielle gblɔ be "esi wònye be suklidɔ medzena le ame ŋu wokpɔna kple ŋku o ta la, amewo menya ale si gbegbe wòvɔ̃ɖii o. "
Danielle notes that "since diabetes isn’t visible, some people don’t realize how serious it is. "
Ðe dɔléle aɖe si medzena le ame ŋu wokpɔna o la le fu ɖem na wò hã?
Do you too suffer from an "invisible " illness?
Ne nenemae la, nu kawoe nàte ŋu asrɔ̃ tso nya siwo Danielle gblɔ me?
If so, what lessons can you learn from Danielle’s expressions?
▪ Natalie gblɔ be nu siwo ɖea fu na ye wu dometɔ ɖekae nye ale si amewo wɔa nui ne wokpɔ ye.
Natalie says that one of the biggest challenges she faces is dealing with how people react when they see her.
Nu kae nàte ŋu awɔ atsɔ ana be ame aɖe si le nɔnɔme si ɖi Natalie tɔa me la naɖe dzi ɖi?
How would you put someone like Natalie at ease?
Ne ènye nuwɔametɔ alo dɔléle aɖe na nèsena le ɖokuiwò me abe Natalie ene la, nu kae nàte ŋu asrɔ̃ tso ale si wòte ŋu kpɔtɔ nye dzidzɔme la me?
If you have an illness or a disability that makes you feel the way Natalie does, how can you imitate her positive attitude?
▪ Ŋlɔ ame siwo nènya, siwo nye nuwɔametɔwo, alo siwo ŋu dɔmavɔleameŋu le, la ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe ete.
List below the names of people you know of who suffer from a disability or a chronic illness.
▪ Nu kae nàte ŋu awɔ atsɔ ade dzi ƒo na ame siawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe?
What can you do to be supportive of each one of them?
Akɔfafa Si Biblia Nana
Comfort From the Bible
▪ Yesu ɖe dɔmetɔtrɔ vavã fia ame siwo nɔ dɔ lém. Marko 1:41.
Jesus has genuine compassion for those who are ailing.​ Mark 1:41.
▪ Yesu to "dɔléle ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi kpakple lãmegbegblẽ ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi " dada na amewo dzi ɖe ale si woayɔ dɔ na dɔnɔwo ne Mawu ƒe Fiaɖuƒea te anyigbaa dzi ɖuɖu la fia. Mateo 4:23.
By "curing every sort of disease and every sort of infirmity, " Jesus demonstrated the healing that will take place under God’s Kingdom.​ Matthew 4:23.
▪ Le Mawu ƒe xexe yeyea me la, "[ame] aɖeke magblɔ be, yele dɔ lém o, " eye vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o. Yesaya 33:24; Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1-4.
In God’s new world, "no resident will say: ‘I am sick,’ " and pain will be no more.​ Isaiah 33:24; Revelation 21:1-4.
▪ ‘Woaɖe ku gɔ̃ hã ɖa kura.’ 1 Korintotɔwo 15:25, 26.
Even death will be "brought to nothing. "​ 1 Corinthians 15:25, 26.
"Nyemeɖe Mɔ Nye Dɔlélea Kpe Dzinye O "
"I Refuse to Dwell On My Illness "
"Ehiãna be woakpe ɖe ŋunye hafi mamlɔ anyi alo afɔ le aba dzi.
"I needed help getting in and out of bed.
Azɔlizɔzɔ zu dɔ nam.
Walking was painful.
Nye ve me xe ale gbegbe be nyemetea ŋu noa nye vevesesenutsitikewo o.
My throat closed up so that I couldn’t swallow my pain pills.
Medze abi siwo gbe kuku, eye wo dometɔ aɖewo va zu abi vɔ̃wo.
I developed sores that wouldn’t heal, some of which later became gangrenous.
Dɔmebi kple dziʋudzo sesẽ aɖe ɖe kpe nam.
I had stomach ulcers and severe heartburn.
Nyemenɔ nu si nɔ dzɔdzɔm ɖe dzinye la gɔme sem o.
I didn’t understand what was happening.
Ƒe ewo koe mexɔ ɣemaɣi. "​ Elisa.
I was just ten years old. "​ Elisa.
Elisa le Biblia me gbedeasia gblɔm na ame aɖe
Elisa sharing the Bible’s message
Togbɔ be wɔna boo mele Elisa ŋu o hã la, Biblia fiafia amewo nana wòkpɔa dzidzɔ
Despite her limitations, Elisa enjoys teaching others about the Bible
ŊUTIGBALẼDƆ si nana ame ƒe ŋutilã liana goŋgoŋ ye le eŋu. Ame miliɔn eve kple afã léa dɔ sia le xexea me godoo.
SCLERODERMA​ meaning "hard skin " ​is a word used to describe diseases that afflict an estimated 2.5 million people worldwide.
Zi geɖe la, dɔ sia ƒomevi siwo léa ɖeviwo la nye esi wɔa ŋutilã ƒe akpa aɖe ko, eye esia nana ŋutilã liana.
The type most often seen in children is localized scleroderma, which mainly involves a hardening of the skin tissues.
Ke hã wokpɔ dɔ sia ƒomevi si xɔa ŋutilã bliboa katã le Elisa ŋu esi wòxɔ ƒe ewo pɛ ko, eye dɔa ge ɖe eƒe lãmenuwo abe ayiku, dzi, dzitodzito kple dɔgbo gɔ̃ hã me.

Elisa, however, was diagnosed at age ten with a form of systemic scleroderma​ a condition that can seriously affect not only the skin but also the function of internal organs, involving the kidneys, heart, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.
Ðɔktawo gblɔ be dɔdamɔnu si woazã la ana Elisa nate ŋu anɔ agbe ƒe atɔ̃ pɛ.
Doctors thought that treatment would prolong Elisa’s life by only five years.
Gake ƒe 14 sɔŋue nye esi va yi Elisa gakpɔtɔ le agbe.
Now, some 14 years later, Elisa is very much alive.
Togbɔ be dɔa gakpɔtɔ le eŋu hã la, meɖe mɔ mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖee le agbe me o.
Although she is not cured, she maintains a positive attitude about life.
Nyɔ! talawo bia gbe Elisa ku ɖe eƒe dɔlélea kple ale si wòte ŋu le te nɔm ɖe nɔnɔmea nui la ŋu.
Awake! spoke to Elisa about her illness and her strength to endure.
Ɣekaɣie nèva de dzesii be yele dɔ lém?
When did you first become aware that you were not well?
Esi mexɔ ƒe asieke la, nane si abɔklugui nam, eye mese veve vevie.
When I was nine years old, I got a cut on my elbow, and it was extremely painful.
Ðeko abia nɔ kekem ɖe edzi hegbe kuku.
The wound got bigger, and it wouldn’t heal.
Esi wodo nye ʋu kpɔ la, wokpɔe be ŋutigbalẽdɔ vɔ̃ɖi sia le ŋunye.
A blood test revealed that I had systemic scleroderma.
Esi wònye be nye dɔlélea nɔ nyanyram ɖe edzi kabakaba ta la, ehiã be míadi dɔ sia dala bibi aɖe be wòakpɔ gbɔnye.
Because my health was deteriorating rapidly, we needed to find a doctor who had experience treating scleroderma.
Aleke nuwo va yie?
How did your search turn out?
Míeva ke ɖe ɖɔkta aɖe si daa dɔ sia ŋu.
We found a rheumatologist.
Egblɔ na dzinyelawo be ne wowɔ kansatike nam la, alé nye dɔlélea nu eye wòana manɔ agbe ƒe atɔ̃ ya teti, eye wosusui hã be ɖewohĩ dɔlélea ava ɖo aɖa le eɖokui si.
She told my parents that chemotherapy could slow down the scleroderma and extend my life by five years, with the possibility that my illness might go into remission.
Gake dɔdamɔnu sia ana nye dɔlélenutsiŋutete nagbɔdzɔ.
The downside was that chemotherapy would compromise my immune system.
Eye wòawɔe be kpeƒoame gɔ̃ hã ate ŋu awum bɔbɔe.
Even a cold could prove fatal.
Edze ƒãa be nu si wonɔ vɔvɔ̃m na medzɔ o, alo?
Obviously, the worst did not happen.
Ɛ̃​ dzidzɔtɔe la, mekpɔtɔ le agbe!
No​ thankfully, I’m still alive!
Gake esi mexɔ ƒe 12 la, akɔta veam vevie henɔa anyi abe miniti 30 ene, eye ɣeaɖewoɣi la, esia hona nam zi eve le ŋkeke ɖeka me.
When I was about 12, though, I started experiencing severe chest pains that would last for about 30 minutes, sometimes twice a day.
Enu sẽna ale gbegbe be ɣli dzi ko menɔna.
They were so bad that they made me scream.
Nu ka gbɔe wòtso?
What was the cause?
Ðɔktawo de dzesii be ʋumenugbagbevidzĩ me nu siwo woyɔna be hemoglobin mesɔ gbɔ le ʋu me nam o, eye esia nana be nye dzi wɔa dɔ wu ale si dze ne egbɔ ʋua le ɖoɖom ɖe ahɔhɔ̃a.
The doctors found that my hemoglobin level was dangerously low and that my heart was working overtime to pump blood to my brain.
Le kwasiɖa ʋɛ aɖewo megbe la, dɔdamɔnu sia na mekpɔ gbɔdzɔe vie ya.
Within a few weeks, treatment relieved the problem.
Gake ɣemaɣi la, meɖo ŋkui be megblɔna na ɖokuinye be nu sia nu ate ŋu adzɔ ɖe dzinye le ŋkeke si kplɔe ɖo me.
But at that point, I remember thinking that anything could happen from one day to the next.
Dzi ɖe le ƒonye wu tsã abe ɖe naneke meli mate ŋu awɔ tso nye nɔnɔmea ŋu o ene.
I felt more helpless than ever, as if I had no control over what was happening to me.
Ƒe wuiene sɔŋue nye esia wokpɔ dɔ sia le ŋuwò, ke aleke nuwo le na wò fifia?
It has been 14 years since your condition was diagnosed. What is the state of your health now?
Megakpɔtɔ sea veve helĩhelĩ, eye dɔléle siwo ŋutigbalẽdɔ sia hena vɛ la hã kpɔtɔ ɖea fu nam.
I still live with pain, and I have a number of ailments that are associated with scleroderma.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye dɔmebi, dzitodzitodɔ kple dziʋudzodɔ.
These include ulcers, lung fibrosis, and severe heartburn.
Ke hã, nyemetsɔa susu ɖoa nye dɔlélea ŋu kaka ahayi nye ɣeyiɣi gblẽ ge ɖe eŋu wòana malé blanui o.
Still, I refuse to dwell on my illness or waste time feeling sad.
Nu bubuwo le ŋunye mawɔ.
I have other things to do.
Abe nu kawo ene?
Like what?
Nutata, avɔlɔlɔ̃ kple atsyɔ̃ɖonuwo wɔwɔ dzɔa dzi nam.
I love drawing, making clothes, making jewelry.
Gake esi wònye Yehowa Ðasefoe menye ta la, Biblia fiafia amewoe nye dɔ vevitɔ si mewɔna.
Most important, though, as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I engage in the work of teaching the Bible.
Le ɣeyiɣi siwo me nyemate ŋu azɔ ayi amewo gbɔ le woƒe aƒe me o gɔ̃ hã la, mekpena ɖe Ðasefo bubuwo ŋu míesrɔ̃a Biblia kple amewo le míaƒe nutoa me.
Even when I am not able to walk to people’s homes, I am able to assist other Witnesses who conduct Bible study sessions with people in our area.
Biblia-nusrɔ̃viwo le nye ŋutɔ hã asinye.
I have even had students of my own.
Gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa na viɖe le nye agbe ŋu.
The ministry gives my life purpose.
Nu ka tae nègawɔa dɔ sia esi wònye be mele ɖeɖem na wò ŋutɔ hã o?
Why do you engage in this work when you have your own problems to contend with?
Menyae be nya siwo megblɔna na amewo la le vevie eye viɖe le wo ŋu.
I know that the information I share with people is vital and beneficial.
Gawu la, ne mele kpekpem ɖe amewo ŋu alea la, mekpɔa dzidzɔ geɖe wu.
Besides, when I keep busy helping others in this way, I’m happier.
Ewɔna nam be nye lãmea ka ɖe eme!
I even feel healthier!
Le ɣeyiɣi kpui siwo metsɔ ɖea gbeƒã na amewo me la, meŋlɔa nye dɔlélea be.
For that brief period of time, I forget that I’m sick.
Aleke Biblia kpe ɖe ŋuwò ale be mɔkpɔkpɔ mebu ɖe wò o?
What role does the Bible play in your positive viewpoint?
Eɖoa ŋku edzi nam be nye fukpekpewo kple ame bubuwo tɔ siaa maganɔ anyi eteƒe nadidi o.
It reminds me that my suffering​ and the suffering of others as well ​is just temporary.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4 gblɔ be le Mawu ƒe ɣeyiɣi ɖoɖi dzi la, atutu "aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi o, eye konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o. "
Revelation 21:4 says that at his appointed time, God "will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore. "
Mawunyakpukpui siawo tɔgbi nana megakana ɖe etsɔme nyui si ƒe ŋugbe Mawu do be yeahe vɛ na amewo katã, ke menye na ame siwo le dɔ mavɔleameŋu lém la ɖeɖe ko o la dzi geɖe wu.
Thinking about scriptures like that helps strengthen my faith in God’s promise of a bright future​ not just for those who suffer with chronic illnesses but for everyone.
Yehowa ‘Tsɔa Nye Agbawo Nam Gbe Sia Gbe’
Jehovah ‘Daily Carries the Load for Me’
Maretha du Raan
Maretha du Raan
Togbɔ be dɔléle sesẽ aɖe si dze abe nu si nu nyemate ŋu anɔ te ɖo o ene ɖea fu nam vevie hã la, mía Fofo lɔlɔ̃a si le dziƒo kpe ɖe ŋunye va se ɖe fifia.
Despite an uncertain health condition that might have seemed unbearable, I have felt the loving support of our dear heavenly Father throughout my life.
Eye ƒe 20 kple edzivɔe nye esia mele mɔɖeɖedɔa wɔm hele dzidzɔ tɔxɛ kpɔm le Yehowa subɔsubɔ me.
And for more than 20 years, I have found special joy serving Jehovah as a pioneer.
Wodzim le ƒe 1956 me kple dzimeƒudɔ aɖe.
I was born in 1956 with spina bifida.
Woyɔa dɔ sia le Eŋlisigbe me be spina bifida. Dɔléle sia na wòsesẽna nam be mazɔ, eye wòhe lãmesẽkuxi sesẽ bubuwo va dzinye.
Because the neural tube in my spine failed to close completely, nerve damage has made it difficult for me to walk and has caused other serious health problems.
Ɣeyiɣi aɖe do ŋgɔ hafi woadzim la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dutanyanyuigblɔla aɖewo dze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ gɔme kple dzinyelawo.
Some time before my birth, missionaries of Jehovah’s Witnesses started to study the Bible with my parents.
Le nye ɖevime la, gbeƒãɖela ʋɛ aɖewo koe nɔ mía de Usakos, le Namibia.
During my childhood, only a few isolated publishers lived in my hometown of Usakos, Namibia.
Eya ta míesrɔ̃a nu siwo woasrɔ̃ le hame ƒe kpekpewo me la abe ƒome ene.
Hence, we considered the material for congregation meetings as a family.
Esi mexɔ ƒe adre la, wowɔ dɔ nam, si me woŋɔ nye ŋutilã ƒe akpa aɖe, afi si maɖɔ aɖuɖɔ atoe.
At age seven, I had a urostomy, an operation performed to create an artificial opening in my body so that I could pass urine.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 14 la, meva nɔ kpeŋuidɔ (adzigbo) hã lém.
At age 14, I developed epilepsy.
Esi sekɛndrisuku (lycée) si le míaƒe nutoa me la didi tso mía gbɔ eye mehiã dzinyelawo ƒe beléle tɔxɛ ta la, nyemete ŋu wu enu o.
Because the nearest high school was far away and I needed special care from my parents, I could not complete my schooling.
Ke hã, meɖoe be mana nye kple Yehowa dome ƒomedodoa me nasẽ.
Nevertheless, I decided to fortify myself spiritually.
Wometa míaƒe Kristotɔwo ƒe agbalẽ geɖe ɖe mía degbe Afrikaans me o.
Many of our Christian publications were not yet available in Afrikaans, my mother tongue.
Eya ta mesrɔ̃ Eŋlisigbe xexlẽ ale be mate ŋu asrɔ̃ míaƒe agbalẽ bubuwo.
So I learned to read English in order to study a number of our books.
Mezu Fiaɖuƒegbeƒãɖela eye mexɔ nyɔnyrɔ esi mexɔ ƒe 19.
I became a Kingdom publisher and got baptized at age 19.
Le ƒe ene siwo kplɔe ɖo me la, lãmesẽ kple seselelãme kuxi geɖewo ɖe fu nam.
During the following four years, I had many health problems and emotional difficulties.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, esi kadodo kplikplikpli le míaƒe kɔƒea me tɔwo dome ta la, amegbetɔvɔvɔ̃ xe mɔ nam be nyemete ŋu nɔ geɖe wɔm le subɔsubɔdɔa me o.
Moreover, in the close-knit community in my hometown, fear of man prevented me from having a zealous share in the ministry.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 20 teti la, míeʋu tso Namibia yi South Africa, eye ɣemaɣie mede ha kple hame aɖe hede kpekpe zi gbãtɔ.
During my early 20’s, we moved from Namibia to South Africa, and for the first time, I was able to associate with a congregation.
Dzidzɔ ka gbegbee nye esi!
How wonderful that was!
Gake eva hiã be woagawɔ dɔ nam ake; woŋɔ nye ŋutilã ƒe akpa bubu, afi si made afɔdzi toe.
However, I had to undergo surgery again this time a colostomy.
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, mese nutome sue dzikpɔla ƒe nuƒo si woƒo tso mɔɖeɖedɔa wɔwɔ ŋu.
Some time later, I heard a circuit overseer speak on the subject of pioneering.
Nya siwo wògblɔ la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye.
His remarks touched my heart.
Menyae be mɔɖeɖedɔa wɔwɔ asesẽ nam le nye lãmesẽ ta, gake mekpɔ ale si Yehowa kpe ɖe ŋunye le nɔnɔme sesẽ geɖe me.
I knew that my health was less than ideal, but I had seen how Jehovah had carried me through many difficulties.
Eya ta mebia be mazu gbesiagbe mɔɖela.
So I applied to be a regular pioneer.
Gake le nye lãmesẽkuxiwo ta la, hamemetsitsiwo he ɖe megbe le asidede dɔbiagbalẽvia te me.
However, because of my health problems, the elders hesitated to approve my application.
Ke hã, metso nya me be mawɔ nye ŋutete katã le Fiaɖuƒegbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me.
Still, I decided to give Kingdom preaching my best effort.
Danye kple nɔvi bubuwo kpe ɖe ŋunye mete ŋu ɖo mɔɖelawo ƒe gaƒoƒonudidia gbɔ ɣleti ade sɔŋ.
With the help of my mother and others, I managed to devote pioneer hours to the ministry over a period of six months.
Esia ɖe ale si meɖoe kplikpaa be mawɔ mɔɖeɖedɔa fia, eye ena wòdze ƒãa be mate ŋu awɔe togbɔ be lãmesẽkuxiwo le ŋunye hã.
That proved my determination to pioneer and showed that my health problems were manageable.
Megade asi mɔɖeɖedɔ ƒe dɔbiagbalẽvia te ake, eye fifia ya woda asi ɖe edzi.
I applied again, and this time my application was approved.
Le September 1, 1988 dzi la, mezu gbesiagbe mɔɖela.
On September 1, 1988, I became a regular pioneer.
Abe mɔɖela ene la, mekpɔa Yehowa ƒe ŋusẽdoame ɣesiaɣi.
As a pioneer, I have constantly experienced Jehovah’s support.
Nyateƒea fiafia ame yeyewo kpɔ tanye, enyim, eye wòkpe ɖe ŋunye metsi le gbɔgbɔ me, ale be nyemetsɔa susu ɖoa nye nɔnɔmea ŋu o.
Teaching new ones the truth instead of focusing on my own situation has protected me, nurtured me, and helped me to grow spiritually.
Mekpe ɖe ame gbogbo aɖewo ŋu woɖe adzɔgbe xɔ nyɔnyrɔ, eye esia he dzidzɔ manyagblɔ vɛ nam.
I have derived immense joy from helping a number of individuals to dedication and baptism.
Nye lãmesẽnyawo tea ŋu trɔna kpata.
My health remains uncertain.
Gake Yehowa ‘tsɔa nye agbawo nam gbe sia gbe.’
But Jehovah ‘daily carries the load for me.’
(Ps.
(Ps.
68:20) Menye ɖeko wòkpena ɖe ŋunye metea ŋu nɔa te ɖe nye kuxiwo nu o, ke enana wònyea dzidzɔ nam be mele agbe!
68:19) He does more than just make my life bearable; he makes it a pleasure for me to be alive!
Megbɔdzɔ Gake Ŋusẽ Le Ŋunye
Finding Strength Out of Weakness
Abe ale si Maite Morlans gblɔe ene
As told by Maite Morlans
Ame aɖeke makpɔ nye ame beli sia le bunɔkeke me ahasusu be ŋusẽ le ŋunye o, elabena nye kpekpeme nye kilogram 29 pɛ ko.
Seeing my fragile 65-pound (29 kg) body seated in a wheelchair, no one would think that I am strong.
Gake esi nye ametia le gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔm la, ŋusẽ si le ememe la léam ɖe te.
But as my body loses its power, inner strength keeps me going.
Na maɖe nu si tae togbɔ be menye ame beli hã megblɔ be ŋusẽ le ŋunye la me.
Let me explain how strength and weakness have shaped my life.
Esime Maite xɔ ƒe ene le France
Maite in France, at age four
Esi mexɔ ƒe ene
At age four
Ne meɖo ŋku nye ɖevime dzi la, mekpɔnɛ be menye ɖevi si dzi dzɔna ŋutɔ; míenɔ aƒe kotoe aɖe me le kɔƒedu aɖe me le France ƒe anyiehe, afi si dzinyelawo nɔ.
Thinking of my childhood brings back memories of happy days in a country cottage in the south of France, where my parents lived.
Fofonye wɔ segblesegble nam, eye melɔ̃a duƒuƒu le míaƒe abɔ me.
My father made a swing for me, and I loved running around the garden.
Le ƒe 1966 me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo vaa mía ƒe me va dzroa Biblia me kple fofonye gaƒoƒo geɖe.
In 1966, Jehovah’s Witnesses visited our home and had long conversations with my father.
Le ɣleti adre ko megbe la, etso nya me be yeazu Ðasefo.
Just seven months later, he resolved to become a Witness.
Eteƒe medidi o, danye hã zu Ðasefo, eye wonyim le ƒome si me dzidzɔ le me.
My mother soon followed in his footsteps, and they raised me in a warm family environment.
Esi míetrɔ yi mía de Spain megbe kpuie koe nye kuxiwo dze egɔme.
My problems began shortly after we returned to Spain, my parents’ home country.
Nye alɔtinuwo kple afɔkɔewo va nɔ veyem vevie.
I started feeling stabbing pains in my hands and ankles.
Esi míetsa le ɖɔktawo dzi ƒe eve sɔŋ megbe la, míeva ke ɖe ŋuɖuidɔŋutinunyala bibi aɖe ŋu, eye wògblɔ moveviɖoɖotɔe be, "Etsi megbe akpa. "
After two years of visiting many doctors, we found a renowned rheumatologist, who solemnly said, "It’s too late. "
Tete danye te avifafa.
My mother started to weep.

Yevugbe me nya gãgãwo, abe "autoimmune chronic illness " (dɔlélenutsiŋutete ƒe nugbegblẽ le lãmenugbagbeviwo ŋu) kple "juvenile polyarthritis " (ŋuɖui si ɖea fu na ɖeviwo) ene ko sem menɔ le xɔ fafɛ ma si me fu kpii la me.
Strange expressions, such as "autoimmune chronic illness " and "juvenile polyarthritis, " echoed around that cold, gray room.
Togbɔ be ƒe ewo pɛ koe mexɔ eye nyemese nu geɖe gɔme o hã la, mekpɔe be nya vɔ̃ aɖee wòanye.
Though I understood little as a ten-year-old girl, I realized that the news was bad.
Ðɔktaa gblɔ be anyo be woakplɔm ayi ɖevi dɔnɔwo dzi kpɔƒe.
The doctor suggested treatment in a children’s sanatorium.
Esi míeɖo afi ma eye mekpɔe be teƒea nye xɔ aɖe si womeɖo atsyɔ̃ na kura o la, nye nu wɔ nublanui na ɖokuinye.
On my arrival, the austere building dismayed me.
Mía dzi kpɔlawo ƒe asi sẽ ɖe mía dzi: Nyɔnu saɖeagaxɔmenɔlawo kpa ɖa nam eye wodo awu miloo aɖe la nam.
Discipline was strict: The nuns cut my hair and dressed me in a dowdy uniform.
Aɖatsi lólo ɖe ŋku dzi nam eye megblɔ le susu me be, ‘Ðe mate ŋu anɔ afi sia?’
‘How can I endure life here?’ I thought, tearfully.
YEHOWA KPE ÐE ŊUNYE
JEHOVAH BECOMES REAL TO ME
Esi dzinyelawo fiam be Yehowae wòle be míasubɔ ta la, megbe be nyemakpɔ gome le Katolikotɔwo ƒe subɔsubɔkɔnuwo me le dɔnɔdzikpɔƒea o.
Because my parents had taught me to serve Jehovah, I refused to take part in Catholic rituals in the sanatorium.
Nyɔnu saɖeagaxɔmenɔlawo mete ŋu se nu si tae megbe ɖo la gɔme o.
The nuns found it hard to understand why I refused.
Meɖe kuku na Yehowa be megagblẽm ɖim o, eye le ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe megbe la, mekpɔe be ele tanye kpɔm.
I implored Jehovah not to abandon me, and I soon felt his protective arm around me, like the warm, firm hug of a loving father.
Esia na mese le ɖokuinye me abe ɖe wòkpla asi kɔ nam abe ale si vifofo kplaa asi kɔ na via lɔlɔ̃tɔe ene.
My parents were allowed to visit me briefly on Saturdays.
Wotsɔ Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽwo vɛ nam be manɔ xexlẽm be wòado ŋusẽ nye xɔse.
They brought me Bible publications to read to keep my faith strong.
Le ɖoɖoa nu la, womeɖe mɔ be agbalẽ aɖeke nanɔ mí ɖeviawo si o, ke hã, mía dzi kpɔlawo ɖe mɔ na nye ya be agbalẽwo kple Biblia, si mexlẽna gbe sia gbe la, nanɔ asinye.
Children normally could not have their own books, but the nuns allowed me to keep them along with my Bible, which I read every day.
Meɖoa dze tso mɔkpɔkpɔ si le asinye be mava nɔ agbe tegbee le Paradiso me le anyigba dzi, afi si ame aɖeke magadze dɔ le o, la ŋu na mía tɔ nyɔnuviawo.
I also talked to other girls about my hope of living forever in the earthly Paradise, where nobody would get sick.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4) Togbɔ be meléa blanui eye metsia akogo ɣeaɖewoɣi hã la, edzɔ dzi nam be nye xɔse nɔ sesẽm ɖe edzi eye meva ɖoa ŋu ɖe Yehowa ŋu geɖe wu.
(Revelation 21:3, 4) Despite feeling sad and lonely at times, I was glad that my faith and trust in Jehovah were growing stronger.
Ɣleti ade sɔŋ megbe la, ɖɔktawo ɖe asi le ŋunye be matrɔ ayi aƒe me.
After six long months, the doctors sent me home.
Nye dɔlélea mevɔ ya o, ke hã dzi dzɔm ŋutɔ be megbɔ va dzinyelawo gbɔ.
My illness had not relented, but I felt happy to be back with my parents.
Nye ƒunukpeƒeewo gava gblẽ ɖe edzi, eye esia na mese veve ale gbegbe.
My joints became more deformed, and I suffered more pain.
Megbɔdzɔ ŋutɔ esi meɖo nye ƒewuiwo me.
I entered my teenage years very weak.
Ke hã, mexɔ nyɔnyrɔ esi mexɔ ƒe 14, eye meɖoe kplikpaa be masubɔ Fofonye si le dziƒo la kple nye ŋutete katã.
Yet, at the age of 14, I got baptized, determined to serve my heavenly Father the best I could.
Medoa gbe ɖa gblɔna be: "Nu ka tae nyee anɔ fu sia kpem?
However, I sometimes felt disappointed in him. "Why me?
Meɖe kuku da gbe le ŋunye dzro.
Please heal me, " I prayed.
Mèle fu siwo kpem mele la kpɔm oa? "
"Don’t you see how much I am suffering? "
Nuwo menɔ bɔbɔe nam kura le nye sɔhɛme o.
Adolescence was a tough time for me.
Eva hiã be malɔ̃ ɖe edzi be dɔ si lém mele la mele vɔvɔ ge o.
I had to accept that I would not get better.
Ðeko metsɔ ɖokuinye nɔa sɔsɔm kple xɔ̃nyewo wole lãmesẽ nyui me eye ŋusẽ le wo ŋu.
I could not help comparing myself with my friends​ so healthy and full of life.
Ewɔ nam be nyemele ɖeke me o; esia wɔe be meɖea ɖokuinye ɖe aga.
I felt inferior, and I became introverted.
Ke hã, ƒonyemetɔwo kple xɔ̃nyewo dea dzi ƒo nam.
Nevertheless, my family and friends supported me.
Meɖoa ŋku xɔ̃nye Alicia si tsi wum ƒe 20 la dzi kple dzidzɔ, elabena xɔlɔ̃ nyui aɖee wònye nam.
I fondly remember Alicia​ 20 years older than I am ​who became a true friend.
Ekpe ɖe ŋunye be maganɔ nye dɔlélea ŋu bum fũu akpa o, eye be matsɔ ɖe le eme na ame bubuwo tsɔ wu be manɔ nye kuxiwo ŋu bum atraɖii.
She helped me to look beyond my illness and to take an interest in others rather than brooding on my own problems.
METI NU SIWO ANA TAÐODZINU NANƆ NYE AGBEA ŊU YOME
FINDING WAYS TO MAKE MY LIFE MEANINGFUL
Esi mexɔ ƒe 18 la, dɔa ho nam vevie, si wɔe be Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpewo dede gɔ̃ hã nana ɖeɖi tea ŋunye belibeli.
When I was 18, I suffered a severe relapse, and even attending Christian meetings left me exhausted.
Ke hã mewɔa "vovoɣi " si su asinye la ŋu dɔ tsɔ srɔ̃a Biblia nyuie.
Nevertheless, I took advantage of all my "spare time " at home to study the Bible carefully.
Gbedodoɖa edziedzi wɔe be "ŋusẽ si gbɔ dzɔdzɔmetɔ ŋu " kple "Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒoa susu ɖe sia ɖe ta " la su asinye.
The book of Job and the Psalms helped me to understand that at present Jehovah God cares for us primarily spiritually rather than physically.
2 Korintotɔwo 4:7; Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7.
My frequent prayers brought me "the power beyond what is normal " and "the peace of God that surpasses all understanding. "​ 2 Corinthians 4:7; Philippians 4:6, 7.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 22 la, meva kpɔe be matsi bunɔkeke me le nye agbemeŋkeke susɔeawo me.
At the age of 22, I had to face up to life in a wheelchair.
Metsi dzi be amewo ava ɖe susu ɖa le ame si menye la dzi ahanɔ kpɔyem ko abe dɔnɔ si le bunɔkeke me ene.
I feared that people would stop noticing me and see only a wheelchair with a sickly woman.
Gake bunɔkekea va de dzinye le go bubuwo me eye wòɖe vi nam wu ale si mesusui.
However, the wheelchair restored some of my independence, and the "curse " became a blessing.
Xɔ̃nye aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Isabel do susua ɖa be yeakpe ɖe ŋunye matsɔ gaƒoƒo 60 aɖe gbeƒã nya nyuia na amewo le dzinu aɖe me.
A friend named Isabel suggested that I set a personal goal of spending 60 hours in the preaching work with her for one month.
Gbã la, mesusui be manya wɔ nam kura o.
At first, I thought the idea was ridiculous.
Gake medo gbe ɖa na Yehowa be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye, eye le nye ƒometɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃wo ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu me la, mete ŋu wɔe.
But I asked Jehovah for help, and with support from my family and friends, I did it.
Ðeko dzinu ma, si me mewɔ dɔ geɖe le la, va yi kabakaba eye mekpɔe be mete ŋu ɖu nye vɔvɔ̃ kple ŋukpea dzi.
That hectic month passed quickly, and I found that I had overcome my fears and embarrassment.
Mese vivi na dɔa ale gbegbe be, le ƒe 1996 me la, metso nya me be manye gbesiagbe mɔɖela, si fia be matsɔ gaƒoƒo 90 anɔ nya nyui gbɔgblɔ dɔa wɔm dzinu sia dzinu.
I enjoyed it so much that in 1996 I decided to become a regular pioneer​ spending a set number of hours each month in the ministry.
Esia nye nyametsotso nyuitɔ siwo mewɔ kpɔ la dometɔ ɖeka, ena mete ɖe Mawu ŋu kplikplikpli wu eye wòde nye lãmesẽ dzi gɔ̃ hã.
It was one of my best decisions, drawing me closer to God and even strengthening me physically.
Nya nyui gbɔgblɔ dɔa na meʋu nye xɔse me na ame geɖe eye mekpe ɖe ame aɖewo ŋu wova zu Mawu xɔlɔ̃wo.
Engaging in the ministry allowed me to share my faith with many people and help some to become God’s friends.
YEHOWA LÉM ÐE TE
JEHOVAH KEEPS HOLD OF ME
Le ƒe 2001 ƒe dzomeŋɔli me la, mekpɔ ʋufɔku sesẽ aɖe eye nye afɔwo kple evea siaa ŋe.
In the summer of 2001, I suffered a bad car accident and broke both legs.
Esi menɔ dɔbadzi le kɔ aɖe dzi henɔ veve sem helĩhelĩ la, meƒo koko na Yehowa le dzi me be: "Yehowa, meɖe kuku, mègagblẽm ɖi o! "
As I lay in a hospital bed in excruciating pain, I fervently offered a silent prayer: "Please, Jehovah, don’t leave me! "
Ɣemaɣi tututu la, nyɔnu si mlɔ aba si le nye axadzi dzi la biam be, "Yehowa Ðasefoe nènyea? "
Just then, a woman in a nearby bed asked me, "Are you one of Jehovah’s Witnesses? "
Ŋusẽ menɔ ŋunye kaka mayi nya ŋu ɖo ge nɛ o, eya ta ɖeko melɔ̃ ta.
I had no strength to answer, so I just nodded.
Eye wògblɔ be, "Menya mi nyuie!
"I know you people!
Mexlẽa miaƒe magazineawo edziedzi. "
I usually read your magazines, " she said.
Nya mawo do ŋusẽm ale gbegbe.
Those words comforted me greatly.
Togbɔ be menɔ nɔnɔme wɔnublanui ma me hã la, mete ŋu ɖi ɖase tso Yehowa ŋu.
Even in my pitiful state, I could give a witness for Jehovah.
Bubu gã kae nye esi!
What an honor!
Esi nye lãme sẽ vie la, medi be magblɔ nya nyuia na amewo le kɔa dzi.
When I recovered a bit, I decided to witness some more.
Menɔ bunɔkeke me, nye afɔ eveawo katã le akalo me, eye danye tutua kekea míeyia amewo gbɔ le kɔdzixɔa me.
My mother wheeled me around the hospital ward with my two legs in plaster.
Gbe sia gbe la, míeyia dɔnɔ aɖewo gbɔ ɖabiaa woƒe fɔfɔ ta se, eye míetsɔa Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ aɖewo naa wo.
Each day, we visited a few patients, asked how they were, and left some Bible literature with them.
Dɔnɔawo gbɔ yiyi alea tea ɖeɖi ŋunye ale gbegbe, gake Yehowa do ŋusẽm ale si dze.
