Those visits were exhausting, but Jehovah gave me the needed strength.
Maite kpakple dzilawo
Maite with her parents
Mía kple dzinyelawo, le ƒe 2003 me
With my parents in 2003
Le ƒe ʋɛ siwo va yi me la, nye veveseseawo nu gasẽ ɖe edzi, eye fofonye ƒe ku hã gagbã dzi nam vevie.
In the past few years, my aches and pains have increased and the loss of my father added to my distress.
Gake medzea agbagba dea dzi ƒo na ɖokuinye.
Still, I try to keep a positive outlook.
Aleke mewɔa esiae?
How?
Zi ale si wòanya wɔ nam la, menɔa xɔ̃nyewo kple ƒometɔwo gbɔ, eye esia kpena ɖe ŋunye meɖea susu ɖa le nye kuxiwo ŋu.
Whenever possible, I try to be with friends and relatives, and that helps take my mind off my problems.
Eye ne metsi akogo la, mexlẽa nu, mesrɔ̃a Biblia, alo meɖea gbeƒã na amewo to telefon dzi.
And when I am alone, I read, study the Bible, or preach to others by phone.
Zi geɖe la, memiãa ŋku yia ŋugble me ʋĩi henɔa xexe yeye si ŋugbe Mawu do la kpɔm le susu me ɖaa abe ɖe mele ekpɔm to "fesre " nu ene
Often I close my eyes and open my private "window " into the new world that God promises
Mekpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe nu suesuewo ŋu, le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne ya fafɛ le ƒoƒom ɖe mo nam alo ne mese seƒoƒo ƒe ʋeʋẽ lilili.
I also try to enjoy simple pleasures, such as the breeze on my face or the fragrance of flowers.
Medaa akpe na Mawu ɖe nu mawo ta.
These give me reasons to be thankful.
Nu siwo doa nukokoe na ame hã doa dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ.
A good sense of humor also works wonders.
Gbe ɖeka esime míenɔ gbeƒã ɖem la, xɔ̃nye si nɔ nye kekea tutum la tɔ be yeade dzesi nane ɖe agbalẽ me.
One day while out preaching, my friend, who was pushing my wheelchair, paused to make a note.
Kasia kekea te zɔzɔ le eɖokui si le esi anyigbaa kɔ kpo vie ta, eye wòzɔ lalala yi ɖalɔ ʋu aɖe si wotɔ ɖi.
Suddenly I was rolling down a slope out of control, and I crashed into a parked car.
Mí ame evea siaa ƒe mo wɔ yaa, gake esi míekpɔe be afɔku aɖeke medzɔ o la, enumake míede asi nukoko me eteƒe mekɔ o.
Both of us were shocked, but when we saw that nothing serious had happened, we had a good laugh.
Maite Morlans
Maite Morlans
Nu geɖe li nyemate ŋu awɔ fifia o.
There are many things in life I cannot do.
Meyɔa wo be nye didi siwo meva eme haɖe o.
I call them my pending wishes.
Zi geɖe la, memiãa ŋku yia ŋugble me ʋĩi henɔa xexe yeye si ŋugbe Mawu do la kpɔm le susu me ɖaa abe ɖe mele ekpɔm to "fesre " nu ene.
Often I close my eyes and open my private "window " into the new world that God promises.
(2 Petro 3:13) Mekpɔa ɖokuinye le afi ma be mele lãmesẽ me, le tsa ɖim hele vivi sem na agbea ale si dze.
(2 Peter 3:13) I imagine myself healthy, walking about and enjoying life to the full.
Fia David ƒe nya siwo nye, "Kpɔ mɔ na Yehowa, sẽ ŋu, eye nàlé dzi ɖe ƒo! " la doa dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ.
I take to heart King David’s words: "Hope in Jehovah; be courageous and strong of heart. "
(Psalmo 27:14) Togbɔ be mele gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔm ɖe edzi le ŋutilã me hã la, Yehowa doa ŋusẽm le ememe.
(Psalm 27:14) Although my body has become more and more fragile, Jehovah has made me strong.
Ɛ̃, togbɔ be mele gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔm hã la, ŋusẽ gale ŋunye ɖom.
I continue to find strength in my weakness.
Ame Siwo Mekpɔa Nu O
Living Without Sight
"Esime wodzim la, ŋkutike sesẽ aɖe si wokɔ ɖe ŋku dzi nam wɔe be nyemekpɔa nu nyuie o.
"I lost most of my sight at birth when I was given harsh eye drops.
Le nye ƒewuiwo me la, nye ŋku va tsi kura eye esia na blanuiléledɔ sesẽ aɖe hã va dze dzinye. " Paqui si nye nyɔnu si le eƒe ƒe 50-awo me, eye srɔ̃a hã nye ŋkunɔ.
During my teenage years, I became totally blind and sank into a deep depression. "​ Paqui, a middle-aged woman whose husband is also blind.
Ŋkutsitsi alo numakpɔmakpɔ nyuie ate ŋu atso nu geɖe gbɔ, esiawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye dɔléle kple nuveviwɔame.
BLINDNESS or serious visual impairment can have many causes, including injury and disease.
Nu siawo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le ŋkua, ŋkukawo alo ahɔhɔ̃a ŋu.
These may affect the eyes, the optic nerves, or the brain.
Zi geɖe la, ame siwo mekpɔa nu nyuie o alo tsi ŋku la mexɔnɛ sena o, woxaa nu eye vɔvɔ̃ léa wo.
People who lose much or all of their sight often experience denial, grief, and fear.
Gake wo dometɔ geɖe dzea agbagba nɔa te ɖe enu nyuie, eye esia nana wonɔa agbe si me dzidzeme le.
Many, though, learn to cope very well and go on to lead satisfying lives.
Míaƒe ŋkuwo koŋ dzie míetona nyaa nu siwo le edzi yim ƒo xlã mí.
The eyes are normally our primary source of information about the world around us.
Eya ta ne ame tsi ŋku la, sidzenu bubu siwo nye nusese, nuʋeʋẽse, asikakanuŋu kple nuɖɔɖɔkpɔ dzi koŋue wònɔa te ɖo nyaa nu siwo le edzi yim.
So when someone loses his sight, he comes to rely more heavily on other senses​ hearing, smell, touch, and taste.
Magazine aɖe (Scientific American) gblɔ be numekuku si wowɔ tso kadodo si le ŋkua kple ahɔhɔ̃a dome ŋu ɖee fia be ŋutete "le ahɔhɔ̃a ŋu be wòatrɔ ɖe nɔnɔmewo ŋu. "
According to the magazine Scientific American, research on neuroplasticity suggests that the brain has the ability "to change with experience. "

Numekukua yi edzi be: Kpeɖodzi gbogbo aɖewo li siwo ɖee fia be ne ahɔhɔ̃a mele nyatakaka xɔm tso sidzenu aɖe gbɔ o la, ŋutete le ahɔhɔ̃a ŋu be wòagbugbɔ atrɔ asi le nuwo ŋu be sidzenu bubuawo nawɔ dɔ ɖe esi mele dɔ wɔm o la nu.
The article adds: "A large body of evidence shows when the brain is deprived of input in one sensory modality, it is capable of reorganizing itself to support and augment other senses. "
De ŋugble tso eƒe kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider the following.
Nusese: Ne amewo se gbeɖiɖiwo kple afɔziwo la, wotea ŋu kpɔa nu si le dzɔdzɔm la le susu me.
Hearing: From voices to footsteps, sounds can paint a mental picture.
Fernando si nye ŋkunɔ la gblɔ be, "mesrɔ̃ ale si maɖo ŋku amewo dzi ahade dzesi wo to woƒe gbe alo woƒe afɔziwo dzi. "
"I have learned to remember and recognize people by their voices or even by how they walk, " says a blind man named Fernando.
Juan si hã nye ŋkunɔ gblɔ be: "Amewo ƒe gbee ŋkunɔwo tsɔ dea dzesi wo. "
Juan, who is also blind, says: "For a blind person, another’s voice is his identity. "
Abe ale si wòle le mí katã gome ene la, ŋkunɔwo tea ŋu dea dzesi ale si amewo le sesem le wo ɖokuiwo me le woƒe nuƒoƒo me.
And like all of us, the blind take careful note of tone, which can convey a variety of emotions.
Ŋkunɔwo ƒe to nɔa nu vovovo siwo yia edzi le nutoa me ŋu nyuie, si nana wòtea ŋu dea dzesi afi si amewo sɔ gbɔ le, ne xɔ aɖe me lolo alo le sue, kple ne mɔxenu le afi aɖe.
To the trained ear of a blind person, sound also says a lot about the environment​ from the direction of traffic to the size of a room to the location of certain obstacles.
Nuʋeʋẽse: Nuʋeʋẽse ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋkunɔwo ŋu woanya nu geɖe siwo le edzi yim ƒo xlã wo, gake menye ʋeʋẽ lililiwo ko o.
Smell: The sense of smell can also be a rich source of information, but not just about the source of an aroma.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me ne ŋkunɔ aɖe le mɔ aɖe dzi zɔm la, ʋeʋẽ siwo sem wòle la ate ŋu akpe ɖe eŋu wòakpɔ afi si nuwo abe kɔfidzraƒe, nuɖuɖudzraƒe, asime kple bubuawo ene le le mɔa dzi le susu me.
For example, when a blind person walks along a certain route, his sense of smell can help him to form a mental map that may include coffee shops, restaurants, markets, and so on.
Gbeɖiɖi nyanyɛ siwo sem wòle hã kpena ɖe eŋu wòkpɔa nu siwo le dzɔdzɔm la le susu me, abe ale si asikaka nuwo ŋu hã kpena ɖe wo ŋu wonyaa nu geɖe ene.
Of course, familiar sounds add to the map, as do details acquired through the sense of touch.
Asikakanuŋu: Francisco gblɔ be, "nye asibidɛwoe nye nye ŋkuwo. "
Touch: "My fingers are my eyes, " says Francisco.
Ati si meléna ɖe asi kpena ɖe ŋunye menyana afi si "ŋku " sia ate ŋu akpɔ nu ase ɖo.
The range of those "eyes " can be extended by means of a cane.

Manasés si ƒe ŋkuwo tsi hafi wodzi, eye wòsrɔ̃ ale si wòatsɔ ati akpɔ nui tso ɖevime ke gblɔ be: "Nye susu kple sidzenu bubuawo kpakple ale si wotrɔ asi le mɔdodowo ƒe akpa si amewo tona ŋu la kpena ɖe ŋunye be menyana afi si tututu zɔm mele. "

Manasés, who was born blind and learned to use a cane in childhood, said, "I know exactly where I am thanks to my other senses, my memory, and the patterns on the sidewalk that I detect with the aid of my cane. "
Ame aɖe le Gbetakpɔxɔ si wota na ŋkunɔwo xlẽm
A person reads a Braille Watchtower magazine
Ame aɖe le Gbetakpɔxɔ si wota na ŋkunɔwo xlẽm
Reading a Braille Watchtower magazine
Asikakanuŋu tea nu kpena ɖe ŋkunɔ geɖe ŋu wotea ŋu xlẽa agbalẽ siwo wota na wo.
The sense of touch also enables many blind people to read by means of literature published in Braille.
Egbea la, nu gbogbo aɖewo li siwo akpe ɖe ŋkunɔwo ŋu woate ŋu asrɔ̃ nu be woaɖi kɔ na woƒe gbɔgbɔmenuhiahiãwo.
Nowadays, in fact, it is not unusual for a blind person to have access to a number of provisions to enrich his mental and spiritual life.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe ŋkunɔwo ƒe agbalẽwo ŋu la, nu siwo woxlẽ lé ɖe mɔ̃ dzi kple kɔmpiuta dzi ɖoɖo bubuwo hã li na ŋkunɔwo.
Besides publications in Braille, these provisions include audio recordings and computer-based technology.
Nu siawo kpena ɖe ŋkunɔwo ŋu woxlẽa Biblia kple Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ vovovowo.
With the help of these, the blind can read the Bible and a variety of Bible study aids.
Agbalẽ mawo siwo ɖe Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo me faa akɔ na Paqui kple srɔ̃a, ame siwo ƒe nya míegblɔ le gɔmedzedzea me la ale gbegbe eye wòna mɔkpɔkpɔ va su wo si le agbe me.
Those spiritual provisions have been a source of immeasurable comfort and hope to Paqui and her husband, mentioned at the outset.
Gbɔgbɔmeƒome gã aɖe si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hame si le wo gbɔ la kpena ɖe wo ŋu.
They have also gained the support of a large spiritual family, the local Christian congregation of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Paqui gblɔ be: "Fifia míetea ŋu wɔa nu geɖewo le mía ɖokui si ale si míate ŋui.
"We are now able to live a full and reasonably independent life, " Paqui says.
Nyateƒee wònye be ne ame ƒe ŋku tsi la nuwo manɔ bɔbɔe nɛ o.
Indeed, blindness presents special challenges.
Gake kpeɖodziwo ɖee fia be ŋkunɔwo tea ŋu trɔna ɖe nɔnɔmeawo ŋu henɔa te ɖe enu si wɔnɛ be wometsia dzi fũu le agbe me o.
But what a testimony to human adaptability and resilience when people confront those challenges and carry on with the joys of life!
Togbɔ Be Menye Ŋkunɔ Hã La, Menɔa Agbe Si Naa Nye Dzi Dzea Eme
Although Blind, I Have a Rewarding Life Marco Antonio and his guide dog, Dante
Marco Antonio nye srɔ̃ŋutsu kple vifofo, eye eya kple ame aɖe woɖo dɔwɔƒe.
Marco Antonio is a husband, father, and joint owner of a business.
Enye ame si ƒe ŋku tsi hafi wodzi.
He is also blind from birth.
Nyɔ! talawo bia gbee wòƒo nu tso nu siwo nana wòkpɔa dzidzɔ kple kuxi siwo wòdoa goe la ŋu.
He spoke with Awake! about some of his joys and challenges.
Èɖo dɔwɔƒe.
You run a business.
Aleke nèwɔa wò dɔwoe?
How do you accomplish that?
Le nye dɔwɔƒea la, meƒoa nu kple asisiwo le telefon dzi, medoa go kpli wo, eye metsɔa ga yia gadzraɖoƒe loo alo ɖea ga le gadzraɖoƒe.
In my work, I handle telephone inquiries, meet clients and suppliers, and do banking.
Nu kae nèwɔna tsɔ ɖea modzakae?
What do you do for recreation?
Haƒoƒo doa dzidzɔ nam.
I love music.
Enana nye dzi dzea eme.
It relaxes me.
Meƒoa saŋku togbɔ be mele bɔbɔe nam o hã, elabena esesẽ nam be matsɔ nye asiwo axlẽ ŋkunɔwo ƒe ha siwo wota ɖe agbalẽ me agatsɔ asi mawo ke aƒo saŋkua hã.
And I play the piano, although it’s a challenge because I cannot read Braille music and at the same time play it with both hands.
Ne medi be maƒo ha yeye aɖe la, metsɔa ɖusi xlẽa haƒoƒoa le agbalẽa dzi, eye metsɔa nye miasi ƒoa saŋku la.
When I first play a piece of music, I read it with my right hand and play the piano with the left.
Meyia ewɔwɔ dzi gake meɖɔlina asiawo.
Then I repeat the process, but with my hands swapping roles.
Ne mesrɔ̃ haa vɔ la, metsɔa asi eveawo ƒonɛ.
When I learn the score by heart, I play with both hands.
Ðe nèdoa go kuxi tɔxɛ aɖewoa?
Have you faced any special challenges?
Esi menɔ tsitsim la, dzinyelawo kple nɔvinyewo lé be nam nyuie, eye womewɔa nu ɖe ŋunye abe ŋkunɔ ene o.
When I was growing up, my parents and siblings took good care of me, and they treated me as if I were not blind.
Edzɔna ɣeaɖewoɣi be meklia nu dzea anyi, gake nye hã mewɔa nu geɖe siwo ame siwo si ŋku le la wɔna, eye esiawo va mam.
Granted, I suffered the usual bumps and falls, but I got used to doing most things a sighted person can do.
Esi metsi la, nu ɖeka si te ɖe dzinye vevie nye be nyemate ŋu aku ʋu o.
When I reached adulthood, the only thing that really bothered me was that I couldn’t drive.
Fifia menye srɔ̃ŋutsu kple vifofo, eye ƒome nyui aɖe le asinye si dzi mekpɔna eye woawo hã wokpena ɖe ŋunye.
Now I am a husband and father, and I have a loving family whom I support and who give me support.
Vinyeŋutsu David lɔlɔ̃a nyi nye dɔlélea dome si na be eya hã tsi ŋku.
My dear son, David, has inherited my condition​ optic nerve atrophy.
Gake medzea agbagba be maɖo kpɔɖeŋu nyui nɛ.
But I am trying to set a good example for him.
Medi be wòakpɔe be ne egbɔ dzi ɖi, eye wòku kutri vevie la, ate ŋu awɔ nu geɖe.
I want him to learn that with patience and determination, he can do many things.
Fifia avu si fiaa mɔ ame le asiwò.
You now have a guide dog.
Nu ka tae nètiae be avu sia nanɔ asiwò?
Why did you choose to get one?
Nye avua ŋkɔe nye Dante, eye ekpena ɖe ŋunye metoa teƒe siwo le dedie hezɔna kabakaba hã.
With Dante​ that’s my dog’s name ​I can walk faster and safer.
Ne mayi teƒe aɖe zi gbãtɔ la, srɔ̃nye Loli si menye ŋkunɔ o la hã yina kpli mí ale be Dante nate ŋu anya mɔa nyuie.
When I go somewhere for the first time, my wife, Loli, who is not blind, accompanies us so that Dante and I can learn the route.
Ne mato nyateƒe la, gbã la, esesẽ nam be maɖe mɔ avu nakplɔm hafi manɔ dedie.
I must confess that at first I found it hard to entrust my safety to a dog.
Gake meva ka ɖe Dante dzi ale gbegbe.
But Dante earned my full trust.
Nu ka kee ɖale dzɔdzɔm o meɖea mɔ naneke hea eƒe susu o.
No matter what happens around us, he concentrates on the job.
Gake ne meɖe kaa ɖa le kɔ nɛ la, eya hã wɔa nu abe avu bubuwo ene.
But when I remove his harness, he behaves like any other dog.
Esi nènye Yehowa Ðasefo ɖe, aleke nèwɔna srɔ̃a Biblia le ɖokuiwò si?
As one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, how do you personally study the Bible?
Esi mɔ̃ɖaŋunu siwo ŋkunɔwo zãna mebɔ tsã o la, srɔ̃nye Loli xlẽa Biblia kple Biblia srɔ̃gbalẽwo nam.
When technology for the blind was limited, Loli read the Bible and Bible study aids to me.
Srɔ̃nyea kpena ɖe ŋunye ale gbegbe.
She was a great help.
Esia wɔnɛ be metea ŋu wɔa dɔdeasiwo le hamea ƒe kpekpewo me.
As a result, I was even able to give talks at congregation meetings.
Gake fifia la, metea ŋu xlẽa nu le ɖokuinye si elabena Biblia kple Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ siwo wota na ŋkunɔwo la le asinye.
Nowadays, though, I can read for myself because I have the Bible and study aids in Braille.
Metea ŋu yia Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org ɖawɔa nu siwo woxlẽ lé ɖe mɔ̃ dzi ƒe kɔpiwo.
I can also go to the website established by Jehovah’s Witnesses​ jw.org​ where I download audio recordings.
Nane le kɔmpiutaa ŋu na ŋkunɔwo si kpena ɖe ŋunye metea ŋu xlẽa nu siwo dzena le kɔmpiutaa dzi.
And I have a Braille display, which enables me to read what is on my computer monitor.
Gavi suesuesue siwo nye ŋkunɔwo ƒe nuxexlẽdzesiwo dzena le nu sia si le kɔmpiuta ŋu la dzi.
The display has small pins that pop up in groups to form Braille characters.
Enye nane si wɔ nuku ŋutɔ!
It’s quite amazing!
Mɔnukpɔkpɔ nyui aɖe si su asinye ye nye ale si mekpea asi ɖe eŋu ne wole agbalẽwo wɔm na ŋkunɔwo le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Madrid, Spain.
A privilege I have especially enjoyed is assisting with Braille transcription at the Spain branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Madrid.
Esi wodi be agbalẽ siwo wɔm wole na ŋkunɔwo naɖe vi geɖe na wo ta la, ame siwo le ewɔm la biaa aɖaŋuɖoɖo tsoa ŋkunɔwo gbɔ.
In order to improve the quality of Braille publications, those preparing them value suggestions from the blind.
Eya ta mate ŋu agblɔ tso dzi me be nye gbɔgbɔmenɔviwo lɔ̃m hedea asixɔxɔ ŋunye.
So I can honestly say that I feel both loved and appreciated by my spiritual brothers and sisters.
Ðe hadede kple ame bubuwo doa dzidzɔ na wòa?
Do you enjoy interacting with others?
Ɛ̃, vevietɔ nye ƒometɔ kplikplikpliwo kple hati Ðasefowo, ame siwo nye kpli wo míeyina ɖaɖea gbeƒã na amewo tso aƒe me yi aƒe me.
Yes, especially with my immediate family and fellow Witnesses, with whom I also go out preaching from door to door.
Nye gbɔgbɔmenɔviwo wɔa nu ɖe ŋunye nyuie abe ale si wowɔa nu ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu ene.
My spiritual brothers and sisters treat me the way they treat anybody else.
Le nyateƒe me la, ɣeaɖewoɣi la, woŋlɔna be be ŋkunɔe menye!
In fact, they sometimes forget that I’m blind!
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa wɔwɔ naa megblɔa mɔkpɔkpɔ xɔasi si le Biblia me ŋu nya na amewo.
I might add that the ministry enables me to share with others the precious hope found in the Bible.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesaya 35:5 gblɔ be ne Mawu Fiaɖuƒea va le anyigba dzi ɖum la, "ŋkuagbãtɔwo ƒe ŋku aʋu. "
For example, at Isaiah 35:5, we read that under God’s Kingdom government, "the eyes of the blind will be opened. "
Esime Yesu nɔ anyigba dzi la, eʋu ŋku na ŋkunɔwo tsɔ ɖe nu si wòava wɔ le etsɔme fia.
When Jesus Christ was on the earth, he cured the blind, giving us a preview of that future time.
(Mateo 15:30, 31) Ŋkutsitsi kple dɔléle bubu ɖe sia ɖe nu ayi kpuie.
(Matthew 15:30, 31) Blindness, therefore, is a temporary problem, which is true of all disabilities.
Ne anyigba va zu Paradiso la, ame aɖeke magblɔ be ‘Mele dɔ lém alo menye nuwɔametɔ o.’ Yesaya 33:24; Luka 23:43.
In the earthly Paradise to come, no one will say, ‘I am sick or disabled.’​ Isaiah 33:24; Luke 23:43.
Jairo Ƒe Ŋkuwoe Kpena Ðe Eŋu Wòsubɔa Mawu
Jairo’s Eyes His Way to Serve God
Abe ale si nɔviaŋutsu Samuel Ruiz-León Arroyo gblɔe ene
As told by his brother Samuel Ruiz-León Arroyo
Ðe nàte ŋu abu ale si agbea anɔ na wò nenye be màte ŋu aʋã wò abɔwo kple afɔwo o, negbe wò ŋkuwo ko ŋu kpɔa?
Can you imagine having no control of your body except for your eyes?
Nɔnɔme ma mee nɔvinyeŋutsu Jairo le.
My brother Jairo is in such a predicament.
Ke hã taɖodzinu le eƒe agbe ŋu.
Yet, he enjoys a meaningful life.
Hafi maƒo nu tso nu si tae Jairo kpɔe be enyo be yele agbe ŋu la, anyo be magblɔ eƒe agbemeŋutinya.
Before I explain why he has found his life to be worth living, let me tell you his story.
Esi wodzi Jairo la, ahɔhɔ̃medɔ si nye cerebral palsy, si nana ame ƒe abɔwo kple afɔwo siaa tuna, si woyɔna be spastic quadriplegia la, le eŋu.
Jairo was born with a type of cerebral palsy called spastic quadriplegia.
Esia wɔe be mekpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe eƒe abɔɖeɖe kple afɔɖeɖe dzi o.
As a result, he has no control over most of his body.
Eƒe ahɔhɔ̃ metea ŋu fiaa mɔ eƒe lãkusiwo o, eya ta eƒe afɔwo dana hetrona le wo ɖokui si.
His brain cannot send clear signals to his muscles, so his limbs twist, or writhe, uncontrollably.
Ale si Jairo ƒe abɔwo kple afɔwo ŋutɔwo ʋãna le wo ɖokuiwo si alea nana wòwɔa nu vevi eɖokui ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Sometimes, Jairo’s unpredictable jerking movements even cause him to hurt himself.
Ne ame siwo tsɔ ɖe egbɔ mele ŋudzɔ o la, ate ŋu awɔ nu vevi woawo hã.
People nearby may also get hurt if they are not alert.
Nublanuitɔe la, ele be woabla eƒe abɔwo kple afɔwo ɖe eƒe bunɔkekea ŋu be wòagawɔ nu vevi amewo o.
Sadly, his arms and legs must often be tied to his wheelchair to prevent such accidents.
FU SIWO WÒKPE ESI WÒNƆ TSITSIM
PAINFUL PATH TO ADULTHOOD
Esi Jairo nɔ tsitsim la, ekpe fu ale gbegbe.
Jairo’s physical growth has been very painful.
Esi wòxɔ ɣleti etɔ̃ ye eƒe dɔa ƒe dzesiwo dze egɔme; edzea ti eye esia nana wòyia ɖi me.
When he was three months old, he started to have seizures that left him unconscious.
Zi geɖe la, Dada fanae ɖe akɔnu hedea afɔ du me yia kɔdzi. Eya ŋutɔ susuna be eku vɔ.
All too often, Mum would hold him tightly and rush him to the hospital, convinced that he was dead.
Esi wònye be Jairo ƒe abɔwo kple afɔwo me hena hetrona ta la, ewɔe be eƒe ƒuwo glɔ̃.
Because of all the tightening and contracting, in time Jairo’s bones became deformed.
Esi wòxɔ ƒe 16 la, eɖɔli eƒe aligo, si wɔe be ehiã be woawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖe nɛ ako eƒe ata, ali, kple eƒe aligo siaa.
At the age of 16, he dislocated his pelvis and required major surgery to his thigh, hip, and pelvis.
Megaɖoa ŋku ale si Jairo nɔa avi fam zã sia zã esi wonɔ hayahayam la dzi kokoko.
I still remember Jairo crying out in pain every night during his recovery.
Jairo ƒe dɔa na be amewoe wɔa nu sia nu nɛ, abe nuɖuɖu, awudodo, kple ekɔkɔ ada ɖe aba dzi ene.
Jairo’s severe disability makes him totally reliant on others to carry out daily functions, such as eating, getting dressed, and getting to bed.
Dada kple Papa ye kpɔa eƒe hiahiã mawo gbɔ nɛ.
Mum and Dad usually perform these tasks.
Togbɔ be Jairo hiã kpekpeɖeŋu ɣeawokatãɣi hã, mía dzilawo ɖoa ŋku edzi nɛ ɣesiaɣi be menye amegbetɔwo si me koe eƒe agbe le o, ke boŋ Mawue lé eƒe agbe ɖe te.
Though Jairo needs constant help, our parents always remind him that his life depends not only on humans but also on God.
WOVA KE ÐE DZEÐOÐO ƑE MƆNU AÐE ŊU
A WAY OF COMMUNICATION OPENS
Yehowa Ðasefowoe mía dzilawo nye, eye woxlẽa Biblia me ŋutinyawo na Jairo tso eƒe ɖevime ke.
Our parents are Jehovah’s Witnesses, and they have been reading Bible stories to Jairo ever since he was a baby.
Wonya nyuie be tameɖoɖo nɔa ame ƒe agbe ŋu wu ne ƒomedodo le woa kple Mawu dome.
They always knew that life is more meaningful when one has a relationship with God.
Ðeko wòdzɔ be Jairo ƒe ametia, si ʋãna enuenu la mede edzi o, gake etsɔmemɔkpɔkpɔ nyui si ŋu kakaɖedzi le ate ŋu asu esi.
Jairo was trapped in a frail body that jerked continually, but he could have a bright, solid hope for the future.
Ke hã womeka ɖe edzi nenye be Jairo ate ŋu ase Biblia me nyateƒea gɔme o.
However, they often wondered if Jairo could grasp Bible knowledge.
Gbe ɖeka, le Jairo ƒe ɖevime la, Papa biae be, "Jairo, meɖe kuku, àte ŋu aƒo nu nama? "
One day, when Jairo was a child, Dad asked him, "Jairo, can you please talk to me? "
Eyome wògblɔ nɛ be, "Ne èlɔ̃m vavã la, àƒo nu nam! "
Then he added, "If you really love me, you will! "
Esi Papa ɖe kuku nɛ be wòagblɔ nya ɖeka pɛ ko na ye la, aɖatsi lólo ɖe ŋku dzi na Jairo enumake.
As Dad begged him to say at least one word, tears welled up in Jairo’s eyes.
Togbɔ be Jairo dze agbagba be yeaɖe yeƒe seselelãmewo agblɔ hã la, ɖeko nàsee be ete gbe me.
Though he tried to express his feelings with words, he could only mutter guttural sounds.
Ete ɖe Papa dzi be yena Jairo fa avi.
Father felt bad for having made Jairo cry.
Ke hã nudzɔdzɔ ma na Papa kpɔe be Jairo se nya si yegblɔ la gɔme.
But that reaction showed that Jairo understood what Father had said.
Gake kuxiae nye be mate ŋu aƒo nu o.
The problem was that he could not speak.
Eteƒe medidi o, mía dzilawo de dzesii be ɣeaɖewoɣi la, Jairo ʋãa eƒe ŋkuwo kabakaba abe ɖe wòle agbagba dzem be yeagblɔ nya aɖe ene.
Before long, our parents noticed that Jairo at times moved his eyes rapidly in an apparent attempt to convey his thoughts and feelings.
Etena ɖe Jairo dzi ŋutɔ be ame aɖeke metea ŋu sea nya si yedi be yeagblɔ la gɔme o.
It was frustrating for Jairo that he could not always make himself understood.
Gake ne dzinyelawo te ŋu se dzesi siwo wɔm wòle kple nu si ta wòle ŋku ɖem ɖo gɔme la, enumake Jairo ɖoa nukomo gã aɖe.
But when my parents learned to decipher his eye signals and get him what he needed, Jairo’s face would beam with a broad grin.
Ema dzi wòtona daa akpe na wo.
It was his way of saying thank you.
Nuƒoƒoŋutete ŋuti aɖaŋuɖola aɖe ɖo aɖaŋu na mí be, be ƒomea nate ŋu aɖo dze kplii nyuie la, anyo be míado míaƒe asiwo ɖe dzi ne míele nya aɖe si ƒe ŋuɖoɖo anye ɛ̃ alo ao biamee.
A speech therapist suggested that for better communication, we should raise both hands in the air when asking him a yes-or-no question.
Nuɖusi afia ɛ̃, eye miasi afia oa.
The right hand means yes, the left hand no.
Ne míewɔe alea la, ana míanya nu si dim wòle ne etrɔ eƒe ŋkuwo ɖe abɔ si alo ekemɛ ŋu.
Thus, he could express his wishes by fixing his eyes on the proper hand.
NU ÐEDZESI AÐE LE JAIRO ƑE AGBE ME
A MILESTONE IN JAIRO’S LIFE
Yehowa Ðasefowo dea takpekpewo zi etɔ̃ le ƒea me, eye le takpekpe mawo me la, woƒoa nuƒo siwo me woɖea Biblia me na nyasela gbogbowo le.
Three times a year, Jehovah’s Witnesses hold assemblies and conventions, where Bible talks are presented to large audiences.
Ɣesiaɣi si wole nuƒo siawo ƒomevi ƒom na ame siwo di be yewoaxɔ nyɔnyrɔ la, dzi dzɔa Jairo ale gbegbe.
Jairo always got excited during the talk that was addressed to baptism candidates.
Gbe ɖeka, esime Jairo xɔ ƒe 16 la, Papa biae be, "Jairo, àdi be yeaxɔ nyɔnyrɔa? "
One day, when Jairo was 16, Father asked him, "Jairo, do you want to get baptized? "
Ðeko wòtrɔ eƒe ŋkuwo ɖe Papa ƒe nuɖusi ŋu enumake, eye esia ɖee fia be edi be yeaxɔ nyɔnyrɔ.
At once, his decisive look at Dad’s right hand revealed his desire to take that step.
Eyome Papa biae be, "Ðe nèdo gbe ɖa na Mawu hedo ŋugbe nɛ be yeasubɔe tegbeea? "
Then Dad added, "Have you promised God in prayer to serve him forever? "
Jairo gatrɔ eƒe ŋkuwo ɖe Papa ƒe nuɖusi ŋu ake.
Once again, Jairo gazed straight at Dad’s right hand.
Eme kɔ ƒãa be Jairo tsɔ eƒe agbe ɖe adzɔgbe na Yehowa xoxo.
It was clear that Jairo had already dedicated his life to Jehovah.
Esi wowɔ Biblia me numedzodzro vovovowo kplii megbe la, esia hã ɖee fia be Jairo se nu si ta wòle vevie be Kristotɔ naxɔ nyɔnyrɔ la gɔme.
After several Bible discussions, it was also clear that Jairo understood the significance of Christian baptism.
Esia wɔe be Jairo va ɖo biabia vevitɔ si wobiae kpɔ la ŋu, le ƒe 2004 me, esi wobiae be, "Ðe nètsɔ ɖokuiwò ɖe adzɔgbe na Mawu be yeawɔ eƒe lɔlɔ̃nua? "
So, in 2004, he answered the most important question he was ever asked, "Have you dedicated yourself to God to do his will? "
Jairo trɔ eƒe ŋkuwo kpɔ dziƒo.
Jairo answered this question by raising his eyes upward.
Emae nye nyaŋuɖoɖo be ɛ̃ ƒe ɖoɖo si wowɔ nɛ do ŋgɔ.
It was his prearranged way of saying yes.
Esia wɔe be, wòxɔ nyɔnyrɔ hezu Yehowa Ðasefo esime wòxɔ ƒe 17.
Thus, at age 17, he got baptized as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
EƑE ŊKUWO LE MAWU ƑE NUWO ŊU
EYES FOCUSED ON THE THINGS OF GOD
Le ƒe 2011 me la, mɔ yeye aɖe si dzi Jairo ato aɖo dze kple amewo la ʋu ɖi nɛ azɔ si nye kɔmpiuta si wotsɔa ŋku fiaa mɔe.
In 2011, a new way to communicate opened up for Jairo an eye-controlled computer.
Mɔ̃ɖaŋunu sia tea ŋu dea dzesi afi sia afi si ame trɔ eƒe ŋku yibɔea ɖo.
This device tracks the movements of his iris so that he can activate icons on the screen.
Ne eɖe ŋku ɖe nutata aɖe le kɔmpiutaa dzi alo ƒo aɖaba ɖee ko la, ewɔa dɔ abe ɖe wòzi edzi kple asi ene.
Blinking or staring at an icon is like clicking a mouse on a computer.
Eya ta wowɔ kɔmpiutakpe aɖe si dzi nutata vovovowo le la na Jairo be wòakpe ɖe eŋu wòate ŋu aɖo dze kple amewo.
A board consisting of pictograms was created to help Jairo communicate.
Ne ele nutatawo dometɔ aɖe kpɔm eye wòƒo aɖaba zi ɖeka ko la, ɖoɖo siwo wowɔ ɖe mɔ̃a me la nana kɔmpiutaa gblɔa nya siwo wolé ɖe mɔ̃a dzi.
When he blinks at one of them, the built-in software converts a written message into an electronic voice.
Jairo le eƒe kɔmpiuta si wòtsɔa ŋku fiaa mɔe la zãm
Jairo using his eye-controlled computer
Esi Jairo va le Biblia gɔme sem ɖe edzi la, edi vevie be yeakpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu woasrɔ̃ nu tso Mawu ŋu.
As Jairo’s understanding of the Bible increased, so did his desire to help others spiritually.
Ne míaƒe ƒomea le Biblia srɔ̃m abe ale si míewɔnɛ Kwasiɖa sia Kwasiɖa ene la, sẽe kple sẽe la, eɖea ŋku ɖem hekpɔa kɔmpiutaa dzi, eye wòwɔa esia enuenu.
During our weekly family Bible study, he often looks back and forth between me and his computer.
Aleae wòɖoa ŋku edzi nam be maŋlɔ ale si yeaɖo nya ŋui ne míeyi Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpewo la ɖe mɔ̃a dzi na ye.
This is his way of reminding me that I should write down comments that he can offer during question-and-answer sessions at meetings of our Christian congregation.
Ne míeyi nusrɔ̃ƒe la, egbɔa dzi ɖi kpɔa kɔmpiutaa dzi heƒoa aɖaba ɖe nutata si sɔ la le kɔmpiutakpea dzi, eye enumake mɔ̃a ŋutɔ gblɔa nya si wòdi be yeagblɔ la ame sia ame sena.
At the meeting, he patiently navigates through the screen to click on the appropriate icon, and then his electronic voice is heard by everyone.
Ɣesiaɣi si wòte ŋu de dzi ƒo na hamea me tɔwo le mɔ sia nu la, ekoa alɔgbɔnu gã aɖe.
He smiles broadly every time he encourages the members of the congregation in this way.
Jairo xɔlɔ̃ siwo nye sɔhɛwo dometɔ ɖeka si ŋkɔe nye Alex gblɔ be, "Ɣesiaɣi si Jairo ɖo nya ŋu ku ɖe Biblia me nyatia aɖe ŋu mese la, ewɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ. "
Alex, one of Jairo’s young friends, observes, "It always impresses me when I hear Jairo’s comments on a Bible subject. "
[Nɔnɔmetata ŋu nya siwo le axa 10, 11]
Jairo using his computer to make a comment at a meeting
Jairo le eƒe kɔmpiutaa zãm tsɔ le nya ŋu ɖom le nusrɔ̃ƒe
Jairo uses his eye-controlled computer and its electronic voice to comment at meetings and to share his beliefs with others
Jairo zãa eƒe ŋkuwo tsɔ gblɔa eƒe dzixɔsewo na ame bubuwo hã.
Jairo also uses his eyes to tell others about his beliefs.
Mɔ aɖe si dzi wòtona wɔa esia ye nye be eƒoa aɖaba ɖe nutata si nye abɔ dama si me lãwo kple ame ƒomevi vovovowo le le ŋutifafa me.
One way he does this is by clicking a pictogram that portrays a garden where animals and people of all races live in peaceful conditions.
Ne eƒo aɖaba alea ko la, eƒe kɔmpiutaa ŋutɔ gblɔna be, "Mɔkpɔkpɔ si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe nye be anyigba ava zu paradiso, afi si dɔléle kple ku maganɔ azɔ o, Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4. "
When he activates this, his computer voice proclaims, "The hope of the Bible is that the earth will be a paradise where there will be no more sickness and death, Revelation 21:4. "
Ne nyaa do dzidzɔ na ame si wòle gbeƒã ɖem na la, egaƒoa aɖaba ɖe nutata bubu eye eƒe kɔmpiutaa gblɔna be, "Àdi be masrɔ̃ Biblia kpli yea "?
If the listener shows interest, another click causes his computer to say, "Would you like to study the Bible with me? "
Nukutɔe la, mía tɔgbui lɔ̃ be wòasrɔ̃ Biblia kpli ye.
Surprisingly, our grandfather accepted this invitation.
Ewɔa dɔ ɖe ame dzi ŋutɔ be wòakpɔ ale si Jairo srɔ̃a nu kple tɔgbui blewuu esime hati Ðasefo aɖe le kpekpem ɖe eŋu la teƒe!
It is thrilling to see Jairo, assisted by a fellow Witness, slowly teaching Grandpa the Bible!
Dzidzɔtɔe la, Tɔgbui xɔ nyɔnyrɔ le nutome gã takpekpe si wowɔ le Madrid, le August 2014 me la me.
Happily, Grandpa got baptized at the regional convention in Madrid in August 2014.
Jairo le gbeƒã ɖe nya nyuia le dutoƒo
Jairo sharing in the public ministry
Jairo ƒe sukunufialawo gɔ̃ hã de dzesi ale si gbegbe wòlɔ̃ Mawui.
Jairo’s devotion to God does not go unnoticed by the teachers at his school.
Aƒenɔ Rosario, si nye eƒe nuƒoƒoŋutete ŋuti aɖaŋuɖola gblɔ gbe ɖeka be: "Ne ahiã be maɖo subɔsubɔha aɖe me le etsɔme la, ke Yehowa Ðasefo koe mazu.
Rosario, one of his speech therapists, once confessed: "If I ever thought about joining a religion, I would become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Mekpɔ ale si gbegbe Jairo ƒe xɔse na taɖodzinu vavã va le eƒe agbe ŋui, togbɔ be eƒe nɔnɔmea sesẽ ŋutɔ hã. "
I have seen how Jairo’s faith has given him a real purpose in life, despite his difficult situation. "
Ɣesiaɣi si woxlẽ ŋugbedodo si le Biblia me, si gblɔ be, "Xɔdrɔ̃wo ati kpo abe zi ene, eye aɖetututɔwo ƒe aɖe atso aseye " la, dzi dzɔa Jairo ale gbegbe, eye esia dzena le mo nɛ.
Jairo’s eyes always light up when I read him the Bible’s promise: "The lame will leap like the deer, and the tongue of the speechless will shout for joy. "
(Yesaya 35:6) Togbɔ be dzi ɖena le eƒo ɣeaɖewoɣi hã la, dzidzɔmee wònye.
(Isaiah 35:6) Although he does get discouraged at times, he is generally in good spirits.
Nu si tae wòle aleae nye be, eƒe agbenɔnɔ bliboa ku ɖe eƒe Mawu kple exɔlɔ̃ Kristotɔwo ŋu.
This is possible only because his life revolves around God and around his Christian friends.
Eƒe dzidzɔ kple eƒe xɔse sesẽ la nye kpeɖodzi be Yehowa subɔsubɔ nana agbea vivina, togbɔ be woanɔ kuxi sesẽwo me tom hã.
His cheerful outlook and strong faith are a testimony that serving Jehovah makes a challenging life worth living.
Nya Si Jairo Xɔlɔ̃wo Gblɔ
What Jairo’s Associates Say
Rosa, si xɔ ƒe 63, gblɔ be: "Ale si gbegbe Jairo kpɔa dzidzɔe kple ale si wòdina vevie be yeasubɔ Yehowae la dea dzo mía me. "
Rosa, who is 63, observes: "Jairo radiates joy. And his intense longing to serve Jehovah is contagious. "
Antonio, si xɔ ƒe 32, gblɔ be: "Ɣesiaɣi si Jairo ʋu eƒe xɔse me la, ewɔa dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ. "
Antonio, who is 32, notes: "I am moved every time I see Jairo expressing his faith. "
Andrés, si xɔ ƒe 67, gblɔ be: "Ewɔ abe Jairo se Biblia ƒe nufiafia aɖewo gɔme nyui wum ene. "
Andrés, who is 67, says: "It seems that Jairo gets the sense of some Bible teachings better than I do. "
Mawu Subɔsubɔ Ye Nye Eƒe Atike!
Serving God Is His Medicine!
Esi nɔviŋutsu mɔɖela eve ge ɖe aƒe aɖe me le Kenya la, woƒe nu ku esi wokpɔ ŋutsu aɖe si le sue ŋutɔ le aba dzi.
When two pioneers were invited into a certain house in Kenya, they were surprised to see the slight figure of a man lying on a bed.
Eƒe akɔta va se ɖe ƒodo le sue ŋutɔ eye eƒe abɔwo le kpuie.
He had a very small torso and short arms.
Esi wogblɔ ŋugbe si Mawu do be "xɔdrɔ̃wo ati kpo abe zi ene " na ŋutsu sia la, eko alɔgbɔnu gã aɖe.
As they shared with him God’s promise that "the lame one will climb up just as a stag does, " the man responded with a wide smile.
Yes.
Isa.
Emegbe mɔɖelaawo va see be lãmeƒu masemasẽ dɔ, alo lãmeƒu siwo ŋena bɔbɔe ƒe dɔléle, ye le Onesmus ŋu.
The pioneers learned that Onesmus, now in his late 30’s, was born with osteogenesis imperfecta, or brittle bone disease.
Ƒu siwo le lãme nɛ bɔbɔ ale gbegbe be ne nane mia ƒuawo sesĩe vie ko la woŋena.
His bones were extremely fragile so much so that the slightest pressure caused them to break.
Esi wometea ŋu daa dɔ sia o ta la, Onesmus nyae be ele be yeanɔ bunɔkeke me ahanɔ veve sem le yeƒe agbemeŋkekewo katã me.
Since there is no cure or effective treatment for the disease, Onesmus expected to spend the rest of his life in pain and confined to a wheelchair.
Onesmus lɔ̃ be woasrɔ̃ Biblia kpli ye.
Onesmus accepted a personal Bible study.
Gake nɔa meda asi ɖe edzi be wòanɔ Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpeawo dem o, elabena esusu be esia ana nu vevi nawɔe eye wòagase veve ɖe edzi wu.
However, his mother objected to his attending Christian meetings, reasoning that this might cause him injury and additional pain.
Eya ta nɔviawo léa kpekpeawo me nyawo ɖe mɔ̃ dzi na Onesmus, eye wòsenɛ le aƒe me.
So the brothers recorded the meetings, and Onesmus listened to them at home.
Esi Onesmus srɔ̃ nu ɣleti atɔ̃ megbe la, etso nya me be yeade kpekpeawo, nu ka kee ɖadzɔ o.
After studying for five months, Onesmus decided that he wanted to attend the meetings despite the risks.
Ðe Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpeawo dede dzi Onesmus ƒe veveseseawo ɖe edzia?
Did attending Christian meetings add to Onesmus’ pain?
Kura o.
The effect was the opposite.
Onesmus gblɔ be: "Ewɔ abe veve si mesena ɣesiaɣi la ɖiɖina ne mele kpekpewo me ene. "
"My constant pain seemed to diminish during the meetings, " Onesmus recalls.
Exɔe se be mɔkpɔkpɔ si va su ye si ye na yeƒe dzi dze eme vie.
He thought that his newfound hope was the reason he felt better.
Onesmus dada kpɔ ale si via le dzidzɔ kpɔmee eye esia do dzidzɔ nɛ ale gbegbe be wòlɔ̃ be woasrɔ̃ Biblia kpli ye hã.
Onesmus’ mother observed the change in her son’s disposition and was so delighted that she too agreed to study the Bible.
Nya si wògblɔna ye nye be: "Mawu subɔsubɔ ye nye vinye ƒe atike. "
"Serving God is my son’s medicine, " she would say.
Eteƒe medidi o, Onesmus zu gbeƒãɖela maxɔnyɔnyrɔ.
Before long, Onesmus became an unbaptized publisher.
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, exɔ nyɔnyrɔ eye wòzu subɔsubɔdɔwɔla fifia.
In time, he was baptized and now serves as a ministerial servant.
Togbɔ be Onesmus metea ŋu zãa eƒe afɔwo kple abɔ ɖeka kura o hã la, edi vevie be yeawɔ nu sia nu si yeate ŋui le Yehowa subɔsubɔ me.
Although he is not able to use his legs and one of his arms, Onesmus had the desire to do all he could in Jehovah’s service.
Edi be yeawɔ kpekpeɖeŋu mɔɖeɖedɔa, gake enɔ hehem ɖe megbe le agbalẽvia kpekpeɖo me.
He wanted to auxiliary pioneer but was reluctant to apply.
Nu ka ta?
Why?
Elabena enyae be ele be yeakpɔ ame bubu aɖe sinu ɣesiaɣi be wòate yeƒe bunɔkeke hafi yeate ŋu ayi gbeadzi.
Because he knew that he would have to rely entirely on another person to push his wheelchair.
Esi wògblɔ eƒe dzimaɖitsitsia na hati Kristotɔwo la, wogblɔ be yewoakpe ɖe eŋu.
When he expressed his concern to his fellow Christians, they promised to support him.
Eye wokpe ɖe eŋu hã, ale be Onesmus te ŋu wɔ kpekpeɖeŋu mɔɖeɖedɔa.
This they did, helping Onesmus to auxiliary pioneer.
Nenema kee Onesmus tsi dzimaɖi esi wòdi be yeawɔ gbesiagbe mɔɖeɖedɔa.
Onesmus’ desire to be a regular pioneer met with the same concern.
Gbe ɖeka la, gbe sia gbe mawunyakpukpui si me wòdzro la de dzi ƒo nɛ.
At one point, however, the daily text provided the encouragement he needed.
Mawunyakpukpuia ye nye Psalmo 34:9, afi si gblɔ be: "Miɖɔe kpɔ, eye miakpɔ be, Yehowa ƒe dɔme nyo. "
The text was Psalm 34:8: "Taste and see that Jehovah is good. "
Esi Onesmus de ŋugble tso mawunyakpukpuia ŋu vɔ la, etso nya me be yeawɔ gbesiagbe mɔɖeɖedɔa.
After meditating on that scripture, Onesmus decided to become a regular pioneer.
Fifia eɖea gbeƒã ŋkeke ene le kwasiɖaa me, eye Biblia nusrɔ̃vi geɖe siwo le ŋgɔyiyi nyui wɔm la le esi.
He now preaches four days a week and has several Bible students who are making good spiritual progress.
Le ƒe 2010 me la, Onesmus de Mɔɖelawo Ƒe Subɔsubɔ Sukua.
In 2010, he attended the Pioneer Service School.
Dzi dzɔe ŋutɔ esi wòdo go nɔviŋutsu siwo ɖe gbeƒã nɛ zi gbãtɔ la dometɔ ɖeka le sukua, eye wònye woƒe nufialawo dometɔ ɖeka!
How delighted Onesmus was to have as his instructor one of the two brothers who initially called on him!
Esusɔ vie Onesmus naxɔ ƒe 40 fifia. Edzilawo megale agbe o, gake nɔvi siwo le hamea me la kpɔa eƒe gbe sia gbe nuhiahiãwo gbɔ nɛ.
Onesmus’ parents have now passed away, but brothers and sisters in the congregation care for his daily needs.
Edaa akpe na Yehowa ɖe yayra siwo su esi va se ɖe fifia ta, eye wòle mɔ kpɔm vevie na ŋkeke si "duametɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, yele dɔ lém o. "
He is grateful for all the blessings he now enjoys, and he looks forward to the day when "no resident will say: ‘I am sick.’
Yes.
" Isa.
Yehowa Ve Nunye Ŋutɔ
Jehovah Has Given Me More Than I Deserve
Abe Ale Si Félix Alarcón Gblɔe Ene
As told by Félix Alarcón
Félix Alarcón
Félix Alarcón
Esime mexɔ ƒe 17 la, nu siwo ŋu metsia dzi ɖo kple nye agbemetaɖodzinuwo nɔ ko abe ƒewuivi bubuwo tɔ ke ene.
I was just 17 years old and had the concerns and ambitions typical of most teenagers.
Hadede kple xɔ̃nyewo, tsiƒuƒu kple bɔlƒoƒo doa dzidzɔ nam.
I loved mingling with my friends, swimming, and playing soccer.
Gake gbe ɖeka fiẽ la, nuwo va trɔ kura le nye agbe me.
But one evening my life changed dramatically.
Medze afɔku vevie esime menɔ dzokeke dzi, si wɔe be metu tso nye kɔ va se ɖe nye afɔ gbɔ.
I was involved in a horrific motorcycle accident that left me paralyzed from the neck down.
Anɔ abe ƒe 30 ye nye esi va yi nu sia dzɔ, eye ɣeyiɣi didi aɖee nye esia metsi teƒe ɖeka.
That was some 30 years ago, and I have been bedridden for a long time now.
Ƒutadu si nye Alicante, si le Spain ƒe ɣedzeƒe ye menɔ tsi.
I grew up in the city of Alicante, on the east coast of Spain.
Míaƒe ƒomea gbã, si wɔe be meva zu gbɔdomevi esime menye sɔhɛ.
My family was completely dysfunctional, so as a youth I spent much of my time on the streets.
Ʋudzraɖoƒe aɖe te ɖe míaƒe aƒea ŋu.
Close to my house was a tire repair shop.
Ame siwo wɔa dɔ le afi ma la dometɔ ɖeka si ŋkɔe nye José María la va zu xɔ̃nye.
There I became friends with José María, one of the employees.
Ne xaxawo tum la, ekpena ɖe ŋunye abe nɔvinye kpamkpam ene.
He was a warm person who gave me the attention I sorely missed in my own family.
Ɛ̃, enye xɔlɔ̃ vavã nam togbɔ be etsi wum ƒe 20 hã.
In times of distress, he was like a real brother to me​ a true friend, although he was 20 years my senior.
Ɣemaɣi la, Yehowa Ðasefowo nɔ Biblia srɔ̃m kple José María.
José María had started studying the Bible with Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Mede dzesii be ekpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe Ŋɔŋlɔawo ŋu, eye eƒoa nu tso Biblia me nyateƒea ŋu nam zi geɖe.
I could tell that he loved the Scriptures, and he often shared Bible truths with me.
Meɖoa toe bubutɔe, gake nyemetsɔ ɖeke le nya siwo wògblɔna nam la me o.
I listened to him respectfully, but I never really took an interest in what he said.
Esi menye ɖekakpui ta la, nye dzi ku ɖe nu bubuwo ŋu.
My teenage heart was preoccupied with other matters.
Gake eteƒe medidi hafi meva trɔ nye nɔnɔme o.
That, however, was about to change.
AFƆKU AÐE NA NYE AGBE TRƆ KURA
AN ACCIDENT THAT CHANGED MY LIFE
Nyemelɔ̃a nuƒoƒo fũu tso afɔku ma ŋu o.
I do not like to talk much about that road accident.
Nya si magblɔ koe nye be nyemedze nunya o eye mewɔ nu ɖekematsɔlemetɔe.
What I will say is that I was foolish and reckless.
Gbe ɖeka kple eƒe zãdodo ko la, nye agbe trɔ keŋkeŋ.
In just one day, my whole life changed completely.
Nye si nye ɖekakpui si ŋu ŋusẽ nɔ lae nye ema va zu lãmetututɔ si tsi dɔba dzi le kɔdzi.
From being a young teenager full of vitality, I suddenly found myself paralyzed and stuck inside a hospital ward.
Ete ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ be nyee va zu alea.
Coming to terms with this predicament was really tough.
Menɔ ɖokuinye biam be, ‘Nu ka tae maganɔ agbe ɖo?’
I kept asking myself, ‘Is there any point in living?’
José María va srãm kpɔ le kɔa dzi, eye wòwɔ ɖoɖo enumake Yehowa Ðasefowo tsoa hame si le nutoa me la me va srãam kpɔ.
José María came to see me, and he quickly arranged for Jehovah’s Witnesses from the local congregation to visit me at the hospital.
Ale si wova kpɔam ɖa edziedzi la wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
Those regular visits touched my heart.
Esi woɖem le kɔdzixɔ si me wokpɔa dɔléle sesẽwo gbɔ le teti ko la, mete Biblia sɔsrɔ̃.
As soon as I left the intensive care unit, I began to study the Bible.
Meva nya nu si tututu tae amewo kpea fu hekuna kple nu si tae Mawu ɖe mɔ afɔkuwo dzɔna.
I discovered the truth about why people suffer and die and why God allows bad things to happen.
Mesrɔ̃ nu tso ŋugbe si Mawu do ku ɖe etsɔme ŋu, esime anyigba bliboa ava yɔ fũu kple ame deblibowo eye ame aɖeke magagblɔ be, "Mele dɔ lém " o la, hã ŋu.
I also learned about God’s promises for the future, when the whole earth will be filled with perfect humans and nobody will ever say: "I am sick. "
(Yesaya 33:24) Emae nye zi gbãtɔ le nye agbe me si meva nya nu tso mɔkpɔkpɔ wɔnuku sia ŋu.
(Isaiah 33:24) For the first time in my life, a wonderful hope was opening up to me.
Esi woɖe asi le ŋunye le kɔa dzi la, metsɔ dzo ɖe Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃a ŋu.
When I left the hospital, I progressed quickly in my study of the Bible.
Bunɔkeke tɔxɛ aɖe si nɔ asinye la wɔe be mete ŋu de Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe kpekpewo hekpɔ gome le woƒe gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me gɔ̃ hã.
With the use of a special wheelchair, I even attended some meetings of Jehovah’s Witnesses and shared in their preaching activity.
Mexɔ nyɔnyrɔ le November 5, 1988 dzi le tsilezɔ tɔxɛ aɖe me esime mexɔ ƒe 20.
On November 5, 1988, at the age of 20, I was baptized by immersion in a special bathtub.
Yehowa Mawu na mekpɔe be agbe nyo wu ku.
Jehovah God had given me a whole new outlook on life.
Gake aleke maɖee afia be mekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe nu si wòwɔ nam la ŋu?
But what could I do to show my appreciation?
MELE ZƆ ÐEM TOGBƆ BE MENYE NUWƆAMETƆ HÃ
ON THE MOVE DESPITE MY DISABILITY
Meɖoe kplikpaa be mawɔ nye ŋutete katã le Yehowa subɔsubɔ me, togbɔ be metsi teƒe ɖeka hã.
I was determined not to let my condition stop me from doing all that I could in Jehovah’s service.
Medi be mawɔ geɖe le mawusubɔsubɔ me.
I wanted to progress.
(1 Timoteo 4:15) Le gɔmedzedzea me la, esia menɔ bɔbɔe o, elabena nye ƒometɔwo tsi tsitre ɖe ŋunye le nye dzixɔse yeyea ta.
(1 Timothy 4:15) At first, that was not easy, for my family was opposed to my new faith.
Gake nye haxɔsetɔwo megblẽm ɖi o, wova le nam abe nɔvinyewo ene.
But I had my fellow believers, who were my spiritual brothers and sisters.
Wokpɔ egbɔ be kpekpe aɖeke meto ŋunye o, eye wokpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔ gome le gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me.
They made sure that I never missed a meeting and that I had an active share in the preaching work.
Gake le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, eva dze ƒãa be ehiã be asi nanɔ ŋunye ɣesiaɣi eye woalé be nam etɔxɛe.
As time went by, however, it became evident that I was going to need round-the-clock specialized care.
Le agbagbadzedze geɖe megbe la, míeva ke ɖe nuwɔametɔwo dzi kpɔƒe aɖe si sɔ la ŋu le Valencia, si didi tso Alicante gbɔ kilometa 160 le dziehe gome.
After a long search, I eventually found a suitable center for the disabled in the city of Valencia, 100 miles (160 km) north of Alicante.
Teƒe siae va zu nɔnyeƒe koŋ.
This center became my permanent home.
Togbɔ be metsi teƒe ɖeka hã la, medzea agbagba be maƒo nu tso nye dzixɔsewo ŋu na amewo
Although bedridden, I am determined to share my faith with others
Togbɔ be metsi teƒe ɖeka hã la, meɖoe kplikpaa be mayi edzi asubɔ Yehowa.
Although bedridden, I was determined to continue pressing forward.
Mezã ga si dziɖuɖua nanam dzinukukui le nye wɔametɔnyenye ta kple gakpekpeɖeŋu bubuwo tsɔ ƒle kɔmpiuta si wova tsi ɖe nye abatia gbɔ.
Using my disability pension and other subsidies, I obtained a computer and had it installed next to my bed.
Meƒle asitelefon hã.
I also purchased a cell phone.
Ŋdi sia ŋdi la, dɔnɔdzikpɔla aɖe va sia nye kɔmpiuta kple asitelefon la nam.
Now, each morning, a caregiver switches on my computer and activates my cell phone.
Mezãa dɔwɔnu aɖe si metsɔa nye glã fiaa mɔe la wɔa kɔmpiutaa ŋu dɔ.
To operate the computer, I use a joystick that I control with my chin.
Ati tɔxɛ aɖe hã li si meléna ɖe nu tsɔ zia ŋɔŋlɔdzesiwo kple xexlẽdzesiwo dzi le nye kɔmpiutaa kple asitelefon la dzi.
I also have a special rod that I hold with my mouth. This rod allows me to type letters on a keyboard and dial numbers on my cell phone.
Félix Alarcón lé ati aɖe ɖe nu hetsɔ le telefon ƒe xexlẽdzesiwo zim
Félix Alarcón holds a rod in his mouth and dials numbers on a cell phone
Mezãa ati tɔxɛ aɖe tsɔ ƒoa ka na amewo le asitelefon dzi
With a rod I can dial numbers on a cell phone
Aleke elektrɔnikdɔwɔnu siawo kpe ɖe ŋunyee?
How has this technology helped me?
Gbã la, ewɔe be metea ŋu yia jw.org Internet dzi nyatakakadzraɖoƒea hezãa Gbetakpɔxɔ INTERNET DZI AGBALẼDZRAÐOƑE la hã.
First of all, it gives me access to the jw.org website and the Watchtower ONLINE LIBRARY.
Dɔwɔnu nyui siawo ɖe vi nam ale gbegbe!
What marvelous tools these have proved to be for me!
Gbe sia gbe la, mezãa gaƒoƒo geɖe ɖe Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽwo me dzodzro kple wo sɔsrɔ̃ ŋu ale be mate ŋu ayi edzi anya nu geɖe tso Mawu kple eƒe nɔnɔme nyoameŋuawo ŋu.
I often spend hours each day studying and researching Bible-based publications so that I can continue learning about God and his wonderful qualities.
Eye ɣesiaɣi si metsi akogo alo dzi ɖe le ƒonye la, mekpɔa nane le nyatakakadzraɖoƒea si dea dzi ƒo nam godoo.
And whenever I feel alone or a little discouraged, there is always something on the website that lifts my spirits.
Ne míaƒe hamea me tɔwo ƒo ƒu le Biblia srɔ̃m le Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpewo me la, nye kɔmpiutaa kpena ɖe ŋunye hã metea ŋu sea nuƒoawo hekpɔa gome le numedzodzrowo me.
My computer also allows me to listen to and participate in congregation meetings.
Metea ŋu ɖoa nya ŋu, doa gbe ɖa, ƒoa nufiamenuƒowo, alo xlẽa Gbetakpɔxɔ la gɔ̃ hã nenye be eɖo dzinye be maxlẽe.
I can comment, offer prayers, present talks, and even read the Watchtower magazine when I am assigned to do so.
Esia wɔe be togbɔ be nyemetea ŋu dea kpekpeawo o hã la, mesena le ɖokuinye me be mele ha dem kplikplikpli kple hamea.
Although I cannot attend those meetings in person, I still feel that I am very much a part of the local congregation.
Asitelefon kple kɔmpiutaa wɔe hã be mekpɔa gome le gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me bliboe.
Having a telephone and a computer also allows me to have a full share in the preaching work.
Ele eme be nyemetea ŋu yia amewo gbɔ tso aƒe me yi aƒe me abe ale si Yehowa Ðasefo akpa gãtɔ wɔnɛ ene ya o.
True, I cannot go from house to house as most of Jehovah’s Witnesses do.
Gake esia mena mede asi asitɛ me o.
But that has not stopped me.
Dɔwɔnu mawo kpena ɖe ŋunye meƒoa nu tso nye dzixɔsewo ŋu na amewo.
Using these tools I am able to share my faith with others.
Le nyateƒe me la, metsɔa dzo ɖe gbeƒãɖeɖe to telefon dzi ŋu ale gbegbe be hamemetsitsiwo de dɔ asi nam be makpɔ telefon dzi ɖaseɖiɖidɔa dzi.
In fact, I enjoy my phone conversations so much that the local elders have even asked me to coordinate telephone preaching campaigns.
Gbeƒãɖeɖe ƒe mɔnu sia kpe ɖe hamea me tɔ siwo tsi teƒe ɖeka la ŋu ŋutɔ.
These campaigns have been particularly helpful to housebound members of the congregation who are unable to leave their homes.
Félix Alarcón le jw.org nyatakakadzraɖoƒea zãm tsɔ le Biblia srɔ̃m kple ŋutsu aɖe
Using the jw.org website, Félix Alarcón conducts a Bible study with a man
Mele Biblia fiam ŋutsu aɖe
Conducting a Bible study
Ke hã menye elektrɔnikdɔwɔnu mawoe xɔa nye ɣeyiɣia katã o.
But my life does not revolve around just technology.
Xɔ̃nyewo va srãnam kpɔ gbe sia gbe.
Each day, dear friends come to see me.
Ne wogbɔna gbɔnye la, wokplɔa woƒe ƒometɔwo kple ame nyanyɛ siwo di be yewoasrɔ̃ Biblia la ɖe asi.
They bring along relatives and acquaintances who are interested in the Bible.
Zi geɖe la, wonana mexɔa ŋgɔ le Biblia me dzodzro kpli wo me gɔ̃ hã.
Often, they even ask me to take the lead in discussions with them.
Ɣebubuɣiwo la, ƒomewo va srãnam kpɔ henana mekpɔa gome le woƒe ƒomea ƒe fiẽsi Biblia-nusɔsrɔ̃a me.
On other occasions, families visit and invite me to share in their evening of family worship.
Ne ɖevi suewo nɔ nye aba dzi le xanye hegblɔ nu si tae wolɔ̃ Yehowa ɖo nam la, edzɔa dzi nam ŋutɔ.
I especially like it when young children sit at my bedside and tell me why they love Jehovah.
Ƒome aɖe va Félix Alarcón gbɔ eye ɖeviawo tsɔ nu siwo wota la le efiam
A family visits Félix Alarcón and the children show him pictures
Mele gome kpɔm le ƒome Biblia-nusɔsrɔ̃ me kple xɔ̃nyewo
Enjoying an evening of family worship with friends
Dzidzɔe wònye nam be ame geɖe va srãnam kpɔ.
I appreciate receiving so many visitors.
Enuenu la, nye xɔa me yɔna kple xɔ̃nye siwo tso didiƒe kple kpuiƒe siaa va be yewoakpɔm ɖa.
My room is often a hub of activity, with friends coming to see me from near and far.
Abe ale si nàsusui ene la, woƒe lɔlɔ̃ɖeɖefia sia wɔa nuku na dɔnɔdzikpɔlaawo.
As you can imagine, this loving attention surprises the caregivers at my center.
Medaa akpe na Yehowa gbe sia gbe be wòna mele nɔviwo ƒe habɔbɔ nyui sia me.
Each day, I thank Jehovah for allowing me to be part of such a wonderful brotherhood.
MELE AVUA DZI
BATTLING ON
Ne ame aɖe do gbe nam hebia nye fɔfɔme ta se la, ɖeko meɖoa eŋu be, "Nyee nye esi, mele avua dzi! "
Whenever anybody greets me and asks how I am, I simply say, "Here I am, still battling on! "
Menyae kɔtɛ be menye nye ɖekae le avua dzi o.
Of course, I know I am not alone in this struggle.
Kristotɔwo katã ʋlia "xɔse ƒe ʋiʋli nyui la, " metsɔ le eme nɔnɔme alo kuxi si me tom wole o. (1 Timoteo 6:12) Nu kae kpe ɖe ŋunye mele ʋiʋlia dzi ƒe geɖewoe nye esia?
Whatever our circumstances or impediments, all Christians are in a fight​ "the fine fight of the faith. " (1 Timothy 6:12) What has helped me to battle on for so many years?
Medoa gbe ɖa daa akpe na Yehowa gbe sia gbe be wòna mɔkpɔkpɔ su asinye le agbe me.
I pray each day and thank Jehovah for giving my life a sense of purpose.
Azɔ hã, medzea agbagba be mawɔ geɖe ale si mate ŋui le mawusubɔsubɔ me eye menana nye ŋku nɔa nye mɔkpɔkpɔa dzi.
And I try to stay as busy as possible in serving God, keeping my eyes focused on the hope ahead.
José Maria, si nye Félix Alarcón xɔlɔ̃ vevi la
José Maria, Félix Alarcón’s good friend
José María
José María
Medea ŋugble le ale si agbea anɔ le xexe yeyea me kple ale si maganɔ du ƒum ahanɔ kpo tim ake la ŋu zi geɖe.
I often think about the new world and what it will be like to run and jump again.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, megblɔna na xɔ̃nye vevi José María, si ŋu atatutudɔ le la fefetɔe be mía kplii míake duɖime ɣemaɣi.
At times, I have joked with my good friend José María​ who suffers from polio ​about running a marathon together.
Mebianɛ be, "Ame kae aɖu dzi? "
"Who would win? "
Eɖoa eŋu nam be, "Menye ame si aɖu dzi lae le vevie o.
I ask him. "It doesn’t matter who wins, " he replies.
Nu vevitɔe nye be míanɔ Paradiso la me ale be míate ŋu ake duɖimea. "
"What really matters is being there, in Paradise, to run the race. "
Tenɔnɔ ɖe nye lãmesẽkuxia nu mele bɔbɔe o.
It has not been easy for me to come to terms with my disability.
Menya be bometsinu aɖe si mewɔ esime menye sɔhɛ lae gblẽ nu le ŋunye vevie alea.
I know that as a teenager, I did something stupid, and that has cost me dearly.
Gake medaa akpe na Yehowa be megblẽm ɖi o. Ena nu geɖem.
Yet, how grateful I am that Jehovah did not abandon me.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, haxɔsetɔ gbogboawo zu ƒome nam, ede agbenɔnɔ ƒe didi menye, kpekpe ɖe amewo ŋu doa dzidzɔ nam, eye wòna etsɔmemɔkpɔkpɔ nyui aɖem.
He has given me so much​ a large spiritual family, the will to live, the joy of helping others, and a wonderful hope for the future.
Ne wobe matsɔ nyagbe ɖeka aɖɔ nye seselelãmee la, magblɔ be, Yehowa ve nunye ŋutɔ vavã.
If I had to sum up my feelings in just one sentence, I guess I would say that Jehovah has truly given me more than I deserve.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ Su Asinye Esime Mehiãe Vevie Wu
I Found Hope When I Needed It Most
Abe ale si Miklós Aleksza gblɔe ene
As told by Miklós Aleksza
Kasia manyaa, nyee nye esi tsyɔ akɔ ɖe tsi dzi.
Suddenly I found myself lying facedown in water.
Mete kpɔ be mafɔ ta dzi agbɔ vie, gake nye kɔ mele ʋaʋãm o.
I tried to lift my head to breathe, but my neck muscles did not respond.
Dzika tsom, medi be matrɔ ɖokuinye, gake nye asiwo kple afɔwo be mada yewo ɖi.
Terrified, I tried to roll over, but my arms and legs refused to move.
Tsi te gege ɖe nye dzitodzitowo me.
My lungs began to take in water.
Tso ƒe 1991 ƒe dzomeŋɔli ƒe ŋkeke ma dzi la, nye agbenɔnɔ trɔ bubui kura.
On that warm summer’s day in 1991, my life changed completely.
Miklós Aleksza
Miklós Aleksza
WODZIM le du si woyɔna be Szerencs me eye kɔƒe si nye Tiszaladány, si le Hungary ƒe dzieheɣedzeƒe gome la, mee menɔ tsi.
I WAS born in the city of Szerencs and grew up in the village of Tiszaladány in the northeast of Hungary.
Le June 1991 me la, nye kple xɔ̃nye aɖewo míeyi be míaɖaƒu tsi le Tisza Tɔsisia ƒe akpa aɖe si míele tsi le kpɔ o.
In June 1991, some friends and I went to an unfamiliar spot on the Tisza River.
Mesusui be tsia goglo, eye medzo dze eme doo.
Thinking that the water was deep, I dived in.
Mewɔ nu ɖokuinye!
It was a big mistake!
Nye kɔƒukpeƒe etɔ̃ ŋe eye wògblẽ nu le nye dzimeƒu ŋu.
I broke three vertebrae in my neck and damaged my spinal cord.
Xɔ̃nyewo de dzesii be nyemenɔ ʋaʋãm o, eya ta wova kɔm ɖɔɖɔɖɔ do go le tsia me ale be nyemagano tsi aku o.
My friend saw that I was not moving and carefully raised me and pulled me out before I drowned.
Togbɔ be nyemenɔ ʋaʋãm o hã la, menɔ ŋute, eye menya be lã aɖe lém.
I remained conscious and knew that something was seriously wrong.
Ame aɖe yɔ ame siwo kpɔa ame siwo dzi afɔku dzɔ ɖo la gbɔ wova kɔm ɖe helikɔpta me yi kɔdzi, eye ɖɔktawo trɔ asi le nye dzimeƒua ŋu.
Someone called the emergency services, and a helicopter arrived and carried me to a hospital, where doctors stabilized my spine.
Emegbe wokɔm yi míaƒe fiadu si nye Budapest ale be woakpe ɖe ŋunye mahaya le afi ma.
Later, I was transferred to the capital city, Budapest, for rehabilitation.
Medze ŋe ɣleti etɔ̃ sɔŋ.
I stayed on my back for three months.
Togbɔ be metea ŋu ʋãa ta hã la, metútu tso abɔta yi afɔ gbɔ.
Although I was able to move my head, I had no muscle control from my shoulders down.
Ƒe 20 ko mexɔ ɣemaɣi, gake mezu nuwɔametɔ keŋkeŋ.
At 20 years of age, I had become completely dependent on others.
Dzi ɖe le ƒonye ale gbegbe be, medi be maku.
I felt so discouraged that I wanted to die.
Esi ɣeyiɣia va de be matrɔ ayi aƒe me la, wona hehe tɔxɛ dzinyelawo ale be woate ŋu anɔ gbɔnye kpɔm.
When at last I was able to go home, my parents received training so that they could care for me.
Gake gbɔnyekpɔkpɔ te ɖeɖi wo ŋu ale gbegbe, eye le ƒe ɖeka megbe la, melé blanuiléledɔ.
But the work was hard on them physically and emotionally, and after about a year, I descended into depression.
Le ɣeyiɣi ma me la, nye nɔnɔmea ŋuti nunyalawo ɖo aɖaŋu geɖe nam, esia kpe ɖe ŋunye meva trɔ susu le ale si mebua nye nɔnɔmeae ŋu.
At that point, I received professional counseling, which helped me to change the way I viewed my disability.
Eye mete tamebubu vevie hã tso agbea ŋu.
I also started to think more deeply about life.
Susu aɖe tae míele agbe ɖoa?
Does it have a purpose?
Nu ka tae afɔku sia dzɔ ɖe dzinye?
Why did this tragedy happen to me?
Mexlẽ magazine kple agbalẽ geɖewo be makpɔ nya siawo ƒe ŋuɖoɖowo.
I read magazines and books in a search for answers.
Metrɔ ɖe Biblia hã ŋu, gake nyemenya ta le emenyawo nu o.
I also tried reading the Bible, but I found it hard to understand.
Eya ta medzudzɔ exexlẽ.
So it went back on the shelf.
Meɖo dze kple mawununɔla aɖe gɔ̃ hã, gake eƒe nyawo mede dzi ƒo nam o.
I even had a talk with a priest, but I found his comments unsatisfying.
Azɔ le ƒe 1994 ƒe adame la, Yehowa Ðasefo eve aɖewo va fofonye gbɔ, eye wòbia tso wo si be woaɖo dze kplim.
Then, in the spring of 1994, two of Jehovah’s Witnesses visited my father, and he asked them to speak to me.
Menɔ to dzi esime wonɔ tame si Mawu ɖo be yeatrɔ anyigba wòazu paradiso eye yeaɖe dɔléle kple fukpekpewo ɖa la me ɖem.
I listened as they described God’s purpose to make the earth into a paradise and to eliminate sickness and suffering.
Woƒe nyawo nya se ŋutɔ, gake nyemeka ɖe wo dzi o.
It all sounded very good, but I was skeptical.
Ke hã melɔ̃ xɔ Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ eve.
Still, I accepted two Bible study aids.
Esi mexlẽ agbalẽawo vɔ la, Ðasefoawo doe ɖa be yewoanɔ Biblia srɔ̃m kplim, eye melɔ̃ ɖe edzi.
After I read the books, the Witnesses offered to study the Bible with me, and I consented.
Wode dzi ƒo nam hã be manɔ gbe dom ɖa.
They also encouraged me to pray.
Meva xɔe se bliboe be Mawu tsɔa ɖe le eme nam vevie
I became convinced that God really does care about me
Esi míeyi nua sɔsrɔ̃ dzi la, meva kpɔ nye nyabiase gbogboawo ƒe ŋuɖoɖowo le Biblia me tẽe.
As our discussions progressed, I received answers to my many questions straight from the Bible.
Meva xɔe se bliboe hã be Mawu tsɔa ɖe le eme nam vevie.
I also became convinced that God really does care about me.
Esi medze nusɔsrɔ̃ gɔme ƒe eve megbe la, wona nyɔnyrɔm ɖe tsi me le míaƒe aƒe me le September 13, 1997 dzi.
Finally, on September 13, 1997, after studying the Bible for two years, I was baptized at home in a bathtub.
Esiae nye ŋkeke si dzi mekpɔ dzidzɔ le wu le agbe me.
It was one of the happiest days of my life.
Le ƒe 2007 me la, wokplɔm yi ɖada ɖe wɔametɔwo dzi kpɔƒe koŋ le Budapest.
In 2007, I moved permanently to Budapest to a home for the disabled.
Esia na mɔnukpɔkpɔ su asinye megblɔa nu wɔnuku siwo mesrɔ̃ la na ame bubuwo.
This move has given me many opportunities to share with others the wonderful things I have learned.
Ne xexea me kɔ la, medoa nye bunɔkeke, si ŋu wotrɔ asi le etɔxɛe ale be metea ŋu tsɔa nye glã kunae la, yia gota ɖaɖoa dze kple amewo.
In good weather, I can even go outside to talk to people, thanks to a specially adapted motorized wheelchair that I steer with my chin.
Ƒome aɖe si le míaƒe hamea me na gam dɔmenyotɔe, ale be mete ŋu ƒle atadzikɔmpiuta tɔxɛ aɖe, eye ne mele ta ʋãm ko la, kɔmpiuta ŋutɔ wɔa nu si medi be mawɔ.
With the generous financial assistance of a family in my congregation, I was also able to obtain a laptop computer that operates by tracking my head movements.
Mezãa kɔmpiuta sia tsɔ ƒoa ka na amewo to internet dzi heŋlɔa nu na ame siwo ŋu míaƒe hamea me tɔwo meke ɖo le aƒe me o hã.
This device allows me to telephone people via the Internet and write letters to householders who were away when members of my congregation called on their homes.
Kpekpeɖeŋu sia nana amewo na be meva bi le dzeɖoɖo me, eye wòwɔe hã be nye susu meganɔa nye lãmesẽkuxia ŋu o.
Helping others in this way has improved my communication skills considerably and has helped me to take my mind off myself.

Miklós Aleksza using modern technology to communicate

Medea Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpewo gɔ̃ hã.
I am even able to attend Christian meetings.
Ne meva Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me la, menɔa nye bunɔkekea me nye haxɔsetɔwo kɔam ɖɔɖɔɖɔ yia dzisasrã gbãtɔ dzi afi si míewɔa kpekpeawo le.
When I arrive at the Kingdom Hall, my spiritual brothers carefully carry me in my wheelchair up one floor to the meeting location.
Ne wobia tso kpekpevalawo si be woaƒo nu le kpekpeawo me, eye medi be mado asi ɖe dzi la, nɔviŋutsu aɖe si nɔa xanye doa asi ɖe dzi ɖe nunye.
During meetings, when the audience is invited to comment, the brother sitting next to me raises his hand for me.
Ekɔa nye Biblia alo Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽa ɖe dzi nam ne mele nyaa ŋu ɖom.
He then holds my Bible or study aid while I make my comment.
Mesea veve ɣesiaɣi, eye ame bubuwoe wɔa nu sia nu kloe nam.
I am in constant pain and need others to do nearly everything for me.
Eya ta dzi gaɖena le ƒonye ɣeaɖewoɣi.
So I still feel emotionally down at times.
Gake xɔlɔ̃dzedze Yehowa faa akɔ nam, elabe menyae be eɖoa tom ne mele nye dzimaɖitsitsiwo gblɔm nɛ.
But I find comfort in my friendship with Jehovah God, knowing that he listens when I pour out my concerns to him.
Biblia-xexlẽ gbe sia gbe doa ŋusẽm, eye nye haxɔsetɔwo hã dea dzi ƒo nam.
I also gain strength through daily Bible reading and from my spiritual brothers and sisters.
Woƒe xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔ, dzideƒoname kple woƒe gbedodoɖa ɖe tanye na be mete ŋu da sɔ le susu me kple seselelãme gome.
Their friendship, emotional support, and prayers in my behalf help me to maintain mental and emotional balance.
Yehowa fa akɔ nam esime mehiãe vevie wu.
Jehovah gave me comfort just when I needed it most.
Ena lãmesẽ deblibo me nɔnɔ le xexe yeyea me ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔ hãm.

Hence, I yearn for the time when I can ‘walk and leap and praise him’ for his extraordinary love and kindness.

Nya Kae Biblia Gblɔ Tso Dzila Tsitsiwo Dzi Kpɔkpɔ Ŋu?
What Does the Bible Say About Caregiving for Elderly Parents?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Vi tsitsiwo ƒe agbanɔamedzi vevi aɖee wònye be woakpɔ egbɔ be yewowɔ ɖoɖo ɖe yewo dzila tsitsiwo dzi kpɔkpɔ ŋu.
Adult children have the important responsibility of making sure that their elderly parents are cared for.

Biblia gblɔ be ele be vi tsitsiwo "nanya nu gbãtɔ si dze be woawɔ na woƒe ƒometɔwo abe ale si hiã le mawusubɔsubɔ me la ene. Esiae nye be vi siawo nakpɔ wo dzilawo dzi, elabe nuwɔna siae dzea Mawu ŋu. " (1 Timoteo 5:4, Eʋegbe Biblia) Ne vi tsitsiwo kpɔ egbɔ be yewowɔ ɖoɖo ɖe yewo dzila tsitsiwo dzi kpɔkpɔ ŋu la, ke wole wɔwɔm ɖe Biblia ƒe se si nye be woabu wo dzilawo la hã dzi.

The Bible says that adult children should "put their religion into practice by caring for their own family and so repaying their parents . . . , for this is pleasing to God. " (1 Timothy 5:4, New International Version) When adult children see to it that their elderly parents are taken care of, they also obey the Bible’s command to honor their parents.
Efesotɔwo 6:2, 3.
Ephesians 6:2, 3.
Biblia mena mɔfiamewo tẽe ku ɖe nu si tututu woawɔ atsɔ akpɔ dzila tsitsiwo dzi ŋu o.
The Bible does not contain specific instructions on caring for aging parents.
Ke hã, eƒo ŋu tso ŋutsu kple nyɔnu xɔsetɔ siwo ɖo kpɔɖeŋu ɖi le esia wɔwɔ me ŋu.
However, it provides examples of men and women of faith who did so.
Azɔ hã, eɖo aɖaŋu nyui siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo le ame tsitsiwo dzi kpɔm la ŋu.
It also offers practical advice that can help caregivers.

Yosef nɔ adzɔge tso fofoa Yakob si ku amegã la gbɔ.
Joseph lived far from his aging father, Jacob.
Esi nɔnɔmeawo ɖe mɔ la, ewɔ ɖoɖo be Yakob naʋu ava teƒe si tsɔ ye gbɔ.
When Joseph was able to, he arranged for Jacob to move closer to him.
Eyome Yosef di nɔƒe na fofoa eye wòkpɔ eƒe nuɖuɖu kple dedienɔnɔ nyawo gbɔ.
Joseph then housed, fed, and protected his father.
Rut kplɔ lɔ̃xoa ɖo yi wo de eye wòku kutri wɔ dɔ sesĩe tsɔ kpɔ edzi.
Ruth migrated to her mother-in-law’s country and worked tirelessly to care for her.
Yesu hã tsɔ dadaa, Maria, si anya zu ahosi ɣemaɣi la, dzi kpɔkpɔ de ame aɖe si ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe do ŋgɔ na eƒe ku.
Jesus, shortly before he died, designated a caregiver for his mother, Mary, who was apparently then a widow.
Yohanes 19:26, 27.
Biblia me aɖaŋuɖoɖo nyui kawoe ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo le ame tsitsiwo dzi kpɔm la ŋu?
What practical advice from the Bible can help caregivers?
Mɔfiamewo le Biblia me siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo le dzila tsitsiwo dzi kpɔm ŋu be woate ŋu atsɔ wo dzila tsitsiwo dzi kpɔkpɔ ƒe agba si tea ɖeɖi ame ŋu henana nu tia kɔ na ame ɣeaɖewoɣi la.
The Bible contains principles that can help caregivers deal with the sometimes physically and emotionally exhausting challenge of caring for elderly parents.
Bu dziwòlawo.
Honor your parents.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ: "Bu fofowò kple dawò. " 2 Mose 20:12.
What the Bible says: "Honor your father and your mother. "
Aleke nàte ŋu awɔ mɔfiame sia dzi?
Exodus 20:12. How can the principle be applied?
Anye bubudede dziwòlawo ŋu ne èna ablɔɖe wo be woawɔ nu siwo wodi le ale si woƒe nɔnɔmeawo aɖe mɔe nu.
Show your parents honor by allowing them to maintain as much independence as their limitations permit.
Zi ale si wòanya wɔ ko la, ɖe mɔ na wo be woawo ŋutɔwo natso nya me le wo dzi kpɔkpɔ ƒe nyawo ŋu.
To the extent possible, let them make their own decisions about their care.
Le ɣeyiɣi ma ke me la, de bubu wo ŋu to ale si nàwɔ nu si nàte ŋui atsɔ akpɔ wo dzi me.
At the same time, show them honor by doing what you reasonably can to assist them.
Se nu gɔme na wo eye nàtsɔ ake.
Be understanding and forgiving.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ: "Ame si sea nu gɔme nyuie la, medoa dziku kabakaba o, eye atsyɔ̃ wònye nɛ be wòaŋe aɖaba aƒu agɔdzedze dzi. "

Lé nyaa kpɔ kple ame bubuwo.
Consult others.

What the Bible says: "Plans fail when there is no consultation, but there is accomplishment through many advisers. "
Lododowo 15:22.
Proverbs 15:22.
Aleke nàte ŋu awɔ mɔfiame sia dzi?

Find out what resources are available in your community to help with their care.
Ðo dze kple ame bubu siwo kpɔ wo dzila tsitsiwo dzi.
Talk with others who have cared for elderly parents.

If you have siblings, consider having a family meeting to discuss your parents’ needs, how to care for them, and how to share the load.
Nyɔnu tsitsi aɖe kpe kple eƒe ƒomea be yewoadzro ale si woakpɔ ye dzi la me

Nya afi si wò ŋutete se ɖo.
Be modest.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ: "Ame siwo nyaa afi si woƒe ŋutete se ɖo la si mee nunya le. "
What the Bible says: "Wisdom is with the modest ones. "

Proverbs 11:2.

How can the principle be applied?
Nya afi si wò ŋutete se ɖo.
Recognize your limitations.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, vovo meganɔa mía dometɔ akpa gãtɔ ŋu o, eye ɖeɖi tea mí katã mía ŋu.
For example, everyone has limited time and energy.
Esiawo ate ŋu awɔe be màte ŋu akpe ɖe dziwòla tsitsiwo ŋu abe ale si nàdi be yeawɔe ene o.
These limitations can affect how much you are realistically able to do for your parents.
Ne èkpɔe be nu siwo dziwòla tsitsiwo dzi kpɔkpɔ bia la va wu tsɔtsɔ na ye la, dae kpɔ be anyo be nàbia kpekpeɖeŋu tso ƒometɔ bubuwo alo ame tsitsiwo dzi kpɔlawo gbɔ hã.
If you find yourself overwhelmed with the demands of caring for elderly parents, consider asking for help from other family members or from professionals.
Lé be na ɖokuiwò.
Look after yourself.

What the Bible says: "No man ever hated his own body, but he feeds and cherishes it. "
Efesotɔwo 5:29.
Ephesians 5:29.

Togbɔ be agba le dziwò be nàkpɔ dziwòlawo dzi hã la, ele be nàkpɔ wò ŋutɔ wò nuhiahiãwo kple wò ƒomea hã tɔ gbɔ, ne srɔ̃tɔe nènye.

The Bible contains no specific direction on whether adult children must care for parents at home.
Ƒome aɖewo tsoa nya me be yewoakpɔ yewo dzila tsitsiwo dzi le aƒe me ɣeyiɣi didi si yewoate ŋui.
Some families choose to keep their aged parents at home for as long as possible.
Gake ne eva ɖo afi aɖe la, ɖewohĩ woakpɔe be anyo wu ne yewokplɔe yi ame tsitsiwo dzi kpɔƒe.

When Your Child Is Disabled
CARLO: "Dɔléle aɖe le mía viŋutsu Angelo ŋu si woyɔna be ‘Down syndrome.’
CARLO: "Our son, Angelo, has Down syndrome.
Edzi kpɔkpɔ nana ɖeɖi tea mía ŋu, míebua tame, hetsia dzimaɖi.
His illness drains our physical, mental, and emotional strength.
Bu nu si gbegbe wòbia be woakpɔ ɖevi si le lãmesẽ me dzi ŋu kpɔ. Míehiã na ema ƒe teƒe alafa ɖeka.
Imagine the energy you need to look after a healthy child, and then multiply that by a hundred.
Ewɔnɛ be kuxi ɖoa míaƒe srɔ̃ɖeɖea me ɣeaɖewoɣi. "

MIA: "Nu suetɔ kekeake si míafia Angelo la gɔ̃ hã bia kutrikuku kple dzigbɔɖi geɖe ŋutɔ.
MIA: "It takes persistence and a tremendous amount of patience to teach Angelo the simplest things.

"When the doctors told me that our son, Santiago, had cerebral palsy, I couldn’t believe it, " says Juliana, a mother in Mexico.
Nye dzi gbã gudugudu. "

Carlo and Mia, quoted in the introduction, sought information from their doctor and an organization that specializes in their son’s condition.
Wogblɔ be: "Esia kpe ɖe mía ŋu míenya kuxi siwo wòle be míakpɔ mɔ na kpakple nu nyui siwo ɖevi siwo ŋu Down syndrome le ate ŋu awɔ la hã.
"This helped us to understand not only the problems that we could expect but also the ‘positive’ aspects of Down syndrome, " they say.

"We saw that our son could lead a life that in many respects would be normal.
Esia fa akɔ na mí ŋutɔ. "

CHALLENGE 2: YOU FEEL EXHAUSTED AND EMOTIONALLY ISOLATED.
Ðewohĩ àse le ɖokuiwò me be nu ti kɔ na wò le viwòa dzi kpɔkpɔ ta.
You may feel that caring for your sick child consumes all your energy.
Jenney, si nye vidada le New Zealand, gblɔ be: "Ƒe ʋɛ aɖewo tso esime vinyea zu bafa la, ɣesiaɣi si mete kpɔ be mawɔ dɔ bubuwo akpe ɖe nye aƒemedɔwo ŋu la, ɖeɖi tea ŋunye ŋutɔ, eye mefaa avi. "
Jenney, a mother in New Zealand, says, "For a few years after my son was diagnosed with spina bifida, I would be exhausted and weepy if I tried to do anything extra around the home. "
Kuxi bubue nye be ɖewohĩ mànya ame si nàgblɔ wò nyawo na o.
Another challenge may be that you feel isolated.
Viŋutsu aɖe le Ben si si nye wɔametɔ si ŋu susumedɔ aɖe hã le.
Ben has a son who suffers from muscular dystrophy and Asperger’s syndrome.
Ben gblɔ be, "Ame akpa gãtɔ mate ŋu ase nu si tututu me tom míele la gɔme akpɔ o. "
Ben says, "Most people will never really understand what our life is like. "
Ðewohĩ àdi be yeaƒo nu tso eŋu na ame aɖe, gake xɔ̃wò akpa gãtɔ ƒe viwo menye wɔametɔwo o.
You may long to talk with someone. Yet, most of your friends have healthy children.
Eya ta ànɔ hehem ɖe megbe be yeaɖe wò kuxiwo dzi na wo.
So you feel reluctant to confide in them.
AÐAŊUÐOÐO: Bia kpekpeɖeŋu, eye nàlɔ̃ woakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
SUGGESTION: Ask for help. And accept it when it is offered.
Juliana, si ŋu nya míegblɔ va yi la gblɔ be: "Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, ekpea ŋu na mía kple srɔ̃nye be míabia kpekpeɖeŋu. "
Juliana, quoted earlier, admits, "Sometimes my husband and I are embarrassed to ask for help. "
Ke hã, egblɔ kpee be, "Míeva de dzesii be míehiã kpekpeɖeŋu.
However, she adds, "We have learned that we are not self-sufficient.
Ne amewo le kpekpem ɖe mía ŋu la, míekpɔnɛ be womegblẽ mí ɖi o. "
When others help us, we don’t feel so alone. "
Ne ƒometɔ alo xɔ̃wò vevi aɖe be viwòa nava nɔ ye gbɔ le Kristotɔwo ƒe kpekpe alo wɔna bubu aɖe teƒe la, lɔ̃ faa.
If a close friend or family member offers to sit with your child at a social event or a Christian meeting, accept gratefully.

"A true companion is loving all the time, " says a Bible proverb, "and is a brother that is born for when there is distress. "

Take care of your own health.

Javier, who has a crippled son, puts it this way: "My son cannot walk, so I feel that I should try to eat well. After all, I am the one who moves him around.
Nyee nye eƒe afɔwo! "
My feet are his feet! "
Aleke nàwɔ akpɔ vovo ɖe wò lãmesẽnyawo gbɔ kpɔkpɔ ŋu?
How can you find time to look after your health?
Dzila aɖewo ɖɔa li wo nɔewo le wo viwo gbɔ kpɔkpɔ me.
Some parents take turns caring for their child.
Esia wɔnɛ be dzila kemɛa tea ŋu ɖina ɖe eme alo kpɔa eƒe hiahiã bubuwo gbɔ.
One parent is thus able to rest or care for other personal needs.
Ahiã be nàɖe ɣeyiɣi si nèzãna ɖe nu siwo mehiã boo o ŋu la dzi akpɔtɔ, eye ate ŋu asesẽ hã be nàda asɔ le wò ɣeyiɣi ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ me.
You will need to buy out time from nonessential activities, and it can be a challenge to maintain a balance.
Gake abe ale si Mayuri, si nye vidada aɖe le India, gblɔe ene la, "Vivivi la ava ma wò. "
But as Mayuri, a mother in India, says, "Eventually you get into a routine. "
Ƒo nu tso wò kuxiwo ŋu na xɔ̃wò si dzi nèka ɖo.
Talk to a trustworthy friend.
Xɔ̃wò siwo ƒe viwo le lãmesẽ me gɔ̃ hã ate ŋu aɖo to wò veveseseɖeamenutɔe.

Àte ŋu ado gbe ɖa na Yehowa Mawu hã.
You can also pray to Jehovah God.
Ðe esia ɖea via?
Will prayer really help?

Yazmin has two children with cystic fibrosis, and she admits, "There have been moments of such intense pressure that I have felt like I was choking to death. "
Gake egblɔ kpee be: "Ne medo gbe ɖa na Yehowa bia gbɔdzɔe kple ŋusẽdodo ko la, ŋusẽ yeye gaɖoa ŋunye. "
Yet, she adds: "I pray to Jehovah for relief and strength. Then I feel that I can carry on. "

Ðevi ƒe dɔléle ate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe nu si ƒomea ɖuna, afi si woyina kple vovo si dzilawo kpɔna ɖe wo viwo ŋu la dzi.
A child’s illness may affect what the family eats, where the family goes, and how much time parents spend with each child.
Esia ate ŋu ana ɖevi bubuawo nase le wo ɖokui me be wogblẽ yewo ɖi.
As a result, the other children may feel neglected.
Azɔ hã, dzilawo ate ŋu ava nɔ ɣeyiɣi geɖe zãm ɖe wo vi si nye dɔnɔa ŋu ale gbegbe be womakpɔ vovo ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu o.
Furthermore, parents can become so busy caring for their sick child that their marriage suffers.
Lionel, si nye vifofo aɖe le Liberia, gblɔ be: "Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, srɔ̃nye gblɔna be agbaa va tsi ye ɖeka dzi, eye nyemetsɔ ɖeke le eme na mía via o.

"I feel belittled, and sometimes I respond unkindly. "

Tsɔ ɖe le eme na viwòwo katã

Aseem, a father in India whose son suffers from seizures, says: "Though my wife and I sometimes feel strained and frustrated, we make it a point to sit down, talk, and pray together.
Ŋdi sia ŋdi, hafi mía viwo nanyɔ la, míedzroa mawunyakpukpui ɖeka me le Biblia me. "

Nɔnye le dɔléle sesẽ aɖe si woyɔna be Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) lém.
My mom has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), a chronic and painful condition that affects the joints, skin, and blood vessels.
Enye dɔ vɔ̃ɖi aɖe si gblẽa nu le ame ƒe ƒunukpeƒewo, ŋutigbalẽ kple ʋukawo ŋu.
There is no cure for the illness, and my mom’s condition has worsened over the past ten years.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, eƒe ʋu ɖiɖina kpɔtɔna ale gbegbe be eƒe agbe ɖoa afɔku me; eye ɣeaɖewoɣi hã, esea veve ale gbegbe be ɖeko wòdina be yeaku.
In fact, there have been times when her blood count was so low that her life was in danger or when the pain was so bad that she didn’t want to live anymore.
Yehowa Ðasefowoe míenye, eye míaƒe hamea me tɔwo nye kpekpeɖeŋutsoƒe gã aɖe na mí!
My family and I are Jehovah’s Witnesses, and our congregation has been so comforting to all of us!

For example, recently a girl who is about my age sent a card to our family to tell us how much she loves us and to assure us that we can always count on her support.
Dzidzɔ gã ka gbegbee nye esi wònye be xɔlɔ̃ siawo tɔgbi le mía si!
It’s so nice to have someone like that as a friend!
Biblia hã kpe ɖe ŋunye ale gbegbe.
The Bible has been a tremendous help to me.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nye mawunyakpukpui veviwo dometɔ ɖekae nye Psalmo 34:18, si gblɔ be: "Yehowa tsɔ ɖe ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã gudugudu la gbɔ. "
For example, one of my favorite scriptures is Psalm 34:18, which says: "Jehovah is close to the brokenhearted. "
Bubu hãe nye Hebritɔwo 13:6, si gblɔ be: "Yehowa ye nye nye kpeɖeŋutɔ; nyemavɔ̃ o. "
Another is Hebrews 13:6, which says: "Jehovah is my helper; I will not be afraid. "
Mawunyakpukpui evelia sia me nyawo dea dzi gbɔ nam ŋutɔ.
I find that last scripture to be especially meaningful.
Nu si mevɔ̃na wue nye be nɔnye ava ku agblẽm ɖi.
My biggest fear is that I will lose my mom in death.
Melɔ̃e ŋutɔ, eye mekpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe si nye kplii míenɔ anyi ɖekae ŋu.
I love her so much, and I’m thankful for each day I have with her.
Mawunyakpukpui ma kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe be nu ka kee adzɔ le etsɔme o, ele be kakaɖedzi sẽŋu nanɔ asinye.
That Bible verse helps me realize that I can face the future with confidence, no matter what it might bring.

Emmaline and her mother work together in the kitchen
Gake mevɔ̃a nu bubu aɖe hã.
But I have another fear.
Woxɔa EDS dɔlélea le ame dzila ŋu.
You see, EDS is hereditary.
Nɔnye xɔe le nɔa ŋu, eye nye hã mexɔe le nɔnye ŋu.
My mom got it from her mom, and I got it from mine.
Ta efia be, EDS le nye hã ŋunye.
That’s right​ I too have EDS.
Gake Hebritɔwo 13:6 na meka ɖe edzi be Yehowa anye "nye kpeɖeŋutɔ " le go sia hã me.
But Hebrews 13:6 assures me that Jehovah will be "my helper " in this area as well.
Eya ta medzea agbagba be makpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe nu si le asinye fifia ŋu, eye be maganɔ nu siwo dzɔ va yi ŋu bum alo atsi dzi fũu ɖe etsɔme ŋu o.
In the meantime, I try to appreciate what I have now and not live in the past​ or worry about the future.
Dzi ate ŋu aɖe le ƒonye ne metsɔa nu siwo nɔnye te ŋu wɔna tsã le sɔsɔm kple nu siwo megate ŋu le wɔwɔm fifia o.
I can get depressed if I compare my mom’s limitations with what she used to be able to do.
