Le nuɖuɖu siwo nana ame dzea dɔ gome la, edadamɔnu bubu aɖeke meli tsɔ wu be ame naƒo asa na nuɖuɖu mawo o.
There is no widely accepted treatment for severe food allergies other than the total avoidance of the particular foods that trigger the allergy.
Ke hã, ne nuɖuɖuawo ƒe fuɖename nu mesẽ boo o la, ke aɖe vi na wò ne èɖe nuɖuɖu mawo ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ si nèɖuna kple ale si nèɖunɛ edziedzi la dzi kpɔtɔ.
On the other hand, if you have milder food allergies or food intolerance, you may see some benefit from simply reducing how often you eat certain foods and the amount.
Le go aɖewo me la, le ale si nuɖuɖua ɖea fu na amee ta la, ele be amea naƒo asa na nuɖuɖu mawo kura alo adzudzɔ wo ɖuɖu hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
In some cases, however, sufferers are compelled to avoid the foods in question altogether, or at least for some time, depending on the severity of the intolerance.
Eya ta ne nuɖuɖu aɖewo nana nèdzea dɔ alo ɖea fu na wò la, efaa akɔ be nànya be ame geɖe siwo ŋu kuxi sia le la srɔ̃ ale si woanɔ te ɖe nɔnɔme sia nu eye wogasea vivi na nuɖuɖu vovovowo.

So if you have a food allergy or a food intolerance, you may find comfort in knowing that many sufferers have learned to manage their condition and still enjoy a wide variety of nutritious and delicious foods.
Asrãdɔ Nu Si Wòle Be Nànya Tso Eŋu
What You Should Know About Malaria
Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔ bu akɔnta be le ƒe 2013 me la, ame miliɔn 198 sɔŋue lé asrãdɔ (atikesi), eye ame akpe 584 aɖewoe dɔ sia wu.
The World Health Organization estimates that in 2013, more than 198 million people were infected with malaria and an estimated 584,000 died as a result of it.
Ame siwo ŋu dɔ sia gblẽ nu le la dometɔ 4 kloe le 5 me nye ɖevi siwo mekpɔ xɔ ƒe atɔ̃ o.
Nearly 4 out of 5 casualties were children under five years of age.
Dɔ sia xɔ aƒe ɖe xexemedukɔ siwo ade alafa ɖeka me, eye ate ŋu agblẽ nu le ame miliɔn 3,200 ŋuti.
The disease presents a threat in about a hundred countries and territories throughout the world, putting some 3.2 billion people at risk.
1 NU KAE NYE ASRÃDƆ?
1 WHAT IS MALARIA?
Ne mu ɖu amee wòléa asrãdɔ alo atikesi.
Malaria is a parasitic disease.
Dɔ sia ƒe dzesiwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye dzoxɔxɔ, vuvɔwɔame, fifiatete, taɖuame, lãmeve, dzigbɔtɔame kple tutru alo xeɖeɖe.
Its symptoms include fever, chills, sweats, headache, body aches, nausea, and vomiting.
Dzesi siawo tea ŋu tɔa te sẽe gavana le gaƒoƒo 48 va se ɖe 72 ɖe sia ɖe me, anɔ te ɖe mu ƒomevi si ɖu amea kple ɣeyiɣi didi si dɔa le amea ŋu dzi.
The symptoms may sometimes recur every 48 to 72 hours, depending on the type of parasite involved and how long the person has had the disease.
2 ALEKE ASRÃDƆ WƆNA KAKANA?
2 HOW DOES MALARIA SPREAD?
Nɔnɔmetata si ɖe ale si asrãdɔlékui kakana ɖe lãme na ame la fia
A diagram of how malaria parasites spread in a human body
Ne munɔ ɖu amee asrãdɔlékui gena ɖe ʋu me na ame.
Malaria parasites protozoans called Plasmodia are introduced into the human bloodstream through the bite of a female Anopheles mosquito.
Dɔlékuia yina ɖe ame si mua ɖu la ƒe aklãmenugbagbeviwo me eye wòdzina sɔa gbɔ le afi ma.
The parasites find their way into the infected person’s liver cells, where the parasites multiply.
Aklãmenugbagbeviawo gbãna eye dɔlékuiawo kakana ɖagena ɖe amea ƒe ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwo me.
When a liver cell ruptures, it releases the parasites, which then invade the infected person’s red blood cells.
Dɔlékuiawo yia edzi nɔa dzidzim ɖe edzi le afi ma hã.
There, the parasites continue to multiply.
Asrãdɔlékuiwo ge ɖe ʋumenugbagbevidzĩwo me eye wona wogbã
Malaria parasites invade red blood cells and cause them to rupture
Eye ne ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩwo gbã la, asrãdɔlékui gbogbowo dona tso wo me ɖagena ɖe ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩ bubuwo me.
When a red blood cell ruptures, it releases the parasites, which invade still more red blood cells.
Alea ko wòyia edzi le ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩawo me ɖaa.
The cycle of red blood cell invasion and rupture continues.
Ɣesiaɣi si ʋumenugbagbevi dzĩawo gbã la, asrãdɔ ƒe dzesi vovovoawo dzena le amea ŋu.
The infected person typically manifests symptoms of malaria each time the red blood cells rupture.
3 ALEKE NÀKPƆ ÐOKUIWÒ TAE?
3 HOW CAN YOU PROTECT YOURSELF?
Ne èle dukɔ si me asrãdɔ bɔ ɖo me la . . .
If you live in a land where malaria is endemic . . .
Mlɔ mudɔ me.
Use a bed net or a mosquito net.
Ele be
It should be
mudɔa nanye esi wode atikee.
treated with insecticide.
wòanɔ nɔnɔme nyui me, afi aɖeke megavuvu nɛ o.
free of any holes or tears.
woadee belia te nyuie.
tucked completely under the mattress.
Wu mutikewo ɖe wò aƒe me.
Use indoor residual spraying in your home.
Ne anya wɔ la, mide ɖɔwo alo gaɖɔwo fesrewo kple ʋɔtruwo ŋu, mizã xɔmefamɔ̃ alo yaƒomɔ̃ ale be muwo magava ɖe fu na mi o.
If possible, install screens on doors and windows, and use air-conditioners and fans, which may discourage mosquitoes from settling.
Do awu alo nàtsyɔ avɔ si ƒe mo kɔ eye nàna wòaxe wo ametia ƒe afi sia afi.
Wear light-colored clothing that fully covers your skin.
Ne anya wɔ la, ƒo asa na gbe siwo me muwo sɔa gbɔ ɖo alo tsiteƒe siwo muwo ate ŋu adzi ɖo nɔnɔ.
Whenever possible, avoid areas of brush, where mosquitoes swarm, and standing water, where they breed.
Ne ède dzesi asrãdɔ ƒe dzesiwo le ŋuwò la, na woawɔ atike na wò enumake.
If you are infected, get treatment promptly.
Ale si amegbetɔwo xɔa asrãdɔlékuiwo tso muwo gbɔ eye muwo hã xɔnɛ tso amegbetɔwo gbɔ
Malaria cycle involving mosquitoes and humans
Asrãdɔlékuia ate ŋu age ɖe lãme na ame ne mu ɖui.
A human can get the malaria parasite from an infected mosquito.
Nenema ke ne mu si ŋu dɔlékui sia mele o ɖu ame aɖe si ŋu dɔlékui sia le la, mua hã xɔa dɔlékuia.
Conversely, a noninfected mosquito can get the malaria parasite from biting an infected human.
Eye ne mu sia ɖu ame bubu la, ame sia hã axɔ dɔlékui sia
Then the infected mosquito can pass the parasite to another human
Ne èwɔ ɖoɖo be yeazɔ mɔ ayi nuto aɖe si me asrãdɔ bɔ ɖo me la . . .
If you are planning to visit a land where malaria is endemic . . .
Ku nu me tso ale si nɔnɔmea le le afi ma fifia la ŋu hafi nàyi.
Get current information before you travel.
Asrãdɔlékuiwo tea ŋu toa vovo tso teƒe yi teƒe, eye esia kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe atike si ƒomevi woawɔ na ame hã dzi.
The type of malaria parasite common in one region may differ from that in another, and this affects which type of medicine is most effective.
Eye anyo hã be nàɖo dze kple wò ɖɔkta ale be wòagblɔ nu siwo wòle be nàƒo asa na etɔxɛe na wò, elabe enya nu tso wò lãmesẽnyawo ŋu.
Also, it would be wise to speak to your physician about things you need to be aware of with regard to your personal health history.
Ne èyi teƒea la, wɔ ɖe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo le nyati sia me, ku ɖe nuto siwo me asrãdɔ bɔ ɖo ŋu la, dzi.
During your visit, follow the guidelines that are presented in this article for those who live in a land where malaria is endemic.
Ne ède dzesi asrãdɔ ƒe dzesiwo le ŋuwò la, na woawɔ atike na wò enumake.
If you become infected, get prompt treatment.
Nyae be ne mu ɖu ame la, asrãdɔ ƒe dzesiwo ate ŋu adze le eŋu le ŋkeke ɖeka megbe, eye ne etsi megbe ƒãa la, kwasiɖa ene.
Be aware that symptoms may appear between one and four weeks after infection.
NU BUBU SIWO NÀGATE ŊU AWƆ
WHAT MORE YOU CAN DO
Di kpekpeɖeŋu tso dziɖuɖu alo nutoa me dɔwɔƒe siwo kpɔa lãmesẽnyawo gbɔ la gbɔ.
Make use of government or community health-care programs.
Ƒle atike tso ame siwo woɖe mɔ na le se nu be woadzra atike ko gbɔ.
Obtain medication only from authorized sources.
(Atike manyomanyo alo atike kpayɔ ate ŋu ana be dɔlélea nagbe vɔvɔ alo enu nasẽ kura.)
(Poor-quality or imitation medication can prolong the illness or increase the risk of death.)
Ðe nu sia nu si me mu ate ŋu adzi ɖo la ɖa le wò aƒe me.
Remove mosquito-breeding sites around the home.
Ne èle nuto aɖe si me asrãdɔ bɔ ɖo me alo nètso afi ma gbɔ la, mègado toku asrãdɔ ƒe dzesi siwo gbɔna o . . .
If you live in a malaria area or you have been in one, do not ignore the following symptoms of malaria . . .
Dzoxɔxɔ gbãgbãgbã
High temperature (fever)
Fifiatete
Sweats
Vuvɔwɔame kple ƒoƒo kpakpakpa
Shaking chills
Taɖuame
Headache
Lãmeve
Muscle aches
Ðeɖiteameŋu
Fatigue
Dzigbɔtɔame
Nausea
Tutru alo xeɖeɖe
Vomiting
Mitsinyenye
Diarrhea
Asrãdɔ si womeda o ate ŋu ana ʋu navɔ le lãme na ame eye esia ate ŋu awu ame le ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe me.
Untreated malaria can cause severe anemia and can quickly become life threatening.
Kpɔ atikewɔlawo kaba hafi dɔa nava do gã, vevietɔ le ɖeviwo kple funɔwo gome.
Seek medical treatment immediately, before symptoms get worse, especially in children and pregnant mothers.
ÈNYAA?
DID YOU KNOW?
Gaƒoɖokui aɖe si le Afrika ƒe anyigbatata dzi
A stopwatch superimposed over Africa
Le Afrika ɖeɖe dzaa la, asrãdɔ wua ɖevi ɖeka le miniti ɖe sia ɖe me
In Africa alone, one child dies every minute from malaria
Ðeviwo kple funɔwo koŋ ŋue dɔ sia tea ŋu gblẽa nu le wu.
Children and pregnant women are most at risk of serious illness if they contract malaria.
Le Afrika ɖeɖe dzaa la, asrãdɔ wua ɖevi ɖeka le miniti ɖe sia ɖe me.
In Africa alone, one child dies every minute from malaria.
Togbɔ be mebɔ o hã la, amewo tea ŋu xɔa asrãdɔ to ʋudodo me.
In rare cases, people have contracted malaria through a blood transfusion.
Ale si nànɔ te ɖe gbɔtotsotso ƒe kuxiwo nu
Meeting the Challenges of Menopause
"Menɔa anyi ko léa blanui zi ɖeka eye nyemenyaa nu si gbɔ wòtsona alo kpɔa dzesi aɖeke doa ŋgɔ o.
"Feelings of sadness overwhelmed me without reason or warning.
Mefaa avi eye mebiaa ɖokuinye be tsu kum mele hã. "
I cried and wondered if I was going crazy. "
Rondro, exɔ ƒe 50.
Rondro, 50 years of age.
"Èfɔ gbe ɖeka ŋdi hekpɔe be wò aƒe me katã le nyamaa.
"You wake up in the morning and find your house is a mess.
Èdi wò nuwo do kpoe.
You cannot find personal things.
Nu siwo nèwɔna bɔbɔe ƒe geɖewoe nye esia la wɔwɔ zu dɔ na wò, eye mènya nu si gbɔ wòtso o. "
What you had been doing with ease for years, now seems so difficult, and you don’t know why. "
Hanta, exɔ ƒe 55.
Hanta, 55 years of age.
MENYE dɔ lém nyɔnu siawo le o.
THESE women were not ill.
Ke boŋ ɖe wole gbɔtotsotso (si fia be wodzudzɔ dzinukpɔkpɔ alo asiɖoɖo anyi) ƒe ɣeyiɣi me tom.
Rather, they were going through the menopause transition, a natural change in a woman’s life and the end of her fertility.
Ne nyɔnue nènye la, ɖe nèle ɣeyiɣi ma gogoma?
If you are a woman, are you approaching that time of life?
Alo ɖe nèle ɣeyiɣi ma me fifia?
Are you going through it?
Aleke kee wòɖale o, ne wò kple wò ame veviwo mienya nu tso ɣeyiɣi sia ŋu nyuie la, akpe ɖe mia ŋu geɖe ŋutɔ miate ŋu anɔ te ɖe kuxi siwo vana le ɣeyiɣi sia me la nu dzidzedzetɔe.
Whatever the case may be, the more that you and your loved ones know about this transition, the better equipped you will be to meet the challenges associated with it.
Gbɔtotsotso Ƒe Ɣeyiɣi
The Menopause Transition
Gbɔtotsotso ƒe ɣeyiɣiwo lɔ ɣeyiɣi siwo do ŋgɔ teti na gbɔtotsotso kple gbɔtotsotsoa ŋutɔ siaa hã ɖe eme.
The menopause transition, also called perimenopause (around menopause), includes both the period leading up to menopause and menopause itself.
Gake zi geɖe la, ne wozã nya gbɔtotsotso la, efia ɣeyiɣi mawo katã.
In common usage, however, "menopause " often refers to the entire transition.
Nyɔnu geɖewo dzudzɔa asiɖoɖo anyi le woƒe ƒe 40-awo me, gake bubuwo tɔ ya dzea egɔme ne wole woƒe ƒe 60-awo me.
Most women start perimenopause in their 40’s, but some do so as late as their 60’s.
Zi geɖe la, ɖe asiɖoanyi nɔa tsotsom vivivi.
In most cases, menstruation ceases gradually.
Esi lãmetsiwo megadzina ɖe lã me na nyɔnuwo ɖe ɖoɖo nu le ɣeyiɣi sia me o ta la, ɣeaɖewoɣi la nyɔnu aɖewo mekpɔa dzinu o alo kpɔa dzinu le vo me alo ʋu gbogbo aɖewo dona le wo ŋu le woƒe asiɖoanyiɣi.
Because of the erratic production of hormones, a woman may skip periods, bleed at odd times, or have extra-heavy periods.
Nyɔnu ʋɛ aɖewo hã dzudzɔa asiɖoɖo anyi gbe ɖeka kple eƒe zãdodo.
A small number of women stop menstruating abruptly, almost overnight, as it were.
Agbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: "Nyɔnu ɖe sia ɖe kple nu si me wòtona ne edzudzɔ asiɖoɖo anyi. "
"Each woman’s menopause experience is different, " says Menopause Guidebook.
(Menopause Guidebook) Agbalẽa gblɔ hã be: "Nu siwo me nyɔnu geɖewo tona ne wodzudzɔ asiɖoɖo anyie nye be woƒe lã me xɔa dzo gbãgbãgbã, " eye vuvɔ tea ŋu wɔa wo vevie le esia megbe.
It also states: "The most common menopause-related discomfort is the hot flash (sometimes called a hot flush), " which may be followed by a cold chill.
Esia nana be wometea ŋu dɔa alɔ̃ o, eye woƒe lã me gbɔdzɔna.
Those symptoms can disrupt sleep and sap energy.
Ɣeyiɣi didi kae nɔnɔme sia nɔa anyi?
How long do the discomforts last?
Le agbalẽ bubu (The Menopause Book) aɖe ƒe nya nu la, "nyɔnu aɖewo ƒe lã me xɔa dzo tso ɣeyiɣi yi ɣeyiɣi hena ƒe ɖeka alo ƒe eve sɔŋ ne wodzudzɔ asiɖoɖo anyi.
According to The Menopause Book, "some women get a few hot flashes for a year or two around the time of the menopause transition.
Nyɔnu bubuwo ya tɔ nɔa anyi ƒe geɖe, eye ame ʋɛ aɖewo hã tɔ yia edzi le woƒe agbe me katã. "
Others suffer for many years, and a very small percentage report occasional hot flashes for the rest of their lives. "
Lãmetsiwo ƒe dɔmawɔmawɔ nyuie tea ŋu nana be nu tena ɖe nyɔnu aɖewo dzi, wonɔa anyi ko léa blanui alo doa dziku, esia wɔnɛ be wofaa avi, wotɔtɔna eye wonɔa nu ŋlɔm be edziedzi.
Because of fluctuating hormones, a woman may also experience depression and mood swings, resulting in weepiness, as well as poor concentration and lapses in memory.
Agbalẽa gagblɔ be: "Mebɔ kura be nu siawo katã nadzɔ ɖe ame ɖeka dzi o. "
That said, "it’s highly unlikely that any one woman will get hit with everything, " says The Menopause Book.
(The Menopause Book) Le nyateƒe me la, nu siawo dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo koe dzɔna ɖe ame aɖewo dzi, eye le ame bubuwo hã gome la, ɖeke kura medzɔna ɖe wo dzi o.
Indeed, some experience few, if any, problems and discomforts.
Ale Si Nànɔ Te Ðe Enui
How to Cope
Asiɖeɖe le nuwɔna aɖewo ŋu ate ŋu aɖe kuxi siawo dometɔ aɖewo dzi akpɔtɔ.
Simple lifestyle changes may reduce some discomforts.
Eɖea vi na nyɔnu geɖewo ne woƒo asa na nuɖuɖu aɖewo.
For example, smokers may decrease the number of hot flashes by giving up tobacco.
Nuɖuɖu siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye esiwo me nu ʋeʋĩwo kpakple sukli le fũu akpa kple aha sesẽ kpakple caffeine-nono, elabena nu siawo tea ŋu nana be ame ƒe lã me xɔa dzo.
Many women also benefit from dietary changes, such as limiting or even avoiding alcohol, caffeine, and spicy or sugary foods, which can trigger hot flashes.
Ke hã, ele vevie be nàɖu nu siwo me nunyiame le.
Of course, it is important to eat well, which means having a balanced and varied diet.
Kamedede hã tea ŋu ɖea kuxi siwo doa mo ɖa ne nyɔnuwo dzudzɔ asiɖoɖo anyi la dzi kpɔtɔna.
Exercise can also be a big help in reducing menopausal symptoms.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, kamedede ate ŋu aɖe alɔ̃madɔmadɔ dzi akpɔtɔ, eye wòaɖe ale si nyɔnu aɖewo nɔa anyi sẽe ko doa dziku alo léa blanui la dzi akpɔtɔ.
For instance, it can reduce insomnia and foster significant improvements in mood, as well as in bone strength and general health.
Ðo Dze Tso Wò Nɔnɔmea Ŋu Faa
Communicate Openly
Rondro si ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi la gblɔ be: "Mègamia nu ɖe wò kuxia dzi o.
"There is no need to suffer in silence, " said Rondro, quoted earlier.
Ne èɖo dze tso eŋu na ame bubuwo la, womagatsi dzi fũu akpa ne wode dzesi nu si le dzɔdzɔm ɖe dziwò o. "
"If you talk openly with loved ones, they will not worry too much when they notice what is happening to you. "
Le nyateƒe me la, ɖe woagbɔ dzi ɖi ahase nu gɔme na wò geɖe wu boŋ.
In fact, they may be more patient and understanding.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Lɔlɔ̃ gbɔa dzi blewu, eye wònyoa dɔme. " 1 Korintotɔwo 13:4.
"Love is patient and kind, " says 1 Corinthians 13:4. Good News Translation.
Gbedodoɖa hã ɖea vi na nyɔnu geɖewo, siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye nyɔnu siwo le nu xam le esi wotso vi ta.
Many women also benefit from prayer, including those who are grieved by their loss of fertility.

Biblia na kakaɖedzi mí be: "[Mawu] faa akɔ na mí le míaƒe xaxa blibo la katã me. " (2 Korintotɔwo 1:4) Nu si hã gafaa akɔ na amee nye enyanya be ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe koe kuxi siwo me ame tona ne edzudzɔ asiɖoɖo anyi la nɔa anyi.
"[God] comforts us in all our troubles, " the Bible assures us. (2 Corinthians 1:4, The New English Bible) Also comforting is the knowledge that the menopause transition is temporary.
Ne ɣeyiɣi mawo va yi la, ŋusẽ yeye gaɖoa nyɔnu siwo léa be na wo ɖokuiwo la ŋu eye wogatea ŋu sea vivi le agbe me hena ƒe geɖe. Blanuiléledɔ Ale Si Woadae
Afterward, women who continue to take good care of their health may find renewed energy and enjoy many more years of quality life.
Blanuiléledɔ Ale Si Woadae
Depression How to Treat It

RUTH si blanuiléledɔ ɖe fu na ƒe geɖe la gblɔ be: "Mía kple srɔ̃nye míetsɔ nye dɔlélea yi kɔdzi, míewɔ tɔtrɔ geɖe le agbe me, eye míedze agbagba vevie nɔa agbe le mɔ aɖe si ana agbea nanya nɔ nam la nu.
"MY HUSBAND and I have sought out medical treatment, made lifestyle changes, and worked hard to develop a routine that I can cope with, " says Ruth, who has suffered with depression for many years.
Míekpɔe be atike si zãm mele la le dɔ wɔm, eye nye nɔnɔmea le kakam ɖe eme.
"We seem to have found an effective medication, and I am doing better.
Gake ɣeyiɣi siwo me nɔnɔmea gadoa mo ɖa eye nu sia nu si míawɔ doa kpo nu la, lɔlɔ̃ si srɔ̃nye ɖena fiaam madzudzɔmadzudzɔe kple xɔlɔ̃wo ƒe ɖetsɔleme ye kpena ɖe ŋunye nyemenaa ta o. "
But during the time when nothing else seemed to work, the constant love of my husband and friends helped me not to give up. "

Abe ale si nu si me Ruth to ɖee fia ene la, ehiã be xɔlɔ̃wo kple ƒometɔwo nana kpekpeɖeŋu geɖe ale si woate ŋui la ame siwo blanuiléledɔ sesẽ le fu ɖem na, hekpe ɖe dɔdamɔnu ɖe sia ɖe si ƒe aɖaŋu ɖɔktawo aɖo la ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ ŋu.
As Ruth’s experience indicates, patients who suffer from clinical depression need all the support they can get, including whatever medical approach might be advisable.
Enye nu si me afɔku le be woaŋe aɖaba aƒu blanuiléledɔa dada dzi elabena dɔ siawo dometɔ aɖewo ate ŋu ade ame ƒe agbe afɔku me ne womele atike wɔm o.
It can be risky to ignore depression because in some cases when left untreated it can be life-threatening.
Anɔ abe ƒe akpe eve enye sia ene la, Yesu Kristo gblɔ be atikewɔlawo ate ŋu ana kpekpeɖeŋu, esime wògblɔ be ‘ame siwo le dɔ lém la hiã atikewɔla.’
About two thousand years ago, Jesus Christ acknowledged that those with medical experience could provide needed help, when he said that ‘those who are ill need a physician.’
(Marko 2:17) Nyateƒeae nye be atikewɔlawo ate ŋu awɔ akpa vevi aɖe atsɔ aɖe blanuiléledɔlélaa ƒe fukpekpewo dzi kpɔtɔ.
(Mark 2:17) The fact is that physicians can do much to alleviate the suffering of many depressed patients.
Edadamɔnu Aɖewo Siwo Ðea Vi
Some Helpful Options
Blanuiléledɔdada ƒe mɔnu vovovo li, eye dɔa ƒe dzesiwo kple ale si enu sẽe la dzie wonɔa te ɖo nyana mɔnu si woazã.
There are a number of treatments for depression, varying according to the symptoms and the severity of the illness.
(Kpɔ aɖaka si le axa 15, si ƒe tanyae nye, "Blanuiléledɔ Ka Ƒomevie? ")
(See the box " What Kind of Depression? ")
Le ame geɖe go la, woƒe ƒomea ƒe ɖɔkta ate ŋu ana kpekpeɖeŋu wo, gake le ame bubuwo ya gome la, wohiã dɔdamɔnu si le etɔxɛ.
Many people may be helped by their family physician, but some need more specialized treatment.
Ðɔktaa ate ŋu aŋlɔ blanuilélenulétike na amea alo akafu kpekpeɖeŋunamɔnu bubu aɖe nɛ.
The doctor might prescribe antidepressant medication or recommend some other form of assistance.
Dɔléla aɖewo ƒe nɔnɔmea ka ɖe eme na wo esi wozã gbetikewo, esi wotrɔ asi le woƒe nuɖuɖu ŋu, alo wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe kamedede si da sɔ ŋu.
Some people have experienced good results with herbal medications, dietary adjustments, or a controlled exercise program.
Kuxi Aɖewo Siwo Doa Mo Ða
Common Issues
Xɔlɔ̃ nyuidinamela siwo si nuteƒekpɔkpɔ boo aɖeke mesu le atikewɔnyawo me o ate ŋu ava gblɔ atike siwo nàzã kple esiwo nàtsri la ŋu nya na wò.
Well-meaning friends with little or no medical training might try to tell you which method of treatment to accept and which to reject.
Woagate ŋu ate tɔ ɖe edzi be ele be nàzã gbetikewo, alo atike siwo ɖɔktawo ŋlɔ na wò loo alo be màgazã atike aɖeke kura o.
They might also have strong opinions about whether you should take herbal medicine, prescribed medication, or nothing at all.
Bu nyaa ŋu: Kpɔ nyuie be kakaɖedzi le aɖaŋuɖoɖo ɖe sia ɖe si dzi nàlɔ̃ ɖo la ŋu.
Consider: Make sure that any advice you accept comes from a reliable source.
Mlɔeba la, wò ŋutɔe awɔ tiatia le dɔdamɔnu si nèkpɔ be esɔ na ye la ŋu.
In the end, you are the one who must make an informed choice.
Dziɖeleameƒo tea ŋu naa dɔnɔ aɖewo dzudzɔa atike si woŋlɔ na wo la nono, elabena wose le wo ɖokui me be nɔnɔmea mele kakam ɖe eme na yewo o alo be eva le nu bubuwo gblẽm le yewo ŋu.
Discouragement may make patients discontinue their choice of treatment because they do not seem to be getting better or because of unpleasant side effects.
Bu nyaa ŋu: ‘Afi si adaŋudede mele o la, tameɖoɖowo tsia akpo dzi; ke afi si adaŋudela geɖewo le la, edzea edzi.’
Consider: "There is a frustrating of plans where there is no confidential talk, but in the multitude of counselors there is accomplishment. "
(Lododowo 15:22) Dɔdamɔnu aɖe si ŋu dɔ wɔm dɔnɔ aɖe le ate ŋu akpɔ dzidzedze nyuie wu ne dzeɖoɖo nyui le ɖɔktaa kple dɔnɔa dome.
(Proverbs 15:22) A program of medical therapy is more likely to succeed if there is good communication between doctor and patient.

Ƒo nu tso dɔa ƒe dzesi siwo doa mo ɖa alo nu siwo ŋu nètsi dzi ɖo la ŋu na wò ɖɔktaa, eye nàbiae nenye be ahiã be nàwɔ asitɔtrɔ aɖewo le atikea nono ŋu loo alo ahiã be nàyi enono dzi veviedodotɔe hafi akpɔ eƒe dɔwɔwɔ hã.
Frankly explain your concerns or describe your symptoms to your doctor, and ask whether you need to adjust the treatment or simply to persevere before you will begin to experience benefits.
Kakaɖeameɖokuidzi akpa ate ŋu ana dɔnɔawo nadzudzɔ atikea zazã kpata le kwasiɖa ʋɛ aɖewo ko megbe le esi wose le wo ɖokui me be nɔnɔmea ka ɖe eme na yewo vie ta.
Overconfidence can make patients stop their medical remedy abruptly after a few weeks because they feel better.
Woate ŋu aŋlɔ ale si gbegbe woƒe nɔnɔmea nye ŋkubiãnyae hafi wodze atikea zazã gɔme la be.
They may forget how debilitating their symptoms were before they started their medication.
Bu nyaa ŋu: Asiɖeɖe le atike si woŋlɔ na ame le kɔdzi zazã ŋu kpata ɖɔktaa mabiamabiae ate ŋu agblẽ nu le ame ŋu alo ade eƒe agbe gɔ̃ hã afɔku me.
Consider: Suddenly terminating medical treatment without consulting a doctor can have serious and even life-threatening consequences.
Togbɔ be Biblia menye atikewɔɖaŋuɖogbalẽ o hã la, Eŋlɔlaa, Yehowa Mawu, ye nye mía Wɔla.
Though the Bible is not a medical textbook, its Author, Jehovah God, is our Creator.
Nyati si kplɔe ɖo adzro akɔfafa kple mɔfiafia siwo Mawu ƒe Nya la naa ame siwo blanuiléledɔ le fu ɖem na kpakple wo dzi kpɔlawo siaa la me. g09 07-E.
The next article will examine the comfort and guidance God’s Word provides both for those who suffer from depression and for their caregivers.
[Etenuŋɔŋlɔ] ^ mm.
WHAT KIND OF DEPRESSION?
Ele be ame sia ame ŋutɔ nada dɔdamɔnu vovovo siwo li la kpɔ nyuie hafi awɔ tiatia. [Aɖaka si le axa 15]
The effectiveness of any particular medical approach depends on what type of depression a patient has.
BLANUILÉLEDƆ KA ƑOMEVIE? Blanuiléledɔdada ƒe mɔnu si aɖe vi na ame la nɔ te ɖe blanuiléledɔ si ƒomevi le fu ɖem nɛ la dzi.
Major depression has symptoms that are severe enough to last six months or longer if untreated and that impact on most aspects of a sufferer’s life.
▪ Nuwɔwɔ tramatrama ƒe dɔ alo blanuiléledɔ si naa nu tena ɖe ame dzi vevie.
Bipolar disorder is also known as manic depression.

Seselelãme ƒe fuɖename siwo gbɔ eme ate ŋu atso nu trama wɔwɔ adãtɔe si nɔa anyi ɣeyiɣi didi dzi ahatrɔ kpata azu blanuiléle vevie. Kpɔ nyati si nye "Tenɔnɔ Ðe Seselelãme Trama Dɔwo Nu, " si dze le January 8, 2004, ƒe Nyɔ! me.

Sufferers may experience emotional extremes that careen between prolonged episodes of intense hyperactivity (manias) and devastating lows (depressions).​ See the article "Living With a Mood Disorder, " in the January 8, 2004, issue of this magazine.
▪ Disaimia blanuiléledɔ; togbɔ be eƒe fuɖename nu mesẽna abe blanuiléledɔ sesẽ tɔ ene o hã la, blanuiléledɔ ƒe dzesi siwo dzena le dɔlélaa ŋu wɔnɛ be megatea ŋu wɔa nu ɖe ɖoɖo nyui nu o.
Dysthymia, although not as disabling as major depression, has depressive symptoms that make it difficult for the patient to function normally.
Le wo dometɔ aɖewo gome la, blanuiléledɔ sesẽ ɖea fu na wo enuenu.
Some may also experience intermittent periods of major depression.

▪ Vidzidzi megbe ƒe blanuiléledɔ nye seselelãmedɔ si ɖea fu na vidadawo vevie le vidzidzi megbe. Kpɔ nyati si nye "Vidzidzi Megbe Blanuiléle Gɔme Sese (Understanding Postpartum Depression,) " si dze le June 8, 2003, ƒe Nyɔ! yevugbe me tɔ me.

Postpartum depression is a debilitating emotional condition that affects many mothers after they give birth.​ See the article "Understanding Postpartum Depression, " in the June 8, 2003, issue of this magazine.
▪ Vuvɔŋɔli me nuteɖeamedzi ɖea fu na amewo le esi womegakpɔa ŋdɔ le kele kple vuvɔŋɔli me o ta.
Seasonal affective disorder likely occurs as a result of a lack of sunlight during autumn and winter.
Zi geɖe la, enu yina le adame kple dzomeŋɔli me.
It usually clears up during spring and summer.
Blanuiléledɔ
Depression
Nu kae nye blanuiléledɔ?
What is depression?
"Wobɔbɔm ɖe anyi, eye woɖi gbɔ̃m eye ŋkeke bliboa mele yiyim le nuxaxa me. "
"I have become disconcerted, I have bowed low to an extreme degree; all day long I have walked about sad. "
Psalmo 38:6, Agbenya La.
Psalm 38:6.
NYA SIWO NUMEKULAWO GBLƆNA
WHAT RESEARCHERS SAY
Mí katã míeléa blanui ɣeaɖewoɣi, gake blanuiléledɔ ya nana wɔna vɔna le ame ŋu eye wònana ame megatea ŋu wɔa eƒe gbe sia gbe dɔwo ale si dze o.
Everyone feels down now and then, but clinical depression is a debilitating disorder that is ongoing and that interferes with a person’s daily life.
Ele be míanya be ɖɔktawo katã ƒe nu mesɔ le nu si nye blanuiléle kple blanuiléledɔ gome o.
It should be noted that not all experts agree on what is "normal " sadness and what constitutes a "disorder. "
Ke hã míate ŋu agblɔe wòasɔ be nu tena ɖe ame aɖewo dzi vevie eye ɣeaɖewoɣi la, wobua fɔ wo ɖokuiwo vevie hesusunɛ be yewomele bo aɖeke nu o.
However, it is safe to say that some people experience profoundly negative emotions, at times accompanied by feelings of worthlessness and inordinate guilt.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Woƒo nu tso ŋutsu kple nyɔnu siwo dzi nu te ɖo vevie la ŋu le Biblia me.
The Bible tells of many men and women who experienced negative emotions.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, wogblɔ be Xana ‘xa nu vevie,’ si gɔme woɖe le Biblia aɖewo me be eƒe "dzi gbã " kple elé "blanui vevie. " (1 Samuel 1:10) Ɣeaɖeɣi la, nu te ɖe nyagblɔɖila Eliya dzi ale gbegbe be wòdo gbe ɖa na Mawu be wòaɖe yeƒe agbe ɖa. 1 Fiawo 19:4

For example, Hannah felt "bitter of soul " a phrase that has been rendered as "brokenhearted " and "deeply distressed. " (1 Samuel 1:10) On one occasion the prophet Elijah was so grief-stricken that he prayed for God to take his life! 1 Kings 19:4.

Wogblɔ na ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me Kristotɔwo be woaƒo nu "na luʋɔ siwo lé blanui la akɔfafatɔe. " (1 Tesalonikatɔwo 5:14) Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be nyagbɔgblɔ "luʋɔ siwo lé blanui " ate ŋu afia ame siwo "agbemekuxiwo do agba na hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe. "

First-century Christians were instructed to "speak consolingly to the depressed souls. " (1 Thessalonians 5:14) According to one reference work, the term "depressed souls " can refer to those "who are temporarily overwhelmed by the stress of life. "
Edze ƒãa be ŋutsu kple nyɔnu nuteƒewɔla siwo ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe la gɔ̃ hã lé blanui ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Clearly, even faithful men and women of the Bible at times felt depressed.
Ame si le blanuiléledɔ lém la ƒe vodadae wònyea?
Is depression the sufferer’s fault?
"Nuwɔwɔ blibo la katã le ŋeŋem ɖekae, eye wòle veve sem ɖekae. "
"All creation keeps on groaning together and being in pain together. "
Romatɔwo 8:22.
Romans 8:22.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Biblia fia nu be aglã si atsu kple asi gbãtɔ dze la gbɔe wòtso be míeléa dɔ.
The Bible teaches that illness is a by-product of the rebellion of the first human couple.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Psalmo 51:7 gblɔ be: "Vodada me wodzim ɖo, eye nu vɔ̃ me danye fɔ nye fu ɖo. "
For example, Psalm 51:5 states: "With error I was brought forth with birth pains, and in sin my mother conceived me. "
Eye Romatɔwo 5:12 hã gblɔ be: "To ame ɖeka [Adam si nye amegbetɔ gbãtɔ] dzi nu vɔ̃ ge ɖe xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va, eye ale ku la kaka ɖe amewo katã dome, esi wo katã wɔ nu vɔ̃ ŋuti la. "
And Romans 5:12 explains that "through one man [the first human, Adam] sin entered into the world and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men because they had all sinned. "
Esi míenyi blibomademade ƒe dome tso Adam gbɔ ta la, mí katã míeléa dɔ eye nu tena ɖe mía dzi.
Because we have inherited imperfection from Adam, each of us is susceptible to illness, both physical and emotional.
Ale wɔ Biblia gblɔ be, "nuwɔwɔ blibo la katã le ŋeŋem ɖekae, eye wòle veve sem ɖekae. "
As a result, says the Bible, "all creation keeps on groaning together and being in pain together. "

(Romatɔwo 8:22) Ke hã Biblia na mɔkpɔkpɔ aɖe mí si dɔdala aɖeke mate ŋu ana o, eyae nye be Mawu do ŋugbe be yeana xexe yeye si me ŋutifafa anɔ nava eye dɔléle kple seselelãmedɔwo, siwo dometɔ ɖekae nye blanuiléledɔ, katã nu ayi.
(Romans 8:22) However, the Bible also offers a hope that no physician can extend God’s promise of a peaceful new world in which all sicknesses and disorders, including depression, will be gone.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4.
Revelation 21:4.
Aleke nàwɔ anɔ te ɖe blanuiléledɔ nu?
How can you cope with depression?
"Yehowa tsɔ ɖe ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã gudugudu la gbɔ, eye wòxɔna na ame siwo ƒe gbɔgbɔ woƒo ƒu anyi. "
"Jehovah is near to those that are broken at heart; and those who are crushed in spirit he saves. "
Psalmo 34:19.
Psalm 34:18.
NU KA TA WÒLE BE NÀTSƆ ÐE LE NYA SIA ME?
WHY IT MATTERS
Màte ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe wò nɔnɔmewo dzi ɣesiaɣi o, eye nu madeamedziwo adzɔ ɖe mía dzi ɣeaɖewoɣi godoo.
You cannot always control your circumstances, and bad things are bound to affect you at times.
(Nyagblɔla 9:11, 12) Ke hã àte ŋu aɖe afɔ aɖewo siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nuteɖeamedziwo nagakpe dziwò o.
(Ecclesiastes 9:11, 12) You can, however, develop a practical strategy so that negative feelings do not dominate your life.
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Biblia gblɔ be ame siwo le dɔ lém la hiã atikewɔlawo.
The Bible acknowledges that those who are sick need a physician.
(Luka 5:31) Eya ta ne èléa blanui wògbɔa eme la, anyo be nàdi atikewɔlawo ƒe mɔ.
(Luke 5:31) So if you suffer from a debilitating mood disorder, there is nothing wrong with seeking medical attention.
Biblia na míenya hã be gbedodoɖa le vevie ŋutɔ.
The Bible also emphasizes the value of prayer.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Psalmo 55:23 gblɔ be: "Tsɔ wò nyawo dro ɖe Yehowa dzi, eyae akpɔ tawò; emana ke naɖe le ame dzɔdzɔe te akpɔ gbeɖe o. "
For example, Psalm 55:22 says: "Throw your burden upon Jehovah himself, and he himself will sustain you.
Menye nu si ana ame nase le eɖokui me be yekpɔ gbɔdzɔe dzro aɖe koe gbedodoɖa nye o, ke boŋ enye nuƒoƒo ŋutɔŋutɔ kple Yehowa Mawu ame si "tsɔ ɖe ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã gudugudu la gbɔ. "
Never will he allow the righteous one to totter. " Prayer is not a psychological crutch; it is real communication with Jehovah God, who is "near to those that are broken at heart. "
Psalmo 34:19.
Psalm 34:18.
Ate ŋu aɖe vi na wò hã be nàɖe wò dzimenyawo agblɔ na xɔ̃wò vevi aɖe.
You may also benefit by confiding your feelings to a close friend.
(Lododowo 17:17) Daniela si nye Yehowa Ðasefo gblɔ be: "Haxɔsetɔ aɖe de dzi ƒo nam xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔtɔe be míaɖo dze tso nye blanuiléledɔa ŋu.
(Proverbs 17:17) "A fellow believer gently coaxed me to talk about my depression, " says Daniela, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Togbɔ be menɔ sisim le dzeɖoɖo sia nu ƒe geɖee nye ema hã la, meva kpɔe be ɖe wòle be maɖo dze tso nya sia ŋu nɛ xoxoxo.
"Although I had been avoiding such a conversation for years, I soon realized that this was what I needed all along.
Nye dzi dze eme ale gbegbe le dzeɖoɖo ma megbe. "
I was surprised at how relieved I felt afterward. "
Nu Ka Tae Maganɔ Agbe Ðo?
Why Go On?
DIANA nye ɖetugbui si ƒe tagbɔ kɔ, edoa vivi ɖe ame ŋu eye wòwɔa xɔlɔ̃.
IF YOU met Diana, you would find her to be an intelligent, friendly, and gregarious young woman.
Togbɔ be nɔnɔme lédziname siawo le Diana si hã la, seselelãme ɖefuname aɖe ɖe kpe nɛ si nana wòsena le eɖokui me be yemele ɖeke me o.
But beneath Diana’s charming exterior lurks a crippling despair that leaves her feeling utterly worthless for days, weeks, or even months at a time.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, seselelãme sia ɖea fu nɛ ŋkekewo, kwasiɖawo kple ɣletiwo.
"Not a day goes by that I don’t think about dying, " she says.
Egblɔ be: "Ku dzroam gbe sia gbe. Mexɔe se be xexea me anya nɔ na amewo wu ne meku. "
"I truly believe that the world would be a better place without me. "
"Numekukuwo ɖee fia be ne ame ɖeka wu eɖokui la, ke ame 200 aɖewo ya tee kpɔ be yewoawu yewo ɖokuiwo eye ame 400 hã bu eŋu. "
"Some studies have shown that for every death by suicide, 200 people have attempted suicide and 400 [other] people have thought about it. "
THE GAZETTE, MONTREAL, CANADA.
THE GAZETTE, MONTREAL, CANADA.
Diana gblɔ be yemawu ye ɖokui gbeɖe ya o.
Diana says that she would never kill herself.
Gake ɣeaɖewoɣi la, menyaa nu si koŋ tae wòagayi edzi anɔ agbe ɖo o.
Still, at times she sees little point in going on with life.
Egblɔ be: "Medina vevie be afɔku aɖe nadzɔ ɖe dzinye maku.
"My greatest wish is to be killed in an accident, " she says.
Ku va zu nye velia, ke menye nye futɔ o. "
"I’ve come to view death as a friend not an enemy. "
Ame geɖe sena le wo ɖokuiwo me abe Diana ene, eye wo dometɔ aɖewo hã susui alo tee kpɔ be yewoawu yewo ɖokui.
Many people can relate to Diana’s feelings, and some of them have contemplated or attempted suicide.
Ke hã, numekulawo gblɔ be le ame siwo tee kpɔ be yewoawu yewo ɖokui ƒe akpa gãtɔ gome la, menye ɖe wodi ŋutɔŋutɔ be yewoaɖe yewoƒe agbe ɖa o.
Experts point out, however, that most people who try to kill themselves do not really want to end their life; they merely want to end their suffering.
Kpuie ko la, wokpɔe be susu aɖe le yewo si si ta wòle be yewoawu yewo ɖokui ɖo.
In short, they believe that they have a reason to die; what they need is a reason to live.
Eya ta nu si hiã koe nye be woakpe ɖe wo ŋu woakpɔe be susu aɖewo li siwo tae wòle be woayi edzi anɔ agbe.
Why go on?
Nu ka tae wòle be nàyi edzi anɔ agbe ɖo?
Consider three reasons to keep living.
ALAKPANYA: Nuƒoƒo tso ameɖokuiwuwu ŋu alo nya ma yɔyɔ ɖeɖe dzaa gɔ̃ hã nana be amewo dina be yewoatee kpɔ.
MYTH: Talking about suicide or even using the word encourages people to try it.
NYATEƑENYA: Nuƒoƒo tso ameɖokuiwuwu ŋu nana be ame si di be yeawu ye ɖokui la bua eƒe kuxia gbɔ kpɔnu bubuwo ŋu.
FACT: Bringing the topic out into the open often helps a person with suicidal thoughts to consider other options.
Ne Agbea Wu Tsɔtsɔ Na Wò
When Life Seems Unbearable
NE NUWO le yiyim nyuie la, agbea vivina.
LIFE can be pure bliss​ when all goes well.
Ke ne nɔnɔmeawo wɔe be agbea wu tsɔtsɔ na wò ya ɖe?
But what if circumstances make your life seem unbearable?
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi ahom sesẽ aɖe gblẽ Sally si le Amerika ƒe nunɔamesi akpa gãtɔ dome la, egblɔ be: "Nyemagate ŋu ado dzi o.
For instance, Sally, in the United States, who lost most of her possessions in a hurricane, explains: "I didn’t know how much more I could take.
Zi geɖe la, mesena le ɖokuinye me be eglom azɔ. "
Many days I felt that I was near the breaking point. "
Ke ne wò ame vevi aɖee ku ya ɖe?
Or what if a loved one dies?
Janice si le Australia gblɔ be: "Esi vinyeŋutsu eveawo ku la, metɔtɔ ale gbegbe be nyemegava nɔ ta kpɔm na naneke o.
Janice, in Australia, says: "When I lost both my sons, I had to gather the fragments of my shattered life and reassemble them as best I could.
Meɖe kuku na Mawu be: ‘Meɖe kuku nyemagate ŋu ado dzi atsɔe o!
I begged God: ‘Please, my heart can’t take any more!
Na maku kpoo.
Just let me sleep.
Nyemedi be maganɔ agbe o.’ "
I don’t want to wake up again.’ "
Le Daniel gome la, esi srɔ̃a to ete la, eƒe dzi gbã ale gbegbe.
Daniel, on the other hand, was devastated when his wife was unfaithful.
Egblɔ be: "Esi srɔ̃nye gblɔ nam be yewɔ ahasi la, ɖeko wònɔ abe ɖe woƒo hɛ̃ ɖe nye dzi me ene.
He explains: "When my wife confessed that she had been unfaithful, it was like a knife pierced my heart.
Mese veve enuenu hena ɣleti geɖe. "
I felt this physical pain stabbing me again and again​ and it lasted several months. "
Gbetakpɔxɔ sia aƒo nu tso nu siwo nàwɔ be nàyi edzi anɔ agbe
This issue of The Watchtower will consider how life can be worth living even when

Disaster strikes

A loved one dies

A spouse is unfaithful

You are dealing with a serious illness
Ne agbea wu tsɔtsɔ na wò

Gake gbã la, nu kae akpe ɖe mía ŋu míado dzi ne afɔku aɖe dzɔ?
So, first, how can we cope when disaster strikes?
Sɔhɛwo Ƒe Blanuiléledɔ Nu Ka Gbɔe Wotso?
Teen Depression Why?
Nu Kae Akpe Ðe Wo Ŋu?
What Can Help?
ANNA gblɔ be: "Ne nane te ɖe dzinye melé blanui vie la, naneke wɔwɔ medzroam o, nyemedina be mawɔ nu siwo melɔ̃a wɔwɔ zi geɖe la gɔ̃ hã o.
"WHEN I have a bout of depression, " says Anna, "I have no motivation to do anything, not even the things I usually love to do.
Alɔ̃ koe medina be madɔ.
All I want to do is sleep.
Ewɔna nam be womelɔ̃m o, nyemeɖi naneke o eye mezu agba na amewo. "
I often feel that I am unlovable, worthless, and a burden to others. "
Julia hã gblɔ be: "Mebui kpɔ be mawu ɖokuinye.
"I thought about suicide, " recalls Julia.
Evɔ menye ɖe medi be maku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
"I didn’t really want to die.
Ðeko medi be ale si menɔ sesem le ɖokuinye me la nu natso.
I just wanted to stop feeling this way.
Metsɔa ɖe le eme na amewo ŋutɔ, gake ne melé blanui la, nyemegatsɔa ɖeke le eme na ame aɖeke loo alo na naneke o. "
I’m normally a caring person, but when I’m depressed, I care little about anyone or anything. "
Ðeko Anna kple Julia ɖo woƒe sɔhɛ me teti koe nye ma blanuiléledɔ ɖe fu na wo zi gbãtɔ.
Anna and Julia were in their early teens when they first experienced depression.
Togbɔ be sɔhɛwo tea ŋu léa blanui vie ɣeaɖewoɣi hã, Anna kple Julia ƒe blanuilélea ya xɔ kwasiɖa aɖewo alo ɣleti aɖewo gɔ̃ hã.
While other young people might occasionally feel down, Anna and Julia had periods of depression that persisted for weeks or months at a time.
Anna gblɔ be: "Ðeko wòle abe nàxaxa ɖe do globoo doviviti aɖe si me màte ŋu ado le o me ene.
"It’s like being stuck in a deep, dark hole with no way out, " Anna says.
Awɔ na wò abe ɖe wò tagbɔ le gbegblẽm eye mègale ame me o ene. "
"You feel like you are losing your mind, losing who you are. "
Menye Anna kple Julia koe kuxi sia ɖea fu na o.
Anna and Julia’s situation is not uncommon.

Sɔhɛ geɖewo va le blanuiléledɔ lém fifia ŋutɔ, eya ta Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔ ka nya ta be, "blanuiléle koŋ gbɔe wòtsona be ŋutsuvi kple nyɔnuvi siwo xɔ tso ƒe 10 va se ɖe 19 la ƒe lãme gblẽna, wogbɔdzɔna eye woƒe susu mewɔa dɔ nyuie o. "

The diagnosis of depression among the young appears to be increasing at an alarming rate, and depression is "the predominant cause of illness and disability for both boys and girls aged 10 to 19 years, " says the World Health Organization (WHO).
Blanuiléledɔ ƒe dzesi siwo ate ŋu adze le ɖevi si le sɔhɛ me ɖom ŋu ƒe ɖewoe nye alɔ̃dɔdɔ fũu, alɔ̃madɔmadɔ nyuie, nuɖuɖu fũu akpa, numaɖumaɖu nyuie kple lolo alo kuɖiɖi.
The symptoms of depression can appear during adolescence and may include changes in sleep patterns, appetite, and weight.
Bubuwo hã ate ŋu anye dzodzodzoetsitsi, mɔkpɔkpɔbuɖeame, nuxaxa kple sese le ame ɖokui me be yemeɖi naneke o.
Feelings of despair, hopelessness, sadness, and worthlessness may also appear.
Ðewo hãe nye ame ɖokui ɖeɖe ɖe aga, susu ƒe nu ŋu manɔmanɔ alo nuŋlɔbe, ame ɖokui wuwu ƒe susuwo alo nuwɔna kple nɔnɔme siwo ŋu ɖɔktawo menya nu tsoe o.
Other signs include social withdrawal, trouble concentrating or remembering, suicidal thoughts or actions, and medically unexplained symptoms.
Dzesi aɖewo siwo dzena le ame ŋu hena kwasiɖawo eye wonana ame ƒe gbe sia gbe nuwɔna trɔna dzie tagbɔdɔdalawo nɔa te ɖo ƒoa nya ta be blanuiléledɔe le fu ɖem na ame.
When mental-health professionals suspect depression, they usually look for groups of symptoms that persist for weeks and that disrupt a person’s everyday life.
NU SIWO GBƆ SƆHƐWO ƑE BLANUILÉLEDƆ ATE ŊU ATSO
POSSIBLE CAUSES OF TEEN DEPRESSION
Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔa gblɔ be: "Nu siwo me ame to, nu siwo dome wònyi kple nu siwo ŋu wòbuna gbɔe blanuiléledɔ tsona. "
According to WHO, "depression results from a complex interaction of social, psychological and biological factors. "
Esiawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye:
These may include the following.
Ƒome si me ame tso, atike muamewo zazã.
Physical factors.
Abe ale si wòle le Julia gome ene la, blanuiléledɔ le ƒome aɖewo me si wɔnɛ be zi geɖe la, ƒome mawo me tɔwo tea ŋu léa dɔa.
As was true in Julia’s case, depression often runs in families, suggesting that genetics can play a role, perhaps affecting chemical activity in the brain.
Nu bubu siwo hã gbɔ dɔa tsonae nye dzidɔ alo ʋukamedɔléle aɖewo siwo nana lãmetsi aɖewo mewɔa dɔ nyuie o kple atikemuamewo zazã ɣeyiɣi didi hã ate ŋu ana dɔa nanyra.
Other physical risk factors include cardiovascular disease and changing hormone levels, as well as ongoing substance abuse, which may intensify depression, if not give rise to it.
Nuteɖeamedzi.
Stress.

Megblẽ naneke ne nu te ɖe sɔhɛ aɖe dzi vie o, gake ne nu te ɖe edzi ɣeyiɣi didi alo vevie la, ate ŋu agblẽ nu le eƒe ametia kple susua ŋu, esia wɔnɛ be ɣeaɖewoɣia sɔhɛ siwo le seselelãmekuxiwo me tom xoxo, alo esiwo blanuiléledɔ le ƒome na la nalé dɔa.

While a little stress can be healthy, chronic or excessive stress can be physically and psychologically harmful, sometimes to the point of plunging a susceptible, or biologically vulnerable, teen into depression.
Togbɔ be ele alea hãa, ame aɖeke menya nu si gbɔ tututu blanuiléledɔ tsona o, ɖewohĩ nu geɖewo gbɔe wòtsona abe ale si míegblɔe va yi ene.
That said, the exact causes of depression remain unclear and may involve a combination of factors, as mentioned earlier.

Nu siwo nana nu tena ɖe ame dzi wòléa blanui ate ŋu anye ame dzilawo ƒe wo nɔewo gbegbe alo kaklã ɖa, ame vevi ƒe ku, ameƒoƒo alo ame gbɔ dɔdɔ sesẽe, afɔku sesẽ aɖe dzedze, dɔléle alo ne ɖevi aɖe menyaa nu o, eye vevietɔ ne ɖevia sena le eɖokui me be wometsɔa ɖeke le eme na ye o.

Stress-related factors linked to depression may include parental divorce or separation, the death of a loved one, physical or sexual abuse, a serious accident, illness, or a learning disability especially if a child feels rejected as a result.
Nu bubu hã ate ŋu anye ne dzilawo kpɔa mɔ be wo vi aɖe nawɔ nu siwo gbɔ eƒe ŋutete ŋu, ɖewohĩ le eƒe agbalẽsrɔ̃nyawo me.
A related factor may be unrealistically high parental expectations, perhaps in regard to scholastic achievement.
Ðewo hãe nye ne wowɔa ŋlɔmi le ame ŋu, ne ame tsi dzi ɖe etsɔme ŋu kple ame dzila si le blanuiléledɔ lém la ƒe nuwɔwɔ ɖe ame ŋu tramatrama.
Other possible causes are bullying, uncertainty about the future, emotional estrangement by a depressed parent, and parental unpredictability.
Ne ɖevi aɖe lé blanui le nu siawo dometɔ aɖe ta la, nu kae ate ŋu akpe ɖe eŋu?
If depression results, what may help a teen to cope?
LÉ BE NA WÒ AMETIA KPLE WÒ SUSU
CARE FOR YOUR MIND AND BODY
Wotea ŋu tsɔa atike aɖewo siwo tagbɔdɔléleŋutinunyalawo nana kple woƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo léa blanuiléledɔ si nu sẽ la nu.
Moderate to severe depression is usually managed with medication and counseling by a mental-health professional.
Yesu Kristo gblɔ be: "Ame siwo le lãmesẽ me la mehiã gbedala o, negbe ame siwo le dɔ lém ko. "
Jesus Christ said: "Those who are strong do not need a physician, but those who are ill do. "
(Marko 2:17) Eya ta dɔléle ate ŋu aɖe fu na míaƒe ametia ƒe akpa sia akpa, ate ŋu aɖe fu na míaƒe susu hã!
(Mark 2:17) And illness can affect any part of our body, including our brain!
Anyo hã be míaɖe asi le agbe aɖewo siwo míenɔna tsã la ŋu le esi susua kple ametiae wɔa dɔ aduadu ta.
Lifestyle changes may also be advisable because our mind and body are closely connected.
Ne èle blanuiléledɔ lém la, dze agbagba nànɔ nu siwo ana wò susu nawɔ dɔ nyuie eye nànɔ lãmesẽ me la wɔm.
If you suffer from depression, take reasonable measures to care for your physical and mental health.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ɖu nu siwo me amenyinu le, dɔ alɔ̃ wòasu wò nyuie eye nànɔ kame dem edziedzi.
For instance, eat wholesome meals, get sufficient sleep, and exercise regularly.
Kamedede nana lãmetsi siwo nana dzi dzɔa ame dzana ɖe lãme na ame, enana ŋusẽ ɖoa ame ŋu eye wònana wodɔa alɔ̃ nyuie.
Exercise releases chemicals that can lift your mood, increase your energy, and improve your sleep.
Ne anya wɔ la, dze agbagba nàde dzesi nu siwo hoa dɔ sia na wò eye nàwɔ nu siwo nàtsɔ alé enu la ŋuti ɖoɖo ɖi.
If possible, try to recognize triggers and early warning signs of a depressive mood and create a suitable plan of action.
Gblɔ wò dɔlélea ŋu nya na ame aɖe si dzi nèka ɖo.
Confide in someone you trust.
Wò ƒomea me tɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃wo ƒe alɔdodo wò ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe dɔlélea nu eye ɖewohĩ ana wòaka ɖe eme na wò gɔ̃ hã.
A supportive network of close family members and friends may help you to cope more effectively with your depression, possibly reducing symptoms.
Ŋlɔ nu siwo vaa susu me na wò kple wò seselelãmewo ɖe agbalẽ aɖe me nu siae kpe ɖe Julia si ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi la ŋu.
Record your thoughts and feelings in a journal a practice that helped Julia, quoted earlier.
Vevietɔ wu la, kpɔ egbɔ be wò kple Mawu dome le nyuie.
Above all, be sure to address your spiritual need.
Esia ate ŋu ana mɔkpɔkpɔ nasu asiwò le agbe me geɖe wu.
This can greatly improve your outlook on life.
Yesu Kristo gblɔ be: "Dzidzɔtɔwoe nye ame siwo nyae be gbɔgbɔmenuwo hiã yewo. "
Jesus Christ said: "Happy are those conscious of their spiritual need. "
Mateo 5:3.
Matthew 5:3.
Nyɔnuvi sɔhɛ aɖe le nu ɖum kple edzilawo, ele kame dem, eye wòmlɔ anyi
A teenage girl has a meal with her parents, exercises, and sleeps
Ðu nu siwo me amenyinu le, dɔ alɔ̃ wòasu wò nyuie eye nànɔ kame dem edziedzi
Eat well, stay active, and get sufficient sleep
Nyɔnuvi sɔhɛ aɖe le Biblia xlẽm
A teenage girl reads the Bible
Ðu nu siwo me amenyinu le, de kame edziedzi eye dɔ alɔ̃ nyuie, Ne wò kple Mawu dome le nyuie la, ana wò dzi nadze eme
You can find comfort by satisfying your spiritual need
Anna kple Julia siaa ɖo kpe Yesu ƒe nya mawo dzi.
Both Anna and Julia attest to Jesus’ words.
Anna gblɔ be: "Dɔ siwo ku ɖe mawusubɔsubɔ ŋu wɔwɔ nana nye susu nɔa ame bubuwo hã ŋu ke menye nye kuxiwo ɖeɖe ko ŋu o.
Anna says: "Spiritual activities make me focus on other people, not just on my own problems.
Esia wɔwɔ menɔa bɔbɔe ɣesiaɣi o gake ne mewɔea enana mekpɔa dzidzɔ. "
That isn’t always easy, but I am much happier as a result. "
Gbedodoɖa kple Biblia xexlẽ ye faa akɔ na Julia.
Julia finds comfort in prayer and Bible reading.
Egblɔ be: "Nye dzimenyawo gbɔgblɔ na Mawu le gbedodoɖa me nana meɖea dzi ɖi.
"Pouring out my heart to God in prayer calms me, " she says.
Biblia kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe be mexɔ asi le Mawu ŋkume eye be eléa be nam.
"And the Bible helps me to see that I am valuable in God’s eyes and that he really cares about me.
Biblia xexlẽ na kakaɖedzi su asinye ɖe etsɔme ŋu. "
Bible reading also gives me a positive view of the future. "
Esi Yehowa Mawue wɔ mí ta la, ese ale si hehe si míexɔ, míaƒe agbemenuteƒekpɔkpɔwo kple nu siwo dome míenyi kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe míaƒe agbenɔnɔ kple seselelãme dzii la gɔme bliboe.
As our Creator, Jehovah God fully understands how our upbringing, experiences in life, and genetic makeup influence our outlook and emotions.
Eya ta etea ŋu naa kpekpeɖeŋu kple akɔfafa si míehiã la mí ɣeaɖewoɣi to mía havi amegbetɔ siwo sea veve ɖe ame nu hesea nu gɔme na ame dzi.
He is therefore able to supply needed support and comfort, perhaps doing so through compassionate and understanding fellow humans.
Azɔ hã, ɣeyiɣi aɖe gbɔna si Mawu ada míaƒe dɔlélewo katã na mí.
Moreover, the time will come when God will heal us of all our illnesses, physical or mental.
Yesaya 33:24 gblɔ be: "Dua me tɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, ‘Mele dɔ lém o.’ "
"No resident will say: ‘I am sick,’ " says Isaiah 33:24.
Ɛ̃, Biblia do ŋugbe be Mawu "atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le [míaƒe] ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o. "
Yes, the Bible promises that God "will wipe out every tear from [our] eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4) Nya sia faa akɔ henaa kakaɖedzi ame lo!
(Revelation 21:4) How comforting and reassuring that is!
Ne èdi be yeasrɔ̃ nu geɖe tso Mawu ƒe tameɖoɖo na amegbetɔ ŋu la, ekema míeɖe kuku yi jw.org nyatakakadzraɖoƒea.
If you would like to learn more about God’s purpose for mankind and the earth, please visit us at jw.org.
Àkpɔ Biblia nyui aɖe kple nyati gbogbo siwo ƒo nu tso nu vovovo siwo dome blanuiléledɔ hã le la ŋu le afi ma.
There you will find an excellent online Bible, as well as articles on a broad range of topics, including depression.
Nu Siwo Dzilawo Ate Ŋu Awɔ
What Parents Can Do
Dzilawo, minyae be esesẽna na sɔhɛ siwo lé blanui be woagblɔ ale si wole sesem le wo ɖokuiwo me eye ɖewohĩ womase nu si le fu ɖem na wo la gɔme o.
Recognize that depressed teens may find it hard to express their feelings or may not understand what is happening to them.
Anɔ eme be womanya gɔ̃ hã be blanuiléledɔe le fu ɖem na yewo o.
They may not even be aware of the symptoms of depression.

Sɔhɛ siwo blanuiléledɔ le fu ɖem na ƒe nuwɔna toa vovo na ame tsitsi siwo le dɔ ma lém la tɔ, eya ta nɔ ŋudzɔ ɖe tɔtrɔ siwo ava viwòa ƒe nuwɔnawo, eƒe nuɖuɖu, eƒe dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ, alɔ̃dɔdɔ alo hadomenuwɔnawo me la ŋu, vevietɔ ne tɔtrɔawo li hena kwasiɖa geɖewo.

Teens tend to express their depression in ways different from those of adults, so be alert to major changes in your child’s behavior, eating habits, moods, sleep patterns, or social interactions especially if the changes persist for weeks.
Mègabui fefenyae ne viwòa gblɔ nya aɖe alo wɔ nane si fia be edi be yeawu ye ɖokui o.
Take seriously any comments or hints regarding suicide.
Ne ewɔ na wò be blanuiléledɔe di be yeaɖe fu nɛ la kplɔe yi kɔdzi ne woadoe kpɔ, (menye blanuiléle vie ƒe nya gblɔm míele o).
If you suspect depression (not just the blues), consider getting a professional diagnosis.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòazã atike siwo ɖɔktaa nae la nyuie eye ne dɔa meka ɖe eme nɛ o alo ne atikeawo le fu ɖem nɛ la, ele be nàna ɖɔktaa nanya.
Help your teen adhere to the doctor’s prescribed treatment, and consult the doctor if you see no improvement or observe unpleasant side effects.
Na wò ƒomea naɖu nu nyuie, minɔ kame dem eye midɔ alɔ̃ nyuie.
Have a stable family routine for eating, exercising, and sleeping.
Nɔ dze ɖom kple viwòa ɣesiaɣi eye nàkpe ɖe eŋu wòanɔ te ɖe nu manyomanyo siwo amewo wɔna alo gblɔna ɖe blanuiléledɔlélawo ŋu la nu.
Maintain good communication with your teen, and help him or her to deal with any stigma associated with depression.
Esi blanuiléledɔ nana ame sena le eɖokui me be yetsi akogo, ŋukpe lé ye alo viɖe mele ye ŋu o ta la, na viwòa naka ɖe edzi be wò ya elɔ̃ ye ɣesiaɣi.
Because depression can make one feel alone, ashamed, or worthless, regularly reassure your teen of your love.
Ŋlɔ Nu Siwo Nàwɔ Ne Dɔa Ho Na Wò La Ði
Create a "First-Aid Kit " for Your Emotions
Nu siwo nàwɔ ne dɔa ho na wo la dometɔ aɖewoe nye, ŋkuɖodzinu, mawunyakpukpuiwo, hadzidziwo, nyatiwo kple nuteƒekpɔkpɔwo
An emotional first-aid kit, including positive and upbuilding momentos, scriptures, songs, articles, and experiences
Ne blanuiléledɔ le ŋuwò la, nu si akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe enue nye be nàŋlɔ nu siwo nàwɔ ne dɔa ho la ɖi.
If you suffer from depression, a practical suggestion to help you control your thoughts and feelings is to create what has been called an emotional first-aid kit.
Nu siwo nàŋlɔ siwo ŋu nàte ŋu anɔ asi trɔm le ɣeaɖewoɣi dometɔ aɖewoe nye nu siwo dze le axa sia:
The kit, which can be adjusted as you see fit, might include the items on this page.
Ŋlɔ ame siwo nàte ŋu ayɔ alo aƒo ka na ne èlé blanui la ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖi
Contact information of people to call when you feel down
Ŋlɔ ha siwo doa dzidzɔ na wò eye wotua wò ɖo la ɖi
Favorite songs that are positive and upbuilding
Ŋlɔ nyagbɔgblɔ kple nyati siwo dea dzi ƒo na wò la ɖi
Inspirational sayings and encouraging articles
Ŋlɔ nya fakɔname siwo tso Biblia me siwo tua ame ɖo abe Psalmo 34:18; 51:17; 94:19; Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7 ene la ɖi
A list of comforting and upbuilding sayings from the Bible, such as Psalm 34:18; 51:17; 94:19; Philippians 4:6, 7
Dzra ŋkuɖodzinu siwo ame siwo lɔ̃ wò na wò la ɖo eye nànɔ wo ŋu dɔ wɔm
Mementos to remind you of people who love you
Nɔ nuteƒekpɔkpɔ nyui kple nu nyui siwo nèsusuna siwo nèŋlɔ ɖi la xlẽm
A journal containing your positive thoughts as well as positive experiences you have enjoyed
Nu Siwo Gbɔ Nyɔnuviwo Ƒe Blanuiléledɔ Tsona
Depression and Teenage Girls
Edze abe blanuiléledɔ ɖea fu na nyɔnuviwo wu ŋutsuviwo ene.
The incidence of depression in teenage girls appears to be higher than that of boys.
Nu siwo gbɔ wòtsona dometɔ ɖekae nye be, zi geɖe la, eva hiãna be nyɔnuviwo nanɔ te ɖe seselelãme, ŋutilãme alo gbɔdɔnya siwo wotsɔ ɖea fu na wo la nu.
One factor may be the stress resulting from emotional, physical, or sexual harassment or abuse, which girls often have to cope with.
Aƒenɔ Sharon Hersh si nye aɖaŋuɖola bibi aɖe ŋlɔ bena: "Ne nu manyomanyo siwo me tom wole le aƒe me alo suku kple woawo ŋutɔwo ƒe seselelãmewo go do la, ewua tsɔtsɔ na wo eye wotɔtɔna. "
"When a scary external world and a chaotic internal world collide, " wrote professional counselor Sharon Hersh, "the result is often overwhelming and confusing. "
Nu siwo nyadzɔdzɔgblɔmɔnuwo hã gblɔna be eyae ana ame ƒe "dzedzeme " nanya kpɔ la kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe wo dzi madzemadzee.
Girls may also be unduly influenced by media portrayals of the "ideal " body.
Nyɔnuvi si buna be yemedze tugbe o alo di be yeƒe nu nadze ye xɔlɔ̃wo ŋu la ate ŋu alé blanuiléledɔ bɔbɔe.
A girl who sees herself as physically undesirable or who is overly concerned about peer approval may be more vulnerable to depression.
Nu Kae Mawɔ Be Madzudzɔ Blanuiléle?
How Can I Stop Being So Sad?
"Ne ame bubuwo le nɔnɔme sesẽwo me tom la, mekpena ɖe wo ŋu hedea dzi ƒo na wo.
"When everyone else falls apart, I’m there to fix their problems and make them feel better.
Gake ame ʋɛ aɖewoe koe nya be ne meyi aƒe me la, menɔa xɔ me hefaa avi. "​ ⁠Kellie.
But then​ and this is the part that few people see I go home to my room and cry. "​ Kellie.
"Ne melé blanui la, meɖea ɖokuinye ɖe aga.
"When I’m down, I isolate myself.
Ne wokpem na wɔna aɖe la, medoa taflatsɛ.
If I get invited somewhere, I come up with an excuse not to go.
Metea ŋu ɣlaa nye blanuilélea ale gbegbe be ƒonyemetɔwo menyana kura be melé blanui o.
I do a good job at hiding my sadness from my family.
Wosusuna be meli nyuie. "​ ⁠Rick.
They think I’m fine. "​ Rick.
Ðe wò hã nèsena le ɖokuiwò me abe Kellie alo Rick enea?
Have your thoughts ever been similar to those of Kellie or Rick?
Ne alea wòle le gowòme la, mègatsi dzi nàƒo nya ta be nane le gbegblẽm le ye ŋu o.
If so, don’t hastily conclude that there’s something wrong with you.
Nya lae nye be, ame sia ame léa blanui tso ɣeyiɣi yi ɣeyiɣi.
The fact is, everyone gets sad now and then.
Nuteƒewɔla siwo ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Biblia me gɔ̃ hã lé blanui. 1 Samuel 1:6-8; Psalmo 35:14.
Even faithful men and women mentioned in the Bible did.​ 1 Samuel 1:​6-8; Psalm 35:14.
Le nɔnɔme aɖewo me la, ɖewohĩ ànya nu si tae yelé blanui ɖo, gake le nɔnɔme bubuwo me la anɔ eme be mànya o.
In some cases, you may know why you are sad; in other cases, you may not.
Anna si xɔ ƒe 19 gblɔ be: "Menye nya sesẽ koe dzɔna ɖe ame dzi hafi woléa blanui o.
"You don’t have to be in a horrible situation to feel sad, " says 19-year-old Anna.
Blanuiléle ate ŋu ava le nɔnɔme ɖe sia ɖe me, ne mèle kuxi aɖeke me tom o gɔ̃ hã.
"It can come on at any time, even if your life is trouble free.
Màse egɔme o, gake edzɔna! "
It’s weird, but it happens! "
Nu ka kee na nèlé blanui o, nu kae nàte ŋu awɔ, ne edze abe mènya nu si gbɔ wòtso gɔ̃ hã o ene?
Regardless of the cause​ or even if there doesn’t seem to be one what can you do when sadness holds you in its grip?
Te mɔnu siwo gbɔna la kpɔ:
Try the following:
Ƒo nu tso eŋu.
Talk about it.
Esi Hiob ɖo nɔnɔme sesẽwo me la, egblɔ be: "Maƒo nu le nye luʋɔ ƒe vevesesewo me. " Hiob 10:1.
In the midst of his turmoil, Job said: "I will speak in the bitterness of my soul! "​ Job 10:1.
Kellie: Gbɔdzɔe si mekpɔna ne meƒo nu tso eŋu na ame bubu la mele gbɔgblɔ me o.
Kellie: The relief I feel after talking to someone is amazing.
Mlɔeba la, mesena le ɖokuinye me be ame aɖe nya nu si me tom mele.
Finally, someone knows what I’m going through.
Le kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ nu la, woate ŋu aɖiɖi ka nam ahahem do goe le blanuiléle ƒe ʋe globo ma me!
They can lower the rope and pull me out of the pit​ saved at last!
Ŋlɔ nu tso eŋu.
Write about it.
Ne blanuiléle na mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖe wò le agbe me la, anyo be nàŋlɔ nu siwo va susu me na wò la ɖe pepa dzi.
When sadness clouds your outlook on life, you might want to try putting your thoughts on paper.
David ŋlɔ nu tso ale si wòlé blanui vevie la ŋu le psalmo siwo gbɔgbɔ ʋãe wòŋlɔ la me.
In his inspired psalms, David sometimes expressed deep sadness.
(Psalmo 6:7) Ne èŋlɔ ale si nèsena le ɖokuiwò me da ɖi la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàlé "nunya vavã kple tamebubu me ɖe asi sesĩe. " Lododowo 3:21.
(Psalm 6:6) Writing about such feelings can help you to "safeguard practical wisdom and thinking ability. "​ Proverbs 3:​21.
Heather: Nye seselelãmewo ŋɔŋlɔ ɖi nana be megbugbɔ ɖoa nu siwo blanuiléle tsɔ do agba ɖe susu me nam la ɖe ɖoɖo nu.
Heather: Writing helps me to organize the mental clutter that accumulates from sadness.
Ne àte ŋu aŋlɔ wò seselelãmewo ɖi ahagbugbɔ wo aɖo ɖe ɖoɖo nu le susu me la, ke blanuilélea makpe dziwò fũu o.
When you can express your feelings and sort them out, the sadness is less overwhelming.
Do gbe ɖa tso eŋu.
Pray about it.
Biblia gblɔ be ne èdo gbe ɖa tso nu siwo le fu ɖem na wò ŋu la, ‘Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒoa susu ɖe sia ɖe ta la, adzɔ wò dzi kple wò tamesusuwo ŋu.’ Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7.
The Bible says that if you pray about your concerns, ‘the peace of God that excels all thought will guard your heart and your mental powers.’​ Philippians 4:​6, 7.
Esther: Menɔ agbagba dzem be manya nu si tae meléa blanui vevie ɖo la, gake nyemete ŋui o.
Esther: I was trying to figure out why I felt so down, and I couldn’t.
Mebia Yehowa be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye manɔ dzidzɔ kpɔm.
I asked Jehovah to help me to be happy.
Ne naneke medzɔ o ko melé blanui la, etena ɖe dzinye vevie.
I was sick of being sad when I had no reason to be.
Mlɔeba la, meva ɖu blanuiléle sia dzi.
I finally broke the cycle.
Mègabu vi si gbedodoɖa ɖena la nu tsɛ kura o!
Never underestimate the power of prayer!
Kpekpeɖeŋu si woana wò kple ale si nàdo vevie nu la ate ŋu ana nàvo tso ale si nèléa blanuiléle vevie la si me
With assistance and effort, you can get out of a deep pit of sadness
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Srɔ̃ ale si nàdo gbe ɖa na Yehowa to ŋugbledede le Psalmo 139:23, 24 me nyawo ŋu me.
Suggestion: Use Psalm 139:23, 24 as a pattern for your own prayer to Jehovah.
Gblɔ wò dzimenyawo nɛ eye nàbiae be wòakpe ɖe ŋuwò nàde dzesi nu si nana nèléa blanui.
Pour out your heart, and ask him to help you identify the root of your sadness.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, nu xɔasiwo le Mawu ƒe Nya, Biblia me siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
In addition to the suggestions mentioned earlier, you have a valuable resource in God’s Word, the Bible.
Ne èna nya tuameɖo siwo le Biblia me la xɔ susu me na wò la, akpɔ ŋusẽ nyui ɖe wò seselelãme dzi. Psalmo 1:1-3.
Filling your mind with upbuilding thoughts that can be gleaned from Bible accounts can have a positive effect on your feelings.​ Psalm 1:​1-3.
Ne blanuilélea xɔ zikpui ɖe gbɔwò
When sadness won’t go away
Aƒetɔvi aɖe si woyɔ be Ryan gblɔ be: "Mesena le ɖokuinye me be anyo nam be mayi edzi anɔ anyimlɔƒe wu be mafɔ le aba dzi agadze ŋgɔ ŋkeke manyataleŋu bubu. "
"On some mornings, " says Ryan, "I feel that it would be easier just to stay in bed and avoid having to get up and face another pointless day. "
Blanuiléle si gbɔ ɖɔktawo ko ate ŋu akpɔ ye nɔ fu ɖem na Ryan, eye menye eya ɖeka koe le nɔnɔme sia me o.
Ryan suffers from clinical depression, and he’s not alone.
Numekukuwo ɖee fia be blanuiléle si nu sẽ alo esi nu mesẽ o ɖea fu na sɔhɛ ɖeka le ene ɖe sia ɖe me hafi wòva zua ame tsitsi.
Studies suggest that about 1 in 4 youths suffers from some type of major or minor depression before reaching adulthood.
Aleke nàwɔ anya be blanuiléledɔ lém ye le?
How can you find out if you suffer from depression?

Dzesi siwo nàkpɔ la dometɔ aɖewoe nye ne wò seselelãme alo nuwɔna trɔna zi ɖeka kpata, èɖea ɖokuiwò ɖe aga, ne nuwɔna ɖe sia ɖe kloe megale fu tsɔm le lã me na wò o, nu meganya le ɖuɖum na wò alo mègate ŋu le alɔ̃ dɔm o, èsena le ɖokuiwò me be yemele ɖeke me o alo èbua fɔ ɖokuiwò madzemadzee.

Some symptoms include a pronounced change in mood and behavior, social isolation, diminished interest in almost all activities, a significant change in eating habits and sleeping patterns, and intense feelings of worthlessness or unwarranted guilt.
Nyateƒee, seselelãme siawo dometɔ ɖeka alo esi wu nenema ɖe fu na mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kloe kpɔ.
Of course, nearly everyone has one or more of those symptoms at some time or another.
Gake ne seselelãme sia nu gbe tsotso kwasiɖa geɖe la, ɖe manyo be nàƒo nu tso eŋu na dziwòlawo be woakplɔ wò ayi kɔdzi ne woado wò kpɔ oa?
But if symptoms persist for more than a couple of weeks, why not talk to your parents about getting a checkup?
Ðɔktawo ate ŋu ade dzesii nenye blanuiléledɔ lém nèle.
A physician can help determine if your sadness has a medical cause.
Ne blanuiléledɔ lém nèle la, mehiã be ŋu nakpe wò o.
If you do suffer from clinical depression, it is nothing to be ashamed of.
Eɖanye blanuilélee na nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me nenema alo nu bubu aɖee o, ɖo ŋku nya fakɔname siwo le Psalmo 34:19 la dzi.
With treatment, many sufferers have begun to feel better​ perhaps the best they have felt in a long time.
Afi ma gblɔ be: "Yehowa tsɔ ɖe ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã gudugudu la gbɔ, eye wòxɔna na ame siwo ƒe gbɔgbɔ woƒo ƒu anyi. "
Whether your sadness is caused by depression or not, remember the comforting words of Psalm 34:18: "Jehovah is near to those that are broken at heart; and those who are crushed in spirit he saves. "
Nu Ka Tae Mesia Ðokuinye?
Why Do I Cut Myself?

Nu ka tae amewo wɔa nu sia?

Interview
Biabia Siwo Ŋu Nàde Nugble Le
Questions for reflection
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Meŋlɔ Da Ði
My scripture journal
Nu kae ameɖokuisisi nye?
What is cutting?
Ameɖokuisisi nye eɖoɖo koŋ atsɔ lãnuwo anɔ nu vevi wɔm ame ɖokui.
Cutting is the practice of compulsively harming oneself with a sharp object.
Esia nye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui gbogbo siwo li la dometɔ ɖeka ko.
It’s just one form of self-injury.
Ðewoe nye dzotsɔtsɔ amè ame ɖokui kple ameɖokuiƒoƒo.
Others include burning, bruising, or hitting oneself.
Nyati sia ku ɖe ameɖokuisisi ŋu, gake mɔfiame siwo le eme ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo wɔa nu vevi bubuwo wo ɖokuiwo hã ŋu.
This article is about cutting, but the principles discussed apply to all forms of self-injury.
Do wò sidzedze kpɔ: Nyateƒee alo aʋatsoe.
Test your knowledge: True or False.
Nyɔnuviwo koe sia wo ɖokuiwo.
Only girls cut themselves.
Ameɖokuisisi nye Biblia ƒe sedede si le 3 Mose 19:28 si gblɔ be: ‘Migasi mia ɖokuiwo o’ la dzi dada.
Cutting violates the Bible command at Leviticus 19:28, which says: "You must not make cuts in your flesh. "
Ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔwo:
Correct answers:
Aʋatsoe.
False.
Togbɔ be nyɔnuviwo koŋue sia wo ɖokuiwo hã la, ŋutsuvi aɖewo hã sia wo ɖokuiwo eye wowɔa nu vevi ƒomevi bubuwo hã wo ɖokuiwo.
While the problem seems more prevalent among girls, some boys cut themselves and engage in other forms of self-injury too.
Aʋatsoe.
False.
Nya si 3 Mose 19:28 gblɔ la ku ɖe trɔ̃subɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema ƒe kɔnuwo ŋu, ke menye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui si ŋu míele nu ƒom tsoe le nyati sia me ŋu o.
Leviticus 19:28 refers to an ancient pagan ritual, not to the compulsive practice of self-injury discussed in this article.
Ke hã susu le eme be míaƒo nya ta be mía Wɔla lɔ̃ame la medi be míawɔ nu vevi mía ɖokuiwo o. 1 Korintotɔwo 6:12; 2 Korintotɔwo 7:1; 1 Yohanes 4:8.
Nevertheless, it stands to reason that our loving Creator doesn’t want us to harm ourselves.​ 1 Corinthians 6:​12; 2 Corinthians 7:1; 1 John 4:8.
Nu ka tae amewo wɔa nu sia?
Why do people do it?
Do wò sidzedze kpɔ: Nya siawo dometɔ kae nèsusu be enye ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ?
Test your knowledge: Which statement do you think is most accurate?
Amewo sia wo ɖokuiwo . . .
People cut themselves . . .
be yewoatsi nuxaxa nu.
because they are trying to cope with emotional anguish.
be yewoawu yewo ɖokuiwo.
because they are trying to kill themselves.
Ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ: A. Ame siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo ƒe akpa gãtɔ medina be yewoaku o.
Correct answer: A. Most people who cut themselves don’t want to die.
Ðeko wowɔnɛ be yewoatsɔ atsi nuxaxa nu.
They just want to end their emotional despair.
Kpɔ nya siwo sɔhɛ siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo dometɔ aɖewo gblɔ ɖa.
Note what some young people have said about their practice of cutting.
Celia : "Enana nye dzi dzea eme. "
Celia: "It brought me a sense of relief. "
Tamara: "Ewɔna nam abe ɖe nuxaxa nu yi ene.
Tamara: "It seemed to provide an escape.
Veve si ame sena ne ewɔ nu vevi eɖokui la nyo sãsãsã wu nuxaxa. "
The physical pain was better than the emotional pain. "
Carrie: "Nyemedina be malé blanui kura o.
Carrie: "I hated feeling sad.
Ne mesi ɖokuinyea, nye susu meganɔa nye blanuilélea dzi o, nye susu va nɔa abi si le veyem la boŋ dzi. "
Cutting took the focus off my sadness and put it onto my physical pain. "
Jerrine: "Ɣesiaɣi si mesi ɖokuinyea, nye susu dzona le kuxi ɖe sia ɖe kloe dzi, eye megahiãna be makpe akɔ kple nye kuxiwo o.
Jerrine: "Every time I cut myself, I became almost unaware of my surroundings, and I wouldn’t have to deal with my problems.
Tɔtrɔ sia dzɔa dzi nam. "
I welcomed the change. "
Ne kuxi sia le ŋuwò la, aleke nàwɔ atasii?
If you have this problem, how can you stop?
Gbedodoɖa na Yehowa nye nu vevi si kpena ɖe ame ŋu wòdzudzɔa nuwɔna sia.
Prayer to Jehovah God can be a vital step to recovery.
Biblia gblɔ be: ‘Midro miaƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo katã ɖe eyama dzi, elabena eléa be na mi.’ 1 Petro 5:7.
The Bible says: "Throw all your anxiety upon him, because he cares for you. "​ 1 Peter 5:7.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Gbã la, do gbe kpui aɖe ɖa, ɖewohĩ nàgblɔ na Yehowa ko be, "Mehiã kpekpeɖeŋu. "
Suggestion: Start with brief prayers, perhaps simply telling Jehovah, "I need help. "
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, ŋutete ava su asiwò nàgblɔ wò dzimenya geɖewo na "akɔfafa katã ƒe Mawu " la. 2 Korintotɔwo 1:3, 4.
In time, you will be able to open up and pour out your feelings to "the God of all comfort. "​ 2 Corinthians 1:​3, 4.
Menye susumenu dzro aɖe si nana ame sena le eɖokui be yekpɔ gbɔdzɔe gbedodoɖa nye o.
Prayer is not some psychological crutch.

Enye dzeɖoɖo ŋutɔŋutɔ kple Fofowò si le dziƒo, ame si do ŋugbe be: "Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò; ŋɔ megadzi wò o, elabena nyee nye wò Mawu, mali ke wò, makpe ɖe ŋuwò, eye matsɔ nye xɔname ƒe nuɖusi alé wò. "
It is real communication with your heavenly Father, who promises: "I will really help you.
Yesaya 41:10.
I will really keep fast hold of you with my right hand of righteousness. "​ Isaiah 41:10.
Ame siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo dometɔ geɖe kpɔ gbɔdzɔe esi woƒo nu tso woƒe kuxia ŋu na wo dzilawo alo ame tsitsi aɖe si dzi woka ɖo.
Many who have struggled with cutting have also found comfort in talking to a parent or another trusted adult.
Se nya siwo sɔhɛ siawo dometɔ etɔ̃ gblɔ la ɖa.
Consider the following comments from three young people who did just that.
Gbebiame
Interview
Diana, ƒe 21
Diana, 21
Kathy, ƒe 15
Kathy, 15
Lorena, ƒe 17
Lorena, 17
Ƒe nenie nèxɔ esime nète ɖokuiwò sisi?
How old were you when you started cutting yourself?
Lorena: Mexɔ ƒe 14.
Lorena: I started when I was about 14.
Diana: Mexɔ ƒe 18, menɔa ɖoɖo nu o.
Diana: I was 18, and the frequency varied.
Mesia ɖokuinye gbe sia gbe hena kwasiɖa ɖeka alo eve, eyome menɔa anyi ɣleti ɖeka sɔŋ esi nyemewɔa nu sia o.
I would cut every day for a week or two and then go for a month without doing it at all.
Kathy: Mexɔ ƒe 14.
Kathy: I started when I was 14.
Megawɔnɛ ɣeaɖewoɣi kokoko.
I still have occasional setbacks.
Nu ka tae nèwɔa nu vevi ɖokuiwò?
Why did you want to hurt yourself?
Kathy: Elabena meléa fu ɖokuinye.
Kathy: I struggled with feelings of self-hatred.
Ewɔna nam be ame aɖeke medi be manye ye xɔlɔ̃ o.
I felt as if no one could possibly want me as a friend.
Diana: Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, blanuiléle nana be nu tena ɖe dzinye eye dzi ɖena le ƒonye.
Diana: Sometimes my sadness would turn into frustration, and my frustration into despair.
Dziɖeleameƒoa nu nɔa sesẽm va se ɖe esime wòwua tsɔtsɔ nam.
The despair would grow until it became overwhelming.
Ðeko wònɔna abe lã wɔadã aɖee le menye eye wòhiã be madze ɖokuinye ne wòado go ene.
It was like a huge beast inside me, and it was as if I had to cut myself to let it out.
Lorena: Nu tena ɖe dzinye vevie, medoa dziku eye nyemegakpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe ɖokuinye ŋu o.
Lorena: I would get really depressed or angry or just feel down about myself.
Ewɔna nam be meƒo ɖi, eye medina be maɖe seselelãme dziŋɔ ma aƒu gbe.
I would feel like dirt, and I wanted to get rid of all that horrible emotional junk.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, mesusunɛ be ele be mawɔ nu vevi ɖokuinye.
Sometimes I would feel like I deserved the physical pain.
Ðe wò dzi dzea eme ne èwɔ nu vevi ɖokuiwòa?
Did hurting yourself make you feel better?
Diana: Ɛ̃.
Diana: It did.
Mevona le ɖokuinye me abe ɖe wodro agba kpekpe aɖe le ta nam ene.
I felt lighter afterward, as if a burden had been lifted from me.
Kathy: Ede sɔsɔ ge kloe kple avifafa.
Kathy: It’s almost like a form of crying.
Nye dzi dzea eme ne mesi ɖokuinye abe ale si ko ame aɖewo hã ƒe dzi dzea emee ne wofa avi wosu wo nyuie ene.
I felt better after I cut myself the same way that some people feel better after a good cry.
Lorena: Nu vevi wɔwɔ ɖokuinye le ko abe bɔl aɖee le menye si me wotu nye nuxaxawo ɖo la ŋɔŋɔ ene.
Lorena: Self-injury was like puncturing a small hole in the balloon of negative emotions inside me.
Maho o; ɖeko ya ado le eme eye wòaɖe asi le nye nuxaxawo katã ŋu woado le menye vivivi.
It wouldn’t pop; it would just leak and let all the negativity out slowly.
Ðe nèvɔ̃a nuƒoƒo tso nu si me tom nèlea ŋu na ame bubuwoa?
Were you afraid to tell anyone what you were doing?
Lorena: Ɛ̃.
Lorena: Yes.
Mevɔ̃na be woabum be menye ame sagã.
I was afraid people would think I was weird.
Eye nyemedina hã be amewo nanya nye agbemenyawo o.
Plus I didn’t want others to know about my personal life.
Diana: Amewo gblɔna ɣesiaɣi be yewobuam ame sesẽe, eye medi be woanɔ buyem nenema.
Diana: People always told me that they thought I was strong, and I wanted them to keep believing that.
Mesusunɛ be ne mebia be woakpe ɖe ŋunye la, ekema medo kpo nu.
I felt that asking for help would have been a defeat.
Kathy: Mevɔ̃na be amewo abum be nyemele nyuie o, eye esia awɔe be ale si mebua ɖokuinyee la nagagblẽ ɖe edzi kura.
Kathy: I was afraid that people would think I was messed up, which in turn would make me feel even worse about myself.
Gawu la, ewɔna nam be medze na nu vevi si wɔm mele ɖokuinye la.
Besides, I felt that I deserved what I was doing to myself.
Nu kae kpe ɖe ŋuwò nètasii?
What was a turning point for you?
Lorena: Meƒo nu tso nye nuwɔnaa ŋu na nɔnye.
Lorena: I told my mom what I had been doing.
Ðɔkta aɖe hã na kpekpeɖeŋum, ekpe ɖe ŋunye meɖu nye seselelãme manyomanyoawo dzi.
I also got help from a doctor, who helped me control my negative emotions.
Megawɔnɛ ɣeaɖewoɣi ya, gake Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃ edziedzi kpe ɖe ŋunye.
I had a few setbacks, but improving my Bible study routine helped.
Meƒoa ɖokuinye ɖe Kristotɔwo ƒe subɔsubɔa me edziedzi hã.
I also stay active in the Christian ministry.
Ðewohĩ ahiã be makpe akɔ kple viɖemanɔameŋu ƒe seselelãme tso ɣeyiɣi yi ɣeyiɣi le nye agbe me katã ya, gake medzea agbagba be nyemaɖe mɔ wòakpe dzinye o.
Perhaps I will always struggle with occasional feelings of worthlessness, but when they arise, I try not to let them rule me.
Kathy: Nɔvinyɔnu Kristotɔ si tsi wum ƒe ewo la de dzesi be nane le fu ɖem nam, eye meɖe nye nyawo gblɔ nɛ mlɔeba.
Kathy: A Christian sister who is about ten years older than I am could tell something was wrong, and I eventually confided in her.
Nukutɔe la, eya hã to nɔnɔme ma me kpɔ.
To my surprise, she too had once struggled with cutting.
Ŋu mekpem be maƒo nu tso nye kuxia ŋu nɛ o, elabe eya ŋutɔ hã to nɔnɔme ma me kpɔ.
I didn’t feel awkward talking to her because she had been through it herself.
Meyi ɖakpɔ ɖɔkta aɖe hã, ekpe ɖe nye kple dzinyelawo ŋu míeva se nuwɔna sia gɔme nyuie wu.
I also got help from a doctor, who helped me and my parents to understand what I was going through.
Diana: Mele atsu kple asi aɖe si dzi meka ɖo la ƒe aƒe me zã aɖe me eye srɔ̃ŋutsua de dzesii be nane le fu ɖem nam.
Diana: One night I was at the home of a couple whom I trusted, and the husband noticed that something wasn’t right.
Ede dzi ƒom nam veveseseɖeamenutɔe be magblɔ nu si le dzɔdzɔm ɖe dzinye la na yewo.
He kindly urged me to tell them what was wrong.
Nɔvinyɔnua lé nye asi eye wòkpla asi kɔ nam abe ale si ko nɔnye wɔna nam le nye ɖevime ene.
His wife held me and rocked me in her arms just the way my mom used to when I was a little girl.
Mewò avi, eye eya hã wò avi.
I started to cry, and so did she.
Esesẽ nam be magblɔ nu si me tom mele la na wo, gake dzi dzɔm ŋutɔ esi megblɔe na wo.
It was hard to tell them what I had been doing to myself, but I’m glad that I did.
Aleke Biblia kpena ɖe ŋuwò?
How has the Bible helped you?
Diana: Biblia kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe dze sii be nye ɖeka nyemate ŋu akpe akɔ kple nuwɔna sia o.
Diana: The Bible has helped me to realize that I can’t fight this on my own.
Mehiã Yehowa Mawu ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu.​ Lododowo 3:5, 6.
I need Jehovah God’s help.​ Proverbs 3:​5, 6.
Kathy: Biblia-xexlẽ kple enyanya be Mawu gbɔe gbedeasi si le eme la tso faa akɔ nam ŋutɔ!​ 2 Timoteo 3:16.
Kathy: Reading the Bible​ and knowing that its message comes from God​ gives me such deep comfort!​ 2 Timothy 3:​16.
Lorena: Ne mawunyakpukpui aɖe wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye la, meŋlɔnɛ ɖe agbalẽ me, eye meva dea ŋugble le eŋu emegbe.​ 1 Timoteo 4:​15.
Lorena: When I come across scriptures that touch me, I write them in a notebook so I can reflect on them later.​ 1 Timothy 4:​15.
Mawunyakpukpui kae wɔ dɔ ɖe dziwò vevie?
Is there a scripture in particular that touched you?
Diana: Lododowo 18:1 gblɔ be: "Ame si ɖe eɖokui ɖe aga le eya ŋutɔ ƒe dzodzro yome dim la, etsia tre ɖe nunyanyawo katã ŋu. "
Diana: Proverbs 18:1 says: "One isolating himself will seek his own selfish longing; against all practical wisdom he will break forth. "
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, esesẽna nam be manɔ amewo dome, gake mawunyakpukpui sia kpe ɖe ŋunye meva kpɔe be afɔku le ameɖokuiɖeɖe ɖe aga me.
Sometimes I find it difficult to be around people, but this scripture helps me to realize that to isolate myself is dangerous.
Kathy: Mateo 10:29, 31 nye mawunyakpukpui eve siwo dɔa dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ, afi si Yesu gblɔ le be atsutsrɔe ɖeka teti hã mekuna le Yehowa Mawu ƒe manyamanya me o.
Kathy: Two Bible verses that I love are Matthew 10:29 and 31, where Jesus said that not even a sparrow dies without Jehovah God noticing it.
Eye wògblɔ kpee be: "Migavɔ̃ o: Miexɔ asi sãsãsã wu atsutsrɔe geɖewo. "
And then he added: "Have no fear: you are worth more than many sparrows. "
Va se ɖe egbe la, ne mexlẽ nya mawo la, eɖoa ŋku edzi nam be Yehowa dea asixɔxɔ ŋunye.
Even now, reading those words reminds me that I’m valuable to Jehovah.
Lorena: Mekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe Yesaya 41:9, 10 me nyawo ŋu ŋutɔ.
Lorena: I appreciate the passage at Isaiah 41:​9, 10, where Jehovah says to his people: "I have not rejected you.
Yehowa gblɔ na eƒe amewo le afi ma be: "Nyemegbe wò o; megavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò; . . . mali ke wò. "
Do not be afraid, for I am with you. . . . I will fortify you. "
Ne mele nu si li ke ŋu bum la nye susu yia nane si sesẽ goŋgoŋ, glikpɔ sesẽ, si naneke mate ŋu aŋɔ o dzi.
When I think of something that is fortified, I think of something impenetrable, a structure with stone walls.
Mawunyakpukpui sia doa ŋusẽm, elabe menyae be Yehowa lɔ̃m eye wòli kplim.
This scripture makes me feel empowered, knowing that Jehovah loves me and that I will have him by my side always.
Biabia Siwo Ŋu Nàde Nugble Le
Questions for reflection
Ne èdi be yeabia kpekpeɖeŋu la, ame kae nàdi be yeaƒo nu tso yeƒe kuxiawo ŋu na?
When you are ready to reach out for help, in whom could you confide?
Nya kae nàte ŋu agblɔ tso kuxia ŋu ne èle gbe dom ɖa na Yehowa Mawu?
What can you say in prayer to Jehovah God about the matter?
Àte ŋu ayɔ mɔnu eve aɖewo (siwo menye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui o) siwo dzi nàto aɖu wò nuteɖeamedzi kple nuxaxaa dzia?
Can you name two methods (that do not involve self-injury) that you can use to release your stress and anxiety?
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Meŋlɔ Da Ði
My scripture journal
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Ne èxlẽ mawunyakpukpui aɖe si na nèkpɔe be Yehowa lɔ̃ ye alo kpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàda asɔ le ale si nèbua ɖokuiwò kple wò gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔwoe la, ŋlɔ mawunyakpukpui ma da ɖi.
Suggestion: When you come across a Bible passage that assures you of Jehovah’s love or that can help you to develop a balanced view of yourself and your failings, write that scripture in a journal.
Ŋlɔ nu si tae mawunyakpukpui ma le vevie na wò la le nyagbe ɖeka alo eve me ɖe egbɔ.
Include a sentence or two about why the passage is meaningful to you.
Be nàkpɔ ale si yeate ŋu awɔ esiae la, mawunyakpukpui aɖewoe nye esi Diana, Kathy kple Lorena ŋlɔ da ɖi.
To help you get started, here are some scriptures that Diana, Kathy, and Lorena found helpful.
Romatɔwo 8:​38, 39
Romans 8:​38, 39
"Mawunyakpukpui siawo ɖee fiam be Yehowa lɔ̃m nenye be mese le ɖokuinye me be nɔnɔmea wu tsɔtsɔ nam gɔ̃ hã. "​ Diana.
"These verses show me that Jehovah loves me, even when I feel that things couldn’t get any worse. "​ Diana.
Psalmo 73:23
Psalm 73:23
"Mawunyakpukpui siawo tɔgbi naa kakaɖedzim be nyemetsi akogo o.
"Scriptures like this one assure me that I’m not alone.
Ðeko wòle abe ɖe Yehowa le gbɔnye tututu ene. "​ Kathy.
It’s as if Jehovah is right here next to me. "​ Kathy.
1 Petro 5:​10
1 Peter 5:​10
"Ate ŋu adzɔ be mímakpɔ gbɔdzɔe enumake o; abia be ‘míakpe fu vi aɖe.’
"Relief may not come immediately; we may have to suffer ‘a little while.’
Gake mlɔeba la, Yehowa ate ŋu ana ŋusẽ si hiã la naɖo mía ŋu míado dzi atsɔ nɔnɔme ɖe sia ɖe. "​ Lorena.
In the end, though, Jehovah can make us strong enough to endure anything. "​ Lorena.
