More scriptures to consider
Psalmo 34:19
Psalm 34:18
Psalmo 54:6
Psalm 54:4
Psalmo 55:23
Psalm 55:22
Yesaya 57:15
Isaiah 57:15
Matthew 11:28, 29
Ðe Biblia Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋunye Ne Melé Blanuia?
Can the Bible Help Me if I’m Depressed?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, elabe "Mawu, ame si faa akɔ na ame siwo ŋu nu te la " gbɔe kpekpeɖeŋu nyuitɔ kekeake tsona.​ 2 Korintotɔwo 7:6.
Yes, because the best help comes from "God, Who comforts and encourages and refreshes and cheers the depressed. "​ 2 Corinthians 7:6, The Amplified Bible.
Ale si Mawu kpena ɖe ame siwo lé blanui ŋui
What God gives to help the depressed
Ŋusẽ.
Strength.
Mawu ‘ado ŋusẽ’ wò. Esia mefia be aɖe wò kuxiawo katã ɖa o, ke boŋ aɖo wò gbedodoɖawo ŋu ne èdo gbe ɖa nɛ be wòado ŋusẽ ye yeanɔ te ɖe kuxia nu.
God "refreshes and cheers " you, not by removing all your problems, but by answering your prayers when you pray for the strength to cope.
(Filipitɔwo 4:13) Ka ɖe edzi be ele klalo be yease wò gbedodoɖawo, elabe Biblia gblɔ be: "Yehowa tsɔ ɖe ame siwo ƒe dzi gbã gudugudu la gbɔ, eye wòxɔna na ame siwo ƒe gbɔgbɔ woƒo ƒu anyi. "
(Philippians 4:13) You can be sure that he’s ready to listen to you, for the Bible says: "Jehovah is near to those that are broken at heart; and those who are crushed in spirit he saves. "
(Psalmo 34:19) Le nyateƒe me la, Mawu ate ŋu ase gbe siwo nàdo ɖa nɛ be wòakpe ɖe ye ŋu, nenye be mete ŋu gblɔ ale si tututu nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me nɛ o hã.​ Romatɔwo 8:26, 27.
(Psalm 34:18) In fact, God can hear your call for help even if you can’t put your feelings into words.​ Romans 8:26, 27.
Kpɔɖeŋu nyuiwo.
Good examples.
Biblia-ŋlɔla aɖe do gbe ɖa na Mawu be: "Yehowa, [nye nuxaxa ƒe] globoƒe mele yɔwòm tso! "
One Bible writer prayed to God: "From the depths of my despair I call to you. "
Hakpala sia kpɔ akɔfafa le eƒe blanuilélea me esi wòɖo ŋku edzi be Mawu lɔ̃na faa tsɔa míaƒe vodadawo kea mí.
This psalmist dealt with his depression by remembering that God doesn’t burden us with guilt.
Eya tae wògblɔ na Mawu be: "Yehowa, ne èbe, yealé vodadawo ɖi la, Aƒetɔ, ame ka anɔ te ma?
Instead, he said to God: "If you kept a record of our sins, who could escape being condemned?
Elabena gbɔwò tsɔtsɔke le, ne woavɔ̃ wò. "​ Psalmo 130:1, 3, 4.
But you forgive us, so that we should stand in awe of you. "​ Psalm 130:1, 3, 4, Good News Translation.
Mɔkpɔkpɔ.
Hope.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe ale si Mawu faa akɔ na mí egbeae ŋu la, edo ŋugbe be yeaɖe kuxi siwo katã nana míeléa blanui la ɖa keŋkeŋ.
Besides providing comfort now, God has promised to remove all the problems that lead to depression.
Ne ŋugbedodo ma va eme la, "womagaɖo ŋku tsãtɔwo [siwo dome blanuiléledɔ hã le] dzi, alo woava ame ƒe ta me o. " Yesaya 65:17.
When he fulfills that promise, "the former things [including depression] will not be called to mind, neither will they come up into the heart. "​ Isaiah 65:17.
De Dzesii: Togbɔ be mí Yehowa Ðasefowo míelɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Mawu naa kpekpeɖeŋu ame siwo lé blanui hã la, míeyia kɔdzi ne míele dɔ, siwo dometɔ ɖekae nye blanuiléledɔ sesẽ, lém.
Note: While acknowledging the help that God provides, Jehovah’s Witnesses also seek medical treatment for ailments such as clinical depression.
(Marko 2:17) Ke hã míekafua dɔdamɔnu aɖeke be eyae nyo wu o, eye míebunɛ be ame ŋutɔe atso nya me le nya mawo ŋu.
(Mark 2:17) We do not, however, endorse any specific medical treatment; we feel that each person should make his own decision on such matters.
Congo-Kinshasa De Se Be Womegatɔ Ŋku Sukuvi Aɖeke Le Sukuwo Me O
Democratic Republic of Congo Prohibits Religious Discrimination in Schools
"Míeho aʋa ɖe ŋkutɔtɔ ame kple ameŋkumekpɔkpɔ ŋu [vevie ŋutɔ] le Dukɔa Ƒe Sukuwo me. "​ Dudɔwɔƒe Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ ƒe Agbalẽŋlɔla Ƒe Dɔwɔƒe, June (Masa) 12, 2014.
"Fighting against discrimination and inequalities is a fundamental [priority] of the National Education. " Secretary Offices of the Ministry of Education, June 12, 2014.
Ƒe geɖee nye esia la, wonyaa Ðasefowo ƒe vi siwo le suku siwo mawusubɔsubɔha bubuwo doa alɔe me le Congo-Kinshasa le esi wogbena be yewomakpɔ gome le subɔsubɔhawo ƒe subɔsubɔwɔnawo me o ta.

For several years, Witness children in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) were expelled from schools sponsored by other religious organizations because they would not participate in religious programs.
Esia va zu kuxi sesẽ aɖe, elabe subɔsubɔhawo va tsɔ woƒe sededewo ɖo ŋgɔ na dziɖuɖua ƒe sededewo eye wotua afɔkpo sukuvi Ðasefowo ƒe gomenɔamesiwo.
This became an issue because the schools had placed their internal rules above government regulations and ignored the rights of Witness students.
Congo dziɖuɖumegãwo va de dzesi nu madzɔmadzɔ wɔwɔ siawo eye woƒo nya ta be gome le ame sia ame si be wòade suku eye ame aɖeke mekpɔ mɔ atɔ ŋkui o.
The Congolese authorities saw the injustice and affirmed the right for all to receive an education free from discrimination.
Suku Siwo Subɔsubɔhawo Doa Alɔe Bua Woƒe Sededewo Vevie Wu Dziɖuɖua Ƒe Sededewo
Church-Sponsored Schools Follow Internal Rules Instead of Government Regulations
Mawusubɔsubɔhawo bla nu kple Congo dziɖuɖumegãwo be yewoado alɔ dziɖuɖusuku siwo le nuto siwo me hiahiã le.
Religious organizations have entered into agreements with the Congolese government to sponsor public schools in areas where there is a need.
Wogblɔ le nubablaa me tẽe be "ele be woakpɔ ɖeviwo ta tso ŋkutɔtɔ ame kple mɔxexe ɖe ame ƒe ablɔɖe nu le subɔsubɔnyawo ta la si me. "
The agreements clearly state that "children are to be protected from practices that promote religious discrimination and intolerance. "
Gake suku siwo subɔsubɔhawo doa alɔe la ƒe sukumegãwo ŋutɔ de se aɖewo le woƒe sukuawo me eye wobiaa tso sukuviwo katã si be woade subɔsubɔwɔnawo ahakpɔ gome le wo me.
The church-sponsored schools, however, have often had internal rules requiring students to attend and participate in religious programs.
Suku siawo dometɔ geɖe te tɔ ɖe edzi be ele be sukuviwo katã nawɔ ɖe yewoƒe sededewo dzi eye woda le nubabla si le wo kple dziɖuɖua dome kple sukuviawo ƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe ablɔɖe dzi.
A number of these schools have insisted on enforcing their internal rules, disregarding both their agreement with the government and the students’ right to freedom of worship.

Kuxia va dze go nyuie le ƒe 2005 me esi wonya sukuvi Ðasefo 52 le suku siwo dzi subɔsubɔhawo kpɔna le Abumombazi si le Equateur Nuto me, elabe wobia be sukumegãwo naɖe mɔ na yewo be yewomagakpɔ gome le subɔsubɔwɔnawo me o.

The problem became apparent in 2005, when 52 Witness students were expelled from a church-sponsored school in Abumombazi, Equateur Province, because they requested exemption from church services organized by school authorities.
Nya la do gã ɖe edzi esi suku siwo subɔsubɔhawo doa alɔe siwo le nuto bubuwo hã me te sukuvi Ðasefowo nyanya.
The problem escalated as church-sponsored schools in other provinces followed suit.
Ɣeaɖeɣi la, wonya sukuvi Ðasefo 300 siwo le xɔ vovovowo me la le suku le Congo, wo dometɔ aɖewo nɔ suku nu wum ɣemaɣi gɔ̃ hã.
In time, more than 300 Congolese Witness students from all grades were expelled, including those nearing graduation.
Kanyere Ndavaro, si nye sukuvi ƒe-13-vi aɖe si wonya madzemadzee le suku le 2009 me gblɔ be: "Ale si wogblẽ nu le nye agbe ŋu alea te ɖe dzinye ŋutɔ.
After being unjustly expelled from school in 2009, 13-year-old Kanyere Ndavaro wrote: "I am very sad about this damage to my life.
Nyemenya ale si etsɔme anɔ nam o. "
I do not know what my future will be. "
Kambere Mafika Justin si wonya le suku ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe do ŋgɔ na eƒe sukunuwuwu le ƒe 2010 me gblɔ be nuwɔna ma "tɔtɔ nye agbe kura. "
Kambere Mafika Justin, expelled shortly before his graduation in 2010, said that his life had been "turned upside down. "
Togbɔ be ete ɖe sukuviawo dzi vevie be womeɖe mɔ na yewo be yewoade suku alo axɔ ɖaseɖigbalẽ o hã la, woɖoe kplikpaa be yewomaɖe asi le yewoƒe mawudzixɔsewo ŋu o.
Although the students were upset at being denied an education or a diploma, they refused to compromise their religious beliefs.
Congo Dziɖuɖumegãwo De Mawusubɔsubɔ Ƒe Ablɔɖe Dzi
Congolese Officials Uphold Religious Freedom
Sukuvi siwo wonya le suku la dzilawo do go kple sukumegãwo be woakpɔ kuxia gbɔ, gake womekpɔ ta nɛ o.
Parents of the expelled children spoke with school administrators in an effort to resolve the problem but met with limited success.
Esia wɔe be Ðasefoawo tsɔ nya la yi dziɖuɖumegãwo gbɔ, eye woke ɖe dziɖuɖumegã ameŋkumemakpɔla siwo tso ɖe nya la ŋu hekpɔ egbɔ be wodzudzɔ ŋkutɔtɔ sukuviawo le woƒe mawudzixɔsewo ta.
Consequently, the Witnesses pursued the matter with governmental authorities and found fair-minded officials who worked to put a stop to the religious discrimination.

Le ƒe 2011 me la, aƒenɔ Bazizane Maheshe, si nye Dudɔnunɔla Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ le Dziehe Kivu Nutoa me ɖe agbalẽvi aɖe ɖe go si ƒe tanyae nye "Mɔxexe Ðe Ŋkutɔtɔ Ame Le Mawusubɔsubɔnyawo Ta Nu, " si ɖɔ sukuviwo ƒe nɔnɔmea be "ewɔ nublanui ŋutɔ. "

In 2011, Mme. Bazizane Maheshe, the Minister of Education for North Kivu Province, published a provincial circular entitled "Ban Placed on Discrimination Based on Religion, " which described the situation as "deplorable. "

Wogblɔ tso nyaa ŋu tẽe le agbalẽvia me be: "Woɖea ŋku tɔa sukuvi siwo le suku siwo subɔsubɔhawo doa alɔe me la le esi wogbe be yewomakpɔ gome le subɔsubɔwɔna siwo woɖo le sukuawo me o la ta, eye woŋea aɖaba ƒua Congo-dukɔa ƒe sededewo dzi. "

The circular addressed the issue clearly by stating: "Students of some religious confessions are subject to discrimination based on internal school rules in disregard of regulations in force in the DR Congo. "
Nya sia de du le dukɔa me le September (Anyɔnyɔ) 4, 2013 dzi, esi Mwangu Famba, Congo-dukɔa ƒe Dudɔwɔƒe Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ de se aɖe si bla sukuwo katã le dukɔa me.

The issue received national attention on September 4, 2013, when Mwangu Famba, the Minister of Education for the Democratic Republic of Congo, published a decree applying to all schools in all districts.

Wogblɔ le "Sedede Ðe Ŋkutɔtɔ Ame Le Mawusubɔsubɔnyawo Ta Nu Ŋuti Gbalẽvi " la me tẽe be: "Gome le sukuvi ɖe sia ɖe si le sukuwo katã me, eye medze be woatɔ ŋku wo dometɔ aɖeke le eƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ta o. "
The "Circular on the Prohibition of Discrimination Based on Religion " unequivocally stated: "All children have the right to apply to any school without adverse distinction based on religion. "
Wogagblɔ le sededea me hã be sukuviwo nyanya le suku le woƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ta nye "dada le Congo-dukɔa ƒe ɖoɖowo kple sewo dzi. "
The decree also stated that expulsion of students on religious grounds was "in total violation of the standards and laws in force in the Democratic Republic of Congo. "
Suku geɖewo wɔ ɖe dziɖuɖua ƒe sededea dzi eye wogbugbɔ sukuvi Ðasefoawo xɔ ɖe woƒe sukuawo me.
Many schools have obeyed the official directives and have welcomed Witness students back into the classroom.
Gake suku ʋɛ aɖewo gbe.
A few schools, however, have resisted.

Eya ta le June (Masa) 12, 2014 dzi la, Dudɔwɔƒe Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ ɖe nyatakaka aɖe ɖe go le September (Anyɔnyɔ) 2013 me si gado ŋusẽ sedede tsãtɔa eye wòhe susu yi se yeye si Congo Dukplɔla de ku ɖe sukudenyawo ŋu la dzi.

Thus, on June 12, 2014, the Ministry of Education published a memorandum reinforcing the September 2013 decree and citing the new framework law on education that was issued by the President of the DRC.

Ŋkuɖodzinya siawo tɔ asi nu si tutu le megbe na kuxi sia dzi eye wona eme kɔ tẽe be ele be woatso ɖe ŋkutɔtɔ ame le eƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ta ŋu eye wòɖo kpe edzi hã be dukɔa kple xexemedukɔwo ƒe sewo le ŋgɔ na sukuwo ŋutɔwo ƒe sededewo.
This reminder addressed the root cause of the problem by highlighting the importance of fighting discrimination and stressed the primacy of national and international laws over internal school rules.
Dudɔnunɔla Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ ɖo nyagɔmekulawo be woaku nya gɔme le suku siwo le dukɔa me godoo ale be woakpɔ ale si wole sedede sia dzi wɔmee.
The Minister of Education also appointed investigators to visit schools throughout the country to ensure that they abide by the decree.
Ðikeke mele eme o be nu nyuiwo ado tso dziɖuɖua ƒe afɔɖeɖe siawo me eye wòakpɔ kuxi sia gbɔ eteƒe nadidi.
No doubt, these measures taken by the government will bring long-standing, positive results.
Eɖe Vi Na Ame Geɖewo
Benefits to Many
Suku siwo le Congo wɔ ɖe sedede sia dzi eye sukuviwo katã ate ŋu akpɔ mɔ be womagatɔ ŋku yewo le suku le yewoƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ta azɔ o.
As Congolese schools act in accordance with the law, all students can expect to receive an education unencumbered by religious intolerance.
Sukuviwo asrɔ̃ ale si woade bubu ame sia ame ŋuti, eɖanye subɔsubɔha ka mee wòle o.
School children will learn to accord respect to all people, regardless of their beliefs.
Esia ana be Congo Dukplɔsea kple Dudɔwɔƒe Si Kpɔa Sukudenyawo Gbɔ ƒe sededewo dzi ko woawɔ le sukuwo me, eye woɖo ameŋkumemakpɔmakpɔ ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nyui aɖe na dukɔa me sɔhɛwo hã.
In so doing, Congolese schools will not only uphold the Constitution of the DRC and the decree from the Minister of Education but also set an example of fairness for its young people.
Wole Ga Me Ƒe Blaevee Nye Esia Le Eritrea​ Enu Ava Yi Gbe Ðeka?
Twenty Years of Imprisonment in Eritrea​ Will It Ever End?
Ƒe blaevee nye esi va yi la, Eritrea dziɖuɖumegãwo lé ɖekakpuivi etɔ̃ aɖewo de ga le Sawa Gakpɔ me, wole nɔnɔme madeamedziwo me, eye wogakpɔtɔ le gakpɔa me va se ɖe egbe.
Twenty years ago, Eritrean authorities arrested three young men and detained them in harsh conditions in the Sawa prison camp, where they remain until this day.
Wometsɔ nya aɖeke ɖe wo ŋu o, eye womena mɔnukpɔkpɔ aɖeke wo hã be woaɖe wo ɖokuiwo nu le ʋɔnu o.
They have never been charged with a crime, nor have they been given the opportunity to defend themselves in a court of law.
Nu ka tae wolé wo de ga madzemadzee?
Why have they been unjustly imprisoned?
Paulos Eyassu, Negede Teklemariam kple Isaac Mogos nye Yehowa Ðasefowo, eye wogbe be yewomaxɔ asrafo ƒe hehe o le woƒe mawusubɔsubɔ si womefena kple o ta.
Paulos Eyasu, Negede Teklemariam, and Isaac Mogos are Jehovah’s Witnesses and conscientiously object to performing military service because of their strongly held religious beliefs.
Ne ɖe wodrɔ̃ ʋɔnu wo hebu fɔ wo be wowɔ "nu gbegblẽ " le esi wogbe be yewomaxɔ asrafo ƒe hehe o ta la, anye ne woka ƒe aɖe koŋ na wo be woanɔ ga me.
Had they been formally charged with the "crime " of refusing military service, they would have been sentenced to a fixed prison term.
Fifia Paulos xɔ ƒe 41, Negede xɔ ƒe 40 eye Isaac hã xɔ ƒe 38, eye wo katã wozã woƒe sɔhɛmenɔɣia katã le ga me.
Paulos, Negede, and Isaac, now aged 41, 40, and 38 respectively, have spent their youth in confinement.
Woxɔ srɔ̃ɖeɖe, vidzidzi, wo dzilawo dzi kpɔkpɔ alo agbenɔnɔ ale si woawo ŋutɔ wodii ƒe mɔnukpɔkpɔ le wo si.
They have been denied the opportunity to marry and have children, give support to their aging parents, or live their lives as they choose.
Eye woxɔ tadede agu ɖekae kple woƒe haxɔsetɔwo ƒe mɔnukpɔkpɔ hã le wo si.
They have also been denied the opportunity to worship with their fellow believers.
Esi wolé Paulos, Negede kple Isaac le September 24, 1994 dzi yi Sawa Gakpɔ me la, gakpɔa dzi kpɔlawo sẽ ŋuta le wo ŋu vevie hewɔ funyafunya wo gɔ̃ hã.
After their arrest on September 24, 1994, Paulos, Negede, and Isaac were treated severely, even tortured, by authorities in the Sawa prison camp.

Gake le ƒe ʋɛ siwo va yi me la, womegasẽa ŋuta le wo ŋu ale o, eye womegawɔa funyafunya wo hã o. Ale si woɖoe kplikpaa be yewomaɖe asi le yewoƒe mawudzixɔse ŋu o la na be gakpɔa dzi kpɔlawo dea bubu wo ŋu.
In recent years, however, the harsh treatment has ended, and their firm determination to remain loyal to their religious beliefs has earned them the respect of the prison guards.
Ðasefo Bubu Siwo Wolé De Ga Le Nɔnɔme Sesẽwo Me
Other Witnesses imprisoned in harsh conditions
Eritrea yee wole Yehowa Ðasefowo yome tim kutɔkutɔe le wu le xexea me godoo.
It is in Eritrea, more than anywhere else in the world, that Jehovah’s Witnesses experience the most intense persecution.
Esime míele nyati sia ŋlɔm la, Ðasefo 73 le ga me, nyɔnuwo, ɖeviwo kple ame tsitsiwo hã le wo dome.
As of this writing, 73 Witnesses are in prison, including women, children, and the elderly.
Wo dometɔ geɖe le te nɔm ɖe gbedadaƒo ƒe nɔnɔme sesẽ mawo nu, womekpɔa nu nyui ɖuna o, womekpɔa tsi nona wosua wo o, eye gakpɔa dzi kpɔlawo wɔa fu wo vevie.
Many have endured under harsh desert conditions, lacking a balanced diet and sufficient water and being mistreated by prison officials.
Wolé Ðasefo etɔ̃ bubu aɖewo hã de ga le Sawa Gakpɔa me ƒe ewo kple edzivɔe nye ema, gake Paulos, Negede kple Isaac le ga me wòdidi wu Ðasefo ɖe sia ɖe le Eritrea.
Three other Witness men have been imprisoned for more than ten years in the Sawa camp, but Paulos, Negede, and Isaac have been in detention the longest of any other Witnesses in Eritrea.
Xexemedukɔwo Le Biabiam Tso Eritrea Si Be Wòadzudzɔ Mawusubɔlawo Yome Titi
International community calls on Eritrea to end religious persecution
Xexemedukɔwo nyae nyuie be Eritrea dziɖuɖua wɔa fu Yehowa Ðasefowo kple subɔsubɔha sue bubuwo me tɔwo.
The international community is well-aware of Eritrea’s mistreatment of Jehovah’s Witnesses and other religious minorities.

Tso ƒe 2004 me la, United States (États-Unis) Dukɔa Ƒe Dɔwɔƒe yɔa Eritrea be enye "dukɔ si ƒe nuwɔna ɖe fu etɔxɛe. " Wozãa "nya sia na dukɔ siwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo ɖoe koŋ yi edzi xea mɔ ɖe mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe ablɔɖe nu megbemakpɔmakpɔe. "

Every year since 2004, the U.S. Department of State has designated Eritrea as a "country of particular concern, " which refers to "any country whose government engages in or tolerates particularly severe violations of religious freedom that are systematic, ongoing and egregious. "
Amegbetɔwo Ƒe Gomenɔamesinyawo Gbɔkpɔha tsi dzi vevie le ale si "Eritrea dziɖuɖumegãwo yi edzi le afɔkpo tum woƒe dukɔmeviwo ƒe gomenɔamesiwo " la ŋu.
The United Nations Human Rights Council has expressed deep concern at the "grave violations of human rights by the Eritrean authorities against their own population and fellow citizens. "
Ebia tso Eritrea dziɖuɖua si be wòade bubu "ame sia ame ƒe . . . tamebubu, dzitsinya, mawusubɔsubɔ kple dzixɔse ƒe ablɔɖe ŋu. "
It calls upon the Eritrean government "to respect everyone’s right to freedom . . . of thought, conscience and religion or belief. "
United States dukɔa ƒe Dukɔwo Dome Mawusubɔsubɔ Ƒe Ablɔɖe Gbɔkpɔha gblɔ le eƒe ƒe 2014 ƒe Ƒe Sia Ƒe Nyatakaka me be: "Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe ablɔɖe . . . ɖo afɔku me vevie ŋutɔ. "
The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom stated in its Annual Report for 2014: "The religious freedom situation is particularly grave for . . . Jehovah’s Witnesses. "

Amegbetɔ ƒe Gomenɔamesi Dzikpɔha gblɔ le eƒe Ƒe 2013 Xexea Me Ƒe Nyatakaka me be Eritrea dziɖuɖua gakpɔtɔ le mawusubɔsubɔha siwo dzi dziɖuɖua "meda asi ɖo o " la me tɔwo lém hele fu wɔm wo, eye Yehowa Ðasefowo koŋue wotɔ ŋkui.

In its World Report 2013, Human Rights Watch acknowledged that the Eritrean government continues to arrest, detain, and torture members of "unrecognized " religions and that "Jehovah’s Witnesses are especially victimized. "

Le December 2005 me la, Afrika Ƒe Amegbetɔwo Kple Dukɔwo Ƒe Gomenɔamesi Ƒe Hakplɔɖoɖowo da asi ɖe Nyametsotso Ku Ðe Amegbetɔ Ƒe Gomenɔamesinyawo Le Eritrea Ŋu dzi eye wòbia tso Eritrea dziɖuɖua si be "wòakpɔ egbɔ be wodrɔ̃ ʋɔnu amewo ameŋkumemakpɔtɔe, woana ame ƒe susu gbɔgblɔ kple nuƒoƒo kpakple kpekpewo wɔwɔ le ŋutifafa me ɣesiaɣi ƒe ablɔɖe amewo. "

In December 2005 the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights adopted Resolution on the Human Rights Situation in Eritrea, which called on Eritrea to "guarantee, at all times, the right to a fair trial, freedom of opinion and expression as well as the right to peaceful assembly. "

Philip Brumley, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe senyawo gbɔ kpɔla gbãtɔ na xexea me godoo gblɔ be: "Míele mɔ kpɔm vevie be Eritrea dziɖuɖua aɖe asi le Yehowa Ðasefo siwo katã le ga me la ŋu, tsɔ kpe ɖe ŋutsu etɔ̃ siawo siwo le ga me ƒe 20 ye nye esia la hã ŋu, eye woadzudzɔ míaƒe haxɔsetɔwo yome titi. "

Philip Brumley, general counsel for Jehovah’s Witnesses, spoke for Witnesses worldwide when he said: "It is our fervent hope that the government of Eritrea will release all Witness prisoners, including these three men who have been detained for 20 years, and bring an end to the persecution of our fellow believers. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Wu Woƒe Dɔwɔƒegã Yeyea Tutu Dɔa Ƒe Akpa Vevitɔ Nu
Jehovah’s Witnesses Complete Peak Construction Phase of New World Headquarters

NEW YORK Tso August (Dasiamime) va se ɖe October (Kele) 2015 me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo wu woƒe dɔwɔƒegã yeyea tutu ƒe dɔ si wode to me le Warwick le New York ƒe akpa vevitɔ nu, eye lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla 3,800 aɖewoe kpɔa gome le dɔa me gbe sia gbe.

NEW YORK From August to October 2015, the building of Jehovah’s Witnesses’ new world headquarters in Warwick, New York, was at peak construction, with 3,800 volunteer workers assisting with the project each day.
Esime dɔa ɖo eƒe ami me la, wotsɔ bɔsu siwo ade 40 lɔa lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla 3,800 aɖewo tsɔ yia dɔa wɔƒe galɔa wo yia wo nɔƒewo gbe sia gbe.
During peak construction, approximately 40 buses were used to help transport some 3,800 volunteers to and from the site each day.
Woɖaa nu na lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo le nuɖaƒe enyi siwo woɖo hena dɔa wɔwɔ.
As many as eight temporary dining rooms have been used to provide meals for the volunteers.
Tso esime wodze dɔa gɔme le July (Siamlɔm) 2013 me la, Ðasefo 18,000 kple edzivɔwo tso Amerika-dukɔa ƒe du vovovowo me kpɔ gome le dɔa me, wo dometɔ aɖewo tso keke Alaska kple Hawaii gɔ̃ hã.
Since breaking ground in July 2013, over 18,000 Witnesses have traveled from every state including Alaska and Hawaii to work on the project.

Dɔwɔla 400 va se ɖe 500 lɔƒo vaa dɔa wɔƒe le kwasiɖanuwuwu ɖe sia ɖe, eye esi woɖo dɔa ƒe ami me ya la, woƒe agbɔsɔsɔme dzi ɖe edzi va ɖo 700 kple edzivɔwo kwasiɖanuwuwu ɖe sia ɖe eye esia yi edzi kwasiɖa ene sɔŋ.

Approximately 400-500 workers arrive each weekend, although this jumped to well over 700 during the peak phase. A large part of the workforce has volunteered for assignments lasting from one to four weeks.
Aƒetɔ Richard Devine, si nye Ðasefowo ƒe Warwick Xɔtukɔmitia ƒe zimenɔla gblɔ be: "Esi wònye ame akpe geɖe vaa dɔa me gbe sia gbe ta la, ele be bɔbɔe be amewo nava sɔ gbɔ ɖe dɔa wɔƒe kpaŋkpaŋ.
Richard Devine, chairman of the Witnesses’ Warwick Construction Project Committee (CPC), explains: "With thousands of people on the job each day, worksites could easily get overcrowded.
Eya ta míeɖe ame 400 le ŋkekemedɔwɔlawo dzi be woawɔ dɔ tso ŋdɔ ga 3 va se ɖe fɔŋli ga 2 ale be nuwo nanɔ ɖoɖo nu le dɔa wɔƒe. "
To keep things organized and efficient, we took about 400 from the day shift and assigned them to work from 3 p.m. to 2 a.m. "
Ame siawo wɔ dɔ tso May (Damɛ) va se ɖe September (Anyɔnyɔ).
That second shift lasted from May through September.
Woɖe foto afi si anye Ðasefowo ƒe dɔwɔƒegã yeyea ƒe mɔnu la le anyinufaɣi.
A view at sunset of what will be the main entrance to the Witnesses’ new world headquarters complex.
Aƒetɔ Richard Devine gblɔ be woawu mlɔƒe eneawo dometɔ eve tututu nu le January (Dzove) 2016 me abe ale si woɖoe ene.
The CPC reports that two of the four residence buildings will be completed by January 2016, as originally planned.
Aƒetɔ Devine gagblɔ be, "ale si ame gbogbo aɖewo kpe asi ɖe dɔa ŋu ta la, dɔ bliboa do ŋgɔ na ɣeyiɣi si wòle be wòawu enu la ɣleti ene sɔŋ. "
However, according to Mr. Devine, "the overall project is four months ahead of schedule thanks to what has been a huge coordinated effort. "
Woɖoe be woawu mlɔƒe susɔeawo, dɔwɔxɔawo kple nudzraɖoƒea nu le September (Anyɔnyɔ) 1, 2016 dzi.
The remaining residence, office, and maintenance buildings are now scheduled for completion by September 1, 2016.
Dɔwɔƒegã yeye tuƒe si wonɔ yame ɖe foto.
Aerial view of the new world headquarters site.

Ðasefowo Te Woƒe Teƒe Siwo Le Brooklyn Dzadzra
Witnesses Begin Highly Anticipated Sale of Brooklyn Properties
NEW YORK Yehowa Ðasefowo le woƒe teƒe siwo le Dumbo kple Brooklyn Heights si le Brooklyn le New York, siwo amewo le mɔ kpɔm na vevie be yewoaƒle la dzram.
NEW YORK Jehovah’s Witnesses are selling some of the most sought-after properties in Dumbo and Brooklyn Heights in Brooklyn, New York.

Asiƒoƒo ƒe wɔnawo dze egɔme ku ɖe teƒe si nye 85 Jay Street si nye Brooklyn ƒe akpa gãtɔ siwo dzi womewɔ dɔ ɖo o la dometɔ ɖeka kple mlɔƒe si nye dziƒoxɔ dzisasrã-ewo si le 124 Columbia Heights la ŋu.
The competitive offering process has begun for 85 Jay Street, one of Brooklyn’s largest undeveloped sites, and the ten-story residence at 124 Columbia Heights.
Wole afi si woƒe dɔwɔƒegã le fifia si nye 25/30 Columbia Heights la hã dzram.
The current location of their world headquarters, 25/30 Columbia Heights, is also on the market.
Gbetakpɔxɔ Habɔbɔa Ƒe Nunɔamesiwo Dzadzra Ƒe Dɔwɔƒee le teƒe etɔ̃ siawo dzadzra ƒe ɖoɖoa dzi kpɔm, eye wokpɔ mɔ be adzra wo vovovo.
The three properties are being offered by the Watchtower Real Estate Office and are expected to sell in separate transactions.

Richard Devine, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela aɖe, gblɔ tso anyigba si ƒe kekeme nye meta 12,500 togodo si le 85 Jay Street ŋu be: "Teƒea xɔ Dumbo-nutoa ƒe akpa gã aɖe eye teƒe si woxɔ mɔɖeɖe be woate ŋu awɔ dɔ ɖo la keke meta 93,000 togodo kloe. "

Richard Devine, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses, states concerning the 135,000-square-foot (12,542 sq m) parcel at 85 Jay Street: "The site spans an entire city block in the dynamic Dumbo neighborhood and has nearly one million square feet of development rights. "
Teƒe si nye 85 Jay Street la le Manhattan Ana gbɔ le Dumbo-nuto si me amewo sɔa gbɔ ɖo fũu.
The 85 Jay Street property sits at the base of the Manhattan Bridge in the vibrant Dumbo neighborhood.
Ðasefowo ƒe mlɔƒe aɖe le teƒe si keke meta 14,000 togodo le 124 Columbia Heights si le afi si amewo ɖia tsa le le Brooklyn Heights nuto ɖedzesi la me.
The Witnesses’ 152,000-square-foot (14,121 sq m) residential building at 124 Columbia Heights is located on the promenade in the acclaimed Brooklyn Heights Historic District.
Aƒetɔ Devine gblɔ be: "Enye xɔ ɖedzesi aɖe, eye ne wole Brooklyn Ana dzi, Ablɔɖe Ƒe Kpetata kple Anyigbe Manhattan kpɔe la, enya kpɔna ŋutɔ. "
"It’s a remarkable building with spectacular views of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty, and the impressive Lower Manhattan skyline, " states Mr. Devine.
Xɔ si nye 124 Columbia Heights le Brooklyn Heights nuto ɖedzesi la me.
124 Columbia Heights is located in the historic Brooklyn Heights neighborhood.

Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dɔwɔƒegã la le 25/30 Columbia Heights (foto etametɔ) ƒe geɖee nye esia, eye New York dua me tɔ geɖewo nyae nyuie le Gbetakpɔxɔ ƒe dzesi ɖedzesi la kple gaƒoɖokui si le afi ma la ta.
The world headquarters of Jehovah’s Witnesses has been located at 25/30 Columbia Heights (top image) for decades and is familiar to many New Yorkers for its marquee Watchtower sign and clock.
Xɔ sia xɔ teƒe si keke wu meta 68,000 togodo la xɔ dua ƒe xɔ tsrala eve kloe xɔƒe, eye ame siwo le Brooklyn Ana dzi la tea ŋu kpɔnɛ nyuie.
The property, totaling over 733,000 square feet (68,098 sq m), covers almost two city blocks and offers unobstructed views of the Brooklyn Bridge.
Aƒetɔ Devine gblɔ tso taɖodzinu vevitɔ si le Ðasefoawo si ŋu be, "Teƒe siawo dzadzra nye ɖoɖo si míewɔ be míaɖe míaƒe dɔwɔƒegã la ayi Warwick le New York ƒe akpa aɖe ko. "
Commenting on the larger scope of the Witnesses’ plans, Mr. Devine adds, "These sales are the next steps in relocating our world headquarters to Warwick, New York. "
Ne èdi nyatakaka bubuwo tso xɔ siawo dzadzra ŋu la, yi míaƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye www.WatchtowerBrooklynRealEstate.com.
For further details on the properties, please see the website www.WatchtowerBrooklynRealEstate.com.
Gbebiamewo kple fotowo li, eye àte ŋu abia woƒe hahokadodo ƒe dɔwɔƒe si nye Office of Public Information la woana wò.
Interviews and photographs are available upon request from the Office of Public Information.
Wona Nunana Ðasefowo Le Biblia-fiafiadɔ Siwo Wɔm Wole Le Mexico-gaxɔwo Me Ta
Witnesses Awarded for Bible Education Work in Mexico Prisons
MEXICO CITY Baja California nuto si le Mexico ƒe dumegãwo na ɖaseɖigbalẽ Yehowa Ðasefowo tsɔ da akpe na wo ɖe Biblia-fiafiadɔ siwo wɔm wole le nutoa me gaxɔwo me la ta.
MEXICO CITY Officials from the state of Baja California, Mexico, presented Jehovah’s Witnesses with a certificate of appreciation for their Bible education work in state penitentiaries.
Nutoa me hahodedienɔnɔ ƒe amegã Daniel De La Rosa Anaya kple gaxɔdzikpɔƒewo ƒe amegã Jesús Héctor Grijalva Tapia woe de asi agbalẽ la te.
The document was signed by state secretary of public security, Daniel De La Rosa Anaya, and by secretary of the state penitentiary system, Jesús Héctor Grijalva Tapia.

Ðaseɖigbalẽa me nyawo yi ale: "Nutoa me dziɖuɖua to hahodedienɔnɔ ƒe amegã dzi le akpe dam na Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖe dɔ vevi si wɔm wole tsɔ le alɔ dom mí, woƒe kutrikuku, woƒe dɔa kple ale si woɖoe kplikpaa be yewoana kpekpeɖeŋu Baja California nutoa me tɔwo ta; wona be gamenɔlawo va le ame ɖɔʋuwo zum eye ne wodo le gaxɔa me la, enɔa bɔbɔe na wo be woawɔ ɖeka kple nutoa me tɔwo. "

The certificate reads: "The state government, through the secretary of public security, grants appreciation to Jehovah’s Witnesses for their invaluable support, dedication, work, and commitment to the Baja California community; contributing to the enhancement of the quality of life and thereby strengthening social reintegration. "
Asitɔtrɔ Le Gamenɔlawo Ŋu ƒe dɔwɔƒe si le Mexicali ƒe amegã Jesús Manuel López Moreno
Director of the Social Rehabilitation Center in Mexicali, Jesús Manuel López Moreno.

Yehowa Ðasefowo dze gaxɔmenɔlawo gbɔ yiyi le gaxɔ siwo le Baja California nutoa me dometɔ geɖe me kple gaxɔ ɖeka aɖe si le Mexicali me edziedzi tso ƒe 1991 me esime gaxɔmenɔla aɖe bia tso wo si be woava kpɔ ye ɖa.
Jehovah’s Witnesses regularly visit several penitentiaries in Baja California, including one in Mexicali, which they began visiting in 1991 after receiving an inquiry from an inmate.

Le gbebiame aɖe si yi edzi le Ðasefoawo kple Asitɔtrɔ Le Gamenɔlawo Ŋu ƒe dɔwɔƒe si le Mexicali ƒe amegã Jesús Manuel López Moreno dome la, egblɔ be: "Ale si mievaa afi sia vanaa kpekpeɖeŋu [gamenɔlawo] la, kpena ɖe mía ŋu míenaa ŋusẽ ɖoa wo ŋu wotea ŋu gblɔna be: ‘Amegbetɔwoe míenye.

In an interview with the Witnesses, director of the Social Rehabilitation Center in Mexicali, Jesús Manuel López Moreno, stated: "Your coming here and caring for those [inmates] supports us in giving them the strength to say: ‘We are human beings.
Nɔnɔme nyuiwo va su mía si, eye ne míaƒe game de la, míagawɔ ɖeka kple nutoa me tɔwo eye ele be míaƒe nuwɔnawo naɖe vi na wo.’ . . .
We have value because, when the time comes, we are going to reintegrate ourselves into society and we must be productive in it.’ . . .
Meda akpe gã aɖe na mi ɖe miaƒe kpekpeɖeŋua ta. "
I am infinitely grateful for your support. "

Aƒetɔ Gamaliel Camarillo, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Mexico gblɔ be: "Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dɔ vevitɔe nye be yewoakpe ɖe amewo ŋu, gaxɔmenɔlawo hã le eme, ne woase Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo gɔme.
Gamaliel Camarillo, spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Mexico, says: "The primary work of Jehovah’s Witnesses is to help people, including prisoners, understand what the Bible teaches.
Hame aɖe si le Mexicali gblɔ be ame enyi ya teti xɔ nyɔnyrɔ zu Yehowa Ðasefowo esime wole ga me le Mexicali gaxɔ me.
A local congregation in Mexicali reports that at least eight individuals have been baptized as Jehovah’s Witnesses while serving their sentences in the Mexicali penitentiary.
Míexɔe se be ele be woana mɔnukpɔkpɔ amewo katã ƒomevi be Biblia-fiafiadɔa naɖe vi na wo. "
We believe that people of all backgrounds should be given the opportunity to benefit from Bible education.
Ðasefo Siwo Le Ghana Tso Kpla Na Kpekpeɖeŋu Esi Tsi Ðɔ Ðe Amewo
Witnesses in Ghana Immediately Respond After Flooding

ACCRA, Ghana Le August (Dasiamime) 2015 ƒe nuwuwu la, Yehowa Ðasefowo wu kpekpeɖeŋunana ame siwo ƒe nuwo tsi ɖe le Ghana ƒe fiadu Accra me la nu. Tsiɖɔɖɔ dziŋɔ aɖe gblẽ amewo ƒe nunɔamesiwo kple aƒewo dome eye ame 200 kple edzivɔ ƒe agbe tsi eme.
ACCRA, Ghana At the end of August 2015, Jehovah’s Witnesses completed their relief efforts in Ghana’s capital, Accra, where severe flooding devastated property and killed more than 200 people.
Nutoa me Ðasefowo le asi fiam afi si tsia va ɖo le woƒe haxɔsetɔ aɖe ƒe aƒe me.
Local Witnesses point to the waterline on the house of a displaced fellow worshipper.
Togbɔ be Ðasefo aɖeke ƒe agbe metsi eme o hã la, tsiɖɔɖɔa na be wo dometɔ 250 aɖewo ʋu le woƒe aƒewo me.
While no Witnesses lost their lives, some 250 were displaced by the floods.

Le June (Masa) 4, 2015, si nye tsiɖɔɖɔa ƒe ŋufɔke dzi la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Ghana ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti aɖe anyi, eye kɔmitia biã ŋku ɖe kpekpeɖeŋu siwo ameawo hiã kpata la nana ŋu, wotsɔ kuntruwo, avɔwo kple tsi yi na ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le.

On June 4, 2015, the day after the flooding, the branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Ghana set up a disaster relief committee, which focused on caring for individuals’ immediate needs by providing blankets, clothing, and water.
Kɔmitia wɔ ɖoɖo hã wodzra aƒe siwo tsi ɖe la hã ɖo.
The relief committee also arranged to clean and repair flooded residences.
Ðasefo siwo le Accra-nutoa me hã kpe asi ɖe dɔ sia ŋu, esi wona woƒe haxɔsetɔ siwo tsi ɖe la va tsi woƒe aƒewo me gbɔ.
Witnesses in the Accra area assisted by opening their homes temporarily to accommodate displaced fellow believers.
Aƒetɔ Dossou Amevor (le miame ɖaa) si nye Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitia ƒe zimenɔla le beliwo mama dɔ si wode to me le Atiman Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me le Madina le Accra la dzi kpɔm.
Disaster relief committee chairman, Dossou Amevor (far left) supervises the distribution of mattresses at the Atiman Kingdom Hall in Madina, Accra.
Tsiɖɔɖɔa na mɔmemidzraƒe aɖe lé dzo le Adabraka eye pɔmpikawo dome gblẽ, si wɔe be nuto ma me tɔwo megakpɔ tsi azã o.
Flooding caused an explosion at a petrol station that damaged pipes in Adabraka, cutting off the area’s water supply.
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒea tsɔ tsigo gã aɖe va da ɖe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata (tadeaguƒe) si le Adabraka la me, ale be Ðasefoawo kple woƒe aƒelikawo nakpɔ tsi azã.
The branch office set up a water tank at the Adabraka Kingdom Hall (a place of worship) for the Witnesses and their neighbors.

Le Memleɖa, June (Masa) 6 dzi la, alɔdzedɔwɔƒea dɔ atikewɔlawo ƒe hatsotso eve ɖo ɖe teƒeawo, ɖɔkita atɔ̃ kple dɔnɔdzikpɔla eve siwo katã nye Ðasefowo kpɔ woƒe haxɔsetɔwo kple ame bubu siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le le nuto siwo woyɔna be Alajo kple Adabraka me la gbɔ.
On Saturday, June 6, the branch office dispatched two medical teams, a total of five Witness doctors and two nurses, to care for their fellow worshippers and other victims in Alajo and Adabraka.
Wokpɔ lãmesẽnya vovovowo gbɔ, ɖewo nye asrã alo atikesi, akɔtadɔ eye ɖewo hã mitsinyenye.
They treated a variety of health issues, such as malaria, chest infections, and diarrhea.
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒea ƒe teƒenɔlawo kple Ðasefo siwo le nutoa me hã yi ɖakpɔa woƒe haxɔsetɔwo ɖa eye wogblɔa Biblia me nyawo tsɔ dea dzi ƒo na wo hefaa akɔ na wo.
Representatives of the branch office and local Witnesses also visited their fellow worshippers to provide spiritual and emotional comfort.
Woɖe foto ɖɔkita atɔ̃ kple dɔnɔdzikpɔla eve siwo katã nye Ðasefowo la le Adabraka Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me, eye afi siae wokpɔ dɔnɔawo gbɔ le.
Three Witness doctors and two nurses pictured inside the Adabraka Kingdom Hall, which was used as a treatment facility.
Aƒetɔ Nathaniel Gbedemah, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Ghana gblɔ be: "Nu siwo gbegbe dome Accra tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ kple ame siwo gbegbe ƒe agbe tsi eme la te ɖe mía dzi ŋutɔ.
Spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Ghana, Nathaniel Gbedemah, comments: "We are pained by the destruction and loss of life caused by the flooding in Accra.
Abe ale si Yehowa Ðasefowo wɔe le nuto bubuwo me ene la, míele nu siwo katã míate ŋui la wɔm le seselelãme, ŋutilã me kple gbɔgbɔ me kpekpeɖeŋu nam ame siwo ŋuti tsiɖɔɖɔ sia gblẽ nu le. "
As Jehovah’s Witnesses have done in other parts of the world, we are doing all we can to respond to the emotional, physical, and spiritual needs of those in our community affected by this disaster. "
Nunyalagãwo Meda Asi Ðe Ale Si Russia Xe Mɔ Ðe JW.ORG Nu Dzi O
Experts Object to Russia’s Banning of JW.ORG
ST.
ST.

PETERSBURG, Russia​ Le July (Siamlɔm) 21, 2015 dzi la, Russia Dziɖuɖua ɖo asi Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org dzi, eye esia wɔe be woabu ame sia ame si ade dzi ƒo na amewo be woazã nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia le Russia-dukɔa me nu vlo wɔlae.
PETERSBURG, Russia On July 21, 2015, the Russian Federation banned jw.org, the official website of Jehovah’s Witnesses, making it a criminal offense to promote it from within the federation.
Le xexea me godoo la, Russia ɖeka koe xe mɔ ɖe jw.org nu.
Russia is the only country in the world to ban jw.org.

Aƒetɔ Yekaterina Elbakyan, si nye subɔsubɔhawo ŋuti nunyala kple nufialagã le Dɔwɔnyawo Kple Hadomegbenɔnɔ Suku si le Moscow gblɔ tso jw.org ŋu be: "Mekpɔe be nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia le vevie, elabe afi siae nàkpɔ nya siwo Yehowa Ðasefowo ŋutɔ gblɔ tẽe tso woƒe habɔbɔa ŋu le, ke menye tso segblɔtɔwo gbɔ o. . . .

Religious studies specialist and professor at the Academy of Labor and Social Relations in Moscow, Yekaterina Elbakyan, comments on jw.org: "I think the website is necessary because it contains objective information directly from Jehovah’s Witnesses about their organization rather than third-party opinions. . . .
Woƒe hameviwo kpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia ŋu, eye ame siwo tsɔa ɖe le subɔsubɔha vovovowo me hã kpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe eŋu.
Not only are its members interested in the website, but also those who are simply interested in various religions.
Menye subɔsubɔhawo ŋuti nunyalawo abe nye ene koe mewɔnɛ o, ke boŋ nyakakadɔwɔlawo kple agbalẽŋlɔla siwo ŋlɔa nu tso subɔsubɔhawo ŋu hã tsɔ ɖe le eme vevie. "
And I’m not only speaking about professional religious scholars like myself but also journalists and publicists who write about religion. "

"Mekpɔe be nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia le vevie, elabe afi siae nàkpɔ nya siwo Yehowa Ðasefowo ŋutɔ gblɔ tẽe tso woƒe habɔbɔa ŋu le. "​ Aƒetɔ Yekaterina Elbakyan, Nufialagã le Dɔwɔnyawo Kple Hadomegbenɔnɔ Suku si le Moscow
"I think the website is necessary because it contains objective information directly from Jehovah’s Witnesses " Yekaterina Elbakyan, Professor, Academy of Labor and Social Relations, Moscow

Aƒetɔ Lev Levinson si nye senyawo ŋuti nunyala bibi aɖe le Amegbetɔ Ƒe Gomenɔamesinyawo Ƒe Dɔwɔƒe le Moscow gblɔ ale si dziɖuɖua ƒe nuwɔna sia ɖi nane si dzɔ kpɔ va yi la ale: "Egbegbe ƒe alafa 21 lia me Russia ƒe dukplɔse na mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe ablɔɖe kple habɔbɔ hena mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe sɔsɔminasɔe ƒe gome amewo.

A legal expert at the Human Rights Institute in Moscow, Lev Levinson, puts this action by the government in historical context: "Twenty-first century Russia has a constitution that guarantees freedom of religion and equality of religious associations before the law.
Gake abe ale si Russia wɔe le ƒe alafa 19 lia me ene la, egale mawunyagbɔgblɔ ƒe ablɔɖe xɔm le dukɔmeviwo si to woƒe agbalẽwo xɔxɔ kple mɔxexe ɖe woƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒea nu me.
However, as in the 19th century, Russia is again restricting the freedom of sharing one’s religious views by confiscating literature and banning websites.
Eye ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo kple nunyalagãwoe trɔ gbo sea tsɔ le nu siawo wɔm tso vɔ nɔ gbɔgblɔm be ɖe wole avu wɔm kple ame siwo dea aglãdzedze ƒe dzi ƒo. "
And this is all being done by judges and experts who apply unlawful regulations under the guise of counteracting extremism. "
Mɔxexe ɖe nyatakakadzraɖoƒea nu ƒe nya sia nye senya si gɔme wodze tso ƒe 2013 me la dzi yiyi.
The ban is the latest development in a legal battle stretching back to 2013.
Le August (Dasiamime) 7 dzi le ƒe ma me la, Russia ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe sue aɖe drɔ̃ nya la le adzame hetso nya me be nyatakakadzraɖoƒea "dea aglãdzedze ƒe dzi ƒo. "
On August 7 of that year, a Russian district court declared the website "extremist " during a secret trial, but that decision was reversed by a regional court on January 22, 2014.
Ke hã Russia Nyagbugbɔdrɔ̃ƒea ƒe Amesamala ƒe Kpeɖeŋutɔ bia tso Russia-dukɔa ƒe Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔ si be wòagbugbɔ ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe suea ƒe nyametsotsoa aɖo te.
However, a Deputy of the Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation appealed to the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation to reinstate the trial decision.
Le December (Dzome) 2, 2014 dzi la, Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔ gbugbɔ drɔ̃ nya la evɔ Yehowa Ðasefowo menɔ kodzoa me aʋli wo ɖokuiwo ta o, elabena womena nyanya wo ale si dze o.
On December 2, 2014, the Supreme Court heard the prosecution’s appeal without the Witnesses present to defend themselves, as they were not properly notified of the hearing.

Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔ de ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe suetɔ ƒe nyametsotsoa dzi eye wògblɔ be nu siwo katã le nyatakakadzraɖoƒea "dea aglãdzedze ƒe dzi ƒo " togbɔ be ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒea ŋutɔ lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be mawusubɔsubɔgbalẽ siwo nu dziɖuɖua de se ɖo la mele nyatakakadzraɖoƒea o hã.

The Supreme Court reinstated the trial decision, declaring the entire website "extremist " although the court conceded that the website no longer contained any religious material prohibited by the Russian authorities.
Ðasefoawo meda asi ɖe nyametsotso sia dzi o eye wobia tso Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔa ƒe zimenɔla si be wòagbugbɔ ŋku alé ɖe nya sia ŋu na yewo, gake ɖeko wògbe.
The Witnesses contested the decision and appealed to the chairman of the Supreme Court, but without success.

Le nyametsotso sia ta la, Russia Dukɔa Ƒe Dudɔwɔƒe Si Kpɔa Ʋɔnudrɔ̃nyawo Gbɔ bu nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia de Agbalẽ Siwo Dziɖuɖua Buna Be Wodea Aglãdzedze Ƒe Dzi Ƒo me le July (Siamlɔm) 21, 2015 dzi eye wòde se ɖe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia nu le Russia dukɔ bliboa me.
As a result of that decision, on July 21, 2015, the Ministry of Justice of the Russian Federation added the website to the Federal List of Extremist Materials, banning the website throughout Russia.
Aƒetɔ Yaroslav Sivulskiy, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Russia gblɔ nu si gbegbe nyametsotso sia gblẽ la ale: "Ete ɖe mía dzi ŋutɔ be Russia dziɖuɖumegãwo ɖe afɔ sia si mehiã hafi o la.
Yaroslav Sivulskiy, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia, comments on the impact of the ban: "We are disappointed that the Russian authorities have taken this unwarranted action.
Mɔxeɖenu sia do kplamatsɛ Yehowa Ðasefo 170,000 kple edzivɔ siwo le dukɔa me godoo la ƒe mawusubɔsubɔ.
This ban curtails the worship of over 170,000 in this country who are Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Gake ne èbu ame 285,000 siwo ʋua nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia gbe sia gbe le Russia ŋu la, àkpɔe kɔtɛe be wona Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃ ƒe mɔnu nyui sia le ame siwo menye míaƒe haxɔsetɔwo o gɔ̃ hã la ŋu tom. "

But when you consider that some 285,000 people in Russia accessed the website every day, it is clear that even those who are not members of our faith have been deprived of an excellent resource for Bible study. "

Aƒetɔ J. R. Brown, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le xexea me godoo gblɔ le woƒe dɔwɔƒegã le Brooklyn le New York be: "Nu siwo le míaƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org la dometɔ aɖewoe nye video siwo ta woxɔ nunana ɖo, Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ siwo le gbe alafa geɖewo me, kple Gbetakpɔxɔ kpakple Nyɔ! siwo nye magazine eve siwo womana wu le xexea me godoo.

Speaking from the Witnesses’ world headquarters in Brooklyn, New York, J. R. Brown, an international spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses, states: "Our official website, jw.org, hosts award-winning videos, publications for Bible study in hundreds of languages, and the two most widely distributed magazines in the world, The Watchtower and Awake!
Woɖenɛ fiana le dukɔwo dome agbalẽɖeɖefia ƒe wɔna gãwo me eye wozãnɛ geɖe le sukuwo hã me.
It has been featured in some of the largest international book fairs and has even been used extensively in schools.
Eɖe vi na ame geɖewo le xexea me eye ame geɖewo hã zãnɛ le Russia-dukɔa me.
It has benefited many communities around the world and was widely used in Russia.
Le nyateƒe me la, ɖe wòle be woado alɔ nyatakakadzraɖoƒe sia hafi. "
Really, this is a website that should be promoted. "
Wowɔ Ŋkuɖodzikpe Aɖe Tsɔ Ðo Ŋku Ðasefo Austriatɔ Aɖe Si Nazitɔwo Wu Dzi, Nutodzikpɔla Ƒe Nuƒo Vevi
Plaque Unveiled for Austrian Witness Executed by Nazis, District Mayor Key Speaker
Vienna ƒe nuto si nye Meidling dzi kpɔla Gabriele Votava le nuƒo si me wòɖe nu le ŋkuɖodzikpea dzi le la ƒom.
Gabriele Votava, mayor of Vienna’s Meidling District, delivering the unveiling speech.

VIENNA​ Le May (Damɛ) 13, 2015 dzi la, ame 400 aɖewo de wɔna aɖe si me woɖe nu le ŋkuɖodzikpe aɖe dzi le. Wowɔ ŋkuɖodzikpe sia tsɔ ɖo ŋku Gerhard Steinacher, si nye Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe si Nazitɔwo wu ƒe 75 aɖewoe nye esia esi wògbe be yemaɖo Germania-ʋakɔa me o la dzi.

VIENNA On May 13, 2015, some 400 attended the unveiling of a plaque dedicated to Gerhard Steinacher, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, who was executed 75 years ago by the Nazis for refusing to join the German army.

Dukɔa ƒe fiadu Vienna ƒe nuto si nye Meidling dzi kpɔla Gabriele Votava ƒo nuƒo vevi aɖe eye wòɖe nu le ŋkuɖodzikpe si woklã ɖe Steinacher ƒomea ƒe aƒe tsãtɔ si le Meidling le Vienna le Lägenfeldgasse 68 ƒe mɔnu.

The mayor of Vienna’s Meidling District, Gabriele Votava, was the key speaker at the curbside unveiling of the plaque affixed to the outside of the Steinacher family’s former residence in Meidling, Vienna at Lägenfeldgasse 68.
Wɔnaa ƒe tanyae nye "Nyemate ŋu ada tu o. " Nya siae aƒetɔ Steinacher gblɔ esime wònɔ biabiam be woakpɔ nublanui na ye.
The program bore the theme "I just can’t shoot, " the explanation Mr. Steinacher uttered during his petition for clemency.
Nya ʋɛ mawo ɖe nu geɖe fia tso Kristotɔwo ƒe dzixɔse siwo me aƒetɔ Steinacher lé ɖe asi vevie la ŋu, esiawo dometɔ ɖekae nye nya si Yesu gblɔ le Mateo 19:19 be: "Lɔ̃ hawòvi abe wò ŋutɔ ɖokuiwò ene. "
Those simple words speak volumes about the Christian values Mr. Steinacher held dear, such as Jesus’ words found at Matthew 19:19: "You must love your neighbor as yourself. "
Esrɔ̃a Biblia tso eƒe ɖevime ke.
As a youth, Gerhard was a student of the Bible.
Esi wòxɔ ƒe 17 la, etiae be yeazu Yehowa Ðasefo.
When he was 17, he decided to become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Le September (Anyɔnyɔ) 15, 1939 dzi la, wolé aƒetɔ Steinacher le esi wògbe be yemawɔ asrafodɔ o le dzitsinya ta kple ale si wògbe be yemaka atam be yeawɔ nuteƒe na Hitler o la ta.
On September 15, 1939, Mr. Steinacher was arrested for conscientiously objecting to military service and for refusing to swear the oath of loyalty to Hitler.
Esi wolé aƒetɔ Steinacher de ga kwasiɖa ade le Vienna megbe la, wokplɔe yi Moabit-gaxɔ me le Berlin le Germany ale be wòanɔ afi ma va se ɖe esime woadrɔ̃ ʋɔnui.
After being imprisoned in Vienna for six weeks, Mr. Steinacher was transferred to pretrial detention at the Moabit prison in Berlin, Germany.
November (Adeɛmekpɔxe) 11, 1939 dzie wodze aƒetɔ Steinacher ƒe nya la dɔdrɔ̃ gɔme eye wotsɔ nya ɖe eŋu be ele kuvia dem lãme na amewo be womegawɔ aʋa la o eye wotso kufia nɛ.
On November 11, 1939, the first day of his first hearing, Mr. Steinacher was charged with subverting the war effort and sentenced to death row.
Eƒo koko na wo be woakpɔ nublanui na ye elabe yeƒe mawudzixɔsewo tae yegbe ɖo.
He petitioned for clemency based on his religious beliefs.
Gake le March (Tedoxe) 2, 1940 dzi la, Reichskriegsgericht (Nazi Dziɖuɖua Ƒe Asrafoʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe) da asi ɖe kufia si wotso nɛ la dzi.
However, on March 2, 1940, the Reichskriegsgericht (Reich Military Court) upheld the death sentence.
Le kwasiɖa ene megbe, le March (Tedoxe) 30 dzi la, wowu aƒetɔ Steinacher kple ametatsomɔ̃ le Plötzensee-gaxɔ dziŋɔ si le Berlin la me.
Four weeks later, on March 30, Mr. Steinacher was executed by guillotine at Berlin’s notorious Plötzensee prison.
Exɔ ƒe 19.
He was 19 years old.
Esi woɖe nu le ŋkuɖodzikpea dzi megbe la, wɔnaa ƒe akpa susɔea yi edzi le Volkshochschule Fefewɔƒe si medidi tso afi ma o.
Following the plaque unveiling ceremony, the event continued at the nearby Volkshochschule Theater.
Nu siwo yi edzi le afi ma la dometɔ aɖee nye Steinacher ƒomea ƒe ŋutinyamenudzɔdzɔwo ɖeɖe fia.
Among the events scheduled was an exhibit that chronicled the Steinacher’s family history.

Le ɖeɖefia ɖeka me la, woɖe aɖakavi aɖe si ŋu wova ke ɖo le ƒe 1976 me la fia. Lɛta 28 siwo aƒetɔ Ignatz kple Luise Steinacher ɖo ɖe wo viŋutsua la le aɖakavi sia me. Eye nyuidinamegbalẽvi 25 kple lɛta siwo Gerhard hã ŋlɔ tsɔ fa akɔ na edzilawo heka ɖe edzi na wo be yealé nu siwo dzi yewoxɔ se me ɖe asi goŋgoŋ la hã le aɖakavia me.

One of the displays featured a small box found in 1976 containing 28 letters from Ignatz and Luise Steinacher written to their son Gerhard while he was in prison as well as 25 postcards and letters that Gerhard wrote to comfort his parents and express his conviction in their shared faith.
Esi Gerhard dada Luise ku le ƒe 1976 me la, wokpɔ aɖakavi sia si me lɛtawo kple nyuidinamegbalẽviwo le la le Steinacher ƒomea ƒe aƒe me.
When Gerhard’s mother, Luise, died in 1976, this box of letters and postcards was found at the Steinacher home.

Wogblɔ le nyati aɖe si dze le nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si woyɔna be Wiener Bezirkszeitung, si wotana le Vienna kwasiɖa sia kwasiɖa me tso nudzɔdzɔ sia ŋu be "ŋkuɖodzi ɖedzesi aɖe ŋutɔe. " Wogblɔ be ŋkuɖodzi sia ɖe aƒetɔ Steinacher ƒe kalẽwɔwɔ tso "viviti me va kekeli me. "

Reporting on the event, an article in Wiener Bezirkszeitung, a weekly Vienna newspaper, describes it as a "remarkable memorial " that brought Mr. Steinacher’s courageous actions "out of the shadows and into the light. "
Wogakafu aƒetɔ Steinacher le nyatia me be: "Ele klalo be yeaku ɖe yeƒe dzixɔsewo ta​ dzixɔse mawo tututu nue wònɔ agbe ɖo. "
The article further extols Mr. Steinacher by stating: "He was prepared to die for his principles the very principles that he lived for. "
Gaƒoƒo ʋɛ aɖewo do ŋgɔ na aƒetɔ Gerhard Steinacher wuwu la, eŋlɔ kaklãnalɛta siawo ɖo ɖe edzilawo (egɔmeɖeɖe dze le ete).
Just hours before his execution, Gerhard Steinacher wrote this farewell letter to his parents (translation below).
Nazitɔwo tututu fli etɔ̃ le lɛta la me.
Three lines were censored by the Nazis.
Nɔnye kple Tɔnye lɔlɔ̃awo,
Dear Mother and Father,
Nya boo megali magblɔ o.
Well, there is no point in saying much.
Wogblɔ nam gaƒoƒo eve aɖewoe nye esi va yi le zã ga 7 me be woawum etsɔ ŋdi ga 5 miniti 50.
I was informed two hours ago, at 7:00 p.m., that I’m to be executed tomorrow at 5:50 a.m.
Gamea de azɔ, Aƒetɔ do ŋusẽm, ɛ̃, gbɔgbɔ la le lɔlɔ̃m, gake ŋutilã ya gbɔdzɔ.
The moment has arrived, Lord give me strength, yes, the spirit is willing but the flesh is weak.
Menɔ anyi ɖe nye gaxɔa me afi sia, eƒo zã 1:00 fifia, ŋutsu eve aɖewo hã le gbɔnye afi sia, du dzi ko gamea le, mele lɛta sia ŋlɔm vivivi, ne nane va susu me nam ko la, meŋlɔnɛ.
I am sitting here in a cell, it’s about 1:00 a.m., two other men are in here with me, time is rushing by, I am writing this letter in stages as things come to mind.
Gota faa miamiamia, sno gale dzadzam.
It’s cold outside, snowing again.
Aƒetɔ la nedo ŋusẽ mi.
May the Lord give you strength.
Medi be mawɔ dɔ, eye meŋlɔ agbalẽ hegblɔe kple nu hã be medi be mawɔ dɔ sesĩe eye makpɔ dzidzeme blibo hã.
I want to work and I’ve promised both orally and in writing that I will work ambitiously and be completely content.
Gake nyemate ŋu ada tu ya o, eye nya sia nya ku ɖe esia ŋu.
However, I just can’t shoot and everything revolves around this one point.
Azɔ Aƒetɔ la ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu neva eme; womate ŋu atɔ te nu si le dzɔdzɔ ge la o.
Now, let the Lord’s will take place; what is to happen cannot be stopped.
Mido ŋusẽ nu, migana esia nagbɔdzɔ mi o, ke boŋ mina esia nana miagalé ɖe mia nɔewo ŋu kplikplikpli wu, migana ta o.
Be strong, do not let this weaken you, but let it bring you closer together, do not give up.
Ðevi ko menye eye ne Aƒetɔ la do ŋusẽm ko hafi mate ŋu anɔ te ɖe esia nu, eye mele ebiam be wòado ŋusẽm.
I am still a child and I can only stand if the Lord grants me the strength, and I ask him to.
Mexɔ miaƒe lɛta mamlɛtɔ si dzi woŋlɔ ɖo be March 25.
I received your last letter marked March 25.
Esiae nye gbedoname 25 lia kple mamlɛtɔ si mexɔ tso mia gbɔ.
The 25th, the last greetings from you.
Eƒo ga 3 kple afã azɔ.
Now it’s around 3:30 a.m.
Nyemebui be atsɔ kaba alea o.
I never thought this would all happen so fast.
[Nazitɔwo tututu fli etɔ̃ le lɛta la me.] . . . ewɔ nuku ne mènya nu si adzɔ le miniti si kple esi kplɔe ɖo dome me o.
[Three lines have been censored by the Nazis] . . . surprise and so you never know what will happen from one minute to the next.
Woatsɔ nye nunɔamesiwo vae na mi.
You will get my belongings.
Nuŋlɔtiwo, agbalẽwo, ga kple awuwo, safui hekpe ɖe nu bubu aɖewo ŋu.
Pens, papers and letters, money and clothing, key, and some other things.
Meɖe kuku mido gbe na tɔgbuinye kple mamanye, Resi, Nyrui, Tasi, Tɔgbui kple Mama, aƒetɔ kple aƒenɔ Hock.
Please give my warmest greetings to my grandparents, Resi, Uncle, Aunt, Grandma and Grandpa, Mr. and Mrs. Hock.
Nye dɔwɔhatiwo katã, ame sia ame si dze sim kple nye ƒometɔwo katã.
To all my workmates, everyone who knows me and all my relatives.
Papa, lé dzi ɖe ƒo, mègana ta o, mègagbɔdzɔ o, ke boŋ lé wò xɔse la me ɖe asi sesĩe le nu sia nu me.
Father, be strong, do not give up, do not fall apart, but be strong in your faith as in everything else.
Eye wò Nɔnye, sẽ ŋu eye nànɔ te sesĩe, eye miado alɔ mia nɔewo.
And you, Mother, be strong and firm and support one another.
Miɖe kuku na Aƒetɔ la be wòakpɔ mia ta, ana ŋusẽ kple mɔkpɔkpɔ mi, eye wòafia mɔ mi le nu sia nu me ale be mianɔ mɔ dzɔdzɔe la dzi eye naneke magadzɔ ɖe mia dzi o.
Beg the Lord that he protects you, gives you power and hope and directs everything so that you stay on the right path and that nothing happens to you.
Nye hã mabiae ɖe mia ta.
I will also ask him on your behalf.
Esi gamea le aƒe tum la, mekpɔ ale si gbegbe míenye gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔtɔwo la dze sii.
As the hour draws closer, I really realize how weak we are.
Va se ɖe fifia la, mɔnukpɔkpɔ le ʋuʋu ɖi nam ɣesiaɣi be matrɔ susu.
Up to this point, I have always had the chance to change my mind.
Medi be mawɔ dɔ, gake ɖeko nyemate ŋu ada tu o.
I want to work, but I just can’t shoot.
Azɔ masee ɖe afi sia.
So now I will finish.
Papa kple Dada, medo gbe na mi eye megbugbɔ mi ƒãa, manye miaƒe Gerhard, si dina vevie be yeanɔ mia gbɔ la, ɖaa zi 100,000 kple edzivɔwo.
I greet and kiss you, dear Father and Mother, I will always be your Gerhard, 100,000 times over, who longed to be with you.
Va se ɖe esime míagakpɔ mía nɔewo le Fiaɖuƒe la me, afi si mí ame enea katã míawɔ ɖeka le.
Until we see each other again in the Kingdom, where all four of us will be together again.
Dzi nedzɔ mi.
Be of good cheer.
Medo gbe na mi vevie.
A million kisses.
Dumegã Siwo Le Canada Ƒe Dzigbenuto Saɖeagawo Me Da Akpe Na Yehowa Ðasefowo Ðe Biblia-fiafiadɔ Tɔxɛ Aɖe Ta
Officials in Remote Northern Canada Thank Jehovah’s Witnesses for Special Bible Education Campaign
TORONTO​ Yehowa Ðasefo siwo ade ame 150 kpɔ gome le Biblia-fiafiadɔ tɔxɛ aɖe si ƒe ɖoɖo Ðasefoawo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Canada wɔ le September (Anyɔnyɔ) kple October (Kele) 2014 me la me.
TORONTO About 150 Jehovah’s Witnesses participated in a special Bible education campaign, organized by the branch office of the Witnesses in Canada, in September and October of 2014.
Wowɔ ɖoɖo be woayi nuto saɖeaga 35 me le dukɔa me godoo.
Arrangements were made to visit 35 remote communities throughout the country.
Ame 32,000 kple edzivɔe le Inuit-tɔwo ƒe nuto 35 siwo gbɔ Ðasefoawo yi la me, nuto siawoe dze le amadede aŋutiɖiɖi la me.
Over 32,000 persons live in these 35 Inuit communities visited by the Witnesses, shown by the yellow markers.
Dɔa keke ta ɖo nuto eve me eye nuto ɖekae nye esia dze le afi sia.
The campaign stretched over two territories and one province, shown in green.

Woma Ðasefoawo ɖe ƒuƒoƒowo me be woawɔ dɔ le nuto si keke tso Aklavik, si le Dzieheɣetoɖoƒenuto me le ɣetoɖoƒe gome va se ɖe Kangiqsualujjuaq le Quebec si le ɣedzeƒe gome, nutoa ƒe didime anɔ kilometa 3,300 kple edzivɔ.

The Witnesses were organized into groups and assigned to visit towns and villages that extended from Aklavik, Northwest Territories, in the west to Kangiqsualujjuaq, Quebec, in the east, a region spanning over 3,300 kilometers (2,000 miles).
Ame siwo le gbeƒãɖeɖedɔ sia wɔm le dukɔa ƒe nutotroe siawo me ŋutɔwoe xe woƒe mɔzɔfewo, eye le ɖewo gome la, dɔlar gbogbo aɖewoe ame ɖeka xe.
Those participating in this outreach campaign cared for their own travel expenses including, in some cases, airline tickets that cost several thousands of dollars per person.
Du siwo me Ðasefoawo yi la dometɔ ɖekae nye Paulatuk.
One of the towns reached by the Witnesses was Paulatuk.
Ame 300 ye le eme eye wòle Beaufort Ƒuta ƒe Dzieheɣetoɖoƒenuto me.
It has a population of about 300 and is located on the shore of the Beaufort Sea in the northern region of the Northwest Territories.
Do ŋgɔ na dɔa la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe Dɔdzikpɔha da asi ɖe edzi be woaɖe video si nye Nu Ka Tae Wònyo Be Nàsrɔ̃ Biblia? gɔme ɖe Inuit-gbe me.
Prior to the campaign, the Governing Body of Jehovah’s Witnesses approved translation of the video Why Study the Bible? into Inuktitut.
Ame 35,000 aɖewoe doa gbe sia le Canada eye wònye gbe si wodona le Nunavut kple Canada ƒe Dzieheɣetoɖoƒenuto me.
This Inuit language is spoken by about 35,000 people in Canada and is recognized as an official language in Nunavut and the Northwest Territories.
Aƒenɔ Velma Illasiak, si nye suku aɖe ƒe tatɔ le Aklavik, ƒo nu tso Ðasefoawo ƒe vava ŋu ale: "Sukuviawo kpɔ dzidzɔ ɖe nu siwo miegblɔ na wo la ŋu ale gbegbe eye wole [wo] ŋu bum . . .
Ms. Velma Illasiak, a school principal in Aklavik, commented about the visit of the Witnesses: "The students really enjoyed the materials that you presented and are thinking about [them] . . .
Míele edam kpɔ be míadɔ agbalẽ si nye Nya Siwo Sɔhɛwo Biana Ƒe Ŋuɖoɖo Vavãwo (si le yevugbe me) la ƒe babla eveawo siaa na sɔhɛ ɖe sia ɖe le sukua . . .
We are considering ordering a copy of both volumes of the book Questions Young People Ask Answers That Work for each teenager in the school . . .
Akpe na mi be mieva míaƒe sukua kple míaƒe nutoa me. "
Thank you for your time at our school and in our community. "

Esi Aƒetɔ Peter Iyaituk, si nye dudzikpɔla le Quebec ƒe dzigbedu si nye Ivujivik me, ƒo nu kple Ðasefoawo eye wòkpɔ video si nye Nu Ka Tae Wònyo Be Nàsrɔ̃ Biblia? vɔ la, ekɔ Ðasefoawo ɖe eƒe ʋu me woɖi tsa le nutoa me.

After speaking with the Witnesses and watching the video Why Study the Bible?, Mr. Peter Iyaituk, the mayor of the northern Quebec town of Ivujivik, spent two hours touring the visitors around the community in his vehicle.
Egakɔ wo ɖe eƒe ʋu me yi yameʋudzeƒe le woƒe dzodzogbe hã eye wòda akpe na wo ɖe woƒe vava ta.
He also drove them to the airport on the day of their departure and thanked them for their visit.
David Creamore, si nye Yehowa Ðasefo la ɖe video si nye Nu Ka Tae Wònyo Be Nàsrɔ̃ Biblia? na Aƒetɔ Peter Iyaituk, si nye Ivujivik dudzikpɔla.
David Creamore, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, shows the video Why Study the Bible? to Mr. Peter Iyaituk, the mayor of Ivujivik.
Aƒetɔ Matthieu Rozon, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Canada gblɔ be: "Edzɔa dzi na Yehowa Ðasefowo be yewoafia Biblia ame sia ame.
Matthieu Rozon, spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Canada, states: "Jehovah’s Witnesses are happy to offer free Bible education to everyone.
Ame siwo kpɔ gome le dɔ sia me se le wo ɖokui me be yewozã yewoƒe ɣeyiɣi nyuie. "
Those who participated in this campaign felt it was well worth their time and effort. "
Le ɣleti eve siwo me Ðasefoawo wɔ dɔ sia me la, woma agbalẽ vovovo siwo wu 37,000.
During the two-month expedition, the Witnesses distributed over 37,000 pieces of literature.
Ame 600 kloe bia be Ðasefoawo nawɔ ɖoɖo be yewoayi Biblia me dzeɖoɖoa dzi.
Almost 600 individuals requested follow-up visits from the Witnesses to continue their Bible discussions.
Ðasefo Siwo Le Zimbabwe Le Ƒe 2015 "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
Witnesses in Zimbabwe Host 2015 "Imitate Jesus! "
Nutome Gã Takpekpewo Wɔm Le Dukɔwo Dome Takpekpe Ðedzesi Aɖe Si Wowɔ Ƒe Ðekae Nye Esia Megbe
Conventions One Year After Historic International Gathering
HARARE, Zimbabwe​ Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le Zimbabwe dze ƒe 2015 "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
HARARE, Zimbabwe Jehovah’s Witnesses in Zimbabwe launched the 2015 "Imitate Jesus! "
Nutome Gã Takpekpewo gɔme le Fiɖa, July (Siamlɔm) 31 lia dzi.
Regional Conventions on Friday, July 31.
Ŋkeke etɔ̃ ƒe wɔna sia ayi edzi kwasiɖa sia kwasiɖa hena kwasiɖa 12 sɔŋ va se ɖe October (Kele) ƒe domedome.
These three-day events are scheduled over 12 consecutive weeks through mid-October.
Geoffrey Jackson, si nye Dɔdzikpɔhaa me tɔ, le Biblia me nuƒo aɖe ƒom le ƒe 2014 dukɔwo dome takpekpea me le Zimbabwe.
Geoffrey Jackson, a member of the Governing Body, giving a Bible discourse during the 2014 international convention in Zimbabwe.
Ðasefo siwo nye dukɔa me tɔ eve le eƒe axa eveawo nɔ eƒe nyawo gɔme ɖem zi ɖeka na vavalawo.
He is flanked by two local Witnesses providing simultaneous translation.

Aƒetɔ John Hunguka, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Zimbabwe gblɔ be: "Amewo le mɔ kpɔm na ƒe sia me ƒe takpekpea vevie le dzidzedze gã si míekpɔ le ƒe 2014 dukɔwo dome takpekpe si míewɔ le Harare me la koŋ ta. Dukɔwo dome takpekpe ma nye wɔna ɖedzesi aɖe le Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le dukɔ sia me ƒe ŋutinya me. "

"Expectations are high for this year’s convention, " states John Hunguka, spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Zimbabwe, "largely due to the resounding success of our 2014 international convention in Harare, which was a milestone in the history of Jehovah’s Witnesses in this country. "

Zimbabwetɔwo ƒe nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ xɔŋkɔ aɖe si woyɔna be NewsDay ka nya ta be dukɔwo dome takpekpe siae nye "subɔsubɔwɔna gãtɔ kekeake " si wowɔ le dukɔ sia me kpɔ, eye wòna be Yehowa Ðasefowo va zu "ame siwo ŋu nyakakadɔwɔlawo yi edzi ƒo nu le wu " le ƒe 2014 me la dometɔ ɖeka.

NewsDay, one of the top newspapers in Zimbabwe, reported that the international convention was "the biggest ever religious gathering " in the country and placed Jehovah’s Witnesses among "the leading newsmakers who kept the nation talking " in 2014.
Ame 82,000 kple edzivɔ aɖewo yɔ Dukɔa Ƒe Bɔlƒoƒe si le Harare taŋtaŋ le takpekpe si wowɔ le ƒe 2014 me la ƒe ŋkeke mamlɛtɔ dzi.
Over 82,000 filled the National Sports Stadium in Harare for the final day of the 2014 event.

Esi wobia gbe aƒetɔ John Jubber, si nye Ðasefoawo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Zimbabwe, ƒe ame dɔdɔ le takpekpea ƒe nuwuwu la, egblɔ be: "Míexɔ ame dɔdɔ 3,500 tso Brazil, Germany, Amerika, Zambia kple Kenya. "
In a post-convention interview, John Jubber, a representative of the Witnesses’ branch office in Zimbabwe, commented: "We had 3,500 delegates from Brazil, Germany, United States, Zambia, and Kenya. "
Le ƒe sia me la, Ðasefo siwo le Zimbabwe awɔ "Srɔ̃ Yesu! " Nutome Gã Takpekpe 39 le teƒeteƒewo.
This year, the Witnesses in Zimbabwe are hosting 39 "Imitate Jesus! "
Teƒe siwo woawɔe le la dometɔ ɖekae nye Zimbabwe Dukɔwo Dome Adzɔnuɖefiaƒe.
Regional Conventions in several locations, including the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair Grounds.
Woawɔ takpekpe bliboa alo eƒe akpa aɖe le Chinagbe (Mandarin), Chitonga (Zimbabwe), Eŋlisi, Ndebele (Zimbabwe), Shona, Swahili kple Zimbabwe Tokunɔgbe me.
The program will be presented in whole or in part in Chinese (Mandarin), Chitonga (Zimbabwe), English, Ndebele (Zimbabwe), Shona, Swahili, and Zimbabwe Sign Language.
Àkpɔ ŋkekeawo kple teƒe siwo tututu woawɔ takpekpe siawo le le Zimbabwe la le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org.
The exact dates and locations for conventions in Zimbabwe can be found on the Witnesses’ official website, jw.org.
Dziɖuɖumegãwo De Bubu Ŋutsu Aɖe Kple Via Ŋutsu Ŋu Le Esi Woɖe Ame Etɔ̃ Aɖewo Tso Ʋu Bidzo Me Ta
Officials Honor Father and Son for Helping to Rescue Three Men From Burning Car
Jorim, Christiane kple Andreas Bonk.
Jorim, Christiane, and Andreas Bonk.
Andreas nɔ kɔdzi le afɔku aɖe si wòdze le nudzɔdzɔ bubu aɖe me la ta le nunanaa xɔɣi.
Andreas was hospitalized in an unrelated incident at the time of the ceremony.

SELTERS, Germany Andreas Bonk, si nye Yehowa Ðasefo kple via ŋutsu Jorim nɔ ame siwo wona nunana tsɔ de bubu wo ŋu le April (Afɔfiɛ) 16, 2015 dzi le esi woɖe ame aɖewo ƒe agbe le ʋu aɖe si bi dzo me la ta.

SELTERS, Germany Andreas Bonk, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, and his son Jorim were among those who received awards on April 16, 2015, for helping to save the lives of three victims of a fiery car crash.

Wonaa nunana wo le nunanawɔna aɖe si me Baden-Württemberg Du si le Germany ƒe anyieheɣedzeƒe ƒe dudɔnunɔla si kpɔa dukɔmenyawo gbɔ kple dudzikpɔla eve siwo tso Obersulm kple Waiblingen, siwo nye du siwo me nunanaxɔlawo tso la, kpɔ gome le la me.

The awards were presented in a ceremony attended by the minister of the interior of the Federal State of Baden-Württemberg, in southwest Germany, and by two mayors, from Obersulm and Waiblingen, the honorees’ home towns.

Dudɔnunɔla si kpɔa Dukɔmenyawo gbɔ aƒetɔ Reinhold Gall (foto si le etame, etɔ̃lia tso ɖusime) tsɔ Baden-Württemberg Dua Ƒe Agbeɖeɖenunana (Lebensrettungsmedaille des Landes Baden-Württemberg) la na aƒetɔ Andreas Bonk.

Minister of the Interior Reinhold Gall (top image, third from right) awarded to Andreas Bonk the Medal for Saving Lives of the Federal State of Baden-Württemberg (Lebensrettungsmedaille des Landes Baden-Württemberg).
Aƒetɔ Bonk srɔ̃ Christiane (foto si le etame, domedome), xɔ nunana la le srɔ̃a ŋkɔ me, elabe ŋutsua dze afɔku le nudzɔdzɔ bubu aɖe me eye wòle kɔdzi le nunanaa xɔɣi.
Mr. Bonk’s wife, Christiane (top image, center), accepted the medal on his behalf, since he was hospitalized in an unrelated incident at the time of the ceremony.
Le wɔna ma ke me la, Obersulm ƒe dudzikpɔla aƒetɔ Tilman Schmidt (foto si le etame, miame ɖaa), tsɔ Bubudeameŋu Ƒe Ðaseɖigbalẽ (Ehrungsurkunde) na Jorim Bonk (foto etametɔ, domedome).
During the same ceremony, the mayor of Obersulm, Tilman Schmidt (top image, far left), awarded Jorim Bonk (top image, center) a Certificate of Honor (Ehrungsurkunde).
Le May (Damɛ) 11, 2014 dzi la, Andreas kple Jorim Bonk tsɔ ʋu to ʋumɔ gã aɖe dzi ɖo ta Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe kpekpe gã aɖe si me Andreas aƒo Biblia me nuƒo le.
On May 11, 2014, Andreas and Jorim Bonk were driving on the highway to a large meeting for Bible education hosted by Jehovah’s Witnesses where Andreas was scheduled to deliver a Bible discourse.
Esi wole mɔa dzi yina la, wova do go ɖe ʋufɔku dziŋɔ aɖe nu.
En route, they came upon a tragic car accident.
Amerikatɔwo ƒe gbadagba ene aɖewo xaxa ɖe ʋu si mu ɖe axa ɖeka dzi henɔ bibim la me.
Four U.S. soldiers were trapped inside a burning car lying on its side.
Aƒetɔ Bonk kple via ŋutsua kple ame eve bubu aɖewo tɔ woƒe ʋuwo va ɖe wo le ʋu bidzo la me.
The Bonks, as well as two other people, stopped to assist.
Andreas de eƒe agbe afɔku me be yeaɖe gbadagba siawo le ʋu si nɔ bibim la me, enɔ edzi ʋuu va se ɖe esime dzotsilawo, kpovitɔwo kple dɔnɔkɔʋuwo va ɖo.
Andreas risked his life trying to help the passengers escape from the burning car until the police, fire department, and ambulance arrived.
Gake nublanuitɔe la, gbadagba ɖeka ƒe agbe tsi eme.
Unfortunately, one of the soldiers died.
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Sulmtaler Woche ka nya ta be Dudɔnunɔla Gall gblɔ na ameɖelawo be, "Miewɔ kalẽ, miewɔ ŋutsu eye miebu miaƒe agbe ŋu gɔ̃ hã o. "
In their coverage of the story, the journal Sulmtaler Woche quotes Minister Gall as stating to the rescuers, "You acted bravely, valiantly, and without a thought for yourselves. "
Dudzikpɔla Schmidt gblɔ kpee be, "Mí Obersulmtɔwo, míekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe mia ŋu ŋutɔ. "
Mayor Schmidt added, "We, the people of Obersulm, are proud of you. "
Foto si woɖe le afi si ʋufɔku la dzɔ le.
Picture taken at the scene of the crash.
Aƒetɔ Andreas Bonk gblɔ nu si ʋãe wòwɔ nu kalẽtɔe ale: "Vevesese ɖe hanyevi ŋue ʋãm metɔ esi mekpɔ ʋu si dze afɔkua.
Andreas Bonk explained what motivated him to perform such a courageous act: "I stopped at the scene of the accident out of concern for my fellow man.
Agbe ɖe sia ɖe xɔ asi le ŋkunyeme. . . .
To me, every life is precious. . . .
Meka ɖe edzi be ne esia tɔgbi dzɔ ɖe nye ƒometɔ aɖe dzi la, ame bubuwo akpɔ nublanui na wo ahado dzi akpe ɖe wo ŋu. "
If I or any of my relatives were ever in such a situation, I hope that others would be decent and brave enough to step in and help. "
Aƒetɔ Jorim gblɔ kpee be, "Ele vevie be míagaŋlɔ ame siwo hiã tu la be o. "
Jorim added, "It’s important that we don’t ignore people in need. "
Nunana ƒe wɔnaa yi edzi le Obersulm Dukpata me.
The awards ceremony took place in the Obersulm Town Hall.

Germaniatɔwo ƒe nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye STIMME.de ka nya ta tso wɔnaa ŋu eye wògblɔ be Waiblingen ƒe dudzikpɔla aƒetɔ Andreas Hesky (foto etametɔ, evelia tso ɖusime), gblɔ be: "Ele be nu si miewɔ la nanye dada na mi.

The German news journal STIMME.de reported on the ceremony and quoted the lord mayor of Waiblingen, Andreas Hesky (top image, second from right), as stating: "You can look back on what you did with great pride.
Enye dada na Waiblingen-dua be dumevi siawo tɔgbi le eme.
The town of Waiblingen is proud to have such citizens.
Mienye kpɔɖeŋu nyui na dukɔmeviwo. "
You are role models in our society. "
Yehowa Ðasefo Siwo Le Ukraine Ƒe Nuto Siwo Me Aʋa Le Edzi Yim Le Kpɔ Wɔna Tɔxɛ Aɖe To Videokadodowo Dzi
Jehovah’s Witnesses Broadcast Special Meeting Into War Zone of Ukraine

LVIV, Ukraine Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le Ukraine wɔ kpekpe tɔxɛ aɖe le February (Dzodze) 14, 2015 ale be woatsɔ Biblia me nyawo ade dzi ƒo na woƒe hametɔ 17,000 kple edzivɔ siwo le Ukraine ƒe ɣedzeƒenuto si me wole aʋa wɔm le me.

LVIV, Ukraine Jehovah’s Witnesses in Ukraine held a special meeting on February 14, 2015, designed to give pastoral support to more than 17,000 of their fellow worshippers living in the war-torn region of eastern Ukraine.
Wowɔ gaƒoƒo eve ƒe wɔna sia le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Lviv eye ame siwo le Ukraine ƒe ɣedzeƒenuto me kple dukɔa ƒe nuto bubuwo me kpɔ wɔna sia tẽe to videokadodowo dzi.
The two-hour program was video streamed live from the branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Lviv to eastern Ukraine and other locations throughout the country.

Kpekpe sia va ɖe ɣeyiɣi nyuitɔ dzi, elabe woda bɔmb wòva gblẽ nu ŋɔdzitɔe le ƒutadu si woyɔna be Mariupol la me le January (Dzove) 24, 2015 dzi, eye esia na be Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe 3 kple woƒe xɔ 58 dome gblẽ.
The meeting was especially timely, since a deadly rocket attack on the port city of Mariupol on January 24, 2015, damaged 3 of the Witnesses’ homes and 58 of their apartments.
Ðasefo ɖeka xɔ abi vevie le nudzɔdzɔ sia me, eye Ðasefo bubu si xɔ ƒe 16 pɛ ko la ƒe agbe tsi eme.
One Witness was seriously wounded in the attack and another, who was only 16 years old, was killed.
Hame geɖewo va kpe ta le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me le Makiyivka si le nuto si me aʋaa le edzi yim le la me be woase wɔnaa me nyawo esime wɔnaa le edzi yim le Ukraine alɔdzedɔwɔƒea.
Congregants gather at a Kingdom Hall in Makiyivka in the war zone to listen as the meeting is broadcast from the Ukraine branch.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe siwo le Russia kple Ukraine wɔ ɖoɖo lé wɔnaa bliboa heɖee na wo nɔvi siwo le Belarus kple Russia.
In cooperation with the branch office in Russia, the Ukraine branch office arranged to record the entire program on video and stream it to Witnesses in Belarus and Russia.

Esia wɔe be Ðasefo 186,258 siwo le Belarus kple Russia hã kpɔ gome le wɔnaa me tsɔ kpe ɖe Ðasefo 150,841 siwo kpɔ gome le eme le Ukraine la ŋu. Ale Ðasefo siwo katã kpɔ gome le wɔnaa me ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ va nye 337,099.
As a result, another 186,258 Belarusian and Russian Witnesses saw the program in addition to the 150,841 Ukrainian Witnesses, bringing the grand total to 337,099 viewers.
Aƒetɔ Gustav Berki, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Ukraine, gblɔ be: "Míaƒe kpekpeɖeŋunadɔwo ŋuti nyatakakawo fa akɔ na mía nɔvi siwo le Ukraine ƒe nuto siwo me aʋa le edzi yim le la ŋutɔ.
Gustav Berki, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Ukraine, explains: "The reports on our relief efforts in Ukraine were a great comfort to those in the war zone.
Eye ale si kpekpeɖeŋudɔwɔlawo le kpekpem ɖe mía xɔlɔ̃ siwo si aʋa yi Rostov-on-Don si le Russia ŋu la hã fa akɔ na ame ŋutɔ. "
It was also a great assurance to learn how the relief committee in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, is caring for our friends who are refugees. "
Aƒetɔ Yaroslav Sivulskiy, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Russia, gblɔ be: "Wonya Yehowa Ðasefowo le xexea me godoo be wonye ŋutifafamewo eye womedea akpa aɖeke dzi le dunyahenyawo me o.
A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia, Yaroslav Sivulskiy, comments: "Jehovah’s Witnesses are well-known around the world for being peaceful and remaining neutral in political affairs.
Wohe susu yi Biblia me nya siwo tae womedea akpa aɖeke dzi o la hã dzi le kpekpe sia me.
This meeting included discussions highlighting the Biblical basis for our neutrality.
Eɖe nu si tae mímekpɔa gome le aʋawɔwɔ me o, míeɖanye Russiatɔwo, Ukrainetɔwo alo dukɔ bubu me tɔwo o la hã me. "
It helped underscore why, whether we are Russian, Ukrainian, or citizens of any other nation, we do not take sides in military conflicts. "
Yehowa Ðasefo eve aɖewo siwo le Horlivka le Donetsk-nutoa me tsi agbe esime bɔmb va dze aƒe si me wonɔ la dzi.
Two of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Horlivka, Donetsk region survived after a rocket hit their home while they were inside.
Va se ɖe fifia la, Ukraine alɔdzedɔwɔƒea ɖo Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti 14 be woakpɔ woƒe hametɔ siwo le nuto si me aʋaa le edzi yim le la ƒe hiahiãwo gbɔ.
To date, the Ukraine branch office has set up 14 Disaster Relief Committees to care for those affected by the war.
Kɔmiti siawo lɔ nuɖuɖu tɔn 149 kple awudodo tɔn 21 kple edzivɔwo yi na woƒe hametɔwo kple ame siwo menye Ðasefowo o siaa le nutoa me.
These committees have provided more than 149 tons of food and 21 tons of clothing to fellow believers and to non-Witnesses in the region.
Kɔmitiawo di mlɔƒe na aʋasila 7,600 kple edzivɔwo eye wole aƒe alo woƒe tadeaguƒe siwo woyɔna be Fiaɖuƒe Akpatawo la dometɔ siwo dome gblẽ la ɖɔm ɖo eye wole yeyewo hã tum.
The committees have arranged housing for more than 7,600 refugees and have been able to repair or rebuild a number of damaged or destroyed homes and Kingdom Halls (places of worship).

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le ƒutadu si nye Mariupol me la, esi wodze dua dzi ƒe ŋkeke eve megbe pɛ la, Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitia wɔ ɖoɖo lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla 160 aɖewo te woƒe hametɔwo ƒe xɔ 34 siwo ŋu nu gblẽ le la ɖɔɖɔ ɖo.
For example, in the city of Mariupol, merely two days after the attack, a Disaster Relief Committee was able to arrange for 160 volunteers to begin repair work on 34 damaged apartments.
Bɔmb gbã ʋutɔɖoƒe aɖe si tsiã ɖe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata nu le Mariupol (medze le fotoa me o).
A parking lot hit by rockets adjacent to a Kingdom Hall (not pictured) in Mariupol.
Aƒetɔ Berki gaɖe nu me yi ŋgɔ ku ɖe ale si kpekpeɖeŋunadɔ siwo dzi kpɔm Ukraine alɔdzedɔwɔƒea le la te ŋu kpɔ amewo ƒe ŋutilãmenuhiahiã siwo hiã kpata la gbɔ na woe la ŋu.
Mr. Berki further outlined how the relief initiatives supervised by the branch office in Ukraine provide for more than immediate physical and material needs.
Egblɔ be: "Tsɔ kpe ɖe kpekpe tɔxɛ sia ŋu la, dzikpɔla mɔzɔlawo yi ɖakpɔa Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hatsotso 136 siwo le nuto si me aʋaa le edzi yim le me la ɖa.
He states: "In addition to this special meeting, traveling ministers continue to visit the 136 communities of Jehovah’s Witnesses in the war zone.
Abe ale si wònɔna le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hamewo me le xexea me godoo ene la, hamemetsitsi siwo le hame mawo me yi edzi le dzi dem ƒo na woƒe hametɔ siwo hiã tu hetsɔ Biblia le akɔ fam na wo. "

And, as is always the case in congregations of Jehovah’s Witnesses around the world, local elders are making a concerted effort to provide comfort and spiritual encouragement to those under their care. "
Yehowa Ðasefo Siwo Tso Dukɔ Vovovowo Me Naa Kpekpeɖeŋu Ame Siwo Ŋu Nepal Anyigbaʋuʋua Gblẽ Nu Le
Jehovah’s Witnesses Coordinate International Efforts to Aid Nepal Earthquake Victims

KATHMANDU si le Nepal Yehowa Ðasefo siwo tso Bangladesh, Germany (Allemagne), India, Japan, Switzerland (Suisse) kple Amerika wɔ ɖeka le kpekpeɖeŋu nam ame siwo ŋu anyigba si ʋuʋu le Nepal le April 25, 2015 dzi gblẽ nu le. Anyigbaʋuʋu sia wu ame akpe geɖewo, eye Yehowa Ðasefo ɖeka kple via eve hã ƒe agbe tsi eme.

KATHMANDU, Nepal Jehovah’s Witnesses from Bangladesh, Germany, India, Japan, Switzerland, and the United States are coordinating their efforts to help victims of the devastating earthquake that hit Nepal on April 25, 2015, and killed thousands, including one Witness and her two children.
Anyigba gaʋuʋu le Nepal ake le May 12, 2015 dzi.
A second quake hit Nepal on May 12, 2015.
Gake Ðasefoawo gblɔ be nu vevi boo mewɔ yewoƒe hamevi aɖeke le anyigbaʋuʋu evelia sia me o, wo dometɔ aɖeke meku o, eye megblẽ nu boo le woƒe nunɔamesiwo hã ŋu o.
However, the Witnesses confirm that, in this latest earthquake, none of their members suffered major injuries, severe damage to their property, or loss of life.
Yehowa Ðasefowo naa nuɖuɖu woƒe haxɔsetɔwo kple ame bubu siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la zi eve gbe sia gbe.
Jehovah’s Witnesses provide food for fellow worshippers and other disaster victims twice a day.

Le ŋkeke si kplɔ anyigbaʋuʋu gbãtɔa ɖo la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Nepal ƒe ame dɔdɔwo yi ɖakpɔ woƒe hame ɖe sia ɖe me tɔwo ɖa le Kathmandu Balime, si nye afi si anyigbaʋuʋua nu sẽ wu le ne woanya ame siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la ƒe hiahiãwo.

The day after the first quake, representatives from the Nepal office of Jehovah’s Witnesses visited each congregation in Kathmandu Valley, an area hard hit by the quake, to assess the needs of the victims.
Anyigbaʋuʋua gbã Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe 38 keŋkeŋ eye wògblẽ nu le woƒe aƒe 126 bubuwo hã ŋu.
The quake had destroyed 38 of the Witnesses’ homes and damaged 126 others.

Wona dzeƒe woƒe hametɔ siwo ƒe aƒewo dome gblẽ la le woƒe haxɔsetɔwo ƒe aƒe me, eye wona dzeƒe wo dometɔ bubuwo hã le woƒe tadeaguƒe siwo woyɔna be Fiaɖuƒe Akpatawo me kple agbadɔ siwo wotu ɖe dogbadzi la me.
Those displaced were given shelter in the homes of fellow worshippers, in their places of worship called Kingdom Halls, and in tents set up in open areas.
Eteƒe medidi o, nuɖuɖuawo va sɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi esi woƒe hametɔ siwo le Bangladesh, India kple Nepal ƒe du siwo nye Birgunj, Damauli, Mahendranagar kple Pokhara me hã lɔ nuɖuɖuwo vae.
The Nepal office also began supplying food, which was soon augmented by supplies from Bangladesh, India, and the Nepali cities of Birgunj, Damauli, Mahendranagar, and Pokhara.
Woɖo Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti aɖe si le lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla siwo tso India, Japan kple Nepal ƒe dɔwo dzi kpɔm wole xɔ tum na ame siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le be woanɔ zazãm gbɔ.
A Disaster Relief Committee is coordinating the ongoing efforts of Witness volunteers from India, Japan, and Nepal in the construction of temporary shelters.
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla siwo tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Nepal le kpekpeɖeŋunanu siwo wolɔ tso Nepal ƒe du si nye Birgunj me la nu ƒom ƒu.
Volunteers from the Nepal office of Jehovah’s Witnesses store relief materials that have arrived from the Nepali city of Birgunj.
