Aƒetɔ Reuben Thapaliya, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Nepal, gblɔ be: "Menye ame siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la ƒe ŋutilãmehiahiãwo ŋu koe míetsi dzi ɖo o, míetsi dzi ɖe ale si míado ŋusẽ wo le mawusubɔsubɔ me hã ŋu.
A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Nepal, Reuben Thapaliya, states: "We are concerned not only with the physical needs of the victims of this disaster but also with their spiritual well-being.
To vovo na tsi, nuɖuɖu kple mlɔƒe didi na ameawo la, míetsɔ Biblia me nyawo hã le akɔ fam na wo. "
Along with our efforts to supply food, water, and shelter, we have mobilized to provide pastoral support. "
Aƒetɔ Gary Breaux, si wodɔ ɖa tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dɔwɔƒegã ɖi tsa to nuto si me anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la me le May 2 va se ɖe May 5, 2015 dzi, eye wòyi ɖakpɔ woƒe hamewo kple ƒome ɖekaɖekawo ɖa.
A representative from the world headquarters of Jehovah’s Witnesses, Gary Breaux, traveled through the affected region May 2-5, 2015, and visited congregations and individual families.
Le May 4, 2015 dzi la, aƒetɔ Breaux ƒo nuƒo tɔxɛ aɖe si wotu ɖe Biblia dzi eye amewo kpɔ wɔnaa tẽe to videokadodowo dzi le hame siwo le nuto bubuwo me hã me.
On May 4, 2015, Mr. Breaux spoke during a special Bible-based program that was presented simultaneously via video streaming to other congregations in the region.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, aƒetɔ Kenji Chichii si wodɔ ɖa tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Japan hã va ɖo le May 5, 2015 dzi.
Additionally, a representative of the Japan branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses, Kenji Chichii, arrived on May 5, 2015.
Eya hã yi ɖakpɔ ƒomewo ɖa eye wòƒo nuƒo siwo wotu ɖe Biblia dzi tsɔ de dzi ƒo na wo.
He also visited families in the area and gave encouraging, Bible-based talks.
Ame dɔdɔ si tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dɔwɔƒegã Gary Breaux (le ɖusime), le ŋku lém ɖe nu siwo gblẽ le aƒe aɖe ŋu la ŋu.
A representative from the world headquarters of Jehovah’s Witnesses, Gary Breaux (right), surveys the damage to one home.

Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Germany dɔ Yehowa Ðasefo aɖewo ɖa, wo dometɔ ɖeka nye ɖɔkta si dea ame alɔ̃ me, ɖeka nye amekola, ɖeka hã nye dɔnɔdzikpɔla eye bubu hã nye dɔnɔdzikpɔla si kpɔa nudzɔdzɔ kpatawo gbɔ.
The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Germany assembled a medical team of Witnesses consisting of an anesthesiologist, a surgeon, a nurse, and a paramedic.

Ame siawo zãa atike siwo Ðasefo siwo le Bangladesh, India kple Japan ɖo ɖa la kple dɔwɔnu siwo wozãna le amekoko kple dɔwɔwɔ na ame siwo xɔ abi vevie me siwo wotea ŋu tsɔna yia teƒeteƒewo bɔbɔe la tsɔ kpɔ ame siwo dze afɔku la gbɔ le Fiaɖuƒe Akpatawo me le afi si anyigbaa ʋuʋu le, eye wowɔ dɔ aduadu kple Nepal Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti la.

Equipped with medicine supplied by Witnesses in Bangladesh, India, and Japan, as well as mobile equipment for surgery and intensive care, this team from Europe worked with the Nepal Disaster Relief Committee to treat patients at Kingdom Halls in the earthquake zone.
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo le nuɖuɖu nam amewo le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata me afi si woxɔ ame siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la ɖo.
The relief team is based in a Kingdom Hall in Kathmandu where Witness victims are given food and shelter.

Aƒetɔ J. R. Brown, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le woƒe dɔwɔƒegã gblɔ be: "Míaƒe kpekpeɖeŋunadɔa ayi edzi ɖaa, elabena míenyae be ame siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋua gblẽ nu le la hiã nu geɖe wu ŋutilãmenuwo ko.

J. R. Brown, an international spokesman at the world headquarters of Jehovah’s Witnesses, states: "Our relief efforts are ongoing, because we recognize that victims of disasters have needs that go beyond physical recovery from a catastrophic event.
Míaƒe haxɔsetɔ siwo le Nepal kple ame bubu siwo tsi agbe le anyigbaʋuʋu siawo me ate ŋu aka ɖe edzi be míayi edzi atsɔ Biblia me nyawo anɔ akɔ fam na yewo ahanɔ ŋutilãmekpekpeɖeŋu hã nam yewo.
Our fellow worshippers in Nepal and other earthquake survivors can be assured of our active spiritual and material assistance.
Míaŋlɔ wo be o, eye míaɖo ŋku wo dzi le míaƒe gbedodoɖawo me. "
They remain in our thoughts and prayers. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Kpɔ Gome Le Agbalẽɖeɖefia Gãtɔ Kekeake Si Wowɔ Le Spania-dukɔ Aɖe Me Kpɔ La Me
Largest Book Fair in the Spanish-Speaking World Hosts Jehovah’s Witnesses

MEXICO CITY​ Wokpe Yehowa Ðasefowo be woava kpɔ gome le Guadalajara Ƒe Dukɔwo Dome Agbalẽɖeɖefia, si nye agbalẽɖeɖefia gãtɔ kekeake si wowɔ le Spania-dukɔ aɖe me kpɔ la me. Le xexea me godoo la, esiae nye agbalẽɖeɖefia gãtɔ evelia si wowɔ kpɔ, eye Frankfurt Agbalẽɖeɖefia si wowɔ le Germany lae nye gãtɔ kekeake.

MEXICO CITY Jehovah’s Witnesses were invited to participate in the Guadalajara International Book Fair, the world’s largest book fair for Spanish-speaking countries and the second largest in the world after the Frankfurt Book Fair in Germany.
Wɔnaa yi edzi le Guadalajara le Mexico tso November 28 va se ɖe December 6, 2014 dzi eye ame siwo ɖi tsa va wɔnaa teƒe la wu 760,000.
The event was held in Guadalajara, Mexico, from November 29 to December 7, 2014, and drew over 760,000 visitors.
Woma agbalẽ si nye Nya Siwo Sɔhɛwo Biana​ Ŋuɖoɖo Siwo Wɔa Dɔ ƒe babla eveawo ƒe agbɔsɔsɔme si nye 4,000 kple edzivɔ.
Over 4,000 copies of the two-volume set Questions Young People Ask Answers That Work were distributed to the public.

Wokpe agbalẽtaƒe 1,900 aɖewo tso dukɔ 44 me be woava kpɔ gome le wɔna sia me, eye Yehowa Ðasefowo hã le wo dome. Ðasefoawo ɖo Biblia kple Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽwo ɖe agbadɔ aɖe me. Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽ siawo ku ɖe ƒomewo, sɔhɛwo kple ɖeviwo ƒe hiahiã aɖewo koŋ ŋu.

Alongside some 1,900 publishing houses from 44 countries, Jehovah’s Witnesses participated in the cultural event with a booth featuring the Bible and Bible-related publications, including books addressing the specific needs of families, teenagers, and children.

Aƒetɔ Gamaliel Camarillo, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Mexico, gblɔ be: "Le ŋkeke ene siwo míeɖo agbalẽwo ɖe agbadɔ sia me me la, ame siwo wu 10,000 sɔŋue va míaƒe agbadɔa me eye míena agbalẽ 29,000 kloe wo gamaxɔmaxɔe.

Gamaliel Camarillo, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Mexico, states, "During the four days that we operated the booth, we had over 10,000 visitors and distributed almost 29,000 pieces of literature, free of charge.
Gake taɖodzinu si le mía si yi ŋgɔ wu agbalẽwo mama ko.
However, our goal is to do more than distribute literature.
Wotrɔ asi le míaƒe agbalẽwo ŋu be woana amewo nakpɔ ale si Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo ɖea vi na ame miliɔn geɖewo gbe sia gbe la. "
Our magazines and books are designed to highlight the Bible’s practical advice, which benefits millions each day.
Yehowa Ðasefowo Dze "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
Jehovah’s Witnesses Launch "Imitate Jesus! "
Takpekpe Gãwo Gɔme Le Amerika Dua Ƒe Nuto 11 Me
Convention Series in 11 US Cities
NEW YORK Yehowa Ðasefowo adze woƒe "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
NEW YORK Jehovah’s Witnesses will start the first of their "Imitate Jesus! "
Takpekpe Gãwo ƒe gbãtɔ gɔme le United States (États-Unis) le Fiɖa, May 22, 2015 ƒe ŋdi.
Conventions in the United States on Friday morning, May 22, 2015.

Le kwasiɖanuwuwu ma la, woawɔ wɔna siawo siwo ame sia ame ate ŋu ade faa femaxee la le teƒe 11 bubuwo. Teƒe siawo dometɔ ɖekae nye Stanley Theater xɔŋkɔ si le Jersey City le New Jersey (foto si le dzedzem le etame).
Over the weekend, these free public events will be held at 11 venues, including the historic Stanley Theater in Jersey City, New Jersey (lead photo).
Ðasefoawo le mɔ kpɔm be ame siwo ade takpekpe sia le teƒe 11 siawo katã awu 41,000 gbe sia gbe.
The Witnesses expect the combined daily peak attendance from all 11 venues to reach over 41,000.

J. R. Brown, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le woƒe dɔwɔƒegã si le Brooklyn le New York, gblɔ be: "Míaxɔ ame siwo katã ava wɔ ɖeka kpli mí le takpekpe sia me le woƒe nutowo me la atuu kple vividodoɖeameŋu gã aɖe, eye míeka ɖe edzi be dzi adzɔ wo ŋutɔ be yewodi ɣeyiɣi va.

J. R. Brown, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses at their world headquarters in Brooklyn, New York, comments: "All who accept our invitation to join us at the convention in their region will receive a very warm welcome, and we believe they will be happy they took the time to attend.
Yesu ƒe nufiafia ʋãmewo ƒe ɖeɖefia wɔdɔɖeamedzi siwo ŋu wotrɔ asi le be wòakpe ɖe ɖeviwo kple tsitsiawo siaa, siwo le nɔnɔme vovovowo me ŋu la, ayi edzi le "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
The ‘Imitate Jesus!’ Conventions promise three days of fascinating presentations of Jesus’ dynamic teachings, designed to help people of all ages and circumstances. "
Takpekpe Gã ƒe ŋkeke etɔ̃awo katã me. " Yehowa Ðasefowo awɔ "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
Throughout the summer and continuing through January 2016, Jehovah’s Witnesses will hold some 5,000 "Imitate Jesus! "
Takpekpe Gã 5,000 aɖewo tso May 2015 va se ɖe January 2016 me le dukɔ 92 me.
Conventions in 92 lands.
Takpekpe sia si ŋu Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe Dɔdzikpɔhaa wɔ ɖoɖo ɖo la bliboa katã alo eƒe akpa aɖewo ayi edzi le gbe 347 me, gbe siawo dometɔ 55 nye tokunɔgbewo.
The program, arranged by the Governing Body of Jehovah’s Witnesses, will be presented in whole or in part in 347 languages, including 55 sign languages.
Ðasefowo Na Kpekpeɖeŋu Ame Siwo Tsi Ðe Le Chile
Witnesses Mobilize Relief Aid for Victims of Chile Floods
Fiaɖuƒe Akpata si le Copiapó si me tsi kple ba yɔ fũu.
A Kingdom Hall in Copiapó was inundated with water and mud.
SANTIAGO, Chile (Chili) Tsi gã aɖe dza le March 25, 2015 dzi le Atacama-nutoa me le Chile ƒe dzigbe, eye wòna ba kple tsi xɔ nutoa me katã. Ƒe 80 sɔŋue nye esia womegakpɔ esia gbegbe teƒe kpɔ o.
SANTIAGO, Chile Heavy rains inundated the Atacama region of northern Chile on March 25, 2015, triggering mudslides and flash floods the worst in the area in 80 years.
Tsiɖɔɖɔ sia gblẽ nu le ame 30,000 kple edzivɔwo ŋu, ena hã be ame 3,000 va tsi sitsoƒe siwo woɖo ɖi na nudzɔdzɔ kpatawo eye woka nya ta be ame 25 ya teti ƒe agbe tsi eme.
Over 30,000 people have been affected by this disaster, with close to 3,000 displaced to emergency shelters and at least 25 confirmed dead.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Chile ka nya ta be nu vevi mewɔ Ðasefo aɖeke o, eye wo dometɔ aɖeke hã meku o.
The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Chile reported that no Witnesses were killed or seriously injured.
Ke hã, Ðasefoawo ƒe aƒe adre dome gblẽ keŋkeŋ eye nu gblẽ le aƒe geɖewo hã ŋu.
However, seven homes of Witnesses were destroyed and dozens more were damaged.
Tsiɖɔɖɔa gbã Fiaɖuƒe Akpata ɖeka keŋkeŋ eye wògblẽ nu le eve bubuwo hã ŋu.
One Kingdom Hall, a place of worship, was completely destroyed and two others were damaged by the flooding.
Nu siwo dome gblẽ le Diego de Almagro, du si ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le vevie.
Property destroyed in the city of Diego de Almagro, a town severely damaged by the floods.
Le Copiapó, si nye du siwo me tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le wu dometɔ ɖeka me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitiwo be woaxɔ nyatakakawo eye woadzra teƒeawo ɖo.
In Copiapó, one of the cities hardest hit by the floods, Jehovah’s Witnesses formed a relief committee to gather information and organize the cleanup efforts.
Wodɔ alɔdzedɔwɔƒea teƒenɔla ɖeka hã ɖo ɖa be wòagblɔ Biblia me nyawo atsɔ afa akɔ na Ðasefo siwo le nutoa me ahade dzi ƒo na wo.
A representative of the branch office has also been sent to provide support and spiritual encouragement to Witnesses in the affected region.
Enumake Ðasefo siwo tso Antofagasta, Arica, Calama, Caldera, Iquique kple La Serena ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunanuwo ɖe woƒe haxɔsetɔ siwo hiã tu.
Witnesses from the cities of Antofagasta, Arica, Calama, Caldera, Iquique, and La Serena immediately sent supplies to support their fellow worshippers in need.
Ðasefoawo le kpekpeɖeŋunanuwo lɔm le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖe me le Alto Hospicio be yewoatsɔ ayi na ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le.
Witnesses gather relief supplies at a Kingdom Hall in the city of Alto Hospicio for delivery to affected areas.

Jason Reed, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Chile, gblɔ be: "Nu si dzɔ ɖe mía nɔviawo dzi te ɖe mía dzi ŋutɔ, eye míaƒe kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitia sɔ gbe be yeana kpekpeɖeŋu le teƒeawo dzadzra ɖo kple xɔ yeyewo tutu ƒe dɔ si axɔ ɣeyiɣi didi la me.
Jason Reed, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Chile, said: "We feel for the victims of this tragedy, and our relief committee is poised to assist with the long-term cleanup and rebuilding work.
Míeɖoe hã be míafa akɔ na ame siwo katã ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le ahade dzi ƒo na wo. "
Our efforts are also focused on providing comfort and encouragement to everyone devastated by the floods. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Ðo Amerika Tokunɔgbegɔmeɖeƒe Le Florida
Jehovah’s Witnesses Open American Sign Language Translation Office in Florida

FORT LAUDERDALE, Florida​ Le November 14, 2014 dzi la, Yehowa Ðasefowo te Amerika Tokunɔgbegɔmeɖeƒea ɖeɖe tso woƒe Gbetakpɔxɔ Habɔbɔa Ƒe Hehenaƒe si le Patterson le New York yi Fort Lauderdale si le Florida ƒe dɔwo gɔme.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. On November 14, 2014, Jehovah’s Witnesses began relocating their American Sign Language (ASL) translation team to Fort Lauderdale, Florida, from the Watchtower Educational Center in Patterson, New York.
Yehowa Ðasefowo dze Biblia kple Biblia-srɔ̃gbalẽwo gɔme ɖeɖe ɖe Amerika Tokunɔgbe me le Patterson tso ƒe 1995 me ke.
The Witnesses have been translating the Bible and their Bible-based publications into ASL from their Patterson facility since 1995.
Le ɣleti ʋɛ siwo va yi me la, Ðasefoawo te asitɔtrɔ le woƒe teƒe si le Fort Lauderdale la ŋu, woɖo dɔwɔxɔ yeyewo kple dɔwɔƒe si woléa nuwo ɖe mɔ̃ dzi le ɖe teƒe sia.
For the past few months, the Witnesses have been retrofitting the Fort Lauderdale property with new offices and recording studios.
Tso May 2015 me la, Ðasefoawo ƒe Amerika Tokunɔgbegɔmeɖeƒea dze dɔ gɔme bliboe le teƒe sia.
As of May 2015, the Witnesses’ ASL translation office has been fully operational.
Ðasefoawo daa Amerika Tokunɔgbe me videowo ɖe internet dzi le woƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org, eye wowɔa DVD geɖewo hã.
The Witnesses make their ASL videos available online at jw.org and on DVD.

Wozãa wo edziedzi le woƒe kwasiɖa sia kwasiɖa ƒe kpekpe siwo wowɔna le tokunɔgbehame 500 kple edzivɔ siwo le xexea me godoo me la me, eye wogazãa wo le woƒe takpekpe sue kple gã siwo wowɔna ƒe sia ƒe hã me.

They also regularly incorporate them into weekly meetings held in over 500 congregations worldwide as well as events held in large venues, including biannual assemblies and annual regional conventions.

Aƒetɔ Jonathan Galvez si nye Ðasefoawo ƒe Amerika Tokunɔgbegɔmeɖeƒea dzi kpɔla si le Florida gblɔ be: "Míaƒe taɖodzinue nye be míana ame siwo katã zãa Amerika Tokunɔgbea nase míaƒe videoawo gɔme bɔbɔe, eɖanye dukɔ ka ke mee wotso alo afi kae wode suku se ɖo o. "

"Our goal is to ensure that our videos are easily understood by the majority of ASL users, regardless of their country of origin or educational background, " states Jonathan Galvez, who coordinates the Witnesses’ ASL translation team in Florida.

Egblɔ yi edzi be: "Wozãa Amerika Tokunɔgbea le dukɔ siwo ade 45 me, eye abe ale si ko ame siwo ƒoa nu ƒe gbewo toa vovo ene la, nenema kee dzesi siwo tokunɔwo zãna tsɔ gblɔa nyawoe hã toa vovo tso teƒe yi teƒe.
He continues: "There are some 45 countries where ASL is used and, as is the case with spoken languages, deaf people have regional accents when signing.
Esi míeɖe míaƒe gbegɔmeɖeƒea yi Fort Lauderdale fifia la, míaƒe gbegɔmeɖelawo va le nuto si me Amerika Tokunɔgbea zãla siwo tso dukɔ vovovowo me la sɔ gbɔ ɖo wu la me. "
Now that our operations have moved to Fort Lauderdale, our translators are immersed in a city with a larger and more diverse population of international ASL users. "

Le ƒe 2014 me la, Frank Bechter, si nye agbalẽnyalagã le hadomenyawo kple gbegbɔgblɔ ŋuti nyawo me la de Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe tokunɔgbe me takpekpe gã aɖe si wowɔ le Richmond si le Virginia kple susu be yeaku nu me tso tokunɔgbewo kple tokunɔwo ŋu.

In 2014, Frank Bechter, who has a doctorate in sociocultural and linguistic anthropology, attended an ASL regional convention of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Richmond, Virginia, as part of his linguistic and anthropological research concerning sign language and the deaf community.

Nunyalagã Bechter gblɔ be, "Ale si miaƒe habɔbɔa léa fɔ ɖe Amerika Tokunɔgbe gɔme ɖeɖe kple tokunɔgbe me wɔna adodoeawo wɔwɔ ŋu dze ƒãa le Richmond wɔnaa me, vevietɔ le ale si miezã mawunyakpukpuiwo ƒe video siwo gɔme woɖe nyuie la edziedzi ta.

Dr. Bechter comments, "Your organization’s dedication to quality ASL translation and presentation indeed seemed quite clear at the Richmond event, particularly because of the repeated use of your well-prepared video translations of Bible verses.
Mekpɔe be Amerika Tokunɔgbe si wozã la de ŋgɔ ŋutɔ. "
I found the ASL in them to be superb. "
Eyi edzi be, "Mekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe Ðasefoawo ƒe kutrikuku le Biblia la gɔme ɖeɖe nyuie ɖe Amerika Tokunɔgbe me la ŋu ŋutɔ, elabe ŋudɔwɔnu vevi aɖe wònye le míaƒe dukɔa kple xexe bliboa ƒe ŋutinya me.
He continues, "I do appreciate the Witnesses’ efforts in translating the Bible so well into ASL, because it is a very important document in our society and in the history of the world.
Eye mexɔe se be ele be tokunɔwo hã ƒe asi nasu ŋudɔwɔnu vevi siwo ɖea vi na ame bubuwo le xexea me godoo la dzi. "
And I believe that deaf people should, like anyone, have good access to the important documents that have shaped the world. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe gbegɔmeɖela siwo le xexea me godoo ɖea video geɖewo gɔme ɖe tokunɔgbe 80 aɖewo me eye womaa wo na amewo femaxee.
Translation teams of Jehovah’s Witnesses around the globe have produced and distributed numerous video publications in some 80 sign languages free of charge.
Yehowa Ðasefowo wɔ JW Library Sign Language dɔwɔnu hã, eye amewo tea ŋu wɔa tokunɔgbe me video siwo le jw.org nyatakakadzraɖoƒea ƒe kɔpi, ɖoa wo ɖe ɖoɖo nu heƒoa wo le edzi bɔbɔe.
Jehovah’s Witnesses have also produced the JW Library Sign Language app that allows users to easily download, organize, and play sign-language videos from jw.org.
Guatemala-sukuwo Le Yehowa Ðasefowo Ƒe Agbalẽwo Zãm Tsɔ Le Sɔhɛwo Ƒe Ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ Nu Tsim
Guatemalan Schools Address Youth Violence; Request Publications From Jehovah’s Witnesses
MEXICO CITY Guatemala-suku etɔ̃ bia tso Yehowa Ðasefowo si be woana woƒe agbalẽwo yewo yewoatsɔ afia nu sukuviwo.
MEXICO CITY Three schools in Guatemala requested publications from Jehovah’s Witnesses for use in their curriculum.
Yehowa Ðasefowo na agbalẽ 3,500 siwo le Spaingbe kple Quichégbe me la sukuawo.
The Witnesses responded by donating a total of 3,500 pieces of literature in Spanish and Quiché.
Quichégbe nye Amerika Indiatɔwo ƒe gbe aɖe si nye Mayagbe ƒomevi aɖe si wodona le Guatemala ƒe ɣedzeƒetonyigbawo dzi..
Quiché is an American Indian language of the Mayan family, spoken in the western highlands of Guatemala.
Dziɖuɖu Ƒe Kɔƒenutowo Me Gɔmedzesuku si le Paraje Xepec: Nufiala aɖe zã Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe agbalẽ siwo nye Nye Agbalẽ si Nye Biblia Ŋutinyawo kple Nye Biblia Nusɔsrɔ̃wo tsɔ le nu fiam sukuviwo.
Official Rural Coeducational Elementary School in Paraje Xepec: Teacher instructing class using My Book of Bible Stories and My Bible Lessons, donated by Jehovah’s Witnesses.

Sukuawo do ta ɖe Yehowa Ðasefowo gbɔ, elabena Yehowa Ðasefowo nye habɔbɔ ʋɛ siwo taa agbalẽwo ɖe Quichégbe me la dometɔ ɖeka, eye woƒe agbalẽwo dometɔ geɖe ƒoa nu tso kuxi siwo me tom Guatemala-sɔhɛwo le la ŋu.
The schools contacted Jehovah’s Witnesses because they are one of the few organizations that produce literature in Quiché and several of their publications address issues that Guatemalan youths face.

Nufialagã Maria Cortez gblɔ le agbalẽ si Dziɖuɖu Ƒe Kɔƒenutowo Me Gɔmedzesuku si le Paraje Xepec ɖo ɖa tsɔ bia agbalẽawo me be, agbalẽ siawo akpe ɖe yewo ŋu "yewoakpɔ agbe nyui nɔnɔ ƒe dzidzenu siwo amegbetɔƒomea hiã vevie la ta. "

In an official document from the Official Rural Coeducational Elementary School in Paraje Xepec, Professor Maria Cortez outlined that the literature was requested "to rescue the values and moral principles that are much needed in society. "
Elisa Molina de Sthall Dziɖuɖu Ƒe Kɔƒenutowo Me Suku: Sukuviwo le Nye Agbalẽ si Nye Biblia Ŋutinyawo si le Quichégbe me xlẽm.
Elisa Molina de Sthall Official Rural Coeducational School: Students reading from My Book of Bible Stories in Quiché.
Numekuku si yi edzi nyitsɔ laa ɖee fia be sɔhɛwo ƒe nu vlo wɔwɔ kple ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ le dzidzim ɖe edzi le Guatemala-dukɔ bliboa me.
Recent studies indicate that criminality and violence among youths is prevalent throughout Guatemala.

Le susu sia ta la, woto habɔbɔ geɖewo vɛ le Guatemala siwo dometɔ ɖekae nye Mɔxexe Ðe Ŋutasẽnuwo Nu Ƒe Ðoɖo kple susu be woana hehe "sukuviwo, dzilawo, nufialawo, nutoa me dziɖuɖumegãwo kple nutoa me tɔwo katã be woawɔ ɖoɖo be dedienɔnɔ nanɔ sukuwo me, eye woawɔ ɖoɖo ɖe sukufefewo kple asinudɔwo fiafia hã ŋu. "

For this reason, organizations in Guatemala such as the Violence Prevention Program (VPP) have been created with the goal of engaging "students, parents, educators, local authorities, and civil society to plan safe zones around schools and provide activities and vocational training for youth[s] and young adults. "

Esia ta Dukɔa Ƒe Gɔmedzesuku Si Me Wosrɔ̃a Nu Tso Agbledede Hã Ŋu Le, Elisa Molina de Sthall Dziɖuɖu Ƒe Kɔƒenutowo Me Suku kpakple Dziɖuɖu Ƒe Kɔƒenutowo Me Gɔmedzesuku si le Paraje Xepec bia be Ðasefowo naɖo Quichégbe me gbalẽ si nye Nye Agbalẽ si Nye Biblia Ŋutinyawo ɖe yewo.

In line with these initiatives, the National Institute of Basic Education with Agricultural Orientation (INEBOA), the Elisa Molina de Sthall Official Rural Coeducational School (EORM), and the Official Rural Coeducational Elementary School in Paraje Xepec, requested copies of My Book of Bible Stories in Quiché.

Dukɔa Ƒe Gɔmedzesuku Si Me Wosrɔ̃a Nu Tso Agbledede Hã Ŋu Le bia hã be Ðasefoawo naɖo woƒe agbalẽ si kpena ɖe sɔhɛwo ŋu si ƒe tanyae nye Nya Siwo Sɔhɛwo Biana-Ŋuɖoɖo Siwo Wɔa Dɔ ƒe Babla 1 kple 2 siwo le Spaingbe me ɖe yewo.
The INEBOA also requested the Witnesses’ youth-oriented publications Volumes 1 and 2 of Questions Young People Ask-Answers that Work in Spanish.
Sukuawo na agbalẽawo sukuviawo dzilawo ale be woate ŋu akpe aɖe wo viwo ŋu woadzra ɖo ɖe woƒe sukudɔdeasi siwo ku ɖe agbe nyui nɔnɔ ŋuti nusɔsrɔ̃ ŋu le aƒe me ŋu.
The school gave copies of the books to parents so that they can help their children prepare the homework lessons for culture class.
Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, sukua le video siwo nye Vi Nudomegblẽlaa Trɔ Gbɔ, si Yehowa Ðasefowo wɔ la zãm tsɔ le nu fiam sukuviawo.
Additionally, the school added the video The Prodigal Returns, produced by Jehovah’s Witnesses, to their curriculum.

Erick De Paz, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Guatemala gblɔ be: "Togbɔ be míaƒe taɖodzinu vevitɔe nye be míagblɔ Biblia me gbedeasia na amewo le woƒe aƒewo me hã la, enye dzidzɔ na mí be nufialawo kple dzilawo siaa le míaƒe agbalẽwo zãm tsɔ le kpekpem ɖe sɔhɛwo ŋu. "

Erick De Paz, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Guatemala, states: "While our primary focus is to share our Bible-based message with people in their homes, we are happy that our publications are useful to teachers and parents for helping young people. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Na Kpekpeɖeŋu Ame Siwo Tsi Ðe Le Angola
Witnesses Assist Victims of Flooding in Angola
Tsi ɖe Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata si le Lobito, ba kple tsi siwo xɔ eme la kɔ va ɖo sentimeta 70.
A Kingdom Hall of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Lobito that was inundated with 70 cm (2 ft) of mud and water.

LUANDA, Angola Tsi gã aɖe te dzadza tso March 11, 2015 dzi le Benguela, si didi tso Luanda si nye Angola ƒe fiadu gbɔ abe kilometa 500 ene, eye tsia ɖɔ ɖe amewo. Tsiɖɔɖɔa wu ame 85 eye wògblẽ aƒe 119 dome.

LUANDA, Angola Beginning on March 11, 2015, torrential rains triggered floods that killed 85 people and destroyed 119 homes in the province of Benguela, located some 500 kilometers (310 miles) from the capital of Luanda.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Angola ka nya ta be Ðasefo aɖeke meku le afɔku sia me o, gake tsia gbã Ðasefo 11 ya ƒe aƒewo alo gblẽ nu le wo ŋu vevie.
The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Angola reported that no Witnesses were killed, but 11 of the Witnesses’ homes were destroyed or severely damaged.
Tsia gblẽ nu le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata (afi si Yehowa Ðasefowo subɔna le) ɖeka ŋu le Lobito.
In Lobito, one Kingdom Hall a local house of worship also sustained flood damage.
Le ŋufɔke la, Ðasefoawo ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti ale be woate ŋu abu nu siwo dome gblẽ la ƒe akɔnta eye woakpe ɖe ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
On the morning following the rainstorm, the Witnesses established a disaster relief committee to assess the damage and organize relief assistance.
Ðasefoawo na kpekpeɖeŋu wo nɔvi Ðasefowo kple ame siwo menye Ðasefowo o siaa le afi siwo dzɔdzɔmefɔku sia gblẽ nu le hã.
The Witnesses provided aid to both their fellow worshippers and non-Witnesses in the affected area.
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo lɔ tsi kple ba si ƒe kɔkɔme nye sentimeta 70 le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata si le Lobito la me, eye wodzra Akpataa me ɖo hewɔ kpekpe tɔxɛwo le eme le kwasiɖaa ƒe nuwuwu.

At the Kingdom Hall in Lobito, volunteers removed 70 centimeters (2 feet) of mud and water and completed other repairs in time to hold one of a series of special meetings on the weekend following the destructive rains.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Angola la teƒenɔlawo tso Luanda va kpekpe sia va gblɔ Biblia me nyawo tsɔ de dzi ƒo na Ðasefo siwo le nuto ma me.
Representatives of the Angola branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses traveled to the meetings from Luanda, providing spiritual comfort and encouragement to the local Witnesses.
Ðasefo siwo le nutoa me dzra Fiaɖuƒe Akpata si le Lobito la me ɖo heɖɔe ɖo.
Local Witness volunteers cleaned and repaired a damaged Kingdom Hall in Lobito.
Aƒetɔ Todd Peckham si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Angola la gblɔ be: "Míese veve ɖe ame siwo katã ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔ sia gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Angola, Todd Peckham, states: "We empathize with all who are recovering from the devastation of these floods.
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Angola ayi edzi anɔ kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitia ƒe dɔwo dzi kpɔm ahanɔ kpekpem ɖe nutoa me tɔwo ŋu. "
The branch office in Angola will continue to oversee the work of the disaster relief committee and provide support to those in the community. "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Ƒe Ƒe 2015 Takpekpe Gãwo Adze Egɔme Le May Me
Jehovah’s Witnesses Announce 2015 Convention Series to Begin in May
NEW YORK Yehowa Ðasefowo adze woƒe ƒe 2015 takpekpe gãwo gɔme le May 22 dzi le United States (États-Unis).
NEW YORK Jehovah’s Witnesses begin their 2015 convention series in the United States on May 22.
Ƒe 2015 "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
The 2015 "Imitate Jesus! "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Ƒe Takpekpe Gã ayi edzi le xexea me godoo va se ɖe January 2016 me.
Regional Conventions will continue worldwide through January 2016.
Le nuto ɖe sia ɖe si me woawɔ takpekpea le me la, Ðasefowo akpe amewo kwasiɖa etɔ̃ sɔŋ be woade takpekpea kpli yewo femaxee.
For each convention venue, local Witnesses will launch a three-week campaign to invite the public to attend the program free of charge.

Aƒetɔ J. R. Brown, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le woƒe dɔwɔƒegã le Brooklyn, New York gblɔ be: "Ƒe sia me ƒe takpekpea ƒe tanya he susu yi Yesu Kristo dzi be enye ame si wonya le xexea me godoo eye wòɖo kpɔɖeŋu nyui ɖi na ame ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi kple dekɔnu ɖe sia ɖe me tɔwo.

"This year’s convention theme recognizes Jesus Christ as a universally known figure and a positive role model for people of all ages, backgrounds, and cultures, " states J. R. Brown, spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses at their world headquarters in Brooklyn, New York.
Míeka edzi be nu yeye siwo woaɖe fia ku ɖe Yesu ƒe agbemenudzɔdzɔwo ŋu ado dzidzɔ na amewo.
"We believe that the public will enjoy the fresh presentation of significant events in Jesus’ life.
Wotrɔ asi le ƒe sia me ƒe takpekpe si me video wɔdɔɖeamedziwo le ŋu be wòakpe ɖe mía ŋu míasrɔ̃ Yesu le míaƒe gbe sia gbe gbenɔnɔ me. Ðoɖowɔɖia ana nyaselawo nakpɔ gome le takpekpea me bliboe. "
This year’s program promises an interactive approach, incorporating meaningful and exciting video features that will show how we can benefit from imitating Jesus in our everyday lives. "
Akpɔ ŋkeke kple teƒe siwo woawɔ Ƒe 2015 "Srɔ̃ Yesu! "
Exact dates and locations of the 2015 "Imitate Jesus! "
Nutome Gã Takpekpe le le míaƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org/ee.
Regional Conventions can be found on the Witnesses’ official website, jw.org.
Nyadzɔdzɔgblɔlawo ate ŋu ado ka kple Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si te ɖe wo ŋu bene woaxɔ Ðasefowo teƒenɔla si woakpɔ ne wodi be yewoava lé takpekpea me wɔnawo la ƒe ŋkɔ kple nyatakaka bubuwo.
Journalists may contact the nearest branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses for more information, including the name of a local media contact for reporters planning to cover the convention.
Woɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Ðe Go Le Tzotzilgbe Me Le Mexico
The New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Tzotzil Is Released in Mexico
Geoffrey Jackson, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe Dɔdzikpɔhaa me tɔ, ɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go le Tzotzilgbe me.
Geoffrey Jackson, a member of the Governing Body of Jehovah’s Witnesses, releases the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Tzotzil.
Edo Jerkil, si nye Tzotziltɔwo ƒe awu si wotsɔa alẽfu wɔna.
He is wearing a Jerkil, a traditional Tzotzil vest made of wool.
MEXICO CITY Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go le Tzotzilgbe me le takpekpe gã aɖe si wowɔ le December 26-28, 2014 le Tuxtla Gutierrez le Chiapas la me.
MEXICO CITY Jehovah’s Witnesses released the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Tzotzil at a convention held December 26-28, 2014, in Tuxtla Gutierrez, Chiapas.
Wowɔ "Yi Edzi Nànɔ Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Dim Gbã! "
The "Keep Seeking First God’s Kingdom! "
Nutome Gã Takpekpe le Tzotzilgbe si nye Mayagbe ƒomevi aɖe la me eye ame bubuwo kpɔ gome le wɔnawo me to videokadodowo dzi le takpekpewɔƒe bubu le Comitan le Chiapas.
Regional Convention was presented in Tzotzil, a Mayan language, and was transmitted to another venue in Comitan, Chiapas.
Menye Biblia koe takpekpea vala 5,073 xɔ o, woxɔ agbalẽ kple nu yeye bubu ade siwo woɖe ɖe go le Tzotzilgbe me hã.
In addition to the Bible, all 5,073 in attendance received six more new publications in Tzotzil.
Gamaliel Camarillo, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Mexico, gblɔ be: "Dzi dzɔ mí ale gbegbe esi woɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe ɖe go le Tzotzilgbe me na mí.
A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Mexico, Gamaliel Camarillo, states: "We are thrilled with the release of the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Tzotzil.
Míele mɔ kpɔm be míana Biblia sia mía havi Tzotzilgbedolawo. "
We look forward to sharing this translation with our Tzotzil-speaking neighbors. "
Ðasefo Tzotzilgbedolawo le Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia yeye si woɖe ɖe go le woƒe takpekpe gã me le Chiapas le Mexico la zãm.
Tzotzil-speaking Witnesses using the newly released New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures at the convention in Chiapas, Mexico.
Mexico-dukɔa ƒe Hahoonufiafia Ƒe Dɔwɔƒe gblɔ be ame 350,000 kple edzivɔwoe doa Tzotzilgbe le Baja California, Campeche, Chiapas, Oaxaca kple Veracruz.
The Tzotzil language is spoken by over 350,000 people in Baja California, Campeche, Chiapas, Oaxaca, and Veracruz, according to the Secretariat of Public Education for Mexico.
Be Yehowa Ðasefowo nate ŋu agblɔ Biblia me gbedeasia na Tzotzilgbedolawo la, woɖo Tzotzil-gbegɔmeɖeƒe le San Cristobal de las Casas le Chiapas, eye gbegɔmeɖelawo nye ame 15.

In order to share the Bible’s message with the Tzotzil people, the Witnesses have set up a remote translation office for the Tzotzil language composed of 15 translators located in San Cristobal de las Casas, Chiapas.
Le ƒe 2002 me la, Ðasefoawo ɖe woƒe agbalẽ gbãtɔ ɖe go le Tzotzilgbe me.
In 2002, the Witnesses released their first publication in Tzotzil.
Yehowa Ðasefowo da Tzotzilgbe me agbalẽwo kple nu bubu siwo wu 60 ɖe woƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si nye jw.org.
Jehovah’s Witnesses now have more than 60 Tzotzil publications available for download on their official website, jw.org.
Ðasefo Russiatɔ Aɖe Fɔ Ga Home Euro 6,000 Gatrɔe Na Gaa Tɔ
Russian Witness Finds 6,000 Euros and Returns Money to Owner
ST.
ST.
PETERSBURG, Russia Le November 2014 me la, Yehowa Ðasefo si ŋkɔe nye Svetlana Nemchinova fɔ agbalẽkotoku aɖe le mɔ dzi si me ga home euro 6,000 le.
PETERSBURG, Russia In November 2014, Svetlana Nemchinova, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, found an envelope on the street containing 6,000 euros (over $6,800 U.S.).
Edi gaa tɔ ʋuu keke va ke ɖe eŋu.
After a lengthy search for the owner, she was able to return the money.
Woƒo nu tso Aƒenɔ Nemchinova ƒe dɔmenyowɔwɔ sia ŋu le television kple radio dzi kpakple internet dzi nyati geɖewo me.
Ms. Nemchinova’s altruism was reported on television, the radio, and in several online news articles.
Aƒenɔ Nemchinova nye mɔdzikplɔla le du si woyɔna be Vologda me.
Ms. Nemchinova is a street cleaner in the city of Vologda, approximately 450 kilometers (280 mi) northeast of Moscow.
Du sia le Moscow ƒe dzieheɣedzeƒe eye wòdzidzi tso Moscow gbɔ kilometa 450.
While on the job, she noticed a plain envelope.
Esi wòʋui la, ekpɔ ga gbogbo aɖe le eme.
Looking inside, she discovered a large sum of money.
Togbɔ be nuwo mede Aƒenɔ Nemchinova kple viawo dzi ale o eye wole xɔ kpokploe aɖe si didi meta 4 hekeke meta 3 pɛ ko me hã la, egblɔ be: "Meva susu me nam gɔ̃ hã be mazi gaa dzi o.
Although Ms. Nemchinova and her three children live modestly in a 12-square-meter (129 sq ft) apartment, she states: "I didn’t even think of keeping the money.
Nu si va susu me nam enumakee nye ale si gaa tɔ anya nɔ nu xam ɖaa. "
Right away I thought about the person who surely was feeling terrible. "
Esi Aƒenɔ Nemchinova dze gaa tɔ didi gɔme la, eklã gaa ŋuti nyatakakawo ɖe gli siwo le afi ma ŋu.
In an effort to find the owner, Ms. Nemchinova first posted an announcement on nearby buildings.
Esi aƒenɔ Nemchinova mekpɔ gaa tɔ o la, etsɔ ga la yi ɖe gadzraɖoƒe aɖe le nutoa me, elabena ekpɔ ɖaseɖigbalẽvi si dzi gadzraɖoƒe ma ƒe ŋkɔ dze le la le agbalẽkotokua me.
When no one responded, Ms. Nemchinova took the money to a nearby bank, since the envelope of money contained a receipt with the bank’s name on it.
Gadzraɖoƒea ku nu me kpɔe be gaa tɔe nye aƒetɔ Pavel Smirnov.
The bank determined that the money belonged to Pavel Smirnov.
Gadzraɖoƒea yɔ aƒetɔ Smirnov zi geɖe hafi va ke ɖe eŋu mlɔeba, eye wona wònya be aƒenɔ Nemchinova ke ɖe eƒe ga ŋu.
After making several attempts to contact Mr. Smirnov, the bank was finally able to inform him that Ms. Nemchinova found his money.
Nyati aɖe si wota ɖe Russiatɔwo ƒe nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Premier me gblɔ be: "Svetlana mebui be nu tɔxɛ aɖee wònye yewɔ o.
An article published in the Russian newspaper Premier states: "Svetlana does not see anything outstanding in her actions.
Enye mawusubɔla eye wòxlẽa Biblia gbe sia gbe. "
She is a religious person and regularly reads the Bible. "

Aƒenɔ Svetlana Nemchinova ɖe nu me le Premier me be nu si wolɔ̃a yɔyɔ be Sikasedede si le Mateo 7:12 lae ʋã ye yetrɔ gaa na gaa tɔ. Mawunyakpukpui sia gblɔ be: "Nu sia nu si miedina be amewo nawɔ na mi la, miawo hã miwɔ nenema ke na wo. "

Ms. Nemchinova further explained to Premier that her actions were a result of applying what is often called the Golden Rule from Matthew 7:12: "All things, therefore, that you want men to do to you, you also must do to them. "
Nutala Pavel Smirnov ɖe foto kple Svetlana Nemchinova esi wòtrɔ eƒe ga si bu la nɛ megbe.
Artist Pavel Smirnov poses with Svetlana Nemchinova after she returned his lost money.
Aƒetɔ Smirnov nye nutala aɖe si to nutaŋɔ ƒomevi aɖee vɛ.
Mr. Smirnov, an artist who invented a special composition of paint, had been saving the money to purchase specialized equipment to further his research of dye structures.
Aƒetɔ sia dzra ga ɖo be yeatsɔ aƒle dɔwɔnu tɔxɛ aɖe atsɔ aku nu me yi ŋgɔe tso amadenuwo ŋu.
"Words cannot express how thankful I am to Svetlana, " stated Mr. Smirnov.
Aƒetɔ Smirnov gblɔ be: "Nyemanya ale si mada akpe na Svetlana o, nu si Svetlana wɔ la na mekpɔe be woate ŋu aka ɖe amegbetɔ dzi.
"After what Svetlana did, your faith in people is restored.
Nya ɖeka koe susɔ magblɔ: ‘Mawu li!’ "
There is only one thing left to say: ‘There is a God!’ "
Yehowa Ðasefowo Wɔ Kpekpeɖeŋunadɔwo Esi Ahom Si Woyɔna Be Pam Tu Megbe
Jehovah’s Witnesses Organize Relief Efforts in the Wake of Cyclone Pam
NOUMEA, New Caledonia (Nouvelle-Calédonie) Tso March 13, 2015 ƒe zã me la, Ahom si woyɔna be Pam tu le Vanuatu-dua ƒe Pasifik-ƒukpowo dzi, eye ahomya ƒe sesẽme nye dzidze 5.
NOUMEA, New Caledonia Beginning on the night of March 13, 2015, Tropical Cyclone Pam tore through the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu with Category 5 winds.

Nyatakaka gbãtɔ siwo míexɔ tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le New Caledonia gbɔ la ɖee fia be nu vevi mewɔ Ðasefo siwo le Vanuatu la dometɔ aɖeke o eye wo dometɔ aɖeke hã meku le ahomya sia me o.
Initial reports from the branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in New Caledonia indicate that no Witnesses in Vanuatu were killed or injured during the cataclysmic storm.
Wogakpɔtɔ le nu me kum tso nu siwo gbegbe dome gblẽ la ŋu. Gake woɖo kpe edzi be le Efate-ƒukpo dzi la, Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe 31 gbã keŋkeŋ eye nu gblẽ le aƒe 58 hã ŋu.
The scope of the damage is still being assessed, but it has been confirmed that on the island of Efate, 31 of the Witnesses’ homes were destroyed and 58 seriously damaged.
Le Tanna-ƒukpo dzi la, Ðasefowo katã kloe ƒe aƒewo gbã keŋkeŋ loo alo nu gblẽ le wo ŋu.
On the island of Tanna, almost all of the homes of the Witnesses were either severely damaged or destroyed.
Ahomya la gbã Fiaɖuƒe Akpata etɔ̃ hã, eye ati mu gblẽ nu le ɖeka hã ŋu.
Cyclone winds also destroyed three Kingdom Halls, while another was damaged by a falling tree.
Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti si woɖo le Vanuatu ƒe fiadu Port Vila me la na nuɖuɖu, tsi kple mlɔƒewo Ðasefowo ƒe ƒome 100 aɖewo.
A disaster relief committee based in Vanuatu’s capital, Port Vila, has provided food, potable water, and basic shelters to some 100 Witness families.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, woɖo kpekpeɖeŋunanu tɔn ɖeka ɖe Ðasefo siwo le Tanna be woatsɔ akpɔ woƒe hiahiã kpatawo gbɔ.
In addition, one ton of relief supplies was sent to the Witnesses in Tanna to provide for their immediate needs.

Alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Australia le asi kpem ɖe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le New Caledonia ŋu le kpekpeɖeŋunadɔawo wɔwɔ me. Dɔ sia bia be woatu mlɔƒewo, woadzra aƒewo ɖo, eye woana abawo, nudodowo kple nu bubuwo ame siwo ŋu ahom la gblẽ nu le.

The branch office in Australia is working along with the branch office in New Caledonia to support the relief efforts, which will include building shelters, repairing damaged houses, and supplying bedding material, clothing, and other provisions.

Jean-Pierre Francine si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le New Caledonia gblɔ be: "Míekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe kpekpeɖeŋunu siwo tso duta kple esiwo dziɖuɖudɔwɔƒewo na mí be míatsɔ ana kpekpeɖeŋu míaƒe haxɔsetɔwo la ŋu ŋutɔ.

Jean-Pierre Francine, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in New Caledonia, states: "We are grateful for the aid from abroad as well as the government agencies that have assisted our fellow worshipers.

Esi yameʋuwo gate Vanuatu yiyi azɔ ta la, alɔdzedɔwɔƒea teƒenɔla aɖe kple Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe dzikpɔla siwo srãa hamewo kpɔ la le nɔvi siwo le ƒukpoa dzi la gbɔ yim le kpekpeɖeŋu nam wo, eye wole akɔ fam na wo hetsɔ Biblia le dzi dem ƒo na wo. "

Now that flights to Vanuatu have resumed, a representative of the branch office in New Caledonia and traveling ministers are visiting the island to offer not only practical support but also comfort and spiritual assistance. "
Wokpɔ Mɔ Be Ame Miliɔn Blaeve Ade Yehowa Ðasefowo Ƒe Wɔna Sia
Twenty Million Estimated to Attend Witnesses’ Annual Event
NEW YORK Le Fiɖa, April 3, 2015 ƒe ɣeɖoto la, Yehowa Ðasefowo aɖu Kristo ƒe ku ƒe Ŋkuɖodzi, si wobua wɔna vevitɔ le ƒea me.
NEW YORK After sundown on Friday, April 3, 2015, Jehovah’s Witnesses will observe the Memorial of Christ’s death, an event that they consider the most important of the year.
Woaƒo miniti 45 ƒe dutoƒonuƒo si ƒe tanyae nye "Kpɔ Ŋudzedze Ðe Nu Si Kristo Wɔ Na Wò La Ŋu! " le wɔna sia me.
The commemoration includes a 45-minute public discourse entitled "Appreciate What Christ Has Done for You! "
Le kwasiɖa siwo ado ŋgɔ na wɔna vevi sia me la, Ðasefoawo adze amewo kpekpe le xexea me godoo, woakpe woƒe aƒelikawo, wo xɔlɔ̃wo kple woƒe ƒometɔwo.
In the weeks leading up to this special occasion, the Witnesses will engage in a global campaign to invite their neighbors, friends, and family members to attend.

J. R. Brown si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le woƒe dɔwɔƒegã si le Brooklyn le New York gblɔ be: "Le ƒe si va yi me la, Yehowa Ðasefo miliɔn 8 aɖewo kpe amewo na Kristo ƒe ku ƒe Ŋkuɖodzia, eye ame siwo ade miliɔn 20 woe kpɔ gome le wɔnaa me.

J. R. Brown, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses at their world headquarters in Brooklyn, New York, states: "Last year, some 8 million Jehovah’s Witnesses reached out to invite the public to the Memorial of Christ’s death, and a total of nearly 20 million were in attendance.
Le ƒe sia me la, míele mɔ kpɔm be ame siwo ava la asɔ gbɔ wu esia. "
This year, we anticipate exceeding that number. "
Ðasefowo Tsɔ Ʋu kple Yameʋu Lɔ Kpekpeɖeŋunanuwo Yi Na Ame Siwo Ŋu Tsiɖɔɖɔ Gblẽ Nu Le Le Mozambique
Witnesses Provide Air and Ground Relief After Destructive Floods in Mozambique

MAPUTO, Mozambique Tsi gã aɖe si tɔgbi mebɔ o la dza kwasiɖa geɖe le December va se ɖe January ƒe domedome le Mozambique ƒe nuto si woyɔna be Zambezia me, esia na tsi ɖe nutoa eye ame 158 ƒe agbe tsi eme.
MAPUTO, Mozambique Weeks of unusually heavy rains from December through mid-January in the Zambezia province of Mozambique led to devastating floods that killed 158 people.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Mozambique ka nya ta be nu vevi mewɔ Ðasefo aɖeke o eye wo dometɔ aɖeke hã meku o.
The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Mozambique reports that no Witnesses have been killed or injured.
Ke hã, tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ woƒe tadeaguƒe si woyɔna be Fiaɖuƒe Akpa eve kple Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe 225 dome.
However, the floodwaters damaged two places of worship, called Kingdom Halls, and destroyed 225 homes of Witnesses.
Ðasefowo ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo le dzadzram ɖo be yewoatsɔ yameʋu alɔ nuɖuɖu ayi na ame siwo tso abo le Chire-du si le Zambezia la me.
Witness volunteers prepare to airlift food supplies to the isolated Chire district of Zambezia.
Ðasefowo ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti geɖewo be woakpe ɖe ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
The Witnesses established several disaster relief committees to care for the needs of their members in the affected area.
Wona woƒe hametɔwo va tsi woƒe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖewo me gbɔ eye womaa nuɖuɖu hã le Akpata siawo me.
Some Kingdom Halls were also used as temporary shelters and food distribution centers.
Tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ tɔdzisasrã siwo dzi wotona yia Chire, si nye du aɖe si dzidzi kilometa 1,500 tso Maputo gbɔ la dome. Esia wɔe be Ðasefo 1,300 tso abo.
In Chire, which is located approximately 950 miles (1,500 km) from Maputo, floodwaters destroyed the bridges that gave access to the area, isolating more than 1,300 Witnesses.
Dukɔa ƒe Yameʋudzeƒe Ƒe Dɔdzikpɔƒea ɖe mɔ na Ðasefoawo be woate ŋu atsɔ yameʋu si woyɔna be helikɔpta alɔ kpekpeɖeŋunanu siwo wu tɔn 17 ayi na ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le.
The Institute for Civil Aviation of Mozambique granted the Witnesses permission to airdrop over 17 tons of relief supplies into the region via helicopter.
In Wole blikotokuwo dem ʋu le Morrumbala be woayi aɖama na ame siwo hiã tu.
In Morrumbala, bags of corn and corn seed being loaded for distribution
Alberto Libombo si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Mozambique gblɔ be: "Ale si míaƒe hametɔwo le asi kpem ɖe kpekpeɖeŋunadɔ si wɔm míele ŋu dɔmenyotɔe la ɖe dzesi ŋutɔ.
A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Mozambique, Alberto Libombo, states: "It has been wonderful to see the generosity of our members in helping with our local relief efforts.
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Mozambique yi edzi le nuɖuɖuwo lɔm le yiyim na ame siwo hiã tu, wole aƒewo dzram ɖo hele bubuwo tum.
The branch office in Mozambique is continuing to organize the delivery of basic foodstuffs and is arranging to rebuild and repair homes.
Míayi edzi awɔ nu sia nu si míate ŋui atsɔ Biblia me nyawo anɔ akɔ fam na ame siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le ahanɔ kpekpeɖeŋu bubuwo nam wo. "
We will continue to do all we can to keep providing spiritual comfort and assistance to the victims. "
Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖe si le Chiromo si me wole nuɖuɖu mam le gbɔ.
Kingdom Hall in Chiromo used as a temporary distribution center
Ðasefowo Ðe Kazakhstangbe Me Biblia Yeyea Fia Le Takpekpe Kple Tsaɖiɖiwɔna Me
Witnesses Feature New Kazakh Bible at Convention and Open House
Dɔdzikpɔhaa me tɔ Gerrit Lösch ɖe Kazakhstangbe me Ŋɔŋlɔ Kɔkɔeawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go.
Gerrit Lösch of the Governing Body of Jehovah’s Witnesses releases the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in Kazakh.
ALMATY le Kazakhstan woɖe Kazakhstangbe me Ŋɔŋlɔ Kɔkɔeawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe takpekpe si wowɔ le September 26-28, 2014 la me.
ALMATY, Kazakhstan The New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures was released in Kazakh at a convention of Jehovah’s Witnesses held September 26-28, 2014.
Vavala 3,721 katã xɔ Biblia yeye sia.
All 3,721 in attendance were able to receive a copy of the new Bible.

Aƒetɔ Alexander Garkavets, si nye Turkikgbe-ŋutinunyala gblɔ tso Kazakhstangbe me Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ŋu be: "Togbɔ be numekugbalẽ kple nu bubu siwo wohiã bene woate ŋu aɖe ŋɔŋlɔ kɔkɔeawo gɔme ɖe Kazakhstangbe me dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo koe li hã la, Ðasefowo ƒe gbegɔmeɖelawo te ŋu wɔ dɔ eteƒe mekɔ o.

Dr. Alexander Garkavets, a specialist in Turkic philology, commented on the New World Translation in Kazakh: "Despite the limited resources for translating holy texts into Kazakh, the Witness translators did a remarkable job.
Ale si wote ŋu to mɔ yeyewo dzi ɖe gbea gɔme ɖe Kazakhstangbe me la ɖe dzesi ale gbegbe.
It is very commendable how they revealed new ways of expressing the source text ideas in Kazakh.
Woɖe Kazakhstangbe Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖea gɔme wòsɔ ɖe ale si amewo doa gbea fifia la nu, eye esia wɔe be egɔmesese le bɔbɔe na ame sia ame. "
The New World Translation reflects the current vernacular and is thus easily understood by all. "
Tsaɖiɖiwɔnaa: Yehowa Ðasefowo tu agbadɔ aɖe si te wowɔ amedzro na tsaɖilawo le.
Open house: The Witnesses set up a traditional yurt (nomadic dwelling) where refreshments were served.
Le kwasiɖa si kplɔ takpekpea ɖo, si nye October 3 lia ƒe kwasiɖa me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Kazakhstan wɔ Biblia yeyea ɖeɖe fia ƒe ɖoɖo si me ame sia ame kpɔ gome le.
The week following the convention, on October 3, the branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Kazakhstan held an open house and featured the new Kazakh Bible.

Radio Azattyq, si nye radio-dɔwɔƒe aɖe le Kazakhstan, ka nya ta be: "Akimat (dukɔa ƒe dziɖuɖudɔwɔƒe aɖe) ƒe amegã siwo le Almaty-dua me kplɔ Aƒetɔ Nurzhan Zhaparkul (si nye Mawusubɔsubɔnyawo Dzi Kpɔƒe ƒe amegã), dutadukɔwo ƒe teƒenɔlawo, mawusubɔsubɔ ŋuti numekulawo kple bubuawo ɖo yi. "

The Kazakhstan-based news agency Radio Azattyq reported on the event: "The center was visited by the officials of the Akimat (state regional administration) of the city of Almaty, led by the head of the Department of Religious Affairs, Mr. Nurzhan Zhaparkul, representatives of the foreign diplomatic missions, experts in religious studies, and others. "
Aƒetɔ Zhaparkul gblɔ be, "Yehowa Ðasefowo xɔ mí atuu le woƒe dɔwɔƒea le Almaty.
Mr. Zhaparkul observed, "Jehovah’s Witnesses welcomed us very openly for this event in their center in Almaty.
Woƒe nuwɔna sia dze na kafukafu eye ekpe ɖe mía ŋu ŋutɔ le míaƒe dɔwɔnawo me. "
This initiative is very commendable and helps us in our work very much. "

Nurzhan Zhaparkul (domedome), Mawusubɔsubɔnyawo Dzi Kpɔƒe ƒe amegã, kple Mawusubɔsubɔnyawo Ƒe Kɔmiti ƒe amegãwo va ɖi tsa le Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒea esime Ðasefoawo kpe amewo be woava ɖi tsa le teƒea.

Nurzhan Zhaparkul (center), head of the Department of Religious Affairs, and other officials from the Committee of Religious Affairs tour the branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses during the open house.
Woma amekpegbalẽvi sia na amewo le Almaty be woava ɖi tsa le alɔdzedɔwɔƒea.
Invitations to the open house were distributed in Almaty.

Aƒetɔ Polat Bekzhan, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Kazakhstan, gblɔ be: "Míekpɔ dzidzɔ ɖe ale si amewo kpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe míaƒe takpekpea ŋu le ƒe sia me kple ale si ame geɖewo le ŋudzedze kpɔm ɖe Kazakhstangbe me Biblia yeyea ŋu la ŋuti.

A spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Kazakhstan, Polat Bekzhan, states: "We were very pleased with the response to our convention this year and how well the Kazakh Bible was received among the growing Kazakh-speaking community.

Míeɖo taɖodzinu si tae míewɔ tsaɖiɖiwɔnaa ƒe ɖoɖoa le míaƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒea hã gbɔ, eyae nye be míena mɔnukpɔkpɔ dziɖuɖumegãwo, nyakakadɔwɔlawo kple mía haviwo wova nya nu geɖe wu tso Yehowa Ðasefowo ŋu. "
Our goal in organizing the open house was also accomplished, offering government officials, the media, and our neighbors an opportunity to become more familiar with Jehovah’s Witnesses. "
Ame Siwo Tsi Agbe Le Auschwitz Aɖu Woƒe Ðeɖekpɔkpɔ Ƒe Ƒe 70 Lia, Woaɖo Ŋku Yehowa Ðasefowo Hã Dzi
Auschwitz Survivors Mark 70th Anniversary of Liberation, Jehovah’s Witnesses Among Those Remembered
WARSAW (VARSOVIE) le Poland (Pologne)​ Le January 27, 2015 dzi la, ame akpe geɖewo aɖu ɖeɖekpɔkpɔ tso Auschwitz ƒe ƒe 70 lia. Auschwitz sia nye Germany ƒe Nazitɔwo ƒe fuwɔamegakpɔ kple amewusaɖa.
WARSAW, Poland On January 27, 2015, thousands will commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, a Nazi German concentration and death camp.
Nu si tae Nazitɔwo tu fuwɔamegakpɔ dziŋɔ sia ɖoe nye be yewoazãe atsɔ atsrɔ̃ ame ƒomevi aɖewo koŋ ɖa, gake wowɔ fu Yehowa Ðasefo siwo nye dukɔ vovovowo me tɔwo hã le afi sia.
This infamous camp, primarily used to eliminate racial groups targeted by the Nazis, was also a mechanism for persecuting Jehovah’s Witnesses of various nationalities, including Germans.
Auschwitz-Birkenau ƒe Blemanudzraɖoƒe kple Auschwitz Dukɔwo Dome Adaŋudeha woe le ɖoɖo wɔm ɖe wɔnaa ŋu.
The Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum and the International Auschwitz Council are organizing the event.
Wokpɔ mɔ be Polandtɔwo ƒe dukplɔla Bronisław Komorowski ava wɔna la teƒe eye xexemedukɔ vovovowo hã aɖo woƒe dziɖuɖumegãwo ɖa.
The president of Poland, Bronisław Komorowski, is expected to attend, and several countries from around the world will send official state delegations.
Auschwitz le Oświęcim, si nye Poland-du aɖe si Nazitɔwo xɔ le Xexemeʋa II lia me ƒe golɔgoe aɖe me.
Auschwitz is located in the suburbs of Oświęcim, a Polish city annexed by the Nazis during World War II.
Le gɔmedzedzea me esi Germanytɔwo ɖo fuwɔamegakpɔ sia le June 1940 me la, wokplɔ Polandtɔ 700 va de ga le afi sia.
It began as a German concentration camp with some 700 Polish prisoners arriving there in June 1940.
Auschwitz fuwɔamegakpɔ la va keke ta kabakaba, eye wova ɖo gaxɔ gã 40 kple gaxɔ sue gbogbo aɖewo ɖe eme.
Auschwitz quickly grew into a massive complex with over 40 camps and subcamps.
Ame 20,000 aɖewo kuna le Auschwitz-Birkenau ƒe aɖiyaxɔ eneawo me gbe sia gbe.
The four gas chambers in Auschwitz-Birkenau claimed as many as 20,000 lives a day.
Woɖo ame miliɔn ɖeka kple akpe alafa ɖeka ya teti ɖe Auschwitz le ƒe atɔ̃ siwo wowɔ fu amewo le afi ma la me. Ame siawo dometɔ 400 kple edzivɔ nye Yehowa Ðasefowo.
At least 1.1 million people, including over 400 Jehovah’s Witnesses, were sent to Auschwitz during its almost five years of operation.

Wogblɔ le Auschwitz-Birkenau ƒe Blemanudzraɖoƒea ƒe nyatakakadzraɖoƒe be: "Ŋutinyagbalẽ siwo ƒo nu tso Auschwitz Fuwɔamegakpɔa ŋu meƒo nu boo tso Yehowa Ðasefo (siwo woyɔna le asaɖa la ƒe nuŋlɔɖiwo me be [Nusrɔ̃viwo]) siwo wolé de ga le woƒe mawusubɔsubɔ ta la ŋu o, negbe nya ʋɛ aɖewo ko wogblɔ tso wo ŋu.

According to the Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum website: "Aside from brief mentions, the literature on the history of Auschwitz Concentration Camp does not take account of the Jehovah’s Witnesses (referred to in the camp records as Bible [Students]) who were imprisoned because of their religious convictions.
Ehiã be míatsɔ ɖe le gamenɔla siawo hã ƒe nya me le ale si wote ŋu lé woƒe agbe nyui nɔnɔ ƒe dzidzenuwo me ɖe asi sesĩe le nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo me woto le fuwɔamegakpɔa me la ta. "
These prisoners deserve closer attention because of the way they managed to hold on to their moral principles under camp conditions. "
Blemanudzraɖoƒea ƒe nuŋlɔɖiwo ɖee fia be Yehowa Ðasefowo nɔ gamenɔla gbãtɔ siwo woɖo ɖe Auschwitz la dome. Yehowa Ðasefo alafa geɖe siwo woɖo ɖe gaxɔ sia me la dometɔ 35 le alafa me ku tsi afi sia.
Museum records indicate that Jehovah’s Witnesses were among the first prisoners sent to Auschwitz, and of the hundreds of Witnesses sent, over 35 percent died there.
Andrzej Szalbot (Gamenɔla–IBV 108703): Nazitɔwo lée le ƒe 1943 me eye wokplɔe yi Auschwitz fuwɔamegakpɔ me esi wògbe be yemakpɔ gome le asrafodɔ me o le dzitsinya ta ŋuti.
Andrzej Szalbot (Prisoner–IBV 108703): In 1943, arrested by Nazis and sent to Auschwitz for conscientiously objecting to military service.
Nazi-dziɖuɖua tɔ ŋku Yehowa Ðasefowo le ƒe 1933 ƒe gɔmedzedze eye woxe mɔ ɖe habɔbɔ sia nu le Germany-dukɔa katã me.
The Nazi government targeted the activity of Jehovah’s Witnesses as early as 1933 and banned the organization throughout Germany.
Ðasefoawo ƒe agbenɔnɔ kple woƒe nuwɔna mesɔ ɖe Nazitɔwo ƒe susuwo nu o.
The Witnesses’ moral principles and practices were not compatible with Nazi ideology.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, wobia tso amewo katã si be woagblɔ "Heil Hitler!, " gake Ðasefowo ya mate ŋu agblɔ nya sia o. Ðasefoawo bunɛ be bubu sia gbegbe dede Hitler ŋu nye nuteƒemawɔmawɔ na Mawu.
For example, the Witnesses would not offer the obligatory "Heil Hitler!, " as they considered paying homage to Hitler a betrayal of their loyalty to God.
Ðasefoawo gbe hã be yewomawɔ asrafodɔ aɖeke o, esia na be dziɖuɖua bua wo be wolé fu dukɔa.
The Witnesses also refused to perform any military-related duties, a stand the regime considered to be anti-state.
Andrzej Szalbot si wolé yi Auschwitz le ƒe 1943 me esime wòxɔ ƒe 19 la gblɔ be: "Woɖoa ame siwo gbe be yewomawɔ asrafodɔ o la ɖe fuwɔamegakpɔ me. "
"To refuse military service meant being sent to a concentration camp, " explains Andrzej Szalbot, who was arrested in 1943 and sent to Auschwitz at only 19 years of age.
Wodoa ŋugbe na Yehowa Ðasefowo be ne wode asi agbalẽ te be yewomeganye habɔbɔa me tɔ o eye wogblɔ be Ðasefoawo ƒe nufiafiawo mesɔ o la, yewoaɖe asi le wo ŋu enumake.
Jehovah’s Witnesses were promised immediate freedom if they signed a document renouncing their membership in the organization and declaring that its teachings were erroneous.
Aƒetɔ Szalbot gbe asidede agbalẽa te.
Mr. Szalbot refused to sign.
Wodo ŋugbe na Yehowa Ðasefowo be yewoaɖe asi le wo ŋu ne wogbe nu le woƒe xɔse gbɔ hede asi agbalẽvi aɖe si le abe esi le dzedzem le afi sia ene la te.
Jehovah’s Witnesses were promised release if they renounced their faith by signing a declaration similar to this one.

Wozã ŋɔŋlɔdzesi kpui si nye "IBV " na Yehowa Ðasefowo le Nazi-dziɖuɖua ƒe nuŋlɔɖiwo me. Ŋɔŋlɔdzesi sia fia Dukɔwo Dome Biblia Nusrɔ̃viwo Ƒe Habɔbɔ (eƒe Germanygbe me tɔe nye Internationale Bibelforscher-Vereinigung).

Official Nazi documentation refers to Jehovah’s Witnesses by using the abbreviation "IBV, " which stood for Internationale Bibelforscher-Vereinigung (International Bible Students Association), the official German name of their organization.
Nazitɔwo bia tso Ðasefoawo si be woade dzesidevɔ dzẽ si le dzogoe etɔ̃ me ɖe woƒe gaxɔmenɔwu ŋu.
The Nazis required the Witnesses to wear a purple triangle on their uniforms.
Dzesi sia kpe ɖe Ðasefoawo ŋu le gakpɔa me wokpɔa wo nɔviwo dzea sii bɔbɔe.
This symbol helped the Witnesses to identify their fellow believers in the camp.
Fiẽ sia fiẽ hafi gamenɔlawo nava ƒo ƒu be woayɔ wo ŋkɔ la, Ðasefoawo kpena dea dzi ƒo na wo nɔewo.
They met every evening before roll call for mutual support.
Wokpena le adzame hã dzroa Biblia me kple gamenɔla bubu siwo dzi Ðasefoawo ƒe dɔmenyonyo kple xɔse wɔ dɔ ɖo.
Secret meetings were also organized to discuss the Bible with prisoners who were impressed by the Witnesses’ kindness and faith.
Gamenɔla geɖewo va zu Yehowa Ðasefowo le Auschwitz fuwɔamegakpɔa me.
A number of prisoners became Jehovah’s Witnesses while in Auschwitz camps.
Le Memleɖa, January 27, 1945 ƒe ŋdi la, Soviet-dziɖuɖua ƒe Asrafoha Dzĩ va ɖo Oświęcim.
On Saturday morning, January 27, 1945, the Soviet Union’s Red Army arrived in Oświęcim.
Le ɣetrɔ ga 3 la, Soviet-dziɖuɖua ƒe aʋakɔa naa ablɔɖe gamenɔla 7,000 siwo le Auschwitz I, Auschwitz II (Birkenau) kple Auschwitz III (Monowitz).
By 3 p.m., the Soviet forces had liberated some 7,000 prisoners from Auschwitz I, Auschwitz II (Birkenau), and Auschwitz III (Monowitz).
Stanisław Zając.
Stanisław Zając.
Eva ɖo Auschwitz le February 16, 1943.
Arrived in Auschwitz on February 16, 1943.
Yehowa Ðasefo si ŋkɔe nye Stanisław Zając nɔ ame akpe geɖe siwo dzi Nazitɔwo zi be woadzo le Auschwitz fuwɔamegakpɔa me hafi Asrafoha Dzĩa nava ɖo la dome.
Stanisław Zając, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, was among the tens of thousands forced by the Nazis to evacuate the Auschwitz camps in anticipation of the Red Army’s approach.
Aƒetɔ Zając kple gamenɔla siwo ade 3,200 ʋu tso asaɖa sue si nye Jaworzno me hezɔ kuzɔli dziŋgɔ ma to sno dziŋɔ ma me.
Mr. Zając and about 3,200 other prisoners left the Jaworzno subcamp and trudged through deep snow as part of the infamous death march.
Wobu akɔnta be gamenɔla siwo tso asaɖa ma me la dometɔ siwo tsi agbe le ŋkeke etɔ̃ ƒe azɔli ma me va ɖo Blechhammer, si nye Auschwitz ƒe asaɖa sue aɖe si le ave me la mede 2,000 o.
It is estimated that less than 2,000 survived the three-day walk to Blechhammer, an outlying Auschwitz subcamp located in the forest.

Le nu siwo Aƒetɔ Zając ŋlɔ ɖi ku ɖe nudzɔdzɔ ma ŋu me la, eƒo nu tso aʋa aɖe si fe ati le asaɖa la me eye eya kple gamenɔla bubuwo be ɖe asaɖa la me ŋu. Egblɔ be: "Míekpɔ aʋawɔʋuwo va nɔ yiyim, gake mía dometɔ aɖeke mete ŋu do dzi be yeakpɔ ɖa be ame kawo wonye mahã o.

In his memoirs, Mr. Zając recalled the battle that ensued while he and other prisoners were hiding in the camp: "We could hear tanks passing by, but nobody got up the courage to go and see to whom they belonged.
Le ŋufɔke ƒe ŋdi la, míede dzesii be Russiatɔwoe. . . .
In the morning, it turned out they were Russian. . . .
Russiatɔwo xɔ avea me katã, eye gbe ma gbee fu dziŋɔ siwo mekpe le asaɖa ma me la wu enu. "
The Russian army was filling the wide clearing and this is where my concentration camp nightmare ended. "
Le ƒe sia me la, woawɔ takpekpe kple ɖeɖefia siwo ku ɖe ablɔɖekpɔkpɔ le Auschwitz ƒe ƒe 70 lia ɖuɖu ŋu le January 27 le du vovovo me le xexea me godoo
This year, on January 27, conferences and exhibitions related to the 70th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz will take place in various cities around the world.
Ƒe Ðeka Le Ahom Si Nye Haiyan Tutu Megbe, Amewo Yi Aƒe Yeyewo Me
One Year After Typhoon Haiyan, Storm Victims Settle Into New Homes
MANILA le Philippines Yehowa Ðasefowo de xɔtudɔ gã nyadri aɖe to me le esi ahom gã si woyɔ be Haiyan tu vɔ megbe be woadzra aƒewo ɖo alo atso yeyewo kura le ƒe ɖeka me, aƒeawo katã ƒe xexlẽme le 750.
MANILA, Philippines Jehovah’s Witnesses launched a massive construction effort following Super Typhoon Haiyan to repair or rebuild almost 750 homes in less than one year.
Xɔtulawo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo si me ame atɔ̃ le la wua aƒe ɖeka nu le ŋkeke atɔ̃ me le mama dedie nu.
On average, a team of five construction volunteers could rebuild a home in five days.
Dean Jacek, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Philippines, gblɔ be: "Míeɖoe be míawu dɔa nu le September 2014 me.
Dean Jacek, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in the Philippines, explains: "We set a goal of completing the work by September 2014.
Míedze dɔa gɔme le ƒea ƒe gɔmedzedze, gake esi lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla gbogbo aɖewo kpe ɖe mía ŋu ta la, míete ŋu wu dɔa nu do ŋgɔ na August ƒe nuwuwu. "
Building work began early in the first part of the year and, with the help of so many volunteers, the construction was completed before the end of August. "
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔla siwo nye dumeviwo kple dutatɔwo siaa kpɔ gome le xɔtudɔawo wɔwɔ me.
Local and international volunteers assisted in the rebuilding effort.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe Dɔdzikpɔha ɖo ga siwo Ðasefo siwo le xexea me godoo dzɔ la ƒe akpa aɖe ɖa be woatsɔ awɔ kpekpeɖeŋunadɔ sia.
The Governing Body of Jehovah’s Witnesses allocated donations sent by fellow worshippers from around the world to fund the relief project.
Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Manila la ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmitiwo le nuto siwo ŋu ahom la gblẽ nu le la me ale be woakpɔ aƒewo tsotso dɔa dzi.
The Witnesses’ branch office in Manila established relief committees to organize the rebuilding work in the affected areas.
Aƒe siwo wodzra ɖo kple yeye siwo wotso le Tacloban Dua me la le 167, Ormoc Dua me tɔwo le 256, Cebu Dua me tɔwo le 101 eye Roxas Dua me tɔwo hã le 218.
This included the repair or complete reconstruction of 167 homes in Tacloban City, 256 homes in Ormoc City, 101 homes in Cebu City, and 218 homes in Roxas City.
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo dometɔ 522 nye Philippines-vi dzidziwo eye Ðasefo 90 hã tso dukɔ bubuwo me.
A volunteer workforce, made up of 522 Witnesses from the Philippines and 90 Witnesses from other countries, participated in the work.
Aƒetɔ Ferdinand Martin G. Romualdez, si nye Leyte Nuto Gbãtɔ teƒenɔla.
Rep. Ferdinand Martin G. Romualdez, First District of Leyte.
Aƒetɔ Ferdinand Martin G. Romualdez, si nye Leyte Nuto Gbãtɔ teƒenɔla gblɔ be: "Yehowa Ðasefowoe nye habɔbɔ siwo menye dziɖuɖu tɔ o ƒe gbãtɔ siwo dze aƒewo dzadzra ɖo dɔwo gɔme la dometɔ ɖeka. . . .

Mr. Ferdinand Martin G. Romualdez, representative of the First District of Leyte, observed: "The Jehovah’s Witnesses were one of the first non-government groups to undertake a house-rebuilding initiative. . . .
Mímate ŋu agblɔ ale si nye kple nye ƒomea kpakple mía detɔwo míekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe miaƒe agbagbadzedzewo ŋu la wòade edeƒe o. "
Words cannot fully express the appreciation and gratitude of my family and our people. "
Dukɔwo Dome Takpekpe Ŋuti Nyatakakawo: Ðasefowo Ðe Biblia Ðe Go Le Seoul Ƒe Bɔlƒoƒe Gã
International Convention Coverage: Witnesses Release Bible at World Cup Stadium in Seoul
Dɔdzikpɔhaa me tɔ David Splane ɖe Ŋɔŋlɔ Kɔkɔeawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia yeyea ɖe go le Koreagbe me.
David Splane, a member of the Governing Body, releases the revised New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in Korean.
SEOUL​ Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖe Ŋɔŋlɔ Kɔkɔeawo​ Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia yeyea ɖe go le "Yi Edzi Nànɔ Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Dim Gbã! "
SEOUL Jehovah’s Witnesses released the revised New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in Korean during the "Keep Seeking First God’s Kingdom! "
Dukɔwo Dome Takpekpe me le Seoul le Korea.
International Convention in Seoul, Korea.
Wowɔ wɔnaa le Seoul Ƒe Bɔlƒoƒe Gã le September 6-8, 2014 dzi.
The event was held in the Seoul World Cup Stadium on September 6-8, 2014.

Ame 56,867 siwo kpɔ gome le wɔnaa me le bɔlƒoƒe sia kple ame 59,091 siwo kpɔ gome le eme le Busan, Daejeon, Gwangju, Jeju, Suwon kple Yeosu to videokadodowo dzi la dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe xɔ Biblia ɖeka femaxee.
Bibles were made available free of charge to all 56,867 in attendance, as well as to the 59,091 tied-in at satellite locations in Busan, Daejeon, Gwangju, Jeju, Suwon, and Yeosu.
Takpekpea valawo dometɔ ɖeka si ŋkɔe nye Joon-yeong Choi gblɔ be: "Takpekpea ƒe akpa si womaŋlɔ be kpɔ gbeɖe o lae nye akpa si woɖe Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go le. "
In the words of one attendee, Joon-yeong Choi, "The most unforgettable moment of this convention was the release of the revised New World Translation. "
Vavala 56,000 kple edzivɔwo se vivi na wɔna si wotu ɖe Biblia dzi
The over 56,000 attendees in the stadium enjoy the Bible-based program.
Ðasefowo tso Canada, Finland, Philippines, Poland (Pologne) kple Amerika va takpekpea le Seoul.
Witnesses from Canada, Finland, the Philippines, Poland, and the United States traveled to attend the program in Seoul.

Dae-il Hong, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Korea, gblɔ be: "Míewɔ dɔ kutrikukutɔe tsɔ dzra ɖo ɖe hehexɔxɔ ƒe ɖoɖo wɔdɔɖeamedzi sia ŋu, eye takpekpea ƒe wɔnawo gbɔ nu siwo míenɔ mɔ kpɔm na la ŋu sãsãsã.
Dae-il Hong, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Korea, stated: "We worked hard in preparing for this stirring, educational event, and the convention exceeded our expectations.
Mɔnukpɔkpɔ gã aɖee wònye na mí be wowɔ takpekpe tɔxɛ sia le mía gbɔ. "
It was an honor to host this special occasion. "
Biblia ƒe nɔnɔme siwo wokpa tsɔ ɖo atsyɔ̃ na bɔlƒoƒea.
Bible sculptures decorating the field.
Vavala siwo nɔ Seoul ƒe bɔlƒoƒea ƒe nu ku esi wova kpɔe be sigbeɖe nyɔnyrɔxɔƒewoe Biblia ƒe nɔnɔme siwo wokpa tsɔ ɖo atsyɔ̃ na bɔlƒoƒea la dometɔ etɔ̃ aɖewo nye.
The audience in the Seoul World Cup Stadium was thrilled when three large Bible sculptures decorating the field were revealed to be baptismal pools.
Wonyrɔ ame 630 le Seoul eye wonyrɔ ame 596 bubuwo le takpekpewɔwɔƒe bubuawo. Ale wɔ ame siwo katã wonyrɔ la ƒe agbɔsɔsɔme va nye 1,226.
A total of 630 people were baptized in Seoul and an additional 596 at the satellite locations, for a combined total of 1,226 baptized.
Nyɔnyrɔxɔƒe siwo nye Biblia ƒe nɔnɔme siwo wokpa.
Bible sculptures used as baptismal pools.
Yehowa Ðasefowo Na Be Wova Le Dɔ Wɔm Na Amewo Ʋumadomadoe Le Denmark
Jehovah’s Witnesses Provide Stimulus for Bloodless Surgery in Denmark
COPENHAGEN le Denmark​ Denmark ƒe nyakakadɔwɔƒe gãgãwo gblɔ be ɖɔkta siwo le Fiadua ƒe nutoa me va le tɔtrɔm ɖe ʋuŋudɔwɔwɔ nyuie ƒe mɔnu yeye aɖe ŋu.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark Denmark’s top media outlets have been reporting that the Capital Region’s medical community is adopting a new approach to blood management.
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Kristeligt Dagblad gblɔ be "woate ŋu awɔ dɔ na dɔnɔ geɖe wu evɔ womado ʋu si amewo na la na wo o. "
According to the journal Kristeligt Dagblad, "it has been discovered that many more patients can do without donated blood. "
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽa yi edzi be, "Yehowa Ðasefowoe na be wova le dɔ wɔm na amewo ʋumadomadoe. "
The journal continues, "Jehovah’s Witnesses have been the reason why blood-free surgery has been introduced. "
Yehowa Ðasefo 8,000,000 siwo le xexea me godoo, siwo dome Yehowa Ðasefo 14,000 siwo le Denmark hã le la, dina be woazã atikewɔmɔnu nyuitɔ kekeake na yewo ʋumadomadoe.
Based on their religious convictions, the over 8,000,000 Jehovah’s Witnesses worldwide, including over 14,000 members in Denmark, seek the best medical care available without blood transfusions.
Wonya kɔdzi siwo le Denmark be wodoa ʋu siwo amewo nana la na dɔnɔwo wu le xexea me godoo, ame siwo wodoa ʋu na tea ŋu sɔa gbɔ wu esiwo Europa-dukɔ bubuwo ƒe kɔdziwo dona na la zigbɔzi eve gɔ̃ hã.
Danish hospitals have been known as the largest per capita users of donated blood in the world, even as much as 50-100 percent more than other European hospitals.

Ke hã, Politiken si nye nyatakakadzraɖoƒe si dzi wogblɔa nyadzɔdzɔwo le ƒe nyati si nye "Dɔwɔwɔ Na Ame Ʋumadomadoe Le Ta Kekem " gblɔ be: "Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒoe ɖe ɖɔktawo nu wova le atikewɔmɔnu yeyewo ŋu dɔ wɔm " siwo to vovo na atikewɔmɔnu siwo me wozãa ʋu si amewo nana le la zi geɖe.

However, in the article "Bloodless Surgery is Gaining Ground, " the news site Politiken notes, "Jehovah’s Witnesses get doctors to explore alternatives " to treatments often performed with donated blood.

Ðɔkta aɖewo va te amekomɔnu siwo me ʋu medona le ame ŋu fũu o zazã na Ðasefowo ƒe dɔnɔwo. Mɔnu siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye atike siwo nye erythropoietin kple iron (fer) kple vitamin B dodo na dɔnɔa do ŋgɔ na dɔwɔwɔ nɛ alo atike ƒomevi aɖewo dodo na dɔnɔa le dɔa wɔɣi.

In caring for Witness patients, some doctors have begun using a number of blood conservation practices, such as preoperative use of erythropoietin and iron and B-complex vitamins, and intraoperative use of antifibrinolytics.
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ (The Copenhagen Post) aɖe gblɔ be "ƒe sia ƒe la, wokoa dzi na Yehowa Ðasefo atɔ̃ alo ade le Aarhus Yunivɛsiti Kɔdzi Skejby " evɔ womezãa ʋu siwo amewo nana la na wo o.
According to The Copenhagen Post, "each year, between five and ten Jehovah’s Witnesses go through extensive heart surgery at Aarhus University Hospital Skejby " without the use of donated blood.

Rigshospitalet kɔdzi, si nye kɔdzi tɔxɛ aɖe eye wòganye Denmark ƒe atikewɔwɔ ŋuti nusrɔ̃ƒe gãtɔ la, de ɖoɖo aɖe to me le ƒe 2009 me le woƒe Fiadua ƒe nutoa me si ana be woakpɔ dɔnɔwo ƒe ʋu ta ne wole dɔ wɔm na wo.
Rigshospitalet, a highly specialized hospital and one of Denmark’s largest educational institutions for medical sciences, initiated a blood management project in 2009 for the Capital Region.
Ðɔkta siwo le Denmark gblɔ hã be numekuku geɖewo va le eɖem fia be afɔku gã aɖewo le ʋudodo me.
The medical community in Denmark has also recognized a growing body of clinical evidence that blood transfusions carry significant risks.

Kɔdzi si woyɔna be Rigshospitalet, si le Copenhagen, de ɖoɖo aɖe to me le ƒe 2009 me si nye be woakpɔ egbɔ be ʋu boo mado le dɔnɔwo ŋu le dɔwɔwɔ na wo me o. Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Berlingske gblɔ be ɖoɖo sia na be ʋu si amewo nana la dodo na amewo dzi ɖe kpɔtɔ zã eye esia wɔe be dɔnɔwo "megadoa go kuxi boo le dɔwɔwɔ na wo me o, eye wo dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo koe kuna. "

Rigshospitalet, in Copenhagen, instituted a blood management project in 2009, which the newspaper Berlingske reports has significantly reduced the usage of donated blood and has resulted in patients having "fewer complications and a lower mortality rate. "
Eye kɔdzi siwo le Fiadua ƒe nutoa me ƒe akpa gãtɔ hã va da asi ɖe ɖoɖo sia dzi ɣeyiɣi aɖee nye esia, eye kɔdzi siwo le nuto bubuwo me hã le ɖoɖo wɔm be yewo hã yewoadze egɔme.
Most of the other hospitals in the Capital Region have since joined the project, and hospitals in other regions are planning to follow suit.

Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Berlingske hã gblɔ ale si Ðɔkta Morten Bagge Hansen, si nye numekula kple ʋu siwo amewo nana la dzraɖoƒe dzi kpɔla le Rigshospitalet kɔdzi gblɔ be ale si woɖe ʋudodo dzi kpɔtɔ zã le Denmark la nye "ŋgɔyiyi gã aɖe si aɖe vi gbogbo aɖe na dɔnɔwo. "

Berlingske also relates how Dr. Morten Bagge Hansen, a researcher and head of the blood bank at Rigshospitalet, describes Denmark’s significant reduction in the use of donated blood as "substantial progress that really benefits the patients. "

Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, wogblɔ le Denmark Radio dzi kple nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Kristeligt Dagblad hã me be Ðɔkta Astrid Nørgaard, si nye Atikewɔlawo ƒe Amegã le Rigshospitalet kɔdzi, gblɔ be "Yehowa Ðasefowo tɔ manɔmee la, mímaɖo afi si míeɖo fifia le dɔwɔwɔ na amewo ʋumadomadoe ƒe nyawo me o. "

Further, Denmark Radio and Kristeligt Dagblad both cite Dr. Astrid Nørgaard, Medical Director at Rigshospitalet, as concluding that "bloodless surgery would not be where it is today, if it were not for Jehovah’s Witnesses. "
Mexico Dumegãwo Kafu Ðasefowo Ðe Ale Si Wodzra Kamedefefewɔƒea Ðo Ta
Officials in Mexico Applaud Witnesses’ Cleanup of Community Sports Facility

MEXICO CITY Yehowa Ðasefo siwo wu 250 tsɔ wo ɖokuiwo na faa be yewoadzra Baldomero "Melo " Almada kamedefefewɔƒea ɖo le June 7, 2014 dzi hena wɔna tɔxɛ aɖe si woawɔ le nutoa me ta, eye dumegãwo kafu Ðasefoawo ɖe ale si wowɔ dɔ siae ta.

MEXICO CITY Over 250 Jehovah’s Witnesses volunteered to help clean the Baldomero "Melo " Almada sports facility on June 7, 2014, in preparation for a special community event, moving local officials to express appreciation.

Nufialagã Antonio Cota Márquez, si nye Huatabampo Kamedefefewɔƒea dzi kpɔla le Mexico di lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo ɣleti geɖe be woadzra kamedefefewɔƒea ɖo ale be wòasɔ gbe hafi dudzikpɔla nava kɔ duƒuƒe yeye si wowɔ ɖe kamedefefewɔƒea la ŋu le July 7, 2014 dzi.

For months, Professor Antonio Cota Márquez, the director of the Municipal Sports Institute in Huatabampo, Mexico, sought volunteers to help clean the stadium in time for the governor to inaugurate the new running track on July 7, 2014.

Yehowa Ðasefowo wɔ ɖe ameyɔyɔ sia dzi va kpe asi ɖe eya kple ame siwo dzraa teƒea ɖo la ŋu wodzra teƒea ɖo, woɖe gbeɖuɖɔwo ɖa le teƒeteƒewo, wosi aŋɔ na basketbɔlƒoƒe ƒe atiwo eye wodzra sɔgbewo dzi ɖo hã.

Jehovah’s Witnesses responded favorably to the director’s request and assisted him and the facility’s cleaning personnel with much-needed improvements, including removing garbage from the stadium, repainting the basketball backboards, and caring for grounds maintenance.
Kpekpewɔƒe si le kamedefefewɔƒea, afi si Ðasefoawo wɔa woƒe kpekpe si wotu ɖe Biblia dzi la le.
Auditorium, within the sports facility, where the Witnesses hold free Bible-education programs.

Aƒetɔ Cota mia asi Ðasefoawo, elabena enya nu tso ale si Ðasefoawo dzraa kamedefefewɔƒea ƒe akpa aɖe si wowɔa woƒe takpekpe siwo wotuna ɖe Biblia dzi le le Spaniagbe kple Mayogbe me edziedzi ɖo nyuie la ŋu.

Director Cota decided to contact the Witnesses because he was already familiar with how they care for one of the auditoriums at the sports facility where they regularly hold free Bible-education programs in the Spanish and Mayo languages.
Esi Aƒetɔ Cota kpɔ ale si Ðasefoawo dzra teƒea ɖo heɖɔ nuwo ɖoe la, egblɔ le gbebiame aɖe me be: "Dzi dzɔ mí be ame siwo media wo ɖokui tɔ o tsɔ woƒe ɣeyiɣi va dzra kamedefefewɔƒea ɖo. "

After observing the way the Witnesses cleaned and repaired the facility, Director Cota said in an interview: "We are glad to see selfless people who are devoting some of their time to clean our sports facility. "
Egblɔ emegbe be: "Mele dudzikpɔla Aƒetɔ Ramón Díaz Nieblas teƒe le akpe dam na mi ɖe dɔ si miewɔ egbea ta.
He later made the statement: "On behalf of our mayor, Ramón Díaz Nieblas, please accept our appreciation for your work this day.
Míayi edzi anɔ megbe dam na miaƒe habɔbɔa ɣesiaɣi si miadi be yewoazã teƒe sia.
We will continue to support your organization’s use of this facility.
Míekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe miaƒe kpekpeɖeŋu kple miaƒe nuwɔwɔ aduadu la ŋu. "
We are very pleased with your responsible and cooperative work. "
Ðasefowo Na Kpekpeɖeŋu Ame Siwo Ŋu Ba Siwo Dudu Le Towo Dzi Gblẽ Nu Le Le Hiroshima
Witnesses Assist Victims of Hiroshima Mudslides
EBINA, Japan Tsi gã aɖe si dza le Hiroshima le August 20, 2014 dzi la na be ba dudu tso towo dzi va wu ame 74 eye ame 1,600 ʋu le woƒe aƒewo me le August 20, 2014 ƒe ŋdi.
EBINA, Japan Heavy rainfalls in Hiroshima led to catastrophic landslides that killed some 74 people and displaced over 1,600 on the morning of August 20, 2014.
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Japan ka nya ta be Ðasefo aɖeke meku o eye nu vevi mewɔ ɖeke hã o. Ke hã Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe enyi dome gblẽ.
The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Japan reports that no Witnesses were killed or injured, although eight homes of the Witnesses were damaged.
Xɔ aɖe si dome gblẽ le Hiroshima.
Interior of a damaged home in Hiroshima.
Esi tsi si ƒe titrime ade milimeta 218 dza gaƒoƒo etɔ̃ pɛ ko la, egblẽ nu geɖe eye esia na be dziɖuɖua de ameɖeɖedɔ aɖe to me.
About 8.5 inches [218 mm] of rain fell over the course of only three hours, causing extensive damage and prompting the government to initiate a national rescue effort.
Enumake Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Japan ɖo kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti aɖe anyi eye Ðasefowo ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo na kpekpeɖeŋu le teƒea dzadzra ɖo me.
The Japan branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses quickly established a disaster relief committee and organized Witness volunteers to help with the clean-up.
Dɔa wɔlawo ɖo le akasa nu nɔ gbeɖuɖɔawo kple kewo lɔm.
The clean-up crews formed a bucket brigade to remove dirt and sand that had washed into homes.
Lɔlɔ̃nu faa dɔwɔlawo wu dɔlékuiwutikewo ɖe teƒe siwo wodzra aƒemenuwo ɖo.
The volunteers also disinfected cleared areas after storing any salvageable household goods.
Ðasefowo le bawo lɔm le xɔwo me.
Witnesses remove mud and sludge from a residential building.
Dukɔa ƒe nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Yomiuri Shimbun ƒo nu tso agbagba si Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe si tsi agbe le dzɔdzɔmefɔku sia me dze la ŋu.
National newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun documented the efforts of one of Jehovah’s Witnesses who survived the accident.
Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽa gblɔ be esi Kayoko Nakamizo, si le Asaminami le Yagi-nuto me dze agbagba te ŋu si le eƒe aƒe me la, "eƒo eƒe aƒelikawo ƒe ʋɔtru ɖe sia ɖe be yeakpɔ ɖa be wole dedie mahã. "

The newspaper reported that Kayoko Nakamizo, who lives in the Yagi district of Asaminami Ward, escaped out of her own home and then "she knocked on each door, checking on the safety of the residents. "
Esia wɔe be Kayoko te ŋu ɖe eƒe aƒelika aɖe ƒe agbe eye wòkpe ɖe amewo ŋu wodzo le afɔkuteƒea.
As a result, Kayoko was able to help rescue a neighbor and assist others in evacuating from the disaster area.
Ichiki Matsunaga, si nye Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe nyanuɖela le Japan, gblɔ be: "Míese veve ɖe ame siwo ŋu baawo gblẽ nu le la nu.
Ichiki Matsunaga, a spokesman for Jehovah’s Witnesses in Japan, states: "We empathize with those who have been affected by the mudslides.
Togbɔ be nɔnɔmeawo sesẽ hã la, dzi le mía ƒo míele kpekpeɖeŋu siwo hiã la nam mía haviwo hele akɔ fam na wo. "
In spite of the difficult situation, we are maintaining a positive attitude as we do our best to provide practical help and comfort to our neighbors. "
Nyatakaka Yeyewo: Yehowa Ðasefowo Na Kpekpeɖeŋu Ame Akpe Geɖe Siwo Si Aʋa Le Ukraine
Update: Jehovah’s Witnesses Organize Relief for Thousands Displaced in Ukraine
LVIV, Ukraine Yehowa Ðasefowo yi edzi le kpekpem ɖe wo nɔvi siwo ŋu aʋa siwo dzɔ le Ukraine ƒe ɣedzeƒenuto me gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
LVIV, Ukraine Jehovah’s Witnesses continue to assist fellow worshippers displaced by the war that has gripped the eastern region of Ukraine.
Ðasefo abe 7,500 aɖewoe si aʋa, eye kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti adre siwo Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒe si le Lviv ɖo la le kpekpem ɖe ame siwo ade 4,000 ŋu.
Of the approximately 7,500 Witnesses that have fled the war zone, almost 4,000 are being cared for by seven disaster relief committees organized by the Lviv branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Ðasefo susɔeawo le woƒe ƒometɔwo kple wo nɔvi Ðasefo bubuwo gbɔ le Ukraine kple Russia.
The remaining victims are being accommodated by relatives and fellow worshippers in Ukraine and Russia.
Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti ade bubuwo le kpekpem ɖe Ðasefo siwo wu 17,500 ŋu le teƒe siwo wole aʋaa wɔm le.
Six additional relief committees are caring for the more than 17,500 Witnesses still living in the war zone.
Bɔmbwo wó gbã Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe geɖewo; wo dometɔ ɖekae nye esi le Semenivka kɔƒe le Donetsk nutoa me.
Bombs destroyed several homes of the Witnesses, including this one in the village of Semenivka, in the Donetsk region.
Lviv alɔdzedɔwɔƒea ka nya ta be Ðasefo ade ye ku tso esime aʋaa dze egɔme.
The Lviv branch confirmed that a total of six Witnesses have lost their lives since the war began.
Ðasefo aɖe si le Kramatorsk ku le June 17, 2014 dzi esime bɔmb aɖe wó le eƒe ʋu gbɔ.
One Witness in Kramatorsk died on June 17, 2014, when a bomb exploded next to the car he was in.
Bɔmb gawu Ðasefo atɔ̃ bubu siwo le du siwo nye Donetsk, Sloviansk, Rozkishne kple Luhansk hã me.
