International delegates are warmly welcomed as they arrive at Sky Harbor International Airport in Phoenix
Tsidzadza Sesẽwo Gblẽ Nu Le Philippines
Monsoon Rains Hit the Philippines
Le August 2019 ƒe gɔmedzedze lɔƒo la, tsidzadza kple yaƒoƒo sesẽwo gblẽ nu le Philippines, si he tsiɖɔɖɔwo kple agaɖeviwo vɛ.
PIn early August 2019, monsoon weather struck the Philippines with heavy rains and strong winds, causing flooding and landslides.
Nublanuitɔe la, nɔviŋutsu aɖe si nɔ ɣeyiɣi aɖe ƒe mɔɖela vevi dɔa wɔm la ku le agaɖevi si dzɔ le Natonin, si le nuto si woyɔna be Mountain Province la me.
Sadly, one brother who was serving as a temporary special pioneer was killed by a landslide in Natonin, Mountain Province.
Nɔviŋutsu bubu aɖe si hã nɔ ɣeyiɣi aɖe ƒe mɔɖela vevi dɔa wɔm la xɔ abi vie le agaɖevi ma ke me.
Another brother, who also serves as a temporary special pioneer, sustained minor injuries in the same landslide.
Le agaɖevi bubu me la, nuvevi wɔ ŋutsuvi aɖe si xɔ ƒe ewo, gake wowɔ atike nɛ hekpɔ egbɔ nyuie.
In a separate incident, a ten-year old boy was injured by debris but received appropriate medical care.
Nu megblẽ le mía nɔviwo dometɔ aɖeke ƒe aƒe ŋu vevie o.
None of our brothers’ homes were seriously damaged.
Ke hã, nu gblẽ le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖe si le Negros Occidental la ŋu vie esi ya ƒo sesĩe si wɔe be Akpataa ƒe xɔmesasrã ƒe akpe aɖe dzɔ ɖe anyigba.
However, one Kingdom Hall in Negros Occidental suffered minor damage from strong winds that caused a portion of the ceiling to fall.
Philippines Alɔdzedɔwɔƒea kple nutome sue dzikpɔla si le nutoa me la tsɔ Biblia me nyawo le akɔ fam na nɔvi siwo ŋu afɔku sia gblẽ nu le hele dzi dem ƒo na wo.
The Philippines branch office and the local circuit overseer are providing spiritual and emotional support to the families of our affected brothers.
Ete ɖe mía dzi be mía nɔvi lɔlɔ̃a ku le afɔku sia me, eye míele gbe dom ɖa ɖe ame siwo le nu xam le eƒe kua ta la ta.
We are saddened to hear of this tragic loss and pray for those grieving the death of our brother.
Míele mɔ kpɔm vevie na ɣeyiɣi si me nudzɔdzɔ dovevesesename siawo "magava susu me na ame " gɔ̃ hã o.
We look forward to the day when painful events will not even "be called to mind. "
Yesaya 65:17
Isaiah 65:17.
Anyigbaʋuʋu Sesẽwo Gblẽ Nu Le California Ƒe Anyiehe Vevie
Earthquakes Rattle Southern California
Tso July 4, 2019 dzi la, anyigbaʋuʋu sẽŋuwo kple anyigbaʋuʋu suesuesue siwo va ɖe eyome la gblẽ nu le California ƒe anyiehe le Mojave Dzogbe ƒe nutoa me.
Since July 4, 2019, powerful earthquakes and aftershocks have struck southern California in the Mojave Desert region.
Le anyigbaʋuʋu mawo me la, wo dometɔ ɖeka ƒe dzidzee nye 7.1, eye woka nya ta be eyae nye anyigbaʋuʋu sesẽtɔ kekeakewo dometɔ ɖeka si dzɔ le ƒe blaeve siwo va yi me le nuto sia me.
This includes a 7.1-magnitude quake that is considered to be one of the strongest recorded in this area in the last two decades.
Nuto si me anyigbaa ʋuʋu le la te ɖe du si nye Ridgecrest ŋu, eye gbeƒãɖela 215 sɔŋ ye le nuto ma me.
The quakes occurred near the city of Ridgecrest, which is home to 215 publishers.
Gake dzidzɔtɔe la, wo dometɔ aɖeke medze afɔku vevie o.
Thankfully, none of our brothers were seriously injured.
Ke hã, nu vevi wɔ gbeƒãɖela etɔ̃ aɖewo ya vie, eye nyatakaka siwo míexɔ va se ɖe fifia ɖee fia be gbeƒãɖela adre zu aƒemanɔsitɔwo.
However, three publishers sustained minor injuries, and initial reports indicate that seven publishers are displaced.
Azɔ hã, nu gblẽ le mía nɔviwo ƒe aƒe 7 ŋu vevie ŋutɔ eye nu gblẽ le aƒe 35 bubuwo hã ŋu vie.
Also, 7 homes of our brothers were heavily damaged and 35 sustained minor damage.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, nu gblẽ le Fiaɖuƒe Akpata eve hã ŋu vie.
Additionally, two Kingdom Halls were lightly damaged.
Nutome sue dzikpɔla eve le ɖoɖo si wowɔ ɖe kpekpeɖeŋunana mía nɔvi siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋuawo gblẽ nu le la dzi kpɔm.
Two circuit overseers are coordinating the relief efforts in the area.
Nutome sue dzikpɔlaawo kple nutoa me hamemetsitsiwo le dzi dem ƒom na nɔvi siwo ŋu anyigbaʋuʋuawo gblẽ nu le hele akɔ fam na wo.
The circuit overseers and local elders are also shepherding the brothers and sisters affected by the earthquake.
Míele gbe dom ɖa be Yehowa ayi edzi ana nunya si mía nɔviawo hiã be woatsɔ anɔ te ɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔku siawo tɔgbi nu la wo.
We pray that Jehovah continues to provide our fellow worshippers with the wisdom needed to cope with natural disasters like these.
Lododowo 2:6-8.
Proverbs 2:6-8.
Ya Sesẽ Kple Tsidzadza Gã Aɖe Gblẽ Nu Le Texas Ƒe Anyiehe
High Winds and Flooding Strike South Texas
Le June 24, 2019 dzi la, ya sesẽ aɖe kple tsidzadza gã aɖe gblẽ nu le Texas ƒe anyiehe vevie.
On June 24, 2019, high winds and heavy rain pounded south Texas.
Nyatakakawo ɖee fia be tsi ɖe aƒe alafa geɖewo eye ame 100 kple edzivɔwoe ʋu le wo nɔƒewo.
News reports indicate that hundreds of homes were flooded and more than 100 people were evacuated.
Togbɔ be gbeƒãɖela aɖeke medze afɔku o hã la, wo dometɔ 47 zu aƒemanɔsitɔwo.
Although no publishers were injured in the storm, 47 were displaced.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, ahom la gblẽ nu le mía nɔviwo ƒe aƒe 65 ŋu, eye xɔ aɖe si tsiã ɖe Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖe ŋu hã le eme.
Additionally, the storm damaged 65 homes of our brothers and sisters, as well as one apartment attached to a Kingdom Hall.
Nutome sue dzikpɔlawo kple nutoa me hamemetsitsiwo yi vɛ le dzi dem ƒo na nɔvi siwo ŋu ahom la gblẽ nu le.
Circuit overseers and local elders are shepherding those affected by the storm.
Azɔ hã, Afɔku Ŋuti Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti aɖe le ɖoɖo wɔm ɖe nuɖuɖu, tsi kple nudodowo mama kpakple afi si nɔviawo anɔ la ŋu.
Also, a Disaster Relief Committee is coordinating the arrangements for housing and the distribution of food, water, and clothing.
Wole aƒe siwo ŋu tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ nu le la me dzram ɖo hele wo ɖɔm ɖo, tsɔ kpe ɖe xɔ si tsiã ɖe Fiaɖuƒe Akpataa ŋu la hã ŋu.
Efforts are already underway to clean and stabilize the damaged homes as well as the Kingdom Hall apartment.
Míayi edzi akpe ɖe mía nɔvi siwo le Texas ƒe anyiehe la ŋu, esi woyi edzi le ŋu ɖom ɖe Yehowa ŋu hele te nɔm ɖe nu siwo tsiɖɔɖɔa gblẽ la ŋu.
We will continue to support our brothers and sisters in south Texas, as they trust in Jehovah and cope with the aftermath of this severe weather.
Yesaya 26:3, 4.
Isaiah 26:3, 4.
Berlin, Germany Ƒe 2019 "Lɔlɔ̃ Nu Metsina Gbeɖe O "!
Berlin, Germany 2019 "Love Never Fails "!
Dukɔwo Dome Takpekpe
International Convention
Ŋkeke Siwo Dzi Wowɔe Le: June 14-16, 2019
Dates: June 14-16, 2019
Teƒe Si Wowɔe Le: Olympic Stadium le Berlin, Germany
Location: Olympic Stadium in Berlin, Germany
Gbe Siwo Me Wowɔe Le: Eŋlisigbe, Germangbe, Russiagbe
Program Languages: English, German, Russian
Vavalawo Ƒe Agbɔsɔsɔ Gbogbotɔ: 37,115
Peak Attendance: 37,115
Nyɔnyrɔxɔlawo Ƒe Xexlẽme: 255
Total Number Baptized: 255
Ame Siwo Tso Duta Ƒe Xexlẽme: 5,000
Number of International Delegates: 5,000
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒe Siwo Wokpe: Brazil, Britain, Canada, Ecuador, Finland, Greece, Poland, Scandinavia, Slovenia, United States
Invited Branches: Brazil, Britain, Canada, Ecuador, Finland, Greece, Poland, Scandinavia, Slovenia, United States
Nuteƒekpɔkpɔ: Wowɔ ɖoɖo ɖe tsaɖiɖi hã ŋu na vavalawo, eya ta wovɛ ɖi tsa le tsaɖiƒe xɔŋkɔ si nye Pergamon Blemanudzraɖoƒea le Berlin.
Local Experience: Delegates toured the famous Pergamon Museum in Berlin as part of the activities surrounding the convention.
Esi teƒea dzɔla aɖe kpɔ mía nɔviwo wole tsa ɖim le teƒea la, egblɔ be: "Mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖe ame geɖe elabe xɔse aɖeke mele wo si o.
After observing our brothers as they visited the museum, a guard stated: "Many people are hopeless because they do not have any faith.
Gake edze ƒãa be xɔse le miawo ya si, eye lɔlɔ̃ hã le mia dome. "
It’s very obvious, however, that you do have faith and love among yourselves. "
Dzɔla bubu aɖe hã gblɔ be: "Ne amewo abe miawo ene va afi sia la, ɣeyiɣia ƒua du kaba ŋutɔ, eye dzi dzɔm be mewɔ dɔ wògbɔ game si wòle be makpã hafi la dzi. "
Another guard said: "With visitors like you, time flies by and I’m happy to work overtime. "
Nɔviwo le wòezɔ dom na vavala siwo tso duta la le yameʋudzeƒe
Local brothers and sisters welcome delegates at the airport
Woɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Ðe Go Le Marshall-gbe Me
Release of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Marshallese

Le May 19, 2019 dzi la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia ɖe go le Marshall-gbe me le takpekpe tɔxɛ aɖe si wowɔ le South Pacific Yunivɛsiti le Majuro, si le Marshall Ƒukpowo dzi la me.

On May 19, 2019, Jehovah’s Witnesses released the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Marshallese at a special event held at The University of the South Pacific in Majuro, Marshall Islands.
Fiaɖuƒe Akpata aɖe si le Ebeye ƒukpo dzi, si didi tso Majuro gbɔ kilometa 440 kple edzivɔ hã tsiã ka kple takpekpea hekpɔ wɔna tɔxɛa.
Also tied in was an audience at a Kingdom Hall on the island of Ebeye, located over 440 kilometers (273 mi) from Majuro.
Ame siwo katã va wɔna tɔxɛa la ƒe xexlẽme le 339, gbeƒãɖela 151 siwo le hame ene siwo le Marshall Ƒukpowo dzi la hã le xexlẽme sia me.
A total of 339 were in attendance for the special meeting, including the 151 publishers who serve in four congregations in the Marshall Islands.
Gbeƒãɖela siawo kple gbeƒãɖela 325 siwo le Marshall-gbedolawo ƒe hame siwo le United States me la ate ŋu azã gɔmeɖeɖe sia azɔ le woƒe kpekpewo, ɖokuisinusɔsrɔ̃ kple gbeadzisubɔsubɔdɔa me.

These publishers, along with the 325 publishers who serve in the Marshallese-language field in the United States, will be able to use this translation at their meetings, in their personal study, and in the ministry.
Wobu akɔnta be Marshall-gbedola 61,000 ye le xexea me godoo.
There are an estimated 61,000 Marshallese speakers worldwide.

Nɔviŋutsu aɖe si kpe asi ɖe Biblia sia gɔmeɖeɖe ŋu la gblɔ be: "Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe Biblia si le Marshall-gbe me lae nye egbegbe Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe si me wogbugbɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ Yehowa ɖo teƒe siwo katã wòle be wòanɔ.

One brother who assisted with the translation project explains: "The New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Marshallese is the first modern-day translation in this language that restores Jehovah’s name in all of the places where it belongs.
Enye Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe aɖe si dzi nɔviwo ate ŋu aka ɖo, eye akpe ɖe wo ŋu be lɔlɔ̃ si le wo si na Yehowa la nayi edzi anɔ tsitsim ɖe edzi. "
It is a translation that brothers and sisters can trust, and it will help them to continue growing in their love for Jehovah. "
Dzi dzɔ mí ɖe Biblia sia si woɖe ɖe go nyitsɔ laa la ŋu ŋutɔ.
We are happy to hear about this recent release.
Ena míekpɔe be Yehowa le yayram ɖe gbegɔmeɖeɖedɔ siwo wɔm wole le gbegbɔgblɔ geɖewo, suewo kple gãwo siaa, me la dzi.
It is evidence that Jehovah is blessing the translation work in many different language groups, "both small and great. "
Psalmo 49:1, 2.
Psalm 49:1, 2.
Dzo Dze Aƒewo Dzi Le Philippines
Fires in the Philippines Consume Homes
Le March 2019 dzi le Philippines la, dzo dze aƒe 128 dzi le Calbayog Du si le Samar Ƒukpo dzi.
In March 2019, a fire in the Philippines burned 128 homes in Calbayog City on Samar Island.
Le ɣleti si do ŋgɔ me la, dzo dze aƒe siwo le Taguig Du si le Luzon Ƒukpo dzi la dzi.
The previous month, fires broke out in Taguig City on the island of Luzon.
Le wo katã me la, Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe aƒe adree bi dzo.
In total, seven homes of Jehovah’s Witnesses were destroyed by these fires.
Mía nɔvi siwo ƒe aƒe bi dzo la va le Ðasefo bubu siwo ƒe aƒe ŋu dzoa megblẽ nu le o la gbɔ.
Our displaced brothers and sisters are currently staying with other Witnesses whose homes were unaffected.
Alɔdzedɔwɔƒea wɔ ɖoɖo afɔtsɔtsɔe ɖo tsi, nuɖuɖu, kple nudodo ɖe nɔvi siwo ƒe aƒe bi dzo.
The branch office responded promptly by organizing efforts to supply food, water, and clothing.
Nutoa me hamemetsitsiwo yi vɛ srã nɔviawo kpɔ hena kpekpeɖeŋu siwo hiã la wo.
The local elders shepherded the affected brothers and provided practical assistance.
Dukɔa Me Xɔtuɖaŋu Kple Xɔtudɔ Dzikpɔƒea ƒe dɔwɔlawo le asi kpem ɖe Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti eve ŋu be woagbugbɔ wo nɔvi haxɔsetɔ siwo ƒe aƒe dome gblẽ la atu na wo.
Two Disaster Relief Committees, with the support of Local Design/Construction personnel, are preparing to rebuild the homes of our fellow worshippers.
Míeka ɖe edzi be Yehowa ayi edzi anye sitsoƒe na nɔvi siwo ŋu dzobibiawo gblẽ nu le.
We trust that Jehovah will continue to be a refuge for our brothers impacted by these fires.
Psalmo 62:8.
Psalm 62:8.
Ahom Sesẽ Si Nye Yutu Gblẽ Nu Le Dziehe Mariana Ƒukpowo Ŋu
Super Typhoon Yutu Brings Destruction to Northern Mariana Islands
Woka nya ta be ahom la nu sẽ ɖo ahom sesẽwo ƒe hatsotso 5 lia ƒe dzidzenu dzi.
On October 24, 2018, Super Typhoon Yutu slammed into the Northern Mariana Islands as a Category 5 storm.
Ƒukpo siwo nye Saipan kple Tinian koŋ ŋue nu gblẽ le vevie esime yaƒoƒo sesẽ si ƒe duƒuƒu nye kilometa 280 le gaƒoƒo ɖeka me la gbã aƒewo eye wòwɔe be elektrik-kaɖi megale ame akpe geɖe si o.
The largest islands of Saipan and Tinian were particularly impacted as 280 kilometers per hour (174 mph) winds destroyed homes and cut power to thousands of residents.
Micronesia alɔdzedɔwɔƒea si kpɔa Dziehe Mariana Ƒukpowo ƒe dɔwo dzi ka nya ta be nɔviŋutsu alo nɔvinyɔnu aɖeke meku alo xɔ abi o.
The Micronesia branch office, which oversees the work in the Northern Mariana Islands, reports that no brothers or sisters were killed or injured.
Ke hã, Ðasefo 15 ƒe aƒe gbã keŋkeŋ eye nu gblẽ le Ðasefo 40 bubuwo ƒe aƒewo ŋu.
However, the homes of 15 Witnesses were completely destroyed and another 40 homes were damaged.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, nu gblẽ le dutanyanyuigblɔlawo ƒe aƒe si le Saipan kple Fiaɖuƒe Akpata siwo le Saipan kple Tinian la ŋu vie.
Additionally, the missionary home in Saipan and the Kingdom Halls on both Saipan and Tinian sustained minor damage.
Afɔku Ŋuti Kpekpeɖeŋunakɔmiti aɖe wɔ ɖoɖo wole kpekpeɖeŋu nam ame siwo ŋu ahom la gblẽ nu le.
A Disaster Relief Committee is coordinating the distribution of relief aid to those affected.
Azɔ hã, Ðasefo siwo le nutoa me la le kpekpem ɖe gbeƒãɖela siwo ƒe aƒewo ŋu ahoma gblẽ nu le la ŋu.
Additionally, the publishers that were displaced by the storm are being cared for by local Witnesses.
Alɔdzekɔmitia me tɔ ɖeka azɔ mɔ ayi nuto siwo me ahom la gblẽ nu le be wòatsɔ Biblia me nyawo ade dzi ƒo na nɔviawo.
A member of the Branch Committee will be traveling to the impacted areas to provide spiritual encouragement.
Míele gbe dom ɖa ɖe mía nɔviawo ta esi wole te nɔm ɖe dzɔdzɔmefɔku sia nu.
Our prayers are with our brothers as they cope with this natural disaster.
Míekpɔa akɔfafa esi míenyae be "Yehowa tsɔ ɖe ame siwo katã yɔnɛ la gbɔ, " eye be "esea woƒe ɣlidodo. "
We are comforted by the knowledge that "Jehovah is near to all those calling on him, " and that "he hears their cry for help. "
Woɖo Asi Yehowa Ðasefowo Ƒe Dɔwo Dzi Le "Donetsk People’s Republic "
"Donetsk People’s Republic " Bans Jehovah’s Witnesses

Le September (Anyɔnyɔ) 26, 2018 dzi la, dukɔ si nye "Donetsk People’s Republic " (DPR) la ƒe Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔ bu fɔ Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe habɔbɔa be enye "aglãdzeha, " si wɔe be woɖo asi míaƒe dɔwo dzi le dukɔ ma me.
On September 26, 2018, the Supreme Court of the "Donetsk People’s Republic " (DPR) declared the religious association of Jehovah’s Witnesses to be "extremist, " effectively banning our activities.
Senyala amesamala si tsɔ nya ɖe míaƒe habɔbɔa ŋu kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo siaa meƒo nu kple Yehowa Ðasefowo dometɔ aɖeke le nyaa drɔ̃ɣi o.
Neither the general prosecutor, who initiated the claim against our legal entity, nor the Court consulted with any of Jehovah’s Witnesses during the proceedings.
Yehowa Ðasefowo yome titi le nuto ma me le gã dom ɖe edzi, eye asiɖoɖo wo dzi sia nye yometitia ŋuti nudzɔdzɔ si gado mo ɖa nyitsɔ laa.
The banning is the latest development in an escalating pattern of religious oppression against Jehovah’s Witnesses in the region.

Tso 2017 ƒe domedome lɔƒo la, nɔnɔmeawo gasesẽ ɖe edzi na mía nɔviwo le Donetsk kple Luhansk nutowo, siwo le Ukraine ƒe ɣedzeƒe la me esi dukɔa ƒe Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe Kɔkɔtɔ tso nya me be míaƒe agbalẽwo dea "aglãdzedze " dzi.

The situation of our brothers in certain territories of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, in eastern Ukraine, has deteriorated since the DPR Supreme Court declared some of our publications to be "extremist " in mid-2017.
Le ƒe ma me la, poliswo bia gbe Ðasefo 170 kple edzivɔ.
During that year, police interrogated over 170 Witnesses.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, setɔ siwo le nuto mawo me la le Fiaɖuƒe Akpatawo xɔm ɖekaɖeka.
Authorities in the regions have also systematically seized Kingdom Halls.
Va se ɖe August (Dasiamime) 29, 2018 dzi la, woxɔ Fiaɖuƒe Akpata 16.
As of August 29, 2018, a total of 16 Kingdom Halls have been confiscated.
Togbɔ be wole tsitre tsim ɖe mía nɔviwo ŋu alea le nuto mawo me hã la, woyi edzi le ŋu ɖom ɖe ‘xɔname ƒe Mawu’ la ŋu.
Despite these attacks on their worship, our brothers and sisters in these territories are continuing to rely on the ‘God of salvation.’
Psalmo 18:46.
Psalm 18:46.
Kpekpeɖeŋunadɔ Si Wowɔ Le Karib-ƒukpowo Dzi Enye Lɔlɔ̃ɖeɖefia Gã Aɖe
Love in Action​ Relief Work in the Islands

Nu siwo wowɔ tsɔ na kpekpeɖeŋu esime ahom sesẽ siwo woyɔ be Irma kple Maria tu le dukɔ siwo le Barbados, France kple Amerika ƒe alɔdzedɔwɔƒewo ƒe dzikpɔkpɔ te me la ŋuti nyatakaka yeyewo le video sia me.
The following video includes an update of the relief work following Hurricanes Irma and Maria in lands under the Barbados, France, and United States branches.

Ame geɖe siwo tsɔ wo ɖokuiwo na faa kpe ɖe wo nɔviwo ŋu la ƒe kutrikuku kple agbagbadzedzewo dze le videoa me, eye ale si Mark Sanderson si nye Dɔdzikpɔhaa me tɔ kple Gary Breaux, si nye Dɔdzikpɔhaa ƒe Subɔsubɔ Kɔmitia ƒe kpeɖeŋutɔ yi ɖakpɔ nɔviawo ɖa la ŋuti nya kpui aɖe hã le eme.

It recounts the tireless efforts of the many who volunteered to assist their brothers and includes a summary of the visit of Mark Sanderson of the Governing Body and Gary Breaux, a helper to the Service Committee.
Ðe Mawu Lia?
Does God Exist?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, kpeɖodzi sẽŋuwo le Biblia me siwo ɖee fia be Mawu li.
Yes, the Bible provides compelling evidence that God exists.
Ke nu si wòxlɔ̃ nu mí be míawɔ boŋue nye be míawɔ míaƒe "tamebubuŋutete " kple "nugɔmesese deto " ŋu dɔ.
It encourages us to build faith in God, not by blindly believing religious assertions, but by using our "power of reason " and "mental perception. "
(Romatɔwo 12:1; 1 Yohanes 5:20) Na míadzro susu siawo siwo nɔ te ɖe Biblia dzi la me kpɔ:
(Romans 12:1; 1 John 5:​20, footnote) Consider the following lines of reasoning based on the Bible:
Esi xexe sia le ɖoɖo nu eye nu gbagbewo le eme ta la, efia be Wɔla aɖe li.
The existence of an orderly universe containing life points to a Creator.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Nyateƒee, aƒe sia aƒe la, amee tsonɛ, ke ame si wɔ nuwo katãe nye Mawu. "
The Bible says: "Of course, every house is constructed by someone, but the one who constructed all things is God. "
(Hebritɔwo 3:4) Togbɔ be numeɖeɖe sia le bɔbɔe ŋutɔ hã la, agbalẽnyala geɖe gblɔna be eɖe kpe ŋutɔ.
(Hebrews 3:4) Although this logic is simple, many well-educated people find it to be powerful.
Mí amegbetɔwo míedina vevie be míase nu si ta míele agbe kple taɖodzinu si le agbea ŋu la gɔme. Eye ne míeɖi kɔ na míaƒe ŋutilãmenuhiahiãwo hã la, didi sia ya gakpɔtɔ nɔa mía me.
As humans, we have an innate desire to understand the meaning and purpose of life, a type of hunger that can remain after our physical needs have been met.
Didi sia nye nu si Biblia yɔ be míaƒe ‘gbɔgbɔmenuhiahiãwo’ la ƒe akpa aɖe, elɔ didi be míanya Mawu ahasubɔe ɖe eme.
This is part of what the Bible calls our "spiritual need, " which includes the desire to know and worship God.
(Mateo 5:3; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Ale si míedina be míaɖi kɔ na míaƒe gbɔgbɔmenuhiahiãwo ɖo kpe edzi be Mawu li, eɖee fia hã be Wɔla lɔ̃ame si di be míaɖi kɔ na didi ma lae wònye.​ Mateo 4:4.
(Matthew 5:3; Revelation 4:​11) This spiritual need not only gives evidence that God exists but also indicates that he is a loving Creator who wants us to satisfy that need.​ Matthew 4:4.
Nyagblɔɖiwo le Biblia me siwo me nyawo wogblɔ ɖi tsitotsito ƒe alafa geɖewo do ŋgɔ eye wova eme pɛpɛpɛ.
Detailed prophecies in the Bible were written centuries ahead of time and came true exactly as predicted.
Ale si nyagblɔɖi mawo va eme pɛpɛpɛ kple ale si wogblɔ wo me nyawo tsitotsito la ɖee fia be ame aɖe si kɔ boo wu amegbetɔwo gbɔe wotso.​ 2 Petro 1:​21.
The accuracy and detail of those predictions strongly suggest that they came from a superhuman source.​ 2 Peter 1:​21.
Anyigba si wole yame kpɔ
Planet Earth as seen from space
Biblia-ŋlɔlawo nya nu tso dzɔdzɔmenuwo ŋu wòƒo wo ŋɔlimetɔwo tɔ ta sãsãsã.
Bible writers had scientific knowledge that was beyond the understanding of their contemporaries.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le blema la, ame geɖewo xɔe se be lã aɖewo dzie míaƒe anyigba la le, eye wogblɔna be lã siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye atiglinyi, gbeha alo nyitsu.
For example, in ancient times many peoples believed that the earth was supported by an animal, such as an elephant, a boar, or an ox.
Gake Biblia ya gblɔ be Mawu "meku anyigba la ɖe naneke ŋu o. "
In contrast, the Bible says that God is "suspending the earth upon nothing. "
(Hiob 26:7) Nenema ke Biblia ɖɔ anyigba ƒe nɔnɔme wòde pɛpɛpɛ be ele "nogoo " alo "godoo. "
(Job 26:7) Similarly, the Bible correctly describes the shape of the earth as a "sphere, " or "globe. "
(Yesaya 40:22, Eʋegbe Biblia) Ame geɖe xɔe se be nu si tae Biblia-ŋlɔlawo te ŋu nya nu mawo siwo ŋu wo ŋɔlimetɔwo menya naneke tsoe o gblɔ lae nye be Mawue ɖee fia wo.
(Isaiah 40:22, footnote; Douay Version) Many people feel that the most reasonable explanation for such advanced understanding is that Bible writers received their information from God.
Biblia ɖo nyabiase sesẽ geɖe siwo ate ŋu awɔe be ame nazu mawudzimaxɔsela ne mekpɔ ŋuɖoɖo na wo o la ŋu.
The Bible answers many difficult questions, the type of questions that when not satisfactorily answered can lead a person to atheism.
Nyabiase siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye, Ne Mawu lɔ̃ ame eye wònye ŋusẽkatãtɔ la, ke nu ka tae fukpekpe kple nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ bɔ ɖe xexea me alea gbegbe?
For example: If God is loving and all-powerful, why is there suffering and evil in the world?
Nu ka tae zi geɖe la, mawusubɔsubɔhawo wɔe be amewo wɔa nu vɔ̃ esi woana be amewo nawɔ nu nyui boŋ?​ Tito 1:​16.
Why is religion so often an influence for bad rather than for good?​ Titus 1:​16.
Ŋusẽ Dzro Aɖe Koe Mawu Nyea?
Is God an Impersonal Force?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu zãa ŋusẽ si ƒo ɖe sia ɖe ta le xexea me godoo.
God exercises unsurpassed force throughout the universe.
Esi Biblia nɔ nu ƒom tso ale si Mawu wɔ ɣletivi gbogbo manyaxlẽ miliɔn akpe geɖewo ŋu la, egblɔ be: "Mifɔ mo dzi, ne miakpɔ nu!
Regarding the way he created the countless billions of stars, the Bible says: "Raise your eyes high up and see. Who has created these things?
Ame ka wɔ nu siawo, eye wòkplɔa eŋu nuwo doa goe dedie?
It is the One who is bringing forth the army of them even by number, all of whom he [God] calls even by name.
Eyɔa wo katã ŋkɔ, eye wo dometɔ aɖeke mesusɔna o le eƒe ŋusẽ geɖe kple alɔkame sesẽ la nu. "
Due to the abundance of dynamic energy, he also being vigorous in power, not one of them is missing. "
Yesaya 40:25, 26.
Isaiah 40:25, 26.
Gake menye ŋusẽ dzro aɖe koe Mawu nye o.
But God is much more than a powerful force.
Biblia gblɔ be seselelãmewo, abe lɔlɔ̃ kple fuléle ene, le esi.
The Bible says that he has feelings, such as love and hate.
(Psalmo 11:5; Yohanes 3:16) Biblia ɖee fia hã be ale si amegbetɔwo nɔa agbee la ate ŋu ana Mawu nakpɔ dzidzɔ alo ado dziku.
(Psalm 11:5; John 3:16) It also reveals that the way humans act can affect God’s emotions.
Psalmo 78:40, 41.
Ðe Nɔƒe Aɖe Koŋ Le Mawu Sia?
Does God Live in a Specific Location?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Nɔƒe aɖe koŋ le Mawu si, eyae nye dziƒowo.
God lives in a specific place the heavens.
Ðe ŋugble tso Biblia me nuŋlɔɖi siawo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider these Bible passages:
Salomo gblɔ le gbedodoɖa me be: "Nàsee le nɔwòƒe le dziƒo. " 1 Fiawo 8:43.
In a prayer, King Solomon said: "May you yourself listen from the heavens, your established place of dwelling. " 1 Kings 8:43.
Yesu fia eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be woado gbe ɖa na wo "Fofo si le dziƒowo. "
Jesus Christ taught his disciples to address their prayers to their "Father in the heavens. "
Mateo 6:9.
Matthew 6:9.
Esi wofɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre la, "dziƒo ŋutɔŋutɔ wòge ɖo, bene wòado ɖe Mawu ŋutɔ ŋkume. "
After Jesus was resurrected, he entered "into heaven itself, now to appear before the person of God. "
Hebritɔwo 9:24.
Hebrews 9:24.
Mawunyakpukpui siawo ɖee fia be ame ŋutɔŋutɔe Yehowa Mawu nye eye be mele afi sia afi o, ke boŋ dziƒo koe nye enɔƒe.
Those verses clearly indicate that Jehovah God is a real person and that he dwells, not everywhere, but only in heaven.
Ðe Ame Aɖe Kpɔ Mawu Kpɔa?
Has Anyone Ever Seen God?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Amegbetɔ aɖeke mekpɔ Mawu ŋkume-kple-ŋkume kpɔ o.
No human has literally seen God.
(2 Mose 33:20; Yohanes 1:18; 1 Yohanes 4:12) Biblia gblɔ be "Mawu nye Gbɔgbɔ, " si fia agbe ƒomevi aɖe si amegbetɔ ƒe ŋku mate ŋu akpɔ o.​ Yohanes 4:24; 1 Timoteo 1:17.
(Exodus 33:20; John 1:​18; 1 John 4:​12) The Bible says that "God is a Spirit, " a form of life that is invisible to the human eye.​ John 4:​24; 1 Timothy 1:​17.
Ke hã mawudɔlawo tea ŋu kpɔa Mawu ŋkume-kple-ŋkume elabena gbɔgbɔe woawo hã wonye.
God can be seen directly by angels, though, because they are spirit creatures.
(Mateo 18:10) Gawu la, woafɔ ame siwo ku la dometɔ aɖewo be woayi dziƒo eye gbɔgbɔŋutilã asu wo si, eye woate ŋu akpɔ Mawu ŋkume-kple-ŋkume.​ Filipitɔwo 3:20, 21; 1 Yohanes 3:2.
(Matthew 18:10) Moreover, some humans who die will be raised to life in heaven with a spirit body and will then be able to see God.​ Philippians 3:​20, 21; 1 John 3:2.
Mɔ si nu nàte ŋu akpɔ Mawu le egbea
How to "see " God now
Biblia zã nya nukpɔkpɔ tsɔ wɔa kpɔɖeŋu na nugɔmesese.
The Bible often uses the idea of seeing figuratively, to represent enlightenment.

(Yesaya 6:10; Yeremiya 5:21; Yohanes 9:39-41) Le gɔmesese sia nu la, amegbetɔwo ate ŋu akpɔ Mawu fifia kple woƒe "dzi me ŋkuwo " ne xɔse le wo si eye wonya eya amea hekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe eƒe nɔnɔme nyuiwo ŋu.
(Isaiah 6:​10; Jeremiah 5:​21; John 9:​39-​41) In this sense, a person can see God now with "the eyes of [his] heart " by having faith so as to know Him and appreciate His qualities.
(Efesotɔwo 1:18) Biblia gblɔ nu siwo wòle be míawɔ be xɔse sia ƒomevi nasu mía si la na mí.
(Ephesians 1:​18) The Bible describes steps to build this kind of faith.
Srɔ̃ nu tso Mawu ƒe nɔnɔmewo abe lɔlɔ̃, dɔmenyo, nunya kple ŋusẽ ene ŋu to eƒe asinudɔwɔwɔwo dzi.
Learn about God’s qualities, such as his love and generosity as well as his wisdom and power, through his creation.
(Romatɔwo 1:20) Esi wohe nuteƒewɔla Hiob ƒe susu yi Mawu ƒe asinudɔwɔwɔwo dzi la, ese le eɖokui me abe ɖe Mawu le eŋkume ŋutɔŋutɔ ene.​ Hiob 42:5.
(Romans 1:​20) After being reminded of God’s creative works, the faithful man Job felt as though God were right before his eyes.​ Job 42:5.
Àte ŋu anya Mawu to Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃ me.
Get to know God by studying the Bible.
Biblia na kakaɖedzi mí be: "Ne [èdi Mawu] la, ekema ana nàke ɖe eŋu. "​ 1 Kronika 28:9; Psalmo 119:2; Yohanes 17:3.
"If you search for [God], he will let himself be found by you, " the Bible assures us.​ 1 Chronicles 28:9; Psalm 119:2; John 17:3.
Àte ŋu asrɔ̃ nu tso Mawu ŋu to nusɔsrɔ̃ tso Yesu ƒe agbenɔnɔ ŋu me.
Learn about God through the life of Jesus.
Esi wònye be Yesu ɖe Fofoa ƒe nɔnɔmewo fia bliboe ta la, Yesu te ŋu gblɔ wòsɔ be: "Ame si kpɔm la, ekpɔ Fofo la hã. "​ Yohanes 14:9.
Since Jesus perfectly reflected the personality of his Father, Jehovah God, he could rightly say: "Whoever has seen me has seen the Father also. "​ John 14:9.
Nɔ nu siwo ana wò nu nadze Mawu ŋu la wɔm, eye àkpɔ ale si wòakpe ɖe ŋuwòe.
Live in a way that pleases God, and see how he acts in your behalf.
Yesu gblɔ be: "Dzidzɔtɔwoe nye ame siwo dza le dzi me, elabena woakpɔ Mawu. "
Jesus said: "Happy are the pure in heart, since they will see God. "
Abe ale si míegblɔe va yi ene la, woafɔ ame siwo ƒe nuwɔna dze Mawu ŋu la dometɔ aɖewo woayi dziƒo, eye "woakpɔ Mawu " le afi ma.​ Mateo 5:8; Psalmo 11:7.
As noted earlier, some who please God will be resurrected to heaven and will thus "see God " there.​ Matthew 5:8; Psalm 11:7.
Ðe Mose, Abraham kple ame bubuwo mekpɔ Mawu ŋkume-kple-ŋkume oa?
Did not Moses, Abraham, and others actually see God?
Le Biblia me nudzɔdzɔ siwo me wòdze le abe ɖe amegbetɔwo kpɔ Mawu ŋutɔŋutɔ ene la, nya siwo ƒo xlã nya mawo ɖee fia be mawudɔla aɖe si le Mawu teƒee wokpɔ loo alo eɖe eɖokui fia wo le ŋutega me.
In accounts where it might seem that the Bible says that humans literally saw God, the context shows that God was represented by an angel or appeared by means of a vision.
Mawudɔlawo.
Angels.
Le blema la, Mawu dɔa mawudɔlawo wonyea eteƒenɔlawo dzena na amegbetɔwo eye woƒoa nu le eƒe ŋkɔ me.
In ancient times, God sent angels as his representatives to appear to humans and to speak in his name.

(Psalmo 103:20) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mawu ƒo nu na Mose gbe ɖeka le ŋuve aɖe si nɔ bibim me, eye Biblia gblɔ be: "Mose ɣla eƒe ŋkume, elabena ele vɔvɔ̃m na Mawu vavã la kpɔkpɔ. " (2 Mose 3:4, 6) Mose mekpɔ Mawu ŋutɔŋutɔ o, elabe nya siwo ƒo xlã nya ma ɖee fia be "Yehowa ƒe dɔla " ye wòkpɔ.​ 2 Mose 3:2.

(Psalm 103:20) For example, God once spoke to Moses from a burning bush, and the Bible says that "Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at the true God. " (Exodus 3:​4, 6) Moses did not literally see God, though, for the context shows that he actually saw "Jehovah’s angel. "​ Exodus 3:2.
Nenema kee esi Biblia gblɔ be Mawu "ƒoa nu kple Mose ŋkume kple ŋkume " la, efia be Mawu ɖoa dze kple Mose abe exɔlɔ̃a ene.
Similarly, when the Bible says that God "spoke to Moses face-to-face, " it means that God conversed with Moses intimately.
(2 Mose 4:10, 11; 33:11) Mose mekpɔ Mawu kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ o elabena exɔ gbedeasi la "to mawudɔlawo dzi. "
(Exodus 4:​10, 11; 33:11) Moses did not actually see God’s face, for the information he received from God "was transmitted through angels. "
(Galatiatɔwo 3:19; Dɔwɔwɔwo 7:53) Ke hã, Mose xɔ Mawu dzi se ale gbegbe be Biblia gblɔ tso eŋu be ɖeko wòle abe ɖe wònɔ "Ame si womekpɔna o la kpɔm " ene.​ Hebritɔwo 11:27.
(Galatians 3:​19; Acts 7:​53) Still, Moses’ faith in God was so strong that the Bible described him as "seeing the One who is invisible. "​ Hebrews 11:27.
Mawu ƒo nu na Abraham hã to mawudɔla aɖe dzi abe ale si ko wòwɔ le Mose gome ene.
In the same way that he spoke to Moses, God communicated with Abraham through angels.
Enye nyateƒe be ne mède ŋugble tso Biblia ƒe akpa sia ŋu nyuie o la, àsusui be ɖe Abraham kpɔ Mawu ŋutɔŋutɔ.
Granted, a casual reading of the Bible might give the impression that Abraham literally saw God.
(1 Mose 18:1, 33) Ke hã, nya siwo ƒo xlã kpukpui siawo ɖee fia be mawudɔla siwo Mawu dɔe "ŋutsu etɔ̃ " siwo wòkpɔ la nye.
(Genesis 18:​1, 33) However, the context shows that the "three men " who came to Abraham were actually angels sent by God.
Abraham kpɔe dze sii be Mawu teƒenɔlawo wonye, eya ta wònɔ nu ƒom na wo abe Yehowa ŋutɔe wònɔ nyaa gblɔm na tẽe ene.​ 1 Mose 18:2, 3, 22, 32; 19:1.
Abraham recognized them as God’s representatives and addressed them as if he were speaking directly to Jehovah.​ Genesis 18:​2, 3, 22, 32; 19:1.
Ŋutegawo.
Visions.
Mawu ɖe eɖokui fia amegbetɔwo le ŋutegawo hã me.
God has also appeared to humans through visions, or scenes presented to a person’s mind.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi Biblia gblɔ be Mose kple Israel-vi bubuwo "wokpɔ Israel ƒe Mawu la " la, nu si dzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔe nye be "wokpɔ Mawu vavã la le ŋutega me. " (2 Mose 24:9-11) Nenema kee Biblia gblɔna ɣeaɖewoɣi be nyagblɔɖilawo ‘kpɔ Yehowa.’

For instance, when the Bible says that Moses and other Israelites "saw the God of Israel, " they really "saw a vision of the true God. " (Exodus 24:​9-​11) Likewise, the Bible sometimes says that prophets "saw Jehovah. "

(Yesaya 6:1; Daniel 7:9; Amos 9:1) Le go siawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe me la, nya siwo ƒo xlã kpukpui mawo ɖenɛ fiana be ŋutega mee wokpɔ Mawu le, ke womekpɔ Mawu ŋkume-kple-ŋkume o.​ Yesaya 1:1; Daniel 7:2; Amos 1:1.
(Isaiah 6:1; Daniel 7:9; Amos 9:1) In each case, the context shows that they were given a vision of God rather than a direct view of him.​ Isaiah 1:1; Daniel 7:2; Amos 1:1.
Ðe Mawu Nye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ Alo Trinitaa?
Is God a Trinity?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Sɔlemeha vovovowo gblɔna be Mawu nye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ alo Trinita Kɔkɔe.
Many Christian denominations teach that God is a Trinity.
Gake de dzesi nya si agbalẽ aɖe (Encyclopædia Britannica) gblɔ: "Trinita alo eŋuti nufiafia gobii aɖeke medze le Nubabla Yeyea me o . . .
However, note what the Encyclopædia Britannica states: "Neither the word Trinity nor the explicit doctrine appears in the New Testament . . .
Nufiafia sia dze egɔme vivivi eye wònye nya wohe ʋuu hafi va ɖoe anyi le ƒe alafa geɖewo megbe. "
The doctrine developed gradually over several centuries and through many controversies. "
Le nyateƒe me la, Biblia ƒe afi aɖeke meɖɔ Mawu kpɔ enye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ ƒe akpa aɖe o.
In fact, the God of the Bible is never described as being part of a Trinity. Note these Bible passages:
De dzesi mawunyakpukpui siawo me nyawo:
"Jehovah our God is one Jehovah. "
"Yehowa, mía Mawu la, Yehowa ɖeka koe! " 5 Mose 6:4.
Deuteronomy 6:4.
"Ŋkɔwòe nye Yehowa, eye wò ɖeɖe koe ɖo kpo ɖe anyigba blibo la dzi! "
"You, whose name is Jehovah, you alone are the Most High over all the earth. "
Psalmo 83:19.
Psalm 83:18.
"Esiae nye agbe mavɔ la bena, woanya wò, Mawu vavã ɖeka la, kple Yesu Kristo, si nèdɔ ɖa la. "
"This means everlasting life, their taking in knowledge of you, the only true God, and of the one whom you sent forth, Jesus Christ. "
Yohanes 17:3, Eʋegbe Biblia.
John 17:3.
"Mawu ɖeka koe. "
"God is only one. "
Galatiatɔwo 3:20.
Galatians 3:20.
Nu ka tae sɔlemeha geɖewo fiaa nu be Mawu nye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ alo Trinita Kɔkɔe?
Why do most Christian denominations say that God is a Trinity?
Ðe Mawu Trɔa Susua?
Does God Change His Mind?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, etrɔa susu le mɔ sia nu be ne amewo trɔ woƒe nuwɔnawo la eya hã trɔa nɔnɔme ɖe wo ŋu.
Yes, he does, in the sense that he changes his attitude when people change their behavior.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi Mawu dɔ nyagblɔɖila aɖe be wòayi aɖagblɔ ʋɔnudrɔ̃gbedeasi aɖe na blema Israel-viwo la, egblɔ be: "Ðewohĩ woasee, eye ame sia ame atrɔ tso eƒe mɔ vɔ̃ dzi, ekema matrɔ susu, eye nyemagahe vɔ̃ si meɖo ɖe wo ŋu le woƒe nuwɔna vɔ̃ɖiwo ta la ava wo dzi o. "​ Yeremiya 26:3.

For example, when God sent a judgment message to the people of ancient Israel, he said: "Perhaps they will listen and each one will turn back from his evil way, and I will change my mind concerning the calamity that I intend to bring on them because of their evil deeds. "​ Jeremiah 26:3.
Woɖe nya sia gɔme le Biblia aɖewo me be Mawu "trɔ dzi me " le vɔ̃ si wòɖo be yeawɔ la gome. Woƒe nya sia ate ŋu afia be Mawu da vo.
Many Bible translations render this verse as saying that God would "repent " over the intended calamity, which could be understood to mean that he had made a mistake.
Gake Hebrigbe me nya si gɔme woɖe la ate ŋu afia "trɔ susu alo trɔ tame. "
However, the original Hebrew word can mean "change of mind or intention. "
Agbalẽnyala gã aɖe ŋlɔ bena: "Ne amewo trɔ woƒe nuwɔna la, Mawu hã trɔa ʋɔnu si wòɖo be yeadrɔ̃ wo la. "
One scholar wrote: "A change in man’s conduct brings about a change in God’s judgment. "
Ke hã, ele be míade dzesii be togbɔ be Mawu tea ŋu trɔa susu hã la, mezi edzi be wòatrɔ susu ɣesiaɣi o.
Of course, just because God can change his mind does not mean that he must change it.
Kpɔ Biblia me nudzɔdzɔ siwo me Mawu metrɔ susu le o la dometɔ aɖewo ɖa:
Consider some situations where the Bible says that God has not changed his mind:
Mawu meɖe mɔ Balak na wòtrɔ susu heƒo fi de Israel-dukɔ la o.​ 4 Mose 23:18-20.
God did not allow Balak to make Him change His mind and curse the nation of Israel.​ Numbers 23:18-​20.
Esi Israel fia Saul tsɔ nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ ɖo dɔe la, Mawu metrɔ tame si wòɖo be yeagbee la o.​ 1 Samuel 15:28, 29.
Once King Saul of Israel became firmly set in badness, God did not change his mind about rejecting him as king.​ 1 Samuel 15:28, 29.
Mawu awɔ ɖe ŋugbe si wòdo be yeana ye Vi nanye nunɔla tegbee la dzi.
God will fulfill his promise to make his Son a priest forever.
Mawu matrɔ susu o.​ Psalmo 110:4.
God will not change His mind.​ Psalm 110:4.
Ðe Biblia megblɔ be Mawu metrɔna oa?
Doesn’t the Bible say that God never changes?
Ɛ̃, Mawu gblɔ le Biblia me be: "Nye Yehowa nyemetrɔ o. "
Yes, the Bible records God as saying: "I am Jehovah; I do not change. "
(Malaki 3:6) Nenema kee Biblia gblɔ be Mawu "metrɔna abe vɔvɔli ene o. "
(Malachi 3:6) Similarly, the Bible says that God "does not vary or change like the shifting shadows. "
(Yakobo 1:17) Gake nya sia metsi tsitre ɖe nya si Biblia gblɔ be Mawu trɔ susu la ŋu o.
(James 1:​17) This, however, does not contradict what the Bible says about God changing his mind.
Mawu metrɔna o le susu sia nu be eƒe nɔnɔmewo kple eƒe dzidzenu ku ɖe lɔlɔ̃ kple dzɔdzɔenyenye ŋu metrɔna gbeɖe o.
God is unchangeable in that his personality and standards of love and justice never alter.
(5 Mose 32:4; 1 Yohanes 4:8) Gake etea ŋu naa mɔfiame vovovowo amewo le ɣeyiɣi vovovowo me.
(Deuteronomy 32:4; 1 John 4:8) Still, he can give different instructions to people at different times.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mawu na mɔfiame vovovowo Fia David le aʋa eve aɖewo me, gake mɔfiame eveawo katã kpɔ dzidzedze.​ 2 Samuel 5:​18-​25.
For instance, God gave opposite instructions to King David for fighting two consecutive battles, yet both methods succeeded.​ 2 Samuel 5:​18-​25.
Ðe wòve Mawu be yewɔ amegbetɔwoa?
Is God sorry that he created humans?
Ao, togbɔ be evenɛ be ame akpa gãtɔ meɖoa to ye o hã.
No, although he does regret that most people ignore or reject him.

Biblia gblɔ tso ale si nɔnɔmeawo nɔ le anyigba dzi do ŋgɔ na Noa ƒe ŋkekea me Tsiɖɔɖɔa ŋu be: "Eve Yehowa bena, wòwɔ ame ɖe anyigba dzi, eye wòɖu dzi nɛ. " (1 Mose 6:6) Dɔwɔnya si wozã le kpukpui sia me be "eve " nye Hebrigbe me nya aɖe si ate ŋu afia "trɔ susu. "

Describing conditions before the global Flood of Noah’s day, the Bible says: "Jehovah regretted that he had made men on the earth, and his heart was saddened. " (Genesis 6:6) In this verse, the word "regretted " comes from the Hebrew word that can mean "change of mind. "
Mawu trɔ susu ku ɖe ame siwo nɔ anyigba dzi do ŋgɔ na Tsiɖɔɖɔa dometɔ akpa gãtɔ ŋu le woƒe nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ ta.
God changed his mind about most of the people who lived before the Flood because they had become wicked.
(1 Mose 6:5, 11) Togbɔ be etena ɖe Mawu dzi be amewo tsɔ nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ ɖo dɔe hã la, metrɔ susu ku ɖe amegbetɔƒome bliboa ŋu o.
(Genesis 6:​5, 11) Even though he was saddened that they chose to follow a bad course, he did not change his attitude toward the entire human race.
Le nyateƒe me la, ekpɔ amegbetɔƒomea ta le Tsiɖɔɖɔa me esi wòna Noa kple eƒe ƒomea tsi agbe.​ 1 Mose 8:21; 2 Petro 2:5, 9.
In fact, he preserved mankind through the Flood by means of Noah and his family.​ Genesis 8:​21; 2 Peter 2:​5, 9.
Nu Kae Nye Gbɔgbɔ Kɔkɔe La?
What Is the Holy Spirit?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔeae nye Mawu ƒe ŋusẽ ɖeɖe fia alo eƒe dɔwɔŋusẽ.
The holy spirit is God’s power in action, his active force.
(Mika 3:8; Luka 1:35) Mawu ɖoa eƒe gbɔgbɔa ɖe teƒewo le mɔ sia nu be eɖoa eƒe ŋusẽ ɖe teƒe mawo ale be eƒe lɔlɔ̃nu nava eme.​ Psalmo 104:30; 139:7.
(Micah 3:8; Luke 1:​35) God sends out his spirit by projecting his energy to any place to accomplish his will.​ Psalm 104:30; 139:7.
Nya si gɔme woɖe le Biblia me be "gbɔgbɔ " la nye Hebrigbe me nya ruach kple Helagbe me nya pneuma.
In the Bible, the word "spirit " is translated from the Hebrew word ruach and the Greek word pneuma.
Zi geɖe la nya mawo fiaa Mawu ƒe dɔwɔŋusẽ alo gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la.
Most often, those words refer to God’s active force, or holy spirit.
(1 Mose 1:2) Gake Biblia zãa nya mawo wofia nu bubuwo hã abe:
(Genesis 1:2) However, the Bible also uses those words in other senses:
Gbɔgbɔ (ŋɔtimegbɔgbɔ).​ Habakuk 2:19; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:15.
Breath.​ Habakkuk 2:​19; Revelation 13:15.
Ya (yaƒoƒo).​ 1 Mose 8:1; Yohanes 3:8.
Wind.​ Genesis 8:1; John 3:8.
Agbegbɔgbɔ alo ŋusẽ si nana be nu gbagbewo ʋãna.​ Hiob 34:14, 15.
The vital, or animating, force in living creatures.​ Job 34:14, 15.
Ame ƒe agbenɔnɔ alo eƒe nɔnɔme.​ 4 Mose 14:24.
A person’s disposition or attitude.​ Numbers 14:24.
Gbɔgbɔmemewo, siwo lɔ Mawu kple mawudɔlawo ɖe eme.​ 1 Fiawo 22:21; Yohanes 4:24.
Spirit persons, including God and the angels.​ 1 Kings 22:21; John 4:​24.
Gbɔgbɔ ƒe gɔmesese siawo katã fia nane si ƒe dɔwɔwɔ dzena amegbetɔwo kpɔna gake wometea ŋu kpɔa gbɔgbɔa ŋutɔ kple ŋku o.
These meanings all share the sense of something invisible to humans that produces visible effects.
Nenema kee Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔa hã "le abe ya ke ene, enye nu makpɔmakpɔ sẽŋu aɖe. "​ An Expository Dictionary of New Testament Words, si W. E. Vine ta.
Similarly, the spirit of God, "like the wind, is invisible, immaterial and powerful. "​ An Expository Dictionary of New Testament Words, by W. E. Vine.
Biblia yɔ Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea be ‘asi’ alo "asibidɛwo. "
The Bible also refers to God’s holy spirit as his "hands " or "fingers. "
(Psalmo 8:3; 19:1; Luka 11:20; tsɔe sɔ kple Mateo 12:28.)
(Psalm 8:3; 19:1; Luke 11:20; compare Matthew 12:28.)
Abe ale si ko aɖaŋudɔwɔla zãa eƒe asi alo asibidɛwo tsɔ wɔa nuwoe ene la, Mawu hã zãa eƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea tsɔ wɔ alo tsɔ wɔa nu siwo gbɔna:
Just as a craftsman uses his hands and fingers to do his work, God has used his spirit to produce such results as the following:
Xexea.​ Psalmo 33:6; Yesaya 66:1, 2.
The universe.​ Psalm 33:6; Isaiah 66:​1, 2.
Biblia la.​ 2 Petro 1:20, 21.
The Bible.​ 2 Peter 1:​20, 21.
Nukunu siwo esubɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema wɔ kple ale si woɖe gbeƒã dzonɔamemetɔe.​ Luka 4:18; Dɔwɔwɔwo 1:8; 1 Korintotɔwo 12:4-11.
The miracles performed by his ancient servants and their zealous preaching.​ Luke 4:​18; Acts 1:8; 1 Corinthians 12:​4-​11.
Nɔnɔme nyui siwo ame siwo ɖoa toe ɖena fiana.​ Galatiatɔwo 5:22, 23.
The fine qualities displayed by people who obey him.​ Galatians 5:​22, 23.
Menye amee gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la nye o
The holy spirit is not a person
Esi Biblia yɔ Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔa be eƒe ‘asi’ alo "asibidɛwo " alo "ŋɔtimegbɔgbɔ " la, eɖee fia be menye amee gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la nye o.
By referring to God’s spirit as his "hands, " "fingers, " or "breath, " the Bible shows that the holy spirit is not a person.
(2 Mose 15:8, 10) Aɖaŋudɔwɔlaa ƒe asiwo mate ŋu awɔ dɔ eƒe susu kple eƒe ŋutilã ƒe akpa bubuwo manɔmee o; nenema kee ne Mawu fia mɔ gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ko hafi wòtea ŋu wɔa dɔ.
(Exodus 15:​8, 10) A craftsman’s hands cannot function independent of his mind and body; likewise, God’s holy spirit operates only as he directs it.
(Luka 11:13) Biblia tsɔ Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔa sɔ kple tsi eye wòtsɔe do ƒome kple nuwo abe xɔse kple sidzedze ene hã.
(Luke 11:13) The Bible also compares God’s spirit to water and associates it with such things as faith and knowledge.
Esiawo katã ɖee fia be menye amee gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea nye o. Yesaya 44:3; Dɔwɔwɔwo 6:5; 2 Korintotɔwo 6:6.
These comparisons all point to the impersonal nature of the holy spirit.​ Isaiah 44:3; Acts 6:5; 2 Corinthians 6:6.
Woyɔ Yehowa Mawu kple Via Yesu Kristo ŋkɔ na mí le Biblia me, gake gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ƒe ŋkɔ medze le afi aɖeke le Biblia me o.
The Bible gives the names of Jehovah God and of his Son, Jesus Christ; yet, nowhere does it name the holy spirit.
(Yesaya 42:8; Luka 1:31) Esi Kristotɔ Stefano si wowu ɖe eƒe xɔse ta kpɔ dziƒo nukutɔe le ŋutega aɖe me la, ame eve ko wòkpɔ le afi ma, menye ame etɔ̃ o.
(Isaiah 42:8; Luke 1:​31) When the Christian martyr Stephen was given a miraculous heavenly vision, he saw only two persons, not three.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe yɔe fũu la, ekpɔ dziƒo gãa, eye wòkpɔ Mawu ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe kple Yesu wòle tsitre ɖe Mawu ƒe ɖusime. "
The Bible says: "He, being full of holy spirit, gazed into heaven and caught sight of God’s glory and of Jesus standing at God’s right hand. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 7:55) Gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe lae nye Mawu ƒe ŋusẽ si wòtsɔ kpe ɖe Stefano ŋu wòkpɔ ŋutega ma.
(Acts 7:​55) The holy spirit was God’s power in action, enabling Stephen to see the vision.
Alakpanya siwo amewo gblɔna ku ɖe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ŋu
Misconceptions about the holy spirit
Nyakpakpa: Gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la nye ame ŋutɔŋutɔ eye wònye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ (Trinita Kɔkɔe) la ƒe akpa aɖe abe ale si wodze le 1 Yohanes 5:7, 8 le Eʋegbe Biblia me ene.
Misconception: The "Holy Ghost, " or holy spirit, is a person and is part of the Trinity, as stated at 1 John 5:​7, 8 in the King James version of the Bible.
Nyateƒea: Nya siwo dze le Eʋegbe Biblia me le 1 Yohanes 5:7, 8 ƒe ɖewoe nye "le dziƒo: Fofo la, Nya la kple Gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la, eye ame etɔ̃ siawo le ɖeka.
Fact: The King James version of the Bible includes at 1 John 5:​7, 8 the words "in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one.
Eye ame etɔ̃e li, ame siwo le ɖase ɖim le anyigba dzi. "
And there are three that bear witness in earth. "
Gake numekulawo va kpɔe be menye apostolo Yohanes ye ŋlɔ nya siawo o, eya ta menye Biblia me nyawoe wonye o.
However, researchers have found that those words were not written by the apostle John and so do not belong in the Bible.
Nufialagã Bruce M. Metzger ŋlɔ bena: "Nya siawo nye nyakpakpawo eye enye nyateƒe be mesɔ be woatsɔ wo akpe ɖe Nubabla Yeyea ŋu o. "​ A Textual Commentary on the Greek New Testament.
Professor Bruce M. Metzger wrote: "That these words are spurious and have no right to stand in the New Testament is certain. "​ A Textual Commentary on the Greek New Testament.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia ƒoa nu tso gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ŋu abe amee wònye ene, eya ta efia be amee wònye.
Misconception: The Bible personifies the holy spirit, and this proves that it is a person.
Nyateƒea: Enye nyateƒe be ŋɔŋlɔawo ƒoa nu tso gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ŋu ɣeaɖewoɣi abe amee wònye ene ya, gake esia mefia be amee wònye o.
Fact: The Scriptures do at times personify the holy spirit, but this does not prove that the holy spirit is a person.
Biblia ƒoa nu tso nunya, ku, kple nu vɔ̃ hã ŋu abe amewoe wonye ene.
The Bible also personifies wisdom, death, and sin.

(Lododowo 1:20; Romatɔwo 5:17, 21) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, woƒo nu tso nunya ŋu be ewɔa ‘dɔ’ eye "viwo " le esi, eye woɖɔa nu vɔ̃ be eblea ame nu, ewua ame eye wòbiãa ŋu.​ Mateo 11:19; Luka 7:35; Romatɔwo 7:8, 11.

(Proverbs 1:​20; Romans 5:​17, 21) For example, wisdom is said to have "works " and "children, " and sin is depicted as seducing, killing, and working out covetousness.​ Matthew 11:19; Luke 7:​35; Romans 7:​8, 11.

Nenema kee esime apostolo Yohanes yɔ Yesu ƒe nyawo la, eƒo nu tso gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la ŋu abe amee wònye ene esi wògblɔ be enye "kpeɖeŋutɔ " si ana kpeɖodzi, afia mɔ, aƒo nu, ase nu, eye wòagblɔ nya, akafu ahaxɔ nya.
Similarly, when the apostle John quoted Jesus, he personified the holy spirit as a "helper " (paraclete) that would give evidence, guide, speak, hear, declare, glorify, and receive.
Nyakpakpa: Amewo nyɔnyrɔ ɖe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la ƒe ŋkɔ me ɖee fia be amee wònye.
He used masculine personal pronouns such as "he " or "him " when referring to that "helper. "
Nyateƒea: Biblia zãa "ŋkɔ " ɣeaɖewoɣi tsɔ fia ŋusẽ alo ɖoƒe.
Fact: The Bible sometimes uses "name " to stand for power or authority.
(5 Mose 18:5, 19-22; Esta 8:10) Wogblɔa nya sia tɔgbi le Eŋlisigbe me be le "sea ƒe ŋkɔ me, " gake esia mefia be amee se la nye o.
(Deuteronomy 18:​5, 19-​22; Esther 8:​10) This is similar to its use in the English expression "in the name of the law, " which does not mean that the law is a person.
Ame si wonyrɔ le "gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la ƒe ŋkɔ me " lɔ̃na ɖe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea ƒe ŋusẽ kple akpa si wòwɔna be Mawu ƒe tameɖoɖo nava eme la dzi.​ Mateo 28:19.
A person who is baptized "in the name of " the holy spirit recognizes the power and role of the holy spirit in accomplishing God’s will.​ Matthew 28:19.
Nyakpakpa: Yesu ƒe apostolowo kple eƒe nusrɔ̃la gbãtɔ bubuwo xɔe se be amee gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea nye.
Misconception: Jesus’ apostles and other early disciples believed that the holy spirit was a person.
Nyateƒea: Esia ƒe kpeɖodzi aɖeke mele Biblia alo ŋutinya me o.
Fact: The Bible does not say that, nor does history.
Numekugbalẽ aɖe (Encyclopædia Britannica) gblɔ be: "Konstantinople ƒe Aɖaŋuɖotakpekpe si wowɔ le ƒe 381 Do Ŋgɔ Na Yesu . . . mee woto nufiafia si nye be Gbɔgbɔ Kɔkɔea hã nye Mawu la vɛ. "
The Encyclopædia Britannica states: "The definition that the Holy Spirit was a distinct divine Person . . . came at the Council of Constantinople in ad 381. "
Esia nye ƒe 250 kple edzivɔ le apostolo mamlɛtɔ ƒe ku megbe.
This was over 250 years after the last of the apostles had died.
Ðe Ŋkɔ Le Mawu Sia?
Does God Have a Name?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ŋkɔ le ame sia ame si.
Humans all have personal names.
Ðe mesɔ be ŋkɔ nanɔ Mawu hã si oa?
Wouldn’t it be reasonable for God to have a name?
Ame nɔewo ŋkɔnyanya kple eyɔyɔ wɔa kpa vevie aɖe le xɔlɔ̃kadodowo me.
Having and using personal names is a vital part of human friendships.
Ðe mele be wòanɔ alea le xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔ kple Mawu hã gome oa?
Should it be different when it comes to our friendship with God?
Mawu gblɔ le Biblia me be: "Nyee nye Yehowa, ŋkɔnyee. "
In the Bible, God says: "I am Jehovah. That is my name. "
(Yesaya 42:8) Togbɔ be dzesideŋkɔ geɖewo, abe "Mawu ŋusẽkatãtɔ, " "Aƒetɔ Dziɖulagã " kple "Wɔla " le Mawu si hã la, ede bubu esubɔlawo ŋu esi wòbia tso wo si be woayɔ ye ŋkɔ ŋutɔ.
(Isaiah 42:8) Although he also has many titles, such as "God Almighty, " "Sovereign Lord, " and "Creator, " he honors his worshippers by inviting them to address him by his personal name.
1 Mose 17:1; Dɔwɔwɔwo 4:24; 1 Petro 4:19.
Genesis 17:1; Acts 4:24; 1 Peter 4:19.
Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ dze le Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe geɖewo me le 2 Mose 6:3.
Many translations of the Bible contain God’s personal name at Exodus 6:3.
Afi ma gblɔ be: "Nyee ɖe ɖokuinye fia Abraham, Isak kple Yakob abe Mawu ŋusẽkatãtɔ ene; ke nyemeɖe nye ŋkɔ Yehowa fia wo o. "
That passage says: "I used to appear to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob as God Almighty, but as respects my name Jehovah I did not make myself known to them. "
Yehowa ye nye ale si woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔe le Eʋegbe me ƒe alafa geɖewoe nye esia.
Jehovah is a rendering of God’s name in English that has been used for centuries.
Togbɔ be agbalẽnyala geɖewo lɔ̃a "Yahweh " zazã hã la, Yehowa ye ame akpa gãtɔ ya zãna.
While many scholars prefer the spelling "Yahweh, " Jehovah is the form of the name that is most widely recognized.
Hebrigbe mee woŋlɔ Biblia ƒe akpa gbãtɔ ɖo. Le gbe sia me la, woxlẽa nu tso ɖusime yia miame me, eye mele abe Eʋegbe ene o.
The first part of the Bible was written not in English but in Hebrew, a language that is read from right to left.
Le Hebrigbea me la, xaxagbeɖiɖi ene, siwo nye יהוה ye wotsɔ ŋlɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔe.
In that language, the divine name appears as four consonants, יהוה.
Amewo lɔ̃a Hebrigbe me ŋɔŋlɔdzesi ene mawo, siwo nye YHWH le míaƒe ŋɔŋlɔdzesi nu la yɔyɔ be Hebrigbe me ŋɔŋlɔdzesi ene.
Those four Hebrew characters transliterated YHWH are known as the Tetragrammaton.
Mawu Ŋkɔe Nye Yesua?
Is God’s Name Jesus?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yesu yɔ eɖokui be "Mawu ƒe Vi. "
Jesus referred to himself as "God’s Son " or "the Son of God. "
(Yohanes 10:36; 11:4) Yesu megblɔ kpɔ be yenye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ o.
(John 10:36; 11:4) Jesus never identified himself as Almighty God.
Gawu la, Yesu do gbe ɖa na Mawu.
Moreover, Jesus prayed to God.
(Mateo 26:39) Esi Yesu nɔ gbedodoɖa fiam eyomedzelawo la, egblɔ be: "Mía Fofo si le dziƒowo, wò ŋkɔ ŋuti nakɔ. "
(Matthew 26:39) And while teaching his followers how to pray, Jesus said: "Our Father in the heavens, let your name be sanctified. "
Mateo 6:9.
Matthew 6:9.
Yesu ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ɖe go esi wòyɔ nya tso blema Ŋɔŋlɔ aɖe me hegblɔ be: "Oo Israel, see, Yehowa mía Mawu la, Yehowa ɖeka koe. "
Jesus revealed God’s name when he quoted an ancient passage of Scripture and said: "Hear, O Israel, Jehovah our God is one Jehovah. "
Marko 12:29; 5 Mose 6:4.
Mark 12:29; Deuteronomy 6:4.
Ame Kae Nye Yehowa?
Who Is Jehovah?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yehowae nye Mawu vavã si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Biblia me, eyae nye nuwo katã Wɔla.
Jehovah is the true God of the Bible, the Creator of all things.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Nyagblɔɖila siwo ŋkɔe nye Abraham kple Mose subɔ eya amea, eye Yesu hã subɔe.
(Revelation 4:​11) The prophets Abraham and Moses worshipped him, as did Jesus.
(1 Mose 24:27; 2 Mose 15:1, 2; Yohanes 20:17) Eyae nye "anyigba blibo la katã " ƒe Mawu, ke menye dukɔ ɖeka aɖe ko tɔ o. Psalmo 47:2.
(Genesis 24:27; Exodus 15:1, 2; John 20:17) He is the God, not just of one people, but of "all the earth. "​ Psalm 47:2.
Biblia na míenya be Yehowa ye nye Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ɖeka kolia.
Jehovah is God’s unique name as revealed in the Bible.
(2 Mose 3:15; Psalmo 83:18) Ŋkɔ sia tso Hebrigbe me dɔwɔnya "evaa eme " me, eye agbalẽnyalagã geɖewo gblɔ be ŋkɔa gɔmee nye "Enana Wòvaa Eme. "
(Exodus 3:​15; Psalm 83:18) It comes from a Hebrew verb that means "to become, " and a number of scholars suggest that the name means "He Causes to Become. "
Gɔmeɖeɖe sia wɔ ɖeka kple Mawu ƒe ɖoƒe abe Wɔla kple Ame si nana be eƒe tameɖoɖo vaa eme ene la nyuie ŋutɔ.
This definition well fits Jehovah’s role as the Creator and the Fulfiller of his purpose.
(Yesaya 55:10, 11) Biblia gakpe ɖe mía ŋu míenya Ame si tutu Yehowa nye, vevietɔ míenya nu tso eƒe nɔnɔme vevitɔ si nye lɔlɔ̃ ŋu.
(Isaiah 55:10, 11) The Bible also helps us to know the Person behind the name Jehovah, especially his dominant quality of love.
2 Mose 34:5-7; Luka 6:35; 1 Yohanes 4:8.
Exodus 34:5-7; Luke 6:35; 1 John 4:8.
Ŋkɔ Yehowa nye Hebrigbe me ŋɔŋlɔdzesi ene siwo nye יהוה (YHWH) siwo wozãna na Mawu la gɔme ɖeɖe ɖe Eʋegbe me.
The name Jehovah is an English translation of the Hebrew name for God​ the four letters יהוה (YHWH), known as the Tetragrammaton.
Mímenya ale si tututu woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa le Hebrigbe si wodona le blema la me o.
The exact pronunciation of the divine name in ancient Hebrew is not known.
Ke hã, woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ le Eʋegbe me be "Yehowa " tso gbe aɖe gbe ke, eye le Eŋlisigbe me la, edze zi gbãtɔ le William Tyndale ƒe Biblia si wota le ƒe 1530 me la me.
However, the form "Jehovah " has a long history in the English language, first appearing in William Tyndale’s Bible translation of 1530.
Nu ka tae mímenya ale si woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa le blema Hebrigbea me o?
Why is the pronunciation of God’s name in ancient Hebrew unknown?
Womeŋlɔa ablɔɖegbeɖiɖiwo le blema Hebrigbea me o, ke xaxagbeɖiɖiwo ko woŋlɔna.
Ancient Hebrew was written without vowels, using only consonants.
Ne Hebritɔwo le nu xlẽm la, woawo ŋutɔ wotea ŋu yɔa ablɔɖegbeɖiɖi siwo hiã la bɔbɔe.
The Hebrew-speaking reader could easily provide the appropriate vowels.
Gake esi wowu Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo ( "Nubabla Xoxoa ") ŋɔŋlɔ nu la, aʋatsodzixɔsewo na be Yudatɔ aɖewo de se be mesɔ be woayɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ o.
However, after the Hebrew Scriptures ( "Old Testament ") were completed, some Jews adopted the superstitious belief that it was wrong to utter God’s personal name.
Eya ta ne wole mawunyakpukpui siwo me Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa dze le xlẽm la, wotsɔa nyagbɔgblɔ siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye "Aƒetɔ " alo "Mawu " ɖɔlinɛ.
When they read aloud a scripture that contained God’s name, they substituted expressions such as "Lord " or "God. "
Le ƒe alafa geɖe megbe la, aʋatsodzixɔse sia va kaka eye ale si woyɔa ŋkɔa la bu keŋ.
As centuries passed, this superstition spread and the ancient pronunciation was eventually lost.
Ame aɖewo susui be ale si woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa lae nye "Yahwé, " eye ame bubuwo hã do susu bubuwo ɖa.
Some feel that the divine name was pronounced "Yahweh, " while others suggest different possibilities.
Woyɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa le agbalẽ xatsaxatsa aɖe si wofɔ le Ƒukukua me si dzi Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Etɔ̃lia ƒe akpa aɖe le le Helagbe me be Iao.
A Dead Sea Scroll containing a portion of Leviticus in Greek transliterates the name Iao.
Helagbe me agbalẽŋlɔla gbãtɔwo hã gblɔ be ele be woayɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa be Iae, Iabe kple Iaoue, gake womate ŋu aɖo kpe edzi be ŋkɔ siawo dometɔ aɖee woyɔ na Mawu le blema Hebrigbe me o.
Early Greek writers also suggest the pronunciations Iae, Iabe, and Iaoue, but none of these can be proved to be the pronunciation used in ancient Hebrew.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa dede Biblia me ŋu
Misconceptions about God’s name in the Bible
Susu totro: Ne "Yehowa " dze le Biblia aɖe me la, ke ɖe wotsɔ ŋkɔ sia kpe Biblia me nyawo.
Misconception: Translations that use "Jehovah " have added this name.
Nyateƒea: Hebrigbe me ŋɔŋlɔdzesi ene siwo wotsɔ ŋlɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa dze zi 7,000 aɖewo le Biblia me.
Fact: The Hebrew word for God’s name in the form of the Tetragrammaton appears some 7,000 times in the Bible.
Woɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ɖa le Biblia geɖe me madzemadzee, eye wotsɔ bubuŋkɔ siwo dometɔ aɖee nye "Aƒetɔ " ɖɔlinɛ.
Most translations arbitrarily remove God’s name and replace it with a title such as "Lord. "
Susu totro: Mehiã be ŋkɔ tɔxɛ aɖeke nanɔ Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la si o.
Misconception: Almighty God does not need a unique name.
Nyateƒea: Mawu ŋutɔ na eƒe gbɔgbɔ ʋã Biblia-ŋlɔlawo wozã eƒe ŋkɔa zi akpe geɖe, eye wòde se hã be ye subɔlawo nazã ŋkɔ ma.
Fact: God himself inspired Bible writers to use his name thousands of times, and he directs those who worship him to use his name.
(Yesaya 42:8; Yoel 2:32; Malaki 3:16; Romatɔwo 10:13) Le nyateƒe me la, Mawu bu fɔ aʋatsonyagblɔɖila siwo dze agbagba be yewoana amewo naŋlɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ be la.​ Yeremiya 23:27.
(Isaiah 42:8; Joel 2:​32; Malachi 3:​16; Romans 10:13) In fact, God condemned false prophets who tried to make people forget his name.​ Jeremiah 23:27.
Susu totro: Le Yudatɔwo ƒe kɔa nu la, ele be woaɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa ɖa le Biblia me.
Misconception: Following the tradition of the Jews, God’s name should be removed from the Bible.
Nyateƒea: Enye nyateƒe be Yudatɔwo ƒe agbalẽfiala aɖewo gbe be yewomayɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa o ya.
Fact: It is true that some Jewish scribes refused to pronounce the divine name.
Gake womeɖe ŋkɔa ɖa le woƒe Bibliawo me o.
However, they did not remove it from their copies of the Bible.
Gake vevietɔ wue nye be Mawu medi be míalé amegbetɔwo ƒe kɔnu siwo mewɔ ɖeka kple eƒe sededewo o la me ɖe asi o.​ Mateo 15:​1-3.
In any case, God does not want us to follow human traditions that deviate from his commandments.​ Matthew 15:​1-3.
Susu totro: Mele be woaŋlɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa ɖe Biblia me o elabe ame aɖeke menya ale si tututu woyɔe le Hebrigbea me o.
Misconception: The divine name should not be used in the Bible because it is not known exactly how to pronounce it in Hebrew.
Nyateƒea: Tamebubu alea afia be Mawu le mɔ kpɔm be gbe vovo dolawo katã nayɔ eƒe ŋkɔa le mɔ ɖeka nu.
Fact: This line of reasoning assumes that God expects people who speak different languages to pronounce his name identically.
Ke hã, Biblia ɖee fia be Mawu subɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema siwo nye gbe vovo dolawo la yɔa ŋkɔ tɔxɛwo le mɔ vovovowo nu.
However, the Bible indicates that God’s worshippers in the past who spoke different languages pronounced proper names differently.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, bu Israel-viwo ƒe ʋɔnudrɔ̃la Yosua ƒe ŋkɔa ŋu kpɔ.
Consider, for example, the Israelite judge Joshua.
Ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me Kristotɔ siwo doa Hebrigbe yɔa Yosua be Yehohsua, evɔ Helagbedolawo ya ayɔe be Iesous.
First-century Christians who spoke Hebrew would have pronounced his name Yehohshuaʽ, while those who spoke Greek would have said Iesous.

Woŋlɔ ale si woyɔa Yosua ƒe ŋkɔa le Helagbe me ɖe Biblia me, eye esia fia be Kristotɔwo ɖe afɔ si me nunya le si nye be woaŋlɔ ŋkɔ tɔxɛwo le ale si ame akpa gãtɔ yɔa wo le wo degbea me la nu.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 7:45; Hebritɔwo 4:8.

The Bible records the Greek translation of Joshua’s Hebrew name, showing that Christians followed the sensible course of using the form of proper names common in their language.​ Acts 7:​45; Hebrews 4:8.
Woate ŋu aɖe afɔ ma ke le Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa gɔme ɖeɖe hã gome.
The same principle can be applied to translating the divine name.
Togbɔ be ale si woyɔa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa ŋutɔŋutɔ le vevie hã la, ŋkɔa dede afi siwo tututu wòdze le le Biblia me ya gale vevie sãsãsã wu.
Far more important than the exact pronunciation chosen is that God’s name be given its rightful place in the Bible.
Ŋkɔ Nenie Le Mawu Si?
How Many Names Does God Have?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ ɖeka koe le Mawu si.
God has just one personal name.
Wozãa ŋɔŋlɔdzesi si nye יהוה tsɔ ŋlɔnɛ le Hebrigbe me, eye woɖea egɔme le Eʋegbe me be "Yehowa. "
It is written יהוה in Hebrew and is usually rendered "Jehovah " in English.
Mawu gblɔ to eƒe nyagblɔɖila Yesaya dzi be: "Nyee nye Yehowa.
Through his prophet Isaiah, God stated: "I am Jehovah.
Ŋkɔnyee. "
That is my name. "

(Yesaya 42:8) Ŋkɔ sia dze abe zi 7,000 sɔŋ ene le Biblia ƒe blemasinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽwo me​ edze enuenu wu ŋkɔnya ɖe sia ɖe si wozãna ɖe Mawu teƒe; le nyateƒe me la, edze zi geɖe wu ame bubu ɖe sia ɖe ƒe ŋkɔ.
(Isaiah 42:8) This name appears about 7,000 times in ancient Bible manuscripts​ far more frequently than any other term for God or, indeed, anyone else’s personal name.
Ðe ŋkɔ bubu aɖewo li siwo woyɔna na Yehowa?
Are there other names for God?
Togbɔ be ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ ɖeka koe Biblia yɔ na Mawu hã la, Biblia zã dzesideŋkɔ geɖewo nɛ.
Although the Bible refers to God by only one personal name, it uses many titles and descriptions for him.
Dzesideŋkɔ siwo gbɔna, kple nya siwo wotsɔ ɖɔ Mawui la dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖe Yehowa ƒe nɔnɔme ɖedzesi aɖe fia.
The following list of some of those titles and descriptions shows how each one reveals an aspect of Jehovah’s nature or his personality.
Dzesideŋkɔ
Title
Mawunyakpukpui
Reference
Egɔmeɖeɖe
Meaning
Allah
Allah
(Ðeke meli o)
(None)
Woɖe nya si nye "Allah " tso Arabgbe me, menye ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔe wònye o, ke boŋ enye dzesideŋkɔ si gɔmee nye "Mawu. "
Derived from Arabic, the word "Allah " is not a personal name but a title meaning "God. "
Arabgbe kple gbe bubu aɖewo zã nya "Allah " na "Mawu " le woƒe Biblia gɔmeɖeɖewo me.
Bible translations in Arabic and other languages use "Allah " as an equivalent for "God. "
Ŋusẽkatãtɔ
Almighty
1 Mose 17:1
Genesis 17:1
Ŋusẽ si nu womate ŋu axe mɔ ɖo o le esi.
Has irresistible power.
Hebrigbe me nya ʼEl Shaddai, si gɔmee nye "Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ, " la dze zi adre le Biblia me.
The Hebrew expression ʼEl Shaddai, "God Almighty, " occurs seven times in the Bible.
Alfa kple Omega
The Alpha and the Omega
Nyaɖeɖefia 1:8; 21:6; 22:13
Revelation 1:8; 21:6; 22:13
Nya sia si gɔmee nye, "gbãtɔ kple mlɔetɔ, " alo "gɔmedzedze kple nuwuwu, " si fia be Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ aɖeke medo ŋgɔ na Yehowa o, eye ɖeke mado megbe nɛ o.
"The first and the last, " or "the beginning and the end, " meaning that there was no Almighty God before Jehovah and there will be none after him.
(Yesaya 43:10) Alfa nye Helagbe me alfabeta ŋɔŋlɔdzesi gbãtɔ eye Omega nye alfabeta ŋɔŋlɔdzesi mamlɛtɔ.
(Isaiah 43:10) Alpha and omega are the first and last letters of the Greek alphabet.
Ame Si Li Tso Gbe Aɖe Gbe Ʋĩi Ke
Ancient of Days
Daniel 7:9, 13, 22
Gɔmedzedze meli nɛ o; eli tso mavɔmavɔ me hafi ame alo nu bubu ɖe sia ɖe va dzɔ.​ Psalmo 90:2.
Had no beginning; existed for an eternity before anyone or anything else came into being.​ Psalm 90:2.
Wɔla
Creator
Yesaya 40:28
Isaiah 40:28
Eyae wɔ nuwo katã.
Brought all things into existence.
Fofo

Mawu
God
1 Mose 1:1
Genesis 1:1
Nu si ame subɔna; Ŋusẽtɔ.
An object of worship; a strong One.
Hebrigbe me nya ʼElohim nye nuyɔyɔ ɖe agbɔsɔsɔ me, eye efia Yehowa ƒe gãnyenye, bubu alo nyonyo.
The Hebrew word ʼElohim is plural, indicating Jehovah’s majesty, dignity, or excellence.
Mawuwo dzi Mawu
God of gods

Deuteronomy 10:17
Eyae nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la, eto vovo na ‘mawu maɖinu’ siwo ame aɖewo subɔna.​ Yesaya 2:8.
The supreme God, in contrast with the "worthless gods " worshipped by some.​ Isaiah 2:8.
Nufiala Gãtɔ

Yesaya 30:20, 21
Isaiah 30:20, 21
Enaa nufiame kple mɔfiame siwo ɖea vi na mí.​ Yesaya 48:17, 18.
Gives beneficial teaching and direction.​ Isaiah 48:17, 18.

Psalm 149:2

Characterized by joy and happiness.​ Psalm 104:31.

Ame Si Menye, Eyae Menye

2 Mose 3:14, Eʋegbe Biblia
Exodus 3:​14, King James Version
Mawu ate ŋu azu nu sia nu si hiã be wòana eƒe tameɖoɖo nava eme.
Becomes whatever is needed to fulfill his purpose.
Wogaɖe nya sia gɔme be, "Mazu nu sia nu si dze ŋunye " alo "Mava Nye Nu Si Metia Be Manye. "
This phrase has also been translated "I Will Become whatsoever I please " or "I Will Become What I Choose to Become. "

(The Emphasised Bible, si J. B. Rotherham ta; Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe) Ale si woɖɔe le afi sia kpe ɖe mía ŋu míekpɔ gɔmesese si le eƒe ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ si nye Yehowa, le kpukpui si kplɔe ɖo me la ŋu.​ 2 Mose 3:15.
(The Emphasised Bible, by J. B. Rotherham; New World Translation) This description helps to explain the personal name, Jehovah, given in the next verse.​ Exodus 3:​15.
Eʋãa Ŋu
Jealous
2 Mose 34:14, King James Version
Exodus 34:14, King James Version
Medina be woasubɔ Mawu bubu aɖeke kpe ɖe ye ŋu o.
Tolerates no rivalry in worship.
Wogaɖe nya sia gɔme be "meɖea mɔ na mawu tutɔwo o " kple "ame si biaa ɖokuitsɔtsɔna blibo. "​ God’s Word Bible; New World Translation.
This term has also been translated "does not tolerate rivals " and "known for requiring exclusive devotion. "​ God’s Word Bible; New World Translation.

Psalm 135:5
Nutɔ alo aƒetɔ; Hebrigbe ʼAdhohn kple Adhonim.
Owner or master; Hebrew ʼAdhohn and ʼAdhonim.
Yehowa Zebaot, aʋakɔwo ƒe Yehowa
Lord of hosts, Lord of Sabaoth
Yesaya 1:9, Eʋegbe Biblia; Romatɔwo 9:29
Isaiah 1:9, King James Version; Romans 9:​29, King James Version
Mawudɔlawo ƒe aʋakɔ nyadri aɖe ƒe aʋafiagã.
Commander of vast forces of angels.
Woagate ŋu aɖe "Yehowa Zebaot " gɔme be "Aʋakɔwo ƒe Yehowa. "​ Romatɔwo 9:29, Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe.
The title "Lord of Sabaoth " can also be rendered "Jehovah of armies " and "Lord of the [heavenly] armies. "​ Romans 9:​29, New World Translation; NET Bible, footnote.

Psalmo 47:2
Psalm 47:2
Eƒe ɖoƒe ƒo ɖe sia ɖe ta.
Occupies the supreme position.

Lododowo 9:10
Proverbs 9:​10
Ele kɔkɔe (ele dzadzɛ) wu nuwɔwɔ bubu ɖe sia ɖe.
More holy (morally clean and pure) than any other being.

Potter
Yesaya 64:8
Isaiah 64:8
Ŋusẽ le esi ɖe ame ɖekaɖekawo kple dukɔwo dzi, abe ale si ko ŋusẽ le zemela si ɖe tsu dzi ene.​ Romatɔwo 9:20, 21.
Has authority over individuals and nations, just as a potter has authority over clay.​ Romans 9:​20, 21.

Redeemer, Repurchaser

Egbugbɔ ƒle amegbetɔƒomea tso nu vɔ̃ kple ku si me to Yesu Kristo ƒe tafevɔsaa dzi.​ Yohanes 3:16.
Recovers or buys back mankind from sin and death through the ransom sacrifice of Jesus Christ.​ John 3:​16.

Enye míaƒe sitsoƒe kple dedienɔƒe.
A secure refuge and source of salvation.

Isaiah 45:21
Eɖea ame tsoa afɔku alo tsɔtsrɔ̃ me.
Delivers from danger or destruction.

Shepherd

Psalm 23:1
Elea be na esubɔlawo.
Cares for his worshippers.

Sovereign Lord

Genesis 15:2
Eƒe ŋusẽ ƒo ɖe sia ɖe ta; Hebrigbe Adhonai.
Has supreme authority; Hebrew Adhonai.

Supreme One
Daniel 7:18, 27
Daniel 7:​18, 27
Eyae ƒo nuwo katã ta.
The highest sovereign.
Teƒewo ƒe ŋkɔwo le Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo me
Place names in the Hebrew Scriptures
Woyɔ Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ kpe ɖe teƒe aɖewo ƒe ŋkɔwo ŋu le Biblia me, gake menye eƒe ŋkɔ bubuwoe emawo nye o.
Some place names in the Bible include God’s personal name, but these are not alternate names for God.

Exodus 17:15

"Jehovah Is My Signal Pole, " or "my Banner. "
(Eʋegbe Biblia) Yehowae nye Mawu si gbɔ eƒe amewo ate ŋu ate ɖo hena ametakpɔkpɔ kple kpekpeɖeŋu.​ 2 Mose 17:13-16.
(Today’s New International Version) Jehovah is a God around whom his people can rally for protection and help.​ Exodus 17:13-​16.
Yehowa-salom
Jehovah-shalom

"Yehowa Le Afi Ma. "
"Jehovah Is There. "
Susu siwo tae wòle be nànya Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ahazãe
Reasons to know and use God’s name
Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ si nye Yehowa la le vevie nɛ elabe ena woŋlɔ ŋkɔa zi gbɔ zi akpe geɖe ɖe Biblia me.​ Malaki 1:11.
God must feel that his personal name, Jehovah, is important, because he included it thousands of times in the Bible.​ Malachi 1:​11.
Mawu ƒe Vi, Yesu, te gbe ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ ƒe vevienyenye dzi zi geɖe.
God’s Son, Jesus, repeatedly stressed the importance of God’s name.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, edo gbe ɖa na Yehowa be: "Wò ŋkɔ ŋuti nakɔ. "​ Mateo 6:9; Yohanes 17:6.
For instance, he prayed to Jehovah: "Let your name be sanctified. "​ Matthew 6:9; John 17:6.
Ame siwo va nyaa Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa hezãnɛ la wɔ afɔɖeɖe gbãtɔ siwo ana be xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔ nanɔ woawo kple Yehowa dome.
Those who come to know and use God’s name take the first steps in building a friendship with Jehovah.
(Psalmo 9:10; Malaki 3:16) Ƒomedodo sia wɔnɛ be Mawu ƒe ŋugbedodo sia ate ŋu aɖe vi na wo, egblɔ be: "Esi melɔ̃a nu le gbɔnye o ta la, nye hã maɖee.
(Psalm 9:​10; Malachi 3:​16) Such a relationship enables them to benefit from God’s promise: "Because he has affection for me, I will rescue him.
Makpɔ eta, elabena enya nye ŋkɔ. "​ Psalmo 91:14.
I will protect him because he knows my name. "​ Psalm 91:14.

Biblia lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be: "Nu siwo woyɔna be mawuwo li, eɖanye le dziƒo alo le anyigba dzi o, abe ale si ‘mawu’ geɖewo kple ‘aƒetɔ’ geɖewo li ene. " (1 Korintotɔwo 8:5, 6) Ke hã, ena eme kɔ ƒãa be Mawu vavã ɖeka si ŋkɔe nye Yehowa koe li.​ Psalmo 83:18.

The Bible acknowledges: "There are so-called gods, whether in heaven or on earth, just as there are many ‘gods’ and many ‘lords.’ " (1 Corinthians 8:​5, 6) Yet it clearly identifies the one true God by his name, Jehovah.​ Psalm 83:18.
Tame Kae Mawu Ðo Ðe Nye Agbe Ŋu?
What Is the Will of God for My Life?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nue nye be nàva nya ye be Ame ŋutɔŋutɔe yenye, nàte ɖe ye ŋu, alɔ̃ ye eye nàsubɔ ye kple wò dzi blibo.
God’s will is that you come to know him as a Person, draw close to him, and then love and serve him with your whole heart.
(Mateo 22:37, 38; Yakobo 4:8) Àte ŋu asrɔ̃ ale si nàwɔ Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu ne èsrɔ̃ nu tso Yesu ƒe agbenɔnɔ kple eƒe nufiafiawo ŋu.
(Matthew 22:37, 38; James 4:8) You can learn how to do God’s will from the life and teachings of Jesus.
(Yohanes 7:16, 17) Menye ɖeko Yesu ƒo nu tso Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu ŋu na amewo o, eya ŋutɔ hã nɔ agbe ɖe enu.
(John 7:16, 17) Jesus didn’t just talk about the will of God he lived it.
Eya tae Yesu gblɔ gɔ̃ hã be tameɖoɖo si le yeƒe agbe ŋu ‘menye be yeawɔ ye ŋutɔ yeƒe lɔlɔ̃nu o, ke boŋ yeawɔ ame si dɔ ye ɖa la ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu.’
In fact, Jesus said that his purpose in life was "to do, not my will, but the will of him that sent me. "
Yohanes 6:38.
John 6:38.
Ðe wòhiã be makpɔ dzesi tɔxɛ, ŋutega alo axɔ yɔyɔ tɔxɛ aɖe hafi anya tame si Mawu ɖo ɖe ŋunyea?
Do I need a special sign, vision, or calling to know what the will of God is for me?
Ao, elabe gbedeasi si le Mawu si na ameƒomea la le Biblia me.
No, because the Bible contains God’s message to mankind.

Nu sia nu si nèhiã be ‘nàdze bliboe, eye nànɔ dzadzraɖoɖi keŋkeŋ na dɔ nyui sia dɔ nyui wɔwɔ’ la le eme. (2 Timoteo 3:16, 17) Mawu di be nàzã Biblia kple wò "tamebubu ŋutete " atsɔ anya tame si yeɖo ɖe ŋuwò.
It has what you need to be "completely equipped for every good work. " (2 Timothy 3:16, 17) God wants you to use the Bible along with your "power of reason " to learn his will for you.
Romatɔwo 12:1, 2; Efesotɔwo 5:17.
Romans 12:1, 2; Ephesians 5:17.
Ðe mate ŋu awɔ Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu ŋutɔŋutɔa?
Can I really do God’s will?
Ɛ̃, àte ŋui, elabe Biblia gblɔ be Mawu ƒe "seawo mesesẽ o. " (1 Yohanes 5:3, Eʋegbe Biblia) Esia mefia be Mawu ƒe sewo dzi wɔwɔ nɔa bɔbɔe ɣesiaɣi o.
Yes, you can, for the Bible says: "God’s commands are not too hard for us. " (1 John 5:3, Easy-to-Read Version) That’s not to say that obeying God’s commands is always easy.
Gake vi siwo Mawu ƒe sewo dzi wɔwɔ ɖena na ame la ƒo agbagba siwo ame dzena hafi wɔa wo dzi la ta sãsãsã.
But the benefits you will gain far outweigh the effort you must put forth.
Yesu ŋutɔ gblɔ be: "Dzidzɔtɔwoe nye ame siwo le Mawu ƒe nya la sem, eye wole edzi wɔm! " Luka 11:28.
Jesus himself said: "How happy are those who hear the word of God and obey it! "
Nu Kae Biblia Gblɔ Tso Tiatiawɔblɔɖe Ŋu?
Luke 11:28, Good News Translation.
Ðe Mawu Ðo Ame Si Nàva Zu Le Etsɔme Ðia?
What Does the Bible Say About Free Will?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
Is God in Control?
Mawu de bubu mía ŋu hena tiatiawɔblɔɖe mí.
The Bible’s answer
Tiatiawɔblɔɖe nye ablɔɖe si Mawu na mí be míawo ŋutɔwo míatso nya me ke menye be Mawu alo dzɔgbese naɖo ale si míava nɔ agbee la ɖi na mí o.
God dignifies us with free will, the power to make decisions of our own rather than having God or fate predetermine what we do.
Bu Biblia ƒe nufiafia siawo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider what the Bible teaches.
Mawu wɔ amegbetɔwo ɖe eƒe nɔnɔme nu.
God created humans in his image.
(1 Mose 1:26) Mía Wɔla wɔ mí ɖe eƒe nɔnɔme nu le mɔ sia nu be ŋutete le mía si míeɖea eƒe nɔnɔmewo, abe lɔlɔ̃ kple dzɔdzɔnyenye ene fiana.
(Genesis 1:26) Unlike animals, which act mainly on instinct, we resemble our Creator in our capacity to display such qualities as love and justice.
Míele abe lãwo ene o elabena lãwo ya wɔa nu ɖe woƒe lãmenusese ko nu.
And like our Creator, we have free will.
Eye abe mía Wɔla ene la, tiatiawɔblɔɖe le mía si.
To a great extent, we can determine our future.
Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be ‘mitia agbe eye miɖo to Mawu ƒe gbe,’ si fia be míalɔ̃ be míawɔ eƒe sewo dzi.
The Bible encourages us to "choose life . . . by listening to [God’s] voice, " that is, by choosing to obey his commands.
(5 Mose 30:19, 20) Nya sia anye dzodzro kple tagbɔsesẽ le ame ŋu ne ŋutete mele mía si be míate ŋu atia nu si míawɔ la o.
(Deuteronomy 30:19, 20) This offer would be meaningless, even cruel, if we lacked free will.
Le esi Mawu nazi nu si wòdi la ɖe mía dzi teƒe la, ɖe wòkpe mí lɔlɔ̃tɔe hegblɔ be: "Ðe wònye ɖe nèɖo to nye seawo la, anye ne wò ŋutifafa anɔ abe tɔsisi ene. "
Instead of forcing us to do what he says, God warmly appeals to us: "O if only you would actually pay attention to my commandments! Then your peace would become just like a river. "
Yesaya 48:18.
Isaiah 48:18.
Menye dzɔgbese aɖekee kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe míaƒe dzidzedzekpɔkpɔ alo kpododonu dzi o.
Our success or failure is not determined by fate.
Ne míedi be míakpɔ dzidzedze le míaƒe agbagbadzedzewo me la, ke ele be míawɔ dɔ sesĩe.
If we want to succeed at an endeavor, we must work hard.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Nu sia nu si wò asi ate ŋu awɔ la, wɔe kple wò ŋusẽ. "
"All that your hand finds to do, " says the Bible, "do with your very power.
(Nyagblɔla 9:10) Egblɔ hã be: "Veviedola ƒe tameɖoɖo hea viɖe vɛ. "
"(Ecclesiastes 9:10) It also says: "The plans of the diligent one surely make for advantage. "
Lododowo 21:5.
Proverbs 21:5.
Nunana xɔasie tiatiawɔblɔɖe nye Mawu na mí, elabena esia nana míelɔ̃nɛ kple míaƒe "dzi blibo, " le esi míetiae be míalɔ̃e ta.
Free will is a precious gift from God, for it lets us love him with our "whole heart " because we want to.
Mateo 22:37.
Matthew 22:37.
Ðe Mawu kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe nu sia nu dzia?
Doesn’t God control all things?
Biblia fia nu be Mawue nye Ŋusẽkatãtɔ, si fia be ame aɖeke ƒe ŋusẽ megbɔ etɔ nu o.
The Bible does teach that God is Almighty, that his power is not limited by anyone other than himself.
(Hiob 37:23; Yesaya 40:26) Gake mezãa eƒe ŋusẽa tsɔ kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe nu sia nu dzi o.
(Job 37:23; Isaiah 40:26) However, he does not use his power to control everything.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi Mawu nɔ nu wɔm kple blema Babilontɔ siwo nye eƒe amewo ƒe futɔwo la, egblɔ be "mezi ɖokuinye dzi. "
For example, the Bible says that God was "exercising self-control " toward ancient Babylon, an enemy of his people.
(Yesaya 42:14) Nenema kee egbea hã, Mawu zi eɖokui dzi heɖe mɔ amewo le woƒe tiatiawɔblɔɖea zãm tsɔ le nu gblẽm le ame bubuwo ŋu.
(Isaiah 42:14) Similarly, for now, he chooses to tolerate those who misuse their free will to harm others.
Gake Mawu mazi eɖokui dzi ɖaa o.
But God will not do so indefinitely.
Psalmo 37:10, 11.
Mawue Nana Míekpea Fua?
Is God to Blame for Our Suffering?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia ɖo eŋu eme kɔ ƒãa be, ao.
The Bible emphatically answers no!
Yehowa Mawu meɖoe kura be amegbetɔwo nakpe fu o.
Suffering was not part of Jehovah God’s purpose for mankind.
Ke hã atsu kple asi gbãtɔ dze aglã ɖe Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu ŋu, eye wotiae be yewo ŋutɔwo yewoatso nya me le nyui kple vɔ̃ ŋu na yewo ɖokuiwo.
However, the first human couple rebelled against God’s rulership, choosing to set their own standards of good and bad.
Woɖe wo ɖokuiwo ɖa le Mawu ŋu eye wokpɔ emetsonuawo hã.
They turned away from God and suffered the consequences.
Egbea míele tiatia gbegblẽ si ame eve mawo wɔ la ƒe fu kpem.
Today we are experiencing the effects of their bad choice.
Eya ta amegbetɔwo ƒe fukpekpe metso Mawu gbɔ kura o.
But in no way did God originate human suffering.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ne ame aɖe le tetekpɔ me tom la, negagblɔ be: ‘Mawue le teyem kpɔ’ o.
The Bible says: "When under trial, let no one say: ‘I am being tried by God.’
Elabena womate ŋu atsɔ nu vɔ̃ɖiwo ate Mawu kpɔ o, eye eya ŋutɔ hã metea ame aɖeke kpɔ o. "
For with evil things God cannot be tried nor does he himself try anyone. "
(Yakobo 1:13) Fukpekpe ate ŋu aɖe kpe na ame sia ame, ame siwo ŋu Mawu kpɔa ŋudzedze le gɔ̃ hã meto le eme o.
(James 1:13) Suffering can afflict anyone even those who are favored by God.
Amegbetɔwo Ƒe Nunyae Le Biblia Mea?
Is the Bible a Book of Human Wisdom?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Nya siwo me nunya le dometɔ geɖe le Biblia alo Ŋɔŋlɔ Kɔkɔeawo me.
The Bible, also known as the Holy Scriptures, does contain many wise sayings.
Ke hã de dzesi nya si Biblia gblɔ tso eɖokui ŋu: "Ŋɔŋlɔ blibo la tso Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ me. " (2 Timoteo 3:16) Kpeɖodzi geɖe le nya sia ŋu.
However, note the claim that the Bible makes for itself: "All Scripture is inspired of God. " (2 Timothy 3:16) There is much evidence to back up that claim.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye esiawo:
Consider the following:
Amewo tee kpɔ be yewoake ɖi ale si ŋutinya si le Biblia me la de pɛpɛpɛ, gake wo katã wodo kpo nu.
No one has ever successfully challenged the historical accuracy of the Bible.
Ame siwo ŋlɔ Biblia la nye ŋutsu anukwaretɔ siwo ŋlɔ nuwo le nyateƒe me.
The Bible writers were honest men who wrote with openness of heart.
Woƒe anukwareɖiɖi na wòdze ƒãa be woƒe nuŋlɔɖiawo nye nyateƒenyawo.
Their candor gives their writing the clear ring of truth.
Tanya vevi ɖekae le Biblia si. Eyae nye ale si Mawu koe dze aɖu amegbetɔƒomea dzi la ta ʋiʋli kple ale si wòato eƒe Dziƒofiaɖuƒea dzi ana eƒe tameɖoɖo nava eme.
The Bible has one central theme: the vindication of God’s right to rule mankind and the fulfillment of his purpose by means of his heavenly Kingdom.
Togbɔ be woŋlɔ Biblia ƒe akpe geɖewoe nye esi va yi hã la, susu totro siwo nɔ dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo si le blema siwo dzi ame geɖewo da asi ɖo la ƒe ɖeke mele Biblia me o.
Although written thousands of years ago, the Bible is free of mistaken scientific ideas that had gained wide acceptance in ancient times.
Blemanudzɔdzɔ siwo ŋu woku nu me le la ɖo kpe edzi be Biblia me nyagblɔɖiwo va eme pɛpɛpɛ.
Documented historical evidence proves that Bible prophecies, or predictions, have come true.
Mawu Ƒe Susuwoe Woŋlɔ Ðe Biblia Mea?
Is the Bible a Record of God’s Thoughts?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia-ŋlɔla geɖewo gblɔ be Mawue gblɔ nu siwo yewoŋlɔ la na yewo.
Many Bible writers state that God directed what they wrote.
Kpɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖewo ɖa:
Note these examples:
Fia David: "Yehowa ƒe [gbɔgbɔ] ƒo nu to dzinye, eye eƒe nya le nye aɖe dzi. " 2 Samuel 23:1, 2.
