King David: "The spirit of Jehovah it was that spoke by me, and his word was upon my tongue. " 2 Samuel 23:1, 2.
Nyagblɔɖila Yesaya: "Ale Aƒetɔ, Yehowa Zebaot, gblɔ esi. "
The prophet Isaiah: "This is what the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies, has said. "
Yesaya 22:15.
Isaiah 22:15.
Apostolo Yohanes: "Nyaɖeɖefia, si Yesu Kristo ɖe fia, si Mawu tsɔ nae. "
The apostle John: "A revelation by Jesus Christ, which God gave him. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 1:1.
Revelation 1:1.
Mose Ye Ŋlɔ Biblia?
Did Moses Write the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu na Mose ŋlɔ Biblia ƒe agbalẽ atɔ̃ gbãtɔwo: Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ, Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Evelia, Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Etɔ̃lia, Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Enelia kple Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Atɔ̃lia.
God used Moses to write the first five books of the Bible: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy.
Eye anɔ eme be eya kee ŋlɔ Hiob ƒe agbalẽa kple Psalmo 90 lia.
He also likely wrote the book of Job and Psalm 90.
Gake ŋutsu 40 siwo Mawu zã woŋlɔ Biblia la dometɔ ɖeka koe Mose nye.
But Moses was only one of some 40 people whom God used to write the Bible.
Ðe Míate Ŋu Anya Ame Siwo Tututu Ŋlɔ Biblia?
Can Anyone Know Who Really Wrote the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Wogblɔ na ame geɖewo be míate ŋu anya ame siwo ŋlɔ Biblia o.
Many people are told that we can’t be sure who wrote the Bible.
Gake zi geɖe la, Biblia me nuŋlɔɖiwo nana míenyaa ame siwo ŋlɔ wo.
But the Bible is often clear about who penned its contents.
Eƒe akpa aɖewo dze egɔme ale: "Nexemya . . . ƒe ŋutinyawo nye esi, " "ŋutega, si Yesaya . . . kpɔ " kple "Yehowa ƒe gbe, si va na Yoel. "
Some parts begin with such phrases as "the words of Nehemiah, " "the vision of Isaiah, " and "the word of Jehovah that occurred to Joel. "
Nexemiya 1:1; Yesaya 1:1; Yoel 1:1.
Nehemiah 1:1; Isaiah 1:1; Joel 1:1.
Biblia-ŋlɔla geɖewo gblɔ be Yehowa, Mawu vavã la ƒe ŋkɔ mee yewoŋlɔ yewoƒe agbalẽawo le, eye eyae fia mɔ yewo.
Most Bible writers acknowledged that they wrote in the name of Jehovah, the one true God, and that they were guided by him.
Nyagblɔɖila siwo ŋlɔ Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo gblɔ wu zi 300 be: "Ale Yehowa gblɔ esi. "
Prophets who wrote the Hebrew Scriptures proclaimed more than 300 times: "This is what Jehovah has said. "
(Amos 1:3; Mixa 2:3; Naxum 1:12) Biblia-ŋlɔla bubuwo xɔ Mawu ƒe gbedeasia to mawudɔlawo dzi.
(Amos 1:3; Micah 2:3; Nahum 1:12) Other writers received God’s message through angels.
Zaxarya 1:7, 9.
Zechariah 1:7, 9.
Ŋutsu 40 aɖewoe ŋlɔ Biblia, eye Biblia-ŋɔŋlɔ xɔ ƒe 1,600 kple edzivɔwo.
The Bible was written by some 40 men over the course of 1,600 years.
Ŋutsu siawo dometɔ aɖewo ŋlɔ Biblia-gbalẽ geɖe.
Some men were used to write more than one book of the Bible.
Ne míagblɔe la, Biblia nye agbalẽdzraɖoƒe sue si me agbalẽ 66 le.
In fact, the Bible is a miniature library of 66 books.
Agbalẽ 39 ye le Biblia ƒe akpa si nye Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo, si ame geɖewo yɔna be Nubabla Xoxoa me, eye agbalẽ 27 ye le Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo, si amewo yɔna zi geɖe be Nubabla Yeyea me.
It consists of the 39 books of the Hebrew Scriptures, called by many the Old Testament, and the 27 books of the Christian Greek Scriptures, often called the New Testament.
Ðe Wotrɔ Biblia Me Nyawoa?
Has the Bible Been Changed or Tampered With?
Ao.
No.
Blemasinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽwo tsɔtsɔ sɔ kple wo nɔewo ɖee fia be wometrɔ naneke le Biblia me o togbɔ be wogbugbɔ ŋlɔe zi akpe geɖe ɖe nu siwo tea ŋu nyunyɔna dzi hã.
A comparison of ancient manuscripts shows that the Bible is basically unchanged despite millenniums of recopying on perishable materials.
Ðe wòfia be womewɔ vodada aɖeke kura esi wogbugbɔ nɔ eŋlɔm oa?
Does this mean that mistakes in copying were never made?
Woke ɖe Biblia ƒe blemasinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ akpe geɖe ŋu.
Thousands of ancient Bible manuscripts have been found.
Vovototo aɖewo dze le wo dometɔ aɖewo me si fia be egbugbɔŋlɔlawo wɔ vodada aɖewo.
Some of these contain a number of differences, indicating that mistakes were made in copying.
Vovototo siawo ƒe akpa gãtɔ nye vodada suesuesue siwo metrɔ gɔmesese si le nyawo ŋu o.
Most of these differences are minor and do not change the meaning of the text.
Ke hã woke ɖe vodada ɖedzesi aɖewo ŋu eye wo dometɔ aɖewo dze abe ame aɖewoe ɖoe koŋ le blema be yewoatrɔ Biblia ƒe gbedeasia ene.
However, a few significant differences have been discovered, some of which appear to be deliberate attempts made long ago to alter the Bible’s message.
Kpɔ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu eve aɖewo ɖa:
Consider two examples:
Le 1 Yohanes 5:7 la, Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe xoxo aɖewo gblɔ be: "ame siwo le ɖase ɖim le dziƒo: Fofo la, Nya la kple gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la, eye ame etɔ̃ siawo le ɖeka. "
At 1 John 5:7, some older Bible translations contain the following words: "in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one. "
Gake asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ siwo ŋu kakaɖedzi le la ɖo kpe edzi be nya siawo mele blemasinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ xoxoawo me o.
However, reliable manuscripts confirm that these words were not in the original text.
Emegbee wode wo eme.
They were added later.
Eya ta woɖe wo ɖa le egbegbe Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe siwo ŋu kakaɖedzi le la me.
Thus, reliable modern Bible translations have excluded them.
Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ dze zi akpe geɖe le Biblia ƒe asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ xoxotɔwo me.
God’s personal name appears thousands of times in ancient manuscripts of the Bible.
Ke hã Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe geɖewo tsɔ dzesideŋkɔwo abe "Aƒetɔ " alo "Mawu " ene ɖo ŋkɔa teƒe.
Yet, numerous Bible translations have replaced it with titles such as "Lord " or "God. "
Aleke míawɔ anya be vodada bubu geɖe mekpɔtɔ le eme o?
How can we be sure that there are not many more errors waiting to be found?
Va se ɖe fifia la, woke ɖe asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ gbogbo aɖewo ŋu si wɔe be ele bɔbɔe wu tsã be woade dzesi vodadawo.
At this point, so many manuscripts have been discovered that it is easier than ever before to detect errors.
Nu kae agbalẽ vovovo siawo tsɔtsɔ sɔ kple wo nɔewo ɖe fia ku ɖe ale si gbegbe Biblia de pɛpɛpɛ egbeae ŋu?
What has a comparison of these documents revealed regarding the accuracy of the Bible today?

Agbalẽnyala si ŋkɔe nye William H. Green gblɔ tso Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo si amewo yɔna egbea be "Nubabla Xoxoa " ŋu be: "Míate ŋu agblɔe kakaɖedzitɔe be blemagbalẽ aɖeke meli si me nyawo woŋlɔ ɖi wòde pɛpɛpɛ alea kpɔ o. "

Commenting on the text of the Hebrew Scriptures (commonly called the "Old Testament "), scholar William H. Green stated: "It may be safely said that no other work of antiquity has been so accurately transmitted. "

Ku ɖe Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo alo "Nubabla Yeyea " ŋu la, Biblia-nyala F. F. Bruce gblɔ be: "Míaƒe Nubabla Yeye la ŋuti kpeɖodzi siwo ŋu woke ɖo la de ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu agbalẽŋlɔla bubu geɖe ƒe nuŋlɔɖiwo, eye ame aɖeke meku drɔ̃e kpɔ be yeake ɖi le wo me nyawo ƒe dede pɛpɛpɛ ŋu gbeɖe o. "

Regarding the Christian Greek Scriptures, or "New Testament, " Bible scholar F. F. Bruce wrote: "The evidence for our New Testament writings is ever so much greater than the evidence for many writings of classical authors, the authenticity of which no one dreams of questioning. "

Aƒetɔ Frederic Kenyon, si nye asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽwo ŋutinunyala gblɔ be, ame "ate ŋu atsɔ kakaɖedzi agblɔ be Biblia si yelé ɖe asi la nye agbalẽ si nye Mawu ƒe Nya, si wotsɔ na mí si me nya veviwo metrɔ o tso dzidzime yi dzidzime hena ƒe alafa geɖe. "

Sir Frederic Kenyon, a noted authority on Bible manuscripts, stated that one "can take the whole Bible in his hand and say without fear or hesitation that he holds in it the true Word of God, handed down without essential loss from generation to generation throughout the centuries. "
Susu bubu kawoe gali siwo ta míeka ɖe edzi be Biblia nye agbalẽ si de pɛpɛpɛ?
What additional reasons are there for confidence that the Bible has been transmitted with accuracy?
Yudatɔ kple Kristotɔ nugbugbɔgaŋlɔlawo siaa kpɔ ŋutinya siwo klo nu le vodada gã siwo Mawu ƒe amewo wɔ dzi la ta.
Both Jewish and Christian copyists preserved accounts that expose the serious mistakes made by God’s people.
(4 Mose 20:12; 2 Samuel 11:2-4; Galatiatɔwo 2:11-14) Nenema kee wogakpɔ Biblia ƒe akpa siwo bu fɔ Yuda dukɔa ɖe woƒe tomaɖomaɖo kple nu siwo klo nu le amegbetɔwo ƒe dzixɔse totrowo ŋu la ta.
(Numbers 20:12; 2 Samuel 11:​2-4; Galatians 2:​11-​14) Likewise, they preserved passages that condemn the Jewish nation’s disobedience and that expose man-made doctrines.

(Hosea 4:2; Malaki 2:8, 9; Mateo 23:8, 9; 1 Yohanes 5:21) Esi wogbugbɔ ŋlɔ ŋutinya siawo ɖi wòde pɛpɛpɛ ta la, nugbugbɔgaŋlɔlaawo ɖe ale si gbegbe míate ŋu aka ɖe wo dzii kple ale si wobua Mawu ƒe Nya nu kɔkɔee la fia.
(Hosea 4:2; Malachi 2:​8, 9; Matthew 23:​8, 9; 1 John 5:​21) By copying these accounts accurately, the copyists showed their trustworthiness and their high regard for God’s sacred Word.
Ðe susu mele eme be míaxɔe ase be Mawu si ŋlɔ Biblia la akpɔ eta be wòade pɛpɛpɛ oa?
Is it not reasonable that God, having inspired the Bible in the first place, would also preserve its accuracy?
(Yesaya 40:8; 1 Petro 1:24, 25) Le nyateƒe me la, menye ame siwo nɔ anyi le blema koe wòdi be eme nyawo naɖe vi na o ke na mí ame siwo li egbea hã.
(Isaiah 40:8; 1 Peter 1:​24, 25) After all, he intended it to benefit not only people of long ago but also us today.

(1 Korintotɔwo 10:11) Le nyateƒe me la, "nu siwo katã woŋlɔ ɖi tsã la, woŋlɔ wo ɖi be woatsɔ afia nu mí, ale be to míaƒe dzidodo kple akɔfafa si míekpɔ tso Ŋɔŋlɔawo me dzi la, mɔkpɔkpɔ nasu mía si. "​ Romatɔwo 15:4.

(1 Corinthians 10:11) In fact, "all the things that were written beforehand were written for our instruction, so that through our endurance and through the comfort from the Scriptures we might have hope. "​ Romans 15:4.
Yesu kple eyomedzelawo yɔ nya tso Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo me kple kakaɖedzi eye womeke ɖi be blemanuŋɔŋlɔ mawo mede pɛpɛpɛ o.​ Luka 4:16-21; Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:1-3.
Jesus and his followers quoted from copies of the Hebrew Scriptures without expressing any concern about the accuracy of those ancient texts.​ Luke 4:​16-​21; Acts 17:​1-3.
Ðe Biblia Me Nyawo Wɔ Ðeka Kple Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya?
Does Science Agree With the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, togbɔ be Biblia menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinyagbalẽ o hã, emenyawo de pɛpɛpɛ nenye be eƒo nu tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu.
Yes, for although the Bible is not a science textbook, it is accurate when it mentions matters of science.

Bu kpɔɖeŋu siwo ɖee fia be Biblia me nyawo wɔ ɖeka kple dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya, eye be nyateƒenya siwo ku ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋu le Biblia me, siwo to vovo kura na dzixɔse siwo nɔ ame siwo nɔ anyi le Bibliaŋlɔɣi la si ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some examples showing that science and the Bible agree and that the Bible contains scientific facts that differed greatly from the beliefs of many people living at the time it was written.
Gɔmedzedze li na xexea.
The universe had a beginning.
(1 Mose 1:1) Gake blema nyakpakpa geɖewo gblɔ be menye ɖe wowɔ xexea o, ke boŋ edzɔ tso zitɔtɔ manɔɖoɖonu aɖe me.
(Genesis 1:1) In contrast, many ancient myths describe the universe, not as being created, but as being organized from existing chaos.
Babilontɔwo xɔe se be mawu siwo na xexea dzɔ la tso atsiaƒu gbahoo eve me.
The Babylonians believed that the gods that gave birth to the universe came from two oceans.
Blemaxotutu aɖewo hã gblɔ be azi gã aɖe mee xexea dzɔ tso.
Other legends say that the universe came from a giant egg.
Dzɔdzɔmesewo dzie xexea zɔna ɖo gbe sia gbe, ke menye mawu aɖewo siwo wɔa nu eŋumabumabui woe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe xexe gbahoo la dzi o.
The universe is governed day-to-day by rational natural laws, not by the whims of deities.

(Hiob 38:33; Yeremiya 33:25) Nyakpakpawo le xexea ƒe akpa vovovowo, siwo fiana be wɔna aɖeke mele amegbetɔwo ŋu le mawu siwo dzi womate ŋu aka ɖo o eye nublanuikpɔkpɔ hã mele woƒe nuwɔnawo me o, la si me o.
(Job 38:33; Jeremiah 33:25) Myths from around the world teach that humans are helpless before the unpredictable and sometimes merciless acts of the gods.
Womeku anyigba ɖe naneke ŋu o.
The earth is suspended in empty space.
(Hiob 26:7) Ame geɖe siwo nɔ anyi le blema xɔe se be anyigba la le gbadzaa eye ame dzɔtsu alo lã gã aɖe, abe to alo klo ene, dzie wònɔ.
(Job 26:7) Many ancient peoples believed that the world was a flat disk supported by a giant or an animal, such as a buffalo or a turtle.
Ɣea hea tsi tsoa atsiaƒu kple tsi bubuwo me yia yame eye wòtrɔna zua tsi, sno alo kpetsi dzana ɖe anyigba dzi eye wogasina yia tɔsisiwo kple tsidzɔƒewo me.
Rivers and springs are fed by water that has evaporated from the oceans and other sources and then has fallen back to earth as rain, snow, or hail.
(Hiob 36:27, 28; Nyagblɔla 1:7; Yesaya 55:10; Amos 9:6) Gake blema Helatɔwo susui be tsi siwo le anyigbaa gɔmee ŋɔna yia tɔsisiwo me, susu sia nɔ amewo si kaka va ɖo ƒe alafa 18-awo me.
(Job 36:27, 28; Ecclesiastes 1:7; Isaiah 55:10; Amos 9:6) The ancient Greeks thought that rivers were fed by underground ocean water, and this idea persisted into the 18th century.
Towo hona ɖe dzi eye wogabuna, eye to siwo li egbea nɔ atsiaƒu gɔme kpɔ.
The mountains rise and fall, and today’s mountains were once under the ocean.
(Psalmo 104:6, 8) Gake nyakpakpa geɖewo gblɔna be mawuawoe wɔ to siwo li egbea.
(Psalm 104:​6, 8) In contrast, several myths say that the mountains were created in their current form by the gods.
Dzadzɛnyenye kpɔa ame ƒe lãmesẽ ta.
Sanitary practices protect health.

Ðoɖo aɖewo nɔ Se si wotsɔ na Israel-dukɔa me, siwo bia tso wosi be woaklɔ wo ɖokuiwo ŋu nenye be woka asi nukuku alo amekuku aɖe ŋu, woaɖe ame siwo ŋu dɔxɔleameŋu le la ɖe aga, eye woaɖi woƒe nugodowo ɖe do me.
The Law given to the nation of Israel included regulations for washing after touching a dead body, quarantining those with infectious disease, and disposing of human waste safely.
(3 Mose 11:25-28; 13:1-5; 5 Mose 23:13) To vovo na ema la, esime wona se sia Israel-dukɔa, Egiptetɔwo wɔa atike aɖe si me amegbetɔwo ƒe nugodo le tsɔ ɖoa abi.

(Leviticus 11:28; 13:​1-5; Deuteronomy 23:13) By contrast, one of the Egyptian remedies in use when these commands were given called for applying to an open wound a mixture that included human excrement.
Ðe vodadawo le nya siwo Biblia gblɔ tso dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya ŋua?
Are there scientific errors in the Bible?
Biblia me dzodzro yi ŋgɔe ɖee fia kɔtɛe be vodadawo mele eme o.
A reasonable examination of the Bible shows the answer to be no.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be ŋkeke ade siwo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nye gaƒoƒo 24 ye wotsɔ wɔ xexea katã.
Here are some common misconceptions about the scientific accuracy of the Bible:
Nyateƒea: Biblia megblɔ ɣeyiɣi tututu si me Mawu wɔ xexea o.
Myth: The Bible says that the universe was created in six 24-hour days.
(1 Mose 1:1) Azɔ hã, nuwo wɔwɔ ƒe ŋkeke si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ la nye ɣeyiɣi agbɔsɔsɔ me si womeyɔ o.
Fact: According to the Bible, God created the universe in the indefinite past.
Le nyateƒe me la, woyɔ ɣeyiɣi si wotsɔ wɔ anyigba kple dziƒo la katã hã be "ŋkeke " ɖeka.​ 1 Mose 2:4.
(Genesis 1:1) Also, the days of creation described in chapter 1 of Genesis were epochs whose length is not specified.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be wowɔ numiemiewo hafi va wɔ ɣea, ale be numiemiewo nazã ɣea ƒe ŋusẽ atsɔ awɔ woƒe nuɖuɖu.​ 1 Mose 1:11, 16.
Myth: The Bible says that vegetation was created before the sun existed to support photosynthesis.​ Genesis 1:​11, 16.
Nyateƒea: Biblia ɖee fia be wowɔ ɣea, si nye ɣletivi siwo le "dziƒo " la dometɔ ɖeka hafi va wɔ numiemiewo.
Fact: The Bible shows that the sun, one of the stars that make up "the heavens, " was created before vegetation.
(1 Mose 1:1) Kekeli si tso ɣea gbɔ la ɖo anyigba dzi flukpee le nuwɔwɔ ƒe "ŋkeke " gbãtɔ dzi.
(Genesis 1:1) Diffused light from the sun reached the earth’s surface during the first "day, " or epoch, of creation.
Esi yame nɔ kɔkɔm va ɖo nuwɔwɔ ƒe "ŋkeke " etɔ̃lia dzi la, ɣea ƒe keklẽ nu sẽ va ɖo afi si numiemiewo te ŋu zãe tsɔ wɔ woƒe nuɖuɖu.
As the atmosphere cleared, by the third "day " of creation, the light was strong enough to support photosynthesis.
(1 Mose 1:3-5, 12, 13) Ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe ko hafi ɣea va te dzedze nyuie.​ 1 Mose 1:16.
(Genesis 1:​3-5, 12, 13) Only later did the sun become distinctly visible from the surface of the earth.​ Genesis 1:​16.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be ɣea ƒoa ɣla anyigba la.
Myth: The Bible says that the sun revolves around the earth.
Nyateƒea: Nyagblɔla 1:5 gblɔ be: "Ɣe dzena, eye wòɖoa to, eye wòɖea abla gatrɔna yia afi si wòdzena tso. "
Fact: Ecclesiastes 1:5 says: "The sun rises, and the sun sets; then it hurries back to the place where it rises again. "
Ke hã, ɖeko nya sia le ale si amegbetɔwo kpɔa ɣea wòtsona ɣedzeƒe va yina ɣetoɖoƒe la ɖɔm.
However, this statement merely describes the apparent motion of the sun as viewed from the earth.
Egbea gɔ̃ hã, amegbetɔwo tea zãa nya siwo nye "ɣe dze " kple "ɣe ɖo to, " evɔ wonyae be anyigbae ƒoa xla ɣea.
Even today, a person can use the words "sunrise " and "sunset, " yet he knows that the earth revolves around the sun.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be anyigba la le gbadzaa.
Myth: The Bible says that the earth is flat.
Nyateƒea: Biblia zã nyagbe si nye "anyigba ƒe seƒe ke, " gake mefia be anyigba la le gbadzaa alo seƒe le eŋu o.
Fact: The Bible uses the phrase "the ends of the earth " to mean "the most distant part of the earth "; this does not imply that the earth is flat or that it has an edge.

(Dɔwɔwɔwo 1:8) Nenema kee nyagbe si nye "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " nye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ si fia anyigba dzi godoo; eye ame aɖe ate ŋu azã taɖoƒefianu (compass alo la boussole) ƒe dzesi eneawo wòafia kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ ma ke.​ Yesaya 11:12; Luka 13:29.

(Acts 1:8; footnote) Likewise, the expression "the four corners of the earth " is a figure of speech referring to the entire surface of the earth; today a person might use the four points of the compass as a similar metaphor.​ Isaiah 11:12; Luke 13:29.
Nyakpakpa: Biblia gblɔ be togodo ƒe ɣlaƒoƒo ɖeka ƒe dzidze nye fli si tso eƒe toga ɖeka yi kemea ƒe teƒe etɔ̃ pɛpɛpɛ, gake togodo ƒe ɣlaƒoƒo ƒe dzidze ŋutɔŋutɔ anɔ abe 3.1416 si nye (pi alo π).
Myth: The Bible says that the circumference of a circle is exactly three times its diameter, but the correct value is pi (π), or about 3.1416.
Nyateƒea: "Gazɔ gã la " si ƒe nya wogblɔ le 1 Fiawo 7:23 kple 2 Kronika 4:2 ɖee fia be eƒe didime tso to ɖeka yi kemea nye abɔklugui ewo eye "ka didime abɔklugui blaetɔ̃e " hiã hafi "akpee ɖo. "

Fact: The measurements of "the Sea of cast metal " given at 1 Kings 7:​23 and 2 Chronicles 4:2 indicate that it had a diameter of 10 cubits and that "it took a measuring line 30 cubits long to encircle it. "
Ate ŋu anɔ eme be woatsɔ nu sue aɖe kpe xexlẽme siawo alo aɖee le eme hafi woade pɛpɛpɛ.
These dimensions might have been merely the nearest round numbers.
Anɔ eme hã be gazɔa ƒe togodo kple eƒe didime tso eƒe toga ɖeka yi kemea tsi tsitre ɖi na gazɔa me kple egodo ƒe dzidze.
It is also possible that the circumference and diameter represented inner and outer measurements of the basin respectively.
Ðe Biblia Fia Nu Be Anyigba La Le Gbadzaa?
Does the Bible Teach That the Earth Is Flat?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, Biblia mefia nu be anyigba la le gbadzaa o.
No, the Bible does not teach that the earth is flat.
Menye dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyagbalẽe Biblia nye o.
The Bible is not a science textbook.
Ke hã, Biblia me nya aɖeke metsi tre ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya si ŋu kakaɖedzi le ŋu o.
At the same time, nothing in the Bible contradicts proved science.
Míate ŋu "aɖo ŋu ɖe " nya siwo Biblia gblɔ la "ŋu ɖaa tegbee. " Psalmo 111:8.
What the Bible says is "always reliable, now and forever. "​ Psalm 111:8.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ be "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " gɔme ɖe?
What does the Bible mean by "the four corners of the earth "?
Ke tetekpɔ si Abosam he va Yesu dzi ya ɖe?
What about the Devil’s temptation of Jesus?
Nya si Biblia gblɔ be "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " gɔme ɖe?
What does the Bible mean by "the four corners of the earth "?
Mele be míase nyagbɔgblɔ "anyigba ƒe go eneawo " kple "anyigba ƒe mlɔenuwo " si Biblia zã la gɔme ɖe nyagbeawo ŋutɔŋutɔ nu abe ɖe dzogoe ene le anyigba si alo abe ɖe seƒe le anyigba si ene o.
The expressions "the four corners of the earth " and "the ends of the earth " used in the Bible are not to be taken literally, as if the earth were square or had ends.
(Yesaya 11:12; Hiob 37:3) Ke boŋ, edze ƒãa be wonye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ siwo fia anyigba bliboa katã dzi.
(Isaiah 11:12; Job 37:3) Instead, these evidently are figures of speech referring to the entire surface of the earth.
Gɔmesese ma ke nue Biblia zãa nyagbɔgblɔ si nye "ɣedzeƒe, ɣetoɖoƒe, dziehe kple anyiehe " le.
The Bible uses the four points of the compass in a similar way.​ Luke 13:29.
Luka 13:29. Anɔ eme be Hebrigbe me nya si gɔme woɖe be ‘dzogoe’ alo ‘mlɔenu’ la nye adagana si wotu ɖe nya si wozãna na "aʋala " la dzi.
The Hebrew term translated "corners " or "ends " seems to be an idiom based on the word for "wings. "
Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be, "esi xewo tsɔa woƒe aʋala tsyɔa wo viwo dzi ta la, [Hebrigbe me nya sia] fia nu sia nu si me wohe la ƒe mlɔenuwo. "

According to The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia, "because the wing of a bird is used as a covering for its young, [this Hebrew term] acquires the meaning of the extremity of anything stretched out. "
Agbalẽ sia ke gagblɔ be nya siwo wozã le Hiob 37:3 kple Yesaya 11:12 la fia "anyigba ƒe liƒowo, mlɔenuwo, alo eƒe yɔyrɔenuwo. "
The same reference work adds that at Job 37:3 and Isaiah 11:12, "the term means the coasts, boundaries, or extremities of the land surface of the earth. "
The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia.
What about the Devil’s temptation of Jesus?
Esi Abosam be yeate Yesu kpɔ la, ekplɔe "yi to aɖe si kɔkɔ ŋutɔ la dzi, eye wòɖe xexemefiaɖuƒewo katã kple woƒe ŋutikɔkɔe fiae. "
To tempt Jesus, "the Devil took him along to an unusually high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. "
(Mateo 4:8) Ame aɖewo gblɔna be Biblia me ŋutinya sia ɖee fia be ame ate ŋu akpɔ xexe bliboa ne etɔ ɖe teƒe ɖeka le anyigba la si le gbadzaa dzi.
(Matthew 4:8) Some claim that this Bible account teaches that the entire world is visible from a single spot on a flat earth.
Ke hã, edze abe "to aɖe si kɔkɔ ŋutɔ " si dze le nuŋlɔɖi sia me la nye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ ene, ke menye teƒe ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
However, the "unusually high mountain " in this account seems to be a metaphor and not a physical location.
Kpɔ nu si tae susu le nyataƒoƒo sia me la ɖa.
Consider why this conclusion is reasonable.
To aɖeke mele anyigba dzi si dzi woatsi tsitre ɖo akpɔ xexemefiaɖuƒewo katã o.
There is no literal mountain on earth from which all the kingdoms of the world are visible.
Menye fiaɖuƒewo katã koe Abosam ɖe fia Yesu o, ke woƒe "ŋutikɔkɔe " hã.
The Devil showed Jesus not only all the kingdoms but also "their glory. "
Ame mate ŋu anɔ teƒe didi aɖe akpɔ nu mawo gbegbe o, eya ta edze abe Abosam ɖe nu mawo fia Yesu to ŋutega ƒomevi aɖe dzi ene.
Such details could not be seen from a great distance, so it seems that the Devil used some sort of vision to show these to Jesus.
Míate ŋu atsɔ esia asɔ kple ale si woɖea xexea ƒe akpa bubuwo fiana le filmwo me egbea.
This could be similar to the way a person uses a projector and a screen to show someone pictures of various places on earth.
Nudzɔdzɔ sia ke ŋuti nuŋlɔɖi si dze le Luka 4:5 gblɔ be Abosam ɖe "anyigbadzifiaɖuƒewo katã [fia Yesu] le ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe ko me, " evɔ manya wɔ be ame natsɔ ŋku dzro ko awɔ esia o.
The parallel account at Luke 4:5 says that the Devil showed Jesus "all the kingdoms of the inhabited earth in an instant of time, " which would not be possible through normal human vision.
Esia fia be Abosam to mɔ aɖe dzi ɖe nu mawo fia Yesu tsɔ tee kpɔ, ke menye be ena wòkpɔ wo kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
This implies that the Devil presented this temptation to Jesus through some means other than literal human sight.
Yevuwo Ƒe Agbalẽe Biblia Nyea?
Is the Bible a White Man’s Book?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Menye Europatɔwoe ŋlɔ Biblia o.
The Bible wasn’t written by Europeans.
Ŋutsu siwo katã Mawu zã woŋlɔ Biblia la tso Asia.
All of the men that God used to write the Bible were from Asia.
Biblia mebua dukɔ aɖeke me tɔwo be wonyo wu bubuawo o.
The Bible doesn’t promote one race as being superior to another.
Le nyateƒe me la, Biblia gblɔ be: "Mawu mekpɔa ame ŋkume o, ke boŋ le dukɔ sia dukɔ me la, ame si vɔ̃nɛ, eye wòwɔa nu dzɔdzɔe la, eyae dzea eŋu. "
In fact, it states: "God is not partial, but in every nation the man that fears him and works righteousness is acceptable to him. "
Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:34, 35.
Ɣekaɣie Woŋlɔ Yesu Ŋuti Nyawo Ði?
When Were the Accounts About Jesus Written?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Apostolo Yohanes gblɔ tso Yesu ƒe agbemenudzɔdzɔ siwo ŋuti wòŋlɔ nu tsoe la ŋu be: "Ame si kpɔe la ɖi ɖase, eye eƒe ɖaseɖiɖi la nye nyateƒe, eye ame ma nya be nyateƒenyawoe yegblɔna, bene miawo hã miaxɔe ase. "

Regarding his record of the events in Jesus’ life, the apostle John wrote: "He that has seen it has borne witness, and his witness is true, and that man knows he tells true things, in order that you also may believe. "
Yohanes 19:35.
John 19:35.

Susu siwo tae wòle be míaxɔ Nyanyuigbalẽ siwo Mateo, Marko, Luka kple Yohanes ŋlɔ la me nyawo dzi ase la dometɔ ɖekae nye be esime woŋlɔ ŋutinya mawo la, ame siwo kpɔ nudzɔdzɔawo teƒe la dometɔ geɖe gakpɔtɔ le agbe ɣemaɣi.
One reason to trust the Gospel accounts recorded by Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John is that they were written while many eyewitnesses to the events they describe were still alive.

Le numekugbalẽ aɖewo ƒe nya nu la, woŋlɔ Mateo ƒe Nyanyuigbalẽa le ƒe 41 me, si nye ƒe enyi le Kristo ƒe ku megbe. Agbalẽnyala geɖe susui be woŋlɔe do megbe na ƒe ma, gake ame akpa gãtɔ lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be wowu Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo alo Nubabla Xoxoa ŋɔŋlɔ nu le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me.

According to some sources, the Gospel of Matthew was written as early as the eighth year after Christ’s death, that is, about 41 C.E. Many scholars favor a somewhat later date, but there is general agreement that all the books of the Christian Greek Scriptures were written during the first century C.E.
Ame siwo kpɔ Yesu esime wònɔ anyigba dzi, eye wokpɔ eƒe ku kple eƒe tsitretsitsi teƒe la, ate ŋu aɖi ɖase tso Nya Nyui Gbalẽawo me nyawo ƒe nyateƒenyenye ŋu.
People who saw Jesus while he was alive on earth, witnessed his death, and observed his resurrection could verify the Gospel accounts.
Ne ɖe wònye be ŋutinyawo mede pɛpɛpɛ o la, anye ne woʋu go esia bɔbɔe.
They could also easily expose any inaccuracies if there had been such.

Agbalẽnyalagã F. F. Bruce gblɔ be: "Nu siwo na apostoloawo ƒe gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa ɖe kpe dometɔ ɖekae nye be woƒo nu tso nu siwo ŋu woƒe nyaselawo ŋutɔ nya nu tso la ŋu; womegblɔna ko be ‘mía ŋutɔwo míekpɔ eteƒe o,’ ke boŋ be ‘abe ale si mia ŋutɔwo hã mienyae ene’ (Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:22). "

Professor F. F. Bruce observes: "One of the strong points in the original apostolic preaching is the confident appeal to the knowledge of the hearers; they not only said, ‘We are witnesses of these things,’ but also, ‘As you yourselves also know’ (Acts 2:22). "
Nu Vevi Kawoe Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò Nàse Biblia Gɔme?
Understanding the Bible What Are the Keys?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia ŋutɔ gblɔ nu vevi siwo akpe ɖe mía ŋu míase egɔme la dometɔ geɖe na mí.
The Bible itself provides many of the keys to understanding it.
Afi ka tɔe nèɖanye alo afi ka nèɖade suku se ɖe o, Mawu ƒe gbedeasi si le Biblia me la, "menye nya masegɔmea wònye o, eye mele didiƒe tso gbɔwò o. " 5 Mose 30:11.
Regardless of your background, God’s message in the Bible "is not too difficult for you, nor is it far away. " Deuteronomy 30:11.
Nu vevi siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàse biblia gɔme
Keys to understanding the Bible
Susu nyui nènɔ asiwò.
Have the right attitude.
Xɔ Biblia be enye Mawu ƒe Nya.
Accept the Bible as God’s Word.
Bɔbɔ ɖokuiwò, elabena Mawu tsia tsitre ɖe ɖokuidoɖedzilawo ŋu.
Be humble, since God opposes the proud.
(1 Tesalonikatɔwo 2:13; Yakobo 4:6) Ke hã ne èxlẽe la ehiã be nàbu tame tso nu si nèxlẽ la ŋu, elabena Mawu di be nàzã wò "tamebubu ŋutete. "
(1 Thessalonians 2:13; James 4:6) However, avoid blind faith God wants you to use your "power of reason. "
Romatɔwo 12:1, 2.
Romans 12:1, 2.
Do gbe ɖa nàbia nunya.
Pray for wisdom.
Biblia gblɔ le Lododowo 3:5 be: "Mègaɖo dzi ɖe wò gɔmesese ŋu o. "
"Do not lean upon your own understanding, " the Bible says at Proverbs 3:5.
Ke boŋ ‘yi edzi’ nànɔ nunya biam Mawu be nàse Biblia gɔme.
Instead, "keep on asking God " for wisdom in understanding the Bible.
Yakobo 1:5.
James 1:5.
Nɔ nu srɔ̃m edziedzi.
Be consistent.
Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃ edziedzi aɖe vi geɖe na wò wu be nànɔ anyi ʋuu adae ɖe eme zi ɖeka.
You will benefit much more from Bible study if you do it regularly rather than sporadically.
Yosua 1:8.
Joshua 1:8.
Nɔ nyatiwo srɔ̃m.
Study by topic.
Ne èsrɔ̃a nyati siwo ɖe Biblia me nufiafia aɖewo koŋ gɔme alo dzro wo me la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò geɖe ŋutɔ nànya Biblia me nufiafiawo nyuie.
A topical study, in which you analyze what the Bible says about a particular topic or subject, is an effective way to learn what the Scriptures teach.
Dze egɔme kple "gɔmedzenufiafiawo " emegbe nàyi edzi kple nufiafia siwo bia "tsitsinyenye. "
Start with "the beginning lessons, " as it were, and then "go forward to more mature (advanced) teaching. "

(Hebritɔwo 6:1, 2) Àva kpɔe be yeate ŋu atsɔ mawunyakpukpuiwo anɔ sɔsɔm kple wo nɔewo eye esia akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔe be Biblia ƒe akpa vovovowo ɖe wo nɔewo me, woɖe esiwo "gɔme sese sesẽ " gɔ̃ hã me. 2 Petro 3:16.

(Hebrews 6:1, 2, Easy-to-Read Version) You’ll find that you can compare scripture with scripture and learn that various parts of the Bible explain each other, even the parts that are "hard to understand. " 2 Peter 3:16.
Bia kpekpeɖeŋu tso ame bubuwo gbɔ.
Get help from others.
Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be míalɔ̃ faa axɔ kpekpeɖeŋu tso ame siwo se Biblia gɔme la gbɔ.
The Bible encourages us to accept help from others who understand the Bible.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 8:30, 31) Yehowa Ðasefowo srɔ̃a Biblia kple amewo faa gamaxɔmaxɔe.
(Acts 8:30, 31) Jehovah’s Witnesses offer a free Bible study program.
Abe ale si Kristotɔ gbãtɔwo wɔnɛ ene la, wozãa Biblia me nyawo ŋutɔ tsɔ kpena ɖe amewo ŋu wokpɔa nu si tututu nye Biblia ƒe nufiafia dzea sii.
Like the early Christians, they use Scriptural references to help others discern what the Bible really teaches.
Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:2, 3.
Nu siwo mèhiã hafi nàse Biblia gɔme o
Things you don’t need
Mehiã agbalẽnyanya fũu kple suku kɔkɔ dede o.
High intellect or education.
Yesu ƒe apostolo wuieveawo se Ŋɔŋlɔawo gɔme eye wofiaa amewo togbɔ be wobu wo "ame manyagbalẽwo kple ame tsɛwo " hã.
Jesus’ 12 apostles understood the Scriptures and taught them to others, even though the apostles were considered by some to be "unlettered and ordinary. "
Dɔwɔwɔwo 4:13.
Acts 4:13.
Mehiã ga o.
Money.
Àte ŋu asrɔ̃ nu si Biblia fia femaxee.
You can learn what the Bible teaches without cost.
Yesu gblɔ na eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be: "Faa miexɔe, faa minae. "
Jesus told his disciples: "You received free, give free. "
Mateo 10:8.
Matthew 10:8.
Ðe Biblia Tsia Tsitre Ðe Eɖokui Ŋua?
Are There Contradictions in the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, ɖekawɔwɔ le Biblia bliboa me nyawo me.
No, the entire Bible is harmonious.
Togbɔ be emenya aɖewo adze abe ɖe wotsi tsitre ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu ene hã la, míate ŋu ase nu si tae wòdze nenema la gɔme ne míewɔ mɔnu siwo gbɔna la dometɔ ɖeka alo esi wu ema ŋu dɔ:
While some passages might seem to show the Bible contradicting itself, they can usually be understood correctly by applying one or more of the following principles:
Lé ŋku ɖe nya siwo ƒo xlãe ŋu.
Consider the context.
Woate ŋu abu agbalẽŋlɔla ɖe sia ɖe ƒe nyawo be wotsi tsitre ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu ne womebu nya siwo ƒo xlã nya mawo o.
Any author can appear to contradict himself if his words are taken out of context.
Nya agbalẽa ŋlɔla ƒe susu.
Consider the writer’s viewpoint.
Ame siwo kpɔ nudzɔdzɔ ɖeka teƒe ate ŋu agblɔ nu siwo dzɔ la wòade pɛpɛpɛ evɔ woƒe nyawo kple numeɖeɖewo ate ŋu ato vovo.
Eyewitnesses might describe an event accurately but not use the exact same wording or include the same details.
Bu ŋutinyawo kple dekɔnuwo ŋu.
Take into account historical facts and customs.
De dzesi kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔwo kple nyagbɔgblɔ siwo ƒe gɔmesese le tẽe.
Distinguish between the figurative and the literal uses of a word.
De dzesii be woate ŋu agblɔ be ame aɖe wɔ nane togbɔ be menye eya ŋutɔe wɔe tẽe o gɔ̃ hã.
Recognize that an action may be attributed to someone even if he did not personally carry it out.
Zã Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe si de pɛpɛpɛ.
Use an accurate Bible translation.
Ƒo asa na agbagbadzedze be yeazã nufiafia totrowo alo subɔsubɔhawo ƒe nufiafiawo atsɔ aɖe Biblia me nyawo me.
Avoid trying to reconcile what the Bible says with mistaken religious ideas or dogma.
Kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna la ɖe ale si míate ŋu awɔ mɔfiame sia ŋu dɔ atsɔ aɖe Biblia ƒe mawunyakpukpui siwo dzena abe ɖe wotsi tre ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu ene la me.
The following examples show how these principles can explain some seeming inconsistencies in the Bible.
Mɔfiame 1: Nya siwo ƒo xlã kpukpuia
Principle 1: Context
Ne Mawu le ɖiɖim ɖe eme tso ŋkeke adrelia dzi la, ke aleke wɔ wògale dɔ dzi?
If God rested on the seventh day, how has he continued working?
Nya siwo ƒo xlã Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ me nyagbɔgblɔ si nye be Mawu te "ɖiɖi ɖe eme le ŋkeke adrelia dzi tso dɔ siwo katã wɔm wònɔ la me " ku ɖe anyigbadzinuwo wɔwɔ ŋu koŋ.

The context of the Genesis creation account shows that the statement that God "began to rest on the seventh day from all his work that he had been doing " refers specifically to his work of physical creation respecting the earth.
(1 Mose 2:2-4) Nya si Yesu gblɔ be "Fofonye le dɔ wɔm va se ɖe fifi " metsi tre ɖe nya sia ŋu o, elabe dɔ si Yesu wɔnɛ la to vovo na anyigbadzinuwo wɔwɔ.
(Genesis 2:​2-4) Jesus did not contradict this, however, when he said that God "has kept working until now, " because he was talking about other works of God.
(Yohanes 5:17) Mawu ƒe dɔ siwo wòwɔnɛ la dometɔ aɖewoe nye amewo ʋaʋã be woaŋlɔ Biblia, mɔfiafia amegbetɔƒomea kple beléle na wo.​ Psalmo 20:6; 105:5; 2 Petro 1:21.
(John 5:​17) God’s works include the inspiration of the Bible and his guidance and care of mankind.​ Psalm 20:6; 105:5; 2 Peter 1:​21.
Mɔfiame 2 kple 3: Agbalẽa ŋlɔla ƒe susu kple ŋutinyawo
Principles 2 and 3: Viewpoint and history
Yesu da gbe le ŋkuagbãtɔ ŋu
Jesus heals the blind man
Afi kae Yesu ʋu ŋku na ŋkuagbãtɔ la le?
Where did Jesus heal the blind man?

Luka ƒe agbalẽa gblɔ be Yesu da gbe le ŋkuagbãtɔ aɖe ŋu "esi Yesu le Yeriko gogom " evɔ esi Mateo nɔ nu ƒom tso nudzɔdzɔ ma ke ŋu la, egblɔ be ŋkuagbãtɔ eve ye, eye be nua dzɔ esi Yesu nɔ "dzodzom le Yeriko. "

The book of Luke says that Jesus healed a blind man as Jesus "was getting near to Jericho, " while the parallel account in Matthew mentions two blind men and says that the incident occurred when Jesus was "going out of Jericho. "
(Luka 18:35-43; Mateo 20:29-34) Ŋutinya eve siawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖe nyatakaka vevi aɖewo ɖe go siwo medze le evelia me o.
(Luke 18:35-​43; Matthew 20:29-​34) These two accounts, written from different viewpoints, actually complement each other.
Mateo ya yɔ ŋkuagbãtɔwo ƒe xexlẽme pɛpɛpɛ, evɔ Luka ya he susu yi ŋkuagbãtɔawo dometɔ si Yesu nɔ nu ƒom na la dzi.
Regarding the number of men, Matthew is more specific as to there being two, while Luke focuses on the one man to whom Jesus directed his remarks.
Le teƒeawo ƒe vovototo gome ya la, tomenukulawo va de dzesii be du evee woyɔna be Yeriko. Yudatɔwo ƒe Yeriko-du xoxotɔ didi tso Yeriko-du yeye si Romatɔwo tso la gbɔ ade kilometa ɖeka kple afã.
As for the location, archaeologists have found that in Jesus’ time Jericho was a double city, with the old Jewish city situated about one and a half kilometers (1 mi) away from the newer Roman city.
Anɔ eme be teƒe aɖe si le du eveawo domee Yesu nɔ esime wòwɔ nukunuawo.
Jesus may have been between the two cities when he performed this miracle.
Mɔfiame 4: Kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔwo kple nyagbɔgblɔ siwo ƒe gɔmesese le tẽe
Principle 4: Figurative and literal terms
Ðe woatsrɔ̃ anyigba la?
Will the earth be destroyed?

Biblia gblɔ le Nyagblɔla 1:4 be, "anyigba ya li tegbee. " Ame aɖewo gblɔna be Biblia me nya sia tsi tsitre ɖe emenya bubu si nye be "anyigba kple eme dɔwɔwɔwo lafiã keŋ " la ŋu. (2 Petro 3:10, Eʋegbe Biblia) Ke hã le Biblia me la, wotea ŋu zãa nya "anyigba " wòfiaa anyigba ŋutɔŋutɔ eye wogatea ŋu zãnɛ le kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ nu hã wòfiaa amegbetɔ siwo le anyigba dzi.

At Ecclesiastes 1:4, the Bible says that "the earth remains forever, " which to some apparently conflicts with its statement that "the elements will be destroyed by heat​ with the earth. " (2 Peter 3:​10, Beck) In the Bible, however, the word "earth " is used both literally, referring to our planet, and figuratively, referring to the people who live on it.

(1 Mose 1:1; 11:1) "Anyigba " la tsɔtsrɔ̃ si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le 2 Petro 3:​10 mefia be míaƒe anyigba si dzi míele la ŋutɔŋutɔ afiã le dzo me o, ke boŋ "ame mavɔ̃mawuwo ƒe ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ kple tsɔtsrɔ̃ " ye wowɔnɛ.​ 2 Petro 3:7.
(Genesis 1:1; 11:1) The destruction of the "earth " described at 2 Peter 3:​10 refers, not to the burning up of our planet, but to the "destruction of the ungodly people. "​ 2 Peter 3:7.
Mɔfiame 5: Woate ŋu agblɔ be ame aɖe wɔ nane evɔ menye eya ŋutɔe wɔe tẽe o
Principle 5: Attribution
Le Kapernaum la, ame kae va bia kpekpeɖeŋu tso Yesu gbɔ na asrafomegã?
In Capernaum, who brought the centurion’s request to Jesus?
Mateo 8:​5, 6 gblɔ be asrafomegã ŋutɔe yi Yesu gbɔ evɔ Luka 7:3 ya gblɔ be Yudatɔwo ƒe dumegãwoe asrafomegã la dɔ ɖe Yesu gbɔ.
Matthew 8:​5, 6 says that the centurion (army officer) himself came to Jesus, while Luke 7:3 says that the centurion sent older men of the Jews to make his request.
Nu si wòfia koe nye be asrafomegã ŋutɔ gblɔ be woabia kpekpeɖeŋu tso Yesu gbɔ na ye, gake edɔ dumegãwo ɖo ɖe Yesu gbɔ abe eteƒenɔlawo ene.
This apparent Bible contradiction can be understood in that the army officer initiated the request, but he sent the older men as his representatives.
Mɔfiame 6: Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe si de pɛpɛpɛ
Principle 6: Accurate translation
Ðe mí katã míewɔa nu vɔ̃a?
Do we all sin?
Biblia na míenya be mí katã míenyi nu vɔ̃ dome tso ŋutsu gbãtɔ Adam gbɔ.
The Bible teaches that we all inherit sin from the first man, Adam.

(Romatɔwo 5:​12) Ale si woɖe Biblia aɖewo gɔme la di be yeatsi tre ɖe nya sia ŋu, esi wogblɔ le wo me be ame nyui "mewɔa nu vɔ̃ o. " (1 Yohanes 3:6, Eʋegbe Biblia) Gake fifiɣeyiɣi mee Helagbe me nya si gɔme woɖe be "nu vɔ̃ " le 1 Yohanes 3:6 la le. Eye ne wozã fifiɣeyiɣi le gbe ma me la, efiaa nuwɔna aɖe si le edzi yim.

(Romans 5:​12) Some translations seem to contradict this by saying that a good person "does no sin " or "sinneth not. " (1 John 3:6, The Bible in Basic English; King James Version) In the original language, though, the Greek verb for "sin " at 1 John 3:6 is in the present tense, which in that language normally indicates a continuous action.
Vovototo le nu vɔ̃ si ƒe dome míenyi kple nu vɔ̃ ɖowɔe, si fia be ame naɖoe koŋ anɔ Mawu ƒe sewo dzi dam la dome.
There is a difference between inherited sin, which we cannot avoid, and the deliberate, continuous practice of disobeying God’s laws.

Eya ta Biblia-gɔmeɖela aɖewo dze agbagba de vovototo nu vɔ̃ ƒomevi eve siawo dome ale be magadze abe ɖe Biblia tsi tsitre ɖe eɖokui ŋu ene o, eye woɖe kpukpui ma gɔme wòde pɛpɛpɛ be "metsɔa nu vɔ̃ wɔwɔ ɖoa dɔe o " alo "meyia edzi nɔa nu vɔ̃ wɔm o. "​ Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe; Phillips.
Thus, some translations clear up this seeming contradiction by accurately using phrases such as "does not practice sin " or "does not habitually sin. "​ New World Translation; Phillips.
Mɔfiame 7: Zã Biblia, ke menye sɔlemehawo ƒe nufiafiawo o
Principle 7: The Bible, not dogma
Ðe Yesu sɔ kple Mawu loo alo ɖe Mawu lolo wu Yesua?
Is Jesus equal to God or lesser than God?
Yesu gblɔ gbe ɖeka bena: "Nye kple Fofo la míele ɖeka. " Ewɔna na ame aɖewo be eƒe nya siawo tsi tsitre ɖe nya bubu si wògblɔ be "Fofo la lolo wum " la ŋu.
Jesus once said: "I and the Father are one, " which seems to contradict his statement that "the Father is greater than I am. "

(Yohanes 10:30; 14:28) Hafi míate ŋu ase eƒe nya mawo gɔme nyuie la, ele be míadzro nya siwo tututu Biblia gblɔ tso Yehowa kple Yesu ŋu me, ke manye be míadze agbagba be míaɖe Biblia me wòasɔ ɖe sɔlemehawo ƒe nufiafia si nye Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ alo Trinita Kɔkɔea, si wometu ɖe Biblia dzi o la, nu o.

(John 10:30; 14:28) To understand those verses correctly, we must examine what the Bible really says about Jehovah and Jesus rather than try to harmonize the verses with the Trinity dogma, which is not based on the Bible.
Biblia ɖee fia be Yehowae nye Yesu Fofo eye wòganye eƒe Mawu hã. Yehowa ye Yesu ŋutɔ gɔ̃ hã dea ta agu na.
The Bible shows that Jehovah is not only Jesus’ Father but also Jesus’ God, the One whom even Jesus worships.
(Mateo 4:10; Marko 15:34; Yohanes 17:3; 20:17; 2 Korintotɔwo 1:3) Yesu mesɔ kple Mawu o.
(Matthew 4:​10; Mark 15:34; John 17:3; 20:17; 2 Corinthians 1:3) Jesus is not equal to God.
Nya si Yesu nɔ gbɔgblɔm hafi gblɔ be "nye kple Fofo la míele ɖeka " ɖee fia be ale si eƒe susu wɔ ɖeka kple Fofoa Yehowa Mawu ƒe tameɖoɖowo ye wòwɔnɛ.
The context of Jesus’ statement "I and the Father are one " shows that he was talking about the oneness of purpose that he shared with his Father, Jehovah God.
Yesu gblɔ emegbe be: "Fofo la wɔ ɖeka kplim, eye nye hã mewɔ ɖeka kple Fofo la. "
Jesus later said: "The Father is in union with me and I am in union with the Father. "
(Yohanes 10:38) Yesu kple eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo hã wɔ ɖeka le tameɖoɖo ma ke gome, elabe edo gbe ɖa na Mawu le wo ta be: "Metsɔ ŋutikɔkɔe si nètsɔ nam la na wo, ne woazu ɖeka, abe ale si míele ɖeka ene.

(John 10:38) Jesus shared this unity of purpose with his followers as well, for he prayed to God about them: "I have given them the glory that you have given me, in order that they may be one just as we are one.
Mewɔ ɖeka kpli wo, eye nèwɔ ɖeka kplim. "​ Yohanes 17:22, 23.
I in union with them and you in union with me. "​ John 17:22, 23.
Ame Kae Alo Nu Kae Nye Mawu Ƒe Nya La?
Who or What Is the Word of God?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Zi geɖe la, nyagbɔgblɔ "Mawu ƒe nya " fiaa Mawu ƒe gbedeasi alo nya siwo wògblɔ.
The expression "the word of God " usually refers to a divine message or to a collection of those messages.
(Luka 11:28) Wozãa "Mawu Ƒe Nya " alo "Nya La " le teƒe ʋɛ aɖewo wònyea dzesideŋkɔ.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 19:13; Yohanes 1:14.
(Luke 11:28) In a few places, "The Word of God " or "the Word " is used as a personal title.​ Revelation 19:13; John 1:​14.
Mawu ƒe gbedeasi.
A divine message.
Nyagblɔɖilawo gblɔna zi geɖe be gbedeasi siwo yewogblɔna la nye Mawu ƒe nya.
The prophets often stated that the messages they delivered were God’s word.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yeremiya dze eƒe nyagblɔɖi gbedeasia gɔme be, "Yehowa ƒe gbe va nam. "
For example, Jeremiah introduced his prophetic messages with the expression "the word of Jehovah came to me. "
(Yeremiya 1:4, 11, 13; 2:1) Hafi nyagblɔɖila Samuel nagblɔ na Saul be Mawu tiae be wòanye fia la, nyagblɔɖilaa gblɔ be: "Tɔ ne magblɔ Mawu ƒe gbe na wò. "​ 1 Samuel 9:27.
(Jeremiah 1:​4, 11, 13; 2:1) Before telling Saul that God had chosen him as king, the prophet Samuel said: "Stand still now, so that I may let you hear the word of God. "​ 1 Samuel 9:​27.
Dzesideŋkɔ.
A personal title.
Biblia zã "Nya la " wònye dzesideŋkɔ na Yesu Kristo esime wònye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ le dziƒo kple esime wònye amegbetɔ nɔ anyigba dzi.
"The Word " also appears in the Bible as a title for Jesus Christ, both as a spirit in heaven and as a human on earth.
Kpɔ susu siwo tae míate ŋu aƒo nya ta alea ɖo la ɖa:
Consider some reasons for this conclusion:
Nya la nɔ agbe do ŋgɔ na nuwɔwɔ bubuwo katã.
The Word lived before all other creation.
"Le gɔmedzedzea me, Nya la li, . . .
"In the beginning was the Word . . .
Ame sia nɔ anyi kple Mawu le gɔmedzedzea me. "
This one was in the beginning with God. "
(Yohanes 1:1, 2) Yesue nye "nuwɔwɔwo katã ƒe gbãtɔ . . .
(John 1:​1, 2) Jesus is "the firstborn of all creation . . .
Etre dzɔdzɔ na nu bubuwo katã hã. "​ Kolosetɔwo 1:13-15, 17.
He is before all other things. "​ Colossians 1:​13-​15, 17.
Nya la va anyigba dzi abe amegbetɔ ene.
The Word came to earth as a human.
"Nya la va zu amegbetɔ, enɔ mía dome. "
"The Word became flesh and resided among us. "
(Yohanes 1:14) Kristo Yesu ‘ɖi gbɔlo eɖokui, eye wòtsɔ kluvi ƒe nɔnɔme heva zu amegbetɔ.’​ Filipitɔwo 2:5-7.
(John 1:​14) Christ Jesus "emptied himself and took a slave’s form and became human. "​ Philippians 2:​5-7.
Nya la nye Mawu ƒe Vi.
The Word is God’s Son.
Esi apostolo Yohanes gblɔ be "Nya la va zu amegbetɔ " vɔ la, eyi edzi be: "Míekpɔ eƒe ŋutikɔkɔe si le abe tenuvi ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe tso fofoa gbɔ ene. "
After stating that "the Word became flesh, " as quoted above, the apostle John continued: "We had a view of his glory, a glory such as belongs to an only-begotten son from a father. "
(Yohanes 1:14) Yohanes gaŋlɔ hã be: "Yesu Kristoe nye Mawu ƒe Vi la. "​ 1 Yohanes 4:15.
(John 1:​14) John also wrote: "Jesus is God’s Son. "​ 1 John 4:​15.
Mawu ƒe nɔnɔmewo le Nya la si.
The Word possesses godlike attributes.
"Nya la nye mawu aɖe. "
"The Word was a god, " or "was divine. "
(Yohanes 1:1) Yesu "ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe fia eye wònye eƒe amenyenye ƒe nɔnɔme pɛpɛpɛ. "​ Hebritɔwo 1:2, 3.
(John 1:1; An American Translation) Jesus is "the reflection of God’s glory and the exact representation of his very being. "​ Hebrews 1:​2, 3.
Nya la nye fia.
The Word rules as a king.
Biblia gblɔ be "fiakuku geɖewo le ta " na Mawu ƒe Nya la.
The Bible states that on the head of the Word of God are "many royal headbands. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:12, 13) Wogayɔ Nya la be "fiawo dzi Fia kple aƒetɔwo dzi Aƒetɔ. "
(Revelation 19:12, 13; footnote) The Word is also named "King of kings and Lord of lords. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:16) Woyɔ Yesu be ‘fiawo katã ƒe Fia kple aƒetɔwo katã ƒe Aƒetɔ.’​ 1 Timoteo 6:14, 15.
(Revelation 19:16) Jesus is called "the King of those who rule as kings and Lord of those who rule as lords. "​ 1 Timothy 6:​14, 15.
Nya la nye Mawu ƒe nyanuɖela.
The Word serves as God’s spokesman.
Dzesideŋkɔ "Nya la " fia be Mawu toa ame si ŋu ŋkɔ ma le la dzi gblɔa eƒe gbedeasiwo kple mɔfiamewo.
The title "the Word " apparently identifies its bearer as one whom God uses to convey information and instructions.
Yesu gblɔ be Mawu zãa ye aleae esi wògblɔ be: "Fofo si dɔm ɖa la ŋutɔe na nya si magblɔ kple ale si maƒo nui ƒe sem. . . .
Jesus said that he performed this role: "The Father who sent me has himself given me a commandment about what to say and what to speak. . . .
Eya ŋuti nya siwo megblɔna la, megblɔa wo abe ale si tututu Fofo la gblɔ wo nam ene. "​ Yohanes 12:49, 50.
So whatever I speak, I speak just as the Father has told me. "​ John 12:49, 50.
Nu Kae Nye Torah?
What Is the Torah?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Woɖe nya "Torah " tso Hebrigbe me nya tohrah me, eye woate ŋu aɖe egɔme be "nufiame " alo "se. "
The English word "Torah " comes from the Hebrew word tohrah, which can be translated as "instruction, " "teaching, " or "law. "
(Lododowo 1:8; 3:1; 28:4) Kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna la ɖe ale si wozãa Hebrigbe me nya sia le Biblia me fia.
(Proverbs 1:8; 3:1; 28:4) The following examples show how this Hebrew word is used in the Bible.
Biblia-gbalẽ atɔ̃ gbãtɔwo, siwo nye 1 Mose, 2 Mose, 3 Mose, 4 Mose kple 5 Mose ye woyɔna zi geɖe be Tohrah.
tohrah often refers to the first five books of the Bible​ Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy.
Wogayɔna wo be Pentateuch, si woɖe tso Helagbe nya aɖe si gɔmee nye "agbalẽ atɔawo ƒe babla " la me.
These are also called the Pentateuch, from a Greek word meaning "fivefold volume. "
Mose ye ŋlɔ Torah la, eya ta woyɔnɛ be "Mose ƒe Segbalẽa. "
The Torah was written by Moses, so it is called "the book of the Law of Moses. "
(Yosua 8:31; Nehemiya 8:1) Anɔ eme be agbalẽ ɖekae wònye hafi, gake emegbe wova mae ɖe akpa atɔ̃ me ale be ekɔkɔ kple ezazã nanɔ bɔbɔe wu.
(Joshua 8:​31; Nehemiah 8:1) Evidently, it was originally written as one book but was later divided for easier handling.
Wogazãa nya Tohrah tsɔ ɖɔa se siwo wona Israel ku ɖe nanewo koŋ ŋu, le kpɔɖeŋu me, "nuvɔ̃vɔsa la ŋuti se [tohrah], " "anyidɔ ŋuti se " kple "se na Naziritɔ. " 3 Mose 6:25; 14:57; 4 Mose 6:13.

tohrah is also used for the laws given to Israel on a particular subject, such as "the law [tohrah] of the sin offering, " "the law about leprosy, " and "the law about the Nazirite. "​ Leviticus 6:​25; 14:57; Numbers 6:​13.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, Tohrah gafiaa nufiame si tso dzilawo, nunyalawo, alo Mawu ŋutɔ gbɔ. Lododowo 1:8; 3:1; 13:14; Yesaya 2:3, etenuŋɔŋlɔ.
tohrah sometimes refers to instruction and teaching, whether from parents, wise ones, or God himself.​ Proverbs 1:8; 3:1; 13:14; Isaiah 2:3, footnote.
Nya kawoe le Torah, alo Pentateuch la me?
What is in the Torah, or Pentateuch?
Nuwo wɔɣi ƒe ŋutinya kpakple ale si Mawu wɔ nu kple amegbetɔwo tso gɔmedzedzea me va de asi na Mose ƒe kuɣi. 1 Mose 1:27, 28; 5 Mose 34:5.
The history of God’s dealings with humankind from creation to the death of Moses.​ Genesis 1:​27, 28; Deuteronomy 34:5.
Mose ƒe Sea ŋuti ɖoɖowo hã le eme.
The regulations of the Mosaic Law.
(2 Mose 24:3) Sedede siwo wu 600 ye le Sea me.
(Exodus 24:3) That Law is made up of more than 600 statutes.
Wo dometɔ si xɔ ŋkɔ wue nye Shema, alo Yudatɔwo ƒe xɔsemeʋuʋu.
Prominent among them is the Shema, or Jewish confession of faith.
Shema la ƒe akpa aɖe gblɔ be: "Tsɔ wò dzi blibo kple wò luʋɔ blibo kpakple wò ŋusẽ blibo lɔ̃ Yehowa wò Mawu la. " (5 Mose 6:4-9) Yesu gblɔ be, esiae nye "sedede gãtɔ kple gbãtɔ. "
One portion of the Shema says: "You must love Jehovah your God with all your heart and all your soul and all your strength. "
(Deuteronomy 6:​4-9) Jesus described this as "the greatest and first commandment. "​ Matthew 22:36-​38.
Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ Yehowa, dze le eme zi 1,800 aɖewo.
Some 1,800 occurrences of the divine name, Jehovah.
Torah la mede se ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋkɔa yɔyɔ ŋu o, ke boŋ sewo le eme siwo bia tso amewo si be woayɔ ŋkɔa. 4 Mose 6:22-27; 5 Mose 6:13; 10:8; 21:5.
Rather than prohibit the use of God’s name, the Torah contains commands that required God’s people to pronounce it.​ Numbers 6:​22-​27; Deuteronomy 6:​13; 10:8; 21:5.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Torah la ŋu
Misconceptions about the Torah
Susu totro: Ele be se siwo le Torah me la nanɔ anyi tegbee, mele be woadzudzɔ wo dzi wɔwɔ o.
Misconception: The laws of the Torah are eternal, never to be set aside.

Nyateƒea: Le Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe aɖewo me la, wogblɔ tso Torah la me se kple ɖoɖo aɖewo, abe esiwo ku ɖe Sabat, nunɔlanyenyea kple Avuléŋkekea ene ŋu be wonye "ɖoɖo mavɔ, " alo be ele be woawɔ wo dzi "tegbee. " (2 Mose 31:16; 40:15; 3 Mose 16:33, 34, Eʋegbe Biblia) Ke hã, Hebrigbe me nya si wozã le kpuikpui mawo me la agate ŋu afia nu si ayi edzi va de asi na etsɔme ʋĩi, ke menye nu si woawɔ tegbee kokoko o.

Fact: Some Bible translations do refer to specific statutes of the Torah​ including those related to the Sabbath, the priesthood, and the Day of Atonement​ as being "perpetual " or "everlasting. " (Exodus 31:16; 40:15; Leviticus 16:33, 34, King James Version) However, the Hebrew word used in these verses can also mean lasting into the indefinite future, not necessarily lasting forever.
Esi wowɔ Mose Ƒe Se ƒe nubablaa ŋu dɔ abe ƒe 900 ene megbe la, Mawu gblɔe ɖi be yeava tsɔ ‘nubabla yeye’ aɖe aɖɔlii.
After the Mosaic Law covenant had been in force for about 900 years, God foretold that he would replace it with "a new covenant. "
(Yeremiya 31:31-33) "Esi [Mawu gblɔ] be ‘nubabla yeye’ la, ena [nubabla] gbãtɔ la do xoxo. "
(Jeremiah 31:31-​33) By "saying ‘a new covenant,’ [God] made the former [covenant] obsolete. "
(Hebritɔwo 8:7-13) Wonɔ te ɖe Yesu Kristo ƒe kua dzi ɖɔlii ƒe 2,000 aɖewoe nye esi va yi. Efesotɔwo 2:15.
(Hebrews 8:​7-​13) It was replaced about 2,000 years ago on the basis of the death of Jesus Christ.​ Ephesians 2:​15.
Susu totro: Ele be woade bubu Yudatɔwo ƒe kɔnyinyiwo ŋuti sewo kple Talmud la ŋu abe ale si ko wodea bubu Torah la hã ŋu ene.
Misconception: Jewish oral traditions and the Talmud have authority equal to the written Torah.
Nyateƒea: Ŋɔŋlɔawo me kpeɖodzi aɖeke meli be Mawu tsɔ kɔnyinyiwo ŋuti sewo kpe ɖe Torah la me nuŋlɔɖiwo ŋu o.
Fact: There is no Scriptural evidence that God gave Moses an oral law to accompany the written Torah.

Ke boŋ, Biblia gblɔ be: "Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: ‘Ŋlɔ nya siawo ɖi.’ " (2 Mose 34:27) Kɔnyinyiwo ŋuti se, siwo wova ŋlɔ ɖi emegbe si woyɔna be Mishnah, lae wokeke ɖe enu wòva zu agbalẽ si nye Talmud la. Farisitɔwo gbɔe Talmud la zazã dze egɔme tsoe, eye Yudatɔwo ƒe kɔnyinyiwo ŋuti se kple ɖoɖowoe le eme.

Instead, the Bible states: "Jehovah went on to say to Moses: ‘You are to write down these words.’ " (Exodus 34:27) The oral law, later written down and known as the Mishnah and finally expanded into the Talmud, consists of Jewish traditions that began with the Pharisees.
Zi ge ɖe la, kɔnyinyi mawo tsia tsitre ɖe Torah la ŋu.
These traditions often conflicted with the Torah.
Le esia ta, Yesu gblɔ na Farisitɔwo be: "Miena Mawu ƒe nya la zu dzodzro le miaƒe kɔnyinyiwo ta. " Mateo 15:1-9.
For this reason, Jesus told the Pharisees: "You have made the word of God invalid because of your tradition. "​ Matthew 15:​1-9.
Susu totro: Mele be woafia Torah la me nyawo nyɔnuwo o.
Misconception: Women should not be taught the Torah.
Nyateƒea: Wogblɔ le Mose ƒe Sea me be ele be woaxlẽ Se bliboa me nyawo na Israel-viwo katã, nyɔnuwo kple ɖeviwo hã le eme.
Fact: The Mosaic Law included a regulation that the entire Law be read to all the people of Israel, including the women and children.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
"Ne woaɖo to, eye woasrɔ̃ ale si woavɔ̃ Yehowa [woƒe] Mawu la, eye woawɔ Se [la] me nyawo katã dzi pɛpɛpɛ. " 5 Mose 31:10-12.
"In order that they may listen and learn about and fear Jehovah [their] God and take care to carry out all the words of [the] Law. "​ Deuteronomy 31:10-​12.
Susu totro: Nya ɣaɣlawo le Torah la me.
Misconception: The Torah contains hidden messages.
Nyateƒea: Mose, ame si ŋlɔ Torah la me nyawo ɖi la, gblɔ be emenyawo me kɔ, ame sia ame ate ŋu ase wo gɔme, eye womele ɣaɣla o.
Fact: Moses, who recorded the Torah, stated that its message is clear and accessible to all, not hidden in a code.

(5 Mose 30:11-14) Nya si amewo gblɔna be nya ɣaɣlawo be ɖe Torah me la dzɔ tso Yudatɔwo ƒe vivimenunya si woyɔna be Kabbalah, si me ‘wokpaa nyawo le aɖaŋutɔe’ tsɔ ɖea Ŋɔŋlɔawo me, la me. 2 Petro 1:16.

(Deuteronomy 30:11-​14) The theory that there are hidden messages in the Torah is rooted in Kabbalah, or traditional Jewish mysticism, which uses "artfully contrived " methods to interpret the Scriptures. ​ 2 Peter 1:​16.
Gɔmesese Kae Nɔa Xexlẽdzesiwo Si Le Biblia Me?
What Do Numbers Mean in the Bible?
Ðe Biblia Da Asi Ðe Xexlẽdzesifakaka Dzia?
Is Numerology Biblical?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Zi geɖe la, xexlẽdzesi siwo le Biblia me la fiaa xexlẽdzesi ŋutɔŋutɔwo, gake ɣeaɖewoɣi la wozãa wo tsɔ fia nu bubuwo.
Numbers in the Bible can often be taken literally, but they are sometimes used as symbols.
Zi geɖe la, nya siwo ƒo xlã nya la ɖenɛ fiana nenye be ɖe wozãe wòfia nu bubu aɖe.
The context usually indicates whether a particular number is used as a symbol.
Kpɔ xexlẽdzesi siwo wozã le Biblia me wofia nu bubuwo dometɔ aɖewo ɖa:
Consider these examples of the symbolic meaning of numbers in the Bible:
1 Ðekawɔwɔ.
1 Unity.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesu do gbe ɖa na Mawu ku ɖe eyomedzelawo ŋu be: "Wo katã woawɔ ɖeka, abe ale si wò, Fofo la, nèwɔ ɖeka kplim, eye nye hã mewɔ ɖeka kpli wò la ene. " Yohanes 17:21; Mateo 19:6.
For instance, Jesus prayed to God that his followers "may all be one, just as you, Father, are in union with me and I am in union with you. "​ John 17:21; Matthew 19:6.
2 Le senyawo me la, ɖasefo eve ɖoa kpe nya ƒe nyateƒenyenye dzi.
2 In a legal setting, two witnesses verify the truth of a matter.
(5 Mose 17:6) Nenema kee ne wogbugbɔ ŋutega alo nya aɖe gblɔ zi eve la, enye kpeɖodzi be nyaa nye nya vavã eye kakaɖedzi le eŋu.
(Deuteronomy 17:6) Similarly, the repetition of a vision or a statement confirms the matter as sure and true.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esime Yosef ɖe drɔ̃e si Farao ku gɔme nɛ la, egblɔ be: "Esi Farao ku drɔ̃ea zi eve la, efia be Mawu vavã la ɖoe kplikpaa, eye Mawu vavã la le ewɔ ge kpuie. " (1 Mose 41:32) Le nyagblɔɖiwo me la, "dzoevee " tea ŋu fiaa dziɖuɖu ƒokpli eve abe ale si woɖe eme na nyagblɔɖila Daniel ku ɖe Medo-Persia Fiaɖuƒea ŋu ene.​ Daniel 8:​20, 21; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:11.

For example, when Joseph interpreted a dream given to Pharaoh of Egypt, he said: "The fact that the dream was repeated to Pharaoh twice means that the thing is firmly established on the part of the true God. " (Genesis 41:32) In prophecy, "two horns " can represent dual rulership, as the prophet Daniel was told regarding the Medo-Persian Empire.​ Daniel 8:​20, 21; Revelation 13:11.

3 Abe ale si ko ɖasefo etɔ̃ ɖoa kpe nya ƒe nyateƒenyenye dzi keŋkeŋ ene la, nenema kee ne wogbugbɔ nya aɖe gblɔ zi etɔ̃ la, etea gbe ɖe edzi keŋkeŋ be nyaa nye nyateƒe.​ Ezekiel 21:27; Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:9-16; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:8; 8:13.
3 Just as three witnesses would firmly prove a matter to be true, a threefold repetition seems to establish it firmly or emphasize it.​ Ezekiel 21:27; Acts 10:​9-​16; Revelation 4:8; 8:​13.
4 Efia nane ƒe nɔnɔme alo eƒe dɔwɔwɔ ƒe blibonyenye abe ale si wòdze le nyagbe si nye "anyigba ƒe dzogoe eneawo " me ene. Nyaɖeɖefia 7:1; 21:16; Yesaya 11:12.
4 This can represent completeness in form or function, as in the expression "the four corners of the earth. "​ Revelation 7:1; 21:16; Isaiah 11:12.

6 Xexlẽdzesi sia fia be ɖeka to le adre, si fia nu ƒe dede keŋkeŋ zi geɖe la me, xexlẽdzesi ade ate ŋu afia nu si mede o, mede blibo o alo nu si do ƒome kple Mawu ƒe futɔwo.​ 1 Kronika 20:6; Daniel 3:1; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:18.

6 Being one less than seven, which often represents completeness, six can stand for something incomplete or imperfect or something associated with God’s enemies.​ 1 Chronicles 20:6; Daniel 3:1; Revelation 13:18.
7 Wozãa xexlẽdzesi sia wòfiaa nu si de keŋkeŋ.
7 This number is often used to represent the idea of completeness.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mawu de se na Israel-viwo be woazɔ aƒo xlã Yeriko-dua ŋkeke adre, eye le ŋkeke adrelia dzi la woaƒo xlã dua zi adre sɔŋ.
For instance, the Israelites were commanded by God to march around Jericho on seven successive days and to march around seven times on the seventh day.
(Yosua 6:15) Wozãa xexlẽdzesi adre le gɔmesese sia nu le Biblia me zi geɖe.
(Joshua 6:​15) The Bible contains many similar examples of such a use of the number seven.

(3 Mose 4:6; 25:8; 26:18; Psalmo 119:164; Nyaɖeɖefia 1:20; 13:1; 17:10) Esi Yesu gblɔ na Petro be wòatsɔ ake ehavi menye "va se ɖe zi adre o, ke boŋ va se ɖe zi blaadre vɔ adre " la, ale si wògbugbɔ xexlẽdzesi adre yɔ le afi sia fia be "seɖoƒe meli " na zi neni si wòatsɔ ake o. Mateo 18:21, 22.

(Leviticus 4:6; 25:8; 26:18; Psalm 119:164; Revelation 1:​20; 13:1; 17:10) When Jesus told Peter that he should forgive his brother "not, Up to seven times, but, Up to seventy-seven times, " the repetition of "seven " conveyed the thought of "without limit. "​ Matthew 18:21, 22.
10 Xexlẽdzesi sia ate ŋu afia nane ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ katã alo eƒe ƒuƒoƒo.​ 2 Mose 34:28; Luka 19:13; Nyaɖeɖefia 2:10.
10 This number can stand for the entirety or aggregate of something.​ Exodus 34:28; Luke 19:13; Revelation 2:​10.
12 Edze abe xexlẽdzesi sia fia Mawu ƒe ɖoɖo si sɔ blibo ene.
12 This number seems to represent a complete, divine arrangement.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, apostolo Yohanes kpɔ dziƒowo le ŋutega aɖe me, ekpɔ du aɖe, "woɖo gɔmeɖokpe wuieve na dua ƒe gli la . . . eye woŋlɔ Alẽvi la ƒe apostolo wuieveawo ƒe ŋkɔ wuieveawo ɖe wo ŋu. "
For example, the vision of heaven given to the apostle John included a city with "twelve foundation stones, and on them the twelve names of the twelve apostles. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:14; 1 Mose 49:28) Gɔmesese sia ke tea ŋu nɔa xexlẽdzesi siwo woate ŋu ama ɖe teƒe 12 pɛpɛpɛ hã si.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 4:4; 7:4-8.
(Revelation 21:14; Genesis 49:28) Multiples of 12 can have a similar meaning.​ Revelation 4:4; 7:​4-8.
40 Wozãa xexlẽdzesi 40 tsɔ do ƒome kple toheɣi kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃gbedeasi geɖewo.​ 1 Mose 7:4; Ezekiel 29:11, 12.
40 Several judgment or punishment periods were linked with the number 40.​ Genesis 7:4; Ezekiel 29:11, 12.
Xexlẽdzesifakaka
Numerology and gematria

Ale si wozã xexlẽdzesiwo le Biblia me woƒe gɔmesese fiaa nu bubuwo la to vovo sãa na xexlẽdzesifakaka. Le xexlẽdzesifakaka ya gome la, wokaa afa dia xexlẽdzesiwo ƒe gɔmesese kple gɔmesese si le xexlẽdzesiwo ƒe ƒuƒoƒowo si.
These symbolic meanings of numbers in the Bible are different from numerology, which involves looking for an occult meaning in numbers, their combinations, and numerical totals.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yudatɔwo ƒe Nyaɣaɣlafialawo xɔe se be gɔmesese ɣaɣla aɖe nɔa nuŋlɔdzesi ɖe sia ɖe si le Hebri Ŋɔŋlɔawo me la si.
For example, Jewish Cabalists have analyzed the Hebrew Scriptures using a technique called gematria, which looks for a hidden code in the numerical equivalents of letters.
Xexlẽdzesiwo tsia tsitre ɖi na nuŋlɔdzesi ɖe sia ɖe.
Numerology is a form of divination, which God condemns.​ Deuteronomy 18:10-​12.
Mawu lé fu xexlẽdzesifakaka.​ 5 Mose 18:10-12.
What Does Bible Chronology Indicate About the Year 1914?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubuwo ɖee fia be woɖo Mawu Fiaɖuƒea anyi le dziƒo le ƒe 1914 me.
Bible chronology indicates that God’s Kingdom was established in heaven in 1914.
Esia dze le Biblia-gbalẽ si nye Daniel ƒe ta 4 me.
This is shown by a prophecy recorded in chapter 4 of the Bible book of Daniel.
Nyagblɔɖia me nya veviwo.
Overview of the prophecy.
Ekpɔ ati gã aɖe le drɔ̃ea me, eye wolã ati la ƒu anyi. Woxe mɔ na eƒe takpoea be magadze o "ɣeyiɣi adre. "
God caused King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon to have a prophetic dream about an immense tree that was chopped down.
Le esia megbe la, ati la agadze ake.​ Daniel 4:​1, 10-​16.
Its stump was prevented from regrowing for a period of "seven times, " after which the tree would grow again.​ Daniel 4:​1, 10-​16.
Nyagblɔɖia ƒe emevava gbãtɔ.
The prophecy’s initial fulfillment.
Ati gã la le tsitre ɖi na Fia Nebukadnezar ŋutɔ.
The great tree represented King Nebuchadnezzar himself.
(Daniel 4:​20-​22) ‘Wolãe ƒu anyi’ le kpɔɖeŋumɔ nu esime wòku tsu ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe eye wòdzo le zi dzi hena ɣeyiɣi adre.
(Daniel 4:​20-​22) He was figuratively ‘chopped down’ when he temporarily lost his sanity and kingship for a period of seven years.
(Daniel 4:​25) Esi Mawu na Nebukadnezar ƒe mo kɔ la, egagbugbɔ xɔ eƒe fiazikpuia eye wòlɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Mawue nye dziɖula.​ Daniel 4:​34-​36.
(Daniel 4:​25) When God restored his sanity, Nebuchadnezzar regained his throne and acknowledged God’s rulership.​ Daniel 4:​34-​36.
Nu siwo ɖo kpe edzi be ele be nyagblɔɖia nava eme le mɔ si lolo wu nu.
Evidence that the prophecy has a greater fulfillment.

Nu si koŋ tae wogblɔ nya sia ɖi ɖo lae nye be "agbagbeawo nanyae be Dziƒoʋĩtɔ lae nye Dziɖula si kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe fiaɖuƒewo dzi, eye ame si dze eŋu la, eyae wòtsɔnɛ nana, eye wòtsɔa ame tsɛtɔ le amegbetɔwo dome gɔ̃ hã ɖoa enu. "

The whole purpose of the prophecy was that "people living may know that the Most High is Ruler in the kingdom of mankind and that he gives it to whomever he wants, and he sets up over it even the lowliest of men. "
(Daniel 4:17) Fia Nebukadnezar dadala mae Mawu di be yeatsɔ dziɖuɖu ma ana mlɔeba?
(Daniel 4:​17) Was proud Nebuchadnezzar the one to whom God ultimately wanted to give such rulership?
Ao, elabena Mawu ɖee fia Fia Nebukadnezar le drɔ̃e aɖe si nye nyagblɔɖi me do ŋgɔ xoxo be fiaɖuƒe sia mayi ɖe eya ŋutɔ loo alo amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖula bubu aɖeke si me o.
No, for God had earlier given him another prophetic dream showing that neither he nor any other political ruler would fill this role.
Ke boŋ Mawu "aɖo fiaɖuƒe aɖe anyi, si matsrɔ̃ gbeɖegbeɖe o. "​ Daniel 2:​31-​44.
Instead, God would himself "set up a kingdom that will never be destroyed. "​ Daniel 2:​31-​44.
Do ŋgɔ na nudzɔdzɔ ma la, Mawu ɖo fiaɖuƒe aɖe si tsi tre ɖi na eƒe dziɖuɖu ɖe anyigba dzi la anyi: eyae nye blema Israel.
Previously, God had set up a kingdom to represent his rulership on earth: the ancient nation of Israel.
Mawu ɖe mɔ ‘wotsrɔ̃’ fiaɖuƒe ma elabena eƒe fiawo mewɔ nuteƒe nɛ o, gake egblɔe ɖi be yeatsɔ fiaɖuƒea ana "ame si tɔ wònye le se nu. "
God allowed that kingdom to be made "a ruin " because its rulers had become unfaithful, but he foretold that he would give kingship to "the one who has the legal right. "
(Ezekiel 21:25-​27) Biblia ɖee fia be Yesue nye ame si woɖe mɔ na le se nu be wòaxɔ fiaɖuƒe mavɔ sia.
(Ezekiel 21:25-​27) The Bible identifies Jesus Christ as the one legally authorized to receive this everlasting kingdom.
(Luka 1:​30-​33) Yesu to vovo na Nebukadnezar dadala ma, elabena Yesu ‘bɔbɔ eɖokui ɖe anyi le dzi me’ abe ale si tututu wogblɔe ɖi ene.​ Mateo 11:29.
(Luke 1:​30-​33) Unlike Nebuchadnezzar, Jesus is "lowly in heart, " just as it was prophesied.​ Matthew 11:29.
Nu kae ati si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Daniel 4 la fia?
What does the tree of Daniel chapter 4 represent?
Wozãa atiwo tsɔ tsia tsitre ɖi na fiaɖuƒewo ɣeaɖewoɣi le Biblia me.
In the Bible, trees sometimes represent rulership.
(Ezekiel 17:22-​24; 31:​2-5) Le nyagblɔɖi si le Daniel ta 4 ƒe emevava gãtɔa me la, ati la le tsitre ɖi na Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu.
(Ezekiel 17:22-​24; 31:​2-5) In the greater fulfillment of Daniel chapter 4, the immense tree symbolizes God’s rulership.
Nu kae atia lalã ƒu anyi fia?
What does the tree’s being chopped down mean?
Abe ale si ko atia lalã ƒu anyi fia be Nebukadnezar maganye fia o va se ɖe ɣeyiɣi aɖe la, nenema kee wòfia hã be Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu le anyigba dzi me atso hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
Just as the chopping down of the tree represented an interruption in Nebuchadnezzar’s kingship, it also represented an interruption in God’s rulership on earth.
Esia va eme esime Nebukadnezar va tsrɔ̃ Yerusalem, du si me Israel fiawo nɔa "Yehowa ƒe fiazikpui dzi " henyea Yehowa ŋutɔ teƒenɔlawo le.​ 1 Kronika 29:23.
This happened when Nebuchadnezzar destroyed Jerusalem, where the kings of Israel sat on "Jehovah’s throne " as representatives of God himself.​ 1 Chronicles 29:23.
Nu kae "ɣeyiɣi adre " la le tsitre ɖi na?
What do the "seven times " represent?
"Ɣeyiɣi adre " la le tsitre ɖi na ɣeyiɣi si Mawu ɖe mɔ na dukɔwo be woaɖu anyigba dzi esime fiaɖuƒe si Mawu ɖo la ɖeke meli ade nu woƒe nyawo me o.
The "seven times " represent the period during which God allowed the nations to rule over the earth without interference from any kingdom that he had set up.
Le Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubu nu la, "ɣeyiɣi adre " la dze egɔme le October 607 Do Ŋgɔ Na Yesu, esime Babilontɔwo tsrɔ̃ Yerusalem. ​ 2 Fiawo 25:1, 8-10.
The "seven times " began in October 607 B.C.E., when, according to Bible chronology, Jerusalem was destroyed by the Babylonians. ​ 2 Kings 25:​1, 8-​10.
Ƒe nenie "ɣeyiɣi adre " la axɔ?
How long are the "seven times "?
Mate ŋu anye ƒe adre ŋutɔŋutɔ abe ale si wònɔ le Nebukadnezar gome ene o.
They could not be merely seven years as in Nebuchadnezzar’s case.
Yesu na míekpɔ ŋuɖoɖoa esi wògblɔ be "dukɔwo atu afɔ Yerusalem [si le tsitre ɖi na Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu] dzi va se ɖe esime dukɔwo ƒe ɣeyiɣi ɖoɖiawo nawu enu. "
Jesus indicated the answer when he said that "Jerusalem [a symbol of God’s rulership] will be trampled on by the nations until the appointed times of the nations are fulfilled. "
(Luka 21:24) "Dukɔwo ƒe ɣeyiɣi ɖoɖiawo " si nye ɣeyiɣi si Mawu ɖe mɔ be dukɔwo natu afɔ "Yerusalem dzi " kee nye "ɣeyiɣi adre " si nu woƒo nu tsoe le Daniel ta 4.
(Luke 21:24) "The appointed times of the nations, " the period during which God allowed his rulership to be "trampled on by the nations, " are the same as the "seven times " of Daniel chapter 4.
Esia fia be esime Yesu nɔ anyigba dzi gɔ̃ hã la, "ɣeyiɣi adre " la mekpɔ wu enu o.
This means that the "seven times " were still under way even when Jesus was on earth.
Biblia kpe ɖe mía ŋu míenya ɣeyiɣi didi si "ɣeyiɣi adre " si wogblɔ ɖi la axɔ.
The Bible provides the way to determine the length of those prophetic "seven times. "
Biblia gblɔ be ɣeyiɣi etɔ̃ kple afã ƒe didimee nye ŋkeke 1,260. "Ɣeyiɣi adre " nye ema ƒe teƒe eve alo ŋkeke 2,520.
It says that three and a half "times " equal 1,260 days, so "seven times " equal twice that number, or 2,520 days.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 12:6, 14) Ne míezã nyagblɔɖi ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubu si nye ‘ŋkeke ɖeka na ƒe ɖeka’ la, ke ŋkeke 2,520 tsi tre ɖi na ƒe 2,520.
(Revelation 12:​6, 14) Applying the prophetic rule "a day for a year, " the 2,520 days represent 2,520 years.
Eya ta "ɣeyiɣi adre " alo ƒe 2,520 wu enu le October 1914 me.​ 4 Mose 14:34; Ezekiel 4:6.
Therefore, the "seven times, " or 2,520 years, would end in October 1914.​ Numbers 14:34; Ezekiel 4:6.
Nyaɖeɖefia Ƒe Agbalẽa Aleke Nàwɔ Ase Egɔme?
The Book of Revelation​ What Does it Mean?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ŋkɔ si le Biblia-gbalẽ si nye Nyaɖeɖefia si le Helagbe me lae nye Apokalypsis si gɔmee nye "Nukoklo le nu ŋu " alo "Nuɖeɖe ɖe go. "
The Greek name of the Bible book of Revelation, Apokalypsis (apocalypse), means "Uncovering " or "Disclosure. "
Esia ɖe gɔmesese si le ŋkɔ Nyaɖeɖefia ŋu la fia, elabe aklo nu le nya siwo le ɣaɣla la dzi eye wòaɖe nu siwo ava dzɔ le eŋɔŋlɔ megbe la ɖe go.
This name indicates the meaning of Revelation​ it uncovers matters that had been hidden and discloses events that would happen long after it was written.
Nyagblɔɖi siwo le eme dometɔ geɖe mekpɔ va eme o.
Many of its prophecies are yet to be fulfilled.
Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me nya veviwo
Overview of the book of Revelation
Ŋgɔdonya.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:1-9.
Introduction.​ Revelation 1:​1-9.
Gbedeasi si tso Yesu gbɔ na hame adreawo.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:10–3:22.
Messages from Jesus to the seven congregations.​ Revelation 1:10–​3:​22.
Ŋutega si me Mawu nɔ eƒe fiazikpui dzi le dziƒo le.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 4:1-​11.
A vision of God on his throne in heaven.​ Revelation 4:1-​11.
Ŋutega vovovowo, ɖe sia ɖe kplɔa ame yia esi kplɔe ɖo gbɔ:
A series of visions, each one leading into the next:
Nutrenu adreawo.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 5:1–​8:6.
Seven seals.​ Revelation 5:1–​8:6.
Kpẽ adre, esi woku etɔ̃ mamlɛawo la, fuwɔame etɔ̃ va.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 8:7–​14:20.
Seven trumpets, the last three of which introduce three woes.​ Revelation 8:7–​14:20.
Kplu adre, fuwɔame si nye Mawu ƒe ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ la le ɖe sia ɖe me, eye woakɔ wo ɖe anyigba la dzi.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 15:1–​16:21.
Seven bowls, each containing a plague representing a divine judgment to be poured out on the earth.​ Revelation 15:1–​16:21.
Ŋutega si me wotsrɔ̃ Mawu ƒe futɔwo le.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:1–​20:10.
Visions of the destruction of God’s enemies.​ Revelation 17:1–​20:10.
Ŋutega siwo ku ɖe ale si Mawu ayra dziƒo kple anyigba la ŋu.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 20:11–​22:5.
Visions of blessings from God for heaven and earth.​ Revelation 20:11–​22:5.
Etaƒoƒo.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 22:​6-​21.
Conclusion.​ Revelation 22:​6-​21.
Nu vevi siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàse Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa gɔme
Keys to understanding the book of Revelation
Emenyawo ƒe gɔmesese ɖea vi na Mawu subɔlawo, menana be vɔvɔ̃ ɖoa wo alo ŋɔ dzia wo o.
Its meaning is positive, not fearful or terrifying to those who serve God.

Togbɔ be ame geɖewo gblɔna be tsɔtsrɔ̃ ƒe nyawoe le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me hã la, le agbalẽa ƒe gɔmedzedze kple eƒe nuwuwu la, wogblɔ be ame siwo xlẽa agbalẽ sia, sea emenyawo gɔme hewɔa wo dzi la akpɔ dzidzɔ.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:3; 22:7.

While many associate the word "apocalypse " with great disaster, the book of Revelation begins and ends by saying that those who read, understand, and apply its message would be happy for doing so.​ Revelation 1:3; 22:7.
Wozã "dzesiwo, " alo kpɔɖeŋu geɖewo le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me, eye mele be míase wo gɔme be nenemae wole ŋutɔŋutɔ o.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:1.
Revelation uses many "signs, " or symbols, that are not to be understood literally.​ Revelation 1:1.
Woƒo nu tso ame vevitɔwo, nu vevitɔwo kple dzesi siwo dze le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me la ŋu do ŋgɔ le Biblia ƒe akpa bubuwo:
Many major entities and symbols in the book of Revelation are introduced earlier in the Bible:
Yehowa​ eyae nye "Mawu vavã le dziƒo, " eyae nye nuwo katã Wɔla.​ 5 Mose 4:39; Psalmo 103:19; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11; 15:3.
Jehovah​ "the true God in the heavens " and Creator of all things.​ Deuteronomy 4:​39; Psalm 103:19; Revelation 4:​11; 15:3.
Yesu Kristo​ "Mawu ƒe Alẽvi " la. Yohanes 1:29; Nyaɖeɖefia 5:6; 14:1.
Jesus Christ​ "the Lamb of God. "​ John 1:​29; Revelation 5:6; 14:1.
Satana Abosam​ Mawu ƒe futɔ.​ 1 Mose 3:14, 15; Yohanes 8:44; Nyaɖeɖefia 12:9.
Satan the Devil​ God’s adversary.​ Genesis 3:​14, 15; John 8:​44; Revelation 12:9.
Babilon Gã​ hã nye Mawu kple eƒe amewo ƒe futɔ, eye wònye aʋatsodzixɔsewo tsoƒe hã abe ale si ko wònɔ le blema Babilon (Babel) gome ene.​ 1 Mose 11:2-9; Yesaya 13:1, 11; Nyaɖeɖefia 17:4-6; 18:4, 20.
Babylon the Great​ like ancient Babylon (Babel), an enemy of Jehovah God and his people and a source of religious lies.​ Genesis 11:​2-9; Isaiah 13:​1, 11; Revelation 17:​4-6; 18:​4, 20.
"Atsiaƒu "​ amegbetɔ vɔ̃ɖi siwo tsi tre ɖe Mawu ŋu.​ Yesaya 57:20; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1; 21:1.
"The sea "​ wicked mankind opposed to God.​ Isaiah 57:20; Revelation 13:1; 21:1.

Avɔgbadɔ si nɔ anyi le blema si me wodea ta agu na Mawu le me nu siwo sɔ kple agbalẽ sia me nuwo​ wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye nubablaɖaka, atsiaƒu si le abe ahuhɔ̃e ene (ze hena ŋutikɔklɔ), akaɖiwo, dzudzɔdonu ʋeʋĩ kple vɔsamlekpui.​ 2 Mose 25:10, 17, 18; 40:24-32; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:5, 6; 5:8; 8:3; 11:19.

Features corresponding to the ancient tabernacle used for God’s worship​ including the ark of the covenant, the glassy sea (basin for washing), lamps, offerings of incense, and an altar of sacrifice.​ Exodus 25:10, 17, 18; 40:24-32; Revelation 4:​5, 6; 5:8; 8:3; 11:19.
Lã wɔadã la​ si le tsitre ɖi na amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo.​ Daniel 7:1-8, 17-26; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:2, 11; 17:3.
Wild beasts​ symbolizing human governments.​ Daniel 7:​1-8, 17-​26; Revelation 13:​2, 11; 17:3.
Xexlẽdzesi siwo wozã le kpɔɖeŋumɔ nu.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:20; 8:13; 13:18; 21:16.
Numbers used symbolically.​ Revelation 1:​20; 8:​13; 13:18; 21:16.
Ŋutegaawo ku ɖe "Aƒetɔ la ƒe ŋkeke " la ŋu, eye ŋkeke sia dze egɔme esime woɖo Mawu Fiaɖuƒea anyi le ƒe 1914 me eye Yesu zu Fia dze dziɖuɖu gɔme.
The visions apply to "the Lord’s day, " which began when God’s Kingdom was set up in 1914 and Jesus began ruling as King.
Ne míedi be míase Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa gɔme la, míehiã nu siwo kpena ɖe mía ŋu míesea Biblia ƒe akpa bubuwo gɔme la ke.
(Revelation 1:​10) We can therefore expect the main fulfillment of Revelation to be in our time.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye nunya si tso Mawu gbɔ kple ame siwo se egɔme xoxo la ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 8:26-39; Yakobo 1:5.

To understand the book of Revelation, we need the same things that help us to understand the rest of the Bible, including wisdom from God and assistance from those who already understand it.​ Acts 8:​26-​39; James 1:5.
Nu Kae Nye Yerusalem Yeyea?
What Is New Jerusalem?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Nya "Yerusalem Yeye, " dze zi eve le Biblia me, eye enye kpɔɖeŋudu si le tsitre ɖi na Yesu yomedzelawo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo aɖe si aɖu fia kplii le dziƒo le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea me.
"New Jerusalem, " an expression that appears twice in the Bible, is a symbolic city that represents the group of Jesus’ followers who go to heaven to rule with him in God’s Kingdom.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 3:12; 21:2) Biblia ɖee fia be woagate ŋu ayɔ ƒuƒoƒo sia be Kristo ƒe ŋugbetɔ la.
(Revelation 3:​12; 21:2) The Bible shows that this group can also be called the bride of Christ.
Nu siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànya nu si Yerusalem Yeyea nye
Keys to identifying New Jerusalem
Dziƒoe Yerusalem yeyea le.
New Jerusalem is in heaven.
Ɣesiaɣi si Biblia ƒo nu tso Yerusalem Yeyea ŋu la, egblɔna be ele ɖiɖim tso dziƒo, afi si mawudɔlawo le dua ƒe agbowo nu dzɔm le.
Each time the Bible mentions New Jerusalem, it is said to come down from heaven, where angels guard the city’s gates.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 3:12; 21:2, 10, 12) Azɔ hã, ale si gbegbe dua loloe la na eme kɔ be menye anyigba dzie wòle o.
(Revelation 3:​12; 21:​2, 10, 12) Also, the city’s great size proves that it could not be on earth.
Ele dzogoe ene me, eye eƒe didime kple kekeme siaa le "stadio akpe wuieve. "
It is a cube measuring "12,000 stadia, " or "furlongs, " around.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:16) Esia fia be eƒe kɔkɔme anye kilometa 560 kloe, eye aɖo keke yamenutowo me ʋĩi ke.
(Revelation 21:16; King James Version) Its sides would thus be almost 560 kilometers (350 mi) high, extending into space.
Yesu yomedzelawo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo si wogayɔna be Kristo ƒe ŋugbetɔ lae nye Yerusalem Yeyea.
New Jerusalem is made up of a group of Jesus’ followers, the bride of Christ.
Woyɔ Yerusalem Yeyea be "ŋugbetɔ la, ame si nye Alẽvi la srɔ̃. "
New Jerusalem is called "the bride, the Lamb’s wife. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:9, 10) Le mawunyakpukpui ma me la, Alẽvi la le tsitre ɖi na Yesu Kristo.
(Revelation 21:​9, 10) In this symbolic description, the Lamb refers to Jesus Christ.
(Yohanes 1:29; Nyaɖeɖefia 5:12) "Alẽvi la srɔ̃, " si nye Kristo ƒe ŋugbetɔ la le tsitre ɖi na Kristotɔ siwo awɔ ɖeka kple Yesu le dziƒo.
(John 1:​29; Revelation 5:​12) "The Lamb’s wife, " Christ’s bride, represents Christians who will be united with Jesus in heaven.
Biblia tsɔ ƒomedodo sia si le Yesu kple Kristotɔ siawo dome la sɔ kple ƒomedodo si le srɔ̃ŋutsu kple srɔ̃nyɔnu dome.
The Bible likens the relationship between Jesus and these Christians to that of a husband and wife.
(2 Korintotɔwo 11:2; Efesotɔwo 5:23-25) Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, woŋlɔ "Alẽvi la ƒe apostolo wuieveawo ƒe ŋkɔ wuieveawo " ɖe Yerusalem Yeyea ƒe gɔmeɖokpewo dzi.
(2 Corinthians 11:2; Ephesians 5:​23-​25) In addition, the foundation stones of New Jerusalem are inscribed with "the 12 names of the 12 apostles of the Lamb. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:14) Nya sia kpe ɖe mía ŋu míenya nu si Yerusalem Yeyea nye, elabena wotu Kristotɔ siwo ayi dziƒo la ɖe "apostoloawo kple nyagblɔɖilawo ƒe gɔmeɖoanyi dzi. " Efesotɔwo 2:20.

(Revelation 21:14) This detail helps to confirm the identity of New Jerusalem, since Christians who are called to life in heaven are "built up on the foundation of the apostles and prophets. "​ Ephesians 2:​20.
Yerusalem Yeyea nye dziɖuɖu aɖe ƒe akpa aɖe.
New Jerusalem is part of a government.

Blema Yerusalem ye nye Israel ƒe fiadu, afi si Fia David, via Salomo kple woƒe dzidzimeviwo nɔ "Yehowa ƒe fiazikpui dzi " heɖu fia le. (1 Kronika 29:23) Eya ta, Yerusalem, si woyɔ be "du kɔkɔe " la, nɔ tsitre ɖi na Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu to David ƒe fiaƒomea dzi.

Ancient Jerusalem was the capital of Israel, the place where King David, his son Solomon, and their descendants ruled "on Jehovah’s throne. " (1 Chronicles 29:23) Jerusalem, called "the holy city, " thus represented God’s rulership in the family line of David.
(Nehemiya 11:1) Woyɔ Yerusalem Yeyea, hã be "du kɔkɔe, " eye du sia me tɔwoe nye ame siwo akpe ɖe Yesu ŋu le dziƒo woaɖu "fia ɖe anyigba la dzi. " Nyaɖeɖefia 5:9, 10; 21:2.
(Nehemiah 11:1) New Jerusalem, also called "the holy city, " is made up of those who join Jesus in heaven "to rule as kings over the earth. "​ Revelation 5:​9, 10; 21:2.
Yerusalem Yeyea ahe yayrawo vɛ na anyigbadzitɔwo.
New Jerusalem brings blessings to people on earth.
Wogblɔ tso Yerusalem Yeyea ŋu be ele "ɖiɖim tso dziƒo gbɔna tso Mawu gbɔ, " si fia be Mawu zãnɛ tsɔ kpɔa anyigbadzinyawo gbɔe.
New Jerusalem is depicted as "coming down out of heaven from God, " showing that God uses it to affect matters outside of heaven.
