(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:2) Nyagbe ma ɖee fia be Yerusalem Yeyea do ƒome kple Mawu Fiaɖuƒea, elabena Mawu zãa Fiaɖuƒe ma tsɔ nana eƒe lɔlɔ̃nu vaa eme "le anyigba dzi abe ale si wòle le dziƒo ene. "
(Revelation 21:2) This expression links New Jerusalem with God’s Kingdom, which God uses to accomplish his will "as in heaven, also on earth. "
(Mateo 6:10) Yayra siwo Mawu ɖo be yeahe vɛ na anyigbadzitɔwo la dometɔ aɖewoe nye esiawo:
(Matthew 6:​10) God’s purpose for people on earth includes these blessings:
Aɖe nu vɔ̃ ɖa.
Removal of sin.
"Agbetsitɔsisi " aɖe sina tso Yerusalem Yeyea ɖadea tsi ‘agbeti’ siwo "nye dɔyɔgbe na dukɔwo. "
"A river of water of life " flows from New Jerusalem and supports "trees of life " that are "for the healing of the nations. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 22:1, 2) Ŋutilãmedɔyɔyɔ kple gbɔgbɔmedɔyɔyɔ sia aɖe nu vɔ̃ ɖa eye wòana amewo nanɔ agbe si de blibo, abe ale si Mawu ɖoe tso gɔmedzedzea me ene. Romatɔwo 8:21.
(Revelation 22:​1, 2) This physical and spiritual healing will remove sin and enable people to gain perfect life, as God originally intended.​ Romans 8:​21.
Ƒomedodo nyui anɔ Mawu kple amegbetɔwo dome.
Good relations between God and humankind.
Nu vɔ̃ gblẽ ƒomedodo si le Mawu kple amegbetɔwo dome.
Sin has alienated humans from God.
(Yesaya 59:2) Ne Mawu ɖe nu vɔ̃ ɖa la, nyagblɔɖi sia ava eme bliboe: "Mawu ƒe agbadɔ la le amegbetɔwo gbɔ, eye wòanɔ anyi kpli wo, eye woanye eƒe dukɔ.
(Isaiah 59:2) The removal of sin will allow for the complete fulfillment of this prophecy: "The tent of God is with mankind, and he will reside with them, and they will be his people.
Eye Mawu ŋutɔ anɔ anyi kpli wo. " Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3.
And God himself will be with them. "​ Revelation 21:3.
Fukpekpe kple ku nu ayi.
The end of suffering and death.
Mawu ato eƒe Fiaɖuƒea dzi "atutu aɖatsi sia aɖatsi ɖa le woƒe ŋkume, eye ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o, konyifafa kple ɣlidodo kpakple vevesese hã maganɔ anyi o. " Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4.
By means of his Kingdom, God "will wipe out every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will mourning nor outcry nor pain be anymore. "​ Revelation 21:4.
Nu Kae Lã Wɔadã Si To Ta Adre Le Nyaɖeɖefia Ta 13 La Nye?
What Is the Seven-Headed Wild Beast of Revelation Chapter 13?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
PThe Bible’s answer
Lã wɔadã si to ta adre si ŋuti woƒo nu le zi gbãtɔ le Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1 la nye xexea me katã ƒe dunyahenuɖoanyi la.
The wild beast with seven heads introduced at Revelation 13:1 represents the worldwide political system.
Ŋutete, ŋusẽ kple fiazikpui le esi, esia ɖee fia be dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyie.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 13:2.
It has authority, power, and a throne, which point to its being a political entity.​ Revelation 13:2.
Eɖua "to sia to kple ame ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi kple gbegbɔgblɔ sia gbegbɔgblɔ kpakple dukɔ sia dukɔ dzi, " eya ta ekeke ta wu dukɔ ɖekaɖekawo ko.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 13:7.
It rules over "every tribe and people and tongue and nation, " so it is greater than a single national government.​ Revelation 13:7.
Lã ene siwo ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Daniel 7:​2-8 ƒe ŋutinuwo dze le eŋu, ele abe lãklẽ ene, eƒe afɔwo le abe sisiblisi tɔwo ene, eƒe nu le abe dzata ƒe nu ene, eye dzo ewo le eta.
It combines features of the four beasts described in the prophecy at Daniel 7:​2-8, including the appearance of a leopard, the feet of a bear, a lion’s mouth, and ten horns.
Wogblɔ le lã siwo ŋuti woƒo nu tsoe le Daniel ƒe nyagblɔɖia me ŋu be wonye fiawo alo fiaɖuƒe siwo ɖu dzi kplɔ wo nɔewo ɖo.
The beasts in Daniel’s prophecy are identified as specific kings, or political kingdoms, that rule in succession over empires.
(Daniel 7:​17, 23) Eya ta lã wɔadã si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia ta 13 la nye dunyahehabɔbɔ ƒokpli.
(Daniel 7:​17, 23) Thus, the wild beast of Revelation chapter 13 represents a composite political organization.
Edo go "tso atsiaƒu me, " esia fia be etso amegbetɔƒomea me tɔ siwo nye agbodzelawo, siwo gbɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo tsona la me.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1; Yesaya 17:12, 13.
It ascends "out of the sea, " that is, from the turbulent masses of mankind that are the source of human governments.​ Revelation 13:1; Isaiah 17:12, 13.
Biblia gblɔ be lã wɔadã la ƒe xexlẽdzesi alo eƒe ŋkɔ​ 666​ nye "ame ƒe xexlẽdzesi. "
The Bible says that the number, or name, of the beast​ 666​ is "a man’s number. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:17, 18) Nyagbɔgblɔ ma fia be lã wɔadã si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia ta 13 la nye amegbetɔwo ƒe habɔbɔ, ke menye gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo tɔe o.
(Revelation 13:17, 18) That expression indicates that the beast of Revelation chapter 13 is a human entity, not a spirit or demon entity.
Togbɔ be dukɔwo ƒe nu mesɔna le nu geɖewo me o hã la, wowɔ ɖeka heɖoe kplikpaa be yewoakpɔ yewoƒe ŋusẽa ta eye wogbe be yewomabɔbɔ ɖe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea te o.
Even though nations may agree on few things, they unite in their determination to maintain their authority rather than submit to the rule of God’s Kingdom.

(Psalmo 2:2) Dukɔwo aƒo woƒe aʋakɔwo hã nu ƒu be yewoawɔ aʋa kple Mawu ƒe aʋakɔ si anɔ Yesu Kristo ƒe kpɔkplɔ te la le Armagedon me, gake woatsrɔ̃ dukɔawo le aʋa sia me.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14, 16; 19:19, 20.
(Psalm 2:2) They will also join forces to battle God’s armies commanded by Jesus Christ at Armageddon, but this war will result in the nations being destroyed.​ Revelation 16:14, 16; 19:19, 20.
"Dzo ewo kple ta adre "
"Ten horns and seven heads "
Wozãa xexlẽdzesi aɖewo le kpɔɖeŋumɔ nu le Biblia me.
Certain numbers are used symbolically in the Bible.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, xexlẽdzesi siwo nye ewo kple adre fiaa blibonyenye.
For example, ten and seven represent completeness.

Nu vevi si akpe ɖe mía ŋu míase nu si tututu Nyaɖeɖefia ta 13 me lã wɔadã ƒe "dzo ewo kple ta adre " fia lae nye "lã wɔadã la ƒe legba " si ŋu wova ƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me​ ebiã helĩhelĩ eye ta adre kple dzo ewo li nɛ.

The key to understanding the specific meaning of the "ten horns and seven heads " of the beast of Revelation chapter 13 is an "image of the wild beast " identified later in Revelation​ a bright-red beast that has seven heads and ten horns.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1, 14, 15; 17:3) Biblia gblɔ be lã wɔadã dzĩ sia ƒe ta adreawo le tsitre ɖi na "fia adre " alo dziɖuɖu adre.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:9, 10.
(Revelation 13:​1, 14, 15; 17:3) The Bible says that the seven heads of this red beast mean "seven kings, " or governments.​ Revelation 17:​9, 10.

Nenema ke lã wɔadã si to ta adre si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1 la hã le tsitre ɖi na dziɖuɖu adre. Wonye fiaɖuƒe vevitɔ siwo ɖu dzi le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya me eye woxɔ ŋgɔ le Mawu ƒe amewo tete ɖe anyi me. Woawoe nye Egipte, Asiria, Babilon, Medo-Persia, Hela, Roma kple Anglo-Amerika.

Likewise, the seven heads of the beast of Revelation 13:1 represent seven governments: the primary political powers that have dominated through history and have taken the lead in oppressing God’s people​ Egypt, Assyria, Babylon, Medo-Persia, Greece, Rome, and Anglo-America.

Ne míeƒo nya ta be dzo ewoawo le tsitre ɖi na dziɖuɖu nɔɖokuisiwo katã, gãwo kple sueawo siaa la, ekema fiakuku siwo le dzoawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋu ɖee fia be dukɔawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kple fiaɖuƒe vevitɔ si le woƒe ɣeyiɣia me la ɖua dzi le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me.

If we conclude that the ten horns represent all sovereign states, small and large, then the diadem, or crown, on each horn shows that each nation rules concurrently with the primary political power of the time.
Nu Kae Lã Wɔadã Si Biã Helĩhelĩ Si Ŋuti Woƒo Nu Tsoe Le Nyaɖeɖefia Ta 17 La Nye?
What Is the Scarlet-Colored Beast of Revelation Chapter 17?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ si ŋuti woƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia Ta 17 le tsitre ɖi na habɔbɔ aɖe si ƒe taɖodzinue nye be yeana dukɔ siwo katã le anyigba dzi nawɔ ɖeka eye yeanye woƒe teƒenɔla.
The scarlet-colored beast, described in Revelation chapter 17, is a symbol of the organization whose purpose is to unite and represent the nations of the world.
Tsã la, eyae nye Dukɔwo ƒe Nubabla, gake eyae va zu Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo egbea.
It first existed as the League of Nations and is now the United Nations.
Ale si nàwɔ akpɔ lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la adze sii
Keys to identifying the scarlet-colored beast
Dunyahehe ƒe habɔbɔ.
A political entity.
‘Ta adre’ le lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la si, eye mawunyakpukpuia gblɔ be ta siawo le tsitre ɖi na "to adre " kple "fia adre " alo xexemedziɖuɖu sesẽ adre.
The scarlet-colored beast has "seven heads " that are said to represent "seven mountains " and "seven kings, " or ruling powers.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:9, 10) Wozãa towo kple lã wɔadãwo le Biblia me wole tsitre ɖi na dziɖuɖuwo.​ Yeremiya 51:24, 25; Daniel 2:44, 45; 7:17, 23.
(Revelation 17:​9, 10) Mountains and beasts are used in the Bible as symbols of governments.​ Jeremiah 51:24, 25; Daniel 2:​44, 45; 7:​17, 23.
Eɖi xexea me dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyia.
A likeness of the worldwide political system.
Lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la ɖi lã wɔadã si to ta adre si ŋuti woƒo nu tsoe le Nyaɖeɖefia ta 13 me, si le tsitre ɖi na xexea me ƒe dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyiawo.
The scarlet-colored beast resembles the seven-headed beast of Revelation chapter 13, which represents the worldwide political system.
Lã evea siaa to ta adre kple dzo ewo, eye busuŋkɔwo le wo ŋu.
Both beasts have seven heads, ten horns, and blasphemous names.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1; 17:3) Woɖi wo nɔewo ale gbegbe be womate ŋu agblɔ be nu dogoɖenunue o.
(Revelation 13:1; 17:3) These similarities are too striking to be a coincidence.
Lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la nye lã wɔadã la ƒe legba alo eƒe nɔnɔmewɔwɔ, si le tsitre ɖi na xexea me dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyia.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 13:15.
The scarlet-colored beast is an image, or likeness, of the worldwide political system.​ Revelation 13:15.
Exɔ ŋusẽ tso fia bubuwo gbɔ.
Power from other rulerships.
Lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la ‘do tso’ alo dzɔ tso fiaɖuƒe bubuwo me.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:11, 17.
The scarlet-colored beast "springs from, " or owes its existence to, other ruling forces.​ Revelation 17:11, 17.
Edo ka kple subɔsubɔhawo.
Linked with religion.
Babilon Gã la, si nye alakpasubɔsubɔha siwo katã le xexea me, bɔbɔ nɔ lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ la dzi, eye esia ɖee fia be subɔsubɔhawo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe lã sia dzi.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:3-5.
Babylon the Great, the world’s collective body of false religions, sits on the scarlet-colored beast, showing that the beast is influenced by religious groups.​ Revelation 17:​3-5.
Edoa vlo Mawu.
Dishonors God.
"Busuŋkɔwo " yɔ lã la ŋuti fũu. Nyaɖeɖefia 17:3.
The beast is "full of blasphemous names. "​ Revelation 17:3.
Adzudzɔ dɔwɔwɔ sẽe.
Temporarily inactive.
Woadee "aʋli me " alo adzudzɔ dɔwɔwɔ sẽe, gake agado ake.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:8.
The scarlet-colored beast would be in "the abyss, " or inactive, for a time but would rise again.​ Revelation 17:8.
Biblia me nyagblɔɖiawo va eme
Bible prophecy fulfilled
Kpɔ ale si Dukɔwo ƒe Nubabla kple Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo si va kplɔe ɖo la ƒe ŋutinya ɖo kpe edzi be Biblia me nyagblɔɖi si ku ɖe lã wɔadã si biã helĩhelĩ ŋu va eme la ɖa.
Consider how the United Nations and its predecessor, the League of Nations, have fulfilled the Bible’s prophecy of the scarlet-colored beast.
Dunyahehe ƒe habɔbɔ.
A political entity.
Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo de dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyi dzi to ale si wòna "dziɖuŋusẽ ƒe sɔsɔminasɔe Emetɔwo katã " me.
The United Nations supports the political system by upholding "the sovereign equality of all its Members. "
Eɖi xexea me dunyahehe ƒe nuɖoanyia.
A likeness of the worldwide political system.
Le ƒe 2011 me la, Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo gblɔ be dukɔ yeye aɖe va ɖo ye me, esiae nye dukɔ 193 lia.
In 2011, the United Nations added its 193rd member state.
Eya ta etea ŋu ƒoa adegbe be yee le dukɔwo kple anyigbadzinɔla akpa gãtɔ teƒe.
Thus, it claims to represent the vast majority of nations and peoples in the world.
Exɔ ŋusẽ tso fia bubuwo gbɔ.
Power from other rulerships.
Dukɔ siwo le Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo mee na wòli, ŋusẽ agbɔsɔsɔme si dukɔ siawo nɛ la koe nye ŋusẽ si katã le esi.
The United Nations owes its existence to its member nations and has only as much power and authority as they grant to it.
Edo ka kple subɔsubɔhawo.
Linked with religion.
Xexea me ƒe subɔsubɔhawo doa alɔ Dukɔwo ƒe Nubabla kple Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo siaa ɖaa.
Both the League of Nations and the United Nations have consistently received the backing of the world’s religions.
Edoa vlo Mawu.
Dishonors God.
Woɖo Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo anyi be wòana "ŋutifafa kple dedienɔnɔ nanɔ dukɔwo dome. "
The United Nations was established "to maintain international peace and security. "
Togbɔ be adze abe taɖodzinu nyui aɖee nye esia ene hã la, ɖe Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo doa vlo Mawu to asiƒuƒu akɔ be yeawɔ nu si Mawu gblɔ be yeƒe Fiaɖuƒea ɖeka ko nava wɔ la.​ Psalmo 46:9; Daniel 2:​44.
While this goal might seem to be praiseworthy, the UN actually dishonors God by claiming to do what he has said only his Kingdom will accomplish.​ Psalm 46:9; Daniel 2:​44.
Adzudzɔ dɔwɔwɔ sẽe.
Temporarily inactive.
Dukɔwo ƒe Nubabla si woɖo anyi le Xexemeʋa I megbe kpuie be wòakpɔ ŋutifafa ta la mete ŋu wɔe be dukɔwo medze wo nɔewo dzi o.
The League of Nations, which was formed shortly after World War I to maintain peace, was unable to prevent international aggression.
Edzudzɔ dɔwɔwɔ esime Xexemeʋa II dze egɔme le ƒe 1939 me.
It ceased to function when World War II began in 1939.
Esi Xexemeʋa II wu enu le ƒe 1945 me la, woɖo Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo anyi.
In 1945, after World War II ended, the United Nations was formed.
Eƒe taɖodzinuwo, nyawo gbɔ kpɔkpɔ kple eƒe ɖoɖowo sɔ kple Dukɔwo ƒe Nubabla tɔ ale gbegbe.
Its purposes, methods, and structure closely resemble those of the League of Nations.
Nu Kae 666 Fia?
What Does 666 Mean?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Le Biblia-gbalẽ mamlɛtɔ ƒe nya nu la, 666 nye lã wɔadã aɖe ƒe xexlẽdzesi alo ŋkɔ. Wokpɔ lã wɔadã sia si si ta adre le eye wòto dzo ewo la do tso atsiaƒu me.
According to the last book in the Bible, 666 is the number, or name, of the wild beast with seven heads and ten horns that comes out of the sea.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:1, 17, 18) Lã sia le tsitre ɖi na xexea me ƒe dunyahenuɖoanyi siwo ɖua "to sia to kple ame ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi kple gbegbɔgblɔ sia gbegbɔgblɔ kpakple dukɔ sia dukɔ dzi. "
(Revelation 13:​1, 17, 18) This beast is a symbol of the worldwide political system, which rules over "every tribe and people and tongue and nation. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:7) Ŋkɔ 666 ɖee fia be dunyahenuɖoanyi siawo do kpo nu kura le Mawu ŋkume.
(Revelation 13:7) The name 666 identifies the political system as a gross failure in God’s sight.
Le mɔ ka nu?
How?
Menye dzesi dzro aɖe koe o.
More than a label.
Gɔmesese nɔa ŋkɔ siwo Mawu naa amewo kple nuwo la si.
Names given by God have meaning.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mawu na ŋkɔ Abram, si gɔmee nye "Fofo Le Kɔkɔƒe (Wodoe Ðe Dzi) " be Abraham, si gɔmee nye "Amehawo Fofo (Ame Geɖewo Fofo) " esime Mawu do ŋugbe nɛ be yeana wòazu "dukɔ geɖewo fofo. " (1 Mose 17:5, etenuŋɔŋlɔ) Nenema ke Mawu na ŋkɔ 666 lã wɔadã la tsɔ fia nane koŋ tso eƒe nɔnɔme ŋu.

For example, God gave the man Abram, which means "Father Is High (Exalted), " the name Abraham, which means "Father of a Crowd (Multitude), " when God promised that He would make Abraham "a father of many nations. " (Genesis 17:5, footnotes) Likewise, God named the beast 666 as a symbol of its defining attributes.
Xexlẽdzesi ade fia blibomademade.
The number six implies imperfection.
Zi geɖe la, wozãa xexlẽdzesiwo le kpɔɖeŋumɔ nu le Biblia me.
Often, numbers are used as symbols in the Bible.
Xexlẽdzesi si nye adre fiaa nu si de keŋkeŋ alo de blibo.
Seven typically represents completeness or perfection.
Ade, si nye ɖeka to le adre me, fiaa nu si mede blibo o alo do kpo nu le Mawu ŋkume, eye wotea ŋu zãnɛ hã tsɔ doa ƒome kple Mawu ƒe futɔwo.​ 1 Kronika 20:6; Daniel 3:1.
Six, being one short of seven, can denote something incomplete or flawed in God’s eyes, and it can be associated with God’s enemies.​ 1 Chronicles 20:6; Daniel 3:1.
Wogblɔe zi etɔ̃ tsɔ te gbe ɖe edzi.
Three times for emphasis.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, wogblɔa nyawo zi etɔ̃ le Biblia me tsɔ tea gbe ɖe nyaa dzi.
The Bible sometimes stresses a matter by stating it three times.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 4:8; 8:13) Eya ta ŋkɔ 666 te gbe ɖe ale si Mawu bua amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo be wodo kpo nu keŋkeŋ la dzi.
(Revelation 4:8; 8:​13) So the name 666 powerfully emphasizes that God views human political systems as gross failures.
Womete ŋu he ŋutifafa kple dedienɔnɔ mavɔ vɛ o. Mawu Fiaɖuƒea koe ahe nu siawo vɛ.
They have been unable to bring lasting peace and security​ things that only God’s Kingdom will achieve.
Lã wɔadã la ƒe dzesi
The mark of the beast
Biblia gblɔ be amewo xɔ "lã wɔadã la ƒe dzesi, " elabena "wodze lã la yome " hede ta agu nɛ.
The Bible says that people receive "the mark of the wild beast " because they follow it "with admiration, " to the point of worshipping it.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:3, 4; 16:2) Wowɔa esia ne wode ta agu na woƒe dukɔa, eƒe dzesiwo kple eƒe aʋawɔŋusẽwo.
(Revelation 13:​3, 4; 16:2) They do this by giving worshipful honor to their country, its symbols, or its military might.
Numekugbalẽ aɖe (The Encyclopedia of Religion) gblɔ be: "Dulɔlɔ̃ va zu subɔsubɔmɔnu vevitɔ le egbexexea me. "
As The Encyclopedia of Religion states: "Nationalism has become a dominant form of religion in the modern world. "
Aleke ame xɔa lã wɔadã la ƒe dzesia ɖe eƒe nuɖusi alo ŋgonu?
How is the mark of the beast placed on someone’s right hand or forehead?

(Nyaɖeɖefia 13:16) Mawu gblɔ tso se siwo wòde na Israel-dukɔa ŋu be: "Mibla wo ɖe miaƒe asi ŋu abe ŋkuɖodzinu ene, eye woanɔ abe ŋgoblanu ene le miaƒe ŋgonu. " (5 Mose 11:18) Esia mefia be Israel-viwo nade dzesi woƒe asiwo ŋu kple ŋgonu ŋutɔŋutɔ o, ke boŋ nu si wòfiae nye be Mawu ƒe nyawo nafia mɔ wo le woƒe nuwɔnawo kple woƒe tamesusuwo katã me.

(Revelation 13:16) Regarding his commands to the nation of Israel, God said: "Bind them as a reminder on your hand, and they should be like a headband on your forehead. " (Deuteronomy 11:18) This meant, not that the Israelites were to mark their literal hands and foreheads, but that God’s words would guide all their actions and thoughts.
Nenema ke mefia be ame siwo dea ta agu na lã la taa 666 ɖe ŋuti ŋutɔŋutɔ o, ke boŋ nu si dzesia fia le ame siawo ŋu le kpɔɖeŋumɔ nue nye be woɖe mɔ xexe sia me dziɖuɖuwo kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe woƒe agbe dzi.
Likewise, rather than being something literal such as a 666 tattoo, the mark of the beast symbolically identifies those who let the political system rule their lives.
Ame siwo xɔ lã ƒe dzesia la tsi tre ɖe Mawu ŋu.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 14:9, 10; 19:19-21.
Those with the mark of the beast place themselves in opposition to God.​ Revelation 14:​9, 10; 19:19-​21.
Nu Kae Nye Babilon Gã La?
What Is Babylon the Great?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Babilon Gã si woɖɔ le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me la le tsitre ɖi na xexea me ƒe alakpasubɔsubɔhawo katã ƒe ƒuƒoƒo, eye Mawu lé fui.
Babylon the Great, described in the book of Revelation, is the world’s collective body of false religions, which God rejects.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 14:8; 17:5; 18:21) Togbɔ be subɔsubɔha siawo to vovo tso wo nɔewo gbɔ le mɔ geɖewo nu hã la, wo katã wokplɔa amewo tranae ale be womagasubɔ Yehowa, Mawu vavã la o.​ 5 Mose 4:35.
(Revelation 14:8; 17:5; 18:21) Although those religions differ in many respects, in one way or another they all lead people away from the worship of the true God, Jehovah.​ Deuteronomy 4:​35.
Nu siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàde dzesi Babilon Gã la
Keys to identifying Babylon the Great
Babilon Gã la nye dzesi.
Babylon the Great is a symbol.

Biblia ɖɔe be enye "nyɔnu " eye wònye "gbolo gã " eye ŋkɔ si nye "nya ɣaɣla " le esi, eyae nye "Babilon Gã la. " (Nyaɖeɖefia 17:1, 3, 5) Esi wònye be ɖe woɖe Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me nyawo fia to "dzesiwo me " ta la, esɔ be míaƒo nya ta be menye nyɔnu ŋutɔŋutɔe Babilon Gã la nye o, ke nane ƒe dzesi ko wònye.

The Bible describes her as "a woman " and a "great prostitute, " having a name that is "a mystery: ‘Babylon the Great.’ " (Revelation 17:​1, 3, 5) The book of Revelation is presented "in signs, " so it is reasonable to conclude that Babylon the Great is a symbol, not a literal woman.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 1:1) Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, ‘ebɔbɔ nɔ tsi geɖewo dzi,’ si tsi tre ɖi na "amewo kple amehawo kple dukɔwo kpakple gbegbɔgblɔwo. "
(Revelation 1:1) In addition, she "sits on many waters, " which represent "peoples and crowds and nations and tongues. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:1, 15) Nyɔnu ŋutɔŋutɔ mate ŋu awɔ nu sia o.
(Revelation 17:​1, 15) A literal woman could not do that.
Babilon Gã la le tsitre ɖi na xexea me katã ƒe nuɖoanyi aɖe.
Babylon the Great represents an international entity.
Woyɔe be "du gã, si ƒe fiaɖuƒe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe anyigbadzifiawo dzi. "
She is called "the great city that has a kingdom over the kings of the earth. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:18) Esia fia be ekeke ta eye eƒe ŋusẽkpɔɖeamedzi de du.
(Revelation 17:18) Thus, she has international scope and influence.
Babilon Gã la nye subɔsubɔhabɔbɔ, ke menye dunyaheha alo asitsaha o.
Babylon the Great is a religious entity, not a political or commercial one.
Blema Babilon nye du si xɔ ŋkɔ le subɔsubɔnyawo me, wonyae ɖe eƒe "gbesawo " kple eƒe "dzosasa geɖeawo " ta.
Ancient Babylon was a profoundly religious city, known for its use of spiritistic "spells " and "sorceries. "
(Yesaya 47:1, 12, 13; Yeremiya 50:1, 2, 38) Alakpasubɔsubɔ si Mawu vavã, Yehowa, lé fui la yi edzi le du ma me.
(Isaiah 47:​1, 12, 13; Jeremiah 50:​1, 2, 38) In fact, false religion in opposition to the true God, Jehovah, was practiced there.
(1 Mose 10:8, 9; 11:2-4, 8) Babilon-fiawo do wo ɖokuiwo ɖe dzi ɖe Yehowa ŋu eye wotsi tre ɖe eƒe subɔsubɔ ŋu.
(Genesis 10:​8, 9; 11:​2-4, 8) The rulers of Babylon arrogantly exalted themselves above Jehovah and his worship.
(Yesaya 14:4, 13, 14; Daniel 5:2-4, 23) Nenema kee wonya Babilon Gã la hã ɖe eƒe "gbɔgbɔyɔnuwɔnawo " ta.
(Isaiah 14:​4, 13, 14; Daniel 5:​2-4, 23) Likewise, Babylon the Great is known for her "spiritistic practices. "
Esia ɖee fia be enye subɔsubɔhabɔbɔ.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 18:23.
That shows her to be a religious organization.​ Revelation 18:23.
Babilon Gã la menye dunyahehabɔbɔ o, elabena Biblia gblɔ be, "anyigbadzifiawo " xa nu esi wotsrɔ̃e.
Babylon the Great cannot be a political entity, because "the kings of the earth " mourn her destruction.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:1, 2; 18:9) Menye asitsahabɔbɔ hãe wònye o, elabena Biblia me nyawo ɖee fia be eto vovo na "anyigbadzisitsalawo. "​ Nyaɖeɖefia 18:11, 15.
(Revelation 17:​1, 2; 18:9) Neither is she a commercial power, because the Bible distinguishes her from "the merchants of the earth. "​ Revelation 18:11, 15.
Babilon Fia Nabonido ƒe Kpetata si dzi mawuetɔ̃ƒokpli siwo nye Sin, Istar, kple Samas ƒe tata le
Stela of Babylonian King Nabonidus with symbols of the triad of gods Sin, Ishtar, and Shamash
Babilon Fia Nabonido ƒe Kpetata si dzi mawuetɔ̃ƒokpli siwo nye Sin, Istar, kple Samas ƒe tata le
Stela of Babylonian King Nabonidus with symbols of the triad of gods Sin, Ishtar, and Shamash
Ale si woɖɔ Babilon Gã la sɔ kple alakpasubɔsubɔhawo pɛpɛpɛ.
Babylon the Great fits the profile of false religion.
Le esi woafia amewo ale si woawɔ ate ɖe Mawu vavã, Yehowa, ŋu teƒe la, ɖe wonana amewo subɔa mawu bubuwo boŋ.
Rather than teaching people how to draw closer to the true God, Jehovah, false religion actually leads them to worship other gods.

Biblia yɔ nuwɔna sia be "gbɔgbɔmehasi. " (3 Mose 20:6; 2 Mose 34:15, 16) Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ alo Trinita Kɔkɔe kple luʋɔ makumaku ƒe nufiafiawo kpakple nuwɔnawo abe nɔnɔmewɔwɔwo zazã le subɔsubɔ me la dzɔ tso blema Babilon, eye woyi edzi xɔ aƒe ɖe alakpasubɔsubɔhawo me.

The Bible calls this "spiritual prostitution. " (Leviticus 20:6; Exodus 34:15, 16) Beliefs such as the Trinity and the immortality of the soul and practices such as the use of images in worship date back to ancient Babylon and continue to permeate false religion.
Xexea me nuwo lɔlɔ̃ hã xɔ aƒe ɖe wo me.
These religions also blend their worship with love for the world.
Biblia yɔ nuteƒemawɔmawɔ sia tɔgbi be gbɔgbɔmehasiwɔwɔ.​ Yakobo 4:4.
The Bible refers to this form of unfaithfulness as spiritual adultery.​ James 4:4.
Biblia ɖɔ Babilon Gã la be ‘edo aɖabɛwu kple awu dzĩ’ eye "wòtsɔ sika kple kpe xɔasiwo kple dzonuwo ɖo atsyɔ̃ na eɖokui, " si ɖe eƒe kesinɔtɔnyenye fia. Alea kee wòle le alakpasubɔsubɔhawo hã gome.

False religion’s wealth and showy display of it match the picture that the Bible paints of Babylon the Great, who is "clothed in purple and scarlet " and "adorned with gold and precious stones and pearls. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:4) Babilon Gã la mee "anyigbadziŋunyɔnuwo " alo nufiafia kple nuwɔna siwo katã medea bubu Mawu ŋu o la dzɔ tso.
(Revelation 17:4) Babylon the Great is the source of "the disgusting things of the earth, " or the teachings and actions that actually dishonor God.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:5) Ame siwo le alakpasubɔsubɔhawo me woe nye "amewo kple amehawo kple dukɔwo kpakple gbegbɔgblɔwo " siwo wɔ ɖeka kple Babilon Gã la.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:15.
(Revelation 17:5) The members of false religion are the "peoples and crowds and nations and tongues " who support Babylon the Great.​ Revelation 17:15.
Babilon Gã lae le megbe na "ame siwo katã wowu le anyigba dzi la. "
Babylon the Great is responsible for the deaths "of all those who have been slaughtered on the earth. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 18:24) Le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya me la, alakpasubɔsubɔhawo da megbe na aʋawɔwɔ kple nu vlo wɔwɔwo, eye womefiaa woƒe hameviwo nyateƒe si ku ɖe Yehowa si nye lɔlɔ̃ Mawu la ŋu o.
(Revelation 18:24) Throughout history, false religion has not only fomented wars and fueled acts of terrorism but has also failed to teach people the truth about Jehovah, the God of love.
(1 Yohanes 4:8) Esia na wokɔ ʋu geɖe ɖi.
(1 John 4:8) This failure has contributed to much bloodshed.
Eya ta esɔ be ame siwo katã di be yewoadze Mawu ŋu la ‘nado go le’ Babilon Gã la me, si fia be woaɖe wo ɖokuiwo ɖa tso alakpasubɔsubɔhawo gbɔ.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 18:4; 2 Korintotɔwo 6:14-17.
For good reason, those who want to please God must "get out of her, " separating themselves from false religion.​ Revelation 18:4; 2 Corinthians 6:​14-​17.
Nu Kae Nye ‘Dzota’ La?
What Is the Lake of Fire?
Eya Kee Nye Dzo Mavɔ Alo Gehena?
Is It the Same as Hell or Gehenna?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Dzota nye kpɔɖeŋu na tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ.
The lake of fire is a symbol of eternal destruction.
Esɔ kple Gehena, gake eto vovo na tsiẽƒe si gɔme woɖena le Biblia aɖewo me be dzo mavɔ.
It is the same as Gehenna, but it is different from hell, which is the common grave of mankind.
Menye ta ŋutɔŋutɔe o
Not a literal lake
Mawunyakpukpui atɔ̃ siwo me "dzota " dze le la ɖee fia be menye ta ŋutɔŋutɔe o, ke boŋ kpɔɖeŋumɔ nue wozãe le.
The five Bible verses that mention "the lake of fire " show it to be a symbol rather than a literal lake.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:20; 20:10, 14, 15; 21:8) Wotsɔ nu vovovo siawo ƒu gbe ɖe dzota la me:
(Revelation 19:20; 20:10, 14, 15; 21:8) The following are cast into the lake of fire:
Abosam.
The Devil.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:10) Esi wònye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔe Abosam nye ta la, dzo ŋutɔŋutɔ mate ŋu afiãe o.​ 2 Mose 3:2; Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 13:20.
(Revelation 20:10) As a spirit creature, the Devil cannot be harmed by literal fire.​ Exodus 3:2; Judges 13:20.
Ku.
Death.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:14) Menye ŋutilãmenue ku nye o, efia dɔmawɔmawɔ alo agbemanɔmanɔ.(Nyagblɔla 9:10) Dzo mate ŋu afiã ku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
(Revelation 20:14) This is not a literal entity but represents a state of inactivity, the absence of life. (Ecclesiastes 9:​10) Death cannot literally be burned.
"Lã wɔadã la kple aʋatsonyagblɔɖila. "
"The wild beast " and "the false prophet. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:20) Esi wònye be kpɔɖeŋunuwoe nu siawo nye ta la, ɖe susu mele be míaƒo nya ta be kpɔɖeŋunue dzota si me wotsɔ wo ƒu gbe ɖo la hã nye oa?​ Nyaɖeɖefia 13:11, 12; 16:13.
(Revelation 19:20) Since these are symbols, doesn’t it seem reasonable to conclude that the lake they are thrown into is also a symbol?​ Revelation 13:11, 12; 16:13.
Etsi tsitre ɖi na tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ
A symbol of eternal destruction
Biblia gblɔ be dzota la "le tsitre ɖi na ku evelia. "
The Bible says that the lake of fire "means the second death. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:14; 21:8) Ku gbãtɔ si ŋu woƒo nu tsoe le Biblia me lae nye ku si Adam ƒe nu vɔ̃ he va mía dzi eye woate ŋu aɖe amewo tso ku sia me to tsitretsitsia dzi.
(Revelation 20:14; 21:8) The first kind of death mentioned in the Bible resulted from Adam’s sin.
Eye Mawu ava ɖe ku sia ɖa mlɔeba.​ 1 Korintotɔwo 15:21, 22, 26.
This death can be reversed by resurrection and will eventually be eliminated by God.​ 1 Corinthians 15:21, 22, 26.
Womete ŋu aɖe ame tso kpɔɖeŋudzota la me o
There is no release from the symbolic lake of fire
Dzota ya le tsitre ɖi na ku ƒomevi bubu alo ku evelia.
The lake of fire represents a different, or second, kind of death.
Togbɔ be eya hã nye agbemanɔmanɔ keŋkeŋ ƒe nɔnɔme hã la, eto vovo sãsãsã na gbãtɔa, elabena Biblia megblɔ nya aɖeke tso tsitretsitsi tso ku sia me ŋu o.
Although it too represents a state of total inactivity, it is different in that the Bible says nothing about a resurrection from the second death.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔ be "ku kple Tsiẽƒe ƒe safuiwo le " Yesu si, eye esia ɖee fia be ŋusẽ le esi be wòafɔ ame siwo ku le Adam ƒe nu vɔ̃a ta la.
For example, the Bible says that Jesus has "the keys of hell and of death, " showing that he has the authority to release people from the death brought by Adam’s sin.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 1:18; 20:13) Ke hã, dzota ya ƒe safui mele Yesu loo alo ame bubu aɖeke si o.
(Revelation 1:​18; 20:13, King James Version) However, neither Jesus nor anyone else has a key to the lake of fire.
Kpɔɖeŋudzota sia le tsitre ɖi na tohehe mavɔ si nye tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ.​ 2 Tesalonikatɔwo 1:9.
That symbolic lake represents eternal punishment in the form of permanent destruction.​ 2 Thessalonians 1:9.
Dzota la kee nye Gehena, si gɔmee nye Hinom Bali
Identical to Gehenna, the Valley of Hinnom
Nya Gehena (Helagbe, geenna) dze le Biblia me zi 12 sɔŋ.
Gehenna (Greek geenna) is mentioned 12 times in the Bible.
Eya hã nye tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ, abe ale si wòle le dzota gome ene.
Like the lake of fire, it is a symbol of eternal destruction.
Togbɔ be woɖe nya sia gɔme le Biblia aɖewo me be "dzo mavɔ " (tsiẽƒe) hã la, Gehena to vovo na tsiẽƒe (Hebrigbe sheohl, Helagbe haides).
Although some translations render this word as "hell, " Gehenna is different from hell (Hebrew sheohl, Greek haides).
Blema Hinom Bali si nɔ Yerusalem-dua godo si me dzo nɔa bibim le ɖaa
The ancient valley of Hinnom outside the wall of Jerusalem with a fire constantly burning
Hinom Bali
The Valley of Hinnom
"Gehena " ƒe gɔmeɖeɖe tẽe nye "Hinom Bali, " si nye bali aɖe le Yerusalem-dua godo tututu.
The word "Gehenna " literally means "Valley of Hinnom, " referring to a valley just outside Jerusalem.
Le Biblia-ŋlɔɣiwo la, dua me tɔwo kɔa gbeɖuɖɔ le balia me.
In Bible times, the city residents used this valley as a garbage dump.
Wona dzo nɔa bibim le afi ma ɣesiaɣi ale be gbeɖuɖɔwo nabi; eye nyéwo ɖua nu siwo dzoa mete ŋu fiã o.
They kept a fire constantly burning there to destroy refuse; maggots consumed anything that the fire did not reach.
Yesu zã Gehena tsɔ wɔ kpɔɖeŋu na tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ.
Jesus used Gehenna as a symbol of everlasting destruction.
(Mateo 23:33) Egblɔ be "nyéwo mekuna " le Gehena o, "eye dzo metsina " le afi ma o.
(Matthew 23:33) He said that in Gehenna "the maggot does not die and the fire is not put out. "

(Marko 9:47, 48) Eto nya siawo dzi le nu ƒom tso nu siwo yia edzi le Hinom Bali la me kple nyagblɔɖi si le Yesaya 66:24 me hã ŋu. Mawunyakpukpui ma gblɔ be: "Woado ayi aɖakpɔ ame siwo da vo ɖe ŋunye la ƒe kukuawo; elabena woƒe nyéwo maku o, eye woƒe dzo la matsi o. "

(Mark 9:​47, 48) He thus alluded to the conditions in the Valley of Hinnom and also to the prophecy at Isaiah 66:24, which says: "They will go out and look on the carcasses of the men who rebelled against me; for the worms on them will not die, and their fire will not be extinguished. "
Yesu ƒe kpɔɖeŋu sia mefia funyafunyawɔwɔ ame o, ke boŋ tsɔtsrɔ̃ ɖikaa.
Jesus’ illustration describes, not torture, but complete annihilation.
Ŋutilã kukuwo domee dzo kple nyéwo gblẽna, menye ame gbagbewo o.
The worms and fire consume carcasses, or dead bodies, not living people.
Biblia megblɔ nya aɖeke si fia be ame siwo yi Gehena la ate ŋu afɔ o.
The Bible gives no indication of any return from Gehenna.
"Dzota " la kple "Gehena ƒe dzo la " siaa le tsitre ɖi na tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ. Nyaɖeɖefia 20:14, 15; 21:8; Mateo 18:9.
"The lake of fire " and "the fiery Gehenna " both represent permanent, everlasting destruction.​ Revelation 20:14, 15; 21:8; Matthew 18:9.
Aleke "woawɔ fu wo zã kple keli tegbetegbee "?
How "tormented day and night forever and ever "?
Ne tsɔtsrɔ̃ koe dzota la le tsitre ɖi na ɖe, ke nu ka tae Biblia gblɔ be "woawɔ fu " Abosam, lã wɔadã la kple aʋatsonyagblɔɖila la le eme "zã kple keli tegbetegbee "?
If the lake of fire is a symbol of destruction, why does the Bible say that in it the Devil, the wild beast, and the false prophet "will be tormented day and night forever and ever "?
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:10) Na míadzro susu ene siwo tae mate ŋu anye be fuwɔwɔ ame ŋutɔŋutɔe wowɔnɛ le afi sia o la me:
(Revelation 20:10) Consider four reasons why this torment does not refer to literal torture:
Hafi woate ŋu anɔ funyafunya wɔm Abosam tegbee la, ke ahiã be wòanɔ agbe tegbee.
For the Devil to be tortured eternally, he would have to be kept alive forever.
Evɔ Biblia gblɔ be woaxɔ ŋusẽ le esi alo atsrɔ̃e ɖa keŋkeŋ.​ Hebritɔwo 2:​14.
However, the Bible says that he will be brought to nothing, or put out of existence.​ Hebrews 2:​14.
Mawu ƒe nunanae agbe mavɔ nye, menye tohehee o.​ Romatɔwo 6:​23.
Everlasting life is a gift from God, not a punishment.​ Romans 6:​23.
Kpɔɖeŋunuwoe lã wɔadã la kple aʋatsonyagblɔɖila nye, eya ta womate ŋu awɔ funyafunya wo o.
The wild beast and the false prophet are symbols and cannot experience literal torture.
Biblia me nyawo ɖee fia be funyafunya si woawɔ Abosam la tsi tsitre ɖi na mɔxexe ɖe enu alo etsɔtsrɔ̃ ɖa tegbee.
The context of the Bible indicates that the torment of the Devil is everlasting restraint or destruction.
Nyagbe "woawɔ fu " si wozã le Biblia me la agate ŋu afia "mɔxexe ɖe ame nu. "
The word used for "torment " in the Bible can also mean "a condition of restraint. "
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, woɖe Helagbe me nya si gɔmee nye "ŋutasẽlawo " gɔme le Biblia geɖewo me le Mateo 18:34 be "gaxɔdzikpɔlawo. " Esia ɖee fia be kadodo aɖe le ‘fuwɔwɔ ame’ kple "mɔxexe ɖe ame nu " dome.
For example, the Greek word for "tormentors " used at Matthew 18:34 is rendered as "jailers " in many translations, showing the connection between the words "torment " and "restraint. "
Nenema ke le Mateo 8:​29 kple Luka 8:​30, 31 siwo ƒo nu tso nudzɔdzɔ ɖeka ŋu la, wotsɔ ‘fuwɔame’ sɔ kple ‘aʋli me,’ si le tsitre ɖi na dɔmawɔmawɔ alo ku.
Likewise, the parallel accounts at Matthew 8:​29 and Luke 8:​30, 31 equate "torment " with "the abyss, " a figurative place of complete inactivity or death.
(Romatɔwo 10:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 20:1, 3) Le nyateƒe me la, wozã "woawɔ fu " alo "wɔ fu " le kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ nu le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me zi geɖe. Nyaɖeɖefia 9:5; 11:10; 18:7, 10.
(Romans 10:7; Revelation 20:​1, 3) In fact, several times the book of Revelation uses the word "torment " in a symbolic sense.​ Revelation 9:5; 11:10; 18:​7, 10.
Nu Kae Nye "Ŋkeke Mamlɛawo " Alo "Nuwuɣi " La Ƒe Dzesi?
What Is the Sign of "the Last Days, " or "End Times "?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia gblɔ nudzɔdzɔ kple nɔnɔme siwo ade dzesi "nuɖoanyi [sia] ƒe nuwuɣi " alo ɣeyiɣi siwo ado ŋgɔ na "xexea me ƒe nuwuwu " la ɖi.
The Bible describes events and conditions that would mark "the conclusion of the [current] system of things, " or "the end of the world. "

(Mateo 24:3; Eʋegbe Biblia) Biblia yɔ ɣeyiɣi sia be "ŋkeke mamlɛawo, " "nuwuwu ƒe ɣeyiɣi, " alo "nuwuɣi " la. (2 Timoteo 3:1; Daniel 8:​19; Eʋegbe Biblia) Nyagblɔɖi siwo le eme vam ku ɖe ŋkeke mamlɛawo, alo nuwuɣia, ŋu dometɔ vevi aɖewoe nye esi:

(Matthew 24:3; King James Version) The Bible calls this time period "the last days " and the "time of the end, " or "end times. " (2 Timothy 3:1; Daniel 8:​19; Easy-to-Read Version) The following are some outstanding features of last-days, or end-times, prophecies:
Aʋawɔwɔ dziŋɔwo.​ Mateo 24:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 6:4.
War on a large scale.​ Matthew 24:7; Revelation 6:4.
Dɔwuame.​ Mateo 24:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 6:​5, 6.
Famine.​ Matthew 24:7; Revelation 6:​5, 6.
Anyigbaʋuʋu gãwo.​ Luka 21:11.
Great earthquakes.​ Luke 21:11.
Dɔvɔ̃wo.​ Luka 21:11.
Pestilences, or epidemics of "terrible diseases. "​ Luke 21:11, Contemporary English Version.
Nu vlo wɔwɔ ƒe dzidziɖedzi.​ Mateo 24:12.
Increase of crime.​ Matthew 24:12.
Amegbetɔwo le anyigba la gblẽm.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 11:18.
Ruining of the earth by mankind.​ Revelation 11:18.

Amewo ƒe nɔnɔme le gbegblẽm ɖe edzi, elabena ame geɖewo nye "ame madakpewo, ame mawɔnuteƒewo, . . . ame siwo melɔ̃na ɖe ɖoɖo aɖeke dzi o, ameŋugblẽlawo, ame siwo meɖua wo ɖokuiwo dzi o, ame wɔadãwo, ame siwo melɔ̃a nu nyui o, yomemɔfialawo, totrilawo, ame siwo doa wo ɖokuiwo ɖe dzi glodzoo. "​ 2 Timoteo 3:1-4.

Deterioration of people’s attitudes, as shown by many who are "unthankful, disloyal, . . . not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride. "​ 2 Timothy 3:​1-4.
Ƒomewo le gbagbãm, elabena ƒometɔ aɖewo ‘megalɔ̃a ame ƒe nya o,’ eye ɖevi geɖe ‘megaɖoa to wo dzilawo o.’​ 2 Timoteo 3:2, 3.
Breakdown of the family, with people who have "no natural affection " and children who are "disobedient to parents. "​ 2 Timothy 3:​2, 3.
Ame akpa gãtɔ ƒe lɔlɔ̃ na Mawu yi to.​ Mateo 24:12.
Love of God growing cold in most people.​ Matthew 24:12.
Subɔsubɔhawo ƒe alakpanuwɔwɔwo le dzedzem gaglãa.​ Mateo 24:12.
Noteworthy displays of religious hypocrisy.​ 2 Timothy 3:5.
Biblia me nyagblɔɖiwo gɔmesese ɖe edzi, esiwo ku ɖe ŋkeke mamlɛawo ŋu hã le eme.​ Daniel 12:4.
Increased understanding of Bible prophecies, including those related to the last days.​ Daniel 12:4.
Gbeƒãɖeɖe Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyuia le xexea me godoo.​ Mateo 24:14.
Global preaching of the good news of the Kingdom.​ Matthew 24:14.
Ame akpa gãtɔ metsɔ ɖeke le kpeɖodzi siwo ɖee fia be nuwuwua gogo me o, eye eɖia kokoe na wo gɔ̃ hã.​ Mateo 24:37-​39; 2 Petro 3:​3, 4.
Widespread apathy and even ridicule toward the evidence of the approaching end.​ Matthew 24:37-​39; 2 Peter 3:​3, 4.
Nyagblɔɖi siawo katã le eme vam le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me, ke menye wo dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo alo wo dometɔ akpa gãtɔ ko o.​ Mateo 24:33.
The simultaneous fulfillment of all these prophecies, not just a few or even most of them.​ Matthew 24:33.
"Ŋkeke mamlɛawo " mee míele vavã?
Are we living in "the last days "?
Yes.
Nu siwo le dzɔdzɔm le xexea me kple Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubuwo ɖee fia be ŋkeke mamlɛawo dze egɔme tso ƒe 1914 me.
World conditions as well as Bible chronology indicate that the last days began in 1914.
Ɣemaɣi la, Mawu Fiaɖuƒea dze dziɖuɖu gɔme le dziƒo, eye tɔtrɔ siwo wòhe vɛ dometɔ ɖekae nye be wonya Satana Abosam kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo le dziƒo ɖo ɖe anyigba dzi.
At that time, God’s Kingdom began ruling in heaven, and one of its first actions was to expel Satan the Devil and the demons from heaven and restrict their activity to the earth.

(Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7-12) Ale si Satana le ŋusẽ kpɔm ɖe amegbetɔwo dzi egbea la dzena le woƒe nuwɔna kple nɔnɔme gbegblẽwo me, si wɔe be ŋkeke mamlɛawo nye ‘ɣeyiɣi sesẽ siwo me nɔnɔ sesẽ’ vavã.​ 2 Timoteo 3:1.
(Revelation 12:​7-​12) Satan’s influence on mankind can be seen in many of the bad attitudes and actions that make the last days "critical times hard to deal with. "​ 2 Timothy 3:1.
Nu Kae Nye Xaxa Gã La?
What Is the Great Tribulation?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia gblɔe ɖi be ɣeyiɣi sia ava le "ŋkeke mamlɛawo " alo "nuwuɣi " la me.
The great tribulation will bring the greatest time of trouble ever to come upon mankind.
(2 Timoteo 3:1; Daniel 12:4) "Anye xaxa si tɔgbi meva kpɔ tso esime Mawu wɔ xexea va se ɖe fifi o, eye etɔgbi megale vava ge ake o. "​ Marko 13:19; Daniel 12:1; Mateo 24:21, 22.

According to Bible prophecy, it will occur during "the last days, " or "the end time. " (2 Timothy 3:1; Daniel 12:4, New American Bible) It will be "a tribulation such as has not occurred from the beginning of the creation that God created until that time, and will not occur again. "​ Mark 13:19; Daniel 12:1; Matthew 24:21, 22.
Nu siwo adzɔ le xaxa gã la me
Events during the great tribulation
Alakpasubɔsubɔhawo tsɔtsrɔ̃.
Destruction of false religion.
Woatsrɔ̃ alakpasubɔsubɔhawo alɔ tsɔtsɔe wòawɔ nuku na amewo.
With surprising speed, false religion will be destroyed.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:​1, 5; 18:​9, 10, 21) Dunyaheŋusẽ siwo katã le megbe na Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo ye Mawu azã atsɔ awɔ esia.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 17:3, 15-18.
(Revelation 17:​1, 5; 18:​9, 10, 21) The political powers represented by the United Nations will carry out God’s will in taking this action.​ Revelation 17:​3, 15-​18.
Subɔsubɔha vavãtɔ dzi dzedze.
Attack on true religion.
Dukɔwo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo si woyɔ le Ezekiel ƒe ŋutega me be "Gog, si tso Magog-nyigba dzi " la adze agbagba be yeatsrɔ̃ ame siwo le subɔsubɔha vavãtɔ me.
A coalition of nations, referred to in Ezekiel’s vision as "Gog of the land of Magog, " will try to annihilate those who practice true religion.
Gake Mawu akpɔ esubɔlawo ta tso tsɔtsrɔ̃ ma me.​ Ezekiel 38:​1, 2, 9-​12, 18-​23.
However, God will protect his worshippers from destruction.​ Ezekiel 38:​1, 2, 9-​12, 18-​23.
Ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ anyigbadzinɔlawo.
Judgment of earth’s inhabitants.
Yesu adrɔ̃ ʋɔnu amewo katã, eye "wòama amewo me tso wo nɔewo gbɔ, abe ale si alẽkplɔla maa alẽwo tso gbɔ̃wo gbɔe ene. "
Jesus will judge all mankind and "will separate people one from another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats. "
(Mateo 25:31-​33) Nu si dzi Yesu anɔ te ɖo adrɔ̃ ʋɔnu amee nye nenye be amea na kpekpeɖeŋu ‘nɔviawo,’ siwo nye ame siwo aɖu fia kplii le dziƒo, alo mena kpekpeɖeŋu wo o.​ Mateo 25:34-​46.
(Matthew 25:31-​33) The basis for his judgment will be the support, or lack of support, that each person gave to Jesus’ "brothers, " those who will rule with him in heaven.​ Matthew 25:34-​46.
Ame siwo aɖu dzi le Fiaɖuƒea me nu ƒoƒo ƒu.
Gathering of Kingdom rulers.
Nuteƒewɔla siwo wotia be woaɖu fia kple Kristo la awu woƒe anyigbadzigbenɔnɔ nu eye woafɔ wo ɖe tsitre woayi dziƒo.​ Mateo 24:31; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:50-53; 1 Tesalonikatɔwo 4:15-17.
Faithful ones who have been chosen to rule with Christ will finish their earthly course and be resurrected to life in heaven.​ Matthew 24:31; 1 Corinthians 15:50-​53; 1 Thessalonians 4:​15-​17.
Armagedon.
Armageddon.
Wogayɔ "Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la ƒe ŋkeke gã la ƒe aʋawɔwɔ " la be "Yehowa ƒe ŋkeke la. "
This "war of the great day of God the Almighty " is also called "the day of Jehovah. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14, 16; Yesaya 13:9; 2 Petro 3:12) Kristo atsrɔ̃ ame siwo woabu fɔ le ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ mamlɛa me.
(Revelation 16:14, 16; Isaiah 13:9; 2 Peter 3:​12) Those judged adversely by Christ will be destroyed.
(Zefaniya 1:18; 2 Tesalonikatɔwo 1:6-10) Esiawo dometɔ aɖee nye xexea me katã ƒe dunyahenuɖoanyia, si woɖɔ le Biblia me be lã wɔadã si ta adre li na la.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 19:19-​21.
(Zephaniah 1:​18; 2 Thessalonians 1:​6-​10) This will include the destruction of the worldwide political system, pictured in the Bible by a seven-headed wild beast.​ Revelation 19:19-​21.
Nu siwo adzɔ le xaxa gã la megbe
Events after the great tribulation
Satana kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo lelé ade aʋli me.
Confinement of Satan and the demons.
Mawudɔla sẽŋu aɖe alé Satana kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ade "aʋli me, " si fia dɔmawɔmawɔ ƒe nɔnɔme si sɔ kple ku.
A great angel will hurl Satan and the demons "into the abyss, " a symbol of deathlike inactivity.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:​1-3) Woate ŋu atsɔ nɔnɔme si me Satana anɔ le aʋlia me asɔ kple gamenɔnɔ; magate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe naneke dzi le teƒe aɖeke o.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 20:7.
(Revelation 20:​1-3) Satan’s condition in the abyss could be likened to being in prison; he will be unable to influence affairs elsewhere.​ Revelation 20:7.
Ƒe Akpa Ðeka Dziɖuɖua dze egɔme.
The Millennium begins.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea adze eƒe ƒe 1,000 dziɖuɖua, si ahe yayra manyagblɔwo vɛ na amegbetɔwo la gɔme.
God’s Kingdom will begin its 1,000-year reign, which will bring great blessings to mankind.

(Nyaɖeɖefia 5:​9, 10; 20:​4, 6) "Ameha gã " aɖe si xexlẽme meli na o ado "go tso xaxa gã la me, " si fia be woatsi agbe eye woakpɔ Ƒe Akpe Ðeka Dziɖuɖua ƒe gɔmedzedze le anyigba dzi.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 7:​9, 14; Psalmo 37:​9-​11.

(Revelation 5:​9, 10; 20:​4, 6) An unnumbered "great crowd " will "come out of the great tribulation, " surviving it to see the start of the Millennium on earth.​ Revelation 7:​9, 14; Psalm 37:​9-​11.
Nu Kae Nye Armagedon-ʋa La?
What Is the Battle of Armageddon?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Armagedon-ʋa nye aʋa mamlɛtɔ si ayi edzi le Mawu kple amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo dome.
The battle of Armageddon refers to the final war between human governments and God.
Fifia gɔ̃ hã la, dziɖuɖu siawo kple wo dzi delawo tsi tsitre ɖe Mawu ŋu le esi wogbe be yewomabɔbɔ ɖe eƒe dziɖuɖu te o ta.
These governments and their supporters oppose God even now by refusing to submit to his rulership.
(Psalmo 2:2) Armagedon-ʋaa ava ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo ɖa.​ Daniel 2:​44.
(Psalm 2:2) The battle of Armageddon will bring human rulership to an end.​ Daniel 2:​44.
Zi ɖeka koe nya "Armagedon " dze le Biblia bliboa me le Nyaɖeɖefia 16:16.
The word "Armageddon " occurs only once in the Bible, at Revelation 16:16.

Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa gblɔe ɖi be woaƒo "anyigba blibo la dzi fiawo " nu ƒu "hena Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la ƒe ŋkeke gã la ƒe aʋawɔwɔ " "ɖe teƒe, si woyɔna le Hebrigbe me be Harmagedon [Armagedon]. "​ Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14.

Prophetically, Revelation shows that at "the place that is called in Hebrew Armageddon, " "the kings of the entire inhabited earth " will be gathered "together to the war of the great day of God the Almighty. "​ Revelation 16:14.
Ame kawoe awɔ Armagedon-ʋa la?
Who will fight at Armageddon?
Yesu Kristo anɔ ŋgɔ na Mawu ƒe dziƒoʋakɔ la woaɖu Mawu ƒe futɔwo dzi.
Jesus Christ will lead a heavenly army to victory over God’s enemies.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:11-16, 19-21) Futɔ siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ame siwo tsi tsitre ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋusẽ ŋu eye wodoa vlo Mawu.​ Ezekiel 39:7.
(Revelation 19:11-​16, 19-​21) These enemies include those who oppose God’s authority and who treat God with contempt.​ Ezekiel 39:7.
Ðe woawɔ Armagedon-ʋa la le Asia ƒe ɣedzeƒenutowo mea?
Will Armageddon literally be fought in the Middle East?
Ao.
No.
Menye nuto ɖeka aɖe me koe woawɔ Armagedon-ʋa la le o, ke boŋ anyigba blibo la katã dzie.​ Yeremiya 25:32-34; Ezekiel 39:17-20.
Rather than being restricted to one area, the battle of Armageddon will encompass the whole earth.​ Jeremiah 25:32-​34; Ezekiel 39:17-​20.
Wogayɔa Armagedon be "Har–​Magedon " (Hebrigbe me nya Har Meghiddhon), si fia "Megido To. "
Armageddon, sometimes rendered "Har–​Magedon " (Hebrew Har Meghiddohn), means "Mountain of Megiddo. "
Le blema la, Megido nye blema Israel ƒe nuto aɖe.
Megiddo was once a city in the territory of ancient Israel.
Wowɔ aʋa gãwo le nuto ma me eye woŋlɔ aʋa siawo dometɔ aɖewo ƒe ŋutinya ɖe Biblia me.
History tells of decisive battles that were fought in its vicinity, including some that are recorded in the Bible.
(Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 5:19, 20; 2 Fiawo 9:27; 23:29) Ke hã, Armagedon mate ŋu afia teƒe ŋutɔŋutɔ aɖe si le blema Megido o.
(Judges 5:​19, 20; 2 Kings 9:​27; 23:29) However, Armageddon cannot refer to the literal area near ancient Megiddo.
To gã aɖeke mele afi ma o, eye Mawu ƒe futɔ siwo le aʋa wɔ ge kplii la katã hã mate ŋu anɔ Yezreel-balia me o.
There is no large mountain there, and even the entire adjoining Low Plain of Jezreel could not contain all those who will fight against God.
Ke boŋ Armagedon nye dzesi na nɔnɔme aɖe si ado mo ɖa le anyigba dzi esime dukɔwo katã atso ɖe Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu ŋu.
Instead, Armageddon is the worldwide situation in which the nations assemble in their last stand against rule by God.
Togbɔ be míenya aʋawɔnu siwo tututu Mawu azã o hã la, nu siwo wòzã tsɔ wɔ aʋa le blema la gakpɔtɔ le esi.
What will conditions be like during the battle of Armageddon?
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye tsikpewo, anyigbaʋuʋuwo, tsiɖɔɖɔwo, tsidzadza gãwo, dzo kple aŋɔ, dzikedzo kple dɔléle vɔ̃ɖiwo.

While we do not know how God will use his power, he will have at his disposal weapons such as those he has used in the past​ hail, earthquake, flooding downpour, fire and sulfur, lightning, and disease.

(Hiob 38:22, 23; Ezekiel 38:19, 22; Habakuk 3:10, 11; Zakariya 14:12) Eye ate ŋu adzɔ hã be Mawu ƒe futɔwo natɔtɔ ahawu wo nɔewo, ke hã woakpɔe adze sii kɔtɛe be Mawue le aʋa wɔm kple yewo.​ Ezekiel 38:21, 23; Zakariya 14:13.

(Job 38:22, 23; Ezekiel 38:19, 22; Habakkuk 3:​10, 11; Zechariah 14:12) In confusion, at least some of God’s enemies will kill each other, yet they will ultimately realize that it is God who is fighting against them.​ Ezekiel 38:21, 23; Zechariah 14:13.
Ðe Armagedon anye xexea me ƒe nuwuwua?
Will Armageddon be the end of the world?
Manye míaƒe anyigba la ƒe nuwuwu o, elabena anyigba anye amegbetɔwo nɔƒe tegbee.
It will not be the end of our planet, since the earth is mankind’s eternal home.
(Psalmo 37:29; 96:10; Nyagblɔla 1:4) Armagedon manye amegbetɔƒomea ƒe nuwuwu o, ɖe Mawu le aʋa sia dzi to ge boŋ aɖe esubɔla siwo anye "ameha gã " aɖe.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 7:9, 14; Psalmo 37:34.
(Psalm 37:29; 96:10; Ecclesiastes 1:4) Rather than destroying humanity, Armageddon actually saves it, because "a great crowd " of God’s servants will survive.​ Revelation 7:​9, 14; Psalm 37:34.
Togbɔ be nya "xexea me " fiaa anyigba le Biblia me hã la, wotea ŋu zãnɛ le Biblia me ɣeaɖewoɣi wòfiaa amegbetɔ vɔ̃ɖi siwo tsi tsitre ɖe Mawu ŋu.
Besides referring to the earth, though, the word "world " in the Bible sometimes refers to wicked human society opposed to God.
(1 Yohanes 2:15-17) Le gɔmesese sia ya nu la, Armagedon nye "xexea me ƒe nuwuwu. "​ Matthew 24:3, Eʋegbe Biblia.
(1 John 2:​15-​17) In this sense, Armageddon will bring "the end of the world. "​ Matthew 24:3, King James Version.
Ɣekaɣie Armagedon-ʋaa adzɔ?
When will Armageddon take place?

Esime Yesu nɔ nu ƒom tso "xaxa gã " si ƒe nuwuwue Armagedon-ʋaa adzɔ ŋu la, egblɔ be: "Le ŋkeke ma kple gaƒoƒo ma ŋuti la, ame aɖeke menyae o, mawudɔla siwo le dziƒo la menyae o, eye Vi la hã menyae o, negbe Fofo la ko. "

When discussing the "great tribulation " that culminates in the battle of Armageddon, Jesus said: "Concerning that day and hour nobody knows, neither the angels of the heavens nor the Son, but only the Father. "
(Mateo 24:21, 36) Ke hã, Biblia ɖee fia be Armagedon-ʋaa adzɔ le Yesu ƒe anyinɔɣi si womakpɔ kple ŋku o la me, eye eƒe anyinɔɣi sia dze egɔme le ƒe 1914 me.​ Mateo 24:37-​39.
(Matthew 24:21, 36) Nevertheless, the Bible does show that Armageddon takes place during Jesus’ invisible presence, which began in 1914.​ Matthew 24:37-​39.
Ðe Woatsrɔ̃ Anyigba La?
Will the Earth Be Destroyed?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Kpao, womatsrɔ̃ anyigba, atɔ dzoe wòafiã, alo awɔ bubu ɖe eteƒe gbeɖe o.
No, planet Earth will never be destroyed, burned in fire, or replaced.
Biblia fia nu be Mawu wɔ anyigba la be woanɔ edzi tegbee.
The Bible teaches that God created the earth to be inhabited forever.
"Ame dzɔdzɔewo anyi anyigba la dome, eye woanɔ edzi tegbee. " Psalmo 37:29.
"The righteous will possess the earth, and they will live forever on it. "​ Psalm 37:29.
"[Mawu] ɖo anyigba gɔme anyi ɖe eƒe anyinɔwo dzi; maʋã akpɔ o tso mavɔ me yi mavɔ me. " Psalmo 104:5.
"[God] has established the earth on its foundations; it will not be moved from its place forever and ever. "​ Psalm 104:5.
"Anyigba . . . li tegbee. " Nyagblɔla 1:4.
"The earth remains forever. "​ Ecclesiastes 1:4.
"Anyigba la Mèla kple Ewɔla, Ame si ɖo egɔme anyi, menye ɖeko wòwɔe dzodzro o, ke boŋ ɖe wòmèe be woanɔ edzi. " Yesaya 45:18.
"The One who formed the earth, its Maker who firmly established it, . . . did not create it simply for nothing, but formed it to be inhabited. "​ Isaiah 45:18.
Ðe amegbetɔwo agblẽ anyigba la?
Will humans ruin the earth?
Mawu maɖe mɔ be amegbetɔwo nato ɖiƒoƒonuwɔnawo, aʋawɔwɔ alo mɔ bubu aɖeke dzi agblẽ anyigba gbidii o.
God will not allow humans to ruin the earth completely by pollution, warfare, or any other means.
Ke boŋ ‘atsrɔ̃ ame siwo le anyigba la gblẽm.’
Rather, he will "bring to ruin those ruining the earth. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 11:18) Aleke wòawɔ esiae?
(Revelation 11:18) How will he accomplish that?
Mawu aɖɔli amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖu siwo mete ŋu kpɔ anyigbaa ta o la kple eƒe Dziƒofiaɖuƒe deblibo la.
God will replace human governments, which have been unable to protect the earth, with a perfect heavenly Kingdom.
(Daniel 2:44; Mateo 6:9, 10) Mawu ƒe Vi, Yesu Kristo ye anye Fiaɖuƒe ma ƒe Fia.
(Daniel 2:​44; Matthew 6:​9, 10) That Kingdom will be ruled by God’s Son, Jesus Christ.
(Yesaya 9:6, 7) Esime Yesu nɔ anyigba dzi la, ekpɔ ŋusẽ wɔnuku ɖe dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽwo dzi.
(Isaiah 9:​6, 7) When on earth, Jesus exercised miraculous powers over natural elements.
(Marko 4:35-41) Eya ta abe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia ene la, Yesu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe anyigba la kple emenuwo dzi.
(Mark 4:​35-​41) As the King of God’s Kingdom, Jesus will exercise full control over earth and its elements.
Agbugbɔ awɔ alo atrɔ asi le anyigbadzinuwo ŋu woazu yeye, abe ale si wònɔ va yi le Eden-bɔ me ene. Mateo 19:28; Luka 23:43.
He will re-create, or renew, conditions on earth, making them similar to those that existed in the garden of Eden.​ Matthew 19:28; Luke 23:43.
Ðe Biblia megblɔ be woatɔ dzo anyigbaa oa?
Doesn’t the Bible teach that the earth will be burned in fire?
Ao, menye nenemae o.
No, it does not.
Susu totro sia tso ale si amewo mese 2 Petro 3:7 me nyawo gɔme nyuie o la gbɔ, afi ma gblɔ be: ‘Wodzra dziƒo kple anyigba si li fifia la ɖo ɖi na dzo.’
Such a misconception often comes from a misunderstanding of 2 Peter 3:7, which says: "The heavens and the earth that now exist are reserved for fire. "
Kpɔ susu vevi eve siwo kpe ɖe mía ŋu míese nu si nya mawo fia gɔme la ɖa:
Consider two important points that help us understand the meaning of those words:
Biblia zãa nya "dziƒo, " "anyigba, " kple "dzo " wofiaa nu vovovowo.
The Bible uses the terms "heavens, " "earth, " and "fire " to refer to more than one thing.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, 1 Mose 11:1 gblɔ be: "Anyigba blibo la katã doa gbe ɖeka. "
For example, Genesis 11:1 says: "All the earth continued to be of one language. "
Le afi sia la, "anyigba " la fia amegbetɔƒomea.
Here, "earth " refers to human society.
Nya siwo ƒo xlã 2 Petro 3:7 na míese nu si dziƒo, anyigba kple dzo siwo woyɔ le afi ma fia la gɔme.
The context of 2 Peter 3:7 indicates the meaning of the heavens, earth, and fire mentioned there.
Hafi Petro nagblɔ nya si le kpukpui 7 me la, eƒo nu tso Noa ƒe ŋkekea me Tsiɖɔɖɔa me nudzɔdzɔa ŋu le kpukpui 5 kple 6 me.
Verses 5 and 6 draw a parallel with the Flood of Noah’s day.
Ɣemaɣi la, wotsrɔ̃ blema xexea, gake womewɔ naneke míaƒe anyigba la o.
On that occasion, an ancient world was destroyed, yet our planet did not disappear.
Ke boŋ, Tsiɖɔɖɔa tsrɔ̃ "anyigba " alo ameƒome sẽŋuta la.
Instead, the Flood wiped out a violent society, or "earth. "
(1 Mose 6:11) Etsrɔ̃ "dziƒo " tɔgbi aɖe si nye ame siwo nɔ ameƒomea dzi ɖum ɣemaɣi la hã.
(Genesis 6:​11) It also destroyed a kind of "heavens "​ the people who ruled over that earthly society.
Eya ta ame vɔ̃ɖiwoe wotsrɔ̃, ke menye míaƒe anyigba la ŋutɔ o.
Thus, wicked people were destroyed, not our planet.
Noa kple eƒe ƒomea tsi agbe le xexe ma tsrɔ̃ɣi eye wonɔ anyigba la dzi le Tsiɖɔɖɔa megbe. 1 Mose 8:15-18.
Noah and his family survived the destruction of that world and inhabited the earth after the Flood.​ Genesis 8:​15-​18.
Abe Tsiɖɔɖɔa ene la, tsɔtsrɔ̃, alo "dzo " si ŋu 2 Petro 3:7 ƒo nu tsoe la ahe ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ƒe xexea va nuwuwui, ke menye anyigba la ŋutɔ o.
Similar to the waters of the Flood, the destruction, or "fire, " of 2 Peter 3:7 will bring an end to the world of wicked people, not to planet Earth.
Mawu do "dziƒo yeye kple anyigba yeye, siwo me dzɔdzɔenyenye anɔ " la ŋugbe na mí. (2 Petro 3:13) "Dziƒo yeye " alo dziɖuɖu yeye si nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea aɖu "anyigba yeye, " alo amegbetɔƒome yeye dzi.

God promises "new heavens and a new earth " in which "righteousness is to dwell. " (2 Peter 3:​13) A "new earth, " or new human society, will be ruled over by "new heavens, " or new leadership​ God’s Kingdom.
Le Fiaɖuƒe ma ƒe dziɖuɖu te la, anyigbaa azu paradiso si me ŋutifafa axɔ aƒe ɖo.
Under the rule of that Kingdom, the earth will become a peaceful paradise.​ Revelation 21:​1-4.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1-4.
When Will the World End?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ele vevie be míase ale si Biblia zã nya "xexea " gɔme, esia akpe ɖe mía ŋu míanya ɣeyiɣi si xexea ƒe nuwuwu ava.
To know when the end of the world will happen, it is necessary to understand how the Bible uses the term "world. "
Zi geɖe la, Helagbe me nya ko′smos, si gɔme woɖena be "xexea, " fiana amegbetɔƒomea, vevietɔ ame siwo meɖoa to Mawu alo wɔa eƒe lɔlɔ̃nu o.
The Greek word kosmos, usually translated "world, " most often refers to the world of humankind, especially the part that is out of harmony with God and his will.

(Yohanes 15:18, 19; 2 Petro 2:5) Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, wozãa nya ko′smos wòkuna ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe nuɖoanyia ŋu, eye esia lɔ asitsahabɔbɔwo, dunyahehabɔbɔwo kple subɔsubɔhawo ɖe eme. 1 Korintotɔwo 7:31; 1 Yohanes 2:15, 16.
(John 15:18, 19; 2 Peter 2:5) At times, kosmos refers to the framework of human society.​ 1 Corinthians 7:​31; 1 John 2:​15, 16.
Nu kae nye "xexea me ƒe nuwuwu "?
What is "the end of the world "?
Woagate ŋu aɖe nya, "xexea me ƒe nuwuwu, " si dze le Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe aɖewo me la, gɔme be "nuɖoanyia ƒe nuwuɣi. "
The phrase "the end of the world, " which appears in many Bible translations, can also be rendered as "the conclusion of the system of things, " or "the close of the age. "
(Mateo 24:3) Nya ma mefia be woatsrɔ̃ anyigba alo amegbetɔwo katã o, ke boŋ efia be amegbetɔwo ƒe nuɖoanyia awu enu. 1 Yohanes 2:17.
(Matthew 24:3; English Standard Version) It refers, not to the destruction of the earth or of all humanity, but to the end of the framework of human society.​ 1 John 2:​17.
Biblia na míenya be "woatsrɔ̃ ame vlowo, " ale be ame nyuiwo nate ŋu ase vivi na agbea le anyigba dzi.
The Bible teaches that "evil men will be done away with " so that good people can enjoy life on earth.
(Psalmo 37:9-11) Ame vlowo ƒe tsɔtsrɔ̃ sia adze egɔme le "xaxa gã " la me, eye wòawu enu le Armagedon-ʋa la me. Mateo 24:21, 22; Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14, 16.
(Psalm 37:​9-​11) This destruction will happen at the "great tribulation, " which culminates in the war of Armageddon.​ Matthew 24:21, 22; Revelation 16:14, 16.
Ɣekaɣie xexea ƒe nuwuwu ava?
When will the world end?
Yesu gblɔ be: "Le ŋkeke ma kple gaƒoƒo ma ŋuti la, ame aɖeke menyae o, mawudɔla siwo le dziƒo la menyae o, eye Vi la hã menyae o, negbe Fofo la ko. "
Jesus said: "Concerning that day and hour nobody knows, neither the angels of the heavens nor the Son, but only the Father. "
(Mateo 24:36, 42) Egblɔ kpee be nuwuwua ava le vo me, "le gaƒoƒo si miesusu be eya dzie wòava o la dzi. " Mateo 24:44.
(Matthew 24:36, 42) He added that the timing of the end would be unexpected, "at an hour that you do not think to be it. "​ Matthew 24:44.
Togbɔ be míate ŋu anya ŋkekea kple gaƒoƒoa o hã la, Yesu gblɔ "dzesi, " alo nudzɔdzɔ siwo aɖee afia be xexea ƒe nuwuwu gogo.
Even though we cannot know the exact day and hour, Jesus did provide a composite "sign, " or group of events, that would identify the time period leading up to the end of the world.
(Mateo 24:3, 7-14) Biblia yɔ ɣeyiɣi si me nudzɔdzɔ mawo ava eme la be "nuwuɣi la, " kple "ŋkeke mamlɛawo. " Daniel 12:4; 2 Timoteo 3:1-5.
(Matthew 24:​3, 7-​14) The Bible refers to this period as "the time of the end, " "the end times, " and "the last days. "​ Daniel 12:4; God’s Word Bible; 2 Timothy 3:​1-5.
Ðe nane agasusɔ ne wotsrɔ̃ xexea?
Will there be anything left after the end of the world?
Yes.
Anyigba akpɔtɔ anɔ anyi, elabena Biblia gblɔ be "maʋã akpɔ o tso mavɔ me yi mavɔ me. "
The earth will still be here, for the Bible says that "it will not be moved from its place forever and ever. "
(Psalmo 104:5) Eye anyigba dzi ayɔ fũu kple amewo, abe ale si Biblia do ŋugbee ene be: "Ame dzɔdzɔewo anyi anyigba la dome, eye woanɔ edzi tegbee. "
(Psalm 104:5) And the earth will be filled with people, just as the Bible promises: "The righteous will possess the earth, and they will live forever on it. "
(Psalmo 37:29) Mawu ana nuwo nanɔ abe ale si wòɖoe tso gɔmedzedzea me ene:
(Psalm 37:29) God will bring about the conditions that he originally purposed:
Anyigba azu Paradiso. Yesaya 35:1; Luka 23:43.
Paradise.​ Isaiah 35:1; Luke 23:43.
Dedienɔnɔ kple nudzedziname axɔ aƒe ɖi. Mika 4:4.
Security and prosperity.​ Micah 4:4.
Ame sia ame awɔ dɔ nyui si me dzidzeme le. Yesaya 65:21-23.
Meaningful and satisfying work for all.​ Isaiah 65:21-​23.
Dɔléle kple amegãkuku alo nyagãkuku maganɔ anyi o. Hiob 33:25; Yesaya 33:24.
Freedom from disease and aging.​ Job 33:25; Isaiah 33:24.
Ame siwo le paradiso me le dzidzɔ dom na wo ɖokuiwo le ƒuta
People in paradise enjoy a day at the beach
Nu Kae Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Awɔ Na Mí?
What Will God’s Kingdom Accomplish?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ava xɔ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo katã teƒe eye wòaɖu anyigba bliboa dzi.
God’s Kingdom will replace all human governments and rule over the entire earth.
(Daniel 2:44; Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14) Ne esia nya va eme ko la, ke Mawu Fiaɖuƒea. . .
(Daniel 2:44; Revelation 16:14) Once that happens, God’s Kingdom will . . .
Aɖe ame vɔ̃ɖi siwo ƒe ɖokuitɔdidinuwɔnawo gblẽa nu le mía ŋu la ɖa.
Remove the wicked, whose selfishness harms us all.
"Woatsrɔ̃ ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ɖa le anyigba dzi. "
"As regards the wicked, they will be cut off from the very earth. "
Lododowo 2:22.
Proverbs 2:22.
Atsi aʋawɔwɔ nu tegbee.
End all wars.
"[Mawu atsi] aʋawɔwɔwo nu va se ɖe anyigba ƒe mlɔenu ke. "
"[God] is making wars to cease to the extremity of the earth. "
Psalmo 46:9.
Psalm 46:9.
Ahe nunyoname kple dedienɔnɔ ava anyigba dzi.
Bring prosperity and security to the earth.
"Ame sia ame abɔbɔ nɔ anyi ɖe eƒe wainka kple eƒe gboti te bɔkɔɔ. "
"Everyone will live in peace among their own vineyards and fig trees, and no one will make them afraid. "
Mixa 4:4.
Micah 4:4, Good News Translation.
Ana anyigba nazu paradiso.
Make the earth into a paradise.
"Gbegbe kple gbedadaƒo akpɔ dzidzɔ, tagba atso aseye, eye wòaƒo se abe dzogbenya ene. "
"Thirsty deserts will be glad; barren lands will celebrate and blossom with flowers. "
Yesaya 35:1.
Isaiah 35:1, Contemporary English Version.
Ana ame sia ame nakpɔ dɔ nyui awɔ eye woƒe dzi adze eme.
Provide everyone with meaningful, enjoyable work.
"[Mawu ƒe] ame tiatiawo aɖu woawo ŋutɔ ƒe asinudɔwɔwɔwo.
"The work of their own hands [God’s] chosen ones will use to the full.
Womadze agbagba dzodzro o. "
They will not toil for nothing. "
Yesaya 65:21-23.
Isaiah 65:21-23.
Aɖe dɔléle ɖa keŋkeŋ.
Eliminate disease.
"Duametɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, yele dɔ lém o. "
"No resident will say: ‘I am sick.’
Yesaya 33:24.
" Isaiah 33:24.
Aɖe amegãkuku ɖa.
Set us free from the aging process.
"Ekema dzo aɖo eƒe lãme abe ɖekakpui ene, eye wòagaɖo eƒe ɖekakpuiŋkekewo me. "
"Let his flesh become fresher than in youth; let him return to the days of his youthful vigor. "
Hiob 33:25.
Agbɔ agbe ame kukuwo.
Bring the dead back to life.
"Ame siwo katã le ŋkuɖodziyɔdowo me la ase [Yesu ƒe] gbe, eye woado go. "
"All those in the memorial tombs will hear [Jesus’] voice and come out. "
Yohanes 5:28, 29.
Aleke Woawɔ Ahe Ŋutifafa Ava Anyigba Dzi?
Peace on Earth How Will It Come?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ŋutifafa ava anyigba dzi gake manye to amegbetɔwo ƒe agbagbadzedze me o. Ke boŋ Mawu Fiaɖuƒe, dziɖuɖu si le dziƒo, si dzi Yesu le fia ɖum le lae ahe ŋutifafaa vɛ.
Peace on earth will come, not by human efforts, but by means of God’s Kingdom, a heavenly government ruled by Christ Jesus.
Kpɔ nya siwo Biblia gblɔ tso mɔkpɔkpɔ wɔnuku sia ŋu la ɖa.
Notice how the Bible teaches us about this wonderful hope.
Mawu atsi "aʋawɔwɔwo nu va se ɖe anyigba ƒe mlɔenu ke, " eye wòato esia me awɔ ɖe ŋugbe si wòdo be yeana "ŋutifafa nanɔ ame siwo ŋu [yekpɔa] ŋudzedze ɖo la dome le anyigba dzi " la dzi.
God will make "wars to cease to the extremity of the earth, " fulfilling his promise to bring "peace on earth to those with whom he is pleased! "
Psalmo 46:10; Luka 2:14.
Psalm 46:9; Luke 2:14, Good News Translation.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒe si le dziƒo la aɖu anyigba bliboa dzi.
God’s Kingdom will rule from heaven over the entire earth.
(Daniel 7:14) Dziɖuɖu sia si aɖu xexea me katã dzi la aɖe dulɔlɔ̃ si gbɔ aʋawɔwɔ geɖe tsona la ɖa keŋkeŋ.
(Daniel 7:14) As a world government, it will eliminate nationalism, which is at the root of many conflicts.
Woyɔ Yesu ame si nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia la be "ŋutifafafia " eye akpɔ egbɔ be "seƒeɖo manɔe na ŋutifafa " o.
Jesus, the Ruler of God’s Kingdom, is called the "Prince of Peace, " and he will ensure that "to peace there will be no end. "
Yesaya 9:5, 6.
Isaiah 9:6, 7.
Womaɖe mɔ na ame siwo ɖoe kplikpaa be ŋutasẽnuwo koe yewoanɔ wɔwɔm la be woanɔ Fiaɖuƒe ma te o, elabe Mawu ƒe "luʋɔ léa fu . . . ame si lɔ̃a ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ. "
People determined to keep fighting will not be allowed to live under the Kingdom, since "anyone loving violence [God’s] soul certainly hates. "
Psalmo 11:5; Lododowo 2:22.
Psalm 11:5; Proverbs 2:22.
Mawu fiaa eteviwo ale si woanɔ ŋutifafa me kple wo nɔewo.
God teaches his subjects how to live in peace.

Eye Biblia ɖɔ nu nyui siwo le dodom tso nufiame sia me ale: "Woatsɔ woƒe yiwo atu kodziwoe, eye woatsɔ woƒe akplɔwo atu hɛ gobɛwoe; dukɔ magatsɔ yi ɖe dukɔ ŋu azɔ o, eye womagasrɔ̃ aʋawɔwɔ hã azɔ o. "

Describing the results of this instruction, the Bible says: "They will have to beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning shears. Nation will not lift up sword against nation, neither will they learn war anymore. "
Yesaya 2:3, 4.
Isaiah 2:3, 4.
Fifia gɔ̃ hã la, ame miliɔn geɖe siwo le xexea me godoo le ale si woanɔ ŋutifafa me kple wo haviwo srɔ̃m tso Mawu gbɔ.
Already, millions of Jehovah’s Witnesses around the world are learning from God how to be peaceable.
(Mateo 5:9) Togbɔ be míenye gbegbɔgblɔ vovovo dolawo eye míetso dukɔ siwo wu 230 me hã la, míegbe be mímatsɔ yi ɖe mía haviwo ŋu o.
(Matthew 5:9) Although we belong to many different ethnic groups and live in over 230 different lands, we refuse to take up arms against our fellow man.
Yehowa Ðasefowo le ale si woanɔ ŋutifafa me kple wo haviwo la srɔ̃m egbea
Jehovah’s Witnesses are learning the ways of peace today
Ame Kawoe Nye "Nunyala Etɔ̃awo "?
Who Were the "Three Wise Men "?
Mawue Na Betlehem Ƒe "Ɣletivi " La Fia Mɔ Woa?
Did They Follow the "Star " of Bethlehem?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Ame geɖe gblɔna be "nunyala etɔ̃ " alo "fia etɔ̃ " ye va kpɔ Yesu ɖa esime wodzii, abe ale si wòdzena le Kristmas ɖuɖu ŋuti kɔnuwo me ene, gake Biblia megblɔ be "nunyala etɔ̃ " alo "fia etɔ̃ " ye va kpɔe ɖa o.
Contrary to popular Christmas tradition, the Bible does not use the terms "three wise men " or "three kings " to describe the travelers who went to see Jesus after his birth.
(Mateo 2:1) Ke boŋ, Nyanyuigbalẽŋlɔla Mateo zã Helagbe me nya ma’goi tsɔ ɖɔ ame siwo va kpɔ Yesu ɖa.
(Matthew 2:1) Instead, the Gospel writer Matthew used the Greek word ma’goi to describe those who visited Jesus.
Anɔ eme be nyagbe ma ku ɖe ame siwo bi ɖe ɣletivimefakaka kple gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ ƒe nuwɔna bubuwo me ŋu.
The word likely refers to experts in astrology and other occult practices.
Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe geɖe yɔ wo be "ɣletivimefakalawo " alo "akunyawɔlawo. "
A number of Bible translations call them "astrologers " or "magi. "
‘Nunyala’ nenie wonye?
How many "wise men " were there?
Fiawoe "nunyalawo " nyea?
Were the "wise men " kings?
"Nunyalawo " ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe?
What were the names of the "wise men "?
Ɣekaɣie "nunyalawo " yi ɖakpɔ Yesu ɖa?
When did the "wise men " visit Jesus?
Mawue na Betlehem ƒe "ɣletivi " la fia mɔ ‘nunyalawoa’?
Did God have the "wise men " follow the "star " of Bethlehem?
‘Nunyala’ nenie wonye?
How many "wise men " were there?
Biblia megblɔe o, gake susu vovovowoe le amewo si ku ɖe woƒe xexlẽme ŋu.
The Bible does not say, and traditions about their number vary.

Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: "Ame geɖe siwo le Asia nutowo me xɔe se be wonye Akunyawɔla [alo nunyala] 12, gake ame siwo le Europa kple Amerika dukɔwo me la xɔe se be ame etɔ̃e, ɖewohĩ le esi wotsɔ nunana etɔ̃, siwo nye ‘sika, lifi kple mire’ (Mateo 2:11) vɛ na ɖevi sue la ta. " Encyclopedia Britannica.

According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, "Eastern tradition sets the number of Magi at 12, but Western tradition sets their number at three, probably based on the three gifts of ‘gold, frankincense, and myrrh’ (Matthew 2:11) presented to the infant. "
Fiawoe "nunyalawo " nyea?
Were the "wise men " kings?
Togbɔ be nenemae wòdzena le nutatawo me le Kristmas ɖuɣi hã la, Biblia ƒe akpa aɖeke megblɔ be fiawoe wonye o.
Although in Christmas tradition the visitors are often depicted that way, nowhere does the Bible call them kings.
Numekugbalẽ ma ke gblɔ be ƒe alafa geɖe le Yesu dzidzi megbe la, amewo va "kpa nyawo " kpe ŋutinya si ku ɖe Yesu ƒe dzidzi ŋu, eye ame geɖe va nɔ gbɔgblɔm be ame siwo va kpɔe ɖa la nye fiawo.
According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, that designation was added centuries later as part of the traditions that "embellished the narrative. "
"Nunyalawo " ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe?
What were the names of the "wise men "?
Biblia meyɔ ɣletivimefakalaawo ƒe ŋkɔwo o.
The Bible does not reveal the names of the astrologers.
Numekugbalẽ bubu gblɔ be: "Ŋkɔ siwo amewo dze agbagba tsɔ na wo, (abe Gaspar, Melchior, kple Balthasar ene) la nye ŋkɔ kpakpawo ko. " The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia.
According to The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia, "attempts to name them (e.g., Gaspar, Melchior, and Balthasar) rest upon legends. "
Ɣekaɣie "nunyalawo " yi ɖakpɔ Yesu ɖa?
When did the "wise men " visit Jesus?
Anye be ɣletivimefakalawo va kpɔ Yesu ɖa ɣleti aɖewo le edzidzi megbe.
The astrologers may have visited Jesus a number of months after his birth.
Míenya esia elabena Fia Herodes, si di be yeawu Yesu la, ɖe gbe be woawu ŋutsuvi siwo katã xɔ ƒe eve kple esiwo mexɔ nenema haɖe o.
This is evident because King Herod, who wanted to have Jesus killed, ordered the slaughter of boys who were two years old and younger.
Nya siwo wòse tso ɣletivimefakalawo gbɔ la dzie wònɔ te ɖo gblɔ be woawu ɖevi siwo xɔ va se ɖe ƒe eve.
He based that age range on information he had received from the astrologers.
Mateo 2:16.
Matthew 2:16.
Menye zã si me wodzi Yesu ye ɣletivimefakalawo va kpɔe ɖa o.
The astrologers did not visit Jesus on the night of his birth.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi woge ɖe aƒea me la, wokpɔ ɖevi la kple dadaa Maria. "
The Bible says: "When they went into the house, they saw the young child with Mary his mother. "
(Mateo 2:11) Esia ɖee fia be ɣemaɣi la, ƒomea nɔ aƒe aɖe me eye Yesu meganye vidzĩ le lãnuɖunu me o.
(Matthew 2:11) This indicates that the family were by then living in a house and that Jesus was no longer an infant in a manger.
Luka 2:16.
Luke 2:16.
Mawue na Betlehem ƒe "ɣletivi " la fia mɔ ‘nunyalawoa’?
Did God have the "wise men " follow the "star " of Bethlehem?
Ame aɖewo xɔe se be Mawue dɔ nu si amewo yɔna be Betlehem ƒe ɣletivi la be wòafia mɔ ɣletivimefakalawo ayi Yesu gbɔ.
Some people believe that God sent the so-called star of Bethlehem to guide the astrologers to Jesus.
Kpɔ nu si tae nya ma mate ŋu anye nyateƒe o la ɖa.
Consider why that cannot be the case.
Nu si dze abe ɣletivi ene la kplɔ ɣletivimefakalawo yi Yerusalem gbã.
What appeared to be a star led the astrologers first to Jerusalem.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ɣletivimefakalawo tso Ɣedzeƒe va Yerusalem, eye wobia be: ‘Afi kae Yudatɔwo ƒe fia si wodzi la le?
The Bible says: "Astrologers from the East came to Jerusalem, saying: ‘Where is the one born king of the Jews?
Elabena míekpɔ eƒe ɣletivi esime míenɔ Ɣedzeƒe, eye míeva be míade bubu eŋu.’
For we saw his star when we were in the East, and we have come to do obeisance to him.’
" Mateo 2:1, 2.
" Matthew 2:1, 2.
Fia Herodes ye nye ame gbãtɔ si fia mɔ ɣletivimefakalawo be woayi Betlehem, ke menye "ɣletivi " lae o.
King Herod, not the "star, " was the first to direct the astrologers to Bethlehem.
Esi Herodes se be wodzi fia bubu, si nye "Yudatɔwo ƒe fia " la, eku nu me tsitotsito tso afi si woadzi Kristo si ŋugbe wodo la le.
When he heard of a rival "king of the Jews, " Herod investigated where the promised Christ was to be born.
(Mateo 2:3-6) Esi Herodes se be Betlehem ye woadzii le la, egblɔ na ɣletivimefakalawo be woayi afi ma, adi ɖevia, eye woatrɔ ava ka eta na ye.
(Matthew 2:3-6) On learning that it was to be in Bethlehem, he told the astrologers to go there, look for the child, and report back to him.
Esia yomee ɣletivimefakalawo ɖo ta Betlehem.
Only then did the astrologers go to Bethlehem.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi wose fia la ƒe nyawo vɔ la, wodze mɔ, eye kpɔ ɖa, ɣletivi si wokpɔ esime wonɔ Ɣedzeƒe la dze wo ŋgɔ ʋuu va tɔ ɖe aƒe si me ɖevia le la tame. "

The Bible says: "After they had heard the king, they went their way, and look! the star they had seen when they were in the East went ahead of them until it came to a stop above where the young child was. "
Mateo 2:9.
Matthew 2:9.
"Ɣletivi " si ɣletivimefakalawo kpɔ la wɔe be nanewo dzɔ si na Yesu ƒe agbe ɖo afɔku me eye wòwɔe be wowu ɖevi manyaɖekewo.
The appearance of the "star " set in motion events that threatened the life of Jesus and resulted in the murder of innocent children.
Esi ɣletivimefakalawo dzo le Betlehem la, Mawu xlɔ̃ nu wo be woagatrɔ ayi ɖe Herodes gbɔ o.
When the astrologers left Bethlehem, God warned them not to return to Herod.
Mateo 2:12.
Matthew 2:12.
Aleke Herodes wɔ nui?
How did Herod react?

Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi Herodes kpɔ be ɣletivimefakalaawo flu ye la, edo dziku vevie, eye wòdɔ amewo woyi Betlehem kple eƒe nutowo katã me ɖawu ŋutsuvi siwo katã xɔ ƒe eve kple esiwo mexɔ nenema haɖe o la ɖe ale si wòbia ɣeyiɣi la tsitotsito tso ɣletivimefakalaawo gbɔe la nu. "

The Bible says: "Herod, seeing that he had been outwitted by the astrologers, flew into a great rage, and he sent out and had all the boys in Bethlehem and in all its districts killed, from two years of age and under, according to the time that he had carefully ascertained from the astrologers. "
(Mateo 2:16) Mate ŋu adzɔ gbeɖe be nu vɔ̃ɖi ma natso Mawu gbɔ o.
(Matthew 2:16) God would not have caused such a wicked thing to be done.
Hiob 34:10.
Afi Kae Kain Kpɔ Srɔ̃ Le Ðe?
Who Was Cain’s Wife?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Atsu kple asi gbãtɔ ƒe ŋgɔgbevi si nye Kain la, anya ɖe nɔvianyɔnu loo, alo nyɔnu bubu si nye eƒe ƒometɔ kplikplikpli.
Cain, the eldest child of the first human couple, married one of his sisters or another close female relative.
Ne míedzro nya si Biblia gblɔ tso Kain kple eƒe ƒomea ŋu me la, míate ŋu aƒo nya ta alea.
This conclusion may be drawn by considering what the Bible says about Cain and his family.
Kain kple eƒe ƒomea ŋuti nya veviwo
Facts about Cain and his family
Amegbetɔwo katã dzɔ tso Adam kple Xawa me.
All humans descended from Adam and Eve.
Mawu ‘na dukɔ sia dukɔ dzɔ tso ame ɖeka [Adam] me, be woanɔ anyigba blibo la dzi.’
God "made out of one man [Adam] every nation of men to dwell on the entire surface of the earth. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:26) Adam srɔ̃, Xawa, va nye "amegbetɔwo katã dada. " (1 Mose 3:20) Eya ta Kain anya ɖe Adam kple Xawa ƒe dzidzimeviawo dometɔ ɖeka.
(Acts 17:26) Adam’s wife, Eve, became "the mother of everyone living. " (Genesis 3:​20) Therefore, Cain must have married a fellow descendant of Adam and Eve.
Kain kple nɔvia Abel ye Xawa dzi gbã hafi va dzi vi bubuwo.
Cain and his brother Abel were the first of a number of children born to Eve.
(1 Mose 4:1, 2) Esi wonya Kain de gbe le esi wòwu nɔvia ta la, egblɔ be: "Ame sia ame si akpɔm la, awum kokoko. " (1 Mose 4:14) Ame kae Kain nɔ vɔvɔ̃m na?
(Genesis 4:​1, 2) When Cain was banished for killing his brother, he complained: "Anyone who finds me will certainly kill me. " (Genesis 4:​14) Of whom was Cain afraid?
Biblia gblɔ be Adam ‘dzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.’ (1 Mose 5:4) Edze ƒãa be, Adam kple Xawa ƒe dzidzimevi siawo dometɔ aɖe ate ŋu awu Kain.
The Bible says that Adam "became father to sons and daughters. " (Genesis 5:4) Evidently, these other descendants of Adam and Eve could have posed a threat to Cain.
Le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya ƒe gɔmedzedze la, enye nu si bɔ be ame naɖe eƒe ƒometɔ.
Early in human history, marrying one’s relative was not uncommon.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nuteƒewɔla Abraham ɖe fofoa ƒe vi.
The faithful man Abraham, for example, married his half sister.
(1 Mose 20:12) Ƒe alafa geɖe le Kain ƒe ku megbe hafi wova de se ɖe srɔ̃ɖeɖe sia tɔgbi ŋu le Mose ƒe Sea me.
(Genesis 20:12) The first prohibitions against such marriage appeared in the Mosaic Law, which was codified centuries after Cain’s day.
(3 Mose 18:9, 12, 13) Edze be dɔléle siwo ate ŋu aɖe fu na ɖevi siwo ƒometɔ kplikplikpli siwo ɖe wo nɔewo dzi mebɔ ɣemaɣi abe ale si wòle egbea ene o.
(Leviticus 18:​9, 12, 13) It seems that children born to close relatives back then were not as prone to birth defects as they are today.
Adam, Xawa, kple woƒe ƒomea ŋu nya si le Biblia me la nye ŋutinya si nye nyateƒe.
The Bible presents the account of Adam, Eve, and their family as accurate history.
Menye Mose ƒe agbalẽ gbãtɔ si Mose ŋlɔ ko mee dzidzimeŋutinya deto si dze egɔme tso Adam dzi la le o, ke ele ŋutinyaŋlɔla Ezra kple Luka hã ƒe nuŋlɔɖiwo me.
Detailed genealogies going back to Adam can be found not only in the book of Genesis, written by Moses, but also in the writings of the historians Ezra and Luke.
(1 Mose 5:3-5; 1 Kronika 1:1-4; Luka 3:38) Biblia ŋlɔlawo ƒoa nu tso Kain ƒe ŋutinya ŋu abe nu si dzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ ene. Hebritɔwo 11:4; 1 Yohanes 3:12; Yuda 11.
(Genesis 5:​3-5; 1 Chronicles 1:​1-4; Luke 3:​38) Bible writers cite the story of Cain as a historical event.​ Hebrews 11:4; 1 John 3:​12; Jude 11.
Nu Kae Nye Nubablaɖaka La?
What Is the Ark of the Covenant?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Nubablaɖaka la nye aɖaka kɔkɔe aɖe si blema Israel-viwo nɔ te ɖe Mawu ƒe sedede kple eƒe mɔfiamewo dzi wɔ.
The ark of the covenant was a sacred chest made by the ancient Israelites according to the command and design of God.
Eya mee wotsɔ "Ðaseɖiɖikpe, " si nye kpe eve siwo dzi Se Ewoawo nɔ la da ɖo be woanɔ dedie.​ 2 Mose 25:8-10, 16; 31:18.
It housed and protected "the Testimony, " the Ten Commandments written on two stone tablets.​ Exodus 25:​8-​10, 16; 31:18.
Ale si wowɔe.
Construction.
Aɖakaa didi sentimeta 111, ekeke sentimeta 67, eye wòkɔkɔ sentimeta 67.
The Ark measured 2.5 cubits long, 1.5 cubits wide, and 1.5 cubits high (111 x 67 x 67 cm; 44 x 26 x 26 in.).
Wotsɔ akasiati kpae hefa sika ɖe eme kple ekɔgo, eye wotsɔ sika ɖo to nɛ kpe ɖo wònya kpɔ.
It was built of acacia wood and was overlaid inside and out with gold, with an artistic border.
Wotsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ eƒe nutunu, eye wowɔ sikakerubi eve ɖe nutunua ƒe go eveawo dzi.
Its cover, made of solid gold, featured two golden cherubs, one at each end.
Kerubiawo dze ŋgɔ wo nɔewo hede mo to ɖe nutunu la dzi, eye woke woƒe aʋalawo do ɖe dzi wòtsyɔ nutunua dzi.
They faced each other with their faces toward the cover and their wings extending upward, overshadowing the cover.
Sikasigɛ ene le Aɖakaa ƒe dzogoewo dzi le afɔtiawo gbɔ lɔƒo.
The Ark had four rings of cast gold above its feet.
Wotsɔa kpo siwo wotsɔ akasiati kpa hefa sika ɖe wo ŋu la ƒona ɖe asigɛawo me tsɔ kɔa aɖakaa.​ 2 Mose 25:10-21; 37:6-9.
Acacia-wood poles overlaid with gold were put through the rings and were used for carrying the Ark.​ Exodus 25:10-​21; 37:​6-9.
Afi si wònɔ.
Location.
