Gbã la, woda aɖakaa ɖe avɔgbadɔa ƒe Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒe; enye agbadɔ si me wosubɔna le, si wote ŋu kakana gatuna ne woʋu yi teƒe bubu, eye eya kple Aɖakaa ye wowɔ le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me.
The Ark was initially kept in the Most Holy compartment of the tabernacle, a transportable tent of worship that was made at the same time as the Ark.
Wotsɔ xɔmetsovɔ xe Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒea ŋkume be nunɔlawo kple ame bubuwo nagakpɔe o.
The Most Holy was screened off from the view of the priests and the people.
(2 Mose 40:3, 21) Nunɔlagãa koe gena ɖe afi ma hekpɔa Aɖakaa zi ɖeka le ƒe me, le Avuléŋkekea dzi.
(Exodus 40:​3, 21) Only the high priest could enter this compartment, one day each year on Atonement Day, and see the Ark.
(3 Mose 16:2; Hebritɔwo 9:7) Emegbe wova kɔ Nubablaɖakaa yi Salomo ƒe gbedoxɔa ƒe Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒea.​ 1 Fiawo 6:14, 19.
(Leviticus 16:2; Hebrews 9:7) Later, the Ark was moved to the Most Holy in Solomon’s temple.​ 1 Kings 6:​14, 19.
Nubablaɖakaa le avɔgbadɔa ƒe Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒe
The ark of the covenant inside the Most Holy compartment of the tabernacle
Taɖodzinu si nɔ eŋu.
Purpose.
Nu kɔkɔe siwo ɖoa ŋku nu si Mawu bla kple Israel-viwo le Sinai Toa gbɔ dzi na wo lae wodzra ɖo ɖe Aɖakaa me.
The Ark was an archive for sacred items that would remind the Israelites of the covenant, or agreement, that God had made with them at Mount Sinai.
Wogazãnɛ etɔxɛ hã le Avuléŋkekea ƒe wɔnawo me.​ 3 Mose 16:3, 13-17.
It also played a key role in the Atonement Day ceremony.​ Leviticus 16:​3, 13-17.
Nu siwo nɔ eme.
Contents.
Kpe siwo dzi woŋlɔ Se Ewoawo ɖoe nye nu gbãtɔ siwo wotsɔ de Aɖakaa me.
The stone tablets inscribed with the Ten Commandments were the first items placed in the Ark.
(2 Mose 40:20) Wova de sikaze si me mana le kple "Aron ƒe atikplɔ si ƒo se " la hã eme emegbe.
(Exodus 40:20) A golden jar of manna and "Aaron’s rod that budded " were later added.
(Hebritɔwo 9:4; 2 Mose 16:33, 34; 4 Mose 17:10) Edze ƒãa be wova ɖe zea kple atikplɔa ɖa le Aɖakaa me, elabe nu siawo menɔ eme esime wotsɔe yi gbedoxɔa me o.​ 1 Fiawo 8:9.
(Hebrews 9:4; Exodus 16:33, 34; Numbers 17:10) Evidently, the jar and rod were removed at some point, because they were not in the Ark when it was moved into the temple.​ 1 Kings 8:9.
Ale si woakɔe.
Transport.
Lewi viwoe tsɔa kpo siwo wotsɔ akasiati kpa la kɔa Aɖakaa ɖe abɔta.
The Ark was to be carried by the Levites on their shoulders by means of the acacia-wood poles.
(4 Mose 7:9; 1 Kronika 15:15) Kpoawo nɔ Aɖakaa ŋu ɣesiaɣi, eya ta mahiã be Lewi viwo naka asi Aɖakaa ŋutɔ ŋu ɣeaɖekeɣi o.
(Numbers 7:9; 1 Chronicles 15:15) The poles remained attached to the Ark at all times, so the Levites never had to touch the Ark.
(2 Mose 25:12-16) Wotsɔa "xɔmetsovɔ " si ma Kɔkɔeƒea kple Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒea dome la tsyɔa Aɖakaa dzi hafi kɔnɛ.​ 4 Mose 4:5, 6.
(Exodus 25:12-​16) "The screening curtain " that separated the Holy and the Most Holy was used to cover the Ark while it was being carried.​ Numbers 4:​5, 6.
Nu si wòtsi tre ɖi na.
Symbolism.
Afi sia afi si Aɖakaa le la, enyea dzesi be Mawu le afi ma.
The Ark was associated with God’s presence.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, alilikpo si nɔa Aɖakaa tame le Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒea kple esi nɔa Israel-viwo ƒe asaɖaa tame la siaa nyea dzesi be Yehowa le wo dome eye eƒe yayra le wo dzi.
For example, the cloud that appeared over the Ark in the Most Holy and at Israelite encampments was a sign of Jehovah’s presence and blessing.
(3 Mose 16:2; 4 Mose 10:33-36) Azɔ hã, esi Biblia gblɔ be Yehowa "bɔbɔ nɔ kerubiwo tame " la, kerubi eve siwo nɔ Aɖakaa ƒe nutunua dzi ŋue wònɔ nu ƒom tsoe.
(Leviticus 16:2; Numbers 10:33-​36) Also, the Bible says that Jehovah "[sat] enthroned above the cherubs, " referring to the two cherubs on the Ark’s cover.
(1 Samuel 4:4; Psalmo 80:1) Eya ta kerubi siawo nɔ "tsitre ɖi na " Yehowa ƒe "tasiaɖam " la.
(1 Samuel 4:4; Psalm 80:1) Thus, these cherubs were "the representation of the chariot " of Jehovah.
(1 Kronika 28:18) Esi Fia David nya nu si Aɖakaa le tsitre ɖi na ta la, esi wokɔ Aɖakaa yi Zion la, ete ŋu gblɔ be Yehowa "le Zion. "​ Psalmo 9:11.
(1 Chronicles 28:18) Because of what the Ark symbolized, King David could write that Jehovah was "dwelling in Zion " after the Ark was moved there.​ Psalm 9:​11.
Ŋkɔ siwo wogayɔna nɛ.
Designations.

Biblia zã ŋkɔ vovovowo na aɖaka kɔkɔe ma; wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye "Ðaseɖiɖiɖaka, " "nubablaɖaka, " ‘Yehowa ƒe Aɖaka,’ kple "Aɖaka, si nye wò [Yehowa ƒe] ŋusẽ ƒe dzesi. "​ 4 Mose 7:89; Yosua 3:6, 13; 2 Kronika 6:41.

The Bible uses a variety of terms for that sacred chest, including "the ark of the Testimony, " "the ark of the covenant, " "the Ark of Jehovah, " and "the Ark of your [Jehovah’s] strength. "​ Numbers 7:​89; Joshua 3:​6, 13; 2 Chronicles 6:​41.

Woyɔa Aɖakaa ƒe nutunu la be "avuléle ƒe nutunu " alo "amenuveveteƒe. " (1 Kronika 28:11; Agbenya La) Ŋkɔ sia he susu yi mɔ tɔxɛ si nu wozãa nutunua le le Avuléŋkekea dzi la dzi, esime Israel ƒe nunɔlagã hlẽa vɔsalãa ƒe ʋu ɖe nutunua ŋgɔ kple egbɔ lɔƒo.

The cover of the Ark was called "the propitiatory cover, " or "the mercy seat. " (1 Chronicles 28:11; King James Version) This term refers to the special function of the cover on the Day of Atonement, when the high priest of Israel would spatter the blood of sacrificed animals toward and before the cover.
Nu siawo siwo nunɔlagã wɔna la léa avu ɖe "eya ŋutɔ ɖokui kple eƒe aƒe la kpakple Israel ƒe ha blibo la katã " ƒe nu vɔ̃wo ta, alo tsyɔa wo dzi.​ 3 Mose 16:14-17.
These actions of the high priest made propitiation for, or covered, sins "in behalf of himself and his house and in behalf of the entire congregation of Israel. "​ Leviticus 16:14-​17.
Ðe nubablaɖaka la gali egbea?
Does the ark of the covenant exist today?
Kpeɖodzi aɖeke meli be eli o.
There is no evidence that it does.
Biblia ɖee fia be Aɖakaa megahiã o, elabena nubabla si do ƒome kplii la megali o, eye "nubabla yeye " si wotu ɖe Yesu ƒe vɔsaa dzi la va xɔ ɖe eteƒe.
The Bible shows that the Ark is no longer needed because the covenant associated with it has been replaced with "a new covenant, " one based on Jesus’ sacrifice.
(Yeremiya 31:31-33; Hebritɔwo 8:13; 12:24) Biblia gblɔe ɖi hã be ɣeyiɣi aɖe ava si nubablaɖakaa maganɔ anyi o, eye Mawu ƒe amewo magaɖo ŋku edzi o.​ Yeremiya 3:16.
(Jeremiah 31:31-​33; Hebrews 8:​13; 12:24) The Bible thus foretold a time when the ark of the covenant would be no more, yet God’s people would not miss it.​ Jeremiah 3:​16.
Apostolo Yohanes kpɔ nubablaɖakaa le dziƒo le ŋutega aɖe si woɖe fiae esime woɖo nubabla yeyea anyi vɔ megbe la me.
In a vision given to the apostle John after the new covenant was established, the ark of the covenant appeared in heaven.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 11:15, 19) Kpɔɖeŋuɖaka sia nye dzesi be Mawu le afi ma eye be eƒe yayra le nubabla yeyea dzi.
(Revelation 11:15, 19) This symbolic Ark represents God’s presence and his blessing on the new covenant.
Ðe Aɖakaa kpɔa Israel-viwo ta le nukumɔ aɖe nua?
Did the Ark serve as a sort of magic charm?
Ao.
No.
Ne nubablaɖaka le Israel-viwo gbɔ la, menye kpeɖodzi be woakpɔ dzidzedze o.
Possessing the ark of the covenant did not guarantee success.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Aɖakaa nɔ wo gbɔ esi wokpe aʋa kple Ai, gake woɖu wo dzi le esi wo dometɔ ɖeka mewɔ nuteƒe o ta.
For example, the Israelites had the Ark in their camp when battling the city of Ai, yet they suffered defeat because of one Israelite’s unfaithfulness.
(Yosua 7:1-6) Emegbe Filistitɔwo ɖu wo dzi togbɔ be wokɔ nubablaɖakaa yi aʋagbea dzi hã.
(Joshua 7:​1-6) Later, they were defeated by the Philistines despite taking the ark of the covenant to the battlefield.
Nunɔla siwo nye Hofni kple Finehas ƒe nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔwo tae woɖu wo dzi ɖo.
That conquest was due to the wickedness of the Israelite priests Hophni and Phinehas.
(1 Samuel 2:​12; 4:​1-​11) Filistitɔwo xɔ Aɖakaa le Israel-viwo si le aʋa ma me tsɔ yi wo gbɔ, gake Mawu wɔ fu wo vevie va se ɖe esime wogbugbɔ Aɖakaa va Israel.​ 1 Samuel 5:11–6:​5.
(1 Samuel 2:​12; 4:​1-​11) The Philistines captured the Ark in that battle, but God struck them with plagues until they returned it to Israel.​ 1 Samuel 5:11–6:​5.
Nubablaɖakaa ƒe ŋutinya
History of the ark of the covenant
Ƒe (D.Y.)
Year (B.C.E.)
Nudzɔdzɔ
Event
Bezalel kple ame siwo kpe ɖe eŋu la zã nu siwo Israel-viwo dzɔ tsɔ kpa Aɖakaa.​ 2 Mose 25:1, 2; 37:1.
Made by Bezalel and his assistants using materials contributed by the Israelites.​ Exodus 25:​1, 2; 37:1.
Mose kɔ Aɖakaa, avɔgbadɔa kple nunɔlawo ŋu.​ 2 Mose 40:1-3, 9, 20, 21.
Inaugurated by Moses along with the tabernacle and priesthood.​ Exodus 40:​1-3, 9, 20, 21.
Tso ƒe 1512 va se ɖe ƒe 1070 megbe
Wotsɔe yi teƒe vovovowo.​ Yosua 18:1; Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 20:26, 27; 1 Samuel 1:24; 3:3; 6:11-14; 7:1, 2.
Moved to various locations.​ Joshua 18:1; Judges 20:26, 27; 1 Samuel 1:​24; 3:3; 6:​11-​14; 7:​1, 2.
Ƒe 1070 megbe
After 1070
Fia David tsɔe va Yerusalem.​ 2 Samuel 6:12.
Brought to Jerusalem by King David.​ 2 Samuel 6:​12.
Wotsɔe va da ɖe Salomo ƒe gbedoxɔa me le Yerusalem.​ 1 Fiawo 8:1, 6.
Moved into Solomon’s temple in Jerusalem.​ 1 Kings 8:​1, 6.
Fia Yosiya trɔe gbɔ va gbedoxɔa me.​ 2 Kronika 35:3.
Returned to the temple by King Josiah.​ 2 Chronicles 35:3.
Do ŋgɔ na ƒe 607
Before 607

Womeyɔe de nu siwo Babilontɔwo lɔ tso gbedoxɔa me dzoe esi wotsrɔ̃ gbedoxɔa le ƒe 607 D.Y. me la dome o, eye menɔ nu siwo wogatrɔ tso Babilon gbɔe va Yerusalem emegbe la dome o.​ 2 Fiawo 25:13-17; Ezra 1:7-11.

Apparently removed from the temple. It is not mentioned in the inventories of articles taken to Babylon when the temple was destroyed in 607 B.C.E. or of those articles later returned to Jerusalem.​ 2 Kings 25:13-​17; Ezra 1:​7-​11.
Romaʋafia Pompey ɖu Yerusalem dzi eye wòge ɖe Kɔkɔeƒewo Ƒe Kɔkɔeƒea hegblɔ be yemekpɔ aɖakaa le afi ma o.
Declared to be missing by Roman General Pompey when he conquered Jerusalem and inspected the Most Holy of the temple.
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ Dzie Mawu To Wɔ Nu Gbagbe Vovovoawoa?
Did God Use Evolution to Create the Different Types of Life?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao.
No.
Biblia gblɔe eme kɔ nyuie be Mawu wɔ amegbetɔwo kpakple nu miemiewo kple lãwo le wo "ƒomeviwo " nu.
The Bible clearly states that God created humans as well as different "kinds " of animal and plant life.
(1 Mose 1:12, 21, 25, 27; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Egblɔe hã be Adam kple Xawa, siwo nye mía dzila gbãtɔwo, mee ameƒome bliboa dzɔ tso.
(Genesis 1:12, 21, 25, 27; Revelation 4:11) It says that the entire human family descended from Adam and Eve, our first parents.
(1 Mose 3:20; 4:1) Biblia meda asi ɖe dzixɔse si nye be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbe vovovoawo la dzi, abe ale si ame aɖewo susuna ene o.
(Genesis 3:20; 4:1) The Bible account does not support the theory that God used evolution to bring about the different kinds of life, sometimes called theistic evolution.
Ke hã nya aɖeke mele Biblia me si tsi tre ɖe nya si dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo gblɔna be nuwɔwɔ siwo le hatsotso ɖeka me ate ŋu ato vovo tso wo nɔewo gbɔ la ŋu o.
The fact is, though, that nothing in the Bible conflicts with scientific observations that variations occur within each kind of life.
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbewoa?
Did God use evolution?
Ðe nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia wɔ ɖeka kple nu si Biblia fia?
Is evolution compatible with the Bible?
Nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbewoa?
What about the ability of plants and animals to adapt?
Ame siwo xɔe se be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbewo la ƒe susu le ale si wòwɔe ŋu la to vovo.
Did God use evolution? The term "theistic evolution " refers to a broad variety of ideas.
Le Encyclopædia Britannica ƒe nya nu la, "ale si nɔnɔmeawo le le dzɔdzɔme nu ye wɔnɛ be nu gbagbewo va toa vovo.
According to the Encyclopædia Britannica, the term promotes the idea that "natural selection is one of the mechanisms with which God directs the natural world. "
Ame aɖewo xɔe se be esia nye mɔ aɖe si dzi Mawu to na be nu gbagbe ƒomevi vovovowo va li. "
Theistic evolution can also include the following ideas:
Susu vovovo siwo le ame mawo si la ƒe ɖewoe nye:
All living organisms descended from common ancestors in the distant past.
Nu gbagbe ƒomeviwo katã dzɔ tso nu ɖeka aɖe me wotɔwotɔwoe tso gbe aɖe gbe ʋĩi ke. Nu gbagbe ƒomevi aɖe ate ŋu atrɔ azu nu gbagbe ƒomevi bubu kura.
One kind of life-form can evolve into a completely different kind of life-form, a concept that is sometimes referred to as macroevolution.
Le mɔ aɖe nu la, Mawu gbɔe wòtso be tɔtrɔ siawo yia edzi.
God is somehow ultimately responsible for these processes.
Ðe nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia wɔ ɖeka kple nu si Biblia fia?
Is evolution compatible with the Bible?
Dzixɔse si nye be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbewo la le fiafiam be nya si Biblia gblɔ tso xexemewɔwɔ ŋu, si le Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ me la mede keŋkeŋ o.
Theistic evolution implies that the Bible’s account of creation in Genesis is not completely accurate.
Ke hã Yesu he susu yi xexemewɔwɔ ƒe ŋutinya ma si le Mose Ƒe Agbalẽ Gbãtɔ me la dzi be enye nu si dzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ.
However, Jesus referred to the Genesis account as historical fact.
(1 Mose 1:26, 27; 2:18-24; Mateo 19:4-6) Biblia gblɔ be hafi Yesu nava anyigba dzi la, enɔ dziƒo le Mawu gbɔ, eye wòkpe asi ɖe Mawu ŋu wowɔ "nuwo katã. "
(Genesis 1:26, 27; 2:18-24; Matthew 19:4-6) The Bible says that before coming to earth, Jesus lived in heaven with God and was involved in helping God to bring "all things " into existence.
(Yohanes 1:3) Eya ta susu si nye be nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ dzie Mawu to wɔ nu gbagbe vovovowo la mewɔ ɖeka kple Biblia ƒe nufiafia o.
(John 1:3) Therefore, the idea that God used evolution to bring about different life-forms is incompatible with Bible teachings.
Ðe ale si atiwo kple lãwo tea ŋu trɔna ɖe nuto si me wole ƒe nɔnɔme nu la ɖo kpe nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia dzia?
What about the ability of plants and animals to adapt?
Biblia meɖe nu me ku ɖe ale si gbegbe nu gbagbewo ate ŋu ato vovo tso wo ƒomevi siwo li xoxo gbɔ la ŋu o.
The Bible does not explain how much variation can occur within a kind.
Gake metsi tre ɖe nyateƒenya si nye be tɔtrɔ viviviwo tea ŋu vana le nu gbagbe siwo Mawu wɔ la ƒe dzidzimeviwo ŋu alo be wotea ŋu trɔna ɖe nuto si me wole la ƒe nɔnɔmewo nu la ŋu hã o.
Neither does it contradict the fact that the different kinds of animals and plants created by God can vary as they breed or adapt to new environments.
Togbɔ be ame aɖewo susuna be tɔtrɔ mawo ɖo kpe nɔnɔmetɔtrɔ ƒe nufiafia dzi hã la, menye nu gbagbe bubu sãa ye dona tso tɔtrɔ mawo me o.
Although some view such adaptations as a form of evolution, no new kind of life is produced.
Ðe Biblia Ate Ŋu Ana Dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ Nanɔ Nye Ƒomea Mea?
Can the Bible Help Me to Have a Happy Family?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Biblia me aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo me nunya le siwo kpe ɖe ŋutsu kple nyɔnu miliɔn geɖewo ŋu woƒe ƒomea le dzidzɔ kpɔm la dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewoe nye esiawo:
Here’s a sample of wise advice based on the Bible that has helped millions of men and women to gain family happiness:
De wò srɔ̃ɖeɖea agbalẽ me alo ɖe srɔ̃ le se nu.
Legalize your marriage.
Ale si srɔ̃ɖeɖe le se nu biana be woawɔ nuteƒe na ame srɔ̃ le ame ƒe agbe me katã nye gɔmeɖoanyi na ƒome kpɔdzidzɔ.​ Mateo 19:4-6.
The lifetime commitment of a legal marriage is the foundation for a happy family.​ Matthew 19:4-6.
Ðe lɔlɔ̃ kple bubu fia.
Show love and respect.
Esia bia be nàwɔ nu ɖe srɔ̃wòa ŋu abe ale si nàdi be wòawɔ nu ɖe ye ŋu ene.​ Mateo 7:12; Efesotɔwo 5:25, 33.
This includes treating your mate in the way that you would like to be treated.​ Matthew 7:12; Ephesians 5:25, 33.
Ƒo asa na nya tɔamewo gbɔgblɔ.
Avoid harsh words.
Ƒo nu tufafatɔe, nenye be srɔ̃wòa gblɔ nya aɖe alo wɔ nane wòve wò hã.
Speak kindly, even if your mate says or does something hurtful.
(Efesotɔwo 4:31, 32) Biblia gblɔ le Lododowo 15:1 gblɔ be: "Nyaŋuɖoɖo fafɛ tsia dziku nu; ke gbe da ɖe ame gbɔ nana dɔmedzoe flana. "
(Ephesians 4:31, 32) As the Bible says at Proverbs 15:1: "An answer, when mild, turns away rage, but a word causing pain makes anger to come up. "
Miwɔ nuteƒe na mia nɔewo.
Be faithful to each other.
Ðoe be ye srɔ̃ ɖeka ƒe nu koe alé dzi na ye eye eya ɖeka ko ƒe nue adzro ye.
Reserve your romantic and sexual attention only for your spouse.
(Mateo 5:28) Biblia gblɔ be: "Bubu nanɔ srɔ̃ɖeɖe me le amewo katã dome, eye womagaƒo ɖi srɔ̃ɖeba la o. " Hebritɔwo 13:4.
(Matthew 5:28) The Bible says: "Let marriage be honorable among all, and the marriage bed be without defilement. "​ Hebrews 13:4.
He viwòwo le lɔlɔ̃ me.
Train your children with love.
Mègafa akpa o eye wò nya me megasẽ hã akpa.​ Lododowo 29:15; Kolosetɔwo 3:21.
Avoid both leniency and harshness.​ Proverbs 29:15; Colossians 3:21.
Ðe Ga Nye Nu Vɔ̃ɖiwo Katã Ƒe Kea?
Is Money the Root of All Evil?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao.
No.
Biblia megblɔ be ga nye nu vɔ̃ɖi o, eye megblɔ hã be gae le megbe na nu vɔ̃ɖi ƒomevi ɖe sia ɖe o.
The Bible does not say that money is evil, nor does it identify money as the underlying cause of all bad things.
Nya si amewo lɔ̃a gbɔgblɔ be "ga nye nu vɔ̃ɖiwo katã ƒe ke " la nye mawunyakpukpui aɖe me nyawo ƒe akpa aɖe si wotro gboe.
The common expression "money is the root of all evil " is an incomplete and misleading Bible quotation.
Nya si Biblia gblɔ boŋue nye be "nu vɔ̃wo katã ƒe ke enye galɔlɔ̃. " 1 Timoteo 6:10, Eʋegbe Biblia, míawoe te gbe ɖe edzi.
The Bible actually says that "the love of money is the root of all evil. " 1 Timothy 6:10, King James Version, emphasis ours.
Nya kae Biblia gblɔ tso ga ŋu?
What does the Bible say about money?
Nu ka tae Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí tso galɔlɔ̃ ŋu?
Why does the Bible warn about the love of money?
Aleke aɖaŋu si Biblia ɖo ku ɖe ga ŋu la ate ŋu aɖe vi na mí?
How can we benefit from the Bible’s advice on money?
Mawunyakpukpui siwo ƒo nu tso ga ŋu
Bible verses about money
Nya kae Biblia gblɔ tso ga ŋu?
What does the Bible say about money?
Biblia na eme kɔ be ne ame zã ga nyuie la, ate ŋu aɖe vi nɛ, eye ate ŋu ‘akpɔ eta’ gɔ̃ hã.
The Bible acknowledges that money, when used wisely, can be useful, even serving as "a protection. "
(Nyagblɔla 7:12) Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, Biblia kafu ame siwo nyoa dɔme na ame, eye dɔmenyo sia ate ŋu anye ganana ame hã.
(Ecclesiastes 7:12) Additionally, the Bible commends those who show generosity toward others, which may include monetary gifts.
Lododowo 11:25.
Proverbs 11:25.
Gake Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí be míagana ga nanye nu vevitɔ na mí le agbe me o.
At the same time, the Bible cautions against making money the focus of life.
Egblɔ be: "Mina miaƒe agbenɔnɔ navo tso galɔlɔ̃ me, eye nu siwo le mia si fifia la nadze mia ŋu. "
It says: "Let your way of life be free of the love of money, while you are content with the present things. "
(Hebritɔwo 13:5) Nu si nya mawo fiae nye be míagana ga nanɔ vevie na mí akpa alo be míati kesinɔnuwo yome o.
(Hebrews 13:5) The lesson is to keep money in its place and not pursue wealth.
Ke boŋ, ne nu siwo hiã mí ŋutɔŋutɔ, abe nuɖuɖu, nudodo kple mlɔƒe ene su mía si la, míana nu siawo nadze mía ŋu.
Instead, we should aim to be content with the things we really need, such as food, clothing, and shelter.
1 Timoteo 6:8.
1 Timothy 6:8.
Nu ka tae Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí tso galɔlɔ̃ ŋu?
Why does the Bible warn about the love of money?
Ŋuklẽlawo makpɔ agbe mavɔ o.
Greedy people will not gain everlasting life.
(Efesotɔwo 5:5) Susu ɖeka si tae nye be, ŋukeklẽ sɔ kple trɔ̃subɔsubɔ, alo alakpasubɔsubɔ.
(Ephesians 5:5) For one thing, greed is a form of idolatry, or false worship.
(Kolosetɔwo 3:5) Susu bubu hãe nye be zi geɖe la, ŋuklẽlawo wɔa nu tovowo ne wole agbagba dzem be nu siwo yewodi la nasu yewo si.
(Colossians 3:5) For another, in their effort to get what they desire, the greedy often abandon good principles.
Lododowo 28:20 gblɔ be: "Ame si tsi klokloklo ɖe hokpɔkpɔ ŋu la, fɔɖiɖi magbe eŋu nɔnɔ o. "
Those "hastening to get rich will not remain innocent, " says Proverbs 28:20.
Ŋukeklẽ ate ŋu ana amewo nawɔ nu vlowo, abe adzodada, ametafatafa, amefifi, alo amewuwu ene gɔ̃ hã.
They might even be tempted to commit crimes, such as blackmail, extortion, fraud, kidnapping, or murder.
Ne galɔlɔ̃ mena ame ƒo eɖokui ɖe nu vlowo wɔwɔ me o gɔ̃ hã la, nu gbegblẽ bubuwo ate ŋu ado tso eme.
Even if the love of money does not lead to bad behavior, it can have other negative consequences.
Biblia gblɔ be "ame siwo ɖoe kplikpaa be yewoazu kesinɔtɔwo la gena ɖe tetekpɔ kple mɔ̃tetre kpakple movidzɔdzɔ ƒe nudzodzro geɖe, siwo wɔa nu vevi ame . . . la me. " 1 Timoteo 6:9.
The Bible says that "those who are determined to be rich fall into temptation and a snare and many senseless and harmful desires. " 1 Timothy 6:9.
Aleke aɖaŋu si Biblia ɖo ku ɖe ga ŋu la ate ŋu aɖe vi na mí?
How can we benefit from the Bible’s advice on money?
Ne mímeɖe mɔ galɔlɔ̃ wɔe be míedana le Mawu ƒe se kple nudidiwo dzi o la, míase le mía ɖokui me be bubu le mía ŋu, eye Mawu hã akpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe mía ŋu ahakpe ɖe mía ŋu.
If we do not compromise moral and spiritual values for the sake of money, we will have self-respect along with God’s favor and support.
Mawu do ŋugbe na ame siwo dzea agbagba vevie be yewoadze eŋu la be: "Nyemaɖe asi le ŋuwò akpɔ o, eye nyemagblẽ wò ɖi hã akpɔ o. "
To those who sincerely try to please him, God promises: "I will never leave you, and I will never abandon you. "
(Hebritɔwo 13:5, 6) Mawu gaka ɖe edzi na mí hã be "woayra nuteƒewɔla geɖe. "
(Hebrews 13:5, 6) He also assures us that "a faithful man will receive many blessings. "
Lododowo 28:20.
Proverbs 28:20.
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Ƒo Nu Tso Ga Ŋu
Bible Verses About Money
Nyagblɔla 7:12: "Ga . . . kpɔa ame ta. "
Ecclesiastes 7:12: "Money is a protection. "
Nu si wòfia: Ne míezã ga nyuie la, ate ŋu aɖe vi na mí, elabena etea ŋu nana ame nɔa dedie le go aɖewo me.
Meaning: When used wisely, money can be beneficial because it adds a measure of security.
Luka 12:15: "Ne nu gbogbo aɖewo le ame si hã la, nu siawo mana agbee o. "
Luke 12:15: "Even when a person has an abundance, his life does not result from the things he possesses. "
Nu si wòfia: Menye gae nye nu vevitɔ le agbe me o, eye menye eyae ana míakpɔ ɖeɖe hã o.
Meaning: Money is not the most important thing in life, and it will not contribute to our salvation.
1 Timoteo 6:10: "Nu vɔ̃ɖi ƒomeviwo katã ƒe ke ɖekae nye galɔlɔ̃, eye esi ame aɖewo ti lɔlɔ̃ sia yome la, wotra mɔ tso xɔse la gbɔ, eye wotsɔ vevesese geɖe ŋɔ wo ɖokuiwo flofloflo. "

1 Timothy 6:10: "The love of money is a root of all sorts of injurious things, and by reaching out for this love some have been led astray from the faith and have stabbed themselves all over with many pains. "
Nu si wòfia: Menye nu gbegblẽe ga nye o.
Meaning: Money in itself is not wrong.
Gake ame siwo lɔ̃ ga eye wona wònye nu vevitɔ na wo le agbe me la hea kuxiwo vaa wo ɖokuiwo dzi, le kpɔɖeŋu me, woƒe ƒomewo gbãna alo lãmesẽnyawo ɖea fu na wo le dɔwɔwɔ atraɖii ta.
But people who love money who make it their main focus in life bring problems on themselves, such as broken families and poor health from overwork.
Hebritɔwo 13:5: "Mina miaƒe agbenɔnɔ navo tso galɔlɔ̃ me, eye nu siwo le mia si fifia la nadze mia ŋu. "
Hebrews 13:5: "Let your way of life be free of the love of money, while you are content with the present things. "
Nu si wòfia: Le esi míadi godoo be míazu kesinɔtɔwo teƒe la, nunya anɔ eme be ne nu siwo hiã mí ŋutɔŋutɔ su mía si ko la, míana nu mawo nadze mía ŋu.
Meaning: Instead of pursuing wealth at all costs, we are wise to be content with what we really need.
Mateo 19:24: "Ele bɔbɔe na kposɔ be wòato abui ƒe vo me wu be kesinɔtɔ nayi ɖe Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la me. "
Matthew 19:24: "It is easier for a camel to get through a needle’s eye than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God. "
Nu si wòfia: Ðeko Yesu kpe ɖekakpui kesinɔtɔ aɖe be wòadze ye yome koe nye ema wògblɔ nya mawo.
Meaning: Jesus had just invited a rich young man to follow him.
Ðekakpuia mewɔ ɖe amekpekpea dzi o, elabena eƒe dzi ku ɖe eƒe nunɔamesiwo ŋu akpa.
The man refused because he was too attached to his possessions.
Eya ta nuxlɔ̃amee Yesu ƒe nya mawo nye.
So Jesus was giving a warning.
Ne kesinɔnuwo didi le vevie na ame aɖe wu Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu wɔwɔ la, agbe mavɔ kpɔkpɔ ate ŋu ato eŋu.
A person who puts riches before God risks losing everlasting life.
Gakuxi Kple Fenyinyi Ðe Biblia Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Mía Ŋua?
Money Problems and Debt Can the Bible Help?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Biblia me mɔfiame ene siwo gbɔna ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò le ganyawo kple fenyinyawo gome:
The following four Bible principles can help you with money problems and debt:
Wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe gazazã ŋu.
Plan your spending.
"Veviedola ƒe tameɖoɖo hea viɖe vɛ, ke ame si tsi klokloklo la, dea hiã aƒe. "
"The plans of the diligent one surely make for advantage, but everyone that is hasty surely heads for want. "
(Lododowo 21:5) Mègatsi dzi nàƒle nane le esi wole edzram ta ko o.
(Proverbs 21:5) Don’t rush to buy something just because it’s on sale.
Wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe gazazã ŋu eye nàzɔ ɖe edzi pɛpɛpɛ.
Make a financial plan​ a budget​ and stick to it.
Mègade ɖokuiwò fe me dzodzro o.
Avoid unnecessary debt.
"Ame si doa nugbana la, dɔla wònye na agbanatɔ. "
"The borrower is servant to the man doing the lending. "
(Lododowo 22:7) Ne fe aɖewo le ŋuwò xoxo eye mètea ŋu le wo xem o la, dzro ɖoɖo bubu si nu nàdi be yeaxe fea le la kple wò fetɔa.
(Proverbs 22:7) If you are already in debt and can’t meet your obligations, try to negotiate new payment plans with your creditors.
Ƒo koko nɛ.
Be persistent.
Wɔ ɖe aɖaŋu si Biblia ɖo na ame si mebu nuwo ŋu nyuie o hafi de megbe na ame le fenyinyi me o la dzi be: "[Xlã] ɖokuiwò ɖe eƒe afɔ nu, eye nàƒoe ɖe hawòvi nu.
Use the Bible’s advice to one who unwisely guaranteed a loan and thus took on responsibility for the debt: "Humble yourself, and pester your neighbor.
Mègana alɔ̃ nava wò ŋku dzi o, eye akɔlɔ̃e megaɖo wò aɖaba me o. "
Don’t let your eyes rest or your eyelids close. "
(Lododowo 6:1-5) Ne meda asi ɖe ɖoɖo si nèwɔ be yeaxe fea nɛ dzi o zi gbãtɔ o hã la, yi ebiabia dzi.
(Proverbs 6:1-5, God’s Word Bible) Even if your first request isn’t successful, keep on asking for an adjustment.
Na susu nyuitɔ nanɔ asiwò ɖe ga ŋu.
Keep money in its proper place.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ŋubiãla le yɔyɔm ɖe kesinɔnu ŋu; ke menyae be, hiã le ye dzi va ge o. "
"Don’t be selfish and eager to get rich​ you will end up worse off than you can imagine. "
(Lododowo 28:22) Eya ta menye ɖeko ŋubiabiã kple ŋukeklẽ ana nàzu feme o, ke ana hã be magatsi dzi ɖe wo kple Mawu dome ƒomedodo ŋu o.
(Proverbs 28:22, Contemporary English Version) Envy and greed not only can lead to financial ruin but also can crowd out spiritual matters.
Na nu si le asiwò la nadze ŋuwò.
Be content.
"Ne nunyiame kple avɔtata le mía si la, mina nu siawo nasɔ gbɔ na mí. " (1 Timoteo 6:8) Ga mate ŋu aƒle dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ alo dzidzeme o.
"Having sustenance and covering, we shall be content with these things. " (1 Timothy 6:8) Money can’t buy happiness or contentment.
Ame siwo kpɔa dzidzɔ wu le xexea me la dometɔ aɖewo menye gatɔ gãwo o.
Some of the happiest people in the world do not have a lot of money.
Nu siwo le wo si nye lɔlɔ̃ si le woƒe ƒomea me, lɔlɔ̃ si le wo kple wo xɔlɔ̃wo dome, kpakple xɔlɔ̃kadodo si le wo kple Mawu dome. Lododowo 15:17; 1 Petro 5:6, 7.
What they do have is the love of family and friends and a friendship with God.​ Proverbs 15:17; 1 Peter 5:6, 7.
Nyemele Ta Kpɔm Na Nye Agbe O Ðe Subɔsubɔ, Mawu Alo Biblia Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋunyea?
I Don’t Feel Good About My Life Can Religion, God, or the Bible Help?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃ woate ŋui.
Yes.
Biblia, si nye blemagbalẽ si me nunya yɔ fũu, la ɖoa agbemebiabia veviwo ŋu eye ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔ dzidzɔ ahase le ɖokuiwò me be yele dedie.
The Bible, an ancient book of wisdom, provides answers to life’s important questions and can help you to feel better and have a sense of well-being.
Kpɔ nyabiase siwo ŋu wòɖo la dometɔ aɖewo ɖa.
Consider some questions that it answers.
Ðe Wɔla aɖe lia?
Is there a Creator?
Biblia gblɔ be Mawue "wɔ nuwo katã. "
The Bible says that God "created all things. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Esi Mawu nye mía Wɔla ta la enya nu siwo míehiã be míase vivi na agbea ahakpɔ dzidzeme.
(Revelation 4:11) As our Creator, God knows what we need to feel good and to find fulfillment in life.
Ðe Mawu tsɔa ɖe le eme nama?
Does God care about me?
Le esi míanɔ Mawu bum be enye ame si ɖe eɖokui ɖe aga sãa tso míagbɔ teƒe la, Biblia gblɔ na mí be: "Mele adzɔge tso mía dometɔ aɖeke gbɔ hafi o. "
Rather than portraying God as aloof from mankind, the Bible says: "He is not far off from each one of us. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:27) Etsɔ ɖe le nu siwo dzɔna ɖe dziwò la me vevie eye wòdina be yeakpe ɖe ŋuwò nakpɔ dzidzedze le agbe me.
(Acts 17:27) He is interested in what happens to you and wants to help you succeed in life.
Yesaya 48:17, 18; 1 Petro 5:7.
Isaiah 48:17, 18; 1 Peter 5:7.
Nu ka tae Mawu nyanya akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàkpɔ dzidzɔ?
How can knowing God help me to feel better?
Ðe Mawu wɔ mí be míatsi dzi ɖe "gbɔgbɔmenuwo, " si fia didi si le mía me be míase nu si tae Mawu wɔ mí ɖo la gɔme ŋu.
God created us with a "spiritual need, " an innate hunger to understand the meaning and purpose of life.
(Matthew 5:3) Nu si gbɔgbɔmenu siawo fia la dometɔ aɖee nye didi si le mía me be míanya mía Wɔla ale be míadze xɔlɔ̃e.
(Matthew 5:3) Our spiritual need also includes a desire to know our Creator and to have a relationship with him.
Mawu akpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe agbagba si nàdze be yeadze sii, elabena Biblia gblɔ: "Mite ɖe Mawu ŋu, eye ate ɖe mia ŋu. "
God will welcome your efforts to get to know him, for the Bible says: "Draw close to God, and he will draw close to you. "
Yakobo 4:8.
James 4:8.
Ame miliɔn geɖe va kpɔe be xɔlɔ̃dzedze Mawu na yewoƒe agbe va ɖɔ ʋu eye wònana wonyana nu si woawɔ be agbea nadze edzi na wo.
Millions of people have found that building a friendship with God has improved their overall well-being and shown them how to feel good about their lives.
Ne ènya Mawu la mefia be èvo tso kuxiwo me o gake eƒe nunya si dze le Biblia me ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò
While knowing God will not make your life trouble-free, his wisdom found in the Bible can help you to
Nàkpɔ dzidzɔ le wò ƒomegbenɔnɔ me.
Have a happier family life.
Ŋutifafa nanɔ wò kple ame bubuwo dome.
Enjoy peace with others.
Nànɔ te ɖe kuxi vovovowo abe blanuiléledɔ, ganyawo ƒe sesẽ kple dɔ mavɔleameŋu ene nu.
Deal with problems as varied as depression, stress about money, and chronic illness.
Subɔsubɔha siwo zãa Biblia la dometɔ geɖe menɔa agbe ɖe Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo nu ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
Many religions that use the Bible do not actually follow its teachings.
Ke hã, subɔsubɔha vavã me tɔwo ya wɔna ɖe Biblia ƒe nufiafiawo dzi pɛpɛpɛ, eye woate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànya Mawu nyuie.
In contrast, true religion, which adheres to what the Bible really says, will help you to get to know God.
Nya Kae Biblia Gblɔ Tso Dzikudodo Ŋu?
What Does the Bible Say About Anger?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia na míenya be dziku si dzi womeɖu o la gblẽa nu vevie; egblẽa nu le ame si le dzikua dom kple ame siwo dome wòle la siaa ŋu.
The Bible teaches that uncontrolled anger is harmful, both to the person who harbors it and to those around him.
(Lododowo 29:22) Togbɔ be asɔ be ame nado dziku ɣeaɖewoɣi hã la, Biblia gblɔ be ame siwo yia edzi nɔa ‘dɔmedzoe dom’ la makpɔ ɖeɖe o.
(Proverbs 29:22) Although anger may be justified at times, the Bible says that those who continue to have "fits of anger " will not gain salvation.
(Galatiatɔwo 5:19-21) Mɔfiame veviwo le Biblia me siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame ŋu wòaɖu dziku dzi.
(Galatians 5:​19-​21) The Bible contains principles that can help a person deal with anger.
Ɣesiaɣie wònye nu gbegblẽ be ame nado dzikua?
Is anger always wrong?
Dziku ka ƒomevie menyo o?
When is anger wrong?
Aleke nàwɔ aɖu dziku dzi?
How can you deal with anger?
Mawunyakpukpui siwo ku ɖe dzikudodo ŋu
Bible verses about anger
Ɣesiaɣie wònye nu gbegblẽ be ame nado dzikua?
Is anger always wrong?
Ao.
No.
Asɔ be ame nado dziku le go aɖewo me.
Anger may be justified in some cases.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi nuteƒewɔla Nehemiya se be wonɔ ye hati tadeagulawo tem ɖe anyi la, ‘dɔme vee ŋutɔ.’ Nehemiya 5:6.
For example, the faithful man Nehemiah "became very angry " when he learned that some of his fellow worshippers were being oppressed.​ Nehemiah 5:6.
Mawu doa dziku ɣeaɖewoɣi.
At times, God feels anger.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi eƒe ame siwo nɔ anyi le blema la tu nu, si wobla be yewoasubɔ eya ɖeka ko eye wova te alakpamawuwo subɔsubɔ la, "Yehowa ƒe dɔmedzoe bi ɖe " wo ŋu.
For example, when his ancient people broke their agreement to worship only him and started to serve false gods, "Jehovah’s anger blazed against " them.
(Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 2:13, 14) Ke hã, dziku mele Yehowa Mawu ƒe nɔnɔme veviawo dome o.
(Judges 2:​13, 14) Even so, anger is not a dominant aspect of Jehovah God’s personality.
Ɣesiaɣi si wòdo dziku la, etɔ dzɔna eye eléa enu hã. 2 Mose 34:6; Yesaya 48:9.
His anger is always justified and controlled.​ Exodus 34:6; Isaiah 48:9.
Dziku ka ƒomevie menyo o?
When is anger wrong?
Dziku si ƒomevi menyo o ye nye ne ame do dziku madzemadzee alo melé eƒe dzikua nu o, eye dziku sia ƒomevie amegbetɔ madeblibowo ɖena fiana zi geɖe.
Anger is wrong when it is uncontrolled or unjustified, which is often the case with the anger displayed by imperfect humans.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me:
For example:
Kain "do dɔmedzoe helĩhelĩ " esi Mawu gbe eƒe vɔsaa.
Cain "grew hot with anger " when God rejected his sacrifice.
Kain ɖe mɔ eƒe dzikua nu va sẽ ale gbegbe be wòwu nɔvia. 1 Mose 4:3-8.
Cain allowed his anger to fester to the point that he murdered his brother.​ Genesis 4:​3-8.
‘Dzi ku’ nyagblɔɖila Yona "vevie " esi Mawu kpɔ nublanui na Niniwetɔwo.
The prophet Jonah "became hot with anger " when God showed mercy to the Ninevites.
Mawu ɖɔ Yona ɖo hena wònya be ‘mesɔ be wòado dɔmedzoe nenema gbegbe’ o, eye be ɖe wòle be eƒe dɔme natrɔ ɖe nu vɔ̃ wɔla mawo siwo trɔ dzi me la ŋu hafi.
God corrected Jonah, pointing out that it was not "right for [him] to be so angry " and that he should have felt compassion for those repentant sinners.​ Jonah 3:⁠10–​4:​1, 4, 11.
Yona 3:10–4:1, 4, 11. Kpɔɖeŋu siawo ɖee fia be amegbetɔ madeblibowo ƒe "dziku mewɔa nu si le dzɔdzɔe le Mawu ŋkume o. " Yakobo 1:20.
These examples illustrate that for imperfect humans, "man’s anger does not bring about God’s righteousness. "​ James 1:​20.
Aleke nàwɔ aɖu dziku dzi?
How can you deal with anger?
De dzesi nu si dziku si dzi womeɖu o gblẽna.
Recognize the danger of uncontrolled anger.
Ame aɖewo asusu be ne yewona yewoƒe dziku fla la, ke efia be yewosẽ ŋu.
Some may think that unleashing their anger is a sign of strength.
Gake ne míagblɔe ŋutɔŋutɔ la, gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔ gã aɖe le ame si metea ŋu ɖua eƒe dziku dzi o la ŋu.
In reality, someone who cannot control his anger has a serious weakness.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ame si meɖua eƒe dziku dzi o la le abe du si ŋu wogbã gli le wòtsi nuvo ene. "
"As a city broken through, without a wall, is the man who cannot control his temper. "
(Lododowo 25:28; 29:11) Gake ne míetea ŋu ɖua míaƒe dziku dzi la, míeɖenɛ fiana be míesẽ ŋu vavã eye míesea nu gɔme.
(Proverbs 25:28; 29:11) On the other hand, when we cultivate the ability to control our anger, we demonstrate true strength and discernment.
(Lododowo 14:29) Biblia gblɔ be: "Ame si gbɔa dzi ɖi blewu la nyo wu kalẽtɔ. " Lododowo 16:32.
(Proverbs 14:29) The Bible says: "The one slow to anger is better than a mighty man. "​ Proverbs 16:32.
Ðu wò dzikua dzi hafi wòana nàwɔ nu si ava ve wò emegbe.
Deal with anger before it causes you to do something you will regret.
Psalmo 37:8 gblɔ be: "Wò dɔmedzoe nu nefa, eye nàdzudzɔ dzikudodo; dzi megaku wò ne nàtrɔ ɖe vɔ̃wɔwɔ ŋu o. "
"Let go of anger and abandon rage, " says Psalm 37:8, adding: "Do not become upset and turn to doing evil. "
De dzesii be ne míedo dziku la, míate ŋu atiae be míaɖe asi le dzikua ŋu ale be wòagana míatrɔ ɖe "vɔ̃wɔwɔ " ŋu o.
Notice that when we feel angry, we have a choice​ we can choose to let it go before we end up "doing evil. "
Efesotɔwo 4:26 gblɔ be, "mibi dzi, ke migawɔ nu vɔ̃ o. "
As Ephesians 4:​26 says, "be wrathful, but do not sin. "
Ne anya wɔ la, dzo le teƒea hafi dzikua nado gã ɖe edzi.
If possible, take your leave when anger starts to build.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dzregɔmetoto le abe ale si woŋɔa tɔʋui ene; eya ta dzudzɔ hafi wòava zu dzre. "
"Beginning a fight is like opening a floodgate, " says the Bible. "Before the quarrel breaks out, take your leave. "
(Lododowo 17:14) Togbɔ be nunya le eme be nàkpɔ masɔmasɔ siwo ɖo wò kple ame bubuwo dome gbɔ kaba hã la, ɖewohĩ ahiã be wò kple ame kemɛa ƒe dzi nafa hafi miate ŋu adzro nyaa me tufafatɔe.
(Proverbs 17:14) Although it is wise to settle differences with others quickly, both you and the other person may first need to cool down before you can discuss matters calmly.
Nya nya bliboa.
Get the facts.
Lododowo 19:11 gblɔ be: "Ame si sea nu gɔme nyuie la, medoa dziku kabakaba o. "
"The insight of a man certainly slows down his anger, " says Proverbs 19:11.
Nunya anɔ eme be míanya nya bliboa hafi aƒo nya ta.
We are wise to gather all the facts before forming a conclusion.
Ne míeɖo to se nyaa ƒe akpa sia akpa nyuie la, anɔ bɔbɔe be míaƒo asa na dzikudodo madzemadzee.
When we carefully listen to all sides of a matter, we are less likely to feel unjustified anger.​ James 1:​19.
Yakobo 1:19.
Pray for peace of mind.
Gbedodoɖa ate ŋu ana be "Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒo gɔmesesewo katã ta " nasu asiwò.
Prayer can help you experience "the peace of God that surpasses all understanding. "
(Filipitɔwo 4:7) Gbedodoɖa nye mɔ vevi aɖe si dzi míetona xɔa Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea, eye gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea wɔnɛ be míeɖea nɔnɔme nyuiwo abe dzigbɔɖi, ŋutifafa kple ɖokuidziɖuɖu ene fiana.
(Philippians 4:7) Prayer is one of the main ways we receive God’s holy spirit, which can produce in us such qualities as peace, patience, and self-control.​ Luke 11:13; Galatians 5:​22, 23.
Luka 11:13; Galatiatɔwo 5:22, 23.
Choose your associates carefully.
Wogblɔna be akpatɔ gbɔnɔla mesẽa akpa dzena o.
We tend to become like the people we associate with.
(Lododowo 13:20; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:33) Eya ta esɔ nyuie be Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí be: "Mègade ha kple dɔmedzoetɔ o, eye mègado ka kple dzikutɔ o. "
(Proverbs 13:20; 1 Corinthians 15:33) For good reason, the Bible warns: "Do not keep company with a hot-tempered man or get involved with one disposed to rage. "
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Ale be nàgava "srɔ̃ eƒe mɔwo eye wòazu mɔ̃ aɖe wò o. " Lododowo 22:24, 25.
"So that you never learn his ways and ensnare yourself. "​ Proverbs 22:24, 25.
Mawunyakpukpui siwo ku ɖe dzikudodo ŋu
Bible verses about anger
Lododowo 16:32: "Ame si gbɔa dzi ɖi blewu la nyo wu kalẽtɔ. "
Proverbs 16:32: "The one slow to anger is better than a mighty man. "
Efia be: Ne èɖua wò dziku dzi la, ke èle eɖem fia be yesẽ ŋu.
Meaning: It is a sign of strength to control your anger.
Lododowo 17:14: "Dzregɔmetoto le abe ale si woŋɔa tɔʋui ene; eya ta dzudzɔ hafi wòava zu dzre. "
Proverbs 17:14: "Beginning a fight is like opening a floodgate; before the quarrel breaks out, take your leave. "
Efia be: Ne èkpɔe be dɔmedzoe te flafla la, dzo le teƒea kpoo.
Meaning: If tempers are flaring, leave the scene.
Lododowo 19:11: "Ame si sea nu gɔme nyuie la, medoa dziku kabakaba o. "
Proverbs 19:11: "The insight of a man certainly slows down his anger. "
Efia be: Míate ŋu aƒo asa na dzikudodo dzodzro ne míede ŋugble le nyaa ƒe akpa sia akpa ŋu, ke menye be míaƒo nya ta evɔ míenya nya bliboa o.
Meaning: We can prevent unnecessary anger by considering all aspects of a situation rather than forming conclusions before we have all the facts.
Lododowo 22:24, 25: "Mègade ha kple dɔmedzoetɔ o, eye mègado ka kple dzikutɔ o, ne nàva srɔ̃ eƒe mɔwo . . . o. "
Proverbs 22:24, 25: "Do not keep company with a hot-tempered man or get involved with one disposed to rage, so that you never learn his ways. "
Efia be: Ne míedea ha kple ame siwo doa dziku kabakaba la, míate ŋu ava nɔ abe woawo ke ene.
Meaning: If we associate with people who are prone to anger, we will probably become like them.
Lododowo 29:11: "Bometsila dudua eƒe seselelãme katã kɔna ɖi. "
Proverbs 29:11: "A stupid person gives vent to all his feelings. "
Efia be: Nunya le eme be míaɖu míaƒe seselelãmewo dzi tsɔ wu be míaɖe mɔ woakpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe mía dzi.
Meaning: We are wise to control our emotions rather than to let them control us.
Galatiatɔwo 5:22, 23: "Gbɔgbɔ la ƒe kutsetse ye nye lɔlɔ̃, dzidzɔ, ŋutifafa, dzigbɔgbɔ blewu, dɔmenyonyo, nyuiwɔwɔ, xɔse, tufafa, ɖokuidziɖuɖu. "
Galatians 5:​22, 23: "The fruitage of the spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faith, mildness, self-control. "
Efia be: Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔea, alo eƒe dɔwɔŋusẽa, ate ŋu ana míatu nɔnɔme siwo akpe ɖe mía ŋu míaɖu dziku dzi la ɖo.
Meaning: God’s holy spirit, or his power in action, can produce in us qualities that help to counter anger.
Efesotɔwo 4:26: "Mibi dzi, ke migawɔ nu vɔ̃ o. "
Ephesians 4:​26: "Be wrathful, but do not sin. "
Efia be: Menye ɣesiaɣie míate ŋu aƒo asa na dzikudodo o, gake míate ŋu aɖu míaƒe dziku dzi.
Meaning: We cannot always prevent ourselves from feeling anger, but we can control how we deal with it.
Yakobo 1:19: "Ame sia ame naɖe abla le nusese me, nanɔ blewu le nuƒoƒo me, nanɔ blewu le dziku me. "
James 1:​19: "Everyone must be quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger. "
Efia be: Ne míenye toɖola nyuiwo la, ate ŋu ana míanɔ blewu le dziku me.
Meaning: We can slow down our anger by being a good listener.
Ame Nyui Aɖe Koe Yesu Nyea?
Was Jesus Just a Good Man?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ame si Yesu nye la yi ŋgɔ wu ema.
Jesus was more than just a good man.
Ne mede ɖeke o la, enye ame si ƒe agbenɔnɔ kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi wu le ŋutinya me.
At the very least, he has proved to be the most influential man in human history.
De dzesi nya siwo ŋutinyaŋlɔla kple agbalẽŋlɔla xɔŋkɔ siawo gblɔ tso eŋu:
Note what these famous historians and writers have said about him:
"Ðikeke mele eme o be Yesu Nazaretetɔ . . . lae nye ame vevitɔ kekeake si nɔ anyi kpɔ. "
"Jesus of Nazareth . . . is easily the dominant figure in history. "
Eŋlisiawo ƒe ŋutinyaŋlɔla H. G. Wells.
H. G. Wells, English historian.
"[Yesu] ƒe agbenɔnɔe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi wu le anyigba sia dzi, eye wòyi edzi le ŋusẽ kpɔm ɖe amewo dzi geɖe wu. "
"[Jesus’] life is the most influential ever lived on this planet and its effect continues to mount. "
Amerikatɔwo ƒe ŋutinyaŋlɔla kple agbalẽŋlɔla Kenneth Scott Latourette.
Kenneth Scott Latourette, American historian and author.
Biblia gblɔ nu si tae Yesu ƒe agbenɔnɔ kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi wu ame nyui ɖe sia ɖe si nɔ anyigba dzi kpɔ tɔ la na mí.
The Bible identifies why Jesus has had a greater impact than any other good man who ever lived.
Esi Yesu bia eyomedzela siwo nɔa eŋu kplikplikpli la be ame kae wobuna be yenye hã la, wo dometɔ ɖeka ɖo eŋu wòsɔ nyuie be: "Wòe nye Kristo la, Mawu gbagbe la ƒe Vi. "
When Jesus asked his closest followers who they thought he was, one of them correctly answered: "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God. "
Mateo 16:16.
Matthew 16:16.
Yesue Nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔa?
Is Jesus Almighty God?
Ale si Bibia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yesu ƒe futɔwo tsɔ nya ɖe eŋu be etsɔ eɖokui sɔ kple Mawu.
Jesus’ opposers accused him of making himself equal to God.
(Yohanes 5:18; 10:30-33) Ke hã Yesu megblɔ kpɔ be yele tasɔsɔ me kple Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la o.
(John 5:18; 10:30-33) However, Jesus never claimed to be on the same level as Almighty God.
Egblɔ be: "Fofo la lolo wum. "
He said: "The Father is greater than I am. "
Yohanes 14:28.
John 14:28.
Yesu yomedzelawo mebu Yesu be esɔ kple Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la o.
Jesus’ early followers did not view him as being equal to Almighty God.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, apostolo Paulo ŋlɔ ɖi be esi wofɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre megbe la, "Mawu [do Yesu] ɖe dzi wòle nɔƒe kɔkɔ aɖe. "
For example, the apostle Paul wrote that after Jesus was resurrected, God "exalted him [Jesus] to a superior position. "
Eme kɔ ƒãa be Paulo mebui be Yesue nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la o.
Obviously, Paul did not believe that Jesus was Almighty God.
Ne menye nenema o la, aleke wɔ Mawu agado Yesu ɖe dzi wòava nɔ ɖoƒe kɔkɔ?
Otherwise, how could God exalt Jesus to a superior position?
Filipitɔwo 2:9.
Philippians 2:9.
Nu Ka Tae Woyɔa Yesu Be Mawu Ƒe Vi?
Why Is Jesus Called the Son of God?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Woyɔa Yesu le Biblia me zi geɖe be "Mawu ƒe Vi. "
The Bible often calls Jesus "the Son of God. "
(Yohanes 1:49) Biblia zã nyagbɔgblɔ "Mawu ƒe Vi " le gɔmesesea nu be Mawue nye Wɔla la, alo agbe ɖe sia ɖe Dzɔtsoƒe eye Yesu ƒe agbe hã le eme.
(John 1:49) The expression "Son of God " acknowledges that God is the Creator, or Source, of all life, including that of Jesus.
(Psalmo 36:9; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11) Biblia megblɔ be Mawu dzi Yesu abe ale si amegbetɔwo dzia vi ene o.
(Psalm 36:9; Revelation 4:11) The Bible does not teach that God literally fathered a child in the same way that humans produce children.
Woyɔa mawudɔlawo hã le Biblia me be "Mawu vavã la ƒe viwo. "
The Bible also calls the angels "sons of the true God. "
(Hiob 1:6) Biblia gblɔ tso amegbetɔ gbãtɔ, Adam, ŋu be enye "Mawu ƒe vi. "
(Job 1:6) And the Bible says that the first human, Adam, was a "son of God. "
(Luka 3:38) Ke hã, esi wònye be Yesue nye Mawu ƒe nuwɔwɔ gbãtɔ, eye eya koe nye ame si Mawu ŋutɔ wɔ tẽe ta la, Biblia gblɔ tso Yesu ŋu be enye Mawu ƒe Vi vevitɔ.
(Luke 3:38) However, because Jesus was God’s first creation and the only one created directly by him, the Bible describes Jesus as the foremost Son of God.
Ðe Yesu nɔ dziƒo kpɔ hafi wova dzii ɖe anyigba dzia?
Did Jesus live in heaven before he was born on earth?
Nu kawoe Yesu nɔ wɔwɔm le dziƒo hafi va anyigba dzi?
What did Jesus do before he came to the earth?
Ðe Yesu nɔ dziƒo kpɔ hafi wova dzii ɖe anyigba dzia?
Did Jesus live in heaven before he was born on earth?
Yes.
Yesu nye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ nɔ dziƒo hafi wova dzii ɖe anyigba dzi.
Jesus was a spirit creature in heaven before he was born as a human on earth.
Yesu ŋutɔ gblɔ be: "Meɖi tso dziƒo va. "
Jesus himself said: "I have come down from heaven. "
Yohanes 6:38; 8:23.
Mawu wɔ Yesu hafi wɔ nu bubu ɖe sia ɖe.
God created Jesus before he created anything else.
Biblia gblɔ tso Yesu ŋu be:
Regarding Jesus, the Bible says:
"Eyae nye . . . nuwɔwɔwo katã ƒe gbãtɔ. "
"He is . . . the firstborn of all creation. "
Kolosetɔwo 1:15.
Colossians 1:15.
Eyae nye "Mawu ƒe nuwɔwɔ ƒe gɔmedzedze. "
He is "the beginning of the creation by God. "
Nyaɖeɖefia 3:14.
Revelation 3:14.
Yesu ŋue wogblɔ le be enye "ame si dzɔɣi tso blemablema ke, tso gbe aɖe gbe ʋĩi ke. "
Jesus fulfilled the prophecy about the one "whose origin is from ancient times, from the days of long ago. "
Mika 5:2; Mateo 2:4-6.
Micah 5:2; Matthew 2:4-6.
Nu kawoe Yesu nɔ wɔwɔm le dziƒo hafi va anyigba dzi?
What did Jesus do before he came to the earth?
Enɔ ɖoƒe kɔkɔ aɖe le dziƒo.
He held an exalted heavenly position.
Yesu he susu yi ɖoƒe sia dzi esi wòdo gbe ɖa be: "Fofo, tsɔ ŋutikɔkɔe si nɔ asinye le gbɔwò hafi xexea va dzɔ la dom ɖe dzi. "
Jesus referred to this position when he prayed: "Father, glorify me . . . with the glory that I had alongside you before the world was. "
Yohanes 17:5.
John 17:5.
Ekpe ɖe Fofoa ŋu le nu bubuwo katã wɔwɔ me.
He helped his Father create all other things.
Yesu wɔ dɔ aduadu kple Mawu abe "dɔwɔla bibi " ene.
Jesus worked alongside God "as a master worker. "
(Lododowo 8:30) Biblia gblɔ le Yesu ŋu be: "Eya dzie woto wɔ nu bubu siwo katã le dziƒowo kple anyigba dzi. "
(Proverbs 8:30) Regarding Jesus, the Bible says: "By means of him all other things were created in the heavens and on the earth. "
Kolosetɔwo 1:16.
Colossians 1:16.
Mawu to Yesu dzi wɔ nu bubuwo katã.
God worked through Jesus to bring every other creation into existence.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye mawudɔlawo kple xexe gbahooa.
This creation included all other spirit creatures, as well as the physical universe.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 5:11) Le mɔ aɖe nu la, míate ŋu atsɔ ale si Mawu kple Yesu wɔ dɔ aduadui la asɔ kple ale si xɔtuɖaŋunyala kple xɔtula wɔa dɔe.
(Revelation 5:11) In some respects, this cooperation between God and Jesus was like that of an architect working with a builder.
Xɔtuɖaŋunyalaa wɔa ale si woatu xɔa ƒe nɔnɔmetata, eye xɔtulaa kpɔa nɔnɔmetataa dzi tua xɔa.
The architect creates the design; the builder brings the design to reality.
Yesu nye Nya la.
He served as the Word.
Esi Biblia nɔ nu ƒom tso Yesu ƒe agbenɔnɔ le dziƒo do ŋgɔ na eƒe anyigba dzi vava ŋu la, eyɔe be "Nya la. "
When speaking of Jesus’ prehuman life, the Bible calls Jesus "the Word. "
(Yohanes 1:1) Anɔ eme be esia fia be Mawu to Via dzi tsɔ gbedeasiwo kple mɔfiamewo na mawudɔla bubuawo.
(John 1:1) Evidently, this means that God used his Son to convey information and instructions to other spirit creatures.
Azɔ hã, anɔ eme be Mawu zã Yesu abe eƒe Nyanuɖela ene tsɔ ƒo nu na amegbetɔwo le anyigba dzi.
Jesus also seems to have acted as God’s Spokesman to humans on earth.
Anɔ eme be Mawu ƒo nu to Yesu dzi abe Nya la ene esime wònɔ mɔfiame nam Adam kple Xawa le Eden-bɔa me.
God likely spoke through Jesus as the Word when giving instructions to Adam and Eve in the garden of Eden.
(1 Mose 2:16, 17) Ðewohĩ Yesu ye nye mawudɔla si kplɔ blema Israel-viwo le gbea dzi, ame si ƒe gbe dzi wòle be Israel-viwo nawɔ pɛpɛpɛ.
(Genesis 2:16, 17) Jesus may have been the angel who guided the ancient Israelites through the wilderness and whose voice the Israelites were strictly to obey.
Exodus 23:20-23.
Ame Kae Nye Kristo Ƒe Futɔ La?
Who Is the Antichrist?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Kristo ƒe futɔ la menye ame ɖeka alo habɔbɔ ɖeka aɖe koŋ o, elabe Biblia gblɔ be "Kristo ƒe futɔ geɖewo " li. (1 Yohanes 2:18) Helagbe me nya si gɔme woɖe be "Kristo ƒe futɔ " la fia "ame si tsi tsitre ɖe Kristo ŋu alo tsɔ eɖokui ɖo eteƒe. " Ame sia ame si wɔa nu siwo gbɔna la nye Kristo ƒe futɔ:

The antichrist is not merely one individual person or entity, for the Bible says that there are "many antichrists. " (1 John 2:​18) Rather, the term "antichrist, " which comes from a Greek word meaning "against (or instead of) Christ, " refers to anyone who does the following:
Egblɔna be menye Yesue nye Kristo (Mesia) la o alo gblɔna be menye Mawu ƒe Vie wònye o.​ 1 Yohanes 2:18.
Denies that Jesus is the Christ (Messiah) or denies that he is the Son of God.​ 1 John 2:​22.
Etsia tsitre ɖe Kristo, Mawu ƒe Amesiamina la, ŋu.​ Psalmo 2:1, 2; Luka 11:23.
Opposes the Christ, God’s Anointed One.​ Psalm 2:​1, 2; Luke 11:23.
Egblɔna be yee nye Kristo la.​ Mateo 24:24.
Pretends to be the Christ.​ Matthew 24:24.
Etia Kristo yomedzelawo yome, elabe Yesu bua nu sia nu si wowɔ ɖe wo ŋu be ye ŋutɔ ŋue wòwɔe ɖo.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 9:5.
Persecutes the followers of Christ, since Jesus views what is done to them as being done to him.​ Acts 9:5.
Edaa alakpa be Kristotɔe yenye evɔ tsɔa sedzimawɔmawɔ kple amebeble ɖoa dɔe.​ Mateo 7:22, 23; 2 Korintotɔwo 11:13.
Falsely claims to be a Christian while practicing lawlessness or deception.​ Matthew 7:​22, 23; 2 Corinthians 11:13.

Biblia yɔ ame siwo wɔa nu siawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe be Kristo ƒe futɔwo eye wògayɔ wo katã abe ƒuƒoƒo ene be "Kristo ƒe futɔ. " (2 Yohanes 7) Kristo ƒe futɔ la do zi gbãtɔ le apostoloawo ƒe ŋkekeawo me eye wògale dɔ dzi vevie va se ɖe egbe.

Besides speaking of individuals who take such actions as being antichrists, the Bible also refers to them collectively as "the antichrist. " (2 John 7) The antichrist first appeared in the time of the apostles and has been active ever since.
Biblia gblɔ esia ɖi.​ 1 Yohanes 4:3.
Bible prophecy foretold just such a development.​ 1 John 4:3.
Ale si nàwɔ akpɔ Kristo ƒe futɔ la adze sii
How to identify antichrists
Wogblɔa alakpanyawo tso Yesu ŋu.
They promote false ideas related to Jesus.

(Mateo 24:9, 11) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ame siwo fiaa Trinita Kɔkɔe alo Mawuɖekaetɔ̃ alo fiaa nu be Yesue nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la tsia tsitre ɖe nya si Yesu gblɔ be "Fofo la lolo wum " la ŋu tẽe.​ Yohanes 14:28.
(Matthew 24:​9, 11) For example, those who teach the Trinity or that Jesus is Almighty God actually oppose the teachings of Jesus, who said: "The Father is greater than I am. "​ John 14:28.
Kristo ƒe futɔ la medaa asi ɖe nu si Yesu fiaa ku ɖe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe dɔwɔwɔ ŋu la dzi o.
Antichrists reject what Jesus said about how God’s Kingdom operates.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, sɔlemehakplɔla aɖewo gblɔna be amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo zãmee Kristo le le eƒe dɔwɔwɔwo me.
For instance, some religious leaders say that Christ works through human governments.
Ke hã woƒe nufiafia sia tsi tsitre ɖe Yesu ŋu, elabe eya ŋutɔ gblɔ be: "Nye Fiaɖuƒe menye xexe sia ƒe akpa aɖeke o. "​ Yohanes 18:36.
Yet, this teaching contradicts Jesus, who said: "My Kingdom is no part of this world. "​ John 18:36.
Wogblɔna be Yesue nye yewoƒe Aƒetɔ gake womewɔna ɖe eƒe sededewo dzi o. Eƒe sedede siawo dometɔ ɖekae nye be woaɖe gbeƒã Fiaɖuƒea ŋuti nya nyuia.​ Mateo 28:19, 20; Luka 6:46; Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:42.
They say that Jesus is their Lord, but they do not obey his commands, including the one to preach the good news of the Kingdom.​ Matthew 28:19, 20; Luke 6:​46; Acts 10:42.
Ame Kae Alo Nu Kae Nye Mawu Ƒe Nya La?
Who or What Is the Word of God?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Zi geɖe la, nyagbɔgblɔ "Mawu ƒe nya " fiaa Mawu ƒe gbedeasi alo nya siwo wògblɔ.
The expression "the word of God " usually refers to a divine message or to a collection of those messages.
(Luka 11:28) Wozãa "Mawu Ƒe Nya " alo "Nya La " le teƒe ʋɛ aɖewo wònyea dzesideŋkɔ.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 19:13; Yohanes 1:14.
(Luke 11:28) In a few places, "The Word of God " or "the Word " is used as a personal title.​ Revelation 19:13; John 1:​14.
Mawu ƒe gbedeasi.
A divine message.
Nyagblɔɖilawo gblɔna zi geɖe be gbedeasi siwo yewogblɔna la nye Mawu ƒe nya.
The prophets often stated that the messages they delivered were God’s word.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yeremiya dze eƒe nyagblɔɖi gbedeasia gɔme be, "Yehowa ƒe gbe va nam. "
For example, Jeremiah introduced his prophetic messages with the expression "the word of Jehovah came to me. "
(Yeremiya 1:4, 11, 13; 2:1) Hafi nyagblɔɖila Samuel nagblɔ na Saul be Mawu tiae be wòanye fia la, nyagblɔɖilaa gblɔ be: "Tɔ ne magblɔ Mawu ƒe gbe na wò. "​ 1 Samuel 9:27.
(Jeremiah 1:​4, 11, 13; 2:1) Before telling Saul that God had chosen him as king, the prophet Samuel said: "Stand still now, so that I may let you hear the word of God. "​ 1 Samuel 9:​27.
Dzesideŋkɔ.
A personal title.
Biblia zã "Nya la " wònye dzesideŋkɔ na Yesu Kristo esime wònye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ le dziƒo kple esime wònye amegbetɔ nɔ anyigba dzi.
"The Word " also appears in the Bible as a title for Jesus Christ, both as a spirit in heaven and as a human on earth.
Kpɔ susu siwo tae míate ŋu aƒo nya ta alea ɖo la ɖa:
Consider some reasons for this conclusion:
Nya la nɔ agbe do ŋgɔ na nuwɔwɔ bubuwo katã.
The Word lived before all other creation.
"Le gɔmedzedzea me, Nya la li, . . .
"In the beginning was the Word . . .
Ame sia nɔ anyi kple Mawu le gɔmedzedzea me. "
This one was in the beginning with God. "
(Yohanes 1:1, 2) Yesue nye "nuwɔwɔwo katã ƒe gbãtɔ . . .
(John 1:​1, 2) Jesus is "the firstborn of all creation . . .
Etre dzɔdzɔ na nu bubuwo katã hã. "​ Kolosetɔwo 1:13-15, 17.
He is before all other things. "​ Colossians 1:​13-​15, 17.
Nya la va anyigba dzi abe amegbetɔ ene.
The Word came to earth as a human.
"Nya la va zu amegbetɔ, enɔ mía dome. "
"The Word became flesh and resided among us. "
(Yohanes 1:14) Kristo Yesu ‘ɖi gbɔlo eɖokui, eye wòtsɔ kluvi ƒe nɔnɔme heva zu amegbetɔ.’​ Filipitɔwo 2:5-7.
(John 1:​14) Christ Jesus "emptied himself and took a slave’s form and became human. "​ Philippians 2:​5-7.
Nya la nye Mawu ƒe Vi.
The Word is God’s Son.
Esi apostolo Yohanes gblɔ be "Nya la va zu amegbetɔ " vɔ la, eyi edzi be: "Míekpɔ eƒe ŋutikɔkɔe si le abe tenuvi ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe tso fofoa gbɔ ene. "
After stating that "the Word became flesh, " as quoted above, the apostle John continued: "We had a view of his glory, a glory such as belongs to an only-begotten son from a father. "
(Yohanes 1:14) Yohanes gaŋlɔ hã be: "Yesu Kristoe nye Mawu ƒe Vi la. "​ 1 Yohanes 4:15.
(John 1:​14) John also wrote: "Jesus is God’s Son. "​ 1 John 4:​15.
Mawu ƒe nɔnɔmewo le Nya la si.
The Word possesses godlike attributes.
"Nya la nye mawu aɖe. "
"The Word was a god, " or "was divine. "
(Yohanes 1:1) Yesu "ɖe Mawu ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe fia eye wònye eƒe amenyenye ƒe nɔnɔme pɛpɛpɛ. "​ Hebritɔwo 1:2, 3.
(John 1:1; An American Translation) Jesus is "the reflection of God’s glory and the exact representation of his very being. "​ Hebrews 1:​2, 3.
Nya la nye fia.
The Word rules as a king.
Biblia gblɔ be "fiakuku geɖewo le ta " na Mawu ƒe Nya la.
The Bible states that on the head of the Word of God are "many royal headbands. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:12, 13) Wogayɔ Nya la be "fiawo dzi Fia kple aƒetɔwo dzi Aƒetɔ. "
(Revelation 19:12, 13; footnote) The Word is also named "King of kings and Lord of lords. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:16) Woyɔ Yesu be ‘fiawo katã ƒe Fia kple aƒetɔwo katã ƒe Aƒetɔ.’​ 1 Timoteo 6:14, 15.
(Revelation 19:16) Jesus is called "the King of those who rule as kings and Lord of those who rule as lords. "​ 1 Timothy 6:​14, 15.
Nya la nye Mawu ƒe nyanuɖela.
The Word serves as God’s spokesman.
Dzesideŋkɔ "Nya la " fia be Mawu toa ame si ŋu ŋkɔ ma le la dzi gblɔa eƒe gbedeasiwo kple mɔfiamewo.
The title "the Word " apparently identifies its bearer as one whom God uses to convey information and instructions.
Yesu gblɔ be Mawu zãa ye aleae esi wògblɔ be: "Fofo si dɔm ɖa la ŋutɔe na nya si magblɔ kple ale si maƒo nui ƒe sem. . . .
Jesus said that he performed this role: "The Father who sent me has himself given me a commandment about what to say and what to speak. . . .
Eya ŋuti nya siwo megblɔna la, megblɔa wo abe ale si tututu Fofo la gblɔ wo nam ene. "​ Yohanes 12:49, 50.
So whatever I speak, I speak just as the Father has told me. "​ John 12:49, 50.
Ame Kae Nye Mawudɔla Gãtɔ Mikael?
Who Is the Archangel Michael?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Edze ƒãa be Mikael, si subɔsubɔha aɖewo yɔna be "Mikael Kɔkɔe, " ye nye ŋkɔ si wona Yesu le dziƒo hafi wòva anyigba dzi kple esi wòtrɔ yi dziƒo.
Michael, referred to by some religions as "Saint Michael, " is evidently a name given to Jesus before and after his life on earth.
Mikael ʋli nya kple Satana le Mose ƒe kukua ŋu, eye wògakpe ɖe mawudɔla aɖe hã ŋu wòtsɔ Mawu ƒe gbedeasi yi na nyagblɔɖila Daniel.
Michael disputed with Satan after the death of Moses and helped an angel deliver God’s message to the prophet Daniel.

(Daniel 10:13, 21; Yuda 9) Ŋkɔ Mikael gɔmee nye "Ame Kae Le Abe Mawu Ene, " eye Yesu nɔ agbe wòsɔ kple ŋkɔ ma, elabena eʋli Mawu ƒe dziɖulanyenye ta eye wòwɔ aʋa kple Mawu ƒe futɔwo.​ Daniel 12:1; Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7.
(Daniel 10:13, 21; Jude 9) Michael lives up to the meaning of his name​ "Who Is Like God? "​ by defending God’s rulership and fighting God’s enemies.​ Daniel 12:1; Revelation 12:7.
Kpɔ susu siwo tae wòsɔ be woaƒo nya ta be Yesue nye mawudɔla gãtɔ Mikael la ɖa.
Consider why it is reasonable to conclude that Jesus is the archangel Michael.
Mikael ye nye "mawudɔla gãtɔ " la.
Michael is "the archangel. "
(Yuda 9) Dzesideŋkɔ "mawudɔla gãtɔ, " si fia "mawudɔlawo ƒe tatɔ " la dze le Biblia me zi eve pɛ ko.
(Jude 9) The title "archangel, " meaning "chief of the angels, " appears in only two Bible verses.
Le go evea siaa me la, womegblɔ be "mawudɔla gãtɔwo " abe ɖe wosɔ gbɔ ene o; esia fia be mawudɔla ɖeka ŋu koe ŋkɔ ma le.
In both cases, the word is singular, suggesting that only one angel bears that title.

Kpukpuiawo dometɔ ɖeka gblɔ be Aƒetɔ Yesu si wofɔ ɖe tsitre la "atsɔ gbeɖeɖe sesẽ kple mawudɔla gãtɔ ƒe gbe . . . aɖi tso dziƒo. " (1 Tesalonikatɔwo 4:16) "Mawudɔla gãtɔ ƒe gbe " le Yesu si, elabena eyae nye mawudɔla gãtɔ Mikael.

One of those verses states that the resurrected Lord Jesus "will descend from heaven with a commanding call, with an archangel’s voice. " (1 Thessalonians 4:​16) Jesus has "an archangel’s voice " because he is the archangel, Michael.
Mikael ye le mawudɔlawo ƒe aʋakɔa nu.
Michael commands an angelic army.
"Mikael kple eƒe dɔlawo wɔ aʋa kple ʋɔ driba la, " si nye Satana.
"Michael and his angels battled with the dragon, " Satan.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7) Ŋusẽ geɖe le Mikael si le dziƒonutowo me, elabena woyɔe be "amegã, " kple "amegãwo ƒe tatɔwo dometɔ ɖeka. "
(Revelation 12:7) Michael has great authority in the spirit realm, for he is called "one of the foremost princes " and "the great prince. "
(Daniel 10:13, 21; 12:1) Dzesideŋkɔ siawo fia be Mikael ye nye "mawudɔlawo ƒe aʋakɔa ƒe tatɔ " abe ale si Nubabla Yeyea ŋuti nunyala David E. Aune gblɔe ene.
(Daniel 10:13, 21; 12:1) These titles designate Michael as "the commander-in-chief of the angelic forces, " as New Testament scholar David E. Aune puts it.
Teƒe bubu ɖeka aɖe koe Biblia gagblɔ le be ame aɖe kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe mawudɔlawo ƒe aʋakɔa dzi.
The Bible mentions only one other name of someone having authority over an army of angels.

Eƒo nu tso "Aƒetɔ Yesu kple eƒe dɔla sẽŋuwo ƒe ɖeɖefia tso dziƒo . . . , esime wòabia hlɔ̃ " ŋu. (2 Tesalonikatɔwo 1:7, 8; Mateo 16:27) Yesu yi "dziƒo, . . . eye wotsɔ mawudɔlawo kple dziɖulawo kpakple ŋusẽtɔwo de ete. " (1 Petro 3:21, 22) Fia eve menɔa zikpui ɖeka dzi o, eya ta Mawu mate ŋu aɖo ame vovo eve, siwo nye Yesu kple Mikael, be woanye mawudɔla kɔkɔewo ƒe tatɔ o.

It describes "the revelation of the Lord Jesus from heaven with his powerful angels in a flaming fire, as he brings vengeance. " (2 Thessalonians 1:​7, 8; Matthew 16:27) Jesus "went to heaven, and angels and authorities and powers were made subject to him. " (1 Peter 3:​21, 22) It would not make sense for God to set up Jesus and Michael as rival commanders of the holy angels.
Eya ta míate ŋu aƒo nya ta wòasɔ be ŋkɔ evea siaa, Yesu kple Mikael, yi na ame ɖeka.
Rather, it is more reasonable to conclude that both names, Jesus and Michael, refer to the same person.
Mikael "ado " le "xaxaɣi " si meva kpɔ o la me.
Michael "will stand up " during an unprecedented "time of distress. "
(Daniel 12:1) Le Daniel ƒe agbalẽa me la, wozãa nya ‘do’ wòkuna ɖe fia aɖe si tso be yeaɖe afɔ vevi aɖe ŋu.
(Daniel 12:1) In the book of Daniel, the expression "stand up " is often used to refer to a king who rises up to take special action.
(Daniel 11:​2-4, 21) Yesu Kristo si wogayɔna be "Mawu Ƒe Nya La, " eye wònye "fiawo dzi Fia " la aɖe afɔ vevi aɖe atsrɔ̃ Mawu ƒe futɔwo katã ahakpɔ Mawu ƒe amewo ta.
(Daniel 11:​2-4, 21) Jesus Christ, identified as "The Word of God, " will take special action as the "King of kings " to strike down all of God’s enemies and protect God’s people.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 19:11-16) Awɔ esia le "xaxa gã si tɔgbi meva kpɔ tso xexea ƒe gɔmedzedze va se ɖe fifia o " la me.​ Mateo 24:21, 42.
(Revelation 19:11-​16) He will do so during a time of "great tribulation such as has not occurred since the world’s beginning. "​ Matthew 24:21, 42.
Ɣekaɣie Wodzi Yesu?
When Was Jesus Born?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia meyɔ ŋkeke si tututu dzi wodzi Yesu o, abe ale si wòdze le numekugbalẽ siawo mee ene:
The Bible does not give a specific date for the birth of Jesus Christ, as these reference works show:
"Ame aɖeke menya gbe si gbe tututu wodzi Kristo o. "
"The true birth date of Christ is unknown. "
New Catholic Encyclopedia.
New Catholic Encyclopedia.
"Gbe si gbe tututu wodzi Kristo la mele nyanya o. "
"The exact date of Christ’s birth is not known. "
Encyclopedia of Early Christianity.
Encyclopedia of Early Christianity.
Togbɔ be Biblia meɖo nyabiase si nye ‘Ɣekaɣie wodzi Yesu?’ ŋu tẽe o hã la, eƒo nu tso nu siwo dzɔ le edziɣi ŋu si na ame geɖe va ƒo nya ta be menye December 25 lia dzie wodzi Yesu o.
While the Bible does not directly answer the question, ‘When was Jesus born?’ it does describe two events surrounding his birth that lead many to conclude that he was not born on December 25.
Mate ŋu anye vuvɔŋɔli o
Not in winter
Ŋkɔŋɔŋlɔ.
The registration.
Do ŋgɔ na Yesu dzidzi teti la, Kaisaro Augusto de se be "woaŋlɔ anyigba dzi nɔlawo katã ƒe ŋkɔ. "
Shortly before Jesus was born, Caesar Augustus issued a decree ordering "all the inhabited earth to be registered. "
Ame sia ame aŋlɔ ŋkɔ "le wo dedu me. " Esia abia be amewo nazɔ kwasiɖa ɖeka alo esi wu nenema ayi wo de.
Everyone had to register in "his own city, " which might have required a journey of a week or more.

(Luka 2:1-3) Ðewohĩ ɖe wòde se ma kple susu be yeanya dukɔmeviwo ƒe xexlẽme le adzɔxɔxɔ kple ame siwo awɔ asrafodɔ ta. Dukɔa makpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe sedede ma ŋu kura o eɖanye ƒea ƒe ɣekaɣie wòɖadee o. Eya ta edze ƒãa be Augusto madi be yeado dziku na eteviwo ɖe edzi to wo dometɔ geɖe dzi zizi be woazɔ mɔ legbee ma le vuvɔŋɔli me o.

(Luke 2:1-3) That order probably made to support taxation and military conscription would have been unpopular at any time of year, but it is unlikely that Augustus would have provoked his subjects further by forcing many of them to make long trips during the cold winter.
Lãhawo.
The sheep.
Alẽkplɔlawo hã nɔ "nuto ma ke me le gbedadaƒo, nɔ woƒe lãhawo ŋu dzɔm le zã me. "
Shepherds were "living out of doors and keeping watches in the night over their flocks. "
(Luka 2:8) Eye agbalẽ si nye Daily Life in the Time of Jesus gblɔ be alẽwo nɔa dogba dzi tso "kwasiɖa si do ŋgɔ na Ŋutitotoŋkekenyuia [March ƒe nuwuwu] " va se ɖe November ƒe domedome.
(Luke 2:8) The book Daily Life in the Time of Jesus notes that flocks lived in the open air from "the week before the Passover [late March] " through mid-November.
Egblɔ kpee be: "Wonɔa kpo me le vuvɔŋɔli; eye esia ɖeɖe dzaa ɖee fia be ŋkeke si woɖo na Kristmas-ɖuɖu, le vuvɔŋɔli la, mesɔ o, elabena Nya nyui gbalẽawo gblɔ be alẽkplɔlawo nɔ gbedzi. "

It then adds: "They passed the winter under cover; and from this alone it may be seen that the traditional date for Christmas, in the winter, is unlikely to be right, since the Gospel says that the shepherds were in the fields. "
Kele ƒe gɔmedzedze
In early fall
Míate ŋu abu akɔnta anya ɣeyiɣi si me wodzi Yesu ne míebui tso eƒe ku dzi le Nisan 14 ƒe Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui si woɖu le ƒe 33 ƒe adame dzi.
We can estimate when Jesus was born by counting backward from his death on Passover, Nisan 14 in the spring of the year 33 C.E.
(Yohanes 19:14-16) Yesu xɔ abe ƒe 30 ene esime wòdze eƒe subɔsubɔdɔ si xɔ ƒe etɔ̃ kple afã la gɔme, eya ta ƒe 2 D.Ŋ.Y. ƒe kele ƒe gɔmedzedzee wodzi Yesu. Luka 3:23.
(John 19:14-16) Jesus was about 30 years old when he began his three-and-a-half-year ministry, so he was born in the early fall of 2 B.C.E. Luke 3:23.
Nu ka tae woɖua Kristmas le December 25 lia dzi?
Why is Christmas on December 25?
Esi wònye be kpeɖodzi aɖeke meli be December 25 lia dzie wodzi Yesu Kristo o ɖe, ke nu ka tae woɖua azã sia le ŋkeke ma dzi?
Since there is no evidence that the birth of Jesus Christ occurred on December 25, why is Christmas celebrated on this date?
Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be ɖe sɔlemehaŋgɔnɔlawo tia ŋkeke ma be wòadze "Romatɔ trɔ̃subɔlawo ƒe azã si nye ‘ɣe si dzi womeɖuna o ƒe dzigbezã’ dzi " le vuvɔŋɔli.
The Encyclopædia Britannica says that church leaders probably chose it "to coincide with the pagan Roman festival marking the ‘birthday of the unconquered sun,’ " at the time of the winter solstice.

(The New Encyclopædia Britannica) Le numekugbalẽ si nye The Encyclopedia Americana ƒe nya nu la, nunyalagã geɖewo xɔe se be ɖe wowɔ esia "be Kristotɔnyenye nado dzidzɔ na trɔ̃subɔla siwo trɔ zu Kristotɔwo. "
According to The Encyclopedia Americana, many scholars believe that this was done "in order to make Christianity more meaningful to pagan converts. "
Ame Kawoe Nye "Nunyala Etɔ̃awo "?
Who Were the "Three Wise Men "?
Mawue Na Betlehem Ƒe "Ɣletivi " La Fia Mɔ Woa?
Did They Follow the "Star " of Bethlehem?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Ame geɖe gblɔna be "nunyala etɔ̃ " alo "fia etɔ̃ " ye va kpɔ Yesu ɖa esime wodzii, abe ale si wòdzena le Kristmas ɖuɖu ŋuti kɔnuwo me ene, gake Biblia megblɔ be "nunyala etɔ̃ " alo "fia etɔ̃ " ye va kpɔe ɖa o.
Contrary to popular Christmas tradition, the Bible does not use the terms "three wise men " or "three kings " to describe the travelers who went to see Jesus after his birth.
(Mateo 2:1) Ke boŋ, Nyanyuigbalẽŋlɔla Mateo zã Helagbe me nya ma’goi tsɔ ɖɔ ame siwo va kpɔ Yesu ɖa.
(Matthew 2:1) Instead, the Gospel writer Matthew used the Greek word ma’goi to describe those who visited Jesus.
Anɔ eme be nyagbe ma ku ɖe ame siwo bi ɖe ɣletivimefakaka kple gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ ƒe nuwɔna bubuwo me ŋu.
The word likely refers to experts in astrology and other occult practices.
Biblia gɔmeɖeɖe geɖe yɔ wo be "ɣletivimefakalawo " alo "akunyawɔlawo. "
A number of Bible translations call them "astrologers " or "magi. "
‘Nunyala’ nenie wonye?
How many "wise men " were there?
Fiawoe "nunyalawo " nyea?
Were the "wise men " kings?
"Nunyalawo " ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe?
What were the names of the "wise men "?
Ɣekaɣie "nunyalawo " yi ɖakpɔ Yesu ɖa?
When did the "wise men " visit Jesus?
Mawue na Betlehem ƒe "ɣletivi " la fia mɔ ‘nunyalawoa’?
Did God have the "wise men " follow the "star " of Bethlehem?
‘Nunyala’ nenie wonye?
How many "wise men " were there?
Biblia megblɔe o, gake susu vovovowoe le amewo si ku ɖe woƒe xexlẽme ŋu.
The Bible does not say, and traditions about their number vary.

Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: "Ame geɖe siwo le Asia nutowo me xɔe se be wonye Akunyawɔla [alo nunyala] 12, gake ame siwo le Europa kple Amerika dukɔwo me la xɔe se be ame etɔ̃e, ɖewohĩ le esi wotsɔ nunana etɔ̃, siwo nye ‘sika, lifi kple mire’ (Mateo 2:11) vɛ na ɖevi sue la ta. " Encyclopedia Britannica.

According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, "Eastern tradition sets the number of Magi at 12, but Western tradition sets their number at three, probably based on the three gifts of ‘gold, frankincense, and myrrh’ (Matthew 2:11) presented to the infant. "
Fiawoe "nunyalawo " nyea?
Were the "wise men " kings?
Togbɔ be nenemae wòdzena le nutatawo me le Kristmas ɖuɣi hã la, Biblia ƒe akpa aɖeke megblɔ be fiawoe wonye o.
Although in Christmas tradition the visitors are often depicted that way, nowhere does the Bible call them kings.
Numekugbalẽ ma ke gblɔ be ƒe alafa geɖe le Yesu dzidzi megbe la, amewo va "kpa nyawo " kpe ŋutinya si ku ɖe Yesu ƒe dzidzi ŋu, eye ame geɖe va nɔ gbɔgblɔm be ame siwo va kpɔe ɖa la nye fiawo.
According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, that designation was added centuries later as part of the traditions that "embellished the narrative. "
"Nunyalawo " ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe?
What were the names of the "wise men "?
Biblia meyɔ ɣletivimefakalaawo ƒe ŋkɔwo o.
The Bible does not reveal the names of the astrologers.
Numekugbalẽ bubu gblɔ be: "Ŋkɔ siwo amewo dze agbagba tsɔ na wo, (abe Gaspar, Melchior, kple Balthasar ene) la nye ŋkɔ kpakpawo ko. " The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia.
According to The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia, "attempts to name them (e.g., Gaspar, Melchior, and Balthasar) rest upon legends. "
Ɣekaɣie "nunyalawo " yi ɖakpɔ Yesu ɖa?
When did the "wise men " visit Jesus?
Anye be ɣletivimefakalawo va kpɔ Yesu ɖa ɣleti aɖewo le edzidzi megbe.
The astrologers may have visited Jesus a number of months after his birth.
Míenya esia elabena Fia Herodes, si di be yeawu Yesu la, ɖe gbe be woawu ŋutsuvi siwo katã xɔ ƒe eve kple esiwo mexɔ nenema haɖe o.
This is evident because King Herod, who wanted to have Jesus killed, ordered the slaughter of boys who were two years old and younger.
Nya siwo wòse tso ɣletivimefakalawo gbɔ la dzie wònɔ te ɖo gblɔ be woawu ɖevi siwo xɔ va se ɖe ƒe eve.
He based that age range on information he had received from the astrologers.
Mateo 2:16.
Matthew 2:16.
Menye zã si me wodzi Yesu ye ɣletivimefakalawo va kpɔe ɖa o.
The astrologers did not visit Jesus on the night of his birth.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi woge ɖe aƒea me la, wokpɔ ɖevi la kple dadaa Maria. "
The Bible says: "When they went into the house, they saw the young child with Mary his mother. "
(Mateo 2:11) Esia ɖee fia be ɣemaɣi la, ƒomea nɔ aƒe aɖe me eye Yesu meganye vidzĩ le lãnuɖunu me o.
(Matthew 2:11) This indicates that the family were by then living in a house and that Jesus was no longer an infant in a manger.
Luka 2:16.
Luke 2:16.
Mawue na Betlehem ƒe "ɣletivi " la fia mɔ ‘nunyalawoa’?
Did God have the "wise men " follow the "star " of Bethlehem?
Ame aɖewo xɔe se be Mawue dɔ nu si amewo yɔna be Betlehem ƒe ɣletivi la be wòafia mɔ ɣletivimefakalawo ayi Yesu gbɔ.
Some people believe that God sent the so-called star of Bethlehem to guide the astrologers to Jesus.
Kpɔ nu si tae nya ma mate ŋu anye nyateƒe o la ɖa.
Consider why that cannot be the case.
Nu si dze abe ɣletivi ene la kplɔ ɣletivimefakalawo yi Yerusalem gbã.
What appeared to be a star led the astrologers first to Jerusalem.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ɣletivimefakalawo tso Ɣedzeƒe va Yerusalem, eye wobia be: ‘Afi kae Yudatɔwo ƒe fia si wodzi la le?
The Bible says: "Astrologers from the East came to Jerusalem, saying: ‘Where is the one born king of the Jews?
Elabena míekpɔ eƒe ɣletivi esime míenɔ Ɣedzeƒe, eye míeva be míade bubu eŋu.’
For we saw his star when we were in the East, and we have come to do obeisance to him.’
" Mateo 2:1, 2.
" Matthew 2:1, 2.
Fia Herodes ye nye ame gbãtɔ si fia mɔ ɣletivimefakalawo be woayi Betlehem, ke menye "ɣletivi " lae o.
King Herod, not the "star, " was the first to direct the astrologers to Bethlehem.
Esi Herodes se be wodzi fia bubu, si nye "Yudatɔwo ƒe fia " la, eku nu me tsitotsito tso afi si woadzi Kristo si ŋugbe wodo la le.
When he heard of a rival "king of the Jews, " Herod investigated where the promised Christ was to be born.
(Mateo 2:3-6) Esi Herodes se be Betlehem ye woadzii le la, egblɔ na ɣletivimefakalawo be woayi afi ma, adi ɖevia, eye woatrɔ ava ka eta na ye.
(Matthew 2:3-6) On learning that it was to be in Bethlehem, he told the astrologers to go there, look for the child, and report back to him.
Esia yomee ɣletivimefakalawo ɖo ta Betlehem.
Only then did the astrologers go to Bethlehem.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi wose fia la ƒe nyawo vɔ la, wodze mɔ, eye kpɔ ɖa, ɣletivi si wokpɔ esime wonɔ Ɣedzeƒe la dze wo ŋgɔ ʋuu va tɔ ɖe aƒe si me ɖevia le la tame. "

The Bible says: "After they had heard the king, they went their way, and look! the star they had seen when they were in the East went ahead of them until it came to a stop above where the young child was. "
Mateo 2:9.
Matthew 2:9.
"Ɣletivi " si ɣletivimefakalawo kpɔ la wɔe be nanewo dzɔ si na Yesu ƒe agbe ɖo afɔku me eye wòwɔe be wowu ɖevi manyaɖekewo.
The appearance of the "star " set in motion events that threatened the life of Jesus and resulted in the murder of innocent children.
Esi ɣletivimefakalawo dzo le Betlehem la, Mawu xlɔ̃ nu wo be woagatrɔ ayi ɖe Herodes gbɔ o.
When the astrologers left Bethlehem, God warned them not to return to Herod.
Mateo 2:12.
Matthew 2:12.
Aleke Herodes wɔ nui?
How did Herod react?

Biblia gblɔ be: "Esi Herodes kpɔ be ɣletivimefakalaawo flu ye la, edo dziku vevie, eye wòdɔ amewo woyi Betlehem kple eƒe nutowo katã me ɖawu ŋutsuvi siwo katã xɔ ƒe eve kple esiwo mexɔ nenema haɖe o la ɖe ale si wòbia ɣeyiɣi la tsitotsito tso ɣletivimefakalaawo gbɔe la nu. "

The Bible says: "Herod, seeing that he had been outwitted by the astrologers, flew into a great rage, and he sent out and had all the boys in Bethlehem and in all its districts killed, from two years of age and under, according to the time that he had carefully ascertained from the astrologers. "
(Mateo 2:16) Mate ŋu adzɔ gbeɖe be nu vɔ̃ɖi ma natso Mawu gbɔ o.
(Matthew 2:16) God would not have caused such a wicked thing to be done.
Hiob 34:10.
Ðe Agbalẽnyalawo Xɔe Se Be Yesu Nɔ Anyi Kpɔa?
Do Scholars Believe That Jesus Existed?
Kpeɖodzi sẽŋuwo le agbalẽnyalawo si siwo ɖee fia be Yesu nɔ anyi kpɔ.
Scholars have a solid basis for believing that Jesus existed.

Esi Encyclopædia Britannica, ƒe 2002 ƒe tata nɔ nu ƒom tso ale si ŋutinyaŋlɔla siwo nɔ anyi le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ kple evelia me ƒo nu tso Yesu kple Kristotɔ gbãtɔwo ŋui ŋu la, egblɔ be: "Nuŋlɔɖi ɖekaɖeka siawo ɖo kpe edzi be le blemaɣeyiɣiwo me la, ame siwo tsi tsitre ɖe Kristotɔnyenye ŋu gɔ̃ hã meke ɖi le Yesu ƒe anyinɔnɔ kpɔ ŋu o, si ŋu wotsɔ susu siwo ŋu kpeɖodzi mele o la ʋli nya le zi gbãtɔ le ƒe alafa 18 lia ƒe nuwuwu, kple emegbe le ƒe alafa 19 lia me, kpakple le ƒe alafa 20 lia ƒe gɔmedzedze. "

Regarding the references made by first- and second-century historians to Jesus and the early Christians, the Encyclopædia Britannica, 2002 Edition, says: "These independent accounts prove that in ancient times even the opponents of Christianity never doubted the historicity of Jesus, which was disputed for the first time and on inadequate grounds at the end of the 18th, during the 19th, and at the beginning of the 20th centuries. "

Le ƒe 2006 me la, agbalẽ aɖe (Jesus and Archaeology) gblɔ be: "Agbalẽnyala xɔŋkɔ siwo li egbea dometɔ aɖeke meke ɖi be Yudatɔ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Yesu si nye Yosef vi la nɔ anyi kpɔ o; wo dometɔ geɖe lɔ̃na ɖe edzi enumake be yewova nya nu geɖe tso eƒe dɔwɔwɔwo kple eƒe nufiafia veviwo ŋu. "

In 2006, the book Jesus and Archaeology said: "No reputable scholar today questions that a Jew named Jesus son of Joseph lived; most readily admit that we now know a considerable amount about his actions and his basic teachings. "
Biblia ƒo nu tso Yesu ŋu be enye ame ŋutɔŋutɔ.
The Bible portrays Jesus as a real person.
Eyɔ etɔgbuiawo ŋkɔwo eye wòƒo nu tso edzilawo kple nɔviawo ŋu hã.
It provides the names of his ancestors and immediate family.
(Mateo 1:1; 13:55) Biblia yɔ ame xɔŋkɔ siwo nɔ anyi le Yesu ƒe ɣeyiɣia me ƒe ŋkɔwo hã.
(Matthew 1:1; 13:55) It also gives the names of prominent rulers who were contemporaries of Jesus.
(Luka 3:1, 2) Nuŋlɔɖi vevi siawo na numekulawo tea ŋu kua nu me hekpɔa kpeɖodzi be Biblia me nuŋlɔɖiwo de pɛpɛpɛ.
(Luke 3:1, 2) Those details allow researchers to verify the accuracy of the Bible accounts.
Ðe Yesu Ƒe Agbemeŋutinya Si Le Biblia Me La De Pɛpɛpɛa?
Does the Bible Contain an Accurate Record of Jesus’ Life?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia-ŋlɔla Luka gblɔ tso Yesu ƒe agbemeŋutinya si wòŋlɔ la ŋu be: "Nye hã meku nuwo katã me tsitotsito tso gɔmedzedzea me. "
The Bible writer Luke said regarding his account of Jesus’ life: "I have traced all things from the start with accuracy. "
Luka 1:3.
Luke 1:3.

Ame aɖewo gblɔna be wotrɔ Yesu ƒe agbemeŋutinya siwo woŋlɔ ɖe Nyanyuigbalẽwo, siwo nye agbalẽ siwo eŋɔlimetɔ siwo nye Mateo, Marko, Luka kple Yohanes ŋlɔ, la me nyawo le ƒe alafa enelia le Yesu dzidzi megbe me.
Some claim that accounts of Jesus’ life as recorded in the Gospels the writings of his contemporaries Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John were altered sometime in the fourth century.
Gake wova ke ɖe Yohanes ƒe Nyanyuigbalẽa ƒe asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ kakɛ aɖe ŋuti le Egipte le ƒe 1900-ƒeawo ƒe gɔmedzedze.
However, a valuable fragment of John’s Gospel was found in Egypt at the turn of the 20th century.
Woyɔa asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ kakɛ sia egbea be Papyrus Rylands 457 (P52) eye wodzrae ɖo ɖe John Rylands Library si le Manchester le England (Angleterre).
It is now known as the Papyrus Rylands 457 (P52) and is preserved at the John Rylands Library, Manchester, England.
Nya siwo dze le Yohanes 18:31-33, 37, 38 le egbe Bibliawo mee le edzi.
It contains what is John 18:31-33, 37, 38 in modern Bibles.
Esiae nye Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo alo Nubabla Yeyea ƒe asinuŋɔŋlɔgbalẽ kakɛ xoxotɔ si ŋu woke ɖo.
This is the oldest known manuscript fragment of the Christian Greek Scriptures.
Agbalẽnyala geɖe xɔe se be ƒe 125 me lɔƒoe woŋlɔe.
Many scholars believe that it was written about 125 C.E., a mere quarter of a century or so after the original was written.
Esia anye ƒe 25 alo esi wu nenema vie ko esime Yohanes ŋutɔ ŋlɔ eƒe agbalẽa megbe.
The text of the fragment agrees nearly exactly with that in later manuscripts.
Aleke Yesu Ƒe Dzedzeme Nɔ?
What Did Jesus Look Like?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
