Esi Biblia meɖɔ Yesu ƒe dzedzeme o ta la, ame aɖeke menya ale si tututu eƒe dzedzeme nɔ o.
No one knows exactly what Jesus looked like, since his physical appearance is not described in the Bible.
Esia fia be Yesu ƒe dzedzeme nyanya mele vevie o.
This indicates that Jesus’ physical features are not important.
Ke hã, Biblia kpe ɖe mía ŋu míenya ale si Yesu ƒe dzedzeme anya anɔ.
However, the Bible does give us some idea of Jesus’ general appearance.
Eƒe Dzedzeme: Yudatɔe Yesu nye eya ta eƒe dzedzeme anya nɔ abe nɔa si nye Sem ƒe dzidzimevi la tɔ ene.
Features: Jesus was a Jew and likely inherited common Semitic traits from his mother.
(Hebritɔwo 7:14) Anye be eƒe dzedzeme menɔ etɔxɛ o.
(Hebrews 7:​14) It is unlikely that his features were especially distinctive.
Ɣeaɖeɣi la, ete ŋu zɔ mɔ le adzame tso Galilea yi Yerusalem eye ame aɖeke mekpɔe dze sii o.
On one occasion he was able to travel in secret from Galilee to Jerusalem without being recognized.
(Yohanes 7:10, 11) Eye edze abe ne Yesu le eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo dome kura gɔ̃ hã la, vovototo boo aɖeke menɔa eya kple woawo dome o.
(John 7:​10, 11) And he apparently did not stand out even among his closest disciples.
Àɖo ŋkui be, ɖe Yuda Iskariot wɔ nane tsɔ de dzesi Yesu hafi amehawo va lée.​ Mateo 26:47-49.
Recall that Judas Iscariot had to identify Jesus to the armed crowd that arrested him.​ Matthew 26:47-​49.
Eƒe ɖa ƒe didime: Ða legbe menya nɔ ta na Yesu o elabe Biblia gblɔ be "ne ɖa legbe le ta na ŋutsu la, enye ŋukpe nɛ. "​ 1 Korintotɔwo 11:14.
Hair length: It is unlikely that Jesus’ hair was long, because the Bible says that "long hair is a dishonor to a man. "​ 1 Corinthians 11:14.
Eƒe ge: Yesu ɖo ge.
Beard: Jesus wore a beard.
Ewɔ ɖe se si wode na Yuda ŋutsuwo be ‘woagafɔ woƒe ge dzi ɖewoɖewoe o’ la dzi.
He followed Jewish law, which prohibited adult males from ‘disfiguring the edges of their beard.’
(3 Mose 19:27; Galatiatɔwo 4:4) Azɔ hã, Biblia ƒo nu tso Yesu ƒe ge ŋu le nyagblɔɖi aɖe si ku ɖe eƒe fukpekpewo ŋu me.​ Yesaya 50:6.
(Leviticus 19:27; Galatians 4:4) Also, the Bible mentions Jesus’ beard in a prophecy about his suffering.​ Isaiah 50:6.
Eƒe ametia: Nu sia nu ɖee fia be ŋusẽ nɔ Yesu ŋu.
Body: All indications are that Jesus was physically robust.
Esi wònɔ eƒe subɔsubɔdɔa wɔm la, ezɔa mɔ kilometa gbogbo aɖewo.
During his ministry, he traveled many miles.
(Mateo 9:35) Ekɔ Yudatɔwo ƒe gbedoxɔa ŋu zi eve, esi wòtrɔ gaɖɔlilawo ƒe gawo ƒu gbe eye wòtu asi woƒe kplɔ̃wo ƒu anyi, eye gbe ɖeka etsɔ atam nya lãwo do goe le gbedoxɔa me.
(Matthew 9:​35) He cleansed the Jewish temple twice, overturning the tables of money changers, and once drove out livestock with a whip.

(Luka 19:45, 46; Yohanes 2:14, 15) Numekugbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: "Nyanyuigbalẽawo ŋlɔlawo katã ƒe nyawo ɖee fia be [Yesu] nɔ lãmesẽ me eye ŋusẽ nɔ eŋu. "​ McClintock kple Strong ƒe Cyclopedia Babla IV, axa 884.
(Luke 19:45, 46; John 2:​14, 15) McClintock and Strong’s Cyclopedia states: "The whole evangelical narrative indicates [Jesus’] sound and vigorous bodily health. "​ Volume IV, page 884.
Eƒe mo ƒe dzedzeme: Yesu doa vivi ɖe ame ŋu hekpɔa nublanui na ame, ɖikeke mele eme o be esia dzena le mo nɛ.
Facial expressions: Jesus was warm and compassionate, and his facial expressions no doubt reflected this.
(Mateo 11:28, 29) Ame ƒomevi vovovowo te ŋu tena ɖe eŋu hena akɔfafa kple kpekpeɖeŋu.
(Matthew 11:28, 29) People of all sorts sought him out for comfort and help.
(Luka 5:12, 13; 7:37, 38) Egbɔ nɔnɔ dzɔa dzi na ɖeviwo gɔ̃ hã.​ Mateo 19:13-15; Marko 9:35-37.
(Luke 5:​12, 13; 7:​37, 38) Even children felt at ease in his presence.​ Matthew 19:13-​15; Mark 9:​35-​37.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Yesu ƒe dzedzeme ŋu
Misconceptions about Jesus’ appearance

Susu totro: Ame aɖewo gblɔna be anɔ eme be Afrikatɔe Yesu nye elabe Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽ tsɔ eƒe taɖa sɔ kple "alẽfu ɣi " eye wòtsɔ eƒe afɔ sɔ kple "akɔbli nyui si wode kpo me wòbiã hẽe. "​ Nyaɖeɖefia 1:14, 15.

Misconception: Some argue that Jesus must have been of African descent because the book of Revelation compares his hair to wool and his feet to "burnished bronze. "​ Revelation 1:​14, 15, The New Jerusalem Bible.
Nyateƒea: Nya siwo woŋlɔ ɖe Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me la nye nu siwo woɖe fia to "dzesiwo " me.
Fact: The book of Revelation is presented "in signs. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 1:1) Ale si woɖɔ Yesu ƒe taɖa kple afɔwo la nye kpɔɖeŋunyagbɔgblɔ si wotsɔ fia Yesu ƒe nɔnɔmewo le eƒe tsitretsitsi megbe, ke menye ale si eƒe dzedzeme nɔ esi wònɔ anyigba dzi o.
(Revelation 1:1) The description of Jesus’ hair and feet uses symbolic language to illustrate Jesus’ qualities after his resurrection, not to describe his physical appearance when he was on earth.
Esi Nyaɖeɖefia 1:14 gblɔ le Yesu ŋu be "eƒe ta kple taɖa fu tititi abe alẽfu ɣi alo sno ene " la, taɖaa ƒe amadede gblɔm wole ke menye eƒe wɔwɔme o.
In saying that Jesus’ "head and his hair were white as white wool, as snow, " Revelation 1:​14 uses color, not texture, as a point of comparison.
Esia tsi tre ɖi na nunya si gbegbe le esi le eƒe ƒexɔxɔ ta.
This represents his wisdom due to age.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 3:14) Mawunyakpukpui sia metsɔ Yesu ƒe taɖa le sɔsɔm kple alẽfu ƒe wɔwɔme o abe ale si ko metsɔe sɔ kple sno ƒe wɔwɔme o ene.
(Revelation 3:​14) This verse is not comparing the texture of Jesus’ hair to that of wool any more than it is comparing the texture of his hair to that of snow.
Yesu ƒe afɔwo le "abe akɔbli nyui si wode kpo me wòbiã hẽe ene. "
Jesus’ feet looked "like fine copper when glowing in a furnace. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 1:15) Azɔ hã, eƒe mo nɔ "abe ɣe si le keklẽm sesĩe ene. "
(Revelation 1:​15) Also, his face was "like the sun when it shines at its brightest. "

(Nyaɖeɖefia 1:16) Esi dukɔ aɖeke me tɔwo ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ƒe amadede mele nenema o ta la, ŋutegaa nye nane ƒe dzesi, si fia be Yesu si wofɔ ɖe tsitre la "le kekeli si ŋu womate ŋu ate ɖo o la me. "​ 1 Timoteo 6:16.

(Revelation 1:​16) Since no race has skin color matching these descriptions, this vision must be symbolic, showing the resurrected Jesus as the one "who dwells in unapproachable light. "​ 1 Timothy 6:​16.
Susu totro: Yesu nye ame beli.
Misconception: Jesus was weak and frail.
Nyateƒea: Yesu wɔa ŋutsu le eƒe nuwɔnawo me.
Fact: Jesus was manly in his behavior.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesu zɔ va ameha siwo lé lãnu ɖe asi va elé ge la gbɔ hegblɔ dzinɔameƒotɔe be nyee nye esi.
For example, he boldly identified himself to the armed crowd that came to arrest him.
(Yohanes 18:4-8) Ŋusẽ anya nɔ Yesu ŋu be wòanye atikpala eye wòazã dɔwɔnu siwo abia be ame ŋutɔ nazã eƒe ŋusẽ.​ Marko 6:3.
(John 18:​4-8) Jesus must also have been physically strong to have worked as a carpenter using manual tools.​ Mark 6:3.
Ke nu ka tae wòhiã be ame aɖe nakpe ɖe Yesu ŋu be wòatsɔ eƒe fuwɔametia?
Why, then, did Jesus need help to carry his torture stake?
Eye nu ka tae wòku do ŋgɔ na ame siwo wohe ɖe ati ŋu kpe ɖe eŋu la?
And why did he die before the others executed with him died?
(Luka 23:26; Yohanes 19:31-33) Do ŋgɔ teti hafi woahe Yesu ɖe ati ŋu la, ŋusẽ vɔ le eŋu vevie.
(Luke 23:26; John 19:31-​33) Just prior to Jesus’ execution, his body was seriously weakened.
Zã si do ŋgɔ la, nuxaxa vevie wɔe be mete ŋu mlɔ anyi dɔ alɔ̃ o.
He had been up all night, in part because of emotional agony.
(Luka 22:42-44) Yudatɔwo sẽ ŋuta le eŋu le zã ma me, eye Romatɔwo wɔ funyafunyae le ŋufɔke.
(Luke 22:42-​44) During the night the Jews had mistreated him, and the next morning the Romans had tortured him.
(Mateo 26:67, 68; Yohanes 19:1-3) Nu mawo katã anya na be Yesu ku kaba.
(Matthew 26:67, 68; John 19:​1-3) Such factors likely hastened his death.
Susu totro: Yesu nye blanuiléla makpɔdzidzɔ.
Misconception: Jesus was always somber, melancholy.
Nyateƒea: Yesu ɖe Fofoa si le dziƒo, ame si Biblia yɔ be "Mawu dzidzɔtɔ la " ƒe nɔnɔmewo fia bliboe. (1Timoteo 1:11; Yohanes 14:9) Le nyateƒe me la, Yesu fia amewo ale si woawɔ anye dzidzɔtɔwo.
Fact: Jesus perfectly reflected the qualities of his heavenly Father, Jehovah, whom the Bible describes as "the happy God. " (1 Timothy 1:​11; John 14:9) In fact, Jesus taught others how to be happy.
(Mateo 5:3-9; Luka 11:28) Nya siawo ɖee fia be dzidzɔ dzena le mo na Yesu zi geɖe.
(Matthew 5:​3-9; Luke 11:28) These facts indicate that Jesus often reflected happiness in his facial expressions.
Ðe Yesu Ðe Srɔ̃ Kpɔa?
Was Jesus Married?
Ðe Nɔviwo Nɔ Yesu Sia?
Did Jesus Have Siblings?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia ɖee fia kɔtɛe be Yesu meɖe srɔ̃ kpɔ o, togbɔ be Biblia meƒo nu tso eƒe srɔ̃ɖeɖe ŋu tẽe o hã.
The Bible makes clear that Jesus was not married, even though it does not specifically comment on his marital status.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider the following.
Edziedzi la, Biblia ƒoa nu tso Yesu ƒe ƒometɔwo kple nyɔnu siwo kplɔnɛ ɖo le eƒe subɔsubɔdɔa me kple nyɔnu siwo nɔ eteƒe esime wowui ŋu, gake Biblia megblɔ kpɔ be srɔ̃ nɔ esi o.
The Bible frequently refers to Jesus’ family as well as to women who accompanied him during his ministry and who stood by when he was executed, yet it never mentions his having a wife.
(Mateo 12:46, 47; Marko 3:31, 32; 15:40; Luka 8:2, 3, 19, 20; Yohanes 19:25) Anɔ eme godoo be esi srɔ̃ menɔ Yesu si o tae Biblia meƒo nu tso eƒe srɔ̃ɖeɖe ŋu o.
(Matthew 12:46, 47; Mark 3:​31, 32; 15:40; Luke 8:​2, 3, 19, 20; John 19:25) The most plausible reason why the Bible is silent on this matter is that he was never married.
Yesu gblɔ na eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo tso ame siwo tiae be yewoanɔ tre ale be yewoate ŋu awɔ geɖe le Mawu ƒe subɔsubɔdɔa me la ŋu be: "Ame si ate [ŋu anɔ tre] la, newɔe. "
Concerning those who remain unmarried so that they can do more in God’s service, Jesus told his disciples: "Let the one who can make room for it [singleness] make room for it. "
(Mateo 19:10-12) Eɖo kpɔɖeŋu na ame siwo tiae be yewomaɖe srɔ̃ o ale be yewoatsɔ yewo ɖokuiwo ana Mawu bliboe la.​ Yohanes 13:15; 1 Korintotɔwo 7:32-38.
(Matthew 19:10-​12) He set the pattern for those who choose not to marry in order to devote themselves more fully to God.​ John 13:15; 1 Corinthians 7:​32-​38.
Do ŋgɔ teti na Yesu ƒe ku la, ewɔ ɖoɖo ɖe nɔa dzi kpɔkpɔ ŋu.
Just before he died, Jesus arranged for the care of his mother.
(Yohanes 19:25-27) Ne ɖe Yesu ɖe srɔ̃ alo viwo nɔ esi la, anye ne ekpɔ egbɔ be yewɔ ɖoɖo ɖe ame siawo hã dzi kpɔkpɔ ŋu.
(John 19:25-​27) If Jesus had been married or had fathered children, he would have made sure that such close family members were provided for as well.
Biblia gblɔna be Yesu ɖo kpɔɖeŋu ɖi na srɔ̃ŋutsuwo, gake menye ale si Yesu wɔ nu ɖe srɔ̃nyɔnu si nye amegbetɔ ŋue wòfiaa asii o.
The Bible uses Jesus as an example for husbands, but it does not refer to the way he treated a human wife.
Biblia gblɔ boŋ be: "Srɔ̃ŋutsuwo, miyi edzi mialɔ̃ mia srɔ̃wo abe ale si ko Kristo la hã lɔ̃ hame la, eye wòtsɔ eɖokui na ɖe eta ene. "
Instead, it says: "Husbands, continue loving your wives, just as the Christ also loved the congregation and gave himself up for it. "
(Efesotɔwo 5:25) Ne ɖe srɔ̃ nɔ Yesu si esime wònɔ anyigba dzi la, ɖe Biblia mazã srɔ̃ŋutsu ƒe kpɔɖeŋu de blibo si wòaɖo ɖi la le kpukpui ma me oa?
(Ephesians 5:​25) If Jesus had actually been married while on earth, would not his perfect example as a literal husband have been used in that verse?
Ðe nɔviwo nɔ Yesu sia?
Did Jesus have siblings?
Ɛ̃, nɔvi ade ya teti nɔ esi.
Yes, Jesus had at least six siblings.
Woawoe nye nɔvia ŋutsu siwo ƒe ŋkɔwoe nye Yakobo, Yosef, Simon kple Yuda kpakple nɔvia nyɔnu eve ya teti.
These included his brothers James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas as well as at least two sisters.
(Mateo 13:54-56; Marko 6:3) Yesu nɔ Maria kple srɔ̃a Yosef ŋutɔwo ƒe viwoe Yesu nɔvi mawo nye.
(Matthew 13:54-​56; Mark 6:3) Those siblings were natural children of Jesus’ mother, Mary, and her husband, Joseph.
(Mateo 1:25) Biblia yɔ Yesu be Maria ƒe "ŋgɔgbevi, " esia fia be Maria gadzi vi bubuwo hã.​ Luka 2:7.
(Matthew 1:​25) The Bible calls Jesus "the firstborn " of Mary, which implies that she had other children.​ Luke 2:7.
Susu totro siwo nɔa amewo si ku ɖe Yesu nɔviwo ŋu
Misconceptions about Jesus’ brothers
Esi ame aɖewo nɔ agbagba dzem be yewoaɖo kpe edzi be Maria nye ɖetugbui leaƒe le eƒe agbe me katã ta la, woɖea nya si nye ‘nɔvi’ gɔme bubui.
In order to support the idea that Mary remained a virgin all her life, some have applied different meanings to the term "brothers. "
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ame aɖewo susui be Yesu nɔvi siwo wowɔnɛ la nye Yosef ƒe vi siwo nyɔnu bubu dzi nɛ hafi wòva ɖe Maria.
For example, some feel that Jesus’ brothers were actually sons of Joseph by an earlier marriage.
Ke hã, Biblia gblɔ be Yesu nyi fianyenye si ƒe ŋugbe wodo na David la dome le se nu.
However, the Bible shows that Jesus inherited the legal right to the kingship promised to David.
(2 Samuel 7:​12, 13; Luka 1:​32) Ne ɖe vi bubuwo nɔ Yosef si siwo tsi wu Yesu la, anye ne woƒe tsitsitɔe anye Yosef ƒe domenyila le se nu.
(2 Samuel 7:​12, 13; Luke 1:​32) If Joseph had been father to sons older than Jesus, the eldest of these would have been Joseph’s legal heir.
Ðe nya ‘nɔvi’ si wozã le afi sia ate ŋu afia Yesu ƒe nusrɔ̃lawo alo gbɔgbɔmenɔviwoa?
Could the expression refer to Jesus’ disciples, or spiritual brothers?
Esia mewɔ ɖeka kple Ŋɔŋlɔawo o, elabe Biblia gblɔ be ɣeaɖeɣi la, "nɔviawo mexɔ edzi se o. "
This idea conflicts with the Scriptures, since the Bible says that at one point "his brothers were, in fact, not exercising faith in him. "
(Yohanes 7:5) Biblia de vovototo Yesu nɔviwo kple eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo dome.​ Yohanes 2:12.
(John 7:5) The Bible distinguishes Jesus’ brothers from his disciples.​ John 2:​12.
Ame aɖewo hã gblɔna be Yesu nɔviŋutsu siwo wowɔnɛ la woe nye eƒe ƒometɔ kpamkpamwo ƒe viwo.
According to another theory, Jesus’ brothers were actually his cousins.
Ke hã le Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo me la, menye nya ɖekae wozãna na "nɔvi, " "ƒometɔ, " kple "ƒometɔ ƒe vi " o.
Yet, the Greek Scriptures use distinct words for "brother, " "relative, " and "cousin. "
(Luka 21:16; Kolosetɔwo 4:10) Biblia-ŋutinunyala geɖewo lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Yesu nɔvi siwo wowɔnɛ le afi sia la fia nɔa ƒe viŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo ŋutɔŋutɔ.
(Luke 21:16; Colossians 4:​10) Many Bible scholars acknowledge that Jesus’ brothers and sisters were his actual siblings.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, agbalẽ aɖe (The Expositor’s Bible Commentary) gblɔ be: "Mɔ si ko nu míate ŋu ase nya ‘nɔviwo’ gɔme le wòasɔ wue nye be . . . efia Maria kple Yosef ƒe viwo, eye le esia ta wonye Yesu nɔ [Maria] ƒe viwo. "

For example, The Expositor’s Bible Commentary states: "The most natural way to understand ‘brothers’ . . . is that the term refers to sons of Mary and Joseph and thus to brothers of Jesus on his mother’s side. "
Ɣekaɣie Woŋlɔ Yesu Ŋuti Nyawo Ði?
When Were the Accounts About Jesus Written?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Apostolo Yohanes gblɔ tso Yesu ƒe agbemenudzɔdzɔ siwo ŋuti wòŋlɔ nu tsoe la ŋu be: "Ame si kpɔe la ɖi ɖase, eye eƒe ɖaseɖiɖi la nye nyateƒe, eye ame ma nya be nyateƒenyawoe yegblɔna, bene miawo hã miaxɔe ase. "

Regarding his record of the events in Jesus’ life, the apostle John wrote: "He that has seen it has borne witness, and his witness is true, and that man knows he tells true things, in order that you also may believe. "
Yohanes 19:35.
John 19:35.

Susu siwo tae wòle be míaxɔ Nyanyuigbalẽ siwo Mateo, Marko, Luka kple Yohanes ŋlɔ la me nyawo dzi ase la dometɔ ɖekae nye be esime woŋlɔ ŋutinya mawo la, ame siwo kpɔ nudzɔdzɔawo teƒe la dometɔ geɖe gakpɔtɔ le agbe ɣemaɣi.
One reason to trust the Gospel accounts recorded by Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John is that they were written while many eyewitnesses to the events they describe were still alive.

Le numekugbalẽ aɖewo ƒe nya nu la, woŋlɔ Mateo ƒe Nyanyuigbalẽa le ƒe 41 me, si nye ƒe enyi le Kristo ƒe ku megbe. Agbalẽnyala geɖe susui be woŋlɔe do megbe na ƒe ma, gake ame akpa gãtɔ lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be wowu Kristotɔwo Ƒe Hela Ŋɔŋlɔawo alo Nubabla Xoxoa ŋɔŋlɔ nu le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me.

According to some sources, the Gospel of Matthew was written as early as the eighth year after Christ’s death, that is, about 41 C.E. Many scholars favor a somewhat later date, but there is general agreement that all the books of the Christian Greek Scriptures were written during the first century C.E.
Ame siwo kpɔ Yesu esime wònɔ anyigba dzi, eye wokpɔ eƒe ku kple eƒe tsitretsitsi teƒe la, ate ŋu aɖi ɖase tso Nya Nyui Gbalẽawo me nyawo ƒe nyateƒenyenye ŋu.
People who saw Jesus while he was alive on earth, witnessed his death, and observed his resurrection could verify the Gospel accounts.
Ne ɖe wònye be ŋutinyawo mede pɛpɛpɛ o la, anye ne woʋu go esia bɔbɔe.
They could also easily expose any inaccuracies if there had been such.

Agbalẽnyalagã F. F. Bruce gblɔ be: "Nu siwo na apostoloawo ƒe gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa ɖe kpe dometɔ ɖekae nye be woƒo nu tso nu siwo ŋu woƒe nyaselawo ŋutɔ nya nu tso la ŋu; womegblɔna ko be ‘mía ŋutɔwo míekpɔ eteƒe o,’ ke boŋ be ‘abe ale si mia ŋutɔwo hã mienyae ene’ (Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:22). "

Professor F. F. Bruce observes: "One of the strong points in the original apostolic preaching is the confident appeal to the knowledge of the hearers; they not only said, ‘We are witnesses of these things,’ but also, ‘As you yourselves also know’ (Acts 2:22). "
Nu Ka Tae Yesu Ku?
Why Did Jesus Die?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yesu ku ale be woate ŋu atsɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe nu vɔ̃wo ake wo eye woakpɔ agbe mavɔ.
Jesus died so that humans could have their sins forgiven and receive endless life.
(Romatɔwo 6:23; Efesotɔwo 1:7) Yesu ƒe kua ɖo kpe edzi hã be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu awɔ nuteƒe na Mawu le tetekpɔ sesẽtɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã me.​ Hebritɔwo 4:15.
(Romans 6:​23; Ephesians 1:7) Jesus’ death also proved that a human can remain loyal to God even when faced with the severest of tests.​ Hebrews 4:​15.
Kpɔ viɖe siwo gbegbe ate ŋu ado tso ame ɖeka ƒe ku me la ɖa.
Consider how the death of one man could accomplish so much.
Yesu ku hena "míaƒe nu vɔ̃wo ƒe tsɔtsɔke. "​ Kolosetɔwo 1:14.
Jesus died for "the forgiveness of our sins. "​ Colossians 1:​14.
Wowɔ amegbetɔ gbãtɔ, Adam, wòde blibo, nu vɔ̃ menɔ eŋu o.
The first human, Adam, was created perfect, without sin.
Ke hã egbe toɖoɖo Mawu.
However, he chose to disobey God.
Adam ƒe tomaɖomaɖoa, alo nu vɔ̃a, gblẽ nu le eƒe dzidzimeviwo katã ŋu.
Adam’s disobedience, or sin, profoundly affected all his descendants.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ame ɖeka ƒe tomaɖomaɖo na ame geɖewo zu nu vɔ̃ wɔlawo. "​ Romatɔwo 5:19.
"Through the disobedience of the one man, " the Bible explains, "many were made sinners. "​ Romans 5:​19.
Ame debliboe Yesu hã nye, gake mewɔ nu vɔ̃ kpɔ o.
Jesus was also perfect, but he never sinned.

Eya ta ate ŋu anye "avulévɔsa ɖe míaƒe nu vɔ̃wo ta. " (1 Yohanes 2:2) Abe ale si ko Adam ƒe tomaɖomaɖoa kplɔ amegbetɔƒomea de nu vɔ̃ me ene la, nenema kee Yesu ƒe kua ɖe ame siwo katã xɔ eya amea dzi se la tso nu vɔ̃ me.

Therefore, he could be "an atoning sacrifice for our sins. " (1 John 2:2; footnote) Just as Adam’s disobedience contaminated the human family with sin, so Jesus’ death removed the stain of sin from all who exercise faith in him.
Le nyaa nu la, Adam dzra ameƒome bliboa na nu vɔ̃.
In a sense, Adam sold the human race into sin.
Gake esi Yesu lɔ̃ faa va ku ɖe mía ta la, egbugbɔ ameƒome bliboa ƒle wòzu etɔ.
Jesus, by willingly dying in our behalf, repurchased humankind as his own.
Esia wɔe be "ne edzɔ be ame aɖe wɔ nu vɔ̃ aɖe la, kpeɖeŋutɔ le mía si le Fofo la gbɔ, si nye ame dzɔdzɔe Yesu Kristo. "​ 1 Yohanes 2:1.
As a result, "if anyone does commit a sin, we have a helper with the Father, Jesus Christ, a righteous one. "​ 1 John 2:1.
Yesu ku "bene ame sia ame si ɖenɛ fiana be yexɔ edzi se la nagatsrɔ̃ o, ke boŋ wòakpɔ agbe mavɔ. "​ Yohanes 3:16.
Jesus died "so that everyone exercising faith in him might not be destroyed but have everlasting life. "​ John 3:​16.
Togbɔ be ɖe wowɔ Adam be wòanɔ agbe tegbee hã la, nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la he ku vɛ nɛ.
Although Adam was created to live forever, his sin brought upon him the penalty of death.
To Adam "dzi nu vɔ̃ ge ɖe xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va, eye ale ku la kaka ɖe amewo katã dome, esi wo katã wɔ nu vɔ̃ ŋuti. "​ Romatɔwo 5:12.
Through Adam, "sin entered into the world and death through sin, and so death spread to all men because they had all sinned. "​ Romans 5:​12.
To vovo na ema la, Yesu ƒe kua ɖe nu vɔ̃ ƒe ɖiƒoƒo ɖe sia ɖe ɖa le ame siwo katã xɔ edzi se la ŋu, eye wògate fli ɖe kufia si wotso na wo le nu vɔ̃ ta la hã me.
In contrast, Jesus’ death not only removed the blemish of sin but also canceled the death sentence for all who exercise faith in him.
Biblia ƒo nya sia ta kpokploe be: "Ale si ko nu vɔ̃ kple ku ɖu fiae la, amenuveve la hã naɖu fia nenema ke to dzɔdzɔenyenye me hena agbe mavɔ kpɔkpɔ, to mía Aƒetɔ Yesu Kristo dzi. "​ Romatɔwo 5:21.

The Bible sums up matters this way: "Just as sin ruled as king with death, so also undeserved kindness might rule as king through righteousness leading to everlasting life through Jesus Christ our Lord. "​ Romans 5:​21.
Enye nyateƒe be amegbetɔwo ƒe agbenɔƒe le kpuie.
Of course, humans today still have a limited life span.
Ke hã, Mawu do ŋugbe be yeana agbe mavɔ ame dzɔdzɔewo eye yeafɔ ame siwo ku la ɖe tsitre ale be Yesu ƒe vɔsakua naɖe vi na woawo hã.​ Psalmo 37:29; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:22.
However, God promises that he will grant righteous humans everlasting life and resurrect the dead so that they too can benefit from Jesus’ sacrificial death.​ Psalm 37:29; 1 Corinthians 15:22.
Yesu ‘ɖo to yi ɖa se keke ku me ke’ tsɔ ɖee fia be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu awɔ nuteƒe na Mawu le dodokpɔ alo nɔnɔme sesẽ ɖe sia ɖe me.​ Filipitɔwo 2:8.
Jesus "became obedient to the point of death, " thus proving that a human could be faithful to God under any test or trial.​ Philippians 2:8.
Togbɔ be Adam de blibo le susu kple ŋutilã me hã la, egbe toɖoɖo Mawu, elabe edi eɖokui tɔ esi wòna nu si menye etɔ o la dzroe.
Despite having a perfect mind and body, Adam disobeyed God because he selfishly desired something that did not belong to him.
(1 Mose 2:16, 17; 3:6) Emegbe Mawu ƒe futɔ gãtɔ, Satana, gblɔ be ame aɖeke mate ŋu aɖo to Mawu ne menye viɖe aɖeke tae o, vevietɔ ne elɔ eƒe agbe ɖe eme.
(Genesis 2:​16, 17; 3:6) Later, God’s chief enemy, Satan, suggested that no human would unselfishly obey God, especially if his life were on the line.
(Hiob 2:4) Ke hã, ame deblibo Yesu ya ɖo to Mawu eye wòyi edzi lé nuteƒewɔwɔ me ɖe asi esime wòdze ŋgɔ vlodoame, vevesese helĩhelĩ kple ku gɔ̃ hã.
(Job 2:4) Yet, the perfect man Jesus obeyed God and remained loyal to him, even undergoing a disgraceful and painful death.
(Hebritɔwo 7:26) Esia kpɔ nyaa gbɔ bliboe: Amegbetɔ ate ŋu awɔ nuteƒe na Mawu le dodokpɔ kple tetekpɔ ɖe sia ɖe si ava edzi la me.
(Hebrews 7:​26) This completely settled the matter: A human can remain faithful to God under whatever test or trial may be brought upon him.
Yesu le fuwɔameti ŋu eye woklã adzodala eve hã ɖe eƒe axawo dzi
Jesus on the torture stake with a robber on each side of him
Nyabiase siwo ku ɖe Yesu ƒe ku ŋu
Questions about Jesus’ death
Nu ka tae wòle be Yesu nakpe fu ahaku hafi aɖe amegbetɔwo?
Why did Jesus have to suffer and die to redeem humans?
Nu ka tae Mawu mete fli ɖe kufia la me ko evɔ o?
Why didn’t God just cancel the death sentence?
Mawu ƒe se gblɔ be "nu vɔ̃ ƒe fetue nye ku. "
God’s law states that "the wages sin pays is death. "
(Romatɔwo 6:23) Mawu meɣla se sia ɖe Adam o, ke boŋ egblɔ nɛ be ne egbe toɖoɖo la aku.
(Romans 6:​23) Rather than hide this law from Adam, God told him that the penalty for disobedience would be death.
(1 Mose 3:3) Esi Adam wɔ nu vɔ̃ la, "Mawu, ame si mate ŋu aka aʋatso o la " wɔ ɖe eƒe nyaa dzi.
(Genesis 3:3) When Adam sinned, God, "who cannot lie, " kept his word.
(Tito 1:2) Menye nu vɔ̃ ɖeɖe koe Adam gblẽ ɖi na eƒe dzidzimeviwo o, ke egblẽ nu vɔ̃ ƒe fetu si nye ku hã ɖi na wo.
(Titus 1:2) Adam passed on to his descendants not only sin but also the wages of sin​ death.
Togbɔ be amegbetɔ nuvɔ̃mewo dze na ku hã la, Mawu na "eƒe amenuveve geɖe " la wo.
Although sinful humans deserve the penalty of death, God extended to them "the riches of his undeserved kindness. "
(Efesotɔwo 1:7) Ðoɖo si wòwɔ dɔ ame deblibo Yesu ɖa wòva ku ɖe mía ta be yeatsɔ aɖe mí la nye eƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye deŋgɔ kple nublanuikpɔkpɔ deto la ɖeɖefia.
(Ephesians 1:7) His provision to redeem mankind​ sending Jesus as a perfect sacrifice​ was both profoundly just and supremely merciful.
Ɣekaɣie Yesu ku?
When did Jesus die?
Yesu ku le ŋkekea ƒe "gaƒoƒo asiekelia " dzi, alo abe ŋdɔ ga etɔ̃ lɔƒo le Yudatɔwo ƒe Ŋutitotoŋkekenyuia ɖugbe.
Jesus died at "the ninth hour " from sunrise, or at about three o’clock in the afternoon of the Jewish Passover.
(Marko 15:33-37) Ŋkeke ma sɔ kple Fiɖa, April 1, 33 K.Ŋ. le egbegbe ɣletigbalẽwo dzi.
(Mark 15:33-​37, footnote) That date corresponds to Friday, April 1, 33 C.E., according to modern calendars.
Afi kae Yesu ku le?
Where did Jesus die?
Wowu Yesu le "teƒe si woyɔna be Ametakoliƒe. Woyɔa teƒe sia le Hebrigbe me be Golgata. "
Jesus was executed at "the so-called Skull Place, which is called Golgotha in Hebrew. "
(Yohanes 19:17, 18) Le Yesu ƒe ŋkekea me la, teƒe sia nɔ Yerusalem "dua ƒe agbo la godo. "
(John 19:17, 18) This site was "outside the city gate " of Jerusalem in Jesus’ day.
(Hebritɔwo 13:12) Teƒe sia anya nɔ togbɛ dzi, elabe Biblia gblɔ be esime wonɔ Yesu wum la, ame aɖewo nɔ "adzɔge " nɔ nu kpɔm.
(Hebrews 13:12) It may have been on a hill, since the Bible says that some observed Jesus’ execution "from a distance. "
(Marko 15:40) Ke hã, ame aɖeke meganya afi si tututu Golgota le egbea o.
(Mark 15:40) However, the present location of Golgotha cannot be determined with certainty.
Atitsoga ŋue Yesu ko ɖoa?
How did Jesus die?

Togbɔ be ame geɖe xɔe se be atitsoga ŋue Yesu ku ɖo hã la, Biblia gblɔ be: "Eya ŋutɔ tsɔ míaƒe nu vɔ̃wo ɖo eƒe ŋutilã dzi le ati la ŋu. " (1 Petro 2:24) Biblia ŋlɔlawo zã Helagbe me nya eve siwo nye stauros kple xylon tsɔ ɖɔ ati si ƒomevi ŋu Yesu ku ɖo.

Although many believe that Jesus was crucified​ executed on a cross​ the Bible reports: "His own self bare our sins in his own body on the tree. " (1 Peter 2:​24, King James Version) Bible writers used two Greek words to refer to the instrument of Jesus’ execution​ stauros and xylon.
Agbalẽnyala geɖewo ƒo nya ta be nya siawo fia ati dzɔdzɔe alo ati tsrala.
Many scholars have concluded that these words refer to a beam or an upright stake made of one piece of wood.
Aleke wòle be woaɖo ŋku Yesu ƒe kua dzie?
How should Jesus’ death be remembered?

Le Yudatɔwo ƒe ƒe sia ƒe Ŋutitotoŋkekenyuia ƒe zã me la, Yesu na mɔfiame bɔbɔe aɖe eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo hede se na wo be: "Minɔ esia wɔm hena ŋkuɖoɖo dzinye. " (1 Korintotɔwo 11:24) Gaƒoƒo aɖewo le ema megbe la, wowu Yesu.

On the night of the annual Jewish Passover, Jesus instituted a simple procedure with his followers and commanded them: "Keep doing this in remembrance of me. " (1 Corinthians 11:24) Hours later, Jesus was put to death.
Biblia ŋlɔlawo tsɔ Yesu sɔ kple alẽvi si wotsɔ sa vɔe le Ŋutitotoa dzi.
Bible writers compared Jesus to the lamb sacrificed at the Passover.

(1 Korintotɔwo 5:7) Abe ale si ko Ŋutitotoŋkekenyuia ɖoa ŋku edzi na Israel viwo be wona ablɔɖe wo tso kluvinyenye me ene la, nenema kee Yesu ƒe ku ƒe Ŋkuɖodzia hã ɖoa ŋku edzi na Kristotɔwo be wona ablɔɖe wo tso nu vɔ̃ kple ku si me.

(1 Corinthians 5:7) Just as the Passover celebration reminded the Israelites that they had been freed from slavery, so the Memorial of Jesus Christ’s death reminds Christians that they have been freed from sin and death.
Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui si woɖuna le Nisan 14 lia dzi le Biblia ƒe ɣletigbalẽ nu la nye ƒe sia ƒe wɔna, nenema kee Kristotɔ gbãtɔwo hã ɖua Ŋkuɖodzia zi ɖeka le ƒe me.
The Passover, held on Nisan 14 according to the lunar calendar, was a yearly celebration; the early Christians likewise observed the Memorial once each year.
Ƒe sia ƒe, le ŋkeke si dze Nisan 14 lia dzi la, ame miliɔn geɖe le xexea me godoo ɖoa ŋku Yesu ƒe kua dzi.
Annually, on the date corresponding to Nisan 14, millions of people worldwide commemorate Jesus’ death.
Atitsoga Ŋutie Yesu Ku Ðoa?
Did Jesus Die on a Cross?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ame geɖe bua atitsoga be enye Kristotɔwo ƒe dzesi si bɔ wu.
Many view the cross as the most common symbol of Christianity.
Gake Biblia megblɔ ale si ati si ŋuti Yesu ku ɖo la le na mí o, eya ta ame aɖeke mate ŋu anya ale si tututu atia le o.
However, the Bible does not describe the instrument of Jesus’ death, so no one can know its shape with absolute certainty.
Ke hã Biblia na wòdze kɔtɛe be ati tsralaa ŋue Yesu ku ɖo, ke menye atitsoga ŋue o.
Still, the Bible provides evidence that Jesus died, not on a cross, but on an upright stake.
Zi geɖe la, ne wole nu ƒom tso ati si ŋu Yesu ku ɖo ŋu le Biblia me la, wozãa Helagbe me nya si nye stauros.
The Bible generally uses the Greek word stauros when referring to the instrument of Jesus’ execution.
(Mateo 27:40; Yohanes 19:17) Togbɔ be woɖe nya sia gɔme le Biblia bubuwo me zi geɖe be "atitsoga " hã la, Biblia-ŋutinunyala geɖewo lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be nu si Helagbe me nya ma fia koe nye "ati tsrala. "
(Matthew 27:40; John 19:17) Although translations often render this word "cross, " many scholars agree that its basic meaning is actually "upright stake. "
Le numekugbalẽ aɖe (A Critical Lexicon and Concordance to the English and Greek New Testament) ƒe nya nu la, nya stauros "mefia ati eve siwo wotsɔ tso ga ɖe wo nɔewo me kpɔ gbeɖe o. "
According to A Critical Lexicon and Concordance to the English and Greek New Testament, stauros "never means two pieces of wood joining each other at any angle. "
Wozãa Helagbe me nya xylon ɖe stauros teƒe le Biblia me.
The Bible also uses the Greek word xylon as a synonym for stauros.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 5:30; 1 Petro 2:24) Nya sia fia "ati, " "atikpo, " "ati tsrala " alo "ati dzɔdzɔe. "
(Acts 5:​30; 1 Peter 2:​24) This word means "wood, " "timber, " "stake, " or "tree. "
The Companion Bible gblɔ be: "Naneke mele Helagbe si me woŋlɔ [Nubabla Yeyea] ɖo la me si ana ame ƒe susu nayi ati eve dzi kura gɔ̃ hã o. "
The Companion Bible thus concludes: "There is nothing in the Greek of the N[ew] T[estament] even to imply two pieces of timber. "
Ðe wòsɔ be woazã atitsoga le mawusubɔsubɔ mea?
Is using the cross in worship acceptable to God?
Crux simplex​ Latingbe me nya si wozãna na ati tsrala siwo ŋu woklãa nu vlo wɔlawo ɖo
A crux simplex​ the Latin term for a single stake used for impalement of a criminal
Eɖanye aleke kee ati si ŋuti Yesu ku ɖo la le o, kpeɖodziwo kple Biblia me nya siwo gbɔna ɖee fia be mele be woazã atitsoga le mawusubɔsubɔ me o.
Regardless of the shape of the instrument on which Jesus died, the following facts and Bible verses indicate that we should not use the cross in worship.
Mawu de se be womegazã nɔnɔmewɔwɔwo, nɔnɔmetatawo kple dzesiwo abe atitsoga ene atsɔ asubɔ ye o.
God rejects worship that uses images or symbols, including the cross.
Mawu de se na Israel-viwo be womegazã "nɔnɔme aɖeke " atsɔ asubɔ ye o, eye wode se ma ke na Kristotɔwo hã be "misi le trɔ̃subɔsubɔ nu. " 5 Mose 4:15-19; 1 Korintotɔwo 10:14.
God commanded the Israelites not to use "the form of any symbol " in their worship, and Christians are likewise told to "flee from idolatry. "​ Deuteronomy 4:​15-​19; 1 Corinthians 10:14.
Kristotɔ siwo nɔ anyi le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me la mezã atitsoga le mawusubɔsubɔ me o.
First-century Christians did not use the cross in worship.
Apostoloawo ƒe nufiafiawo kple woƒe kpɔɖeŋuwoe wòle be Kristotɔwo katã nasrɔ̃.​ 2 Tesalonikatɔwo 2:15.
The teachings and example of the apostles set a pattern that all Christians should adhere to.​ 2 Thessalonians 2:​15.
Trɔ̃subɔlawo gbɔe atitsogazazã le subɔsubɔ me dzɔ tso.
Use of the cross in worship has a pagan origin.

Ƒe alafa geɖe le Yesu ƒe ku megbe la, esime sɔlemehawo va tra ɖa tso Yesu ƒe nufiafiawo gbɔ lae woɖea mɔ na ame yeye siwo va nɔ sɔlemehawo me ɖom la be "woakpɔtɔ anɔ nɔnɔmewɔwɔwo kple dzesi siwo wozãna le trɔ̃subɔsubɔ me la dometɔ akpa gãtɔ zãm. " Dzesi siawo dometɔ ɖekae nye atitsoga.

Hundreds of years after the death of Jesus, when the churches had deviated from his teachings, new church members "were permitted largely to retain their pagan signs and symbols, " including the cross.

(The Expanded Vine’s Expository Dictionary of New Testament Words) Ke hã Biblia meda asi ɖe edzi be woaɖe mɔ ɖe trɔ̃subɔlawo ƒe dzesiwo zazã ŋu be wòakpe ɖe trɔ̃subɔlawo ŋu woatrɔ dzi me azu xɔsetɔwo o.​ 2 Korintotɔwo 6:17.
(The Expanded Vine’s Expository Dictionary of New Testament Words) However, the Bible does not condone adopting pagan symbols to help make new converts.​ 2 Corinthians 6:​17.
Esi Wofɔ Yesu Ðe Tsitre La, Eƒe Amegbetɔŋutilãe Nɔ Eŋu Loo Alo Gbɔgbɔŋutilãe?
After Jesus’ Resurrection, Was His Body Flesh or Spirit?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia gblɔ be wowu Yesu "le ŋutilã me, ke wogbɔ agbee le gbɔgbɔ me. " 1 Petro 3:18; Dɔwɔwɔwo 13:34; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:45; 2 Korintotɔwo 5:16.
The Bible says that Jesus "was put to death in the flesh but made alive [resurrected] in the spirit. "​ 1 Peter 3:​18; Acts 13:34; 1 Corinthians 15:45; 2 Corinthians 5:​16.
Yesu ŋutɔ ƒe nyawo ɖee fia be ne wofɔ ye la, yeƒe ŋutilã maganye amegbetɔ ƒe ŋutilã azɔ o.
Jesus’ own words showed that he would not be resurrected with his flesh-and-blood body.
Egblɔ be nu si yeana ‘ɖe xexea ƒe agbe ta lae nye yeƒe ŋutilã.’
He said that he would give his "flesh in behalf of the life of the world, " as a ransom for mankind.
(Yohanes 6:51; Mateo 20:28) Ne ɖe wògatrɔ tsɔ eƒe amegbetɔŋutilãa esime wofɔe ɖe tsitre la, ke efia be ete fli ɖe eƒe tafevɔsa, si fia vɔ si wòsa ɖe ameƒomea ta la, me.
(John 6:​51; Matthew 20:28) If he had taken back his flesh when he was resurrected, he would have canceled that ransom sacrifice.
Medzɔ alea o, elabe Biblia gblɔ be etsɔ eƒe ŋutilã kple eƒe ʋu na "zi ɖeka ɖe ɣeyiɣiawo katã nu. "
This could not have happened, though, for the Bible says that he sacrificed his flesh and blood "once for all time. "
Hebritɔwo 9:11, 12.
Hebrews 9:​11, 12.
Ne gbɔgbɔŋutilãe nɔ Yesu ŋu esime wofɔe ɖe tsitre la, ke aleke wòdzɔe be eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo te ŋu kpɔe?
If Jesus was raised up with a spirit body, how could his disciples see him?
Gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔwo ate ŋu ado amegbetɔŋutilã.
Spirit creatures can take on human form.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, mawudɔla siwo wɔ esia le blema te ŋu ɖu nu, no nu kple amegbetɔwo.
For example, angels who did this in the past even ate and drank with humans.
(1 Mose 18:1-8; 19:1-3) Ke hã, wokpɔtɔ nye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔwo eye wote ŋu dzo le xexe si wokpɔna kple ŋku la me.​ Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 13:15-21.
(Genesis 18:​1-8; 19:​1-3) However, they still were spirit creatures and could leave the physical realm.​ Judges 13:15-​21.
Esi wofɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre megbe la, eya hã do amegbetɔŋutilã ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe abe ale si mawudɔlawo wɔe do ŋgɔ nɛ ene.
After his resurrection, Jesus also assumed human form temporarily, just as angels had previously done.
Esi wòzu gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ ta la, etea ŋu dzena zi ɖeka kpoyi eye wògatea ŋu buna zi ɖeka vĩi hã.
As a spirit creature, though, he was able to appear and disappear suddenly.
(Luka 24:31; Yohanes 20:19, 26) Menye amegbetɔŋutilã ɖeka ma kee nɔ eŋu esi wòdze na amewo le nɔnɔme vovovowo me o.
(Luke 24:31; John 20:19, 26) The fleshly bodies that he materialized were not identical from one appearance to the next.
Eya ta Yesu xɔlɔ̃ veviwo gɔ̃ hã mete ŋu kpɔe dze sii o va se ɖe esime wòwɔ nane alo gblɔ nya aɖe hafi.​ Luka 24:30, 31, 35; Yohanes 20:14-16; 21:6, 7.
Thus, even Jesus’ close friends recognized him only by what he said or did.​ Luke 24:30, 31, 35; John 20:14-​16; 21:​6, 7.
Esi Yesu dze na apostolo Toma la, edo amegbetɔŋutilã si ŋu abiwo le.
When Jesus appeared to the apostle Thomas, he took on a body with wound marks.
Ewɔ esia tsɔ do ŋusẽ Toma ƒe xɔse, elabena Toma menɔ kakam ɖe edzi be wofɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre o.​ Yohanes 20:24-29.
He did this to bolster Thomas’ faith, since Thomas doubted that Jesus had been raised up.​ John 20:24-​29.
Yesu Naa Ðeɖe Le Mɔ Ka Nu?
Jesus Saves​ How?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yesu na ɖeɖe amegbetɔ wɔnuteƒewo esi wòtsɔ eƒe agbe na wònye tafe ɖe wo ta.
Jesus saved faithful humans when he gave his life as a ransom sacrifice.

(Mateo 20:28) Eya ta Biblia yɔ Yesu be "xexea ɖela. " (1 Yohanes 4:14) Egagblɔ be: "Xɔxɔ la megale ame bubu aɖeke me o, elabena ŋkɔ bubu aɖeke mele dziƒoa te, si wona amegbetɔwo, si dzi míato akpɔ xɔxɔ o. " Dɔwɔwɔwo 4:12.

(Matthew 20:28) Thus, the Bible calls Jesus the "Savior of the world. " (1 John 4:​14) It also states: "There is no salvation in anyone else, for there is no other name under heaven that has been given among men by which we must get saved. "​ Acts 4:​12.
Yesu ‘ɖɔ ku kpɔ ɖe ame siwo katã’ xɔa edzi sena la ta.
Jesus ‘tasted death for everyone’ who exercises faith in him.
(Hebritɔwo 2:9; Yohanes 3:16) Esia megbe la, "Mawu fɔe ɖe tsitre tso ame kukuwo dome, " eye Yesu zu gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ trɔ yi dziƒo.
(Hebrews 2:9; John 3:​16) Thereafter, "God raised him up from the dead, " and Jesus returned to heaven as a spirit creature.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 3:15) Le afi ma la, Yesu "ate ŋu aɖe ame siwo le tetem ɖe Mawu ŋu to eya amea dzi la bliboe hã, elabena ele agbe ɣesiaɣi, be wòaxɔ woƒe nya ɖe akɔ. " Hebritɔwo 7:25.
(Acts 3:​15) There, Jesus is able "to save completely those who are approaching God through him, because he is always alive to plead for them. "​ Hebrews 7:​25.
Nu ka tae wòle be Yesu naxɔ míaƒe nya ɖe akɔ?
Why do we need Jesus to plead for us?
Mí katã míenye nu vɔ̃ wɔlawo.
We are all sinners.
(Romatɔwo 3:23) Nu vɔ̃ nye mɔxenu le mí kple Mawu dome, eye wòkplɔa mí yia ku me.
(Romans 3:​23) Sin puts a barrier between us and God, and it leads to death.
(Romatɔwo 6:23) Ke hã Yesu nyea "ametaʋlila " na ame siwo xɔa eƒe tafevɔsaa dzi sena.
(Romans 6:​23) But Jesus serves as "an advocate " for those who exercise faith in his ransom sacrifice.
(1 Yohanes 2:1, etenuŋɔŋlɔ) Yesu xɔa nya ɖe akɔ ɖe wo ta, eye wòbiaa Mawu be wòase woƒe gbedodoɖawo eye wòanɔ te ɖe yeƒe vɔsakua dzi atsɔ woƒe nu vɔ̃wo ake wo.
(1 John 2:1, footnote) He pleads in their behalf, asking God to hear their prayers and grant forgiveness of their sins on the basis of Jesus’ sacrificial death.
(Mateo 1:21; Romatɔwo 8:34) Mawu wɔna ɖe Yesu ƒe biabia mawo dzi elabe wowɔ ɖeka kple Eƒe lɔlɔ̃nu.
(Matthew 1:​21; Romans 8:​34) God acts on such pleas made by Jesus because they are in harmony with His will.
Mawu dɔ Yesu ɖo ɖe anyigba dzi "be woaɖe xexea to edzi. " Yohanes 3:17.
God sent Jesus to the earth "for the world to be saved through him. "​ John 3:​17.
Yesu dzi xɔxɔ se koe hiã be míakpɔ ɖeɖea?
Is belief in Jesus all that we need to be saved?
Ao.
No.
Togbɔ be ele be míaxɔ Yesu dzi se hafi akpɔ ɖeɖe hã la, egabia nu bubu geɖewo hã.
Although we must believe in Jesus to gain salvation, more is required.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 16:30, 31) Biblia gblɔ be: "Ale si ŋutilã gbɔgbɔ manɔmee nye nu kuku la, nenema kee xɔse dɔwɔwɔ manɔŋui hã nye nu kuku. "
(Acts 16:30, 31) The Bible says: "Just as the body without spirit is dead, so also faith without works is dead. "
(Yakobo 2:26) Be míakpɔ ɖeɖe la, ele be:
(James 2:​26) To be saved, we must:
Míasrɔ̃ nu tso Yesu kple Fofoa, Yehowa ŋu. Yohanes 17:3.
Learn about Jesus and his Father, Jehovah.​ John 17:3.
Míaxɔ wo dzi ase. Yohanes 12:44; 14:1.
Build faith in them.​ John 12:44; 14:1.
Míaɖe míaƒe xɔse afia to woƒe sewo dzi wɔwɔ me.
Demonstrate our faith by obeying their commands.
(Luka 6:46; 1 Yohanes 2:17) Yesu fia nu be menye ame sia ame si le ye yɔm be "Aƒetɔ " lae akpɔ ɖeɖe o, negbe ‘ame siwo le ye Fofo si le dziƒowo ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu wɔm’ la ɖeɖe ko. Mateo 7:21.
(Luke 6:​46; 1 John 2:​17) Jesus taught that not everyone who called him "Lord " would be saved but only those "doing the will of [his] Father who is in the heavens. "​ Matthew 7:​21.
Míayi edzi aɖe xɔse afia ne míele nɔnɔme sesẽwo me tom gɔ̃ hã.
Continue to demonstrate our faith despite hardships.
Yesu na esia me kɔ ƒãa esi wògblɔ be: "Ame si do dzi va se ɖe nuwuwu la, eyae akpɔ ɖeɖe. " Mateo 24:13.
Jesus made that clear when he said: "The one who has endured to the end will be saved. "​ Matthew 24:13.
Aleke Yesu Ƒe Vɔsa Nye "Tafe Na Ame Geɖewo "?
How Is Jesus’ Sacrifice "a Ransom for Many "?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yesu dzie Mawu ato aɖe amegbetɔƒomea alo axɔ nɛ tso nu vɔ̃ kple ku si me.
Jesus’ sacrifice is the means by which God delivers, or saves, humankind from sin and death.
Biblia gblɔ tso Yesu ƒe ʋu si wokɔ ɖi la ŋu be enye mía tafe.
The Bible refers to the shed blood of Jesus as a ransom price.
(Efesotɔwo 1:7; 1 Petro 1:18, 19) Eya tae Yesu gblɔ be yeva be "yeatsɔ yeƒe agbe ana wòanye tafe na ame geɖewo. " Mateo 20:28.
(Ephesians 1:7; 1 Peter 1:​18, 19) Thus, Jesus said that he came "to give his life a ransom for many. "​ Matthew 20:28, King James Version.
Nu ka tae wòhiã be woana "tafe na ame geɖewo "?
Why was "a ransom for many " needed?
Wowɔ amegbetɔ gbãtɔ Adam wònye ame deblibo eye nu vɔ̃ aɖeke menɔ eŋu o.
The first man, Adam, was created perfect, or without sin.
Mɔnukpɔkpɔ nɔ esi be wòanɔ agbe tegbee, gake ebu mɔnukpɔkpɔ sia esi wòda Mawu ƒe se dzi.
He had the prospect of living forever but lost it by choosing to disobey God.
(1 Mose 3:17-19) Esi wòdzi viwo la, viawo nyi nu vɔ̃ ƒe dome tso egbɔ.
(Genesis 3:​17-​19) When he had children, he passed on to them the defect of sin.
(Romatɔwo 5:12) Susu sia tae Biblia gblɔ be Adam ‘dzra’ eya ŋutɔ kple viawo wozu kluviwo na nu vɔ̃ kple ku.
(Romans 5:​12) For this reason, the Bible indicates that Adam "sold " himself and his children into slavery to sin and death.
(Romatɔwo 7:14) Esi wònye be Adam ƒe viwo katã nye ame madeblibowo ta la, wo dometɔ aɖeke mate ŋu agbugbɔ nu si Adam bu la aƒle o.​ Psalmo 49:​7, 8.
(Romans 7:​14) Being imperfect, none of them could buy back what Adam lost.​ Psalm 49:​7, 8.
Mawu ƒe dɔme trɔ ɖe Adam ƒe dzidzimeviwo ŋu le mɔkpɔkpɔmanɔamesi ƒe nɔnɔme si me wole la me.
God felt compassion for Adam’s descendants in their hopeless situation.
(Yohanes 3:16) Gake Mawu ƒe ʋɔnu dzɔdzɔe dɔdrɔ̃ wɔe be Mawu mate ŋu aŋe aɖaba aƒu nu gbegblẽ wɔwɔa dzi alo atsɔe ake ne susu aɖeke meli o.
(John 3:​16) However, God’s standard of justice required that he not simply overlook or excuse their sins without a valid basis.
(Psalmo 89:14; Romatɔwo 3:23-26) Mawu lɔ̃ amegbetɔwo, eya ta ena nane si dzi wòanɔ te ɖo le se nu atsɔ woƒe nu vɔ̃wo ake wo ahaɖe nu vɔ̃ ɖa keŋkeŋ.
(Psalm 89:14; Romans 3:​23-​26) God loves mankind, so he provided the necessary legal means for their sins to be not only forgiven but also eliminated.
(Romatɔwo 5:6-8) Tafe lae nye nu si wòna le se nu.
(Romans 5:​6-8) The ransom is that legal basis.
Aleke tafea wɔa dɔe?
How does the ransom work?
Le Biblia me la, nya "tafe " lɔ nu etɔ̃ siawo ɖe eme:
In the Bible, the term "ransom " involves the following three elements:
Enye fexexe.​ 4 Mose 3:46, 47.
It is a payment.​ Numbers 3:​46, 47.
Enana woɖea amewo alo ɖea asi le wo ŋu.​ 2 Mose 21:30.
It brings about a release, or redemption.​ Exodus 21:30.
Esɔna kple nu si ta wole fea xem ɖo la ƒe home.
It corresponds to the value of what is paid for, or covers it.
Kpɔ ale si nu siawo dze le Yesu Kristo ƒe tafevɔsaa me ɖa.
Consider how these elements apply to the ransom sacrifice of Jesus Christ.
Fexexe.
Payment.

Biblia gblɔ be "ho gã aɖee wotsɔ ƒle " Kristotɔwo. (1 Korintotɔwo 6:20; 7:23) Ho gã mae nye Yesu ƒe ʋu si wotsɔ "ƒle amewo tso to sia to kple gbegbɔgblɔ sia gbegbɔgblɔ kple ame ƒomevi ɖe sia ɖe kple dukɔ sia dukɔ me na Mawu. " Nyaɖeɖefia 5:8, 9.

The Bible says that Christians were "bought with a price. " (1 Corinthians 6:​20; 7:​23) That price is the blood of Jesus, with which he "bought people for God out of every tribe and tongue and people and nation. "​ Revelation 5:​8, 9.
Ðeɖe.
Release.
Yesu ƒe tafe la dzie "woto ɖe mí " tso nu vɔ̃ si me. 1 Korintotɔwo 1:30; Kolosetɔwo 1:14; Hebritɔwo 9:15.
Jesus’ sacrifice provides a "release by ransom " from sin.​ 1 Corinthians 1:​30; Colossians 1:​14; Hebrews 9:​15.
Esɔna kple nua ƒe home.
Correspondence.
Yesu ƒe vɔsaa ƒe kpekpeme sɔ pɛpɛpɛ kple nu si Adam bu, si nye amegbetɔ ƒe agbe deblibo.
Jesus’ sacrifice corresponds exactly to what Adam lost​ one perfect human life.

(1 Korintotɔwo 15:21, 22, 45, 46) Biblia gblɔ be: "Ale si ko ame ɖeka [Adam] ƒe tomaɖomaɖo na ame geɖewo zu nu vɔ̃ wɔlawoe la, nenema kee to ame ɖeka [Yesu Kristo] ƒe toɖoɖo me hã woana ame geɖewo nazu ame dzɔdzɔewo. "

(1 Corinthians 15:21, 22, 45, 46) The Bible says: "Just as through the disobedience of the one man [Adam] many were made sinners, so also through the obedience of the one person [Jesus Christ] many will be made righteous. "
(Romatɔwo 5:19) Esia na ale si ame ɖeka ƒe ku ate ŋu axe fe ɖe nu vɔ̃ wɔla gbogbo aɖewo ta la me kɔ keŋ.
(Romans 5:​19) This explains how the death of one man can pay the ransom for many sinners.
Le nyateƒe me la, Yesu ƒe vɔsa nye "tafe si sɔ ɖe enu ɖe amewo katã ta, " efia ame siwo katã aɖe afɔ siwo hiã ale be wòaɖe vi na wo la ta.​ 1 Timoteo 2:​5, 6.
In fact, Jesus’ sacrifice is "a corresponding ransom for all " those who take the steps necessary to benefit from it.​ 1 Timothy 2:​5, 6.
Nu Ka Tae Wòle Be Míado Gbe Ða Le Yesu Ƒe Ŋkɔ Me?
Why Pray in Jesus’ Name?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ele be míado gbe ɖa na Mawu le Yesu ƒe ŋkɔ me elabe mɔ ma ko dzie Mawu be míato ado gbe ɖa na ye hafi yeasee.
We must pray to God in Jesus’ name because this is the only way God has approved for us to approach Him.
Yesu gblɔ be: "Nyee nye mɔ la kple nyateƒe la kpakple agbe la.
Jesus said: "I am the way and the truth and the life.
Ame aɖeke mevaa Fofo la gbɔ o, negbe to dzinye ko. "
No one comes to the Father except through me. "
(Yohanes 14:6)Yesu gblɔ hã na eƒe apostolo wɔnuteƒeawo be: "Vavã, vavã mele egblɔm na mi be: Ne miebia nane Fofo la la, atsɔe ana mi le nye ŋkɔ me. "
(John 14:6) Jesus also told his faithful apostles: "Most truly I say to you, If you ask the Father for anything he will give it to you in my name. "
Yohanes 16:23.
John 16:23.
Susu bubu siwo ta míado gbe ɖa le Yesu ƒe ŋkɔ me
More reasons to pray in Jesus’ name
Míedea bubu Yesu kple Fofoa Yehowa Mawu ŋu.
We honor Jesus and his Father, Jehovah God.
Filipitɔwo 2:9-11.
Philippians 2:9-11.
Míeɖenɛ fiana be míelɔ̃ ɖe edzi be Yesu ƒe kuae nye mɔ si dzi Mawu to be yeaɖe mí.
We show that we appreciate Jesus’ death as God’s provision for our salvation.
Mateo 20:28; Dɔwɔwɔwo 4:12.
Matthew 20:28; Acts 4:12.
Míelɔ̃ ɖe ɖoƒe tɔxɛ si Yesu le abe Nyaxɔɖeakɔla le Mawu kple amegbetɔwo dome la dzi.
We recognize Jesus’ unique role as Intercessor between God and men.
Hebritɔwo 7:25.
Hebrews 7:25.
Míedea bubu ɖoƒe si le Yesu si abe Nunɔlagã ene ŋu, be enye ame si ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu ƒomedodo nyui nanɔ mí kple Mawu dome.
We respect Jesus’ service as the High Priest who can help us gain a good standing with God.
Hebritɔwo 4:14-16.
Hebrews 4:14-16.
Nu Kae Nye Kristo Ƒe Vava?
What Is the Coming of Christ?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ŋɔŋlɔawo ƒo nu tso ɣeyiɣi si Kristo ava le etsɔme ava drɔ̃ ʋɔnu anyigbadzitɔwo la ŋu zi geɖe.
The Scriptures make dozens of references to the future time when Christ comes to judge the people of the earth.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mateo 25:31-33 gblɔ be:
For example, Matthew 25:31-​33 says:
"Ne Amegbetɔvi la va ɖo le eƒe ŋutikɔkɔe me, eye mawudɔlawo katã le eŋuti la, ekema abɔbɔ nɔ eƒe ŋutikɔkɔefiazikpui la dzi.
"When the Son of man [Jesus Christ] comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, then he will sit down on his glorious throne.
Eye woaƒo dukɔwo katã nu ƒu ɖe eŋkume, eye wòama amewo me tso wo nɔewo gbɔ, abe ale si alẽkplɔla maa alẽwo tso gbɔ̃wo gbɔe ene.
All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate people one from another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
Eye wòatsɔ alẽawo aɖo eƒe ɖusime, ke atsɔ gbɔ̃awo ya aɖo eƒe miame. "
And he will put the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on his left. "
Ʋɔnudrɔ̃ɣi sia anye "xaxa gã " si meva amegbetɔƒomea dzi kpɔ o la ƒe akpa aɖe.
This time of judgment will be part of a "great tribulation " unlike anything in human history.
Armagedon-ʋa ava wu xaxa gã ma nu.
That tribulation will culminate in the war of Armageddon.

(Mateo 24:21; Nyaɖeɖefia 16:16) Kristo ƒe futɔwo siwo woyɔ le lododoa me be gbɔ̃wo la "akpɔ tsɔtsrɔ̃ mavɔ ƒe tohehe. " (2 Tesalonikatɔwo 1:9; Nyaɖeɖefia 19:11, 15) Gake Yesu yomedzela wɔnuteƒe siwo nye alẽwo ya akpɔ "agbe mavɔ. "​ Mateo 25:46.

(Matthew 24:21; Revelation 16:16) Christ’s enemies, described in his illustration as goats, "will undergo the judicial punishment of everlasting destruction. " (2 Thessalonians 1:9; Revelation 19:11, 15) In contrast, his faithful servants, the sheep, will have the prospect of "everlasting life. "​ Matthew 25:46.
Ɣekaɣie Kristo ava?
When will Christ come?
Yesu gblɔ be: "Le ŋkeke ma kple gaƒoƒo ma ŋuti la, ame aɖeke menyae o. "
Jesus said: "Concerning that day and hour nobody knows. "
(Mateo 24:36, 42; 25:13) Gake egblɔ "dzesi " ƒokpli si woate ŋu akpɔ atsɔ ade dzesi ɣeyiɣi siwo ado ŋgɔ teti na eƒe vava va se ɖe eƒe vava dzi.​ Mateo 24:​3, 7-​14; Luka 21:10, 11.
(Matthew 24:36, 42; 25:13) However, he did describe a visible, composite "sign " that would identify the period leading up to his coming.​ Matthew 24:​3, 7-​14; Luke 21:10, 11.
Ne Kristo va la, gbɔgbɔŋutilãe anɔ eŋu loo alo amegbetɔŋutilãea?
Does Christ come in a body of spirit or of flesh?
Esi wòfɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre la, ezu gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ si ŋu gbɔgbɔŋutilã le, eya ta gbɔgbɔŋutilãe anɔ eŋu ne eva, ke menye amegbetɔŋutilã o.
Jesus was resurrected with a spirit body, so he comes as a spirit creature, not in the flesh.
(1 Korintotɔwo 15:45; 1 Petro 3:18) Esia tae Yesu te ŋu gblɔ na eƒe apostolowo le ŋkeke si do ŋgɔ na eƒe ku dzi be: "Esusɔ vie ko xexea magakpɔm o. "​ Yohanes 14:19.
(1 Corinthians 15:45; 1 Peter 3:​18) For this reason, Jesus could tell his apostles on the day before his death: "In a little while the world will see me no more. "​ John 14:19.
Susu masɔmasɔ aɖewo siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Kristo ƒe vava ŋu
Common misconceptions about Christ’s coming
Susu masɔmasɔ: Amewo susuna be esi Biblia gblɔ be amewo akpɔ Yesu "le dziƒolilikpowo dzi gbɔna " la, efia be ne Yesu va la amewo akpɔ eya amea kple ŋku.​ Mateo 24:30.
Misconception: When the Bible says that people will see Jesus "coming on the clouds, " it means that Jesus will come visibly.​ Matthew 24:30.
Nyateƒenya: Zi geɖe la, Biblia zãa alilikpo wòdoa ƒome kple nu siwo womate ŋu akpɔ kple ŋku o.
Fact: The Bible often associates clouds with something hidden from view.
(3 Mose 16:2; 4 Mose 11:25; 5 Mose 33:26) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Mawu gblɔ na Mose be: "Kpɔ ɖa, megbɔna gbɔwò le alilikpo dodo me. " (2 Mose 19:9) Mose mekpɔ Mawu kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
(Leviticus 16:2; Numbers 11:25; Deuteronomy 33:26) For example, God told Moses: "I am coming to you in a dark cloud. "
Nenema kee Kristo ‘anɔ dziƒolilikpowo dzi’ ava le gɔmesese sia nu be amewo ade dzesi eƒe vava togbɔ be womate ŋu akpɔ eya amea ŋutɔ kple ŋku o hã.
(Exodus 19:9) Moses did not literally see God. Likewise, Christ ‘comes on the clouds’ in that people perceive his coming even though they cannot literally see him.
Susu masɔmasɔ: Amewo susuna be nya si wogblɔ le Nyaɖeɖefia 1:7 be "ŋku sia ŋku akpɔe " esi wonɔ nu ƒom tso Kristo ƒe vava ŋu la fia be amewo akpɔ eya amea kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ.
Misconception: The expression "every eye will see him, " used at Revelation 1:7 when speaking of Christ’s coming, is to be understood literally.
Nyateƒenya: Wozãa Helagbe me nya siwo gɔme woɖe le Biblia me be "ŋku " kple "akpɔe " ɣeaɖewoɣi wofiaa nu si gɔme woate ŋu ase alo akpɔ le susu me, ke menye be woakpɔe kple ŋku ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
Fact: The Greek words in the Bible for "eye " and "seeing " are sometimes used in the sense of discerning or perceiving rather than referring to literal sight.

(Mateo 13:15; Luka 19:42; Romatɔwo 15:21; Efesotɔwo 1:18) Biblia gblɔ be Yesu, si wofɔ ɖe tsitre la, "le kekeli si ŋu womate ŋu ate ɖo o la me, ame si amegbetɔ aɖeke . . . [mate] ŋu akpɔ o. " (1 Timoteo 6:16) Eya ta "ŋku sia ŋku akpɔe " le gɔmesese sia nu be amewo katã akpɔe adze sii be Yesue le Mawu ƒe ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ hem va amewo dzi.​ Mateo 24:30 24:30.

(Matthew 13:15; Luke 19:42; Romans 15:21; Ephesians 1:​18) The Bible says that the resurrected Jesus is "the one . . . who dwells in unapproachable light, whom no man . . . can see. " (1 Timothy 6:​16) Thus, "every eye will see him " in that all people will perceive that Jesus is the one who brings God’s judgment.​ Matthew 24:30.
Susu masɔmasɔ: Amewo susuna be 2 Yohanes 7 me nyawo fia be ne Yesu va la, amegbetɔŋutilãe anɔ eŋu.
Misconception: The words of 2 John 7 show that Jesus will come in the flesh.
Nyateƒenya: Mawunyakpukpui ma gblɔ be: "Ameblela geɖewo do go yi xexea me, ame siwo meʋua Yesu Kristo me be eva le ŋutilã me o. "
Fact: That Bible verse states: "Many deceivers have gone out into the world, those not acknowledging Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh. "
Le apostolo Yohanes ƒe ŋkekeawo me la, ame aɖewo gblɔna be menye amegbetɔe Yesu nye o, eye meva le ŋutilã me o.
In the apostle John’s day, some denied that Jesus had come to earth in the flesh as a man.
Woyɔa ame siawo be Sidzedzehametɔwo.
They were called Gnostics.
Woŋlɔ 2 Yohanes 7 be woatsɔ aɖee fia be aʋatsonyawoe Sidzedzehametɔwo ƒe nufiafia mawo nye.
Second John 7 was written to refute their false claim.
Nu Kae Nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒe La?
What Is the Kingdom of God?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu ƒe Fiaɖuƒe la nye dziɖuɖu ŋutɔŋutɔ si Yehowa Mawu ɖo anyi.
God’s Kingdom is a real government established by Jehovah God.
Woyɔa "Mawu fiaɖuƒe la " le Biblia me hã be "dziƒofiaɖuƒe, " elabena eɖua dzi tso dziƒo.
"The kingdom of God " is also called "the kingdom of heaven " in the Bible, since it rules from heaven.
(Marko 1:14, 15; Mateo 4:17) Esɔ kple amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo le nu geɖe me geɖe me, gake ede ŋgɔ sãsãsã wu wo.
(Mark 1:14, 15; Matthew 4:17, King James Version) It shares many attributes of human governments, yet it is superior to them in every way.
Dziɖulawo.
Rulers.
Mawu ɖo Yesu Kristo Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia eye wòtsɔ ŋusẽ si ƒo amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖulawo tɔwo ta sãsãsã la nɛ.
God has appointed Jesus Christ as King of the Kingdom and has given him more authority than any human ruler could ever have.
(Mateo 28:18) Nyui koe Yesu zãa ŋusẽ sia tsɔ wɔna, elabena eɖee fia xoxo be yenye Kplɔla si dzi woate ŋu aka ɖo si sea veve ɖe ame nu.
(Matthew 28:18) Jesus uses this power only for good, since he has already proved to be a reliable and compassionate Leader.
(Mateo 4:23; Marko 1:40, 41; 6:31-34; Luka 7:11-17) Mawu fia mɔ Yesu wòtia amewo tso dukɔwo katã me ale be woawo kple Yesu woanɔ dziƒo aɖu "fia ɖe anyigba la dzi. "
(Matthew 4:23; Mark 1:40, 41; 6:31-34; Luke 7:11-17) Under God’s direction, Jesus has selected persons from all nations who will "rule as kings over the earth " with him in heaven.
Nyaɖeɖefia 5:9, 10.
Revelation 5:9, 10.
Ɣeyiɣi ƒe didime.
Duration.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea "matsrɔ̃ gbeɖegbeɖe " alo enu ayi abe ale si wòle le amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖu siwo vaa zi dzi egbea ko etsɔ wo nu yi ene la ene o.
Unlike human governments, which come and go, God’s Kingdom "will never be brought to ruin. "
Daniel 2:44.
Daniel 2:44.
Fiaɖuƒea teviwo.
Subjects.
Ame sia ame si wɔa nu si Mawu di la ate ŋu anye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea tevi, eɖanye dukɔ ka me tɔe wòɖanye o.
Anyone who does what God requires can be a subject of God’s Kingdom, without regard for ancestry or birthplace.
Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:34, 35.
Sewo.
Laws.
Menye nu gbegblẽ wɔwɔwo nu koe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea dea se ɖo o.
The laws (or commandments) of God’s Kingdom do more than just prohibit wrong behavior.
Seawo kpena ɖe eteviwo ŋu wonɔa agbe si ɖɔ ʋu wu.
They raise the moral character of its subjects.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔ be: "‘Ele be nàlɔ̃ Yehowa wò Mawu kple wò dzi blibo kple wò luʋɔ blibo kple wò tamesusu blibo.’
For example, the Bible says: "‘You must love Jehovah your God with your whole heart and with your whole soul and with your whole mind.’
Esiae nye sedede gãtɔ kple gbãtɔ.
This is the greatest and first commandment.
Evelia, si ɖii, lae nye esi: ‘Ele be nàlɔ̃ hawòvi abe wò ŋutɔ ɖokuiwò ene.’ " (Mateo 22:37-39) Lɔlɔ̃ si le Fiaɖuƒea teviwo si na Mawu kple wo haviwoe ʋã wo be woadi nyui na ame bubuwo.
The second, like it, is this, ‘You must love your neighbor as yourself.’ " (Matthew 22:37-39) Love of God and neighbor moves subjects of the Kingdom to act in the best interests of others.
Nusɔsrɔ̃.
Education.
Menye ɖeko Mawu Fiaɖuƒea tsɔ nudidi deŋgɔ ɖo eteviwo ŋkume ko evɔ o, ewɔ ɖoɖo be woafia ale si woawɔ aɖo nudidi siawo gbɔ la hã wo.
While God’s Kingdom sets high standards for its subjects, it also teaches people how to meet those standards.
Yesaya 48:17, 18.
Isaiah 48:17, 18.
Taɖodzinu.
Mission.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea menana ame siwo aɖu fia le fiaɖuƒe sia me la mebaa wo teviwo hezua kesinɔtɔwo o.
The Kingdom of God doesn’t enrich its rulers at the expense of its subjects.
Ke boŋ eƒe taɖodzinue nye be wòana Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu, si ƒe akpa aɖee nye ŋugbe si wòdo be ame siwo lɔ̃a ye la nava nɔ agbe tegbee le paradiso me le anyigba dzi la nava eme.
Instead, it will accomplish God’s will, including the promise that those who love him will live forever on a paradise earth.
Yesaya 35:1, 5, 6; Mateo 6:10; Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1-4.
Isaiah 35:1, 5, 6; Matthew 6:10; Revelation 21:1-4.
Ðe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Le Wò Dzi Mea?
Is the Kingdom of God in Your Heart?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, Mawu Fiaɖuƒea menye nɔnɔme aɖe le Kristotɔwo ƒe dzi me o.
No, God’s Kingdom is not merely a condition in the hearts of Christians.
Biblia na míenya afi si tututu Fiaɖuƒea le esi wòyɔe be "dziƒofiaɖuƒe. "
The Bible identifies its true location by calling it "the kingdom of heaven. "
(Mateo 4:17, Eʋegbe Biblia) Na míadzro ale si Biblia ɖee fia be dziɖuɖu ŋutɔŋutɔ wònye le dzi ɖum tso dziƒo la me.
(Matthew 4:​17, King James Version) Consider how the Bible shows it to be a real government that is ruling from heaven.
Dziɖulawo le Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la si, eteviwo, sewo kple ɖoɖowo hã le esi. Eƒe dɔdeasie nye be wòana woawɔ Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu le dziƒo kple anyigba dzi siaa.​ Mateo 6:10; Nyaɖeɖefia 5:10.
God’s Kingdom has rulers, subjects, laws, and a mandate to establish the will of God in heaven and on the earth.​ Matthew 6:​10; Revelation 5:​10.
Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu alo Fiaɖuƒea aɖu "amehawo, dukɔwo kple gbegbɔgblɔ ɖe sia ɖe dolawo " dzi.
God’s government, or Kingdom, will rule over all "the peoples, nations, and language groups " of the earth.
(Daniel 7:13, 14) Eƒe ŋusẽ metso eteviwo gbɔ o, ke boŋ Mawu ŋutɔ gbɔ eƒe ŋusẽa tso tẽe.​ Psalmo 2:4-6; Yesaya 9:7.
(Daniel 7:​13, 14) The authority for its rulership comes, not from its subjects, but directly from God.​ Psalm 2:​4-6; Isaiah 9:7.
Yesu gblɔ na eƒe apostolo wɔnuteƒeawo be woakpe ɖe ye ŋu le Dziƒofiaɖuƒea me eye woanɔ "fiazikpuiwo dzi. "​ Luka 22:28, 30.
Jesus told his faithful apostles that they would join him in the Kingdom of heaven to "sit on thrones. "​ Luke 22:28, 30.
Futɔwo le Fiaɖuƒea si, eye ele wotsrɔ̃ ge ɖa.​ Psalmo 2:1, 2, 8, 9; 110:1, 2; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:25, 26.
The Kingdom has enemies, which it will destroy.​ Psalm 2:​1, 2, 8, 9; 110:​1, 2; 1 Corinthians 15:25, 26.
Biblia mefia nu be Dziƒofiaɖuƒe la le wò dzi me le susu sia nu be eɖua dzi to amegbetɔ ƒe dzi me o.
The Bible does not teach that the Kingdom of heaven is in your heart in the sense that it rules through a person’s heart.
Ke hã egblɔ be "Fiaɖuƒea ŋuti nya la " alo "Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyui " la ate ŋu awɔ dɔ ɖe amewo ƒe dzi dzi eye ele be wòawɔe hã.​ Mateo 13:19; 24:14.
However, it does show that the "word of the Kingdom " or the "good news of the Kingdom " can and should affect our hearts.​ Matthew 13:19; 24:14.
Ke nu kae nya si wogblɔna be "mawufiaɖuƒe la le mia me " ya fia?
What does "the kingdom of God is within you " mean?
Ale si woɖe Luka 17:21 gɔme le Biblia aɖewo me na be ame aɖewo tɔtɔ le afi si tututu Fiaɖuƒea le la gome.
Some people have become confused about the location of the Kingdom by the rendering of Luke 17:21 in some Bible translations.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Eʋegbe Biblia (ƒe 2010 tɔ) gblɔ be "mawufiaɖuƒe la le mia me. "
For example, the King James Version says that "the kingdom of God is within you. "
Hafi míate ŋu ase mawunyakpukpui sia gɔme nyuie la, ele be míabu nya si gblɔm wonɔ hafi gblɔ emenyawo la ŋu.
To understand this verse correctly, we must consider the context.
Subɔsubɔhakplɔla siwo tsi tre ɖe Yesu ŋu dometɔ aɖewo
Some of the religious leaders who opposed Jesus
Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la menɔ amewula dzimesẽla siwo tsi tre ɖe Yesu ŋu la ƒe dzi me o
God’s Kingdom was not in the heart of Jesus’ obstinate and murderous opposers
Farisitɔwo nye subɔsubɔhakplɔlawo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo si tsi tre ɖe Yesu ŋu eye wokpɔ gome le nugbe si woɖo ɖe Yesu ŋu hewui la me.
Jesus was speaking to the Pharisees, a group of religious leaders who opposed him and shared in arranging for his execution.
(Mateo 12:14; Luka 17:20) Ðe susu anɔ eme be míabui be Fiaɖuƒe la nye nɔnɔme aɖe le dzimesẽla mawo ƒe dzi mea?
(Matthew 12:14; Luke 17:20) Does it make sense to think that the Kingdom was a condition in their obstinate hearts?
Yesu gblɔ na wo be: "Mia me yɔ fũu kple alakpanuwɔwɔ kple sedzimawɔmawɔ. "​ Mateo 23:27, 28.
Jesus told them: "Inside you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness. "​ Matthew 23:27, 28.
Biblia bubu aɖewo ɖe nya si Yesu gblɔ le Luka 17:21 me eme kɔ nyuie be: "Mawufiaɖuƒe la le mia dome. "
Other translations accurately clarify Jesus’ statement at Luke 17:21: "God’s kingdom is here with you. "
(Miawoe bi nya tsɔ te gbe ɖe edzi; Eʋegbe Biblia) "Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la le mia dome. "
(Italics ours; Contemporary English Version) "The Kingdom of God is among you. "
(Xexe Yeye Gɔmeɖeɖe) Dziƒofiaɖuƒe la nɔ Farisitɔwo "dome " le susu sia nu be Yesu, ame si Mawu tia be wòaɖu Fia la, tsi tsitre ɖe wo dome afi ma.​ Luka 1:​32, 33.
(New World Translation, footnote) The Kingdom of heaven was "with " or "among " the Pharisees, in that Jesus, the one designated by God to rule as King, was standing before them.​ Luke 1:​32, 33.
Nu Kae Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Awɔ Na Mí?
What Will God’s Kingdom Accomplish?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ava xɔ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo katã teƒe eye wòaɖu anyigba bliboa dzi.
God’s Kingdom will replace all human governments and rule over the entire earth.
(Daniel 2:44; Nyaɖeɖefia 16:14) Ne esia nya va eme ko la, ke Mawu Fiaɖuƒea. . .
(Daniel 2:44; Revelation 16:14) Once that happens, God’s Kingdom will . . .
Aɖe ame vɔ̃ɖi siwo ƒe ɖokuitɔdidinuwɔnawo gblẽa nu le mía ŋu la ɖa.
Remove the wicked, whose selfishness harms us all.
"Woatsrɔ̃ ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ɖa le anyigba dzi. "
"As regards the wicked, they will be cut off from the very earth. "
Lododowo 2:22.
Proverbs 2:22.
Atsi aʋawɔwɔ nu tegbee.
End all wars.
"[Mawu atsi] aʋawɔwɔwo nu va se ɖe anyigba ƒe mlɔenu ke. "
"[God] is making wars to cease to the extremity of the earth. "
Psalmo 46:9.
Psalm 46:9.
Ahe nunyoname kple dedienɔnɔ ava anyigba dzi.
Bring prosperity and security to the earth.
"Ame sia ame abɔbɔ nɔ anyi ɖe eƒe wainka kple eƒe gboti te bɔkɔɔ. "
"Everyone will live in peace among their own vineyards and fig trees, and no one will make them afraid. "
Mixa 4:4.
Micah 4:4, Good News Translation.
Ana anyigba nazu paradiso.
Make the earth into a paradise.
"Gbegbe kple gbedadaƒo akpɔ dzidzɔ, tagba atso aseye, eye wòaƒo se abe dzogbenya ene. "
"Thirsty deserts will be glad; barren lands will celebrate and blossom with flowers. "
Yesaya 35:1.
Isaiah 35:1, Contemporary English Version.
Ana ame sia ame nakpɔ dɔ nyui awɔ eye woƒe dzi adze eme.
Provide everyone with meaningful, enjoyable work.
"[Mawu ƒe] ame tiatiawo aɖu woawo ŋutɔ ƒe asinudɔwɔwɔwo.
"The work of their own hands [God’s] chosen ones will use to the full.
Womadze agbagba dzodzro o. "
They will not toil for nothing. "
Yesaya 65:21-23.
Isaiah 65:21-23.
Aɖe dɔléle ɖa keŋkeŋ.
Eliminate disease.
"Duametɔ aɖeke magblɔ be, yele dɔ lém o. "
"No resident will say: ‘I am sick.’
Yesaya 33:24.
" Isaiah 33:24.
Aɖe amegãkuku ɖa.
Set us free from the aging process.
"Ekema dzo aɖo eƒe lãme abe ɖekakpui ene, eye wòagaɖo eƒe ɖekakpuiŋkekewo me. "
"Let his flesh become fresher than in youth; let him return to the days of his youthful vigor. "
Hiob 33:25.
Agbɔ agbe ame kukuwo.
Bring the dead back to life.
"Ame siwo katã le ŋkuɖodziyɔdowo me la ase [Yesu ƒe] gbe, eye woado go. "
"All those in the memorial tombs will hear [Jesus’] voice and come out. "
Yohanes 5:28, 29.
Nu Kae Nye "Fiaɖuƒe La Ƒe Safuiwo "?
What Are "the Keys of the Kingdom "?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
"Dziƒofiaɖuƒe la ƒe safuiwo, " tsi tre ɖi na ŋusẽ si woatsɔ aʋu mɔ be amewo nate ŋu "ayi ɖe Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la me. "
"The keys of the Kingdom, " sometimes called "the keys to the kingdom, " represent the authority to open the way for people to "enter into the Kingdom of God. "
(Mateo 16:19; Dɔwɔwɔwo 14:22) Yesu tsɔ "dziƒofiaɖuƒe la ƒe safuiwo " na Petro.
(Matthew 16:19; The New American Bible; Acts 14:22) Jesus gave Peter "the keys of the Kingdom of the heavens. "
Esia fia be wona ŋusẽ Petro be wòafia nuteƒewɔlawo be mɔnukpɔkpɔ ate ŋu asu wo si be woayi ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me le dziƒo, ne woxɔ Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la.
This means that Peter received the authority to unlock information about how faithful people, by receiving God’s holy spirit, could enjoy the privilege of entering the Kingdom in heaven.
Ame kawoe Petro zã safuiawo na?
For whom were the keys used?
Petro zã ŋusẽ si Mawu nae la tsɔ ʋu mɔ na ame hatsotso etɔ̃ aɖewo be woage ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me:
Peter used authority from God to open the way for three groups to enter the Kingdom:
Yudatɔwo kple Yudatɔ siwo zu Kristotɔwo.
Jews and Jewish converts.
Le Yesu ƒe ku megbe kpuie la, Petro de dzi ƒo na ameha aɖe si nye Yudatɔ siwo va zu xɔsetɔwo be woaxɔ Yesu, ame si Mawu tia be wòanye Fiaɖuƒe la ƒe Fia.
Shortly after Jesus’ death, Peter encouraged a crowd of Jewish believers to accept Jesus as the one selected by God to rule in the Kingdom.
Petro fia nu si woawɔ be woakpɔ ɖeɖe la wo.
Peter showed them what they must do to get saved.
Eto esia dzi ʋu mɔ na wo be woayi ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me, eye ame akpewo "xɔ eƒe nya la. "​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:38-41.
He thus opened the way for them to enter the Kingdom, and thousands "accepted his word. "​ Acts 2:​38-​41.
Samariatɔwo.
Samaritans.
Emegbe woɖo Petro ɖe Samariatɔwo gbɔ.
Peter was later sent to the Samaritans.
Egazã Fiaɖuƒea ƒe safui ɖeka esi eya kpakple apostolo Yohanes woyi "ɖado gbe ɖa ɖe wo ta be woaxɔ gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe " la.
He again used a key of the Kingdom when he, along with the apostle John, "prayed for them to get holy spirit. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 8:14-17) Esia ʋu mɔ na Samariatɔwo be woayi ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me.
(Acts 8:​14-​17) This opened the way for the Samaritans to enter the Kingdom.
Dukɔwo me tɔ siwo va zu Kristotɔwo.
Gentiles.
Ƒe etɔ̃ kple afã le Yesu ƒe ku megbe la, Mawu ɖee fia Petro be mɔnukpɔkpɔ asu Dukɔwo me tɔwo (ame siwo menye Yudatɔwo o) hã si be woage ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me.
Three and a half years after Jesus’ death, God revealed to Peter that Gentiles (non-Jews) would also have the opportunity to enter the Kingdom.

Petro zã safuiawo dome ɖeka esi wògblɔ nya nyuia na Dukɔwo me tɔwo, eto esia dzi ʋu mɔ na wo be woaxɔ gbɔgbɔ kɔkɔe la, azu Kristotɔwo eye mɔnukpɔkpɔ asu wo si woanye Fiaɖuƒea gomekpɔlawo.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:30-35, 44, 45.

In response, Peter used one of the keys by preaching to Gentiles, thus opening the door for them to receive the holy spirit, become Christians, and be prospective members of the Kingdom.​ Acts 10:30-​35, 44, 45.
Nu kae wòfia be ‘woayi ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me’?
What does it mean to "enter into the Kingdom "?
Ame siwo anye Yesu ƒe hatidziɖulawo le dziƒo ye "ayi ɖe Fiaɖuƒe la me. "
Those who actually "enter into the Kingdom " become corulers with Jesus in heaven.
Biblia gblɔe ɖi be ‘woanɔ fiazikpuiwo dzi’ eye "woaɖu fia ɖe anyigba la dzi. "​ Luka 22:29, 30; Nyaɖeɖefia 5:9, 10.
The Bible foretold that they would "sit on thrones " and "rule as kings over the earth. "​ Luke 22:29, 30; Revelation 5:​9, 10.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Fiaɖuƒea ƒe safuiwo ŋu
Misconceptions about the keys of the Kingdom
Susu totro: Petro ye atso nya me le ame si ayi dziƒo la ŋu.
Misconception: Peter decides who may enter heaven.

Nyateƒea: Biblia gblɔ be Kristo Yesu ye "woɖo be wòadrɔ̃ ʋɔnu agbagbeawo kple kukuawo, " ke menye Petro o. (2 Timoteo 4:1, 8; Yohanes 5:22) Le nyateƒe me la, Petro ŋutɔ gblɔ be Yesu ye "Mawu ɖo be wòanye agbagbeawo kple kukuawo siaa ƒe ʋɔnudrɔ̃la. "​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:34, 42.

Fact: The Bible says that Christ Jesus, not Peter, "is to judge the living and the dead. " (2 Timothy 4:​1, 8; John 5:​22) In fact, Peter himself said that Jesus "is the one decreed by God to be judge of the living and the dead. "​ Acts 10:34, 42.
Susu totro: Dziƒotɔwo lalana be Petro natso nya me le ɣeyiɣi si wòazã Fiaɖuƒea ƒe safuiawo ŋu.
Misconception: Heaven waited on Peter to decide when to use the keys of the Kingdom.

Nyateƒea: Esi Yesu nɔ nu ƒom tso Fiaɖuƒea ƒe safuiwo ŋu la, egblɔ na Petro be: "Nu sia nu si nàbla le anyigba dzi la anɔ babla xoxo le dziƒowo, eye nu sia nu si nàtu le anyigba dzi la anɔ tutu xoxo le dziƒowo. "
Fact: When Jesus spoke about the keys of the Kingdom, he told Peter: "Whatever you bind on earth shall be bound in heaven; and whatever you loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven. "

(Mateo 16:19) Togbɔ be ame aɖewo se nya sia gɔme be Petro ƒe nyametsotsowo dzie woalɔ̃ ɖo le dziƒo hã la, Helagbe me dɔwɔnya siwo wozã fia be Petro ƒe nyametsotsowo awɔ ɖeka kple esiwo wowɔ xoxo le dziƒo; Petro mado ŋgɔ atso nya me le anyigba dzi o.

(Matthew 16:19, The New American Bible) Although some understand this statement to mean that Peter dictated decisions to heaven, the original Greek verbs show that Peter’s decisions would follow those made in heaven rather than precede them.
Biblia ƒe akpa bubu fia be Petro bɔbɔa eɖokui ɖe dziƒo te le Fiaɖuƒea ƒe safuiwo zazã me.
The Bible elsewhere shows that Peter was subject to heaven when using the keys of the Kingdom.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ewɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi esime wònɔ safui etɔ̃lia zãm.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:19, 20.
For example, he responded to instructions from God when using the third key.​ Acts 10:19, 20.
Nu Kae Nye Dziƒo?
What Is Heaven?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Gɔmesese vovovo etɔ̃e le nya "dziƒo " ŋu le Biblia me: (1) yame si míekpɔna; (2) gbɔgbɔmenuto me; eye (3) enyea kpɔɖeŋu na ɖoƒe kɔkɔ.
The word "heaven " is used in three basic senses in the Bible: (1) the physical heavens; (2) the spirit realm; and (3) a symbol of a high or exalted position.
Le wo katã gome la, nya siwo wogblɔ ƒo ɣlae ye afia dziƒo si ŋu nya gblɔm wole.
In each case, the context helps determine the correct understanding.
Yame si míekpɔna.
The physical heavens.
Le go sia me la, "dziƒowo " nye yamenuto me, afi si ya ƒona le, afi si xeviwo dzona le, afi si tsi ɖona le, afi si sno tsona dzana kple afi si dzi kea dzo le.
In this sense, "the heavens " refers to earth’s atmosphere, where the winds blow, the birds fly, the clouds produce rain and snow, and the lightning flashes.
(Psalmo 78:26; Lododowo 30:19; Yesaya 55:10; Luka 17:24) Agate ŋu afia afi si "ɣe, ɣleti kple ɣletiviwo " le hã.​ 5 Mose 4:19; 1 Mose 1:1.
(Psalm 78:26; Proverbs 30:19; Isaiah 55:10; Luke 17:24) It can also mean outer space, the location of "the sun and the moon and the stars. "​ Deuteronomy 4:​19; Genesis 1:1.
Gbɔgbɔmenuto me.
The spirit realm.
Nya "dziƒo " agate ŋu afia gbɔgbɔmenuto me, afi si kɔkɔ eye wòyi ŋgɔ wu yame si míekpɔna.
The term "heaven " also refers to the spiritual heavens, or spirit realm, a level of existence higher than and outside of the physical universe.
(1 Fiawo 8:27; Yohanes 6:38) Mawu, si nye "Gbɔgbɔ, " kple mawudɔla siwo hã nye gbɔgbɔwoe le dziƒo sia.
(1 Kings 8:​27; John 6:​38) These spiritual heavens are occupied by Jehovah God, who is "a Spirit, " as well as by the angelic spirit beings whom he created.
(Yohanes 4:24; Mateo 24:36) Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, woɖɔa "dziƒowo " wòfiaa mawudɔla wɔnuteƒe siwo nye "ame kɔkɔewo ƒe ha. "​ Psalmo 89:5-7.
(John 4:​24; Matthew 24:36) At times, "the heavens " are personified to represent the faithful angels, "the congregation of the holy ones. "​ Psalm 89:​5-7.

Biblia zãa "dziƒo " wòtsia tsitre ɖi na gbɔgbɔmenuto ƒe akpa si nye Yehowa ƒe ‘nɔƒe.’ (1 Fiawo 8:43, 49; Hebritɔwo 9:24; Nyaɖeɖefia 13:6) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔe ɖi be woatsɔ Satana kple eƒe gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo aƒu gbe tso dziƒo eye womagaɖe mɔ na wo woado ɖe Yehowa ŋkume o.

The Bible also uses "heavens " to refer specifically to the portion of the spirit realm where Jehovah actually resides, his "dwelling place. " (1 Kings 8:​43, 49; Hebrews 9:​24; Revelation 13:6) For example, the Bible foretold that Satan and the demons would be thrown out of heaven, no longer being allowed to enter Jehovah’s presence.
Gake woakpɔtɔ anɔ gbɔgbɔmenutowo me.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7-9, 12.
However, they would remain in the spirit realm.​ Revelation 12:​7-9, 12.
Enye kpɔɖeŋu na ɖoƒe kɔkɔ.
A symbol of a high or exalted position.
Ŋɔŋlɔawo zãa "dziƒo " wònyea kpɔɖeŋu na ɖoƒe kɔkɔ, eye zi geɖe la, edoa ƒome kple dziɖuŋusẽ.
The Scriptures use "heaven " to represent an elevated position, usually in connection with ruling authority.
Woate ŋu azã ɖoƒe sia na:
Such a position could be occupied by:
Yehowa Mawu ŋutɔ, si nye Dziɖulagã ŋusẽkatãtɔ la.​ 2 Kronika 32:20; Luka 15:21.
Jehovah God himself as the almighty Sovereign.​ 2 Chronicles 32:20; Luke 15:21.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la, dziɖuɖu si axɔ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo teƒe.
God’s Kingdom, the government that will replace human rule.
Biblia yɔ Fiaɖuƒe ma be "dziƒo yeye. "​ Yesaya 65:17; 66:22; 2 Petro 3:13.
The Bible refers to that Kingdom as the "new heavens. "​ Isaiah 65:17; 66:22; 2 Peter 3:​13.
Kristotɔ siwo si dziƒo yiyi ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔ le, esime wokpɔtɔ le anyigba dzi.​ Efesotɔwo 2:6.
Christians who, while on earth, have the hope of going to heaven.​ Ephesians 2:6.
Amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖula siwo kɔ wo ɖokuiwo ɖe dzi wu wo teviwo.​ Yesaya 14:12-14; Daniel 4:​20-​22; 2 Petro 3:7.
Human governments that have exalted themselves over their subjects.​ Isaiah 14:12-​14; Daniel 4:​20-​22; 2 Peter 3:7.
Gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃ siwo le xexea dzi ɖum fifia.​ Efesotɔwo 6:12; 1 Yohanes 5:19.
Wicked spirits who now rule over the world.​ Ephesians 6:​12; 1 John 5:​19.
Aleke dziƒo le?
What is heaven like?
Nu geɖe yia edzi le dziƒo.
The spirit realm is a hive of activity.
Yehowa ƒe gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ akpe alafa geɖe "siwo wɔa eƒe nya dzi " la le afi ma.​ Psalmo 103:20, 21; Daniel 7:10.
It is occupied by hundreds of millions of spirit creatures "who carry out [Jehovah’s] word. "​ Psalm 103:20, 21; Daniel 7:​10.
Biblia ɖɔ dziƒo be enye teƒe si kekeli geɖe le.
The Bible describes heaven as being brilliantly lighted.
(1 Timoteo 6:15, 16) Nyagblɔɖila Ezekiel kpɔ ŋutega aɖe si ku ɖe dziƒo ŋu, si me "keklẽ " manyagblɔ aɖe nɔ; Daniel hã kpɔ ŋutega bubu si ku ɖe dziƒo ŋu, si me wòkpɔ "dzotɔsisi " aɖe le.
(1 Timothy 6:​15, 16) The prophet Ezekiel received a heavenly vision marked by "brilliant light, " while the vision of heaven that Daniel saw included "a stream of fire. "
(Ezekiel 1:26-28; Daniel 7:9, 10) Dziƒo le dzadzɛ alo le kɔkɔe, eye wònya kpɔ ŋutɔ.​ Psalmo 96:6; Yesaya 63:15; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:2, 3.
(Ezekiel 1:​26-​28; Daniel 7:​9, 10) Heaven is holy, or clean, and beautiful.​ Psalm 96:6; Isaiah 63:15; Revelation 4:​2, 3.
Nya siwo Biblia gblɔ tso dziƒo ŋu la wɔ nuku ale gbegbe.
The overall impression that the Bible gives of heaven is awe-inspiring.
(Ezekiel 43:​2, 3) Gake manya wɔ na amegbetɔwo be woase dziƒo ŋu nyawo gɔme bliboe o, elabena nu siwo le gbɔgbɔmenutowo me gɔmesese gbɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe susu ŋu.
(Ezekiel 43:​2, 3) Nevertheless, it is not possible for humans to comprehend heaven fully, since the spirit realm is beyond our senses.
Ame Kawoe Ayi Dziƒo?
Who Go to Heaven?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
he Bible’s answer
Mawu tia Kristotɔ wɔnuteƒewo ƒe xexlẽme sue aɖe, siwo woafɔ ɖe tsitre woava nɔ agbe le dziƒo le woƒe ku megbe.
God selects a limited number of faithful Christians who, after their death, will be resurrected to life in heaven.

(1 Petro 1:3, 4) Ne wotia wo la, ele be woayi edzi alé xɔse sesẽ me ɖe asi eye woanɔ agbe dzadzɛ si dze Kristotɔ be woakpɔtɔ adze na domenyinu si le wo si le dziƒo la.​ Efesotɔwo 5:5; Filipitɔwo 3:12-14.

(1 Peter 1:​3, 4) Once they have been chosen, they must continue to maintain a Christian standard of faith and conduct in order not to be disqualified from receiving their heavenly inheritance.​ Ephesians 5:5; Philippians 3:​12-​14.
Nu kae ame siwo ayi dziƒo la ava wɔ?
What will those who go to heaven do there?
Woanye fiawo kple nunɔlawo aɖu dzi kple Yesu ƒe 1,000.
They will serve alongside Jesus as kings and priests for 1,000 years.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 5:9, 10; 20:6) Woanye "dziƒo yeye " alo dziƒo dziɖuɖu si aɖu "anyigba yeye " alo amegbetɔƒomea dzi.
(Revelation 5:​9, 10; 20:6) They will form the "new heavens, " or heavenly government, that will rule over the "new earth, " or earthly society.
Dziƒodziɖula siawo akpe asi ɖe eŋu woagbugbɔ ameƒomea aɖo dzɔdzɔenyenye ƒe nɔnɔme si Mawu ɖo le gɔmedzedzea me la te.​ Yesaya 65:17; 2 Petro 3:13.
Those heavenly rulers will help restore mankind to the righteous conditions that God originally intended.​ Isaiah 65:17; 2 Peter 3:​13.
Ame nenie woafɔ ɖe tsitre woayi dziƒo?
How many will be resurrected to heaven?
Biblia ɖee fia be ame 144,000 ye woafɔ ɖe tsitre woava nɔ agbe le dziƒo.
The Bible indicates that 144,000 people will be resurrected to heavenly life.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 7:4) Le ŋutega aɖe si apostolo Yohanes kpɔ, si woŋlɔ ɖe Nyaɖeɖefia 14:1-3 me la, ekpɔ "Alẽvi la le tsitre ɖe Zion To la dzi, eye ame akpe alafa ɖeka blaene vɔ ene . . . le eŋu. "
(Revelation 7:4) In the vision recorded at Revelation 14:​1-3, the apostle John saw "the Lamb standing on Mount Zion, and with him 144,000. "
Le ŋutega sia me la, "Alẽvi la " le tsi tre ɖi na Yesu si wofɔ ɖe tsi tre.
In this vision, "the Lamb " represents the resurrected Jesus.
(Yohanes 1:29; 1 Petro 1:19) "Zion To " la tsi tsitre ɖi na ɖoƒe kɔkɔ si Yesu kple ame 144,000 siwo aɖu dzi kplii la le le dziƒo.​ Psalmo 2:6; Hebritɔwo 12:22.
(John 1:​29; 1 Peter 1:​19) "Mount Zion " represents the exalted position of Jesus and the 144,000 who rule with him in the heavens.​ Psalm 2:6; Hebrews 12:22.
‘Ame yɔyɔ kple ame tiatia’ siwo aɖu fia kple Kristo le Fiaɖuƒea me ye woyɔ be "alẽha sue " la.
Those "who are called and chosen " to rule with Christ in the Kingdom are referred to as a "little flock. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:14; Luka 12:32) Esia fia be woanye ameha sue aɖe ŋutɔ ne wotsɔ wo sɔ kple alẽ ƒe agbɔsɔsɔme si le Yesu si.​ Yohanes 10:16.
(Revelation 17:14; Luke 12:32) This shows that they would be relatively few in comparison with the complete number of Jesus’ sheep.​ John 10:16.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe ame siwo ayi dziƒo ŋu
Misconceptions about those who go to heaven
Susu totro: Ame nyuiwo katã ayi dziƒo.
Misconception: All good people go to heaven.
Nyateƒenya: Mawu do ŋugbe be ame nyui akpa gãtɔ anɔ agbe tegbee le anyigba dzi.​ Psalmo 37:11, 29, 34.
Fact: God promises everlasting life on earth for most good people.​ Psalm 37:11, 29, 34.
Yesu gblɔ be: "Ame aɖeke melia yi dziƒo o. "
Jesus said: "No man has ascended into heaven. "
(Yohanes 3:13) Eƒe nyaa fia be ame nyui siwo nɔ agbe do ŋgɔ na eya amea abe Abraham, Mose, Hiob, kple David ene meyi dziƒo esime woku o.
(John 3:​13) He thus showed that good people who died before him, such as Abraham, Moses, Job, and David, did not go to heaven.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:29, 34) Ke boŋ mɔkpɔkpɔ nɔ wo si be woava fɔ yewo ɖe tsitre ne yewoanɔ agbe le anyigba la dzi.​ Hiob 14:13-15.
(Acts 2:​29, 34) Instead, they had the hope of being resurrected to life on earth.​ Job 14:13-​15.
Woyɔ tsitretsitsi yi dziƒo la be "tsitretsitsi gbãtɔ. "
The resurrection to heavenly life is called "the first resurrection. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:6) Esia ɖee fia be tsitretsitsi bubu aɖe gali.
