(Revelation 20:6) This indicates that there will be another resurrection.
Anye anyigba dzi ƒe tsitretsitsia.
It will be an earthly one.
Biblia fia nu be le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe dziɖuɖu te la, "ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o. "
The Bible teaches that under the rule of God’s Kingdom, "death will be no more. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4) Anyigbaa ŋue nya sia ku ɖo elabena ku mele dziƒo o.
(Revelation 21:​3, 4) This promise must apply to the earth, since death has never existed in heaven.
Susu totro: Ame sia ame ŋutɔe tianae nenye be anɔ agbe le dziƒo loo alo anyigba dzi.
Misconception: Each person chooses whether he or she will receive life in heaven or on earth.
Nyateƒenya: Mawu ye tiaa Kristotɔ wɔnuteƒe siwo axɔ "dziƒo ƒe fetu, " si nye agbenɔnɔ le dziƒo ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔ la.
Fact: God determines which faithful Christians receive "the prize of the upward call, " that is, the hope of heavenly life.
(Filipitɔwo 3:14) Eya ta menye ame ŋutɔ ƒe didi alo nɔƒe gã didi ƒe nya aɖeke dzie woanɔ te ɖo atia amewo o.​ Mateo 20:20-​23.
(Philippians 3:​14) Personal desire or ambition has no bearing on a person’s being chosen.​ Matthew 20:20-​23.
Susu totro: Agbe mavɔ nɔnɔ le anyigba dzi ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔa mede ŋgɔ o, ame siwo medze na dziƒo yiyi o lae axɔ esia.
Misconception: The hope of everlasting life on earth is an inferior one, offered only to those not worthy of going to heaven.
Nyateƒenya: Mawu yɔa ame siwo anɔ agbe tegbee le anyigbaa dzi be "nye amewo, " "nye ame tiatiawo " kple "Yehowa ƒe ame yayrawo. "
Fact: God calls those who will receive everlasting life on earth "my people, " "my chosen ones, " and "those blessed by Jehovah. "

(Yesaya 65:21-23) Mɔnukpɔkpɔ asu wo si woana tame si Mawu ɖo ɖe amegbetɔwo ŋu tso gɔmedzedzea me, si nye be woanɔ agbe tegbee le paradisonyigbaa dzi la nava eme.​ 1 Mose 1:28; Psalmo 115:16; Yesaya 45:18.
(Isaiah 65:21-​23) They will have the privilege of fulfilling God’s original purpose for humankind​ everlasting life in perfection on a paradise earth.​ Genesis 1:​28; Psalm 115:16; Isaiah 45:18.
Susu totro: Dzesi koe 144,000 si woyɔ le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me la nye, menye xexlẽme ŋutɔŋutɔe o.
Misconception: The number 144,000 mentioned in Revelation is symbolic, not literal.
Nyateƒenya: Togbɔ be xexlẽme siwo nye kpɔɖeŋuwo le Nyaɖeɖefia ƒe agbalẽa me hã la, xexlẽme aɖewo nye xexlẽme ŋutɔŋutɔwo.
Fact: Although Revelation contains symbolic numbers, some of the numbers it uses are literal.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, eƒo nu tso "Alẽvi la ƒe apostolo wuieveawo ƒe ŋkɔ wuieveawo " ŋu.
For example, it speaks of "the 12 names of the 12 apostles of the Lamb. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:14) Kpɔ kpeɖodzi siwo tae míate ŋu aƒo nya ta be xexlẽme ŋutɔŋutɔe 144,000 hã nye la ɖa.
(Revelation 21:14) Consider the evidence for concluding that the number 144,000 should likewise be taken literally.
Nyaɖeɖefia 7:4 gblɔ be, "ame siwo nu wotre [alo ame siwo wotia be woanɔ agbe le dziƒo] la ƒe xexlẽme, wotre ame akpe alafa ɖeka blaene vɔ ene nu. "
Revelation 7:4 records "the number of those who were sealed [or, confirmed for life in heaven], 144,000. "
Esi wogblɔ nya siawo vɔ teti koe wogaƒo nu tso ame hatsotso evelia aɖe hã ŋu be, "ameha gã aɖe si ame aɖeke mete ŋu xlẽ o. "
In the immediate context of this verse, a second group is contrasted: "a great crowd, which no man was able to number. "
"Ameha gã " la me tɔwo hã akpɔ ɖeɖe tso Mawu gbɔ.
Those of the "great crowd " also receive salvation from God.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 7:9, 10) Nenye be kpɔɖeŋudzesi koe 144,000, si nye ame hatsotso aɖe si ŋu xexlẽme mele o nye la, ke vovototo si le ame hatsotso eveawo dome la madze nyuie o.
(Revelation 7:​9, 10) If the number 144,000 were symbolic, referring instead to a group without number, then the contrast between the two groups would be lost.
Azɔ hã, wogblɔ tso ame 144,000-awo ŋu be ‘woƒle wo tso amegbetɔwo dome be woanye kutsetse gbãtɔ.’
In addition, the 144,000 are described as being "bought from among mankind as firstfruits. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 14:4) Nyagbɔgblɔ "kutsetse gbãtɔ " fia ametiatia sue aɖe.
(Revelation 14:4) The expression "firstfruits " refers to a small representative selection.
Esia ɖɔ ame siwo aɖu dzi kple Kristo ɖe wo tevi gbogbo siwo xexlẽme meli na o la dzi le anyigbaa dzi la nyuie.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 5:10.
It aptly describes those who will rule in heaven with Christ over an undetermined number of subjects on earth.​ Revelation 5:​10.
Ðe Nɔƒe Aɖe Koŋ Le Mawu Sia?
Does God Live in a Specific Location?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Nɔƒe aɖe koŋ le Mawu si, eyae nye dziƒowo.
God lives in a specific place the heavens.
Ðe ŋugble tso Biblia me nuŋlɔɖi siawo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider these Bible passages:
Salomo gblɔ le gbedodoɖa me be: "Nàsee le nɔwòƒe le dziƒo. " 1 Fiawo 8:43.
In a prayer, King Solomon said: "May you yourself listen from the heavens, your established place of dwelling. " 1 Kings 8:43.
Yesu fia eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be woado gbe ɖa na wo "Fofo si le dziƒowo. "
Jesus Christ taught his disciples to address their prayers to their "Father in the heavens. "
Mateo 6:9.
Matthew 6:9.
Esi wofɔ Yesu ɖe tsitre la, "dziƒo ŋutɔŋutɔ wòge ɖo, bene wòado ɖe Mawu ŋutɔ ŋkume. "
After Jesus was resurrected, he entered "into heaven itself, now to appear before the person of God. "
Hebritɔwo 9:24.
Hebrews 9:24.
Mawunyakpukpui siawo ɖee fia be ame ŋutɔŋutɔe Yehowa Mawu nye eye be mele afi sia afi o, ke boŋ dziƒo koe nye enɔƒe.
Those verses clearly indicate that Jehovah God is a real person and that he dwells, not everywhere, but only in heaven.
Ðe Abosam Li Ŋutɔŋutɔa?
Is the Devil Real?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ɛ̃, Abosam li ŋutɔŋutɔ.
Yes, the Devil is real.
Eyae nye "xexea dzi ɖula, " si nye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ si va zu gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃ɖi hedze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu.
He is "the ruler of the world, " a spirit creature who became wicked and rebelled against God.
(Yohanes 14:30; Efesotɔwo 6:11, 12) Biblia yɔ ŋkɔ siwo gbɔna tsɔ ɖɔ Abosam ƒe amenyenye:
(John 14:30; Ephesians 6:11, 12) The Bible reveals the Devil’s personality through these names and descriptions:
Satana, si gɔmee nye "Tsitretsiɖeŋula. "​ Hiob 1:6.
Satan, which means "Resister. " Job 1:6. Devil, which means "Slanderer. "
Abosam, si gɔmee nye "Amegɔmezɔla. "​ Nyaɖeɖefia 12:9.
Revelation 12:9.
Da la, si Biblia zã wòfia "Ameblela. "​ 2 Korintotɔwo 11:3.
Serpent, which is used in the Bible to mean "Deceiver. " 2 Corinthians 11:3.
Tela.​ Mateo 4:3.
Tempter. Matthew 4:3.
Aʋatsokala.​ Yohanes 8:44.
Liar. John 8:44.
Menye vɔ̃ɖivɔ̃ɖi ƒe nɔnɔme aɖee wònye o
Not a principle or quality of evil
Ame aɖewo susunɛ be Satana Abosam nye vɔ̃ɖivɔ̃ɖi ƒe nɔnɔme aɖe si le mía me.
Some view Satan the Devil as just a principle or quality of evil that exists inside us.
Ke hã, Biblia ƒo nu tso dzeɖoɖo aɖe si yi edzi le Mawu kple Satana dome la ŋu.
However, the Bible records a conversation between God and Satan.
Esi Mawu de blibo ta la, mate ŋu adzɔ be wòanɔ dze ɖom kple nu vɔ̃ɖi aɖe si nɔ eya ŋutɔ me o.
God is perfect, so he could not have been talking to an evil part of himself.
(5 Mose 32:4; Hiob 2:1-6) Abosam te Yesu hã kpɔ togbɔ be nu vɔ̃ menɔ eŋu o hã.
(Deuteronomy 32:4; Job 2:1-6) Likewise, Satan tempted Jesus, who is free of sin.
(Mateo 4:8-10; 1 Yohanes 3:5) Eya ta Biblia fia mí be Abosam li ŋutɔŋutɔ ke menye vɔ̃ɖivɔ̃ɖi ƒe nɔnɔme aɖe si le mía me ye wònye o.
(Matthew 4:8-10; 1 John 3:5) Thus, the Bible shows that the Devil is real and not merely a personification of evil.
Ðe wòle be wòawɔ nuku na mí be ame geɖe mexɔe se be Abosam li ŋutɔŋutɔ oa?
Should we be surprised that many people don’t believe that the Devil is real?
Kura o, elabe Biblia gblɔ be Satana toa amebeble dzi ɖoa eƒe taɖodzinuwo gbɔ.
Not at all, for the Bible says that Satan uses deception to accomplish his aims.
(2 Tesalonikatɔwo 2:9, 10) Eƒe ayemɔ gãtɔwo dometɔ ɖekae nye be yeaflu amewo woaxɔe ase be yemeli ŋutɔŋutɔ o.​ 2 Korintotɔwo 4:4.
(2 Thessalonians 2:9, 10) One of his greatest tricks has been to blind many people to his existence. 2 Corinthians 4:4.
Susu totro bubu siwo le amewo si ku ɖe Abosam ŋu
More misconceptions about the Devil
Susu Totro: Abosam ƒe ŋkɔ bubue nye Lucifer.
Myth: Lucifer is another name for the Devil.
Nyateƒea: Woɖea Hebrigbe me nya si gɔme woɖe le Biblia aɖewo me be "Lucifer " gɔme be "ame si le keklẽm. "
Fact: The Hebrew word that in some Bibles is translated "Lucifer " means "shining one. "
(Yesaya 14:12) Nu si ŋu wonɔ nu ƒom tsoe hafi yɔ ŋkɔ sia ɖee fia be Babilontɔwo ƒe fiaƒome si Mawu abɔbɔ ɖe anyi le esi wòdo eɖokui ɖe dzi ta la ŋue nya sia ku ɖo.
(Isaiah 14:12) The context shows that this term refers to the dynasty, or line of kings, of Babylon, which God would humiliate for its arrogance.
(Yesaya 14:4, 13-20) Eya ta nyagbɔgblɔ "ame si le keklẽm " la nye alɔmeɖenya si wogblɔ ɖe Babilon fiaƒomea ŋu esi wòmu vɔ megbe.
(Isaiah 14:4, 13-20) The expression "shining one " was used to mock the Babylonian dynasty after it was overthrown.
Susu Totro: Satana wɔa dɔ na Mawu abe amewo ƒe "ʋɔnudrɔ̃la " ene.
Myth: Satan works for God as a "prosecuting attorney. "
Nyateƒea: Mawu ƒe futɔe Abosam nye, ke menye esubɔla o.
Fact: The Devil is God’s enemy, not his servant.
Satana Abosam tsia tsitre ɖe ame siwo subɔa Mawu ŋu eye wòtsoa wo nu alakpatɔe.​ 1 Petro 5:8; Nyaɖeɖefia 12:10.
Satan the Devil opposes and falsely accuses people who serve God.​ 1 Peter 5:8; Revelation 12:10.
Mawue Wɔ Abosam La?
Did God Create the Devil?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia na eme kɔ ƒãa be Mawu mewɔ Abosam o.
The Bible shows that God did not create the Devil.
Ke boŋ ewɔ ame aɖe si va zu Abosam emegbe.
Instead, He created the person who became the Devil.
Biblia gblɔ tso Mawu ŋu be: "Eƒe nuwɔwɔ de blibo; elabena eƒe mɔwo katã dzɔ.
Regarding God, the Bible says: "Perfect is his activity, for all his ways are justice.

Mawu nyateƒetɔ wònye, eye alakpa mele eme o, nuteƒewɔla kple dzɔdzɔetɔ wònye. " (5 Mose 32:3-5) Nya mawo na wòdze kɔtɛe be ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, Satana de blibo, eye wònye ame dzɔdzɔe, eye wònye mawudɔlawo dometɔ ɖeka.

A God of faithfulness, with whom there is no injustice; righteous and upright is he. " (Deuteronomy 32:3-5) From that statement, we can conclude that Satan the Devil was at one time perfect and righteous, namely, one of God’s angelic sons.
Le Yohanes 8:44 la, Yesu gblɔ be Abosam "meli ke ɖe nyateƒe la me o, " si fia be tsã la, Satana nye anukwareɖila kple ame maɖifɔ.
At John 8:44, Jesus said that the Devil "did not stand fast in the truth, " implying that Satan had at one time been truthful and guiltless.
Gake abe ale si ko wòle le Yehowa ƒe nuwɔwɔ bubu siwo si nunya le gome ene la, ablɔɖe le mawudɔla si va zu Satana la hã si be wòatiae be yeawɔ nyui alo vɔ̃.
However, like the rest of Jehovah’s intelligent creatures, the angel who became Satan had the freedom to choose between right and wrong.
Esi wòtiae be yeatsi tre ɖe Mawu ŋu, eye wòna atsu kple asi gbãtɔ wɔ ɖeka kplii ta la, ewɔ eɖokui Satana, si gɔmee nye "Tsitretsiɖeŋula. " 1 Mose 3:1-5; Nyaɖeɖefia 12:9.
By choosing a course in opposition to God and inciting the first human couple to join him, he made himself Satan, which means "Resister. " Genesis 3:1-5; Revelation 12:9.
Afi Kae Abosam Le?
Where Does the Devil Live?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Gake menye dzo mavɔ mee teƒe sia nye o.
As a spirit creature, the Devil lives in an invisible realm.
Menye teƒe aɖe si wònɔa funyafunya wɔm ame vɔ̃ɖiwo le abe ale si wòdze le nɔnɔmetata si le nyati sia me la me ene o.
However, this is not in a fiery hell where he makes the wicked suffer, as is depicted in the artwork accompanying this article.
"Aʋa dzɔ le dziƒo "
"War in heaven "
Ɣeaɖeɣi la, Satana Abosam tea ŋu yia afi sia afi si dzroe le gbɔgbɔmexexea me faa, eye etea ŋu nɔa mawudɔla wɔnuteƒewo dome woyina ɖe keke Mawu ŋkume ke gɔ̃ hã.
For a time, Satan the Devil moved about in the spirit realm at will, including entering directly before God alongside the faithful angels.
(Hiob 1:6) Gake Biblia gblɔe ɖi be aʋa adzɔ "le dziƒo " eye woatsɔ Satana aƒu "gbe ɖe anyigba " dzi.
(Job 1:6) But the Bible foretold that there would be a "war in heaven " that would result in Satan’s being expelled from heaven and "cast out into the earth. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7-9) Biblia ƒe ɣeyiɣikɔntabubu kple xexemenudzɔdzɔwo siaa ɖo kpe edzi be wowɔ aʋa sia vɔ.
(Revelation 12:7-9, King James Version) Both Bible chronology and world events confirm that this war in heaven has already taken place.
Fifia Abosam va tsi anyigba ƒe nutowo me.
The Devil is now confined to the vicinity of the earth.
Ðe esia fia be Abosam ƒe nɔƒe le míaƒe anyigba ƒe teƒe aɖe koŋua?
Does this mean that the Devil lives in a specific place on our planet?
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, wogblɔ tso blemadu Pergamo ŋu be enye "afi si Satana ƒe fiazikpui le " kple "afi si Satana le. "
For example, the ancient city of Pergamum was said to be "where the throne of Satan is " and "where Satan is dwelling. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 2:13) Anɔ eme godoo be nu si koŋ nya siawo fiae nye ale si trɔ̃subɔsubɔ xɔ aƒe ɖe du ma me blibaa.
(Revelation 2:13) Actually, these expressions likely refer to the concentration of satanic worship in that city.

Biblia gblɔ be Abosam le "anyigba dzi nɔlawo ƒe fiaɖuƒewo katã " dzi ɖum, eya ta menɔa anyigba ƒe teƒe aɖe si woate ŋu akpɔ kple ŋku o, ke boŋ ele anyigba ƒe nutowo me eye woxe mɔ ɖe enu be nuto ma me ko wòanɔ.​ Luka 4:​5, 6.

The Bible says that the Devil rules over "all the kingdoms of the inhabited earth, " so he does not dwell in any one physical location on earth but is confined to the vicinity of the earth.​ Luke 4:​5, 6.
Ðe Abosam Ate Ŋu Akpɔ Ŋuse Ðe Amegbetɔwo Dzia?
Can the Devil Control Humans?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Abosam kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe amegbetɔwo dzi ale gbegbe be Biblia gblɔ be: "Xexe blibo la katã le vɔ̃ɖitɔ la ƒe ŋusẽ te. " (1 Yohanes 5:19) Biblia ƒo nu tso mɔ siwo dzi Abosam tona kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi la ŋu.

The Devil and the demons influence mankind so much that the Bible says: “The Evil One controls the whole world.” (1 John 5:​19, New Century Version) The Bible identifies ways that the Devil exerts this influence on people.
Beble.
Deception.
Biblia de dzi ƒo na Kristotɔwo be woanɔ "te sesĩe ɖe Abosam ƒe aɖaŋu vɔ̃wo nu. "
The Bible encourages Christians to “fight against the devil’s evil tricks.”
(Efesotɔwo 6:11) Eƒe ayemɔwo dometɔ ɖekae nye be yeana amewo naxɔe ase be Mawu ƒe subɔlawoe yeƒe dɔlawo nye. 2 Korintotɔwo 11:13-15.
(Ephesians 6:​11, NCV ) One of his tricks is to deceive people into believing that his agents are actually servants of God.​—2 Corinthians 11:13-​15.
Gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ.
Spiritism.
Abosam toa gbɔgbɔyɔlawo, abe ŋɔliyɔlawo, afakalawo alo ɣletivimefakalawo ene dzi flua amewo.
The Devil misleads people through spirit mediums, fortune-tellers, and those who practice divination or astrology.
(5 Mose 18:10-12) Atike vɔ̃ɖi zazã, goloɖoɖo kple ŋugblemeyiyi ʋĩ si me woɖea nu sia nu ɖa le susu me keŋkeŋ hã nana gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe amewo dzi.
(Deuteronomy 18:10-​12) Drug use, hypnotism, and meditation techniques that empty the mind also expose a person to demon control.​—Luke 11:24-​26.
False religion.
Alakpasubɔsubɔha. Subɔsubɔha siwo fiaa alakpanuwo la flua amewo wogbea toɖoɖo Mawu.
Religions that teach false doctrines mislead people into disobeying God.
(1 Korintotɔwo 10:20) Biblia yɔ alakpadzixɔse mawo be "gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ƒe nufiafiawo. " 1 Timoteo 4:1.
(1 Corinthians 10:20) The Bible calls such false beliefs “teachings of demons.”​—1 Timothy 4:1.
Gbɔgbɔdzeamedzi.
Possession.
Biblia ƒo nu tso ame siwo dzi gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃ɖiwo kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖo la ŋu.
The Bible records cases of evil spirits taking control of individuals.
Ame siwo dzi gbɔgbɔawo dze la dometɔ aɖewo ƒe ŋku gbã alo wozu mumuwo eye ɖewo hã wɔ nu vevi wo ɖokuiwo. Mateo 12:22; Marko 5:2-5.
Sometimes demon-possessed people were struck blind or mute or even injured themselves.​—Matthew 12:22; Mark 5:​2-5.
Nu si nàwɔ be Abosam nagakpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe dziwò o
How to avoid the Devil’s influence
Mele be nàvɔ̃ na gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ƒe ŋusẽkpɔɖeamedzi o, elabena Biblia fia nu si míawɔ atsɔ atsi tre ɖe Abosam ŋu la mí:
You need not live in dread of demon control, for the Bible shows how you can successfully oppose the Devil:
Dze agbagba nàde dzesi Abosam ƒe ayemɔwo ale be eƒe ‘nugbeɖoɖowo naganɔ manyamanya me na wò o.’ 2 Korintotɔwo 2:11.
Learn to recognize the Devil’s methods so that you are “not ignorant of his designs.”​—2 Corinthians 2:​11.
Na Biblia me sidzedze nasu asiwò eye nàwɔ ɖe nu siwo nèsrɔ̃ la dzi.
Take in knowledge from the Bible, and then apply what you learn.
Ne ètsɔ Biblia me mɔfiamewo wɔ dɔe la, akpɔ tawò be Abosam makpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe dziwò o. Efesotɔwo 6:11-18.
Applying Bible principles will protect you from the Devil’s influence.​—Ephesians 6:​11-​18.
Gblẽ nu siwo katã do ka kple gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo la do me.
Get rid of anything connected with demon activity.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 19:19) Esia dometɔ aɖewoe nye hadzidzi, agbalẽ, magazine, boblodogbalẽ kple video siwo katã doa gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ ɖe ŋgɔ.
(Acts 19:19) That includes music, books, magazines, posters, and videos that encourage spiritism.
Abosam Gbɔe Fukpekpewo Katã Tsona?
Is the Devil the Cause of All Suffering?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer

Mawu ƒe Nya, Biblia, ɖee fia be Satana li vavã, eye abe ale si nu vlo wɔlawo ƒe tatɔ sẽŋuwo wɔa nui ene la, eya hã toa "amebeble ƒe dzesiwo " kple "madzɔmadzɔnyenye ƒe beble " ƒe mɔnuwo dzi be yeana yeƒe tameɖoɖowo nava eme.

The Bible reveals that Satan the Devil is a real person who, like a powerful criminal kingpin, sees to it that his will is accomplished through "lying signs " and "deception. " In fact, he "keeps transforming himself into an angel of light, " says the Bible.
Le nyateƒe me la, Biblia gblɔ be etrɔa "eɖokui wɔa kekeli ƒe dɔla. " (2 Tesalonikatɔwo 2:9, 10; 2 Korintotɔwo 11:14) Nenema kee nu vɔ̃ɖi siwo Abosam wɔna la ɖoa kpe edzi be eli.
(2 Thessalonians 2:9, 10; 2 Corinthians 11:14) The Devil’s existence can be perceived by the damage he causes.
Ke hã menye Abosam gbɔe míaƒe fukpekpewo katã tsona o.
However, the Devil is not responsible for all suffering.
Aleke wɔ?
Why not?
Mawu wɔ amegbetɔwo hena ŋutete wo be woate ŋu atiae be yewoawɔ nyui alo vɔ̃.
God created humans with the capacity to choose between doing good and doing bad.
(Yosua 24:15) Ne míewɔ tiatia gbegblẽwo la, fukpekpee dona tso eme na mí.
(Joshua 24:15) When we make poor choices, we reap bad consequences.
Galatiatɔwo 6:7, 8.
Galatians 6:7, 8.
Ðe Gbɔgbɔ Vɔ̃wo Li Ŋutɔŋutɔa?
Are Demons Real?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Yes.
Gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo nye "mawudɔla siwo wɔ nu vɔ̃, " wonye gbɔgbɔmenuwɔwɔ siwo dze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu.
Demons are "angels that sinned, " spirit creatures who rebelled against God.
(2 Petro 2:4) Mawudɔla gbãtɔ si wɔ eɖokui gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃e nye Satana Abosam, ame si Biblia yɔ be "gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ƒe fia. "​ Mateo 12:24, 26.
(2 Peter 2:4) The first angel to make himself into a demon was Satan the Devil, whom the Bible calls "the ruler of the demons. " Matthew 12:24, 26.
Aglãdzedze le Noa ƒe ŋkekea me
Rebellion in Noah’s day
Biblia ƒo nu tso mawudɔlawo ƒe aglãdzedze do ŋgɔ na Noa ƒe ŋkekea me Tsiɖɔɖɔa ŋu be: "Mawu vavã la ƒe viwo kpɔ be amegbetɔwo ƒe vinyɔnuwo dze tugbe ŋutɔ.

The Bible records a rebellion by angels before the Flood of Noah’s day: "The sons of the true God began to notice the daughters of men, that they were good-looking; and they went taking wives for themselves, namely, all whom they chose. "

Ale woɖe wo dometɔ siwo katã dze wo ŋu. " (1 Mose 6:2) Mawudɔla vɔ̃ɖi mawo ‘gblẽ woawo ŋutɔwo ƒe nɔƒe ɖi’ le dziƒo eye wodo amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutilã va anyigba dzi ale be woate ŋu adɔ kple nyɔnuwo.​ Yuda 6.
(Genesis 6:2) Those wicked, or fallen, angels "forsook their own proper dwelling place " in heaven and materialized human bodies in order to have sex with women.
Esi Tsiɖɔɖɔa dze egɔme la, mawudɔla dzeaglã mawo gblẽ woƒe amegbetɔŋutilã ɖi hetrɔ yi dziƒo.
Jude 6. When the Flood came, the rebellious angels abandoned their human bodies and returned to heaven.
Ke hã, Mawu nya wo ɖa le eƒe ƒomea me.
However, God expelled them from his family.
Woƒe tohehea ƒe akpa aɖee nye be, womagate ŋu ado amegbetɔŋutilã akpɔ gbeɖe o.​ Efesotɔwo 6:11, 12.
As part of their punishment, the demons are prevented from ever again taking on human form. Ephesians 6:11, 12.
Tameɖoɖo Kae Le Agbea Ŋu?
What Is the Meaning of Life?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Nu ka tae míele anyigba dzi afi sia ɖo? alo Ðe tameɖoɖo aɖe le nye agbe ŋua?
The question of the meaning of life may be asked in many ways, such as Why are we here? or Does my life have a purpose?
Biblia ɖee fia be nu si tae míele agbe ɖoe nye be míana xɔlɔ̃kadodo nanɔ mí kple Mawu dome.
The Bible shows that our purpose in life is to build a friendship with God.
Bu nyateƒenya vevi siwo Biblia ɖe ɖe go la dometɔ aɖewo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some of these fundamental truths that the Bible reveals.
Mawue nye mía Wɔla.
God is our Creator.
Biblia gblɔ be: "[Mawue] wɔ mí, eye etɔ míenye. " Psalmo 100:3; Nyaɖeɖefia 4:11.
The Bible says: "It is [God] that has made us, and not we ourselves. "​ Psalm 100:3; Revelation 4:11.
Mawu ɖo ta me ɖe nu sia nu si wòwɔ la ŋu, eye mí amegbetɔwo hã míele eme.
God has a purpose for everything he creates, including us.​ Isaiah 45:18.
Yesaya 45:18. Mawu wɔ mí be didi nanɔ mía me ɖe "gbɔgbɔmenuwo " ŋu, eye esiawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye didi be míanya tameɖoɖo si le míaƒe agbe ŋu.
God created us with a "spiritual need, " which includes the desire to find meaning in life.
(Mateo 5:3) Edi be míaɖi kɔ na didi sia. Psalmo 145:16.
(Matthew 5:3) He wants us to satisfy that desire.​ Psalm 145:16.
Míeɖia kɔ na didi sia ne míena xɔlɔ̃kadodo va le mía kple Mawu dome.
We fill our spiritual need by building a friendship with God.
Togbɔ be gbɔgblɔ be xɔlɔ̃kadodo nanɔ mía kple Mawu dome adze nu si manya wɔ o na ame aɖewo hã la, Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be: "Mite ɖe Mawu ŋu, eye ate ɖe mia ŋu. " Yakobo 4:8; 2:23.
Although the idea of being God’s friend might seem far-fetched to some, the Bible gives us this encouragement: "Draw close to God, and he will draw close to you. "​ James 4:8; 2:23.
Be míanye Mawu xɔlɔ̃ la, ele be míaƒe agbenɔnɔ nawɔ ɖeka kple eƒe tameɖoɖo.
To become God’s friend, we must live in harmony with his purpose for us.
Biblia ƒo nu tso tameɖoɖo sia ŋu le Nyagblɔla 12:13. Egblɔ be: "Vɔ̃ Mawu, eye nalé eƒe seawo me ɖe asi; elabena esia nye amegbetɔwo katã tɔ! " Nyagblɔla 12:13.
The Bible states this purpose at Ecclesiastes 12:13: "Have reverence for God, and obey his commands, because this is all that we were created for. "​ Good News Translation.
Le etsɔme la, ne Mawu ɖe fukpekpe ɖa eye wòna agbe mavɔ exɔlɔ̃wo, siwo nye ame siwo subɔnɛ la, ekema ta me si wòɖo ɖe mía ŋu le gɔmedzedzea me la ava eme bliboe. Psalmo 37:10, 11.
In the future, we can experience in full God’s original purpose for us when he eliminates suffering and grants everlasting life to his friends, those who worship him.​ Psalm 37:10, 11.
Aleke Nàwɔ Anɔ Agbe Tegbee?
How Can You Live Forever?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia do ŋugbe be: "Ame si wɔa Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu la nɔa anyi yi ɖe mavɔmavɔ me. " (1 Yohanes 2:17) Nu kae Mawu di tso asiwò be nàwɔ?
The Bible promises: "The person who does what God wants lives forever. " (1 John 2:​17, Holy Bible​ Easy-to-Read Version) What does God want you to do?
Srɔ̃ nu tso Mawu kple Via Yesu ŋu.
Learn about God and his Son, Jesus.
Yesu do gbe ɖa na Mawu gblɔ be: "Esiae nye agbe mavɔ la bena woanya wò, Mawu vavã ɖeka la, kple Yesu Kristo si nèdɔ ɖa la. "
In prayer to God, Jesus said: "This means everlasting life, their coming to know you, the only true God, and the one whom you sent, Jesus Christ. "
(Yohanes 17:3) Nu kae wòfia be "woanya " Mawu kple Yesu?
(John 17:3) What is involved in "coming to know " God and Jesus?
Míate ŋu anya wo ne míesrɔ̃a Biblia eye míenɔa agbe ɖe emenyawo nu.
We can get to know them by studying the Bible and applying its message in our life.
Biblia ɖe mía Wɔla, Yehowa Mawu, si nye míaƒe Agbenala la ƒe susuwo fia mí.
The Bible reveals the thinking of our Creator, Jehovah God, who is the Giver of life.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 17:24, 25) Biblia gaƒo nu tso Via, Yesu si fia "agbe mavɔ nyawo " amewo la ŋu.
(Acts 17:24, 25) The Bible also tells us about his Son, Jesus, who taught "sayings of everlasting life. "​ John 6:​67-​69.
Yohanes 6:67-69. Xɔ Yesu ƒe tafevɔsa la dzi se.
Exercise faith in the ransom sacrifice of Jesus.
Yesu va anyigba dzi "be yeasubɔ eye yeatsɔ yeƒe agbe ana wòanye tafe. "
Jesus came to earth "to minister and to give his life as a ransom. "
(Mateo 20:28) Yesu ƒe tafevɔsaa ʋu mɔnukpɔkpɔ ɖi na amegbetɔwo be woanɔ agbe tegbee le Paradiso me le anyigba dzi.
(Matthew 20:28) Jesus’ ransom sacrifice opened the way for humans to live forever in Paradise on earth.
(Psalmo 37:29) Yesu gblɔ be: "Mawu lɔ̃ xexea ale gbegbe be wòtsɔ eƒe Tenuvi la na, be ame sia ame si xɔa edzi sena la nagatsrɔ̃ o, ke boŋ wòakpɔ agbe mavɔ. "
(Psalm 37:29) Jesus said: "God loved the world so much that he gave his only-begotten Son, so that everyone exercising faith in him might not be destroyed but have everlasting life. "
(Yohanes 3:16) De dzesii be ebia nu geɖe wu Yesu dzi xɔxɔ se dzro ko.
(John 3:​16) Note that more is required than simply believing in Jesus.
Ele be ‘míaxɔ edzi ase,’ si fia be míatiae be míanɔ agbe wòawɔ ɖeka kple eƒe nufiafiawo kple Fofoa ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu. Mateo 7:21; Yakobo 2:17.
We must ‘exercise faith in him,’ choosing to live in harmony with his teachings and with the will of his Father.​ Matthew 7:​21; James 2:​17.
Tu xɔlɔ̃wɔwɔ sẽŋu ɖo le wò kple Mawu dome.
Build a strong friendship with God.
Mawu di be míate ɖe ye ŋu eye míanye ye xɔlɔ̃wo.
God wants us to draw close to him and become his friend.
(Yakobo 2:23; 4:8) Mawu li tegbee.
(James 2:​23; 4:8) God is eternal.
Maku akpɔ gbeɖe o, eye edi be ye xɔlɔ̃wo hã nanɔ agbe tegbee.
He will never die, and he wants his friends to live forever as well.
Mawu to eƒe Nya dzi gblɔ nyui si wòdina na ame siwo katã dinɛ la be: "Mise vivi le agbe me tegbee. " Psalmo 22:26.
Through his Word, God expresses what he wants for all who seek him: "May you enjoy life forever. "​ Psalm 22:26.
Susu Totro Siwo Le Amewo Si Ku Ðe Agbe Tegbee Nɔnɔ Ŋu
Misconceptions About Living Forever
Susu totro: Amegbetɔwo ƒe agbagbadzedzewo ahe agbe tegbee nɔnɔ vɛ.
Misconception: Human efforts will result in everlasting life.
Nyateƒea: Togbɔ be ŋgɔyiyi siwo wɔm wole le atikewɔnyawo me la dzena abe ɖe woate ŋu adzi amegbetɔwo ƒe agbenɔƒewo ɖe edzi ene hã la, agbagbadzedze mawo mana amewo nanɔ agbe tegbee o.
Fact: Although some medical advances promise to increase the human life span, such efforts will not lead to everlasting life.
Mawu ɖeka koe ate ŋu ana míanɔ agbe tegbee elabe eya gbɔe "agbedzɔƒe le. "
Only God can give us everlasting life, because only he is "the source of life. "
(Psalmo 36:9) Edo ŋugbe be ‘yeami ku tegbee,’ eye yeana agbe mavɔ amegbetɔ wɔnuteƒewo katã. Yesaya 25:8; 1 Yohanes 2:25.
(Psalm 36:9) He promises to "swallow up death forever " and grant everlasting life to all faithful humans.​ Isaiah 25:8; 1 John 2:​25.
Susu totro: Ame ƒomevi aɖewo koe anɔ agbe tegbee.
Misconception: Only people of certain races will live forever.
Nyateƒea: Mawu mekpɔa ame ŋkume o.
Fact: God does not show favoritism.
Ke boŋ "le dukɔ sia dukɔ me la, ame si vɔ̃nɛ eye wòwɔa nu dzɔdzɔe la, eya ƒe nue dzea eŋu. "
On the contrary, "in every nation the man who fears him and does what is right is acceptable to him. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 10:34, 35) Ame siwo tso teƒe vovovowo eye woƒe dekɔnuwo to vovo, siwo ɖoa to Mawu, ate ŋu anɔ agbe tegbee.
(Acts 10:34, 35) People of all ethnic and cultural backgrounds who obey God can live forever.
Susu totro: Agbe tegbee nɔnɔ ati ame.
Misconception: Everlasting life will be boring.
Nyateƒea: Mawu, ame si lɔ̃ mí eye wòdi be míakpɔ dzidzɔ lae na mɔnukpɔkpɔa mí be míava nɔ agbe mavɔ.
Fact: The offer of everlasting life comes from God, who loves us and wants us to be happy.
(Yakobo 1:17; 1 Yohanes 4:8) Enya be hafi míakpɔ dzidzɔ la, míehiã dɔ si ŋu taɖodzinu vavã le.
(James 1:​17; 1 John 4:8) He knows that in order for us to be happy, we need purposeful work.
(Nyagblɔla 3:12) Mawu do ŋugbe be ame siwo anɔ agbe tegbee le anyigba dzi la awɔ dɔ si me dzidzeme vavã le, si aɖe vi na wo kple woƒe ame veviwo. Yesaya 65:22, 23.
(Ecclesiastes 3:​12) God promises that those who live forever on earth will have satisfying, meaningful work that will benefit them and their loved ones.​ Isaiah 65:22, 23.
Gawu la, ame siwo anɔ agbe tegbee la ayi edzi asrɔ̃ nu yeye geɖe tso wo Wɔla la kple eƒe nuwɔwɔ gbogboawo ŋu.
Moreover, those who live forever will continue to learn new things about their Creator and his vast creative works.
Ewɔ amegbetɔwo kple didi be woanɔ agbe tegbee ahasrɔ̃ nu tso ye ŋu, togbɔ be ‘womanya mɔnu le dɔ siwo Mawu vavã la wɔ la ŋu tso gɔmedzedze va se ɖe nuwuwu o’ hã.
He made humans with a desire to live forever and to learn about him, though they "will never find out the work that the true God has made from start to finish. "
(Nyagblɔla 3:10, 11) Eya ta, mɔnukpɔkpɔ asu ame siwo anɔ agbe tegbee la si be woasrɔ̃ nu dodzidzɔname geɖe ahase vivi na wo wɔwɔ.
(Ecclesiastes 3:​10, 11) Thus, those who live forever will always have interesting things to learn and do.
Nu Kae Nye Luʋɔ?
What Is the Soul?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Hebrigbe me nya si nye nephesh kple Helagbe me nya si nye psykhe gɔmee woɖe le Biblia me be "luʋɔ. "
The word "soul " in the Bible is a translation of the Hebrew word nephesh and the Greek word psykhe.
Hebrigbe me nya sia ƒe gɔmeɖeɖe tẽe nye "nuwɔwɔ si gbɔna " eye Helagbe me tɔa hã gɔmee nye "nu gbagbe. "
The Hebrew word literally means "a creature that breathes, " and the Greek word means "a living being. "
Eya ta nu si luʋɔ fiae nye nu gbagbe bliboa, ke menye nane si le nu gbagbea me si yia edzi nɔa agbe ne nu gbagbea ku o.
The soul, then, is the entire creature, not something inside that survives the death of the body.
Kpɔ ale si Biblia ɖee fia be amegbetɔ blibo lae nye luʋɔ la ɖa:
Consider how the Bible shows that the human soul is the whole person:
Adam, nye luʋɔ le esime wowɔe
Adam, a living soul, at the time of his creation
Womede luʋɔ Adam me o​ ɖe wòzu "luʋɔ gbagbe "
Adam was not given a soul​ he "became a living soul "
Esi Yehowa Mawu wɔ Adam si nye amegbetɔ gbãtɔ la, Biblia gblɔ be "ame la zu luʋɔ gbagbe. " (1 Mose 2:7) Womede luʋɔ Adam me o​ ɖe wòzu luʋɔ alo ame gbagbe.
When Jehovah God created the first man, Adam, the Bible says that "man became a living soul. " (Genesis 2:7, King James Version) Adam was not given a soul​ he became a living soul, or person.
Biblia gblɔ be luʋɔ ate ŋu awɔ dɔ, nuɖuɖu ate ŋu adzroe, ate ŋu aɖu nu, ate ŋu awɔ se dzi eye ate ŋu aka asi nu kuku ŋu.
The Bible says that the soul can work, crave food, eat, obey laws, and touch a dead body.
(3 Mose 5:2; 7:20; 23:30; 5 Mose 12:20; Romatɔwo 13:1) Ame bliboae wɔa nu siawo.
(Leviticus 5:2; 7:​20; 23:30; Deuteronomy 12:20; Romans 13:1) Those activities involve the entire person.
Ðe luʋɔ nye nu makumakua?
Is the soul immortal?
Ao, luʋɔ ate ŋu aku.
No, the soul can die.
Mawunyakpukpui geɖewo ɖee fia be luʋɔ kuna.
Dozens of Bible verses refer to the soul as being mortal.
Wo dometɔ aɖewoe nye esiawo:
Here are some examples:
"Luʋɔ, si wɔ nu vɔ̃ la, eyae aku. "​ Ezekiel 18:4, 20, Eʋegbe Biblia.
"The soul that sinneth, it shall die. "​ Ezekiel 18:​4, 20, King James Version.
Le blema Israel la, to si wohena na amewo le nu vɔ̃ gã akpa gãtɔ gomee nye be "wotsrɔ̃a luʋɔ " mawo.
In ancient Israel, the punishment for the most serious offenses was that the "soul shall be cut off. "
(2 Mose 12:15, 19; 3 Mose 7:20, 21, 27; 19:8, King James Version) "Woatsrɔ̃ eƒe agbe ɖa. "​ 2 Mose 31:14, Eʋegbe Biblia.
(Exodus 12:15, 19; Leviticus 7:​20, 21, 27; 19:8, King James Version) The person would "be put to death. "​ Exodus 31:14, King James Version.

Ne amea ku la, woyɔa eƒe ŋutilã kukua le Biblia aɖewo me be "luʋɔ kuku. " (3 Mose 21:11, etenuŋɔŋlɔ; 4 Mose 6:6, etenuŋɔŋlɔ) Togbɔ be Biblia geɖewo zã nya siwo nye "ŋutilã kuku " alo "ame kuku " le kpukpui siawo me hã la, nephesh alo "luʋɔ " ye wozã le kpukpui siawo me le Hebri nuŋlɔɖiawo me.

After a person dies, the literal term "dead soul " is used for the corpse in some Bible verses. (Leviticus 21:11, footnote; Numbers 6:6, footnote) Although many Bible translations use the terms "dead body " or "dead person " in those verses, the original Hebrew uses the word nephesh, or "soul. "
"Luʋɔ " ate ŋu afia "agbe "
"Soul " can mean "life "
Wotea ŋu zãa "luʋɔ " le Biblia me hã wòfiaa "agbe. "
The Bible also uses "soul " as a synonym for "life. "
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, wozã Hebrigbe me nya (nephesh) si gɔme woɖena be "luʋɔ " wòfia "agbe " le Hiob 33:22.
For example, Job 33:22 uses the Hebrew word for "soul " (nephesh) as a parallel for "life. "
Nenema ke Biblia ɖee fia be ame ate ŋu ade eƒe luʋɔ afɔku me alo atsrɔ̃e.​ 2 Mose 4:19; Ʋɔnudrɔ̃lawo 9:17; Filipitɔwo 2:30.
Similarly, the Bible shows that a person’s soul, or life, can be risked or lost.​ Exodus 4:​19; Judges 9:​17; Philippians 2:​30.
Nya "luʋɔ " zazã le gɔmesese sia nu akpe ɖe mía ŋu míase mawunyakpukpui siwo me wogblɔ le be luʋɔ "nɔ dodom " alo nɔ "dzodzom " la gɔme.
This use of the word for "soul " helps us to understand verses in which the soul is said to be "going out " or "departing. "
(1 Mose 35:18; King James Version) Nyagbɔgblɔ sia fia be amea ƒe agbe nu nɔ tsotsom.
(Genesis 35:18; King James Version) This figure of speech indicates that the person’s life is ending.
Woɖe 1 Mose 35:18 me nya sia gɔme le Biblia aɖewo me be "egbɔ zi mamlɛtɔ. "​ Good News Translation; New Jerusalem Bible.
Some translations render this expression at Genesis 35:18 as "she breathed her last. "​ Good News Translation; New Jerusalem Bible.
Afi si luʋɔ makumaku ƒe dzixɔsea dzɔ tso
Where belief in an immortal soul comes from
Helatɔwo ƒe xexemenunya mee Kristotɔwo ƒe subɔsubɔha siwo xɔe se be luʋɔ mekuna o la kpɔ woƒe nufiafia sia tso, menye Biblia mee o.
Christian denominations that believe in an immortal soul get this teaching, not from the Bible, but from ancient Greek philosophy.
Numekugbalẽ aɖe (Encyclopædia Britannica) gblɔ be: "Nu si wowɔnɛ le Biblia me be luʋɔ la do ƒome kple ŋɔtimegbɔgbɔ eye mede vovototo aɖeke luʋɔ makpɔmakpɔ kple ŋutilã si wokpɔna la dome o.
The Encyclopædia Britannica says: "Biblical references to the soul are related to the concept of breath and establish no distinction between the ethereal soul and the corporeal body.
Blema Helatɔwo gbɔe Kristotɔwo ƒe dzixɔse si nye be luʋɔ to vovo na ŋutilã la dzɔ tso. "
Christian concepts of a body-soul dichotomy originated with the ancient Greeks. "
Mawu meda asi ɖe edzi be míatsɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe xexemenunya atsaka yeƒe nufiafiawo o.
God does not condone merging his teachings with human philosophies, such as belief in an immortal soul.
Biblia xlɔ̃ nu mí boŋ be míakpɔ "nyuie be ame aɖeke nagato xexemenunya kple beble dzodzro si wotu ɖe amewo ƒe kɔnyinyiwo dzi aɖe aboyo " mí o.​ Kolosetɔwo 2:8.
Instead, the Bible warns: "Look out that no one takes you captive by means of the philosophy and empty deception according to human tradition. "​ Colossians 2:8.
Ame Kawo Ƒe Ŋkɔwoe Woŋlɔ Ðe "Agbegbalẽ La " Me?
Whose Names Are Written in "the Book of Life "?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ame siwo ava nɔ agbe mavɔ la ƒe ŋkɔwoe nɔa "agbegbalẽ la " si wogayɔna be "agbegbalẽ xatsaxatsa " alo "ŋkuɖodzigbalẽ " la me.
"The book of life, " also called "the scroll of life " or "book of remembrance, " contains the names of people in line to receive the gift of everlasting life.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 3:5; 20:12; Maleaxi 3:16) Mawue tsoa nya me le ame si ƒe ŋkɔ anɔ agbegbalẽa me la ŋu, eye esia nɔa te ɖe ale si amea wɔ nuteƒe na Mawu heɖo toe dzi. Yohanes 3:16; 1 Yohanes 5:3.
(Revelation 3:5; 20:12; Malachi 3:16) God determines those names based on a person’s faithful obedience to him.​ John 3:16; 1 John 5:3.
Mawu léa esubɔla wɔnuteƒe ɖe sia ɖe ɖe susu me abe ɖe wòŋlɔ eƒe ŋkɔ ɖe agbalẽ me ene tso "xexea ƒe gɔmeɖoanyiɣi " ke.
God has kept each of his loyal servants in his memory, as if writing their names down in a book, since "the founding of the world " of mankind.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 17:8) Edze ƒãa be nuteƒewɔla Abel ye nye ame gbãtɔ si ƒe ŋkɔ woŋlɔ ɖe agbegbalẽa me.
(Revelation 17:8) The faithful man Abel was apparently the first one whose name was recorded in the book of life.
(Hebritɔwo 11:4) Menye amewo ƒe ŋkɔwo dzro ko woŋlɔ ɖe afi ma o, elabe agbegbalẽa ɖee fia mí be Yehowa nye Mawu lɔ̃ame si "nya ame siwo nye etɔ " la nyuie. 2 Timoteo 2:19; 1 Yohanes 4:8.
(Hebrews 11:4) It is not just a cold list of names, though, for the book of life shows us that Jehovah is a loving God who "knows those who belong to him. "​ 2 Timothy 2:19; 1 John 4:8.
Ðe woate ŋu atutu ŋkɔ siwo woŋlɔ ɖe "agbegbalẽ la " mea?
Can names be erased from "the book of life "?
Yes.

Mawu gblɔ le tomaɖola siwo nɔ blema Israel la ŋu be: "Ame si wɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe ŋunye la, eya ƒe ŋkɔ matutu ɖa le nye agbalẽ me. " (2 Mose 32:33) Gake ne míeyi edzi wɔ nuteƒe la, míayi edzi anɔ "agbegbalẽ xatsaxatsa " la me.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 20:12.

God said regarding disobedient people in ancient Israel: "Whoever has sinned against me, I shall wipe him out of my book. " (Exodus 32:33) But if we prove faithful, we will remain in "the scroll of life. "​ Revelation 20:12.
Nu Ka Tae Amewo Kuna?
Why Do People Die?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Esɔ le dzɔdzɔme nu be míadi be míanya nu si tae amewo kuna, vevietɔ ne míaƒe ame vevi aɖe ku.
It’s natural to wonder why people die, especially when we lose someone close to us.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Veve si hea ku vanɛ lae nye nu vɔ̃. " 1 Korintotɔwo 15:56.
The Bible says: "The sting producing death is sin. "​ 1 Corinthians 15:56.
Nu ka tae amewo katã wɔa nu vɔ̃ hekuna?
Why do all people sin and die?
Amegbetɔ gbãtɔ siwo nye Adam kple Xawa ku elabe wowɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe Mawu ŋu.
The first humans, Adam and Eve, lost their lives because they sinned against God.
(1 Mose 3:17-19) Ku koe woƒe aglãdzedze ɖe Mawu ŋu ate ŋu ahe vɛ na wo, elabe Mawu gbɔe "agbedzɔƒe le. " Psalmo 36:10; 1 Mose 2:17.
(Genesis 3:17-19) Death was the only possible outcome of their rebellion against God, for with him is "the source of life. "​ Psalm 36:9; Genesis 2:17.
Adam ƒe dzidzimeviwo katã nyi nu vɔ̃ ƒe dome tso egbɔ.
Adam passed on the defect of sin to all his descendants.
Biblia gblɔ be: "To ame ɖeka dzi nu vɔ̃ ge ɖe xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va, eye ale ku la kaka ɖe amewo katã dome, esi wo katã wɔ nu vɔ̃ ŋuti. "
The Bible says: "Through one man sin entered into the world and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men because they had all sinned. "
(Romatɔwo 5:12) Amewo katã kuna elabe wo katã wowɔ nu vɔ̃.​ Romatɔwo 3:23.
(Romans 5:12) All people die because they all sin.​ Romans 3:23.
Mawu do ŋugbe be yeava mi "ku saɖagatsi tegbee. "
How death will be eliminated
(Yesaya 25:8) Hafi wòate ŋu aɖe ku ɖa la, ele be wòaɖe nu vɔ̃ si hea ku vanɛ la ɖa.
God promises a time when "he will actually swallow up death forever. "
Mawu awɔ esia to Yesu Kristo ame si "le xexea ƒe nu vɔ̃ ɖem ɖa " la dzi.
(Isaiah 25:8) To remove death, he must eliminate its root cause, which is sin.
Yohanes 1:29; 1 Yohanes 1:7.
God will do this through Jesus Christ, who "takes away the sin of the world. "​ John 1:29; 1 John 1:7.
Nu Kae Dzɔna Ðe Ame Siwo Ku La Dzi?
What Happens When You Die?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia gblɔ be: "Agbagbeawo nyae be, yewogbɔna kuku ge, ke kukuawo menya naneke o. "
The Bible says: "The living are conscious that they will die; but as for the dead, they are conscious of nothing at all. "
(Nyagblɔla 9:5; Psalmo 146:4) Eya ta ne ame ku la, meganɔa anyi o.
(Ecclesiastes 9:5; Psalm 146:4) Therefore, when we die, we cease to exist.
Kukuawo mebua tame, wɔa nu alo sea nu le lãme o.
The dead can’t think, act, or feel anything.
"Anyi ke nàgatrɔ azu "
"To dust you will return "
Mawu gblɔ nu si adzɔ ɖe ame dzi ne eku esi wòƒo nu kple amegbetɔ gbãtɔ Adam.
God explained what happens when we die when he spoke to the first man, Adam.
Esi Adam meɖo to Mawu o ta la, Mawu gblɔ nɛ be: "Anyi nènye, eye anyi ke nàgatrɔ azu! " (1 Mose 3:19) Adam menɔ afi aɖeke hafi Mawu tsɔ anyi mèe o.
Because Adam was disobedient, God said to him: "Dust you are and to dust you will return. " (Genesis 3:19) Before God created Adam "out of dust from the ground, " Adam did not exist.
(1 Mose 2:7) Eya ta esi Adam ku la, egatrɔ zu anyi eye megali o.
(Genesis 2:7) Likewise, when Adam died, he returned to dust and ceased to exist.
Nu ma kee dzɔna ɖe ame siwo kuna egbea hã dzi.
The same thing happens to those who die now.
Biblia gblɔ tso amegbetɔwo kple lãwo siaa ŋu be: "Anyi me wo katã wotso, eye anyi wo katã woagazu. " Nyagblɔla 3:19, 20.
Speaking of both humans and animals, the Bible says: "They have all come to be from the dust, and they are all returning to the dust. "​ Ecclesiastes 3:19, 20.
Ku menye nu sia nu ƒe nuwuwu kokoko o
Death is not necessarily the end of everything
Zi geɖe la, Biblia tsɔa ku sɔna kple alɔ̃dɔdɔ.
The Bible often compares death to sleep.
(Psalmo 13:4; Yohanes 11:11-14; Dɔwɔwɔwo 7:60) Ame si dɔ alɔ̃ yi eme ʋĩi la meganyaa nu siwo le edzi yim o.
(Psalm 13:3; John 11:11-14; Acts 7:60) A person who is fast asleep is unaware of what is happening around him.
Nenema kee kukuawo hã menyaa naneke o.
Likewise, the dead are not conscious of anything.
Ke hã Biblia gblɔ be Mawu ate ŋu afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre abe ale si wofɔa ame tso alɔ̃ me ene eye wòana woagava nɔ agbe ake.
Yet, the Bible teaches that God can awaken the dead as if from sleep and give them life again.
(Hiob 14:13-15) Le ame siwo Mawu afɔ ɖe tsitre ɖe gome ya la, ku menye nu sia nu ƒe nuwuwu o.
(Job 14:13-15) For those whom God resurrects, death is not the end of everything.
Nya Kae Biblia Gblɔ Tso Dzotɔtɔ Ame Kukuwo Ŋu?
What Does the Bible Say About Cremation?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Biblia mena mɔfiame aɖeke kã tso dzotɔtɔ ame kukuwo ŋu o.
The Bible contains no specific direction on the practice of cremation.
Biblia mede se aɖeke ku ɖe ame kukuwo ɖiɖi alo dzotɔtɔ wo ŋu o.
There is no Bible command regarding either burial or cremation of the dead.
Biblia ƒo nu tso go vovovo siwo me Mawu subɔla wɔnuteƒewo ɖi woƒe ame kukuwo le ŋu.
The Bible does report instances of faithful servants of God burying their dead.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Abraham dze agbagba ƒle anyigba aɖe be wòanye ameɖiƒe, eye wòɖi srɔ̃a, Sara ɖe afi ma. 1 Mose 23:2-20; 49:29-32.
For example, Abraham went to great lengths to secure a burial place for his wife, Sarah.​ Genesis 23:​2-​20; 49:29-​32.
Azɔ hã, Biblia na míenya be nuteƒewɔla aɖewo tɔ dzo woƒe ame kukuwo.
The Bible also mentions faithful individuals burning the remains of the dead.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi Israel Fia Saul kple viaŋutsu etɔ̃ ku le aʋagbedzi la, woƒe kukuawo nɔ futɔawo ƒe anyigba dzi le gɔmedzedzea me, eye woɖi gbɔ woƒe kukuawo.
For example, when King Saul of Israel and three of his sons were killed in battle, their corpses initially remained in enemy territory and were treated dishonorably.
Esi Israel-vi wɔnuteƒe siwo nye aʋawɔlawo se nu tso eŋu la, woyi ɖatsɔ Saul kple viaŋutsuawo ƒe kukuawo, wotɔ dzo wo, eye woɖi woƒe ƒuwo.
Hearing of the situation, faithful Israelite warriors retrieved the bodies of Saul and his sons, burned them, and buried the remains.
(1 Samuel 31:8-13) Biblia ɖee fia be ale si Israel-vi mawo wɔ woƒe kukuawoe la sɔ. 2 Samuel 2:4-6.
(1 Samuel 31:​8-​13) The Bible indicates that this was an acceptable way to treat the remains of those men.​ 2 Samuel 2:​4-6.
Susu totro siwo le amewo si ku ɖe dzotɔtɔ ame kukuwo ŋu
Common misconceptions about cremation
Susu totro: Dzotɔtɔ ame kuku nye bubumademade eƒe ŋutilã ŋu.
Misconception: Cremation dishonors the body.
Nyateƒenya: Biblia gblɔ be ne ame ku la, egatrɔna zua anyi, eye le dzɔdzɔme nu la, nu siae dzɔna ɖe ŋutilã kuku dzi ne enyunyɔ.
Fact: The Bible says that those who die return to the dust, which is what naturally happens to a corpse when it decomposes.
(1 Mose 3:19) Ne wotɔ dzo ŋutilã kuku wòzu afi la, enana be wòzua anyi kaba.
(Genesis 3:​19) Cremation speeds up the process by reducing the body to ashes, or dust.
Susu totro: Le blema la, ame siwo ŋu Mawu mekpɔ ŋudzedze ɖo o koe wotɔa dzoe le woƒe ku megbe.
Misconception: In Bible times, only people in God’s disfavor were burned after death.
Nyateƒenya: Wotɔ dzo ame mawɔnuteƒe aɖewo, abe Akan kple eƒe ƒomea ene, ƒe kukuawo.
Fact: The dead bodies of some unfaithful people, such as Achan and his family, were burned.
(Yosua 7:25) Ke hã, le go akpa gãtɔ me la, menye nenemae wònɔna o.
(Joshua 7:​25) However, this was an exception rather than the rule.
(5 Mose 21:22, 23) Abe ale si míekpɔe va yi ene la, wotɔ dzo nuteƒewɔla aɖewo, abe Fia Saul viŋutsu Yonatan ene, ƒe kukuawo.
(Deuteronomy 21:22, 23) As noted earlier, the bodies of even some faithful people, such as King Saul’s son Jonathan, were burned after death.
Susu totro: Ne wotɔ dzo ame la, awɔe be Mawu mate ŋu afɔe ɖe tsitre o.
Misconception: Cremation prevents God from resurrecting a person.
Nyateƒenya: Ku ɖe ame kukuwo fɔfɔ ɖe tsitre ŋu la, woɖaɖi ame si ku o, woɖatɔ dzoe o, atsiaƒu mee wòtsi o, lã wɔadã aɖee vuvui o, Mawu ate ŋu afɔe ɖe tsitre.
Fact: Regarding resurrection of the dead, it does not matter to God whether a person’s body was buried, cremated, lost at sea, or eaten by wild animals.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:13) Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la ate ŋu agawɔ ŋutilã bubu na amea bɔbɔe. 1 Korintotɔwo 15:35, 38.
(Revelation 20:13) The Almighty can easily re-create a new body for the person.​ 1 Corinthians 15:35, 38.
Dzotɔtɔ Ame Kuku Alo Eɖiɖi? Ale Si Nàtso Nya Me
Cremation or Burial?​ How to Decide
Ne eva hiã be nàtso nya me be yeatɔ dzo ame kuku loo alo aɖii la, bu nya siwo gbɔna la ŋu.
When deciding how to dispose of a dead body, consider the following factors.
Nu si amea gblɔ be yedi hafi wòku.
The wishes of the deceased.
Biblia me kpɔɖeŋuwo li ku ɖe ale si ƒometɔwo wɔ ɖe nya siwo ame aɖe gblɔ da ɖi ku ɖe ale si woawɔ yeƒe kukua ŋui dzi la ŋu. 1 Mose 50:4, 5; 2 Mose 13:19.
The Bible records instances in which family members respected the instructions a person gave regarding treatment of his body after his death.​ Genesis 50:​4, 5; Exodus 13:19.
Dekɔnuwo.
Local customs.
Zi geɖe la, dekɔnuwo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe nu si wowɔa ŋutilã kukuwoe dzi.
These often have a bearing on how dead bodies are treated.
(Yohanes 19:40) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le Biblia ŋlɔɣiwo la, zi geɖe la, woɖia ame siwo ku.
(John 19:40) For instance, in Bible times, people customarily buried the dead.
(1 Mose 49:31; 1 Samuel 28:3) Nenema kee egbea, ame aɖe ate ŋu atiae be yeaɖi ame si ku la le woƒe dekɔnuwo nu, zi ale si dekɔnu mawo metsi tre ɖe Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo ŋu o ko.
(Genesis 49:31; 1 Samuel 28:3) Likewise today, a person may choose to deal with the remains of the deceased according to local customs as long as such customs do not conflict with Bible principles.
Nu si dukɔa ƒe sewo bia.
Legal requirements.
Biblia de dzi ƒo na mí be míabɔbɔ mía ɖokui ɖe ŋusẽtɔwo te.
The Bible encourages obedience to secular authorities.
(Romatɔwo 13:1) Le teƒe aɖewo la, dziɖuɖua dea sewo ku ɖe nu si woawɔ na ame kukuwo ƒe ŋutilã ŋu.
(Romans 13:1) In some areas, the authorities enact laws about the treatment of dead bodies.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne woatɔ dzo ame kuku la, dziɖuɖu ƒe sewo li ku ɖe afi si woakɔ ame si wotɔ dzoe la ƒe afiwo ɖo ŋu.
For instance, in the case of cremation, some authorities place restrictions on where the ashes may be disposed of.
Ame bubuwo ƒe seselelãme.
The feelings of others.
Ŋɔŋlɔawo de dzi ƒo na mí be míadi ame bubuwo ƒe nyonyo.
The Scriptures encourage us to look out for the interests of others.
(Filipitɔwo 2:4) Ne eva hiã be míatso nya me be míaɖi ame si ku loo alo atɔ dzoe la, míate ŋu ade ŋugble le nyabiase siawo ŋu: Nu kae nye ƒometɔ bubuwo ƒe susu le dzotɔtɔ ame kukuwo alo wo ɖiɖi ŋu?
(Philippians 2:4) When deciding how to deal with a dead person’s remains, we might consider these questions: How do other family members feel about cremation or burial of the deceased?
Nu kae nye nutoa me tɔwo ƒe susu le dzotɔtɔ ame kukuwo alo wo ɖiɖi ŋu?
How does the local community view such customs?
Aleke Nàwɔ Aɖu Vɔvɔ̃ Na Ku Dzi?
Fear of Death​ How Can You Overcome It?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Esɔ be míavɔ̃ na ku si nye míaƒe futɔ, eye míaɖe afɔ siwo hiã atsɔ akpɔ mía ɖokuiwo ta.
We rightly fear death as an enemy and take reasonable steps to protect our life.
(1 Korintotɔwo 15:26) Gake ame siwo xɔ nyakpakpawo kple aʋatsodzixɔsewo dzi se la vɔ̃na na ku ale gbegbe be wozu "kluviwo le woƒe agbenɔɣi katã. "
(1 Corinthians 15:26) However, an irrational fear of death based on falsehood or superstition makes people "subject to slavery all through their lives. "
(Hebritɔwo 2:15) Ne èse nu si tututu ku nye gɔme nyuie la, akpe ɖe ŋuwò be màgavɔ̃ na ku wu ale si dze o, elabe vɔvɔ̃ sia ate ŋu ana be màgase vivi le agbe me o. Yohanes 8:32.
(Hebrews 2:​15) Knowing the truth will free you from a morbid fear of death​ a fear that can rob you of the ability to enjoy life.​ John 8:​32.
Nyateƒe si ku ɖe ku ŋu
The truth about death
Kukuawo meganyaa naneke o.
The dead are not conscious.
(Psalmo 146:4) Mele be nàvɔ̃ be yeava nɔ veve sesem alo woawɔ fu ye ne yeku o, elabe Biblia tsɔ ku sɔ kple alɔ̃dɔdɔ.
(Psalm 146:4) You need not fear pain or torment after you die, for the Bible compares death to sleep.​ Psalm 13:3; John 11:11-​14.
Psalmo 13:3; Yohanes 11:11-14.
The dead cannot harm us.
‘Wɔna vɔna le’ ame siwo lé fu mí kaɖikaɖi gɔ̃ hã ŋu ne woku.
Even formerly violent enemies are "impotent in death. "
(Lododowo 21:16) Biblia gblɔ be "woƒe amelɔlɔ̃ kple fuléle kpakple ŋuʋaʋã hã nu yi xoxo. " Nyagblɔla 9:6.
(Proverbs 21:16) The Bible says that "their hate and their jealousy have already perished. "​ Ecclesiastes 9:6.
Le tsitretsitsia me la, Mawu afɔ amewo woagava anɔ agbe ake.
Death is not necessarily the permanent end of our existence.
Yohanes 5:28, 29; Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15.
By means of a resurrection, God will bring back to life people who have died.​ John 5:​28, 29; Acts 24:15.
Mawu do ŋugbe be le ɣeyiɣi aɖe si gbɔna me la, "ku maganɔ anyi o. "
God promises a time when "death will be no more. "
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4) Biblia gblɔ tso ɣeyiɣi ma ŋu be, "Ame dzɔdzɔewo anyi anyigba la dome, eye woanɔ edzi tegbee, " eye woavo tso vɔvɔ̃ na ku si me keŋkeŋ. Psalmo 37:29.
(Revelation 21:4) Concerning that day, the Bible says: "The righteous themselves will possess the earth, and they will reside forever upon it, " completely free from any fear of dying.​ Psalm 37:29.
Aleke Míabu Nya Siwo Ame Siwo Nɔ Ði Me Ʋuu Hafi Fɔ Gblɔna La?
Near-Death Experiences​ What Do They Not Mean?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
PThe Bible’s answer
Ame siwo nɔ ɖi me ʋuu hafi va fɔ gblɔna be yewokpɔe be yewodo go le yewoƒe ŋutilã me, yewokpɔ kekeli aɖe si nu sẽ alo yewokpɔ teƒe aɖe si nya kpɔ eteƒe mekɔ o.
Many people who have come close to dying say that they recall being separated from their body or seeing a bright light or a place of great beauty.
Agbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: ‘Ame aɖewo bunɛ be woƒe nya siawo ɖee fia be nu siwo le edzi yim le agbe bubu aɖe mee wokpɔ.’
‘Some consider the experience to be a privileged glimpse of another realm of existence,’ states the book Recollections of Death.

(Recollections of Death) Togbɔ be Biblia meƒo nu tso nɔnɔme si me ame siwo yia ɖi me nɔna la ŋu o hã la, nyateƒenya vevi aɖewo le eme siwo ɖee fia be nu siwo ameawo gblɔna la menye nu siwo le edzi yim le agbe bubu aɖe mee wokpɔ o.
Although the Bible doesn’t mention such near-death experiences, it does contain a fundamental truth that shows that they are not visions of the next life.
Kukuawo menyaa naneke o.
The dead are unconscious.
Biblia gblɔ be "kukuawo meganya naneke kura o. "
The Bible says that the dead "are conscious of nothing at all. "
(Nyagblɔla 9:5) Ne míeku la, míeyia agbenɔnɔ dzi le teƒe bubu aɖeke o, ke boŋ míegali o.
(Ecclesiastes 9:5) At death we pass, not into another plane of existence or thinking, but into nonexistence.
Nufiafia si nye be luʋɔ makumaku aɖe le mía me si dona le míaƒe ŋutilã me ne míeku la metso Biblia me o.
The teaching that we have an immortal soul that survives after our body dies does not come from the Bible.
(Ezekiel 18:4) Eya ta nya siwo ame siwo nɔ ɖi me ʋuu hafi fɔ gblɔna la menye ale si agbenɔnɔ le dziƒo, dzo mavɔ me, alo ku megbee wokpɔ o.
(Ezekiel 18:4) Thus, any memories from a near-death experience cannot be glimpses of heaven, hell, or the afterlife.
Nu kae Lazaro gblɔ be yekpɔ le ku me esime wofɔe?
What did Lazarus say about an afterlife?
Nya si Biblia gblɔ tso Lazaro ŋuti la nye nu si dzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ, elabe eku ŋkeke ene hafi Yesu fɔe ɖe tsitre.
The Bible’s account of Lazarus describes an actual death experience: He was resurrected by Jesus after being dead for four days.
(Yohanes 11:38-​44) Ne ɖe Lazaro nɔ dzidzɔ kpɔm le ku megbe hafi Yesu gafɔe ɖe anyigba sia dzi la, anye ŋutasesẽ le eŋu.
(John 11:38-​44) If Lazarus had been enjoying some form of afterlife, it would have been cruel of Jesus to bring him back to life on earth.
Gake Lazaro megblɔ naneke le Biblia be yekpɔ ale si agbenɔnɔ nɔna le ku megbe o.
However, the Bible records no comments from Lazarus about the afterlife.
Ðikeke mele eme o be ne ɖe Lazaro kpɔ nane le ku megbe la anye ne egblɔe.
Surely Lazarus would have spoken about his afterlife experience if he had had one.
Eɖe dzesi ŋutɔ be Yesu tsɔ Lazaro ƒe kua sɔ kple alɔ̃dɔdɔ, si ɖee fia be esime Lazaro ku la meganya naneke o.​ Yohanes 11:11-​14.
Significantly, Jesus described Lazarus’ death as being like sleep, indicating that while Lazarus was dead, he was conscious of nothing at all.​ John 11:11-​14.
Ðe Woɖo Ɣeyiɣi Si Míaku La Ðia?
Is Our Time to Die Predetermined?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, womeɖo ɣeyiɣi si míaku la ɖi o.
No, we do not have a predetermined time to die.
Biblia meda asi ɖe dzɔgbese alo nu ɖoɖiname ƒe nufiafia dzi o, nu si wòfia boŋue nye be zi geɖe la, "nuɖiɖeame " gbɔe míaƒe ku tsona.
Rather than supporting belief in fate, the Bible says that death is often due to "unexpected events. "​ Ecclesiastes 9:​11.
Nyagblɔla 9:11. Ðe Biblia megblɔ be "kuɣi li " oa?
Doesn’t the Bible say that there is "a time to die "?
Ɛ̃, Nyagblɔla 3:2 gblɔ be "Vidziɣi li, eye kuɣi li; nuƒãɣi li, eye nuŋeɣi li. "
Yes, Ecclesiastes 3:2 says that there is "a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted. "
Ke hã nya siwo ƒo xlã nya siawo ɖee fia be ale si agbemenuwɔnawo yia edzi ɖaa ŋutie Biblia le nu ƒom tsoe.
(King James Version) However, the context of this verse shows that the Bible is discussing the continuing cycles that are common to life.
(Nyagblɔla 3:1-8) Abe ale si ko Mawu mezia agbledela aɖeke dzi be wòaƒã nu le ɣeyiɣi aɖe koŋ me o la, nenema kee Mawu meɖo ɣeyiɣi si míaku la ɖi na mí o.
(Ecclesiastes 3:​1-8) God has not set our personal time to die any more than he forces a farmer to plant at a particular moment.
Ke boŋ nya la ƒe veviƒee nye be míaƒo asa na dzitsitsi ɖe xexemenuwo alo ŋutilãmenuwo ŋu ale be míagagblẽ mía Wɔla la ɖi o.​ Nyagblɔla 3:​11; 12:​1, 13.
Instead, the point is that we should avoid being so preoccupied with mundane matters that we neglect our Creator.​ Ecclesiastes 3:​11; 12:​1, 13.
Míate ŋu anɔ agbe didi
Life can be extended
Togbɔ be míate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe agbemenudzɔdzɔwo dzi o hã la, míaƒe nyametsotso nyuiwo ate ŋu awɔe be míanɔ agbe didi.
Despite life’s uncertainties, we can often live longer if we make wise decisions.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Nunyala ƒe nufiafia la, agbevudo wònye, eɖea ame tso ku ƒe mɔ̃tetrewo me. "
The Bible says: "The teaching of the wise one is a source of life to turn one away from the snares of death. "
(Lododowo 13:14) Nenema ke Mose hã gblɔ na Israel-viwo be woate ŋu anɔ "agbe didi " nenye be wowɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe sewo dzi.
(Proverbs 13:14) Likewise, Moses told the Israelites that they could "live a long time " if they obeyed God’s commands.
(5 Mose 6:2) Gake míate ŋu atso míaƒe agbe dzi nenye be míenɔa agbe baɖa alo wɔa bometsinuwo.​ Nyagblɔla 7:17.
(Deuteronomy 6:2) In contrast, we can carelessly shorten our life by bad or foolish actions.​ Ecclesiastes 7:​17.
Ke hã, aleke ke míeɖadze nunya alo ɖɔ ŋu ɖo le agbe mee o, mímate ŋu asi le ku nu o.
No matter how wise or careful we are, though, we cannot escape death.
(Romatɔwo 5:12) Gake manɔ alea ɖaa o, elabe Biblia do ŋugbe be ɣeyiɣi aɖe gbɔna esime "ku maganɔ anyi akpɔ o " Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4.
(Romans 5:​12) Yet, this situation will change, for the Bible promises a time when "death will be no more. "​ Revelation 21:4.
Nu Kae Nye Dzo Mavɔ?
What Is Hell?
Afi Si Wowɔa Funyafunya Amewo Le Tegbee Wònyea?
Is It a Place of Eternal Torment?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Woɖe Hebrigbe me nya "Sheol " kple eƒe Helagbe me tɔ si nye "Hades " si nye ameƒomea ƒe yɔdo gɔme le Biblia aɖewo me be "dzo mavɔ. "
Some Bible translations use the word "hell " for the Hebrew word "Sheol " and the matching Greek word "Hades, " both of which refer to the common grave of mankind.
(Psalmo 16:10; Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:27) Ame geɖewo xɔ dzo mavɔ dzi se abe ale si wòdze le subɔsubɔhawo ƒe nutata si dze le nyati sia me la mee ene.
(Psalm 16:10; Acts 2:​27) Many people believe in a fiery hell, as shown in the religious artwork accompanying this article.
Ke hã nu si Biblia gblɔ tso nya sia ŋu to vovo sãa.
However, the Bible teaches otherwise.
Ame siwo le tsiẽƒe si gɔme woɖena be dzo mavɔ la meganyaa naneke o, eye womesea veve hã o.
Those in hell are unconscious and so cannot feel pain.
"Elabena nuwɔwɔ alo tamebubu, sidzedze alo nunya mele tsieƒe, afi si yi ge nàla o. "
"There is no work nor devising nor knowledge nor wisdom in Sheol. "​ Ecclesiastes 9:​10.
Nyagblɔla 9:10.
Good people go to hell.
Nuteƒewɔla Yakob kple Hiob nɔ mɔ kpɔm be yewoayi afi ma.​ 1 Mose 37:35; Hiob 14:13.
The faithful men Jacob and Job expected to go there.​ Genesis 37:35; Job 14:13.
"Ame si ku la, woɖee tso eƒe nu vɔ̃ me. "
Death, not torment in a fiery hell, is the penalty for sin.
Romatɔwo 6:7.
"He who has died has been acquitted from his sin. "​ Romans 6:7.
Funyafunyawɔwɔ amewo tegbee mewɔ ɖeka kple Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye o.
Eternal torment would violate God’s justice.
(5 Mose 32:4) Esi ŋutsu gbãtɔ Adam wɔ nu vɔ̃ la, Mawu gblɔ nɛ be to si yeahe nɛ lae nye be maganɔ agbe o.
(Deuteronomy 32:4) When the first man, Adam, sinned, God told him that his punishment would simply be to pass out of existence: "Dust you are and to dust you will return. "
Egblɔ nɛ be: "Anyi nènye, eye anyi ke nàgatrɔ azu! " (1 Mose 3:19) Ne ɖe Mawu tsɔ Adam de dzo aɖe si le bibim tegbee me la, ke efia be enye alakpatɔ.
(Genesis 3:​19) God would have been lying if he were actually sending Adam to a fiery hell.
Meva susu me na Mawu kpɔ gɔ̃ hã be yeawɔ funyafunya amewo tegbee o.
God does not even contemplate eternal torment.
Nu si wofiaa amewo be Mawu awɔ funyafunya amewo le dzo mavɔ me tegbee la mewɔ ɖeka kple Biblia ƒe nufiafia si nye be "Mawu nye lɔlɔ̃ " la o. 1 Yohanes 4:8; Yeremiya 7:31.
The idea that he would punish people in hellfire is contrary to the Bible’s teaching that "God is love. "​ ⁠1 John 4:8; Jeremiah 7:​31.
Ame Kawoe Yia Dzo Mavɔ Me?
Who Goes to Hell?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Nu si nya si gɔme woɖe be dzo mavɔ (Hebrigbe me nya "Sheol " kple Helagbe me nya "Hades ") fia koe nye yɔdo alo tsiẽƒe, ke menye teƒe aɖe si dzo nɔa bibim le tegbee si wowɔa funyafunya amewo lee o.
Hell ( "Sheol " and "Hades " in the Bible’s original languages) is simply the grave, not a place of fiery torment.
Ame kawoe yia afi ma?
Who go to hell?
Nu nyui wɔlawo kple nu gbegblẽ wɔlawo siaa.
Both good people and bad people.
(Hiob 14:13; Psalmo 9:17) Biblia gblɔ be ameƒomea ƒe yɔdo siae nye afi si "agbagbeawo katã ƒoa ta kpli ɖo. " Hiob 30:23.
(Job 14:13; Psalm 9:​17) The Bible says that this common grave of mankind is "the house of meeting for everyone living. "​ Job 30:23.
Yesu gɔ̃ hã yi tsiẽƒe si gɔme woɖe be dzo mavɔ esi wòku.
Even Jesus went to hell when he died.
Ke hã, "womegblẽe ɖe tsiẽƒe o, " elabe Mawu fɔe ɖe tsitre.​ Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:31, 32, Eʋegbe Biblia.
However, "he was not kept in hell, " because God resurrected him.​ Acts 2:​31, 32, The Bible in Basic English.
Ðe ame siwo yi teƒe si woyɔna be dzo mavɔ me la anɔ afi ma tegbeea?
Is hell eternal?
Yesu azã Mawu ƒe ŋusẽ atsɔ afɔ ame siwo katã yi tsiẽƒe si gɔme woɖena be dzo mavɔ la.
All those who go to hell will come back out, brought to life by Jesus through God’s power.
(Yohanes 5:28, 29; Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15) Wogblɔ le Nyaɖeɖefia 20:13 tso ame kukuwo ƒe tsitretsitsi ŋu be "ku kple Hades tsɔ ame kuku siwo nɔ wo me la na. "
(John 5:​28, 29; Acts 24:15) Speaking of that future resurrection, the prophecy at Revelation 20:13 says that "death and hell delivered up the dead which were in them. "
Ne wonya fɔ ame siwo katã le tsiẽƒe si gɔme wolɔ̃a ɖeɖe be dzo mavɔ me vɔ ko la, nu si amewo lɔ̃a yɔyɔ be dzo mavɔ la maganɔ anyi o, elabena "ku maganɔ anyi o. "
(King James Version) Once hell has been emptied, it will no longer exist; no one will ever go there again because "death will be no more. "​ Revelation 21:​3, 4; 20:14.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4; 20:14.
Not everyone who dies goes to hell, though.
Biblia gblɔ be ame aɖewo nyrɔ wo ɖokuiwo ɖe nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ me ale gbegbe be womagate ŋu atrɔ dzi me o.
The Bible shows that some people become so steeped in wickedness that they are beyond repentance.
(Hebritɔwo 10:26, 27) Ne ame siawo ku la, womeyia teƒe si woyɔna be dzo mavɔ o, ke boŋ Gehena, si fia tsɔtsrɔ̃ ɖikaa.
(Hebrews 10:26, 27) When such ones die, they go, not to hell, but to Gehenna, which is a symbol of everlasting destruction.
(Mateo 5:29, 30) Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesu gblɔ na subɔsubɔhakplɔla alakpanuwɔla siwo nɔ anyi le eŋɔli la be woayi Gehena.​ Mateo 23:27-33
(Matthew 5:​29, 30) For example, Jesus indicated that some of the hypocritical religious leaders in his day would go to Gehenna.​ Matthew 23:27-​33.
Ðe Nya Ŋutiklɔdzo Dze Le Biblia Mea?
Is Purgatory Mentioned in the Bible?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao.
No, it is not.
Nya "ŋutiklɔdzo " medze le Biblia me o, eye Biblia mefia nu be wokɔa ame siwo ku ƒe luʋɔwo ŋu le ŋutiklɔdzo me o.
The Bible does not contain the word "purgatory, " nor does it teach that the souls of those who have died are purified in purgatory.
Bu nu si Biblia fia ku ɖe nu vɔ̃ kple ku ŋu, kple ale si ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe nufiafiaa tsi tsitre ɖe nufiafia mawo ŋu la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider what the Bible teaches about sin and death and how it contradicts the doctrine of purgatory.
Yesu ƒe ʋu dzi xɔxɔsee klɔa nu vɔ̃ ɖa le ame ŋu, ke menye ŋutiklɔdzo me nɔnɔe o.
Faith in the blood of Jesus, not time in a so-called purgatory, purifies a person from sin.

Biblia gblɔ be, "[Mawu Vi] Yesu ƒe ʋu klɔa nu vɔ̃ ɖe sia ɖe ɖa le mía ŋu " eye be ‘Yesu Kristo na ablɔɖe mí tso míaƒe nu vɔ̃wo me to eya ŋutɔ ƒe ʋu me.’ (1 Yohanes 1:7; Nyaɖeɖefia 1:5) Yesu ‘tsɔ eƒe agbe na wònye tafe na ame geɖewo.’​ Mateo 20:28.

The Bible says that "the blood of [God’s] Son Jesus cleanses us from all sin " and that "Jesus Christ . . . freed us from our sins by his blood. " (1 John 1:7; Revelation 1:5, New American Bible) Jesus gave "his life as a ransom for many " to pay for their sins.​ Matthew 20:28, NAB.
Ame siwo ku la meganya naneke o.
People who have died are unconscious.
"Agbagbeawo nyae be yewogbɔna kuku ge, ke kukuawo meganya naneke kura o. "
"The living know that they are to die, but the dead no longer know anything. "
(Nyagblɔla 9:5) Ame si ku la megasea veve aɖeke o, eya ta womate ŋu atsɔ ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe tohehe akɔ eŋu o.
(Ecclesiastes 9:5, NAB) A person who has died cannot feel anything and therefore cannot be cleansed by any fire of purgatory.
Nu vɔ̃ ŋuti tohehe aɖeke meli na ame si ku o.
There is no punishment for sins after a person dies.
Biblia gblɔ be "nu vɔ̃ ƒe fetue nye ku " eye be "ame si ku la, wotso afia nɛ ɖee tso eƒe nu vɔ̃ me. "
The Bible says that "the wages of sin is death " and that "a dead person has been absolved from sin. "
(Romatɔwo 6:7, 23) Ku ye nye nu vɔ̃ ƒe tohehe.
(Romans 6:​7, 23, NAB) Death is the full and complete punishment for sin.
Nu kae nye ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe nufiafia la?
What is the doctrine of purgatory?
Katolikotɔwo ƒe nufiafia ɖe ŋutiklɔdzo me be enye teƒe alo nɔnɔme si me ame si ku ƒe luʋɔ va nɔna ale be wòalé avu ɖe eƒe nu vɔ̃ siwo wometsɔ ke o ta be eŋuti nakɔ.
Purgatory is defined in Catholic teaching as the state, place, or condition where the souls of those who die atone for their unforgiven sins and are purified.
Le agbalẽ si nye Catechism of the Catholic Church ƒe nya nu la, "ehiã be woaklɔ amewo ŋu hafi woate ŋu age ɖe dziƒo ƒe dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ me. "
According to the Catechism of the Catholic Church, this purification is needed "to achieve the holiness necessary to enter the joy of heaven. "
Agbalẽa gblɔ kpee be "Sɔlemehaa ƒe kɔnyinyi . . . ƒo nu tso ŋutikɔklɔ ƒe dzo ŋu, " abe ale si wòdze le nyati sia ƒe nɔnɔmetata me ene.
The Catechism adds that "the tradition of the Church . . . speaks of a cleansing fire, " as depicted in the artwork accompanying this article.
Gake nufiafia sia metso Ŋɔŋlɔawo me o.
However, this is not a Scriptural teaching.
Afi kae ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe nufiafiaa dzɔ tso?
Where did the doctrine of purgatory come from?
Blema Helatɔwo xɔ Limbo kple ŋutiklɔdzo dzi se.
The ancient Greeks believed in Limbo and purgatory.
Helatɔwo ƒe xexemenunya kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe Clement si tso Alexandria dzi wògblɔ be, ame kukuwo ŋu ate ŋu akɔ tso nu vɔ̃ me ne nenye be woklɔ wo ŋu le ŋutiklɔdzo me.
Influenced by Greek philosophy, Clement of Alexandria asserted that the dead could be cleansed of sin by a purifying fire.
Ke hã, agbalẽ si nye The History of Christian Doctrines ɖe eme be Papa Gregory Gãtɔ ye xɔ ŋutikɔklɔ ƒe dzo ƒe dzixɔse sia de eme be nya aɖeke meku ɖe eŋu o.
However, it was Pope Gregory the Great who stressed the fire of purgatory as a matter of unquestioned belief, according to The History of Christian Doctrines.
Agbalẽ sia gblɔ kpee be Gregory, si nye papa tso ƒe 590 va se ɖe ƒe 604 K.Ŋ. "ye woyɔna be ‘ame si to ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe nufiafia vɛ.’
This reference work adds that Gregory, who was pope from 590 to 604 C.E., "is usually called ‘the inventor of purgatory.’
" Katolikohaa ɖe ŋutiklɔdzo ƒe nufiafia la fia le adaŋudetakpekpe siwo wowɔ le Lyons (ƒe 1274) kple Florence (ƒe 1439) me eye emegbe wogate gbe ɖe edzi le Trent Adaŋudetakpekpea me le ƒe 1547 me.
" The Catholic Church defined its official teaching of purgatory at the councils of Lyons (1274) and Florence (1439) and reaffirmed it at the Council of Trent in 1547.
Nu Kae Nye Tsitretsitsi La?
What Is the Resurrection?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Nya si gɔme woɖe le Biblia me be "tsitretsitsi " la, tso Helagbe me nya anastasis, me. Nya sia gɔmee nye "fɔfɔ ɖe tsitre " alo "tsotso ɖe tsitrenu ake. "
In the Bible, the word translated as "resurrection " comes from the Greek anastasis, which means "raising up " or "standing up again. "
Ame si wofɔ ɖe tsitre la fɔna tso ku me gava nɔa agbe ake abe ale si wònɔe tsã ene.​ 1 Korintotɔwo 15:12, 13.
A person who is resurrected is raised up from death and restored to life as the person he was before.​ 1 Corinthians 15:12, 13.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yehowa do ŋugbe to nyagblɔɖila Hosea dzi be: "Maɖe wo le Tsiẽƒe si me; magbugbɔ wo axɔ le ku si me. "
Although the word "resurrection " is not in the Hebrew Scriptures, often called the Old Testament, the teaching appears there.
Hosea 13:14; Hiob 14:13-15; Yesaya 26:19; Daniel 12:2, 13.
Through the prophet Hosea, for example, God promised: "From the power of the Grave I will redeem them; from death I will recover them. "​ Hosea 13:14; Job 14:13-​15; Isaiah 26:19; Daniel 12:​2, 13.
Afi kae ame siwo woafɔ ɖe tsitre la anɔ?
Where will people be resurrected?
Woafɔ ame aɖewo be woava ɖu fia kple Kristo le dziƒo.
Some people are resurrected to life in heaven to rule as kings with Christ.
(2 Korintotɔwo 5:1; Nyaɖeɖefia 5:9, 10) Biblia yɔ tsitretsitsi sia be "tsitretsitsi gbãtɔ " kple "tsitretsitsi si ado ŋgɔ " eye nya siawo fia be tsitretsitsi bubu akplɔ esia ɖo.
(2 Corinthians 5:1; Revelation 5:​9, 10) The Bible calls this "the first resurrection " and "the earlier resurrection, " both expressions implying that there is another resurrection to follow.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 20:6; Filipitɔwo 3:11) Le tsitretsitsi si akplɔe ɖo me la, woafɔ amewo woava nɔ anyigba dzi, tsitretsitsi sia mee ame akpa gãtɔ akpɔ gome le.​ Psalmo 37:29.
(Revelation 20:6; Philippians 3:​11) This later resurrection will be to life on earth, which the vast majority of those brought back to life will enjoy.​ Psalm 37:29.
Aleke woafɔ amewo ɖe tsitree?
How are people resurrected?
Mawu na ŋusẽ Yesu be wòafɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre.
God grants Jesus the power to raise the dead.
(Yohanes 11:25) Yesu afɔ "ame siwo katã le ŋkuɖodziyɔdowo me la " ɖe tsitre, wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kple eƒe nɔnɔme, amenyenye kple nuteƒekpɔkpɔwo.
(John 11:25) Jesus will restore "all those in the memorial tombs " to life, each one with his unique identity, personality, and memories.
Le ame siwo woafɔ ɖe tsitre be woanɔ agbe le anyigba dzi gome la, woana amegbetɔŋutilã wo eye woanɔ lãmesẽ blibo me. Yesaya 33:24; 35:5, 6; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:42-44, 50.

(John 5:​28, 29) Those resurrected to heaven receive a spirit body, while those resurrected to life on earth receive a healthy physical body, completely sound.​ Isaiah 33:24; 35:​5, 6; 1 Corinthians 15:42-​44, 50.
Ame kawoe woafɔ ɖe tsitre?
Who will be resurrected?
Biblia gblɔ be "tsitretsitsi li na ame dzɔdzɔewo kple ame madzɔmadzɔwo siaa. "
The Bible says that "there is going to be a resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous. "
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15) Ame dzɔdzɔe siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye nuteƒewɔla siwo nye Noa, Sara kple Abraham.
(Acts 24:15) The righteous include faithful people, such as Noah, Sarah, and Abraham.
(1 Mose 6:9; Hebritɔwo 11:11; Yakobo 2:21) Ame madzɔmadzɔawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye ame siwo menɔ agbe ɖe Mawu ƒe sewo nu o le esi mɔnukpɔkpɔ mesu wo si wosrɔ̃ nu tso wo ŋu hewɔ wo dzi o ta.
(Genesis 6:9; Hebrews 11:11; James 2:​21) The unrighteous include those who failed to meet God’s standards but did not have the opportunity to learn and follow them.
Gake womafɔ ame siwo vɔ̃ɖi ale gbegbe be tɔtrɔ megale wo ŋu o la ya ɖe tsitre o.
However, those who become so wicked that they are beyond reform will not be resurrected.
Ne ame siawo ku la, efia be wotsrɔ̃ gbidii eye tsitretsitsi ƒe mɔkpɔkpɔ aɖeke megali na wo o.​ Mateo 23:33; Hebritɔwo 10:26, 27.
When such ones die, they suffer permanent destruction with no hope of a return to life.​ Matthew 23:33; Hebrews 10:26, 27.
Ɣekaɣie woafɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre?
When will the resurrection take place?
Biblia gblɔ be woafɔ ame siwo ayi dziƒo la ɖe tsitre le Kristo ƒe anyinɔɣi si dze egɔme tso 1914 me.
The Bible foretold that the resurrection to heaven would take place during Christ’s presence, which began in 1914.
(1 Korintotɔwo 15:21-23) Woafɔ ame siwo anɔ anyigba dzi le Yesu Kristo ƒe Ƒe Akpe Ðeka Dziɖuɖua me, esime anyigba katã azu paradiso. Luka 23:43; Nyaɖeɖefia 20:6, 12, 13.

(1 Corinthians 15:21-​23) The resurrection to life on earth will occur during the Thousand Year Reign of Jesus Christ, when the earth will be transformed into a paradise.​ Luke 23:43; Revelation 20:​6, 12, 13.
Nu ka tae susu le eme be míaxɔ tsitretsitsia dzi ase?
Why is belief in the resurrection reasonable?
Biblia ƒo nu tso ame asieke aɖewo siwo wofɔ ɖe tsitre la ƒe tsitretsitsi ŋu tsitotsito.
The Bible provides detailed accounts of nine resurrections, each confirmed by eyewitnesses.

(1 Fiawo 17:17-24; 2 Fiawo 4:32-37; 13:20, 21; Luka 7:11-17; 8:40-56; Yohanes 11:38-44; Dɔwɔwɔwo 9:36-42; 20:7-12; 1 Korintotɔwo 15:3-6) Ale si Yesu fɔ Lazaro ɖe tsitre ya gaɖe dzesi ŋutɔ, elabe Lazaro ku ŋkeke ene hafi wòfɔe, eye Yesu wɔ nukunu sia le ame gbogbo aɖewo ŋkume.

(1 Kings 17:17-​24; 2 Kings 4:​32-​37; 13:20, 21; Luke 7:​11-​17; 8:​40-​56; John 11:38-​44; Acts 9:​36-​42; Acts 20:​7-​12; 1 Corinthians 15:​3-6) Jesus’ resurrection of Lazarus is especially noteworthy, since Lazarus had been dead for four days and Jesus performed the miracle before a crowd of people.
(Yohanes 11:39, 42) Ame siwo tsi tsitre ɖe Yesu ŋu gɔ̃ hã mate ŋu agblɔ be womefɔ Lazaro o, eya ta woɖo nugbe be yewoawu Yesu kple Lazaro siaa.​ Yohanes 11:47, 53; 12:9-11.
(John 11:39, 42) Even those who opposed Jesus could not deny the facts of the matter, so instead they plotted to kill both Jesus and Lazarus.​ John 11:47, 53; 12:​9-​11.
Ame siwo wofɔ ɖe tsitre siwo ŋuti nya le Biblia me la dometɔ etɔ̃: ahosi la ƒe vi, nyɔnu Kristotɔ kple Yesu xɔlɔ̃ Lazaro
Three resurrections as recorded in the Bible: a widow’s child, a Christian woman, and Jesus’ friend Lazarus
Biblia ɖee fia be ŋusẽ le Mawu si be wòafɔ ame kukuwo eye wòdi vevie hã.
The Bible shows that God has both the ability and the desire to bring back the dead.
Ezãa eƒe ŋusẽ triakɔ la tsɔ léa ame siwo katã wòafɔ ɖe tsitre la dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋuti nyatakakawo ɖe eƒe susu si seɖoƒe meli na o la me.
He keeps in his limitless memory a detailed record of each person he will resurrect by means of his almighty power.
(Hiob 37:23; Mateo 10:30; Luka 20:37, 38) Mawu ate ŋu afɔ ame kukuwo ɖe tsitre eye edi vevie be yeawɔe hã!
(Job 37:23; Matthew 10:30; Luke 20:37, 38) God is able to restore the dead to life, and he wants to!
Biblia gblɔ tso Mawu ŋu ku ɖe tsitretsitsi si le ŋgɔ gbɔna la ŋu be: "Wò asinudɔwɔwɔ ƒe nu le dzrowòm vevie. " Hiob 14:15.
Describing the coming resurrection, the Bible says of God: "You will long for the work of your hands. "​ Job 14:15.
Alakpanya siwo amewo gblɔna tso tsitretsitsia ŋu
Misconceptions about the resurrection
Nyakpakpa: Tsitretsitsia nye ŋutilã kple luʋɔ la ƒe ɖekawɔwɔ ake.
Myth: The resurrection is a reuniting of the soul with the body.
Nyateƒea: Biblia fia nu be ame blibo lae nye luʋɔ la, eye amegbetɔ ƒe akpa aɖeke meyia agbenɔnɔ dzi le ŋutilã ƒe ku megbe o.
Fact: The Bible teaches that the soul is the entire person, not some part that survives death.
(1 Mose 2:7, etenuŋɔŋlɔ; Ezekiel 18:4) Menye ɖe ame si wofɔ ɖe tsitre lae gbugbɔ va wɔ ɖeka kple eƒe luʋɔ la o, ke boŋ wogbugbɔ wɔe wòzu luʋɔ gbagbe.
(Genesis 2:7, footnote; Ezekiel 18:4) A person who is resurrected is not reunited with his soul; he is recreated as a living soul.
Nyakpakpa: Woafɔ ame aɖewo ɖe tsitre eye woagatsrɔ̃ wo enumake.
Myth: Some people are resurrected and then immediately destroyed.
Nyateƒea: Biblia gblɔ be "ame siwo wɔ nu vlowo la " tɔ gome anye "ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ ƒe tsitretsitsi. "
Fact: The Bible says that "those who practiced vile things " will receive "a resurrection of judgment. "
(Yohanes 5:29) Gake nu siwo woawɔ ne wofɔ wo ɖe tsitre megbe la dzie woanɔ te ɖo adrɔ̃ ʋɔnu wo, ke menye nu siwo wowɔ do ŋgɔ na wo fɔfɔ ɖe tsitre o.
(John 5:​29) However, this judgment is based on what they do after they are resurrected, not before.
Yesu gblɔ be: "Ame kukuwo ase Mawu ƒe Vi la ƒe gbe, eye ame siwo ɖo to la anɔ agbe. "
Jesus said: "The dead will hear the voice of the Son of God, and those who have paid attention will live. "
(Yohanes 5:25) Woaŋlɔ ame siwo ‘ɖo to’ nu siwo wosrɔ̃ le woƒe tsitretsitsia megbe la ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe "agbegbalẽ " la me. Nyaɖeɖefia 20:12, 13.
(John 5:​25) Those who ‘pay attention’ to, or obey, the things they learn after they are resurrected will have their names recorded in "the scroll of life. "​ Revelation 20:12, 13.
Nyakpakpa: Ne wofɔ ame ɖe tsitre la, ŋutilã si tututu nɔ eŋu hafi wòku la ke koe anɔ eŋu.
Myth: When resurrected, a person receives exactly the same body that he had before he died.
Nyateƒea: Anɔ eme godoo be ne ame ku la, eƒe ŋutilã anyunyɔ.
Fact: After death, a person’s body would likely have broken down and disintegrated.
Nyagblɔla 3:19, 20.
Ecclesiastes 3:​19, 20.
Ðe Biblia Fia Nu Tso Gbugbɔgadzɔ Ŋua?
Does the Bible Teach Reincarnation?
Ale si Biblia ɖo eŋui
The Bible’s answer
Ao, Biblia mefia naneke tso eŋu o.
No, it does not.
Nya "gbugbɔgadzɔ " alo nufiafia sia ƒe susu aɖeke medze le Biblia me o.
Neither the word "reincarnation " nor the idea appears in the Bible.
Nufiafia si nye be luʋɔ mekuna o dzie wotu gbugbɔgadzɔ ƒe dzixɔsea ɖo.
Belief in reincarnation is based on the teaching of the immortality of the soul.
Gake Biblia fia nu be ame blibo lae nye luʋɔ eye be luʋɔ kuna.
However, the Bible teaches that the soul is the entire person and is thus mortal.
(1 Mose 2:7, etenuŋɔŋlɔ; Ezekiel 18:4) Ne ame ku la, meganɔa agbe o.​ 1 Mose 3:19; Nyagblɔla 9:5, 6.
(Genesis 2:7, footnote; Ezekiel 18:4) At death, a person ceases to exist.​ Genesis 3:​19; Ecclesiastes 9:​5, 6.
Vovototo kae le gbugbɔgadzɔ kple tsitretsitsia dome?
What is the difference between reincarnation and resurrection?
Nu si Biblia fia tso tsitretsitsia ŋu medo ƒome aɖeke kple luʋɔ makumaku ƒe nufiafia o.
The Bible’s teaching of the resurrection is not based on the immortality of the soul.
Le tsitretsitsia gome la, Mawu azã eƒe ŋusẽ atsɔ agbɔ agbe ame siwo ku.
In the resurrection, people who have died will be brought back into existence by God’s power.
(Mateo 22:23, 29; Dɔwɔwɔwo 24:15) Tsitretsitsia na mɔkpɔkpɔ nyui ame siwo ku la be woafɔ wo ɖe tsitre woava nɔ agbe le xexe yeye me, eye womagaku azɔ o.​ 2 Petro 3:13; Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.
(Matthew 22:23, 29; Acts 24:15) The resurrection offers the positive hope of coming back to a new earth with the prospect of never dying again.​ 2 Peter 3:​13; Revelation 21:​3, 4.
Susu totro siwo ku ɖe gbugbɔgadzɔ kple nya siwo wobe Biblia gblɔ ŋu
Misconceptions about reincarnation and the Bible
Susu totro: Biblia gblɔ be nyagblɔɖila Eliya gbugbɔ dzɔ va zu Yohanes Amenyrɔɖetsimela.
Misconception: The Bible says that the prophet Elijah was reincarnated as John the Baptist.
Nyateƒea: Mawu gblɔ ɖi be: "Mele nyagblɔɖila Eliya dɔm ɖe mi, " eye Yesu ƒe nyawo ɖee fia be Yohanes Amenyrɔɖetsimela dzie nyagblɔɖi sia va eme ɖo.
Fact: God foretold: "I am sending to you Elijah the prophet, " and Jesus showed that John the Baptist fulfilled this prophecy.
(Malaki 4:5, 6; Mateo 11:13, 14) Gake esia mefia be Eliya ye gbugbɔ dzɔ va zu Yohanes Amenyrɔɖetsimela o.
(Malachi 4:​5, 6; Matthew 11:13, 14) However, this did not mean that Elijah had been reincarnated as John the Baptist.
Yohanes ŋutɔ gblɔ be menye yee nye Eliya o.
John himself said that he was not Elijah.
(Yohanes 1:21) Ke boŋ ɖe Yohanes wɔ dɔ siwo ɖi Eliya tɔ, eɖe gbeƒã Mawu ƒe gbedeasi si bia dzimetɔtrɔ.
(John 1:​21) Instead, John performed a work like Elijah’s, proclaiming God’s message calling for repentance.
(1 Fiawo 18:36, 37; Mateo 3:1) Yohanes hã ƒe "gbɔgbɔ kple ŋusẽ " anɔ abe nyagblɔɖila Eliya tɔ ene.​ Luke 1:​13-​17.
(1 Kings 18:36, 37; Matthew 3:1) John also proved to be "strong and mighty like the prophet Elijah. "​ Luke 1:​13-​17, Good News Translation.
Susu totro: Biblia gblɔ be gbugbɔgadzɔ ye nye "gbugbɔgadzi. "
Misconception: The Bible refers to reincarnation as being "born again. "
Nyateƒea: Biblia ɖee fia be wogbugbɔa ame dzina le gbɔgbɔ me esime amea kpɔtɔ le agbe, ke menye ɖe amea kuna hafi o.
Fact: The Bible shows that being born again is a spiritual rebirth that takes place while a person is still alive.

(Yohanes 1:12, 13) Be woagbugbɔ ame adzi le mɔ sia nu mefia agbe si ame nɔ va yi me tsonu siwo nu mate ŋu asi le o, ke boŋ enye yayra si tso Mawu gbɔ, si naa etsɔme mɔkpɔkpɔ tɔxɛ aɖe ame.​ Yohanes 3:3; 1 Petro 1:3, 4.
(John 1:​12, 13) This rebirth is, not an inevitable consequence of past actions, but a blessing from God, giving those who receive it a unique hope for the future.​ John 3:3; 1 Peter 1:​3, 4.
